column2: TORONTO, Jan. 24 -- The Brooklyn Americans, playing with only thirteen men, fought desperately to move out of sixth place in the National Hockey League tonight, but faltered momentarily in the third period and dropped a 3 -- 2 decision to the Toronto Maple Leafs.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A mighty battle tonight raged indecisively in the greatest confusion along the eighty-mile breadth of the Malay Peninsula approximately seventy miles north of Singapore.

MODEL airplane builders, the young men who pioneered the development of aviation and who today are important factors in the air power of America, may play an even greater part in the national defense effort in the near future.

The resignation of Allyn R. Jennings as general director of the New York Zoological Park, the Bronx, and consequent changes in the administrative plan, were announced yesterday by the executive committee of the New York Zoological Society.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- Today's resolution recommending an economic and financial break with the Axis was approved by Argentina and Chile, but both voted approval with reservations.

SINGAPORE, goal of the Japanese forces in Malaya, is three things -- an island, a great naval base and a great maritime city. Its place in the strategic picture is far-reaching. It dominates the vital passage from the Pacific and the South China Sea into the Indian Ocean. It is the key to the defense of the Netherlands Indies.

NOT only does the Rembrandt exhibition at the Metropolition constitute in itself an illuminating and memorable experience; it is bound, also, to surprise many of us by the evidence it submits concerning the opulence of the museum's own collection of work in various media by the great seventeenth-century Dutch master.

SO much has happened since "The Good Earth" was published (in the year of the Japanese seizure of Manchuria, but how little ruffled we were by that!) that it seems as if a whole generation must have passed between that book and its present successor.

NOW that Jack Oakie has come and gone, night club society in these parts can again straighten its tie, order another Scotch-and-soda, and get on with the grim business of winning the war. For when Mr. Oakie is on vacation bent, neither rain nor snow nor gloom of night will stay him from his appointed rounds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Household consumption of sugar will be reduced to about fifty pounds per capita in 1942, compared with 74 pounds last year, under terms of the rationing regulations now being prepared by the Office of Price Administration, Leon Henderson announced tonight.

Muddy thinking has surrounded the specialist ever since the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was drawn. The Securities and Exchange Commission has been toying with two concepts and trying to merge them into a single formula. It has not had much luck.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Navy hinted again today that German submarines in Atlantic coast waters were having a rough time.

To raise funds for its current wartime needs, the Citizens Housing Council of New York has taken over the performance of "Carfe Crown," with Sam Jaffe and Morris Carnovsky in the leading roles, for Thursday night at the Cort Theatre.

THAT European modernism has not been crowded off the local boards as a result of the exigencies of wartime was substantially proved last week by three openings of more than routine interest. These served to bring before the public paintings by Piet Mondrian at the Valentine Gallery, paintings by a group of well-known artists at the Pierre Matisse and sculpture by Jacques Lipchitz at the Buchholz.

THE art of conversation is said to be lost. Dinner music, the loquacious radio, contract bridge, the telephone-inspired habit of brevity and the pursuit of material blessings are suspected of doing away with it. Philosophers are not alarmed.

Home owners who have admired the fine turf maintained in varied locations by the Park Department of the City of New York will be interested to know that many of the methods used, under the direction of the department experts, can be applied to the solution of their own lawn problems.

A nation-wide organization to provide dogs as sentries and guards both in civilian defense and with the United States armed forces has been formed and is already functioning, according to an announcement yesterday by Harry I. Caesar, who has been elected president.

Pointing out that men and women in various professions continue to offer all their spare time to civilian defense work, Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer office, announced yesterday that a total of 2,611 men and women had registered last week, or 200 more than the preceding week.

RAPHAEL HAKIM now owns the American rights to the Charles du Perrey-Chappuis "Frenesie," a play which lurked on the Katharine Cornell schedule for a time. Mr. Hakim has himself made the translation but hasn't yet selected the adaptor or found the feminine star the work requires.

Although New York is known as a center of apartment life and of towering skycrapers, the fact is that more than two-thirds of all its buildings are private homes and their valuation is greater than the combined value of the office structures, lofts and store buildings in the city.

New York women's organizations are framing plans to follow up bills pending or to be introduced during the present session in Albany dealing with various phases of the juvenile delinquency problem. These groups, notably the State League of Women Voters and the Women's City Club, have for several years assiduously followed all legislation in Albany concerning women and children and are pioneers in advocating special treatment of young offenders.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 -- A statement by Morris L. Cooke, oil appraiser named by President Roosevelt, that he felt confident of attaining a settlement of the Mexican expropriation question that would be "satisfactory to both of our governments and the affected business interests" was interpreted here today to mean that Washington held out hopes that the Mexican Government would at last recognize sub-soil values of American oil properties nationalized in 1938.

THE seventy-fifth annual exhibition of the American Water-Color Society will be held at the new National Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue, from March 7-29. Only original works in water-color and pastel are eligible and must be received at the Academy on Feb. 26, between the hours of 9 A.M. and 5 P.M.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 24 -- Netherland bombers, maintaining aerial supremacy over the Strait of Macassar, upset a great Japanese invasion liner and scored clean hits on a destroyer and another transport today in their second assault in two days on the enemy's southbound expeditionary fleets.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 24 -- About one-half of the 20,000,000 families owning automobiles in the United States have made plans to cut down on their driving as a result of tire rationing.

THE reaction of the critics to "Brooklyn, U. S. A.," contains an element of dramatic theory which merits more discussion than any individual play. The question of form and content, that is to say, is broader and more enduring than any example of its application.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 24 -- In an effort to make its accelerated program conform as closely as possible to undergraduate needs Dartmouth College this week completed a canvass of student plans and opinion in the three lower classes and learned that about 77 per cent of the men either plan definitely to attend the college's added Summer term or hope to attend.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- This city, in common with many others, waited until the first shots were fired before it realized the woeful inadequacy of its civilian defense preparations.

Determined not to be caught off guard by any sudden enemy air raids, New York City, Westchester and Nassau Counties and Hudson County, N.J., are operating under a mutual protection plan, providing for extensive interchange of fire equipment in the event of disastrous fires, Assistant Fire Chief John J. McCarthy said yesterday.

The Baldwin Rubber Company reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Dec. 31, a net income of $77,257, equal to 25 cents a share on 315,254 shares of common stock, compared with $208,586, or 66 cents a share on 315,754 shares of common stock in same period of 1940.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The abundantly sown seed of Japanese propaganda against the United States and Britain is falling on unfertile soil in the Soviet Union and observers are watching closely for the signs of a change in the trend of Russia's relations with Japan.

The current year, declares Davt Cronheim, head of the Cronheim Organization in Newark, N. J., wall probably be recorded as one of /he most important in the history of the American real estate businmss. It is,he explains, a transition period during which real estate ;men will be called on to readjust [heir operating plans to conform with situations never befor face

WHEN shadows are used unconventionally in photography to produce startling or otherwise unusual effects the results are obtained simply by exaggerations of the basic methods of ordinary lighting procedure.

Yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall the National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, gave the third program of the Winners Series being presented this season at the organization's Gabrilowitsch Memorial Concerts. Once more the purely orchestral offerings were by composers who had won awards in important composition contests, and the soloist was a prize winner in outstanding instrumental competitions.

As the government moved swiftly last week to channel all vital materials into the armament production line under the one-man control of Donald M. Nelson, evidence increased that production of practically all of the important consumers' durable goods products will have dwindled to a trickle by June 1.

Genuine national unity would be the perfect birthday gift to President Roosevelt from the American people at this time, Rabbi Hyman J. Schachtel declared yesterday in West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street, in a sermon on the President's sixtieth birthday.

Young women headed by Miss Elizabeth Stilwell, all former students at Smith College, will sell flowers at the performance of "Carmen" on the night of Feb. 4 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Smith College Club of New York.

New York City officials and teachers are struggling to solve one of the gravest problems that the schools have ever been compelled to face. Because of the decreased enrollment and the shift in curriculum interests thousands of regularly licensed teachers now find themselves assigned to classes outside their specialized field.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 24 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish communique said:

Shipping operators engaged in South American trade were perturbed last week when mandatory decreases in freight rates on cargo moving from Argentina, Uruguay and Southern Brazil went into effect on all commodities.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 24 -- A general revival of group and community singing as a means of sustaining civilian morale was envisaged this week by Dr. R. Nathaniel Dett, musician and composer, who is head of the music department at Bennett College here. Bennett is one of the two colleges in this country devoted exclusively to the higher education of Negro women.

"MARION ALIVE" is as much a Vicki Baum story as any of her numerous novels. One might open it in the middle and grow fascinated at once without even knowing the beginning. And one might read it with equal interest from beginning to end.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- There has been a marked increase in activity in industrial plants and sites in the last two weeks which should add even more momentum as the war effort gets into full swing, Walter S. Schmidt of Cincinnati, president of the Society of Industrial Realtors, reported here today.

A startling increase in the employment of minors, aggravating the conflict between child health standards and work opportunities, gives pertinent emphasis to the celebration of this Child Labor Sunday. In the first half of 1941, the number of minors employed was three times as great as in a similar period of the previous year, according to a report from the Children's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor.

Dr. Walter Damrosch, dean of American orchestra conductors, will celebrate his eightieth birthday on Friday. Directors of the Metropolitan Opera Guild will give a small reception in his honor at 4:15 P.M. in the opera house. At night his fellow-members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, of which he is president, and the National Institute of Arts and Letters will give a dinner for him in the academy, 688 West 155th Street.

An increased demand for information on defense matters, together with a decline in the normal use of books by students, has been caused by the war, Dr. Charles C. Williamson, director of libraries at Columbia University, declared in his annual report made public yesterday.

FOR an adequate realization of radio's tremendous influence in wartime, this presentation of the manner in which it has been used by the belligerent nations, including the United States, is indispensable. Likewise it is an aid to intelligent listening, for it gives the details and purposes of enemy propaganda, and helps the reader to stem the psychological offensives that are hurled against him.

All taxes are inherently destructive. Those levied without regard for ability to pay, or those whose impact so disturbs the taxpayer's mental and financial balance as to retard him in his efforts, react destructively not only upon him but upon the cause he is serving.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Tuffield La Tour of the Saranac Lake Bobsled Club won the Dietrich Wortman Trophy race today by piloting his two-man bobsled down the Mount Van Hoevenberg run from the half-mile mark in record time.

A garden club pilgrimage to Natchez provides the setting for this mystery-romance, and the key to the mystery lies in a family secret that has been kept long after the reason for keeping it has ceased to exist. As for the Southern hospitality, perhaps Mrs. Cornelia Cartwright puts rather too great a strain upon it.

A bridge and entertainment by Broadway stars will be given the afternoon of Feb. 10 in the Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Episcopal Actors Guild for the benefit of the American Theatre Wing War Service. The Theatre Wing, which in the last two years has participated in British civilian relief, has been reorganized since the United States entered the war for voluntary American war relief.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 -- Loopholes in the Federal tax laws cause an annual loss to the government of almost $1,000,000,000 a year, about one-eighth of the entire receipts from the income tax during the current year, Secretary Morgenthau said today in an address before the Forum of the City Club.

VARIED and numerous were the exhibitions of the week, with artists of many countries represented. In the wake of the recent exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, in which the art and craft of our neighboring republics to the south were so thoroughly presented, two department stores are currently presenting similar material on an extensive scale.
Many of the major league clubs have not yet mailed contracts, but all are ready to head for training camps within a few weeks, according to The Associated Press.

STEPHEN LAIRD was Berlin correspondent for Time in 1940 and 1941, and at the end of last September he went to London. There he was naturally associated with Walter Graebner, who has been London correspondent for Time since 1937.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The communique of the Netherlands Indies armed forces said:

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- American and British pilots shot down sixteen more Japanese planes in another unsuccessful enemy attack on Rangoon today and British land forces stiffened for a major battle in The Moulmein sector in defense of the Burma Road.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Jan. 24 -- Some time between tomorrow and Monday a man will throw a switch at the control board of the massive Pinopolis power house, thirty-five miles inland and a new public power system which has altered the map of South Carolina will set wheels turning in an important new defense plant here.

Apprehension in financial circles over the Securities and Exchange Commission's challenge of the validity of the traditional underwriting and selling-group agreements used in the distribution of new securities mounted to a new peak last week.

Hitler has been making "feints" at Spain to distract attention from Turkey, which he will invade within three months, thus cutting communications with the Near East, according to Alex Dreier, NBC correspondent in Berlin for two years, who arrived in New York yesterday.

VICHY, Jan. 24 -- Instructions to lodge a formal protest with the Chinese Government against the air bombardments in Indo-China on Jan. 22, were forwarded to the French Minister in Chungking today. In official circles it was said that there was no definite information as to the airplanes that took part in the attacks, but that the protest was made on the ground that they came over Indo-Chinese territory from China.

As the Japanese drove deeper into the Malay barrier last week, spokesmen of some of the United Nations debated the vital question of strategic priorities. Europe or Asia, Atlantic or Pacific -- which is the vital theatre? Which should receive maximum reinforcements?

FACED with a decline in violin study, some teachers of the instrument have organized the Violin Teachers Guild of Greater New York. Its main aim is to repopularize the violin and string instruments generally.

Two hundred Hunter College girls are qualified to operate the college elevators in case an emergency leaves the Park Avenue building without elevator men, it was announced yesterday by John J. Fleischmann, custodian-engineer of the college.

G.P. PUTNAM'S SONS announce for publication on Feb. 13 "I Who Should Command All," by Alice Jaynes Tyler. This book contains extracts from hitherto unpublished letters of John James Audubon, and these letters give support to a theory said to have been held by Audubon and his family, the theory that he was the Lost Dauphin.

One hundred members of the congregation of Riverside Church, at Riverside Drive and 122d Street, yesterday began the construction of sand-bagged shelter for Sunday communicants, filling 1,800 sandbags and packing them against a window of the main assembly hall on the two lower floors of the building.

Charged with acting as an unregistered foreign agent, Richard Ernest Weber, 55 years old, who served in the German Army from 1906 to 1908 and was interned in this country during the first World War, was arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein, in the Federal Building in Brooklyn.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 24 (AP) -- The United States Lapham Cup team today retained the trophy won last year in Toronto, when it easily defeated Canada's fifteen-man squash racquets team, 13 to 2.

The dispatches of the past seven days have dramatized the fact that the United States is engaged in a war which is being fought in three continents and two oceans, and which has been carried close to the shores of the two remaining continents and to the island continent of Australia.

Four persons were arrested yesterday by State and local police in what officials describe as a vast cigarette-tax fraud in which the State lost about $20,000 in the wholesale distribution of more than 1,000,000 packages of cigarettes. They bore fraudulent meter marks purporting to show that a tax of 2 cents had been paid to the State on each package.

The Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday, which for the last several years has presented a notable series of entertainments for the dual purpose of observing the birthday of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and raising funds to carry on the nationwide fight against infantile paralysis, will bring to the Waldorf-Astoria on Friday night a Diamond Jubilee Ball that is expected to be one of the most impressive and colorful of these commemorative fetes.

IN Switzerland the Winter winds are now crinkling the lakes to slaty gray, and snow blows down the mountain valleys. The high peaks of the Alps are white and remote above the little land hemmed in by war; the cities at their base are huddled close together in the cold. On week-ends, skiers raise long feathered trails of powder snow on mountain trails, and day by day the sentries on the borders stand their watch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- The United States Civil Service Commission today recommended the discharge of J.E.D. Stewart, director of the Georgia Bureau of Unemployment Compensation, and Marion A. O'Connor, director of the bureau's division of employment service, for alleged violations of the Hatch "clean politics" act.

The hockey game between the New York Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks on the night of Feb. 10 at Madison Square Garden will be a benefit for the Cooperative Committee of the Big Sisters. The sponsoring organization, composed of members of the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish Big Sisters Association, has taken over the sale of boxes, arena and promenade seats for the game.

MIRCLES of business and industry have always held a fascination for the historian and the biographer. Yet it is astonishing that until now the pyramiding mass of aeronautical literature in this country has produced no work of consequence on the most fabulous industry of this most fabulous era -- commercial aviation.

While the public's heavy buying rush showed a tendency to taper off in this area last week, retail merchants were convinced that there would be sporadic repetitions of such splurges as government curtailment actions widen to take in additional products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Shifts United States foreign trade of such major significance "that they must have a decided effect upon the pattern of world trade in the post-war world" are remarked upon by Secretary Jones in his annual report to Congress for 1941.

When Ardisia crenulata, that nice greenhouse plant with the long lasting red berries, was lifted from our garden in August, it had as thorough a case of scale as I have ever seen on a single plant. The usual remedies for clearing off a mild case of scale, such as sometimes appears during Winter, were of no avail on this malignant case; but today the plant is clean as a whistle.

BECAUSE a young reader gives himself up without reserve to a tale which he likes, a really good story which shows people of another day busy about their daily tasks or their amusements, plays a tremendous part in making a period of time real to boys and girls.

GOOD old Betsy (or "Crate," or new Henderson Eight)! Whatever its name, the family car has a long way to go in the next few years. Because this task lies ahead, the car could do with a little pampering and better treatment than it got in the recent days before rationing.

NO one was being very definite about it as these notes were written, but it appears that the program scheduled soon to restore Al Jolson to the air will be a half-hour dramatic show, probably on WEAF. Song and comedy have, of course, heretofore been the old mammy-singer's stock-in-trade on the ether, but the drama is not entirely new to him.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The Norton Gallery recently acquired the jade collection of Stanley Charles Nott, and now a new wing of three rooms is under way to house it. Mr. Nott, who has been appointed curator for life, is producing a catalogue with full-page illustrations of each piece and descriptions of their symbolism.

IN the automotive field, the War Production Board under Donald M. Nelson has taken steps to make the industry toe a mark other than of its own drawing. "Debate" is out and the course rapidly being set, Mr. Nelson said last week. He ordered cessation of car and light truck output at the close of January.

Some tapering off in the buying rush which has boomed retail sales figures developed here last week. Gains were cut down to about 25 per cent over the corresponding week of last year as consumers started to encounter gaps in retail stocks and could not find the exact styles and patterns they wanted.
SOME of the authors and publishers in England are reacting to the current status of the book trade there rather like victims of a practical joke.

Despite restrictions on new automobiles and supplies, the license renewals for 1942 are running a little ahead, so far, of the comparable figure for last year, it was reported yesterday by I. James Brody, Deputy Motor Vehicle Commissioner, in charge of the New York City district.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The world-wide war became in the past ten days an immediate and personal thing to millions of Americans living on the Eastern seaboard of the United States, when an undetermined number of nearby German submarines started smashing shells and torpedoes into the hulls of merchant ships.

Railway shares, going to the best levels since November, led the stock market to higher ground yesterday and the whole list closed irregularly stronger. The rails were in demand on the theory that the Interstate Commerce Commission will act favorably on the petition for higher freight rates to offset the carriers' increases in wages.

The principal cause of juvenile delinquency and crime is not poor economic conditions but the "bad reaction" of parents to such conditions, John Warren Hill, presiding justice of the New York City Domestic Relations Court, declared yesterday.

WHEN the elderly and supposedly respectable Mrs. Amelia M. Carr of Newark was arrested for swindling she gave herself away by saying that "a canary had been singing." In prison argot, and Mrs. Carr had been in prison, a "canary" is a stool pigeon, an informer.

More than five hundred secondary school teachers from the metropolitan area met yesterday in response to an invitation issued by Teachers College, Columbia University, to consider the problems of high-school education in the war emergency.

With representatives of civilian defense organizations stressing the importance of a strong civilian defense program as a vital aid to the country's armed forces and in bolstering the morale of the American people, the American Red Cross Information Center staged yesterday a colorful war rally in 590 Madison Avenue.

TELEVISION, youngest of the communications arts, begins tomorrow its most important civilian wartime role, when the first of a series of preliminary air raid defense teleview programs is presented by the National Broadcasting Company in cooperation with the New York police.

The production of books in 1941 is now accounted for. One hopes that author, printer and publisher have all been prosperous. How few the publishers were some years ago! Last year 263 of the tribe issued more than five books; 17 more than 100. They have long ceased to eat their authors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The text of the Roberts commission report on the Pearl Harbor disaster is as follows:

Confused and uncertain as to the exact nature of the restrictions facing their industry, but aware of their tremendous responsibility in meeting the nation's food needs during the wartime emergency, an estimated 35,000 representatives of all branches of the food trade are gathering in Chicago this week for a series of conventions more important than any they have held since 1918.

FOLLOWING a tradition that makes even cultural attainments the concern of the State all over Latin America, the Ministry of Public Education in Caracas has issued a two-volume anthology of the Venezuelan short story, besides a thicker compilation of national poetry.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is prophesied in the Australian press that "if Singapore falls Churchill will fall with it, and the political repercussions will be cataclysmic." Similar reports come from England. Many of us Americans will hope that these predictions are unfounded.

WE found Sir Thomas Beecham's performance of Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Coq d'Or," on the night of his Metropolitan debut, as sincerely and admirably conceived as his remarks on the interpretation of opera made last week in these columns.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 25 -- Australia mobilized all defense forces on a war footing today and braced for a bitter-end battle against the imminent threat of attack by powerful Japanese air, sea and land forces from the north.

Means of combating defeatism, one of the important factors through which modern wars are decided, are analyzed by Stefan T. Possony, member of the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, N.J., and a specialist in military problems, in a study, "Defeatism," made public yesterday.

Faced with the largest demand for industrial property since the expansion of industry in the First World War, realtors and community agencies have run into a series of problems posed by the same conditions which created the demand, according to comment last week.

In only three years in history -- 1929, 1930 and 1937 -- were dividends paid higher than in 1941, according to the New York Stock Exchange's magazine The Exchange. Disbursements on common stocks were 16 per cent below 1929's all-time high.

The steady depletion of the nursing services of hospitals and health departments has been responsible for a call for 100,000 volunteer nurses' aides during the course of the year. The American Red Cross has been asked by the United States Office of Civilian Defense to train these aides.

With Manager Mel Ott due to arrive tomorrow morning and Bill Terry, now general manager of the Giant farming system, following him on Tuesday, baseball's off season will move to its climax for the coming fortnight.

Odette LaCoste, 19 years old, and her brother, Rene, 15, of 47-15 Forty-fifth Street, Woodside, are walking nightly on Air Raid Wardens Post 7, Section G, Woodside, in the place of their father, Adrien LaCoste, French naval veteran, who was buried on Jan. 17.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- An immediate reduction in the manufacture of radios and phonographs for civilian use was ordered today by the War Production Board with a warning that further drastic cuts would follow.

Delegates from junior groups of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, meeting for their annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Saturday, will hear a review of junior activities throughout the country by Mrs. Kenneth H. Rogers of Los Angeles, chairman of the junior clubwomen committee of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

THE SHAH OF IRAN tells a TIMES correspondent that the Berlin radio is recommending Hitler to the Iranians as a Mohammedan; one born, in fact, with a green belt around his middle, and therefore a direct descendant of the Prophet.

Full moon is at 4:12 A.M. (E.S.T.) on Sunday, Feb. 1. The last quarter moon occurs at 9:52 A.M. (E.S.T.) on the 8th. On Sunday, the 15th, the moon is new at *5:02 A.M. (E.S.T.) and the first quarter phase is attained at *10:40 P.M. (E.S. T.) on Sunday, the 22d.
Following the sixth performance of Miss Sonja Henie's 1942 Hollywood Ice Revue in Madison Square Garden last night, officials said that the attendance thus far had reached 100,000.

NO NOTE of explanation tells whether or not this is a true story. But its account of the life of a group of children evacuated in 1939 from the slums of a Scotch city to "lovely Tharrus," a beautiful, happy, well-managed farm, has the ring of first-hand knowledge.

HOPE you will permit me some space for the all too necessary task of debunking "the debunker of debunkers," Mr. Raymond Gram Swing's description of Dr. Gustav Stolper. Mr. P.W. Wilson's review of "This Age of Fable" in your pages clearly calls for this reply.

A total of $60,916,444 has been raised by 343 communities reporting on the 1941-42 community chest campaign season so far, according to an announcement by Tom K. Smith, chairman of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs.

Increasing trade between Chile and North America has made further expansion necessary for the Chilean Line, and the concern has opened its own freight headquarters and general offices at 29 Broadway, it was announced yesterday in a joint statement issued by Francisco Subercaseaux, general manager of the line, and Augustin Huneeus, general representative in the United States and Canada.

Under the auspices of the Women's Conference of the Society for Ethical Culture, a card party, reception and tea will be held tomorrow at the Plaza to raise funds for furthering the organization's projects for war relief, civilian defense, refugee aid and community work.

DOUBTLESS some details of the new radio censorship code will be altered from time to time as the situation demands; but in the main, and barring unforeseen circumstances, it is likely to continue along the lines laid down by Byron Price, Director of Censorship, and J. Harold Ryan, his assistant in charge of radio.

Experienced officials of long-established rubber companies express strong doubts of the predicted progress of the government's program for the production of synthetics. However, they believe that these plans increase Sharply the potential national value of the crude rubber stocks now on hand and in transit.

MUSSORGSKY wrote his Pictures at an Exhibition for the piano, but the chances are that you have heard it more often in an orchestral version. There have been a number of transcriptions, and at least three of these -- by Maurice Ravel, Lucien Cailliet and Leopold Stokowski -- have been recorded.

The home of the Foreign Office of the United States of Brazil is a picturesque building in the heart of Rio de Janeiro's business district. The Itaramaty Palace -- its name is an Indian word for "white stone" -- is set among fountains and artificial lakes and looks out on a palm-lined lagoon.

Dr. Paul J. Raver, administrator of the Bonneville Power Administration, is in New York to negotiate deals designed to utilize to the utmost, through public ownership, the power facilities of the Pacific Northwest, according to The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Reconsideration of the controversial aid-to-Russia resolution may be expected tomorrow, Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, revealed today. The resolution, tabled yesterday by the board of the federation, caused a great deal of argument in the business session because it contained a reaffirmation of the federation's long-standing opposition to communism.
ROME, Jan. 25 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Miss Helena Mroczkowska of the Fencers Club, former national and intercollegiate champion, carried off principal honors in the annual women's open fencing competition on the Greco strips yesterday. A clean sweep of eight bouts in the final round-robin enabled the erstwhile Hofstra College foils-woman to defeat Miss Elizabeth Bruskin of Salle Santelli by the margin of one point.

DARWIN, Australia, Jan. 25 -- Sir Keith Murdock, publisher of The Melbourne Herald, who returned here today from a 26,000 mile round-the-world tour, declared that the loss of the main points in the Northern Pacific archipelago would foreshadow one of the greatest disasters to the white race in all history and argued that all possible help must be concentrated at the best strategic points there.

AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Thirty-six men died in the flames enveloping a Norwegian tanker as the result of a torpedo attack by a submarine in the Western Atlantic recently, it became known tonight with the arrival of five survivors, who were on the tanker's bridge when the attack came.

Three Bronx youths were arrested yesterday after they admitted stealing nine automobiles in the Bronx and Westchester during the last month, changing the license plates and abandoning the cars after taking "joy rides."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 25 -- Arthur Devlin, 19-year-old Lake Placid Club Sno Bird ace, carried off the New York State Class A ski-Jumping championship today under conditions suitable for anything but Winter sports.

Moving sharply upward after five successive weeks of more moderate advances, the cotton market last week reached the highest level since 1929. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts, all of which were priced at one time at more than 19 cents a pound, showed net gains of 84 to 86 points for the week at the close of trading Saturday.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 25 (Reuter) -- The Economist calculates in detail the proportions of the national income taken by all taxation in Britain at 37.3 per cent and in the United States at 24.1 per cent during the current fiscal year.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Jim Bickford of Saranac Lake staged furious bobsledding duels today with a former Olympic teammate, Francis Tyler, to capture both the Commissioner Lithgow Osborne and the Samuel Packer four-man race trophies.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 25 -- Sensationally heavy Japanese air losses during mass attacks on Singapore and Rangoon last week are believed responsible for lessening enemy aerial activity here in the past two days.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Establishment of a departmental system of awards to industrial plants for exceptional production of naval equipment was announced today by the Navy.

Basketball bulletins concerning the local teams were few and far between last week because of examinations, which was probably just as well, because all the news received was bad news for their adherents. L.I.U. was upset by De Paul in Chicago, Fordham lost to Syracuse and Manhattan dropped decisions to Scranton and Providence.

One point out of many worth pondering in the grimly frank post-mortem on the disaster at Pearl Harbor refers to the role of the State Department in this affair and, by extension, its function generally in the world-wide drama in which America's tragic curtain-raiser is an episode.

A bill is now being drafted for introduction in the Legislature which, if passed, will make it possible for youngsters between the ages of 14 and 16 years to hunt "in the company of their parent or legal guardian."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 25 -- Yale students today are stronger, taller, heavier and younger than they were fifty-nine years ago, according to tables compiled under the direction of Robert J.H. Kiphuth, director of the Yale gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A pin, "the Emblem of the Americas," was presented today to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and other prominent persons at a luncheon given by Bruce Gould, editor of The Ladies Home Journal, which promoted the emblem.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- Beginning tomorrow the three daily newspapers in this city will discontinue publication of the total sales on the New York Stock Exchange, except in round figures, as means to handicap operations of the local "numbers racket."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 -- William E. Robinson, New York Herald Tribune advertising executive, carded a medal-winning 73 as New York Athletic Club members and guests opened a four-day mid-winter golf tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club today.

The United States, which "muffed" an opportunity at the conclusion of the first World War to organize a world based on "international cooperation and justice," must not repeat that error, the Rev. Dr. Harold Cooke Phillips, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Cleveland, declared yesterday in a sermon at Riverside Church.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 25 -With a stiff easterly wind buta clear sky overhead, Winter sailing was carried on today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Bob De Coppet, in his B boat Zotom, and George (Scotty) Isdale, in his X craft Margaret Rose, scored top honors.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Reports were current at the Conference of Foreign Ministers today that Chile, having obtained the advance opinion of both candidates in the presidential elections of Feb. 1, may break relations with the Axis powers immediately after the conference closes Tuesday.

Two hundred persons, including social and theatre figures, attended the formal opening yesterday afternoon of an exhibit of Van Gogh paintings for the benefit of the Red Cross. The show, in which there are eleven of the works created during the last three years of the painter's life, will continue to Feb. 7 at the Paul Rosenberg Co. gallery, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street.

In his recent budget message the President estimated Government receipts in the fiscal year to end June 30, 1943, at $16,487,000,000 and expenditures at $58,928,009,000. These figures are too huge to carry any real meaning to the mind, and it has become increasingly apparent that we cannot regard them as accurate estimates of what the National Government is going to collect or spend.

Are we a less sentimental people than we were in 1917 and 1918? It is so easy to draw a long bow on comparisons with the last war, and the temptation to reach resounding conclusions is strong. Yet we can be fairly sure that the drama enacted in the American home follows well-tested lines, and that it is as moving in its emotional force as ever.

The 107th anniversary of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Fifty-first Street, was observed yesterday afternoon with a pageant representing the conversion of St. Paul and his continuing effect on the Church down to the present day.

A pamphlet portraying how 400 families with incomes averaging $1,132 a year were given a chance for happiness in Clason Point Gardens, the city's first public housing project to consist of houses and gardens rather than apartment buildings, was released yesterday by Gerard Swope, who has just resigned as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority to become an assistant to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr.

CALLENDER, Ont., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Yvonne, Annette, Cecile and Emilie fidgeted with curiosity just outside the door of a bedroom in their nursery here today while two orthopedic specialists examined Marie, smallest of the sisters Dionne, for suspected muscular atrophy of one leg.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The seasonal decline in the note circulation of the Bank of England continues, but at a considerably slower rate than normal. The decrease of u3,000,000 shown in the last report compares with one of u6,100,000 in the previous week and one of u4,400,000 in the same week last year.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 25 (AP) -Skaters from five cities in the United States and two competitors from Winnipeg captured individual championships on the final day of the North American speed skating meet today.

The appointment of James M. Kingsley Jr., assistant librarian at Cooper Union, as assistant to Dr. Harry Miller Lydenberg in the operation of the Biblioteca Benjamin Franklin, a "typical United States public library," just opened in Mexico City by the American Library Association, was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- An innovation that would cost the nation several million sterling in revenue was advanced today by the Inland Revenue Staff Federation on behalf of married women who, it was said, suffer under the existing scheme, which is considered a "serious deterrent to their entry into full-time employment and hence is retarding maximum war production"

America is suddenly faced with the fact that sugar is going to be rationed. But, as the Victorian novelists would put it, all is not lost. With careful and patriotic planning and an intelligent use of substitutes, we may still serve meals that taste as good as those we enjoyed in the sweet old days -- and, what's more, they'll be better for us!
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- The battle dress that is serving the Russian Army so well this Winter provides a maximum of warmth with a minimum of handicap to freedom of movement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Roosevelt attended the National Theatre tonight for a command performance of Lillian Hellman's anti-Nazi play, "Watch on the Rhine." It was the President's first public appearance away from the White House since the war began, except to address Congress and attend church.

Many of the difficulties with which Great Britain has contended in the planning and executing its war program are like those now confronting the United States, in the opinion of the Guaranty Survey, monthly business and financial review of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Formation of a committee of representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations to meet with President Roosevelt on all matters relating to labor's participation in the war was hailed yesterday by C.I.O. leaders as "the greatest victory" won by organized labor in this country.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Jan. 25 -- The death on New Year's Day of the five-man crew of an Army B-25 medium bomber, which crashed in an abandoned sand pit to avoid possible death or injury to the civilian population, was commemorated here today with a brief ceremony that included the unveiling of a plaque bearing the names of the dead fliers, at New Hyde Park Road and Oak Drive.

There was not a dull moment in the fine concert given by the New York Symphony Orchestra, under Sir Thomas Beecham's direction, last night in Carnegie Hall, in the series being presented currently by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The wholesale price index of the Board of Trade for December, based on 1930 as 100, was 155.9, compared with 155.2 for November, last; 148.6 for December, 1940, and 98.1 for August, 1939.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined from 102.6 to 102.5. The declines were confined almost entirely to the foodstuffs and farm products groups, where sharp rises had recently been occurring. In the farm products group, the prices of eggs, grains, live poultry and lard declined, but offsetting gains in cattle, hogs, cotton and hay prices were sufficient to cause the index as a whole to rise by 0.2 per cent.

Four hundred Luxembourgers and citizens of Luxembourg descent attended a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel George Washington, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, in honor of the birthday of the Grand Duchess Charlotte, who is now in London, heading her government-in-exile.

Division among the people, dangerous at all times, is intolerable while the country is gathering all its energies for an unprecedented effort to preserve the freedoms of civilization for ourselves and other liberty-loving peoples, Maurice Wertheim, president of the American Jewish Committee, declared yesterday in an address before the organization's thirty-fifth annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A "consolidation of authority" for the defense of all vital points where the Army and Navy forces are operating together is being worked out by President Roosevelt and the Army and Navy as a result of the Roberts report on the lack of a coordinated command at Pearl Harbor, it was learned on high authority tonight.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Florida's racing season, only one-third gone, already has produced more than $1,000,000 in tax revenue for the State's counties and for public welfare work.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Congress approaches the fourth week of its session tomorrow with action still uncompleted on its biggest current problem, a price control bill.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Elimination last week of the uncertainty in regard to price-control legislation as a result of the agreement reached by House and Senate conferees resulted in a marked broadening in speculative and mill interest in the wheat market and prices rose to within a fraction of a cent of the season's high levels, before profit-taking checked the advance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Joplin, Mo., and Vallejo and Napa, Calif., with gains of 40 and 37 per cent, respectively, showed the largest increases in department store sales during December, according to the report by cities put out by the Federal Reserve Board.
The sixtieth anniversary of the founding of the New York Board of Jewish Ministers was observed yesterday afternoon in the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 25 -- Importance is attached here to an official report from Helsinki that the Finnish Minister of Supply, Henrik Ramsay, has returned from Berlin with German promises of extensive help.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 25 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Netherlands Indies Fighting Services issued this communique this afternoon:

Erich W. Kath of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., cotton goods concern at 43 Leonard Street, has sold Twin Brooks Farm, a 106-acre property on both sides of Middlebury Road, in Southbury, Conn., to a client of Donald M. Joseph, broker. The place has a nine-room homestead, superintendent's house, dairy barn, stable and garage.

VICHY, Jan. 25 -- The law of Dec. 17 which authorizes the government to close certain factories has begun to be applied. An important reduction in the textile industry, notably in the cotton spinning mills, is being put into force.

OTTAWA, Jan. 25 -- Following the announcement that sugar would be rationed in the United States, the Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board has fixed a weekly allowance of three quarters of a pound per person, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The wartime task of the Department of Agriculture is "to provide food for freedom, without waste of land, labor or machinery," Secretary Wickard said in his report for 1941, made public today. He asserted that the domestic food situation appeared to be adequate for any emergency and should make unnecessary any serious rationing in agricultural products.
The War of the World rapidly approached a crisis last week in several theatres and on many fronts.

A 4-year-old victim of infantile paralysis who has been active in the 1942 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis since his release from the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled four months ago will have a second birthday party next Friday, President Roosevelt's birthday, as Mrs. Roosevelt's guest at luncheon in the White House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- In a double-barreled war effort, designed both to save steel and expedite delivery the Treasury Department prepared today to place orders for more than $48,000,000 worth of wooden office furniture and equipment under a new streamlined purchasing plan.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- The output of steel ingot throughout the country remained last week unchanged at 97 per cent of rated capacity, which again was attributed to lack of sufficient scrap metal to make possible a higher level of operations.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The progress of the war in the Pacific continues to preoccupy the British commodity trade. In connection with the Japanese attack on Burma, the occupation of Tavoy is regarded as a serious threat to the Burmese metal mines.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- The political advantage afforded the executive branch of the State Government over a Legislature controlled by the opposite party seems likely to be exhibited again tomorrow night when Governor Lehman will submit his budget to the Legislature.

HONOLULU, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Civilians learned with amazement today the background of events leading up to Japan's "sneak" attack of Dec. 7 as the report of President Roosevelt's investigating commission was made public.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 25 -- Uruguay has promptly carried out the decisions of the Rio de Janeiro conference and shares with Peru the distinction of being the first to act in accordance with the resolution recommending a rupture of relations with the Axis.

With the vast experience gained in various entertainment fields at his finger tips, Ben Hecht, ex-newspaper man, resolutely steps out tonight in the dual capacity of sole author (no collaborator this time) and director of his play, "Lily of the Valley," opening at the Windsor.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The strange spectacle of Communists and other leftists -- with whom Winston Churchill has shown scant patience -- warning the Prime Minister against "intrigues" within his own Conservative party to unseat him was unfolded tonight as the nation awaited the three-day war debate in the House of Commons.

The use of silver in arts and industries last year in the United States and Canada is placed at a new peak of 80,000,000 ounces by Handy Harman, bullion dealers at 82 Fulton Street, in their review of the silver market for 1941. This represents an increase of almost 95 per cent over 1940, when the previous high record of 41,000, 000 ounces for the two countries was established.

Citizens for Victory, which was organized last month to build up civilian morale to help "win the war, win the peace and preserve democracy," announced yesterday that Russell W. Davenport, former managing editor of Fortune Magazine and one of the strongest supporters of Wendell L. Willkie in his Presidential campaign, has been named president of the new organization.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- In their erratic behavior last week, the stock markets here corresponded closely to the variegated pattern of the war developments.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 25 -- Australians today for the first time in the 154 years of their history were fighting against an alien invader, with the militia and Imperial land and air forces opposing the Japanese on the island of New Britain.

Mayor La Guardia made yesterday a tour of the Harlem Defense Recreation Center for service men, which took him from the meeting room on the top floor to the kitchen in the basement of the five-story building as 2348 Seventh Avenue.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Jan. 26 -- The Red Army is maintaining unrelenting pressure against the German lines on the vast new Valdai sector of the Easttern Front. Yesterday the Russians made a large-scale break-through near Novaya, at the headwaters of the Meza tributary to the Dvina River, the Russian military spokesman said in a broadcast this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -Ben Hogan clinched a stronger hold on first place in the seventytwo-hole San Francisco open golf tournament today. He cleared the halfway mark with an eight-under-par total of 136.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command communique today follows:

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 25 -- Attacking during two days and one night British air raiders have severely damaged a huge Axis convoy, probably sinking a 20,000-ton liner, setting fire to a smaller merchantman, hitting a cruiser and a destroyer with torpedoes, landing bombs near other warships and merchantmen and possibly hitting a battleship.

The controversy between Mayor La Guardia and former Market Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr., who resigned on Dec. 28, charging the Mayor had interfered with appointments in the Department of Markets, broke out anew yesterday as the Mayor announced that Daniel P. Woolley, a retired vice president of Standard Brands, Inc., would be sworn in at City Hall at 11 A.M. today as Mr. Morgan's successor.

BOSTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- With Young Nick Damore of the Hershey American Hockey League Club guarding their net, the Boston Bruins regained the victory road by overwhelming the Canadiens of Montreal, 7 -- 3, tonight before 10,300 fans at the Garden.

Your editorial on a "Zionist" army is based on a series of assumptions that are at variance with all the facts in the situation. There has been no demand for the formation of a "Zionist" army. The proposal for the formation of a Jewish military force in Palestine has received the support of more than "a number of deeply sincere and well-meaning people."

Widespread gains at retail, together with the prospect of shortages later on in many lines, were reflected last week in active buying at wholesale, both for immediate and future needs. In general, there was plenty of merchandise for Spring selling, but some doubt as to whether Fall needs could be covered in full.

Declaring that the world is witnessing a "catastrophic eclipse of charity, justice and sanity," Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, in a pastoral letter read in every church in the archdiocese yesterday, asked Catholics to contribute "as generously as possible" to the annual Peter's Pence offering that will be received at all masses next Sunday.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 25 -- The second great blizzard of January late last week roared out of Russia and across Central and Southeastern Europe, crippling vital Axis military communications and burying Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria beneath almost unprecedented snows.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- Widespread unrest in Rumania has led to the arrest of at least 150 persons of "high Rumanian society,'' according to reports from Bucharest this evening.

The nation's 60,000 drug stores are being enlisted in a drive for collection of thousands of tons of valuable tin contained in used tubes from toothpaste, shaving cream and other drug products, a committee operating with approval of the Bureau of Industrial Conservation in Washington has announced.

WITH UNITED STATES INFANTRY FORCES, Bataan Front, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- American troops fought their third large-scale ground engagement of the war early today, turning back a strong Japanese night attack with heavy losses to the enemy.

The Life Underwriters Association of the City of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that estimated total sales of ordinary life insurance in this city in December were $75,617,000, compared with $48,966,000 in the same month of 1940.

TOKYO, Jan. 25 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Headquarters said tonight that Japanese troops were driving back General Douglas MacArthur's forces on Bataan Peninsula in the Philippines.

Announcing that the Red Cross War Fund has now passed the halfway mark in its drive for $7,330,000 in this city, Leon Fraser, chairman of the campaign, said yesterday in a statement issued from the fund headquarters at 67 William Street that the nearly 50,000 volunteer workers would redouble their efforts to complete the quota by Feb. 11.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's soldiers are scoring successes against Japanese forces in three widely separated parts of China.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 25 -- The stage was set tonight for declarations of the severance of diplomatic relations with the Axis by nineteen countries and possibly twenty by the time the conference of American Foreign Ministers ends Tuesday night.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 24 -- Allied military and diplomatic circles, as well as Turkish military experts, made no attempt tonight to disguise their concern over the German counter-attack in Libya and the Allied reversals in the Far East.
SOUTHWEST PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS of the United Nations, on Java, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The No. 1 communique of this headquarters, issued today, follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Irving Berlin has written another song for "Mr. Henry Junior," the Treasury Department said today. Its title is: "I Paid My Income Tax Today."

The Rev. Dr. Clarence E. Krumbholz, executive secretary of the Inner Mission Board of the United Lutheran Church of America, outlined yesterday morning a corrective program designed to counteract three predominant characteristics in the temper of our time "that are obscuring the sense of God."

WITH BRITISH FORCES, On the Malayan Front, Monday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- British troops fought in a steady downpour and boot-high mud throughout yesterday to hold positions stretching across Johore State from sixty to seventy-five air miles from Singapore.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received up to 1 P.M., Eastern standard time, said:

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 25 -- The belief in informed circles here and other capitals today was that the compromise resolution at Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, achieved much less than that unity which was the purpose of the conference and that this resolution marked the end of one chapter and the beginning of a new one in Pan-American relations.
TOKYO, Jan. 25 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese troops are within sixty-two miles of Singapore, Imperial Headquarters said tonight.
WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Central Front, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- General Gregory K. Zhukoff, who won the battle for Moscow, gave today his explanation of the defeat of the Germans.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 25 -British bombers have ravaged Bangkok, capital of Thailand, it was revealed tonight as Imperial troops, aided by a stream of Chinese reinforcements, fought off a combined Japanese-Thai invasion threat to Rangoon and the Burma Road from the southeast.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Soy beans for delivery in July brought more than $2 a bushel on the Board of Trade here last week, going into new high ground for the season and coming within 3/4 cent of their high record. They have risen about 20 cents in the last three weeks.

FREEPORT, L.I., Jan. 25 -- Donald Lundergan, 3-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lundergan of 18 Nassau Avenue, was saved from drowning this afternoon by his 47-year-old grandfather, Clifford Shirley of 274 Bedell Street, a former deep-sea diver and former detective lieutenant on the Los Angeles police force.

While taking a short cut through a lot at Nelson Avenue and 166th Street, the Bronx, last night, Michael Quinn, 12 years old, of 1150 Woodycrest Avenue, near by, saw some papers blowing around in the wind. Picking them up, the boy decided they "look important" and took them to the Highbridge station.

The New York Rovers ran their undefeated string to six yesterday afternoon when they handed the sixth-place Jersey Skeeters a 5-to-3 setback in the Eastern Hockey League fracas featuring the amateur twin showing at Madison Square Garden. The locals have won three and tied three in their last six outings.

The Hercules Powder Company has issued for publication today a report showing net earnings of $6,098,712 for 1941 after all charges and taxes, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $4.23 a share on 1,316,710 common shares. This compares with $5,807,769, or $4.01 a share, earned in 1940.

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, minister of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that faith and fellowship were the chief sources of strength of religion. Dr. Chalmers said:

Steps that America must take to win the war and make a lasting peace were discussed from New York City pulpits yesterday. Trust in the leadership and power of the Almighty, conviction of the righteousness of the cause, and spiritual unity of mankind, were among suggestions offered.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- By 519,000 votes to 250,000 the Swiss people rejected today a Socialist proposal for direct election of the Federal Council, which is the equivalent of a Cabinet in most other countries. The vote also rejected an increase of the Federal Council from seven to nine members.

The movement for a change in the leadership of Tammany has gained impetus and a committee, headed by Charles H. Hussey, chairman of the executive committee, will call on Christopher D. Sullivan some day this week to ask him to resign, it was learned yesterday.

The report of the special Presidential commission headed by Justice Roberts on the Pearl Harbor disaster is a remarkably candid, thorough and able document, but no American can read what it has to report without sickness of heart. Prior to the attack almost every military mistake possible seems to have been made by those immediately in charge of the defense of Hawaii, while the evils of unlucky chance added to those of incompetence.

Japan's armies move forward toward the Dutch Indies and Northern Australia. Within the past forty-eight hours there have been additional landings in the Bismarck Archipelago, mandated to Australia; at Balik Papan in Southeast Borneo, and at Kendari in the Southern Celebes.

The moving strains of the poetry of Robert Burns mastered the hearts of Scotland at a time when not only Scotland but all Europe was seething with discontent, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, of which he is the pastor.

Predictions that America's food-consuming habits would be revolutionized and that methods of production in the food industry would become more efficient as a result of the war were made by 102 of America's leading food manufacturers in a survey by the Research Market Corporation of America.

Unless we turn this war into a spiritual crusade as well as a battle to defend our way of life, Hitler and his allies may yet win, the Rev. Dr. George St. John, headmaster of the 'Choate School of Wallingford, Conn., said yesterday in his sermon as guest preacher at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Commissioner Alexander M. Damon, Eastern Territorial Commander of the Salvation Army since 1935, and Mrs. Damon will retire from active duty on Friday, after a combined service of nearly 103 years, it was announced yesterday from the Army's headquarters, 120 West Fourteenth Street.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 25 -- Reich's Ambassador Franz von Papen canceled his projected Berlin journey and plans to return to Ankara almost immediately, according to a report from usually well-informed diplomatic circles at Istanbul tonight.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Britain's defenders of Singapore paid tribute today to two Australian "lost battalions" whose magnificent effort to relieve an Indian brigade was ranked with the Balaklava Charge of the Light Brigade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Colonel Charles C. Hillman of the Surgeon General's Office of the Army today issued an urgent call for blood donors. Although Army and Navy forces operating in war areas are now equipped with blood plasma, collected by the American Red Cross, even larger donations must be made if they are to be fully supplied.
BAY CITY, Mich., Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Eight persons, including a family of five, perished today in the blazing ruins of two Bay County homes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Operating with the tactical skill characteristic of the great American military leaders of the past, General Douglas MacArthur has counter-attacked on his right flank in the Bataan Peninsula and thwarted a three-dimensional Japanese offensive -- from the land, the air and the sea -- that threatened to decimate his small force in the Philippines, the War Department announced today.

During last week, the stock market sold slowly down, touching the lowest average of the present year, but not the lowest of 1941. The bond market moved irregularly, but on the whole gained ground. Stocks would have gone lower but for the fractional advance in the railway share average, plainly due to the 10 per cent increase, awarded by the Commerce Commission in passenger fares and to the rather general expectation of higher freight rates.

Five new films will open in local theatres during the week. The first arrival, "The Prime Minister," a British biographical film about the young Disraeli with John Gielgud and Diana Wynyard in the lead roles, will have its premiere tomorrow at the Art Theatre in East Eighth Street.
The Army and Navy declared yesterday, in a joint statement for publication today, that under closely coordinated command the Eastern seaboard was being guarded by land, sea and air forces.

An advertisement titled "Newspaper Advertising in a Nation at War," which discusses the added responsibilities of American newspapers in wartime to both the public and to advertisers, has been released by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, to member papers for publication in their columns.

A city-wide plan to instruct the Catholic population of New York in first aid by offering the standard American Red Cross course in first aid in every parish of the archdiocese, was revealed yesterday morning by Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre.

That heap of waste paper and old magazines cluttering up your attic and your closets is needed by the Government for war purposes. Besides, if there should be air raids, it could be a serious menace. Old tires, bits of iron and steel and copper that aren't doing anybody any good might better be gathered up and turned over to the Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- United States warships, ranging across Japanese convoy lanes in the Strait of Macassar near Borneo, have sunk five additional enemy transports and probably one other without loss to themselves, the Navy Department reported tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- A "shuttle service" organized by the American Red Cross is to have an important part in expediting any future evacuation work in the big Pacific war zone, the announcement of a program disclosed here today.

Mal Stevens, New York University football coach, said last night he had known for the last week of the university's intention to drop the sport, but added he was still hopeful the university council, which meets today to discuss the situation, might arrive at a solution other than outright abolition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Emergency power plants capable of generating up to 30,000 kilowatts are being built under order of the War Production Board and are to be installed on four specially built barges ready to be towed to cities or to war plants where they can be used if necessary to supplement or replace stationary power units.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 25 -- Speaking in the heart of the automobile industry where controversy still rages over the labor-sponsored Reuther plan, Secretary Morgenthau told a mass meeting of the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers today that "American labor has been ahead of us all in its willingness to produce armaments to win the war, whatever the sacrifices, whatever the consequences."
THE most vivid report, long or short, I have ever seen on Rumania comes out this morning under the title of "Athene Palace."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 -- Reports that the Commodity Credit Corporation had received bids for 1,160,000 bales of cotton, whereas the government could sell only 300,000 bales in any one month under the law, and promises from Washington that probably the high ceiling provisos in the price-control bill would be retained were main factors in the advance in cotton futures here last week to new highs for the season and best levels since 1929.

Mal Stevens, New York University football coach, said last night he had known for the last week of the university's intention to drop the sport, but added he was still hopeful the university council, which meets today to discuss the situation, might arrive at a solution other than outright abolition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Emergency power plants capable of generating up to 30,000 kilowatts are being built under order of the War Production Board and are to be installed on four specially built barges ready to be towed to cities or to war plants where they can be used if necessary to supplement or replace stationary power units.
Your editorial "A Zionist Army?" seems to me such a much-needed recall to sanity on a difficult problem that more emphasis on it is well worth while.

VICHY, Jan. 25 -- If there were need of proof of the extreme abundance of money on the market, the movements of funds in the savings accounts which have just been published would supply it. Last year the savings fund, which is managed by the Caisse des Depots et Consignations, increased by 3,500,000,000 francs and the amount due to depositors of the National Savings Fund increased by 3,000,000,000 as well.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- General Liu Wei-chang of the Operations Board predicted in an article in the newspaper Sao Tang Pao that "Singapore will be the Verdun of World War II." He pointed out that the British fortress was designed for a long defense and therefore, he said, Singapore could not be judged by the British setbacks in Malaya.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Imperiled Australia delivered a new, plain-spoken demand on London today for a direct voice in Imperial war councils.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Securities Exchange Act and its administration by the Securities and Exchange Commission have protected investors, but at the same time deprived them of investing opportunity, according to a study of "The Investor and the Securities Act," by Professor Homer V. Cherrington of Iowa University, issued today by the American Council on Public Affairs.
BERLIN, Jan. 25 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The regular German High Command communique today follows:
Three goals in the short space of 48 seconds provided one of the accomplishments by the New York Rangers in their game against the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night.

Three torpedoes from enemy submarines struck the Norwegian tanker Varanger only thirty-five miles off the New Jersey coast at 3:10 o'clock yesterday morning and sent her to the bottom with her valuable cargo of oil, but the entire crew of forty was saved, the Navy Department announced last night.

THE War Productions Board is arranging swiftly for a cutting down of many civilian luxuries and accessories. Some fussy citizens are pretty well cut up about it, but this observer is all out for the cutting down to a war economy basis and has some further saving suggestions to put on file for consideration by the proper authorities.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The British Far East Command communique today said:

SIKESTON, Mo., Jan. 25 (AP) -- A critically wounded Negro, suspected of an attempted attack on a white woman, was taken from the city jail today by a crowd of more than 300, which dragged him through the Negro district and then set the body afire.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks crept within two points of third-place Toronto tonight by defeating the Maple Leafs, 6 -- 4, in a hard-fought and thrilling National Hockey League game before a season's record crowd of 18,679 in the Stadium.

Verdi's "Un ballo in Maschera" ("Masked Ball"), which was revived last season after a 24-year absence from the Metropolitan Opera's repertoire and was reported to have been abandoned when it was learned that Jussi Bjoerling would not return to the company, will be given this season after all.

Condemning the existing probation services for adolescent offenders in New York City's courts as "grossly inadequate," the Society for the Prevention of Crime recommended yesterday the creation of a centralized, city-wide court to handle the cases of the 4,000 youths between the ages of 16 and 18 who are arrested annually.
The favored Brookhattans were eliminated from the National Challenge Cup soccer competition by the Brooklyn Hispanos, 1 -- 0, before a crowd of 3,000 at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The first word that another of Britain's new battleships, the Duke of York, was in service came tonight with the announcement that Prime Minister Winston Churchill had traveled across the Atlantic in her in December to see President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Four firms in the New York area have agreed to desist from sales practices found by the Federal Trade Commission to violate existing laws and regulations, the commission announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Austrians, Austrian-Hungarians and Koreans under certain conditions are exempted from applying for alien enemy certificates of identification, under regulations announced by Attorney General Biddle today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 25 -Use of closed automobile showrooms for light defense industry is being encouraged by the Montclair Town Commission. The first step came last week when the commission confirmed the action of the Board of Adjustment in granting a zone exception on property formerly occupied by the Fisher Cadillac Corporation at 7 North Willow Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks crept within two points of third-place Toronto tonight by defeating the Maple Leafs, 6 -- 4, in a hard-fought and thrilling National Hockey League game before a season's record crowd of 18,679 in the Stadium.

Verdi's "Un ballo in Maschera" ("Masked Ball"), which was revived last season after a 24-year absence from the Metropolitan Opera's repertoire and was reported to have been abandoned when it was learned that Jussi Bjoerling would not return to the company, will be given this season after all.

Condemning the existing probation services for adolescent offenders in New York City's courts as "grossly inadequate," the Society for the Prevention of Crime recommended yesterday the creation of a centralized, city-wide court to handle the cases of the 4,000 youths between the ages of 16 and 18 who are arrested annually.
The favored Brookhattans were eliminated from the National Challenge Cup soccer competition by the Brooklyn Hispanos, 1 -- 0, before a crowd of 3,000 at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The first word that another of Britain's new battleships, the Duke of York, was in service came tonight with the announcement that Prime Minister Winston Churchill had traveled across the Atlantic in her in December to see President Roosevelt.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Sea-borne Japanese invaders forced their way through the Strait of Macassar and made two more landings perilously close to Java today after United States and Netherland bombs, shells and torpedoes had sunk or damaged at least eighteen and possibly twenty-two ships of the invasion fleet.

The most important vocational demand at present is for chemists, physicists, accountants, and statisticians, according to Miss Josephine Hammond, vocational counselor in charge of graduate placement at Hunter College, and positions in scientific and experimental research are being obtained by most of Hunter's physics and chemistry majors even before graduation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- "The American Way," the George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart spectacle, which ran for 164 performances on Broadway in the Winter and Spring of 1939, has been acquired by Columbia in a profit-sharing deal in which the authors and the stage producers will participate.

A nation-wide organization, Bundies for America, which will supply knitted garments, comfort kits, and other needs of men in all the armed services of the United States and the merchant marine was announced yesterday by Mrs. Wales Latham, founder of Bundles for Britain, Inc., who will head the new organization.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill tonight faced the most serious challenge to his leadership since he took office, because of British reverses in Malaya and the increasing Japanese threat to Australia, but observers did not believe an attempt would be made to unseat him in the three-day parliamentary debate expected this week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The following War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., was issued today:
