A Junior committee under the chairmanship of Miss Marie Chris-i topher has been formed to super-I vise ticket sales for a luncheon and fashion show to be given Feb. 3 atI Le Coq Rouge under the joint! auspices of the Free French Relief Committee and the British American Ambulance Corps.
The esthetic vied with the practical in interest yesterday, when 3,200 garden lovers were introduced to new specimens for both their flower and vegetable gardens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- _bout 700 American colleges and universities have been invited to participate in a nation-wide discussion of inter-American affairs, it was announced today by Nelson A. Rockeifeller, coordinator of Inter-_4xnerican Affairs.

Discriminating burglars looted the Donald Murray store at 33 Irving Place, southwest corner of Sixteenth Street, of general merchandise valued at $15,000 over the week-end, it was discovered yesterday when the store was opened. They had removed a hollow tile brick from the wall that separates the shop from an adjacent perfume manufacturer.

MAJOR MICHAEL HOME'S story called "Attack in the Desert"* is quite a story. It is no great shakes as a work of belles lettres and some parts of the plot are practically as ancient as the desert itself, but the novel as a whole is good and the background is of extraordinary interest at this time.

Yehudi Menuhin, who is 25, has been a famous violinst for two-thirds of his life, and he might be pardoned if a suggestion of satiety crept into his playing or platform manner. But his first appearance of the season at Carnegie Hall last night found him an absorbed and devoted performer.

A NORTHERN IRISH PORT, Jan. 26 -- The first American Expeditionary Force of World War II to be sent directly into the European battle zone set foot on the soil of the United Kingdom here today. Several thousand strong, this force arrived unheralded after a secret voyage across the perilous Atlantic.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The landing of United States troops on the soil of the United Kingdom was regarded by the British public today with a deep sense of satisfaction that was not easily expressed in words, particularly by a naturally reticent people. The Briton's first reaction was a "What, really?"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Consumption of sugar this year should average almost one pound per person per week, but this does not mean that under the rationing plan now being developed it will be possible to buy that much per person each week for home use, Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, said today.
With improved weather, Florida anglers are once more churning the blue water, and the Silver Sailfish Derby at West Palm Beach is now rolling along.

The Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation, which makes annual awards to young musicians in the form of New York debut recitals, has a high average in picking its winners. Lura Stover, who appeared at the Town Hall yesterday, is a Naumburg winner who helps bear out this contention.
Play in the Metropolitan Class A singles squash racquets championship started yesterday on the University Club courts. The tournament will continue through the week, with the final on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Installation of a complete water disposal system in which sixty-two landowners participated, and an altered tillage technique have solved a serious soil erosion problem in vineyards along the shore of Central New York's Lake Keuka.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan. 26 -- Women of the United States have little cause for concern over the war's effect on their beauty, says Dr. Emil G. Klarmann, chief chemist of Lehn Fink Products Company, here, manufacturer of Dorothy Grey products.

George A. Barnewall, vice president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, was elected president of the Brooklyn Council of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York at the annual meeting of the council last night at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- The Netherlands Indies charged today that Japan began preparing to invade these rich islands at the end of World War I and that she used her Ambassadors to organize a fifth column in planning "a brutal conquest."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Fred MacMurray will be seen with Bing Crosby in Paramount's "True to Life," a photoplay about the writers of radio serials. Bob Hope originally had been mentioned for the role MacMurray will play. Irving Cummings, who is committed to direct the picture for Paramount, has been tentatively assigned to "Red Harvest" with Paulette Goddard and Brian Donlevy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- The garbage fleet reported today its first victory of the war over a Japanese submarine. It put in its claim, as the West Coast's first "daylight alert" since the war started cut Southern California radio stations off the air for nearly four hours.

The mechanical division of the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday that it had begun a survey to reduce railroad consumption of tin, nickel, copper, brass, rubber, steel and other materials required for armament.

While various conditions caused by the war are taking many New Yorkers to other localities, it is equally true, points out John T. Meenan of the West Side brokerage firm under his name, that similar causes are drawing their quota of newcomers to the city.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- The failure of the Federal Government to begin construction of a Westchester County airport in Purchase, although the county agreed five weeks ago to buy the site, constitutes a national defense debacle, Supervisor Jefferson Armstrong of Yonkers charged this afternoon at a meeting of the County Board of Supervisors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Congress learned today of negotiations to transfer the Brooklyn Naval Hospital to the Jersey City Medical Center.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Price Control Bill which has been before Congress for more than six months inched another step toward final action today when the House, by a vote of 286 to 112, accepted the conference agreement on differing House and Senate versions which was reached last week.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- The yacht Concubine of the Nassau fleet, sailed by Count Alfred de Marigny, won the Bacardi Cup in the sixteenth International Star Class series today with a total of thirty points when she crossed the finish line fourth in the third and final race.

The little city of Sikeston, Mo., earned an unholy notoriety on Sunday when a mob took a seriously wounded Negro prisoner from the city jail, dragged him through the streets and ended by setting the body on fire. The man was charged with breaking into a house and wounding a white woman.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 -- Although the British forces continued to engage the advancing Germans in Western Cyrenaica yesterday, the center of fighting shifted some forty-five miles northeastward from Antelat to the neighborhood of Msus.
Five National Football League records were established by Don Hutson of the Packers in the 1941 professional gridiron campaign. Hutson also tied one record.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Lehman submitted tonight to the Legislature a State budget which will drastically and immediately reduce the State income tax burden. Virtually certain of adoption by the Republican-controlled Senate and Assembly, it calls for a 25 per cent emergency reduction in the income tax payable this April 15 and April 15, 1943.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Bread and water have been abolished as a punishment diet for prisoners on Harts Island, and violators of the institution's rules henceforth are to receive the same food as the regular inmates. This was disclosed today in a report by James McC. Shillinglaw, senior inspector of the Commission of Correction.

The organization of a physicians' war council by the Medical Society of the County of New York, largest county medical society in the United States, was announced last night by Dr. Maximilian A. Ramirez, in his inaugural address as president of the society, at a meeting at the New York Academy of Medicine.

A NORTHERN IRISH PORT, Jan. 26 -- Big ships that had been made gray by paint -- and drab by use -- tossed lines of Manila hemp around bollards of British iron in this port today, after which Irish dockers laid down planks for soldiers from the United States.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 26 -- A victory of "ever-increasing proportions" in the desert war in Africa is being claimed by Germany and Italy. Today's Italian communique announced the arrival in Libya of another large convoy, and the German bulletin said that German planes had scored a direct hit on a light British cruiser off Tokoruk.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Under whatever regulations may he issued for the allocation or rationing of sugar, the White House "will have exactly what every one else does," Mrs. Roosevelt told her press conference today.

Returns for 1941 issued by individual railroads yesterday bore out the predictions issued at the beginning of the year by the Association of American Railroads. In the case of compaines such as the New York Central and the Pennsylvania gross revenues were the highest since 1929 and 1930, respectively.

The letter of Pauline K. Skinner, published recently in your columns, criticized as "a ridiculous project" the collecting of used stamps, which are sold to English dye factories for their coloring matter, the proceeds being devoted to hospital funds.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Dispatches from Russia indicated tonight that the blizzard-braving assault of the Red Army northwest of Moscow was threatening the Nazi stand at Velikiye Luki, eighty miles from the Latvian frontier, and had virtually sealed the doom of the Germans in the upper Volga town of Rzhev, 130 miles northwest of the Soviet capital.

From the contrasting characters of an 11-year-old girl named Virginia and a philosophical old hobo called Ben, found in a novel written by Edwin Corle and published a year ago, John van Druten has fashioned his newest play, "Solitaire," which opens tonight at the Plymouth.

The buying splurge which has been in progress here since the first of the year slackened its pace last week. Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 23 per cent over a year ago, whereas the gain in the preceding week had been 41 per cent, according to the flash report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Under heavy buying by trade interests and professional operators, prices of cotton futures yesterday were carried to their best levels in twelve years. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active contracts closed near their top prices of the day at net gains of 19 to 29 points, or 95 cents to $1.45 a bale.

An exhibition of unusual interest opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street. It is billed as "A History of American Water-Color Painting." And we may, I think, quite safely accept the assurance that this is "the first survey of the subject to be attempted on so extensive a scale."

Free concerts of chamber music will be given weekly at the New York Public Library and the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the duration of the war, Ernest Hutcheson, president of the Juilliard School of Music and the prime mover in the enterprise, announced yesterday at a luncheon for the musical press at the Metropolitan Museum.

Despite the announced toll taken of Axis submarines, the Navy disclosed yesterday that another sinking -- the seventh in the battle off the Atlantic Coast -- had taken place in North Carolina waters early Saturday. The American ore-carrier Venore went to the bottom with 23,000 tons of iron ore, and twenty members of her crew of forty-one were feared lost.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 26 -- Informed sources indicated here today that Bolivia was awaiting word from Foreign Minister Eduardo Anze Matienzo at Rio de Janeiro regarding measures by the United States to aid in the defense of Bolivian territory, in connection with the impending issuance of a decree severing diplomatic and economic relations with the Axis nations.

OTTAWA, Jan. 26 -- Canada will stand side by side with Australia and give every help possible in men and machines in the present crisis, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King declared this evening in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt has signed bills vesting broad war-time powers in him over the nation's wire communications facilities, and liberalizing the Civil Service Retirement and Pension Act, the White House announced today.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 26 -- Economic experts here today said that the mutual reduction of tariffs between the United States and Latin America, under negotiation at Rio de Janeiro, would affect inter-American trade only to a moderate extent, since in wartime the lack of shipping and United States priorities were greater trade barriers than tariffs.
ROME, Jan. 26 (From Italian broadcast recorded by the Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

General Zhukoff, successful defender of Moscow and leader of the Russian counter-offensive, points out the Nazi handicaps. The Germans are used to wireless communication, but the Russians can use wires. The Germans had 3,000 tanks which were stopped by snow, but the Russians have Cossack cavalry.

LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The sinking of the 5,473-ton Spanish freighter Navemar, which had taken thousands of refugees from Europe packed in her hold, was reported to agents of the ship today.

Christopher D. Sullivan was angered yesterday by the renewed movement to bring about his retirement as leader of Tammany Hall. Informed that a committee headed by Charles H. Hussey, chairman of the executive committee, was planning to call on him to resign to pave the way for a reorganization of the New York County Democratic machine, the Tammany leader said:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 26 -- Newark was notified today by the Army that 206 acres of Port Newark would be used as a base from which to ship warplanes. At the same time the Navy announced that work would start tomorrow on a 100-acre shipyard near by.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- Moscow, now 100 miles from the nearest fighting, continues to wear today a look of the front lines. Muscovites tell you that from the moment the Germans invaded Russia there has been a feeling of powder and blood in the air here; and the Nazi retreat has not changed that mood.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- Miss Mary Jane Garman of Hammond, Ind., with a score of 78, took the qualifying medal and was established as the favorite in the Miami Biltmore Women's Golf Tournament today.

While your column Topics of The Times usually has been friendly to the interests of free public education, it made a serious blunder on Jan. 20 when it stated that "New York school teachers want extra pay for their services during the proposed additional Summer session."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The War Production Board said tonight that unions and shipyard owners had ratified an agreement for round-the-clock shipyard operations seven days a week on the Pacific Coast.

Reflecting the sharp increase in group insurance, new insurance written in 1941 gained 14 per cent over the previous year and exceeded the total for any year since 1937, according to the Association of Life Insurance presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

Two men pleaded guilty yesterday, while eight others were placed on trial in Federal court, under an indictment alleging the operation of a large bootleg liquor conspiracy, said to have cheated the government out of $1,000,000 in alcohol taxes from 1934 to 1938.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Strong limitations upon the scope of the Federal Communications Commission investigation into newspaper ownership of radio stations were laid down today by the United States Court of Appeals in ordering James G. Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville Banner and former president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, to testify before the commission.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The valiant but weary defenders of Singapore dropped back tonight along the West Malayan coast, abandoning the anchor city of Batu Pahat, sixty miles northwest of Singapore, but on the other fronts they stanchly stood their ground against superior numbers of Japanese invaders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A full Congressional investigation of the Pearl Harbor disaster Dec. 7 was demanded in Congress today by some members of both parties who held that the report of the Presidential investigating committee headed by Associate Justice Owen J. Roberts of the Supreme Court had uncovered a picture of incompetence which should be further delved into.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies communique said today:
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 26 -- Australia took further measures today to protect civilians in Australian New Guinea, while the Japanese undertook further bombing operations there, and Prime Minister John Curtin announced that negotiations were under way for giving Australia a place on the staff of General Sir Archibald Wavell, Commander in Chief of the Forces of the United Nations in the Southwest Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Roosevelt today appointed twenty-four associate members of the War Labor Board who, when the occasion arises, will serve as alternates to the twelve regular members of the board on labor disputes.

It was probably inevitable that the Roberts report on Pearl Harbor should be seized upon by some of the old opponents of the President's foreign policies as a means of reopening an argument which had apparently been closed in the first days of our new-found unity following Japan's act of treachery.

Day nurseries to care for the children of women working in war industry are being set up under the leadership of a joint committee of the New York State Board of Education and the State Department of Labor, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Ruth Andrus, chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Congress may accept the advice which at least one administration spokesman was offering today: "Leave to future inquiry, and to immediate executive disciplinary action, the answers to several important questions raised and unanswered in the Roberts report; let's concentrate now on fighting the war."

Charley (Lulu) Costantino, unbeaten East Sider, outboxed Victor Corchado, Puerto Rico, in the main bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night to run his string of triumphs to fifty-one. A crowd of about 3,000 looked on. Costantino weighed 130 1/4, Corchado 125 3/4.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 26 -- Dr. Eugene E. Agger of Rutgers University was confirmed by the Senate today as State Banking and Insurance Commissioner to succeed Louis A. Reilly of Newark.

William Flynn, 28 years old, an ex-convict, of 541 East 150th Street, the Bronx, one of three aspects arrested by three detectives "on a hunch" early last Sunday in the midtown district, was arraigned yesterday in Homicide Court on his alleged admission that he was the gunman who, early last Wednesday, killed a patron in the single-handed hold-up of a bar and grill at 1748 Park Avenue.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique said the Red Army had registered new advances and liberated numerous additional villages in fiercely contesteed engagements that had cost the Germans heavy losses.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 26 -- Dr. Albert E. Austin, former Republican Representative from the Fourth Connecticut District and health officer of this town for twenty years until 1937, died at his home here tonight after a long illness. His age was 64. He was president of the old Greenwich Trust Company, a practicing physician and an orator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Stephen T. Early, Presidential press secretary, said today that President Roosevelt, to his knowledge, had not yet discussed the Roberts report with his War and Navy Secretaries.

The Naval Aviation Cadet Selection Board of the Third Naval District, swamped by a rush of candidates said to be four or five times greater than before the declaration of war, moved, yesterday into new and larger offices at 120 Broadway.

Word from Washington yesterday that the corset and brassiere industry would receive an allocation of rubber greatly encouraged manufacturers here and tended to dispel the uncertainty overhanging the trade since the rubber conservation order was issued last month.

ROCKAWAY, N.J., Jan. 26 -- Charles James, chairman of the Rockaway Township Defense Council, announced here today that through the cooperation of the Warren Foundry and Pipe Corporation the council had obtained the use of two abandoned iron-ore haulage tunnels, which have been converted into air-raid shelters capable of accommodating 5,000 persons.

It is regrettable that the Senate voted so hastily to grant the Truman committee an additional $60,000 to continue its work throughout this year. Investigating the progress of the national defense program and the conduct of the war is one of the most important functions that Congress can now undertake, but the spirit and competence with which the Truman committee has performed this function have been highly questionable.

WITH THE A.E.F. IN NORTHERN IRELAND, Jan. 26 -- The first thousands of United States Army combat troops to land on Old World soil in the new war landed here today after a safely conducted voyage by the United States and British Navies.

A report that the government had decided to freeze the sale of electric refrigerators swept through the appliance industry yesterday and resulted in manufacturers being flooded with inquiries from dealers. The Office of Price Administration in Washington, however, denied any knowledge of the report.
Favorable results were disclosed in the annual statements of two leading insurance companies issued for publication today.
On June 8, 1917; General John J. Pershing led a hundred Army men and officers and a civilian staff of equal size from the decks of the White Star Line's steamer Baltic into a British port.

A peanut-butter croquette is better for you than a pill. That is the consensus of the best nutritional minds in the country, and the reason is that very elusive substance, Vitamin B. According to these authorities, the B-complex vitamins that abound in roasted peanuts are better than any number of the pretty pellets that may be bought in a box.

TOK'YO, Jan. 26 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The Japanese Army will tax occupied areas in Southern Asia, if economic conditions permit, to help meet military expenditures, Finance Minister Okinori Kaya asserted in the Diet today.

Confusion reigned in the markets for all classes of tax-exempt securities yesterday as dealers and investors attempted to appraise values under the new threat of legislation designed to make income from the $20,000,000,000 of State and municipal securities outstanding subject to Federal income taxes.

A NORTHERN IRISH PORT, Jan. 26 -- A modest young former dishwasher, who lived on the "Main Street" of a typical country town in the United States, has already become a famous American doughboy. He was the first private in the United States Army to land in Europe as a member of the first American Expeditionary Force to come here since this war began.

Alfred Decker Cohn, Inc., makers of Society Brand clothes, yesterday urged its retail accounts to adopt a "prudent and conservative policy" with regard to forcing the sale of men's clothing within limited periods of time and for special events.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The proposed merger of eight Atlantic seaboard trucking companies, one owned by Kuhn, Loeb Co., into Associated Transport, Inc., was opposed before the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the anti-trust division and the Department of Agriculture on the ground that it was a monopoly.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- When trading in grain futures eased at the close today farmers were able to secure more money for their surplus wheat, corn, oats and rye than at any time since 1937, with soy beans at a new all-time peak since that commodity became of commercial importance, and oats was slightly under the top prices since 1928.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York and former Director of the Budget, today accepted from President Roosevelt the post of assistant lease-lend expediter in London.

A "Blitz" from the heavens startled Brooklyn residents from deep sleep early yesterday morning. Extraordinary lightning flashes and thunderclaps followed by snow and ice pellets that rattled windows and rooftops brought nearly all the sound effects of an aerial attack.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A naval appropriation bill for $17,722,565,474, designed to carry out this nation's policy of "unquestioned supremacy" on the seas wherever we may be called upon to fight, was reported to the House today by its Appropriations Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The White House announced three joint British and American boards for conduct of phases of the war: the Combined Raw Materials Board, the Munitions Assignments Board and the Combined Shipping Adjustment Board.

The football situation at New York University remained unchanged yesterday, following a meeting of the University Council at Washington Square. Although it had been reported that the Violet would give up intercollegiate football and stress intramural sports, the governing body of N.Y.U. discussed matters for more than two hours, then released the following statement:

Salary increases of one cent each for four clerks and a typist employed by Borough President James J. Burke of Queens were sought in Mr. Burke's new budget request submitted yesterday to Budget Director Kenneth Dayton. He seeks to increase the five salaries from $1,799.99 a year each to $1,800,which has the effect of promoting the five from second-grade ratings to the $1,800 starting salary for third-grade employes.

Business leasing activity reported yesterday was featured by a contract calling for occupancy of space on several floors in the building at 7 Dey Street by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The lease, which was negotiated by the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation, agent for the Bank of Savings, completes the rental of the structure.

The big sports problem confronting colleges throughout the land -- that of freshman participation in varsity athletics during the war -- will be settled within the next few months at faculty and conference meetings, but not without considerable dispute.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Java, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- A communique issued by General Sir Archibald P. Wavell's United Nations Headquarters today said that United States Flying Fortresses had sunk a large Japanese transport yesterday and scored a direct hit on a cruiser. A Netherlands Indies communique said that a Netherland submarine had sunk a Japanese destroyer and torpedoed a cruiser, with undisclosed results.
Camouflage is not confined to the military sphere these days. Yesterday it appeared in Spring millinery presented by Fred Lacome, 19 West Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Fifty-one enemy ships have been sunk by United States action in the Pacific, according to official announcements up to 3 P.M. today. The tabulation follows:

While the United States was still a "neutral," friendly to the Allies, one of the most popular and hard-working organizations in this country was Bundles for Britain. It enabled many Americans to express their feelings in genuine helpfulness, and aside from the real service performed for the British people it did wonders for their morale.
BERLIN, Jan. 26 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:
Two brothers sat in Kings County Court yesterday, one charged with a double murder and the other defending the accused as his first client since he was admitted to the bar three months ago.

The war has clearly demonstrated that American colleges are institutions as much "essential to the defense of democracy at war" as they are to the "successful operation" of democracy in peacetime, Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, declared last night.

A NORTHERN IRISH PORT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The honor of carrying the A.E.F.'s national and regimental colors ashore went to Technical Sergeant James M. Cartwright, 22, a married man, and Staff Sergeant Paul Springer, 27, also married, who has a year-old son, Dickie.
My daughter, who is living in England, sent me the following suggestions in a recent letter. They may well be of common interest:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 --Henry Wolf Bikle; who was appointed vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad a month ago and had headed the legal department of the line for almost a decade, died this morning at his home in suburban Stratford. He was 64 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Senate brought the "Second War Powers" bill within striking distance of a final vote today, but adjourned late in the afternoon when it appeared that another hour or two would be required, to debate two remaining controversial amendments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The nation's entire supply of aluminum was marshalled for war today by Production Chief Donald M. Nelson with the issuance of Conservation Order M-1-e. Aluminum has been under strict priority control since early last year. Today's order, effective immediately, prohibits the use of aluminum in any manufacture except on war contracts and the items specifically set out in the order.

Wendell L. Willkie added his contributions to the Victory Book Campaign yesterday, declaring that he had known throughout his life and particularly when he was a soldier in the last war how important books are when the going is hard.
OTTAWA, Jan. 26 -- A beginning was made in Parliament today of what Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King characterized as "one of the most important debates ever to take place in this country."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- President Roosevelt led the nation today in paying tribute to General Douglas MacArthur, whom he congratulated on the occasion of the general's sixty-second birthday, for the magnificent stand he and his men are making in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A two-day stoppage of 150 men in a machine tool plant was ended on Jan. 22, following certification of the dispute to the National War Labor Board, the Labor Division of the War Production Board said today.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- Arrival of the American Expeditionary Force put into the hands of Prime Minister Churchill tonight a veritable thunderbolt to hurl at his critics when he opens three days of war debate at the next meeting of the House of Commons tomorrow.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- Japanese shock troops, storming Batu Pahat under a deadly hall of bombs and bullets, have captured the west coast anchor post, where Australian and Indian forces made the longest stand of the Malaya campaign so far, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- A reporter who apparently believed that the President's wife should campaign for reform of the young men in the armed services sought comment from her today on a reported statement of a retired Army officer that what the Army needed was "not morals, but morale," and that "liquor and women" were necessities of a soldier's life.

OTTAWA, Jan. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced late today in the House of Commons a projected expansion in the Canadian troops overseas from a corps to an army of two corps. He also said Canada would give Britain enormous financial aid through purchase of outstanding Canadian securities held in Britain and freewill gifts of supplies.

Governor Lehman describes his budget for the next fiscal year as that of a State dedicating itself to the successful prosecution of the war. That is correct, but the result is far different from what is ordinarily the effect of war upon budgets. In the case of New York State, budgeting for wartimes means getting out of the road of the national effort.
The earnings of two important oil companies were considerably above those of 1940, according to figures reported for 1941.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- The evidence of German dead, of German prisoners and deserters, and of Russian villagers in areas recovered by the Red Army indicates a condition of filth, demoralization and slovenliness in strong contrast to the generally held view of the German.

As one of the milkshed farmers whom John L. Lewis allegedly hopes to register in his all-encompassing United Mine Workers, I read Saturday's letter by Professor James Drury of New York University, advising against such union entanglements with undetached amazement.

Ben Hecht is a man of many ideas. In "Lily of the Valley," which was acted at the Windsor last evening, he has written an allegory in the county morgue. Rounding up a collection of the unnamed dead who are tagged and photographed in the local charnel house, he has brought them to a state of consciousness in a demi-world between earth and heaven and speculated about their destinies.

Reporting to stockholders on operating results for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, E.S. Phillips, president of Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., said sales and net profits reached the highest levels in the company's 188-year history.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY in Luzon, Jan. 26 -- General Douglas MacArthur, as always a figure of supreme confidence, spent his sixty-second birthday anniversary today working on immediate battle problems and future plans for an eventual democratic victory.

Gus Lesnevich, world light-heavyweight champion, and Bob Pastor, Inwood heavyweight, today will appear before the state Athletic Commission for a physical examination for their ten-round non-title bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 26 -- The political committee of the conference of American Foreign Ministers, in its preparations today for the final ratifying session of the conference tomorrow, adopted a resolution declaring that the American republics could continue relations with the governments of countries invaded by the Axis powers, thereby indicating support for the smaller members of the warring United Nations group.

Sales of defense bonds are proceeding, in record-breaking volume, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Sales of all series of defense savings bonds in the Second Federal Reserve District, other than those of postoffices, aggregated about $189,000,000 from Jan. 1 to 23, inclusive, a total larger than for any full month previously.
Formation of the Lou Gehrig Memorial Fund to raise funds for the purchase of ambulances to be given to the city in memory of the Yankee star who died last June was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Helen Keller, who has overcome the handicap of being deaf and dumb since infancy, had a brief audience with President Roosevelt today and was permitted to touch his face, which, she said, "made me humble and proud."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt heads a distinguished list of patrons, while the Mayor and Mrs. La Guardia are among those representing official life both here and in Washington who are expected to attend tonight's Metropolitan Opera festival for the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York.

The first of a number of "Salvage for Victory" depots was opened yesterday at 471 Amsterdam Avenue, near Eighty-third Street, with a brief ceremony at which Edgar J. Nathan, Borough President of Manhattan, praised "the spontaneous efforts by citizens to respond to war needs."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Office of Defense Health and Welfare Activities has endorsed Federal action against prostitution in defense areas, but has made "no recommendation on liquor," Paul V. McNutt told the Federation of Women's Clubs today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The torpedoing of a Japanese aircraft carrier by an American submarine in the Strait of Macassar was announced by the Navy tonight in a report of further successes in the continuing action against Japanese convoys in the passage between Borneo and Celebes.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Tomorrow the Dziennik Polski, a Polish newspaper, will publish more news from Poland about the inhumane treatment of Russian war prisoners by the Germans. A Ukrainian fugitive from the Biala camp in Eastern Poland said that Jews and Red Army political commissars were killed outright upon arrival at camps.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Lehman conferred today with Army, police and highway officials and drew up plans to lessen the danger of possible sabotage on the State's transportation and communication system.

Television took its place officially in the civilian defense scheme last night with the first of a series of four basic lessons presented by the National Broadcasting Company from Station WNBT, with the cooperation of the Police Department.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique said today:

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 26 -- Chinese sources reported tonight from Shiukwan that Japanese military authorities had ordered the evacuation of 700,000 persons from the former British crown colony of Hong Kong and at neighboring Kowloon.

AS part of the campaign to get that $50,000,000 for the American Red Cross, this observer was asked to call attention in print to the Sonja Henie ice show that will go on at Madison Square Garden tomorrow for the benefit of the fund. Every nickel -- and every other coin or bill taken in at the gate -- will be passed along to the Red Cross coffers.

An exhibition of nearly 100 posters created by comic strip artists and newspaper and magazine cartoonists to aid the work of the United China Relief was opened yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Favorable reaction to price control developments in Washington, which would place the ceiling on live hogs considerably above current levels, was responsible for a gain of 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds in hog prices here today. The best swine brought $11.90 and the average offering sold for about $11.75, peak January quotation for fifteen years. Eastern shippers were in the market for heavy supplies.

The name of the person referred to by Mayor La Guardia Sunday as "a tenant who occupied space in the Bronx Terminal Market for the past eight years and got his electricity without paying for it by plugging in on city lines" was disclosed yesterday by a suit against the city.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Steuben County's three-day anterless deer season last month -- New York's first controlled harvest of other than antlered bucks -- yielded 459 animals, bringing the county's total 1941 bag to 1,073.

All unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations were advised yesterday to demand "substantial" wage increases and the union shop or some other form of union security in forthcoming collective bargaining negotiations.

To say that the municipal bond traders were excited and concerned yesterday by Secretary Morgenthau's suggestion that outstanding State and municipal bonds should be made subject to Federal income taxes would be putting it mildly. However, the fears, expressed by municipal dealers ever since the agitation was started years ago to tax future issues, that such a move would be only an opening wedge to "get at" the outstanding issues, have been justified.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The text of Governor Lehman's budget message, sent to the Legislature tonight is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Japanese Government not only used narcotics as an instrument of national policy against the Manchurians and the Chinese but connived in the smuggling of narcotics into the United States from Japan, Commissioner Harry J. Anslinger today reported to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 26 -- The Japanese Ambassador, Baron Shu Tomii, called at the Foreign Ministry this morning, as the German charge d'affaires did on Saturday, to request a "clarification" of the resolution for a rupture of relations with the Axis approved at the Rio de Janeiro conference and to ask what interpretation the Argentine Government placed upon it.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 26 -- Bolivia and Paraguay severed diplomatic and economic relations with the Axis powers today as the conference of American foreign ministers here completed preparations for the ratifying of its decisions and adjourning at a plenary session tomorrow.

Demand for admission tickets for the course on "Vegetable Growing for Victory," which will open tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 o'clock at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, has exhausted all the available pasteboards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) --Creation of a man-power mobilization board with far-reaching powers to say where and how men and women should work during the war has been proposed to President Roosevelt by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

A group composed of Alex. Brown Sons, Goldman, Sachs Co. and Kaiser Co. received yesterday the award of an issue of $750,000 of public improvement bonds of the city of Alexandria, Va., on a bid of 101.28 for a fixed interest rate of 2 1/2 per cent. The bonds, dated Dec. 15, 1941, will mature serially from Dec. 15, 1943 to 1977.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Exceptions whereby enemy aliens in jail, or who are aged or infirm, likewise such aliens who are ill at the time, need not file applications for identification certificates, were announced by Attorney General Biddle today.

A shortage in nearly all types of industrial space is facing New Jersey's industrial brokers at the start of the new year, points out Julius I. Kislak, president of the Jersey City firm bearing his name and governing councillor of the Society of Industrial Realtors.

HONOLULU, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- The Star-Bulletin said today that the Roberts report was "convincing proof that negligence and ineptitude in the conduct of the war will not be tolerated, no matter how highly placed the offenders may be."

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has undertaken to build a large-scale garden-type housing project that will accommodate 1,200 war workers and their families in the "hill section" of Brooklyn, not far from the New York Navy Yard.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Following the announcement today of last year's results, Woolworth shares fell to 56 1/4s from 58 3/4s. The dividend also was below expectations, with a final declaration of 1 1/2s on 5s shares, making with a 1s interim a total of 2 1/2s a share for the year.

John Gunther and William Rose Benet will be guest authors this afternoon at 4 o'clock at the Burma Road Mart, 535 Madison Avenue, under the auspices of the Writers Committee of the United China Relief. The authors will autograph their books.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Conquered peoples must supply the Japanese armed forces with foodstuffs, war supplies and labor, said an official Tokyo radio announcement, recorded tonight by the Columbia Broadcasting System's listening post here. The Tokyo radio was quoted as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 -- In semi-darkness and miserable playing conditions, Beltin' Ben Hogan charged home like the champion he is to win the $5,000 San Francisco open golf tournament today with a seventy-two-hole total of 279, nine under par.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior forecast today that discontinuance of new car production, control of rubber stocks and rationing of tires would reduce domestic crude oil requirements next month to 4,101,800 barrels daily, or 36,600 less than the average daily consumption in January.

HUTCHINSON, Minn., Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- Private Milburn Henke, the first American soldier ashore in this war's first American Expeditionary Force to Europe, was a hero tonight in the small town where he left his job as a waiter to enlist in the Army.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- Free French quarters said tonight they expected a renewal of pressure by the United States to persuade their forces to evacuate the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon, but added they are determined not to yield.

Mina Hager, mezzo-soprano, whose only appearance here in recent years has been in a program of work by Charles Ives with the pianist John Kirkpatrick, last night gave a solo recital at Town Hall. Her program was devoted to four composers, Pergolesi, Schumann, John Alden Carpenter and the contemporary Italian, Ildebrando Pizzetti.
As the crisis in the Southwestern Pacific was intensified yesterday with continued Japanese assaults upon the Malay barrier, it was evident that the Battle for Asia was a race against time.

Increasingly in recent months Mayor La Guardia has shown a petulant resentment against old friends who approved of most of what he has done but ventured to differ in some details. Every one would like to think that this impatience is due to overwork and would disappear if the Mayor limited himself to being Mayor.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 26 -- A young girl was killed and three other persons injured, two of them seriously, when a car skidded on a slippery highway here this morning and crashed into a telephone pole and a tree.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 26 (AP) -- American volunteer pilots added still another stunning defeat to the Japanese Air Force today in the utter rout of forty enemy raiders approaching Rangoon while on the land front in Southern Burma British Imperial forces held the invader to a standstill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A naval torpedo boat again harried the Japanese invaders of Luzon Island in the Philippines today by dashing into Subic Bay and sinking a second 5,000-ton vessel, while the United States-Filipino forces under General Douglas MacArthur enjoyed a relatively quiet day, according to communiques issued by the War and Navy Departments.

" The Corsican Brothers," now in its second week at the Capitol, will enter its third week on Thursday, and the opening of "Design for Scandal," which was announced for that date, has been set tentatively for Thursday, Feb. 5. . . "Son of Fury," with Tyrone Power and Gene Tierney, will arrive at the Roxy on Thursday with preview showings of the film schedules for tomorrow night. . .

Al Baggett of West Texas State and Clair Bee of Long Island University, two coaches who look for size as much as skill when they round up players for their teams, rose in defense of the big man in basketball at yesterday's luncheon meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln.

WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Central Front, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- The hero of Mozhaisk, Lieut. Gen. Leonid Alexandrovitch Govoroff, whose troops are beating the Germans back an average of five miles a day in this sector, predicted today that the war would reach a crisis next Spring when the Germans resume mass tank attacks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today at his press conference that the Treasury intended to ask for legislation empowering it to tax outstanding and future issues of State and municipal bonds but not outstanding issues of Federal bonds, since the latter would be a breach of the contract made by the Federal Government with the buyers of its securities.

PAL BEACH, Jn. 26 -- Mr. and Mrs. John 1Vfoffat were dinner hosts tonight at the Everglades Club, entertaining first with cocktails at their apartment. Present were Mr. and 1VIrs. Paulding Fosdick with iVfrs. Carey Reed, .Lr. and Mrs. D, Dulany Hunter, Colonel and Mrs. William Hayward, iVIr. and /Hrs. Jacques Stern and Mr. and Mrs. Claude K. Boettcher.
The east and west sides of the midtown section shared in the apartment renting activity reported yesterday by brokers handling that type of transaction.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- The first detailed statement, since the war's outbreak, of the canned foods requirements of government agencies was presented to canners today by an official spokesman at the opening sessions of the National Canners Association, which is meeting in its thirty-fifth annual convention here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The arrival of United States troops in Northern Ireland today was announced here in a brief statement issued by the War Department in the name of Secretary Henry L. Stimson.

A project permitting Army and Navy officers up to the rank of captain and senior lieutenant, respectively, to buy tickets at half price for Broadway shows, including the Music Hall, was started yesterday at a luncheon given by John Golden in the Hotel Commodore.

At a recent luncheon of fashion authorities, speculation arose concerning the influence of women's uniforms, already unmistakably reflected in suit styles, upon hair styles this coming season. The consensus was that the greatest change would be toward still shorter hair.
There's nothing wrong with the Giants that a good pitcher and a second-string catcher can't remedy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Ensign George Cox, 27-year-old commander of the United States motor torpedo boat that sent a 5,000-ton Japanese vessel to the bottom in a raid near Subic Bay, is a holder of the Croix de Guerre, French military decoration.

The Norwegian settlers of Minnesota and Wisconsin used skis for cross-country travel as far back as 1840. Until five years ago the Midwest, where the National Ski Association of America was founded in 1904 at Ishpeming, Mich., was known only for its ski jumping an langlauf facilities.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- With all her sugar stocks sold, Cuba today was beginning to harvest the present crop with the prospect for the first time in many years of sending abroad all the available cane supply.

Exporters, by profession well acquainted with the uses of diplomatic verbiage, were pleased yesterday with the week-end exchange of messages between Washington and the Rio de Janeiro Conference, in which a policy permitting export premiums on price ceilings was established, but they were inclined to await practical measures effectuating the policy before expressing jubilation.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The following are unofficial tables showing the savings in prospect for taxpayers, estimated from Governor Lehman's recommendations cutting tke State income tax 25 per cent, and from the elimination, voted last year, of the 1 per cent emergency levy. The computations are made only on personal exemptions and do not take into account other deductions which serve to reduce the tax further:

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 -- J.M. Miles's Peep Show, a 15-to-1-shot winner over the turf course last Friday, returned to the main track at Hialeah Park today and drove to a half-length triumph in the Silver Bluff Purse. The Display colt, apparently beaten in the stretch, staved off his challengers in unusually game fashion and paid $11.40 for $2.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Jan. 26 -- The defense of the Anglo-American Pacific war policy made by Prime Minister Peter Fraser last night was viewed here today as strikingly different than the Australian and Chinese pronouncements of last week.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Governor Lehman, in his budget message tonight, imposed a flat embargo on the construction of highways and parkways, grade-crossing eliminations and new State-financed housing, for which $340,000,000 of bond issues have been authorized.

Richard W. Lawrence, president of the Young Men's Christian Association of New York since 1935, has been elected to the New York University Council, governing body of the institution, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Fred I. Kent, council president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has a tremendous birthday cake, weighing 350 pounds and standing 6 feet 4 inches tall.

The greatly publicized West Texas State basketball team that unashamedly admits it is "The Tallest Team on Earth," will draw a near capacity crowd to Madison Square Garden tonight as the series of collegiate court double-headers is resumed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The effect on Anglo-American trade and Britain's balance of payments with the United States of the loss of some $300,000,000 a year which she formerly amassed by selling Malayan rubber and tin to this country were discussed yesterday by Lord Halifax, British Ambassador, and Sir Frederick Philipps, Under-Secretary of the British Treasury, with Secretary Morgenthau.
A zither zoomed into the war scene yesterday to point up the need for instruments of recreation at Army camps.
She's enthusiastic and energetic and one day she wants to keep bees. So until that shadowy sometime arrives she contents herself with the next best thing -- selling honey in a fledgling shop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference six, eight or ten American Expeditionary Forces were outside the United States; he discussed the legislative situation with Confessional leaders; designated Harry Hopkins, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land and William L. Batt as the country's representatives on the joint British-United States Boards to control munitions, shipping and raw materials pools.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Unprecedented demand for American cheese has encouraged 125 plants in dairying areas to manufacture it for the first time, the Department of Agriculture said today, and the record-breaking output is running 50 per cent higher than last year.

Reports for 1941 issued by the railroads yesterday continued to show substantial increases in earnings for the year compared with 1940. The statements did not in all cases give the net income after all deductions, but frequently the gains in net operating income were impressive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Alleging that the Navy Department appeared to show little interest in saving money once the contracts for ships were awarded, Senator Truman recommended legislation today that would tax "unreasonable and unconscionable" profits out of such contracts.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Press reports said that 1,500 British troops were killed or captured in fighting around Kluang, in the middle of the Malay Peninsula, and that a similar fate awaited 1,000 troops surrounded near Batu Pahat, while Japanese soldiers pursued smaller enemy units who had succeeded in escaping the envelopment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The War Department communique based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27 -Dartmouth overcame Yale, 6 to 4, tonight in a Pentagonal Hockey League contest and displaced the Elis as leaders of the circuit. Dartmouth has won both of its starts, while the Blue suffered its first setback in three league games.

The State Athletic Commission's seal of approval yesterday was placed upon Gus Lesnevich, world light-heavyweight champion, and Bob Pastor, who are to battle ten rounds Friday night in Madison Square Garden. Lesnevich's title will not be involved, since the battle has been signed at the heavyweight poundage.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The British War Relief Society of America today opened the $350,000 Churchill Hospital at Headington, Oxfordshire. The Duchess of Kent officiated at the ceremony, where Admiral Robert Lee Ghormley represented Ambassador John G. Winant.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 27 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Following is today's communique of the Netherlands Indies fighting services:
BERLIN, Jan. 27 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Soviet Embassy public today an account, cabled from Kuibyshev, Russia, of heroic war feats by members of the Soviet Navy. It was written by Novikov Priboi, described as one of the most popular of the older generation of Soviet writers, a former sailor in the Czarist Navy and author of the novel, "Tsusina."
The Pearl Harbor report is the most humiliating indictment of America that Americans have ever had to face.

Many anglers familiar with inshore and offshore waters, from Rhode Island to New Jersey, will have an opportunity to serve their country under the new Naval Reserve classification, which offers ratings commensurate with each individual's experience.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The point gained from a bruising scoreless overtime tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs enabled the Boston Bruins to pull into a first-place National Hockey League deadlock tonight before a capacity crowd of 14,500 at the Boston Garden.

The Navy Department declined to comment yesterday on the latest German claims of submarine successes off the Atlantic Coast. A naval spokesman in Washington said that when the time was right the box score would be made public.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Jan. 28 -- Strongly reinforced German units counter-attacked at several points on the Eastern Front yesterday in a futile attempt to halt the Russians' advance, according to the midnight communique of the Russian High Command.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Legislative attention centered on defense today as the Governor's office and legislative leaders prepared for a joint conference of executive and legislative branches tomorrow on the details of the Governor's program to which the leaders have subscribed in principle.

A North Irish port on a January morning is one of the dreariest landing places in the world. The cold fog hangs like a wet blanket over the gray coast towns. The cobbled streets are slippery and bleak and the huddled houses turn a dour, forbidding face upon the passerby.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes entertained with a cocktail party today at Beretania for their guests, the Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef of Austria.

THE part of the Pearl Harbor report that had to do with the attitude of the Army and Navy commanding officers toward one another's activities out yonder brought to mind the old moth-eaten legend of the Harvard varsity oarsman so imbued with team spirit that, really, he spoke to everybody in his boat except a couple of bally bounders up in the bow.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, announced yesterday a proposed plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, which is in bankruptcy. This one would be in opposition to the plan backed by a group of fiduciary institutions headed by John W. Stedman, vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Republican leaders of the Legislature gave full approval today to Governor Lehman's plan for a 25 per cent cut in the income tax and no obstacle stands in the way of its enactment in time to benefit taxpayers in their April 15 returns.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Sales by main store departments in the 236 stores which reported to the Federal Reserve Board during December, 1941, were 12 per cent greater than for the corresponding month of 1940, it was announced today.
ROME, Jan. 27 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:
The Community Service Society gave aid last year to 81,120 persons in 32,502 families, in keeping with its aim to improve family and community life, according to the annual report yesterday.
The shipbuilding industry is reaching its "stride" and is coming nearer to its wartime goal than any other industry, according to J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The four seeded players survived the quarter-finals of the Atlantic Coast squash racquets tournament at Haddon Hall today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Announcement that the price control bill had passed the House served as a signal for rather general buying of wheat and rye futures in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, with both grains selling at new high levels since 1937.

Sufficient outside support failed to enter the stock market yesterday and, although the gains of Monday were extended in the morning, the familiar timidity reappeared after the noon hour with final prices irregularly easier. Misgivings likewise cropped out in the commodity markets where fresh buying, created by the House approval of the price-control legislation, gave way to profit-taking.

Out-of-town buyers arriving in the market last week numbered 1,522, which compared with 1,528 in the previous week and 1,000 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's visiting buyers totaled 593, as against 772 for last Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan, 27 -- Jack Benny was signed today by Warner Brothers to star in the screen version of "George Washington Slept Here," Broadway comedy of 1940 by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart, which Warners purchased for $83,000.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 3418 Gates Place, the Bronx, was sold by Albert J. Schuss to a client of Sidney Leichter, attorney. The structure contains forty-two apartments and is said to have an annual rent roll of $26,500. David A. Teichman was the attorney for the seller.

End of the fight to legalize birth control was seen yesterday by Morris Ernst, counsel to the New York State Federation for Planned Parenthood, who predicted that the government would take over the movement as it had taken over fire control, public education and the mails.

For the fifth consecutive session the cotton market advanced yesterday into new high ground since 1929, as active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered gains of as much as 24 to 26 points, or $1.20 to $1.30 a bale, in early trading.

Margaret C. Lyons of 1015 Seventy-seventh Street, Brooklyn, a student in the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University, has been named the winner of the 1942 scholarship of the Women's Press Club of New York City, it was announced yesterday at the university.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The first indication that the British are willing to drive a wedge into their continental blockade on behalf of Greece was given today in the House of Commons by Hugh Dalton, Minister of Economic Warfare, who said the British and United States Governments were prepared to authorize a single shipment of 8,000 tons of wheat under the auspices of the International Red Cross.
The deep shadows of secrecy that have obscured many of the war fronts were somewhat illuminated yesterday as fierce fighting continued in many theatres.

RANGOON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Japanese-Thai push into Burma appeared to have been checked tonight after British planes bombed and machine-gunned the invaders' troop and supply trucks on the Kawkareik Road east of strategic Moulmein.

Several luncheon parties were given yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher entertained with a luncheon for her granddaughters, Miss Eleanor Darlington Fisher, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher Jr., and Mrs. De Witt L. Alexandre.

Contrary to the impression given by the report of the Truman investigating committee, the engineering and production record of the United States aviation industry is so good that improved planes now being made in mass production, with new technical devices, promise "frightful surprises" for the Germans and Japanese, according to Colonel John H. Jouett, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Miss Irene M. Dill of Detroit, making her first Florida Winter golf tour, became one of the favorities in the Miami Biltmore women's tournament today by eliminating the medalist, Miss Mary Jane Garman of Hammond, Ind., 4 and 2.
LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique announcing the loss of the 31,000-ton battleship Barham said today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Accepting a call to give America's "major answer" to "the challenge issued by the forces of autocracy" through Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor, the House of Representatives, by a vote of 388 to 0, passed today an appropriation bill carrying $19,977,965,474 for the Navy, $17,722,565,474 in new cash and the rest in contract authorizations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 27 -- Definite settlement of the 125-year-old frontier dispute between Peru and Ecuador was announced tonight after obstacles in the old controversy had delayed the closing of the conference of American Foreign Ministers until tomorrow.

The first serious threat to Yankee supremacy in the American League this year came yesterday with the announcement that Tommy Henrich, guardian of right field, may be lost to the club. Henrich's draft board at Massillon, Ohio, in fulfillment of instructions from Selective Service headquarters in Washington, reclassified Henrich, shifting him tentatively to Class 1 from Class 3A.

HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- The first race in the Cup of Cuba series in the sixteenth international Star Class regatta was won today by the Cuban yacht Kurush II, sailed by Charles de Cardenas, with G. Aurioles acting as crew. She crossed the finish line after 1 hour 39 minutes 11 seconds, leading Harry Nye Jr. of Southern Lake, Mich., in his new boat Gale, by more than 2 minutes.

For his work in "the development and successful operation of oceanic air transport," Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways System, received last night the Daniel Guggenheim Medal for 1941 at the tenth anniversary dinner of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

The International Nickel Company has taken a long lease on a major portion of the second floor in 67 Wall Street for its mailing department, and a new elevator to this floor has been installed for the new tenant. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., negotiated the lease.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The conference of Foreign Ministers in Rio de Janeiro has been asked to authorize hemisphere-wide civilian defense activities by women.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The battle of the Strait of Macassar, with its frightful cost to the Japanese in men and ships, was declared authoritatively tonight to have set back Japan's invasion clock and to have put the enemy face to face with the question of revising his whole plan of Southern Pacific conquest.

Mme. Lotte Lehmann, Metropolitan Opera soprano, who made her New York debut ten years ago this month in a recital at Town Hall, was honored yesterday at the annual theatre luncheon given by the board of trustees of Town Hall at the Hotel Astor.
MELBOURNE, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- It was announced here today that the army had canceled harvesting leave for thousands of militiamen in an all-out mobilization to curb the invaders.
WITH THE A.E.F. in Northern Ireland, Jan. 27 -- Light work was ordered today for some of the United States combat troops now established in their camps in Northern Ireland.

In their drive against pinball machines which began last Wednesday, the police have confiscated a fourth of the estimated 11,080 machines in the five boroughs, it was made known yesterday. They have taken to station houses and a Brooklyn warehouse 3,031 machines and have summoned to court 1,562 small store owners and machine distributors.

LEWES, Del., Jan. 27 -- A submarine that loomed briefly alongside to inspect the damage caused by a single torpedo claimed the tanker Francis E. Powell of the Atlantic Refining Company, seventeen survivors said tonight while they were recovering from exhaustion and exposure at the Lewes Coast Guard station.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The bonds between the United States and Great Britain in their prosecution of a common war were drawn closer today when President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill simultaneously announced the formation of three Anglo-American committees to administer jointly the shipping, munitions assignments and raw materials of the two nations.

A program as enchanting as it was unhackneyed was presented at the Town Hall last night by the Dessoff Choirs under the direction of that searching and imaginative musician Paul Boepple. It was a program devoted entirely to Orlando Lassus, who lived and died in the sixteenth century and whose music remains fresh and powerful and meaningful.

A NORTHERN IRISH PORT, Jan. 27 -- White the first contingent of United States troops to land in the United Kingdom settled in several camps somewhere in Northern Ireland today it was announced that headquarters of the United States Army Forces in the British Isles had been established somewhere in England, with Major Gen. James E. Chaney in command.
The East Side of the midtown section accounted for the bulk of the contracts for residential quarters reported yesterday by brokers.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The 31,000-ton British battleship Barham was sunk in the Mediterranean on Nov. 2, the Admiralty announced today with the explanation that the delay in making the loss public arose from the enemy's ignorance for some time that the warship had been sent to the bottom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -Major Gen. James E. Chaney is no stranger to jobs combining military affairs with diplomacy. He was a member of the United States military mission that visited Moscow last September, and in 1932 he was technical adviser to General George S. Simonds at the disarmament conference in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The text of the White House announcement of the establishment of three joint British-American boards to coordinate further the war effort was as follows:
"The Norsemen Call -- Skiing for All," appropriate slogan of the Norsemen S.C., founded in 1921, was heard at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

A new publishing house known as the Pamet Press has been founded by a group of authors, editors and artists who live on Cape Cod. The press is named after the Pamet River, a tidal stream which passes through Truro, where the house will have its main office.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Sixty Pearl Harbor widows have applied for jobs in an airplane plant with the motto "Keep 'Em Flying to Avenge Our Husbands' Deaths."

The primary responsibility for the disaster at Pearl Harbor must rest where the report of the Roberts Commission placed it -- on the men in command at Hawaii itself. No long-distance check-up from Washington, five thousand miles away, even if it had been more thorough than the report actually showed it to be, could have compensated for negligence and incompetence on the spot.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique said today:

Reporting earnings of $307,500,000 for 1941, before deducting taxes, a result considerably above that of any year since 1918, the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday a net profit, after all taxes and other charges, of $116,019,518.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -..arly enthusiasm Pushed best hogs up to $12. a gain of 10 cents a hundredweight, on the livestock narket today, but the advance failed to hold and closing prices were down as much as 15 cents from initial transactions. At $12 best hogs were selling at their highest since Sept. 20, 1941, and at a new peak for January for the last fifteen years.
Pirie MacDonald, one of the foremost photographers of men, observed his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary yesterday by working as usual in his tenth-floor studio at 576 Fifth Avenue.
In the city trading reported yesterday residential realty of various types went into new hands. Several private dwellings as well as tenements were included.

Lily Pons gave her only recital of this season in New York at Carnegie Hall last night. There was an audience of 2,500 and the first-tier boxes were draped with flags, for the recital was a benefit for Belgians in Britain, a division of Bundles for Britain.

The price-control bill finally passed yesterday by Congress cannot be called a "hasty" measure. It is six months since the President sent a special message to Congress asking for such a bill. Unfortunately, in this case the long delay has been far from a sign of mature consideration.

A syndicate headed by Smith, Burris Co. and Tobey Co. will offer today to the public a new issue of 20,000 shares of 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and 20,000 shares of common stock of the Diana Stores Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Word received here from the Philippine Islands battle front today emphasized the fact that pursuit planes of a modern American type were assisting General Douglas MacArthur's greatly outnumbered forces in holding their own on the battlefield in the Bataan Peninsula on Luzon Island.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 27 -- Dr. Eugen Steinach, celebrated Austrian physician and discoverer of the function of the hormone in the "reactivization" of the human body, will celebrate his eighty-first birthday here tomorrow "still feeling spiritually many years less than my mathematical age."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission was accused before a Congressional committee today of conducting a "type of terrorism" that is "unjust, unfair and certainly un-American."

Art has proved of so much interest to men in the armed services that the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has created a new position on its staff to further cooperation between the museum and the Army and Navy.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 27 -- President Roosevelt celebrates his sixtieth birthday this Friday enjoying the highest measure of public confidence and support of any time since he took office.

The 1941 tax bill of the United States Steel Corporation was the largest borne by the company since 1918, and except for that year and 1917, was the largest in the forty years of its existence. Earnings before all taxes in 1941 were $307,500,000, against $187,600,000 in 1940, $252,600,000 in 1929 and $169,000,000 in 1926.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Full authority to ration all goods and commodities sold at retail in the United States was given today to Leon Henderson, the Price Administrator, by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

Phelps, Fenn Co. and A.E. Masten Co. of Pittsburgh were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $1,000,000 State of West Virginia road bonds, receiving the award on an interest cost basis of 1.73 per cent. The winning bid was par for $960,000 as 1 3/4s and $40,000 as 1 1/2s.

Governor Lehman's nice little gift of a proposed 25 per cent cut in the income tax is all the pleasanter because of those Federal income tax blanks which Washington has been thoughtful enough to send out for careful preliminary study.

The market for tax-exempt State and municipal bonds gave signs yesterday of recovering from the initial shock of Secretary Morgenthau's suggestion that outstanding issues be made subject to Federal income tax levies, which had virtually demoralized trading in those issues on Monday.

The 1,700-ton destroyer Rodman was commissioned yesterday in the navy yard in Brooklyn, another formidable hunter of "enemies who follow no ethics of warfare and who know no limits as to brutality," in the words of Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the Third Naval District and commander of the North Atlantic Naval Coastal Frontier.
DUBLIN, Jan. 27 -- All Eire's morning newspapers carried stories today of the arrival of United States troops in Northern Ireland while Dublin's three dailies made the story a subject for posters.

In a speech in Cleveland last Saturday Secretary Morgenthau declared that it is high time for the Federal Government to tax the income of outstanding as well as future issues of State and municipal securities. On Monday the market for tax-exempt municipals was so badly disorganized by this news that it was thought best not to publish quotations in the following day's edition of this paper.

While Robert W. Johnson, New Jersey State Rationing Administrator, announced yesterday in Trenton that he was at work, under orders from the Office of Price Administration, on plans for rationing sugar, new automobiles and recapped and retreaded tires as well as new tires, Harold W. McGraw, Federal Rationing Administrator for this city, was without instructions from Washington relative to the extension of rationing.

Fares paid by the thousands of commuters who travel to and from New York City on railroad lines wholly within this State will not soon be increased by 10 per cent along with passenger rail rates throughout the country, it was indicated yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill told Great Britain today that United States fighter and bomber squadrons would participate "in the coming offensive against Germany," and gave his assurances that in 1943 the United Nations would be able to set out in "good style" to destroy Japan.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force bombers, escorted by American "Flying Tigers," blasted Japanese and Thai troop columns along the roads east of Moulmein today until the "invasion route" from Thailand was temporarily blocked by corpses and wrecked trucks.

With John Ezersky making 21 points, more than half his team's total, Power Memorial's five turned back St. Ann's Academy, 41 -- 35, in a Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A. game on the latter's court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- On the ground that bus lines have been confronted with substantial increases in the cost of labor and the prices of materials and supplies, the National Bus Traffic Association, Inc., of Chicago, representing nearly all the interstate passenger bus operators in the United State, has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to permit a 10 per cent increase in bus fares.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Fifty British planes were shot down yesterday, thirty-nine of them in air battles during which British formations of bombers and torpedo planes attempted to attack groups of Japanese transports off Endau on the east coast of Malaya, it was announced in Tokyo today.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- When Prime Minister Winston Churchill spoke today in the House of Commons he made one of the longest speeches he has delivered since he became Prime Minister. Apart from its purely parliamentary portions, which were considerable, he packed into his address much discussion of the war as a whole.

The day's mail was exceptionally heavy yesterday for Gerry King, the 4-year-old "polio" patient who is to be a White House guest on Friday to help the President celebrate his sixtieth birthday. Four flights up the stairs at 448 West Fifty-eighth Street in Gerry's home, the postman dropped a special sack of mail containing hundreds of contributions to the 1942 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

In spite of repeated warnings as to the seriousness of their prospective duties, 350 Brooklyn women volunteered yesterday as hospital aides after a mobilization rally in the Hotel Bossert, 98 Montague Street. The rally, the first in a series arranged by the United Hospital Fund to assist the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, was attended by 650 women, twice the number expected.

As the result of a recent change in the zoning regulations by the East Orange, N.J., City Council, the Western Electric Company has leased four contiguous properties in the area bounded by South Sixteenth Street, Central Avenue and South Seventeenth Street in that community for the storage and distribution of telephone equipment.
