While prices are not likely to rise rapidly during the next two years, the United States and probably the entire world has now entered upon an inflationar cycle that will continue for many years in the post-war period, Roy Wenzlick, president of the Real Estate Analysts, St. Louis, told the annual convention yesterday of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Far be it from me to add to the controversy that seems always to rage when any matters of how to use air power are debated. I cannot help remembering what a great general remarked to me in the last war about these controversies:...
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 27 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish communique today said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary Perkins asked today for a relaxing of State labor standards where labor shortages existed in war industries. In a statement of policy concurred in by the War and Navy Departments, she said:

The war production program will necessitate a reduction in the average standard of living in the United States to the depression levels of 1933, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Two new films will open in Broadway houses this morning. "Sullivan's Travels" the fourth comedy to be written and directed by Preston Sturges, will be the new attraction at the Paramount. Joel McCrea and Veronica Lake enact the principal roles, while William Demarest, Robert Warwick, Franklin Pangborn, Porter Hall and Eric Blore are among the featured players. . . . Metro's "A Yank on the Burma Road," will be the new offering at Loew's Criterion.

Half the city's 600,000 automobiles expected to be in use early next month are carrying the Federal use tax stamps that must be affixed to the vehicles after Jan. 31, it was estimated last night. Four days remain before the tax is due.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Jan. 27 -The press here today hailed the statement of Prime Minister Peter Fraser on the Pacific situation as revealing that the Allied war plan was moving ahead for powerful counter-blows against the Axis despite the misgivings of some of the United Nations.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- A twenty-six-bill program, dealing with the care and treatment of criminal offenders between the ages of 16 and 19 and those under 16 who come into the jurisdiction of the children's courts has been submitted to the Legislature by Fred A. Young, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee studying children's court jurisdiction and juvenile delinquency.

Assurance that the War Production Board does not expect any serious shortage in paper for the printing and publishing industries was given yesterday by George A. Renard, acting chief of the printing and publishing division of the WPB, in a forum discussion on business problems sponsored by the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Senate approved today, 65 to 14, the Wartime Price Control Bill and sent it to the White House amid predictions that it was not adequate to halt inflation and charges that Congress shirked its responsibility in refusing to face over-all control of wages, commodity prices, industrial profits, rents and other elements entering into the price structure.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Official assurance that the canning industry would be permitted to obtain necessary supplies of sugar under the terms of the new sugar order was received by canners here today at the thirty-fifth annual convention of the National Canners Association.

Because the United States and Great Britain are now full partners in the war, the statements of Mr. Churchill have even greater interest and importance for readers in this country than in the days before Dec. 7. Yesterday's speech in the House of Commons, was the first report on the progress of the war that the Prime Minister has made since his visit to this country.

A seven-man committee on national defense has been appointed by the American Gas Association to replace a group of forty-seven set up by the association in May, 1940, it was announced yesterday by George S. Hawley, president.

One of the most unusual musical events of recent years was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York. It was an Opera Festival, including not only parts of four operas given in full regalia but a closing event called "Salute to the Colors" that enlisted virtually all the members of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 27 -- The Royal Australian Air Force made a second bombing attack last night on Japanese ships in Rabaul Harbor, New Britain, set two of the vessels afire and damaged a third, it was announced today. It is believed that in Saturday's and yesterday's raids four ships in all were damaged.

After receiving a collection of twenty-one German, Italian and Japanese medals at City Hall yesterday for his metal salvage scrap pile Mayor La Guardia said the philosophy of the dictator nations would be junked as rapidly as their decorations.

In "Solitaire," which was acted at the Plymouth last evening, John van Druten has gone straight to the heart of a poignant situation. He is writing about a child who tries to conform to an arbitrary adult world. Edwin Corle wrote it first in the form of a novel.

A shortage of railway baggage cars brought about by the war is likely to compel touring theatrical attractions to depend on buses for transportation, it became known yesterday. The Southern Railway System has notified the management of "Hellzapoppin" that it will be unable to supply any baggage cars to transport scenery and possibly coaches to carry the Billy House-Eddie Garr aggregation now playing in Hershey, Pa.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 27 -The curiosity of Assemblymen concerning the results of Bermuda's recent official delegation to Washington to discuss with United States authorities matters arising from the leasing of defense bases here went unsatisfied this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Six, eight or ten American expeditionary forces are operating in various parts of the world, President Roosevelt told his press conference today.
Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the First Army, called yesterday for a halt of the idle rumors that are being spread concerning the war.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Prime Minister Churchill, after his opening remarks in the House of Commons today, spoke as follows :
A new spurt in Manhattan loft building activity was reported yesterday, when brokers and agents announced sales of a number of such properties along the lower West Side.

OTTAWA, Jan. 27 -- While asking the country to release him from past commitments with regard to conscription for overseas service, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King is making no new commitments, he stated yesterday and reiterated today.

The report of the President's commission to investigate the most disgraceful episode in the history of our country, the successful Japanese surprise attack upon our Hawaiian defenses on Dec. 7, in the thoroughness of its disclosure and the justice of its condemnation of the neglect and incompetence of the responsible naval and military commanders, is beyond criticism.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 -- Women members of America's great army of migratory farm workers, who came to public attention especially in California in the last few years, were credited today by the regional office of the Farm Security Administration with doing more "in the way of war production" than any other group of American women.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Competent authorities in Washington and representatives of the Free French National Committee in London recently reached an agreement about the use to be made for military purposes, of the French possessions all through the Pacific area.
DUBLIN Jan. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's statement:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, asked the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today to expand the borrowing power of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by $2,500,000,000 to care for many requests from industry for war plant expansions.

The general death rate in New York City, which had been slightly above the "expected" level the previous week, declined to normal again last week, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.
Tami Mauriello, Bronx heavyweight, stopped Gunnar Barlund, Finnish ring veteran, in the eighth round of a scheduled ten-round feature battle at the New York Coliseum last night.

Rallying executives and supporters of the Boys Club movement to "make boys fit for the tasks of the nation," former President Herbert Hoover asserted last night at a regional conference of Boys Club officials in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, that "America cannot be defeated in this war."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -Midway Island is "still holding -and that's that!"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -More than 1,000,000 women will be needed as skilled workers in America's arms and munitions plants this year, Sidney Hillman, labor director of the War Production Board, estimated today.

Combined net earnings of the Massachusetts Bonding and Insurance Company in 1941 amounted to $1,401,608 from underwriting, interest, dividends and rents. The amount is equal to $8.76 a share on 160,000 shares outstanding and compare with $9.45 a share on same basis the year before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Rogers bill, providing for a women's Army Auxiliary Corps, with the age limits 21 to 45 years, was unanimously approved today by the House Military Affairs Committee. The measure went to the committee with the full endorsement of the War Department and Army officials.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 27 -- The raging famine and plague and the freezing cold of deep Winter have produced a scourge of ghouls who prowl the graveyards of Greece at night, robbing the dead of their clothing and jewelry for warmth and food in Athens and the Piraeus, where the death toll is nearly 1,700 persons a day, according to shocking eyewitness reports smuggled from Greece to informants of this correspondent tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A move for "thorough study" of the situation at Pearl Harbor preceding the surprise Japanese attack, with a Congressional investigation as a possible development, was reported today as gaining support in the House Committee on Naval Affairs although Chairman Vinson opposes further investigation at this time.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 27 -- German cities have a great shortage of potatoes, reports the Berlin correspondent of Dagens Nyheter.

The second of a series of workroom demonstrations, given last night by the Museum of Costume Art at its headquarters, 630 Fifth Avenue, was devoted to coats and suits and was headed by two well-known American designers, Vera Maxwell and Vincent Coppola.

It was almost like a preview of the Easter parade at the luncheon hour at the Ritz-Carlton yesterday. Gunther showed luxurious furs for Spring and Summer. They were presented with custom-made suits from Knize and hats from John-Frederics.

When a merchant complains that business is too brisk the fact is news. Retail merchants, particularly those who operate department stores, are making that complaint now. They are anxious about "panic buying," which they think is chiefly responsible for a retail sales volume running close to 50 per cent above that of a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The right of the Federal Wage and Hour Administration to investigate the books and records of The Lowell Sun was challenged before the Supreme Court today in a brief by Elisha Hanson, counsel for The Sun and for the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Attacks by submarines upon two more American tankers off the East Coast were disclosed by the Navy yesterday. Whether the two ships had been sunk remained uncertain, however. If they went down, the German score in near-by Atlantic waters -- as tabulated from our Navy reports--would be nine vessels sunk and one damaged in the series of raids that began Jan. 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Authority to operate the priorities system and to administer regulations under requisitioning acts was officially vested in James S. Knowlson, Director of the Division of Industry Operations, by Regulations Nos. 1 and 2 of the War Production Board issued today by Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Major Gen. James E. Chaney assumed his new command only twenty-four hours after the announcement that United States troops had landed in Northern Ireland to man bases prepared for them there.

AUNT MARY DINES, born a slave in Prince George's County, Md., said that the first song sung for President Lincoln at the contraband camp was "My Country, 'Tis of Thee." She remembered that the President took off his hat and sang too, and that "he certainly had a sweet voice."

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 27 -- A formal charge of premeditated murder was made here tonight against Private Carl Strother, 20 years old, a Negro of Boston, in connection with the shooting of another Negro soldier, Private Fred Robinson, 28, of Washington, D.C., while on guard duty Saturday morning.

National advertisers are encountering many new headaches, as a result of the war, it was pointed out yesterday. Problems affecting media, public relations and packaging are developing every day and no sooner has one been solved than another crops up.

Earnings of the Shell Union Oil Corporation amounted to $21,300,000 in 1941, according to preliminary figures announced yesterday by R.G.A. van der Woude, president. From this it is proposed to deduct $4,000,000 for a special reserve, leaving net earnings at $17,300,000.

Friday night, Feb. 6, will usher in "The Flowers of Virtue" at the Royale. First slated to open here tonight, the Marc Connelly comedy was postponed to Feb. 5 and again to Feb. 6. Cheryl Crawford is sponsoring the production, which has a cast headed by Frank Craven, Isobel Elsom and Vladimir Sokoloff.

Expecting a public demand for equipment for women in defense services and for the incidental necessities of soldiers and sailors, the American Women's Voluntary Services will open a "war shop" this morning at 14 East Fifty-second Street.

Announcement was made yesterday by Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge, president of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club of Madison, N.J., that the annual all-breed outdoor dog show of that organization, scheduled next May, had been canceled.

Warning machine tool and machinery producers that they must establish new records in production in 1942 because this year we are to make nearly three times as many weapons as we have made in the last eighteen months, Sydney Hogerton, district manager of the Priorities Field Service of the War Production Board, promised them yesterday that the priorities division would help them in every way possible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The War Production Board stated categorically today that it "is not intended to maintain nonessential industries when no effort is being made to tie production into the war program." The statement was made in an announcement outlining a simplified production requirements plan for manufacturers whose annual volume of business is less than $100,000, issued by the Division of Industry Operations of the WPB.

The Maryland Casualty Company had an increase in 1941 of $4,099,547 in net premiums, the second largest annual gain in its forty-four-year history, Stewart McDonald, chairman of the board and president of the company, reported yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting.

The defeat of the defending champion by an unseeded player going through his first season of competition in the Class A ranks furnished the Metropolitan Class A singles squash racquets championship with a stunning upset at the University Club last night.

Joseph Dunwald, 17 years old, a messenger boy for the Mercury Messenger Corporation, dropped a typewriter he was carrying and leaped to the tracks of the IRT Lexington Avenue subway at Twenty-third Street yesterday morning when he saw a man fall into the path of an incoming downtown local train.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 27 -- Axis agents operating among the wild tribes between Afghanistan and the British Northwestern Indian frontier are inciting the lawless Pathan tribesmen to launch an invasion into the rich Indian Punjab, coincident with inflammatory radio broadcasts from Berlin and Tokyo calling for a revolt in Northwest India, according to reliable reports filtering into Turkey from Afghanistan, India and the Near East.

Equity Corporation at the last year-end had net assets equivalent to $42.59 for each share of its $3 convertible preferred stock, against $50.30 a year earlier. This stock has a preference in liquidation of $50 a share and accumulated dividends.

Ward A3 in Bellevue Hospital was the scene of a unique ceremony yesterday when Elizabeth Kenney, 17 years old, who has been a patient there for seven years, received a diploma certifying the completion of elementary school studies.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- Dr. Albert C. Barnes, owner of one of the world's finest collections of modern art, announced today the purchase for $175,000 of Renoir's "Mussel Fishers at Berneval." Dr. Barnes said the sale price was the second highest ever paid for a Renoir.
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- A feature on the Stock Exchange today was continued weakness in the chain store shares, a direct result of the decline shown in Woolworth's profit for 1941.

Claims aggregating $3,427,628 have been filed by 593 persons against the owners and charterers of the steamship Navemar, according to a report filed yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, by Louis W. Arnold, Special Commissioner in Admiralty, of 217 Broadway, Manhattan, who was appointed by Judge Robert A. Inch to receive such claims.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Private motor truck carriers were assured today by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, that he foresaw no present need to bring them within the confines of public regulation along with the for-hire carriers under the Motor Carrier Act.

TRENTON, Jan. 27 -- After a conference today with Lieut. Col. H.B. Vaughan Jr., United States Army district engineer, Governor Charles Edison expressed hope that work could be started soon on the proposed sea-level canal across the tip of Cape May peninsula from Cold Spring Inlet to New England Creek on Delaware Bay.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 27 -Princeton avenged an early season loss by triumphing over the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York, 5 -- 3, on Baker Rink tonight. Defenseman Bill MacCoy led the Tigers with two goals.

Having adopted a strategy of rapid advance, Japan must keep going despite mounting risks. Consequently, every setback now means a disruption of the Japanese time-table. Two setbacks have occurred thus far. The Philippines are still unconquered in the eighth week of attack.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- If courts-martial are ordered for the Navy and Army commanders at Pearl Harbor Dec. 7, or if these are granted at the officers' requests -- which is their right -- the growing disposition in Congress to go beyond the report of the Roberts Commission may be kept in check until the military courts have reported.
Formation and incorporation of a new company in the real estate management, leasing and brokerage field was announced yesterday by Melvin Brown, who will serve as president of the firm.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 27 -- General Arturo Espinoza took over this afternoon the army units that will control the Presidential elections next Sunday. He acted under a government measure adopted to assure order throughout the country in view of the rising pitch of excitement in both parties, the Leftists supporting Juan Antonio Rios and the Rightists supporting General Carlos Ibanez, retired.

Acceptance by Lewis W. Douglas of the post of assistant at London in administering the lease-lend program assures the country the services of a first-rate man. The task of that post is both delicate and important. Mr. Harriman must be more or less upon the road.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 27 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

Having adopted a strategy of rapid advance, Japan must keep going despite mounting risks. Consequently, every setback now means a disruption of the Japanese time-table. Two setbacks have occurred thus far. The Philippines are still unconquered in the eighth week of attack.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- If courts-martial are ordered for the Navy and Army commanders at Pearl Harbor Dec. 7, or if these are granted at the officers' requests -- which is their right -- the growing disposition in Congress to go beyond the report of the Roberts Commission may be kept in check until the military courts have reported.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 27 -Commenting on Premier Hideki Tojo's speech in the Japanese Diet on Wednesday, Dr. Wang Shih-chieh, Minister of Information, said his proposed post-war settlements were opposed to the concepts of the Atlantic Charter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, assumed full responsibility today for the success or failure of the arms production and procurement program, and won a pledge of full and wholehearted cooperation from a special Senate Committee which has been openly critical of defense progress.

MAHANOY CITY, Pa., Jan. 28 -- Scores of witnesses who said they represented "the forgotten people of America" appeared before the Federal Anthracite Economic Investigating Committee at two hearings today to warn that many towns and cities in this region were teetering on the verge of bankruptcy and that some faced actual obliteration unless prompt assistance were forthcoming from Washington in one of two forms.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- Equality of representation on the Westchester County Board of Supervisors should be attained by adjusting the voting power of each supervisor to correspond with the size of the population he represents, the executive committee of Westchester County's dominant Republican organization decided at a meeting here this evening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The blood of Negro and white donors alike will be accepted hereafter by the American Red Cross, but will be processed separately, "so that those receiving transfusions may be given plasma from blood of their own race."

The fuss about the filing of an unusual number of applications for retirement in the Police Department was in the nature of making a mountain of a molehill. That less than 1 per cent of the police force and about 3 per cent of the eligible men applied would indicate that the movement was not of the wholesale nature the Mayor would have the public believe.
523. A sailor's love that's all true blue goes with this Valentine, sweetheart, to you.

Defense construction this year will reach the record high total of about $11,000,000,000, but civilian building will be limited and the retail lumber and building material business should shape its plans accordingly, W.D. Connor Jr., chief of the lumber section of the War Production Board, told the annual convention yesterday of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 -- A woman's place, traditionally in the home, is now in the aircraft factory so far as this area is concerned -- and will be until peace is restored.

Secretary of Agriculture Wickard's pledge to hold agricultural prices to parity levels yesterday brought about the first sharp downward reaction in the cotton market in more than a month. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts dropped as much as 61 points, or $3.05 a bale, under Tuesday's close in one of the most active of recent sessions.

Cornelia Otis Skinner, actress and daughter of the late Otis Skinner, has signed a contract with Houghton Mifflin for a biography of the Skinner family. At the same time the firm makes known a contract with Angna Enters, the dancer, who also will do an autobiographical work.

I was very much interested to read Dr. Kempner's letter dealing with his suggestion for classifying the different alien groups. In his communication Dr. Kempner referred to the forthcoming identification program of aliens of enemy nationalities as a "reregistration," and attributed that phrase to Attorney General Biddle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Accusing James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, of maintaining "an active and ambitious Gestapo," Representative Cox of Georgia proposed on the House floor today that Congress investigate the FCC.

ADVANCED BRITISH HEADQUARTERS, On the Johore Front, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Australian field batteries and British anti-aircraft guns kept up an almost continuous cannonade today, holding the Japanese back along the central sectors of the Johore front as British and Indian battalions fought bitterly to stem the enemy push down the west coastal road at a point forty-five miles northwest of Singapore.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 28 -- The signing of an agreement between the United States and Bolivia for a $25,000,000 Bolivian development program was announced here today.

A story of international intrigue aimed at building up Germany's power and prestige -- as well as dollar credits -- in still neutral nations, but with a background of the military extortion of millions of dollars in diamonds from the invaded Netherlands and Belgium, was disclosed here yesterday by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Wartime extension of the maximum work week under the Wages-and-Hours Act from forty to forty-eight hours is proposed in a bill introduced in the Senate today by Senator Reed of Kansas.

The New York construction industry has offered its "wholehearted support" to the Federal war-building program and has pledged its aid to Secretary of the Navy Knox on the basis of his recent call for cooperation, William Joshua Barney, president of the Metropolitan Builders Association, announced at the seventh annual dinner of the organization last night in the Engineers Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- American smugness and sense of superiority were blamed for the losses at Pearl Harbor today by Associate Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts in his first public address since returning from Hawaii last week as head of the commission which investigated the Dec. 7 disaster.

" Son of Fury," the Twentieth Century-Fox screen version of the Edison Marshall novel, "Benjamin Blake," will be the new attraction today at the Roxy. Starring Tyrone Power, the adventure features Gene Tierney, Roddy McDowall, George Sanders, Frances Farmer, John Carradine and Elsa Lanchester.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 28 -- The entire reorganization of the defenses of the northern part of Mexico's Pacific Coast area in ever closer cooperation with the United States Army has been completed and soon will be extended to other vulnerable regions of this country, it was learned here today.

The mobilization of 60,000,000 of the nation's men and women for all-out war is the ultimate objective of the Selective Service System, Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, its national director, declared yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 28 -- As part of an intensified effort by the War Department to have "the soldiers on the firing line" meet "the soldiers on the production line," a group of Army officers and enlisted men visited two major ordnance plants in this bustling arms center today.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Debate on conduct of the war raged in Parliament today with a political fury quite equal to the fighting on the fronts. At the end of one of the longest single day's sittings that Parliament has had since the war began, there was little doubt that Prime Minister Winston Churchill would get a big majority in a vote of confidence that will close the three-day debate.

Directors of R.H. Macy Co. authorized yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share, payable on April 6 to holders of record of March 13. This dividend is in lieu of a similar disbursement made by the company for several years on March 1.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Firmer conditions ruled in most of the securities markets here today. All the oil shares went ahead and several of the kaffirs reflected buying from the Cape. Leading industrials generally were better.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 28 -- Major Vidkun Quisling is expected to become Regent of "the Kingdom of Norway" on Friday, or the Norwegian Horthy with this difference, that Admiral Nicholas Horthy was unanimously elected Regent in 1920 by the Hungarian National Assembly, while the Norwegian "Regent" will be installed by a foreign power.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., was the successful bidder yesterday for $5,150,000 of Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company one-to-ten year equipment trust certificates, naming an interest cost basis of 1.90 per cent. The winning bid was 99.222 for 1 3/4 s.

Distinguished veterans and comparative newcomers made significan contributions to the performance of "Walkuere" given yesterday as the second of the Wagner matinee cycle in the Metropolitan Opera House. Thus Mr. Schorr, the Wotan of the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered new hearings today in the reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad with a view to reporting promptly a new plan of reorganization for the company.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic Seaboard at the end of last week were 19,812,000 barrels, a decline of 549,000 from the 20,361,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks dropped 1,535,000 barrels to 14,207,000 and heavy fuel oil supplies were down 494,000 to 9,615,000.

F.S. Smithers Co. have been named by the International Business Machines Corporation for three months to handle fractional quantities of scrip which stockholders may wish to buy or sell. The scrip arises out of the 5 per cent stock dividend declared by the company.

The largest group of Axis nationals to be brought here since the United States entered the war arrived yesterday on an American liner from South America closely guarded and kept in seclusion by State Department agents, armed Coast Guardsmen and a detail of soldiers carrying riot guns.
SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The United States forces began to learn today about Nazi bombers and the high cost of whisky.

VICHY, France, Jan. 28 (AP) -- New demonstrations by housewives over the difficulties in food distribution in unoccupied France were reported tonight after the Ministry of Interior had rushed hundreds of tons of food to the Departments of Herault and Card following hunger disorders that lasted for days.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Formation of the Society of Independent Motion Picture Producers was announced today by Charles Chaplin, Walt Disney, Samuel Goldwyn, Alexander Korda, Mary Pickford, David O. Selznick, Walter Wanger and Orson Welles. Loyd Wright, Los Angeles attorney, was named president of the society, with James Allen as executive secretary.

Tonight the electric light bulbs on the marquee of the Longacre will spell out the name of a star new to Broadway when Katina Paxinou opens in Luther Greene's revival of "Hedda Gabler." Miss Paxinou is making her American debut in English with a new translation of the Ibsen drama furnished by Ethel Borden and Mary Cass Canfield.

The New York A.C. retained the championship of the Class A division of the Metropolitan League squash tennis tournament by beating the Bayside T.C., 4 to 1, as the race ended on the Winged Foot courts yesterday. This gave the winners a record of ten victories in as many starts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Roosevelt conferred today with the Combined Chiefs of Staffs Commission in Washington for nearly two hours. It was the first meeting of its kind announced publicly.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 28 -- The Inter-American Conference of Foreign Ministers adjourned after a plenary session tonight. Delegates of all twenty-one American republics signed the final act, embracing resolutions previously approved in committee for the severance of diplomatic, commercial and financial relations with the Axis powers and making the Western Hemisphere as watertight as possible for economic and military defense in the face of the Axis attack on the United States.

Further improvement in sentiment was evident yesterday in the market for tax-exempt State and municipal bonds. The market, as a whole, had pretty well shaken off the shock that paralyzed it on Monday following the Treasury Department's suggestion that outstanding issues should be made subject to Federal income taxes.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- A complete blackout of a 100-mile strip of the Texas coast was ordered for tonight following an announcement by Captain Alva D. Bernhard, commander of the naval air station here, that two Axis submarines were reported operating off the South Texas coast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill establishing the Office of Civilian Defense under a $100,000,000-expenditure limitation, the bill to permit Canadian ships to carry ore between United States Great Lakes ports; nominated Patrick J. Hurley to be the first Minister to New Zealand, and conferred with United States and British military leaders, with Breckenridge Long, assistant Secretary of State, and with Edward J. Flynn, the National Democratic chairman.

With a record entry of 120 taking part, the two-day Eastern States figure-skating championships will begin tomorrow morning at the Iceland rink atop Madison Square Garden. The first test on the program, men's novice school figures, will start at 8 A.M.

Inviting all corporations and all State, county and municipal fiscal officers in the Second Federal Reserve District, employing 1,000 or more persons, to become issuing agents for defense savings bonds, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as fiscal agent for the government, issued yesterday a formal announcement that an increase in the number of issuing agents would facilitate prompt deliveries of bonds to buyers.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 28 -- American Flying Fortresses, steadily sapping the strength of a Japanese invasion armada in the Strait of Macassar, off Netherland Borneo, sank another large transport yesterday, left a second in flames and straddled a Japanese cruiser with several sticks of bombs, the United Nations Command announced today.

The pinball machine business is a "racket dominated by interests heavily tainted with criminality" and has an annual "take" of more than $20,000,000 derived largely from the "pockets of school children in the form of nickels and dimes given them as lunch money," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in an affidavit submitted to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy.

Appointment of William B. Baer as dean of New York University's College of Arts and Pure Science, oldest of the university's fifteen schools, colleges and divisions, was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university.

The Nedick's chain of soft drink and luncheonette stands has leased the store, basement and mezzanine on the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and East Fifty-ninth Street for ten years at a reported aggregate minimum and percentage rental of about $200,000.
Frank (Pancho) Snyder, who served as Giant catcher under the late John J. McGraw, yesterday was named manager of the Jersey City Giants of the International League.

Orders to the Victory Book Campaign headquarters in New York from the Morale Division of the Army, many of them hurry-up calls giving only the number of books needed and code word destinations, have moved 100,000 books to the armed services and the merchant marine in the last ten days, it was learned yesterday.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $50,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

Holders of the Niagara Falls Power Company's first and refunding mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds of 1936 have been notified that $1,200,000 of these bonds has been drawn for redemption at 106 1/2 on March 1. The bonds will be redeemed at any time at the Marine Trust Company, Buffalo, or at J.P. Morgan Co. here.

By constructing "Clinton Hill" houses for 1,200 war workers and their families, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has at once protected the residential character of a famous old section of Brooklyn and found a means to advance a worth-while building construction project in time of war.

Heida Hermanns, pianist, gave her first Town Hall recital last night. While a student at the Academy of Music in Berlin, Miss Hermanns won the international competition at that school. Later she concertized widely in Europe before coming to America.

George F. Rand, president of the Marine Midland Corporation, in his annual report to stockholders yesterday said that the consolidated operating income of the corporation and its constituent banks, trust companies and affiliates for 1941 amounted to $3,857,443, equivalent to 68 cents a share on the stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The wool shortage threatened today to make skirts shorter.
BERLIN, Jan. 28 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
HAVANA, Jan. 28 -- A decree by President Fulgencio Batista authorizing the sale to the United States of almost all of Cuba's 1942 sugar crop was made public today.

War entered Wall Street by the back door yesterday, when the stock transfer department of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York received a request for re-issue of a stock certificate which had been ruined in the attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7.

Stocks were unable yesterday to generate any enthusiasm as investors became more perplexed by developments in Washington affecting the nation's economic system. The share list on the Stock Exchange drifted throughout the day and values closed moderately lower in the dullest and narrowest session since the start of the week.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- In both London and Belfast today the question of bases in Eire came to the forefront, while in Dublin the government of Premier Eamon de Valera defended its use of emergency powers as necessary for the maintenance of precarious neutrality.

The congregation of the Riverside Church accepted last night with expressions of regret the resignation from its staff of ministers of the Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Carder, who assumed his duties twenty-three years ago when the church was known as the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church.

Citing overpopulation in Japan and other Axis countries as an obstacle to permanent future peace, speakers at the annual meeting of the Birth Control Federation of America in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria agreed yesterday that planning of families was the solution for any pacific international adjustments in the post-war world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Lieut. Col. Lewis G. Merritt, Marine Corps pilot, on an observation mission in Africa, was shot down with a party in a British bomber on Jan. 7 but with his companions survived the crash, it became known here today.

THE arrival in this country of Guillermo Huidobro, middle distance runner from Chile who will compete in the current indoor campaign, brings to mind another problem dropped in the laps of the officials of amateur athletics on account of the war. What about the Pan-American Games that, as far as this observer knows, still are on the calendar for November, 1942, in Buenos Aires?

Miss Cornelia Wilmot Allen, chairman of the debutante committee for the pre-opening performance of "Hedda Gabler" at the Longacre Theatre in aid of the American Friends of Norway, entertained with a "curtain dinner" at the Sherry-Netherland last night in advance of the benefit.

Many British manufacturers made the mistake of stopping advertising at the outbreak of the war and not resuming it until their products were no longer available, according to a letter just received by Erwin, Wasey Co., Inc., from Robert Freeman, manager of the agency's London office.

A suite of nine rooms and four baths in the apartment house at 1148 Fifth Avenue has been leased by Malcolm E. Smith, president of the real estate firm bearing his name, in one of several rentals arranged by the Madison Realty Company.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The first Roosevelt-Churchill meeting in Washington, at which President Roosevelt consented to send troops to Northern Ireland, was "worth while," but there was "much to follow," Lord Beaverbrook said tonight in describing the series of conferences at the White House.

TRENTON, Jan. 28 -- Louis A. Reilly, chairman of the State Racing Commission, renewed today an estimate that horse racing tax revenue for the 1942-43 fiscal year would be $1,000,000 as he urged the joint legislative Appropriations Committee to approve a $44,846 budget for his board.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN NORTHERN IRELAND, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Major General Russell Hartle, commanding American troops in Northern Ireland, said today that his forces would "carry the fight to the challenger." General Hartle expressed supreme confidence in his troops, who came here from the Middle West, many of whom joined the Army as selectees.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Describing the Axis Powers as "one indivisible, total enemy," Secretary Knox declared here today that the task of the American Navy in the present war means "protection everywhere and effective fighting in all of the seas and all the oceans," and added that this country would not fall into Hitler's trap and "throw all our growing strength into the Pacific."

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Announcement of the order restricting the use of cans for certain food products, which has been keenly awaited by the food industry, was greeted today by the various trade conventions in session here as being less drastic than might have been expected under the war-time conditions.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Speedy Russian shock forces, carrying guns on sleighs, were reported driving straight south tonight from the Valdai salient northwest of Moscow and directly threatening the German positions at Smolensk and Vyazma.
SEATTLE, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Dec. 13, 1941 -- Fired.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Corn and rye prices broke the permissible limit of 5 cents a bushel at one time today on the statement by Secretary of Agriculture Wickard that the recent upturn in corn was not justified and that his department would use every means at its disposal to maintain reasonable feed prices.

Net income of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company increased 22 per cent in 1941 to $23,117,510 from $18,985,428 the year before, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday by A.W. Robertson, chairman.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Rochester Ordnance District, reporting today the award of more than $540,000,000 in contracts for military supplies, gave these illustrations of conversion:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Mrs. Margaret Emerson entertained tonight with a dinner at her home. Mrs. Harold FitzGerald also had guests at her residence, and Mrs. James H. Kennedy was a dinner hostess at Kenlewinai.

A five-year extension of the first mortgage of $450,000 on the fifteen-story apartment on the northwest corner of Broadway and Eighty-eighth Street has been arranged for the Bernheimer estate, represented by Meyer Steffens, Inc., with the Mutual Life Insurance Company, by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Uncle Sam's baseball teams will get a chance to play the St. Louis Cardinals in the coming Summer.

ACCRA, African Gold Coast, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The Vichy government has been snubbed by Africa's Brong chieftains and hundreds of their tribesmen, who have abandoned their homes on the French Ivory Coast to cross into British Ashanti, it was learned today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -- Arnold Pressburger, United Artists producer, has bought an option on "Tomorrow Never Comes," the comedy by Hugh Wedlock and Howard Snyder which Frank Capra has owned since last May. Capra will be inactive as a producer because of his service with the Army Signal Corps, and Pressburger will buy the property from him if a suitable cast can be obtained for the film.

Dr. Ruth Andrus, chairman of the committee established by various departments of the State to provide daytime care for the children of mothers employed in defense industries, yesterday requested THE NEW YORK TIMES to emphasize the scope of the projected program, which she felt had been misunderstood as described in a news story of Tuesday morning.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Measures to prepare the way for a Netherlands imperial conference after the war to carry out certain reforms to foster political emancipation of the overseas territories within the existing framework of the empire were announced yesterday by the Netherlands Government in London.

A prediction that Hitler would give this city at least a token bombing was made yesterday by William L. Shirer, radio news commentator and author of "Berlin Diary," at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Biltmore, where the commerce and industry division of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York learned that $5,045,000 already had been raised in the drive here for $7,330,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said tonight that the Vinson Committee's conclusion that "American trade unions have sought to benefit from the defense program to the detriment of the public interest" is "utterly without foundation or substantiation" and constitutes "a slur on the record of the American trade union movement."

Stan Waxman wriggled clear underneath and hooked in a basket eight seconds from the end of an overtime period to give Long Island University a spectacular 58-56 victory over West Texas State at Madison Square Garden last night before a frenzied crowd of 18,117, the largest of the basketball season.

You hear many sportsmen speak of the "good old days," and the freedom they enjoyed from manifold regulations, but Ducks Unlimited has dug up a law enacted in Massachusetts in 1727 which proves that even the Colonial duck hunters were bound by certain regulations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Plans for government aid in insuring property against war-caused damage began to take form today at a hearing of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee and may be completed at an executive session called for tomorrow.
OTTAWA, Jan. 28 -- In the ten years since 1931 the population of Canada has increased by 1,043,110 to 11, 419,896, according to the census figures for 1941 made public today.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he resented criticism aimed at him by Westchester officials as a result of the failure of the Federal Government to begin work on the Westchester County Airport at Rye Lake in Purchase, N.Y.

Production of finished steel products in 1941 amounted to 65,361,688 net tons, a new high record, and 34.5 per cent above an output of 48,584,860 net tons in 1940, the previous high mark, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The average woman is dumpy. If that's a seditious statement take it up with the Agriculture Department.

VICHY, France, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- German authorities have eased restrictions on 340 American hostages held at Compiegne and indicated some physicians needed in American hospitals in Paris may be released if the hostage quota is maintained by internment of other Americans in their places, it was learned today.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- George W. Welsh Jr., 27, was indicted today for the slaying of his 24-year-old sister, Leila Adele Welsh, who was beaten with a bricklayer's hammer-chisel and slashed with a 20-cent knife as she slept in their Kansas City home last March 9.

The public and Congressional reaction to the shocking facts revealed by the Roberts report on the Pearl Harbor tragedy ranged yesterday from demands for courts-martial for Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Major Gen. Walter C. Short to suggestions for a further allocation of blame.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate voted today to permit American soldiers, sailors and marines to mail their letters home and elsewhere, wherever they may be serving, postage free, but it had great difficultly in establishing which Senator's measure was to receive full credit for the plan.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 28 -- American volunteer fliers, outnumbered by at least three to one, put to rout a force of thirty-seven enemy planes today, shooting down at least seven of them in a new encounter four miles above the green Burma jungle east of Rangoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Plans for immediate government purchase of 200,000,000 yards of osnaburgs to form a stockpile for manufacture of sandbags, food bags, packaging and camouflaging were announced today by the War Production Board.
The best place to make an appointment with Mayor La Guardia is the Metropolitan Opera House.

Joseph Alvin Kugelmass, who was said to have used the name Joe Lesly in the brief time last December that he was editor of Stag, a magazine recently enjoined by the Federal court, was indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury in alleged misappropriations of checks that should have been sent to writers or their literary agents whose articles he had published in the magazine.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 28 -- The Berlin correspondent of the Social Demokraten reports tonight that "responsible authorities in Germany let it be understood" that despite reduction in production, the shortage of man power is now extremely acute.

Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president of the Freeport Sulphur Company, reported yesterday in a preliminary statement for the year 1941, net income of $3,149,030 after depreciation, depletion, reserve for taxes and all charges. The net is equal to $3.95 each on 796,380 common shares and compares with $3,033,472, or $3.81 a share earned in 1940.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Another Spanish ship, the Navemar, has fallen victim to Axis U-boats, the Admiralty announced today. The Admiralty said it was necessary to issue a denial that any British or Allied submarine was at the time anywhere near the scene of the incident because the Axis had broadcast charges that the Navemar was torpedoed by a British submarine.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The British Headquarters communique said today:

In an age of ersatz we can accept unblinkingly the lovely new substance of buttercup yellow that smells like good, rich chicken fat, looks like chicken fat, tastes like chicken fat, but actually is a combination of peanuts and coconuts and soy bean oil! Considering that the tariff on bona fide chicken fat has reached a staggering figure in recent weeks, this novel shortening is as welcome as it is good.

A fine of $15,800 was imposed yesterday on the Winthrop Chemical Company by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind on the company's admission that it had shipped in interstate commerce an adulterated product improperly labeled as sulfathiazole tablets.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Yale may get a new football coach for a valentine. The next meeting of the Yale corporation, which has the final say on the coaching matter, is scheduled for Feb. 14.

Assets of the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America rose $8,128,934 in 1941 to a new high mark of $156,716,585, James A. McLain, president, revealed to stockholders yesterday in the company's eighty-second annual statement.

The Chemist Advisory Council, Inc., which for four years has been carrying on the work begun by the Chemists Unemployment Committee in 1931, will decide soon whether to disband and spread its responsibilities among other groups in the chemical industry, M.R. Bhagwat, secretary, said yesterday at the council's office, 60 East Forty-second Street.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, Jan. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Thirty-three tough British seamen rescued from their torpedoed freighter rested in a navy league hostel here today and cursed the German U-boat commander who wished them a sarcastic "good night" before he disappeared in the Winter night, leaving them tossing about on the chill Atlantic for thirty-three hours.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, Secretary of War in the Hoover Cabinet, was nominated today by President Roosevelt for the post of first United States Minister to New Zealand.

Music in America is still spreading and growing in quantity and quality, Walter Damrosch declared yesterday in expressing his conviction that our future in art is a thing in which we can have absolute confidence.

SEATTLE, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The three-masted auxiliary schooner Black Douglas, formerly of Savannah, Ga., was attacked twice by Japanese submarines off the Pacific Coast while en route to Seattle from Savannah last month, the Thirteenth Naval District headquarters disclosed today.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The British communique said tonight:

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 -- An anti-fifth column campaign aimed at ridding State and city payrolls of all persons of Japanese ancestry, even though they themselves are American citizens, and moving all Japanese nationals to internment camps or at least out of the coastal war zone, made progress today on several fronts.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 28 -- The war has taken another turn, in the opinion of foreign observers here. Now it has become a war of diversion following lightning war, war of position and war of attrition. And attrition and diversion can scarcely be separated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The alleged laxity of the New York Curb Exchange in disciplining J. Chester Cuppia and other members accused of splitting commissions in violation of its rules, taken in conjunction with the case of Richard Whitney, once president of the New York Stock Exchange, has convinced the Securities and Exchange Commission that it should have power to take direct action to compel exchanges to live up to their own rules.

Guillermo Huidobro of Chile, the 800 and 1,500 meter champion of South America, arrived yesterday in New York and will start training today for his initial start in the United States, the famed Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose A.A. games at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday.

A 65-year-old sandwich-board man was burned to death and the owner of a key-making shop was burned badly at noon yesterday in a fire in Fulton Street, near Broadway. The blaze attracted thousands of lunch-hour strollers and necessitated two alarms before it was controlled.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. A.B. Letellier's Jack Twink withstood a furious rush by Alfred Parker's Kentown to win the John McDonogh purse at the Fair Grounds today.

HONOLULU, Jan. 28 -- The dugout cut into a creek bank was not much, judged by normal living standards, but to the graying top sergeant who had spent nine months in the trenches in France during 1917 and 1918, it was a comparatively comfortable habitat.

Two new high schools and additions to three other schools, providing seating accommodations for 8,686 students at a total cost of $5,660,000, are scheduled to open at the start of the Spring term on Monday, the Board of Education announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A statement that a military victory for the democracies is not enough because social disintegration and eventually another international conflagration may be expected unless post-war economic frustration and mass unemployment are avoided was made in a pamphlet issued today by the National Resources Planning Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- After two days of debate and voting showdowns, but with few changes made in the Administration draft, the Senate passed the Second War Powers Bill unanimously today. The measure expands further the government's authority along many fronts to expedite production and movement of supplies, to watch profits, ward off money market disturbances and conserve needed metals. It now goes to the House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The NRA National Labor Board, predecessor of the present Labor Relations Board, ordered reinstatement of Pilot Wayne Williams after ruling that the reasons advanced by T.W.A. were not justified.

Disapproving Mr. Lewis's proposal for negotiations looking to a present merger of the C.I.O. and the A.F. of L., President Roosevelt suggested instead the formation of a committee consisting of three members from each organization to settle jurisdictional disputes and to consult with him frequently.

NORMAN CORWIN has the touch. There's no question about it. Several million people realize it already, and even members of a certain Benevolent and Protective Order, who are sworn to throttle radio authors and lynch radio announcers on sight, should relent somewhat upon reading "Thirteen by Corwin."*
A West Side warehouse, downtown lofts and tenement houses were sold in realty deals reported yesterday in Manhattan. Repossessed properties of banks were among the parcels traded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Six men -- three American citizens and three Japanese nationals -- were indicted by a Federal Grand Jury today on charges of distributing pro-Japanese propaganda in violation of the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- After paying tribute to British youth for its part in the defense of Britain, United States Ambassador John G. Winant, speaking at a luncheon of the National Defense Public Interest Committee in London today, went on to speak of the part that the youth of the United States would play in the war and of American preparedness.

HONOLULU, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Depth charges were heard exploding offshore today, and although Navy officers refused to say whether enemy submarines had been detected they admitted that there had been an alert signal, summoning all personnel on shore leave to their stations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Four temporary major generals and in twenty temporary brigadier generals were named today by President Roosevelt in a list of nominations sent to the Senate for confirmation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 28 -- Although fighting in Libya continued in the area of Msus yesterday, it appeared that the German advance had been slowed considerably. The rudiments of a line were being formed between Soluch and positions near Msus, giving some hope that the drive undertaken by General Erwin Rommel, the German commander, would be stopped soon.

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- The 1,500 American citizens who were in Hong Kong when it fell to the Japanese on Christmas Day were all safe when the latest information leaked out of the Crown Colony Jan. 6, it was learned today.

With a squad that approaches maximum strength and is driven by the desperate necessity for victory, the Americans will take to the ice tonight at Madison Square Garden for their third contest of the National Hockey League campaign with the Bruins.
Cass Canfield's very just criticism of A.R.P. shortcomings, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 22, should have the immediate attention of every New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- An extraordinary story of thirteen men battling the open sea for an entire month, which may become one of the great small-boat sagas of maritime history, was reported by the Navy Department tonight on the basis of fragmentary information received from Wellington, N.Z.

A lot of pet theories about the cultivation of vegetable gardens were replaced by good, practical advice yesterday at the opening of a six-week lecture course on "Vegetable Growing for Victory" in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- A bill providing a mandatory six-month jail sentence for any one convicted of stealing an automobile tire or tube during the war was introduced today under the sponsorship of the legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Liberty Aircraft Product Corporation of Farmingdale, N.Y., has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 60,000 shares of cumulative convertible preferred stock without par value and 120,000 shares of common stock, $1 par value, the latter to be reserved for issuance upon the exercise of conversion rights of the preferred stock.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 28 -- A decision that the Mexican Supreme Court has just handed down is interpreted here as reversing decisions of that court in 1938, upon which the Mexican Government ever since has based its refusal to compensate expropriated American oil companies for subsoil rights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The United States-Filipino forces still holding the fortified hills of Bataan peninsula in the Philippines enjoyed a third consecutive day of rest following their last hard engagement with the Japanese invaders, it was indicated today in a brief communique based on advices from General Douglas MacArthur, Commander in Chief of the United States Armed Forces.

The preliminary report for 1941, announced yesterday by the Wheeling Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries, disclosed a net profit of $8,506,304 after all charges including Federal taxes. The profit is equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $11.71 a share on 569,441 shares of common stock outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The views of the "average" man and woman on the nation's war effort have been collected and recorded for presentation to President Roosevelt and by radio to the American people.

Joan Crawford's full salary of $112,500 for playing the role originally intended for the late Carole Lombard in Columbia's forthcoming production of "He Kissed the Bride" will be allocated to several outstanding charities, it was announced by that studio yesterday, coincident with Miss Crawford's assignment to the film.

Leon Henderson has a standing offer to eat on the steps of the Capitol any genuine evidence of a subversive past. Unfortunately, as the closing debate on the price bill in Congress showed, there are still those who view this sporting offer with doubt, whether it springs from a clear conscience or a powerful digestive system.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 28 -- The story of the sinking of the Lady Hawkins, as I look back on it, is one of bravery and discipline, tears and laughter, alternate hope and despair and, above all, a tale of real human courage.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The decision to send American troops to Northern Ireland was made in Washington when Prime Minister Churchill urged President Roosevelt to do so, Lord Beaverbrook, Minister of Supply, said in a broadcast tonight.

In spite of the reluctance of Argentina and Chile to break with the Axis Powers, the Conference of Foreign Ministers at Rio de Janeiro has adjourned in an atmosphere of success. When the conference opened on Jan. 15 ten American republics, including the United States, were at war with the Axis.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 28 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Finnish war communique today said:
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 28 -- The German press today touches on the arrival of American troops in Northern Ireland and asserts that it will "bring no change in the general situation."

One of the most complete blackouts thus far attempted in New York was staged last night in what is known to civilian defense authorities as Section D, Zone 3 -- the south side of Eighty-sixth Street, from Central Park West to Riverside Drive.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 28 -- A pinball machine player, who had boasted that he had become an expert in the manipulation of one machine, not only was fined $25 today for indulging in the plunger-pulling pastime, but was reprimanded by the judge for wasting his money instead of buying defense bonds.

Assailing the "superstition" that America is traditionally isolationist and asserting that virtually from their beginning the English-speaking people have had world-wide interests and influence, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared yesterday that when the war was won they would be called upon to go forward as leaders in the policies on which alone world peace and morality can rest.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 -- Neither sabotage nor mechanical difficulty caused the Transcontinental and Western Air transport crash which killed Carole Lombard, actress, fifteen ferry pilots and six other persons, reports Representative Jack Nichols of Oklahoma, chairman of a House committee investigating air accidents.
MOUNT HARRIS, Colo., Jan. 28 (AP) -- Colorado's worst coal mine disaster in twenty-five years, an explosion 5,500 feet down in the Wadge Mine, killed thirty-four miners and imperiled four others.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association, said today that now, if ever, was the time for leaders in scientific nutrition to establish for the American public eating habits "which may be of immense benefit to the nation's health."

Shareholders of the National Power and Light Company, at a special meeting yesterday in Jersey City, approved a plan for the exchange of the company's $6 preferred stock for the outstanding common stock of the Houston Lighting and Power Company, one of its largest subsidiaries.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A Chungking radio report of a severe battle developing over a wide area in South China was recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave listening station here.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies armed services issued this communique today:

An investing client of Sidney Levine, broker, bought from Linda Properties, Inc., subject to a first mortgage of $21,810, the three-story apartment house at 2070 Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, on a plot 40 by 100 feet. There are twelve suites in the house, which is valued for taxation at $30,000.

The United States "will have to underwrite the rehabilitation of the post-war world if civilization is not to pass into a lasting decline," William E. Wickenden, president of the Case School of Applied Science, Cleveland, told the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers last night in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 (From broadcasts recorded in New York) -- Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, who was relieved of command of the United States Fleet after the attack on Pearl Harbor, has been sentenced to death, the Japan Times Advertiser was quoted as asserting today in a dispatch by D.N.B., German news agency, from Tokyo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The House, by a voice vote, approved today the Senate version of amendments to the Foreign Agents' Registration Act. It rejected by a standing vote of 228 to 40 a motion of Representative Dies requiring that the House conferees insist on inclusion of his floor amendments listing the Communist party, the German-American Bund and the Kyffhauser Bund as foreign agents.

Deductions for business expenses, in order to be allowed in Federal income tax returns, the Bureau of Internal Revenue explained yesterday, must be for expenditures in connection with the maintenance and operation of the taxpayer's business or business properties.

BERLIN, Jan. 28 (From broadcasts recorded in New York) -- Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, who was relieved of command of the United States Fleet after the attack on Pearl Harbor, has been sentenced to death, the Japan Times Advertiser was quoted as asserting today in a dispatch by D.N.B., German news agency, from Tokyo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The House, by a voice vote, approved today the Senate version of amendments to the Foreign Agents' Registration Act. It rejected by a standing vote of 228 to 40 a motion of Representative Dies requiring that the House conferees insist on inclusion of his floor amendments listing the Communist party, the German-American Bund and the Kyffhauser Bund as foreign agents.

Deductions for business expenses, in order to be allowed in Federal income tax returns, the Bureau of Internal Revenue explained yesterday, must be for expenditures in connection with the maintenance and operation of the taxpayer's business or business properties.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The giving of "supreme command" to local Directors of Civilian Protection, during blackouts and actual air raids, plus the creation of a new, relatively mild penalty for civilian infraction of blackout and air raid orders, featured defense legislation which Governor Lehman submitted today to the Republican leaders of the Legislature.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 28 -- Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia is already considering appointments to the war councils agreed upon by Prime Minister Winston Churchill, it was revealed here today. Mr. Curtin said that Mr. Churchill's speech was in accord with the general purpose for which the whole British Commonwealth of Nations stood and that the mechanics it indicated were in line with the unified pursuit of one goal.

The sinking of the Canadian passenger liner Lady Hawkins, with the probable loss of 250 lives, became known yesterday after the arrival of seventy-one survivors in San Juan, P.R. They reported that the vessel had been torpedoed without warning on Jan. 19 and that they had passed five days at sea in an overcrowded lifeboat before they were picked up by a rescue ship.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Coming on in the stretch with power that was a shock to backers of Market Wise and Dispose, F.J. Buchanan's Zacatine won the Grade B Handicap at Hialeah Park today as 10,192 persons looked on. Some marked the slow time of 1:19 2-5 for six and a half furlongs over a fast track where the record is 1:15 4-5.

For the second time in as many days a seeded player was upset in the Metropolitan Class A squash racquets singles championship at the University Club last night when A.H. Barker of the Yale Club, seeded third, was eliminated. Richard S. Rothschild, who beat Barker for the title last year, and who was the No. 1 favorite, was defeated on Tuesday night.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Those American League baseball clubs campaigning for a big wartime schedule of night games should give a thought to some twilight contests and other starting time changes, the Cleveland Indians suggested today.

A newly formed group of Americans of German descent and friendly enemy aliens enlisted the support of Wendell L. Willkie at a meeting last night at the RKO Building, 1270 Sixth Avenue, and displayed their loyalty to the United States by buying defense bonds.

The Boston Safe and Deposit and Trust Company and the Second National Bank of Boston purchased yesterday $200,000 of tax-anticipation notes of Dedham, Mass., at 0.24 per cent. The obligations will become payable in installments on Nov. 13 and 27, 1942. and 27, 1942.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- The Jones family, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Jones and their four children from a farm near Shelton, Conn., received tonight the Gimbel National award as typifying the thousands of American families who are doing their best "in daily living and in their communities for freedom and defense."

A procedure by which importers of United States merchandise in Brazil must obtain import licenses at Rio de Janeiro, after which the Brazilian Consulate here will apply for export licenses at Washington will go into effect within the next few weeks, it was reported in foreign trade circles yesterday.

Choice lots of skunk brought keen price competition at the sale conducted yesterday by the New York Auction Company. Northwestern long and broads were in active request, while Eastern blacks and Shorts sold freely. The top was $3.95, about last year's level.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate passed unanimously the $12,556,672,474 Supplemental War Department Supply Bill for the procurement of 33,000 war planes in a half hour today and sent it to the White House.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- Fifty-three divisions, including thirteen tank divisions totaling 3,000 machines, were hurled around and against Moscow during the mid-November attack, according to high military circles here. Of the thirteen armored divisions, seven were on the northern salient, three on the central and three on the southern or Moscow front.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- President Roosevelt tonight heartily praised the accomplishments of the American nations at the Rio de Janeiro conference, which recommended severance of relations with the Axis powers, in a message to President Getulio D. Vargas of Brazil.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Europe is beginning to show signs of strain in places and ways that have come as something of a surprise even to the Ministry of Economic Warfare. It was disclosed today that in addition to shortages many countries on the Continent are now hard pressed to produce things they had in plenty before the war.

Cotton cloth converters expressed doubt yesterday whether their voluntary observance of the request of Dec. 17 by the OPA that they hold their prices down to their October basis would continue in the face of sharply rising raw cotton, which in turn is lifting gray-goods ceilings and eating sharply into their margins.

Recently newspapers carried the news that President Roosevelt favored "baseball as usual," and that he laid special emphasis on more night baseball so that defense workers could in their off hours relax and enjoy the national pastime.

Two of five men charged with conspiracy to ship platinum out of this country in violation of a Presidential proclamation putting the metal on a list of essential defense supplies pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn. They are Arnold Weisz of 628 Blake Avenue, Brooklyn, and Hirsch Neumann of 2 Elwood Street, Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- On The United Press news ticker today this item appeared:

Both retail and manufacturing quarters here took in their stride yesterday the authority given to the Office of Price Administration to ration consumer goods. Actions of this kind had been regarded as a possibility for some time. Two questions, however, were uppermost in the minds of business executives -- how extensive the rationing would be, and when it was likely to be put into effect.

A gathering of 10,000 attended the matinee performance which Miss Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue cast gave at Madison Square Garden yesterday for the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund. Although the bad weather limited the crowd, the receipts amounted to $17,740, all of which went to the fund.

Defense expenditure will bring down the living standard of the American people to the level of 1933, at the depth of the depression. This is the forecast of the National Industrial Conference Board. One question immediately comes to the mind.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 -- Thousands of housewives on the Pacific Coast, judging from reports, are aroused over the status of the "salvage-for-victory" campaign begun by the Industrial Conservation Bureau of the former Office of Production Management.

An enthusiastic group of South American skiers arrived yesterday for an eight-week tour of United States ski centers. Four Chileans and two Bolivians made up the contingent, whose trip is being sponsored as a good-will measure by the National Ski Association of America and the coordinator of inter-American affairs.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The seriousness of Singapore's position became more apparent by the hour today, although there was virtually no official news from the fighting fronts.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J, Jan. 28 -- A goal in the last thirty seconds of the fourth and final period by Al Parsells broke a 12-all tie and gave the Closter Polo Club a 13-to-12 victory over Pegasus in the final-round of the annual New York A.C. invitation seven-goal tournament at the Pegasus Club tonight.

Sitting as judges and jury in a "court martial" proceeding, ee air raid zone wardens have cleared Major Frank Knowles of 2120 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, zone warden of Zone 3, of charges by a subordinate that the Major's conduct had been "unbecoming an officer of the civilian defense."

SINGAPORE, Jan. 28 -- The British Command cleared the terrain tonight for the Battle of Singapore by ordering complete evacuation of civilians and livestock from a mile-wide strip along the northern shore of Singapore Island.

On the theory that clothing and other vital commodities, in addition to sugar, automobiles and tires, may be rationed, Mayor La Guardia said last night that he wanted consumer and labor representation on local rationing boards. At present they are composed principally of businessmen.
Several prominent psychiatrists here have formed a committee to prevent and treat mental disorders among children affected by air raids or other war upsets, it was disclosed yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Massachusetts Republican, expressed the hope tonight that the nation's sporting program would not be upset unnecessarily by the war emergency.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 28 -- New York City is emptying sewage effluent into its Kensico and Croton watersheds and recently began dumping sewage sludge into Long Island Sound near Westchester and Bronx bathing beaches, Westchester County officials charged today in questioning the sincerity of objections to a proposed Westchester airport adjacent to the City's Rye Lake reservoir in purchase.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- A Japanese armada, bent on a full-scale invasion of Java, has been battling its way southward through the Strait of Macassar for six days and although it has lost many ships, there are at least sixty-five still afloat with 150,000 troops aboard, The Daily Mail reported today in a Batavia dispatch.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 29 -- The Royal Australian Air Force reported today that its planes made a third raid on Japanese ships in the harbor of Rabaul, New Britain Island, last night, hitting one and possibly another. Visibility was bad, and the planes had to fly high. All the aircraft returned to their base.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Secretary Ickes said today that the oil supply situation in the East Coast area was getting tighter but that coal deliveries, especially in New England, which had dropped below normal in recent weeks, were proceeding more satisfactorily.

Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions sentenced yesterday Hans Stephen Muesch, 46 years old, a German alien butler of 76 East Eighty-sixth Street, who has been in this country eleven years, to serve eighteen months to three years in Sing Sing for a $700 forgery.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Prices of hogs rose 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight today, with further evidences of strength in dressed pork. Light pork loins rose 1/2 to 1 cent a pound in the wholesale trade, the second advance in two days for these cuts, which sold as low as 18 to 19 cents late last week.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies Armed Forces issued this communique today:

OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press ) -- Automobile drivers in Canada will be allowed to use between 300 and 380 gallons of gasoline a year for non-essential driving when gasoline rationing becomes effective April 1, Munitions Minister C.D. Howe announced today.
