The desire of the government to maintain in operation every plant, no matter how small, which may eventually be used for war production lies behind the modified production requirements plan which was ordered by the WPB a few days ago, according to Sydney Hogerton, district manager of the WPB Priorities Field Service.

Fritz Busch conducted the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, and Adolph Busch was the soloist of the evening, playing the intermmable Reger violin concerto, opus 101, for the first time in this city. The concerto originally lasted 65 minutes.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops battered today at Japanese railway and highway communications near Canton, Shanghai and Hankow as the Chinese Army, through its newspaper, Sao Tang Pao, called on the United States to fill the East Asia skies with planes.
BERLIN, Jan. 29 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Congressional Medal of Honor, the highest decoration which can be awarded to a member of the nation's armed forces for bravery in action was conferred posthumously by President Roosevelt today on Second Lieutenant Alexander Ramsey Nininger Jr. of the Fifty-seventh Infantry (Philippine Scouts).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt has telegraphed to President Manuel Prado y Ugarteche of Peru congratulations for the government and people of Peru on breaking diplomatic relations with Germany, Japan and Italy.

As an Irishman, resident hero and who personally knows Mr. de Valera and understands his policy, I should like to say something about his announcement as it appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES. The Prime Minister has put what he calls "partition" again in the news; and it is an issue which will not die from Anglo-Irish relationships until settled, as the final friction between the two countries.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Mrs. Amelia M. Carr, 66-year-old ex-convict and confidence woman, pleaded no defense today before Judge Daniel J. Brennan in Special Sessions Court here to seven additional complaints of obtaining money under false pretenses.

Plans for remodeling a building just east of Times Square to house! the executive offices of a large in-i dependent chain with motion-pie-I ture theatres in Brooklyn and Long! Island were announced yesterday in connection with the sale by the Bank for Savings of the eight-story structure at 132 to 136 West Fortythird Street.

Reclining in hospital chairs, Fanny Amato, 17 years old, for ten years a patient in Bellevue Hospital, and Thelma Reid, 13, were graduated yesterday morning from P.S. 401, otherwise known as the "School Without a Schoolhouse," on the fourth floor of the hospital.

A limited menu will be provided by the fickle weather man for Eastern ski enthusiasts the next few days unless more snow visits the area extending from the Poconos to the rugged heights of Mount Washington. The recent storm brought delight mostly to metropolitan enthusiasts, who found public park and golf course skiing really good, a condition that most points in the North country also would like to report.
The belated British admission of the loss of the battleship Barham in the Mediterranean last Nov. 25 adds another mighty leviathan to the large toll taken of capital ships in this war.
Gavels substituted for a bell-alarm system -- which as yet is lacking -- when a five-minute practice air-raid drill was staged yesterday in the seventy-year-old Jefferson Market Court building.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 -- Labor continues to be a major problem for Germany, according to all accounts reaching here, and they are confirmed by Italian sources. Latest reports indicate that Dr. Heinrich Mansfeld of the Labor Ministry, acting for Secretary Friedrich Syrup, variously described as either sick or definitely removed from his post, has received full powers for the mobilization of all available labor in the Reich.
More than 3,000 women are expected to serve as messengers for telegraph companies this year, officials declared yesterday. All must be more than 21 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The $19,977,965,474 supplemental naval appropriation which the House of Representatives passed Tuesday as the largest money grant of its kind ever made by a legislative body, will undergo enlargement by $4,000,000,000 -- all for extra airplanes -- it was indicated strongly tonight.

Clear, shining eyes of the current generation are no accident. Girls now take sounder care of their eyes than their mothers did. They demand efficiency, not flattery, from their reading and working lights, and, instead of fighting shy of glasses, clap them on when necessary, grateful to manufacturers that spectacles are no longer the disfiguration they used to be.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- A comprehensive scrap rubber campaign to keep America's cars in operation was urged here today by J.J. Newman, vice president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, in an address at a luncheon sponsored by his company at the Hotel Statler.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Prices of several farm products -- principally livestock and livestock products and vegetable oil crops -- have apparently reached the level of minimum price ceilings authorized in the Price Control Bill now awaiting President Roosevelt's approval.

BELTSVILLE, Md., Jan. 29 -- Jars of honey, molasses and various syrups line the tables in the experimental kitchens of the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Home Economics here as technicians, working with renewed effort, seek data on cooking with sugar substitutes.

TRENTON, Jan. 29 -- The New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals sustained today the Essex County Circuit Court in awarding $7,200 to Frank F. Nelson of Jackson Heights, Queens, as damages in a suit for false arrest and assault and battery against three Newark detectives who seized him on Oct. 6, 1938, in an investigation of petty thefts from the Eastern Air Lines and a forged endorsement of a company check.

Gus Lesnevich, ruler of the light-heavyweight division, will make a bid for recognition as a heavyweight tonight when he opposes the veteran Bob Pastor in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden. Lesnevich won the 175-pound title last August, and since that time has engaged in one championship defense, a successful venture against Tami Mauriello.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- British bombers raided Muenster, industrial and railway city in Central Germany, and docks at the German-occupied cities of Boulogne, France, and Rotterdam, the Netherlands, last night, the Air Ministry announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- Captain Colin P. Kelly Jr., first hero of World War II, was honored posthumously by the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association tonight as "the most valorous athlete of the year."

People engaged in the milk industry are entitled to remind us that the postman is not the only public servant whom neither rain nor snow nor heat nor gloom of night can keep from his appointed rounds. There is the milkman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved a bill today authorizing the government to aid private companies in insuring property against air raid or other war-caused damage and carrying a $1,000,000,000 money-raising authority for the RFC to obtain the funds.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- The Texas Gulf Coast emerged from its first blackout today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- General Douglas MacArthur reported today that the Japanese again made "headlong" infantry assaults against his forces yesterday, but that his artillery had smashed the attacks with heavy losses.

The Dutch Navy in the Pacific "hopes to sink at least one Japanese ship a day," E.N. van Kleffens, Netherlands Foreign Minister, declared yesterday on his arrival here. "And we can do it if you will give use the tools," he added.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 -- Bengazi, Libya, changed hands once more today, according to announcements in both Berlin and Rome, which said that in the early hours of this morning German and Italian units entered its streets.

Charles Edmund Merrill Jr. was a New Yorker of sensitive social conscience and the choicest fiber of manhood. Succeeding his honored father as a publisher, he was an intelligent and a generous man of business. Like that father, he was a pious son of Yale. An early Plattsburger, he was a gallant officer in the First World War.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board; Dean G. Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State; Mayor La Guardia of New York, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and others.

Sales of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in 1941 set a new high mark of $961,240,737, nearly 60 per cent above the previous high of $602,202,618 in 1940 and more than twice the volume of $448,000,000 reported for 1918, the best year of the first World War.

As long as non-citizens here conduct themselves in accordance with the law they need not fear any interference from the Department of Justice or any agency of the Federal Government, Mathias F. Correa, United States Attorney, declared last night at a dinner in the Grand Street Boys Clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street, of the New York Council, American Friends of the Hebrew University in Palestine.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

Twenty men, fourteen inspectors, three former inspectors and three investigators of the Federal Alcohol Tax Control Unit were named in an indictment handed up by the Federal grand jury yesterday to Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Despite yesterday's order for evacuation of the outer defense area of this base, faith that the United Nations would be able to hold Singapore remained unshaken, the general public attitude indicated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt expects to make a radio address to the nation about Feb. 22 in order "in so far as possible, to give the country a clearer understanding of the war and all it involves," it was announced at the White House today.

The World Wide Broadcasting Foundation, which operates the Boston short-wave station WRUL, will extend its activities early next month by opening a New York news room and program department at 630 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Walter S. Lemmon, president of the foundation.

Mrs. Harry C. Mills gave a farewell luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mrs. Reed Albee, who is leaving shortly for Palm Beach. Other guests included Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour, Mrs. Conn Cohalan, Mrs. J. Herbert Todd, Mrs. Kenneth Watkins, Mrs. Elmer Diefenbach, Mrs. Hugo Keller, Mrs. Joseph Downey Barker and Mrs. Paul Albus.
TRENTON, Jan. 29 -- A bill to make daylight-saving time the official time of New Jersey after 2 A.M. Feb. 9 will be introduced in the Legislature next Monday.

2. sharp increase in awards for engineering construct/on work Was made this week when a total of $221,694,000 was reached. This is the highest figure for any week! since Aug. 7, 1941. and represents a gain of T4 per oent over a week ago and 124 per cent over the corresponding period last year.

A message from Lotte Lehmann, the Metropolitan soprano, to the people of Germany, urging them to "save body and soul by adhering again to what makes life worth living, to the ideals of free humanity," was broadcast yesterday from London by the British radio.

Experimentation with a system of partly blacking out New York City's traffic lights by means of metal discs that will permit only a small cross of illumination to show was begun yesterday by Police Department engineers. If the test is successful it may be extended throughout the city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed Feb. 11 as Thomas Alva Edison Day in honor of the inventor, who was born in a small Ohio town ninety-five years ago that day.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese forces advancing on the western coastal strip of the Malay Peninsula hammered relentlessly throughout yesterday at British mechanized units trapped in the marshes south of Batu Pahat, it was reported today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Mr. Stevens, former director of the Goodman Theatre a repertory company here, studied, at the Art Institute and later taught and lectured there in the fields of mural painting and the history of art. He lectured at the University of Wisconsin, 1912-13; was head of the Drama Department of Carnegie Institute of Technology, 1913-24; was director of the Goodman Theatre, 1924-30, and also headed the School of Dramatic Art there.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 29 -- Swerving northwestward from the area of Msus as part of an attempted pincer movement, strong German forces reached Er Regima, about sixteen miles from Bengazi, yesterday. Other German columns, made up of tanks and other arms, moved toward the coast of the Gulf of Sidra south of Bengazi and were met and at least temporarily blocked by British advance units.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 29 -- An increase last year in Westchester County real estate transactions was shown today in the 1941 report of the division of land records of the Westchester County County Clerk's Office. The total number of documents filed with the department was 37,332, compared with 33,920 in 1940.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 29 -- Ray Eliot, who had $8 in his pockets and the ambition to play under Bob Zuppke when he came to Illinois as a freshman thirteen years ago, today was named head football coach of the Illini.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Major Gen. Millard F. Harmon, commanding general of the Second Air Force, with headquarters at Fort George Wright, Wash., has been assigned to duty as chief of the air staff, Army Air Force, with headquarters in Washington, the War Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The House by a vote of 190 to 140 recommitted to its Agriculture Committee today a bill seeking to provide cash benefits up to $500 for distressed cotton and tobacco farmers and dairymen in up-State New York.
Several large apartment leases in the tifth Avenue and Park Avenue sections of the East Side were included in the lists of rentals reported by brokers yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 29 -- Colonel Pedro L. Zanni, 50, commander of the Argentine Army Air Force and a pioneer of South American aviation, died late tonight of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. His car was in a collision with a truck just outside the Campo de Mayo military garrison twenty miles from Buenos Aires.

The two remaining seeded players, Donald M. Frame and S.E. Davenport 3d, both of the Harvard Club and listed in the lower half of the draw, reached the semi-final round in the metropolitan Class A squash racquets singles championship at the University Club last night.

A collision involving a truck and two private automobiles at Tenth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, caused the death last night of the truck driver and slightly injured a woman pedestrian who was struck by glass.

For the first time in six weeks, excess reserve of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City and for the Reserve System as a whole showed declines. And, according to present indications, these declines may be expected to continue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 29 -- Foreign Ministers Eduardo Solf y Muro of Peru and Julio Tobar Donoso of Ecuador appended their signatures this morning to an historic document ending their 125-year-old boundary controversy.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN IRELAND, Jan. 29 -- Troops of the American expeditionary force that reached here this week have already settled down in their stations and taken up combat training where they left off at home.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Governor Lehman signed today a bill designed to speed New York's war effort by giving the Industrial Commissioner authority to suspend labor regulations hampering defense production.

A jury in Queens County Court returned yesterday a verdict of guilty of criminal negligence causing death against Edgar Beardon, 24 years old, of 34-33 Fifty-seventh Street, Woodside, in a case in which the prosecution offered only circumstantial evidence.

Public curiosity as to why stores and shops maintained by nationals of enemy countries -- Italy, Germany, Japan -- remain open resulted yesterday in a survey which disclosed that such establishments are under strict government supervision.
Don't fill that bathtub with water when and if the air raid siren blows in New York City, the Board for Civilian Protection in this area warned the public yesterday.
The American Steel Foundries voted a 50-cent dividend on the common stock, an increase of 25 cents over the disbursement in March, 1941.

War-risk insurance underwriters, taking for the first time official cognizance of the presence of submarines off the Atlantic coast, advanced their rates yesterday, but they still were betting 100 to 1 that any coastwise ship, even a tanker, would reach its destination.

The Blue Ridge Corporation and its affiliates reported yesterday that net assets of the parent company, priced at the market, had dropped from $25,464,062 at the end of 1940 to $20,030,541 at the end of 1941. This cut the net asset value of the preference stock from $66.18 a share to $58.51 a share and reduced the amount available for the common stock from 56 cents to 15 cents a share.

Emile C. Mathis, who came to this country as a French refugee in August, 1940, received yesterday the Bureau of Ordnace flag and the Navy "E" pennant because his company, the Matam Corporation, had completed a government contract for shells seven months ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Soon the President is to hear a series of recordings of the views of the average citizen on the war effort. It would be interesting if one of the average citizens should attempt to defend the people of the United States as a whole from the primary guilt of a charge that has been increasing in volume lately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Munitions works, chemical factories, troop training centers and airports throughout the nation, in addition to more than a half-million rural homes, were lighted and powered by current from electric lines financed by the Rural Electrification Administration during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1941.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England increased 1,749,000 last week after decreases in the three previous weeks.

Although Katina Paxinou made her New York debut in English in "Hedda Gabler" at the Longacre last evening, she made her New York debut in 1930. She played Clytemnestra to Mme. Cotopuli's "Elektra" in a performance in Greek, staged on a memorably wet night at the New Yorker Theatre.

Eight new members of the board of trustees of the City Club of New York took office last night after the annual meeting of the organization at its headquarters, 55 West Forty-fourth Street. The meeting was followed by a dinner attended by 250 members and their guests. Maurice Hindus, writer on Russian affairs, was the principal speaker.

To make way for expansion of Federal agencies in 253 Broadway, the Postal Telegraph Company is moving its New York headquarters from that building to the fifteen-story structure at 157 Chambers Street, Edwin F. Chinlund, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The general level of wholesale prices, after advancing to a twelve-year peak in mid-January, reacted last week, causing the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics to drop to 95.5, based on the 1926 average, from 95.6 the week before.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- The sinking of another German transport in Barents Sea is mentioned in today's navy communique. It was the eighth such ship sunk recently in those waters by Soviet submarines.

Mr. de Valera is in the habit of placing his demands upon the very highest moral and ethical plane, and of invoking on behalf of them -- and of the protest he now makes to the United States -- the eternal verities, the principles of Abraham Lincoln and the promises of Woodrow Wilson.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- A serious shortage of canned salmon was forecast for the nation here today, following an official announcement of restrictions on the activities of Alaska salmon fishermen and indications that at least 40 per cent of next year's pack would be lost through elimination of the Alaska Peninsula and Bristol Bay fishing areas.

In an effort to coordinate and intensify local moves to bring government agencies here from Washington, representatives of more than 100 trade, civic and commercial organizations with memberships totaling more than 100,000 business men and taxpayers met yesterday in the assembly room of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, 233 Broadway, to plan a united campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today consented to a 10 per cent increase in passenger bus fares by the interstate bus lines of the United States except for soldiers and sailors on furlough.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's Red Army of the Ukraine, in a mighty offensive carrying more than sixty-two miles in ten days, has recaptured Lozovaya, seventy-five miles south of Kharkov and only sixty miles from the Dnieper bend, a special communique announced tonight.

Bellevue Hospital and the children's societies already are feeling the backwash caused by the closing of Wiltwyck School at Esopus, N.Y., to new juvenile cases, Dr. Lauretta bender, senior psychiatrist in charge of the children's at Bellevue, said yesterday.
ROME, Jan. 29 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- All Japanese, German and Italian alien enemies are being ousted from vital areas in San Francisco and Los Angeles, on the recommendation of the War Department, Attorney General Biddle said today.

A dozen agents of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury Department, acting on signal, raided three tenement house apartments on the lower West Side at 3 P.M. yesterday, took two men into custody and seized large stores of whiskies, wines and liquors, bottles, labels and Internal Revenue stamps, some genuine and some forged.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The implications of a bill permitting the Federal Government to construct part of the New York City to Massena power line through the State Forest Preserve are causing concern among Republican legislators, who fear that it may be a "back door" route by public power advocates to create the Eastern, publicly owned grid system which they have always opposed.
I read with interest the story which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 28 about the British seaman, Allan Harvie, who is quoted as saying that he has heard too much loose talk for his comfort.

A set of the original folio edition of "The Birds of America" by John J. Audubon brought $15,600, a record auction price last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the sale of the library of the late Judge James D. Smith of Burlington, Iowa.

The Reading Company had a net income of $9,330,204 in 1941. It was equal to $4.66 a share on common stock, Edward W. Scheer, president, said yesterday in Philadelphia. This was a gain of 45 per cent from the $6,427,217, or $2.59 a common share, earned in 1940.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A stoppage of nylon hosiery manufacture in the near future was indicated today.

The ninth annual Butlers Ball, at which the domestic staffs of New York's prominent families, such as the Astors, Vanderbilts and Morgans, danced and frolicked in fashionable evening dress, was held last night at the Hotel Commodore.

BERLIN, Jan. 29 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Blizzards were reported by the High Command today to have restricted fighting in the Crimea and on the southern sector of the Russian mainland front.

Check transactions for the week ended on Wednesday continued well above the volume for the corresponding week last year. The total for the major cities of the country, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $7,138,753,000, an increase of 28.6 per cent over the $5,549,519,000 in the similar week of 1941, and only $33,649,000 under the amount recorded last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Treasury said today, in announcing its dismissal of eight officials of the Schering Corporation, that the company not only made drugs important to American defense but also was conducting "vital research" in its laboratories at Bloomfield which could be coordinated with scientific discoveries in other United Nations laboratories to help defeat the Axis.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 -- The National Lutheran Council named a committee today to draft a plan creating one unified church in the United States. The council, which represents eight Lutheran groups, also voted to set aside $650,000 for wartime activities and to continue short-wave broadcasts of church services to German-occupied countries in defiance of Hitler's ban on foreign radio listening.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 -- The Tribune de Lausanne has been printing a series of letters from a corespondent traveling in unoccupied France. Yesterday he wrote:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- As a step in "smashing completely a long-range German scheme to control an important segment of the pharmaceutical market in the Western Hemisphere," the Treasury Department announced today that it had suspended Dr. Julius Weltzien, president, and seven other executives of the Schering Corporation of Bloomfield, N.J., manufacturer of anti-shock vaccines, hormones, sulfa compounds and other medicines essential to the war effort.

A gala Diamond Jubilee Ball will be given tonight in the grand ballroom and adjoining suites of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and its Greater New York Chapter, and at the same time to mark the observance today of President Roosevelt's sixtieth birthday.

Lippy Leo Durocher breezed into town yesterday, but was in no mood to talk -- much. Placing direct blame for his surprising indisposition to give a lively interview on a rocky plane trip from Miami, the pilot of the National League champion Dodgers submitted to questioning by telephone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The National War Labor Board reported today settlement of two labor disputes. One involved 500 employes represented by the Teamsters Union, A.F.I., in six trucking firms banded together in the Carolina Transportation Association, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Four critical combat areas within the regions affecting the United States have been placed under single commanders who exercise full authority of Army, Navy and Air Forces, Secretary Stimson revealed today.

APPARENTLY the main idea in holding heavyweight bouts now is to find some way of giving Private J. Louis Barrow of the United States Army a good time when he is allowed a furlough. Joe probably would like nothing better than a chance to step in again with some "logical contender" or "worthy opponent." Money would be no object as far as Private Barrow is concerned.

There is no such rank as "probationary patrolman" under the city's administrative code, and the Board of Estimate was without power to fix at $1,200 a year the salary of policemen during the first six months of "probationary" service, Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan ruled yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 29 -- Dr. Enrique Ruiz Guinazu, Argentine Foreign Minister, and his party escaped without serious injury this morning when the plane in which they intended to return to Buenos Aires from the inter-American conference here crashed in Rio de Janeiro Bay just after taking off.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The Times of London, in its leading editorial tomorrow, on the occasion of President Roosevelt's sixtieth birthday, will pay tribute not only to his qualities and to his ability in his positions of leader and commander-in-chief of a people united to fight to the last ounce, but also to the President's qualities as a statesman.

ABOARD THE QUEEN ELIZABETH, Flagship of the British Mediterranean Fleet, Nov. 25, 1941 -- The British battleship Barham, struck by four torpedoes from an enemy submarine, exploded and sank within five minutes today off the Libyan coast.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The first engagement between British and Japanese surface warships occurred Monday night off Endau, in the east coast of Malaya, when a destroyer of the Royal Navy, accompanied by one of the Australian Navy tackled an enemy cruiser and three destroyers, the Admiralty announced today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The British Headquarters said in a communique today:

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Among the 'war-imposed difficulties" of super-market grocery merchandising is the employment of women as checkers and the discovery that they are "more than satisfactory" to shoppers, William H. Albers, president of the Super-Market Institute, declared at a meeting of the organization here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29, -- Protection of West Coast industry and vital waterfront areas from possible sabotage was viewed here as the apparent aim of the Army and Justice Departments in ordering the removal of enemy aliens from the San Francisco and Los Angeles districts, proscribed today.

"The Body Disappears," a Warner comedy melodrama with Jeffrey Lynn, Jane Wyman and Edward Everett Horton, will open this morning at the Palace. Marguerite Chapman, Willie Best, David Bruce and Hobart Bosworth are among the supporting players. "The Man Who Came To Dinner" is the associate picture on the double-feature program.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 29 -- Revealing the growing strength of the Free French movement in French Indo-China and the French island possessions in the Pacific, The Japan Times Advertiser, Foreign Office organ, sharply warns today that "if the present situation continues to interfere with the Greater East Asia Co-prosperity Sphere or obstructs Japan's military operations, Japan will not hesitate for a moment to resort to force to stamp out de Gaullists in the Pacific."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A hint thrown out by Secretary Morgenthau at his press conference today was taken as corroboration of reports that the proposed extension of lease-lend to cover more material for Britain would include the purchase of supplies from South America to this end.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 29 -- First Fiddle and City Talk, both hot favorites, captured the Seminole and Florida Purses, twin features at Hialeah today, where 9,049 turned out for the races. For a couple of heavily backed public choices to come romping home was a welcome change for many, and the horses left no doubt in either race, for the margins were as wide as the prices were narrow.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- Thomas Conroy, formerly the janitor at a tenement at 583 East 138th Street, the Bronx, New York City, was put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison tonight for the murder of 10-year-old Genevieve Connolly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Connolly of 286 Brook Avenue, also the Bronx.

"Sissy games," such as badminton, ping-pong and such, are fun, but they don't hold a candle to such "he-man" activities as wrestling, boxing and long-distance running when it comes to preparing the average Columbia College man to fight a war.

After listening to the testimony of Donald M. Nelson, the Truman committee withdrew its recommendation to the Senate that all dollar-a-year men and other persons working in defense agencies without compensation either be dispensed with or put on the regular Government payroll.

TRENTON, Jan. 29 -- Increased use of potatoes, turnips and other starchy vegetables as replacements for sweets in the diet was urged on housewives today by Dr. Carl R. Fellers, professor at Massachusetts State College, in a discussion of the effects of sugar rationing before the New Jersey Horticultural Society, meeting here in connection with the annual farm-week program of the State Department of Agriculture.

Emphasizing the need for the development on a large scale of air-cargo transportation to speed the war program on all fronts, Grover Loening, consulting engineer at Roosevelt Field, said yesterday that the United States should prepare and aim for command of transportation by air and not merely command of the air after the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Jan. 30 -- A special Russian communique issued late last night announced a large-scale counter-offensive in the Donets Basin, one spearhead of which had seized the junction of Lozovaya, less than sixty-two miles northeast of Dniepropetrovsk.

Japan's war aims were originally laid down in the Tripartite Pact of 1940, but Tokyo's post-war policy after her final victory over the Allied nations and total domination of the Pacific will aim at an even greater goal: the complete disarmament of the United States.

The Mathieson Alkali Works, Inc., manufacturer of chemicals, had in 1941 a net income of $1,743,628 after reserve of $1,150,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes, according to the fiftieth annual report issued yesterday by E.M. Allen, chairman of the board and president.

With selling pressure at a minimum but with buyers few, only isolated sections of the stock market managed yesterday to gain any lift from the day's news developments. Pivotal issues were relegated almost entirely to the background as the meager activity of the session developed in sugar and soft-drink securities.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The veteran Syd Howe bagged goals in the second and third periods tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 2-to-0 National Hockey League victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 7,164 spectators. It was the third shut-out of the season for Goalie Johnny Mowers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Newspaper-affiliated radio stations and stations without newspaper connections do not differ materially in their operation, the Federal Communications Commission was told today.
Two parcels in New Jersey, which long had been held by members of two different families, were reported yesterday as having been sold.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The following are textual excerpt from Prime Minister Churchill's speech today in the House of Commons:

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 29 -- Despite a full week of blasting counter-attack from air and sea in which thirty-eight to forty-six Japanese warships and transports have been sunk or damaged, a still powerful Japanese invasion armada manoeuvred tonight in a reckless gamble for a foothold on Java after having made a new landing, this time in Western Borneo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- William Langer should be expelled from his seat as a Senator from North Dakota on grounds of moral turpitude involving "continuous, contemptuous and shameful disregard" of all decent concepts of public service, the Senate Privileges and Elections Committee reported today in a seventy-five-page explanation of the 13 to 3 decision to this end reached more than a month ago.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Judge Ashley B. Carrick of the Fourth Criminal District Court has enlisted in the Army and he will leave tomorrow morning for Fort Dix.

Scrap metals and other materials that New Yorkers want to contribute to help win the war may be placed outside of houses or apartment buildings on Sunday mornings and they will be picked up about 11 o'clock by Department of Sanitation trucks, the New York City Salvage Committee announced yesterday.

Paintings "in the Pennsylvania Dutch motif" by Waiter Emerson Baum are displayed in the lounge of the Guild Theatre, where the new comedy "Papa Is All" is the current attraction. Mr. Baum has furnished a score of canvases -- landscapes, for the most part, depicting aspects of the Pennsylvania Dutch countryside.

James B. Black, president of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, announced yesterday that, on a preliminary basis, earnings of the company for 1941 were equivalent to $2.30 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, compared with $2.68 a share in 1940.
With eighty-five skaters slated to take part in the singles events, the Eastern States figure-skating championships will get under way today at the Iceland Rink, atop Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York City conferred at length this afternoon with President Roosevelt but declined later to be specific about his future plans.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Three Army ferry command pilots on a training flight were killed today when their bomber plunged into a swamp with a terrific impact and burned.

SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 29 -- This city, metropolis of the anthracite region, asserted today that its coal deposits were nearing exhaustion and that its destiny was that of "a ghost city in a deserted valley," unless new industrial resources were provided by the Federal Government.

A lead of three goals midway in the game proved a big help to the Brooklyn Americans in their National Hockey League contest with the world champion Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night. Red Dutton's athletes, seemingly on the way to a one-sided triumph, suddenly encountered opposition of the sternest sort, but managed, none the less, to squeeze out a 5-to-4 triumph over the speedy sextet from the Hub.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The text of the War Department communique based on reports received here up to 9:30 A. M. Eastern standard time today, follows:
To relieve the acute shortage of foot patrolmen, Commissioner Valentine ordered yesterday the transfer of 500 men from other departments, principally the detective and traffic divisions.

Full support of President Roosevelt's efforts to win the war has been pledged by the members of the College Newman Clubs of the New York Province in a letter sent to the President by Edward J. Kelly, chairman of the clubs' twenty-third annual convention, it was announced yesterday by the province's Newman Club Federation.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 -- A prediction that war production in the automobile industry will call for a peak employment of more than 700,000 workers by Jam 1, 1943, was made today by Ernest C. Kanzler, chief of the automotive branch of the War Production Board.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- A thinly veiled hint that the dispatch of United States troops to Northern Ireland would have a salutary effect on the government of Eire was made today by Prime Minister Winston Churchill just before the House of Commons gave him the biggest vote of confidence he has ever received, 464 to 1.

George R. Stewart, author of the best selling novel, "Storm," now back at the University of California where he teaches English, writes: "I am an emergency ambulance driver with my new station wagon. Since I was in the ambulance service in '17, this raises the question whether we ever get anywhere."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- (AP) The Treasury Department today ordered the closing and liquidation of the Pilot Reinsurance Company of New York City, because of alleged Axis control.

A bit more than seventy years ago a little Breslauer of 9 came to this town with his father, a famous conductor. Face to face or by hearsay the child knew or knew of the great German musical figures of his time. He was born to be a musician. The father founded the Oratorio Society.

During the present crisis students should give more attention to developing manual skills than to ready-made textbooks, Dr. Margaret M. Mead of the American Museum of Natural History declared last night at the Hunter College High School commencement.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Paced by three resolute Texans, the unbeaten American Volunteer Group's squadron and its Royal Air Force colleagues tore thirteen and possibly seventeen more Japanese planes out of a mass enemy fighter sweep over Rangoon today and boosted their score of raiders destroyed over Burma and Thailand since the start of the war to at least 111 machines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Department store sales during the week ended Jan. 24 were 34 per cent greater than in the corresponding week of 1941, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Sales showed a gain of 45 per cent for the week ended Jan. 17.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Netherland Admiralty today issued the following communique, dated Jan. 8.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 29 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

Nine years ago today Adolf Hitler became Chancellor of Germany. He headed a coalition government of National Socialists and Nationalists. In the presence of the aged and failing President von Hindenburg he took a solemn oath of allegiance to the Constitution of the German Republic, which he then proceeded to destroy.
2.-demand 'for store and office space in buildings in the midtown section of Manhattan was indicated by leases reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that he had received from Governor McGrath of Rhode Island support for his proposal to make outstanding State and municipal tax-exempt bonds subject to Federal income tax.

The injunction suit to restrain the Police Department from further seizures of pinball machines belonging to the Savoy Vending Company, Inc., was withdrawn in Supreme Court yesterday by Leonard M. Wallstein, attorney for the company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A series of conversations between the United States Government and the French Government at Vichy has resulted in the resumption of trade between this country and Vichy Africa, it was learned tonight.

The Union Electric Company of Missouri, one of the nation's largest operating utilities, will register its entire outstanding common stock capitalization with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the next few days, it was announced yesterday by J. Wesley McAfee, president of the utility.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -- "The Meanest Man in the World," a comedy by Augustin MacHugh which George M. Cohan produced on Broadway in 1920 with Frank M. Thomas in the leading role, will be Jack Benny's next vehicle at Twentieth Century-Fox, the studio announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The anti-Axis German language newspaper Zeitung, published in London, will say tomorrow that a compromise reached by Adolf Hitler and elements of the German High Command is "equivalent to an admission on the part of Hitler that he is unable to carry on the Eastern campaign without the aid of experienced strategists."

A bill designed to end the objections of New York sportsmen and fly-tyers to the Audubon Society plumage law has been introduced in the Legislature and, if passed, will put an end to the heated battle which has been raging between sportsmen and the society.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A treaty with Mexico, providing for adjustment and settlement of about 4,300 outstanding claims of nationals of each country against the government of the other, and under which Mexico will pay the United States $40,000,000, was ratified by a voice vote of the Senate today.

War or no war, things are looking up, according to the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, which reports that almost every popular cut of meat has gone down in price in the last week. Smoked hams -- which have gone up a cent to sell at a city-wide average of 34 cents a pound -- are the only exception to this pleasant state of affairs.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 29 -- As a result of the discovery of a shortage of more than $50,000 in the funds of the First National Bank of Park Ridge, N.J., Charles S. Gray, cashier of the bank, and Samuel Kaplowitz, a depositor of the bank, were in Federal custody today charged with appropriating Federal funds to their own use.

With yesterday's business at license-issuing offices of the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles in the city double that of the preceding day, the indications were that a sizable increase in 1942 automobile registrations would be shown over those of last year.

That Thornton Wilder play, "Skin of Our Teeth," which the author recently submitted to Jed Harris, will be done by Michael Myerberg, business manager for Leopold Stokowski and Mr. Wilder. As a producer Mr. Myerberg was last represented on Broadway by "Symphony" (1935).

A cell in the Federal House of Detention continued yesterday and last night to be the residence of Werner von Clemm, the naturalized German who was accused on Wednesday of serving as fence for the Nazi High Command. The 44-year-old kin of Germany's Foreign Minister, who has established a sizable importing firm here, was unable to procure the required bail of $5,000.

Conflicting opinions were expressed before the Board of Estimate yesterday on the validity of the term "low cost housing" as applied to the proposed Edwin Markham Houses on Staten Island, with the City Planning Commission criticizing the project on the ground that it would house families with incomes up to $4,320 a year.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29 -- A large attendance marked tonight's opening of the Colony Club where both the inner room and the patio were filled with guests. Andre Embericos entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Heminway, Mrs. Jay O'Brien, Mrs. Hudson Ammidown and Ronald Balcom.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's southern command is engaged in severe fighting in several sectors, according to reports received here, but it is not specified just where the battles are proceeding between Kharkov and the Sea of Azov.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's southern command is engaged in severe fighting in several sectors, according to reports received here, but it is not specified just where the battles are proceeding between Kharkov and the Sea of Azov.

The cotton market yesterday lost as much as 48 points, or $2.40 a bale, before trade buying orders appeared in sufficient quantity to bring about a sustained rally. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly at levels 1 point lower to 3 points higher than Wednesday's final quotations.
A glum young man who had wagered against Long Island University Wednesday night when the Blackbirds played West Texas State voiced his disgust at his mistake afterward.

Norman P. Mason of North Chelmsford, Mass., was elected president of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association at the conclusion yesterday of the annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mr. Mason, who also heads the Massachusetts Retail Lumber Dealers Association and is treasurer of the William P. Proctor Company, succeeds J.A. Detweiler of Rochester, N.Y.

The desire to destroy Hitler and the idea of totalitarianism is the most important of the many reasons why so many New Yorkers are working to raise the Greater New York quota of $7,330,000 toward the $50,000,000 War Fund of the American Red Cross, Thomas W. Lamont, chairman of the national advisory committee, yesterday told a meeting of the women's special gifts committee at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton.
Bubbling over with excitement, 4-year-old Gerry King of 448 West Fifty-eighth Street boarded a train at the Pennsylvania Station at 10:40 o'clock last night for his great adventure.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The days when Army volunteers paid their own expenses on their way to war were recalled today when it was disclosed that the United Spanish War Veterans are turning over to the State a fund of more than $39,000 which has been in their possession for many years.

Mayor La Guardia, hinting once more of his possible resignation as director of the Office of Civilian Defense or as Mayor, declared last night, at a dinner of the New York University Law Alumni Association, that "I am about to give up this double life."

Two facts will probably be in many persons' minds as they think of Franklin Delano Roosevelt on this, his sixtieth birthday. Either one of them was enough to keep him from the Presidency. The first was the accident of birth in a wealthy and democratic family.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Three Marine majors recruited from the football coaching ranks agreed today the nation needed athletics now more than ever, and endorsed proposals that colleges schedule regular contests with service teams.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Peggy Schwartz, research worker at a movie studio, pointed a finger at Frank Carbo in Superior Court today and said: "That's the man."

Retail stores are frantically trying to get all the orders possible down on men's Fall furnishings, particularly those made of wool. Currently, manufacturers and resident offices are being flooded with requests for Fall hosiery, in which a definite shortage is expected, wool-lined gloves, mufflers and bathrobes.

The eight-family house at 110 Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the Oreenpoint Savings Bank to Rose Stallone through Noah Clark, Inc., broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Mortgage loans made by the mutual savings banks in New York State in 1941 showed a gain of 28 per cent over the previous year, according to figures reported yesterday by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Sugar production in the Caribbean area will be "stepped up," and shipments to the United States increased in quantities sufficient to modify substantially any impending shortage due to the cutting off of supplies from other sources, Secretary Ickes said today.

Strong men with true palates were called to the test yesterday. For the first time in beverage history, a wine tasting event devoted exclusively to Latin-American wines and spirits was held at R.H. Macy Co.'s executive offices.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 -- After a careful study of the "handwriting on the wall" contained in Prime Minister Churchill's address of last Tuesday, the German press began last evening to prepare its readers for any psychological "setback" they might be inclined to feel "should he receive his vote of confidence."

Mrs. Elizabeth Festner of 1173 "Throgmorton Avenue, the Bronx, at 9 A.M. walked up the alley yesterday beside a four-family, two-story frame house at 3155 Rawlings Avenue, the Bronx. She had an appointment to take Mrs. Anna Unterholzner, 38 years old, to the Psychiatric Division of the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital for treatment.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 29 -- The British line held firm today in the Western Malaya sector but was being beaten back to within thirty miles of Singapore on the central front despite the strong and gallant bayonet counter-attacks of the outnumbered Australians.

Weather is still the master strategist of the war. During recent weeks military operations in Europe have been dominated by the onset of the most violent Winter in a century. Opposing armies, navies and air fleets have been struggling for mastery in a vast storm that swept Europe from end to end, darkened the Mediterranean and whirled the sands of Libya into a blinding haze.

While the Navy Department was officially disclosing in its communique last night that its counter-measures against enemy submarines off the Atlantic coast were proving "increasingly effective," a spokesman for the department revealed a terse but graphic report of the sinking of one of the marauders by a naval plane.

One person who does not believe that women are going to cast aside formal evening gowns because of the current emergency is Phillippa MacDonald. She demonstrated her faith in full-dress fashions yesterday by presenting fifteen models in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre at the luncheon hour.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 29 -- Yale University and its employes signed tonight a wage agreement which calls for rises amounting to about $100,000 annually, with downward revision of working hours.

Gold holdings as stated in the subjoined table represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title to actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30. 1934.

Looking back over fifty years during which he has seen his church become a center of recreational, social and educational activities, John C. Tiedeman, sexton of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, will observe his golden jubilee today.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

With the view of eventually providing first-aid training in all 360 parishes of the New York Archdiocese, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman has called on Catholic teachers to enroll in special courses to be conducted by the American Red Cross at five Manhattan and Bronx Catholic institutions, the Chancery Office announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- A decided change in sentiment occurred over night in the grain markets, and with soy beans in the lead, prices moved up quickly today. A lack of pressure rather than aggressive buying was responsible for the strength.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 29 -- The German High Command has withdrawn between 80,000 and 100,000 from Yugoslavia for service on the eastern front in consequence of the arrival of seven Bulgarian divisions and one and one-half divisions of Hungarians in Serbia and Serbian Macedonia, according to reports tonight from foregin military intelligence sources here.

"Have your garden and eat it, too" was adopted yesterday as a wartime policy by the Woman's National Farm and Garden Association at the midwinter executive and council meeting held at the Hotel New Weston.

Nat Smilen, 44 years old, president of Smilen Brothers, Inc., who operate a chain of twenty-eight retail fruit and vegetable stores in the city, was found guilty yesterday by Justices Troy, Doyle and Hackenburg in Special Sessions of committing perjury before the grand jury in December, 1939, in its general investigation of racketeering in that business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, sought today to prevent an increase in agricultural equipment prices, because higher machinery costs to farmers would boost the cost of food to America's soldiers and civilians.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The stock market showed little activity today pending the conclusion of the debate in Commons. Gilt-edge issues were steady, but little movement was shown in foreign bonds. The industrial leaders were maintained, and the textile group was firm again, but the tobaccos, shipping issues and stores were dull.

The firm of Schlater, Gardner Co., 60 Broadway, dealers in municipal bonds, filed yesterday in Supreme Court an attachment against funds here belonging to the city of Asbury Park, N. J., as the first step in a suit for $20,000 as payment due for services in effecting a refunding of bond issues of Asbury Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- During the week ended Jan. 28 member bank reserve balances decreased $70,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $20,000,000 in money in circulation and $18,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, and decreases of $44,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $6,000,000 in gold stock, offset in part by decreases of $8,000,000 in Treasury cash and $9,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Liberalized requirements for officer candidates among the Army's enlisted men were announced today by the War Department.

The problem of price control needs some type of handy, mechanical assistance and licensing provides such a mechanism, Walter Mitchell Jr., director of business surveys for Dun Bradstreet and consultant to the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Commodore.

TORONTO, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Maple Leafs strengthened their hold on third place in the National Hockey League race tonight when they downed the Canadiens, 7 -- 3, in a wild game featured by a free-for-all fight in the third period.

Gyorgy Sandor, Hungarian pianist, was heard in his third New York recital last night in Town Hall. The youthful artist again aroused his audience to outbursts of enthusiasm by the nimbleness of his fingers and the engaging quality of his exceedingly suave, mellow tone.

Crime, ill health and poverty in Harlem cannot be eliminated until planned parenthood is "fully recognized and applied" in that overcrowded section of the city, the Birth Control Federation of America was told yesterday at its annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The recent sea disasters along the Atlantic seaboard are making Americans realize that the war at sea must be won and that winning it depends on the personnel of the Navy, Coast Guard and merchant marine.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 30 -- The sturdy Netherland Navy and Air Force were reported authoritatively tonight to have sunk or damaged fifty-four Japanese ships in that many days as Netherland troops still battled the invaders inside the charred East Borneo oil city of Balik Papan on the debris-strewn Strait of Macassar.

Nearly 450,000 Federal automobile tax stamps valued at $940,000 have been purchased in the last two weeks by motorists in New York City who expect to use their vehicles when or soon after the new tax becomes effective tomorrow Stamps have been sold for use by 87 per cent of the 515,000 automobiles expected to be in operation in February.

The St. John's University basketball team squared its 40-to-38 setback at the hands of Brooklyn College last year by sweeping to a 49-39 triumph over the Kingsmen in the De Gray Gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night.

The cotton market moved up 21 to 27 points in early trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, but news of President Roosevelt's expressed dissatisfaction with the Price Control Bill discouraged buying, and the market lost ground rapidly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The 1942-43 Naval Appropriation Bill was raised to $26,494,265,474 today by a Senate Appropriations subcommittee at the request of President Roosevelt.

Householders and farmers were urged yesterday to rummage through their attics, cellars, garages, barns and tool sheds; to pick over rags and old clothes, to turn out kitchen drawers and sweep out the hall closet, and even to look over the back yard to see what could be salvaged for war industry.

Members of the medical staff of the Good Samaritan Dispensary and Hospital joined yesterday in honoring John H. Hallock, president of the institution for the past twenty-years. The members of the medical staff, forty in all, and Miss Raie Sones, superintendent, held a luncheon for Mr. Hallock at the Hotel McAlpin.

An organized group of "listeners" whose duty it is to hear people relate their bombing experiences is now part of England's home defense plan, Professor Winifred C. Cullis, director of the women's section of the British Library of Information, declared yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (AP) -- President Michael Kalinin of the Soviet Union sent this birthday greeting today to President Roosevelt:

Over the last twelvemonth farm prices have advanced 42 per cent. The loopholes of the Emergency Price Control Bill leave ample room for still further advances. Grains can go up another 30 per cent before coming under the control of the Price Administrator; fruit prices another 60 per cent, and so on down the commodity line.

TRENTON, Jan. 30 -- An order by State Milk Director Arthur F. Foran increasing the retail price of milk one cent a quart throughout New Jersey was sustained today by the State Milk Control Board in the face of widespread protests by private and commercial consumer groups.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Accidents of all kinds killed 101,500 persons last year and injured 9,300,000 at an estimated loss in dollars of $3,750,000,000, the National Safety Council reported today. The toll was greater than in 1940 by 5 per cent.
TOKYO, Jan. 30 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Domei today gave the following picture of the fighting on the Malayan front:

WE learn quickly these days. In 1940 a public opinion poll elicited the strange information that only a little more than half the people of mainland America were in favor of fighting to defend the Hawaiian Islands. (This, despite the fact that the Pearl Harbor naval base was constructed, not as an end in itself, but to provide for the defense of Seattle, Portland and San Francisco.)

The textile industry, by foresight and intelligent planning, can do much to assure an even and continuous flow of goods for both government and civilian consumption. To accomplish this and to soften the impact of government priorities on the established channels of trade a survey of the actual and potential productive facilities of the industry should be made and the findings correlated with the present and prospective ratios of governmental and civilian requirements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A high official maid today that American experience in sending food to unoccupied France had not been 100 per cent satisfactory.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- A treaty binding the fortunes of Iran with those of Britain and the Soviet Union "for not longer than six months after the end of the war" was signed yesterday in Teheran, Iran, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Virtual abandonment by the United Gas Corporation of its long pending and much controverted refinancing program which called for the issuance of $75,000,000 of bonds which fourteen insurance companies had agreed to buy, was announced late today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
THIS is the story as it was told by a man who had been out on the snow-covered hills where the skiers meet.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- Conscription of labor in territories occupied by the Germans is likely to be ordered soon, according to indications from various parts of the Reich.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Though the Midway Islands were attacked by Japan as soon as the war began, our flag still flies there. Guam, our stepping-stone to the Philippines, had to be written off in the first week. Wake, whose defenders held out with such heroism, is also lost. But while we hold Midway we still have a base within 2,600 miles of Tokyo.

Sensible motorists will try to make the most of what is left to them in the way of rubber rather than besiege the tire boards for permits that cannot be granted or get rid of perfectly good vehicles on the ground that they have become useless encumbrances. There are many steps that the average owner of a car can take to prolong the life of his present tires.

New York City's observance of President Roosevelt's sixtieth birthday was centered last night on the gala Diamond Jubilee Ball held in the grand ballroom and adjoining suites of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. This function ended the 1942 fund-raising campaign for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.
Looking frostbitten but otherwise appearing in tiptop shape, Joe McCarthy, manager of the world champion Yankees, breezed in yesterday from Buffalo for his midwinter visit to New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Roosevelt signed the Price Control Bill today and pledged vigorous administration of its provisions, warning the American people that it would be necessary to step on the toes of many people to make those provisions effective.

An apartment and store building in West Hempstead, Nassau, the two-story structure at 194-6 Hempstead Avenue, has been sold by the Methodist Episcopal Church Home, in the City of New York, to the Wally Realty Company, Inc., August Riesterer, president.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Sale of shares of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company (Kentucky) to the parent Standard Gas and Electric Company and to the public was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 30 -- Despite courageous fighting by Indian troops, the jaws of a German pincers operation closed on Bengazi yesterday. Apparently greatly reinforced within the last few days, the Germans threw such numbers of tanks and mechanized infantry into the fray that British Imperial units in the immediate vicinity found themselves heavily outnumbered.

The author of "Food for Midas," presented last night by the Players Repertory Theatre at the Master, 103d Street and Riverside Drive, believes all the misery in the world has been caused by a "bankers' combine," which controls the National Reserve Banks.

VICHY, France, Jan. 30 -- Vice Premier Francois Darlan returned to Vichy tonight after three days of consultation in Paris attended by extraordinary secrecy. No mention of the visit was permitted here during the period of his absence and there were no indications as to whom he conferred with or the subject of the discussions.

DUBLIN, Jan. 30 -- The government charged today that the landing of American troops in Northern Ireland violated Eire's neutrality and said it was determined to raise an army as quickly as possible to resist invasion from any direction.

Marine war risk underwriters decided yesterday that United States and neighboring coastal waters in the Pacific are safer than those in the Atlantic. They issued revised war-risk rates on cargo which, in effect, bet 200 to 1 that a cargo would arrive safely in Pacific coastwise routes between points within the United States or to or from Canada, Mexico and Central America not south of the Panama Canal.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 30 (AP) -Reorganization proceedings, begun a year ago by the Ambassador Hotel Corporation of Atlantic City, were terminated today in favor of a two-year debt settlement plan approved by United States District Judge John Boyd Avis and the principal mortgagor.

No more important "soldier" exists in the country's victory program than the housewife, who controls the purchase and use of the myriad essentials that make a home, as "this is a war of materials," the Consumer Committee of the Office of Civilian Defense in Brooklyn maintains.

Establishment of an export premium of 3 cents a hundredweight in the ceiling schedule issued on Thursday for lithopone, against a basic ceiling of $4.25, was regarded yesterday by exporters as absurdly low. They explained that these prices meant they must pay $85 a ton for the material and might charge not more than $85.60, which they asserted obviously was low to cover their operating costs.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 30 -- The government's Information Bureau issued a statement of "a member of the Supreme Court" tonight declaring that this week's ruling by that tribunal reversing a previous decision on subsoil property rights -- the main issue in the controversy over expropriation of foreign oil holdings -- was not of major importance in the oil issue.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The text of a War Department communique based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, today follows:

WINCHESTER, Mass., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Miss Jean E. McKenzie was married in San Francisco today to Ensign Cecil L. Webber while her father here and her own minister, in Pinehurst, N.C., took part in the ceremony by telephone.

Approval of a bill pending before the Legislature that would make it mandatory for cities throughout the State to maintain kindergartens for children between 4 and 6 years old, was voted yesterday by the Board of Education. The approval was conditioned, however, upon the passage by the Legislature of another bill providing State aid for kindergartens.
I would be a pretty poor protagonist of my own parallel skiing technique if I did not reply to the major points raised in Stanley Hope's letter of Jan. 17.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 30 -- President Roosevelt's birthday was celebrated here and at other centers in Brazil tonight with several receptions for Brazilians and Americans being held both jointly and separately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Fighting on the Bataan Peninsula was light during the past twenty-four hours, according to reports received here from General Douglas MacArthur. Meanwhile the Japanese are sending fresh troops to the mountainous front after the failure of propaganda tactics to break the morale of General MacArthur's American and Filipino forces.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 30 -- Very grave apprehensions have been caused in Argentine financial and economic circles by Uruguay's recent measure of drastically restricting the transfer of funds to and from countries that maintain diplomatic relation with the Axis.

RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP) -- Big Ralph Guldahl found his old-time skill on the golf links today for the first time in many months and tied for first place in the first day's firing of the $5,000 tournament staged by Bing Crosby.

Max Packer's letter of last week decrying the lack of sportsmanship of City College basketball fans reminds one of the grouchy grade-school disciplinarian who goes around smacking the knuckles of pupils who happen to whisper out of turn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -The War Production Board said today that it had seized a rich cargo of vital war materials on the German motorship Willmoto, which was interned at San Juan, P.R., before the declaration of war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 30 -- Finnish unrest in face of totalitarian tendencies that have become manifest in certain circles, and the determination to defend Finnish democracy, are forcibly expressed by the influential Suomen Sosialdemokraatti in Helsinki.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told 250 industrialists at a closed meeting in New York last night that "one weapon today is worth two tomorrow, or ten next year," and urged upon them the utmost speed in meeting President Roosevelt's armament goals without haggling about cost.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Jan. 30 -A three-alarm fire at the Springfield Arsenal seriously damaged today the new field service building under construction. It was to have been ready in three weeks for the expanding manufacture of Garand rifles for the armed forces.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -- A move to revoke business and professional licenses held by an estimated 5,000 enemy aliens in California was announced today by Governor Olson as a drive against potential fifth columnists gained rapid momentum on the West Coast.
Rear Admiral Harry Lerch Brinser, U.S.N., through Mary Lewis, penthouse in 434 E 52d St; Gersham Realty Co., Inc, broker.

Can it be that Jenghiz Khan was responsible for the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor? If the Mongol conqueror had succeeded in adding Japan to his conquests along with China eight hundred years ago, then the history of Nippon would have moved in harmony with that of China, instead of in conflict.

Beginning on Monday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and its branch in Buffalo will not accept for collection from member banks or from non-member clearing banks in this district any postal money orders except those drawn on or issued by postoffices in New York City, Brooklyn, Buffalo or Washington, D.C., or in another Federal Reserve city or Federal Reserve branch city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Jan. 17 was 3,152,210 shares, compared with 3,919,330 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The Figueroa String and Piano Quintet, an unusual musical ensemble composed of five brothers, who come from Puerto Rico, appeared in a concert at the Town Hall last night. They were presented under the auspices of the Government of Puerto Rico.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -To simplify their protection of belligerent interests, including those of the United States, the heads of the special Swiss mission in Berlin have established their quarters and residences in various embassy and legation buildings, according to reports from the German capital.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 30 -- Though some Ministers desire the creation of an imperial war cabinet with executive functions, it was considered obvious here today that the unwillingness of Canada and South Africa to participate would make that objective impracticable; hence it was believed likely that Prime Minister Churchill's offer to give Australia permanent access to he British War Cabinet without the right to participate in its decisions would be accepted.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 30 -Deanna Durbin, who was suspended from salary by Universal on Oct. 16, has settled her disagreement with the company and returned to work, the studio announced today. The reasons for the breach between Universal and the star has never been disclosed, and the terms of the settlement were also withheld.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Disturbed by a speech by Secretary Wickard, in which he said that farm prices should not go above parity and over the Agriculture Department's plan to halt rising corn and wheat prices, the Senate Agriculture Committee decided today to call Mr. Wickard before it in closed session tomorrow "to explain" his farm-price views.

Carrying important Army papers on his way to La Guardia Field where he was to board a plane for Washington, Colonel Philip L. Gerhardt was killed instantly yesterday morning when the Army automobile in which he was a passenger collided with a Department of Sanitation truck at South and Roosevelt Streets.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy refused yesterday to accept the withdrawal by the Savoy Vending Company, Inc., of its injunction suit to restrain the Police Department from interfering with its pinball machines.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Eire and Third Covey won the principal races today at Hialeah Park, where 12,680 persons turned out for the Miami Jockey Club's War Benefit Day. John Clark, president of the Miami Jockey Club, had as his guests the commanding officers of the adjacent military and naval stations as well as men and women active in the work of the Infantile Paralysis Fund.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -Adolf Hitler, in his Berlin speech today, said, in part:

Major Frank Knowles, air raid zone warden of 2120 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, who was cleared by three other zone wardens after a "court martial" proceeding on charges by a subordinate that his conduct had been "unbecoming an officer of the civilian defense," announced yesterday that he would hand in his resignation today.

Surveys of school pupils and preschool age children in twenty-one cities of the State outside the metropolitan area, to establish plans for evacuating the children to rural areas in air raids, have been started by the State Housing Division, Edward Weinfeld, Housing Commissioner, said yesterday A corresponding survey of New York City children is being handled separately by the Board of Education.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Jan. 30 -Any planning for peace which is to endure, Jonathan Daniels told a Southern post-war planning conference at the University of North Carolina tonight, "must not only preserve the four freedoms but must create in terms of plenty and decency for all mankind, for the man in Mississippi and the man in Malaya.

Keith Morgan, national chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday for the Benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, told Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday that New Yorkers would contribute about $500,000 toward the foundation's 1942 goal of $3,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Roosevelt told "parasites" today to get out of Washington and make room for persons needed for war work. He suggested that Washington newspapers print headlines across the top of their front pages asking the question, "Are You a Parasite?"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A war President, directing the life-or-death struggle of the United States, took time off on his sixtieth birthday anniversary today for luncheon with a 4-year-old boy from New York, a victim of infantile paralysis.

Lynn U. Stambaugh of Fargo, N.D., national commander of the American Legion, told 800 Legionnaires at a Brooklyn luncheon yesterday that it was the duty of Legion members to dispel any thought that the Federal Government was not doing all in its power to win the war.

The council and governing body of the New York Academy of Medicine yesterday took the unprecedented step of publicly dissociating itself from a proposal to permit "open" fee splitting, outlined Monday night by Dr. Maximilian A. Ramirez in his inaugural address as president of the Medical Society of the County of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Roosevelt spent his sixtieth birthday in a round of activity which started with a stirring message from General MacArthur and his embattled men in the Philippines and was marked tonight by a radio broadcast by Mr. Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's radio address tonight to those celebrating his sixtieth birthday:

Benjamin Winter, operator, added yesterday to his holdings of loft properties in Manhattan by purchasing from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company the eleven-story National Building at 826-8 Broadway and 59-63 East Twelfth Street.

On his eightieth birthday Dr. Walter Damrosch was honored yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House by the unveiling of a plaque, and in the evening by a dinner at the American Academy of Arts and Letters, of which he is president, in appreciation of his vital contribution to the musical life of this country.
The crisis of the struggle for Singapore -- and all that Singapore means -- has been reached.

In the largest increase since July, the value of manufacturers' shipments rose to a new peak in December, lifting the index 6 per cent above the November level and 32 per cent over a year earlier, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

Hosiery manufacturers have "reason to believe" that, as nylon supplies are diverted to military uses, they will be allotted increasing quantities of rayon yarns in sufficient amounts to take up the slack, according to Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Information regarding Americans from Wake Island, Guam and the Philippines now held as prisoners of war by the Japanese soon may be available to their relatives, under the terms of an agreement announced here today by Norman H. Davis, national chairman of the American Red Cross.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 30 -- The Japanese invaders tonight had smashed down to within eighteen to twenty miles of Singapore on both the British left and center, and this great menaced base went under military curfew.
WITH THE A.E.F. in Northern Ireland, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -- Uncle Sam's doughboys took their first route march in force today and were greeted by smiling Irish eyes all over the Ulster countryside.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Mrs. Leonard B. Ettelson entertained with a cocktail party at her residence for the Princesses Camilla and Francesca Rospigliosi, who, with their mother, Princess Laura Rospigliosi, are her guests, and for Mr. and Mrs. Pasquale di Cicco.

While "token" air raids are to be expected on cities of the East and West Coasts, attacks from the "enemy within our gates" are a more likely and more important threat, Lieut. Col. Edward B. Towns told 250 volunteer defense speakers yesterday at a "speakers' institute" meeting at the headquarters of the Second Civilian Defense Region, 111 Eighth Avenue.
