Testimony linking three members of the chemistry department of City College with the Fales Chemical Company, 545 Fifth Avenue, was placed in the record yesterday during a Board of Higher Education trial and will be called to the attention of the conduct committee of the board.

Camp Fire Girls are cooking their way to victory. Under this year's program -- Fortifying the Family -many of them are learning at their group meetings just what all this talk of vitamins, minerals and proteins is really about. They are learning, too, how to make out a grocery order that will include these essentials, and what to do with it when they get home.

The hour's torrent of turgid, bitter, repetitious ding-dong that constitutes a Hitler speech ended yesterday without a renewal of the pledge that was given to the German people a year ago. Then Hitler, facing a Britain that stood alone, promised flatly: "The year 1941 will bring consummation of the greatest victory in our history."

Another victim -- the eleventh -- in the underwater battle off the Atlantic Coast was acknowledged last night when the Navy Department announced that the 6,836-ton American oil tanker Rochester had been torpedoed by an enemy submarine, but that survivors had been picked up and were on their way into port.

Abandoned in open court by Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler, who refused to support what he termed an "unseemly squabble," Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, was rebuffed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter after he had argued the case as his own attorney.

VICHY, Jan. 30 -- Three American banks, the Chase, the Guaranty Trust and J.P. Morgan Co., appear on the initial list of foreign banks licensed to do business in France as it was issued by the Committee on Permanent Professional Organization of Banks and Financial Establishments today.

Sharp percentage gains again featured retail trade here this week, despite unfavorable weather on several days. The average sales increase of department stores here was estimated at around 32 per cent over the corresponding week last year.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, in Northern Ireland, Jan. 30 (AP) -- United States forces will soon know British methods and weapons as well as their own and will blend efforts with troops in a combat sector, Major Gen. Russell P. Hartle, commander of the American forces, said today after a tour of the United States bases.

Judge Jonah J. Goldstein yesterday in General Sessions revived the perennial complaint against the rigors of the Baumes crime laws when, in imposing long mandatory prison sentences on two Harlem robbers, he declared the sentence in each case was too severe.

A new Howard Johnson restaurant is planned in the Van Cortlandt area of the Bronx on the west side of Broadway, 75 feet north of 254th Street, where an irregular plot about 75 by 200 feet has been purchased from Augustus Van Cortlandt and Kathleen G. Marcato.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- In firm possession of the railway gate to both the Ukraine granary and the Donets coal basin, the Red Army was reported officially tonight to have outflanked, outknifed and encircled the German enemy in scores of sectors in a master Stalin plan of throwing the Germans from every acre of Russian soil in 1942.

We are not fighting Germany. We are not fighting Japan and Italy. We, rational, thinking people, are fighting an ideology of a host of men throughout the world; a hideous primitive ideology that would once again make men hysterical fanatics governed by their emotions.

International developments of the week, especially the accomplishments of the Inter-American Conference of Foreign Ministers at Rio de Janeiro, will be discussed by clergymen tomorrow in their sermons. Comment will also be made on the celebration of the birthday of President Roosevelt and the campaign against infantile paralysis.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 30 -- Police throughout Brazil today received instructions to imprison persons who favored Germany, Italy and Japan or who distributed Axis literature.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Following is the text of a statement issued by President Roosevelt in connection with his signing of the new price control law:

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30 -With Washington casting about for new sources of revenue for war, the idea of government lotteries as proposed in a bill introduced in Congress has substantial popular support. A nation-wide poll by the American Institute of Public Opinion shows that a majority of Americans with opinions on the subject would approve such lotteries at this time.

The seven cancer committees serving the metropolitan area received last year 53,544 public contributions aggregating $134,765.94, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Francis J. Rigney, commander of the Women's Field Army of the New York City Cancer Committee, at its annual meeting at Town Hall Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The War Production Board announced today that it would make "the most detailed statistical study of the metals industries ever undertaken in this country" among 10,000 manufacturers and said that it would serve as the basis for decisions governing distribution of critical and strategical materials during the calendar quarter beginning April 1.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Prices of hogs reached today their highest levels for a January in fifteen years. Gains ranged from 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight and the top price soared to $12.15. Numerous loads were taken at $12, the previous high mark for 1942. The average cost rose above $11.80, compared with $8.07 a year ago and $5.23 two years ago.

Donald M. Frame, holder of the State title, and Germain G. Glidden, former national and metropolitan champion, qualified last night to meet in the final of the metropolitan squash racquets singles championship at the University Club. Both came through hard and well-played semi-final matches.

Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday there had been a marked drop in civilian automobile traffic in the city in the last few weeks, basing his observation, he declared, on reports made by observers of traffic on the major city bridges and the fact that police served 6,000 less summonses in the first two weeks of 1942 than in the same period in 1941.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 30 -A trial mobilization of State, town and village police agencies from Nassau and Suffolk Counties, to test the speed and efficiency by which law-enforcement units could reach the scene of an emergency, will be held here tomorrow morning at 7:45 o'clock by order of Governor Lehman. It is believed it will be the first experiment of the kind in this part of the State.

Greetings to President Roosevelt on his birthday were voiced in word and song in an hourlong broadcast beginning at 11:15 o'clock last night and carried over four national networks from aircraft and tank factories, a shipyard and ballrooms and broadcasting studios in all regions of the country.

Mayor La Guardia's new two-seated black coupe blossomed out in a girdle of blackout paint at City Hall yesterday, setting the style for other city vehicles that must be on the streets in war emergencies. The Mayor's car appeared with its front and rear bumpers covered with luminous paint of a dull ivory shade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Roosevelt conferred today on the war in the Pacific with Dr. T.V. Soong, Chinese Foreign Minister, and Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Netherlands Foreign Minister, who arrived in this country yesterday from London.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, announced today that his office did not contemplate any increase in the basic fixed maximum price of green coffee, and said that rumors in New York trade quarters that the coffee quota was to be enlarged and prices were going up had hampered the free flow of supplies to this country.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 30 -- In the first hour of President Roosevelt's birthday, Nicaragua began celebrations in his honor.
BERLIN, Jan. 30 (From German broadcast) -- Following are parts of Adolf Hitler's speech today:

The advent of nation-wide daylight saving a week from Monday will bring its problems to the railroads but they are prepared for it, officials said yesterday. They recalled that they met a similar problem in the last war, although it is to be doubted if many of the operating men concerned with the change then are in active service now.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -Adolf Hitler warned today that an "enormous" increase in the number of German submarines would show the United States what these craft could achieve.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Passenger automobile and light truck production came to an end to all practical purposes today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The substantial gain in wholesalers' sales throughout the United States in the first three quarters of 1941 was maintained during the last three months, so that for the year as a whole they were 31 per cent above those in 1940, the Department of Commerce announced today.

With legislative plans in hand whereby the Treasury would be authorized to borrow directly from the Federal Reserve Banks, there appears to be no thought that such procedure would be employed immediately. With excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System now on the downgrade, it is conceivable that the time may not be far distant when the Treasury would borrow from the Reserve Banks directly and avoid tightening the money market.

DUBLIN, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Official concern was felt here today that the arrival of United States troops in neighboring Ulster might be preliminary to seizure of Eire's naval bases that the Allies need badly for the Battle of the Atlantic, an informed source said today.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The First Lord of the Admiralty, Albert V. Alexander, in broadcasting greetings from a concert at His Majesty's Theatre, paid tribute to "the splendid fight" of General Douglas MacArthur in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -Fourteen-year-old "Admiral" James C. Waxley and his command, the "U.S. Naval Club," received official recognition from Secretary Knox today and a commendation for "splendid patriotism."

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- One of the features today in a generally dull market want sharp reaction in the Kaffir market, which was upset by news of sabotage from South Africa. The other markets were subdued, with buyers marking time awaiting fresh news from the Far East.

The management of the Iowa Southern Utilities Company has decided to abandon for the present one phase of its proposed $15,160,000 financing plan, which has been in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for some time, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Federal Communications Commission clamped down today on the construction of new radio broadcasting stations, to conserve materials for defense. Simultaneously Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, established maximum prices for sale by manufacturers of non-commercial radio and television receiving sets, phonographs and radio tubes and parts after Feb. 9.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30 -The Presidential candidacy of General Carlos Ibanez, who is accused by his opponents of being pro-Nazi, has gained considerable ground in the last few days. Betting odds, which previously favored his opponent, Juan Antonio Rios. shortened today to even money.

Ruth Suckow, the Iowa novelist, who has published no novels since "The Folks" in 1934, will have her new one brought out Feb. 23 by Farrar Rinehart under the title "New Hope." It is the story of two years of life in an Iowa town about the turn of the century.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -R.R. Deupree, Cincinnati soap manufacturer, today was elected chairman of the Business Advisory Council of the Commerce Department. Mr. Deupree, who is president of the Procter Gamble Company, succeeded William L. Batt, who declined re-election because of his work in the War Production Board.

Featured by the presence for the third successive week of offerings from local housing authorities, new State and municipal issues scheduled for sale next week will amount to $14,042,447. This compares with $31,459,780 this week and a week ly average of $37,623,706 for the year to date.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -- Japanese gains reported by British Imperial Headquarters in the twenty-four hours since its last communique approximated thirteen miles in the center -- from Layang-Layang to Kulai -- and twenty miles in the west coast area.

One million one hundred thousand students in the city's 745 public schools were authorized yesterday to participate in the Red Cross War Fund drive of Greater New York by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, whose bulletin to principals and teachers said the Junior Red Cross organization in the schools would be allowed to collect the voluntary contributions from students.

The report of the Consolidated !Gas Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore for 1941 ]issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income for the year of $6,701,383. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $4.64 a share on the company's outstanding common stock and compares with a net of $6,255,324, or $4.41 a common share, it. 1940.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 30 (UP) -- A new battle broke out near the Thailand border east of Moulmein today as Japanese and Thai troops resumed their drive toward Rangoon and the Burma Road, but Imperial headquarters reported that the situation still was "well in hand."

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Soy bean prices advanced 3 to 3 1/2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade in the early trading today to a new high record, the July selling at $2.05 1/2. Liberal profit taking developed, however, and the market reacted quickly, with the close at gains of 1/4 to 3/4 cent.

Two items in a day's news give a glimpse of total war, American plan. One is General Hershey's warning that under the selective service system we must "budget" the work of the sixty million able-bodied men and women who will not be in military service. The other item is William L. Shirer's statement that a token bombing of New York City by light Nazi planes, taking off from and returning to Brest, is a possibility.

HAVANA, Jan. 30 -- The Cup of Cuba, for International Star Class yachts, was won by a Cuban boat for the first time since the race was inaugurated when Charles de Cardenas sailed his Kurush II over the line first in the final of the three-race series this afternoon for a total of 17 points.

War is here and now more than ever it is the duty of our schools to prepare our boys for the defense of our country. President Roosevelt recognizes the contribution that athletics make to the all-around physical development of the individual and has urged that there be no curtailment in this program.

HONOLULU, Jan. 29 (delayed) -- The United States land and sea forces in the Pacific areas under his command are constantly being strengthened, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said today in an interview explaining the operation of his authority as supreme commander of all American military arms in the Pacific.

Permit me to congratulate you on your deft handling of Dad Mitchell's inquiry as to why Harvard's decision to make freshmen eligible for varsity athletic competition received more space than a similar decision taken earlier by Brooklyn College.

Winners in the Art Students League semi-annual competition for high school students are announced with awards amounting to a total of $723. The winners include Raymond A. Weiss of Evander Childs, Jessie Joy of Washington Irving, Phil Masnick of De Witt Clinton; Norma Levy of Evander Childs and Concetta, Caceiola of the High School of Music and Art.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Here, to start with, is a most significant item in rounding up information as to how the fight is going in the whole Malaysian area, including the outlook for Singapore.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 30 -- It has become known here that Axis agents in Mexico are systematically propagandizing by word of mouth the rumor that when the United States occupies Mexican ports and airfields it will soon afterward occupy Mexico City.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

A youngster inspired to become a champion figure skater after watching Felix Kaspar win the world crown at Prague in 1938 yesterday became the men's Eastern States novice titleholder in the competition at the Iceland Rink.

One thousand members of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Parish, 207 East Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn gathered last night to honor their sexton and superintendent of buildings, John C. Tiedeman, on his completion of fiftyyears of service to the church.

"New Wine," which will have its local premiere today at the Little Carnegie Playhouse, completes the week's list of new film arrivals. Produced by William Sekely, the United Artists release, which is a romantic dramatization of the life of Franz Schubert, stars Ilona Massey and Alan Curtis.

Despite increased taxes, earnings of the Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries in 1941 more than doubled those of the previous year, according to the preliminary annual report announced yesterday. Consolidated net income amounted to $16,532,540 after Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions.

Today's events: "Rigoletto," 2 P.M., and "Phoebus and Pan" and "Le Coq d'Or," 8 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Jan Kiepura, tenor, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Prudence Reehl, soprano, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30 P.M.; orchestra of the Juilliard School of Music, Concert Hall, 130 Claremont Avenue, 8:30 P.M.

Adolf Hitler came to power on Franklin Roosevelt's birthday, and never since has the President been able to celebrate the occasion without the growling accompaniment of a Hitler speech. Worse, it's always the same speech. Nine years ago the new Chancellor began explaining how it happened, and he has been at it ever since.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Lakin Baldridge gave dinner last night in their apartment in the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Sylvia B. Follett and Mr. Baldridge's son, Russell Young Baldridge, whose marriage will take place this afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

A youngster inspired to become a champion figure skater after watching Felix Kaspar win the world crown at Prague in 1938 yesterday became the men's Eastern States novice titleholder in the competition at the Iceland Rink.

It will be best for the peace of mind and physical well-being of Gus Lesnevich, the world's light-heavyweight champion from Cliffside Park, N.J., if he puts aside, temporarily, at least, any thought of a ring meeting with the Brown Bomber known as Joe Louis.

The reduction in trading that has been spreading in the stock market for two weeks brought business yesterday to the lowest level since Oct. 1 of last year, while price alterations were so small that nothing conclusive could be drawn from the session.

The Southern fishing is now approaching its peak, according to a letter just received from Ernie Lyons of Stuart, Fla., who reports that most of the boats fishing out of the St. Lucie Inlet are returning with from ten to fifteen sailfish flags flying.

About 278,000 German, Italian and Japanese nationals above the age of 14 who have not acquired full United States citizenship are expected by Department of Justice officials to apply to local postoffices for certificates of identification, it was announced yesterday.

Since 1933, the fatal year of Hitler's ascent to dictatorship, some 5,600 physician have fled to this country from persecution abroad. Now that the armed forces are draining the universities, hospitals and private offices of the younger doctors, we need these men. Yet from their first appearance obstacles have been put in their way, especially in rural communities where there have never been physicians enough.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -President Roosevelt reported today that although WPA employment as a whole was declining steadily, an increasing percentage of relief workers were doing defense jobs.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- President Roosevelt's birthday was celebrated in London today at a tea party in Grosvenor House attended by representatives of twenty-six united nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -Secretary Ickes declared in a statement addressed to the oil-producing States and the petroleum industry today that "it is extremely essential from the standpoint of promoting the war effort" that the oil production rates certified for each producing State "be met by every State without delay."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Roosevelt asked citizens of the United States today to continue to make sacrifices for foreign relief through recognized organizations such as those approved by the committee headed by Joseph E. Davies, former diplomat.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Prime Minister Churchill, Mrs. Churchill and John G. Winant, United States Ambassador, attended a memorial service for the Duke of Connaught, the King's great uncle -- at Westminster Abbey today.

Even in time of war the work of the private welfare agencies must be maintained intact, lest the marginal population of this city be left without its surest protection and its most helpful friends. This permanent need in a changing world is emphasized in the annual report of The Community Service Society, the largest private family welfare organization in the country.

THE NEW YORK TIMES comments editorially this morning as follows: "Retail merchants, particularly those who operate department stores, are making the complaint that business is too brisk. They are anxious about panic-buying which they think is chiefly responsible for a retail sales volume running close to 50 per cent above that of a year ago."

Brooding because she was dependent on public relief, "the most harrowing experience imaginable," Melissa Tilford, 28 years old, attempted suicide yesterday in her furnished room at 223 East Seventy-second Street, after writing to newspapers how and why she was taking the step.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, told the Federal Communications Commission today that discrimination against newspapers in the licensing of radio stations would be "a first step away from sound democratic principles."

A farmer who operates a farm for profit, the Bureau of Internal Revenue explained yesterday is entitled to deduct from gross income as necessary expenses all amounts expended (other than those constituting capital expenditure) in the carrying on of the business of farming.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The President approved today the list of fifteen captains named for promotion to rear admiral. The officers are:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -The "victory suit" is definitely coming, but an unsettled question is whether it should have two pairs of pants.

Plans for expanding the new York branch of the Allstate Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co., were announced yesterday when the concern leased the eighth floor in the Masonic Building, at the northeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 30 -- There was a line-up of seven owners of sloops practically certain to race again next Summer on Long Island Sound, when plans were talked over tonight at the annual meeting of the Victory Class Association at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

New bond financing this week dropped sharply from the record volume of the preceding period, as only two issues with a total volume of $6,150,000 were placed on the market. This compared with $152,835,000 in new bonds offered last week and with $18,240,000 marketed in this week a year ago.

Three hundred and seventy-four youths in the khaki uniform of the High School of Aviation Trades last night received diplomas that will ultimately send many of them into the war production plants and to flying fields in combat areas.

An accelerated three-year program for the medical degree has been adopted by the five medical colleges in New York City, it was announced yesterday. This was done, college officials declared, in response to the need for the training of a large number of men in medicine to take the places of those called into service.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., Jan. 30 -Williams College took the team and individual honors today in the cross-country race that marked the first day of the Williams Carnival ski meet, transplanted to Woodstock's slopes because of poor snow conditions at Williamstown, Mass.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., Jan. 30 -Williams College took the team and individual honors today in the cross-country race that marked the first day of the Williams Carnival ski meet, transplanted to Woodstock's slopes because of poor snow conditions at Williamstown, Mass.

A British broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday quoted a Russian Air Force general as saying that the Germans were now operating in formations of twenty to thirty planes, instead of 100 to 150 as formerly, because the German Air Force was unable to cope with Winter conditions.
The three remaining active ships of the Eastern Steamship Lines, the George Washington, Robert E. Lee and Madison, have been requisitioned by the government for war routes.

Plans for expanding the new York branch of the Allstate Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co., were announced yesterday when the concern leased the eighth floor in the Masonic Building, at the northeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

AT the concert tomorrow by the Bach Circle, Bach, the oft-transcribed, will be heard in one of his important works for harpsichord as transcriber. This is only fitting, since, of course, no one was more industrious in the transcription of works by himself and others than Bach.

WHITE PLANS, N.Y., Jan., 31 -- Officers of the Westchester League of Women Voters and of the Federation of Westchester Taxpayers Associations announced their opposition today to the plan of the county's dominant Republican organization to seek equality of representation for communities on the County Board of Supervisors by adjusting the voting power of each supervisor to correspond with the size of the population he represents.

A SHARED sense of danger has stirred the peoples of the North and South American countries and set us wondering about one another. We are trying to take one another's measure. Certain questions weave through the diplomatic combinations, the military consultations, the planned pools of money and materials and knowledge.

There are some things that women should bear in mind when contemplating. Spring purchase of town coats-quality and style. While no one can prophesy whaty the future holds in store for the fabric market, it is reasonably certain that many of the fine woolens now on hand will not be available next year. The are to be bought and treasured for long range wear.

A procedure for recommending deferment of military training for students, based mainly on the individual's scholarship rating, progress toward a degree and his general evaluation and special qualifications as a potentially "necessary'' man, has been put into effect by Columbia University, Edward J. Grant, registrar, reported yesterday.

This laconic announcement was made yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Arthur Ernest Percival, commander of British Empire forces in the crucial fighting on the tip of southeastern Asia. Under cover of darkness on Friday night, weary Aussies, Tommies and Indian troops had streamed over the causeway that links Singapore Island to the Malay Peninsula.

THE "tears" from which Miss Webster would free Shakespeare are those shed by library and schoolroom students; and, as is fitting in the director of Maurice Evans's most enjoyable ventures, she would give us instead the delights of practical, though by no means unscholarly, productions in the theatre.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- Henry Ford has threatened the Ku Klux Klan with legal action if it does not cease the publication of anti-Semitic literature in association with his name, it was made known tonight by I.A. Capizzi, Mr. Ford's attorney.
WHATEVER hopes Mayor La Guardia and certain independent film producers might have entertained about setting up a miniature Hollywood in New York were finally and completely crushed last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Evicting the "parasites" -- those who live in Washington for pleasure only -- to make room for war workers in this bursting city is the President's semi-serious suggestion, and its appeal will be widespread. But even if the definition of parasite could be perfected, and all who belong in that category could be sent outside the capital, the problem to which the President was addressing himself Friday will be little diminished.

INTRODUCING a spice of variety into the menu is a sure cure for the February doldrums. A new dish will give the same lift to a meal -- and to those who eat it -- that a woman gets from a new Spring bonnet. And dinner becomes an adventure if it takes you a bit off the beaten track.

ALTHOUGH aircraft production figures are now classed as military secrets, it is no violation of government orders to report that the production of airplanes of all types, and engines to power them, is increasing from day to day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and chairman of its Steel Workers Organizing Committee, charged today that scrap brokers and some members of the steel industry have created an artificial scrap shortage in order to drive scrap prices upward and resist expansion of steel ingot production capacity.
THIS book is only half described by its subtitle -- and until you look through it you can have no idea how interesting it is.

JENKINTOWN, Pa., Jan. 31 -- In response to many requests of girls at Beaver College for practical courses in foods and nutrition for those students outside the home economics and allied departments, Dean Ruth L. Higgins has announced two non-credit courses in food preparation and nutrition.

TORONTO, Jan. 31 -- The Boston Bruins gained undisputed leadership of the National Hockey League tonight by beating the third-place Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 2, in overtime. The victory gave the Bruins a two-point margin over the New York Rangers.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 31 -- Dr. Arthur de Souza Costa, Minister of Finance, will go to Washington on Monday accompanied by Valentim F. Boucas, it was announced today.

Two veteran inspectors of the United States customs service retired yesterday after long careers on the New York waterfront. Both were staff officers assigned to board vessels entering the port and supervise the landing of passenger luggage and cargo.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Because this war is regarded as a battle of production, one of the big issues of 1942 is certain to be the length of the work week. How many hours a week must Americans work to win the war?

Hailed as the greatest skater New York has had in a generation, 13-year-old Dorothy Goos was crowned women's Eastern States figure-skating champion at the end of a two-day test at the Iceland rink yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 (AP) -- More assembly lines were ripped out of automobile production today to be replaced by machinery adapted to the manufacture of aviation engines, tank parts and aircraft subassemblies. Machines designed to stamp out sheet metal were moved out to make room for equipment to process armor plate.

RAINER MARIA RILKE is the greatest modern German poet, unless he has some unknown competitor. Miss Babette Deutsch translates fourteen poems from his early work Das Stundenbuch, written around 1900. The German is printed on one page and the English on the other.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 -- Victories in their respective breeds by several prominent eastern canine campaigners were among the highlights today as the twenty-ninth annual Maryland Kennel Club dog show opened at the Fifth Regiment Armory.

The Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland at the-end had net assets equivalent to $471 for each share of Class A preferred stock, against $583 at the end of 1940, it was announced yesterday. After caring for the preferred, assets remaining to the common stock were equivalent to $7.15 a share, against $9.33 at the end of 1940.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Sumner Welles, Under Secretary of State, returned today by air from Rio de Janeiro where he was a delegate of the United States at the Conference of Foreign Ministers of the twenty-one American republics and expressed satisfaction over the results of the conference.

The John H. Finley memorial lectures, a series of four bi-weekly public talks by leading economists and government officials, will open in City College, 139th Street and Convent Avenue, on Wednesday at 8:30 P.M., it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- Now that the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association has stamped its approval on the date of March 14 for the eighth annual race meet of the Sandhill Steeplechase and Racing Association, at the Barber estate course, the Spring season in the North Carolina sandhills will be marked with two major horse events.

A small specimen tree on lawns or in a conspicuous location in landscape planting, which often attracts attention and an inquiry as to its name, is the Silk-tree -- Albizzia Julibrissin to the botanists. While fairly hardy, it is tropical in appearance, and often called a mimosa because its leaves resemble those of the sensitive plant.

An Army recreation activity that began unpretentiously at Camp Custer, Mich., has produced pictures of Army life by soldiers of so much interest that the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has brought the collection to New York for public display beginning next Wednesday.
WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES ON BATAAN PENINSULA, Jan. 29 (Delayed) -- American fighting planes and pilots remaining in this area may be few, but they still pack a wallop.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The battered and diminished American-Filipino forces of General Douglas MacArthur again have hurled back and frustrated determined Japanese attempts to infiltrate their Bataan Peninsula lines, and have taken some prisoners as well.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -- Axis agents in East Coast ports may be tipping off German submarines to the movement of American and Allied ships in Atlantic sea lanes, according to reports that tonight reached Chairman Martin Dies, of the House Committee on un-American Activities.

The anti-aggressor portion of the war-wracked world found time last Friday to celebrate a man's birthday. In communities of the United States 12,540 parties were held in his honor and to raise funds for the victims of infantile paralysis, a project he has long promoted.

Investigation of the progress of the defense effort and the conduct of the war is one of the most essential functions that a Congressional or Presidential committee can perform. A week ago the public received from the Roberts Commission, appointed by the President, a brilliant light on the disaster at Pearl Harbor.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 31 -- That enormous area vaguely known as the Middle East, poised between the active battlefields of Africa and the Far East, is now being subjected to a wide-spread Axis propaganda barrage designed not only to fertilize the traditional seeds of discontent which have been sprouting in the Islamic world for the past two decades but to prepare the machinery for fomenting wholesale disorders to accompany potential invasions.

Several new feature exhibits will be included in the 1942 National Sportsmen's Show, which will run from Feb. 21 to March 1 at Grand Central Palace, according to an announcement from the Campbell-Fairbanks Expositions, sponsor of the affair.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- A team race between four American and four Cuban yachts, the final event of the sixteenth International Star Class regatta, was won today by the Americans with a total of 21 points to the Cubans' 15.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Japanese troops are in full retreat toward Canton tonight after being defeated in a five-day battle with Chinese forces east of the city, a Chinese communique said tonight.

I DON'T know very much about writing articles. The last one I wrote was for a military organ called the Parkfield Air Gnat. This was in 1918. I was asked for 300 words of humor and they printed it anyway because they were short of material. The paper expired right after that and I did not write again until 1928, except letters of condolence and requests to my father for money.

How the gains made in public education may be protected and extended during the present war will be considered this week by the Teachers Guild Associates, a citizen group which is completing twenty years of service to New York City schools.

Many of the suits currently in store windows are tailored to the point of severity and will be good backgrounds for something dashing in the way of accessories. One item in that category most spirited in new Spring versions is gloves. Eyen if you're still in the stage of saving up for a Spring suit, gloves can help greatly in making an ensemble look as if something new had been added.

THE Borough of Brooklyn is many miles from Buenos Aires and a play by Pirandello is a far cry from the Joseph Kesselring comedy, "Arsenic and Old Lace," yet these obvious facts are the reasons for a startling revival of the theatre in South America.

The old-time practice of growing tuberoses in a sunny window, now unfortunately rarely followed, might well be revived. All that is needed, according to my experience, is blooming-size tubers, a warm, sunny window, and a little patience.

Murder on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House is no rare occurrence, but usually the corpse comes to life in time to come before the curtain and take a bow. Not so with Erich von Oedischer, the German bass-baritone who plays the part of Mephisto in the performance described in this book.

ON Nov. 24 last year the Supreme Court of the United States handed down a momentous decision in the "Okie" case, that of Fred F. Edwards v. the People of the State of California. A Texan, unemployed and indigent, had been brought to California in violation of the law of that State.

Birthday tributes to President Roosevelt and prayers for his health were offered by rabbis here yesterday. His victory over infantile paralysis was cited as a special source of inspiration to Americans.

I was interested to read in the current issue of The Publishers Weekly that the Readers Club has selected as its current book "Henry Ward Beecher: An American Portrait," by Paxton Hibben, apparently the only new feature being an introduction by Sinclair Lewis.

New securities offered to the public in this market in January were the largest in volume for any month since last May, although somewhat less than in January last year. Bond flotations, which were the largest since May, were more than double the amount marketed in December, while stock emissions were the biggest since last July.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Scoring easily and powerfully by three lengths in time that set a new grass track record, Sir Marlboro today captured the $6,460 Miami Beach Handicap in 1:44 4-5, for a mile and a sixteenth. A crowd of 11,016 watched the 6-year-old son of Swift and Sure carry the silks of Mrs. J. Eitinger to their first victory of this scope.

THIS fellow Preston Sturges is like the United States Cavalry; whenever things are looking shaky, he always comes charging up. Away back in the Summer of 1940, at a moment when the screen was languishing for want of a vital new craftsman to give it a little jolt, Mr. Sturges came romping to the rescue with his first outstanding film, "The Great McGinty."

AFTER moderating somewhat, the surge of "scare buying" turned upward again in the week as the news was received on rationing developments. Retailers found the demand spreading through all articles of wool, rubber and metal.

Tax reform is not expected to make headway in a time of emergency. When pressure for revenue runs high, legislators are generally content with getting the most out of existing levies, and with readopting measures which have served past emergencies.

The United States Department of Justice yesterday warned all aliens of enemy nationalities that they must apply at postoffices nearest their place of residence for certificates of identification, and that failure to do so may be punished by severe penalties, including possible internment for the duration of the war.

THE freight train is a long one -- so long that motorists at the grade crossing cut their ignition and resign themselves to counting the cars; seventy, eighty, ninety, and perhaps forty more before the cabin car, alias "caboose," trundles past. Mile-long loaded trains are a commonplace in the United States this year.

Once again Wall Street is buckling on its armor for another tax- reduction crusade on Albany. There have been three crusades, all won in the Legislature and all lost in the Governor's mansion. This year Wall Street is hoping again. It thinks it can by-pass Governor Lehman.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- "For those who expected that the Chancellor Fuehrer would seize this occasion to strengthen internal morale in Germany by some concrete assertions of victorious probabilities, Hitler's speech came as a severe disappointment * * *," says the Tribune de Lausanne.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A unified war command for the entire Pacific under an American naval officer was advocated today by Walter Nash, newly arrived Minister from New Zealand.

The philanthropic projects of Greenwich House, a settlement at 27 Barrow Street, will be aided by two benefit entertainments within the next few weeks. The first of these is a "Valentine for Victory" party to be given on the night of Feb. 13, eve of St. Valentine's Day, at Le Coq Rouge.

THE twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers, which will include more than 370 examples of graphic art, will be held this year in the National Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue, opening on Feb. 11 and continuing through the month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- George A. Renard, acting chief of the War Production Board's printing and publishing branch, said today there appeared to be sufficient newsprint and black ink for ordinary needs of publishers of newspapers, magazines, books, etc., but that a cut of "probably" 25 per cent would have to be made in the consumption of colored inks.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Princeton's basketball team inaugurated its Eastern Intercollegiate League campaign in auspicious fashion by routing Yale, 59 -- 24, tonight in the university gymnasium before 1,500 spectators.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The management of the world-champion Boston Bruins announced today that the team's Kitchener Line -- Milt Schmidt, Bobby Bauer and Woody Dumart -- had been granted leave of absence from the Royal Canadian Air Force until Feb. 14.

BEFORE the war, the early Sunday morning news from Tokyo used to reach New York in time to make the Saturday afternoon papers. Now that there is war in the Pacific, some of these days you may read that a Japanese fleet steaming toward Hawaii on Sunday morning was met and routed by an American fleet twelve hours later on Saturday night.

PAUL HENRY LANG, in his provocative article "Our Musical Life," published in THE TIMES of Jan. 25, suggests that it is through chamber music, choral compositions, opera of the chamber variety and works scored for small orchestra that the American composer will come into his own.
The submarine is one of war's most terrible weapons. It skulks below the surface, waiting for its chance to launch torpedoes containing hundreds of pounds of explosives at an enemy ship.

AT AN ATLANTIC PORT, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The second mate of the 7,236-ton tanker Pan Maine, which outmanoeuvred an attack by a submarine, declared today that if the two vessels had been any closer he would have given orders to ram the undersea craft.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Sixty non-commissioned officers were guests of members of the Sun and Surf Club at tonight's opening dinner dance on the oceanfront terrace for which part of the proceeds were for Aid America, Inc.

Abraham Lincoln's two most celebrated observations do not always dwell together in some minds. A man will fervently subscribe to government of the people, by the people, and for the people. That same man will go on to assert, openly or tacitly, that you can fool all of the people all of the time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The American automobile industry, chief pride of a nation dedicated to a mass production, low-cost economy, admittedly holds a most important card in the international poker game which will determine continuance of the American way.

The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1941 a consolidated net income of $4,283,697 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. The net was equal to $6.53 each on 656,000 shares of capital stock and compared with $3,035,606, or $4.63 a capital share, in 1940.

The second Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Trophy was retired from competition yesterday as Barringer High School's fencing team of Newark swept through the final round of the ninth annual high and prep school tourney sponsored by the Washington Square College of New York University on the strips of the East Building.

A century and a half ago Colonel Shoemaker of Pottsville hauled nine wagonloads of hard coal into Philadelphia, but could sell only two. In 1923 production reached its all-time high of more than 93,000,000 tons. By 1940 this total had fallen to a little more than 49,000,000 tons.

To their long list of books which tell of many different breeds of dogs with understanding and imagination, Margaret and Helen Johnson have now added this tale of a Norwegian elkhound. In the remote wilderness of Northern Scandinavia Rolf was born, son of Kari, the sturdy gray dog who was the pride of her Lapp owner.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- Although war wounds are of a severer character than those in the last war, the use of prophylactics and early treatment with sulfanilimides are considerably reducing deaths and permanent maiming. That is the view of Professor M.O. Friedland, chief military surgeon at Moscow's Botkin Hospital, where most of the 2,350 beds are available to the war wounded.

VITAL links are missing the system of expressways metropolitan New York must have to accommodate the motor age. But the picture is vastly different from that of fifteen years ago. Then even the idea of a system was lacking and the prevailing "thought" was to let the motor age shift for itself to reach the metropolis.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 31 -- A New Zealand field ambulance officer who was captured by the Germans but escaped reports that many Italians are so anxious to get out of the war that they are injuring themselves in the hope that they will be sent back to Italy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Charged with directing counter-attacks on all organisms producing disease, a new medical "General Headquarters," complete with detector, counter-espionage and combat commands and combat teams has been organized by Major Gen. James C. Magee, Surgeon General of the Army, the War Department announced today.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 31 -- Dartmouth defeated Army's basketball team tonight in a spirited, rough game that see-sawed back and forth until the final ten minutes. Then the Indians ceased trading baskets with the West Pointers and drove to a 47-38 triumph.

THE tides of war swept Michele Morgan and Paul Henreid to Hollywood. The 22-year-old French girl, who played opposite Charles Boyer and Jean Gabin in Gallic films, fled Paris at the oncoming of the German tanks, motored to Cerebere on the Spanish frontier and planed to Barcelona, whence she took passage here on the last voyage of the Excalibur before our government commandeered it.

THREE books on the background of the Pacific war are to be published on Feb. 16 by Alfred A. Knopf. One of them, "The Japanese Enemy," by Hugh Byas, describes Japan's social and political organization, shows how the Japanese mind works, who are the real rulers of the nation, what is their master-plan for the war, and what we must do to defeat them.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 31 -- Dispatches from Berlin by Swedish newspaper correspondents in connection with Adolf Hitler's latest speech suggest -- in so far as it can be done from there -- that the Sportspalast meeting was just another "command performance" patterned on all the earlier ones, with Herr Hitler's hand picked audience registering thunderous applause for selected passages.

SINCE Hanya Holm is not planning to give a Broadway performance this season, it was necessary for those who wished to see her new work, "From This Earth," to go down to the Washington Irving High School last week.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 31 -- Yale's swimmers swept every event today to defeat the Naval Academy tankmen by 59 to 16. It was the Blue's fourth straight victory of the season and its second in the Eastern Intercollegiate League. The Elis now hold the undisputed lead in the circuit.

THE Copyright Division of the Library of Congress again finds diminishing activity on the part of the playwrights, thus aligning itself with the managers and actors -- every one, in fact, save the dramatists. For in the calendar year 1941 it allowed copyrights on only 5,188 potential plays and musical shows, in English or in other languages, that number being a considerable drop from 1940.

Manhattan Beach, on the ocean-front near Coney Island, and known for more than half a century as a recreation center, has been chosen by the Navy Department as the site for development of a recruit training center for the Coast Guard.

EARLY in that tranquil year of 1940, during the rehearsals of a play of mine, "Night Music," I felt the need of keeping a daily journal. It seemed to me an interesting idea to keep an informal daily notation of rehearsal progress.

"The German radio station broadcasts the news at 8 P.M., to which we must listen * * * And at 9 P.M. the English station comes in with the news. If you change to the end of the hour we would only have to go to the radio once at 8:45 P.M." So wrote a German short-wave listener to the National Broadcasting Company.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Adopting a suggestion made by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, the Social Museum of Vassar College has created a graphic exhibit to illustrate the American principle of freedom for all races, nationalities and religions.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The British, Far East Command issued this communique today:

A BEAUTIFUL woman turned to nod good-bye. "There's a fine girl," said George Jean Nathan. "Do you know her? She was the great love of (so-and-so's) later life. Made all his funeral arrangements . . . ." He seemed to find it difficult to talk about himself.

ON Sunday evening, Nov. 9, 1941, at 10:30 P.M., we crossed our fingers and gave the opening cue, and the Government of the United States was on the air. Tonight at 10:59:30 we shall have completed the first thirteen weeks' cycle of this series.

QUARRYVILLE, Pa. -- Ground-Hog Day will be celebrated here tomorrow with mock pomp and homespun humor by Slumbering Ground-Hog Lodge, a 36-year-old organization of wits under the leadership of Quarryville's banker, hardware merchant and sage, George W. Hensel Jr.

TOSCANINI will conduct the Philadelphia Orchestra at its sixth New York concert of the season, Tuesday night, Feb. 10, in Carnegie Hall. The program will consist of Tehaikovsky's Sixth symphony, the Ballade and Polonaise, Op. 38, of Vieuxtemps, which will be performed by fourteen violins; the "Queen Mab" scherzo from Berlioz's "Romeo and Juliet" and Debussy's "La Mer."

Since basic cost justification is at the foundation of the new Price Control Act, industry will have to prepare more detailed analyses of operating figures in terms of products, territories, customers and methods of distribution, Victor H. Stempf, chairman of the committee on public information of the American Institute of Accountants, writes in the current issue of the organization's publication, the Journal of Accountancy, out this week.

I READ recently Mr. Schnabel's recently article in THE TIMES on the alleged neglect of Schubert's piano compositions, especially his sonatas. Now it is certainly not in my mind to concern myself with an evaluation of Schubert's masterpieces, songs, piano of instrumental works.
More than 2,500,000 pounds of sugar or three and one half tons daily probably is wasted yearly in New York City, Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, estimated yesterday.

IT took a war to give private flying its biggest job. In the form of the Civil Air Patrol, now under intensive organization in every State, the task ranks third in the air to military and commercial aviation. Before the emergency ends, it may challenge job No. 2 -- the airlines.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 31 -- The farmer has a job to do in this war of which he is not yet fully aware. This is the appraisal of a farm expert who does not himself farm but is in constant contact with farmers and believes he is in a position to estimate their relationship to the national scheme both objectively and subjectively.

The glee club of the New York Junior League will present its annual benefit concert on Friday night in the Great Hall of the clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The proceeds as for many years past will be used to advance the musical therapy work of the glee club in hospitals throughout the city.
ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 31 -- When members of the Woman's Club of Orange observe founders' day with a luncheon Tuesday they will mark the seventieth anniversary of the organization.

Schools and colleges throughout the country were called upon last week to place greater emphasis in the classroom and lecture halls on the role of Japan and the Far East in modern society. Ignorance of the philosophy, culture and language of our Pacific enemy was termed a threat to American welfare and world security.

The Lotos Club, whose formal dinners have been an institution in this city since 1872, devoted its first dinner of the year to a celebration of the centenary of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York last night.

Social welfare problems as affected by war conditions will be under discussion by delegates from more than 200 clubs meeting on Friday for the Winter convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs. In an all-day session at the Hotel Astor, they will hear late developments in this field on a program to be presented by Mrs. Jean Smalbach, chairman of the federation's social welfare department.

Complete reorganization of Briarcliff Junior College, to bring it closer to the community and add new courses in defense, is planned by Clara M. Tead, new president, who assumes her office tomorrow. Located at Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., the institution became a junior college in 1933.

STRANGE how things sometimes happen. When George Gershwin's opera, "Porgy and Bess," was first sung in 1935, it was not a commercial success. It ran for 124 performances -- a good record for successive performances of an opera, but not good according to the standards of a Broadway musical show. It did not earn back the cost of production.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The British, Middle East Command communique today follows:

How best to serve the community in wartime is the question now facing the American college. On a thousand campuses this question is being answered by resolute actions. And while educators are introducing new courses, changed calendars and special curricula to help build a great military machine, they are not forgetting that the democratic ideals fostered by liberal education must be the main driving power in a confident nation's march toward victory.

The famous Vanderbilt mansion at 640 Fifth Avenue, one of New York's midtown landmarks, will be opened again for a benefit cause on the night of Feb. 11 when a diversified entertainment will be given to augment the Red Cross War Fund. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt has donated the use of her home for the fete, which will include a bridge tournament, towie, gin-rummy, general dancing and supper.

Commissioner Charles G. Steele of the National outboard Racing Broad has a word of cheer for outboard drivers. He has Been assigning the coveted low racing numbers for 1942 but plans to give the pilots only about three more weeks to apply.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Jan. 31 -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis and Miss Carmelita Landry of Fitchburg, Mass., appeared to have good chances of retaining their senior men's and women's titles at the close of today's events in the national outdoor speed skating championships.

ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- Cornell University has in operation a miniature Institute of Public Opinion designed to study the impact of the war on student psychology and to find a basis for morale building within the democratic framework of the campus.

Jane Tompkins writes of animals in their natural surroundings with knowledge and imagination. Once more choosing two individual animals (her "Beaver Twins," "Penguin Twins" and "Polar Bear Twins" are well-known and popular with children), this time two snowshoe rabbits in the northern forests, the author tells their life story.

Harold J. Laski's letter in THE TIMES of Jan. 18, written for the purpose of impressing upon the American people "the urgency, at this time, not merely of realizing the paramount importance of victory, but of the ends for which that victory is attained," and the principles which he states we must accept as the "inarticulate major premises' of our thinking," has given me much food for thought.

In an endeavor to provide a national example for an ideal Y, the women's war work division of the Y.M.C.A. is offering an outstanding program of activities for service men stationed at Fort Jay, Governors Island, one of the few such centers in the country on a military reservation.
The Clyde-Mallory Line, one of the last remaining coastwise steamship lines in operation, has decided to suspend operations because of the scarcity of tonnage, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- A Presidential announcement which in effect would cause the government to fill its requirements from accumulated supplies of grain and cotton taken over on defaulted loans to farmers resulted today in sharp declines in prices of grains and soy beans on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The War Production Board today allocated 900,530 tons of steel and 2,250 tons of copper to the nation's railroads to meet their maintenance of way and structural requirements in the first three months of 1942.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Feb. 1 -- The Russian Army has captured Berestovoya, about 115 miles west of German-held Taganrog and thirty miles north of the Sea of Azov, in a smashing blow threatening the Southern Ukraine anchor of the German defense lines, the army newspaper Red Star reported today in a dispatch from the front.

The mounting agony of France in unoccupied as well as in occupied territory, is revealed in private letters to this country. Conditions in the occupied sections are retailed by visitors who cross into the unoccupied section, where they are more safely written down.

Proof that the seeding in the Monte M. Sterling squash tennis tournament, annual fixture at the New York Athletic Club, had been done with thoroughness was furnished yesterday when all eight seeded players came through their first-round matches successfully.

NOTHING that automobile insurance this year costs 3.5 per cent more in thirty-four States as a result of higher accident claims rates in 1941 among insured drivers, the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators expresses concern over the size of concurrent gains among uninsured drivers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 31 -- The capture of Bengazi may have a pleasant sound to German ears, but that little seaport is not the gateway to Cyrenaica. Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's drive into the edge of the Jebel el-Achdar, or Green Mountain, region thus far has been most successful because of a series of circumstances that worked in favor of the Axis forces.

VICHY, France, Jan. 31 -- Today's Cabinet meeting, in so far as it was reported in the official communique, was devoted to economic questions and the crisis of food supplies. There was no mention of Vice Premier Admiral Francois Darlan's report on his recent trip to Paris.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Along the easterly drop of Bearfort Mountain, on the shore of the elongated lake here, fifty-one ice boats were lined up today ready to race for the 1942 championships of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Navy called upon the youths in American high schools today to take a direct and vital part in the training of its fast-growing air service.

In THE TIMES of Jan. 27 attention was drawn to the renewed short-cutting of women's hair as in the last war. On the other hand, hairdressers from all parts of the country report an unmistakable tendency to baldness in our younger women. In proof of it, recent measurements of their hair growth have revealed deficiencies up to 55 per cent from what women of similar ages grew nineteen years ago.

AT a famous recreational center near Moscow, in a park that a Baedeker of former years described as "a favorite resort of the lower classes on Sundays," thousands of Soviet troops are taking intensive courses in skiing and ski fighting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The dramatic and portentous announcement that United States troops had landed this week in Northern Ireland, coupled with President Roosevelt's statement that six, eight or ten American expeditionary forces already were operating in various parts of the world, served notice that this country's war policy is rapidly being executed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Civil Air Patrol will take over local patrol duties, courier flights and plane ferry service for the armed forces, releasing Army and Navy fliers for active war service, under plans announced tonight by Earle L. Johnson, executive officer of the patrol.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 31 (Reuter) -- Disorder is rife in Hong Kong under the Japanese, according to Hu Lin, general manager of the Chinese newspaper Ta Kung Pao, who recently escaped to Free China.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 31 (Netherlands Indies news agency) The Netherlands Indies Armed Serving issued this communique today:

POINTING make-believe weapons at loving mothers, racing up and down the block uttering hideous cries, drilling with broomsticks, piling a planeload of "bombs" -- children are "playing war." Parents want them to stop.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- On the day after American troops had landed in Northern Ireland, they were officially designated as the United States Army Forces in the British Isles. This, even when shortened to U.S.A.F.B.I. for headline purposes, remains unwieldy.

All records for the registration of pure-bred dogs were broken during the year 1941, according to figures compiled from the studbook of the American Kennel Club and announced yesterday by the governing body. Total registration for all recognized breeds was 88,000.
Here are romance and murder mystery with a background of army life in London during the long cruel months of 1940-41. A minor but not the least interesting aspect

CONVINCED of the vital importance of music for the preservation and strengthening of the morale of our people during the war, the National Music Council, through its committee on wartime activities, has drafted a comprehensive program for the nation-wide use of music, a carefully worked out list of civilian, military and general objectives.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 31 -- Weary British Imperials gave up the fight on the Malaya mainland today and withdrew into the hot, tight little island of Singapore for a long and wasting siege unless reinforcements arrive to reverse the tide of Japanese conquest.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 31 -- A freshman course in English which is intended to bring to American history and life the peculiar services of literature, to vivify, humanize and dramatize history, begins this term at Western Reserve University.

HOW long does it take to fall in love? Hollywood's answer to that question is "But immediately!" Streamlined, fever-pitch, immediate romance still is the trend in films today. Just look at the evidence.

PAINTINGS by Guy Pene duBois have been placed on view at Eraushaar's there to remain through the festival of St. Valentine. Incidentally, should you be looking around for some very exceptional valentines this year, you might find just what you want in the series of small oils on paper. Some of these little oils are captivating.

A group of women of prominence, with Mrs. Samuel L.M. Barlow as chairman, is assisting with arrangements for the recital to be given by Joseph Szigeti, violinist, on the night of Feb. 25 at Carnegie Hall, as a benefit for the British War Relief Society.

Work of the Y.W.C.A. in foreign countries and reports from the American staff abroad will be reviewed at the annual dinner meeting of the foreign division of the national board of the association to be held on Friday at headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue.

SWEET BRIAR, Va., Jan. 31 -- A course on interpretation of the news as it appears in the public press will be offered to freshmen and sophomores at Sweet Briar College during the second semester beginning next week.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

THE author of "The Gay Sisters" has it in for the lawyers. But he would not be the smart young Mr. Stephen Longstreet if he let his animosity solidify in a dull mold. By the alchemy of his brash cleverness, instead -- and with the aid of a still well-remembered New York legend -- he transmutes his malevolence into gleaming celluloid: slick, strident, and as swift-moving as any able mechanism can make it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Navy Department announced plans tonight to turn out 30,000 pilots a year in what it called "the greatest aviation training program in naval history."

PROBABLY not even the warmest admirer of Edith Pargeter -- a title for which the present reviewer wishes to be considered a candidate -- would think of describing "People of My Own" as a major novel. Yet if it is not so, one has the odd conviction that this can be only because Miss Pargeter had no such lofty intention when she set out to write it.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- Fast production of warplanes means the restricting of each plant to one type and that is the policy the War Production Board has now adopted, Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen, the War Department's new production chief, said here today.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 31 -- A water-drinking contest among two sisters and their brother resulted in the death today of one of the participants, 12-year-old Margaret Boylan, who succumbed to what the medical examiner described tentatively as "internal drowning."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- While fliers searched vainly for them over thousands of miles of fog-bound wilderness in the Yukon, Lieut. Col. Harold H. Carr and Corporal Richard Pompeo made their way on foot, with heavy packs, back to Fairbanks, Alaska, after their plane had been forced down 250 miles northeast of that city during a flight to Whitehorse.

Scheduling and planning, rather than advance buying, are the important objectives of industrial purchasing agents under present conditions, according to the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, is sued yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Among the sports features of the season is the eighth annual tropical trap-shoot of the Peckaway Skeet and Trap Club opening today on the club's range and continuing through Tuesday. The shoot was for a time tentatively postponed because of the war.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Despite a slow start, Colgate overcame Army in a hard-fought hockey match today by 5 to 3. Greg Batt was the visitors' star, accounting for three goals and assisting in another.

SAN FRANCISCO -- A wealth of diversion ranging from active sports to the passive enjoyment of motoring from snow-line to acacia gardens, with exotic scenes on every hand -- such are the possibilities of a Winter vacation in the San Francisco Bay area and the region lying within a day's driving radius.

FOR many years Sacha Guitry was the "enfant terrible" of the French stage, while being at the same time France's leading and most prolific playwright. He flouted most of the rules of his craft and the accepted social concepts as well, as if to prove that if one had sufficient charm one could successfully set one's own precedents.

NEWTON, N.J., Jan. 31 (AP) -- While three of his young children looked on tonight, Thomas Hendershot, 58 years old, killed his wife, Laura, 38, with a shotgun and later took his own life in their home at Lafayette, in Sussex County; State Trooper Charles Kiseljack reported.

Secret Service agents of the Treasury Department and city detectives of the safe and loft squad, raiding two East Side apartments early yesterday morning, seized 10,290 counterfeit 50-cent pieces and counterfeiting equipment and arrested three alien Estonians on charges of making and passing bogus coins.

THROUGH the century-and-a-half period that ended abruptly on Dec. 7, 1941, the world thought of Honolulu in terms of tropical glamour, Clifford Gessler says. And even if the garlands that welcomed travelers were merely a recent $200,000-a-year item in the tourism that has been Hawaii's third big industry, glamour has been genuine, many-colored and indeed continuous about this "gentle port."

There were no crowds, just dock workers, a handful of high officials and the Stars and Stripes fluttering from two flagpoles. A grimy stevedore shouted "Hurray!" as a gray salt-crusted transport nosed through the mist and tied up at a pier in Northern Ireland.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 31 -- Planes of the Royal Australian Air Force bombed Japanese ships at Rabaul, New Britain Island, again Friday night, scoring at least one hit. All the aircraft returned.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- Syracuse put on a sensational second half rally to defeat the Pennsylvania basketball team at the Palestra tonight, 43 -- 27. It was the first home setback of the season for Penn.

Final arrangements have been completed for the third annual supper dance of the Canadian Women's Club of New York, to be held Friday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Anthony Bassler, president of the club, is executive chairman of the fete.

"IT is a tale told in the Northern Neck of Virginia between the Potomac River and the Rappahannock River," says Mr. Cabell; in other words, a legend which apparently has been handed down for some 350 years, since it goes back to the sixteenth century, before ever an English voice was heard in Virginia.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 31 -- After having fought their way through German positions, two columns of the Seventh Indian Brigade have reached the British main forces outside the Bengazi area, thus foiling, at least partially, the German plan to trap the defenders of Bengazi between columns that cut off the city from north, east and south.
Donald Frame of the Harvard Club scored his third big conquest of the local squash racquets season yesterday by regaining the metropolitan Class A championship.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- The elements continue to make things uncomfortable for the skiing world. A constant downpour began to play havoc today with the snow on towering Norsemen Hill, where the nineteenth annual United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association jumping championships are scheduled tomorrow.

CANTON, N. Y., Jan. 31 -- The host team, coached by Otto Schniebs, won the third annual intercollegiate ski meet sponsored by St. Lawrence University today with a total score of 576 points for the cross-country, downhill, slalom, and jumping events.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31 -- Yale attained a two-goal lead over Princeton in the opening period and breezed ahead to a 4-1 victory in a Pentagonal Hockey League contest tonight.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 31 -- Dartmouth wrested the lead from Williams in the skiing events of the latter's Winter carnival by winning the downhill, slalom and combined slalom-downhill contests on the icy Suicide Six run today.

Entering its fourth week, the Victory Book Campaign has achieved about one-tenth of its goal, Althea Warren, national director of the drive, declared yesterday. Although lacking complete reports from all States, Miss Warren estimated that 1,000,000 books had been collected toward the national goal of 10,000,000 volumes for the use of the armed services and merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Members of the Senate Agriculture Committee conceded today that apparently they faced defeat of their hopes that the new price control act would bring higher prices for farm products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Roosevelt today congratulated the Presidents of Ecuador and Peru on the settlement of their ancient boundary dispute and emphasized that it was necessary for the American nations to settle all future disputes by "amicable discussion and cordial collaboration."

MOST of these stories were written after the attack upon Poland and all of them were written before the attack on Pearl Harbor. Perhaps this in part explains why there is so little light in this city for which Mr. Shaw is the spieler, for those were ugly months.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A combined Army-R.A.F. communique said tonight:

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 31 -- The inclusion of dramatics in the creative arts program of education at Princeton University last Fall has exposed many needs and faults in the study of drama on the campus, according to C. Norris Houghton, its director.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 31 -- Dr. Eugenie Andruss Leonard, a member of the university faculty, has been appointed as dean of women, a new post just established at the institution, the Most Rev. Joseph M. Corrigan, rector of the Catholic University, announced today.

IT was last Thursday night and just about an hour before Art Ross sent his Bruins against the Brooklyn Americans on Madison Square Garden ice. There were some fellows gathered in a room talking hockey and the principal speakers were Mr. Ross, the Lone Wolf of the Ice Pack, and Mervyn the Red Dutton, the noted heckler of hockey referees.

WHAT must be far and away the most elaborate government radio program yet concocted is now in preparation at Archibald MacLeish's Office of Facts and Figures and scheduled for a premiere on or about Saturday, Feb. 15. The general idea, as reported to this sector, is about as follows:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- The hunter championship in the Secor Farm's Schooling Horse Show was won by Mrs. Charles Govern's chestnut gelding, Proseaic, tonight as a result of points in six events, in two of which he took blue ribbons.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 31 -- Plans for the celebration of the 200th anniversary of Moravian Seminary and College for Women to be held May 1 through May 4 were disclosed today by Miss Edith Jane Stauffer, dean of the college and chairman of the Bi-Centenary Committee.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the pre-opening performance of Marc Connelly's new play, "The Flowers of Virtue," on Wednesday night at the Royale Theatre for the benefit of Hamilton House.

The giant strides of the aircraft industry toward the goal of 125,000 planes in 1943 were described yesterday by J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, in a resume that gave $1,500,000,000 as the value of the finished production of the aircraft industry in this country last year.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (Reuter) -- Results of football matches played today in Britain follow:

A preview opening and reception will be held tomorrow from 2 to 5 P.M. at Thrift House -- said to be the largest permanent rummage mart in the country -- in its new quarters at 18 West Fifty-seventh Street. The guests of honor will be several women of prominence who have been largely responsible for the support of the shop since its establishment in 1933.

A recruiting station where prospects for this city's quota of student nurses may find information on training schools is ready for its opening day tomorrow. The local center, part of a nation-wide plan being carried out by professional groups represented on the Nursing Council on National Defense, is located in the new offices of the New York Counties Registered Nurses Association at 424 Madison Avenue.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- The death last night of Michael D. Williams, 56 years old, personnel director of the Horn Hardart Company, chain of automat restaurants, was listed by Westchester Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire tonight as "accidental" and due to an "overdose of sleeping potion."

The Maritime Commission disclosed last week that despite withdrawals of foreign flag vessels from important trade routes and the diversion of a considerable volume of American tonnage to Army and Navy use, this country's importation of ten major raw materials vital to the war production increased sharply during 1941.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Sugar rationing may be just what the country needs, the public education department of the American Dental Association said today.

Industrial profits in 1941 were second only to those of 1929 and, for some groups, exceeded the records of that boom year by a comfortable margin, a survey of the first seventy-one principal corporations to report last year's results shows.

LOOKING north from a New York skyscraper's observation tower on a clear Winter's day you can sometimes see the foothills of an abundant New England holiday realm that stretches behind Gotham's back door.

Practically all of the wholesale markets here enjoyed increased activity last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. In the coat and suit markets there was a very heavy demand for silver fox trimmed Winter coats, dressy Spring coats and suits of all types.
THE annual Long Island championships come to a close today with a two-session mixed-pair contest, which will be played at 2 and 8 P.M. The tournament is held at the Plaza Hotel in Brooklyn.
Permit me to introduce the firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., who are about to establish themselves in the banking business.

TAMARA is a very romantic Russian name, rich in literary association. The young woman who is invested with the name of Tamara in Irma Skariatina's latest book has all the qualities to be expected of her.

FROM our only living ex-President we might well expect in this grim hour some words that would help awaken the country to the gravity of its danger, that would appeal to the heroic elements in the national temper, and that would bind us closer to our democratic Allies.
