CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 31 -- A new one-year program leading to the degree of Master of Education, and twelve new short courses dealing with education in the war period were announced today by the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- With the war emergency exerting increasing demands upon the civilian population, the University of Buffalo School of Medicine will conduct a special educational service -- a series of five public lectures on "The Care of Your Health During the War."

HERE is no companion piece to Miss du Maurier's "Rebecca," full of subtle psychological implications. At first blush it might seem so, for the first chapter gives the setting round Helford River on the Cornish Coast, rich in legends of a romantically sinister past.

SCARCELY less interesting for the intrinsic merit of a number of the pictures included than for the broad interpretation of the exhibition's theme, the show of baroque paintings at the Schaeffer Galleries provides one of the season's outstanding attractions.

New York University polished its shooting and polished off the Lehigh quintet in the same motion at the University Heights court last night. The Violet won at 67 to 40 for its tenth victory in eleven starts this season. This was a Naismith memorial game, with the proceeds going to the Naismith Fund.

JAMES PATTON M'CORMICK, lecturer in Wayne University, Detroit, has done literature good service in this objective and searching study of the Brownings. One could wish the book might become as widely known as the overemphasized version of the famous love story and its near-tragedy brought to life in the theatre by Katharine Cornell, of which it is, in fact, a scholarly corrective.

THIS useful new volume on home decoration is exactly what its name states, a handbook. Characteristically, it begins with sensible suggestions on budgeting and directions for the informed choice of furniture that is genuinely durable.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- A group of leaders of New York City's civic and commercial organizations discussed with Representative Bloom today the feasibility of locating in New York some of the government offices which will be forced to leave Washington because of the demand by war agencies for more space here.

BASRA, Iraq, Jan. 25 (Delayed) -- This teeming port in the lower valley of the Tigris and the Euphrates, colorful with khaki-clad soldiers from points as far apart as the Tibetan borders and the English Downs, is now functioning as a key junction on one of the most important military supply routes yet developed in the war.

LEASE-LENDER: President Roosevelt last week summoned back into government services a man who had been one of the leading figures of the early New Deal. The Chief Executive appointed Lewis W. Douglas, once Budget Director in his Administration, to the post of assistant lease-lend expedition in London.

RAPIDLY crystallizing here, in the world's greatest center of higher education, are new plans to help produce the almost staggering number of radio technicians needed in industry and at the front. Already huge, the demand for radio men is growing daily.

The current demand by government for all-out war production and by labor for a share in the management process call for a skill in business management which is deplorably lacking today, Harris S. Bigelow, partner with Robert Bruck in the Sales Analysis Institute, declared here yesterday.

It is not unusual for those of us who constantly work on lawns -- our own and those of other people -- to meet owners who in their ambition to have a perfect lawn have bought and are using unusually large amounts of a really high priced, special-grade grass seed.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Twelve upperclass students from the Skidmore Department of Nursing left today to begin work at the New York Post- Graduate School and Hospital, under the new affiliation between the college and hospital, in a five- year collegiate course in nursing.

Jan Kiepura, the Polish tenor, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall which attracted such a large audience that many seats had to be provided on stage to accommodate the overflow. The artist was in fine vocal form, and with his genial, magnetic personality and expert showmanship as important assets, won ovations after every offering presented.

RANCHO SANTE FE, Calif., Jan. 31 -- Shattering par by six strokes with a 66, Johnny Dawson of Hollywood, an amateur, put the powerful professional ranks in the shade today to lead the field at the halfway stage of the $5,000 Bing Crosby thirty-six-hole golf tournament.

TOKYO, Jan. 3 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Domei dispatch from the Malayan front today said that Japanese forces moving down upon Johore Strait had seized control of a water reservoir serving the Island of Singapore from the mainland.

Here we have Jane Amanda Edwards again with her sister, Annie, and her brother, Arthur -- all with their capacities for getting into trouble quite unimpaired. The trouble has to do with sabotage and murder in a factory engaged in defense work.

The double bill composed of Bach's "Phoebus and Pan" and Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Le Coq d'Or" was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Sir Thomas Beecham conducting. Because of her accident at the previous performance of the Rimsky-Korsakoff work, Rosa Bok was replaced by Josephine Antoine as the Queen of Chemakha and due to the indisposition of Ezio Pinza the role of King Dodon was assumed by Norman Cordon.

JUDY (played by Barbara Bel Geddes) took off the high-heeled shoes, her first pair, and rubbed her aching toes. There was a small appreciative laugh from the audience. Now the big tender moment was coming. The moment that would certainly tell whether or not "Junior Miss" was a show for the Army to see.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 31 -- Rangoon today ranks with Chungking and London as one of the most-bombed cities in the Allied world, said a high Burmese official who arrived here today.

When Adolf Hitler sets out to write -- or rewrite -- history he does what must be a job satisfactory to himself for he never has any difficulty in proving his points from the record as he concocts it. But his versions will scarcely satisfy any one who cares anything about the truth of the record.

A substantial number of retail organizations, including department stores, a leading mail order concern and an outstanding variety goods chain have definitely committed themselves to the "last-in, first-out" or "lifo" method of inventory valuation, and other large retailers have also indicated they plan to use it, it was learned here yesterday.
The United States has embarked somewhat feverishly but quite properly on the enterprise of establishing bonds of mutual understanding and cooperation among the nations of the Western Hemisphere.

A musical event of much interest to society and of wide philanthropic appeal will occur at the Town Hall next Friday evening when a concert entitled "Spirituals of a United Nation" will be presented under the auspices of the New York City Mission Society, an undenominational religious corporation which ministers to people of all classes and all ages, particularly to the needy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Civil non-agricultural employment in December was at a new high record of 40,940,000 persons, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins reported today. She said the total was 5,000,000 above the level of December, 1929, and that unemployment now remained greater by about 1,500,000 than it was thirteen years ago.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 31 -- More than five years of research into the music lore of the anthracite mining regions of Northeastern Pennsylvania by Dr. Melvin LeMon of the Bucknell University Music Department, has made available to Americans a new type of folk-singing in the presentation of the anthracite miner's ballads.

Arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of juvenile delinquency, two boys, 13 and 12 years old, were accused by detectives of the East Sixty-seventh Street precinct of committing between thirty-five and forty burglaries in the last five or six weeks in city and suburban homers.

FOR a long time now -- it might be said to run into a matter of some half dozen decades, for those who like to count in resounding round numbers -- the American School has been notably strong in its department of water-color painting.

FROM Vichy comes an unheralded series of semi-postals released last November. The purpose of the surtaxes is not yet known here. Each has as its design the coat-of-arms of a French city or town. As with other recent stamps of Vichy origin, "R.F." (for "Republique Francaise") is missing; instead, the major inscription is "Postes Francaises" (French Postage).

PASSWORD: The story was told last week of Japanese trying to infiltrate United States lines on the Bataan Peninsula by dressing in Filipino uniforms. American sentries countered the trick by using passwords with L's, which the Japanese pronounce like R's. A favorite was "lollapalooza."
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Thousands of 17-year-old boys were registered today under the Youth Service scheme that will sort them out in preparation for more serious business later.

AN astonishing business in more ways than one, the radio is never more fascinating than when some curious-minded sleuth sets out to discover what makes it tick, and then comes in from the field with a batch of statistics proving -- well, you never can be quite sure what they prove, because there are so many imponderables and, after all, not every set-owner in the United States can be interviewed.

I HAVE received a copy of The New York Times Book Review of Nov. 16, 1941, in which an article seemingly implies that my novel "Rebecca" was plagiarized from Carolina Nabuco's novel "A Sucessora," published previously in Portuguese. I never heard of Miss Nabuco or her book until last year.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine for Jan. 11 the article "Invitation to Garibaldi," by Carey Shaw Jr., apparently tries to minimize negotiations between Lincoln and Garibaldi for the latter's command of Union forces.

Although this Country must stand solidly behind an "all out" war, the war should not be used to encroach unnecessarily upon the leisure time needed by municipal and other workers, Stanley M. Isaacs, Councilman from Manhattan, declared yesterday in an address before the fourth annual convention of Local 1, State, County and Municipal Workers of America, affiliated with the C.I.O.

President William G. Bramham of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues arrived in New York yesterday with a hopeful outlook for the country's minor leagues. Bramham is here to attend the baseball writers' dinner tonight.

WASHINGTON -- When the railroads moved 600,000 troops and equipment recently, with such speed and efficiency that a high official called the accomplishment "miraculous," it was an effective demonstration that the iron horse was in top form and ready for the race, however difficult it might be.

NEW HAVEN Conn., Jan. 31 -- The Yale School of Engineering, placing its curriculum on a war footing, is offering special comes to undergraduates which may prove especially valuable in either the armed forces or industry.

PATROLLING the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts for enemy ships or planes, U.S. Army combat crews are outfitted with the best clothing protection against the extreme cold of high altitudes, the foundation of which is the lowly sheepskin.

"ONLY when men are persuaded that their death will serve the larger interests of mankind -- which are almost exclusively moral interests -- will they go forth to die in battle." That is one of the obiter dicta Jay Franklin offers in "Remaking America."

IT was September, 1933, and the country people were celebrating their harvest festival of Thanksgiving in a blaze of new hope. Depression was over. War could be forgotten. The day of the peasant and the artisan was coming back, with all the good life's stable simplicities.

Motorists estimated to number 30,000 jammed the offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau in the city yesterday morning in a rush to buy 1942 license plates, although the deadline for using last year's tags does not arrive until midnight tomorrow.

In 1942 small gardens unquestionably will assume an importance ranking high in the scale of the country's assets. Since few persons can boast extended garden plots, every effort will be made by the patriotic grower to produce as rich a yield as possible from a limited space.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 31 -- With the war needs of the country reaching out for as much man power as possible, the University of Wisconsin faculty has adopted a revised calendar for the remainder of the school year, and made definite plans to institute new courses designed to contribute to students' immediate participation in various phases of the war program.

To raise funds for war-suffering people of bombed English towns the Namesake Towns Committee of the English-Speaking Union will give a tea and illustrated lecture Tuesday afternoon in the headquarters of the union's New York branch, at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

INTESTINAL AMEBAE -- From Dr. Gordon H. Ball (University of California) comes the cheering news that, though intestines may harbor half a dozen varieties of amebae, only one is dangerous. One person in twenty may harbor this particular variety, which is not necessarily fatal.
At the New York Botanical Garden, five miles north of the heart of Manhattan, tropical gardens invite the Winter-weary urbanite to forget icy gales and slushy streets.

Beginning today 42,000 children who before July 1, 1941, received assistance from the Board of Child Welfare, will be included in the relief milk program Under which each child under 16 years old will receive a pint of milk a day, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

Twenty thousand Italians and Americans of Italian ancestry booed mention of Mussolini, cheered Mayor La Guardia's declaration that the United States would redeem Italy from its Nazi and Fascist rulers and presented to him a check for $20,000 for the American Red Cross in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
An expanded program has been prepared for the executive meeting of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at its midwinter sessions on Wednesday and Thursday at the Hotel Astor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved with one minor change today the $26,494,265,474 Navy bill submitted by a subcommittee yesterday.

But for a chance encounter with a small Negro boy who is nearly run down by their car Chauncey O'Day and Carrie Storm might never have heard of the strange happenings at Olinden, the home of the Grayson family.
THIS is a footling enterprise for me for I know well that spears cast at critics are boomerangs and that the groans of a wounded playwright are not very attractive or convincing sounds.

By persistent faith in God and the church, we may be happy despite the "natural sadness" in the world today, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman declared yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral at the semi-annual commencement exercises of Cathedral High School for Girls.

DO you doubt the existence of hell? Do you need Prescription No. 13 to avoid being a "tobacco maniac"? Do you bring booze to the fireside where your little ones are at play? Do you want a hymnal, a gas-saving device for your car or a permanent wave?

"DE SHOOTINEST GENT'MAN" is one of the best loved of all American sporting tales, and is for the first time published between its own boards, with drawing by Robert Ball (Charles Scribner's Sons, $2).

Emil Meyer, 39 years old, of 427 West Eighteenth Street, shot and killed himself early yesterday morning in a cell at the West Twentieth Street police station, where he had been committed the previous afternoon on a charge of possessing a pistol.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Robert B. Parker Jr. of South Orange, N.J., formerly an Associated Press correspondent in Europe, received today the first award ever given by the students of Union College to a graduate of the institution for "distinguished service in the field of journalism."

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 31 -- A furious battle on land, sea and in the air flamed today between the Netherland defenders of Amboina, the Indies' second naval base, and a Japanese invasion force that struck with great strength into the strategic bastion on the archipelago's eastern flank.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Delegates to the C.I.O. legislative conference this afternoon adopted a program which endorsed President Roosevelt's action in setting up a CIO-AFL board and took favorable action on about a dozen of the more than 1,000 resolutions which had been presented to the program committee.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 31 -- The University of Michigan reorganized its athletic set-up today and placed in the hands of H.O. (Fritz) Crisler, athletic director and football coach, virtually full power to hire all coaches.

DR. MAX LERNER is a professor at Williams College and also a journalist who commands a following faithful enough to warrant the publication of his occasional articles and book reviews in a book. Reference to "Acknowledgments" in the back of "Ideas for the Ice Age" reveals that only one section of the text is marked "unpublished."
BRITISH authorities have ousted and "detained" the Premier of Burma, who is accused of dealing with the Japanese. British rule in Burma goes back to 1886.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique broadcast today follows:

Notices were sent yesterday to the member clubs of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound that the executive committee of that organization has decided to recommend to the delegates at the regular meeting in March that the full championship racing schedule for next Summer be carried out.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Labor Union officials placed before officials of the War Production Board today a plan for concentrating production of a limited number of streamlined, standardized "Victory" refrigerators in a few plants for the duration of the war. The remaining refrigerator plants would be devoted to producing war materiels in the shortest possible time.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- Very frank revelations were made in Strasbourg today by the German sub-Prefect Herr Bickler at a ceremony marking the admission into the National Socialist party of 400 Alsatians, men and women, "who, for the last twenty years fought for Germanism in Alsace."

President Roosevelt's instructions to the Commodity Credit Corporation to release its commodity stocks to other government agencies for purposes of war production unleashed in the cotton market yesterday a wave of liquidation offerings that carried prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to losses of as much as 52 to 58 points, or $2.60 to $2.90 a bale.

OTTAWA, Jan. 31 -- The controversy that has arisen in Canada over the Government's proposal to hold a plebiscite asking for release from past pledges regarding "the method of raising men for military service" has for the moment tended to obscure much that has been splendid in Canada's war accomplishment.

FEBRUARY is fairly new in the calendar. For ages the world got along without it. The story is that the wild tribes of Northern Europe gave the year ten months, beginning with the first sign of Spring and continuing till the ground froze for Winter.
ATHENS, Ohio, Jan. 24 -- Courses in Chinese, civilian defense and explosives headline over sixty war courses added to the curricula at Ohio University.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., Jan. 31 -- The Closter polo team was the winner of annual New York A.C. high-goal indoor tournament at the Pegasus Club tonight. Originally listed as a four-team competition, the tournament was conducted along the lines of a round-robin because of the entrance of the entire Rockleigh team into the armed forces.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- Norway tomorrow will embark on "a new era" of collaboration with Germany when Major Vidkun Quisling, from the steps of the City Hall of Oslo, will read a "proclamation of state" naming himself Chief of State over the Norwegian people, according to information in Scandinavian diplomatic quarters here tonight.

There is a great desire in Argentine collegiate circles to adopt the United States university system, Dr. Cesar Barros-Hurtado, Professor of Political and Social Science of the University of La Plata, declared yesterday.

The big parade of track and field talent is about to start. The major footracing season will open in Madison Square Garden on Saturday when the Millrose A.A. conducts its thirty-fifth annual games. This newest edition of an always colorful show promises to match or surpass its predecessors, since Director Fred Schmertz has managed to corral most of the available talent.

THAT unique and peculiarly democratic institution -- the President's press conference -- is in debate again. Before the war the question whether the President should cancel his meetings with the reporters was widely discussed in official circles; today the discussion is renewed and intensified and the President himself has indicated that he is considering the possibility of halting the conferences.

CANCELLATIONS on letters from men in the service are usually designed to conceal the location of troops. In the case of the United States, each base postoffice has a number with which most cover collectors are familiar.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 31 -- I came back from the Malaya mainland with the forces protected by British Imperials fighting one of the coolest and most effective rear-guard actions of the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Roosevelt discussed war finances today with Secretary Morgenthau and Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, and talked with William C. Bullitt, his personal representative in the Middle East, who gave a preliminary report on the course of the war in that area.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 31 (AP) -- By less than a second in total time, Jim Bickford of Saranac Lake claimed the two-man bobsled title today in Adirondack Association A.A.U. championship racing lover the Mount Van Hoevenberg mile run.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- Police began rounding up scores of totalitarian agents today and restricted the activities of Axis nationals as a result of the government's severance of relations with Germany, Japan and Italy.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 31 -British defenders of the Burma Road evacuated the strategic port of Moulmein and fell back under a powerful Japanese enveloping attack today to establish strong new lines west of the deep, three-mile-wide Salween River, about ninety-two miles from Rangoon.

The North has a fascination for very young readers, as the popularity of Mrs. Peary's "Snow Baby," Schwatka's "Children of the Cold," and Lucy Fitch Perkins's "Eskimo Twins" have shown over a long period of years. "The Little Igloo" is now receiving an enthusiastic welcome from the 5 to 7 year olds.

TACOMA, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A walkout of welders disputing with unions of the American Federation of Labor took 1,654 men off their jobs in Puget Sound shipyards today in the face of a flat refusal by the War Production Board to recognize their independent organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Curtailment of the use of uniforms by non-military organizations in order to conserve wool, rayon, and cotton was urged again today by the War Production Board. Officials of the American Red Cross indicated, however, that they would not heed a suggestion that makers of bandages and surgical dressings wear ordinary civilian dresses instead of white cotton uniforms.

Asserting that "wars are won by quick and effective action on the home front, as well as the battle front," Leon Fraser, chairman of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, said yesterday that New York still was $2,000,000 short of its minimum goal of $7,330,000 in the drive.

Management expansion is taking place so rapidly as a result of increasing war production that stricter attention must be given to organization principles, Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association, declared yesterday in reporting an unusually heavy demand by companies for the "Ten Commandments of Good Organization," recently issued by his organization in two-color poster form and printed below.

ALBERT MAYER, whose "Olympiad," published several years ago (Harper), is a fine story of ancient Greece with a well-drawn, lifelike hero, has now written an adventure story with Central Europe in the latter half of the tenth century as a background.

The home maker who is buying furniture may well give a thought to the new harmonized pieces. Here is a chance to get away from the cast-iron conventionality of the traditional living or bedroom grouping and at the same time to be sure of a unified effect.

A footnote can be added to the very interesting piece on the Malay language which appeared in your issue of Jan. 18: that is, the Indian or Sanskrit origin of many of the words used in that part of the world.

The annual exhibitors' meeting of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., will be held tomorrow at New York Times Hall (formerly the Little Theatre) at 240 West Forty-fourth Street, at 1 P.M. A discussion of the schedule will take place from 1 to 3 P.M. At 3 P.M. Fredrick W. Cassebeer will show colored slides of the decorative arrangement exhibited in the 1941 International Flower Show.

ART is long and life is short, says the old Latin proverb, and that precisely is what most worries the ever-decreasing number of managers of the so-called "art" or "little theatres." While commercial-minded Broadway waxes fat on box office lucre, the art theatre major domos are looking more like lean and hungry Cassius every day; while Broadway is cooking with gas, the art theatres are lucky to find a can of Sterno.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 31 -- Foreign Minister Juan Bautista Rossetti intends to ask the Chilean Congress next week to authorize the breaking off of diplomatic relations with the Axis powers and to approve other decisions adopted at the Rio de Janeiro conference, it was learned tonight on the eve of a closely contested Presidential election.
The Patent Office granted 670 patents this week among which were the following inventions:

A vacation fund for sending several thousand children of all sects and creeds to St. Helene's Camp at Palenville, N.Y., will be augmented by proceeds of the third annual Musical Evening concert sponsored by the Divine Providence Day Nursery, 225 East Forty-fifth Street, which will be held Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Biltmore.

A shot is fired, and a man falls dead, but he is not supposed to be dead, for all this happens in a play being put on in a Summer theatre. Can it be that the actor who fired the shot used a real cartridge instead of a blank? Rather too obvious, isn't it?

TRAVEL'S vital new job during and after the war was one of the principal topics at a recent Washington meeting of the National Association of Travel Officials. The aims set forth at the sessions are to provide for recreation and change for persons working harder than ever before on war jobs or jobs related (as a great many jobs are) to national defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- Walter Nash, who arrived here yesterday after flying from New Zealand, crossed paths in Honolulu with Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, new United States Minister to New Zealand, en route to his post.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Major Gen. Johnson Hagood, retired coastal defense commander, asserted today that the Pearl Harbor disaster resulted largely from "faulty organization" of the War Department along with a "lack of authority and responsibility."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- Warfare of two kinds is being waged in the Far Pacific. One, covered by the daily communiques, is between the armed forces of the Allies and the Axis. The other is a war of air waves, with the General Electric Company's short-wave radio station KGEI of this city pitted against powerful Axis transmitters in Tokyo, Manchukuo and Saigon.

Under the sponsorship of several high-ranking military officers, the annual Colonial Ball given jointly by the Continental Guard of the Sons of the American Revolution and the Junior Groups of the Daughters of the American Revolution, will take place Feb. 21 at the Plaza.
Events in baseball's waning off-season are about to rush to a climax which, within the next few days, promises to provide the nation's random with startling developments.

"Need what you buy that you may buy what you need" strikes the keynote of an anti-hoarding campaign being instituted by the Women's City Club. With the use of slogans such as this and other educational devices the club will give its full support to a movement to forestall a trend toward excessive buying of both foods and bearing apparel in which scarcities are already felt or anticipated because of military needs for raw materials.

STILL the fascination persists. Pooh-pooh the glory of the "bad man," strip from him the sentimentality with which he has been invested, even refuse to give the devil his due, and what have you? Answer: You have a romantic figure in whom four out of five average males show (or conceal) an intense interest.

Maria-Theresa, who was one of the six "Isadorable" Duncans, gave one of her rare dance recitals last night at Carnegie Hall, assisted by Otto Herz, pianist, and the group of nine young girls of Greek descent whom she calls the Heliconiadies.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31 -- The Pan-American conference at Rio de Janeiro has closed without achieving complete hemispheric unity, but it seemed to indicate a growing awareness in Latin America of new dangers and a general recognition that the fifth column is more than a figment of North American imagination, as some argued six months ago.

Retail trade here again forged ahead last week despite the handicap of somewhat unfavorable weather. Sales increases ranging up to 34 per cent were reported by department stores here and estimates indicated the average gain for these stores would not be far from this figure.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Survivors of the tanker Rochester, sunk off the Virginia coast yesterday, disagreed after their landing here today about the size of the attacking submarine, but agreed that the German U-boatmen were "bum shooters."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 -- Thousands of enemy aliens living in areas adjacent to shipyards, docks, power plants and defense factories prepared today to find new homes as Attorney General Biddle added sixty-nine more districts in California to the earlier list of West Coast sections barred to Japanese, Italian and German nationals.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Health, housing, child care, business and industry, government service, journalism, social work and teaching, are included in the long list of vocations to be discussed at a five-day Conference on Vocations and Defense to be held at Sarah Lawrence College beginning Monday.

GOOD fellowship among amateur photographers will be rendered more than lip service in an idea to be inaugurated by the Miniature Camera Club of New York on Friday, Feb. 13, when the first session of the Miniature Camera Club Troubleshooters will be held.
Indemnification of directors of corporations for the cost of suits which may be brought against them as a result of their being directors has provided an interesting example of legal evolution.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in January totaled $88,341,000, the smallest total for that month since 1938. It compared with $179,694,000 for the preceding month and with $440,973,000 in January, 1941.

The case of sugar shows how quickly war can convert surpluses into shortages. For years our neighbor Cuba struggled with the problem of too much sugar, and our own national policy was to restrict imports by quotas and tariffs so as to insure domestic sugar interests a major part of the market relieved of the competition of cheap and abundant offshore sugar.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 31 -- A transfer tax appraisal filed here with Surrogate Leone D. Howell today by David F. Soden, Tax Appraiser, showed that Daniel Guggenheim, capitalist and mining developer, left a gross estate of $20,686,292.93 at the time of his death at Sands Point, L.I., on Sept. 28, 1930.

The courts continue to find ways of limiting the extent to which colleges are entitled to tax exemption by virtue of their charters. Two recent decisions of the Supreme Court of North Carolina illustrate the trend.

In discussing American public opinion it is now customary to speak of before and after Pearl Harbor as though that event had made a change both instantaneous and revolutionary. It is now time, seven weeks after that momentous event, to take account of stock and ask whether we are, as is commonly said, a united people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Steel which does not age is revealed in patent (No. 2,271,242) granted to Clarence L. Altenburger of Dear-born, Mich. The patent covers a process for extracting from steel an element which when present above certain amounts causes the steel to age.

BATAVIA, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- The defenders of Amboina Island battled throughout tonight against numerically superior Japanese invasion forces attacking the Indies' base in a new drive to cut Allied supply lines via Australia.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 31 (AP) -- The General Assembly of Virginia today acclaimed John D. Rockefeller Jr. as an honorary citizen of the Commonwealth and heard Senator F. Byrd call for complete dedication to the war effort and giving the "whole truth" to the American people except where such information would be of value to the enemy.

IN "Pageant in the Sky" Raymond S. Deck, writer and ornithologist, tells for student and layman alike the story of the birds of the Western Hemisphere in terms of those migrations whose paths testify to vanished continental land-bridges and trace "lost valleys, buried rivers," so old that "even time has forgotten their courses and only the birds remember."

THE International Society for Contemporary Music will hold its nineteenth festival next July in San Francisco. Works for symphony orchestra, small chamber music combinations, and solo voice with instrumental accompaniment, will be presented at the concerts.

Leo Durocher yesterday signed a contract to manage the Dodgers through the campaign of 1942. He will be player-manager for at least part of the season. Announcement of the agreement on terms came from President Larry MacPhail after his meeting with the manager who last year gave Brooklyn its first National League baseball penant in twenty-one years.

The United States Maritime Commission announced last week award of contracts for fifty-three additional "Liberty" ships -- type EC-2 cargo vessels -- to make 1,038 of that type to date in the commission's wartime program.

THE name of Dr. William Hallock Park of New York is inseparably associated with the conquest of diphtheria, since it was he who first -- and persistently -- gave practical use in this country to the scientific discoveries which made the control of that disease possible.
READING, Pa., Jan. 31 -- Long Island University met a Tartar tonight in the Albright basketball team, which battled the victorious Blackbirds to a 59-to-54 count before more than 3,000 frenzied fans.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31 -- An effort was made here today, by one member of the Supreme Court among others, to minimize the implications of Tuesday's decision of that court upholding the private ownership of subsoil in oil fields, thus apparently reversing the decision upon which the present and previous Mexican Governments since 1938 have refused payment for expropriated subsoil rights.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (Canadian Press) -- The powerful Arsenal football team strengthened its hold on first place in the London League today by routing the Watford club, 11 -- 0, in its highest-scoring game of the season. Reg Lewis, young army center forward, scored five of the goals.

CHUNGKING, Jan. 31 (U.P.) -- An entire division of Japanese-equipped Nanking soldiers has deserted to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, it was announced today. The desertion was attributed to the United States entry into the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle this week went to Atlanta and presented "Award of Merit" certificates to several score of the prisoners at the Federal penitentiary there for outstanding work in production of war materials.

STORRS, Conn., Jan. 31 -- The clatter of a pneumatic drill, a familiar sound at the University of Connecticut for the past five years, is silent now. The war has put a stop to all non-defense construction work just as a $3,000,000 building program had been completed, a program which doubled the size of the physical plant as a long first step toward satisfying the higher education needs of the State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The White House stated today that the Administration had "gratefully accepted" a plan of the four major radio netorks for a series of factual programs designed to dramatize and interpret the wartime resources and activties of the nation to the American people and the world.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after an irregular advance during the week on most types of slaughter animals except lambs. Reduced receipts in all departments helped to strengthen prices.

Seems we have upward of 20,000,000 boys and girls aged 5 to 13 and that 85 per cent of their families have at least one radio. (Think what that means in box tops!) Any one who thinks that the best in drama, music and story telling is not being offered to this audience can do more than criticize, in the opinion of the Radio Council on Children's Programs, 9 Rockefeller Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Norwegian Legation said today that "a new wave of German executions in Norway has brought death to at least ten Norwegian patriots during the past four days."

In the Jan. 11 issue of your magazine, in an article on "Immortal War Slogans," you attribute the phrase "Millions for defense, but not one cent for tribute" to Robert Goodloe Harper, Congressman from South Carolina.

RECOGNITION of Dimitri Shostakovich's status as a composer may be had from this month's record output. Two of his major works have been issued, which amounts almost to an endorsement of the composer's position among the ablest of living writers.

Special training in field map interpretation, use of aerial photographs, courses, dealing with ground water distribution and the exploration and economics of mineral deposits are among the wartime techniques to be taught geology students at Columbia University beginning tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

Shares on the New York Stock Exchange continued soft and dull yesterday and closed moderately lower. Sales were 228,140 shares, against 291,680 on the preceding Saturday, but the market was relatively broad. Of the 576 issues traded, 296 were lower, 112 were higher and 168 were unchanged.

New York City used only 28 per cent of its quota of passenger car tires and 13 per cent of its quota of truck tires in January, the first month of rationing, Leo S. Buckingham, Acting Federal Rationing Administrator for the city, reported yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 31 -- With the integration of all defense activities at Tulane University under a single head, the conversion of the university program to a war-time basis is rapidly under way, President Rufus C. Harris has announced.

THIS is emphatically a distinguished book. Distinguished in its thought, in its uncompromising integrity both as to material and artistic rightness, particularly distinguished in its unusual central theme and in its central character.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the first month of the new year was the smallest since last August and the dullest for a corresponding month since 1919. Sales failed to cross the million-share marke in any session, the largest day's turnover amounting to only 801,860 shares on Jan. 6.

IN Mme. Undset's new book, the first chapter, "Norway, Spring 1940," sets the measure of its high quality. Here a great drama is conveyed to us by a master hand. A country centuries old, a decent people, magnificent in its silent courage, is invaded by "an army of marauders who came to live where they have not built, to reap where they have not sown, to rule over a people they have never served.''

IF there is one legend of which Vermonters have been proud it is that of Ethan Allen and the Green Mountain Boys. Mr. Thompson's grandfather, D.P. Thompson, contributed to it in his classic thriller, "The Green Mountain Boys."

WITH GENERAL MacARTHUR, on the Bataan Peninsula, Luzon, Jan. 27 (Delayed) -- Equipment taken from captured Japanese snipers has proved surprisingly complete. It enables each man to fight independently for from two weeks to a month behind enemy lines, if he can get a minimum of food and water from the countryside.

In the eight weeks since the United States was plunged into war, the mobilization of American industry has proceeded at a blistering pace and almost as many curbs and controls over the manufacture and distribution of goods have been issued as came out during the entire eighteen months of our participation in the First World War.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 31 -- Wallace Wade, who has never absorbed a bad licking in a quarter-century of coaching, would rather turn out a weak football team at Duke next Fall than one composed partly of freshmen.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Two young theological students stood up in police court today to explain why they did not stand up when "The Star-Spangled Banner" was played in the Avalon Theatre last night.

ECUADOR placed on sale at Quito and Guayaquil on Friday a series of eight stamps, each 24 by 35 millimeters in size, commemorating the "discovery" of the Amazon River four centuries ago by Francisco de Orellana (1512-1546), Spanish adventurer who sailed down the Amazon from the River Napo to the Atlantic.

In the total of services undertaken for war work, a sizable portion is the contribution of college women's clubs in the city, whose well-equipped headquarters furnish useful bases of operation and whose trained memberships can provide both leisure time and adaptable skills.

The present national emergency faces America with many problems, not the least of which is laying plans for a happier future. In order to prepare for that future we must conserve human intellect as well as tin, copper, rubber and other strategic materials, and this conservation of human intellect is at present a major problem which should be attacked and solved in a suitable fashion.

"LIV KONGEN! Liv Danmark!" is the salutation of the Free Danish short-wave station to its King and its people. For fifteen minutes each day a stanch voice from the secretly located radio blasts Danish Quislingists and appeals to all loyal Danes to fight the Nazi menace.

HENRY ROSENBLATT, who sings on today's Metropolitan Opera "Auditions of the Air," is the inheritor of a singing tradition of ten generations. His father was Joseph Rosenblatt, regarded as one of the foremost cantors of Europe and North America, and a concert singer of enviable reputation.

THERE they stood, fifty-eight of them, lined up in twos, already striving to achieve some semblance of military bearing. A murderous wind whipped around the comer of Church and Vesey, making some of the more poorly clad among the lot involuntarily lean toward the cold stone wall of the Federal Office Building for protection. Passers-by curiously eyed the little band.

The Catholic Church is the "great bulwark" of democracy in the world today because it is, and always has been, the "champion of the natural, rights of man," the Rev. Francis P. Le Buffe, S.J., secretary of the Sodality of Our Lady, declared yesterday at the twenty-third annual convention of the New York Province of the Newman Clubs in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Furniture and white sales continued fairly active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Suits and blouses drew good consumer response.

ENGLAND has for generations afforded a place of refuge for exiles. Her "latch-string never was drawed in" to exclude men and women who have had to flee from their homeland, whether monarchs who have lost their crowns or revolutionists anxious to escape the noose.

Furniture and white sales continued fairly active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Suits and blouses drew good consumer response.

ENGLAND has for generations afforded a place of refuge for exiles. Her "latch-string never was drawed in" to exclude men and women who have had to flee from their homeland, whether monarchs who have lost their crowns or revolutionists anxious to escape the noose.

JULIA TRUITT YENNI'S new novel is a family chronicle -- original, lively and vastly entertaining. The adventures, mostly minor, of the Larbells of Louisiana are reminiscent of "February Hill" with a difference -- not so earthy and direct.

AMONG the several industries that have developed rapidly but without out much fanfare in the last few years in this country is pottery. And, priorities permitting, the progress is likely to continue because, although shipments are still coming in from England, the volume is bound to be cut down somewhat and the manufacture of chinaware in England curtailed.

Letters from A.D. Wallace and from Culver Glaysteen in THE TIMES of Jan. 23 are commendable in their spirit, but they show a fundamental ignorance of what the colleges and schools are actually doing in their war effort.

The only rubber experimental station in the United States, a little-known 150-acre United States Plant Introduction Station at Miami, which has been quietly growing rubber saplings since 1925, may play a major part in the nation's defense program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator and retail rationer, announced today a procedure for releasing to civilians between Feb. 12 and Feb. 26 new passenger cars which had been purchased, but not delivered, before the government "froze" all automobile sales on Jan. 1.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Jan. 13 -- Thirty-five per cent of the men students on cooperative jobs at Antioch College are working in defense industries, helping to build the nation's fighting planes, its bombers, its submarine engines.

LANSDOWNE, Pa., Jan. 31 -- Charles S. Satterthwait, a Quaker whose son is serving a prison term of a year and a day for refusing to register under the Selective Service Act, announced today that he would resign from the Society of Friends tomorrow in order to be ready for combat duty if the government called him.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 31 -- The contribution teachers can make to war, victory and reconstruction will be considered by students in teacher-training courses in Eastern colleges and universities, at a conference which New Jersey College for Women has called for Saturday, Feb. 28, under the auspices of the Department of Education.

THE Klondike has been seriously maligned by Hollywood and particularly by Mae West, according to Mrs. Kate Rockwell Matson, who was known simply as Klondike Kate in the Alaska gold rush days at the beginning of the century, when she was 19 years old.

While the Axis submarine campaign off the Atlantic Coast has startled the American public, the volume of losses actually has been small in proportion to the volume of shipping moving in and out of the ports affected.

JOHN SMITH and Charles Jones, pilots in the Army Air Corps, may never win promotion or acquire any medals for bravery under fire, but their names are rapidly becoming as familiar in military aviation circles as that of General H.H. (Hap) Arnold, their chief.

A NOVEL by an active officer of the British Army with a setting of the Libyan Desert during the latter half of 1940 has today a fortuitous timeliness with Cyrenaica just conquered and Imperial and Free French troops eagerly scanning Tripolitania across the Gulf of Sidra.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- That their operations are certain to be revolutionized, through sheer force of the war effort, out that government agencies are anxious to render sympathetic assistance during the unsettled period, are probably the two outstanding convictions with which members of the food industry are returning from their week-long series of conventions here.

THE simulation of three dimensions on a two-dimensional plane has been under experimentation with varying success in the workshops of both the technician and the practical photographer. Two methods in the first category have recently been made public, both achieved by specially designed devices.

Problems encountered by the administrators of universities and professional schools as a result of the wartime shortening of many college curricula will be studied in a new type of professional course beginning next Saturday at the New York University School of Education.

MAYBE Williams Haynes is right. Or maybe he is simply modest. In a foreword to his book called "This Chemical Age,"* he says that what he has written may send cold shivers up and down the spines of professors of chemistry and chemical engineers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -"Submarine School," a naval training story which George Seaton is writing at Twentieth Century-Fox, has been scheduled as a vehicle for Pat O'Brien to follow "Manila Calling" on the actor's schedule. William Perlberg will produce the film, and Lynn Bari is expected to play the feminine lead.

Rediscovery of the romance in religion and the realization that God does not always travel the road we expect Him to will give new courage in a world of crisis, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said in his sermon yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A fifty-five-mile advance on a sixty-mile front in the Ukraine in the last few days was reported in Soviet war dispatches today. From Leningrad to Crimea came report after report of the success. Although few definite places were named, it was indicated that whole areas that appeared to be under German control actually had been isolated.

The International League will run an all-star game next Summer for the first time and will devote the gross receipts to the purchase of baseball equipment for the armed forces of this country and Canada.

Despite Billy Rose's communiques to the effect that the weekly grosses for his production of "Clash by Night" were steadily mounting, Mr. Rose's office yesterday suddenly announced the final performance would be given on Saturday night. Reports that differences between Mr. Rose and Tallulah Bankhead; who is starred, brought about the unexpected closing announcement would not be discussed by the producer's office. Miss Bankhead was not available for comment.
For one period the New York Rangers were unable to do a thing against Turk Broda, guardian of the Toronto-Maple Leafs' cage, in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

The 1942 Fifty Books of the Year exhibition of the American Institute of Graphic Arts will open at the New York Public Library, Room 312, on Thursday. The books in the show were selected for their artistic and technical excellence from 631 titles submitted by 148 publishers.

VICHY, Feb. 1 -- The trend of the Bourse at Lyon as well as that in Paris was changed completely at the opening last week. Offers were much more numerous and exceeded demands on certain stocks. The result was an increase in transactions, and some appreciable declines were noted, while for other stocks the demand was maintained with further advances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that the annual fund-raising dinners of the party would be held Monday night, Feb. 23, when President Roosevelt will make a Washington's Birthday fireside address.

No gain or loss is recognized for income tax purposes as a result of an exchange of stock or other securities of a corporation, solely for those of another corporation in a reorganization to which both concerns are parties, the Bureau of Internal Revenue explained yesterday.

Artur Schnabel, pianist, gave his fifth and final all-Schubert recital under the auspices of the New Friends of Music late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. He played the Moments Musicales and the Sonatas in A minor, Opus 143, and in D major, Opus 53.

OTTAWA, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's national income, "the most comprehensive measure of economic progress," rose to $456,400,000 in December, compared with $442,300,000 in November, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics has reported.

The Jonah Realty Corporation, represented by Abraham Beier, attorney, bought from the Chase National Bank the taxpayer on a plot 60 by 100 feet at 8613-15 Twentieth Avenue, Brooklyn, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $8,400.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Sharply at issue at some points with recent critical findings of the special Senate (Truman) committee investigating the national defense program, a similar body of inquiry of the House of Representatives reported tonight it had found that American war planes now being made were equal in most types to those in production anywhere.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 1 -- Evasions of food regulations in Italy that came to the knowledge of the courts numbered more than 20,000 in November and December, the Minister of Justice was reported today to have told a Cabinet committee on supplies, under Premier Mussolini, that met in Rome last night.

If people wish to escape from the type of religion that invokes fear, gloom and self-torturing asceticism, they must turn to the inner wealth of "New Testament Christianity," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, declared yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

Four undergraduate colleges at New York University and one professional school will offer speed-up programs cutting the usual four-year course to three years with the opening of the second semester at the university's fifteen colleges, schools and divisions tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.
These days, when already busy women are taking up additional duties, every moment counts, particularly those slippery seconds before 9 A.M.

In a study prepared for the National Resources Planning Board, Professor Alvin H. Hansen disputes the widespread theory that a post-war depression is inevitable. We must have, he says, a "positive program of post-war economic expansion and full employment, boldly conceived and vigorously pursued."

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- The highest price on record for soy beans was hung up last week on the Board of Trade, with July selling at $2.05 1/2 a bushel, but the market gave way quickly in sympathy with corn and on the establishment of a relative low parity price by the Department of Agriculture.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. gave a luncheon today at the Gulf Stream Club for Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Dillman, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sidney, Mr. and Mrs. John Holliday Perry, Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Godde and Mr. and Mrs. Horace E. Dodge Jr.

Real estate in the Borough of Richmond is valued at $290,192,345 on the tentative assessment rolls for 1942-43 made public yesterday by the City Tax Commission. This total includes ordinary real estate having a tentative valuation of $270,961,395 and real estate of utility companies valued at $19,230,750.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Warships and planes of the United States Pacific Fleet have delivered smashing assaults with shell, bomb and torpedo against the strategically situated and powerfully armed and manned Japanese-mandated Marshall Islands and against a Japanese-occupied island in the Gilbert group, the Navy Department announced today.

Manhattan's taxable real estate is valued at $7,494,089,000 on the tentative assessment rolls for 1942-43, made public yesterday by the Tax Commission of the City of New York. This total includes ordinary real estate, tentatively assessed at $6,786,900,750, and utility companies' real estate, assessed at $707,188,250.

Announcement by the Tax Department that agents seeking reductions in assessments in behalf of property owners must either file a signed authorization or show by affidavit that this was impossible because of the owner's illness or absence from the city caused the Real Estate Board of New York to issue a statement explaining in detail the procedure for making pleas for cuts in assessments.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- More favorable weather conditions for the Winter wheat crop developed late last week. Heavy snow was reported in various important producing areas and the fall occurred ahead of cold weather so that the crop is amply protected in many sections.

The Red Cross "Flag of Mercy" was consecrated yesterday afternoon to the service of the nation's armed forces by the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, rector, at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

If bombs should fall on New York City 162,000 persons now studying first aid with Red Cross instructors here would be ready to assist in the emergency care of the injured, the national headquarters of the American Red Cross reported yesterday in revealing that nearly 500,000 residents of New York State are now first aid students.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Introduction tomorrow night of five of the principal defense bills sponsored by Governor Lehman is expected to place in the spotlight the announced determination of the Republican majority leaders of the Legislature that politics must be forgotten in the handling of defense in the national emergency.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Netherlanders, confident that the disastrous blows to Japan's convoy in the Strait of Macassar have smashed her most ambitious invasion plan so far, battled today to confine the enemy to scattered points where landings already have been achieved.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Having been assured of 80 per cent of the sugar it consumed during February, 1941, as a basis for operations during February of this year, the confectionery industry is hopeful that this ratio can be maintained for some time to come.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 1 (Australian Associated Press) -- For the second time within a year the Australian Imperial Force -- whose men helped hold Tobruk half a world away in North Africa -- forms part of a beleaguered garrison.

Taking the lead among the Westchester communities where commuter indignation runs high against the latest bid of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to boost its fares, the New Rochelle City Council plans to adopt a resolution tonight petitioning the Public Service Commission to deny the railroad's application for a 10 per cent rate increase.

Staten Island children petted reptiles yesterday for the first time at the zoo of the Staten Island Zoological Society on Broadway, West New Brighton, and many adults witnessed the extraction of venom from poisonous snakes. Of course the snakes handled by the children were non-poisonous.
The week-end brought tidings of grave crisis in the Far East.

RUMMAGING through a bookcase, there came to hand a paper-covered booklet of historical material. It was an account of the happenings at the first modern Olympic Games at Athens, 1896, translated from the Greek. Written on the spot by an enthusiastic Greek author, it had a quaint flavor. Some excerpts will be offered for perusal.

It was with incredulity followed by dismay that I read the report in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the remarks made by the incoming president of the County Medical Society. Dr. Maximilian A. Ramirez, at the Academy of Medicine on the subject of fee-splitting.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 1 -- Singapore's guns along the low north shore today opened fire for the first time in direct defense of this principal Far Eastern British base, sending their shells screaming across the Strait of Johore.

Total deposits of mutual savings banks operating in seventeen States were $10,489,679,543 at the year end, a decline of $116,544,205 from the amount on June 30, 1941, according to figures compiled by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

It is safe to say that no one is much pleased with the Price-Control Act, not even the Administrator, upon whom it confers great powers, the National City Bank says in its monthly letter for February. "The question, still unsettled," it adds, "is what are the objectives and the practicable area of price control, and what criteria should be used in the exercise of the Administrator's powers."

Opposition to an increase of the fare on subway and elevated lines to 15 cents for two rides and a dime for a single trip, as recently proposed by the Committee of Fifteen, headed by Paul Windels, former Corporation Counsel to Mayor La Guardia, gathered headway yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A conference of newspaper management and labor representatives will be held here March 2 by Thomas W. Holland, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Division of the Department of Labor, with the view of determining which job classifications in the newspaper industry are exempt from coverage under the wages and hours law.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- Japanese invaders of Burma tonight were reported attempting to bridge the broad Salween River north of Moulmein, continuing an offensive that now seems aimed directly at this gateway to the Burma Road, 150 miles northwest of Moulmein.

If we remember that the Christian ideal for unifying the world in brotherhood must lie in the foundation stone of belief in God, we are secure; if we forget it, we are in danger, the Rev. Dr. F. Howard Callahan declared yesterday in his first sermon as pastor of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

Baseball went all out last night to forget its immediate troubles when more than 1,000 guests, including most of the game's outstanding figures, attended the nineteenth annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Appointment of Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, to the War Production Board was urged here today by eleven national organizations whose members make use of the country's highways to ensure "adequate presentation of transportation problems as they relate to the parallel problems of production."

Dr. Franklin Dunham, executive director of the National Catholic Community Service, yesterday urged members of the College of Mount St. Vincent Alumnae Association to participate actively in community social service work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Independent retail sales during 1941, according to reports based on 23,653 stores, were 17 per cent larger than in 1940, which, in turn, were 8 per cent over those during 1939, the Commerce Department announced. December's sales were 13 per cent above those for the corresponding month last year.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 1 -- Reports in foreign military circles here tonight were that a vigorous counter-offensive against Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's strong armored forces in Libya was imminent, and that the British Eighth Army's new assault probably would be directed personally by General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck.

William Monypeny Newsom, broker and hunter, died suddenly at 8 o'clock last night in Jamaica, Queens, after he had become ill while driving on Grand Central Parkway, returning from a hunting trip to his home at 224 East Sixty-first Street. He was 54 years old.

In a simple ceremony on the windswept handball courts of Manhattan Beach, the new Coast Guard recruit training center there was commissioned yesterday afternoon and placed under Commander George E. McCabe.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Leo Lavalle, 24-year-old Pawtucket, R. I., athlete, and Miss Virginia Jahn, New York University sophomore, triumphed in the annual Middle Atlantic speed-skating championships today before more than 1,000 spectators.

The open season on broiled chicken, lamb chops and even the rare filet mignon, to be taken only in the company of not less than 200 other anglers or hunters, is just about getting under way, and this month will find at least a dozen of the local clubs in the throes of annual dinners.

Topics of The Times, Jan. 23, takes issue with statements made by me at the annual dinner meeting of the New York Urban League. While agreeing that "Negroes in search of jobs have to face discrimination," the writer contends that discrimination has no connection necessarily with economic depravity.
Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the third naval district and commander, North Atlantic naval coastal frontier, issued the following statement yesterday:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The War Department communique, covering reports received until 1 P.M., said:

TOKYO, Feb. 1 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The fate of Singapore is sealed, Japanese reports from the Malayan front declared today, asserting that the loss of the mainland water supply had inflicted severe privation on 3,000,000 inhabitants of the besieged British island.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces exerting increasingly heavy pressure on the Japanese in the Canton area have captured the important port of Sheklung, on the east bank of the Pearl River estuary forty-five miles east of Canton and the same distance north of Hong Kong, a communique announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's reference to the formation of a Ministry of Production and the publication of agreements for Allied coordination of raw materials were the chief topics last week in the commodity trade here.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- The injury-riddled Boston Bruins fell from undisputed possession of the National Hockey League lead to a first-place tie with the New York Rangers by permitting the lowly Brooklyn Americans to overtake them for a 2-1 triumph before a crowd of 8,500 tonight at the Boston Garden.
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Forty travel-weavy Americans, including twenty-one diplomatic officials, arrived here today from Rumania en route home.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's day communique follows:

The National Bureau of Economic Research has just published, in two volumes, the results of a study conducted over a period of years by Simon Kuznets on "National Income and Its Composition, 1919-1938." Some of the results of this study have a direct bearing on our major social problems and particularly on the problem of wax financing.

Calling for greater civilian contribution to the war and for a wider religious activity, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman told 1,800 Holy Name delegates at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that more sweat by every one will mean less shedding of blood of our fighting men and fewer tears for their loved ones.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- Strong Imperial units stood constant guard here today at the $12,000,000 stone and concrete causeway, the only link between Singapore Island and the mainland, in which a fifty-yard breach was blasted at the Johore end after the withdrawal from the peninsula.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Stabilization of war-risk insurance rates on merchant vessels by publishing them monthly instead of daily was announced today by the Maritime Commission after discussions with the American Marine Insurance Syndicate and other commercial marine underwriters.

Use of prison labor for production of war supplies is urged in a report that will be presented to the Legislature today by the Prison Association of New York as the first of thirteen "minimum recommendations" that it feels are "both vital to our present day needs and necessary for future planning."

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 102.5 to 102.6. Price changes among the groups were similar to those of the previous week. Farm products gained by 0.3 per cent, as higher prices for eggs, cattle, hogs, corn, cotton and lard were largely offset by lower quotations on fruits, wheat, oats, live poultry and potatoes.

An army of 5,000,000 men requires about 32,500 medical officers. This little army of highly trained men is not easily found without impairing the health of the general population. There are about 186,000 licensed physicians, of whom perhaps 40,000 have retired from practice because of age, administrative duties and disability.

Moved by fear that employment of children to overcome shortages of farm labor may undermine protective legislation, the National Child Labor Committee yesterday issued a statement designed to serve as a guide "for the appraisal of any suggestions for relaxation of present child labor and school attendance standards."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 1 -- Dr. H.V. Evatt, Minister of External Affairs, announced today that Lieut. Col. Eugene Gorman had been appointed Australian Consul General to the Netherlands Indies, and that Stanley M. Bruce High Commissioner in London, had been named Minister to the Netherlands court in London.

The old order changeth -- the luxuries that once made life bright are dwindling away and we find ourselves in an austere world becoming devoid of balloon tires and bombes glacees and girdles. In the name of patriotism we willingly bid a fond farewell -- or au revoir -- to two-thread hose and pate de foie truffe and caviar.

A very real problem arises from the inability of thousands of native-born Americans to establish their citizenship to the satisfaction of employers. The States in which bureaus of vital statistics have been in operation for less than a generation are compelled to furnish birth certificates on the basis of affidavits, family Bibles, old insurance policies and other evidence the value of which is largely cumulative.

Buying in anticipation of expected shortages continued heavy at both retail and wholesale last week. This was particularly true in the coat and suit markets, where demand was strong for silver fox-trimmed Winter coats and dressy Spring coats, and where manufacturers were finding it increasingly difficult to meet deliveries due to the wool situation.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 108.8 on Jan. 20, compared with 108.5 on Dec. 30, 108.4 on Dec. 9, 102.5 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Attorney General Biddle warned the 1,100,000 German, Japanese and Italian enemy aliens tonight that they must register and be finger-printed this month or face a penalty of internment for the duration of the war.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Headquarters communique said:

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The last-place Canadiens defeated the fourth-place Black Hawks tonight, 3 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game before 14,057 spectators in the Chicago Stadium. Red Hamill of the Hawks was banned from the game midway in the first period, receiving major misconduct penalties.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 1 -- In his address to the German nation last week Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler virtually promised victory over Russia this year and committed the German Armies once again to an offensive on the Eastern Front in the Spring.

A tract of thirty-three acres, formerly part of the Long Island Motor Parkway, at Searingtown, directly opposite the Links Club, has been purchased by an investing client of L'Ecluse, Washburn Co., brokers. The seller in the current deal bought the parcel about four years ago from the parkway through the same brokers.

Mifflin Large and Donald Strachan of the Merion Cricket Club of Philadelphia won the twelfth annual University Club invitation squash racquets doubles tournament for the A.H. Lockett Trophy yesterday by defeating Germain Glidden of the Englewood Field Club and Gordon Lindsay of Greenwich.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- January's passing puts the prospects of Spring in the forefront of Russian minds, although Winter has not yet shown all its teeth. To many in this land of workers and peasants Spring means sowing, and at present great attention is being paid to the problem of putting into production the maximum amount of regained land by distribution of seed and provision of machines for plowing.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Trading in lard futures on the Board of Trade last week was relatively quiet as traders awaited further developments in regard to price ceilings on oil and fats. There is a strong belief in many quarters that the ceiling prices on commodities such as lard, cotton seed oil and soy bean oil will have to be lifted ultimately.

The completion of a program for distributing identification tags to all children of the city was announced yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, in a report covering all school defense activities under the auspices of the School Defense Council, which includes representatives of the Board of Education, the parochial schools and other private schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The House Military Affairs Committee's special subcommittee on aviation made the following recommendations in the report it issued today:

BROWNSTOWN, Pa., Feb. 1 -- A small group of Lancaster County's Mennonites -- the Plain People with the broad-brimmed, black felt hats and the stern religious beliefs -- aired their grievance against Uncle Sam today. It is quite true, they said, that they find the United States "too socialist" and too bossy in such matters as compulsory education and the draft.

A nation goes bankrupt not because textbooks say it should but because it has run out of essential materials, according to Stuart Chase in "The Road We Are Traveling," a study of post-war economy made for the Twentieth Century Fund.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Sidney Hollander of Baltimore was re-elected president of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds today at the annual business meeting of the council. Mr. Hollander has headed the council since 1939.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 -- Cotton here fluctuated widely in both directions last week, advancing before midweek to the highest levels in twelve years, only to falter badly on Thursday after a statement by Secretary of Agriculture Wickard that farmers must be satisfied with prices "around parity" and growing indications that importation of South American cotton may be expanded by recently reduced freight rates.

RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Johnny Dawson, an amateur -- and for many years one of the best in the country -- today the best in the country -- today captured the sixth annual $5,000 pro-amateur golf tournament staged by Bing Crosby with a record-breaking score registered before a record-breaking crowd.

Countering proposals from labor circles for increased unemployment insurance benefits and other changes in the State job insurance law, New Jersey's Unemployment Compensation Commission, headed by Joseph G. Buch of Trenton, submitted a report to Governor Charles Edison yesterday urging that the law should not be changed now in favor of either the worker or the employer.

The words "the United Nations'' stand for something that ought to endure and grow, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday in a sermon in the James Memorial Chapel of the seminary at Broadway and 120th Street.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday at City Hall that he "expects to relinquish" his Federal post of Director of the Office of Civilian Defense as soon as he has disposed of several matters now pending in the organization of that agency.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Prices of grains and soy beans fluctuated most erratically last week on the Board of Trade. An early advance lifted grains to the highest ground in four years or more and soy beans to the highest point on record, but the bulge was followed by a sharp decline.

The New York City Housing Authority provided low-rent apartments last year for 2,943 additional families in four new projects and now operates twelve completed developments for 13,180 families, according to its annual report to Mayor La Guardia yesterday.

WITH THE A. E. F., in Northern Ireland, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Payday -- most important day of the month for soldiers anywhere -- brought cheers from United States troops here today. Then came the problem of assessing the pound sterling in terms of the United States dollar.

A duplex apartment comprising the entire two upper floors in the building at 115 East Thirty-fifth Street has been leased by John D. Beaufort, dramatic critic of The Christian Science Monitor, through Gilliam McVay, agents. The latter sold the property last Spring to Harlan W. Major, writer, who altered the dwelling into two apartments from plans by Hardie Phillip, architect.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- H.A. Millis, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, reported tonight that its most significant development of last year was the "vastly, increased desire of the workers ot determine their bargaining representatives."

A message from Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will be contained in "Buy-A-Brick" folders that will be distributed among 40,000 parochial school children to assist the St. Vincent's Hospital Building Fund campaign, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. James F. McDonnell, chairman of the women's division of the fund.

Holders of external twenty-year 5 per cent bonds of the State of New South Wales, Australia, due in 1957, have been asked by the Chase National Bank to submit tenders for the sale to it of sufficient bonds to exhaust the sum of $214,723 held in the sinking fund.

Acting in her capacity as chairman of the State Defense Council's committee on discrimination in employment, State Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller appealed to defense employers yesterday not to discriminate against foreign-born citizens and aliens, pointing out that no State or Federal law forbids the employment of aliens in defense and war industries.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Juan Antonio Rios, heading a pro democracy ticket, scored a decisive triumph over the Rightist candidate, General Carlos Iba+/-ez del Campo, in Chile's Presidential election today.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 -- The primary task of the steel industry and the War Production Board in the war effort continued last week to be one of distribution of steel carried on in such a manner that vital requirements of the Army, the Navy, The Maritime Commission and the lease-lend program would get the preference over all other work.

Reductions in assessed realty valuations contained in the tentative rolls of the Tax Department were described as "scattered" and "paltry" in a statement issued yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York. Commenting on the figures, the board said they showed the need of an inexpensive and impartial review of tax values, and urged a speedy report by the Bewley Legislative committee, which is studying proposals for a State board to review assessments.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in her Sunday evening sponsored broadcast over the Blue Network, tonight counseled girls in college not to curtail their preparations for life by a hasty marriage "because your beau is going into the Army."
