WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 1 -- Press discussion and a vote in the Commons show that New Zealanders still accept Winston Churchill's leadership and approve of the course adopted by the British Government in diverting aid to Russia despite the threat to Singapore.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The German radio broadcast a news agency announcement today saying Maj. Gen. Hans Georg Hofmann, chief group leader of the Storm Troopers and Under Secretary of State for Bavaria, died Saturday at Munich of a heart attack.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 1 -- Premier Refik Saydam in a radio appeal to the nation tonight called upon Turkish business, industry and agriculture to unite against waste and wartime profiteering under the newly revised Law of National Protection.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Feb. 2 -- After three days of fighting in which they crushed imposing German rear-guard forces in quick succession, Russian troops from Lozovaya, in the Donets Basin, succeeded yesterday in making contact with what were described as the main German lines nineteen miles northeast of Dniepropetrovsk, it was reported this morning by a commentator on the Moscow radio.
Eleven-year-old twin sisters captured first and second places in the Eastern States juvenile figure skating championships at the Iceland rink yesterday.

Alex Sandalack's goal in the third period broke a 1-all tie and enabled the Rovers to hand the front-running Boston Olympics a 2-to-1 setback in the Eastern Hockey League contest featuring the amateur twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Procter Gamble was the largest-national advertiser in magazines, network radio and farm papers last year, according to a survey by Advertising Age, out today. The company's total expenditure in these three media amounted to $12,988,877, compared with $13,645,337 in 1940.

The intricate mechanisms and gaudy trimmings of 2,450 pinball machines seized by the Police Department in crusades against gambling devices have been reduced to ten tons of needed defense metals, it became known yesterday.

Sir Thomas Beecham conducted the New York City Symphony Orchestra for the second time this season at Carnegie Hall last night. There was no assisting soloist, but the concert nevertheless attracted an audience of 2,890. It was the thirteenth in the popular-priced series being sponsored jointly by Mayor La Guardia And the New York City WPA Music Project.

With a note written in German and a hypodermic syringe on a desk near him, Dr. Ernst Steinitz, 63-year-old physician, was found dead on the floor of his consulting room at 147 East Fiftieth Street shortly after 11 O'clock last night. The body was discovered by his wife, Kate, when she returned after an absence from home during the evening.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 1 -- Another splendid best-in-show triumph was gained by the famed Irish setter Oh. Rosecroft Premier tonight to cap the twenty-ninth annual Maryland Kennel Club all-breed exhibition at the Fifth Regiment Armory.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 1 -- Major Vidkun Quisling was today proclaimed Premier of Norway by Reich Commisar Joseph Terboven. The new title did not change anything in Major Quisling's status as puppet.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- Charles S. Satterthwait, a Quaker whose son, a conscientious objector, is serving a prison term for refusing to register for the draft, resigned today from the Society of Friends as "a conscientious objector" to its stand against war.

Showing a tentative net decrease of $45,814,255 from the final figures for 1941-42, taxable real estate and special franchises in New York are tentatively assessed at $16,177,322,971 on the assessment rolls for 1942-43, released yesterday.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 27 (Delayed) -- British diplomacy is now busy consolidating the Allied position in the Middle East with more than a modicum of assistance rendered in Iran by the Soviet Legation and in both Iran and Iraq by United States' able Ministers.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 1 -- Japanese bombers struck today at Netherland Timor, southernmost of the Indies, only 310 miles from the Australian coast, while Netherland troops battled landing parties at four points, including the Amboina naval base.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 1 -- Juan Antonio Rios, Popular Front candidate, who has promised to press the policy of collaboration with the United States pursued by the late President Pedro Aguirre Cerda, today defeated General Carlos Ibanez del Campo, Rightist, by a decisive majority of more than 55,000 votes in Chile's Presidential election.
SEATTLE, Feb. (U.P) -- Striking welders in Puget Sound defense industries answered a government return-to-work demand by petitioning the Army and Navy tonight to take over operation of the plants.

At a meeting attended by thirteen sector wardens of Zone 3, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon, Captain William O'Brien of the Bathgate Avenue station read a letter of resignation from Major Frank Knowles, the subject of recent "court-martial" proceedings in an air raid warden dispute.

SALISBURY MILLS, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- The impossible occurred today during the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's nineteenth annual jumping championships when Torger Tokle, 23-year-old former Norwegian, met a stunning upset at the hands of Ola, a member of the Royal Norwegian Air Force stationed in Toronto.
CHUNKING, China, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- Chinese newspapers here clamored today for use of Chinese troops in Burma against the Japanese to save Rangoon and the Burma Road.

It would be surprising in these days laden with grief and danger if men did not pray more than ordinarily. In different times prayer takes different forms. If there is less of the formal saying of grace at meals, it does not mean of necessity that there is less giving of thanks.
BERLIN (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press), Feb. 1 -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

The Brooklyn Hispanos played to a tie with the champion Pawtucket eleven in the quarter-final round of the National Challenge Cup competition of the U.S.F.A. at Starlight Park yesterday, before a crowd of 3,000.

Stuart Gracey, baritone from Geneva, N.Y., made known a superior voice and estimable interpretive gifts at his first Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. His freely emitted, well-equalized tones were sonorous and resonant, capable of wide dynamic gradations, and used with intelligence and admirable musicianship.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The financial markets here, while refusing to yield in their exhibition of underlying strength, experienced a difficult week. There has been almost too much news for their digestive capacities and the result has been something like stagnation.

Both in New York and at London, last week's financial markets simply drifted. This was not because it was a week without news; but rather because, as in so many recent weeks, the news was curiously conflicting. If the markets had been continuously active, they would have moved alternately up and down.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- In blasts of a cold northwest wind that wrecked many boats, the 1942 sailing championships of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association were decided today off the New Lakeside Ice Yacht Club.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 -- British troops in the Jebel el-Achdar fought rear-guard actions yesterday against German forces advancing eastward in Cyrenaica, and by nightfall had withdrawn to the vicinity of Maraua, which is some eighty miles northeast of Bengazi.

The issue on which Mr. Churchill asked and received his overwhelming vole of confidence last week was the issue made crucial by war in the Pacific. He started for Washington immediately after the attack on Pearl Harbor, not only because the United States had become an active belligerent, but because the entry of Japan dictated drastic revision of British imperial defense plans.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Bullish sentiment in corn ran high early last week on the Board of Trade, but a statement attributed to Secretary of Agriculture Wickard that the government would attempt to hold the market price of that grain down to 85 per cent of parity caused a break of 5 cents a bushel, the permissible limit for one day's trading, on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Private Joseph L. Lockard, 20, of Williamsport, Pa., was the soldier who detected Japanese planes approaching Pearl Harbor while he was practicing at the listening device the morning of Dec. 7 only to have his warning disregarded, Representative Harness of Indiana reported tonight.

Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, reported that last week it enrolled 2,557 volunteers. She pointed out that these figures did not relate to activities in the protective services, such as air raid wardens and fire auxiliaries, but to activities in the social welfare field, clerical jobs and such work as nurses' assistants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Service on the Chicago, North Shore Milwaukee Electric Railroad was disrupted today as union employes of Chicago's elevated lines refused to throw switches for the North Shore trains on the elevated tracks.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- In blasts of a cold northwest wind that wrecked many boats, the 1942 sailing championships of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association were decided today off the New Lakeside Ice Yacht Club.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 -- British troops in the Jebel el-Achdar fought rear-guard actions yesterday against German forces advancing eastward in Cyrenaica, and by nightfall had withdrawn to the vicinity of Maraua, which is some eighty miles northeast of Bengazi.

The issue on which Mr. Churchill asked and received his overwhelming vole of confidence last week was the issue made crucial by war in the Pacific. He started for Washington immediately after the attack on Pearl Harbor, not only because the United States had become an active belligerent, but because the entry of Japan dictated drastic revision of British imperial defense plans.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Bullish sentiment in corn ran high early last week on the Board of Trade, but a statement attributed to Secretary of Agriculture Wickard that the government would attempt to hold the market price of that grain down to 85 per cent of parity caused a break of 5 cents a bushel, the permissible limit for one day's trading, on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Private Joseph L. Lockard, 20, of Williamsport, Pa., was the soldier who detected Japanese planes approaching Pearl Harbor while he was practicing at the listening device the morning of Dec. 7 only to have his warning disregarded, Representative Harness of Indiana reported tonight.

Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, reported that last week it enrolled 2,557 volunteers. She pointed out that these figures did not relate to activities in the protective services, such as air raid wardens and fire auxiliaries, but to activities in the social welfare field, clerical jobs and such work as nurses' assistants.

Real estate of all kinds in the Borough of Brooklyn tentatively is assessed for 1942-43 at $3,620,159,756. The total includes ordinary real estate having a tentative aggregate assessment of $3,355,162,381 and real estate of utility companies valued at $254,997,375.
LA CROSSE, Wis., Feb. 1 -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis successfully defended his national senior men's skating championship today by taking a second in the final event, the five-mile race.

Treachery received its highest reward of the war yesterday when Hitler elevated Major Vidkun Quisling to be Norway's Chief of State. This man, whose betrayal of his own people made his name a hateful symbol in every free land will now attempt the impossible task of persuading Norway to "collaborate" with Germany.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Australian Cabinet announced tonight that it had made secret defense decisions to meet the changing situation as a result of the Japanese gains in Malaya and the East Indies. War Minister Francis Forde said the measures could not be disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Three Latin-American women leaders are returning soon to their native countries following tours through the United States, convinced that they can accomplish much in clearing up misconceptions about this country's way of life.

VICHY, Feb. 2 -- The governor's report to the annual assembly of the Bank of France shows an increase of 71,500,000,000 francs in advances to the State in 1941, of which 46,700,000,000 was in the first half year and 24,800,000,000 in the second.

"Kings Row," which has its world premiere tonight at the Astor, is the first of the six new films scheduled to be presented this week at mid-town theatres. The cast of the Warner drama, which is based on the novel by Henry Bellamann, is headed by Ann Sheridan, Ronald Reagan, Betty Field, Claude Rains and Robert Cummings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Long-range American guns, barking salvos some ten miles across the water from four fortresses in Manila Bay, have blasted and destroyed a Japanese concentration of men and boats, caught by surprise in apparent preparation for an attempted mass invasion of Corregidor and other Manila Bay strongholds, the War Department announced today.

Ruth Lipscomb, 26-year-old Negro pianist from Bluefield, W. Va., who is a graduate of the Juilliard School of Music, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Her program was made up of three major works -- Bach's Suite in G major, Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 90, and Schumann's "Etudes Symphoniques" -- and shorter pieces by Albeniz, Debussy and Liszt.

Helen Traubel, American soprano, will sing the role of Bruennhilde in "Goetterdaemmerung" for the first time next week, when the opera is presented at the Metropolitan Opera House as the concluding work of the uncut "Ring" and the fourth performance of the Wagner matinee cycle.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Ten thousand guerrilla fighters are in action against Hungarians in the Carpatho-Ukraine, that part of former Czechoslovakia ceded to Hungary, it was reported tonight by Pavel Cebere, representative of the Carpatho-Ukrainians on the Czechoslovak State Council in London.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A report of the Federal Power Commission on the condition of the electric utility industry at the beginning of 1941 which covers 95 per cent of the privately-owned electric utilities in the United States, shows that annual operating revenues had risen to $2,403,711,699.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- Australian bombers made another smash at the Japanese invasion armada in the harbor of Rabaul, New Britain Island, as Japanese war planes continued raids on towns in northeast New Guinea, it was announced.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 1 -- The thousands of empire troops manning battle stations in this island fortress are determined to check the hordes of Japan so that the Netherlands Indies and Australia can gain a breathing spell.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 1 -- General Draja Mikhailovitch and his loyal Yugoslav regular troops and Chetnik forces, who have waged relentless warfare against the Axis armies of occupation in Yugoslavia for seven months, have exhausted large reserves of their munitions and food stores and now urgently need assistance from their allies, according to reports reaching foreign military intelligence sources and Yugoslav circles abroad.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Two defeats at Changsha -- in which the Chinese claim 100,000 Japanese fell -- have proved too much for the Japanese commander, Lieut. Gen. Korechika Anami, Chinese reports said today, and the sword-rattling little general has killed himself.

John W. Stedman, chairman of the committee acting for the holders of the first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, has sent a letter to owners of these securities attacking an alternative reorganization proposal advanced by the Alleghany Corporation on the ground that it is a tax-avoidance scheme.

Bach's name was not taken in vain by the earnest performers assembled for the second Town Hall concert, last night, of the Bach Circle. He was respectfully represented as a transcriber, in his arrangement for harpsichord of concerto movements by Vivaldi, and as a composer by his sonata for flute and violin in G major and his Fifth Brandenburg Concerto.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 2 -- Miss Hope Gilmour belongs to an old Ottawa family. It was while Lord Tweedsmuir was here as Governor General that she became acquainted with his son, now Lieutenant Buchan. She went to England last September as a member of the Women's Transport Service and has been driving an ambulance attached to the Polish Army.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt had no engagements today. He asked Congress to approve a loan of $500,000,000 to China, ordered the Office of Government Reports to expand the governmental information services, nominated Leon Henderson as Price Control Administrator and nominated Rear Admiral Alexander H. Van Keuren to be chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ships. He signed three minor bills.

There are in this country a great many people who, even though they are unable to do actual defense work, can contribute constructive ideas and suggestions which would be of great benefit to the public if tested and generally adopted.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Feb. 3 -- A series of bitter counter-attacks launched against the Russians positions at several points on the tremendous Donets front in yesterday's operations failed to halt Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's offensive directed against Dniepropetrovsk, according to reports received here from Moscow early this morning.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 2 -- To meet wartime conditions the Harvard Law School announced today condensation of the three-year course into twenty-seven months, operation on a full-year basis, establishment of at least eleven national scholarships with maximum stipends of $650 each, acceptance of certain students after only three years of college work, and admittance of students in June and February, as well as in September, beginning next June 22.

The home of George Blumenthal, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, who died last June at the age of 83, will become immediately available to the museum instead of after two years, according to an accounting filed yesterday in Surrogates Court by Carl J. Schmidlapp of 834 Fifth Avenue and Louis M. Loeb of 1120 Park Avenue, temporary administrators.

Before a crowd of 17,000 at Madison Square Garden last night Herman Van Putten, a maintenance man on the George Washington Bridge and runner-up in the 1942 national speed skating championship, carried off top honors of the eighteenth annual Silver Skates competition staged by The Daily News Welfare Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the grain and soy bean markets in sympathy with a sharp break in cotton and on disappointing news from Washington. Outside buying was not aggressive and at no time were prices above the close on Saturday, with the finish about the bottom.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Norwegian circles in London today reported fresh stories of harsh German measures in Norway with the arrest of at least thirty-three personal friends of King Haakon, the execution of ten Norwegian patriots and the arrest of many others just before Vidkun Quisling took office as "Premier" of German-occupied Norway.

The American Red Cross expects to have information soon concerning American prisoners held by the Japanese and also to be able to send them boxes of food and clothing, it was announced yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, vice chairman of the drive to raise $7,330,000 as Greater New York's quota of the $65,000,000 war fund sought throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The scope of Federal power concerning interstate commerce was broadened by the Supreme Court in two opinions today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Another government effort to stop blanket and increasing discrimination against the employment of aliens in factories working on war contracts was started today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

A kaleidoscope of hats presenting many themes and all founded on one basic thought, "Women must be 150 per cent feminine in wartime," was offered at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday morning. They were the outpourings of the imagination of one young man, Josephi, to whom the Fifth Avenue specialty house gave his first one-man show.

Charles H. Lipsett, publisher of The Daily Metal Reporter, yesterday sent a telegram to Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board in Washington, characterizing as "amazing" the published statement of Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, charging that there was a conspiracy between steel mills and scrap dealers to create a scrap iron shortage.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- Thousands of letters from women eager to join the Army are piling up on the desk of Representative Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 2 -- Prime Minister John Curtin on his return from West Australia said today that he was amazed and shocked at allegations casting doubt on the unity between Australia and Britain. He said there was complete unity between the whole people of Australia and the people of Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- General Douglas MacArthur's forces have "repulsed with heavy Japanese losses" a furious attempt by two full Japanese divisions to encircle the heroic but dwindling United States and Filipino garrison on the Bataan Peninsula, the War Department announced today.

Guilty pleas to misdemeanors were accepted yesterday by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein in General Sestions from the defunct Madison Personal Loan Corporation, formerly at 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, and an affiliated insurance agency, in addition to their three owners and a woman executive.

Among sixty passengers who arrived in a ship from South America yesterday were fifty-two German and Italian nationals from Venezuela. The Germans and Italians, officials at their nations' legations in Venezuela, and their families were taken to White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., to await an exchange of diplomats with the Axis governments.
The magnificent resistance of General Douglas MacArthur's armies in the Philippines is now ending its second month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- With tire retreading and recapping facilities of the country swamped by demands from car owners outside the categories of those entitled to new tires, government officials are considering some form of control of rationing which will insure an equitable distribution of the tire repair work, according to reports today.

The problem of what to do about Germany after the war was discussed last night by Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador to the United States, in a speech at the fifty-fifth annual dinner of the Church Club of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Patrolman Eligio Sarro, 35 years old, of 362 Broome Street, fatally wounded one hold-up man and routed three others at 10 o'clock last night when the four attempted to rob twenty members in the store clubroom of the Spring Arrows Social and Athletic Club at 344 Broome Street, between the Bowery and Elizabeth Streets.
SINGAPORE, Feb. 2 -- Singapore sat down to a rationed dinner tonight with an orchestra of guns hurling tons of high explosives across Johore Strait.

John T. Whitaker, foreign correspondent of the Chicago Daily News, is now in the Polyclinic Hospital here in a plaster cast that he must wear about his body another five months to be able to serve the United States in combat. He said yesterday that he "didn't see any copy in that."

The Boston Comic Opera Company will swing into its second bill this evening at the St. James, offering one of the most popular operettas in the Gilbert and Sullivan cycle, "The Mikado." In keeping with contemporary events, the liberty has been taken of slightly modifying the satirical musical; Sir W.S. Gilbert's complimentary reference to the "gentlemen of Japan" has been altered to "We are gangsters of Japan."

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Production of war material at the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's tin mill in Gary has been cut 50 per cent by a slowdown of eighty reckoners who count and pile tin plate, company officials said today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 2 -- Hampered by the fierce counter-attacks of the Fourth Indian Division, part of the German African Corps continued yesterday to advance along the main roads leading eastward from Barce. One German unit reached the vicinity of Slonta.

Viscount Trenchard, Britain's Marshal of the Royal Air Force, has always enjoyed the reputation of being a man of few words the force of which invariably commands loyal obedience and confidence in his judgment. He is probably the world's most experienced exponent of air power for defense and offense regardless of whether the task be branded naval, military, independent or home defense.

The pioneer pickets of the Brass Rail, Seventh Avenue between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, have long since vanished from the scene, a check-up disclosed yesterday. The young men and young women who pace in front of the Brass Rail now, in the fourth year of tireless patrol, are new links in the chain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- In order to conserve woolens, cotton, rayon and other materials used for uniforms, the American Red Cross volunteer special services, composed of women Red Cross workers, will observe a new set of rules to this end, it was announced today by Mrs. Dwight Davis, national director of this branch of the Red Cross organization.

The Right Rev. Alfred A. Gilman, Bishop of Hankow, and seven other Episcopal missionaries are interned by the Japanese in Hankow and Wuchang, China, according to a cablegram received yesterday at the office at 281 Fourth Avenue of the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Presidential determinations of foreign policy can neither be disregarded by the courts nor upset by the States, the Supreme Court held, 5 to 2, today deciding that the United States Government has prior claim to the assets of the New York branch of the First Russian Insurance Company.

Predicting that the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System will show declines from now on, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in the February issue of its review of credit and business conditions, points out that the substantial increase in January in these excess funds may be considered in the nature of an interim movement.

For the third time in less than a week the cotton market suffered yesterday a sharp setback. An accumulation of liquidation and hedging offers at the opening of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange carried prices of active futures to losses of as much as 27 to 55 points, or $1.35 to $2.75 a bale.

Recent findings of the Department of Agriculture indicate that most American women are "dumpy." Dumpiness is as often the result of faulty posture as of any unkind design of nature. Bad posture can be overcome, and many women are working hard at it these days.

An appeal to the qualified young women of the nation to join the nursing services and "do their bit" in the war and in the post-war reconstruction period was made last night by representatives of the government and the nursing profession at a rally in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Nursing Council on National Defense.

Sales of common and preferred shares in off-the-market offerings in 1941 amounted to 8,408,825 shares, or less than 5 per cent of the volume on the New York Stock Exchange last year, according to a survey compiled by Shields Co. The firm has gathered a list of all secondary distributions, which is thus made available in complete detail for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Appeals to both President Roosevelt and the House for appropriate recognition of the action of a soldier which, if followed up, might have averted or greatly lessened the Pearl Harbor disaster, were made today by Representative Harness of Indiana.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt today designated the advanced time system which will go into effect Feb. 9 as "war time."

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Governor Lehman announced today the promotion of his assistant counsel, Thomas L.J. Corcoran, to the newly created full-time job of executive secretary and counsel to the State Defense Council. George Xanthaky of Long Beach was named to succeed Mr. Corcoran.

The authenticity of a six-volume copy of the first edition of Henry Fielding's novel "Tom Jones" was placed in issue yesterday in a suit filed by Baron Nathaniel Mayer Victor Rothschild against Owen D. Young and Gabriel Wells in Federal court. Mr. Wells, prominent dealer in rare books, was Mr. Young's agent in the sale of the item to Baron Rothschild in 1937.
Apartment rental activity reported yesterday was centered in the East and West sides of the midtown areas and in the West Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt directed Lowell Mellett, Director of the Office of Government Reports, today to expand the facilities of the United States Information Service so as to provide in Washington a central clearing house for the convenience of business men attempting to obtain advice and direction for utilization of their facilities in the war effort.

DETROIT, Feb. 2 -- The controversy over double pay for Sunday work that had threatened to delay the introduction of the seven-day work week in automobile plants converted to the manufacture of arms appeared headed for speedy settlement today when it became known that the General Motors Corporation, with $5,000,000,000 in war orders, was ready to abide by any decision of the War Labor Board on the dispute.

The jury of awards (Raymond P.R. Neilson, Nan Greacen and Keith Shaw Williams) for the forty-third annual exhibition of the American Society of Miniature Painters, met yesterday morning at the Hotel Gotham branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries.

The five-story ten-family flat at 118 Clinton Street, Hoboken, N.J., was sold by the Hoboken Bank for Savings to the York Holding Company, Inc. The new owner gave back a purchase money mortgage for $9,900.

An unscheduled "added attraction" was played for nearly two hours yesterday afternoon before a small but select audience on the seventh floor of Loew's State Building, 1540 Broadway, in Times Square, when two fledgling pigeons were "rescued" from their nest in a ventilator shield in the accounting department of Loew's, Inc.

SINCE the letter was not only passed by the naval censor but bore on each typewritten page a stamped notice in red ink reading "Released by Cinc Pacflt for Publication," it must be all right to expose it to public view. That "Cinc Pacflt," of course, means Commander in Chief, Pacific Fleet. They're even saving on red ink and red tape now.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- The council of the Corporation of Foreign Bondholders in its sixty-eighth annual report today commented critically on the treatment accorded by a number of South American nations to British holders of their external bonds.

History will not fail to note, with more than a little irony, that the first American initiative in the war in the Pacific was directed against a group of islands acquired by Japan under a mandate from that same League of Nations on which the American people turned their backs in 1942. This group is the Marshall group, which Japan pledged itself not to fortify.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- On all the principal sectors of the Russian-German front the advancing Soviet forces were seeking combat with the enemy's main forces, while at the two extremes of active fighting -- Leningrad and Sevastopol -- the initiative was gradually passing to the Russians, according to advices available here today.

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- R.J. Lamont, president of the Seattle-Tacoma Shipbuilding Corporation, said today that a strike of welders was "definitely finished" at Seattle and that the Tacoma situation was "rapidly improving."

VICHY, France, Feb. 2 -- A recurrence of bombings and assaults on the troops of the occupation forces resulted in an announcement today by the German authorities in Paris of the execution of six persons and the deportation to Eastern Europe of one hundred others described as Communists and Jews.

An investment purchase in Yorkville was reported yesterday when a client of R. Solove, broker, bought from Piroska Muller for cash above four mortgages totaling $71,400 the five four-story tenements known as 235-7 East Eightieth Street, 346 East Eighty-fifth Street, 404 East Seventy-fifth Street and 411 East Seventy-eighth Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Prospects of curtailment of garment production growing out of shortages of materials caused by wartime needs and the unemployment of workers resulting therefrom headed the agenda of the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which opened its quarterly session today with David Dubinsky, the president, presiding.

A "package" bid submitted by a banking group headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co. won the award in competitive bidding yesterday of $10,000,000 first mortgage and first lien 3 per cent bonds and 150,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.
Mrs. Walter Eyre Lambert gave a luncheon yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Among her guests were Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge, Mrs. David C. Hanrahan and Lord Marley.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- The Rio de Janeiro Pan-American Conference was described as an important political and diplomatic success for the United States and as a serious blow to Axis plans in an article by an expert in South American affairs in today's Pravda.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The War Department issued this communique, covering reports received up to 9:30 A.M. today:

HONOLULU, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, disclosed today that combat vessels of all types participated in the attack on Japanese naval and air bases in the Marshall and Gilbert Islands and said it was "certain that extensive damage was done."

DUBLIN, Feb. 2 -- It is common knowledge throughout Eire that since early last December army authorities of this State have been receiving supplies of arms and ammunition, with some artillery and equipment, delivered by the British across the Northern Ireland border.

A brief word about publishing in occupied France comes through from The Times Literary Supplement, London. The Times reports that a special section of Goebbels's Propaganda Ministry functions with "Prussian thoroughness" at its offices at the Champs Elysees, passing on all editors add press contributors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- The government will start mass registration of potential labor this month by sending work-experience questionnaires to all men within the new draft ages of 20 to 45, officials of the United Sates Employment Service said tonight.
The general public will be given today its first opportunity to participate in the ownership of the eighty-one-year-old House of Morgan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to authorize a $500,000,000 loan to China as a means of strengthening that country's position "as regards both her internal economy and her capacity in general to function with great military effectiveness in our common effort."

A gradual shift in track and field interest from the mile and two-mile events to races over shorter distances as a result of this country's participation in the war was predicted by Emil Von Elling, New York University coach, at yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Track Writers Association at the Hotel Paramount.

A banking group headed by Alex Brown Sons won yesterday the award of an issue of $920,000 of Baltimore County, Md., metropolitan district bonds at an interest cost basis of 1.86 per cent. The successful bid was 100.259 for $575,000 as 2s and $345,000 as 1.60s.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 28 (delayed) -- More effectively to combat the Axis propaganda flowering in Iraq and Iran from seeds planted in the last seven years, the British Public Relations Division, created in recent months, now is using the Gallup system of questioning all classes of Moslems on the effectiveness of the word battles being staged in this area.
"There was evidence that the old-school tie was hindering the progress being made in Singapore."

CEICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Hog prices ad! vanced today 25 to 40 cents a hundred pounds to a new high since August, 1937, { and to peak levels for February since 1927. Th top price of $12.50 compared wints 1512.65 in August, 1937. Light pork win rose cent a pound to 20 to 21 cents.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Agreements for exchange of American and Axis diplomats have been reached "in principle and in many details," the State Department announced today.

Miss Caroline Myers of Vassar, by winning two hard-fought matches, gained the semi-finals of the eleventh annual New York Junior League invitation squash racquets tournament as play began on the Junior League courts yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The House received and began consideration today of the third of its regular appropriations bills for the fiscal year 1943, that for the Treasury and Postoffice Departments, which carries a total of $1,112,926,899. A vote on the bill is set for tomorrow.

At precisely 4:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon Eddie Brannick sneaked out of the meeting room in which the major league executives were in session, gathered the group of impatient scribes around him and proudly announced that Harry Danning had signed a contract to play baseball for the Giants in 1942.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Sol Lesser, who joined RKO as executive producer last July, will leave the company March 1 to return to independent production, he announced today. His first independent film will be "Strange Victory," which United Artists will release. When Lesser left United Artists to go to RKO, he promised to deliver "Strange Victory" at a subsequent date.

The Silver Purchase Act of 1934 has long since proved itself a dud. It has accomplished none of the objectives that were set for it except the bald, indefensible objective of providing a Government handout to silver producers. On the record, Secretary Morgenthau would be on sound ground at any time in urging, as he did yesterday before a House Appropriations subcommittee, the repeal of the silver legislation.
Major league baseball swung briskly into action yesterday with inauguration of a program whereby its vast resources promise to provide a maximum yield to the nation's all-out war effort.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 2 -- The German High Command is apprehensive of the middle of February as the time when the Russians may well develop the full strength of their Winter offensive, and they are making preparations to meet the blow by throwing in ahead of schedule fresh or refitted divisions originally meant for the Spring drive, according to what may be considered reliable information from Berlin tonight.

Former marines, soldiers and sailors who are regarded as "over age and unfit for action" may serve on special guard duty with the Marine Corps at naval shore bases within the continental limits of the United States, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Victor Morrison, in charge of Marine Corps recruiting at 90 Church Street.
DETROIT, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- A strike of A.F.L. teamsters at the Detroit stockyards today threatened to tie up 80 per cent of the city's meat supply, and the market place for 70,000 Michigan farmers.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., told the Legislature today that it had full power to act in connection with the rate of the subway fare in New York City, despite the home rule provisions of the State Constitution.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 2 -- Admiral Gino Ducci, a conservative Italian military commentator, writing in the review Oggi, warned his readers today that "the Anglo-Saxon powers have apparently made up their minds to disregard , for the moment the Pacific theatre of operations to concentrate their attention on the European front."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- California intensified its drive against potential fifth columnists today with a surprise "raid" by Federal agents against the big Japanese fishing colony on Terminal Island at Los Angeles, with more arrests at San Diego and San Francisco and with the preparation of Statewide plans to deal with illegal Japanese societies and violators of the Alien Land Law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Leon Henderson of New Jersey to be Federal Price Administrator, charged with operating the machinery of a new law designed to stabilize living costs and prevent wartime inflation or post-war deflation.

A lease of the entire seventh floor in the building at 107 William Street, 60 John Street and 51-3 Maiden Lane by the Home Insurance Company has just been arranged by Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., with the New Amsterdam Casualty Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Four of the chief war-production officials of the nation tonight called on striking welders in the Puget Sound shipyards to return to work and "repudiate the leadership which has encouraged a reckless disregard of the needs of the country."

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The war news from the Far East unsettled the stock markets today. Gilt-edge issues were a fraction lower and most home rails eased after a firm opening. The leading industrials were fairly well maintained, but Guinness weakened to 85s.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 2 -- Once again rumors are current today that German desires are about to be expressed to the French Government in Vichy and once again it is added that this time "the matter is serious."

American Business Shares, Inc., sponsored by Lord, Abbett Co., Inc., yesterday reported net assets of $3,761,379 as of Dec. 31, 1941. The sum is equal to $2.44 a share on 1,541,059 shares, against $2.97 a share at the end of 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- Stanford and Notre Dame Universities are two of the four collegiate institutions which have been selected by the Navy as centers for its new aviation training program, it was learned tonight.

Owing to persistent demands from Australia and other quarters, Mr. Churchill has at last agreed to establish an Imperial War Council or Cabinet, which will be composed of representatives of Great Britain, Australia, Canada, New Zealand and South Africa, completely ignoring India and thus refusing to accord equal status to India within the British Commonwealth of Nations, as has been demanded by Indian political leaders anxious for Indo-British cooperation.
In your issue of Jan. 29 you view with misgivings the course adopted by President Roosevelt with respect to the manoeuvers of John L. Lewis to establish "unity" in the ranks of labor.

Writing in the February issue of the American Rifleman, official organ of the National Rifle Association, Colonel Ned M. Green, U.S.A., retired, asserts that a million riflemen a month could be trained by certified N.R.A. instructors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Ceiling prices designed to protect buyers and assure "reasonable profits" to automobile dealers were established today by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, for all makes of new passenger automobiles.

Marshal Rommel's panzer divisions have pushed 100 miles beyond Bengazi and now threaten both Derna on the coast and Mekili in the highlands. Once more they are moving uncomfortably close to the Egyptian border.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Some of the difficulties the Navy faces in fighting a war 7,000 mites across the Pacific were outlined in testimony of Secretary Knox, made public today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 -- Several officers from Morrison Field were entertained at the Everglades Club's informal dinner dance tonight. Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Rutherford and Captain and Mrs. Cyrus R. Miller were hosts to Colonel and Mrs. Paul E. Burrows and Miss Lynn Cary Burrows.

Ambassador Laurence A. Steinhardt delivered yesterday what was probably the shortest speech ever made by a diplomat. Mr. Steinhardt, until recently envoy to Moscow, and soon to leave for his new post as Ambassador at Ankara, was the guest of honor at a luncheon tendered by Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, at the Metropolitan Club.

The Norwegian people officially paid tribute to their "Ambassadors on skis" yesterday at the Norwegian Club, where survivors of the torpedoed tanker Varanger mingled with some of Norway's most distinguished figures in welcoming Ola, Sigurd and Fredrik at a luncheon.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 2 -- With the election of Juan Antonio Rios, the Popular Front candidate for President, definitely confirmed -- General Carlos Ibanez del Campo, his Rightist opponent, called on him this afternoon to pledge cooperation -- the question of when Chile would break off relations with the Axis remained pending tonight.

CHUNGKING, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- The Communist newspaper New China Daffy today urged China to carry on the war against Japan even if the Burma Road were cut and regardless of any Tokyo "peace offensive" aimed at releasing Japanese troops from China for use in the South Pacific.

The effects of the war in the Pacific on the tea-drinking habits of the American people became more apparent yesterday when the United States Board of Tea Experts, a seven-man body, began its annual five-day session of tea-tasting at the United States Appraisers Stores, 201 Varick Street.

The right of many of the city's large law firms to practice under the name of eminent lawyers who have been dead for many years was the subject of a unique action in the Appellate Term of the Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday.

A collapsible two-stretcher cradle that will make possible the conversion of any station wagon or light delivery truck into an efficient, emergency ambulance in a few minutes was demonstrated yesterday by its designer, William V.C. Ruxton, president of the British American Ambulance Corps, at headquarters of his organization, 420 Lexington Avenue.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- A resolution condemning the proposed 10 per cent increase in commutation rates of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and directing the Corporation Counsel to protest before the Public Service Commission was adopted unanimously tonight by the New Rochelle City Council.

Dean G. Edwards, who left city service last year to work for the Office of Production Management in Washington, was appointed as consulting engineer for the Borough of Manhattan yesterday by Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an ended Jan. 31 over the correspond-week Jan. 31 over the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

One hundred and eighty days of horse racing have been allotted to the five major tracks in this State, an increase of five days over last season, according to an announcement yesterday by the New York State Racing Commission.

Coordination of the national Junior League program with that of national defense, and now with the war program, was outlined yesterday at the opening of the annual February board meeting of the National Association of the Junior League of America in organization headquarters at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

In these demanding days of overstuffed schedules and undernourished budgets the tin can has come into its own. That pathetic figure of fact and fiction -- the blushing bride who embarks upon housekeeping with nothing but unbounded confidence and a can opener -- is being imitated on every side by cooks of long standing and consummate skill.

In his last press conference President Roosevelt referred to the decline in American gifts for war relief work in the allied countries. Many of those who used to give and could still give seem to think that now we, too, are at war we shall need all our money for our own people.

Warning that the last war should not be used as a barometer for business planning now, Julius Green, president of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., told members last night that, in view of the uncertainty concerning the near future, it would be best for them to cut their budgets one-half for the next six months and to buy from hand to mouth.

Several young women, comprising a junior committee, are aiding in the plans for the cocktail party, entertainment and buffet supper for the benefit of Bundles for Buddies to be held on Thursday at the Park Lane under the auspices of Mrs. Charles S. Peabody's unit of the Women's Victory League.

HONOLULU, Feb. 2 -- Further details of the Pacific Fleet's attack on the Japanese-mandated islands -- part of Japanese "loot" from World War I -- were not available today and probably will not be until the attacking units have returned to one of the fleet's bases in the broad Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- All materials which can be allocated to smaller manufacturers without hampering defense and essential civilian production will be given them, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said in a report today to the Senate committee on aid to small business.

George Townsend of Jackson Heights triumphed in five games in the first round of the metropolitan Class B singles squash tennis championship at the Yale Club yesterday. He won alternate games from W.M. Smith Jr., home club representative, after capturing the first.
BERLIN, Feb. 2 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's German High Command communique:

Although the decline was halted yesterday in the stock market after a week of inroads into values, the rally was only fractional and accomplished on too light a volume to be indicative of a major turn. The volume was the smallest in seven months, or since June 30, with sales 330,270 shares on the Stock Exchange against 377,490 on last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Chided in verse by a young woman Federal worker for his campaign to establish a 10 o'clock curfew for feminine government employes in Washington, Representative Earl Wilson of Indiana insisted today he would stick to his guns.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- New York State is faced with a "critical" shortage of electric power for war production industries which threatens power rationing in up-State communities this year and in New York City in 1943, the State Power Authority said in its eleventh annual report, submitted tonight to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 2 -- A communique issued in Rome today only to the foreign press, and received here, said Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, commander in chief of the German Air Force, has been in Italy since last Tuesday on an inspection tour of air bases in Southern Italy and Sicily and for conferences with Italian and German military leaders in Italy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A special provision allowing export agents and export merchants of iron and steel to charge above ceiling prices on export sales was added to the iron and steel price schedule today by the Office of Price Administration.

RUMER GODDEN (Mrs. Laurence Foster of Calcutta) is a novelist after all. Some of us thought so when her first book published over here, "Black Narcissus," appeared in 1939, but then came "Gypsy, Gypsy," which practically canceled the other out. The third proves it: the delicate, morbid, mysterious "Breakfast With the Nikolides."*

Owners of motor vehicles in New York State may not operate them legally beginning today without 1942 license plates or Federal tax stamps. The deadline for operating with 1941 licenses or without stamps expired at midnight yesterday and delinquent operators are subject to arrest and penalties of fines, imprisonment or both.
AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, Feb. 2 (U.R) -- Crew members of a British freighter that arrived today with her bow damaged believed she might have rammed and sunk two enemy submarines.

Although operating costs and tax charges of the Atlas Powder Company in 1941 were considerably higher than in the previous year, an increase of 68 per cent in sales enabled the concern to report slightly larger earnings.
Orders for the organization of the salvage warden service, mentioned Sunday by Mayor La Guardia in his radio address, went out yesterday over the police teletype system.

It is endlessly fascinating to observe with what a difference creative artists can approach and explore themes that reveal an at least basic relationship. Both Beatrice Cuming, whose one-man show of paintings opened yesterday at the Guy Mayer Gallery in the Fuller Building, and Julian Levi, making his second one-man appearance at the Downtown Gallery, 43 East Fifty-first Street, today, find themselves attracted to marine subjects -- harbors, beaches, ships.

Frederique Petrides' Orchestrette of New York may not play with all the finesse of a first rank organization, but, as it proved again last night at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, it can give an uncommonly interesting evening of music.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- An investigation by Westchester County of telephone toll rate "inequalities" in this area was asked today by Supervisor Charles H. Bellows, New Rochelle Republican, at a meeting of the County Board of Supervisors.

HONOLULU, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Fleet's spectacular assault on Japanese concentrations in the Gilbert and Marshal Islands on Sunday was in accordance with the characteristic United States Navy tradition -- seek out the enemy and destroy him -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, said in a statement here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve system in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 28. Increases of $57,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $93,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills and $321,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $98,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $148,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

In a determined bid to strengthen their failing defense for the battle tonight at Madison Square Garden against the Rangers, the Americans yesterday completed a deal with Toronto which brought Jack Church, defense man, here in exchange for Lorne Carr and an undisclosed cash consideration.

Amid much howling and barking and in a setting of fire plugs, poles and fire alarm boxes, the annual elimination contest for Fire Department Dalmatians to choose the dogs to be entered in the annual Westminster Kennel Club Show at Madison Square Garden next Monday was held yesterday in the yard of the Fire Department training school, 154 East Sixty-eighth Street.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 2 -- The death of a Pennsylvania Railroad fireman in his locomotive cab last night was being investigated by Jersey City police this evening after an autopsy had disclosed that the man was killed by a .22-caliber rifle bullet.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 2 -- A ring of sewing machine thieves who robbed dress factories in North Jersey and in New York has been smashed by Newark police, the department announced today. The machines, valued at $250,000, were shipped to buyers in Mexico and South America.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will sound a timely military note tomorrow when it opens a loan exhibition of Colt percussion revolvers; showing the evolution of this weapon. The 130 firearms in the exhibition, ancestors of the present-day military weapon, date from 1836 to 1872.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- After two hours of discussion, much of it diverted to other subjects, the Senate today passed and gave back to the House for its concurrence the new-record $26,495,265,474 naval appropriation bill, carrying an extra $6,517,300,000, principally to provide and arm 23,354 more war planes than the 1,709 which the lower branch had approved recently.

Conscription for women was advocated yesterday by Professor Winifred Cullis, head of the women's section of the British Library of Information. Addressing 500 members of the New York City League of Women Voters at a war rally in John Wanamaker's auditorium, Professor Cullis said:

TOKYO, Feb. 2 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- Japanese bombers, attacking in the face of furious anti-aircraft fire, made four mass raids on Singapore Saturday night and Sunday, sinking a 50,000-ton floating dock and doing heavy damage to other military targets, Domei reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Small formations of United States Army Flying Fortresses, continuing their pressure against the enemy drives on Singapore and the Netherlands Indies, raided Japanese air fields in the Malay Peninsula and shot down nine Japanese planes in the vicinity of Macassar Strait, the War Department announced today.

Sidney Lanier was born a hundred years ago today. In Baltimore, as a lecturer at Johns Hopkins, he made the studies that, collected in "The Science of English Verse," for sixty years have kept their place as an original and a classic work on the relations of sound in verse and music.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Biff Jones, once more Major Lawrence McC. Jones, returned to his alma mater today as graduate manager of athletics after an absence that was just three days less than ten years.

Andre Mathieu, 12-year-old Montreal pianist and composer, has been declared winner of the $200 first prize in the young composers' contest sponsored by the Young People's Concerts Committee of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Representatives of the Cabot Gas Corporation of Wellsville, N.Y., urged the Federal Power Commission today to approve an application to sell the corporation's property and franchises in Monroe County, N.Y., to the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, Rochester, N.Y., for $100,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Banks debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Jan. 28 aggregated $11,019,000,000.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 2 -- A five-year-old controversy between the Bolivian Government and the Standard Oil Company of Bolivia reached a favorable solution today, according to a communique issued by the government. It said the government had accepted a proposal that it pay to the Standard Oil Company $1,000,000 for the latter's surveys of oil properties and in settlement of all other claims, giving Bolivia unquestioned title to her oil fields.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Spurred by heavy consumer "scare buying" in the last three weeks, retail store buyers came into Chicago today in such numbers as to upset previous forecasts of a 10 per cent drop in attendance for the three Spring market weeks by comparison with 1940.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- An official of the Office of Price Administration condemned today a movement to suspend the Wool Labeling Act.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Two important changes in Governor Lehman's program for the stiffening of home defense organization were agreed to as the principal bills were introduced, in amended form, under bi-partisan sponsorship in the Legislature tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 2 -- "Singapore can and will be defended," asserted the Chinese Army newspaper Sao Tang Pao today, but it insisted that Singapore's "outer defenses," especially Sumatra, must be strongly held by the United Nations to insure the defense.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 2 -- Japanese troops were hurled by the hundreds into the treacherous Salween River today when British planes smashed and riddled barges and boats in which they were trying to force a crossing 130 miles east of here for a drive toward the Burma Road.

Betty Schreibman has purchased from the Title Guarantee and Trust Company through A. MacMurray, broker, the two-story dwelling at 245 West Walnut Street, Long Beach, Nassau County, on a plot 40 by 100 feet.

A customers' brokers committee has been appointed by James F. Burns Jr., president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms. It consists of representatives of this association and the Association of Customers' Brokers and will act as liaison between the two organizations.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 2 -- The threat to this Netherlands Indies capital increased today as Japanese planes hovered over Banka Island, in the Java Sea only 220 miles north of here. This aerial vanguard of invasion apparently was based on the western coast of Netherland Borneo, where Japanese troops have seized Pontianak, the big port city only 440 miles from Batavia.

Private Jerome H. Meline, 26 years old, who has been A.W.O.L. from the Fourth Army Headquarters in San Francisco for the last ten days, was arrested early this morning and charged with grand larceny after he crawled out from beneath an overturned United Parcel Service truck on Grand Central Parkway, Kew Gardens, Queens, Police said he stole the truck in front of a shop at Fifty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue last night.

The Spring term in the city's public schools started yesterday with two new high schools and three additions to other schools being opened for the first time. Forty thousand new pupils, according to estimates, were enrolled.

A proposal for the creation of $25,000,000 fund by the automobile industry for a joint advertising campaign in daily newspapers has been advanced by DeLisser, Inc., publishers' representatives, in a letter sent to auto and agency men and publishers throughout the country.

A proposal for the creation of $25,000,000 fund by the automobile industry for a joint advertising campaign in daily newspapers has been advanced by DeLisser, Inc., publishers' representatives, in a letter sent to auto and agency men and publishers throughout the country.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, won the medal in the thirty-sixth annual South Florida golf tournament today with his one-over-par 71. He was two strokes in front of Gene Dahlbender Jr., Atlanta, and J.A. Mason, Gulf Stream, Fla.

"The Prime Minister," which has its local premiere at the Art Theatre on East Eighth Street, is this morning's only film newcomer. Produced in England, the Warner release features John Gielgud as Disraeli, Diana Wynyard as Mrs. Lewis and Fay Compton as Queen Victoria. Will Fyffe, Owen Nares, Lyn Harding and Frederick Leister are among the picture's featured players.

HONOLULU, Feb. 2 -- For the mothers of Hawaii today was the nearest normal that they have known since Dec. 7 -- the children went back to school. The schools had been closed since Dec. 7 for a variety of reasons, including the use of school buildings for such purposes as hospitals, Army engineers' quarters and registration centers and the employment of teachers as censors, civilian enrollment clerks and other defense workers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The White House confirmed today the receipt last week of a letter from Ralph M. Levey, president of International Looms, Inc., 464 Fourth Avenue, New York, containing a check for $1,000, "to be used as a victory award to any crew or ship of our armed forces in the air, on the sea or on the land who sink any Japanese battleship or cruiser weighing 6,000 tons or over."

TRENTON, Feb. 2 -- The Legislature suspended rules today for passage immediately after introduction of a bill putting New Jersey on "war time" at 2 P.M. next Monday. Clocks will be moved ahead one hour then in conformity with the new Federal law.

For its first full year of operation, the New York Stock Exchange firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, largest brokerage house in the country, made a net profit of $459,258, according to the pamphlet report issued yesterday.

Secretary Wickard has surprised nearly every one. In the debate over the price-control bill he appeared to have ranged himself alongside the Congressional farm bloc in its demands for provisions that would permit farm prices to go far above "parity." Now that the bill has become law he has announced firmly that "parity" is still his goal.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 2 -- Heavy black smoke floated across Singapore throughout the day from fires started by Japanese air raiders engaged in a grand-scale effort to soften up the stronghold for a final invasion thrust across the mile-wide Johore Strait.

The addition of 2,500 patrolmen to the police force and the assignment of uniformed clerical employes to patrol was recommended yesterday in a report of the New York State Chamber of Commerce as the result of an investigation of the Police Department. The survey was made by the committee on public service of the chamber.

Despite cancellations by blanket mills and bath mat manufacturers, the number of exhibitors at the seventeenth semi-annual National Domestics and Linen Show at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday was greater than that of a year ago. The line of only one blanket mill, Pearce Manufacturing Company, was shown, but no goods were offered for sale.

The corner drug store probably would be a "most dangerous" place in an air raid because of the large quantity of glass supplies and fittings, and therefore it will not be used as a casualty depot by defense authorities, Colonel H. Van Zile Hyde, medical officer, Second Defense Region, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Charges that H.W. Lederer of New York, president of two companies, one of which sold Bibles to funeral parlors while the other marketed hand-bag mirrors to night clubs and cafes, misrepresented the position of the companies in their respective fields were made by the Federal Trade Commission today.

Sales of defense savings bonds, Series E, in the Second Federal Reserve District from Jan. 1 to 29, inclusive, amounted to $126,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was exclusive of sales made through postoffices.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, on the Moulmein Front, Burma, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- From an observation post on the bank of the broad Salween River I am looking across 1,000 yards of water that represents the difference between the holding and the losing of Moulmein.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 2 -- Brazil may deny passport visas to Axis diplomats wishing to go to Argentina or Chile, it was learned today. There was no indication as to whether Argentina had suggested such action, or whether the plan was Brazil's.

The dispute that has arisen between the automobile unions and manufacturers concerning double pay for Sunday work is an example of one of the harmful results that follows when the Government refuses to announce a definite wartime labor policy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Fifteen thousand Palestine Jews are serving voluntarily with British forces in many theatres of the war, Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, reported today before the closing sessions of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds.

Unless production of non-essential products for civilian use is "cut to the narrowest point possible" the nation "cannot possibly do the job" required under the defense program, Colonel George S. Brady, materials consultant, division of civilian supply, WPB, declared yesterday.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue defined the term "capital assets" yesterday as meaning property held by the taxpayer, whether or not connected with his trade or business. It does not include stock in trade of the taxpayer or property of a kind that would properly be included in the taxpayer's inventory of stock on hand at the close of the tax year.

The Security Insurance Company of New Haven in its 100th anniversary year produced the largest premium volume in its history, Peter J. Berry, president, reported yesterday at a meeting of stockholders. The company's subsidiaries, the East and West Insurance Company of New Haven and the Connecticut Indemnity Company, also improved, he said.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 2 -- The Bahaman Government announced today that, in conformity with the action of the United States and under British regulations, it had blacklisted the enterprises of Axel Wenner-Gren, Swedish industrialist and friend of the Duke of Windsor, who, as Governor, signed the blacklisting order.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Allocations of a list of chemicals, iron and steel, tin plate and farm machinery to Brazil by our State Department will be followed by allocation among Brazil's industries of her quotas of each of the products concerned, Dr. Walder Sarmanho, commercial counselor of the Brazilian Embassy, said here yesterday.

Hundreds of customers crowded into the new building conducted by Thrift House at 18 West Fifty-seventh Street yesterday and as a result of steady purchases brought to one million the total number of sales made by this organization since its establishment in 1933.

Total sales of defense savings bonds in the Second Federal Reserve District, by issuing agencies other than postoffices, aggregated $267,770,000 in January, according to complete figures for the month announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Brigadier John Charles Campbell -- who has already won the Distinguished Service Order and Bar in this war and the Military Cross in the last war -- has been awarded the Victoria Cross in "recognition of the most conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty" at Sidi Barrani and Rezegh, North Africa, last November, according to an official announcement tonight.

It seems to me that in his discussion of Mr. De Valera's pronouncement about the arrival of American forces in Northern Ireland, Sir Norman Angell has neither understood nor presented the essentials of the matter. And beyond and above what Sir Norman and Mr. Healy have communicated to you, there is another point which I believe to be of primary importance.

Twelve men who had been on trial in Special Sessions for two days as the result of the gambling raid on the old Lincoln League Republican Club at 281 Grand Street last Nov. 25 were found guilty yesterday by Justices Cooper, Doyle and Flood.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Wayne L. Morse, arbiter in Pacific Coast longshoremen's disputes, gave orders tonight for a 10-cent hourly basic wage increase for 17,500 West Coast longshoremen, effective tomorrow, and admonished the C.I.O.'s International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union on the necessity for avoiding "slowdowns" and performing more fully their "work efficiency obligations."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Eventual compulsory registration of women for selective replacement service in war industries was viewed as a possibility today as two committees of Congress were told by draft officials that legislation soon would be presented to enable the induction into the military service of men now deferred because of dependents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Further analysis of the Tokyo short-wave propaganda drumfire, paralleling Japanese military thrusts in the Pacific war, reveals an effort hatched in Berlin to promote religious as well as racial feeling against the anti-Axis powers, particularly in the Philippines.

Secretary Morgenthau acknowledges that he has abandoned his earlier view that two-thirds of the money required by the Government should be raised by taxes. This was inevitable. Next year's budget calls for $59,000,000,000 of expenditures. To raise two-thirds of that by taxes is impossible.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has purchased "Annabel Lee" from Warner Brothers as a vehicle for John Shepherd and Linda Darnell and will film it under the title "The Loves of Edgar Allan Poe." Bryan Foy, who prepared the story while he was at Warners, will produce the film for Fox, where he is now under contract.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, N.J., Feb. 3 -- A. mother, her daughter and her grandchild were killed late today in a head-on automobile collision on Route 23, in front of Donohue's Restaurant, here. The driver of the second car suffered serious injuries.

Two of the Metropolitan Opera's fine voices, Dusolina Giannini and Jan Peerce, appeared in joint recital last night as the fourth event of the Hurok Carnegie Hall series. Both singers were in estimable form, and for sheer quality of vocal tone, dramatic soprano and tenor have seldom been heard to better advantage.

The Tammany Hall executive committee was summoned yesterday to meet Friday afternoon for a vote on the ouster of Christopher D. Sullivan as its leader and spokesman. The call was issued by Charles H. Hussey, chairman of the executive committee, after Mr. Sullivan had rejected a request for his resignation and had challenged his opponents on the committee to depose him.

A millinery designer new to New York made her debut at the Ritz Carlton luncheon yesterday. She is Helene Garnell. She was born in New York, acquired her fashion abilities in France under such distinguished designers as Jean Patou and Maria Guy.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 3 -- Twenty-six Japanese bombers escorted by swarms of fighter planes rained explosives today on the great naval base of Surabaya and its surrounding airdromes in an attempt to smash the United Nations' offensive power, which apparently has kept a Japanese invasion armada bottled up in the Strait of Macassar, more than 450 miles to the north.

The stock market accomplished little in the matter of business or price alterations yesterday as another session purely for the record dragged through five hours of do-nothing. Pivotal issues appeared on the ticker tape only after lengthy intervals and the meager volume was centered in specialties, but that interest, too, was scant.

UNDER the leadership of Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, the white-haired warrior with the fighting name, the baseball magnates buckled down to their own war problem yesterday. It's a case of backing up the front. They came out of conference with a program of increased night games and two all-star games instead of one.

Formal offering to the public will be made today by a syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co. of $25,000,000 of bonds and preferred stock of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, which was awarded to the group in competitive bidding on Monday.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The communique of the Dutch armed forces follows:

SINGAPORE, Feb. 3 -- The Japanese invading columns, expanding by the hour as reinforcements marched endlessly down through Southern Malaya, stood silent before Johore Strait today while enemy bombers cast fire and explosives over Singapore in violent raids, apparently heralding an imminent attempt to force the strait with troops.

A goal by Alan Kuntz only 18 seconds after the start of the overtime session gave the New York Rangers a 3-to-2 victory over the Brooklyn Americans in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Red Dutton's men fought bitterly in an attempt to erase this quick tally, but were kept away from Jim Henry in the Ranger nets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Many communities on the East and West Coasts are not organized to deal with bomb attacks and are unwilling to join cooperation protective measures largely because their people have not awakened to the fact that the United States is at war, James M. Landis, executive of the Office of Civilian Defense, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House passed by a vote today the $1,112,928,899 appropriation bill for the Treasury and Postoffice Departments for 1943, after having defeated by only two votes a Republican attempt to nullify the 1934 Silver Purchase Act.

TWO self-appointed local experts, Jack Goodman and Alan Green, have prepared a book on how to do things. They call it "How to Do Practically Anything."* It is a gracious and thoroughly unreliable piece of work; but while the authors were at it, why didn't they explain how to explain "How to Do Practically Anything"?

Inspectors of the New York State Conservation Department, each of whom is in charge of a large area covered by game protectors, have received orders to jack up their automobiles as a result of the tire shortage, according to a report received yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The government's decision to set up a committee of four men to inquire into the conditions of the three women's services -- the Women's Auxiliary Territorial Service, the Women's Royal Naval Service and the Women's Auxiliary Air Force -- brought forth a storm of criticism from women members in the House of Commons today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 3 -- After professing indifference toward the recent Inter-American Conference at Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, the Italian Government today assailed the United States and warned the Latin-American nations of political and economic consequences.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Representative Martin of Massachusetts said today he would continue as chairman of the Republican National Committee at least until after the Congressional elections in November.
BERLIN, Feb. 3 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique toddy:

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- A project for scrap collection by large industrial corporations, enlisting the aid of thousands of employes and dealers scattered throughout the country, was submitted today by Fowler McCormick, president of the International Harvester Company, to Lessing J. Rosenwald, chief of the war production board's Industrial Conservation Bureau.
Relay matchings were completed yesterday by Director Fred Schmertz for the Millrose games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. He has placed the seven fastest teams in the meet in his two top races.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The R.A.F. communique said today:

A funeral service, with full Police Department honors, was held yesterday for former Chief Inspector Dominick Henry at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory the Great, 138 West Ninetieth Street, where a high mass of requiem was celebrated.

No deduction in income tax returns is allowable, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced yesterday, for losses from sales or exchanges of property, directly or indirectly, between (a) members of a family, (b) a corporation and an individual owning more than 50 per cent of its stock (liquidations excepted), (c) a grantor and fiduciary of any trust, or (d) a fiduciary and a beneficiary of the same trust.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Princeton's hockey team rolled over Army, its new Pentagonal League rival, by 6 -- 1 in Baker Rink tonight.
VICHY, Feb. 3 (AP) -- German destruction of historic quarters in Paris was protested today in a letter sent to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain by 100 prominent French intellectuals.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday the arrest of six persons charged with smuggling platinum out of this country in violation of a Presidential proclamation putting the metal on a list of essential defense supplies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Under the rationing program which is nearing completion here, "sugar stamps" issued by the government to registered consumers will be required before retailers can make a legal sale of sugar.
