ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 3 -- The German High Command has begun largo-scale withdrawal of troops and equipment, including planes, from Bulgaria, Hungary and Yugoslavia and is concentrating a new army corps on the Eastern Front and within Germany itself, while continuing to mass troops upon the Mediterranean, according to reports reaching foreign military intelligence sourced here.

The first benefit project undertaken by the newly formed Women's Division of the Navy League is a gala performance of "It Happens on Ice" planned for Feb. 24 at the Center Theatre. The proceeds will be shared jointly by the Navy League's New York City Council, headed by Mrs. Charles Howland Russell Jr. and the American Friends of Norway, Inc., of which Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former Minister to Norway, is chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The 100,000th volunteer to join the Navy since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7 enlisted yesterday. The Navy Department made this known today and also that the day and night operations of the Navy Recruiting Service on a seven-day week basis had brought in an average of 1,786 enlistments a day during the eight-week period since the war began.

Nothing about the revival of "The Mikado," which opened at the St. James last evening, is more diverting than the management's attempt to fit Gilbert and Sullivan's venerable classic into the current war program. "We are gangsters of Japan," sing the mincing gentlemen of Japan in the first chorus, looking very much like an American basketball team on a holiday.

Production has been curtailed so sharply in the appliance fields by government orders that some companies, particularly the smaller ones, are planning to abandon voluntarily the manufacture of such appliances and swing as soon as possible into war work, it was learned here yesterday.

A banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers received yesterday the award of an issue of $2,157,000 city of Yonkers, N.Y., various purpose bonds on an interest cost basis of 2.686 per cent. The successful bid was 100.11 for the bonds, bearing an interest rate of 2.70 per cent.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Spotted typhus has spread from the Eastern Front to Germany and the Nazi-occupied areas, the German Health Ministry announced today, listing 126 cases in Germany and 138 in the occupied Eastern countries.

The Long Island University basketball team defeated Wheaton College of Illinois, 83 to 36, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy last night. It was the eighteenth victory against two losses for the Blackbirds, who scored their highest total of the season.

Although contracts have not been signed yet, the chances are considered excellent for Paul Muni to act in the Emlyn Williams play, "The Light of Heart," under the auspices of the Theatre Guild, it became known yesterday. Margaret Webster has been approached to stage the production.

SPOKANE, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A "bundles for Congress" campaign started by the Athletic Round Table is getting "bigger and better by the minute," Joe Albi, the president, reported today. Sally Rand is the latest celebrity to contribute to the campaign, aimed at ridiculing out of existence the pensions voted by Congressmen for themselves, Mr. Albi said.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- The British and Soviet Russian condominium over Iran's entire communication system, which was confirmed in the tripartite treaty of Teheran last week, has in fact been effective for at least the last three months, or since substantial shipments for Russia from Australia, India, Britain and America began arriving in Persian Gulf ports.

Patrolman Patrick J. Carey of the East Fifty-first Street precinct stiffened to attention around 10 o'clock yesterday morning when the patrol car's speaker raucously called his number as he cruised through the East Forties.
ROME, Feb. 3 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The British Royal Air Force has again bombed Palermo, Sicily and Naples, the Italian High Command announced today.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- Favorites stroked their way into the third round of the $1,500 Roney Plaza professional tennis tournament today.

SEATTLE, Feb. 3 -- On the heels of its denunciation yesterday by the heads of the War Production Board, the War and Navy Departments and the Maritime Commission, the strike of welders at Puget Sound shipyards appeared tonight virtually to have collapsed.

Joseph Lilly, president of the Tax Commission, said yesterday that the property of the Henry George School of Social Science at 30 East Twenty-Ninth Street had been removed from the list of tax-exempt properties and placed on the city tax rolls as a result of a complaint made against the school to the State Education Department.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The German Air Force is now using a new type long-range bombing plane that is capable of carrying a torpedo or a bomb load, can be used as a dive bomber and has a superior all-round performance, it was revealed tonight by officials here.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- Japanese planes today struck the first blow at rich Java, heart of the Netherlands Indies and seat of the United Nations command, with a fierce raid on the naval base and city of Surabaya and on several towns.

Though only a battalion of men is involved, and though hope of further reinforcements is problematical, it is stirring news that American bluejackets and marines are now fighting with General MacArthur's gallant soldiers. No American commander ever sat on a hotter spot than that which MacArthur has occupied since the fall of Manila.

With a quiet efficiency that goes almost overlooked in the more dramatic reports of war efforts, the industrial community in nearby New York and New Jersey is contributing most of the precision manufactures required by the nation's arms program.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 3 -- A Japanese bomber attacked Port Moresby, capital of Papua, on New Guinea, 320 miles from the Australian mainland, at 3 o'clock this morning, dropping six bombs, a Royal Australian Air Force communique revealed.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Wednesday, Feb. 4 -- Seventy Americans, with five members of the consular staff in Singapore, have arrived in Batavia, having left the British stronghold after the siege of the island began.

Rangoon to Mandalay, Mandalay to Lashio, Lashio over the mountains to Kunming (the old Yunnanfu) in the Chinese Province of Yunnan, from Kunming to the Free Chinese capital of Chungking on the Yangtze River -- such is the route American and British supplies must now follow into China.

"Dr. Kildare's Victory," latest release in the popular Metro series, will open today at Loew's Criterion. Lew Ayres and Lionel Barrymore continue in the lead roles. Anna Ayars, a newcomer making her first appearance in the series; Robert Sterling, Jean Rogers, Barry Nelson, Alma Kruger and Edward Gargan are among the supporting players.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Wickard today set Saturday, May 2, as the date for a nation-wide farmer referendum on marketing quotas for the 1942 wheat crop.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 3 -- A childhood dream will be one step nearer realization tomorrow for Miss Dorothy Jeffas, 21 years old, of Jersey City, who works as a secretary, when, notebook and pencil in hand, she attends her first session of the aviation ground school of the New Jersey Council of the National Aeronautic Association at Newark Academy here, and starts piling up hours of preliminary work until she becomes a qualified test pilot.

The presidents of the American Bankers Association and of the American Bar Association, speaking on the same platform here yesterday, called for "shirt sleeve" sessions directed toward war service and for self-discipline "which subordinates the well-being of the individual to the safety of the nation."

Heavily increased demands on hospitals and charitable institutions partly supported by the city were reflected yesterday in a request for $3,000,000 in additional funds this year when the budget requests of the institutions were submitted by Harry Gordon Lynn, who supervises the institutions for Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- The "Bundles for Congress" campaign originated by the Spokane, Athletic Round Table to "keep 'em laughing" at the expense of Congressmen who voted pensions for themselves failed to amuse some legislators tonight, but others laughed about it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The proposed loan of $500,000,000 to the Chinese Government, which favorable action by the House Committee on Foreign Affairs today started toward rapid enactment, is widely viewed here as an ideal combination of war, diplomatic and economic policy.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Wendell Willkie, declaring that "it was never so important that the American people be told the truth as now," called tonight for an abandonment of "the route of pure partisanship."

A handsome blonde German-American girl of 18 appeared in Federal court yesterday and began her story of a group of Nazi agents so devoted to their work that they spent even their leisure hours visiting airplane factories and flying fields on Long Island.

An increase in the number of applications and allotments of automobile tires and tubes was reported yesterday by the office of the Federal Rationing Administrator for New York City in line with a forecast by his office last week.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The Republican majority in the Senate blocked immediate action today on a bill which would have paved the way for a wartime defense power line carrying current from New York City to the Massena aluminum plant on the St. Lawrence River.

Visiting buyers registered in the market in January totaled 6,574, the largest monthly total on record and 13.3 per cent more than in January, 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Arrivals last week totaled 1,132, against 1,522 in the preceding week and 971 in he like week last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- The nation's third city and its environs, where 3,000,000 persons live and nearly $2,000,000,000 worth of war material is being produced, were blacked out almost to the last possible glimmer for fifteen minutes tonight in the largest test of civil defense preparedness ever attempted in America.
The trial by cold continued on the Russian front yesterday as the months that may decide the war opened.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 3 -- Accelerating output for war, the Union Electric Company of Missouri, one of the nation's largest operating utilities, opened today a new steam generating power plant designed to add immediately 40,000 kilowatts to the St. Louis area, engaged in production of $800,000, 000 of war orders.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The news from Singapore caused further declines in many sections of the stock markets today. Gilt-edge securities eased, the selling being attributed to the need for funds to meet income tax payments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Unification of the country's defense housing program was announced today by the Federal Works Agency under a plan by which the construction of homes for war plants' employes become the direct responsibility of three FWA officials in Washington and six regional representatives, but all of them directly accountable to the administrator for getting done, in record time, the undertakings assigned to their respective jurisdictions.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- The grain markets developed a firmer undertone today after a short period of easiness at the start. Scattered liquidation has apparently run its course, with most operators waiting for further developments in regard to price control policies.

Hearings in the ease of the Chosen Corporation before Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon took a dramatic turn yesterday when Harry T. Zucker of Hollander Bernheimer, attorneys for F.E. Banbury and F.A. Kelly in their $5,900,000 suit against Serge Rubinstein and others, began asking questions relative to the alleged smuggling of 3,000,000 yen from Japan in 1938.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Numerous objections to the application before the Public Service Commission of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for a 10 per cent increase in commutation fares were raised tonight at a meeting of twenty-six Mayors and Corporation Counsels of Westchester County communities at City Hall here.

When the book critics of the nation participated a year ago in a poll conducted by the Book-of-the-Month Club on the "outstanding" books of 1940 they selected as the leading book, "For Whom the Bell Tolls." This book had been a book club selection not long before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized railroads serving ten New England ports to store on the ground shipments intended for movement abroad, rather than tie up railroad equipment by holding the cargoes in railroad cars until they can be routed directly onto ships.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Spring and Summer style clinics being held today and tomorrow for buyers at the Merchandise Mart have demonstrated that the women of America are cheerfully substituting rayon for silk, cotton for chiffon and denim for dainty fabrics.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- A substantial majority of American citizens polled in a nation-wide survey believe that every one in the United States should be required to carry an identification card containing not only his picture but his fingerprints as well.

Colonel Henry T. Blair gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. M. Orme Wilson. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A. Thompson, Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Lady Lister-Kaye, Mrs. Arthur Ryle and Mrs. Wales Latham.

James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, told 1,000 union butchers at Manhattan Center last night that complacency, "silent partner of the Axis," had to be beaten "before we can hope to beat the rest of the gang."
I should like to suggest -- or perhaps revive -- a plan whereby colleges and universities throughout the country could meet very generous Red Cross obligations with a minimum of effort.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 3 -- As the Chinese Government spokesman at a press conference today, Dr. T.F. Chiang, former Ambassador to Russia, said in regard to the news of projected American and British loans:

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 4 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Lieut. Col. Yoshiaki Hotta of the Japanese Army press section said today that the Imperial Army was planning "unique as well as decisive methods for the final capture of Singapore."

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Feb. 3 -- Morgan W. Jopling of Smithtown Branch, L.I., 58 years old, an industrialist, died from shock and exposure early today after he fell from his auxiliary yacht Encore into the icy waters of Port Jefferson Harbor.
The four top fighters on the Madison Square Garden card for Friday night were called for examination yesterday by the State Athletic Commission and went through the ordeal with flying colors.

The appointment of four business executives as Manhattan district chairmen of the men's committee of the Civilian Mobilization for The Salvation Army was announced yesterday by George A. Brownell, campaign chairman. The district chairmen, supported by subcommittees of business and professional men, will organize this year's annual solicitation of gifts in Manhattan.

ATLANTA, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Former Governor E.D. Rivers and five others were indicted again today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the State through large scale purchases of road machinery and other supplies during his administration.

TRENTON, Feb. 3 -- Governor Charles Edison interceded today with Governor Frank M. Dixon of Alabama on behalf of Nathan Beauchamp, a Negro, who escaped from an Alabama prison camp in 1940 while serving a life term, and voluntarily surrendered to Essex County authorities last month upon the advice of the Newark branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

An intensive after-school training Program in trade subjects has been arranged for boys in the New York City academic schools, it became known yesterday. Pupils who plan to complete their high-school course this June are to receive training in ten trade subjects considered essential in defense industries.

In what Federal Attorney Harold M. Kennedy in Brooklyn said was the first test case of its kind in this country, the Federal grand jury in that borough handed up to Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, in the United States District Court yesterday, an indictment charging three individuals and three corporations with violation of the Social Security Act.

Professor Conrad A. Elvehjem of the University of Wisconsin Biochemistry Department, one of the world's leading authorities on nutrition, warned Americans in a lecture last night at the New York Academy of Medicine that they would deprive themselves of a number of still unknown important vitamins and other essential food factors unless they relied on a variety of natural foods for their vitamin supply.

Excellent customer reaction was reported by officials of John Wanamaker, New York, to the policy put into effect yesterday whereby merchandise prices throughout the downstairs store and a limited number of comparable price lines in the upstairs store have been lowered so as not to include the delivery service.

Despite an unusually severe loss in automotive linage, advertising in eight New York newspapers declined only 1.9 per cent in January from the like 1941 month, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Four papers suffered losses and an equal number had gains.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Treasury clamped down today on efforts of foreigners to use their "frozen" American money to get control of American businesses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Sharp curtailment of output by the typewriter industry, which last year built over 1,000,000 machines, will be carried out in the near future in order to convert its productive facilities to armaments output, the War Production Board announced today following a meeting with industry representatives.

The 180 students at St. Francis College are firmly convinced that they have the best basketball team in town. Tonight the unbeaten Terriers will be put to a supreme test when they face once-defeated N.Y.U. in the feature game of an all-metropolitan double-header at Madison Square Garden. St. John's will square off against Manhattan in the opener.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- House and Senate conferees agreed today on the $26,495,265,474 Navy Supply Bill and expect to report it tomorrow to their respective houses, which, in turn, are scheduled to approve it and send it to the White House.

The Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body of all the entertainer unions of the A.F. of L., has established a talent coordinating committee to facilitate the handling of entertainment connected with the war. Twenty thousand members of the five actor unions that make up the Four A's have received a letter from the committee instructing them how to avoid being exploited "by unauthorized individuals, committees and organizations."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Thousands of persons who pay Federal income taxes, new and old, have taken the gloom out of March by filing their returns early, the Treasury disclosed today in announcing that such tax receipts to date were twice as large as they were a year ago.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 3 -- An 18-year-old Newark youth, charged with a series of automobile thefts and purse snatchings, was arrested by the East Orange police last night at the home of a local high school girl, who offered to cooperate with the authorities after she learned that her new "boy friend" was being sought in a number of crimes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Sharp debate arose in the Senate today on assessing the responsibility for Pearl Harbor. The question whether Guam should have been fortified and whether such fortification would have prevented the fall of the island to the Japanese and deterred them in their surprise attack on Hawaii Dec. 7 was also acrimoniously discussed.
LONDON, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- The government in effect rejected again today pleas for India's immediate independence as a means of winning her ful support in the war.
The temperature at 7 A.M. yesterday fell to a new low for the year, when it reached 4.7 degrees, one-tenth of a degree below the lowest point reached on Jan. 8.

Clarence A. Hathaway, the ousted editor of the Communist paper, The Daily Worker, walked into General Sessions yesterday, and, through his lawyer, Edward Kuntz, told Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., he had quit his fight to set aside his conviction in that court twenty months before on a criminal libel indictment.

DETROIT, Feb. 3 -- Concerned about the possibility that unemployed mechanics will seek war employment in other parts of the country instead of waiting four to six months for arms jobs in converted automobile plants, Governor Van Wagoner headed a delegation of Michigan officials in a trip to Washington tonight to urge Congressional approval of President Roosevelt's plan for a special $300,000,000 fund to aid victims of priorities unemployment.
Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Reeves have come from Bryn Mawr, Pa., to the St. Regis.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 3 -- The confusion which exists in the public mind here regarding the effect of United States defense bases on local affairs was illustrated in the Supreme Court today when Julius Ralo, an American employed on naval base construction at the west end of the colony, was charged with stealing $80 from a fellow-worker.

Mrs. Isobella Bresson, the 78-year-old Scotswoman who donated her own and her late husband's wedding rings to the British War Relief Society, as the last things of value she had left in the world, has received them again through the generosity of well-wishers who heard of her sacrifice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The delivery to Russia of less than half of the war equipment promised by the United States in the last three months is causing considerable concern to certain war administrators who know the extent of German preparations for a new Spring drive against Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Beginning March 2, cotton pillow cases and sheets sold to consumers must bear labels stating the type and class of the product, whether or not it is a "second" and, if the piece does not meet minimum specifications, designating it as "sub-standard" under terms of an order issued today by the Office of Price Administration.

Dr. Maxmilian A. Ramirez, president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, yesterday sent a letter to the Comitia Minora (board of directors) and the 5,362 members of the society saying that he was "opposed to the division of professional fees by physicians under any and all circumstances."

Two ominous developments suggest that the Japanese are about to launch a major attack on Java, the chief citadel of the Netherlands Indies. They are bombing Banka and Billiton Islands, which cover the approach to Batavia, the Dutch capital, as well as Surabaya, the only great naval base in the Southwestern Pacific which the United Nations can still use.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Good demand from shipping interests kept hogs selling at prices steady with yesterday's sharp upturn on the livestock market today. Top price, however, declined 10 cents a hundred weight to $12.40. Shippers took 5,000 head. The reduction in receipts, livestock circles believe, has been a major factor in sending hogs to a fifteen-year February high this week.

The cotton market registered yesterday its first gains in a week as pressure eased from the liquidation which had carried prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to losses of as much as $8 a bale since last Tuesday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Mrs. Vera S. Bragg, the New Yorker who has won so consistently in California, showed Florida how victories are scored when two of her color-bearers came home first at Hialeah Park today, the second of them in the featured Imperial River Purse.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 3 -- The chief representatives in Mexico of the expropriated American and British oil companies have gone to New York, it was learned today, after studying the decision of the Mexican Supreme Court which leading constitutional lawyers say reverses the rulings that had justified the nationalization of subsoil rights.

Counsel for railroads studied yesterday the decision of the United States Supreme Court on Monday that the Southwest Consolidated Corporation was not exempt from taxation under the revenue law of 1934, although the concern had been reorganized.

Group Securities, Inc. -- Dec. 31: Of the various groups, each a small investment trust in itself, only two showed gains in net asset value in 1941. Distillery and brewing shares rose from $2.70 to $2.76 and petroleum shares rose from $3.88 to $3.93.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Little Mush March, the National Hockey League's oldest winger, rapped in the tying and winning goals while the Chicago Black Hawks were outplaying the Boston Bruins for a 5-3 overtime victory tonight before 9,500 at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Harold D. Smith, director of the budget, announced today that the Department of Agriculture had agreed to move 3,848 employes out of Washington to make room for defense branches of the government.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 3 -- Patriotic Norwegians have replied to Major Vidkun Quisling's nomination as Prime Minister with a wave of terror.
HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 3 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish Army Headquarters issued this communique:

Increases in the incidence of the four principal diseases of childhood and three deaths from these so-called "mild" illnesses were recorded in New York City last week, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

Canada's aluminum Industry can supply the war production needs of both Canada and Great Britain and in addition furnish 750,000,000 pounds of this vital product to the United States in the next two years, Victor T. Goggin, general manager of Wartime Housing, Ltd., of Canada, declared yesterday.

War conditions in Northern Ireland are not the only thing to trouble A.E.F. boys on town leave and eager to invest part of their pay checks in steaks and hamburgers and pastry. Meat and sweets are scarce for British civilians, and the American soldier boys no doubt find that they fare better in regular mess.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 3 -- Pressing forward despite rear-guard actions by portions of the Fourth Indian Division, reinforced columns of the German Afrika Korps yesterday reached positions in the Jebel el-Achdar due south of Cirene.

An underwriting group headed by Scott Stringfellow of Richmond, Va., and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will offer to the public today a block of 104,813 shares of common stock of the Chesapeake Corporation of Virginia, pulp and paper manufacturers.

Deere Co., manufacturers of farm equipment, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 31 last net income of $14,269,420 after $10,592,863 reserve for Federal income and excess profits taxes and $3,325,446 provision for contingencies.

Governor Lehman, Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti and Federal and State conservation officials will address members of the State Salvage Committee at a conference in Albany this afternoon on the collection of scrap material for war industry. Murray Willard, chairman of the committee, will preside.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A large number of barges full of crack Japanese shock troops who attempted a bold midnight landing behind General Douglas MacArthur's lines on the Bataan Peninsula yesterday were driven back into the sea "with heavy casualties in men and boats," the War Department announced today.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- British Imperial machine gunners wiped out several small Japanese patrols as they leaped from boats today, and maintained an unbroken hold on the whole west bank of the Salween River, the main barrier to the Japanese drive on the Burma Road.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- Forty-one Japanese warships escorting twenty-one transports passed through Formosa Strait off Amoy, South China, bound in a southerly direction on Jan. 23, a Chinese military spokesman said today.

Maxie Shapiro, East Side lightweight, defeated Sal Bartola, Boston, before 3,800 fans in the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night. Fighting for a fourth time, these ring rivals thrilled the crowd in the eight-round feature.
Mrs. Edmond Borgia Butler, director of the Corps of Volunteers of St. Vincent's Hospital, has laid down three crisp rules for the 100 women who work under her.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, in Bataan, Philippines, Feb. 3 -- The spectacular battle in which American naval, land and air units early today smashed a strong Japanese attempt to land from the China Sea was fought under a brilliant full moon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Recent political, military and economic developments in China, as related by five Cabinet officers in secret session today, spurred the House Committee on Foreign Affairs to recommend to its parent body within a few hours that up to $500,000,000 of financial aid be extended to China with the greatest possible promptness and under terms of "widest latitude."

Once there was a small, sunny room with an odd little bow window overlooking the Bois de Boulogne. Every morning all Winter long, precisely at 7 o'clock, a diminutive maid with a bright blue apron tapped softly at the door, then tiptoed in with her tray.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Plans to draw from vast reservoirs of untapped strength -- men with dependents and those suffering from minor physical defects -- to build up the nation's fighting forces were disclosed today by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service.

Acting in what they understood to be frill accordance with the wishes of President ROosevelt for an expansion of night baseball, the major league clubs owners yesterday completed steps which promise virtually to bathe the countryside in floodlights next Summer.

The Hartford Electric Light Company in its report for 1941, issued yesterday, declared that although the war would increase the demand for electricity, there would be no increased profits for stockholders.

HONOLULU, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- Blackout regulations, which have kept all unauthorized persons off the streets of Honolulu at night since the Japanese attack, were eased today by the establishment of an 8 P.M. curfew.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- By unanimous voice vote the Senate passed today and sent to the House a bill setting up a war damage corporation to insure property from bombing and other war damage at government expense up to $15,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Naval vessels and planes are expected to fire so many shells, torpedoes, machine-gun bullets and bombs during the next five months that it will take "the major part" of a $6,000,000,000 appropriation to replace them, published testimony before a Senate appropriations subcommittee disclosed today.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 4 (AP) -- German reserve troops have failed to halt the advancing Russians and today Red Atomy columns were stabbing toward the Nazi anchor city of Smolensk, 230 miles west of Moscow, and filtering into the Ukraine between the Donets and Dnieper Rivers.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Free French officials announced today the completion of construction work on two important roads through French Equatorial Africa. The roads will play an important part in the transportation of supplies across Africa to Cairo, whence the supplies could be sent to the British forces in the Western Desert, to the Russian armies, or even to the United Nations forces in the Far Eastern theatre of war.

While many retail buyers have urged earlier showings of Fall lines of women's apparel, action toward this end by manufacturers and mills awaits results of the meeting scheduled for tomorrow in Washington, which is expected to set quotas on new wool for the second quarter, it was reported here yesterday.

When a firm of lawyers presumes to conduct business in a name and style made famous by dead founders, are the living partners but ineffectual shadows whose appearance as counsel can be challenged? The current representatives of the long-known Alexander Green have been so challenged, and the motion of the challengers, denied by a Municipal Court justice, is up for decision by the Appellate Term of the Brooklyn Supreme Court.

Members of the Board of Higher Education and the presidents of the city's four colleges will be asked to explain why there are no Negroes among the 2,232 faculty members of the city institutions, Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of the City Council said at City Hall yesterday.

The verbal broadsides that were expected yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court to enliven the feud between Mayor La Guardia and William Fellowes Morgan Jr., recently resigned Commissioner of Markets, were avoided. The case reached an anti-climax when Mr. Morgan filed an affidavit at a short hearing before Justice Isidor Wasservogel in defense of the tenant in Bronx Terminal Market whom the city is trying to evict.

Smith, Barney Co., as the sole distributors yesterday in the offering of a block of 16,500 shares of capital stock of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., spent both an active and interesting day. The first part of the day was spent answering the flood of inquiries from dealers, which gradually gave way to actual investor interest and the confirmation of sales at a satisfactory rate.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 3 -- Foreign Minister Juan Bautista Rossetti, who had been expected to ask the Chilean Congress this week to approve a rupture of relations with the Axis, reported to the Cabinet today, and will leave tomorrow for a holiday, and it is now believed that the step will be postponed another two or three weeks at least.

Expressing the belief that an effort was being made to prevent him from disclosing additional corruption in a city-wide $1,000,000 paving racket, Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen opposed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court an application for an injunction restraining the city from financing his paving fraud inquiry.

The American Women's Voluntary Services, now entering its third year of activity, was described yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional defense coordinator of New York State, as being as efficient as any other defense organization in the country.

The directors of the Municipal Art Society have approved, as a means of protection against economic reaction at the end of the war, the city government's policy of advance planning for vast peacetime public works, it was announced yesterday by Ely Jacques Kahn, president and a director of the society.

The Museum of Modern Art opened with a preview yesterday afternoon of an exhibition of art by soldiers at Fort Custer, Mich. The work has been placed in galleries on the main floor of the museum and may be visited by the public, beginning today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- President Roosevelt received no callers.

Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, who has publicly opposed from the bench severe mandatory Baumes Law sentences of some second offenders when jurists feel the penalties should be far less severe, demonstrated yesterday in General Sessions that, if granted discretionary powers by these laws, in many cases the courts would be no less severe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

Mrs. James N. Dunlop gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 122 East Eighty-second Street, for members of the debutante committee aiding in the plans for the forthcoming auction to be held at the Plaza Art Galleries under the auspices of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., on Feb. 25 to raise funds for the equipment of recreation rooms in Army and Navy camps.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- A two-year agreement between Britain and Ethiopia was announced by Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons today, under which Britain provides Haile Selassie with 2,500,000. It also provides for a British military mission and British advisers to the Emperor as well as for the presence of British magistrates in Ethiopian courts.

Success of the city's 1942 parking drive with doubled fines of $4 was reported yesterday by Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran. He announced first-month totals of 51,800 cases handled and $155,904 fines collected in six traffic courts. Fines, averaging $3.01 a case, increased 89 per cent and the number of cases 2 per cent over January, 1941.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 -- Mrs. R. Jay Flick gave a dinner tonight at her villa for Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., U.S.N., retired, former Chief of Staff of the United States Fleet, who addressed the Palm Beach Round Table this afternoon at the Everglades Club on "War in the Pacific."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 -- Although no mass ousting of Japanese aliens from the Pacific Coast war zone is planned, serious study is being given to a proposal to establish thousands of nationals of Japan, Germany and Italy in inland farm colonies, it was disclosed today by Thomas C. Clark, coordinator of enemy alien control for the Far West.

The fire that swept Pier 83 at West Forty-third Street and the Hudson River on Jan. 8 "clearly proves with certainty the conflagration hazard of the majority of piers in the port of New York," the New York Board of Fire Underwriters Bureau of Fire Prevention and Water Supply declared in its report released yesterday.

The offering to the public of shares in J.P. Morgan Co., Inc. is a logical sequence to the incorporation two years ago of the private banking house of J.P. Morgan Co. But even more than the act of incorporation, this public offering of shares emphasizes the transition in "The Corner" from an old-time family-owned private bank to a public institution.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that its net income in 1941 was $32,296,018, against $34,429,223 in 1940. The figures for the last three months of 1941 include only the applicable part of certain adjustments booked in those periods but which are applicable in whole or in part to earlier periods.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A plan for compulsory registration of women for wartime work, if that step becomes necessary because of a long-time drain upon the country's labor supply, was disclosed today by Miss Thelma McKelvey of the War Production Board's Labor Division. She voiced the opinion, however, that the United States was "at least a year away" from following Great Britain's lead in that direction.

A $2,000,000 union motor truck terminal to eliminate uneconomical part-load trucking and other inefficient features of the present haphazard system in the city has been proposed by the Port of New York Authority, it was announced yesterday.

Magazines are not only conscious of their important role in keeping public opinion informed and building up morale during the war period, but are also taking definite steps to achieve economies in the manufacture of their product, according to a survey conducted by the Market Research Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Presentation by Representative Smith of Ohio of a petition for a House vote on repeal of the old-age pension for Congressmen, which was recently passed, reflects the fear of retribution at the polls which has arisen among some law-makers, observers state.

After a lull of several days submarine activity off the Atlantic coast flared up again yesterday with the sinking somewhere off Maryland of the 3,627-ton freighter San Gil, owned by the Balboa Shipping Company, Inc., and operated by the United Fruit Company.

Notwithstanding the War and the fact that if artists go to South America they will have to go by plane, Latin American impresarios are hopeful that more United States singers and instrumentalists will visit the southern republics this year than last.

The flag-draped grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria provided a patriotic setting last night for the fortieth annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club. The event drew an attendance of nearly 2,500 persons prominent in society, political and civic circles, including Mr. and Mrs. Wendell Willkie, members of the club and their guests, and some three hundred officers and enlisted men of the armed forces.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The war on the Eastern Front has entered a crucial phase that foreign military specialists here believe will determine the strength Germany will be able to throw into her Spring offensive.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Russians declared officially today that 2,800 more Germans had fallen on the snowy battlefields far west of here on the road to Smolensk, and that the Red Army still was rolling ahead in its mighty Winter offensive despite fierce resistance by fresh Nazi troops.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The House quickly approved today the conference report on the $26,495,265,474 regular Navy appropriation bill, bringing to more than $115,000,000,000 funds voted or in the process of legislative approval for defense and war purposes since the beginning of the fiscal year 1941.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 (AP) -- With Phil Piche ramming home four goals, the Baltimore Orioles defeated the New York Rovers, 7 to 5, in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight in a fast game marked by a dozen penalties.

The traders in stocks appeared yesterday with sufficient buying power to cause a moderate advance in prices on the Stock Exchange. While the general run of gains was not impressive, the return of purchasing orders to the more investment type of issues brought a better feeling in Wall Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- In the face of renewed Democratic demands and a plea from a ranking officer of the Army Engineer Corps for immediate action, Republican members of the Senate continued today to block passage of a bill which would pave the way for completion of the New York City-Massena power line, needed for defense aluminum production.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 4 -- The State Governors have arranged to hold a meeting at Mazatlan, Sinaloa State, on Feb. 18 for the purpose of discussing West Coast defenses to be undertaken jointly with the United States.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic Seaboard at the close of last week were 19,536,000 barrels, a decline of 276,000 from the 19,812,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Returning to the Broadway scene this evening is Marc Connelly as the author and director of a comedy entitled "The Flowers of Virtue," opening at the Royale, where it will have its delayed premiere. Mr. Connelly, who wrote the Pulitzer Prize play, "The Green Pastures," has been absent since "Everywhere I Roam" (1938), with which he was associated in the triple capacity of co-author, co-producer and director.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- Despite its approach to perfection, the test blackout of Philadelphia last night resulted today in the reporting of more than 200 violations of a city blackout ordinance.

TOKYO, Feb. 4 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press at New York and San Francisco) -- The Tokyo radio said today that Japanese forces had subjected Singapore to an intensive twenty-four-hour bombardment and that the island fortress faced "imminent capture."

WE are still trying to fathom the Germans and the mystery of the German mind. Two new books on the subject are available. Neither could be called definitive or disinterested, but the first is illuminating. The second gives off about three times as much heat as light.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. "Woman of the Year" with Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy, will have its world premiere at the Radio City Music Hall. The Metro comedy, which has a newspaper background, was directed by George Stevens, and includes Fay Bainter, Reginald Owen, Minor Watson, and William Bendix among its featured players.

Heinrich Himmler, chief of Adolf Hitler's secret police, was the recipient of information gathered by Kurt Frederick Ludwig and his assistant, 18-year-old Lucy Boehmler, from testimony in Federal court yesterday. Her testimony contained a clear implication that some of this information resulted in the destruction of ships that sailed from this port.

A large store and basement in the new building at 116-22 West Fiftieth Street, in the Radio City area, has been leased for a restaurant, cocktail lounge and soda fountain by Mary M. Anthony. Samuel Geller was the broker. The new place will be under the management of James J. Garis, for twenty years owner of the Rismont Restaurant in the Capitol Theatre building, according to William F. Berghold, attorney for the landlord.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A joint communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries said today:

LONDON, Feb. 4 (Reuter) -- The annual report of the Council of Foreign Bond Holders records improvement in the foreign exchange position of most of the Latin-American countries as a result of, first, the Pan-American coffee "arrangement," which caused a sustained rise in prices of coffee; second, the British and United States war purchases, and third, the maintenance and extension of United States credits.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- An upward revision of the ceiling prices on rash lard and linseed oil, combined with strength in cotton, influenced traders today to take the buying side of wheat futures on the Board of Trade. Prices at one time were around 1 cent a bushel above Tuesday's finish, but the market ran into profit-taking on the upturn and part of the advance was lost, with the close 3/8 to 5/8 cent higher.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 4 -- Imports from the United States last year fell not far short of 1940 imports from all sources, according to figures made public today.

Complete fields were announced yesterday for the nine invitation events for the annual Millrose games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. Late entries have rounded out the fields and permitted Director Fred Schrnertz to announce them.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- An American version of the French photoplay "Crossroads" will go before the cameras at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in two weeks with William Powell and Hedy Lamarr heading the cast, the studio announced today.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company reported today that total admitted assets on Dec. 31, 1941, were $1,439,889,824, having increased $80,890,176, or 6 per cent in the year.

Motion pictures showing the sinking of American ships off the Atlantic Coast of the United States have reached Berlin -- possibly indicating the return of some of the first U-boat raiders sent to this side of the ocean -- according to a broadcast by the German Trans-ocean Radio intercepted here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A total of 1,292 officers and men of the Navy and Marine Corps are prisoners of the Japanese or missing in the Far Eastern war, spokesmen for the two fighting forces revealed today before the Senate Naval Affairs Committee.

Chayote is the squash's country cousin, a tender, tropical vegetable, native habitat of which is Mexico and Central America. But the fresh green spheres that are rolling into town this week hail from Florida -- and they're crisp and delicious.

OTTAWA, Feb. 4 -- Speaking from the government bench in the defense of the plebiscite proposal with regard to drafting men for overseas service, Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley this afternoon roundly accused extremist conscriptionists and extremist anti-conscriptionists of impeding Canada's war effort by the wildness of their outcry against the plebiscite.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Government facilities for training advanced meteorology students have been augmented 100 per cent for the training course beginning March 2, the Department of Commerce said today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Bruce Barnes of Houston, Texas, ranked fifth, was eliminated from the $1,500 Roney Plaza professional tennis tournament when he became ill in the third set of a scheduled three-out-of-five match and defaulted to Herman Paterson of Fishers Island, N.Y., today.

A suite of nine rooms and four baths in the building at 50 East Seventy-seventh Street has been leased by Henry M. Hubshman, president of the factoring firm of H.M. Hubshman Bro., through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Yale beat the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York for the second time this season by gaining a 4-3 victory before 1,000 fans at the Playland Ice Casino tonight. Three times Yale came from behind to tie the score before taking the lead at 19:05 in the second session.

Max (The Jerk) Golob, a minor member of the Brooklyn murder ring, was permitted yesterday in Kings County Court to plead guilty to second-degree assault, although he had been indicted for first-degree murder in an underworld slaying on March 3, 1935.

Distribution of recently offered new securities progressed quietly yesterday in investment banking circles. Syndicate managers for the group that offered $10,000,000 of 3 per cent bonds and 150,000 shares of 5.60 per cent preferred stock of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company reported that the bonds had been placed immediately, primarily with institutional investors, while the preferred stock had moved more slowly, but had met a fairly broad demand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- All efforts of the Japanese invading forces to crush American and Filipino resistance on the Bataan Peninsula in the Philippines continued to meet costly failure. Last night elements of the enemy's Sixteenth, or Kimura, Division launched an attack on the left flank of General Douglas MacArthur's forces fighting in the sector.

Plans for a twelve-round non-title bout between Sammy Angott, world lightweight champion, and Bob Montgomery, Philadelphia challenger, in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, were unexpectedly dropped yesterday when Angott reported himself unable to fulfill the contract. It is proposed to schedule the bout for March 6.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The war will have such a violent impact on local governmental revenues that the State and the country as a whole may be confronted by an epidemic of bankrupt communities, J. Russel Sprague, County Executive of Nassau County, declared today in a letter to Chairman Moffat of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

Small cans and jars used to pack individual servings of foods may shortly be dropped from production as part of the campaign to save metals and other materials needed for the war, it was reported yesterday in the wholesale grocery trade.

George Sessions Perry's novel, "Hold Autumn in Your Hand," published a year ago last month by Viking, has been voted the Booksellers Discovery of 1941, winning for its author the National Book Award, it was announced yesterday in Publishers Weekly.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Participants in the personnel conference of the American Management Association here were warned today that the war presented a challenge alike to management, labor and the industrial relations departments of corporations with far-sighted employment policies.

Forty-one-year-old Freddy Fitzsimmons yesterday signed for his eighteenth year in the majors and forthwith became the first big league player voluntarily to divert 10 per cent of his salary to the purchase of defense bonds.

Coupling of the quality labeling requirement with the price ceiling on finished cotton sheets and pillowcases by the Office of Price Administration set a precedent representing not only a war emergency step, but one also likely to have permanent significance in the post-war period, in giving consumers adequate merchandise information to guide them in their buying, according to comment here yesterday.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies armed forces issued this communique:

Adolf Hitler as a painter was "panned" by speakers at the private view of an exhibition of 112 paintings by artists of the United Nations at the National Arts Club galleries, 15 Gramercy Park, last night.

Continued heavy shipments of United States currency to Cuba were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly report on currency movements. The bank reveals that $5,907,000 was shipped abroad during January by United States banks, compared with $5,327,000 in December.
Sales of three apartment houses and an office building in scattered sections of Manhattan by the Dry Dock Savings Institution featured realty activity yesterday.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 4 (Australian Associated Press) -- Australians who were cut off from their units during the bitter Muar-Pakit-Sulong fighting in Malaya nearly a fortnight ago have been returning to the main body of the Australian Imperial force during the last few days.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4 -- Against fierce rear-guard action in the Germans' attempt to cover a general retreat Soviet troops continue to advance in all important sectors, according to reports released here today.
MOSCOW Thursday, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following today:

Margaret Speaks has been around in show business and has made the grade in radio. Her reputation precedes her. At her second Town Hall recital last night, she had a large audience and what looked like a host of friends. Since the soprano has an agreeable voice and an attractive personality, it was an evening pleasantly if not excitingly spent.

The first month of double fines for illegal parking has produced results which are plain to every one. The streets are more open than they have been in several years. Traffic at last begins to flow as it should, with proper clearance for essential services. The main point now is to keep conditions as they are and not to relax vigilance at this first success.

The store and loft building at 801 to 807 Broadway, northwest corner of Eleventh Street, which is occupied largely by manufacturers of men's clothing, has been purchased by an investor from Melrose Properties, Inc, represented by Jesse H. Barkin, attorney.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Creation of a special War Frauds Unit of the Department of Justice which will investigate and prosecute complaints arising from war-production contracts was announced today by Attorney General Biddle. The new unit, which will function jointly under the Anti-Trust and Criminal Divisions, will be headed by Fowler Hamilton, special assistant to the Attorney General.

How a union collaborated with an employer to deprive eleven workers of their jobs after they had joined the union in the belief that they would thereby obtain job protection and better working conditions was disclosed yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board in a report submitted to it by Howard Myers, trial examiner in the case.

Nazi wrecking operations in historic Paris neighborhoods have brought forth a protest signed by one hundred French intellectuals. Among them are Paul Valery, Andre Siegfried, Paul Morand and the painter Derain. "Paris," says their letter in Figaro, "which in June, 1940, miraculously escaped trial by fire and the horror of destruction, is unexpectedly menaced by new destruction."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 -- A large number of California's 110,000 enemy aliens face vastly altered living conditions after Feb. 24 with the announcement today by Attorney General Biddle of a "curfew zone" embracing more than a quarter of the State, with extension of the area virtually certain.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and associates will offer to the public today $1,000,000 of fifteen-year 4 per cent debentures of the Fisher Brothers Company. The bonds, due Feb. 1, 1957, will be priced to the public at par. The company was incorporated in Ohio in 1908 and operates 243 retail food stores in and around Cleveland.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 4 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued the following communique tonight:

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Because of public apathy, Newark is failing to attain the results in its school system that are warranted by the city's heavy expenditures for education, it was asserted in a report made public today on a seven-month investigation of the system by a survey staff from Teachers College, Columbia University.

In first place and with the longest consecutive-game-scoring record in National Hockey League history, the New York Rangers tonight will face the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden in what promises to be one of the most exciting skirmishes of the season, waged before a turn-away crowd.

The third application of the trustees of the Silesian-American Corporation for a loan from Swiss interests to make possible the payment in full of the principal and interest of the fifteen-year 7 per cent collateral trust bonds of the company due on Aug. 1, 1941, has been denied by the Treasury Department in Washington, according to a letter sent yesterday to the holders of these bonds.

Miss Elaine Murray-Jacoby, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. H. Murray-Jacoby, gave a tea yesterday at the home of her parents, 1165 Fifth Avenue, for a group of young women aiding in the plans for the Colonial Ball to be held on Feb. 21 at the Plaza.

A 14-year-old veteran of a naval battle two years ago between Polish and German sea forces in the Baltic Sea has tried to enlist in the United States Navy as a cabin boy or bugler, it was revealed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- The right of private employers to discharge employes who fail to do their work satisfactorily, regardless of union affiliation, was upheld today in a sharp opinion by Judge Wherman Minton of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.
After two months of war, the first phase of the Battle of the Far East has ended and the second and possibly decisive chapter has opened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- J.E. Barnes, Washington legal representative of the Todd Shipyards Company, told the Senate Naval Committee today that his company had "no right to profit" on war contracts and urged Congress to reclaim through taxes certain earnings which he acknowledged had been excessive.

More "soldiers" and fewer "generals" are needed in volunteer defense organizations, Mrs. Oswald B. Lord, in charge of citizen voluntary participation for the Office of Civilian Defense, Second Region, declared yesterday.

Philip H. Hubbard, vice president of the Reinhold Publishing Corporation of New York, has purchased from the Bank for Savings the ten-room residence with three baths and a two-car garage at - 2 Bonmar Road, Pelham Manor, Westchester.

Never able to take the lead until two and a half minutes from the end, New York University capped a long uphill fight by toppling the St. Francis quintet from the ranks of the unbeaten at Madison Square Garden last night before a howling crowd of 11,587 by a 40-37 score.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- The Dies Committee on Un-American Activities soon will make public a "Yellow Paper" on Japanese activities in the United States, disclosing a wide-spread spy ring of about 150,000 members, a committee spokesman said tonight.

Main Street glowing less brightly, housewives reducing their consumption of electricity in refrigerators, vacuum-cleaners and other appliances -- such is the picture of an acute power shortage presented by the State Power Authority. One conclusion drawn from this is a recommendation for immediate construction of the St. Lawrence project.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Frank Edward Smith, 21 years old, of Wayne Avenue, Stony Point, who is in a critical condition from a self-inflicted wound at the Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, was placed under arrest today by Clarence J. Sullivan, of the State Police Bureau of Criminal Investigation, on a charge of murdering his father, Frank Doyle Smith, 47.

A business property in the Journal Square district of Jersey City, the three-story structure at 900-2 Bergen Avenue, has been sold by Arbee Estates, Inc., Robert Benenson, president, of New York City, to the Nine Hundred Two Bergen Avenue Corporation, Ruth Freid, president.

Both cheerful and discomforting news was received from Eastern ski circles yesterday. Last weekend, while the metropolitan area was being drenched with rain, most of the popular centers in the Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians were being blanketed with from five to twelve inches of new powder snow.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The stock markets were steadier today, but the turnover was small. Gilt-edge issues again had little support, but prices of home rails were maintained. Industrials showed little movement.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A Board of Trade order today promised cheaper suitings and more goods for clothing coupons.

A plan by which freight cars ordered by the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad are put into service as soon as they are completed and before they are delivered to the railroad was announced yesterday by C. McD. Davis, executive vice president.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 14 -- Bombers of the Royal Australian Air Force made a fifth raid last night on enemy ships in Rabaul harbor, New Britain, directly hitting a large vessel. For the first time enemy fighters took off when the bombers appeared but were driven off by Australian aerial gunners.

We are not going "back to normalcy" after this war, declared Charles W. Elliot, director of the National Resources Planning Board, in an address here last night, adding that "it may very well be that the chaos which follows the downfall of the Japs, the Nazis and the Fascists will be almost indistinguishable from war."

PALM BEACH Fla., Feb. 4 -- Town officials, civic leaders and officers of the Palm Beach Art League and the Four Arts Society gave a reception this afternoon at the Norton Art Galleries for Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hubbard Norton, donors of the galleries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Army is prepared to abandon its indefinite quantity contract buying of all meats, meat products and fish in line with a new procurement procedure to be followed by the country's quartermaster market centers.

The old Tombs, the city prison that was abandoned last November after serving as a detention pen for the city's most notorious criminals for forty-four years, will be remodeled within the next few months as a "college" for the training of firemen, according to an announcement last night by the Fire Department.

Many members of society attended the performance of "Carmen" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Scholarship Fund of the Smith College Club of New York. All of the boxes for the performance had been reserved by subscribers.

In enforcing the city's drive against the illegal parking of automobiles the police yesterday reached into a classroom of the Seward Park High School on Grand Street to arrest a 16-year-old girl student on charges of repeated parking violations.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Army got back in the winning column at basketball today, defeating the University of Pennsylvania in a fast game, 40 to 34. The cadets were slow to start but after the first ten minutes were always in the van. Army led at half time, 22 to 14.

Joe Cook, one of the merriest comedians ever to spread cheer over the footlights, announced yesterday the end of a thirty-five-year career during which he touched almost every phase of the entertainment world.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Deliberations of the House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church centered on a nation-wide wartime program today at the opening session of a two-day meeting, the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, presiding Bishop, urging aggressive "offensives," not only to meet war conditions but to prepare for the period immediately following the War.

THE esteemed editor of The Amateur Athlete, the monthly publication of the A.A.U., has come up with some added military information in the latest issue. The esteemed editor is Dan Ferris, the stylish-stout secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U., and he likes to keep track of the boys wherever they are. He reached rather far back when he added Private Joseph Louis Barrow to his list of A.A.U. alumni in the armed service.

Buttons made of pine cones, costume Jewelry of baked porcelain and web bows of horse hair to adorn the wartime coiffure are whimsical step-children of priority rulings to be seen this week at the National Notion and Novelty Exhibit at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced today that Dr. Hoyt H. Hudson, chairman of the English Department, had resigned to go to Stanford University as Professor of English.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Zacatine came right back to win at Hialeah Park after a previous victory that had made some suppose the hurdle today would be too steep. As a result the betting on the Grade B Handicap found Zacatine second choice to the Western flyer Big Ben.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- George H. Earle, former American Minister to Bulgaria, said today that hatred of the Nazis -- a hatred perhaps unequaled in history -- was sweeping through Europe.

The New York State Labor Relations Board has settled or averted 1,067 strikes since its establishment in 1937, according to a report covering the four and one-half years ended last December and made public yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John P. Boland, chairman.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Lord Beaverbrook was named today to the newly created War Cabinet post of Minister of War Production. To succeed Lord Beaverbrook as Minister of Supply King George named Sir Andrew Rae Duncan, who held that office before Lord Beaverbrook.

Substantial reductions in venereal disease in the Navy and Marine Corps in the last few years, with the syphilis rate in the Navy at the lowest point in history, were reported yesterday by Rear Admiral Ross T. McIntire, Surgeon General of the Navy and personal physician to President Roosevelt, and Captain C.S. Stephenson, in charge of the division of preventive medicine of the Navy.

Harry and David Gabe sold to a client of Frederick and Jerome Weiss, attorneys, the five-story apartment at 550 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, on the corner of 150th Street. This is a thirteen-family building with two stores, valued for taxation at $32,000.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- The Congressional committee investigating anti-Argentine activities today asked the Governor of the Brazilian State of Rio Grande do Sul for a detailed report on Axis nationals who have left Brazil for Argentina since Dec. 7, the date of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

A banking group composed of Stifel, Nicolaus Co., Inc., Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., and B.V. Christie Co. has received the award of an issue of $459,000 of sewer bonds of West University Place, Texas, on a net interest cost basis of 3.718 per cent.

Continuing to play her fast, hard-hitting game, Miss Caroline Myers of Vassar won the eleventh annual New York Junior League invitation squash racquets tournament by defeating Miss Helen Stone of the Rockaway Hunting Club on the league courts yesterday.

The annual citations of honor of the Young Men's Hebrew Association at Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, were awarded at a dinner there last night to Laurence Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Turkey, and Hank Greenberg, Detroit baseball star, now a sergeant of infantry at Fort Dix, N.J.

On the recently enacted price control bill the work of the Washington reporters was, in my opinion, excellent. The editorial comment not only in your paper but also in many others, I am frank to say, indicates a lack of knowledge of the bill.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The defenders of Java, acutely aware of the danger of a Japanese invasion, tonight grimly counted 174 casualties and "very considerable" fighter aircraft losses after yesterday's two-hour assault by more than seventy bombers on Surabaya, the United Nations naval bastion that has replaced Singapore as an offensive base.

The hazards of sacrificing freedom of thought and expression in the war were stressed last night by Dr. Irwin Edman, Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, at the opening of the "Fifty Books of the Year" exhibition, sponsored by the American Institute of Graphic Arts at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A Treasury report on the national debt showed today that on Jan. 31 it was within less than five billions of the $65,000,000,000 statutory limit. This means that the Treasury must soon ask Congress for a new enlargement of the debt limit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Establishment of a ceiling price schedule by OPA today wiped out recent substantial increases in wholesale prices for women's nylon hosiery. Leon Henderson, price administrator, in announcing the schedule, said that it specifically exempts retail sales but warned that "retail prices already are as high as they can be permitted to go."

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's visit to Italy is assuming added importance in direct ratio to German and Italian endeavors to minimize it. It is reported here from Berlin, for instance, that the mere fact that Marshal Goering is holding conversations in Rome "proves the close contact existing between the leaders of the German and the Italian armies."

Because of the advances made in medicine, the men serving in this war will have a far greater chance to survive than any of the fighting forces in history, one hundred young women interested in wartime nursing careers were told yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4 (AP) -- An announcement today of German food allowances for the period from Feb. 8 to March 9 showed that the Germans were maintaining wartime rations more than twice as large as those of some German-occupied territory and almost double the Italian rations.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 4 -- It was only a question of time before the Japanese began the Battle of Java by bombing the kernel of Indonesian defense and selecting what probably is the most important objective -- the Surabaya naval base and neighboring air stations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Detail sales last year of $53,600,000,000 were the highest in history, the Department of Commerce reported today. Sales were 17 per cent higher than 1940, 11 per cent above 1929, and more than twice the volume of 1933, the depression low in retail trade.

One of the primary tasks of the new national defense squad recently established in the Police Department by Commissioner Valentine will be the suppression of gambling, prostitution and other vice in areas near military and naval establishments and in districts frequented by soldiers and sailors on leave, it was disclosed yesterday.

John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, has been appointed chairman of the fifth annual drive of the Greater New York Fund on behalf of 400 private welfare and health agencies, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- British light naval forces and units of the Polish Navy intercepted and sank two laden enemy supply ships off the Channel Islands today, the Admiralty announced tonight. Both ships were engaged at close range, according to the communique.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- With war traffic requiring an ever-increasing portion of the transportation system, Americans will have to rely more on shoe leather in traveling, Joseph B. Eastman, director of defense transportation, told the American Transit Association today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- The Equitable Life Insurance Company of Iowa, Des Moines, in its seventy-fifth annual report, announced today that assets in 1941 increased $14,261,126 to $220,077,848. New life insurance sold amounted to $51,738,911, an increase of 14.8 per cent compared with 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- All field activities of the War Production Board were consolidated tonight by the chairman, Donald M. Nelson, to provide "faster, more efficient service to business and industry."

Staid Sutton Place was "bombed" yesterday morning and incendiary bombs "dropped" at East Fifty-sixth Street and Sutton Place South. But the bombs did no damage and created no panic. Constable Herbert Scott, British Air Raid Protection expert, was there to put them out with the equipment from his new air raid patrol car.

Vivienne Simon, youthful lyric soprano, who has been heard in opera at the Juilliard School of Music, gave her first New York recital last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Miss Simon's singing was uneven because of a constantly varying production, but when at its best had ingratiating charm.
Mr. and Mrs. William Kent Dupre gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 40 East Sixty-sixth Street, for former Governor Clyde R. Hoey of North Carolina.

Development of a new type of war production pool, in which a non-defense company with limited machine tool facilities becomes a prime contractor in the manufacture of war materials, was announced yesterday by the Sloane-Blabon Corporation, third largest linoleum manufacturer in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- While the Senate was defending Mr. Wheeler of Montana from the surprising charge that (a) he had blocked the passage of a bill to permit the use of wire-tapping in counter-espionage, and (b) the absence of this permission enabled the Japanese to surprise the defenders of Pearl Harbor, it got into an enlightening discussion of our failure, some years back, to fortify Guam.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 4 -- Military measures to safeguard Argentine territory during the present international crisis were announced by Acting President Ramon S. Castillo after a Cabinet council this morning.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- The Ford Motor Company announced today the termination of its $20,000,000 group-insurance plan for employes and the Ford local of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) discussed means of carrying it on.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The Salvation Army Staff in the Eastern territory, which directs welfare activities in eleven States from its headquarters in this city, is prepared to cooperate in "all auxiliary war activities" here, Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, the new commander, declared yesterday.

VICHY, France, Feb. 4 -- Chief of State Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, addressing the first national council of the French Legion, his organization of war veterans, said today that indifference and veiled hostility, even within the government's administration, had confused the French public about the legion's role.

Buyers paid $14,147 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for Currier Ives lithographs belonging to the New York Zoological Society and to B.W. Lockwood of Chicago and others; for English color prints from the estate of Margaretta C. Clark, Bernardsville, N.J.; for American views from the collection of Mrs. E. Leipprand, Riverdale, and for other lots.
The possibility of a shortage of cocoa and chocolate is remote, a survey of trade opinion by The Associated Press disclosed yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt arranged today to meet Friday with six leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations. Sidney Hillman, labor director of the War Production Board, will attend the session which, it is thought probable, will devote some attention to the task of mobilizing sufficient trained manpower to produce the armament called for by the President's war program.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Roadside markers to designate civilian evacuation routes from New York City to New England were installed in Westchester County yesterday by employes of the State Highway Department. The routes follow chiefly the secondary roads that parallel strategic highways and parkways.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The House Immigration Committee was told today that enactment of legislation (H.R. No. 1844) to authorize the naturalization of Filipinos who are permanent residents of the United States would serve as "an inspiration to all Americans of foreign birth to intensify their efforts for the victory program."

The twenty-nine-story Master Hotel on a knoll above Riverside Drive at 103d Street was blacked out for fifteen minutes last night in a test to keep the occupants of the 370 apartments in the building "on the alert" for air raid alarms.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 4 -- The Supreme United Nations Command, charging the defenders of Singapore to hold on at all cost, assured this besieged island today that "great reinforcements" of British and American forces were being sent to the Southwestern Pacific.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt signed two minor bills dealing with naval administration. He received no callers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission announced today that eight French merchant ships laid up in American ports would be operated by American companies.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Governor Robert A. Hurley today summarily suspended from office, pending a hearing, William J. Cox, Highway Commissioner, after receiving from the Attorney General a letter in which the latter charged the commissioner had been "guilty of material neglect of duty and incompetence."

Although the United States is at war with Japan, a Japanese company must be allowed to defend itself against a suit brought in the New York State courts by an American concern, Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter declared yesterday in granting an application on behalf of Mitsui Co., Ltd., for a stay of all proceedings in a suit for $45,000 by Murray Oil Products Company, Inc.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 4 -- The railroads are prepared to move wartime traffic, "with no illusions about the magnitude," but they require the aid of shippers and travelers, R.W. Brown, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, said tonight to the Wyoming Valley Traffic Club.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 4 -- Mexico tomorrow will celebrate the anniversary of her Constitution of 1917, which nationalized subsoil wealth.

A proposal that corporations supplement Social Security benefits with private pension funds was offered yesterday at the midwinter conference of the trust division of the American Bankers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The proposal to tax outstanding tax-exempt government bonds was denounced yesterday as "an act of bad faith" by the committee on taxation of the New York State Chamber of Commerce, which, if successful, would be an act of dishonor which would impair confidence in the pledges of the government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The resources of the Federal Reserve System for purchasing Federal securities "are practically unlimited," Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Friday.

The American Locomotive Company has about $300,000,000 of unfilled orders on hand, of which about 75 per cent are for munitions of war, William C. Dickerman, chairman, announced yesterday. The company's plant in Schnectady, N.Y., where employment dropped to 800 persons in the depression years, now has more than 7,000 men and women on the rolls.
