The consumer rush for men's wear in this area definitely subsided this week, retailers reported yesterday. Business was good but lacked the buying fervor of the last three weeks in January, which was a record period for men's wear stores. Stores will have to scrape a little harder for business this month and some are ready to release advertising copy announcing the receipt of new Spring stocks.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- China's armies are getting in shape for major offensives against Japan with war equipment provided by the United States, military officials revealed today. They said the offensives would begin this year, possibly soon

Nevil Ford, State Administrator of the New York Defense Savings Staff, announced yesterday that 17,500 of the 40,000 employes of the New York Telephone Company were regularly buying defense savings bonds through a payroll deduction plan at an annual purchase rate of $2,141,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Without debate and with only a few minutes' preliminary discussion, the House today approved by a voice vote a joint resolution authorizing a $500,000,000 loan to China to help stabilize her currency and aid her in her war effort in the United Nations' cause.

Despite establishment of ceiling prices on exports, merchandise for which export licenses have already been granted will not be affected by the OPA controls, a representative of the Office of Export Control, Board of Economic Warfare, asserted yesterday.

Gross earnings of the Acme Steel Company and its subsidiary amounted to $8,518,726 for the twelve months ended with December, an increase of $5,007,158 over the preceding twelve-month period, according to the preliminary report announced yesterday.

The cotton market moved up again yesterday and prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near their best levels of the session at net gains of 13 to 16 points. With the market in a better technical position after its recent sharp decline, offerings were limited and prices responded to small orders from trade and mill sources.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- Tommy Milton's speedway background and his technical knowledge of automobiles today won the one-time ace of the world's racing drivers an acquittal on a charge of negligent homicide.

Reasserting his contention that he had been erroneously convicted twenty months ago on a criminal libel indictment, and adding that the Court of Appeals would uphold him despite the recent decision of the Appellate Division affirming the verdict, Clarence A. Hathaway, the ousted editor of the Communist newspaper The Daily Worker, yesterday began serving his thirty-day workhouse term.

Showing a clever passing attack, the fast La Salle Academy basketball team scored its fourth victory in five Manhattan-Richmond C.H. S.A.A. contests and gained a firmer hold on second place by routing Power Memorial, 30 to 11, in the finale of a school double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Apprentice Jimmy George brought home five winners today in the seven races he rode on the eight-event Fair Grounds card, boosting his total to twenty-six for the meet.
SPOKANE, Wash., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The "Bundles for Congress" truck, which the Athletic Round Table is sending to Washington Representatives and Senators, will leave Spokane tomorrow.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 4 -- Issuance of $25,000,000 of 3 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1977 by the Commonwealth Edison Company was authorized today by the Illinois Commerce Commission.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- If a workman changes his clothes of his own accord at the start and end of the day the time he takes need not be counted as time worked, the wage-hour division ruled today.

Declaring that those who make the policy of the United Nations must not forget "the right of little nations" to participate in the ultimate victory, Senator Claude Pepper of Florida appealed last night for the formation of a Palestine Jewish fighting force.

In a statement said to have been smuggled out of France, former Premier Leon Blum, a defendant in the approaching "war guilt" trials, describes himself as a man "already condemned." Undoubtedly he is. The Riom court which is expected to try Blum, Daladier, Reynaud, Gamelin and possibly other defendants this month, is an, extra-legal body, political in nature and obviously created for the purpose of condemning the prisoners brought before it.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Violation of rationing, freezing and price-fixing orders of the Federal Government would be made a misdemeanor punishable by the State, under terms of the third major defense bill on the State's program, and introduced today.

Gordon W. Lillie, whose real name was almost forgotten in the greater glory of "Pawnee Bill," is dead in his artificial Indian "trading post" of Pawnee. A little less than sixty years ago he joined Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show. Old Easterners can still smell that dusty and gunpowdered air, and hear the tympanum-tearing yells.
CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Chinese Army headquarters today acknowledged reverses in Kwangtung Province on China's south coast but claimed successes in Kiangsi, north of Kwangtung.

When the city took over the subways a great many benefits and improvements were expected -- the subway employes did receive benefits, which, no doubt, were long overdue, but the general public received nothing. If anything, the subways are dirtier and the service worse.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4 -- German troops that form the spearhead of the Axis offensive in Libya entered Derna, easternmost large town in the region of the Jebel el-Achdar, yesterday.

Twelve young women who prefer to be known as "prospective policewomen" will begin today a two-year pre-service training course at the City College Division of Public Service Training, 139th Street and Convent Avenue. The course previously was open only to men.

The Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West Seventy-third Street, just west of Broadway, and the Harlem-New York Presbyterian Church, 2 West 122d Street, will petition the Presbytery of New York for permission to merge. A special meeting of the Presbytery has been called for next Monday in the Rutgers Church to act on the petition.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 4 -- Blistering artillery barrages from the British stronghold at Martaban and sweeping attacks by low-flying American and British planes checked the Japanese drive into Burma along the fifty-mile Salween River front today for the fourth successive day.

An order was served yesterday on the New York State Insurance Department, returnable on Feb. 11 in the Supreme Court of New York County, special term, part 1, to show cause why the Superintendent of Insurance should not be restrained from paying out any funds of the New York branch of the First Russian Insurance Company until there are further proceedings.

Asserting that "nothing in history has turned out to be more impermanent than military victory," Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, called yesterday for faith in the ultimate victory of good over evil. He spoke to a group of students, faculty and alumni of Columbia University at the opening session of Columbia's first Conference on Religion in the Modern World held in the Milbank Chapel of Teachers College, Broadway and 120th Street.
SINGAPORE, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Carrying on the grind to which they have long been accustomed, salvage crews, fire fighters and medical services immediately took over today's bombed area.

Speeches by two vice chairmen of the Red Cross War Fund drive of Greater New York emphasized yesterday that attainment of the $7,330,000 goal here is a war effort of equal importance with fulfillment of the nation's industrial production program.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The girls are going up in the air to aid in the Victory drive, the State Defense Council said today in a report indicating that 15 per cent of New Jersey's 500 volunteers in the civil air patrol are women.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Five inmates of the "drunk tank" of San Diego's new "model jail" were killed and twelve other prisoners were burned when a fire, started by an overnight occupant of a padded cell, swept one floor of the jail early today.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Criticism of British industry on the ground that it still has "unutilized reserves," combined with praise for the "splendid morale" of British working men and women, was voiced today by N.M. Shvernik, leader of a Soviet Russian trade union delegation that has been visiting Britain for the last few weeks.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4 -- "Hold at all cost" seems to have been the order given by Commander in Chief Adolf Hitler to his troops in Russia before leaving his field headquarters for his mountain fastness at Berchtesgaden. Swedish sources report his arrival there today, adding that he may remain there "some time."
MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4 -- The withdrawal by British troops in Libya and the report that Derna has been evacuated by the British cause no surprise in Rome, according to reports received here. Derna has never been strongly defended during the see-saw campaigns in Cyrenaica.

The use of a stamp plan for the rationing of sugar, which is to be set up shortly by the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration, will be an effective method of assuring fair treatment of consumers, retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers, according to comment in the food trade yesterday.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- Major interest here and in the Western Pacific generally continues focused on Singapore, with considerable confidence that the British there will be able to hold out until a United Nations counter-attack in Far Eastern theatres as a whole will develop to sufficient extent to relieve Japanese pressure on the island.

Losses arising from "fires, storms, shipwrecks or other casualty" need not be connected with the taxpayer's trade or business to be deductible on his income tax return, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced yesterday. If his home or automobile is destroyed by fire, or his Summer bungalow damaged by flood or storm, he may claim a deduction of the loss sustained.

Members of the Tammany executive committee expressed confidence yesterday that they had the votes needed to oust former Representative Christopher D. Sullivan as leader at the meeting of the committee tomorrow afternoon.

The Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in the Graybar Building, Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, announced yesterday that it had been asked by Selective Service headquarters to provide 4,200 women to help local draft boards on Feb. 15-16, when men between the ages of 20 and 45 years will be registered for military service.
Electric power for advertising signs, street lighting and industries not essential to war production will be rationed, the State Power Authority warned yesterday.

The stamp of practical wartime clothes was definitely in evidence at the luncheon showing at the Waldorf-Astoria presented by Arnold Constable yesterday. The collection was based on simple lines dressed up with feminine froufrou. Color, too, had its word to say. "Hot pink" led off.

We publish on this page a letter from Senator Brown of Michigan defending the price-control law just enacted. Both because Senator Brown and other commentators are mistaken about this newspaper's attitude on some of the provisions and omissions in that law, and because the economic policies involved are of the first importance, it seems desirable to restate our position on some points.

Cooperation between a pool of fire and casualty insurance companies and the Federal Government to provide bombing and similar war risk insurance of property is suggested by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, in his annual report to the Legislature, which was made public yesterday.
The forgotten man of this era is the high school boy living in defense areas, Goldie Carter, Y.W.C.A. supervisor in the Southern-Central and Southern States, declared yesterday.

"As Artists See New York" is the title of an exhibition of contemporary prints arranged by the Prints Division of the New York Public Library in Room 316. The exhibition, which opens today, will continue through May 3. It is divided into groups, one of which characterizes the whole event, being called "East Side, West Side, All Around the Town."

Those planning to fish this season in Florida waters would do well to write for one of the new fishing guides compiled by Erl Roman of The Miami Herald. Roman has done a thorough job of describing the fishing possibilities from Miami to Key West.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Attorney General Biddle issued two new orders today further restricting the movements of enemy aliens on the Pacific coast.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The State's record in vehicle accidents last year was the worst since 1937, Carroll E. Mealey, commissioner, states in his annual report today. The increase in traffic deaths over 1940 was 8.5 per cent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Taking six of nine first places, Princeton's well-balanced swimming forces routed Rutgers, 52 -- 23, for their third straight victory of the season today. It was the first defeat in five starts for the Scarlet.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Dartmouth, defending champion in the Eastern Intercollegiate League, moved into a tie for first place with Cornell by conquering the Princeton basketball team, 54 -- 50, in an overtime struggle on the losers' court tonight.

Salary increases for the junior members of the New York Stock Exchange staff, which will become effective today, were made possible by a policy of cutting down other benefits of employes, according to a letter addressed by Emil Schram, president, to the personnel.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 4 -- Brooklyn College rallied in the second half, but lost to the Villanova quintet tonight, 36 -- 33, before 1,500 spectators when Billy Woods of the Wildcats bunched five of his twelve points in the last four minutes. The Wildcats led at the half, 21 -- 12.

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 4 -- Blanketed under six inches of snow on parking lots outside automobile factories in this area lie millions of dollars of discarded equipment, only visible reminder of the assembly lines that turned out thousands of passenger cars each day.

Hair combed slickly, boots gleaming, and standing rigidly at attention, 12-year-old William Reardon received the tenderfoot pin of the Boy Scouts yesterday in a brief ceremony enrolling him officially as the 300,000th member of the Greater New York organization.

Custom tailors made their contribution to national conservation yesterday by introducing the "economy" suit, which embodies virtually all the suggestions made thus far for saving wool material. Using only two and five-eighths yards of material compared with the usual three and a half yards, the streamlined outfit has no collar or lapels, lacks cuffs and pleats on the trousers and flaps on the pockets, is shorter in the jacket and narrower in the trouser legs.

HAVANA, Feb. 5 -- Although Cuba has no currency system, having utilized United States money since the beginning of the republic, with the exception of silver pesos issued for local circulation, the United States dollar was quoted at seven-eights per cent discount here today.
ROME, Feb. 5 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

OTTAWA, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The widow of Flying Officer Douglas Van Buskirk of Bronxville, N.Y., was informed today by the British Air Ministry that he had died at the controls of his Stirling bomber when it was shot down over Germany on Nov. 7.
BERLIN, Feb. 5 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
Due to the great increase in no trespassing signs in many Eastern States, and the resultant decrease in open game areas, public hunting has become a serious problem in many places.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 5 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering returned to Berlin tonight from Rome after passing several days in Italy. When he left the Italian capital last evening Premier Mussolini was at the railroad station to bid him farewell and "they exchanged cordial words testifying to the sincere friendship binding the Axis powers," says a dispatch from Rome.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -Representative Celler charged the War Department tonight with "summarily and injudiciously" seeking to acquire the property known as the Foreign Trade Zone at Staten Island, as an embarkation point for troops and supplies.

An increase of 30 per cent in the wages of the 35,000 employes of the city's unified transit system is asked in a petition submitted to the Board of Transportation yesterday by the New York City Transit Employes Benevolent Association. The petition, said to be signed by 7,000 employes, representing all three divisions of the city system, is now in the hands of Chairman John H. Delaney.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- A series of bills, easing some restrictions of the Page-Anderson Motor Vehicle Financial Responsibility Law, which went into effect Jan. 1, were introduced today in the Legislature by Senator Page and Assemblyman Anderson, Republican coauthors of the act.

Rules and precedents were smashed yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange opened its floor to a group of twenty young women from stage, screen and society and allowed them to sell tickets for the Navy Relief Show to be held in Madison Square Garden on March 10.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The promotion of Captain W.G. Tennant to the rank of rear admiral was announced today soon after the officer had given King George a first-hand account of the loss of his ship, the battle cruiser Repulse, off Malaya last December.

In "The Flowers of Virtue," which was acted at the Royale last evening, Marc Connelly has written a discursive little drama that concludes with an expression of hope for the times. Not to fumble around among the amenities, that is the most that can be said for the first play to bear his signature in four years.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin granted yesterday a limited injunction restraining Serge Rubinstein and other officers and directors of the Chosen Corporation and its New York subsidiaries from removing assets now under litigation from the jurisdiction of the court.

The New York State Federation of Women's Clubs will give an ambulance to the United States forces in the field as its special project in its expanded war program. The announcement was made yesterday by Mrs. Guy W. Cheney, federation president, during the midwinter session of federation executives at the Hotel Astor.

John Mark Glenn has been elected a trustee of the Community Service Society, it was announced yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, chairman of the board of trustees. A social work leader for forty-five years, Mr. Glenn was general director of the Russell Sage Foundation for twenty-four years until 1931, when he retired and was appointed secretary of its board. He still holds the post of secretary.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Reserve ratio for the New York bank also was at the year's high.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Professional operations dominated the action of the grain markets today, with wheat and corn declining around 1 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade at one time. Although commission houses supported the markets at times, wheat closed 5/8 cent lower and corn was off 1/2 cent to 5/8 cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- "The Yearling," by Marjory Kinnan Rawlings, which Metro abandoned last Summer after spending an estimated $500,000 on it, will be salvaged this Spring if a child actor can be found to replace Gene Echman, who played the lead in the sequences shot last year.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A hospital ship carrying wounded American soldiers and nurses from the Philippines to an Australian port was attacked nine times in one day by Japanese bombers and fighter planes that "came over like swarms of flies," it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The general level of wholesale prices, led by prices of farm and textile products, resumed its upward movement during the week ended on Jan. 31, following the slight reaction of the previous week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

About 200,000 posters were on their way yesterday to 60,000 retail drug stores throughout the country in a nationwide drive to tell American consumers how they may cooperate to save tin for war purposes. Tin tubes aggregating some 6,000 tons were estimated to be on home medicine cabinet shelves and the objective of the drive is to conserve the twenty to twenty-five tons which consumers normally throw away every day.

With four months elapsed since the new housing project in the East Bronx, known as Clason Point Houses, was dedicated, the New York City Housing Authority surveys the conditions under which the development's 400 tenant families live and finds them eminently satisfactory.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Creation of a branch of military service, a War Technical Training Corps, to be enlisted from "a large reservoir of men and women now outside the colleges but already partly trained," was proposed to the Army and the Navy and other government services today by President Hotchkiss of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute as a means of alleviating the shortage of trained personnel for the technical and scientific aspects of war.

A demonstration exhibition, "The Appreciation of the Arts," organized by the Cincinnati Museum under the sponsorship of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, will open tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum and will continue through March.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Plans of the Army to erect printing and bookbinding plants in each corps area for pamphlets, booklets and books of instructions for troops have apparently been sidetracked as a result of protests made by representatives of the War Production Board.

Your witty and provocative editorial of Feb. 4, "The Dead Hand of Names," dealing, from the "layman's" standpoint, with the pending court proceeding re the use of the name Alexander Green by lawyers named neither Alexander nor Green, raises some additional questions of interest to the general public.

RANGOON, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- American and British fliers today hurled a murderous rain of bombs and cannon and machine-gun fire on Japanese troops massed in the Paan sector, 105 miles east of here, for an attempt to cross the Salween River in force and reach the Moulmein-Rangoon railway.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 5 (AP) -- With vessels provided by the United States and manned by Uruguayan naval crews, Uruguay will patrol her own strategic coasts on the Atlantic and the River Plate estuary, where the shattered, refuged German pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee was scuttled after a battle with the British in December, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The War Production Board disclosed today that President Roosevelt's "blueprint for victory" would require production of $2,000,000,000 worth of machine tools and related metal-working machinery this year, as compared with a present production rate of about $1,100,000,000.

Modern war requires an entirely new style of home defense and far greater service from the Red Cross than in any previous war, Leon Fraser, chairman of the Greater New York War Fund drive, declared yesterday in his headquarters at 57 William Street.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast the following communique today:

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 5 -- With a field of sixty-four contestants in the six events, the Outing Club of Dartmouth College starts its thirty-second Winter carnival tomorrow morning with the downhill race.

In their first change of ownership since 1886, the two five-story tenements on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 334-6 East Twenty-ninth Street have been sold by the Interborough Funding Corporation to a client of Bertram Shelley, attorney. They contain forty apartments and are assessed at $36,000.

Winners of most of last year's sprints and hurdles championships have been seeded at the top of the 60-yard dash and the 60-yard high hurdles for the Millrose games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, Director Fred Schmertz announced yesterday.

The downward movement of excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System continued in the week ended on Wednesday and was even more pronounced than in the previous week. The excess funds of member banks of the entire system declined $150,000,000 in the week to $3,330,000,000, as actual reserve balances dropped $226,000,000 while reserve requirements declined $76,000,000.

Congress has stirred up a hornet's nest by its recent action in amending the Civil Service Retirement Act so as to include Senators and Representatives. Two main questions are involved. The first is whether Congress ought, under any circumstances, to come under the Civil Service Retirement System.

Plans that may make possible the very early release of 5,000 tons of scrap steel for war uses have been made in connection with the properties of the defunct New York, Westchester Boston Railway, it was learned yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 5 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho is again studying the oil expropriation question in connection with the whole problem of Mexico's industrial development with the aid of foreign capital, according to a high Mexican source.

Largely unaware of any change, the majority of American motorists operating the 34,000,000 motor vehicles in the United States have been driving for more than a month on gasoline reduced 5 to 10 per cent in octane rating, a survey showed yesterday.
Senora de Michels, wife of Don Rodolfo de Michels, Chilean Ambassador, has arrived from Washington and is at the WaldorfAstoria.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Participants in the American Management Association conference on personnel relations here today were assured by E.C. Morse, manager of the personnel relations division, RCA Manufacturing Company, Inc., Camden, N.J., that it was possible to build employe morale under a union contract and to work with the union successfully in speeding government contracts on defense work.

A campaign to align the foreign-language groups in New York City in the defense savings bond program was started yesterday by the New York Defense Savings Staff at a meeting with foreign groups at the staff's headquarters at 1270 Sixth Avenue.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- McClellan Field said tonight that a twin-motored B-18 Army bomber carrying four men was missing on a flight between here and Spokane.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Tunis Quick, 21-year-old butcher's apprentice of Montclair, N.J., on trial here for the last four days before Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan for the fatal shooting last August of 14-year-old Rosemary Abbott of North Caldwell, N.J., was found guilty of manslaughter tonight by a jury that deliberated three hours.

Mayor La Guardia was accused of violating the Hatch act through holding the dual offices of Mayor and United States Director of the Office of Civilian Defense in a letter sent yesterday to Chairman Hatton W. Sumners of the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives by the newly formed Committee for a Full-Time Mayor.

LONDON Feb. 5 -- Movements on the stock markets today were small with an easier tendency shown in most sections. Gilt-edge issues were Steady with the exception of the 3 cent war loan which eased fractionally. In the industrial list Woolworths lost is at 52 1/2s and British American Tobacco dropped 1 1/4s below the 4 mark.

During the rest of this year, the package as much as the product may provide themes for advertising campaigns as a result of the numerous packaging changes that are scheduled to get under way. A new campaign for Veteran Coffee, packed by Brewster-Gordon Company Inc., Rochester, illustrates this trend.

Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, launched a dispute with Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler yesterday after the Commission had voted unanimously to appeal a court order requiring payment of salaries to four employes of the Register's Office.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- The success of the Commandos in their daring forays into occupied France and along the coast of Norway, harassing the Nazis and blowing up harbor works, inspired the British Army to form the new Reconnaissance Corps, in which brains will be as important as brawn, it was indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- An application by Standard Oil of New Jersey for exemption from the Holding Company Act on the ground that it was "only incidentally a holding company" within the meaning of the act and is primarily engaged in other than the business of a public utility company, was denied today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Democratic National Chairman, Mr. Flynn, has proved before that he does not fear to gallop into territory which angels prefer to bypass. He demonstrated this a couple of times in the last campaign, when he set out to establish as a fact that editorial support of Mr. Willkie and unworthy incentives were synonymous.

Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera" ("Masked Ball") which had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, is a singer's opera. The libretto is ponderous, creaky and thoroughly old-hat, but the work abounds in cracking good tunes.

For a listener who missed the first part of the program the feature of the concert given by Fritz Busch and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall was the performance of Smetana's symphonic poem, "Blanik," which is the last of a series of six tone-poems which make the famous cycle called "My Country."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- "On very definite suspicions of espionage" among enemy aliens in the Mare Island Navy Yard area, Federal agents and local police raided dozens of establishments in Vallejo and near-by sections this afternoon and tonight, taking prisoners and seizing contraband cameras and radio sets.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, warned carriers and shippers today that they must use existing equipment and facilities to greater advantage.

Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder signed yesterday an order requiring the Long Island Railroad Company, the New York Central Railroad and the Staten Island Rapid Transit Company to show cause why they should not be enjoined from increasing their basic rates 10 per cent within the city limits on Tuesday.

A bronze bust by Malvina Hoffman of the late Artur Bodansky, conductor of the German wing of the Metropolitan Opera Association from 1915 until his death in November, 1939, was unveiled and dedicated late yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The bust was the gift to the Metropolitan of the Artur Bodansky Memorial Committee.
TOKYO, Feb. 5 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by Reuter) -- The Tokyo radio broadcast the following this afternoon:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Roosevelt is "gratified" by reports coming from his advisers that the huge war production program which he outlined to Congress in his annual message was becoming "a reality."
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The British, Middle East Command communique today follows:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 5 -Yale University announced tonight that, in conjunction with its Big Three rivals, Harvard and Princeton, it was modifying, for the duration of the war, the "Three Presidents Agreement" so as to make freshmen eligible for varsity competition and to permit starting football practice on any date.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Forty Japanese bombers, escorted by twenty fighter planes probably operating from an aircraft carrier, made a two-hour attack on the Surabaya naval base today, the second in three days, starting fires and causing "some material damage."

MONTREAL, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks won their second straight National League hockey game tonight when Bobby Carse came through with the payoff goal at 17:52 of the final period to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 3.

Departing tomorrow night is "Hedda Gabler," which introduced Katina Paxinou, the Greek actress, to Broadway. It will vacate the Longacre after giving twelve performances. Luther Greene staged and produced the revival, which had been translated by Mary Cass Canfield and Ethel Borden.
Boston, Mass., will be in the market today with an issue of $5,000,000 of temporary-loan notes. The obligations, dated Feb. 11, will become payable on Nov. 2.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Seventy-seven American evacuees told on their arrival from besieged Singapore today how their crowded American freighter had narrowly escaped Japanese air raiders. The evacuees estimated that about fifty United States citizens had remained in Singapore, determined to "see it through."

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $442,451,466 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on Jan. 31 was $24.70 compared with $24.46 at the end of December.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Telephone toll rates in Westchester County are based generally on the airline distance between postoffices, the New York Telephone Company said today in reply to charges of widespread "inequalities" in the Westchester rate structure.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Air forces of the United Nations, operating over wide stretches of European and Pacific waters, sank or damaged at least seventy-four Axis vessels of all types in January, it was estimated in an official summary released tonight. In the Pacific theatre, where the United Nations' strength is increasing, fifty-two Japanese vessels were sent to the bottom or hit.

The Granlyn Building Corporation has given a first mortgage of $450,000 to the Seamen's Bank for Savings on the twelve-story apartment house at 80 Cranberry and 60 Henry Streets, Brooklyn, the Lawyers Title Corporation issuing the title policy.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Red Wings twice rallied tonight to battle Toronto to a 3-to-3 overtime tie in a National Hockey League game before 8,054 spectators. The veteran Mud Bruneteau bagged two Detroit goals, one producing the deadlock with less than three minutes to play in regulation time.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -Rabbi Genzel Friedman, 41, of New York, and Bernice Weisz of Brooklyn, were charged by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today with attempting to smuggle $1,500 worth of platinum from New York to Lisbon by clipper plane.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The National War Labor Board announced today that, on its own motion, it had taken jurisdiction in the Sunday pay dispute between the General Motors Corporation and the Congress of Industrial Organization's United Automobile, Aircraft and Implement Workers and had set a hearing for Tuesday.

Employers were urged yesterday by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national director of Selective Service, to consider carefully whether their employes were vitally necessary to the war effort at home before requesting their deferment, because physical qualifications for military service must be lowered now to get as large an army as the country needs and at the same time keep war production up to the requirements of that expanded fighting force.

Quoting Admiral Luetzow, naval spokesman for the Berlin radio, the British radio said yesterday that he declared in a talk Wednesday night that "air power will never succeed in driving a navy off the seas."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate completed today legislative action on President Roosevelt's request for authorization of a $500,000,000 loan to China to bolster her internal economy and her war effort against Japan. The vote was 74 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Satisfaction with the measures taken to cope with the control of enemy aliens, especially on the Pacific Coast, was expressed in a joint statement today by Secretary Stimson and Attorney General Biddle.

Greater changes in the economic and social status of women will result from this war than did from the last World War, Fanny Hurst, the author, told 611 young women who received degrees last night at the eighty-first commencement exercises of Hunter College, held in the assembly hall at 695 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Agriculture Department disclosed tonight that eleven experts were on their way to Latin and South America to ascertain the possibility of obtaining major supplies of rubber from wild rubber trees growing there.

Cotton textile mills increased their output in 1941 by 19.3 per cent, according to figures given to the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York yesterday by W. Ray Bell, president, in his annual report. He said output reached 11,898,000,000 square yards, an increase of 2,300,000,000 square yards over the record established in 1940.

The five-story apartment house for thirty-eight families at 140 Seventy-eighth Street, North Bergen, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to Rose Shapiro. The C.B. Snyder Realty Company, the broker in the sale, reported that the rent roll of the property is $22,000 annually and the assessed valuation $80,800. The plot is 75 by 100 feet.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 5 -- The Japanese are acknowledged to have forced patrol crossings of the Salween River above fallen Moulmein. A thrust apparently aimed at Thaton, forty miles to the north, intended to cut off the British garrison at Martaban, is developing.

Collections of scrap materials for war purposes have been reduced "almost to the vanishing point" upState because of bad weather, the New York City Salvage Committee declared yesterday in urging New Yorkers to make up for the "acute" deficiency by digging up every available piece of scrap metal, rags, paper and rubber.

Traffic officials said yesterday that they felt railroad passenger capacity was still to be reached and that, for some time at least, "rationing" of travel should take care of itself. Their comment was elicited following warnings by Joseph B. Eastman, director of defense transport, that the railroads might not be able to carry all the traffic diverted to them by tire and other shortages.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Reports by 135 Class I railroads showed an aggregate estimated net income of $500,545,671 in 1941, which was more than two and onehalf times the 1940 profit of $191,050,214, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

Directors of the Electrolux Corporation voted yesterday to suspend the company's policy of paying quarterly dividends, stating that as and when conditions justified dividend action it would be considered.

War in the Pacific has cut off regular supplies of the cocoanut oil which used to come from the Philippines. It is this oil which gives to soap the heavy lathering qualities which Americans have learned to expect from their ablutions.

Reckoned merely in the cold light of efficient use of national resources, the 1941 totals for accidental deaths made public by the National Safety Council are shocking. In a year when conservation of manpower should have been our paramount consideration, enough men within the age-brackets of the Selective Service Act to supply almost two Army divisions met accidental death; enough workers were killed in on-and-off-the-job accidents to build 7,000 heavy bombers.
Trade and mill buying continued yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and active futures closed near their best levels of the session at gains of 10 to 20 points.

SPOKANE, Feb. 5 -- The Athletic Round Table's "Bundles for Congress" truck is not going to Washington. A matter of minutes before the truck was to be loaded today, Joe Albi, president, announced that the trip would not be made.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that next week he would issue a white paper outlining the nature and scope of the job that Lord Beaverbrook is taking over in the New Ministry of War Production.

John J. Murphy, vice president of Gilliam McVay, Inc., plans to reside in 201 East Thirty-fifth Street, where he has taken an apartment through his own firm, which also reports leases with Frank Schuyler in 121 Madison Avenue, James J. Cox, in 211 East Thirty-fifth Street; Gordon K. Smith, in 123 East Thirty-seventh Street, and Joseph Coutts Appelbe, in 25 West Fifty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -Previously, United States aerial action in the Southwest Pacific has been carried out by squadrons of formidable Flying Fortresses --giant bombers with a cruising range in excess of 3,000 miles. Because of their tremendous range, the Fortresses were more readily available than the pursuit ships, with their comparatively short range.

Japan's relentless raids are inflicting serious damage on Surabaya, after Singapore the biggest naval base in the South Seas. The ominous silence of Amboina portends that the next most important base is occupied. Every day since the capture of Moulmein the enemy has been crossing the Salween River and edging closer to the Burma Road.

HAVANA, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Winston Guest, the Long Island polo star and big game hunter, rushed into the Cerro Hunting Club today just in time to start the international pigeon shoot which he won from the noted trap star, Joe Hiestand of Hillsboro, Ohio.

Pettijohn as general counsel for the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America (the Hays office) was announced yesterday. It will become effective on March 5, a date which also will mark the twentieth year of Mr. Petijohn's service with the organization.

Joseph von Bradish, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, published in your issue of Feb. 3, proposed that there be established in the Federal Government a clearing house to accept suggestions and ideas to aid the war effort and other work of the government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today an increase of $134,000,000 in money in circulation in the week ended yesterday, and some officials said it might be a sign of hoarding of currency. They remarked that such an increase at this season of the year was "suspicious," but they warned against any premature conclusions.

The Womrath Book Shops and Libraries, Inc., who operate a chain of stores throughout the city, have leased 18,000 square feet of space on two floors of the building on the east side of Third Avenue between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets, purchased last year by Henry Hof.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The White House disclosed today that word of America's increasing military might was being carried directly to the people of occupied France in pamphlets dropped by British Royal Air Force planes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Senate completed action today on a long-pending bill granting annuities to civilians who were employed three years or more in the construction of the Panama Canal and to widows of such employes who lived in the Canal Zone for a year or more during the construction period.

S. Park Harman, labor supply officer of the Social Security Board and acting chairman of the Regional Labor Supply Committee, with offices at 11 West Forty-second Street, issued a statement yesterday stressing the need of skilled workers in defense industries.

Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick, County Judge George W. Martin of Brooklyn and Surrogate George A. Wingate of Brooklyn were among the officials who received pensions from the Board of Estimate yesterday on their retirements from city service.

Traders' confidence in the stock market on Wednesday proved yesterday to be fleeting, for prices reverted to irregular trends and volume decreased. Only the rails as a group managed to elude the drifting movement and they made some substantial gains.

Epigrams, "essaylets" and "capsule" dramas by American authors were asked for yesterday as part of their contribution to the nation's war program. The plea was made by Rex Stout and Clifton Fadiman, members of the Authors League War Committee, at a reception held by the Authors Guild in the Hotel Commodore.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association said yesterday publishers generally were taking steps which it was believed would justify government control of newsprint by rationing.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- A fine example of the conversion of machines and skill from civilian manufacture into war production is to be found today in the Philadelphia Ordnance District, which includes this metropolitan area, the region north to Trenton, N.J., and eastward and southward to the Atlantic.
Singapore ended its sixth day of siege yesterday as beleaguered American forces in the Philippines were concluding their second month of fighting.

It was fifty-five years ago that E. Phillips Oppenheim, then about 20, had his first book published. It was called "Expiation" and "sold enough copies to pay for itself." Since then the author has averaged about three books a year, a sustained pace that will number his forthcoming autobiography (Feb. 18, Little, Brown) his 156th book.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The possibilities of establishing a compulsory savings system for the United States later in the year are under increasing discussion in Congressional and Administration circles, where the problem of reducing consumer purchases to reinforce the war effort and check inflation is still a vital matter.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies armed forces issued this communique today:

The state of the stores is almost as unsettled as the state of the nation, according to the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, reporting on this week's retail prices. Pork prices are up, veal and lamb prices are down, while beef seems undecided.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Treasury Department wants Congress to permit the use for war purposes of small cash donations made by patriotic citizens, including two enthusiastic boys and an irate Chinese.

The earning assets of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City declined $55,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $12,137,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

BASLE, Switzerland, Feb. 5 -- A 3,000,000 Swiss franc credit for the purchase of foodstuffs in the Balkans for the starving population of Belgium has just been granted by a banking consortium here after several weeks' negotiations with a three-man Belgian commission from Brussels.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- In the mass of contradictory propaganda that floods the world in these times of war, every one is doubtful as to what to believe and what to discard. Let me therefore give you my view as to the reliability of Russian news.

Consolidated net sales of the United States Rubber Company last year rose 38 per cent to the record volume of $315,345,328, according to the fiftieth annual report issued by F.B. Davis Jr., president and chairman of the board, and made available for publication today.
DETROIT, Feb. 5 -- The United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., will ask for wage increases of $1 a day and a union shop in the coming contract negotiations with the General Motors Corporation.

The signing of contracts for the auction sale of the art collections of the late Horatio S. Rubens and of Mrs. Leonard K. Elmhirst (Mrs. Willard D. Straight, the former Miss Dorothy Payne Whitney, sister of the late Harry Payne Whitney) was announced yesterday by Frederic A. Gimbel, managing director of Gimbel Brothers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -The House Banking Committee approved today a billion-dollar program for insuring property against air raids and other enemy attacks, but balked at proposals to make part of the insurance free. The committee decided that premiums should be charged at a rate to be determined by the RFC's War Damage Corporation.

BROWNING, Mont., Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- The last hereditary chieftain of the Blackfeet Nation, 94-year-old Mountain Chief, was buried today. Blind, with only memories of his greatness in the Indian wars of the last century, he died at his home of old age.

Virtually living in hopes this Winter, the Eastern ski army is expected to give vent to its pent-up enthusiasm the next few days if the best snow conditions of the season, as reported yesterday, continue. The Hudson Highlands, including Bear Mountain Park, the Catskills, Adirondacks, Poconos, Litchfield Hills, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians all report good skiing in general, with the Berkshires reporting fair conditions.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Thomas Huggett, a steward aboard the German-captured 8,046-ton tanker San Casimiro, received the British Empire Medal tonight for his feat a year ago in surreptitiously painting a tree-foot high "SOS" deck sign, which enabled British patrols to recapture the ship.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The loss of the British submarine Triumph, which had a distinguished war record, was announced today by the Admiralty. Offsetting this bad news it was also announced that "several Italian submarines which had joined the German forces in the Atlantic battle had been sunk, including the Ferraris, the commander of which had been decorated for the fictitious sinking of three supply ships."

Edward Vito, solo harpist of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall, where he was warmly received by an audience of good size. John Wummer, flute, and Earl Wild, piano, were the assisting artists.

It isn't often that the world champion Yankees go out of their way to obtain material in the open market. The vast farm system which Ed Barrow and George Weiss have developed generally produces whatever the New Yorkers require. But yesterday came an announcement from the Yankee offices that demonstrated the shrewdness of the local organization.

Priorities have now reached the typewriter. A sizable cut is expected in the larger machines, a drastic reduction in the portable typewriters. The effect? One by one some of the oldest arts and practices of man are coming back into use under the stress of war.

Troops from the United Kingdom -- England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland -- have suffered 71.3 per cent of the total casualties of the British Commonwealth of Nations in land fighting in all parts of the world since the war began, according to an official statement cabled from London to the British Press Service here and released yesterday.

BUFFALO, Feb. 5 (2P) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation reported today a profit of $1,970,645 after taxes and contingencies for 1941, compared with $284,745 for 1940. Gross sales were $46,414,444 compared with $5,188,001. Both profits and sales were the largest in the company's history.

Tire manufacturers were pleased yesterday that the War Production Board had decided to ease tire specifications to permit the use of more reclaimed rubber but at the same time expressed concern over the possibility of a decline in scrap rubber supplies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -Testimony that radio broadcasting of news and features has not resulted in decreased reading of newspapers was given to the Federal Communications Commission today.

Southwest African Persians met the broadest demand yesterday at the sale conducted by Lampson, Fraser Huth. All of the offering of these skins was sold. The top was $12,50, unchanged. Half of the Afghanistans were sold. The high was $16.50.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Charges that the former Office of Production Management was "utterly ruthless toward little business" and that there is no sign that its successor, the War Production Board, "will take a materially different attitude," were made in a report today of the Senate's special Small Business Committee.

When Kurt Frederick Ludwig, who is accused of spying for Hitler, wrote to his 18-year-old girl associate that "competition" was very bad, and asked her to "write Marion Pon," he meant that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was making things very hot for him, and that he wanted to notify Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Gestapo, in code, the girl, Lucy Boehmler, testified yesterday in Federal court.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- British military circles talked tonight of digging in again at Tobruk, indicating the conclusion, no longer escapable, that the British offensive in Libya had failed. Once more the Axis had the initiative, and, with no indication to the contrary, Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's counter-offensive seemed destined to carry him back to the blasted escarpment of Solum, near the Libyan-Egyptian border.

In the spirit of the man who protested that the report of his death was grossly exaggerated, may I call to the attention of your readers an error with reference to the Council for Democracy in the excellent letter by Professor Ralph Barton Perry in THE TIMES of Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Nazi conquerors have despoiled Greece of her food supplies and created a famine in the little country that fought successfully against Italian invaders and gallantly against the German war machine, Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, said today.

Five candidates were being considered yesterday for the post of Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, to succeed Bishop Ernest M. Stires. A contest is expected Tuesday, when a special diocesan convention will be held in Garden City, L.I., to conduct an election.

Although factors that make for wartime inflation are at work, "physical and regulatory measures" in force now will prevent anything similar to the currency expansion of the last war, in the opinion of Montfort Jones, Professor of Finance at the University of Pittsburgh.

The hero of the torpedoed freighter San Gil, sunk somewhere off Maryland on Wednesday, was the radio operator, Robert L. Thorp. Mr. Thorp's aerial went to glory with the first explosion. Mr. Thorp rigged a jury wire and sent out a call for help. But if Mr. Thorp was the hero, Captain Walter W. Koch, in addition to not being scared, was the best-natured member of the ship's company.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- President Mikhail Kalinin told the Russian people tonight that "the hour is near when all the occupied [Soviet] republics will return to the family," and declared that Adolf Hitler's dream of conquest "now is pursuing him like a shadow" back across the snowy battlefields of Russia.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5 -- Warning that every one must prepare for a long war and have an "awful lot of patience," Lieut. Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton, who is back on leave after more than two years in command of the Canadian Army in Britain, said at a press conference today that "we are going to see a lot of fighting before it is through."
John Hay (Jock) Whitney will appear with the leading court tennis players of the country in a series of exhibition matches for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

For the last five years, Frieda Hempel, concert soprano and former member of the Metropolitan Opera Company, has left a box of meat each day for a stray dog named Brownie, who inhabits vague territory on the east side of Central Park.

G-10, the lowest quota on the priorities rating list, became A-1 on the fashion scene yesterday. In the first show of its type to be staged in the city, Gotham Silk Hosiery Company, Inc., presented at the Hotel Plaza a style show featuring fashions low in priority materials.
Yesterday's weather was voted "a miserable mess" by the weather man, no matter from what angle it was viewed.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 5 -- Except for a slight shift of British positions -- effected for strategic purposes -- little change occurred in the situation in Cyrenaica yesterday. The Germans continued to move eastward from Derna, but at a slightly slower pace, reaching positions around Tmimi, which is about forty miles southeast of Derna and about fifty-five miles west of Tobruk.

Several varieties of corsage and table flowers are available in metropolitan flower markets this week-end at reasonable prices. Daffodils, shipped from local greenhouses, are arriving in increasing numbers daily. King Alfreds and Firsts are the types in greatest abundance now.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (AP) -Four to six months ahead of schedule, two destroyers and a cruiser will be launched here and in Camden, as a Lincoln's Birthday celebration, Thursday, the Navy announced today.
Spring strolled into the millinery salon of Braagaard, Inc., 15 West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday, symbolized in the provocative hats that were presented at a fashion showing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Differences of from 119 to 282 per cent between identical bills for the supply of "mixed" gas for cooking or heating to residents of twenty-four cities were reported today by the Federal Power Commission in a study of prices charged for gas service to residential customers in all cities of 50,000 population and lover in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today litigation intended to determine whether the Federal Wage-Hour Act could be applied to newspapers.

For Currier Ives, those recorders and painters of everything American that jumped into their notice in their time, one comes to have a sort of deep affection. They were virtuous in their lives. Their fame goes marching on and earns profits that they can't collect.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- J.M. Elizalde declared today "no Filipino of any importance whatever" would serve as head of a Japanese-controlled puppet state in the islands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Department-store sales during the week ended Jan. 31 again showed a fairly large increase over the corresponding period a year ago, rising 29 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Last week an increase of 34 per cent was reported. For the four-week period, the sales were 35 per cent above the like period a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Plans have been completed for opening an Army chaplain school at Fort Benjamin Harrison, Indianapolis, in a few days.

Negotiations for a wage agreement between the Steel Workers Organizing Committee and the Bethlehem Steel Company begun on Sept. 16 broke down yesterday and steps were taken to place the case before the War Labor Board in Washington. There was no immediate threat of a strike.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 5 -- Behind their Strait of Johore moat British Imperial artillerymen today traded punches with Japanese batteries pointed at Singapore Island and, one after another, silenced an unspecified number of them.

Warners' "Wild Bill Hickok Rides," which will open at the Strand, is this morning's sole film newcomer. The cast of the Western adventure is headed by Bruce Cabot, in the title role, Constance Bennett and Warren William. Betty Brewer, Ward Bond, Howard da Sylva and Russell Simpson are featured in supporting roles.

TORONTO, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Robert Laurier, Minister of Mines in the Ontario Province Government, resigned tonight coincident with a formal repudiation of Ontario Premier Mitchell F. Hepburn by a caucus of Ontario members of the House of Commons in Ottawa.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Air Current and Cash Basis won at Hialeah Park today, each upsetting a heavily played favorite. The former carried the famous orange silks with blue sleeves of L.L. Haggin 2d, scion of James B. Haggin, while Cash Basis won for W.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Feb. 5 -Not until the last shot of the war is fired and her son, George returns from Army Air Corps service will the United States flag in front of her home at 116 Fisher Avenue be lowered again, Mrs. Lathrop W. Barnaskey, wife of a bank clerk here, said this evening in refusing to strike the colors at sunset.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Allotments of tin plate for the manufacture of tin cans have been scaled down so sharply by the War Production Board that many packers of fruits and vegetables who were sure three weeks ago of permission to pack on an unrestricted basis this season will have to curb their civilian production by 25 per cent or more, according to reports which circulated here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -Melvyn Douglas, the screen actor whose appointment in the Office of Civilian Defense drew Congressional fire, today was at work on his new job. He was appointed head of the arts council by Dean James M. Landis, OCD executive, and he reported for work on Monday.

With the necessary technique and drugs already at hand, all that is needed to eliminate venereal disease is proper community controls, a panel of expert told an audience of 250 physicians, nurses and social workers yesterday at a meeting in the Health Building, Worth and Centre Streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- It is now a fairly well established fact that the Vichy authorities in Tunis had something to do with Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's drive against the British army in Libya. Merchant ships and lorries were placed at the disposal of the German-Italian command and these were filled with various supplies, including petroleum.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Bank of England reported today an increase in note circulation of almost 4,000,000 for the week ended on Feb. 4. All other items included in the statement showed declines.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 -- The skilled toolmakers and machine repair men whose speed will determine how fast the automobile industry gets into large-scale war production promised today that they would not fail the boys fighting in the Far East.

Twenty-five of the seventy survivors of the Canadian passenger liner Lady Hawkins, which was torpedoed in American waters with the loss of 251 lives on Jan. 19, arrived in this port yesterday after a second narrow escape from enemy submarines.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Feb. 5 -Not until the last shot of the war is fired and her son, George returns from Army Air Corps service will the United States flag in front of her home at 116 Fisher Avenue be lowered again, Mrs. Lathrop W. Barnaskey, wife of a bank clerk here, said this evening in refusing to strike the colors at sunset.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Allotments of tin plate for the manufacture of tin cans have been scaled down so sharply by the War Production Board that many packers of fruits and vegetables who were sure three weeks ago of permission to pack on an unrestricted basis this season will have to curb their civilian production by 25 per cent or more, according to reports which circulated here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -Melvyn Douglas, the screen actor whose appointment in the Office of Civilian Defense drew Congressional fire, today was at work on his new job. He was appointed head of the arts council by Dean James M. Landis, OCD executive, and he reported for work on Monday.
The gain registered in bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday was smaller than in previous weeks, but the total remained well above the same week a year ago.

Wage increases totaling $3,750,000 for the year 1942 were granted to 31,000 employes of the Consolidated Edison system in a decision announced yesterday by a board of review consisting of representatives of the company and the Brotherhood of Consolidated Edison Employes, presided over by Aaron Horvitz of the United States Conciliation Service, acting as impartial chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Another twenty-four hours of a calm that is ominously suggestive of a renewed Japanese assault on General Douglas MacArthur's toughly defended positions on Bataan Peninsula in the Philippines was reported by the War Department today in its ninety-second communique of the war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Axis short-wave strategy is hammering on religion as a wedge to divide the United Nations, Archibald MacLeish declared tonight.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Two young Russian guerrillas, one a young woman, the other a boy of 17 who was hanged by the Germans, were decorated for valor today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 5 -- Dr. Luis Fernando Guachalla, Bolivian Minister to Washington, declared today that he was "absolutely convinced of the victory of the democracies under the guidance of their two great leaders, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill."

Attorney General Francis Biddle told 1,000 members and friends of the Brooklyn Bar Association last night at their annual dinner that members of the legal profession must accept and exercise the responsibility of leadership in the new World War.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Russians were reported today to be threatening many vital communication points despite the arrival of many fresh Nazi divisions on the long front. One Soviet dispatch said these reinforcements mostly were drawn from older classes.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The organization of a tough, hard-hitting Reconnaissance Corps, the newest of the British Army's task forces, was disclosed today in an official announcement that said the units had a "scale of armaments and degree of mechanization unprecedented in military history."

The Republic Steel Corporation and the National Steel Corporation, ranking third and fifth in size of American steel producers respectively, issued yesterday preliminary reports for 1941 showing substantial gains in net profits despite large increases in provisions for taxes.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 5 -The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, in a closing message of the two-day meeting of the House of Bishops here, urged expansion of the church's program among industrial workers in defense areas and in foreign fields as well as the work for the Army and Navy.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell entertained with a dinner tonight at Oceanic Cottage for Mr. and Mrs. Lewis E. Waring of New York, their house guests.

Efforts of the Coast Guard to issue identification cards to all persons whose business takes them on the city's waterfront received added impetus this week with the opening of a new registration unit in the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 5 -The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church, in a closing message of the two-day meeting of the House of Bishops here, urged expansion of the church's program among industrial workers in defense areas and in foreign fields as well as the work for the Army and Navy.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 5 -- Jimmy Angel, daredevil American flier, was forty-eight hours overdue at Ciudad Bolivar today on the return leg of a mercy errand in the wilderness to bring out the wife of Captain Felix Cardona to a maternity hospital.

A warning that increased taxes represent a serious hazard in the granting of credit was issued by Dr. Joseph J. Klein of Klein, Hinds Finke, and former president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, last night at a meeting of the New York Credit Women's Association in the Hotel Fifth Avenue.

An end to the "competition" which exists between the Boards of Education and Higher Education in the offering of graduate teacher-training courses was requested yesterday by Dr. Esek Ray Mosher, dean of the City College School of Education.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell entertained with a dinner tonight at Oceanic Cottage for Mr. and Mrs. Lewis E. Waring of New York, their house guests.

Efforts of the Coast Guard to issue identification cards to all persons whose business takes them on the city's waterfront received added impetus this week with the opening of a new registration unit in the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.

Earnings of the Johns-Manville Corporation in 1941, before income and excess profits taxes, rose to the record amount of $17,491,975 from the $9,252,071 earned in 1940, according to the annual report of Lewis H. Brown, president, mailed to stockholders last night.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 6 -- Ever-rising prices of foodstuffs are creating a problem for Italy that Premier Mussolini himself will try to settle at a meeting of the Cabinet called for tomorrow.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Japanese have strengthened their hold on Borneo's eastern coast in the drive on Java by occupying Samarinda, sixty miles north of the wrecked oil port of Balik Papan, the Netherlands Indies High Command announced today.

Conversion of civilian factories to war production, aimed at conserving scarce materials and stepping up war output, is having the incidental effect of reducing demand for certain secondary products and thus easing pressure on the scarcities of these latter products, the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association reported yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Battle of the Atlantic has taken a turn for the worse, largely because of increased sinkings off the Canadian and United States coasts, it was said here today. Sinkings in January were above the average for the last six months, although still below the figure of January, 1941.

This is in reply to "Harvard, '25," who "does not profess to quote facts." I acknowledge that Harvard is an educational institution of great merit, but Brooklyn College happens to be a fine educational institution also. As far as the relative intelligence of students is concerned, entrance requirements are quite as high as at Harvard. That is, except for the financial angle.

Time was when Wagner's music-dramas, especially the last great works, dominated the Metropolitan Opera repertory. But the absence of one singer and the war have made a difference. Thus yesterday afternoon's performance of "Siegfried," third presentation in the annual Wagner cycle, was the season's first for the music-drama, and works like "Tristan und Isolde" and "Die Meistersinger" have not been done at all, with little or no likelihood that they will see production this season.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill declared recently that the British would defend vital airfields even if they had to do it with pikes -- and now, to the amazement of some quarters, the War Office actually has issued spiked poles to Home Guard units.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, N.J., Feb. 6 -- Two girls, 11 and 8 years old, were burned to death and their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gambeis, were injured here early today in a fire that destroyed a log cabin tavern in which they lived on Riverlawn Drive.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Besieged Singapore's defenses, now as thick as those of England in proportion to area, beat off low-level Japanese air attacks today and whittled down the enemy fire power by knocking out battery after battery across the Strait of Johore.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 6 -- Parliament met yesterday to consider the war situation, and at a secret session last night on the Pacific war Prime Minister Peter Fraser reviewed the strategic situation and made a statement on New Zealand's defenses and Pacific diplomatic and inter-Dominion representation.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 6 -- A perusal of the Polish provincial press reveals that within the past weeks anti-German sabotage has increased considerably.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 -- The news available here today indicates stubborn battles between the Germans, whose defense seems to be stiffening, and the Russians, who are being counseled in the military press against over-impetuousness. The German resistance is especially stiff on the southwestern and southern fronts.
"We wanted to be on Uncle Sam's team" said Edgar White, 12 years old, "And that's why we joined the Boy Scouts," echoed his twin brother, Sumner.

Mountain Chief, last hereditary head of the Blackfeet, blind and 94, is dead in his capital at Browning, Mont. Many tourists go there, so the Grand Old Man of the Blackfeet must be known by sight to not a few Americans. They might learn dignity from their Indian brethren.

The resources of the American Red Cross and the civilian Conservation Corps will be pooled to provide relief and care for evacuees if enemy air attacks make civilian evacuations necessary, according to announcement yesterday by Stuart M. Crocker, executive director of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, who had been apprised of the plan earlier in the day by Norman H. Davis, national chairman of the Red Cross.

William L. Batt, director of materials for the War Production Board, warned in an address here last night that the American people were not sufficiently awake to the danger that we can lose the war, and Said that we could not get the full industrial production we need to win until we understand fully "the dark side of the picture" and go all-out as the British did after Dunkerque.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Avery Brundage, president of the United States of America Sports Federation, announced today that the United States would participate in the Pan-American games at Buenos Aires in November if the State Department gave its sanction.

TOKYO, Feb. 6 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Two Netherland cruisers were sunk and a third Netherland cruiser and a United States cruiser of the Marblehead class were heavily damaged by Japanese naval planes in the Java Sea, Japanese Imperial Headquarters claimed today.

Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Bassler gave a dinner yesterday at their home, 121 East Seventy-first Street, later taking their guests to the supper dance at the Plaza given by the Canadian Women's Club of New York for the benefit of the Canadian Red Cross.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- John Van Kuren Newkirk, identified in Rangoon dispatches as "Scarsdale Jack," ace of the American fliers defending the Burma Road, has been a good marksman since he was 5 years old and at the age of 10 demonstrated his aim by shooting a sheriff with a bow and arrow, his family said today.

Changes of sentiment ascribable to the war were reflected last month in figures of the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange. The total rose from 349,154 shares at the end of December, the lowest level since the figures were first compiled, to 460,577 shares, not counting short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.
BERLIN, Feb. 6 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said:
That stanch old friend, the familiar and lowly potato, comes into its own with the publication of a free booklet entirely devoted to singing its praises.

THERE will be a fellow at the Millrose Meet at Madison Square Garden tonight who can pole vault 15 feet. He did it a dozen times. Not in New York City. No, sir, never in that dust-burdened, germ-laden atmosphere, but often in his native California, where the atmosphere is pure, the skies are pellucid, the scenery is, etc., etc. (see advertisements).

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 6 -- A controversy within the air raid warden service here resulted today in the announcement by First Selectman Wilbur M. Peck that the warden credentials of the Rev. Lockett Ford Ballard had been demanded and obtained from the curate of fashionable Christ Episcopal Church by a committee of wardens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Washington will be the military staff headquarters for the United Nations, especially the Pacific War Councils dealing with the Southwestern Pacific area, according to announcements made today by President Roosevelt and the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Ten civilian employes of the Supply Department at the Pearl Harbor Navy Yard were cited for bravery' during the Japanese attack by Rear Admiral C.C. Bloch, commandant of the Fourteenth Naval District, the Navy Department revealed today.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Lloyd's, the British underwriters, published figures today indicating that Germany is obtaining large quantities of foodstuffs and other products through French Mediterranean ports in spite of the British blockade.

The Citizens Union, in opposing the proposed increase in subway fare, points out that the fact that "other cities charge higher fares has little meaning because of the fact that in most of those cities the higher fares have failed to keep operating companies out of receivership."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Jan. 31 were 250,740,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented an increase of 2,576,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 2,661,000 barrels in domestic stocks, but a decline of 85,000 in foreign stocks.

Our failure to make the utmost use of refugee physicians stands in marked contrast to Great Britain's policy. According to the London correspondent of The Journal of the American Medical Association, a Polish faculty of medicine has been established in the University of Edinburgh, some Polish medical officers have been trained in hospitals and others have been spread among various clinics.
Richard Dickson of the Bayside Tennis Club outlasted John P. Leo Jr. in the final of the Monte Sterling squash tennis tournament at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.
ROME, Feb. 6 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- In my previous article I have dealt with the material side of the Russian war effort, and I now come to deal with the political aspect of our association with the Soviet Union in the common struggle.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 6 -- The "accelerated" physical education course instituted at Rutgers University on Jan. 19 to harden the physiques of its 1,700 students for eventual military service has resulted in painful shoulder injuries to eight students, minor bruises and contusions to a number of others and a rising chorus of discontent among the still healthy members of the student body, it was disclosed today.

Failure of the railway shares to maintain their recent upward movement was the signal yesterday for a steady whittling of values in other sections of the stock market and losses were the largest in about two weeks. Declines generally ran from fractions to a point, although the chemical group was under special pressure, and only fleeting support appeared at scattered moments in the session.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- Major General Irving J. Phillipson, commanding the Second Corps Area, with headquarters at Governors Island, New York, advised Governor Charles Edison today that Federal troops cannot be detailed to guard bridges and other State-owned property in New Jersey.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 -- Germany's strategic position as the third Spring of the war draws near bears many striking resemblances to her situation last year. The success or failure of Adolf Hitler's program for the year again depends on a complex series of factors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- C.S. Stamps, a Kansas City Negro, filed a complaint with the Interstate Commerce Commission today against the trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company and against the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company, the Burlington Quincy Railroad Company and the Gulf, Colorado Santa Fe Railway Company, charging discrimination in train accommodations.

"Nine Bachelors," the French film written and directed by Sacha Guitry, will have its local premiere this morning at the World Theatre. The cast of the comedy, which is headed by Guitry, includes also Elvire Popesco, Genevieve Guitry, Max Dearly, Betty Stockfield and Marguerite Moreno.

Bad weather restricted sales gains here this week.
