Volume of leading department stores was estimated as ranging around 10 to 15 per cent over a year ago; against an average rise of 20 per cent in the preceding week. White merchants are on the alert for a decline in the "scare buying" which featured recent weeks, most of them were inclined to trace the smaller gains this week almost entirely to weather conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Roosevelt met today for the first time with a joint American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations committee which he created to make labor's contribution to the war effort "most effective."

The castle of Balmacaan in the highlands of Scotland will soon feel the light tread of children's feet, Mrs. Macneil of Barra, chairman of the Scottish Clans Evacuation Plans, announced yesterday in Washington, D.C. She said that 100 additional children from the bombed cities and towns of England would be sent to Scottish havens in the next few weeks.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- As Britons debated today the pros and cons of the usefulness of the pike, it was found that many Home Guardsmen supported its adoption. It is possible that even the crossbow and catapult might prove useful, some of them maintained, pointing out that all belligerents in World War I reverted to the headpiece of ancient knights and adopted steel helmets.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 6 -- It was said in informed circles tonight that contracts would soon be let here to United States construction companies for a vast railway and road-building project in Mexico to be financed by additional United States loans.
As Russians and Germans, locked in icy struggle, contest the dominion of Europe, the Winter campaign in retrospect more and more clearly shows the influence of weather upon war.

Bernard Wankel Jr., who has conducted a general hardware business at 1573 Third Avenue for a number of years, plans to expand and has purchased for additional quarters the two-story and four-story buildings at 202 and 204 East Eighty-eighth Street from the W.S.P. Shields estate.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Today's communique reported that for the first day in some time there were no new military operations in the Australian area during the past twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The present session of Congress, to fight this country's foes, has shoveled out appropriations or contract authorizations at the rate of $14,566 every second since it convened a month ago.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by twenty municipalities aggregates $14,201,960, compared with $20,542,447 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year now stands at $34,776,830.

Annual "Scout Sunday" will be observed tomorrow throughout the city in Protestant and Catholic churches to mark the thirty-second anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts of America. In more than one hundred synagogues Scouts either attended services last night or will attend them this morning.

ROME, Feb. 6 From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Axis troops pushing the British backward toward Egypt in Libya have occupied the town of Thimi, on the Mediterranean coast 140 miles from the Libyan-Egyptian border and only sixty miles west of Tobruk.

The three-story industrial building on a plot 52 by 167 feet at 96-98 Forest Street, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by H. Rivington Pyne, executor of Percy R. Pyne, to Albert B. Green. The parcel is assessed for $49,500 and brought a stated consideration of $10,000.

The annual "Fireside Sportsmen's Shove" of the Jones Beach Surf Fishing Club is one event the Long Island sportsman cannot afford to miss, for he is sure to find both entertainment and instruction in matters pertaining to hunting and fishing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Jan. 24 was 2,789,170 shares, compared with 3,152,210 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

For thirty-five years the International Rubber Company has been extracting rubber from the guayule shrub, which it has been growing in Arizona, Texas and the Salinas Valley of California. Impressed by this long record, the House has passed a bill which authorizes the purchase of the company's processing plant, nurseries and 23,000 pounds of selected seed.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Retirements from member firms of the New York Stock Exchange include Alden C. Towne from Elmer H. Bright Co., Saunders Hobson from Davenport Co., W. David Owen from Hornblower Weeks, Peter McDonnell from McDonnell Co., Glenn C. Munn, Francis W. Wheeler and the late William S. Markle from Paine, Webber Co.
John Kieran's suggestion that Frank Frisch be considered as a future member of Baseball's Hall of Fame must have been approved by your readers.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 -- Reports of several organizations formed to send relief to Greece indicate the food situation in Athens and other larger cities is desperate.

The Selective Service Board announced yesterday that volunteers are needed to help in the draft registration Feb. 15 and 16. The announcement was made through the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer office and said both men and women are needed, and that the men need not be more than 44 years old, as announced previously.

RANGOON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- When Japanese planes swarmed over the big Rangoon airdrome during three alarm periods before dawn today, lack of night-flying equipment kept the Americans grounded, but an R.A.F. Hurricane night fighter tore into their formations.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will divest itself of its stock ownership in its natural gas utility companies as a result of the decision handed down on Thursday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to a statement made yesterday by W.S. Farish, president of the parent concern.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company, Inc., for 1941, made public yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $4,692,859, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after requirements on the preferred dividends, to $1.27 each on 1,909.968 common shares, and compared with $5,354,159, or $1.61 a common share, in 1940.

Commemorating the birthday anniversary next Thursday of Abraham Lincoln, Christian clergymen will preach sermons of tribute tomorrow and rabbis will preach sermons today. Tomorrow being annual Boy Scout Sunday and today annual Boy Scout Sabbath, troops of Scouts in uniform will attend services and hear sermons on scouting.

With Johnny Carroll enjoying a sharp shooter's holiday by registering twenty-five points, the Fordham basketball team turned back a stubborn Holy Cross quintet in the Rams' gym last night, 54 to 49. Although the home athletes held the lead from the start, the game held sufficient interest for the 1,000 spectators down to the end.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Mi Estrellita was the setting for a buffet dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Philip Kauffmann tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Still another step in the direction of making civil defense a national service, with whole-time workers enrolled by compulsion if necessary and assigned to areas where they are most needed, was proposed by Herbert Morrison, Minister of Home Security, in a memorandum made public today.

Three detectives and a patrolman yesterday chased a suspected hold-up man over the roofs of two Bronx tenements and finally captured him hidden under bed coverings after he had frightened a tenant in one of the houses into concealing him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- President Roosevelt vetoed today a special bill to raise from $30 to $100 the monthly pension given the widow of Major Gen. Charles T. Menoher, who commanded the Rainbow Division in the First World War.

Mayor La Guardia laid the groundwork yesterday for the speedy removal of Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, and Wallace S. Sayre and Ferdinand Q. Morton, its other members, when he suspended the entire commission and ordered the three officials to show cause at 11 o'clock Monday morning why they should not be removed from office.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The stock markets generally were firm today, one of the features being a renewed demand for several foreign railway stocks. Little movement was seen in the home rails and there were few changes in the gilt-edge issues. In foreign bonds Brazilians improved.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Heading a crew of twenty-two par busters, Lanky Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago set a spectacular pace through the first round of the $5,000 Western open today with a six-under-par 65.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 6 -- The government called today for the cooperation of the nation in a counter-espionage campaign, following the revelation yesterday of the leakage of secrets of military significance to Japan.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -- Landslides and floods, the aftermath of two weeks of steady rain, killed at least four persons in Northern California today and caused property damage which is expected to mount into millions of dollars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Charges that the Farm Security Administration was engaged in "insidious and indefensible" practices and was paying poll taxes of Alabama clients, in violation of the State Constitution and Federal statutes, were made today to the joint Congressional Economy Committee by two witnesses, who urged that the committee undertake its own investigation.

BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Varying degrees of their old-time skill and terrific speed were demonstrated by sixteen of the greatest players of the National Hockey League's modern era tonight as they waged a 4-4 tie with the world champion Boston Bruins in a thirty-minute exhibition charity game before an overflow crowd of 14,622 at the Boston Garden.

On a recent morning I hiked for three miles on the Doodletown Ski Trail from my cabin on the Doodletown Road to the underpass near the tennis courts at the Bear Mountain playground, where the ski trail as such starts. I have been wondering for six weeks why hundreds of skiers have been asking me where the trail is, even when they were on it.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- A majority of labor union members polled throughout the country by the American Institute of Public Opinion are opposed to one of organized labor's long entrenched and most widely discussed practices -- the check-off.
SINGAPORE, Feb. 5 (delayed) (Australian Associated Press) -- We are rapidly becoming accustomed to the sound of shellfire, which has increased in intensity during the past twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Formal War Department approval of the proposed $25,000,000 International Alaska Highway was given to the House Roads Committee today through Colonel James K. Tully of the General Staff.

Without fanfare, in a manner characteristic of his own disposition, Mel Ott, new manager of the Giants, has signed and delivered to President Horace Stoneham his contract as player-manager for the campaigns of 1942-43. It has been estimated Ott's contract calls for a salary of $825,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Following the debate in the House over appointments to the Office of Civilian Defense, James M. Landis, executive of the OCD, issued a statement this evening saying that in "building civilian defense against enemy attack" it would not be "deflected by petty criticism or personal attack."

DETROIT, Feb. 6 -- With thousands of workers in Michigan arms plants living in "shack towns" and trailer camps, Detroit officials are frankly worried about the housing problem which they will have to face when all automobile factories have been tooled up for war production and 250,000 more workers have jobs in the Detroit area than ever before.

The discovery of Vitamin B1 as the dietary cure for beri beri, the disease that long was a curse to the Japanese, has been one of the most important factors in furthering that nation's imperialistic ambitions, Victor Lindlahr, nutritionist, declared yesterday in an address at the convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.
Advertising and mail order houses figured prominently in the business leasing yesterday, when a number of full-floor units were taken.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Irish Minister, Robert Brennan, after a twenty-minute conversation today with Sumner Welles, Under Secretary of State, said that he thought the talk would result in a better understanding in Dublin regarding the presence of American troops in Northern Ireland.

We all have to be grateful to Count Sforza for having outlined his aims on some post-war problems in a recent letter to THE TIMES. Every man -- Italian or not -- who seeks fascism's overthrow was anxious to know the stand of one of the leading men deserving to play a prominent role in post-war free Italy.

The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company reported yesterday in its annual statement for 1941 that its assets totaling $48,024,000 and net premium income of $21,606,000 were the highest on record. The gain in income of $3,565,000 over the previous year was made principally by a gain of $1,993,000 in marine business and $1,226,000 in fire premiums, the report explains.
Several persons prominent in professional circles were among those listed in the apartment rentals yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- In an upsurge of revolt against the appointment of Melvyn Douglas, screen actor, and Mayris Chaney, Mrs. Roosevelt's dancer-protege to high civilian defense posts, the House voted, 88 to 80, today to forbid use of civilian defense funds for "instructions in physical fitness by dancers, fan dancing, street shows, theatrical performances or other public entertainment."

College sophomores, juniors and seniors 18 to 24 years may enlist in the Marine Corps Reserve as privates first class until they complete their training and get a degree, at which time they will be enrolled in a special three-month course leading to commissions as second lieutenants, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Victor I. Morrison, in charge of the district recruiting office at 90 Church Street.

VICHY, France, Feb. 6 -- The reconstruction of railways, communication lines and waterways in France is nearing completion, while small progress has yet been made in the reconstruction of towns and homes destroyed in the war, it was said today in a report to the press by Jean Berthelot, State Secretary of Communications.

The entire cadet corps of the Knickerbocker Greys, comprising 200 boys from 8 to 14 years old, staged a full-dress review for their fathers yesterday afternoon at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
A dispatch from Ilya Ehrenburg, Soviet war correspondent, reporting that the German losses had been "exceedingly heavy," gave as examples of the enemy casualties the following:

The market for government bonds took "in stride" yesterday the Treasury's announcement that a new issue of $1,500,000,000 of securities will be offered for cash subscription on next Friday, Feb. 13. Even the superstitious were unable to disturb the quiet tenor of the market, which did little more than "mark time" during the day.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. A.E. Percival, commander of the British Imperial land forces in Singapore, disclosed tonight that some stores, personnel and equipment have been moved from the Singapore naval base and several air fields on the island because the base and fields cannot operate under the present conditions of siege.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 6 -- With considerable help from a freshman, making his first appearance in major ski competition, New Hampshire was away today to a comfortable lead in defense of its laurels in the Dartmouth Winter carnival ski meet.

Representatives of eight nations attending a meeting of the foreign division of the national board of the Young Women's Christian Association were told last night that in the present world conflict the Axle is waging "a war against the international idea, against the Christian idea and against the human idea."

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 6 -- Major Vidkun Quisling, recently appointed Premier of Norway by Germany, wanted to be Foreign Minister also, says a dispatch from Stockholm, but Berlin refused. Germany took the stand that the foreign policy of Norway, as an occupied country, must be directed from Berlin.

The new War Time, as against the old Daylight Saving Time, will be gladly hailed by men and women with a poor head for mathematics; and especially by commuters. There is no more Standard Time for the railroads to observe religiously in their time-tables and for the passenger to add one hour to, like something in a casserole recipe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor was cited to the Supreme Court today as proof that government agents should be permitted to intercept communications of "enemies of the nation."

Four longshoremen loading sheet tin and pig iron in a box car on a float at the north end of the pier at Leroy Street were missing last night after the car came loose from its trucks and fell into forty feet of water in the Hudson River.

BERNIE, Switzerland, Feb. 6 -- The problem of the German national community's faith in its own force gravely preoccupied Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Reich Propaganda Minister, who editorialized on the subject in this week's Reich.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said today that Germany faced a possible rationing of potatoes for the first time since the war started.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Feb. 6 -- Believing that the United States will have to provide much of the world leadership at the end of the war, Taft School inaugurated tonight, by presenting Dr. Ernest Hopkins, president of Dartmouth College, a series of open forums as a first step in a long-range program designed to make its students internationally-minded.
ROSLYN, L.I., Feb. 6 -- Charles D. Plumb of the Meadow Brook Hunt was breaking some of his trotters to two-wheeled jog carts this afternoon on the Plumb Estate at East Norwich.

Rummaging around for new plays for Catholic theatres, the Blackfriars' Guild has come up with "The Years Between," which Father Carey's chickens acted in their Fifty-seventh Street theatre last evening. It is the work of one Edward Burbage, who doubtless uses another name in good society.

Labor in Twentieth Century America is the general title given to a series of books that Farrar Rinehart will start on its way a week from Monday with the publication of "The Needle Trades," by Joel Seidman. Books on lumbering, agriculture, cotton textiles, the building trades, maritime labor, printing and the railroads are among the studies already contracted for.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- With crude oil one of the vital necessities for winning the war, the Petroleum Industry War Council today urged measures for increasing the supply. Noting that additions to the national oil reserves had been dropping for three or four years, the council submitted a program to Harold L. Ickes petroleum coordinator.

"The Flowers of Virtue," which returned Marc Connelly to the Broadway scene after an absenceof four years as author and director, ends its run tonight at the Royale Theatre, where it opened on Thursday, it was announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 -- Pat O'Brien's contract with Twentieth Century-Fox has been amicably terminated, and the actor will go to Universal to co-star with George Raft in the latter studio's remake of "Broadway," it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- "I came to make plans for the economic mobilization of our resources for a victory that is now our victory as well as that of the United States," said Dr. Arthur de Souza Costa, Finance Minister of Brazil, on his arrival here today for two weeks of conferences with the United States Government.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 6 -- In a swift and effective shift from offense to defense fighter pilots of the American Volunteer Group and the Royal Air Force broke up a chain of vicious Japanese raids on the Burma Road port today by destroying at least ten and probably twenty raiders, up to two-thirds of the attacking force.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The Egyptian Parliament is to be dissolved to make way for a general election, Premier-Designate Mustafa Nahas Pasha confirmed today.

Organization of a free, "on-the-spot" metallurgical advisory service for North Jersey plants manufacturing war products was announced yesterday by John F. Wyzalek, chairman of the committee in charge and chief metallurgist for Hyatt Bearings Division at Harrison.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 -- Led by Alsab, who will be making his seasonal debut, fourteen thoroughbreds have been named for the $5,000 added Bahamas Handicap, speed test for 3-year-olds which will be the feature at Hialeah Park tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The market value of total sales on registered securities exchanges during 1941 was $7,603,044,033, 21.8 per cent less than in 1940, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- Miss Mayris Chaney said tonight that she had been on the job for two months without receiving any salary.
An increase of $2,211,522 was requested yesterday by the Department of Education in a total budget request of $148,465,087 submitted to Budget Director Kenneth Dayton.

After showing strength in the early trading yesterday, the cotton market turned easier and declined 10 to 15 points. Buying by spot houses near the close brought about a recovery, however, and the finish of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was 5 points higher to 3 points lower on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Army freight transport Cynthia Olson, with thirty-five persons aboard, was given up as lost by the War Department tonight as a result of enemy action in the Pacific.

Good news reached the local ski fraternity with the announcement yesterday from the New Haven and New York Central railroad officials that popular one-day snow trains, the first of the season, are scheduled to depart tomorrow morning for the Berkshires and Catskills.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The German Embassy has been closed since Brazil broke relation's with Germany, Italy and Japan, and it said that the transmitter seized today had not been in operation since then.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Hurley Machine Division of Electric Household Utilities Corporation, Chicago, today was ordered to suspend production and sale of electric washing and ironing machines until Aug. 1. The company is charged with producing over 32,000 more washing machines than the 44,376 it was permitted to produce in its Fall quota.

The record-breakers will be out in force at Madison Square Garden tonight when the new track season presents its first major meet, the thirty-fifth annual Millrose Games. This should be as glittering a show as in the past, and a near capacity crowd is expected.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 6 -- A Federal grand jury here returned an indictment today charging the National Wholesale Druggists Association, twenty-three of its member companies and twenty-nine of their officers and agents with conspiring to violate the Sherman act by fixing wholesaler profit margins on drug products.

A few weeks ago, when Washington's basketball team came here and rocked N.Y.U. with its drive and stamina, the floodgates were opened again. Most of the critics accepted the rout as a token that out-of-town court teams were infinitely superior to our local squads.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- General Douglas MacArthur again upset plans of the Japanese in the Philippines when his artillery destroyed enemy gun emplacements on the southeastern shore of Manila Bay, which apparently had been designed for an attack on the island fortress of Corregidor, the War Department announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- Newbold Morris, president of the City Council of New York, told the Committee of Seventy, a reform organization, today to be on the alert for unprincipled politicians who might try to steal the government while patriotic citizens were busy with the war efforts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Scattered liquidation developed in the grain and soy bean markets today and disclosed a lack of aggressive demand. A bearish construction was placed by traders on a statement made late yesterday by J.B. Hutson, president of the Commodity Credit Corporation, indicating that the government would continue to sell cash wheat and corn below parity prices.

Garden City won three matches in Metropolitan Badminton Association men's Class A competition during the week, defeating Great Neck and Jamaica, each by 5 -- 0, and Gramatan Hills, 3 -- 2. Montclair blanked Old Sixty-ninth, 5 -- 0 in another match in this division.

A big Norwegian whaler, unarmed and steaming in ballast off the American coast on the morning of Jan. 19, chased an enemy submarine seaward for forty-five minutes in a game of "bluff" which succeeded until the superior speed of the undersea craft enabled her to get away.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Democratic leaders would not speak for quotation today about President Roosevelt's comment on Congressmen, but one House leader said the reference to those "who have a record" in backing up the government included important votes on measures passed before Pearl Harbor.

The regrettable action of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, taken on the recommendation of Mrs. Hartley Dodge, in canceling its show is a shock to thousands of dog lovers and additional thousands of dog exhibitors.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Brit ish headquarters issued this communique today:

The annual report of the P. Lorillard Company, tobacco manufacturer, and its subsidiaries announced yesterday for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1941, disclosed a net income of $3,383,168 after Federal and State income taxes and excess profits taxes applicable to subsidiary earnings, minority interest and other charges.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 6 -- Yale officials, members of the faculty and representatives of undergraduate bodies are working on a program of compulsory athletics to "toughen" the students, but the form of the training has not yet been determined.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- In a survey of the automobile driving practices of school children here a committee of school officials said today that 28 per cent of the high school juniors and seniors who drive have neither learners' permits nor drivers' licenses.

Carl Richard Bruno Braun, a native of Germany who was a metal worker and lived alone in a rooming house for years, died leaving an estate that included more than $5,000 in cash, stock in nationally known corporations and a collection of coins some of which are believed to be rare, it was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- The Universities of Georgia and Iowa have been selected by the Navy as the Southern and Midwestern centers for its expanded pilot training program, it was announced tonight by Representative Vinson, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee.

The 102d annual Emerald Ball was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the patronage of Governor and Mrs. Lehman and other State and city officials. There was an unusually long list of patrons this year and all the boxes were taken.

OTTAWA, Feb. 6 (Canadian, Press) -- Note circulation in Canada declined to $73,205,000 at Dec. 31 from $79,201,000 Nov. 30 and $83,789,000 Dec. 31, 1940, the Finance Department reported today in its monthly charted bank statement.

"SOMETHING WENT WRONG"* is Lewis Browne's title for his "summation of modern history." The "something," one gathers, is man's use of the machine. The little contraption of James Watt's that "ate fire, belched smoke, and pumped like hell" on a certain day in March, 1776, promised man an economy of plenty on a unified planet.

Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila" received its second performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with Kerstin Thorborg assuming the role of the woman of Sorek for the first time here. Miss Thorborg's conception of the part, if not entirely convincing, had sweep and fire.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- The American Management Association personnel conference was told at its final sessions here today that the employment of women in war industries had been a success in England and that the United States should prepare now to take a similar step as the war developed.

If Joe Cook's physicians advise him to retire from show business because of poor health the public will have to accept their verdict in the absence of proof to the contrary. But Joe's medicine men must realize fully the responsibility they are assuming. For Joe is not the sort of comedian who can be spared for trivial reasons.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The W.H. Davey Steel Company has informed its stockholders that war conditions have made it necessary to liquidate the company, but Harry L. Berno, president, disclosed that Detroit interests might buy the plant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Roosevelt declared today that the United States at war needed Congressmen regardless of party who will back up their government and who had a record of backing up the country in an emergency regardless of party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- George Hill, second secretary to Representative Hamilton Fish, was sentenced today to serve from two to six years in prison for perjuring himself before a Federal grand jury which has been investigating Nazi propaganda in the United States.

ALRANY, Feb. 6 -- New stock incorporations registered here in January numbered 1,035, compared to 1,630 the year before, Secretary of State Walsh announced today. Of the month's formations 436 had a capitalization of $8,961,300, falling below the total of $16,581,587 a year ago by $7,620,188.

Your accounts of the annual meeting of the Birth Control Federation of America were legitimate news stories; but since the views which were there given expression are contrary to the teaching of the Catholic Church, it is hoped that you will entertain a statement of the Catholic view.
BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 6 (AP) -- A new Panama Canal safeguard has been established in a forty-eight-mile trans-isthmian highway, over which Army machines can travel ocean-to-ocean in two hours.
News of the formation of a Women's Voluntary Services unit in Nicaragua, patterned after the American Women's Voluntary Services, has been received at A.W.V.S. headquarters here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Legislation to create the long-projected Women's Army Auxiliary Corps today received the unanimous approval of the Senate Committee on Military Affairs and moved toward early floor consideration, possibly early next week, by the House.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The War Department communique based on reports up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today to the Polk-Peterson Corporation of Des Moines, Iowa, the right to withdraw its broker-dealer registration and instead revoked its registration and expelled the corporation from membership in the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The text of the War Department statement announcing the establishment of a combined chief of staff group read:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Two hundred of the 800 Civilian Conservation Corps camps will be closed by early March in order to eliminate all work not connected with the national defense program, Paul V. McNutt, the Federal Security Administrator, said today. Thus the enrollment will be cut 25 per cent, down to 120,000.

Bernie Mayer, now a freshman at New York University, made his final effort as an interscholastic competitor a successful one yesterday when he retained his city P.S.A.L. senior high school indoor 12-pound shot-put crown in the Textile High gymnasium.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 6 -- The German military offensive in Russia is promised for the Spring, but there are many signs that the industrial offensive is considered even more important and that it is under way already and that it is aimed at counterbalancing American production.

In a grim continuation of the warfare that already has claimed thirteen announced victims in United States waters, another American tanker has been picked off by an enemy U-boat operating off the New Jersey coast. Twenty-six of her crew of thirty-eight are missing, the Navy Department disclosed yesterday.

The Federal Government's projected power line to carry surplus electricity from New York City to Massena, N.Y., for the manufacture of aluminum was denounced by Park Commissioner Moses as "destructive, uneconomical and unnecessary" in a letter to State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Westchester County made public yesterday by Mr. Williamson.
LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Cautious confirmation was given here today to reports that war material was now moving from Vichy France to reinforce the Axis troops under Marshal Erwin Rommel in Libya.

"Vested interests" in this country are, in spite of the national crisis, diligently working to prevent the increased importation of Peruvian sugar into this country, it was said yesterday by Monroe Douglas Robinson.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -- Demands for the removal of Japanese from the Pacific Coastal area grew in volume today as Governor Olson had a "heart to heart" talk with Japanese-American leaders at Sacramento and officials of the petroleum industry charged the existance of a sabotage plot that awaits only the "zero hour" before being put into effect in the rich Southern California oil fields.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The United States Census of 1940, which delved so deeply into personal conditions and affairs within American homes as to provoke Congressional charges of "prying for political purposes," has taken on a new, wartime value as an aid in the protection of the country against espionage and sabotage.
HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- Obligatory planting of rice, corn, beans, peanuts and other food products was decreed by President Fulgencio Batista and the Cabinet yesterday.

Twenty-one of the twenty-six mutual savings banks in Manhattan and the Bronx have organized payroll-deduction plans for employes for the purchase of defense savings bonds, it was announced yesterday by George L. Harrison, president of the New York Life Insurance Company, who is chairman of the financial division of the New York Defense Savings Staff.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Moves to repeal recent legislation providing optional pensions to Senators and Representatives gained strength today in the light of an official statement that at least one member of Congress could receive about $350 a month for the rest of his life if he were to pay $1.39 into the pension fund.

Two months ago today Japan struck at Pearl Harbor. That first blow was the opening move in a campaign that has been carried forward with great daring and uninterrupted success over the longest front in the history of modern warfare.

Average weekly work hours in war industries have increased sharply since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and this increase highlights the December wage and hour statistics released yesterday by the division of industrial economics of The Conference Board (National Industrial Conference Board, Inc.).

An Astoria housewife was arrested early today as the young woman who has stolen jewelry, furs and other valuables from fashionably furnished apartments on the East Side during the last two years after gaining admission by posing as a prospective sublessee.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 6 (AP) -- British Army Headquarters issued this communique today:

A new plan under which members and member firms may offer through the facilities of the New York Stock Exchange large blocks of securities that could not be absorbed on the floor within a reasonable time without severely depressing prices will be put into effect by the Stock Exchange on Feb. 16.

Four new types of alloy steels that will require less virgin chromium and nickel and thus make the nation's limited reserves of these metals go farther without impairing production of guns, tanks, warships and aircraft were announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

For reasons of conservation, samples, combination offers and premiums may soon have to be eliminated for the duration of the war, according to the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association. In a bulletin to the trade it was pointed out that, while no official order has been issued on the subject, such decrees loom large in the thinking of key government officials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Charges made by the Senate Committee on Small Business that the Treasury was neglecting small business brought from Secretary Morgenthau a statement today that almost half the contracts awarded by the Treasury Procurement Division under the lease-lend program had been for amounts less than $25,000.

Edward F. McCormack, broker, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday asking the court to declare void his expulsion as a member of the New York Curb Exchange and to restrain the Exchange from transferring or selling his membership.

The Tammany executive committee last evening ousted Christopher D. Sullivan as leader by a vote of 145 to 136 and named Charles H. Hussey, chairman of the executive committee, to act as temporary leader until Feb. 27, when another meeting of the committee will be held to elect a permanent leader.

VICHY, France, Feb. 6 -- Speaking of the Paris police as a military corps carrying on a battle against the forces of disorder, Rear Admiral Rene Bard, the Prefect of Police there, said in an interview published in the Gringoire yesterday that its task was to fight against agitators and the authors of aggression against the occupying troops.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Prices of hogs experienced today their worst break since the United States entered the war, dropping 15 to 50 cents a hundredweight, on rumors that the government might place a ceiling on wholesale pork quotations. The top price declined to $12.70 from $12.85 yesterday, but most losses were larger.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The primary importance of housing not only as a war necessity but as a major factor in post-war reconstruction was urged today by President Roosevelt as the National Public Housing Conference held its eleventh annual meeting here.

The War Labor Board has taken jurisdiction in the dispute between the General Motors Corporation and the union in its plants over the question whether double-time shall be paid for Sunday work. The demands of the United Automobile Workers in the General Motors Corporation for wage increases of $1 a day and the closed shop will also presumably soon come before the board.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- The Soviet High Command said tonight that the German Army in Russia suffered "enormous losses in equipment and manpower" as the Red Army continued its relentless offensive in several sectors of the wintry front.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 6 -- Coming from behind in the last event of the meet, the 400-yard relay, Dartmouth's swimming team defeated the Harvard mermen today, 39 -- 36, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet. The result put the Indians in a tie for first place with Yale.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The arbitrary preventing of newspapers from owning radio broadcasting stations would be a step toward "subjecting free speech to governmental regulation," Roscoe Pound, dean emeritus of the Harvard Law School, informed the Federal Communications Commission today just before its inquiry into the subject was recessed indefinitely.

New bond financing this week, while more than double that of the preceding period, nevertheless held to the modest volume of $14,217,000. This total compared wih $6,150,000 in new bonds placed on the market last week and with $62,138,000 in this week last year.

The principle of the kaleidoscope, traditional children's toy, is being utilized by American chemists to speed up production of essential war materials, it was reported last night at a meeting of the New York section of the American Chemical Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Dr. Thomas R.P. Gibb Jr. of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 6 -- Flakes of paint and plaster are falling from the ceiling and the window frames, from which the glass has been removed, are rattling in this house on a hilltop that provides a grandstand view of Singapore Island on the seventh day of the siege.

PANAMA, Feb. 6 -- President Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia, in his first press conference since Dec. 7, said today that all of Panama should be made part of the Canal Zone defense area and exempt from restrictions on exports from the United States.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 -- A system of compulsory athletics for all students, The Harvard Crimson said today, is being considered by the presidents of Harvard, Princeton and Yale.

First Grade Detective John J. Duane, attached to the Bomb Squad, shot and killed himself about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in a washroom on the eighth floor of the Police Headquarters Annex, 400 Broome Street, according to a police report.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 6 -- For the first time since the last war, the Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard has decided to cancel its annual production because of the national emergency and the pressure of new demands upon students, Publicity Manager Holbrook R. Davis, '43, announced tonight.

"Spirituals of a Nation," a program of characteristic music of the various racial groups of this city, was presented last night in Town Hall, under the auspices of the New York City Mission Society. The Rev. Kenneth D. Miller presided at the concert, in which the participants included the Siberian Singers, under Nicholas Vasilieff, and seven other choirs.

Lucy Boehmler left the witness stand in Federal court yesterday afternoon looking as cool and demure as when she began her testimony on Tuesday. Although she spent much of the time replying "I don't recall" to the cross questioning of defense attorneys, her story of espionage in association with the seven persons on trial remained unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The duty of issuing sugar rationing books to every man, woman and child in the country was entrusted tonight to public school teachers. They were instructed to deal firmly with hoarders until the secreted supplies are exhausted.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 6 -- The British forces in Cyrenaica continued to consolidate their positions near the Gulf of Bomba yesterday and the Germans made no violent attacks. It appears that the British are preparing for a battle to determine whether the Germans are able to advance farther.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- Although Edward Hueber, Pennsylvania's sensational junior, won two free-style sprint races and also anchored the victorious 400-yard relay team, the Naval Academy defeated the Red and Blue in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet at Hutchinson Pool tonight, 39-36.

Surrogate James A. Foley, it was learned yesterday, has approved an agreement whereby the trustees of the $1,630,010 fund, established by the late Henry R. Towne to aid a museum of peaceful arts, will discontinue payment of the income to the Museum of Science and Industry after the payment of $60,749 to that institution, and distribute the principal between the Museum of Natural History and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

As the Japanese approach the island of Java they come close to the heart of a colonial empire of about 70,000,000 people, of whom more than 46,000,000 live on this one island and its smaller neighbor, Madura. The Dutch possessions, swinging 3,600 miles across the Equator, are most unevenly populated.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Held in check for two periods, the Montreal Canadiens broke loose with three goals in the third session to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game tonight, before a crowd of more than 7,000.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Notre Dame outscrambled the Kentucky quintet tonight, 46 to 43, in the roughest game of the season on the Irish court. Twenty-two personal fouls were called on Kentucky and thirteen on Notre Dame.

The warden loaded the last of his supplies on the long sled, glanced over the dogs in their traces and with a careless wave at the storekeeper took the north road out of Frenchville, that tiny dot on the map of Aroostook County.

Several thousand women in various parts of the country, all affiliated with chapters of Bundles for America, Inc., yesterday began the task of packing more than 100,000 comfort kits, requested by officers of naval districts to supply the needs of their men, it was announced by the organization at 475 Fifth Avenue.

A recommendation that the colleges and universities of this country abandon their present admissions policy, based on credits and written examinations, is contained in the report of the nation-wide eight-year experiment conducted by the Commission on the Relation of School and College, to be made public this week.

MAIMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Welby Van Horn of Los Angeles, one-time boy wonder of amateur tennis, will meet Wayne Sabin of Reno, Nev., tomorrow afternoon in the final of the $1,500 Roney-Plaza professional tournament.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP) -- James Bickford captured another bobsled championship today -- this time adding the Adirondack A.A.U. junior two-man title to his triumphs.

POSSIBLY because she has once again turned to India for her setting, "Breakfast With the Nikolides," Rumer Godden's third novel has much the same quality of enchantment as "Black Narcissus," her first. There seems to be something in the air of India to which Miss Godden's fragile and exotic talent is particularly attuned.

Amateur artists throughout the country should be encouraged by the fact that tomorrow work of thirty of their number will be placed on exhibition in East Fifty-seventh Street, the stronghold of professional painters and sculptors.

With but few exceptions, the country's leading industrial organizations are as unprepared to maintain their industrial research activity through a post-war deflation as they were during the depression years of the early Thirties, Maurice Holland, research consultant, declared yesterday, following submission of results of a survey to members of the Industrial Research Institute, holding its Winter meeting at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza.
Don Frame of the Harvard Club, holder of the New York State and metropolitan crowns, captured two matches yesterday in the Long Island squash racquets championship at the Jackson Heights Squash Club.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Bard College, residential unit of Columbia University, has revamped its whole academic schedule to meet the needs of students who eventually will join the armed forces. The college has cut out almost all vacations and also shortened slightly the length of each semester.
BUFFALO, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A new "express train of the air" is taking form at the Curtiss-Wright Corporation airplane division as the company moves into production of high-speed Army cargo planes.

WITH GENERAL M'ARTHUR'S FORCE IN WESTERN BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 5 (Delayed) -- American and Filipino troops today annihilated the main force of a Japanese suicide battallion of 300 picked soldiers who landed from the sea some time ago.

Belief that Russia will dominate Europe if that nation defeats Germany was expressed yesterday by Dennis McEvoy, correspondent of The Chicago Times Syndicate, at a luncheon in the National Republican Club.

ASERIES from Liechtenstein presents four portraits new to philately's gallery. On 20-rappen brown is "Hans Ad." -- Prince Hans Adam von Liechtenstein, "the real founder and father of the present-day principality." Late in the sixteenth century he purchased the estates of Schellenburg and Vaduz and merged them under his rule.

Declaring that Germany cannot be starved out but must be defeated by military might, Dr. Karl Brandt, economist of the Foods Research Institute of Stanford University, told 700 members of the Foreign Policy Association at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor that "Germany is exactly as strong as the unpreparedness of those who oppose her."

RADIO has combed the vaudeville, musical and legitimate field for talent, but it seems there's plenty of it in radio's own back yard. For instance, there's Walter Compton, master of ceremonies on the Double or Nothing quiz program heard over WOR-Mutual at 6:00 Sunday evenings. Mr. Compton has been in radio most of his professional life.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 7 -- To give students an opportunity to prepare for war industries or the armed services, Holy Cross College has altered its curriculum to meet current needs. New courses have been added, old ones have been enlarged, new equipment has been set up in the various laboratories, and physical education has received an added impetus.

Madeleine Goss's biographies of musicians (she has already given us a life of Beethoven and one of Bach) combine a delightful spontaneity with sound musical knowledge. Entering imaginatively into the events of the composer's life and thoroughly familiar with his work, she presents the man and the musician in such a way that the reader's interest is never allowed to flag, and he is thoroughly convinced of the reality of the portrait.

Providing volunteer workers for the Army Extension School, Army and Navy recruiting offices, the Second Military Area office, and for Selective Service headquarters, the members of the National Security Women's Corps have given more than 10,000 hours of service to governmental agencies since this country's entry into the war.

Gardeners on the lookout for something novel and distinctive in fruiting shrubs will find the Beach Plum to their liking. This hitherto neglected little bush is practical as well as ornamental, providing a spectacular sight during May with its spikes of creamy-white flower clusters, and in Fall yielding a fruit that is unsurpassed for jellies and preserves.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- Extensive oil fires, which may yet play a part in Singapore's defense against Japanese attack, raged on the north coast today while British big guns blasted Japanese batteries on the Johore shore into silence and blew some small enemy ships out of the water.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Full cooperation between the United States and China for "the common victory that shall be ours" was pledged today by President Roosevelt in a message transmitted to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, war leader of the United Nations in the Chinese area.

OTTAWA, Feb. 7 -- Except in the electoral division of Quebec East, where the-newly appointed Minister of Justice, Louis St. Laurent, is being opposed by an anti-conscription near-isolationist, Paul Bouchard, the conscription issue has scarcely figured in any of the four Parliamentary elections to be held on Monday.

More than 150 committees, covering all locals of the C.I.O. in New York, have been formed as part of organized labor's drive for $1,000,000 for the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by the Greater New York Industrial Union Council.

Brazil is planning far-reaching changes throughout its entire educational structure to prepare for the establishment of post-graduate schools, Dr. Luthero Vargas, son of the President of Brazil, who arrived in New York last week to investigate orthopedic work in American hospitals, disclosed yesterday.

Many of the wholesale markets here continued active last week, with deliveries becoming slower and scarcities more evident, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

A well-balanced DeWitt Clinton High School squad, manufacturing points in all but two events, retained its city P.S.A.L. indoor track and field championship at the thirty-ninth annual running of the senior high school games at Madison Square Garden yesterday. afternoon before a crowd of 5,000.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 7 -- South Carolina's "better farm living" program designed to have farm families raise 75 per cent more of their food and feed programs, saw 5,500 families receive today certificates signed by Governor Harley for meeting those requirements in 1941.

OTTAWA, Feb. 7 -- Reports said to be current in the United States that tires might be obtained in Canada under less severe restrictions than those of the United States were denied emphatically today by A.H. Williamson, controller of supplies in the Department of Munitions and Supply.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Minnesota scored its seventh triumph in ten starts in the Big Ten basketball race tonight, swamping Ohio State, 63 -- 33. The Gophers were never headed after wresting the lead from Ohio State in the first few minutes.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

SECRETARY OF THE NAVY KNOX, according to Rome's midday fairy-tale hour, "is recovering from a coma which began in Holland Tunnel." The affliction, Rome declared, was caused by knock-out drops fed the Colonel by "disgruntled naval bigwigs."

The Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, announced yesterday that he appreciated efforts of friends in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island to nominate him next Tuesday, at a diocesan convention in Garden City, L.I., as candidate for bishop, but that he had asked that his name not be presented.

Nobody in these times can make too much of a stew about mispronunciations. STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Feb. 7 -- On the basis of questionnaires answered by students at second semester registration, the success of the new three-term plan at the Pennsylvania State College seems assured. The addition of another semester will put the college on virtually a twelve-month basis.

ACCIDENT-WISE, the United States got off to a bad start in this war. Traffic deaths and crashes began to rise long before war started two months ago yesterday. The 1941 national toll, now being totaled, has been estimated at 40,000 deaths, a 16 per cent gain over 1940 and 1 per cent greater than the worst year, 1937.

One sound way of snapping yourself out of the midwinter wardrobe doldrums is to spend some time wandering around a few of the dress material departments. New Spring fabrics are just in and there are pure silks and wools, as well as mixtures of synthetics, practically as far as the eye can see.

The 1942 edition of "Books for Young People" is just off the press. Evander Childs High School has revised most of its courses for this semester to include a study of Latin-American culture and customs, Dr. Hymen Alpern, principal of the school, announced yesterday. Dr. Alpern said that last month the United States Office of Education selected Evander Childs, Lincoln School of Teachers College, and Corpus Christi Parochial School to serve as "demonstration centers for Inter-American education" in this city.

Two youths en route to Poughkeepsie to borrow money for weapons with which to start on a crime career were arrested early yesterday by State troopers on the lookout for their automobile, stolen a few hours earlier in Long Island City.

FOUR CHEESES -- Danish blue, royal Danish, English Stilton and American cream -- make a pungent, pleasantly tart spread which is to be used for canapes or very special sandwiches. The precious imported varieties are put through a grinder. Then, after the cream cheese has been added, the mixture is beaten until soft and creamy.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Outstanding women golfers from all parts of Florida will congregate here this week-end for the Women's Championship of Palm Beach, one of the annual sports events inaugurated in the early days.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Army was no match for Harvard in an Eastern Pentagonal Hockey League game played today in the West Point arena on fast ice. The Crimson triumphed, 6 to 2. Army has yet to win a game in league competition.

TORONTO, Feb. 7 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs broke the New York Rangers' seven-game winning streak by outscoring them, 6 -- 4, before 13,539 spectators at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight. The victory put Toronto two points behind the second-place Boston Bruins, who were idle, and prevented the Rangers from extending their four-point margin in the National Hockey League race.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 7 -- Although a wide area was combed day and night by surface vessels and six expert divers were flown from Washington, the S-26 was not located until Jan. 29, lying in 301 feet of water, the Navy said today. Robert J. Agness, a diver, made the descent to this extreme depth but found no signs of life when he tapped on the hull.

BY air comes the news from Stockholm that "Berlin Diary" is one of the popular successes of the season. Johan Hanson, as head of Natur och Kultur, which brought out the Swedish translation, has long been a champion of liberal thinking, and since the war broke out he has taken a determined stand against suppression of a free press.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Confronted by dwindling petroleum stocks in the East, due to sinking of tanker ships and diversion of oil vessels to war service, the Office of Petroleum Coordination called upon the petroleum industry today to pool its products to meet war and essential civilian requirements in the Atlantic seaboard States.

Wales of the School of Engineering of Rhode Island College, which yesterday began a three-year course for all its engineering curricula.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red gross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens,$250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 - -With all but three of the eligible Boston University graduates of last year now working, the university placement bureau has attained the highest record of jobs for students in its history and looks forward to breaking this record with the 1942 graduates, Warren E. Benson, director of the bureau, reported today to President Daniel L. Marsh.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Japanese shells that fell in Singapore's suburbs today apparently were hurled from twelve miles away.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Feb. 8 -- Aware of the grave danger to its plans for a Spring offensive, the German High Command appeared today to have launched heavy attacks now to stem the Russians on a line from the central front to Kharkov.

Birkhead, national, director of Friends of Democracy, Inc., 103 Park Avenue.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- Earnings of workers employed by the General Motors Corporation reached a new high level in 1941, amounting to $500,142,165, an increase over 1940 of $143,169,343, or 40 per cent, C.E. Wilson, president of the company, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Sixty-two naval-trained American fliers now operating with the Chinese forces in the Burma area were commended today by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox and Rear Admiral John H. Towers, Chief of the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Joe Louis and an unnamed Negro hero of Pearl Harbor are among the persons listed in the Honor Roll in Race Relations of 1941, made public yesterday by Dr. L.D. Reddick, curator of the Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature of the New York Public Library, in connection with Negro History Week, which begins today.

The United States will go on war time tomorrow at 2 A.M., when clocks throughout the nation will be moved ahead one hour. The daylight-saving measure, signed by President Roosevelt on Jan. 20, is designed to promote greater efficiency in our industrial war work and is expected to save 736,282,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity annually.

Marshall Goldberg of the Chicago Cardinals was the most diligent pass interceptor in the National Football League last year, official figures show. The former Pitt ace was tied with Art Jones of the Pittsburgh Steelers in the number of intercepted passes with seven, but took the title on greater returns.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 -- Impact of war upon educational processes has been felt in every section but nowhere else quite so directly as in California, which the Army regards as the first line of defense for continental United States. From kindergarten to university, there have been effects upon both State and private educational institutions.

ANEW Aeronautical Engineering Department has been established in the School of Engineering of Princeton University. Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, in making this announcement also revealed that Daniel Sayre, an experienced aeronautical engineer, has been appointed department head.

LAREDO, Texas -- Mexico has hit on an idea to keep up its American tourist trade. Alejandro Buelma, head of the tourist department of Mexico, announced here recently that Americans tourists visiting Mexico can obtain all of the automobile tires they need below the border.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A new electron microscope which is claimed to give "in principle" magnifications of 1,000,000 diameters, five times the magnifying power of other electron microscopes, won a patent (No. 2,271,990) for Edward G. Ramberg of Haddon Heights and George A. Morton of Audubon, N.J.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 7 -- Unsung Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio, who feared his putting and then canned two shots of 75 and 60 feet on the greens, pushed the more famous professional contingent into the background and took a two-stroke lead at the midway stage of the $5,000 Western open golf championship today.

SNOWSHOERS are out in force in the Quebec area, where those who follow the sport are staging a Sports Day (following championship races) at Levis, across the river from Quebec, next Sunday. Prizes won during the Winter will be awarded at Le Bucheron Club's dinner on March 15, at Chateau Frontenac.

Manhattan's swimming team extended its winning streak to three victories yesterday by handing St. Peter's of Jersey City a 40-35 setback at the Park Central Hotel pool. The Jaspers won six of the events to keep their record clean.
MIAMI, Fla. -- The eighth annual Professional Baseball Players Golf Tournament, on the Miami Country Club course on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, will be the principal sports event here this week.

Edward Massey, playwright and stage director, was found dead in his one-room apartment at 1 Sheridan Square at 8:30 A.M. yesterday by a building attendant who smelled gas. His death was listed as a suicide.

Moving quietly and within a 9-point range, the cotton market lost all its early strength again yesterday under small Southern selling and hedge offers. On the New York Cotton Exchange final prices of active futures showed net losses of 1 to 6 points. The March position was weakest under some near-month liquidation.

High winds and a heavy rain caused minor property damage throughout the city yesterday, keeping emergency squads busy in the morning hours lashing down loosened signs and roping off streets inundated by rising water. Koenig, Chief of Intelligence, First Air Force, Tuesday and Thursday 10:15 A.M., over WMCA, it was announced yesterday.

THE war in Asia has added one more form of locomotion to the number already in use. Advancing across the Thai frontier recently, Japanese troops rode not in tanks nor in armored cars but on the backs of elephants.

SYDNEY -- Australians, a perennially footloose people and one to whom their vast continent offers a constant challenge, are not sitting down quietly under the gasoline rationing plans offered by their various federal governments in the effort to help along the war drive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The petroleum industry moved a record 164,700 barrels of oil daily to the East by tank cars in the week ended January 31, Petroleum Coordinator Ickes reported today. The rail movement numbered 5,125 cars, as compared with the high previous week of record, October 18, 1941, when 4,396 cars moved an average of 141,300 barrels daily into the 17-State area.

More than two years of war, including months of terrific aerial bombardment, merchandise shortages, rationing and controlled profits, have not diminished the courage, determination and ingenuity of British retailers, according to letters received from London department stores in answer to a special survey made by the sales promotion division of Kirby, Block Co.

BY dramatizing Edwin Corle's "Solitaire" John van Druten has raised an old question. Should a drama critic, the embattled prophet of virtue in the theatre, read a novel before he sees the dramatization of it, or should he assist at the premiere unprepared and all unlettered?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- American industry was told tonight by Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, that it must step up the speed of conversion of its non-defense facilities into machines producing for war and essential civilian needs.

In wartime most schools and colleges are confronted with the problem of decreasing enrollments and, at the same time, with the necessity of maintaining staff, plant and the ordinary activities of peace-time education. The need for men in the armed forces and in productive capacities is expected to make great inroads into the student body of men's colleges and universities the country over.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- Under the blinding sparkle of acetylene torches in the hands of wreckers, the symbol of mass production in the automotive industry was being obliterated today in more than one of Detroit's automobile plants.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP) -- New York State is nearing the end of a half-century effort to put more than 220,000 public workers under Civil Service regulation.
