Fruit trees -- especially those set out in Autumn -- are frequently injured by rabbits during February and March, when heavy snows may cover the ground and food is scarce.

MR. KRISHNALAL SHRIDHARANI in his indignant letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review of Jan. 25 has added a rather tricky new complication to the much discussed problem of book reviewing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The War Production Board announced today that three special plants will be constructed in Southwestern cities to process tin cans for use in boosting copper mine production.

IN THE BRITISH FRONT LINES, in Libya, Feb. 6 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Great clouds of acrid black smoke drifted over the desert today as British and Imperial troops carried out a "scorched earth" retreat to new defense lines around Tobruk.

SOME further slackening of the public buying spurt was reported for the week and weather conditions were blamed in part. Retailers were inclined to believe that the hoarding movement had passed its peak and that other influences, such as the approach of the income tax date and the spread of "priorities unemployment," were coming more strongly into play.

Just what effect the thirteen-round knockout he suffered at the hands of Joe Louis has had on Billy Conn, former world light-heavyweight champion, is expected to be revealed in the ring at Madison Square Garden Friday night.

With more than $800,000,000 of national defense orders already awarded to the St. Louis Industrial area, that section of the nation is fast becoming one of the most important inland arsenals of democracy.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 7 -- King George II has decided to bring to an end the Greek dictatorship. His action is greeted with marked satisfaction by representative Greek communities in the Middle East and, it is safe to assume, elsewhere as well.

THOUGH there are a good many recordings of the Chopin waltzes -- several in albums and most of them on single disks -- there is no one traversal of all the waltzes that would satisfy one's desires in every respect.

SWITZERLAND is one of the few countries in Europe which the American regards with unalloyed sympathy. In spite of this fact most people know astonishingly little about this tiny land in the heart of Europe.

Tire and tube allotments for the first quarter of February came closer to exhausting quotas than was the case in the first quarter of January, it was apparent yesterday in figures released by Lee S. Buckingham, acting Federal rationing administrator for the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- What could have and should have been an all-winning night for New York City college basketball teams did not materialize tonight at Convention Hall. That it did not can be traced directely to the Violets of New York University, who forged to a ten-point lead over Temple and proceeded to let that advantage slip away, finally losing at 43 -- 40.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Among the paramount issues in this year's Congressional election campaign is almost certain to be the question whether the Administration is pushing America's war effort vigorously and efficiently enough.

On behalf of Einer Lyngklip, who died at his home in Brooklyn on Jan. 11, I am writing in the hope that some writer among your readers may be interested in completing a book on Frank Harris, in the research on which my husband had been engaged for more than twenty years before his death.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Roosevelt emphasized today that children's health contributes to the strength of the nation as he proclaimed May 1 as Child Health Day.

FAR out on a desert plateau, "somewhere in the Middle East," an ambulance drives perilously over a road that has been cut up by enemy bombs and by the treads of heavy tanks. A while back it was machine-gunned by a low-flying fighter, but it did not stop.

An emergency surcharge of 22 per cent on freight rates on traffic between United States ports and ports in Haiti nd on the east coast of Mexico has been approved by the Maritime Commission following hearings in Washington.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman is one of the scheduled speakers at a two-day conference opening tomorrow in Albany to formulate the legislative program of the New York League of Women Voters. During its sessions, the State budget and current bills will be considered in preparation for the league's recommendations to the Legislature.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Americans will not be deprived of circuses, fairs and carnivals this year because of the war, but the men in charge of these outdoor amusements know that they face a tough year filled with knotty problems.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 7 (AP) -- A dairymen's organization claiming 22,000 members in the nation's largest milkshed moved today to join C.I.O.'s United Mine Workers under John L. Lewis, who, its leaders said, is pledged to the "farmers' fight for a living price for milk."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Warning that maximum retail prices would be set on sugar unless the sales quotations on this vital family commodity were held within bounds voluntarily, Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration, appealed to consumers, already facing strict rationing, to "police" their own purchases.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY IN THE PHILIPPINES, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- United States troops here have a namesake of the Rainbow Division's famed Father Francis P. Duffy and he carries on heroically amid greater handicaps than that spiritual guide of World War fighters had in France.

Amid all that is being said and written these days about vegetable gardening for victory, it is perhaps well to remember that with many home owners the growing of vegetables is not merely a current patriotic urge, but a year in and year out undertaking that is considered both good fun and good business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Representative Taber of New York said today that he had received several anonymous telephone calls and telegrams cautioning him to "lay off" criticism of the Office of Civilian Defense and its personnel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The submarine S-26 was sunk in a collision with another United States naval vessel on the night of Jan. 24 off Panama, Secretary Knox said today. About thirty-two men were believed lost.

In the lexicon of World War II Spring has been synonymous with grand offensives on which Nazi Germany pinned her hopes for quick and decisive triumph It was on an April day of 1940 that Blitzkrieg enveloped Denmark and Norway -- the prelude to the giant drive against the Low Countries and France and to the deadlock in the Battle of Britain.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, pioneer in the feminist movement, will be honored with a reception and tea to be given on Wednesday by the National Council of Women and the recently organized Women's Society for a Free and Democratic Europe.

WHILE most of Hollywood was stirring restlessly last week Universal and Deanna Durbin struck a blow for solidarity by settling their four-month-old disagreement and resuming the placid relationship of their first six years together.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway announced yesterday that it had put in service ten freight locomotives with a 2-6-6-6 wheel arrangement, the first of their kind to be used. The engines have a pair of leading wheels, followed by three pairs of drivers connected to one pair of cylinders, another three pairs of drivers connected to another pair of cyclinders and three trailing wheels.

THE American Institute of Graphic Arts has for the twentieth time completed its annual choice of "The Fifty Books of the Year" and they will be on exhibition in the New York Public Library, Room 112, on the main floor, until the end of the month.

WHEN James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, recently authorized the New York Philharmonic-Symphony to play under the non-union Serge Koussevitzky, there was more in his gracious nod than might have appeared at first glance.

THE tragedy of France can today be summed up in two words: Vichy-de Gaulle, for in that dualism of duty, obligation, hope, lies the profound horror of the French case. Defeat, as the French knew in 1870, is bitter, but the divided loyalty, the confused counsel, the frustrated aspiration of 1940 is more bitter still.
RANGOON, Burma, Sunday, Feb. 8 -- Japanese bombers swept over Rangoon early today and subjected this great Burma Road terminus to its heaviest night raid of the war.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 7 -- With one of the finest exhibitions any team has given in the thirty-two years the event has been held, New Hampshire's well-balanced ski team took top honors today in the Dartmouth Winter carnival for the second year in a row.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 7 -- The Manhattan College basketball team climbed over the .500 mark tonight, defeating Rutgers by a 53-46 count before 500 fans in the Rutgers gymnasium.

IT is surprising how many military words in English are French and date from the Norman Conquest of 1066. William the Conqueror established French as the official language of Britain, and the Britons readily adopted the French military vocabulary while being trained for army service.

ICE fishermen, the hardiest of Winter sportsmen, are at the peak of their season. Cold weather has covered lakes and ponds with ice and drawn the heavy-coated sons of Izaak Walton from their warm homes to frosty woods and shores.

The Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office reported yesterday that last week was the most successful for enrollment and placement of civilian defense volunteers since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman, said that to date 22,345 men and women had enrolled for civilian defense training courses and duties.

TANGIER, Spanish Morocco, Feb. 7 -- Rioting against British business concerns flared up here tonight, twenty-four hours after twenty-five persons were believed killed in a time-bomb explosion, again focusing attention on the delicate alignments in North Africa.

"Victory Concert No. 1," the first of a series of free chamber music concerts to be sponsored jointly by the Juilliard School of Music, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the New York Public Library, was presented at 5 P.M. yesterday in Room 213 of the New York Public Library.

From now on women will do their own two-way stretching, by decision of the War Production Board. The dismay and apprehension which followed news that there would be almost no rubber allotment for girdles emphasized the importance of disciplining, by means of exercise and diet, secret and unlovely bulges.
ROME, Feb. 7 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique today said:
"Keep 'em swinging for war relief and defense" is the slogan suggested by Morton G. Bogue of New York, U.S.G.A vice president.

ALL Ben Hecht's animadversions on the critics' "fungused egos," on their sterility, on their senile exhaustion make for pleasant reading but bad arguing. The faults of the critics are irrelevant to the faults of "Lily of the Valley."

Speakers on national defense say that the best way for most of us to help is to go right on with our regular jobs, but to do them better. Part of the home owner's regular job is to keep the home planting healthy and attractive. To do this he must continue to have effective tools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A photoflash bulb made from synthetic plastic instead of glass, and which is said to give a more intense light for taking pictures than the conventional lamp having a glass bulb is the subject of a patent (No. 2,272,059) awarded to Michael J. Neumann de Margitta of New York City.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 7 -- Whatever possibilities "collaboration" between France and Germany may ever have held out, the fact remains that today it is dead, dead as a doornail. Some will tell you it was stillborn.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 -- Jack Twink, owned by Mrs. A.B. Letellier of New Orleans and ridden by Jimmy George, accounted for the Louis XIV Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

Rachmaninoff: Concerto No. 1, in F sharp minor. Sergei Rachmaninoff, piano, and Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Eugene Ormandy. (Victor M-865, three 12-inch records.) Though this is Rachmaninoff's official Opus 1 and was composed in 1890-91, it was extensively revised in October, 1917.

The indoor track season, off to a rather delayed start this year, will zoom along in high gear this week, with three meets scheduled for three different cities. The three are, chronologically, the metropolitan intercollegiate championships at the Bronx Coliseum on Thursday, the Penn A.C. games at Philadelphia on Friday and the Boston A.A. games at the Hub on Saturday.

Belief that the Interstate Commerce Commission would grant higher freight rates at yesterday's meeting buoyed the railway shares in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. The whole list closed mixed but steadier in dull trading.

THE musical diet of the men in the Army camps has begun to include some real music. Jascha Heifetz is one of the artists who provide it. He began at this Pacific Coast station, and he will visit many posts before the year ends, playing a seventy-five-minute concert sponsored by the U.S.O.-Camp Shows, Inc.

The Americans will oppose the Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Brooklyn skaters have been idle since Tuesday night, when they dropped a 3-to-2 decision to the Rangers.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., -- This resort is preparing for February holiday crowds that will mark the climax of the Winter season. Hotels are planning special events for guests over Lincoln's and Washington's birthdays, while many others also will include Valentine Day programs.

ARRANGING it as a "gesture of welcome" on the part of American artists; the National Arts Club placed on view last week a large group of paintings by foreign artists of the United Nations. Omitted is work by Western Hemisphere painters, but the roster embraces many Allied European countries and China.

ROME, Feb. 7 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command announced today that Axis troops had reached E1 Gazala, which is about forty miles west of Tobruk, and had captured the Gialo Oasis, which is about 250 miles to the southwest of El Gazala.

The patriotic spirit among members of the artistic professions in donating their services to war relief and defense efforts is currently manifest in plans for the recital to be given by Yehudi Menuhin, distinguished violinist, on the night of Feb. 18 at Carnegie Hall.

EASTON, Pa., Feb. 7 -- An accelerated program at Lafayette College for the duration of the war, which will enable students to be graduated in three years and at the same time permit remunerative employment in defense industries during the Summer, was announced today by President William Mather Lewis.

Two beautiful girls and a bartender combine forces to save Nick Abbott when he appears to be headed straight for the electric chair. He is accused of having murdered his wife, and there is no doubt whatever that he had motive enough and to spare.

W.R. BURNETT is always readable, always fast-paced and skillful. But he is more than that. He handles the language with grace and accuracy; and he has the quality of the serious novelist, both in character presentation and in theme. It is true that he has scarcely touched on complex characters or involved themes.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The United Nations must regain sea and air supremacy in the Pacific with fleets of planes and ships from Britain and the United States to insure Australia's safety, Sir Keith Murdoch, a leading Commonwealth editor, declared today.

Now that Winter finally has brought good skiing to the Northlands, recreational and competitive skiers are looking forward to many weeks of sport before climbing the upper reaches of the Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians for Spring skiing.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Removal of war industries at this stage from either coast inland would be the most effective possible way to help win the war for the Japs and the Nazis," said Dr. Robert A. Millikan, scientist and educator, in a national broadcast last night.

The Maritime Commission announced last week that its ship production program in January had maintained the rate of about one a day established toward the close of last year, with fourteen merchant launchings between Jan. 15 and 31.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- An "honor roll" of donors of yachts to the Navy, Coast Guard and Maritime Commission training service was made public today by the Maritime Commission.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 7 -- The Japanese drive against Indonesia is now in a phase of consolidation in preparation for a new major blow.

NEW YORK PORT has seen a good many wars. It has been the outright cause of at least one. Sometimes wars have profited the port; sometimes, as in the years leading up to the War of 1812 and as in this one, war has dealt serious injury.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 7 -- In a special message for the United States, Foreign Minister, Juan Bautista Rossetti of Chile declared last night, "The United States can have full confidence in Chile" and disclosed that he would submit to the Chilean Congress the agreements reached at the Rio de Janeiro conference -- including that recommending a rupture of relations with the Axis -- at the end of this month or early in March.

TIME, which changes all things, is subject itself to change. Tonight, for instance, all branches of the Federal Government and all interstate commerce will set the clock ahead one hour and go on daylight-saving time, and the rest of the country will join in to make it unanimous.

THERE doesn't seem to be any exact count of the number of skiers in the United States, but it is well over two million. Most of them took up the sport in their twenties and thirties, and quite a number obviously believe that life begins at 40. However, only a small percentage of them are really good skiers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Cabinet members, Under-Secretaries and Federal Administrators have been instructed by the White House to submit to the Office of Facts and Figures, headed by Archibald MacLeish, for "clearance," any public speeches they plan to make.

IT'S up to Major Lawrence McC. (Biff) Jones to keep the athletic program rolling along at West Point now. Back from Nebraska, where as football coach he sent one aggregation of Cornhuskers as far as the Rose Bowl, Biff is taking the place of Colonel Louis Hibbs as graduate manager of athletics at the Academy. Colonel Hibbs is headed for artillery work in the field.

A SOLDIER'S day begins at reveille, that is 6 o'clock, and half an hour earlier if you are a KP or on duty with the kitchen police.

A PHONETIC typewriter which types words according to their sound was patented recently by a New York inventor. About the size of a small portable typewriter, the new machine records the language phonetically by syllables.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 7 -- The Netherland defenders of Amboina Island sank a Japanese cruiser and damaged another cruiser and a submarine before relinquishing control of that air and naval base, the second most important in the Netherlands Indies, it was announced in a communique today.

Telegrams and petitions harassing legislators in Albany reflect a determined campaign being mobilized by women's groups to oppose the Young-Milmoe bill, which proposes a six-week extension of school leaves for children to work in agriculture.

ONLY a short time back, a significant and subtle change came over that indispensable citadel of masculine vanity and beauty -- the barber shop. Unless you happen to know what took place, you won't be able to nonce it.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 7 -- President Getulio Vargas today issued a decree setting forth rules for preparation against air raids, while the War Minister retained all conscripts of the class of 1941 in the Rio Grande do Sul military region after expiration of their service time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The United Nations are no more united in their war effort or their war aims than the United States was united on what to do about the war before the attack on Pearl Harbor, but considerable progress has been made toward a common effort by the United States and the British Commonwealth since the conversations between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill.

The annual report of the Bendix Aviation Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries, issued yesterday, showed for the quarter and twelve months ended with December increased earnings over the previous year despite much larger tax deductions.

THE largest museum exhibition devoted to the dance since the Dance International of 1937-38 will open its doors to the public on Wednesday, when the Museum of the City of New York turns over its theatre gallery to a show called "Dancing Through Two Centuries, 1740-1940."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 7 -- With three members of the crew severely wounded, with holes in the gasoline tank and fuselage and navigation instruments demolished an Australian Hudson [Lockhead] bomber this week defeated a Japanese fighter in a battle over the Bismarck archipelago.

"THE countess was shooting craps," is the stimulating first line of "Blue Horizons." A neat enough line to build a novel round, Miss Baldwin probably considered. And so she did, with apparent ease and extensive branching off.

SIXTY inches of snow at Badger Pass. Twenty-four-inch snow on Valley Floor. Skiing good. Skating, tobogganing, sleighing, dog-sledding at Yosemite National Park. These are among cheering news items from the Pacific Coast, where the vigorous are mixing open-air and healthy sport with the defense duties all citizens at present are intent on.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Jimmy Foxx expects pitchers to be the principal beneficiaries of the increase in the number of night games in the major leagues because "a batter sees only half a ball coming at him in a night game."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Richard T. Haines Halsey, a member of the governing board of the New York Stock Exchange from 1900 to 1924, died at a hospital tonight from injuries suffered Jan. 20 when he was struck by an automobile near his home here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- War relief workrooms are being opened in all of the chief centers of activity of the Daughters of the American Revolution, it was announced today by Mrs. William H. Pouch, President General. The rooms will be available for all members of the society for all kinds of war relief work. Mrs. Harry McKeige of 1473 East Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, originated the idea.
Sparkling shooting and deft passing gave the St. John's University basketball team a well-earned 78-42 verdict over Providence College last night at De Gray gymnasium in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Representatives of independent retail grocers expressed satisfaction with practically all features of the nation's sugar rationing program here today. Criticism which they were prepared to level at the program disappeared under official assurance that a check on the volume of business each retailer did in normal times is contemplated.
CHICAGO is genuinely relieved to discover that Ethel Barrymore's resentment toward it is less elephantine than Noel Coward's.

Export traffic handled through the Port of New York has reached the volume of the peak days of the first World War and is steadily increasing, according to records maintained by George C. Randall, chairman of the special port traffic committee of the Association of American Railroads, at 30 Vesey Street.

ONE might have thought that the American Revolution, from Quebec to the Carolinas, by land and by sea, had been pretty thoroughly dealt with in the fiction of the past ten years. Loyalists and patriots, spies and Hessians, red-coated officers and backwoods riflemen have stalked across the pages of more really fine historical novels than any similar period in our literature can show.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 -- A research program on the problems land plans of industry, labor and capital in a war and post-war world will be undertaken by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the Spring, Professor Ralph E. Freeman, head of the Department of Economics, announced today.

The first and only man ever to vault 15 feet outdoors became the first and only man ever to touch that height indoors as Cornelius Warmerdam sailed over the bar at 15 feet 3/8 inch last night for a new world record before the enraptured gaze of a capacity crowd of 15,000 in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Navy announced in a communique today that the combined naval forces of the Australian-New Zealand area had been placed under command of Vice Admiral Herbert F. Leary of the United States Navy, with the title of "Commander Anzac Forces."

Eleven years ago Lieut. Gen. Douglas MacArthur's mother, the late Mrs. Mary P. Hardy MacArthur, received a gold medal from the National Society of the United States Daughters of 1812 for being the mother of an illustrious son, Miss Minnie B. Wade recalled yesterday at the thirty-ninth annual luncheon meeting of the Order of Americans of Armorial Ancestry at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7 -- Argentine public opinion as voiced by press and political parties and organizations is overwhelmingly pro-democratic and thoroughly in sympathy with the United States in the present world crisis. To conclude from this, however, that the majority of Argentines repudiate the attitude assumed at the Rio de Janeiro conference by their country's delegation would be a mistake.

WHEN you come right down to it, Hollywood glamour is worth precisely one-twentieth of a cent per foot. This mathematical verity stems from the fact that the motion picture studios use about a billion and a half feet of positive film annually to record their Cinderella pipe-dreams.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- A broadside of criticism was leveled at Washington today by speakers at a symposium on "Labor in Wartime," called by the University of Pennsylvania, Temple University and the Pennsylvania State College and conducted at Temple.

Whitlow Wyatt arrived here yesterday from the Georgia farm country and forthwith became the first obstructionist to the plan of intimate salary discussion introduced by President Larry MacPhail of the Dodgers this year.

A series of streamlined courses embracing the practical and recreational aspects of wartime living will begin at New York University School of Education tomorrow. Aimed principally at individuals and families with fixed incomes, its purpose is to provide satisfactory substitutes for commodities and pleasures which may not be available in the future, as emergency restrictions continue.

ALTHOUGH Japanese war-planes have scored impressively in the last two months, their success has been due more to Allied default than to inherent Japanese strength in the air. Tokyo's air forces are small. On Dec 7 they used only 2,500 first-line planes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- How Germany is making an economic "new order" in Europe at the expense of neutrals and occupied countries with which she deals is described by Henry Chalmers of the Commerce Department this week in the Foreign Commerce Weekly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The War Department announced tonight that General Douglas MacArthur had personally decorated Major Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright and Brig. Gen. Albert M. Jones with the Distinguished Service Cross for extraordinary heroism in action in the Philippines.

AMONG the score of new exhibitions that fell to my lot last week were two especially interesting ones by American artists -- recent paintings by Elliot Orr, at Kleemann's, and wood sculpture by John Rood, at Georgette Passedoit's Gallery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Senate farm group started a new bipartisan effort today to prevent the government from applying the brakes to agricultural prices before they reach the levels possible under the new Price Control Law.

THE Metropolitan Opera's 1941-42 season wouldn't be complete if there weren't difficulties for the Spring tour too. One difficulty has been obtaining the seventeen freight cars needed to transport the scenery and costumes.

When the New York Rangers and Chicago Black Hawks, teams of the National Hockey League, meet on the Madison Square Garden ice Tuesday night, the occasion will be a benefit for the Cooperative Committee of Big Sisters.

The Westminster Kennel Club will open its sixty-sixth annual all-breed dog show in Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock Wednesday morning, the exhibition to continue through Thursday evening. Judging will be started at 10 A.M. both days, with additional performances at 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.

Adoption Feb. 16 of the new "special offering" plan devised by the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission seems likely to bring about important changes in Wall Street. All but the largest secondary distributions off the board will be eliminated, unless non-member firms choose to make them without member help.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7 -- With Captain Howie Johnson leading the way, Yale's crack swimmers today established two new university records and equaled one N.C.A.A. standard as the Elis vanquished Army, 62 to 13, in dual meet in the Payne Whitney exhibition pool.

DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Ralph Bietila's Class C ski jumping crown was blown off his head by a strong wind today and snatched up by Jack Pauly of the Edina Ski Club of Minneapolis as competition got under way in the 1942 national championships on Duluth's 60-meter hill.

The 156th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers (A.I.M. and M.E.) will open here tomorrow at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, and continue through Thursday. Despite the fact that many leading members must remain at key positions in defense industries, more than 2,000 of the total of 15,513 members are expected to attend, according to A.B. Parsons, secretary of the institute.
WAR has dimmed for a while the radiance of America's most famous and beloved of national shrines -- the Statue of Liberty.

LONG BRANCH, N.J. Feb 8 -- As the culmination of the "S.O.S. -- Stay on the Sidewalk" campaign, in which several hundred children in schools here composed acrostics on the safety slogan, a gold medal will be presented to the winner on the steps of City Hall, on Lincoln's Birthday.

As a result of the shortages of many materials and the ban on their use for certain types of packages the most widespread package redesigning program in the history of the country is now going on, designers reported here yesterday. The changes range from a printing job in some instances, in which one color has been substituted for two, to complete redesigning of a package in a completely different material.

Talk of silk stockings will eventually be dropped from hosiery lingo for the simple reason that there will be few if any to talk about. The dire moment is not in the immediate offing, however. Most manufacturers still have some silk yarns on hand and will, of course, continue to offer stockings while their stock lasts.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Florida racing has netted the State $1,687,302 in tax revenue this season, Governor Spessard L. Holland reported today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7 -- An opportunity to obtain the master's degree in half the time formerly required will be offered by Yale University beginning with the academic year which starts July 6, it was announced today.

The recently established Franco- Belgian Institute for Advanced Studies Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes), the first French-speaking university in the United States, with a faculty composed of sixty exiled French and Belgian scholars, will be dedicated next Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Professor Gustave Cohen, formerly of the Sorbonne, Paris, now visiting professor at Yale University.

QUIETLY but effectively, as recent collectors' items prove, the United States censorship for civilian mail is carrying on its extensive duties. Apparently all incoming and outgoing mail, to or from beyond our borders, is now being inspected.

TO keep an active child diverted and relatively quiet long enough to measure his weight, height and chest may seem no great task, but when measurements must be more scientifically detailed, accurate within a few grams or millimeters, and continued from thirty-five to forty minutes, the procedure is something else again.

THE faint praise department, being called upon for testimony regarding the radio version of "Abie's Irish Rose," deposes and says that it is better than Miss Anne Nichols's longevous play or the motion picture extracted therefrom.

New York women's organizations endorsing the extension of workmen's compensation coverage to domestic workers are actively participating in the campaign to promote passage of the Condon-Crews bill in Albany. The women's groups are basing their support of the measure on the increased protection afforded through its provisions to both employe and employer against accidents occurring in the home.

Knowledge of family name, address and telephone number by young children is considered a good idea, so we hear from the Greater New York Fund. Boys and girls at Madonna House day nursery are taught a jingle which starts --

Captain Howard L. Vickery, a member of the United States Maritime Commission, was named to the post of vice chairman last week. He will be second in command of the government agency that is directing the greatest ship construction program ever attempted by any nation.

A BOY under 20, with a heart and "hands" for horses, is the engaging hero of this enthusiastic story. Sparke had a good head, too, and even when he was new at the game of driving a trotter the older hands at it had a hard time fooling him.

An effective way to enhance the beauty of fine antique furniture is to group it with craftwork of an equally high quality. This has been done with fortunate results at the newly opened exhibition at the Newark Museum of a collection of European cabinetwork, silver and Sheffield plate, with textiles, metal work and pottery from India and Persia.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 7 (UP) -- A Chinese Government spokesman, Dr. T.F. Tsiang, said today that China had war stocks sufficient for "some time" and suggested that the Chinese might be supplied by air even if the Burma Road "lifeline" was cut.

Completion of a $3,259,000 addition to the group of buildings comprising the Pilgrim State Hospital at West Brentwood, L.I., makes this the largest institution of its kind in the State, with a capacity of 9,260 patients, according to William E. Haugaard, State Commissioner of Architecture, under whose direction the plans were drawn.
WE rise to ask a plain question: What is the actual meaning, and what are the representative illustrations, in contemporary music, of the word "neo-classic"?

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7 -- Paced by Co-Captain Bill Busik, who scored 14 points and played a brilliant floor game, the Naval Academy basketball team today defeated the University of Virginia quintet, 51 to 37.

For the first time in its 152-year history, the United States Coast Guard is making a public appeal for funds to carry on its welfare work in this district, and to this end has arranged a benefit dance and entertainment, which will be given next Saturday night at the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street.

THAT searching appraiser of the lives of Napoleon, Bismarck and Lincoln, in applying the findings of psychological biography to the Latin-American liberator, succeeds in presenting this moving historical character from perhaps the only angle that had been heretofore allowed to remain in the dark.

The recently organized New York City Women's Council of the Navy League is now working toward the success of its first benefit project -- a gala ice carnival and entertainment at the Center Theatre on the night of Feb. 24. Sharing in the proceeds with the council will be the American Friends of Norway.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Although it has switched to a three- term-a-year basis and planned for each term a group of new courses expected to be of particular benefit to students during the war period, Colgate University announced through President George B. Cutten's office today that it would continue to emphasize the conviction that a liberal arts college should have as its principal objective the development of all-around men.

CAMERA angle can spell the difference between success and failure in candid work. It seems to be inherent in humans to ignore a camera man who is looking elsewhere. The average man seems to believe that a photographer must look at him in order to take a picture of him.

THE custom of sending valentines on Feb. 14 may seem to some people like nothing more than a memory of childhood -- of nursery excitement over blue and lace paper and red hearts. But judging by the amount of stuff available in department stores and candy shops, it is still a very active one.

THE most eloquent words ever written about books as an expression of the human spirit were those set down by John Milton in his "Areopagitica." published in defense of the liberty of unlicensed printing. They will bear reprinting many times:

LONDON, Feb. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Everton moved into a first-place tie with Bristol City in the Football League Cup qualifying competition today by beating Burnley, 3 -- 2, while the Bristol eleven dropped a 2-1 decision to Swansea. Only eleven games were played in the cup competition.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Alsab and other great horses failed at Hialeah Park today as American Wolf captured the $6,260 Bahamas Handicap and Sheriff Culkin drove home first in the British West Indies Purse. It was a day to thrill all of the 16,316 who turned out, for form held up remarkably well with the notable exception of the seven-furlong Bahamas, in which Mrs. Alice F. Sherman's color-bearer returned 17 to 1.

"When in Need of a Script," reads the title of a short article in the Sunday TIMES of Jan. 18. The implied conclusion is "try Dumas, pere." That Duman has been one of the most prolific sources of screen material is entirely warranted by the evidence.

ALTHOUGH he painted them in peacetime, and because, purely and simply, he wanted to paint them, there yet is point in Rockwell Kent's assembling the forty-two canvases (now at Wildenstein's) under the collective title "Know and Defend America."
In two months of war the wings of the plane have cast a long and ominous shadow across the Western Pacific.
A QUESTION that is being asked with more and more eagerness and, as should be the case, with increasing urgency is this: How can American artists help win the war?

Only nine gunners braved the storm that swept down Long Island Sound from the east to compete at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The conditions were about the poorest of the season and as a result the scores were all low.

Two games which have come to be outstanding events on the local calendar headline a heavy college basketball program this week. These are the Long Island University-Duquesne and New York University-Notre Dame fixtures, booked at Madison Square Garden for tomorrow and Saturday nights, respectively.

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- Prices of livestock steadied today after a general advance during the week led by hogs, which ended yesterday with a break. The quotable top today was $12.65 a hundredweight, off 5 cents from yesterday's peak when average price was $12.27, compared with $11.86 a week before and $7.81 a year before.

THIS week thirty enlisted men from the United States and Allied armed forces will leave the busy laboratories and projection rooms of the March of Time at 369 Lexington Avenue to return to their respective commands after an intensive six months' training in movie-making.

The number of stockholders in the banking house of J.P. Morgan Co., Incorporated has increased just about five-fold since last Monday. Approximately 540 individuals, institutions or estates are listed today as the owners of the 200,000 shares of stock that constitute the capital of "The Corner."

While most Russians have been busy giving Hitler lessons in the art of war, some Russians, archaeologists by profession, have been digging peacefully. Their headquarters are in Samarkand, in the Uzbek Republic, which may be reached by rail from Krasnovodsk on the Caspian, via Bokhara.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The United States has made inquiries as to whether the Vichy government has, as reported from London, permitted use of French territorial waters for shipment of supplies to German forces in Libya or has itself shipped such supplies.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- The Rockland Voluntary Aid Society, Inc., which was founded a year ago as an experiment to provide assistance to needy persons not eligible to benefits from public agencies, has proved a success, according to the organization's first annual report, issued today by its president, Dr. E. Armand Scala, local surgeon.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 7 -- After a conference with President Manuel Avila Camacho, General Abelardo Rodriguez, former President of Mexico, said today that the present Chief Executive's contribution to progress of the country would be strict adherence to the laws.

THE modern foreign correspondent is often a man of culture and learning, anxious to understand what he sees about him. Mr. Deuel, representing The Chicago Daily News in Berlin during six years, is just such a correspondent. His book, rich in information gathered from men and books alike, is both a compilation of newspaper articles and a kind of dissertation on Hitler's Germany.

When I first tried raising thalictrums in variety from seed, I lost all my T. flavum seedlings through damping off, although the others thrived. Attributing my failure to improper xv'atering and ventilation of the seed pan in which they were started, I tried again, with all the best traditions observed, only to have the tragedy repeated.

I AM not against the private competitive basis of broadcasting (see my article -- "Sponsorship we acknowledge * * *" and "We have no patience with those who tilt at advertising as such" -- or words to that effect). And I believe definitely that a BBC system is quite inapplicable in this country.

Nazi U-boats operating off the United States coast claimed their biggest prize when two of the pack sank the 15,355-ton Swedish motorship Amerikaland thirty miles off Cape Hatteras, N.C., last Monday, with a probable loss of twenty-eight lives, the Navy Department revealed last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A two-million man air force -- the world's largest -- was announced today as the Army's eventual objective with half that number to be mustered before the end of the year.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 7 -- Ernie Lombardi, for ten years first-string catcher of the Reds, was traded to the Braves tonight for two players upon whom the clubs have not yet agreed, general manager Warren C. Giles of the Reds announced.

A PILGRIM in Lincoln's home town of Springfield, Ill., wandering in the State Capitol there, fell into talk with a total stranger, a gray-haired business man of the city, and confided that he had only seven hours in which to view the Lincoln scene and satisfy the longing of a lifetime.

New York University's varsity fencing team and freshman basketball team were victors yesterday. The swordsmen opened their season by defeating Fordham, 20 -- 7, on the East Building strips, while the cub quintet scored a 61-35 triumph over the Kips Bay Boys Club at the University Heights gymnasium.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 7 -- At least two new outbreaks against the Germans in occupied France occurred today, followed by immediate measures by the Nazi authorities, according to word received here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- America's dinner tables will support a quantity of foodstuffs this year greater than in any previous year and a variety almost as complete as ever, despite the fact that this country is now involved in war.

CAPTURED: Spokesmen for the Navy and the Marine Corps last week announced that 1,292 officers and men of the two fighting forces are missing or have been made prisoners of the Japanese since the outbreak of hostilities in the Pacific. The report, first since Secretary of the Navy Knox revealed Pearl Harbor casualties, raised to 5,273 the known number of Army, Navy and Marine Corps personnelkilled, wounded or captured since Dec. 7.

The annual statement of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, filed with the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, shows substantial increases in insurance in force and in the amount of new business written in the year, and new high records for assets and surplus on Dec. 31, 1941.

THIS city has a Dock Street Theatre but no Dock Street. It has a group called the Footlight Players who perform without footlights. From the Dock Street Theatre to the Footlight Players Workshop is just around the corner, yet the distance between them is the bridgeless gap of Charleston.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, Feb. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Torpedoed off Canada's eastern seaboard, fifty-four survivors from a small coastal freighter were recovering here today from exposure and shock.

LEESBURG, Va., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Judge J.R.H. Alexander of Loudoun County Circuit Court sentenced today Paul B. Hoback on Bluefield, W.Va., and Herbert B. Porter of Brentwood, Md., both 16 to life imprisonment in the penitentiary for the murder of Ward Loveless, 51-year-old Washington lawyer, at his home here.

The first dancing school in our town flourished in 1737. And that gives a rough starting point for an exhibition entitled "Dancing Through Two Centuries," beginning this week at the Museum of the City of New York. Pictures on this page from contemporary music sheets give an idea of how New Yorkers have danced at various periods since the waltz, which had come from Germany to Paris, crossed over the ocean to us.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- In seventy-five English and Welsh cities and towns Britain today launched Warship Week -- drives to raise funds for ships and, as if to emphasize the safety of ships in convoy, the Admiralty announced that two British convoys had successfully reached port after fighting off successive air attacks in which two Dornier bombers were shot down and three more damaged.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Senator McNary of Oregon suggested today that the sugar shortage could be "alleviated" if more industrial alcohol were made from surplus corn and wheat.

THE Chamber Music Society of Lower Basin Street, that half-hour session of swing music and tongue-in-cheek commentary in the long-hair style, is about to have its second birthday. To its enthusiasts, whose name seems to be approximately legion, that's an event to celebrate.

THIS is in answer to miss Lansdale Oakley's article in today's paper. I should like to point out to Miss Oakley, first of all, that her thinking is very definitely of a limited kind. When one views the whole field of art one sees clustered about the base of the great works of all time smaller masterworks, perhaps lesser in their stature but certainly no poorer in quality.

The shipping industry of New York was pleased last week by Governor Lehman's nomination of Eugene F. Moran, veteran towboat operator of New York, for membership on the Port of New York Authority. The nomination, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Alexander J. Shamberg, is expected to receive the approval of the State Senate.

SAN FRANCISO, Feb. 7 -- California's Personnel Board was blocked today by a State Justice Department ruling in its plan to "cleanse" the civil service lists of hundreds of American-born job eligibles who are descended from nationals of Japan, Italy and Germany.
THE TIMES could do the leaders of this nation and the general public a great service if it would point out the apparently overlooked fact that most public speeches are too long.

Last year Professors Elliot Blackwelder, H.D. Goodale and Gerrit S. Miller Jr. expressed some pessimistic views on the future man in Science. Professor Blacwelder saw little hope for man and opined that he would have to improve his brain to outstrip the present species of homo sapiens.

Reaching out for a peace formula to combat the New Order for Europe plan of Adolf Hitler, the democracies have bestirred themselves and created the Atlantic Charter and the United Nations pact. These measures have not yet kindled high the flame of hope that leads men to greater effort and victory.

School was over for the weekend at 3 P.M. on Friday and 6-year-old Janet Sanchez, a first-grade pupil at P.S. 54, Amsterdam Avenue at 104th Street, yielding to an impulse common to many of her sex, decided to go visiting. So, arm in arm with her classmate, Nilda Cancel, she went to the latter's home at 20 West 104th Street and spent an exciting four hours "playing house" and exchanging classroom gossip.

IT IS rare -- indeed, without digging, we can't cite you a single previous time -- when this column has an occasion to mention in the same Sabbatical breath a film which will certainly stand up as one of the top comedies of the year and a film which has already gone down as one of the sorriest mistakes ever made.

NEW broadcast station construction has been "frozen" for the duration of the war. However, current among radio men here is the view that the Federal Communications Commission order -- first of its kind in broadcast history -- may, in general, prove not a hardship but a blessing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 (AP) -- The story of how Richard Thomas of Omaha, Harvard wrestling captain and astronomy student, worked the facts of a new comet in 30 hours was revealed tonight by his instructor in stargazing, Dr. Fred L. Whipple.

IF chamber music is important only as a "mild form of home recreation," according to Lansdale Oakley in THE TIMES on Feb. 1, why then do such contemporary composers as Shostakovich, Schoenberg, Stravinsky, R. Vaughan Williams, Randall Thompson, Aaron Copland, Samuel Barber, Roy Harris, Walter Piston, John Alden Carpenter, Villa-Lobos, Quincy Porter, Eugene Goossens, to name a few, still continue to write string quartets, trios and quintets for chamber groups?

TWENTY-SEVEN photographs are included in the current exhibition of United States Army Illustrators of Fort Custer, Mich., at the Museum of Modern Art. Participating in a showing of soldier art which also includes work in gouache, water-colors and drawings, the prints depict various aspects of army life, in blizzard, rain and snow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The War and Navy Departments reported today that Major Gen. Walter C. Short and Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel had applied for retirement. The commander of the Hawaiian Department of the Army and the commander-in-chief of the Pacific Fleet were relieved from active duty ten days after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7.

The magnitude of the wartime task of the Young Women's Christian Association and how it is being carried out in sixty nations from England and the Near East to Latin America and the Far East were told yesterday at final sessions of the annual meeting of the foreign division of the national board.

TWO biographies which promise to be of unusual interest are announced for publication either next Fall or in the Spring of 1943 by Houghton Mifflin Company. One is "Silly Girl," the autobiography of Angna Enters, dancer, mime and painter.
FRANK KNOX is a genial, friendly man who has been fighting for almost half a century. At 68 he is up to his ears in the biggest fight he has ever been in and he is having the time of his life.

THERE are more things in university libraries than the students know about -- we hope. But the chief cataloguer has to know, and that is why Gilda Gorham, who is chief cataloguer in the library with which this story deals, is the ideal person to do the sleuthing when two members of the faculty are murdered in the library.

Teachers College of Columbia University, one of the world's leading institutions in the field of education, has made available to the nation's war effort the combined experience and intellectual resources of its 4,000 students and faculty members, as well as the laboratories and specialized facilities of its fourteen buildings, coordinating all branches of its war work under a Central Committee on Problems of War and Defense, it was announced.

A real cooperation with Russia must emerge out of the struggle against fascism and nazism under the rule of "live and let live," Dr. Jan Masaryk, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Czechoslovak Government-in-Exile, declared last night in an address before the annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the Hotel Astor.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- The recovery of the liberated regions of Russia is proceeding apace. Rail traffic is being resumed. The first train to reach Klin from Moscow since, the enemy was driven back made the run last week. The line from Mozhaisk to the west which the Germans converted to narrow gauge is now being hastily altered again.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- Is the present Russian advance going to meet a determined German attempt to stop it along a general line? Or are the Germans going to continue a general retreat, relying on delaying action by their rearguards, in the confidence that, with new armies, they will be able to sweep back over Western Russian in the Spring?

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 7 -- The Japanese attack against the United States produced a series of startling and apparently contradictory developments in Chile. It was Chile that summoned the conference of the American republics at Rio de Janeiro last month, and most persons jumped to the conclusion that she would take the lead in breaking off relations with the Axis powers and in any other steps that would help the United States.

Blue, real blue, is always at a premium in the garden. There is one easily grown plant, however, which grows most readily, and which, in its several types, provides an almost uninterrupted succession of blue flowers from April until October.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Reports from the country continue to assert that the spirit of urgency and alarm, so needful for a successful war effort, is not rising at the pace of war production. It is still lagging and sluggish, and susceptible of easy relapses, according to officials who think that the establishment of this attitude is not second, but entwined with, the attainment of production capacity in materiel.

This country needs all techniques possible to protect it from the psychological warfare of its enemies, which is "magnificently conceived and skillfully executed," Arthur Upham Pope, chairman of the Committee for National Morale, declared yesterday at the auditorium of Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

JAPAN'S advances in the Pacific have posed questions for which philately is awaiting answers. The Nipponese forces have captured or penetrated a score of stamp-issuing lands. What sort of postal systems are the invaders setting up?

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (Reuter) -- Dogs now have a new task in aiding the Red Army. They are being used to drag wounded Soviet soldiers back from the battlefield on little sledges after the soldiers have been found by first-aid men. Alsatians do most of this work, but airedales have also been found capable.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 7 -- The Italian press led by the Piccolo today launched a particularly significant campaign against the Tunisian press -- and by implication the French Tunisian authorities -- for its intransigent attitude toward the Axis effort in Libya.

Profit-sharing bonuses paid to employes as additional compensation are allowable deductions from the employer's gross income for income-tax purposes when such payments are made for services actually rendered. It is assumed, of course, that such payments, when added to the salaries or wages, do not exceed a reasonable compensation for the services rendered.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- While the first meeting of President Roosevelt with a joint committee of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations augured well for continuance of peaceful wartime labor relations, especially as they concern rivalry between the two labor movements, it appeared at week's end that the Administration's machinery for settling labor disputes was headed for a major test within the next few weeks.

WITH the constantly increasing requirements of the armed services to be met and with automobile and ship travel greatly restricted, the railroads face the greatest demands upon their facilities in history.

Frederic Ernst, Associate Superintendent of Academic High Schools, sharply criticized Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians yesterday for their refusal to permit musicians to play at five-cent matinees of musical comedies and operettas for school children.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 -- More than 500 persons tonight attended the dinner for the benefit of the Good Samaritan Hospital at the Everglades Club, of which Hugh Dillman, club president and member of the hospital board, was general manager.

WATERVILLE, Me., Feb. 7 -- Extensive use of microfilm as a teaching technique is made in the course on social technology at Colby College conducted by William T. Boyle, former Professor of Bio-Chemistry at Harvard.

Members of the farm bloc are muttering in discontent, but the public should be pleased that Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, and Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, have composed their differences and agreed upon a common policy for price control.

After Welfare Commissioner William Hodson had declared that the full effect of priorities unemployment would not be felt here before May 1, the one-day Trade Union Conference on Union Welfare and Health Work appealed to Congress to hasten passage of the $300,000,000 appropriation proposed by President Roosevelt to relieve the situation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 7 -- On Feb. 1 Major Vidkun Quisling received from Reich Commissar Joseph Terboven the title of Prime Minister of Norway. According to both Herr Terboven and Major Quisling, this "act of state" at the old Oslo fortress of Aker symbolized the triumph of the "new order" in Norway.

"Priorities unemployment" is not as widespread as has been feared or predicted, but is reasonably serious in New York City and somewhat less so in the rest of New York State, according to Richard C. Brockway, director of the regional office of the United States Employment Service.

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Rafael Munoz, Havana sportsman, won the international live pigeon championship in a shoot-off today with four others, including E.R. Lutz of Knoxville, Tenn., and Alex Schwarz of Philadelphia.

Several thousand retail buyers will attend the annual Spring market week to be opened tomorrow by Butler Brothers, dry goods and general wholesalers, at its New York showrooms at 860 Broadway, according to Q.P. Witte, general manager.

DEEMS TAYLOR'S "Ramuntcho," an opera in three acts with text by the composer based on Pierre Loti's novel of the same name, will receive its world premiere by the Philadelphia Opera Company, under Sylvan Levin, Tuesday night, at the Academy of Music, Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Sufficient scattered liquidation developed today in the early trading on the Board of Trade to carry prices of grains and soy beans to new low marks on the current downturn, with wheat showing a loss of more than 6 cents a bushel and soy beans losses of 10 1/2 to 12 7/8 cents from the recent high points.

Eight New York University freshmen who began their studies at four of the university's undergraduate schools last week have received Charles Hayden scholarships totaling $2,500, Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle today designated the eighteen areas in Arizona from which all Japanese, German and Italian aliens would be ousted by Feb. 24.

Mayor La Guardia's action in bringing removal charges against Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, and his two associates, Commissioners Wallace S. Sayre and Ferdinand Q. Morton, will, if successful, bring national as well as local political repercussions, it was predicted yesterday in well-informed circles.

The prodigal son, Archer Caldwell, returns after fourteen years during which time his family has heard nothing from him. But is he the real Archer Caldwell? Vincent, the brother who is next in line, has his doubts, but Archer has proof of his identity in the form of tattooed initials on his back, initials which are known to have been there when he disappeared.

TAOS, N.M. -- In the pueblos which dot the Rio Grande Valley of New Mexico, in the pueblos atop the mesas of Hopi land, at Zuni, and in the great reaches of the Navajo desert, the great ceremonial dances which take place during the months "when the thunder sleeps" have already begun.

A REVIEWER once playfully remarked that American Book-Prices Current was about as entertaining as a telephone directory, and somehow the description managed to cling to it. But only a rank outsider would really find it that dull.
SINGAPORE, Feb 7 -- I am permitted to reveal tonight that Britain's great Singapore naval base now stands empty and deserted. It was evacuated on Jan. 31.

Behind at least one of the many black clouds of bad news obscuring the horizon there has come a bright lining in the implication of the current Gallup poll, which reports that 69 per cent of the customary cross-section favor the compulsory carrying of an identification card bearing the citizen's photograph and fingerprints.

About 75 per cent of the Hunter College class of '42 favor the establishment of an American organization corresponding to the British Women's Auxiliary Air Force, a recent poll among the graduating seniors revealed. The majority of the 260 students polled said they would join such a force.

War production in New York State has been retarded because some employers have refused to hire workers from this city to compensate for labor shortages in their own communities, it was charged last night by Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, who is also State Defense Coordinator, in an address at the forty-sixth annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

"Gardens to Live With" will be the subject of the free lecture to be given Saturday at 3 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden by Dr. Hugh Findlay of Columbia University. Dr. Findlay will discuss those gardens which serve both a practical and an esthetic purpose.

To acquaint students with the culture and philosophy of oriental life, Spence School, 22 East Ninety-first Street, has introduced courses dealing with the Far East. All seniors are required to study the philosophy of Buddhism and its surge through the countries of Asia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Japanese heavy artillery, concealed near the southeastern shore of Manila Bay, bombarded the American forts at the mouth of the bay for three hours, but without effecting material damage, and the forts returned the fire, the War Department said in a communique today.

American foreign traders, perhaps more realistic even than State Department officials, are generally inclined to believe that Argentina will cooperate with the United States in its program for hemispheric unity despite the official attitude displayed at the recent Rio conference.

Tangier is in the former international zone off Spanish Morocco, over which the Franco government of Spain has declared Spanish authority and protection. It would be important in any German move to bolster strength in North Africa by sending troops through Spain to Morocco.
Lieut. Col. Henry T. Blair, U.S.A., gave a farewell luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton before his departure on Wednesday for duty with the Air Corps at Langley Field, Va.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Cornell scored its fourth victory in five Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League starts by defeating Pennsylvania, 46 -- 36, in their annual Junior Week game today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 7 -- The severance of diplomatic relations with the Axis brought Brazilians face to face with the realization that a nationwide network of powerful foreign organizations endangers the Brazilian regime and Pan Americanism.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The marooned parachutist of Devil's Tower is in the Army now -- as a parachute instructor.

RED CROSS, A.W.V.S., Air Raid Precautions -- never have there been so many demands upon a woman's time. Well-thought-out schedules are the only solution. Our days of aimless, leisurely puttering about the kitchen are over for the duration.

Who killed Everett Marston? Captain Kerrigan of the Homicide Squad is pretty sure that Mrs. Marston did it. Peter Clancy discovers evidence that implicates Marston's secretary, Olive Lacey. Each of these ladies has a lot of explaining to do, and neither appears to be telling the whole truth.

GENERAL NATHAN BEDFORD FORREST'S admonition to "get there fustest with the mostest" has proven as applicable to motion picture premieres as to military science. Since the first de luxe premiere of a film, twenty-nine years ago, the impresarios of cinematic openings have varied their technique but never their aim.

THE International Society for Contemporary Music will hold its nineteenth festival during the latter part of July at the University of California in Berkeley. Compositions will be selected by a jury of Bela Bartok, Carlos Chavez, Aaron Copland, Albert Elkus and Darius Milhaud.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Syracuse University gave Colgate's quintet one of its worst beatings in years tonight, riddling the Maroon zone defense and scoring almost at will to triumph by 62 -- 32.

Today is Poland Day. Three years ago this occasion might have been celebrated by a thousand-year-old nation which had but recently regained its independence after long subjection. It will not be celebrated openly on Polish soil today, for Poland lies wholly in Nazi hands.

THIS is the story of a father with a son just old enough and keen enough to be today in the front line of battle and a daughter barely old enough to be a worker in the war's danger zone, but who insists on getting there.

WHEN Professor Hayden was writing this monumental book he did not know how extraordinarily timely it was going to be. He did not find out until he was reading the final proofs of his preface, and then he had barely time to write a six-line note.

Puccini's "Tosca," with Grace Moore in the title role, received its fourth performance of the season before a large audience yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Frederick Jagel sang the role of Mario for the first time this season.
BERLIN, Feb. 7 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

ON an embankment of the Sumida River in Tokyo a line of peak-capped, trousered women are relaying buckets of water to a smoke-masked man. They pass the water along to the megaphoned orders of a uniformed man leader. Near by a practice fire is smoking thickly.

FOR more than ten years this country struggled with the paradox of idle money, idle men, idle machines. In a land of abundant resources and enormous productive capacity there was chronic want and chronic unemployment.

THIS is an odd sort of book to come out of an age which some men have called apocalyptic. Indeed, it reads as though it were produced in the Yellow Nineties. A Paterish, and at times Wildish, atmosphere hangs over the tale, in which the murder that takes place is only an irrelevant episode.

The author of "Drink to Yesterday" and "A Toast to Tomorrow" brings us another story of Tommy Hambledon, British secret agent, who is now back in England after a long and successful career as a spy in Germany. The time is before the outbreak of the present war.

Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard heads the committee for the Washington's Birthday card party to be held on the afternoon of Feb. 24 in the main ballroom of the Bossert Hotel in Brooklyn for the benefit of the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

SERGEANT QUIRT and Kipling's Mulvaney probably wouldn't approve, but the new American soldier has turned scholar. In barracks schools, as part of his regular training, he absorbs international imponderables. He gets instruction in geography, geopolitics, world trade, the enemy's social and political philosophy as contrasted with the American, and comes away with a fair idea of what the shooting's for and where he fits into the scheme.

The first meeting for this season of the Lenten Sewing Class of the Cribside Social Service Committee of the Babies' Hospital will be held on the morning of Feb. 19 at the home of Mrs. Carll Tucker. Subsequent meetings will be held on Thursday mornings throughout the Lenten season at the homes of Mrs. Joseph R. Ramee, Mrs. J. Frederick Brown and Mrs. Eugene Holman, and at the Colony Club.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- The Red Army reported tonight that the siege of Leningrad had been further relieved and that huge Soviet tanks were striking at stiffened German defense lines on the central front.

HEART-SOUND RECORDS -- Last week Dr. George D. Geckler (Hahnemann Medical College, Philadelphia), demonstrated in New York a method of recording heart sounds. It is now possible for a physician to sit at a phonograph and hear through his stethoscope murmurs and wrong rhythms at a realistic tone level.

IT would be a dull year indeed if Mr. Nathan, the theatre's plenipotentiary to the nation, failed to enliven us with a new book. If this his twenty-sixth volume, not counting collaborations with Mencken, had been published anonymously, its authorship would still have been transparent.

Good activity was noted in women's suits, main floor departments and housewares in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer-Both Reports.

LIKE most newly discovered writings of famous authors, this sixty-eighth book by Anthony Trollope is a disappointment. There is no question that such works ought to be published; they afford easy gratification to the collectors of first editions, and help to satisfy the scholar's craving for completeness.

DETROIT -- Within a few days the automobile industry will close its shops on a forty-two-year era in which more than 69,000,000 motor vehicles were produced by American plants. Out of the present emergency, when automotive plants are devoting 100 per cent of their energy to war output, will come a vastly new concept of automotive transportation.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 7 -- High in the craggy wilds of the forbidding "no man's land" of the lawless Pathan tribes, Afghanistan's mighty Pamir Massif and the Hindu Kush, extending southwestward beyond the frontiers of Baluchistan, key agents and gunrunners of Japan and Germany struggled last week to awaken the spark of revolt and inflame the frontier hillmen to an invasion of the plains of the Punjab over Britain's bastions of defense in Northwestern India.

Its first week of operation successfully ended, the New York War Work Center of the Daughters of the American Revolution discovered yesterday that its organization has set an example for the national membership. Mrs. William H. Pouch, president general, reported that the idea of a central workroom where chapters could combine in war relief services has inspired widespread interest, and that chapters in other cities are preparing to pool their efforts for the duration.

The New York City Police Department has nominated 271 key men in the city's civilian defense program to attend defense courses at Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by Nicholas McD. McKnight, associate dean of Columbia College and director of the civilian council of the university.

THERE are some obscure people in this town and in the commuting belt and scattered in sparse handfuls all through the country who are immensely valuable to the theatre, yet nobody knows them. They never go backstage, they don't hear theatre gossip and don't want to.

ROBERT B. IRWIN, the executive director of the American Foundation for the Blind, who has had so much to do with the production and distribution of "talking books" for persons who cannot read print, has been "dark blind," as he phrases it, since he was 5 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Speculative operations having resulted in resales at three to nearly four times the quotations of producers, price ceilings were established by OPA today on citric acid, used widely in such household products as pharmaceuticals and food and beverage flavors, and on the basic acid for aspirin tablets and other remedies.

PRINZ-ALBRECHT STRASSE in Berlin is not very different from any other street in the heart of the Reich capital. It is a wide, tree-bordered thoroughfare, with only a few office buildings at the corners, and, along most of its length, two big, palace-like structures facing each other across the street.
THE annual Eastern championships, which will be played Feb. 28 to March 8 at the Park Central Hotel, will offer the same events as last year. The schedule will be:

ONE of the biggest and least publicized clothing factories in America is the Naval Clothing Depot, over in Brooklyn. Last year it had almost 370,000 guaranteed customers -- and all of them were dressed substantially alike.

The importance of the Boy Scout movement to civilian defense was stressed by rabbis here yesterday, at services marking the observance of Boy Scout Week. Other sermon subjects included the inspiration of the examples of Lincoln and Washington to America at war and discrimination against Negroes in defense work.

BELLEVILLE, Ill., Feb. 8 -- A passenger in a commercial sight-seeing airplane was seriously wounded by bullets this afternoon when Army troops guarding a defense plant drove the plane away from the restricted zone with machine-gun fire.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Lifting of the price ceiling on cash lard by the Office of Price Administration last week had relatively little effect on the lard futures market, as the price for the cash article was considerably out of line with futures contracts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -Determination of men whose work in pictures is deemed "indispensable" will be made carefully in each case, Y. Frank Freeman, chairman of the Hollywood branch of the war activities committee of the motion picture industry, declared today in commenting on the decision of the director of Selective Service to defer drafting of essential workers in the industry.

MICHEL DE NOSTREDAME, that grand old sixteenth-century quack, has at last arrived. He has at last made the grade. He is at last established. He has been published by all and sundry for hundreds of years, but now he rubs elbows, if you please, with such as Proust, Swift, Dante, Marx, Dickens, Thoreau and Dostoyevsky.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- State and local councils of defense generally were termed today as "political frauds" by E.J. Lever, C.I.O. representative in the labor division of the War Production Board, who called for their aboltion in favor of groups more considerate of the needs of labor.

Because of legislation enacted at Albany in 1940 and 1941 there is a real danger that the Board of Estimate will be under a mandate to increase the fare on the city's subway and elevated lines after next Sept 10, State Senator Charles Muzzicato, Manhattan Republican, declared yesterday.

Paul S. Hitlin resold to Maylus Realty, Inc., the four-story apartment building for forty families at 111 East Twenty-sixth Street for cash over a first mortgage of $171,000 held by the Broadway Savings Bank and due in November, 1947. The building is colonial in design and occupies a plot 103 by 98.9 feet.

The motion picture industry is "an activity essential in certain instances to the national health, safety and interest, and in other instances to war production," according to a ruling by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, which was revealed yesterday through the war activities committee of the industry.

Resident buyers and assistant buyers are entitled to full benefits under the Federal Wage and Hour Act, although the government will not seek restitution of back pay which they may claim individually under the law, Arthur J. White, regional director of the Wage and Hour Division, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The anticipated Japanese attack on the mountainous defense positions on Bataan Peninsula in the Philippine theatre held by General Douglas MacArthur and his relatively small force of American and Filipino soldiers was unleashed between 4 P.M. yesterday and 1 P.M. today, a War Department communique of the war indicated.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 8 -Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar of Portugal had sent a message to all countrymen, whether in the homeland or in the colonies, to vote again for General Carmona because of the present serious circumstances.

One of his incomparable readings of a great classical symphony, an exciting new piano concerto and a splendid performance of an important but seldom-heard nineteenth century work was the fare offered by Sir Thomas Beecham last night at Carnegie Hall at his third concert of the season with the New York City Symphony Orchestra of the WPA Music Project.

VICHY, Feb. 8 -- The Secretary of State for Industrial Production gave in a recent speech significant figures on the shortage in raw materials. Supplies of coal amount to 2,800,000 tons a month, compared with 4,500,000 tons in 1938; in gasoline for automobiles 8,000 tons a month compared to 28,000 tons consumed in 1938.

The second War Powers Bill, in authorizing the Federal Reserve System to make purchases of Government securities directly from the Treasury instead of exclusively through the open market, does not break new and untried ground. It would merely restore an old familiar instrument of money-market control which the Reserve System regularly employed in the "tight-money" days of the Twenties but which was taken away by the Banking Act of 1935.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 8 -Major Gen. Fritz Todt, the "Wizard of Communications in Greater Germany" and constructor of the Westwall forts was killed this morning, according to a Berlin announcement, in an airplane accident "while carrying out an official mission to the East."
Of the seven new films listed for this week, five will arrive on Thursday. The program follows:

Earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. before Federal taxes on income and excess profits and special contingency reserves set a new high mark of $203,591,470 for 1941, more than 40 per cent above the $144,382,173 in 1940 and not quite double the $107,268,664 net before taxes of 1939, according to the annual report, issued today.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 8 (Australian Associated Press) -- Hundreds of newly trained Chinese troops, enlisted here but under twelve leaders sent especially from Chungking, have taken up battle stations to help in the British imperial defense of Singapore.
