PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 -- One of three La Salle Gold Medals to be awarded this year by the La Salle Civic and Social Congress will go to Henry Ford, it was announced tonight, for having "the courage and magnaminity" to reverse his labor policies last year by accepting a contract with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 13 per cent for the week ended Feb. 7, in comparison with the same week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

An underwriting group headed by Eastman, Dillon Co. will offer to the public today $1,500,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent convertible debentures of the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation. The debentures will be priced at 100 and accrued interest.

The Phoenix-London insurance group, which for twenty-one years has occupied an entire building on Maiden Lane, plans to move about May 1 into the building known as 60 John Street, on the southwest corner of William Street, where a lease has just been signed for about 11,000 square feet on the street and second floors. Raymond D. Ryan was the broker.
Whatever effect priorities may have in the future, there are still plenty of excellent perfumes to go around -- with even a few new ones added to the list.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 -- "Achtung!" The corporal shouted as we, two Red Army officers and myself, approached.

One of the largest investment banking groups ever organized for the underwriting of a public utility common stock issue was announced yesterday to distribute the entire outstanding common stock -- 2,695,000 shares -- of the Union Electric Company of Missouri.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- The story of how Robert (Bobby) Bauer, "the brain" of professional hockey's most active line, falsified his age so the Boston Bruins' "Kraut" unit would remain together for Canadian military service was revealed authoritatively today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 9 -- Although it appeared that the force of the German offensive had spent itself, at least temporarily, the British sent patrols probing into the desert yesterday to make sure that Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was not planning some surprise move.

Resenting an alleged attack made by members of Congress on the loyalty of the theatrical industry, Eddie Cantor, Ole Olsen And Chic Johnson have sent a telegram to William Green and Philip Murray, heads of the A.F. of L. and C.I.O., reading as follows:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to suspend operation of Section 7 of the Neutrality Act of 1939 for the duration of the war.

A record total of 15,490 men enlisted by the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard here since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7 was revealed yesterday by the recruiting officials of the three services. The Army figure was not disclosed.

In receipt of four signed contracts yesterday, President Ed Barrow of the Yankees came up smiling at the club's headquarters despite the mental strain over the status of his outstanding star, Joe DiMaggio.

Bad news comes from the Mountain of Reims, and from Epernay and Chalons. There is mildew in the vineyards which produce champagne grapes. We can guess the reason for the mildew. How could good vines grow in the presence of what has come across the Rhine?

Aiming at the greatest goal-scoring record compiled by a forward line in the last decade of National Hockey League activity, the New York Rangers tonight will tackle the Chicago Black Hawks in Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Reports reaching Republicans here is that Thomas E. Dewey has definitely stated to party leaders his intention of running for Governor again this year. Mr. Dewey disclosed his plans to a small group of party leaders in response to a question from them, it was reported.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 9 -- The Newark City Commission today gave tentative approval to a tax budget of $47,396,009 carrying a tax levy of $38,047,000 and an estimated tax rate of $5.45 for each $100 of valuation. The levy represents a drop of $3,631,921 from that of 1941 and the tax rate a reduction of 30 points from that of last year.

Tammany Hall may justly lay claim to one fundamental trait of true Americanism. It believes in majority rule. Tammany Hall in its day has done some very expert work in producing majorities, but when the official count has been announced it abides by the result.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Aided by United States-made planes, the Russians hurled the Germans back for new and smashing gains on both ends of the 1,500-mile front today and Soviet authorities announced the capture of "one village after another" from German forces floundering westward in disordered retreat.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- After an all-day session here the War Production Board clearance committee, which passes upon orders before they are finally issued, was reported today to have approved the proposed regulation curtailing the uses of tin cans for packaging various food products.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The House received today a substitute for the bill of Representative Cannon providing $300,000,000 for Federal aid to workers made jobless by plant conversion to war purposes. The Ways and Means Committee will begin public hearings on it Wednesday.

The recent purchase by the North American Philips Company, manufacturers of the war materials, of the Methodist Book Concern property in Dobbs Ferry, Westchester County, was due, it is stated, to the need for additional space to expand the facilities of the Philips Company's plant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Tax adjustments totaling $698,158 are being demanded of the Union Electric Company of Missouri and its subsidiaries by the Federal Bureau of Internal Revenue, Union informed the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A Treasury statement today showed that the per capita holding of currency in the United States on Jan. 31 was $83.43. This represents a large increase in currency in circulation as compared with $64.76 on Jan. 31 a year ago but only 5 cents more per capita than a month ago.

The stock market suffered yesterday the most serious over-all setback of the new year. In no case was there any hint of pressing or forced selling, as the share list retreated without fanfare, and a good part of the slump was laid to the withdrawal of supporting bids.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Mrs. Roosevelt disclaimed today responsibility for the selection of Melvyn Douglas to head an "arts council" for the Office of Civilian Defense, and declared that she had "suggested" but had not appointed Miss Mayris Chaney to formulate and direct an OCD recreation program for children.

Washington will not impose any arbitrary plan of conservation and waste regulation upon the nation at large, but will depend on a decentralized campaign to achieve results, Herbert L. Gutterson, chief of the general salvage section of the United States Bureau of Industrial Conservation, declared yesterday.

Four hundred dock workers and air raid wardens were pressed into service yesterday to assist sixty traffic policemen in rerouting automobiles around the Normandie fire zone. They performed their tasks so efficiently that Commissioner Valentine said that "traffic never was tangled seriously."

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- A resolution calling upon the President to remove Mrs. Roosevelt from her post as Assistant Director of Civilian Defense and replace her "with a person who can and will devote full time to the duties of that important position" was introduced in the Assembly tonight by Malcolm Wilson, Westchester Republican.

In addition to acting as issuing agents for defense savings bonds, many of the 134 mutual savings banks in this State are now offering the public free safekeeping facilities for these bonds, according to the State Savings Banks Association. The association reports that eighty-three of the 134 savings banks now offer this service, with some limiting such facilities to their own depositors.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Tuesday, Feb. 10 -- Batavia, the capital of the Netherlands Indies, was attacked by Japanese planes yesterday for the first time. The attack was carried out by eight fighter planes that swept in at a low altitude and machine-gunned two airdromes in the suburbs of the capital. Military planes were damaged, and at one field two passenger planes were splattered with bullets. One enemy-plane was shot down and another probably was destroyed.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- A Pacific Council, representing the British Commonwealth and the Netherlands, which will coordinate views on the war in the Pacific for transmission to the Anglo-American Chiefs of Staff in Washington, has been established here, it was announced tonight. The council will hold its first meeting tomorrow.

The Normandie was one of the proudest gestures the Third French Republic ever made. She was built in strength, in luxury and in loveliness. She was built for peace and for pleasure, for profit and for glory. She had the best of French engineering and the most delicate of French decoration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Senator Wheeler, who opposed the Administration's foreign policy before the war, said today that developments since Pearl Harbor had proved his contentions that the nation was not adequately prepared.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Tuesday, Feb. 10 -- Batavia, the capital of the Netherlands Indies, was attacked by Japanese planes yesterday for the first time. The attack was carried out by eight fighter planes that swept in at a low altitude and machine-gunned two airdromes in the suburbs of the capital. Military planes were damaged, and at one field two passenger planes were splattered with bullets. One enemy-plane was shot down and another probably was destroyed.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., at their annual meeting March 16 will act on a proposal to limit future pensions of officers and employes of the company to $5,000 annually. Provision also may be made to reduce pensions already in effect in excess of $5,000 to the $5,000 level.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle announced today that two classes of aliens from Axis-dominated countries were exempt from restrictions placed upon enemy aliens by the Department of Justice.

Mayor La Guardia asserted yesterday that "there is no need of any fear that under existing law the Board of Estimate is compelled to increase the fare by Sept. 10 if the revenue from fares is not sufficient to meet all operating expenses and all interest and amortization on the outstanding bonds."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 9 -- Among the planes that evacuated women and children from New Guinea was the late Charles T.P. Ulm's famous old Faith in Australia, which made a record-breaking flight from the United Kingdom to Australia in 1933, and another from Australia to New Zealand in 1934, it became known today.

The complete report of a Nazi spy who had made a detailed, personal study of defense activities and facilities at Pearl Harbor was intercepted by counter-espionage agents of undisclosed identity nearly a year ago, it was revealed yesterday when the actual document was placed in evidence by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa at the trial of six men and a woman accused of spying for Germany.
Morris Benjamin, formerly with Hirsch, Lilienthal Co., is associate manager of the branch office at 99 Madison Avenue of Newburger, Loeb Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

Mayor La Guardia continued yesterday the suspensions of Paul J. Kern, president of the Civil Service Commission, and Wallace S. Sayre, one of its two other members, and said that when he made his decision he would communicate it directly to the two men.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today approved defense housing projects totaling 8,076 homes for the families of workers in war industry and enlisted men in ten areas.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A communique of the Netherlands Indies armed forces today said:

Signe Sandstrom, young 'cellist from Springfield, Mass., who made her New York debut last season, gave her second recital here last night at Town Hall. The major works on her program were Handel's G minor Sonata, Bach's unaccompanied G major Suite, Schumann's Fantasiestuecke, Op. 73, and the F sharp minor Sonata for 'cello and piano by the French composer, Jean Hure.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 10 -- It appeared today, according to a consensus of authoritative sources here, that the Mexican Supreme Court's decision upholding private rights in the subsoil of oil lands would not lead immediately to any change of policy on the part of the Mexican Government, unless President Manuel Avila Camacho should decide to make such a change for other reasons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Donald Kirkpatrick, general counsel of the American Farm Bureau Federation, outlined to the Joint Congressional Economy Committee today what he described as "long-time tenure objectives" of the Farm Security Administration.

"Marketing information for the consumer is no longer a fetish, but a necessity," Mrs. Bertha Adams Mulvey, regional representative of the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday in an interview at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Wednesday, Feb. 11 -- The Japanese advanced still deeper into the Netherlands Indies outer isles yesterday by landing troops in the vicinity of Macassar, on the southwestern tip of Celebes, while at the same time pushing overland still farther south on Borneo to the neighborhood of Banjermassin.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (Reuter) -- Increases in service pay and allowances amounting to 55,000,000 yearly were announced in the House of Commons by Prime Minister Churchill today.

It requires an effort of the imagination to realize that that great hulk of a once proud ship lying on her beam in the Hudson River at the foot of Forty-ninth Street is not suffering humiliation. The sight of her hurts the human eye and heart.

The British War Relief Society made public yesterday a report on the Piccadilly Arcade, miniature model of the London arcade of the same name, which was opened last October at the society's headquarters at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

Setting a new record for percentage increase over the preceding year, sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 34.58 per cent in January, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Harry A. Reoux, chairman of the Assembly Reapportionment Committee, told the lower house today that bills carrying out Congressional and legislative district reapportionment in the State would be introduced early next month.

President Roosevelt in his annual message to the Boy Scouts of America yesterday praised the record of the organization last year and assured each individual Scout of membership in "Uncle Sam's team to help us win the war."

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The government concluded late today its presentation of evidence in the Union Electric Company of Missouri "slush fund" case. It was the nineteenth day of the trial. Frank J. Boehm, former executive vice president, had just testified that his superiors thought a Federal investigation of the utility's political activities would "die a natural death."

J. Seelye Bixler, Professor of Theology at Harvard University; Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, Professor of Christian Ethics at Union Theological Seminary, and Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, were the principal speakers at yesterday's sessions of the Columbia University Conference on Religion in the Modern World.

Many parties will be given tonight in connection with the supper dance in behalf of the American Red Cross which will be held at the home of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, 640 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. George B. St. George heads the executive committee for the event, at which the guests of honor will be leading representatives of the Army, Navy and Air Corps.

The embarrassment in which Congress finds itself as a result of having voted itself pensions at a time when the entire country is being called upon for self-sacrifice is in no way relieved by the disclosure that apparently nobody in either branch understood fully the implications of the measure when it was voted upon.

EVERY so often somebody takes a pot shot at Lieut. Comdr. Gene Tunney's battalion of body-builders in naval , uniforms. The athletes who signed up with Gene have been called skulkers, gold-brickers and other such uncomplimentary names. This innocent bystander recently wrote that, after all, these athletes were now under Navy direction and were doing what their superior officers ordered, presumably for the best interests of the service.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Getting down at once to the practical problems connected with the Far Eastern theatre of war, the Pacific [War] Council, the establishment of which was announced yesterday, met today at 10 Downing Street under the chairmanship of Prime Minister Churchill.

DETROIT, Feb. 10 -- Ernest C. Kanzler, chief of the automotive branch of the War Production Board, said today that he had not noticed "holding back" in the automobile industry's approach to converting its facilities from civilian to arms production.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- It was merely fortuitous that the President's assignment to Admiral Emory S. Land of full and final control of war shipping should have been made public on the same day that the Lafayette (Normandie) burned at her pier. But the calamity added the replacement of 83,423 tons to the many problems which have been given to Admiral Land for solution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Heavy reinforcements of Japanese troops have become "increasingly evident" in Bataan Peninsula in recent days, the War Department reported tonight. Nevertheless, General Douglas MacArthur's troops not only have continued to defend their positions but today carried out a counter-attack that cleared away units that had filtered through the left wing.

It's not hard to ask the question this year. "Will you be my valentine?" may be gracefully posed in any number of ways -- as absurdly or as seriously as your mood and pocketbook warrant. City stores have gone completely and colorfully romantic.

Net asset value of Atlas Corporation common stock at the close of 1941 was $11.42 a share, against $11.81 on June 30 and $12.26 a share at the end of 1940, according to the annual report, issued yesterday. The year's decline is about 7 per cent after payment of dividends of 50 cents a share in 1941, contrasting with a general decline in the stock-market average by almost 18 per cent, the report says.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 10 -- From dawn to dusk the Japanese invaders, greatly strengthened by new landing forces sent across Johore Strait, beat with rising fury today at the British defenders, who are falling back from the outer ring of Singapore's defenses under merciless enemy assaults by air and land.

The news from Singapore was responsible yesterday for a break in the stock market through the December lows. Although the extreme losses made in the early trading were recovered in part in the afternoon, the net losses for the day were 1 to 2 points.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 (From broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Strong Russian forces seeking to crack the German lines before Leningrad were beaten back, the German High Command reported today, while Nazi artillery fired "with good results" at objectives near the naval base of Kronstadt.

In Topics of The Times of Feb. 9 you seemed to feel that you owed an apology to feminine readers due to the news item "The Average Woman Is Found Dumpy," which appeared in THE TIMES Jan. 29 from a statement by the Department of Agriculture. Personally, I feel that you rate praise rather than rebuke.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A party of Americans from Malaya and Thailand arrived today after a journey during which their ship was sunk by Japanese planes at an unspecified port while they huddled in trenches 100 yards away.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- How Customs, Secret Service, Internal Revenue, Alcohol Tax, Narcotics and Foreign Funds Control enforcement agencies of the Treasury clamped down the lid on Japanese business houses in the United States, seized control of books and records, "froze" bank accounts and strong boxes and put nationals of the enemy under surveillance was told today in a report to Secretary Morgenthau.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- The apparent destruction of an enemy submarine by depth charges after she had crash-dived to escape ramming by a United States destroyer was described in a log made public here today by headquarters of the Twelfth Naval District.

Distribution to the local rationing boards of application blanks for the release of new automobiles bought before Jan. 1, 1942, is under way and this group of cars will be turned over to properly certified owners between tomorrow and Feb. 26, it was announced yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, Acting Federal Rationing Administrator for New York City.

A syndicate headed by W.C. Langley Co. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer to the public today a new issue of $5,000,000 of Iowa Southern Utilities Company of Delaware 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures, due Dec. 1, 1966. The debentures will be priced at 100 and accrued interest.

The long-standing jurisdictional dispute between the American Federation of Musicians and the American Guild of Musical Artists has been amicably settled and the lawsuit between them now pending in the State Supreme Court has been discontinued, it was announced yesterday in a statement signed by James C. Petrillo, president of the federation, and Lawrence Tibbett, president of the guild.

The Citizens Budget Commission, in making public yesterday its annual report for 1941, listed among its major objectives for this year the bringing about of an increase in the subway fare, development of a master plan for the use of land, and repeal of mandatory legislation "shackling the city's finances."

Even in ordinary times the physician cannot stand aloof from the public. At any time of the day or night he is summoned to the bedside of a sufferer whom he has never seen before, whereupon he starts the elaborate machinery of diagnosis and treatment -- machinery which includes hospitals, laboratories, drug stores, public health departments.

DUBLIN, Feb. 10 -- Adherents of William T. Cosgrave's Opposition party from all parts of Eire, who filled the Oak Room of Dublin's Mansion House for the party's annual convention today, heard a straight-shooting speech on Ireland's relation to the United States by the deputy leader of the party, James Dillon.

A first mortgage of $550,000 has been made by the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn., through the Urban Servicing Co., Inc., on the twenty-six-store taxpayer at 37-12 37-58 Junction Avenue, Emhurst, Queens, to the A.L.S. Realty Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Opponents of the Dies Committee on un-American activities turned out in force today to protest before the House Rules Committee over continuation of the investigating body until the beginning of the new Congress on Jan. 3.

The Chicago Black Hawks hustled to a well deserved 5-to-2 triumph over the Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Patterning their play after the style usually displayed by their blue-jerseyed rivals, the speedy Hawks provided the New Yorkers with a lesson in alertness.

Loss of a considerable volume of the trade which has passed through the New York Foreign Trade Zone, estimated yesterday at more than $100,000,000 annually, was predicted yesterday by importers following the court order which gave the United States Government possession of the fifty-five acre tract and four piers which constituted the only free port on United States soil.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 10 -- The British Ambassador, Sir Hughe Knatchbull-Hugessen, left Ankara at 2 o'clock this morning on the southbound Taurus Express, accompanied by Maj. Gen. Allan Arnold, British Military Attache.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- An accusation that the Vichy authorities in North Africa have been aiding the Axis forces in Libya with war supplies was made in the House of Commons today by Hugh Dalton, Minister of Economic Warfare.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- With a comparatively small run of hogs offered for sale, prices ruled steady to l0 cents a, hundred pounds higher today. The best price remained unchanged at $12.70.

CANBERR., Australia, Feb. 10 -- Prime Minister John Curtin announced tonight the War Cabinet's decision to implement far-reaching measures designed to accelerate the marshaling of the national resources behind the war effort, involving intensified direction of labor and industry, stricter control of prices, profits, investments, wages and interest rates.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- Japanese shock troops swarmed toward the city of Singapore from three directions today, and some military experts predicted that the battle for this island fortress might be over by tomorrow noon.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 10 -- In an effort to dissociate the Spanish colony in Mexico from the pro-Axis Spanish Falange, six members of the Spanish community here constituting the "committee of defense of the colony" issued a statement today urging the Spaniards here to place themselves at the service of Mexico and be on guard against "pernicious propaganda."

All of the principal securities and commodity markets in the United States will be closed tomorrow in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. The New Orleans Cotton Exchange states that it will be closed tomorrow "as a war measure," following the procedure adopted last year, when the exchange was closed on Feb. 12 for the first time in many years.

The annual steel ingot producing capacity of the United States increased 4,418,000 net tons in 1941 to a new record of 88,570,000, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The increase since the beginning of 1940 amounted to 6,950,000 net tons.
I should like to call to your attention an error in your definition of Second Reserve nurses which appeared in your editorial "Wanted, More Nurses."

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Grains and soy beans, after dipping sharply in the early trading on scattered liquidation induced by easiness in cotton and securities, rallied rapidly late in the session on the announcement that the Senate Agricultural Committee had adopted a bill seeking to prohibit sales of government-owned stocks at less than parity prices.

Leon Henderson, the Price Administrator, is to be congratulated on his politically courageous statement yesterday to the National War Labor Board advising that body to rule against general, "substantial" wage increase demands by union labor, because of their inflationary influence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- Sam Wood was signed today by Warner Brothers to a three-year contract under which he will direct one picture a year and reportedly participate in profits. His first assignment will be the screen version of Emlyn William's play, "The Corn Is Green," which Warners bought a year ago, and which Hal Wallis will produce.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Appointment of Colonel Bernard Lentz, originator of the widely used Lentz system of cadenced calling of military drill orders, as commander of Fort Slocum, the depot here for soldiers going overseas, was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- Deems Taylor's batting average as a composer of operas could hardly be improved. He has written three operas, and has had them all performed. The first two -- "The King's Henchman" and "Peter Ibbetson" -- were done at the Metropolitan Opera House.

A fashion revue, entitled "Hope for Spring" will be held during the luncheon hour next Tuesday at the Stork Club under the auspices of the Committee of French-American Wives. The funds realized will further the work of the committee, organized in November, 1939, in purchasing food and clothing for distribution among French civilians evacuated from Occupied France.

Today is the ninety-fifth anniversary of the birth of the late Thomas Alva Edison, famous inventor. In accordance with President Roosevelt's recent proclamation, the anniversary will be marked here and in many other parts of the country.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Four Air Corps cadets crashed to their deaths and a fifth parachuted to safety after a group of training planes encountered a blinding rainstorm near Hachita, N.M., last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Warned by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, against the granting of "substantial" pay increases, the National War Labor Board this week will consider its future wage policy in the face of C.I.O. demands for an increase of $1 a day in two war industries.

The question whether opera should be presented here in English or in the language of the composer was debated last night before members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild at the Metropolitan Opera House. The audience then voted on the issue.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The news from Singapore caused a general weakening of prices on the stock markets today, but apart from the rubbers and chain store shares the selling was not heavy.

The New York Giants now have two pitching Hubbells. John, young right-handed brother of the famous Meal Ticket, has sent in his signed contract, Secretary Eddie Brannick announced yesterday -- but without any predictions.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's communique last night said Russian troops had continued to carry out offensive operations and had advanced to capture "a number of populated points." Four German planes were reported brought down.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Roosevelt accepted the resignation of Mayor La Guardia as Director of Civilian Defense and announced that James M. Landis would succeed him. He held a conference with the press, talked with his party leaders from Capitol Hill, and had as callers Dr. Arthur De Souza Costa, Brazilian Minister of Finance; Dr. Carlos Martins, Brazilian Ambassador; Dr. Louis Bloch and Leland Harrison, Minister to Switzerland, and Mrs. Harrison.

One day ahead of time and on Friday the Thirteenth the Booksellers League of New York will hold a Valentine party at the Hotel Brevoort. Among the guests will be Carl Carmer, Fannie Hurst, Oscar Levant, Clare Leighton and Ilka Chase, all of whom will either say a few words or sing, "depending on their Valentine spirits."

Weather information that exceeds in detail the meteorological data that the Navy Department ruled could be of service to enemy submarines has been broadcast at frequent intervals by the radio stations of the commercial airlines in the United States and Canada, it became known yesterday.

Out-of-town buyers arriving in the market last week numbered 1,318, compared with 1,132 in the preceding week and 1,184 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 452, against 627 for last Tuesday.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday rejected the suggestion of Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Adjutant General, that he was trying to create "a little private army" in the guise of a city guard, and informed the State official that his purpose was merely to establish an "auxiliary police."

Textile selling agents, converters and buyers, who have been wrestling with the problem of how to meet government and civilian needs, were told yesterday that "you haven't seen anything yet" in the way of priorities, and that "every item that uses critical materials will simply pass out of the picture unless it is for direct war production or essential civilian use."

TOKYO, Feb. 10 (From Japanese broadcasts) -- Thousands of leaflets signed by Lieut. Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita were scattered over Singapore today. They demanded the surrender of that stronghold and declared that "the Japanese forces desire to refrain from seeing the city reduced to ashes."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Representative McKeough, Illinois Democrat, today denounced an editorial appearing in The Chicago Tribune, and charged the publisher of the paper, Colonel Robert R. McCormick, with treason.

BATASA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Japanese troops have begun landing in Southwestern Celebes near Macassar, key port lying 500 bomber miles from Surabaya, main United Nations naval base, in a steady pincers movement against the Java stronghold, it was announced officially tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 10 (AP) -Prime ]Plinister John Curtin announced in Canberra today that the War Cabinet had decided to call up additional men for full-time army duty to meet the general deterioration of the Pacific situation, especially the Japanese invasion of Singapore Island.

Louise Doschek, young Pittsburgh pianist, who as Mary Paff appeared here last season in a sonata recital with her husband, Anton Doschek, violinist, yesterday afternoon gave her first New York solo recital at Town Hall. Her program consisted of Brahms's Sonata, Op. 5; Ravel's Gaspard de la Nuit, a Chopin group, and Debussy's suite Pour Le Piano.

In wartime even the line of American diplomacy must follow the curve of American production. Our power to influence policy depends as much as the military effort itself on our capacity to turn out armament. That is to say, that the supply line dominates everything else at this stage of the world struggle.

There may be, as an old advertising slogan declares, men who would walk a mile for a certain brand of cigarette, but we have had telephone calls from a score of gun cranks who insist they would cover several miles on their hands and knees providing they could buy a thousand or so primers at the end of the crawl.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, has warned Congressional leaders that the security of the nation's sea coasts is being risked by delay in enacting legislation to create a women's Army auxiliary corps.

If the attitude of the boys and girls in the sixth grade of one public school in the metropolitan area is any criterion -- and the men of at least one anti-aircraft battery sta tioned near the school think it is -- the spirit of young Americans is one of absolute confidence in the Army and gratitude for the sacrifices it will make in the country's defense.

The news from every point on the long front that reaches from Burma to the islands of the South Seas shows clearly that the war in the Pacific is approaching an immense crisis. Under heavy Japanese attack, the position of Singapore is tragic. From Washington we are warned that worse news from the Philippines must be expected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Establishment of a man-power organization to deal with allocation of laborers for farms, factories and other vital productive facilities is under consideration by President Roosevelt.
VICHY, France, Feb. 10 -- The loss of the Normandie, France's blue ribbon liner of the Atlantic, came today as another great shock to French pride, which has already suffered so much.

European reports indicated last night that secret conferences were going on among the top leaders of France, Spain and Portugal, possibly foreshadowing some major war development in the Western Mediterranean.

It is not invidious, and it is not disparagement of other excellent effort, to say that when we heard Arturo Toscanini conduct the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall we heard that great orchestra play with a transparency and beauty of tone, a significance and also a fusion of the individual parts which lent a new sensibility to the playing and a fresh, significance to the music.

ALBANY, Feb. 10, Governor Lehman, addressing the State League of Women Voters at a luncheon here today, denounced complacency about the war as a threat to victory. This war, he said, will be no "push-over." Those who think so are merely deluding themselves.

After shuttling from one playhouse to another off Broadway showing its wares, an intrepid group called the American Youth Theatre enters the Broadway area tonight with the topical revue, "Of V We Sing," opening at the Concert Theatre, 202 West Fifty-eighth Street.

Anonymous donors have contributed $4,000 for fellowships in the newly-established Research Center for European Federation at New York University's Graduate School of Arts and Science, Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university, announced yesterday.

While the fire-ravaged liner Normandie lay grotesquely on her side in her West Forty-eighth Street slip yesterday, naval authorities remained non-committal on the one question everybody was asking: Can she be salvaged?

In Madison Square Garden at 9 A.M. today the Westminster Kennel Club will open its sixty-sixth annual all-breed dog show, which will continue through tomorrow night. On the benches in the basement there will be exhibited 2,388 noted pure-bred dogs from all parts of the United States and Canada.
BETHEL, Alaska, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Nat Browne, veteran flier, is five days overdue on a flight from Marshall to Nome with Deputy Marshal O'Leary and two prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Telegrams of endorsement of the project for creating a Jewish military force, based on Palestine, have come to Senator Wagner, chairman of the American Palestine Committee, from 200 prominent Americans since events in Libya took a turn adverse to the British.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company ended 1941 with $25,433,226,148 of life insurance in force, according to its annual report published yesterday. Accident and health insurance providing $1,634,617,475 principal sum benefits and $25,997,024 weekly benefits added to the protection given to more than 29,400,000 policyholders in the United States and Canada, according to the report, signed by Frederck H. Ecker, chairman, and Leroy A. Lincoln, president.

The twenty-three physicians and surgeons deemed to have contributed most toward the creation of Polyclinic Hospital were honored yesterday when their portraits were unveiled in the faculty room of the hospital, 341 West Fiftieth Street.
Active leasing of business space in buildings on Fifth Avenue was reported by brokers yesterday. In some other sections of Manhattan commercial space also was said to be in brisk demand.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 10 -- All French diplomatic missions abroad have been warned by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Secretary of State Jacques Benoist-Mechin under strong pressure from Germany to rid the Vichy Government of all diplomats and service attaches suspected of pro-Allied or anti-Nazi sentiments, according to reports circulating in high foreign diplomatic quarters in the Turkish capital tonight.

A tentative decision to reject various suggestions for divorcing Tammany Hall, the political organization, from the Tammany Society, a patriotic group, was reached last evening at an informal meeting of the political group's executive committee.
New cases of scarlet fever among New York children continued their month-long increase last week Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 -- United States naval forces have established a trans-Pacific supply terminus at Wellington, New Zealand, after having convoyed sizable contingents of American service men to way-station islands along the route, it was reported today to The Christian Science Monitor.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 10 -- An Australian Army communique today announced that the Japanese landed yesterday at Gasmata, a port of a considerable plantation area on the south coast of New Britain, and in Papua, the mandated territory on New Guinea.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The prayer used by the British in their bomb-shelters was used to open the session of the State Assembly this morning. The Rev. William E. Sprenger, former Chaplain of the Assembly, but now attached to the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, delivered it.

The melancholy gentleman in the greeting-cards shop opposite the Fifth Avenue Library confided yesterday that the trade was caught short on servicemen's valentines. Greeting cards, he explained, are made up eighteen months in advance of a holiday or any special event, but the trade couldn't anticipate a war.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- A drive for the restoration of full State aid for education, based on the increased burdens put on the schools during the war emergency, was one feature of the annual budget hearing held today before the Joint Taxation and Finance Committees of the Senate and Assembly.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Taking a leaf out of the United States' book, Prime Minister Churchill, in naming Lord Beaverbrook Minister of War Production, has placed him in a position similar to that held by Donald M. Nelson:

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, the most powerful Chinese of modern times, launched today a personal campaign to swing India into a 100 per cent war effort against Japan as the common enemy of all continental Asia.

Two Broadway theatres will present new film offerings today. At Loew's Criterion Republic's "Lady for a Night," starring Joan Blondell and John Wayne, will be the new attraction. Featured in the drama, which is laid in the post-Civil War South, are Ray Middleton, Philip Merivale, Blanche Yurka, Edith Barrett, Leonid Kinskey and Carmel Myers. . . .
ROME, Feb. 10 (from Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 10 -- Out of a total population of 11,500,000, 422,000 Canadians have enlisted in the army, the navy and the air force for service anywhere, Colonel J.L. Ralston, Minister of Defense, stated in Parliament today. He added that by March, 1943, it is planned to have a total armed force of between 595,000 and 615,000 men.
More families in the United States are keeping their life insurance in force than at any time since 1920, according to figures released yesterday by the Institute of Life Insurance.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10 -- O1ympus and Dispose, two horses that had seemed cut out for the top flight, won at Hialeah Park today in very fast time, each as something of a surprise, to the jubilation of their admirers.
HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 10 (From Finnish broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- The Screen Actors' Guild defended the appointment of Melvyn Douglas to a civilian defense office position today and protested against congressional criticism of the role of actors in the war effort.

Tony Zale of Gary, Ind., world middleweight champion, yesterday concluded hard training for his twelve-round non-title battle with Billy Conn of Pittsburgh, former light-heavyweight ruler, in Madison Square Garden Friday night.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 10 -- A joker in the "definitive settlement" of German-Norwegian relations scheduled to occur this week with a declaration by Major Vidkun Quisling that "a state of war no longer exists between Norway and Germany," has just been discovered.

Two Sackett Graduate Scholarships, given annually to students doing outstanding work in the law of libel, are included in awards for scholastic achievement granted to twenty-five members of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, it was announced yesterday at the university.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Commerce Department research specialists estimated today that if the high 1942 war output goals set by the President are realized, production for military purposes in the United States will be about 53 per cent of our aggregate industrial production this year as compared with 21 per cent last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Ceiling prices expressed in "dollars per dozen" maxima which manufacturers may charge for women's nylon stockings, and which forbid wholesalers to add more than 10 per cent to the manufacturers' maxima, were established today by the Office of Price Administration.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

Mrs. Emma Van Courtren, 59 years old, the mother of twelve children -- nine sons and three daughters -- who had brooded since Dec. 7 because two of her sons were on duty with the Navy at Pearl Harbor, was reported yesterday at Police Headquarters as missing from her home at 2258 Grand Avenue, the Bronx.

War efforts of Mr. Mackenzie King's Government do not satisfy the Conservatives; much less dissenting Liberals like Mr. Hepburn, Premier of Ontario. Again their cry is for a National Government, with posts for the dissenters and opponents, and a "total" instead of Mr. King's war.

Modification of the Federal Trade Commission order on the use of French trade names or trade marks as applied to perfumes, as required by the recent decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, clarifies considerably the law governing the use of these terms, Hugo Mock, counsel for the Toilet Goods Association, advised members in a special bulletin yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- The Red Army today reported continued advances on widely separated fronts in battles increasing in size and intensity as the Germans bring up more reserves to reinforce their stubbornly defended lines.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Demands that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt quit the Office of Civilian Defense arose in Congress today.

The advice "Put Your Scrap into the Big Scrap," circulated nationwide by the Wastepaper Conservation Commission, is being closely followed by the American housewife. The commission announced yesterday that a record in wastepaper conservation was established in January with the collection of almost five pounds of paper for every person in the country.

Stewart (Snuffy) McIlvennan, varsity fullback on the Columbia eleven last Fall, last night was named the winner of the Class of 1913 Football Cup, an award which goes annually to the member of the football squad who achieves the highest scholastic grades during the Fall semester.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 (AP) -- An R.A.F. communique today said:

HONOLULU, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- Army authorities here said today that twenty-four persons were missing and thirty-six had been rescued from the United States Army transport Royal T. Frank, which was sunk in the Hawaiian area on Jan. 28 by a torpedo from an enemy submarine.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- international cartel of French and German industrialists was reliably reported today to have started organizing a new campaign for a negotiated peace between Germany and the United Nations on business grounds.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 10 -- British troops smashed tonight at a small enemy force north of Martaban. Their commanders declined comment on an enemy claim that that city had fallen.

The Ritz-Carlton witnessed strange sights yesterday noon in the Oval Room, at the luncheon hour: A blackout with three young girls luminous with phosphorescent paint doing daily setting-up exercises; a young man in shorts swinging an air raid warden's pails in dance rhythm and maidens with expressionless masked faces gingerly gliding down the runway.

The Staten Island Rapid Transit Company, submitting yesterday to the Transit Commission figures in support of an application for a rise of 10 per cent in commutation rates, declared that in 1941 the company had a deficit of $734,562. The railroad's total revenue of $1,790,332 included $841,215 from 8,850,995 passengers, of whom 37.6 per cent had commutation books, witnesses for the company said.

Bobby Ruffin, Astoria lightweight, scored a technical knockout over Charlie Varre of Brooklyn last night in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round feature bout before 3,500 at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx.

John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, former member of the Securities and Exchange Commission and chairman of the 1942 drive of the Greater New York Fund, was elected yesterday a director of three companies in the Tri-Continental group: Tri-Continental Corporation, Selected Industries, Inc., and General Shareholdings Corporation.

The entire active organization of the Manufacturers Trust Company, consisting of all directors, 317 officers and 2,932 staff members, has agreed to participate in a payroll deduction plan for the purchase of defense savings bonds, it was announced yesterday by Harvey D. Gibson, president of the bank.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Compensation for civilians who may be killed or injured as a result of enemy attack would be provided by the government under a measure introduced in the Senate today by Senator Pepper of Florida. Payments would be on various scales, with special provision for persons at work in defense industries.

Contributions amounting to $52,000,000 -- the nation's response to the appeal of the Red Cross for a war fund of $65,000,000 -- demonstrate the unity of this country, S. Sloan Colt, national chairman of the drive, declared yesterday at a report meeting of the women's special gifts committee of the Greater New York campaign for $7,330,000 in the Hotel Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. George F. Baker, chairman of the woman's committee, presided.

George Sessions Perry, a tall, soft-voiced Texan who has successfully marketed his writing to magazines but whose two published novels have fallen considerably short of the best-seller lists, received yesterday the National Book Award for 1941 -- a sort of consolation prize that the booksellers hope will draw attention to his work.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Cincinnati's trainless railroad still piles up the profits. Cincinnati leases the tracks of its Cincinnati Southern Railway to the Cincinnati, New Orleans Texas Pacific Railway Company, a subsidiary of the Southern Railway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- After a second "indignation meeting" over the government's announced policy of keeping farm prices at or below parity in spite of the permissible 110 per cent of parity prices provided by the new Price Control Law, the Senate Agriculture Committee today unanimously reported a bill prohibiting sale of government stocks of cotton, wheat, corn and other products at less than parity levels.

It is not really a conclusive answer to say that foremost in any attack on the Administration are the Administration haters. The answer is certainly not enough if hate is made a synonym for opposition, and if every critic or opponent becomes ipso facto a hater.

In this war there are just two kinds of people: friends or adherents of the Axis, and friends or adherents of the United Nations. This fact applies to aliens in this country. If they are our friends, we need their help and they need our help. If they are enemies, they must be forcibly restrained; and if we cannot be certain what they are, they must be watched and their movements restricted.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Jacob Epstein, the sculptor, unveiled another mighty creation today -- a four-ton, seven-foot-high group depicting the struggle between Jacob and the angel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- American Export Airlines, which vainly besought Congress last year to grant a mail subsidy for an air service to Lisbon in competition with Pan-American Airways, received today a temporary certificate from the Civil Aeronautics Board for operation of an airline from New York to Foynes, in Eire.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 10 -- Foreign diplomatic circles in Ankara were apprehensive tonight over persistent rumors circulated by high Axis sources and Turkish official and private quarters alleging that the British in Syria and Iraq and British and Soviet military authorities in Iran are concentrating fresh troops upon these three Turkish frontiers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Grinning broadly, President Roosevelt disclosed today that much-criticized legislation for pensioning members of Congress also made it possible for him to receive a pension of $37,500 annually for life by paying only a few dollars during the next three years of his term.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, expressed confidence after a conference today with Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, that his government could justify itself against charges that it had been giving aid to the Axis forces in Libya.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Panicky buying by consumers is speeding the day when the rationing of tea will be mandatory in the United States, according to officials of the War Production Board and of the Office of Price Administration in statements today.

A prediction by the Office of Price Administration that President Roosevelt would veto any new Congressional legislation to restrict sales of commodities by the government checked a recovery movement in the cotton market yesterday and induced a sell-off in which prices retreated to the low levels which had been touched earlier in the session.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 10 -- Melvyn Douglas, who has been the object of Congressional criticism, today telegraphed a statement to his agent, Phil Berg, in connection with his return to Hollywood Friday to begin work in a new picture.

Captain Willard Reed Jr., son of Mrs. Ferdinanda Reed, part owner of The Daily Worker, was killed recently in the fighting on the Pacific front, where he was the pilot of a Marine Corps bomber, according to word received here yesterday by his mother-in-law, Mrs. McAdoo Taylor of 410 Park Avenue.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 10 -- The spotlight of world attention today was focused sharply on the bitter Battle of Singapore. The stakes are high and the Japanese know it, for which reason they have thrown everything they have into the battle.

IT'S fine country up the west shore of the Hudson around Newburgh, New Windsor and Cornwall. It's fine country farther back in Orange County, too -- altogether about as fine as any to be found anywhere within fifty or sixty miles of the New York skyline.

Industrial advertisers spent on the average 2.01 per cent of their 1941 gross sales for advertising as against 2.07 per cent in 1940, according to a "National Survey of Industrial Advertising Budgets," made by the National Industrial Advertisers Association. The ratio spent for selling amounted to 10.65 per cent last year as compared with 11.46 in the previous year.
BERLIN, Feb. 10 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's communique from the German High Command follows:

A contract for the erection of 5,000 prefabricated demountable homes to be completed in five months for personnel of the Portsmouth, Va., Navy Yard has been awarded to Barrett Hilp, contractors, of San Francisco, by the Federal Works Agency, according to F. Vaux Wilson Jr., vice president of the Homasote Company, manufacturers of prefabricated housing, whose product will be used for the project.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that production of oranges for the current (1941-42) marketing season is estimated at 84,414,000 boxes, compared with 84,726,000 a month ago, 84,082,000 the previous season, 75,667,000 two years ago, and 60,283,000, the average of the ten previous seasons.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Feb. 10 -- The Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, was elected Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Long Island diocese tonight on the fifteenth ballot taken at a special convention of the diocese.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Claims for $908,628 for services and expenses in connection with the reorganization of the Wabash Railroad were cut virtually in half today by Federal Judge Charles B. Davis, who allowed $481,878 to sixty law firms, banks and bondholders' committees.

The Federal authorities began yesterday to deliver alien enemy identification booklets to those who had applied for them on Monday, but both in Manhattan and in Brooklyn the postmasters were disappointed in the number of aliens making application.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Artillery, once called the "King of Battles," was still playing a major role yesterday in the Winter war in Russia as the Red Army battered at the German salient of Rzhev.

KWEILIN, Kwangsi Province, China, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Chinese Christian refugees from Japanese-occupied Hong Kong reported today that American missionaries trapped there when the war broke out in the Pacific were interned in the former British Crown Colony.

Fordham's varsity basketball team had easy sailing against the soldier quintet from Fort Monmouth last night in the Maroon gymnasium. Never behind at any stage, the Rams held a 36-21 edge at half-time. The final gun found Fordham on top, 76 -- 53.

Mr. and Mrs. John M. Morehead gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Lispenard Seabury Crocker, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Savage Crocker, whose marriage to Marshall Green of Washington will take place here on Saturday in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Roosevelt notified all Federal departments and agencies today that he had adopted a uniform policy on draft deferment of Federal officials and employes.

Officials of the State of Maryland received yesterday eighteen bids for an issue of $522,000 of general obligation certificates of indebtedness. The securities were awarded to Clark, Dodge Co. on a bid of 100.45 for 1 1/4s. The certificates, dated Jan. 15, 1942, will mature from Jan. 15, 1950 to 1957.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 10 -- Germany's acute shortage of man power, raw materials and transport -- all of which have been ear-marked for an "all out" effort in preparation for the forthcoming Spring offensive -- has led to the cancellation of all trade fairs throughout "Greater Germany" for 1942, it was learned here tonight.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Treasury officials will likely be surprised at the extent to which American wage-earners are willing to accept pay deductions for the purchase of Defense Bonds.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Miss Georgia Tainter of Fargo, N.D., and Miss Grace Amory of Palm Beach, the co-favorites, advanced in the Palm Beach annual women's golf tournament today, but another highly rated player, Miss Nancy McClave of Maplewood, N.J., bowed out in the first round.

The 133d anniversary of the birth of President Abraham Lincoln, humble rail splitter who led the United States through the perils of a great war, will be celebrated tomorrow here and in many other parts of a nation sobered by the trials of a gigantic struggle with powerful foes.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Boston's famous Krauts; making their last appearance as Bruins for the duration of the war, went on a scoring rampage tonight whfie the Stanley Cup champions were overwhelming the Montreal Canadiens, 8 -- 1, before a hockey crowd of 10,420 at the Garden.

Mrs. David Wagstaff of Tuxedo Park gave a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria for women participating in the Sixty-sixth annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club as judges, stewards, officials and members of various Red Cross committees assisting the Dog Show Committee.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 10 -- At any time in the more or less distant future the financial factor may dominate the situation in France and overshadow all other considerations, even those of "collaboration" with Germany, it was believed here today.

Noting that bad debts constitute a considerable item in the returns of many taxpayers, the Bureau of Internal Revenue pointed out yesterday that they may be treated in either of two ways in Federal income tax returns. They may be deducted from gross income in respect to debts found to he wholly or partly worthless and charged, or by a deduction of a reasonable addition to a reserve for bad debts.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Democracy is not "a free lunch counter" releasing its beneficiaries from responsibilities and restrictions, visitors to Cornell's Farm and Home Week here were told today by Mark L. Entorf, psychiatrist and extension professor of the New York State College of Home Economics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York relinquished direction today of the much-criticized Office of Civilian Defense, and told President Roosevelt that he awaited "any order from you to serve in any capacity for the defense of our country."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The War Department awarded the Distinguished Service Medal today to Staff Sergeant Joseph L. Lockard, who reported hearing airplanes approaching Pearl Harbor on the morning of Dec. 7, but whose warning was disregarded by his superior officer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The War Department today issued the following communique, based on reports received up to noon:

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 10 -- Notable gifts of prints and sculpture from the art collection of Mr. and Mrs. Felix M. Warburg of New York have been made to Vassar College, presented in memory of the late Felix M. Warburg by his wife and children.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate $5,430,000,000 in cash to augment the lease-lend program by which the United States is to aid the Allies.
One of the most important deals of the year involving Manhattan residential property has just been consummated on the crest of Lenox Hill.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 10 (AP) -- An American ship rescued all 120 passengers and crew -- including some United States women and children -- found adrift in lifeboats after their vessel had been shelled and sunk by the enemy, it was learned today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 -- Mrs. Julian Stuart Jones, who is at Brazilian Court, gave a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club for Mrs. W. Howard Hamilton of Baltimore.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 10 -- A group of United States destroyers was credited by authoritative sources today with delivering the main setback to the Japanese naval and troop expedition in a daring action in the Strait of Macassar during the running battle of Jan. 23-26.

I wish to bring to your attention a situation existing today which I believe has been overlooked by the civil service authorities. This problem is greatly accentuated by the fact that at present these officials of both the city and State make provision for competitive civil service examinations at the various military camps of draftees who are unable to be present at the regular places.

The twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers opened with a preview last evening in the new National Academy Building at 1083 Fifth Avenue. The exhibition opens to the public today and will remain current until the end of the month.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10 -- Mrs. Julian Stuart Jones, who is at Brazilian Court, gave a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club for Mrs. W. Howard Hamilton of Baltimore.

The output of magnesium, an essential war mineral for the manufacture of planes and incendiary bombs, has been increased sixty-fold since 1939, and will reach a hundred-fold production in 1943, with yields sufficient to carry out the Victory program, it was reported yesterday before the 156th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Socities Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 10 -- Fernando de Noronha, Brazilian island situated 260 miles off the South American Continent, changed its political status yesterday and became a dependency of the Federal government.

The twenty-sixth annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers opened with a preview last evening in the new National Academy Building at 1083 Fifth Avenue. The exhibition opens to the public today and will remain current until the end of the month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 -- Raids which took an army of Federal agents and police through the rich lettuce-growing Salinas Valley and into Japanese colonies throughout the Monterey Bay district, eighty miles south of San Francisco, led today to the arrest of a group of Japanese aliens and seizure of a truckload of arms and ammunition, besides great quantities of other contraband.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Roosevelt declared today that the first objective in the major strategy of the United Nations is to prevent a break-through by the Axis powers, and wage a war of attrition, destroying as much as possible of the enemy's forces while awaiting the day when the United States and her associates will have the overwhelming superiority necessary for ultimate victory.

The annual report of the F.W. Woolworth Company and its Canadian subsidiary, announced yesterday, shows a net profit for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1941, of $26,114,372 after Federal income and excess profits taxes. It is equal to $269 a share on the 9,703,608 shares of $10-par stock, excluding 46,392 treasury shares. This compares with the 1940 net profit of $24,104,815, or $2.48 a share.

The output of magnesium, an essential war mineral for the manufacture of planes and incendiary bombs, has been increased sixty-fold since 1939, and will reach a hundred-fold production in 1943, with yields sufficient to carry out the Victory program, it was reported yesterday before the 156th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Socities Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 10 -- Fernando de Noronha, Brazilian island situated 260 miles off the South American Continent, changed its political status yesterday and became a dependency of the Federal government.
A NAVAL AIR PATROL STATION, Feb. 11 -- I went flying with the Navy's new airship patrol that is hunting down submarines off the coasts.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 -- Exeter Academy's hockey team won easily from Andover today at the Skating Club rink, 5 to 1. The New Hampshire team forced the action all the way, leading by 4 to 0 before Andover made its point against a second-string goalkeeper.

A net profit of $5,062,709 was reported yesterday by the Allegheny-Ludlum Steel Corporation in a preliminary statement for the ended on Dec. 31, 1941. This year is after provision of $9,700,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 11 -- Great battles are in progress on the Smolensk and Lake Ilmen fronts, according to information reaching Stockholm from Berlin today. That German losses have been heavy is indirectly admitted by Berlin's mention of a Spanish ski unit of 205 men that was reduced to thirty-four during an engagement.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies Thursday, Feb. 12 -- The eastern front in the Indies was extended to the southwest peninsula of Celebes Island yesterday, but a Japanese air fleet trying to reach the main naval base of Surabaya was broken up by Netherland fighters over the Java Sea.

The more money turned over to the Navy Relief Society, the fewer the ships that will turn over in New York harbor, George Jessel, chairman of the society's entertainment committee, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the labor division of the society at the Hotel Astor.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11 -- Heavy fighting about Leningrad and in the southern sectors was indicated in today's reports of the Red Army's advance, while progress toward White Russia also was reported on the central front, where German forces were sharply engaged in several towns and villages.

Colonel Egmont F. Koenig, intelligence officer of the Army Air Forces in the Atlantic Coast area, and Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, an associate Professor of Law at Columbia on leave of absence, will be the principal speakers today at the thirty-fifth annual Columbia University Alumni Day luncheon.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 12 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- Dispatches said that Japanese troops started "their direct offensive against British troops in the city of Singapore" at 10 A.M. today, Singapore time [10:40 P.M. Wednesday, Eastern War Time] "Before the attack handbills were distributed to the people, urging them to take shelter," it was reported.

The virtual removal of nylon from the civilian market was indicated last night when E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. issued a brief statement announcing that nylon would no longer be sold on contract, but would be offered on a spot basis (if and when it is available).

Elsie Houston was the soloist last night in Town Hall at the sixth event in this season's Town Hall Endowment Series. The Brazilian soprano bravely agreed on short notice to appear in place of Grace Moore, who was indisposed. The program could hardly have been more engaging had the gifted artist spent months devising it, and its offerings were delivered with rare fascination.

TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- At the request of Governor Charles Edison, the Legislature, which recessed on Monday until March 9, will return next Monday, but it was uncertain tonight what the Republican majority might do to help him end confusion in the State's civilian defense effort.

OTTAWA, Feb. 11 -- The quoted statements of Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario that the United States Fleet was "in hiding" brought a sharp rebuke today in the Canadian House of Commons from Navy Minister Angus L. MacDonald.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation is expected to file today or tomorrow with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement which was filed late last year, in which drastic revision in its proposed financing program will be outlined.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- In its first decision the War Labor Board ruled today that the attitude adopted by Federated Fishing Boats of New England and New York, Inc., toward government arbitration of a labor dispute was "defiant and adamant" and lacking in "appreciation and understanding of patriotic obligations."
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11 -- Three more French citizens have been shot by the German occupying authority in France, according to reports from Paris. They faced firing squads this morning.

A great deal is currently being done to help finance the war and avoid (bank deposit) inflation by promoting private sales of United States bonds and savings stamps. Why is it that, when outright gifts would accomplish the same purposes even better, nothing is being done to encourage these gifts?

Close-order drill and the manual of arms are less important than many regular academic subjects in preparing high school boys for possible future armed service, according to a report of the Board of Superintendents, made public yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt's visitors included Harold D. Smith, Director of the Budget, and Frederic A. Delano, chairman of the National Planning Commission; Senator George and Ellis Arnall, Attorney General of Georgia; Edward J. Flynn, the Democratic chairman; the Venezuelan Ambassador; Nathan Straus, William C. Bullitt, Alfred M. Landon, Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold and Secretary Stimson and General George C. Marshall.

Three new films will open in Broadway theatres today. "Captains of the Clouds," the Warner drama dealing with the R.C.A.F. and starring James Cagney, will have its world premiere tonight at the Strand. The Technicolor aviation adventure was directed by Michael Curtiz and includes Brenda Marshall, Dennis Morgan, Alan Hale, George Tobias, Reginald Denny and Reginald Gardiner among its featured players.

A practical demonstration of the amount of attention an espionage suspect may expect from the Federal Bureau of Investigation was given in Federal court yesterday at the trial of Kurt Frederick Ludwig and six others accused of spying out American defense secrets for Hitler.

Private Abraham Weissman, of an infantry regiment stationed in the South, appeared in General Sessions Court yesterday to tell how while on a furlough here last June he recognized a man who had robbed him of a $1,371 payroll which he was carrying to the Pinking Shears Corporation at 102 Prince Street four and a half years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- More than 3,311,000,000 pounds of agricultural commodities valued at more than $367,000,000 were delivered to the British Government for lease-lend shipment between April, 1941, and Jan. 1, 1942, according to a statement by the Department of Agriculture.

Though far distant from the front line, the British in South America are doing their share in the war effort, and, proportionate to their numbers, it is a large share. The sons have for the most part left to join the forces in England and Canada, while the daughters have gone to England for hospital work or to Trinidad in the censorship service.

The volume of bankers' dollar acceptances and of commercial paper outstanding continued to gain in January, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday, but the gains were smaller than is usual at this season.

The railroads are "ahead of the market" in moving oil by train to Eastern refining points, according to the Association of American Railroads. They believe they can "take up the slack" if more enemy action results in depleting the supply of tank ships or even if the operation of these ships ceases as a result of enemy activity off our coasts.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- Singapore's defenders ignored a Japanese demand for unconditional surrender and held on grimly tonight under an incessant rain of bombs and shells, it was announced in a communique from the embattled city.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops today stormed across the Salween River just above Martaban, apparently taking that city, but thirty miles farther north, near Paan, British Imperials turned back the enemy's invasion boats with a withering barrage of gunfire in an all-day battle.

After devoting eighteen months to the preparation of its controversial land-use maps, the City Planning Commission voted yesterday to junk the plan put forward when Rexford G. Tugwell, now Governor of Puerto Rico, was chairman of the commission.

According to a Tokyo dispatch of the German Transocean Agency, recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES last night, members of crews of Japanese aircraft carriers and planes selected for the Dec. 7 attack on Hawaii visited Shinto shrines the day before their departure and swore to their ancestors that "we will beat our enemies or we will never return."

Only a few weeks ago Admiral Thomas C. Hart was named commander in chief of the Allied Naval Forces in the Western Pacific. That he is so soon and suddenly relieved of that command for reasons of ill health does not sound very convincing. Since Pearl Harbor, however, we know little of the movements of the United States fleets in the Pacific except that the Navy has successfully established a sea route to New Zealand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today gifts and sales of securities aggregating millions of dollars at current market prices during December, by so-called "insiders" -- officers, directors and principal owners of corporations.

The annual St. Valentine's kettledrum and bridge party for the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged took place yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Delmonico. A fixture on the Winter social calendar in New York, the kettledrum is one of the city's longest-established charity events, having been given annually since 1873.

Dadour Dadourian, dealer in clothes and general merchandise, has purchased from Deebee, Inc., the seven-story store and loft building on a plot 74 by 94 feet at 41 to 47 Elizabeth Street: The structure has a basement and subbasement and is assessed for $80,000.

During the last war Thomas Alva Edison drew up a plan to keep the United States permanently safe from "predatory nations," which if followed would have found the country better prepared for its present struggle, Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey disclosed yesterday.

Taking its cue from the United States Golf Association, the Metropolitan Golf Association has abandoned its championships for the duration of the war, it was announced yesterday. According to P. James Crowhurst, chairman of the publicity committee, the association will limit its activities to tournaments lasting not more than one day.
William Kohler, secretary and treasurer of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, has leased an apartment in 67 Park Avenue through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 11 -- Preservation by Great Britain and the United States of their war-formed partnership promises the world "an even greater good" than that wrought by Abraham Lincoln in his fight to save the Union, Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to Washington, said tonight in an address broadcast from the High School auditorium.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Felix Powell, composer of one of the most popular songs of the first World War, "Pack Up Your Troubles in Your Old Kit Bag," died yesterday in a hospital in Brighton, Sussex, a few hours after he had been admitted with a gunshot wound in the stomach.

The questions if, how and when the keeled-over liner Normandie can be righted remained officially unanswered yesterday following a general summary of the disaster by the Third Naval District, the spokesman for which disclosed that a special Naval Board of Inquiry would be appointed to study all phases of the fire.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Paramount today bought "Let's Face It," Vinton Freedley's current Broadway show by Herbert and Dorothy Fields and Cole Porter, for $225,000, as a vehicle for Bob Hope. Of the purchase price $100,000 went to Twentieth Century-Fox for screen rights to "Cradle Snatchers," on which the book of "Let's Face It" is based.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Representative Ramspeck today charged with "damagoguery" the critics of his measure for Congressional pensions. Several members had expressed resentment that the bill slipped through the House under a unanimous consent rule.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 11 -- I saw the fleet of eight United States Flying Fortresses take off from a jungle airport near Samarinda, on the eastern coast of Borneo, for their Jan. 4 raid on Japanese warships in Davao Bay, in the south of the Philippine island of Mindanao.

The 1,171 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $59,075,678,533 par value as of Jan. 31, had a total market value of $56,261,398,371, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Dec. 31, there were 1,173 issues, aggregating $58,236,901,332 par value, which had a total market value of $55,033,616,312.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Don Hutson, Green Bay's sensational pass receiver, today was named the National Football League's most valuable player for 1941.

No man in public life ever faced a more nearly unanimous demand than that made upon Mayor La Guardia to give up his work in the Office of Civilian Defense. And now the day has come and passed. The Mayor has come home. Heaven knows we need him.

The four-story apartment house at 149-51 Zabriski Street, in the Heights section of Jersey City, N.J., has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to a client of J.I. Kislak, Inc. There are twenty-five two and three-room suites in the building, which is said to be fully rented, with an annual yield of about $11,000.

Charges that the measures taken for the defense of Singapore were so inadequate that its courageous garrison was foredoomed to defeat reached New York yesterday from Sydney, Australia, in a broadcast by Cecil Brown, radio correspondent.
