WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- A mystery of the disappearance of 6,000 nickels from automobile parking meters in the White Plains business area was believed solved today with the arrest of Patrolman Robert Foster as the alleged pilferer of the coins, according to charges filed in City Court by Police Chief William Miller.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- American troops have been sent to the Netherland islands of Curacao and Aruba in the Caribbean Sea to assist in their defense and to protect vital oil refineries, it was announced tonight by the State Department.

The need for "heroic sanctity" in the light of current events and its achievement through religion were stressed yesterday by the Rev. William E. Orchard, noted Catholic priest of the Diocese of Westminster, England, in the second interfaith luncheon of the Columbia University Conference on Religion in the Modern World.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- James Grayson Luttrell, chairman of the Federal Tea Board in Washington, noting that heavy consumer buying of tea has been draining wholesale stocks in recent weeks, said today that the country's supply on hand was sufficient for five or six months at normal sales volume.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Loss of "untold millions" in exorbitant commission fees for defense brokers was charged today by a House military subcommittee, which disclosed that it already had asked the Department of Justice for action "in all cases where the evidence justified prosecution."

Preparation for a World Congress of Women to be called "whenever and wherever the peace conference is held" was urged yesterday by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt at the first meeting of the Society for a Free and Democratic Europe at Holland House, 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

The most optimistic note sounded yesterday in connection with the question of righting and refloating the Normandie came from Vladimir I. Yourkevitch, Russian-born designer of the 83,423-ton former luxury liner.

Despite the expressed opposition of Selective Service officials to blanket deferments of any kind, forty members of Mayor La Guardia's business advisory committee voted yesterday to ask draft boards to defer city firemen with two or more years' experience from military duty on the ground that they were needed in an essential public service.

Tonight Gilbert Miller will usher into Henry Miller's Theatre his third offering of the season, "Heart of a City," presented by arrangement with T. Hayes Hunter. Written by Lesley Storm (pen name for the Mrs. Lesley Clark, whose "Billy Draws a Horse" was seen here in 1939), "Heart of a City" depicts British fortitude as exemplified backstage in a London music hall during the terrific air blitzes of 1940.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Singapore is gone.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- A symposium on the "Food for Victory Program" was the chief feature of today's Farm and Home Week sessions at Cornell University. Farmers and home makers heard the country's food outlook discussed in relation to nutrition, feed supplies for livestock, and labor and prices.

ATLANTA, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A New York banker today cautioned banks against "offensive merchandising" of their small-loan facilities lest they become associated in the public mind with "high-rate lenders."

When a General Sessions jury yesterday convicted Beatrice de Tavara, 60 years old, the widow of a Spanish count, and William MacDowell, 31, a 6-foot-2 former cowboy, in the beating of James Riley, 60, a process server, near the widow's home at 35 West Sixty-ninth Street last July 18, Judge George L. Donnellan remarked that never before had he heard so much defense perjury in one case.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 11 -- An Australian communique today announced that Japanese four-engined flying boats this morning again bombed Samarai, in Southeastern Papua, New Guinea. The results were not known. The Japanese also made daylight reconnaissance flights over the south coast of Papua.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- Boscobel, the historic Georgian mansion that Westchester County got as an unwanted bonus in a park purchase, was saved for another six months from housewreckers' axes this evening by vote of the County Park Commission.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies ?igkting Services oommuniqu aid today:

New York City's first air raid sirens will be installed today, according to Police Commissioner Valentine, who announced yesterday that a contract for installing five sirens had been awarded to W.E. Blume, Inc., electrical contractors, of 126 Hudson Street, Brooklyn.

Former District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, in commending the aid rendered by the medical and nursing staff of St. Vincent's Hospital during the fire on the liner Normandie, warned yesterday that this city must be prepared for many emergencies if the war is to last "for two or three years."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes, as solid fuels coordinator, appointed today an Industry Committee on Solid Fuels "to advise on the coordination of the nation's fuel supply and to meet war-time needs."

Steel production in January amounted to 7,129,351 net tons, the highest for the month on record, and the fourth largest for any month in the history of the steel industry to date, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Output in January, 1941, was 6,928,085 net tons, the previous January high, while in December, 1941, production was 7,163,999 tons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Admiral Thomas C. Hart today relinquished voluntarily his position as commander of the Allied naval forces in the Southwestern Pacific in favor of Vice Admiral C.E.L. Helfrich of the Royal Netherlands Navy, commander of the Netherlands East Indian Navy.

I was much disturbed when I read in THE TIMES that Mme. Frieda Hempel, former member of the Metropolitan Opera Company, was arrested while leaving food for a homeless dog in Central Park. Possibly the persons who reported her to the police honestly thought her action suspicious, but it seems queer that when there are so many evil doings in the world a simple humanitarian deed should get a woman into custody.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt's "Fireside Chat" to the country on Feb. 23 will not be a political speech and will not be related to the Democratic dinners held that evening to raise funds to pay off party debts and finance the 1942 campaign, Stephen T. Early, White House press secretary, said today.
BABSON PARK, Fla., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Roger W. Babson urged today that surplus cotton, wild rubber from Brazil and tar and naval stores products be used to manufacture automobile tires.

When Japanese planes were on their way to attack Pearl Harbor there was one buck private whose ears were open and whose mind was working. Joe Lockard of the Signal Corps wanted to learn his job thoroughly. So, on the morning of Dec. 7 he stayed after hours listening on an aircraft detector which would otherwise have been shut off.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Prospects increased today that the Legislature might pass a bill barring an increase in the five-cent fare without a referendum by the people of New York City. It seems likely that unless there is a drastic shift in policy, both houses will pass the Dunnigan-Crews bill setting up such a procedure.

A simple white organdy dinner dress covered with a pastel fantasy of tropical prints expressed the keynote of Hawaiian fashions introduced yesterday by The Tailored Woman, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. Costumes designed by Tina Leser featured hand-painted prints inspired by exotic blossoms of the Hawaiian Islands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Income of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for the calendar year 1941 was $62,043,573, the largest in the corporation's history. Leo T. Crowley, chairman, reported today.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 12 -- Imperial troops, scorning a Japanese demand for unconditional surrender but forced back by the weight of the enemy thrust, were fighting bitterly last night with their backs to the gates of the city of Singapore.

Basing their prediction on attendance figures and the enthusiasm exhibited by visitors to the Boston Sportsmen's Show, officials of the exhibition expect a record attendance at the New York exposition, which opens at Grand Central Palace on Feb. 21.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11 -- The leaders of Europe's remaining Latin neutrals, Spain and Portugal, met tonight in Seville for what some diplomatic observers believed was a unified effort to cling to non-belligerency in this Second World War.

Holiday enthusiasts can look forward to a week-end of good skiing, starting today. Reports received from the North Country last night indicated that one of the best periods of recreational sport for skiers this Winter is promised.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11 -- For the duration of the war all Harvard undergraduates, except members of the present senior class or those who may be excused for physical reasons, will be obliged to report for supervised physical training four hours a week, ordinarily in one-hour periods.

The National City Bank of New York and associates received yesterday the official award of the entire $11,000,000 of Milwaukee County, Wis., notes and bonds which were offered for sale on last Monday. The $3,800,000 of corporate purpose notes was awarded on a bid of 100.038 for a rate of 0.60 per cent, and the $7,200,000 of serial bonds on a bid of 100.069 for a coupon rate of 1.40 per cent.

A joint fund to finance an investigation into the possibility of organizing a hand-sewing industry for table linens and other household items in Latin America, to replace the Chinese and other sources now lost to the United States because of the war, was voted yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Linens and Domestics Buyers Club at the Advertising Club.

A knockout triumph over Tony Zale, world middleweight champion, will be the goal of Billy Conn, Pittsburgh's former light-heavyweight titleholder, when they clash tomorrow night in a twelve-round non-title bout in Madison Square Garden.

TRENTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court, dismissing a commuters' suit to upset a Board of Public Utility Commissioners' order allowing the Pennsylvania-Reading seashore lines to discontinue passenger service on three little-used branch lines in South Jersey, cited warnings from Washington that big troop movements made elimination of unnecessary train service vital.

E.E. Aldous was elected yesterday president and a director of the Scully Steel Products Company of Chicago, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation. L.B. Worthington was made vice president and a director, and Charles B. Vernooy, controller, secretary and a director.

To the President's statement that the country is becoming, more and more "realistic" every day about the war situation, there is at least one glaring exception. The Congressional farm bloc is still stubbornly bent on "business as usual." It did its best to destroy the usefulness of the Price-Control Bill.

Dr. Edward P. Kilroe, president of the Metropolitan Jockey Club, announced yesterday that there would be eight stake races during the twenty-seven-day Spring meeting which will open the local turf season at Jamaica on April 9. These races carry a total of $77,500 in added money, an increase of $10,000 over the past season.

Those old rivals, Fordham and N.Y.U., will have it out tonight in a battle for the metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championship at the Coliseum in the Bronx. The Rams, the I.C. 4-A indoor titleholders, and the Violet, the outdoor kingpin as well as the defending metropolitan ruler, are considered the class of the eight competing colleges.

An association of nations for the maintenance of world peace after the war, to which will be admitted only those nations "who have shown themselves capable of self-government and who have a reasonably long record of international honesty," was outlined last night at the dinner of the 156th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The six-story apartment house for 150 families at 1555 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, known as Rockwood Hall, has been sold by a client of Goodman Mabel to a syndicate controlled by S.N. Petchers for cash above a first mortgage of $555,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- An extension of time on the air for WNYC, the New York municipal radio broadcast station, was tentatively refused by the Federal Communications Commission today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Problems confronting the Negroes in Harlem were discussed yesterday at a conference held in the Riverside Church under the auspices of the Women's Division of the Interracial Committee of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

George Willard Smith, president of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, informed policyholders yesterday in the company's ninety-eighth annual report that the 1941 scale of dividends would ge continued through 1942.

The ghost of Abraham Lincoln does not walk in the White House this year or any year. Mr. Lincoln was a constitutional President, as he read the Constitution, and one can imagine him saying in his characteristic way that the people of the United States didn't elect him to administer the Presidency in 1942.

Wives and parents of four of the nation's war heroes stood grimly in spotlights in a darkened ballroom of the Hotel Commodore yesterday and listened to citations of their men by the American Red Cross.
A 63-year-old veteran of three wars returned to active Navy duty at district headquarters at 90 Church Street yesterday following eighteen years of retirement.

In a lecture on "Summer Care of the Vegetable Garden," given yesterday at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, George H. Gillies, head gardener at the Marshall Field estate in Huntington, L.I., placed particular emphasis on the problems of the spare-time amateur gardener, interested this year in growing a small wartime vegetable garden.
James F. Towers has been elected president of Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., of this city, engineers, to succeed William von Phul, who has been appointed chairman of the executive committee.
Surprises marked the first day's competition in the sixty-sixth annual exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club, which opened in Madison Square Garden yesterday morning and will end tonight.

The proposed offering to the public of 2,695,000 shares of common stock of the Union Electric Company of Missouri -- now owned by the North American Company -- will be delayed a few days, if not longer, because of matters of detail on filings and hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was learned last night.

In order to insure filling of all government needs and equitable distribution of pulp among American industries, the War Production Board is now putting the finishing touches on a general pulp allocation order, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Sumner Welles has returned from the Pan-American conference at Rio de Janeiro with his country's praises. But every foot of ground gained by the Japanese in the Far East, every check by the Nazi armies of the Soviet drive in Russia and the British thrust in Libya, hastens the day of the supreme test of the accomplishments of that conference.

In a letter which appeared in THE TIMES of Feb. 7, Edward J. Heffron, executive secretary of the National Council of Catholic Men, makes certain comments on the proceedings of the annual meeting of the Birth Control Federation of America as reported in your columns.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- Though the front-wide Red Army offensive sems to have fallen off in the last ten days, because of both stiffening German resistance and Winter storms, military reports today indicated that the Russians still were pushing on.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- Perhaps significantly, today's announcement of the transfer of the supreme command of United Nations naval forces in the Southwestern Pacific from United States to Netherland hands followed a series of White House conferences last week between President Roosevelt and Lieut. Gov. Hubertus van Mook of the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Board of Economic Warfare, Office of Export Control, issued new licensing rules today to conserve existing supplies of medicines and at the same time remove any possibility of their falling into Axis hands.

Mrs. Alice Hegan Rice deserves to be remembered by more than one book, and her "Mr. Opp," the Kentucky newspaper man, may better please some judges; but "Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch" was so extraordinarily successful as book, play, photoplay, that it overshadowed her other writings.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Chinese troops, striking in Anhwei Province, have recaptured Mengcheng, 150 miles northwest of Nanking, killing 400 Japanese and hurling the invaders southward across the Kwo River, the government announced tonight.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 12 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Domei dispatch from the Singapore front, issued at 6 A.M. today [5 P.M. Wednesday, Eastern War Time], said that Japanese advance units were continuing their penetration of the city of Singapore, "mopping up resistance wherever it is offered."

VICHY, France, Feb. 11 -- Reports of the new bombings in occupied territory recall to observers here that such aggressions for several months have occurred whenever international negotiations reach a stage that it appears as if some change of status is impending, and for some days there have been rumors that some alteration of Franco-German relationship is in view.

The war situation in the Far East precludes any encouragement at this time for the hope that the future supply of woolen fabrics will be large enough to meet civilian needs, because of rigorous conservation of wool for military use, R.R. Guthrie, head of the clothing, textiles and leather division of the War Production Board, warned yesterday.

Crude oil production in the United States last week reached a new high level of 4,336,900 barrels daily, an increase of 465,550 over the 3,871,350 produced in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 235,100 barrels more than the recommendations of 4,101,800 daily for February by the Bureau of Mines.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Steps being taken here to foster education among Europeans who are exiled from their own countries were told by Richard Austen Butler, President of the Board of Education, at a meeting of Ministers of Education of the United Nations.

No loyal American will question either the necessity or the propriety of sugar rationing. He will, however, be justified in demanding that those in charge of the machinery of rationing use a little forethought and be willing to learn from the experience of other countries, where the just distribution of available supplies is an old story.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- West Virginia University defeated Army today at basketball by 57 -- 40. It was the Mountaineers' seventh victory in a row.

Mrs. William F. Carey and Mrs. Edgar Cecil Melledge are cochairmen of the committee in charge of the arrangements for the Mardi Gras to be held on Monday night in the ballroom of the Beekman Tower under the auspices of the Beekman Hill Unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

The solution to the mysterious slaying of Abe Bebchick, Brooklyn policy king alleged to have paid police for protection, was demanded last night by Kings County Judge Samaul S. Leibowitz from a defendant just convicted of first-degree robbery and facing a possible maximum sentence of twenty-to forty years in prison.
Vernon Gomez, southpaw pitcher and airplane expert extraordinary, will be on the Yankee mound staff again this year, he finally assured President Ed Barrow yesterday.

Fordham's swimmers defeated Lehigh University, 39 to 36, yesterday in the Rose Hill pool. The Rams, while taking only four first places to Lehigh's five, managed to win enough second and third places to outscore the visitors from Bethlehem.

More is going up smoke in burning Singapore than a proud white city planted at the crossroads of the earth. More than a stronghold is tottering as Dutch and British ships dodge bombs and submarines to evacuate women and children from the greatest port in the Orient.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The War Production Board ordered tonight drastic reductions in the use of tin for canning, which may man the disappearance from consumers' shelves of many familiar items of canned goods unless manufacturers are able to find substitute containers in sufficient quantities to supply the market.

The printing industry in this city, employing 40,000 persons in printing and allied trades, plans to buy $5,000,000 of defense savings bonds through payroll deduction plans, it was announced yesterday by the New York Defense Savings Staff.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had a two-hour talk today with Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, the powerful Indian leader, and Maulana Abul Katam Azad, president of the All-India Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The House Rules Committee granted a rule today under which a bill to establish the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps could be considered by the House. Leaders said the measure probably would be put on next week's calendar.

New low levels were established again yesterday by the stock market under the weight of the news from Singapore and the recess today in observance of the anniversary of Lincoln's birth. Even though the share list entered the worst territory since April 1, 1938, the shrinkage of values was not so severe as on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The danger of an eventual junction between German and Japanese forces was a subject of diplomatic discussion in Washington today as the imminent fall of Singapore cast deep gloom in the capital, and a high official said that "things are going to be gloomier before they get better."

A drifting lifeboat containing either six or eight dead men was sighted somewhere off the Atlantic Coast on Tuesday afternoon by passengers and officers of a South American steamship, they reported yesterday when the ship docked at a United States port.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11 -- Yale's sextet skated through Williams defense at will tonight to triumph, 13 to 0. The visitors threatened only rarely, the Elis easily checking every thrust. In the first period Bert Martin, Yale goalie, was forced to make only one save.

All men, whether citizens or aliens, 20 to 44 years old, inclusive, must register for Selective Service on Sunday or Monday, between 7 A.M. and 9 P.M., unless they have previously registered or are in the Federal armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The War Production Board is developing a plan for a Spring production drive in industry by which it is hoped to obtain results similar to the British arms-making drive in the weeks after Dunkirk.

Directors of the American Gas and Electric Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 10 cents in addition to the regular quarterly of 40 cents a share on the common stock. A similar extra has been paid in preceding quarters.

The internal revenue code provides for "a reasonable allowance for the exhaustion, wear and tear of property used in the trade or business, including a reasonable allowance for obsolescence," the Bureau of Internal Revenue noted yesterday. Such allowance is usually called depreciation.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service here, revealed yesterday how aliens registering on Sunday and Monday will be classified. He said also that able-bodied physicians, dentists and veterinarians under 45 years of age and unwilling to volunteer for commissions, may be drafted into the ranks because of a shortage of members of these professions in the armed forces.

HONOLULU, Feb. 11 -- The thin pencil marks on the navigator's chart of the Central Pacific didn't look as if they covered much of an area. But before the day was over the Flying Fortress had flown over so much blue water that the observer in the bombardier's bird cage in the nose of the plane had waves dancing before his eyes.

When Dr. Stires last year announced his intention of resigning as Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island it was in the hope of turning his work over to a younger man. The Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, who has now been elected to succeed him, is only 46 years old. Both in vigor and in churchly experience he should prove a happy choice to head the fourth largest diocese in the Episcopal Church.

Americans have overcome the confused thinking and the disruptive influences that divided this nation during the six years before Pearl Harbor, and, while still hating war, today believe wholeheartedly in the war and "will most certainly win it," Archibald MacLeish said last night.

A continuing "run" on wholesale stocks of tea and coffee by retailers seeking to meet heavy buying by consumers was reported in the wholesale grocery trade yesterday. To meet the situation, salesmen's orders are now being "rationed" on the basis of sales made during the corresponding month last year, it was said.

The fall of Singapore would by no means spell the end of Allied resistance in the Western Pacific and one should not assume that it would mean the inevitable fall of Java to the Japanese, Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, declared yesterday.

AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, Feb. 11 (UP) -- A search by air and sea was in progress today for two lifeboats, believed to contain twenty-eight men, still missing from a tanker, torpedoed and sunk off Nova Scotia. Twenty survivors were landed here yesterday, having been rescued by a British freighter after sixty-four hours in a lifeboat.

The Senate has acted promptly on the President's recommendation that Section 7 of the Neutrality Act be suspended for the duration of the war. There is every reason to believe that the House will promptly follow suit. Section 7 still makes it unlawful for any person in the United States to lend money to a foreign Government at war.
Yesterday's warning from Washington on tea hoarding received ample support during the day in a check of New York stores.
BERLIN, Feb. 11 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The text of the German communique follows:
VICHY, France, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Today brought to the occupied zone one of the most drastic anti-Semitic measures yet imposed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Secretary Wickard said today that passage of the farm group bill offered in the Senate yesterday, which for bids the government to sell its surplus stocks of wheat, corn and cotton at less them parity price levels, would cost consumers $1,000,000,000 a year in increased food prices.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A British communique tonight said:

Aside from skeleton staffs in the foreign departments of banks and a few other establishments in the financial district, Wall Street will observe the Lincoln's Birthday holiday today. All of the principal securities and commodity markets throughout the country will be closed, as will be the banks in twenty-eight States, including New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania.

The Spring fashion story at B. Altman Co., as disclosed yesterday at a style show at the Waldorf-Astoria, is divided into two parts. The first is woven around the theme of tailored slacks and suits for comfortable, casual wear; the second, in contrast, stresses femininity in afternoon and evening gowns.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 -- Former Ambassador Hugh Wilson, who discussed "America's Role in the World Crisis" before the Round Table today at the Breakers, was honored at a dinner given at the Beach Club by Arthur Bradley Campbell.

After more than a week-long shutdown because of a shortage of raw sugar, the Edgewater plant of the National Sugar Refining Company will resume operations today. The inventory of raw sugar is still low, however, and it is understood that unless new cargoes arrive soon the plant will have to close again in a couple of days.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

The New York City News Association, one of the world's great news gathering agencies, whose reporters always remained anonymous, passed out of existence at 7 o'clock last night with the announcement that the Associated Press would continue coverage of its territory -- Manhattan, the Bronx and La Guardia Field.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The government rested its case against Miss Laura Ingalls today with testimony that the flier received $300 a month from the German Embassy to campaign for American neutrality, and that an embassy official even tried to get money to her after the United States entered the war.

With the arrival here of three survivors who had been picked up semi-conscious after drifting for two days in an open boat the Navy released news yesterday of the sinking of the 6,182-ton tanker W.L. Steed, owned by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Miss Anna Haney, 52 years old, a wealthy recluse whose frugal wardrobe contained only one spare dress and one pair of shoes, was found dead in her room at a small hotel on South Carolina Avenue late today.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Alexander Saharic, 26 years old, of White House Station, and a young woman tentatively identified as Miss Florence Wilson, 17-year-old Flemington High School student, were killed today in the crash of a rented airplane in which Saharic was reported to have been "stunting.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 11 -- Some New Zealanders share Prime Minister Churchill's view that the presence of Dominion representatives at the empire council table would create serious problems, it is evident from comments made here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Alfred M. Landon, the Republican Presidential nominee of 1936, charged tonight that "the New Dealers are treating the war as just another political alphabetical project" Those he termed the New Dealers he contended, were leading the country toward "totalitarian collectivism," while they and all other Americans should be subordinating partisan considerations to winning the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Allied Van Lines, Inc., of Chicago and some 350 common carriers of household goods by motor truck in various parts of the United States, including New York City, have petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to pool their entire interstate and intercity household goods carrying business.

The Grand Street Boys Association, formed originally for social purposes, enlarged its program of activities last night to meet the war emergency. Bennett E. Siegelstein, chairman of the law committee, announced the following amendments to the association's charter:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Immediate enactment of the $965,000,000 rivers and harbors omnibus bill, now on the House calendar, was urged today by President Roosevelt.

With market sentiment still depressed by the news from the Far East, prices of cotton futures drifted lower yesterday in quiet trading on the New York Cotton Exchange and closed with net losses of 8 to 10 points. Business was limited and the market reacted to small orders on either side.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11 -- Harvard College began extensive revisions today of its system of housing students in a further step to adapt its educational program to wartime conditions.

Support of important members of the national Administration, if it is found impossible to get backing direct from President Roosevelt, is being sought by aspirants for the leadership of Tammany to succeed Christopher D. Sullivan, deposed by a narrow majority of its executive committee last Friday, it became known yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11 -- The increasing importance of German financial interests in the Balkans is revealed by the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung in a survey of banking activity in Southeastern Europe.

WITH THE U.S.A.F.F.E. in the Philippines, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- It's high time for those rip-roaring, death-defying, seldom-sleeping engineers of General Douglas MacArthur's Army, heroes every one, to take a bow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The text of a War Department communique, based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M. Eastern War Time today, follows:

Henry Hudson Bridge, erected at a cost of approximately $2,000,000 for its two levels, is a financial pygmy by the side of a $60,000,000 Triborough Bridge. It is physically a mere child compared with the huge Triborough towers and roadways flung out octopus fashion in every direction and binding together three great boroughs.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The Legislature pushed through today bills to relieve the housing shortage caused by the concentration of airplane factories in the Buffalo area. Governor Lehman signed the measures immediately.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Appointment of a legislative committee to study the advisability of continuing New York City as a separate unit outside of State defense plans was proposed today in a resolution introduced by Senator Robert E. Johnson, Richmond-Rockland Republican.

MONTREAL, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Bands of youths were admonished to vote "no" to conscription for overseas service and urged to start a "peace campaign" at a rally here tonight, and then they fanned out over the city in demonstrations that resulted in injury to at least four policemen and several civilians, and the smashing of thirty windows.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The stock markets opened weak today on the news from Singapore, but later bargain hunting produced a recovery in one or two groups.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Stephen T. Early, White House press secretary, emphasized today that President Roosevelt was speaking "facetiously" when he talked of his new right to claim an annual pension of $37,500 for life by paying only a few dollars a year in the period between now and the end of his term in the White House.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 -- Calls for a solution of the West Coast's Japanese problem through a declaration of martial law grew in volume today, with Earl Warren, California's Attorney General, going on record in favor of this step, at least in a modified form.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 11 -- The imminent fall of Singapore has produced a tremendous impression in Chile, which feels more exposed than any other country in the Americas to the danger of Japanese attack. A general belief prevailed tonight that there was now only a very small chance of Chile's breaking off relations with the Axis until after the inauguration of President-elect Juan Antonio Rios April 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, advised Representative Dies, chairman of the Committee Investigating Un-American Activities, that monitoring of foreign shore-wave broadcasts by FCC staff members in August, September and October disclosed that Representative Dies had received "as many favorable references in Axis propaganda to this country as any living American public figure."

The crack St. Francis basketball forces, still prominent in the race for the metropolitan championship, crushed Brooklyn College in the Terriers' gymnasium last night, 57 to 36, for their eleventh victory in twelve starts. The Franciscans, never behind, coasted to a comfortable 30-13 lead at the half.

Trustees of the Connecticut Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund plan to authorize agencies other than mutual savings banks of the State to sell savings bank life insurance, it was disclosed yesterday. Under the plan, persons in cities having no issuing or agency banks of the system would be able to purchase this type of life insurance from designated credit unions, trust companies, labor groups and teachers' associations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- The grain markets showed a weak undertone in the early trading today. Selling was induced by a break in cotton following announcement by the Office of Price Administration that any legislation designed to prevent sales of government-owned commodities would be vetoed by the President.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- How Chinese workers, inspired by patriotic determination to defend their country against Japanese aggression, are managing to meet the highest American machine-shop standards in the manufacture of war equipment in factories housed in caves and dugouts, was described today by A. Manuel Fox, United States representative on the five-man Chinese Stabilization Board.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The Legislature pushed through today bills to relieve the housing shortage caused by the concentration of airplane factories in the Buffalo area. Governor Lehman signed the measures immediately.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Appointment of a legislative committee to study the advisability of continuing New York City as a separate unit outside of State defense plans was proposed today in a resolution introduced by Senator Robert E. Johnson, Richmond-Rockland Republican.

WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Army officials at Bradley Field announced tonight that five men had been killed and another was missing in the crash of a multi-motored plane, on a routine flight, between East Granby and Tariffville, just west of here.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11 -- There were three winners of the two featured races today at Hialeah Park, where favorites continued to finish up the stretch and a dead-heat was considered a major victory for the harassed form players.

In the magazine field, trade and business papers are among the first to institute programs designed to save paper, vital metals and printing inks, reports yesterday indicated. The chief conservation step taken by consumer magazines has been a relaxation of their rules governing the use of vital metals in advertising plates, but they have hesitated to take steps that might detract from the appearance of their publications.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 11 -- There has been patrol action in the sector allotted to Chinese troops in Burma, it was announced today by Major Gen. Lancelot E. Dennys, chief of the British Military Mission to China. He also confirmed that Thai troops were actively cooperating with the Japanese attacking Burma, thus far in small units.

Wholesalers have presented a formal protest to the Bureau of Labor Statistics asserting that the data gathered and disseminated under the classification of "Wholesale Prices" in price indices are "misleading," it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Acting swiftly, the Senate passed and sent to the House today legislation suspending for the duration of the war a section of the Neutrality act prohibiting American citizens from extending credit to agencies of belligerent governments, including Allies of the United States.

The seventy-ninth renewal of Columbia-Pennsylvania basketball rivalry, reputedly the oldest and closest in the country, will feature the annual Alumni Day sports program on Morningside Heights tomorrow. The Lions will attempt to register their forty-third victory over the Quakers, who have won thirty-six in the series which began in 1902, in the game scheduled to begin at 3:30 P.M.

DETROIT, Feb. 11 -- Work on machine tools vitally needed for the production of four-motored Army bombers was halted today when a controversy over one worker made 10,000 skilled mechanics idle in the tool and die departments of the Ford Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Alfred M. Landon told reporters today that he was 100 per cent "back of the Administration" in its effort to win the war, but criticized recent political statements by Democratic party leaders.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- Rallying with three goals in the last period, the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York subdued the Harvard six, 6 to 4, at the Playland Casino tonight. The defeat was the fifth of the season for the collegians, who opened their campaign with an overtime verdict over the St. Nicks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Temporary aid to all workers to help them bridge the gap caused by the transition of industry from peacetime to wartime pursuits, is planned by the Federal Security Agency, to be administered through the State unemployment compensation organizations, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, told the Ways and Means Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Rationing regulations on recapped and retreaded tires almost as stringent as those applying to new tires will be invoked Feb. 19, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, announced today. Commenting upon the need for rubber conservation he added that "it is quite probable that there will be no crude rubber available for retreading except for the small number of vehicles already eligible to obtain new tares and tubes."

EARL the Red Blaik, head football coach at West Point, is going to have a harder time turning out an Army team now. His chief assistant, his constant companion and perennial pal, Harry O. Ellinger, was found dead in bed yesterday, He died of a heart attack.
MIAMI, Feb, 11 (AP) -- Three former big leaguers carded par 72s today to take the lead as thirty baseball men ran the gamut from eagles to 9s in the first round of their championship golf tournament.
Youngsters between the ages of 6 and 12 came lugging twenty-pound loads of waste paper into the Jones Center of the Children's Aid Society, 405 East Seventy-third Street, yesterday afternoon.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 11 -- The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company assured its 78,000 employes today of a "grubstake" in the post-war period when reconstruction might necessitate some layoffs.

The lack of martial spirit is the most notable deficiency in the country's war effort to date. We are warned by Arthur Krock that "reports from the country continue to assert that the spirit of urgency and alarm, so necessary for a successful war effort, is not rising at the pace of war production and that it is still lagging and sluggish."

The city won a double victory yesterday in Supreme Court in its legal fight to uphold the right of the Police Department to seize pinball machines as gambling devices. Justice Aaron J. Levy, in a decision hailed by city officials as a "major defeat" for pinball operators, refused an injunction against the police in one suit, and the plaintiffs in a second injunction suit informed the city that they would withdraw their action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The most recent Japanese assault against the United States and Filipino defenders of the Bataan Peninsula diminished today, General Douglas MacArthur reported, but apparently only to permit the Japanese commander to bring in greater reinforcements.

Unbeaten James Monroe High's basketball team yesterday became the first P.S.A.L. five to clinch a sectional title this season when it collared the Bronx honors by downing Evander Childs, 37 to 24, on the Monroe floor. It was the thirteenth triumph and the fifth loop victory of the campaign for Monroe.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- The Ministry of Economic Warfare charged today that 5,500 tons of motor fuel had been shipped from France to the German forces in Libya within the last two months alone.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 11, 10:30 A.M. (Feb. 10, 11:10 P.M. Eastern War Time) -- The sky over Singapore is black with the smoke of a dozen huge fires this morning as I write my last message from this once beautiful, prosperous and peaceful city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- James M. Landis said today upon assuming the directorship of the Office Civilian Defense that much-criticized agency was to undergo a general reorganization so as to have it "geared and built for action.''

The four-story apartment for sixteen families at 133-35 Van Wagenen Avenue, Jersey City, was sold by the Plainfield Trust Company as trustee to the Trover Realty Corporation, Abraham I. Ticker, president. The building is on a plot 40 by 100 feet and has a monthly rental of $612.

Seventeen graduates of the Chilean Merchant Marine Officers School in Valparaiso have arrived in New York for a visit lasting several days before they return to South America and enter active duty, it was announced yesterday by the Navy.

In a night launching, a Navy craft, described only as a submarine combat vessel, will be put into the water late today at the shipyard of the Sullivan Dry Dock and Repair Corporation, at the foot of Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn. This will be the first night launching in the third naval district since the war began in Europe.
Holdout trouble is going to assail President Larry MacPhail unless wartime humility takes hold of two of his important Dodgers and one rated not so essential to the 1942 pennant scheme.

Captain William J. Pedrick was sworn in by Judge Murray Hulbert yesterday as Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second District here at ceremonies in the United States Court House attended by former Postmaster General James A. Farley, Attorney General John J. Bennett and Walter Hoving, president of the Fifth Avenue Association.

Hyman Popowitz, 36-year-old news dealer, and his son, Alvin, 6, died of burns and suffocation, and five other members of the Popowitz family suffered burns last night in a fire that wrecked their apartment at 211 Kosciusko Street, Brooklyn.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Dresselhuys entertained tonight with a dinner at the Patio. Among their guests were Colonel and Mrs. William Hayward, Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Cartier, Prince and Princess Alexis Zalstem-Zalessky and their house guest, George Schlee of New York, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Farrell, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Heminway, Mr. and Mrs. Julien Chaqueneau, Colonel and Mrs. Latham R. Reed and Mrs. John Ringling North.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The memory of a great king and of a gallant tradition reached across the years today to bless the youthful pilots of the Royal Air Force's newest Belgian fighter squadron as they received the squadron colors with the command to "unfurl them in the sunshine of liberty."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, Chicago, asked the Federal Power Commission today for authority to extend its pipe-line system to Milwaukee, Madison, Burlington, Racine, Waukeshau, Sheboygan, Manitowoc, Two Rivers, Green Bay, Appleton, Fond du Lac, Oshkosh, Beloit and Janesville and other cities and towns in Southern and Eastern Wisconsin.

State Senator Charles Muzzicato, Manhattan Republican, who declared recently that under existing law the fare on city subway lines must be increased after Sept. 10, charged yesterday that Mayor La Guardia "wants to go on discussing the nickel fare without ever coming out for it."

Mgr. Martin J. Drury, dean of Catholic clergy in Ulster and Sullivan Counties, appealed yesterday to delegates of the New York Archdiocesan Union of Holy Name Societies as active members of the church militant to put their faith in Christ "in a world that is sick and very badly in need of a cure."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Early rationing of gasoline in the East appeared tonight to be a probability as a responsible source said that Atlantic seaboard oil companies had reported that fast-dwindling stocks, due to war loss and diversion of tanker ships, justified restrictions on non-essential consumption.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Jean Gabin's second American film will be "The Night the World Shook," based on the French novel "Eight Hundred Convicts Marched on Caraibo," by Steven Wendt, Twentieth Century-Fox announced today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Women who take the place of men in industry should be paid the same wages as men. That is the opinion of an overwhelming majority of American voters polled in a national survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The North American Company suggested today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would postpone until Feb. 24 the proposed offering of 2,696,000 shares of common stock of the Union Electric Company of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Sixteen Japanese ships, thirty-eight fighting planes and an impressive amount of shore establishments were destroyed by the United States Pacific Fleet in a raid on the Marshall and Gilbert Islands in the Pacific on Jan. 31, the Navy announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- To speed the letting of war contracts and make the most effective use of all production facilities, including those of smaller manufacturers, the War Production Board plans to substitute negotiations for competitive bidding in the placing of all orders, Douglas C. MacKeachie, Director of Purchases of the WPB, told the Senate's Special Defense Investigating Committee today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Microfilm copies of important records are being buried on farms back from the Atlantic and Pacific coasts or hidden in vaults in communities remote from areas which might be subjected to bombing from the air, it was disclosed today at the annual exhibit sponsored by the Office Management Association of Chicago.

All men, whether citizens or aliens, 20 to 44 years old, inclusive, must register for Selective Service on Sunday or Monday, between 7 A.M. and 9 P.M., unless they have previously registered or are in the Federal armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Secretary Stimson said today that the Army's preventive measures against yellow fever would be "the first large-scale vaccination against the tropical disease ever attempted by a military force."

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Black Hawks tonight defeated the Red Wings, 4-2, in the Detroiters' final Chicago appearance of the regulation National Hockey League season. Their 1941-42 competition at the Stadium produced three victories for the Hawks and one for the Wings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Speedy approval was given today by the two Congressional appropriation committees to war fund bills. The House group voted to report a $22,888,901,000 measure for the Army, and the Senate committee the Deficiency Bill containing $100,000,000 for the Office of Civilian Defense.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A tribute to officers and men of the Merchant Marine who "are facing daily hazards and loss of life but do not falter," was paid today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce. The Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, which examines and licenses officers and issues certificates to seamen in the Merchant Marine, is under the Commerce Department.

Billy Conn returns to the local boxing scene tonight. The Pittsburgh boxer, who came close to lifting Joe Louis's heavyweight championship of the world last June in his last appearance in a New York ring, will trade punches with Tony Zale, Gary, Ind., holder of the world middleweight title.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- The thirty-second annual exhibition of the Pittsburgh Associated Artists opened tonight in the Carnegie Institute Galleries, the display including 259 oil paintings and 61 pieces of sculpture.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- Wendell L. Willkie, in a Lincoln's Birthday address tonight, called on the Republican party to adopt a wartime policy based on an independent program and to shun the traditional minority course of "continual negation" of majority aims.

Restrictions on civil flying are being administered so as to bring about as little dislocation of air travel as possible. The airlines report increasing traffic, and the priority plan announced by Brig. Gen. Connolly, Military Director for Civil Aviation, will not interfere to any large extent with travel by the general public, although it will assure, quite properly, expedited service for military and other Government personnel whose missions call for speed.

May I contribute a point to the current discussion of the potential destruction of faith in the government inherent in Secretary Morgenthau's proposal for taxing certain Federal securities -- a proposal which repudiates promises and assurances made in good faith?

Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, will address 120 new officers at graduation ceremonies tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Naval Training Indoctrination School at Fort Schuyler, Throgs Neck, the Bronx, it was announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 -- While ground forces sparred in the desert area southwest of the Gulf of Bomba yesterday, British planes continued to range over Cyrenaica, protecting British troops and striking at the reinforced German air force, which for the first time since Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's counter-attack began is becoming an important factor.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The new Free French Caisse Centrale will have the exclusive privilege of issuing notes to circulate as legal tender in territories controlled by the de Gaulle government. The notes will be issued either against the withdrawal of existing notes or a corresponding amount of gold or foreign exchange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Laura Ingalls, speed flier, accused of being an unregistered Nazi agent, testified today that in her contacts with the German Embassy she pictured herself as "a Mata Hari, an international spy" working to scotch subversive influences in the United States.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 -- A definite decline in business conditions and in inventories during January was reported here today in the monthly business survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit. Buying policy "is developing into a steady three months' affair, with hand-to-hand buying gaining a little strength due to curtailment of auto production," the report pointed out.

OTTAWA, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits decreased $4,963,000 to $32,839,000 in the week ended yesterday, the Bank of Canada reported today in its weekly statement. Notes in circulation increased $1,843,000 to $483,507,000.

Man's oldest friend, the dog, is always discussed in terms of affection, the love which he gives and receives. Who has ever written about the dog as an unsentimental, economic factor? Who would ever think of using the dog in a composite business index along with cotton, steel, beer, tobacco and pork and beans?

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press) -- Nervous holders offered stocks at declining prices again today on the Toronto Stock Exchange and all four indices were driven down to new low levels for the year. The gold shares closed at their lowest level since 1933.

The annual exhibition of oil paintings by members of the Salmagundi Club will open with a stag reception at the club this evening at 8:30 o'clock. The exhibition will open to the public tomorrow and continue through March 6.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A new money issue of $1,500,000,000 of 2 1/4 per cent bonds, maturing in 1955 but redeemable in 1952, will be offered tomorrow by the Treasury, Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced tonight. The interest rate is one-quarter of 1 per cent higher than that on the $500,000,000 of 1951-55 new-money bonds sold on Dec. 4 last.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The fighting blood of the Navy is a heritage with Vice Admiral William Frederick Halsey, who carried out the attack on the Gilbert and Marshall Islands. He is the son of a Navy captain, William F. Halsey.

VICHY, France, Feb. 12 -- Bombings and attacks on German troops continue to hold attention while France is engaged in negotiations for improved relations with Germany on the one hand and informative conversations with the United States on the other.
Leighton McCarthy, the Canadian Minister, and Mrs. McCarthy have arrived from Washington, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The stock markets failed today to maintain yesterday's late recovery as renewed selling developed on the news from Singapore. Losses were seen in the Australians, industrials, oils and rubbers.
Hundreds of old grads returned to Columbia's campus yesterday for the annual Alumni Day. The graduates attended luncheons and meetings, listened to speeches and turned out for an athletic program.

The electric refrigerator industry wound up 1941 with a 30.5 per cent sales gain over 1940, while electric ranges enjoyed a 69.2 sales increase, according to figures released yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- The twenty-four selective service boards in Westchester County will open supplemental offices for the registration from 7 A.M. to 9 P.M. on Feb. 14, 15 and 16 of men 20 to 45 years old. Local circumstances, however, will restrict the use of a few registration places during the three-day period.
WASHINGTON, Conn., Feb. 12 -- Dr. Russell S. Bartlett has been appointed headmaster of the Gunnery School, to take office in August, succeeding the Rev. Tertius Van Dyke.

Although two backgrounds are better than one, they do not equal a standard-gauged play. In "Heart of the City," which was well produced at Henry Miller's last evening, Lesley Storm has done what she can to prove that they do. For she has written a sentimentally appreciative sketch of backstage in a London threatre during wartime.

Count Edward Raczynski, Foreign Minister of the Polish Government in Exile at London and Polish Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived here yesterday on a Pan-American Airways transatlantic clipper for a visit to Washington "to establish contact with the State Department."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Ways and Means Committee, again weighing the problem of aiding workers displaced by the conversion of industrial plants to war purposes, heard protests from witnesses against the proposal to appropriate $300,000,000 to increase by 20 per cent the amount of State Unemployment Compensation benefits up to a maximum of $24 weekly for a period of twentysix weeks.

When Singapore was still a port its tin and rubber exports sometimes went 12,000 miles east around the world to New York via the Panama Canal and sometimes 12,000 miles west to New York via the Cape of Good Hope. The shortest route was a little over 10,000 miles by way of Suez.
MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

Retail prices advanced more in January than in any month since September, according to the Fairchild Publications Retail Price Index, issued yesterday. This was partly due to panic buying on the part of the consumer, it was said. Another reason was the fact that retail prices had not yet fully reflected the increases at wholesale.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Coinciding with conversations here of China's visiting Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek with Indian Nationalist leaders and British officials, the British Government today invited India to sit in on high strategy of the empire through representation in the Imperial War Cabinet and the Pacific War Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Roosevelt laid a wreath on the Lincoln Memorial in commemoration of the 133d anniversary of the birth of the Civil War President. He received a medal for effective use of wireless from a delegation headed by James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

VICHY, France, Feb. 12 -- French comment on the apparently imminent fall of Singapore is of necessity reserved, but official circles do not conceal their surprise at the rapidity of the Japanese advance. The newspapers publish long accounts and the Paris papers stress the blow to British prestige and the superiority of Japanese methods.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The British began today to face the belief that Singapore was lost.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- Seven hundred representatives of industrial and mercantile concerns who either ship by freight from the New England area or receive freight in that area voted unanimously today, at an emergency meeting called by the New England Shippers Advisory Board, to police their own activities in order to put an immediate stop to practices which tend to create railroad car shortages.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The entire American Army was ordered today made ready for possible dispatch to any tropical fighting front by being immunized against yellow fever.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Officials of the War Labor Board may appeal to Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Russia and Belgium, to help end a deadlock between Federated Fishing Boats of New England and New York, Inc., and the board, if the employers' association, operating fishing craft off the New England coast, does not "reply immediately" to a new board demand made today that it buy war-risk insurance for its crews.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Another northwest blow, of which there have been many for the sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club in recent weeks, swept Long Island Sound today, but it was defied by seven crews, most of whom managed, by nautical acrobatics, to struggle through four contests.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Retail hardware sales in the Middle West are getting back to a more normal pace after January increases which ranged as high as 60 per cent in isolated cases, it was learned today at the offices of the Illinois Retail Hardware Association.
CANBERRA Feb. 12 (U.P.) -- Newspapers today showed no bitterness over the imminent loss of Singapore and said its fall would serve as a spur to greater efforts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- With his head bared to a wintry wind, President Roosevelt stood at attention before the marble Lincoln Memorial today in tribute to Abraham Lincoln, Civil War President, during brief and simple ceremonies commemorating the 133d anniversary of Lincoln's birth.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Clarence Budington Kelland, executive and publicity director of the Republican National Committee, said today that a war-time political recess would mean "the destruction of the two-party system, the erection of the tyranny of the one-party system and the disappearance of the republic."
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 12 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler spoke today at the State funeral for Major Gen Fritz Todt, Reich Highways Commissioner. The ceremonies were held in the new Chancellery in Berlin.

Robert Penn Warren, who wrote the novel "Night Riders" and who was one of the founders and editors of The Southern Review, will have his "Bearded Oaks and Other Poems on the Same Theme" brought out next month under New Directions, Poet of the Month series.

Protests against the designation of several foreign countries as co-belligerent, neutral or enemy nations reached Selective Service headquarters, 1 East Forty-fourth Street, yesterday from a large number of persons who said they belonged to one or another of the alien groups that must register Sunday or Monday.

Representative George J. Bates of Massachusetts, member of the House Navy Committee, announced in Washington yesterday that he would propose a Congressional investigation of the burning and capsizing of the former French liner Normandie, now the Navy auxiliary Lafayette.
Oil paintings, water colors, pastels, prints and maps from the collection of the late Horatio Seymour Rubens were sold at auction last night for $13,037.50 at the Kende Galleries at Gimbel Brothers.
A few months ago the letters were coming in thick and fast from anglers who wanted to know "what happened to the bluefish," and now we can give something in the way of an answer.
After sixty days of war it would seem that officialdom has snarled itself in red tape, while the people pursue their amiable course just as if the country were not at war.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Governor Lehman announced today that a revision of expenditure estimates for the coming fiscal year, based on the latest figures, will permit a reduction in the State budget of about $3,000,000. He will make the changes in the supplemental budget to be submitted to the Legislature next week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Mme. Ivy Low Litvinoff, the English-born wife of the Soviet Ambassador, had her first "at home" tonight, and an Episcopal clergyman, capitalists, diplomats and official Washington came to call.

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Mitchell Hepburn, Ontario Premier, sounded the possibility tonight of a Japanese invasion of Canada in three months and charged that the American Navy "is afraid to make contact" with the Japanese Fleet.
The transfers and appointments of five pastors in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York were announced yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman as follows:

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- About 600 employes of the Newark Department of Public Works voted unanimously tonight to go on strike at a date to be determined by a strike committee and the executive committee of their union, Local 277 of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, C.I.O. affiliate.
ALL that Billy Conn has to do tonight at Madison Square Garden is to puzzle Tony Zale. Billy the Conn Man has everybody else puzzled already.

The Nazi movement in Germany is on the eve of disaster because of its lack of spiritual foundations, Assistant Secretary of State A.A. Berle Jr. declared last night at a dinner closing the five-day Columbia University Conference on Religion in the Modern World.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12 -- A daylong pilgrimage to the tomb of Abraham Lincoln today marked the 133d birthday of the Civil War President. Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, and Governor Dwight Green, various organizations and the plain people of Illinois joined in the tribute.

Otis Peabody Swift, an executive of Time, Inc., publishers, has taken a large apartment in the building at 23 East Seventy-third Street. Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., also report leases, with Charles Kaufman, in 330 East Seventy-ninth Street; Gwendolyn Bell, in 304 East Fiftieth Street; Mrs. Mabelle Powers, in 67 Park Avenue; Margaret C. Bostwick, in 6 East Eighty-first Street, and Palmer S. Harmon, in 5 East Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Japanese invading forces on Luzon Island in the Philippines withheld further attempts to unseat the defending army in the Bataan Peninsula today pending the arrival of greater reinforcements, General Douglas MacArthur reported to the War Department here.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The Japanese Government will allow no new enterprises to be established in the occupied areas in Asia and will control all imports from them and exports to them, Count Hideo Kodama, head of a committee entrusted with their economic development, revealed in Tokyo today.

The best snow conditions of the season continue to prevail in the North Country, according to reports received last night. Virtually every point in upper New York State, New England and the Laurentians of Canada has good skiing, with the result that trails and slopes in those areas should attract the season's largest crowd this week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Venezuela will participate or, in any event, will have the right to participate with the United States and the Netherland armed forces in the protection of the Netherland West Indies islands of Curacao and Aruba off the Venezuelan coast, Sumner Welles, Under Secretary of State, emphasized today in response to questions at his press conference.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 12 -- Michigan's Legislature voted today to put the State on a "two-time" basis, after a comedy of errors complicated enactment of the bill.

The urgent need now for clarifying an active peace program after the war was stressed yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, in a talk to 2,000 members of the Jewish Teachers Association at the association's fifteenth annual luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

The fourth program in the "Festival of Fantastic Films," which opens today at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse, includes "The Living Dead" and "Vampire." "The Living Dead" is an adaptation of Edgar Allan Poe's "The Black Cat" and "Dr. Tarr and Professor Feather," and of Robert Louis Stevenson's "The Suicide Club."

Plans for a new relief exhibit, "The Street of the Allied Nations," were announced yesterday following a meeting of representatives of the relief committees of twelve Allied Nations at the headquarters of the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Secretary of State, weary, half-ill and somewhat cast down by the failure of his efforts to alert our forces against Japan, is about to take a holiday to regain his accustomed health and vigor. Whether a holiday will also regain for Mr. Hull those areas of his appointed province which have been given over to invaders is a matter of conjecture.

The star performance of the concert given by Eugene Goossens, guest conductor, and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was Mr. Goossens's opening interpretation of the Beethoven "Fidelio" Overture, which he directed with admirable spirit and understanding and finely adjusted orchestral tone.

One field in which advertising will probably be encouraged rather than discouraged is the soap industry, which produces glycerine as a by-product. The government is encouraging increased production of glycerine by soap manufacturers for the expanded munitions program and the resultant expanded soap output will demand greater sales effort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Problems of supplying Russian forces with United States-made arms to resist the German armies were reviewed at the White House today by President Roosevelt and General A.K. Repin, chief of the Soviet military mission, who will return soon to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Scarcity of necessary materials has led the Defense Communications Board to urge a virtual halt of construction of all new commercial radio broadcasting facilities. Recommendations made by the board to the War Production Board and the Federal Communications Commission would bring such a result.

Julius Gershowitz, 28 years old, also known as Pickles Girsch, who had been hunted by the police for nearly two years as the suspected leader of a bold hold-up gang, was captured at 2 A.M. yesterday when he emerged from an apartment at 1 Post Avenue to buy a newspaper.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 12 (U.P.) -- Netherland troops, determined to fight on with or without United Nations reinforcements, are struggling desperately to hold back Japanese invaders from Banjermassin, capital of Netherland Borneo, and Macassar, capital of Celebes, it was announced today.

The wildcat strike in the tool and die departments of the Ford Motor Company, even though now settled, was a profoundly disturbing symptom. Ten thousand skilled mechanics became idle, and work on machine tools vitally needed for the production of four-motored Army bombers was halted, all because of a controversy concerning a single worker.

Asserting that the people of the United States, failing to realize the magnitude of the task of financing the war, are continuing to spend as if no dangers confronted the nation, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, called last night at Town Hall for an end to complacency and recommended a policy of action and a program of taxation to meet the situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Six Senators and nearly seventy Representatives will have to register Monday when the selective service takes an inventory of men not more than 44 or less than 20 years of age and not already registered.

The Dramatic Workshop of the New School for Social Research has selected as its first experimental production an innocuous comedy called "A Democratic Body," by Geoff and Mary Lumb, in private life Mr. and Mrs. Lumb. The Workshop presented it last night in the expansive interior of the school's Studio Theatre at 66 West Twelfth Street.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 12 -- Australian bombers set a Japanese transport afire in an attack yesterday afternoon at mast height on enemy shipping at Gasmata, on the southeast coast of New Britain, a communique announced today.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Japanese attack on the Salween River line wavered and broke in the Paan area today before a stout British Imperial defense. A communique related that a bayonet charge in another vital sector had sent the invaders scrambling for cover, abandoning their weapons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The United States will shortly send several experts to Britain to help coordinate the economic warfare procedures of the two countries, it was learned tonight. The object of this mission is to help bring about a more unified AngloAmerican policy on the amount of goods to be shipped by the two countries into Spain, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the neutral territories of North Africa.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Blimps, "gas bags of the skies," may be one of the effective answers to the continuing German submarine operations along our coasts.

Six five-story walk-up apartment houses, comprising a blockfront on Clay Avenue, between 168th and 169th Streets, the Bronx, have been sold by the estate of A.J. Schwarzler to Leo Eisenberg and Julius Borenstein for a cash consideration above the first mortgage of $308,750.
TRENTON, Feb. 12 -- State Rationing Administrator Robert W. Johnson announced today the appointment of Mrs. Irma Nowell of East Orange as Deputy State Rationing Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Tackling the controversial and explosive North-South wage differential question, three public and four labor members of the National War Labor Board joined today in decreeing a 7-cent hourly increase for workers in the Southern plants of the Aluminum Company of America.

When Rome fell, the scholars fled to Constantinople. When Constantinople fell, about a thousand years later, the scholars returned to Italy. Barbarian rule in various countries at various times has always benefited other countries to which the wise and thoughtful were exiled. So in our own day.
The entire eighteenth floor in 530 Seventh Avenue has been leased for three years by Parnis-Levinson, wholesale dress concern, through the Louis Adler Realty Company, for occupancy about March 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (U.P.) -- Secretary Ickes today described as "dangerously close to sabotaging our war program" a movement in Puerto Rico to oust Rexford G. Tugwell as Governor of the island.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The British Army Command issued this communique tonight:

A vast "casting office" by which subcontracts on war production would be assigned throughout the United States, in much the same manner that motion picture producers select their actors and actresses, is in process of organization by the War Production Board at the suggestion of the National Association of Manufacturers, Walter B. Weisenburger, executive vice president of the N.A.M., told a NEW YORK TIMES reporter yesterday.

The fantasy created by nine highly decorative murals depicting the habitat of 2,500 specimens of 104 species of fish, at the new Aquarium, which was officially opened yesterday in the Lion House at the Bronx Zoo, proved to be the most popular attraction for the 6,000 first-day visitors.

In what is believed to be the first joint anti-hoarding drive anywhere in the country, twelve local retail establishments yesterday appealed to consumers to abandon soare buying "in the interest of intelligent purchasing and patriotic behavior."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- With the fall of Singapore conceded by military authorities and consequent loss to the United Nations of the great tin smelting facilities there, the War Production Board acted today to expand domestic smelting capacity as rapidly as possible.

The highest January total of engineering construction awards on record was piled up last month when contracts with a dollar value of $628,780,000 were reported. The Engineering News-Record points out that although the activity in the first half of the month was slow, there was sharp upturn in the final weeks, resulting in a weekly average for the month of $126,756,000, a 7 1/2 per cent gain over the 1941 level.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 12 -- Reports to foreign military intelligence sources here tonight said that a serious split has occurred between the Pavelitch-Italian bloc and the Ustashi-German power group in Croatia, where the dissension is reported so violent that some Balkan experts predict armed rebellion.

DETROIT, Feb. 12 -- Yielding to pleas from their union leaders 10,000 members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations employed in the tool and die departments of the Ford Motor Company resumed work today after a new one-hour tie-up of production on machine tools vitally needed in the manufacture of four-motored Army bombers.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- American shore defense guns have smashed into complete and costly failure another Japanese effort to crack the western flank of Gen eral Douglas MacArthur's lines on Bataan Peninsula, and have inflicted heavy losses on the enemy in doing so.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Leading practically from start to finish, the Maryland-owned Cape Cod today again broke the much-shattered mile track record at Hialeah Park as he dashed first over the finish line in the Abraham Lincoln Purse in 1:37 flat. Behind him, driving his hardest to save the place, was Challenger II's son, Pictor, making his 1942 debut in preparation for the $50,000 Widener to be run March 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Led by a drop in agricultural commodity prices, the general level of wholesale prices underwent a general but moderate reaction last week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, dipped to 95.7 during the week ended Feb. 7 from the high point of 95.9 on Jan. 31, although still above the Jan. 24 figure of 95.5.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- In a speech noteworthy for what it told of Britain's production performance in the past, as well as an outline of future Allied procedure, allocations and supply problems, Lord Beaverbrook reported to the House of Lords today on his conception of his new job as Minister of War Production.

Exporters of benzol reported yesterday that, having been refused export licenses because the Export Control Office regarded their prices as too high, they have prepared detailed schedules of their export costs in an effort to obtain a reversal of the license rejections.

The Alumni Association of the School of Journalism of Columbia University last night honored the "heroic" work of war correspondents by dedicating its annual meeting and "open house" on the Columbia campus to them.

Glass and paper containers will keep everything from coffee to pork and beans on the grocery shelf despite the War Production Board's order on Wednesday under which the use of tin for canning foods was drastically reduced. The transition to glass or paper will be virtually painless for the consumer, according to industry spokesmen interviewed here yesterday, because of the advance work done in both fields in anticipation of the banning of tin cans.

A trusty who acted quickly, with little regard for his own life, prevented a break at the Bronx County Jail last night after grappling with three other prisoners who had subdued a guard. The potential jail-breakers were caught huddled together in a room on the main floor of the jail.

Animal experiments showing that biotin, a member of the family of B vitamins and widely distributed in human and animal tissues, exerts an influence in the development of artificial cancer of the liver in the animals, are described in the current issue of Sicence, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
