Slight declines in many quarters are reported by the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets in its week-end bulletin of retail prices in the city. Fresh pork prices furnish the only sour note in the general theme -- these exhibiting a 2-cent rise in the average price of every cut since last Friday.

The assertion that a group of appeasers in Washington and other cities, "an American Cliveden set," were scheming for a negotiated peace with the Axis powers and might seek to use the Republican party to achieve this "cowardly end," was made last night by Thomas E. Dewey at the fifty-sixth annual dinner of the National Republican Club at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- The distant boom of cannon and the trickle of battle news from the jungle telegraph have bolstered the morale of the people in occupied Manila, authenticated advices reaching the United States fighting forces disclose.

VICHY, France, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Nazi authorities in occupied France have ordered the execution of forty-five Frenchmen as hostages if the instigators of two recent attacks against Germans in the occupied zone are not discovered within the next few days, it was learned here today.

May I congratulate you on your editorial of Feb. 11, "Common Sense About Aliens," which sounds not only like common sense but is in full accord with the findings of criminology. What effect nationality or race may have as a crime factor is still a moot point, but the crime rate of the first generation immigrants is unquestionably lower than the rate of native Americans.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Combating a powerful crosswind and the tricky, snow-covered Bear Mountain slide, Torger Tokle returned to his winning stride today by annexing the fifteenth annual Palisades ski jump before an enthusiastic holiday crowd that braved freezing weather.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 12 -- The difficulties involved in sending food to famine-stricken Greece in response to demands from both America and Britain are stressed here and elsewhere in the Middle East, where food stocks earmarked for Greece remain in storehouses.

Consumption of apparel wools in the United States in December totaled 102,295,000 pounds on a greasy shorn basis, the Wool Associates of New York Cotton Exchange reported yesterday. This was the first time in the history of the industry that it had exceeded 100,000,000 pounds.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 -- With fighting becoming grimmer on every front as the Germans stubbornly attempt to hold strong points and the Russians persistently press forward, news items from various sectors today recorded the now familiar succession of German counter- attacks repelled, Russian advances maintained and more villages liberated.
The victory lifted the third-place Leafs to within 2 points of the second-place Bruins and within 4 of the league-leading Rangers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of the Czechoslovak Government in London, told reporters after a conference with President Roosevelt today that economic sabotage was progressing very well in his homeland and that production at the giant Skoda munition plants, for example, has been reduced 35 per cent by "slowdown strikes."

LONDON, Friday, Feb, 13 -- The Imperial forces defending Singapore, still resisting grimly although the Japanese flung in more troops in a determined effort to batter their way into the city, counter-attacked four times yesterday, once with some success, it was announced today.

Charging that the battle of production is being "hamstrung" by the failure of the Army, Navy and draft boards to recognize the vital importance of technically trained men, the American Chemical Society warned yesterday that training and proper use of chemists and chemical engineers must continue or the war may be lost.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission refused today to accept as part of its record of hearings on newspaper-radio relationships a court decision that it had no authority to bar newspapers from owning or operating radio stations.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Ray Lenahan, who once pitched for the Pirates, kept plugging along close to par today while others were blowing up, and as a result took an eight-stroke lead over the field at the two-thirds mark of the baseball players' golf championship.
WINNIPEG, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Prices of wheat had a firmer tone on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today when buying attributed to seaboard houses and United States and Canadian mills found offerings light.
CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Cubs will not play night baseball in Comiskey Park, home field of the White Sox, this season.

Sales of defense bonds and stamps by savings banks in New York in January amounted to $76,000,000, or two-and-one-half times greater than in December, Henry Bruere, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, announced yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 12 -- Reich Ambassador Franz von Papen called at the Turkish Foreign Office today for a long conversation witeh Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu.

Two hundred eager and confident members of the Royal Canadian Air Force, many of whom will soon be manning the battle planes of the R.A.F. on the fronts of the United Nations, toured New York City yesterday as the R.C.A.F. paid its first official visit here since the United States entered the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Asserting that the American people were now in the greatest peril since the founding of the Republic, Senator Byrd declared today that "the first battle we have to win is the battle of Washington."

The New Friends of Music have made plans to go on with their annual series of concerts for the seventh consecutive year next season, despite the war. I.A. Hirschmann, founder, announced yesterday that the music of J.S. Bach will form the main part of the programs, with chamber music and Lieder by Robert Schumann and chamber music by Josef Haydn.

Charging that certain anti-Fascist refugees in Mexico known as opponents of the Communist party and of the Communist International were being made the victims of a campaign by the Communist party of Mexico seeking their deportation from that country, more than 160 prominent Americans addressed a letter to President Manuel Avila Camacho yesterday protesting against such action and pleading for his intervention in behalf of the refugees in question.
LONDON, Friday, Feb. 13 -- Germany's 26,000-ton battleships, the Scharnhorst and Gneisenau, are on the loose again.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 12 -- Argentina is the center from which a Nazi Fifth Column operates in the whole American continent, said Deputy Raul Damonte Taborda, chairman of the Chamber of Deputies committee to investigate anti-Argentine activities, in an article printed by today's Argentina Libre.
Following is the address by Wendell L. Willkie at the Lincoln birthday dinner of the Middlesex Club in Boston last evening, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- All day today and into the evening the Singapore radio assured the world that the Imperial banners had not yet been struck, hopeless though the position still appeared.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 12 -- On third reading the Hungarian lower house today adopted the bill providing for a Vice Regency. The measure will now go to the upper house, where no opposition is expected, according to advices from Budapest.

America will win the war with its striking force of four-engine bombers, in the production of which it already leads the world, Colonel Egmont F. Koenig, Intelligence Officer of the First Air Forces, protecting the Atlantic Coast, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The War Production Board's order restricting the use of cans for the packing of certain types of food-stuffs will have no effect upon the important canned foods and consumers will find them in plentiful supply, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, said today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (UP) -- Foreign military observers expressed the belief tonight that the Red Army, behind the cloak of its recent secretiveness, had launched new offensives intended to set the Nazis back hard on their heels before milder weather arrives.

LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The statement of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday, made public today, recorded an increase of more than 3,000,000 in note circulation. The Bank's reserve decreased almost a similar amount and private deposits were reduced 5,390,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 12 -- Warning against an ostrich-like attitude, Dr. John W. Studebaker United States Commissioner of Education, called today on the schools of this country to engage in an all-out campaign to help win the war, even though it would mean drastically modified curricula.

Two awards of $1,000 each were made yesterday to the authors of the books published last year that were held to have contributed most to the literature and scholarship of racial relations. The prizes, known as the John Anisfield Awards, were won by Dr. Leopold Infeld, Polish-born physicist, for his autobiography, "Quest: The Evolution of a Scientist," and by Professor James G. Leyburn, sociologist and author of "The Haitian People."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 12 -- Arriving here as naval commander in the Anzac area, United States Vice Admiral Herbert F. Leary today said that the democracies had been a little slow in getting started, "but we are building as fast as we can."

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (U.P.) -- Allied resistance in the Pacific is mounting and the United States is preparing to strike back at the Japanese with steadily increasing force, the Communist party newspaper Pravda said today.

TOKYO, Feb. 12 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Singapore reverted to a frontier town today as Japanese troops poured in from all directions, mowing down British defenders until the "streets ran with blood," war dispatches said tonight.

The appointment of Prescott S. Bush of Greenwich, Conn., as national chairman of this year's fundraising campaign of the United Service Organizations was announced yesterday by Walter Hoving, chairman of the board of the service men's recreational organization. Mr. Bush succeeds Thomas E. Dewey, who conducted the first USO drive in 1941.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 12 -- European political circles attach importance to the long conversations that took place today in Seville, Spain, between General Francisco Franco and the Portuguese Premier, Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, in the presence of Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suffer of Spain.
WITH AMERICAN VOLUNTEER FLIERS, in Southwest China, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- Most of them are six feet tall and blond. The Chinese worship them. The Japanese fear them.

Leslie MacMitchell must have felt like some violent exercise last night, because the boy wonder from N.Y.U. ripped off a dazzling 4:08 mile to steal the show completely at the second annual metropolitan intercollegiate championships before some 3,000 spectators at the Coliseum.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- In a State-wide round-up of enemy aliens last night F.B.I. agents and State and municipal police arrested one Italian and eighteen German nationals and confiscated short-wave receiving sets, firearms, subversive literature and data about German secret societies in this country, it was disclosed today at the local F.B.I. office.

In observance of the eighty-second year of its founding, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company will begin the celebration of Founder's Week next Monday. The company, veteran organization of three wars, which was two years old at the outbreak of the Civil War, will honor during the week George Huntington Hartford, originator of its straight line method of distribution.

HALIFAX, N.S., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Einard Nellson, first mate of the torpedoed United States tanker W.L. Steed, died in a military hospital here Tuesday, it was disclosed today. His body will be sent to his home in Brooklyn, N.Y.

The Navy Department last night announced the good news that our recent naval attack on Japanese bases in the Marshall and Gilbert Islands resulted in destruction of five enemy warships and eleven auxiliaries. Earlier dispatches from New Zealand have already revealed that the attack was by no means an isolated raid.

The latest in the series of luncheons given by the arts and interests committee of the Junior League will take place at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, on Monday, when T.R. Ybarra, authority on Latin-American and European affairs, will speak on "The Human Factor in Pan-American Relations."

A dye known because of its color as "butter-yellow" mixed with food almost invariably brings down rats with cancer of the liver. Not so long ago Dr. C.P. Rhoads showed that the rats could be protected if casein, cysteine, choline and some vitamins were added to the fatal food.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Paced by Captain Dan Stuckey, who made three goals, Princeton's hockey team outclassed a favored Boston College sextet, 5 -- 2, in Baker Rink tonight. It was the sixth triumph in eleven starts for the Tigers, and the visitors' second defeat in ten games.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will relinquish her associate directorship of the Office of Civilian Defense when the civilian participation branch of it is thoroughly organized, she told a press conference here this morning, and then reiterated her intention in an address this afternoon at the Farm and Home Week exercises at Corner University.
LONDON, Friday, Feb. 13 (AP) -A joint Air Ministry and Admiralty communique early today said:

LINCOLN, England, Feb. 12 -- Abraham Lincoln would have grasped the reasons that have made Britain and the United States allies in this war, Ambassador John G. Winant said today at a luncheon commemorating the American Emancipator's birthday.
BERLIN, Feb. 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command said in its communique today:

The report of the United Corporation, utility holding company, for 1941, issued yesterday, shows a net income for the year, after expenses and charges, of $6,811,213, compared with $9,557,142 in 1940.

The United States Army will soon provide Protestant, Catholic and Jewish soldiers with 1,250,000 pocket-size, khaki-bound prayer books containing authorized readings from the Old and New Testaments, it was disclosed in a letter from Brig. Gen. William Arnold, Army Chief of Chaplains, to the Rev. Joseph F. Stedman, Director of the Confraternity of the Precious Blood, 5300 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, made public yesterday.

A deeply impressive performance of "Goetterdaemmerung" was given at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon as the fourth event in the current Wagner cycle. At this initial presentation of the work this season Helen Traubel made her first appearance as the Bruennhilde, and in the trying role scored a real triumph.

The Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, told a committee that notified him yesterday of his election as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island that he hoped "shortly to be able to make a response acceptable not only to you but to the church we serve."

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Creation of a Hew York State Good-Will Commission, whose primary functions would be designed to promote American unity among all citizens of the State regardless of rate, creed, color or national origin, was proposed today in a bill submitted to the Legisla/mre by Assemblywoman Todd and Eenator Young, Republicans.

A West Highland white terrier of distinguished ownership and of notable ancestry was named best in show as the sixty-sixth annual exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club came to a close in Madison Square Garden last night. Victorious was the immaculately white Champion Wolvey Pattern of Edgerstoune.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Senator Wallgren of Utah suggested today that the Federal Land Bank System receive the same right to issue Treasury-backed currency now granted to the Federal Reserve System. He advanced the proposal at a hearing held by the Senate Banking Committee at which Albert G. Black, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, asked Congressional approval of legislation to revamp the present system of government mortgage loans for farmers.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday were smaller than in the preceding week, but were well ahead of those in the same week last year, which included Lincoln's Birthday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Taking the role of Killer Kane, Tony Canzoneri, the former lightweight champion, will turn actor tonight in a farce dealing with the mazes of the prize-fighting industry called "They Should Have Stood in Bed," which will have its postponed premiere at the Mansfield.

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The management committee of the Toronto Stock Exchange approved this afternoon changes in the schedule of commissions to be charged by broker members on trades in stocks which will mean a considerable increase in the cost of buying and selling stocks in the higher price brackets.

In a statement taking issue with an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 21 opposing the creation of a Jewish Army, Moshe Shertok, chief of the Political Department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said at Jerusalem recently that the Jews were entitled to make their contribution to the Allied war effort as a people and not anonymously.

At last night's performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan the name part was assumed by Francesco Valentino for the first time at the house. The baritone sang with pronounced dramatic intensity, and his capable acting was in line with the established traditions of the role.

Talk about post-war problems has been pushed into the background by the gravity of immediate war problems. But it is worth remembering that the first thing most of us can do to help the war effort is also the best thing we can do to help meet post-war problems. This is to invest a part of our current income in Defense Savings Bonds and Stamps.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- Owing chiefly to a pronounced drop in freight shipments and the practical end of new motor car registrations, business in the Pittsburgh district declined severely last week, according to the bureau of business research, University of Pittsburgh.

CAMP DAVIS, N.C., Feb. 12 -- New York selectee members of the Ninety-sixth Coast Artillery (AA) Regiment who are in training here are keeping "up to the minute" on the latest news under a new program requiring battery commanders to inform their men of interna tional developments every twenty-four hours.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12 -- Within the space of fifteen minutes today a cruiser and two destroyers were launched into the Delaware River and the keels of two escort vessels were laid in one of the most telling displays of industrial manpower ever witnessed in this country.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Admiral William H. Standley, just appointed Ambassador to Russia, warned today that "America can be licked" by the Axis, and pleaded for "absolute unity in our war effort."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A War Department communique based upon reports received up to 9:30 A.M. Eastern war time today said:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Westchester County obtained today extensions to March 15 of options on the Rye Lake airport site in Purchase and County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach announced that the tract now could be bought for $266,000.

Contracts for building and engineering construction awarded last month in the thirty-seven Eastern States amounted to $316,846,000, an $11,000,000 increase over the total of $305,204,000 in January, 1941. The dollar volume of nonresidential work last month was up 4 per cent from the corresponding month in 1941, residential building was down 8 per cent and public works and utilities construction was up 21 per cent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 13 -- Four reports from Germany and occupied countries published side by side by the newspaper Aftonbladet show how hunger and food restrictions extend throughout German-dominated Europe.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- The women who are being employed in ever-increasing numbers by Buffalo war factories in many instances are superior to the men they replace as electrical workers, mechanical assemblers, inspectors and welders, personnel managers agree.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Possibilities of a United Nations offensive against Japan from Alaskan bases were discussed at the White House today by President Roosevelt and Ernest Gruening, Governor of Alaska.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Mrs. Montaigu La Montagne entertained tonight with a dinner at the Everglades Club for Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Glasgow. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Duncan, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Grey, Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Cartier and Mrs. Cornelius Dresselhuys.

One thinks today of thousands of unknown poets, the Valentine Virgils. How is the crop this year? Has it been plowed in for the benefit of the younger and universal greeting card? One used to inspect the yearly offering on Third Avenue and Ninth Avenue and elsewhere in more pretentious shops.

Pearl Harbor left Americans with a deeply disturbing sense of carelessness in high places but with no doubt of American courage. Now we know, as full reports reach us of the attack on the Marshall and Gilbert Islands on Feb. 1, that the Navy can plan and act with what a naval spokesman at Pearl Harbor yesterday described as "Swiss-watch precision."

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies Feb. 13 (AP) -- The harbor district of Macassar, chief port of Celebes, has been set aflame by the Netherland defenders and the torch also has been put to other vital areas in the south of the island that the Japanese are seeking to consolidate as a base against Java.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Seventeen brigadier generals were nominated today by President Roosevelt for promotion to be temporary major generals in a list of Army changes sent to the Senate for confirmation. He nominated thirty-five colonels for promotion to temporary brigadier generals.

TRENTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that Consumers Research, Inc., a consumer service organization at Washington, N.J., was not exclusively a scientific and educational enterprise, and therefore was subject to the State Unemployment Compensation Act.

Under the Sugar Act of 1937 Latin-American countries other than Cuba are limited to an initial import quota amounting to only a fraction of 1 per cent of the total quota, except that whenever the Philippines are unable to fill their quota the deficiency is reallocated among these other countries.

Plans for the emergency lodging and care of any persons made homeless by air raids on this city were revealed yesterday at campaign headquarters of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, 57 William Street.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- The Cabinet today adopted a series of measures governing the conduct of Axis nationals, implementing Paraguay's severance of relations with Germany, Italy and Japan.
WITH GENERAL MacARTHUR'S ARMY IN THE PHILIPPINES, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- American and Filipino troops, after six weeks of battling here in the wilds of Bataan, now are seasoned campaigners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Asserting that the defense program labor union practice of charging large initiation fees as a condition of employment was continuing on war projects, Senator Byrd today called upon Secretary Stimson to give a "full report" on the effects of these fees on the production of the materials and accommodations required by the troops.

ON BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- American tanks, one of the defenders' most fear-inspiring weapons, recently fought an outstandingly successful engagement, killing several hundred Japanese and suffering not a single death or injury.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 13 -- Jim Olsen, Dartmouth center, scored a basket with five seconds to play to give the Green a 57-55 victory over Princeton's quintet tonight. An overflow crowd cheered the Indian five as it rallied to snatch the victory after trailing throughout the contest.

A New Year begins tomorrow for the friendly folk in New York's Chinatown -- a year that opens with the young men of their families serving with our own armed forces, with relatives in the homeland fighting the most desperate battle in all of China's long history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Representative Vito Marcantonio said today that he thought the transfer of Etienne Burin des Roziers, third secretary of the French Embassy here, to Tokio was "very dangerous to our war program."

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The stock markets were comparatively steady today with several firmer features being seen. Gilt-edge securities were unchanged and the oils better, notably Ultra Mars which continued in demand, while the Mexican Eagles and the Eastern group were supported.

For the benefit of both Sergeant Walter Black and Wally McNally, whose Kansas vs. Creighton passage enlivened your letter box recently, I would like to point out that Kansas and Creighton met on the basketball court last night and that the Jayhawks beat the Bluejays, 53 to 49.

The concert given by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall will be historic in the annals of the New York appearances of the organization and its distinguished leader. And this was so in spite of the fact that two very familiar symphonies made the whole program -- symphonies that Dr. Koussevitzky has repeatedly directed in this city, and which represent two of his most distinguished achievements.

During the course of approximately nine months out of each year letters come in to this department expressing the writers' envy of the life of a rod and gun editor, but there is a surprising scarcity of such expressions from December to March.

Tenders will be considered on Feb. 27 by officials of Harris County, Texas, on $2,000,000 of road and bridge bonds for which bidders are asked to specify the interest rate. The bonds, dated March 10, 1942, will mature from March 10, 1943, to 1962.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 13 -''Yankee Cavalcade," a story suggested by Noel Coward's "Cavalcade," has been placed on the future production schedule at Twentieth Century-Fox, and Norman Riley Raine has been assigned to write the scenario.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Naval Lieutenant Etienne Henri Larive, 26 years old, who escaped German prison camps five times in twenty months, has reached England and rejoined the Netherland Navy, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A warning that production of radios for civilian use will probably be stopped entirely April 1, when the present War Production Board order restricting production to 60 per cent of last year's levels expires, was given here today by R.R. Guthrie, head of the WPB's Bureau of Industry Branches.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 13 -Leading all the way, but showing a marked scoring superiority only in the second quarter, Seton Hall defeated Scranton University, 52 -- 42, before 3,500 in the Setonia gym tonight. Captain Joe Thomas of the losers gave an amazing display of scoring ability by tallying 21 points, 13 in the second half.

OTTAWA, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Banknote circulation in Canada increased by $136,007,111 in 1941 and stood at $495,956,232 on last Dec. 31, it was shown in the annual report of the Bank of Canada, issued tonight.

The Appellate Division took to task yesterday the Municipal Civil Service Commission, two of whose three members, including Paul J. Kern, president, are under suspension by Mayor La Guardia for ignoring its own regulations and changing the rules governing a civil service test in a way that "frustrated" the competition required by the State Constitution and Civil Service Law.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Feb. 13 -- A further tightening of restrictions against enemy aliens on the West Coast, with possible action also against any American-born Japanese whose presence near vital defense areas might be looked upon as dangerous, was foreshadowed today as Thomas C. Clark, Enemy-Alien Control Coordinator for the Far West, prepared to fly to Washington with new recommendations.

The work of moving the offices, equipment and personnel of the Wages and Hours Division of the Department of Labor from Washington to New York will be started today by the newly created Office of Decentralization Service of the Public Buildings Administration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A War Department commuque based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. Eastern war time today said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Laura Ingalls, speed flier and self-styled "international Mata Hari," was convicted by a Federal District Court jury today on a charge that she acted as a paid agent of the German Reich without registering with the State Department.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13 -- A slight majority of American citizens living in communities where liquor is sold believe that liquor regulations in their areas are not strict enough. More voters likewise think that drunkenness in their communities is increasing than think it is decreasing.

Charles (Pickles) Gershowitz acted as his own attorney yesterday when he was arraigned before General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., charged with leading a gang that robbed home-going night-club patrons of $2,000,000 in jewelry.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 13 -Adolf Hitler's plea for "munitions, more munitions" in his latest speech to the German people is being heeded, according to advices from Berlin. Foreign observers, while agreed on this point, make it evident, however, that in the mind of more than one German the plea is considered an admission of a lack of preparation for Winter campaigns.

The manager and a salesman of the Carnegie Bootery, Inc., at 152 West Fifty-seventh Street, got stiff sentences yesterday in Special Sessions for trying to defraud two girl detectives in separate sales of two pairs of shoes the defendants said had been manufactured for a large Fifth Avenue department store.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -Governor Gruening, in his interview after conferring today with President Roosevelt, said:

Just what is literary atmosphere? Most of the time it means something that is not atmospheric at all. A few days ago Sinclair Lewis was reported to have dropped in on the State Legislature at Albany to get atmosphere for his new book.

An "ever increasing" trade between the United States and Mexico may be expected as a result of the community of interest brought on by the war and the growing understanding between the peoples of the two countries, Joseph M. Marrone, executive secretary of the Inter-American Commercial Arbitration Commission, declared yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti warned a Farm and Home Week audience at Cornell University this afternoon that if Americans do not put aside personal considerations, they "can lose this war." National disaster will be the outcome of the present struggle, he declared, unless personal and material interests are forgotten,
VICHY, France, Feb. 13 -- General Charles Nogues, Resident General in Morocco, arrived in Vichy today for his regular consultation on African affairs. [Ten words censored at point of origin.]

LONDON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Allies face a bitter fight for control of the North Atlantic. It is feared the Scharnhorst, Gneisenau and Prinz Eugen, now at safe anchor for repair and supply would rendezvous with a Nazi Atlantic fleet strong enough "to go wherever it likes," from the Orkneys to Long Island."

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Republican legislative leaders began a series of conferences today on the budget for the coming year, with their task of obtaining economies made more difficult because of Governor Lehman's announcement that he had planned a further cut of $3,000,000, to be made in the supplemental budget next week.

Despite a further increase of $88,000,000 in money in circulation to a new high record of $11,319,000,000, the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $30,000,000 to $3,360,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures disclosed yesterday, one day late on account of the holiday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Dr. John R. Steelman, chief of the United States Conciliation Service, said that he had been told late this afternoon that employes of the Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyards at Baltimore, who quit work at noon, had agreed to return.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Ray Lenahan, a better golfer than ever he was a pitcher, outclassed the diamond stars today to win the baseball players' golf championship by six strokes.

All men, whether citizens or aliens, 20 to 44 years old, inclusive, must register for Selective Service on Sunday or Monday, between 7 A.M. and 9 P.M., unless they have previously registered or are in the Federal armed force.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The government took its first step today to prosecute violators of the tire rationing program as a Southern Indiana Federal grand jury indicted La Salle Motor Sales Corporation of Boonville, Ind., and two of its officers on a charge of making false affidavits concerning the number of tires on hand when rationing began in December.

Because some 4,800,000 workers were added to payrolls and because of expansion of the armed forces last year, unemployment dropped to the lowest level since 1930, the Division of Industrial Economics of the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

Large Republican gain in the Congressional and State elections next November were predicted yesterday by Alfred M. Landon, former Governor of Kansas and Republican Presidential candidate in 1936, as a result of his talks with persons throughout the country.

Your editorial of Feb. 5 "State Power Shortage" agrees with the recently issued annual report of the Power Authority to the point of conceding that serious power shortage may lie ahead for the State of New York. Nevertheless, this editorial minimizes the danger by insisting that the Power Authority has understated the existing surplus of power capacity in the State and that it has erroneously asserted an already realized power shortage up-State.

The death of Iowa's famous "regionalist," Grant Wood, is said in one sense to mark the end of an era in our native art. As a matter of fact, the so-called "American Scene" furor which swept the land some years ago did not, in its full virulence, last a great while. Swarming little painters of barn and silo seemed, for a time, omnipresent.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- British patrols stabbed at Axis lines in the Libyan desert today and the Royal Air Force announced that a new blow had been struck against the enemy supply port of Tripoli, where a "large fire" was started in the harbor area.

TOKYO, Feb. 13 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japanese battled against stiff resistance in Singapore street two miles from the heart of the city today, according to dispatches received here, land threw a pincer drive against the big naval base, closed in on defending forces between the reservoirs in the center of the island land smashed more evacuation ships in the harbor.
The superstitious aspect of Friday the Thirteenth had no effect whatever yesterday on 100 couples who obtained marriage licenses at the Manhattan Municipal Building.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of John Q. Adams of Chicago and Robert V. Fleming of Washington to be public governors of the Exchange. Both were nominated by Mr. Schram.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today the application of the Hanover Fire Insurance Company of New York for leave to intervene in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's reorganization proceedings, which will be reopened for hearing in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, on Feb. 17.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced tonight that the subscription books for the $1,500,000,000 of 2 1/4 per cent thirteen-year new-money bonds offered this morning had been closed this evening, indicating that the loan had been a success.
ATLANTA, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Bees are going to get top priority rating and all the sugar they can eat whenever rationing begins.

The fighting spirit of the participants in the United States Navy's victory on Jan. 31 over the Japanese at the Marshall and Gilbert Islands was described yesterday by an eyewitness, Commander Miles R. Browning of the Navy, who spoke from Honolulu in a broadcast over networks of the National Broadcasting Company.

The national defense effort received impetus from a wage settlement negotiated yesterday between Local 325 of the Cooks, Countermen's and Soda Dispensers Union, A.F. of L., and Dubrow's Cafeteria, 1110 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

The worried eyes of the British people were fixed on faraway straits -- on Malacca and Macassar and Suez. They were thinking of the last stand of Singapore, of Rangoon, of channels in the Antipodes, the broken arteries in the circulatory system of the empire.

The foremost court tennis players of the country will gather at Greentree, the Payne Whitney estate at Manhasset, L.I., today for a series of exhibition matches for the benefit of the American Red Cross War Fund.

Recently Lieut. Comdr. Gene Tunney said that he did not know of any heavyweight champion in the past who could have beaten Joe Louis, with the possible exception of Bob Fitzsimmons. Tunney said he based this statement on what he had heard of Fitzsimmons.

New bond financing this week was again restricted to a limited volume although the offerings wore fairly well diversified. Three classifications of issuers accounted for a total of $15,444,000 in new bonds placed on the market compared with $14,217,000 last week and with $8,265,000 a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- Greg Rice stopped off at Convention Hall tonight for what most folks figured was a tune-up race for his return meeting with Gil Dodds in Boston tomorrow night. But before long it was obvious that any one who thought along such lines was wrong.

A committee composed of sixteen representatives of the oil industry, which will be known as the Committee on Supplies and Distribution, has been formed for the Atlantic Seaboard to prevent as far as possible shortages resulting from the possible further sinking of tankers or the diversion of facilities used for the transportation of petroleum products from the East Coast to meet war needs.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 13 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed today file arrest of a German alien housewife and the seizure of a powerful short-wave radio receiving set she was found operating in the basement of her home when they arrived to take her into custody.

Deborah, a 7-month-old black and white spaniel that jumped out of a TWA plane at La Guardia Field just before it was to depart for Arizona on Monday with her mistress, Mrs. Mirian Mallinson of 7 Gracie Square, has been found. As a matter of fact, the errant cocker spaniel probably will rejoin her mistress in Phoenix today.

The successful dash of the Scharnhorst, Gneisenau and Prinz Eugen through the English Channel to the safety of home ports is in effect a German victory. Holed up at Brest, the two battleships and the new cruiser were useless. Reunited with the German Navy, they constitute a formidable flotilla.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer dismissed yesterday a suit against E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., brought by a stockholder of the United States Rubber Company, and also dismissed the major allegations of the complaint against directors and officers of the United States Rubber Company.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- Successful in his mission of swinging political chieftains closer to all-out Indian support for the war, Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek concluded his consultations here and flew today to Peshawar and Lahore.

Aided by more favorable weather and the holiday, retail trade here showed larger increases this week than in the preceding week, merchants here reported yesterday. Department store volume was estimated as rising about 20 per cent over the corresponding week last year, against a rise of 14 per cent in the previous week.

TORONTO, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario, revealing he had received numerous telegrams of protest from United States citizens for his criticism of their Navy, repeated in the Ontario Legislature today his charge that "the United States fleet has been in hiding since the treacherous attack upon Pearl Harbor."

It would be a mistake, we believe, to pass by without comment the remarks of Premier Hepburn of Ontario on a subject of great interest both to his people and our own. A few days ago Mr. Hepburn expressed the opinion that "the American Navy is in hiding." He followed his first remark with the assertion that the American Navy "is afraid to make contact" with the Japanese fleet.

Edwin Posner of Andrews, Posner Rothschild was elected yesterday vice chairman of the New York Curb Exchange's board of governors. The board re-elected its three public representatives, John T. Madden, Benjamin H. Namm and Victor F. Ridder.

Ruth Reynolds of The New York Daily News and Mary Tobin, formerly with The New York Evening Post, received the New York Newspaper Women's Club annual awards for distinctive reporting, as announced last night at the twentieth annual Front Page Ball,

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Prices of hogs jumped today 10 to 15 cents a hundred-weight, reaching a new peak on the current advance at $13, as producers curtailed shipments and dressed pork exhibited additional firmness in wholesale trade, Salable receipts fell one-third below official expectations, amounting to only 8,000 head.

As sub-title to "They Should Have Stood in Bed," which was acted at the Mansfield last evening, Leo Rifkin, Frank Tarloff and David Shaw are entitled to the use of "Four Men on a Pug." For the three men on the authorship of this harum-scarum comedy are writing a prize-ring rumpus in the breezy style of "Three Men on a Horse" and "Room Service," which are parts of this country's cultural heritage.

The United States Gypsum Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1941 net income of $7,033,629 after Federal income and excess-profits taxes and other charges. After allowing for preferred dividend requirements the earnings are equal to $5.42 a share on 1,196,373 shares of common stock. They compare with $7,052,974, or $5.44 a common share, earned in 1940.

Gilbert Cant has put into his forthcoming "The War at Sea" the major naval operations, battles and other actions of this war from Sept. 3, 1939 through Dec. 2, 1941. He has written a running narrative that he worked up from communiques, from observers' accounts, from interviews and from a tapping of confidential sources.

Sharp losses in automotive and classified advertising last month resulted in total advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records falling 4.1 per cent behind the like 1941 month. All classifications, except retail and national, fell behind January, 1941.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Saturday, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- While official reports to the Aneta News Agency contradicted earlier announcements of a Japanese landing at Balang Nipa, other landing parties were reported driving on Macassar from the north, south and east.

The Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission, sitting jointly at a public hearing on the application of the Long Island Railroad for a 10 per cent rise in commutation fares, heard testimony yesterday by Charles Kimmich, expert for the Association of Long Island Commuters, in support of the contention that progressive increases in the railroad's general and commutation traffic in 1942 would make such rate rises unnecessary.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT (Canadian Press), Feb. 13 -- Their ship sunk in a collision with another ship while traveling in convoy somewhere in the Western Atlantic, forty-one Russian seamen -- including two women -- and a dog mascot have arrived here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Independent strength in rye and soy beans was a feature of the grain markets here today, but there was nothing in the news to account for the upturn. Brokers said most of the buying seemed to be of a professional character which found offerings light.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 13 -- Hoping to clear himself of a charge that prevents him from getting citizenship papers, Anthony Randazzo, 45 years old, of 25-50 Ninety-eighth Street, Corona, Queens, surrendered today to the police to face a robbery indictment returned against him twenty-seven years ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Jan. 31 was 2,762,890 shares, compared with 2,789,170 the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

The War Production Board is now working on an order which would permit manufacturers of small electric appliances to continue their manufacturing operations through the second quarter of this year, it was learned here yesterday.

An urgent message appealing to downtown office workers for support of the Beekman Hospital war emergency fund was posted yesterday on the Sub-Treasury Building in Wall Street. The "aerogram," as it was called, was signed by Alfred E. Smith, member of the hospital's board of director.

HONOLULU, Feb. 13 -- A United States destroyer rescued six hungry and almost naked men the total surviving population -- from Baker and Howland Islands on Jan. 31, after the remote American outposts had been shelled by Japanese submarines in a series of attacks, it was revealed today.

The New York State Labor Relations Board released yesterday the text of its decision and order directing Dr. Morris A. Mason, owner and operator of the Royal Hospital, 2021 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, to "cease and desist from refusing to bargain collectively with Building Service Employes International Union,
BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Nine survivors, rescued by a United States plane which made a daring landing in the Atlantic 160 miles off Bermuda, said today an enemy U-boat fired two torpedoes into their British tanker off the American coast near New York Jan. 31.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Senator Tydings, calling on the government to speed a heavily guarded convoy of reinforcements to General MacArthur in the Philippines or the British at Singapore, said:

Development of a "concerted program of public information" was proposed yesterday at a luncheon meeting in Town Hall by Miss Mabel G. Flanley, vice president of the Advertising Federation of America, as a specialized wartime task of the Advertising Women's Club of New York.

Protestants, Catholics and Jews in 2,000 communities throughout the country are expected to join in the ninth annual observance of Brotherhood Week, which begins today in synagogues and tomorrow in churches. This announcement was made yesterday at the headquarters of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, 381 Fourth Avenue, under the auspices of which the week will be celebrated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Department store sales showed a much smaller decline in value last month than is usual after the Christmas season and the adjusted index of the Federal Reserve Board, based on the 1923-25 average, rose to 138 in January, compared with a previous peak of 134 last August.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Roosevelt directed overstaffed non-defense Federal agencies today to channel their, surplus personnel into war work, but declared that the main responsibility and initiative for over-all reductions in nonmilitary expenditures rested with Congress and not with the Chief Executive.

In the first night launching of the war, the Navy's newest submarine chaser PC 552 slid down the ways last night at the Sullivan Dry Dock and Repair Company at the foot of Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn. She was flanked by two sister ships that will join her soon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A warning was sounded today by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, that increased income and corporate taxes, as well as enforced savings, would be necessary this year to siphon off $11,000,000,000 to $15,000,000,000 of excess national income which would remain as an inflationary hazard after current taxes and voluntary savings had drained off some consumer spending power.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Federated Press stated today that it had filed a complaint with the Justice Department's anti-trust division charging The Associated Press with violation of the anti-trust laws.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 13 -- Following their conference at Seville, Spain, yesterday, the Portuguese Premier, Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, left to return to Lisbon by road today and Generalissimo Francisco Franco went back to Madrid by way of Algeciras and Cadiz, inspecting Spanish Army posts en route.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Price schedules issued by the Office of Price Administration since its creation last April will remain in effect under terms of the Emergency Price Control Act and must continue to be observed, Leon Henderson, Administrator, announced today.

More room for Russia at the council tables where the grand strategy of the United Nations' world-wide struggle is planned was suggested last night by Senator Claude Pepper of Florida at the "Prescription for Victory" dinner of the Greater New York Physicians' Committee for Russian War Relief at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A brand new foundation is heralded as a totally different cosmetic. Luminous and palely gray in its little jar, this soft, firm cream, which spreads smoothly over the face, changes on the skin to give the complexion the transparent fragility of porcelain.

Now that the rampaging Rangers have taken over first place in the National Hockey League, there is no better time than the present to sing their praises. Of course, almost every one realizes that their rise to the top has been attained through the dauntless efforts of that already famous first line of Patrick, Watson and Hextall.

The ranks of Yankees signed for the baseball campaign of 1942 swelled to eight yesterday when Buddy Hassett and Mike Chartak forwarded their autographed contracts to President Ed Barrow. There was no word from the dissatisfied Joe DiMaggio.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -Secretary Wickard said today that rationing of fertilizer, farm machinery, processing equipment and some other crop production supplies might become inevitable because of shortages of nitrogen and other raw materials needed for munitions.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 13 -- Complying with the Opposition request, Prime Minister John Curtin has summoned Parliament to meet next Friday in a secret session to consider the continued deterioration of the Pacific situation. After the secret sitting Mr. Curtin will probably make a public statement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Half a dozen Senators demanded today prompt repeal of the recently enacted Congressional pension plan in two hours of acrimonious floor debate which culminated in a general attack by Senator Tydings on the Administration's and the nation's war effort.

The magic in the name of Notre Dame will produce a capacity crowd of 18,000 in Madison Square Garden tonight when the fast-moving Irish from Indiana face N.Y.U. in the feature of a collegiate basketball double-header. In the preliminary, St. Francis will be preponderantly favored over Manhattan.

A Valentines for Victory supper party, with defense bonds as special awards for a valentine-making contest, was given last night at Le Coq Rouge as a benefit for the Greenwich House Camp Fund, which sponsors Camp Herbert Parsons in Dutchess County for children from crowded districts of the city.

Substitutes for scarce materials and new methods of manufacturing to save vital materials are outlined in the February report on industrial material developments prepared for the National Association of Purchasing Agents by Colonel George S. Brady, chief of the substitution division, Civilian Allocation Division, War Production Board.

Soldiers and sailors on furlough in the city wish to be steered away from dinners at private homes, according to the hospitality and welfare committee of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee.

RANGOON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A second strong Japanese attempt to smash through the British-held Salween River line at Paan was under way tonight with fierce fighting in which the results of the battle still were obscure, a communique said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, said today that 1942 was "the critical year in the existence of the United States" and that every weapon made now "is worth ten times what we might produce next year."

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- While Soviet troops on the central front were smashing their way across the frontiers of White Russia, the six-month-old blockade of Leningrade was broken and convoys of Russian trucks took bread to the northern city's hard-pressed inhabitants, it was reported here today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Boviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

The British authorities in Palestine gave permission yesterday for 3,000 Jewish refugees to enter the country before March 31, it was announced here by the United Palestine Appeal. The news was received by cablegram from the Jewish Agency for Palestine to Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, National Chairman of the United Palestine Appeal.
Red and white flowers, suitable for St. Valentine's Day offerings, predominate in the flower markets this week-end.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Feb. 14 -- A little less than five months after they were driven out of White Russia with the opening of the Smolensk offensive, Russian troops in yesterday's fighting crushed the German left wing north of Vitebsk to make a spectacular re-entry into that province in the neighborhood of Usvyat, according to reports from Moscow last night.

Final instructions to the 600,000-odd men living in New York City who must register tomorrow or Monday were broadcast last night from Radio Station WMCA by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, local Selective Service director.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Schenley Distillers Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement, disclosing that it now proposes to issue only $15,000,000 of debentures instead of an aggregate of $27,500,000 contemplated in the original registration statement filed on Dec. 30.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill appropriating $500,000,000 for a loan to China. His callers included Ernest Gruening, Governor of Alaska; George E. Earle, Minister to Bulgaria, who presented his resignation, and the Netherlands Minister, Dr. A. Loudon, who was accompanied by General A.Q. Dyxhoor and Admiral J.W. Termytelen of the Netherlands Army and Navy.
BERLIN, Feb. 13 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command said in a communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, turned thumbs down today on plans on former King Carol of Rumania to come to this country from Mexico and head what Carol has said would be a "Free Rumania" movement.
DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- Mayor Jeffries is having a private war with the British Government, but he gave assurance today that the controversy would not be allowed to get in the way of the main war effort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The National War Labor Board seemed today to be headed for a showdown on wage and union security issues which may determine its ability to prevent labor strife for the duration of the war.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and its subsidiaries for 1941, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $12,141,227 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal after requirements on the preferred dividends to 9 cents a share on 33,673,328 shares of common stock and compared with $13,048,510, or 12 cents a common share, in 1940.

At this time contributors are re-examining the welfare and health agencies which they customarily support to make sure that each dollar contributed goes to necessary and effectively conducted organizations. Though this should always be a matter of concern to the conscientious contributor, it becomes urgently so now with the variety of wartime agencies asking for support as well as with the increase in taxation.

Emanuel Vardi, 26-year-old viola player of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, who gave his first Town Hall recital last season, was heard again in the same surroundings last night. The richly gifted artist had devised an interesting program which included five novelties.

Elated by the fact that the best skiing of the Winter awaits them this week-end, metropolitan skiers received further good news yesterday when the announcement from the New Haven and New York Central Railroads that they will sponsor the popular one-day excursions on a full scale tomorrow morning.

If, as I have heard may be done, our clocks are going to be pushed ahead another hour beyond their present advancement in localities which normally sponsor daylight saving time, I think the baseball magnates would do well to consider holding twilight games.

A three-way collision involving a truck, an interstate bus bound for New Jersey and a taxicab snarled traffic in Times Square at Forty-third Street for about fifteen minutes yesterday from 4:55 P.M. Mrs. Margaret Leavitt, 50 years old, of 36 Central Park South, a passenger in the taxicab, was injured.

The Board of Education will appeal the decision handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred V. Norton directing discontinuance of the practice of assigning teachers who hold No. 1 licenses to teach mathematics in the seventh, eighth and ninth grades of the elementary schools instead of appointing eligible mathematics teachers, it was announced by Theodore Fred Kuper, law secretary of the board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -The nominations of Rear Admiral William H. Standley as Ambassador to Russia and of Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley as Minister to New Zealand were approved by the Senate today, but not before some comment about the advisability of naming even retired members of the armed forces to positions normally held by civilians.

In the uniform of a private in Uncle Sam's Army at Madison Square Garden last night Joe Louis saw Billy Conn, Pittsburgh's former holder of the light-heavy-weight title, hammer out a twelveround victory over Tony Zale, world middleweight Champion from Gary, Ind.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that appropriate rewards would be given to officers and men who took part in the daring raids on the Marshall and Gilbert Islands on Jan. 31.

I read with interest John Kieran's recent column on the young athletes untrained for teaching who have been given posts as athletic instructors in the United States Navy. I would like to relate my own experience.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Attacking the imposition of a poll tax in some Southern States, President Roosevelt defended without reservation today household budget loans made by the Farm Security Administration which include funds with which this voting levy, imposed under State Constitutions and laws, may be paid by tenant farmers.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 13 -- Secondary and college educational systems are endangered as a result of hasty wartime acceleration of programs from four to three years, prominent educators attending the Eastern section national conference of the Progressive Education Association warned today.

HONOLULU, Feb. 13 -- The casual bravery with which the American fliers and ships' officers and crews carried out their assignments during the attack, Jan. 31, on Japanese bases in the Marshall and Gilbert Islands and their subsequent retirement under heavy enemy aerial bombardment was one of the factors that most impressed news reporters and photographers who accompanied the United States force.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Cameras, radios and other articles received from enemy aliens by local Police Departments will be turned over to United States marshals for inventory and safekeeping, Attorney General Biddle said today.

HAVANA, Feb. 13 -- The Ministry of the Treasury warned the public today that United States currency is legal tender in Cuba and cannot be rejected. The official note said also that speculators attempting to depreciate the American dollar would be prosecuted.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 13 (AP) -Drawlin' E.J. (Dutch) Harrison, the Arkansas slow-poke, mused on the first tee today that he was out to regain the Texas open title he won in 1939 and promptly put wisdom in those words with a first round, 4-under-par 67 that led the field.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Third Cavalry of Fort Myer, which has provided guards of honor for distinguished visitors since 1919, participated in inaugural parades and staged notable shows for charities, has been ordered transferred to Fort Oglethorpe, Ga., where it will have ample room for training for war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Wendell Willkie's suggestion yesterday that General Douglas MacArthur be brought home from the Philippines and placed in supreme command of our armed forces under the President is a suggestion that is sound in principle but difficult in application.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Even with a disqualification, neither the favorite nor the second choice could get first money in today's featured Melbourne Purse, witnessed by 10,847 persons a Hialeah Park. The winner, place first by the stewards, was Sam Houston, trained by J.B. Burnstein and carrying his wife's colors.

Five hundred noisy children and prominent stage, screen and radio stars yesterday wandered in and out of the doors of P.S. 135, First Avenue at Fifty-first Street, at the city's first neighborhood bazaar for national defense.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Heavy fighting has broken out between Chinese and Japanese forces in the south of Shantung Province, North China, the Chinese announced in a war communique tonight.

" Lady in Distress," starring Paul Lukas and Michael Redgrave, which opens at the Globe, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The English drama, which is being released here through Times Pictures, Inc., features Sally Gray, Hartley Power, Patricia Roc, Glen Alyn land Gertrude Musgrove.
Mrs. Byford Ryan, Red Cross instructor, doesn't expect a single failure from among the examination papers of forty-seven leading actresses, submitted to her yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Senator Lucas of Illinois called tonight on the people to cast aside their sense of complacency and awaken to the grim fact that America and her Allies may not win the war.

The Tammany executive committee voted yesterday to take a year's lease on its headquarters in Tammany Hall, thereby ending until the primary election in September at least any possibility of abandoning the name of Tammany by the New York County Democratic organization.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 14 -- Although the situation of Singapore is still desperate, according to latest reports reaching London, resistance by the Imperial British defenders continued stubbornly during the last twenty-four hours, and one report said that the defenders had stabilized their positions.

Annual Brotherhood Week will be observed beginning tomorrow in the churches and this morning in the synagogues. The observance will be under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Clergymen will preach sermons on the need of the spirit of brotherhood even in a world at war.

Next to the writings of Hashimuro Togo, Japanese schoolboy, the least likely source of sinister or subversive utterance would be the poetry of K. Nippo. The Office of Censorship in Washington, it developed yesterday, is a bit behind on current literature, and sternly suspicious of everything.

A parachute corps of women "nurses" is being organized, it was learned yesterday when the Bronx Office of Civilian Defense started to take applicants. It was said that all Offices of Civilian Defense are handling applications for the course,
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -Announcement was made by the State Department today of part of the arrangement under which economic warfare methods of the United States will be coordinated and simplified.
Because prices asked were "too high," nine new bids for installation of air-raid sirens in New York City have not been accepted, Police Commissioner Valentine disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Use of Federal funds to increase unemployment compensation for workers displaced for the war program to 60 per cent of their average pay, with a maximum benefit of $24 a week, was urged today before the Ways and Means Committee by W.L. Lund of Detroit, executive secretary of the Michigan Unemployment Compensation Commission, and Frank Fenton, representing the American Federation of Labor.

HONOLULU, Feb. 13 -- A priority list for transport to the mainland, when facilities become available, of civilians wishing to leave Hawaii was announced yesterday by the Military Governor. Passage will be furnished by the Army transport service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- Following Under-Secretary of State Welles's statement to the effect that ex-King Carol -- indulging in Rumanian politics here -- would be "persona non grata," it was disclosed that many influential persons -- especially the socially conscious who would expect to bask in the royal limelight if Carol were here -- have campaigned to get the necessary entry visa for him.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 13 (AP). -- An account of war at sea and a spectacular but futile suicide plunge of a Japanese dive bomber was related today by Joseph Rucker, veteran Paramount newsreel man. He was the only civilian aboard an aircraft carrier Jan. 31 [Feb. 1, Marshall Island time] when United States ships attacked the Japanese mid-Pacific islands.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Reiterating the decision she announced in Ithaca yesterday to step out of her post as associate director of the Office of Civilian Defense soon, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told OCD executives here today that before resigning she wanted to impress upon them, and through them the public, the seriousness of the war, and the importance of their part in it.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Heavy bombers, including Flying Fortresses and more fighter planes have reached the American Volunteer Group in Burma, where the Japanese are expected to unleash an offensive as soon as their troops at Singapore are free, it was revealed today.

A sudden plea of guilty yesterday by Hans Helmut Pagel, one of the seven persons on trial in Federal Court for espionage, was followed by testimony in which Kurt Frederick Ludwig, alleged master spy, was quoted as having admitted sending United States defense information abroad for transmission to Germany.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 13 (UP) -- Heavy bombers, including Flying Fortresses and more fighter planes have reached the American Volunteer Group in Burma, where the Japanese are expected to unleash an offensive as soon as their troops at Singapore are free, it was revealed today.

A sudden plea of guilty yesterday by Hans Helmut Pagel, one of the seven persons on trial in Federal Court for espionage, was followed by testimony in which Kurt Frederick Ludwig, alleged master spy, was quoted as having admitted sending United States defense information abroad for transmission to Germany.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- A sort of shudder of horror passed over Britons today when they realized that the German battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau and the cruiser Prinz Eugen had done the incredible -- crashed through the Strait of Dover -- and tonight apparently were safe in German ports.

PORT WASNINCTON, L.I., Feb. 13 -- Mrs. Francis B. Gilbert, 34-year-old wife of a New York City stock broker, was found dead early this morning in a bedroom of her home at 5 Barker's Point Road, Sands Point.

OTTAWA, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press) -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Mackenzie King will join in an international broadcast Sunday night on the eve of Canada's second Victory Loan campaign for $600,000,000, the National War Finance Committee stated today.

An elderly, well-dressed man with a record of twenty-eight arrests and twenty-one convictions since 1898 was arrested yesterday by detectives of the police forgery squad and inspectors of the Postoffice Department on a charge of stealing more than 1,000 pieces of mail from mail boxes in the lower Manhattan area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt and Under-Secretary of State Welles disclosed today that the United States and Brazil were studying a far-reaching program for exploitation of the rich Amazon basin, with its wild rubber trees and fabulous mineral wealth, which may prove the answer to pressing supplies problems of the Allies.

Today's events: "Tannhaeuser," 2 P.M., and "The Barber of Seville, 8:15 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Rey de la Torre, guitar, Town Hall, 3; Young Performers for Young Listeners, last of four concerts for children, home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond, 9 East Ninety-first Street, 3;

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 13 -Kenneth L. Post, 25 years old, of Bradley Gardens, who was accused of having strangled his 5-months-old daughter because her crying annoyed him while he was listening to a radio program, was sentenced today to serve ten to fifteen years in the State prison after he pleaded guilty to a second-degree murder charge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Japanese dive-bombers that yesterday renewed attacks upon the defenders of the Bataan Peninsula mistakenly attacked part of the Japanese forces, with consequent heavy casualties, the War Department reported here today.

A St. Valentine's party for about seventy-five men and women, most of them more than 70 years old, was given by the Community Service Society last night at the Tompkins Square Apartments, 131 Avenue B, a furnished apartment house maintained by the society for elderly persons with low incomes.

Presidents of the four city colleges and a member of the Board of Higher Education told the rules committee of the City Council yesterday that there was no discrimination against Negroes in making appointments to teaching posts in the city institutions.

Reflecting heavy increases in loans to finance war industries, commercial loans of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City jumped $55,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday. It was the widest gain of any week in several years.

For the first time in more than a week the stock market showed yesterday some evidence of stability, although the volume was too light to indicate the performance was conclusive. In the face of contradictory war news business plodded along at a snail's pace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- President Roosevelt signed today the bill appropriating $500,000,000 for a loan to China to stabilize her domestic economy and aid in acquiring military material and other needs.

Halfback Jim Blumenstock and End Jim Lansing, 1942 captain-elect, are among the twenty-one Fordham men who will begin training today to become naval aviators at Floyd Bennett Field. These Ram students will be trained as a unit, to be known as the Flying Rams, Unit No. 1.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 13 -- Full details of the damage done by units of the Pacific Fleet in their surprise attack on Feb. 1 [Jan. 31 in New York] on Japanese naval and air bases on six atolls of the Marshall and Gilbert Islands in the Western Pacific were released for publication at fleet headquarters here today.

HONOLULU, Feb. 13 -- Vice Admiral William Frederick Halsey Jr., who directed the units of the Pacific Fleet in the attack on the Marshall and Gilbert Islands on Jan. 31, has received the Distinguished Service Medal, it was announced today at fleet headquarters here.

After an early accumulation of hedging and liquidation offers had been absorbed, the cotton market rose slowly yesterday under moderate trade buying. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were at their highs for the session and showed net gains of 13 to 19 points.

ON BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- Tough, wiry Igorotes, their keen-edged bolos slung over their backs, rode the tops and sides of American tanks today helping General Douglas MacArthur's Filipino troops launch a successful counter-attack in the hilly terrain on the western flank of the Bataan front.

Alex. Brown Sons will discontinue their investment advisory department on Feb. 15. Naess Cummings, investment advisers, will take over the work of the department. Paul B. Thomas, who headed the Brown firm's department, has become a partner in Naess Cummings.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- A mobile canteen dedicated to Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margaret Rose was presented to the Mayor of the Borough of Chelsea today for the use of that borough by Bertram de N. Cruger, representing the British War Relief Society of the United States.

The first American refugees from Penang and Singapore arrived in New York yesterday with bitter denunciation of the British in the Far East, both in the defense of the Malay Peninsula and in their treatment of Americans.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- General John J. Pershing assumed tonight the leadership of another A.E.F., this time a humanitarian drive organized under the name of Army Emergency Fund.

The Detroit Edison Company ceased yesterday to be a subsidiary of the North American Company when the latter declared a dividend on its outstanding common stock in the form of capital shares of Detroit Edison. The dividend, payable on April 1, is subject to the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- John Scott medals and premiums were awarded tonight by the Board of City Trusts to Major Edwin H. Armstrong, who developed frequency modulation in radio, and Dr. Robert R. Williams, who succeeded in synthesizing thiamin, or vitamin B1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The month-old campaign by German submarines off the Atlantic Coast of the United States is furnishing rather bitter evidence of the fact that the World War no longer is a matter of distant interest for residents of this country.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14 -- Best dog of the 500 specimens benched today in the twenty-second annual all-breed show of the Elm City Kennel Club, held in the New Haven Arena, was the marvelous white poodle, Champion Broadrun Cherry, owned by the Blakeen Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Stamford, Conn., and handled by Mrs. Hoyt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The outbreak of war in the Pacific Dec. 7 made sugar rationing for consumers in this country ineviable, government officials here explain, despite the fact that for a country which used about 7,000,000 tons of sugar last year the United States had ample stocks on hand when the war broke out.

The first anniversary of the founding of the Institute of Jewish Affairs will be marked tomorrow night by a dinner at the Columbia Faculty Club. Seventy-five distinguished men will be inducted into the institute's advisory council and a forum will be devoted to a discussion of the post-war problem of reconstruction of Jewish life.

THERE is nothing of the helpless or bewildered male about these men who are taking a course for prospective fathers. Today's parents are realistic in preparations for a first baby; prospective fathers keep the free classes of the Maternity Center Association booked full.

Andrew Jackson's unbeaten quintet, runner-up for the Public Schools Athletic League title last year, stretched its current string of victories to fourteen by defeating Jamaica, 38 to 25, in the feature contest of a scholastic basketball quintuple-header, witnessed by a crowd of 7,500 at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Wage increases averaging $26 a month have been obtained by 166 radio operators employed by fifteen steamship companies following protracted negotiations and the intervention of the United States Conciliation Service, it was announced yesterday by Harry Morgan, vice president of the American Communications Association.

NOW and then -- and not so infrequently, either -- a reviewer, in the first flush of his enthusiasm for a good book, exclaims in all sincerity that here is a volume which he feels sure he will read again. Sometimes, no doubt, his conviction is largely the product of a feeling that he would like to read the book in more leisurely fashion than was possible in the preparation of his review.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation reported today that its assets increased by $4,720,769 last year to $132,735,491 at the end of 1941.

The United States and its Allies have been suffering from "Singapore and Maginot Line complexes, a psychological unpreparedness for war's realities, reflecting itself in inadequate defenses and aggravated by underestimation of the enemy's strength," Rabbi Israel Goldstein warned yesterday in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway.

IN the Eighteen Fifties it seemed as if man had conquered nature, as if there were no limit to his achievement or end to his prosperity, as if audacity were the sure weapon for measureless triump. That was when the missionary's wife, Abigail Carfax, became Boston's most glamorously popular novelist and when the architect Fenton Sweyton built the largest and most daring of all the clipper ships.

THE New England Conservatory of Music in Boston is celebrating its seventy-fifth anniversary this week. A series of events stretching over four days includes concerts, receptions, alumni meetings, luncheons, dinners and an "open house" during which the public will be admitted to rehearsals of the orchestra and chorus.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 14 -- The battle for Sumatra began today when picked Japanese assault troops in more than 100 fighter-protected transport planes attacked the oil-refining area of Palembang. Netherlands Indies defense forces killed enemy parachutists by the dozens.

The New York Athletic Club staged its first track and field meet seventy-four years ago, and the Winged Footers have become rather expert in the selecting of the fields and the running of these annual shows. At Madison Square Garden on Saturday the annual N.Y.A.C. games will be conducted with spectacular performances promised.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- General MacArthur's report from Bataan today that the enemy was entrenching in some sections was regarded here as further evidence that the Japanese attacks had thus far failed in their purpose. Savage fighting in the Bataan jungles has taken a heavy toll of the Japanese.

The job of the woman's college during the war is to produce the educated workers needed by the government and industry, according to a report of thirty women's colleges who met at Barnard College recently. The institutions were also advised to turn over their campuses and buildings to the government this Summer for women officers' training schools.
