TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Feb. 14 -- Plans for the complete revision of social studies instruction in the public schools of Indiana in light of the war have been completed at Indiana State Teachers College, following a survey by a committee named by the State Board of Education.

Despite some opposition from industry, the War Production Board has definitely decided on a policy of conversion to war work of all the larger units in individual industries and concentration of production of essential civilian needs in the smaller companies, it was learned here yesterday.

Contending that a large volume of war production is being held up because of various State regulations forbidding the use of benzol or benzol products under certain conditions, producers and potential users of benzol have initiated a movement looking toward relaxation of these rules for defense products for the duration of the war.

The Third Naval District officially announced yesterday the "rescue" of a seaman who actually had died five days ago; then it stuck to its story, although the body of the victim was being buried in Staten Island at the time the announcement was being questioned.

A large luncheon with a fashion show entitled "Soon It Will Be Spring" will be given March 5 at the Stork Club for the benefit of the Girls Vacation Fund, sponsors of Camp Manitou in Central Valley, N.Y., where many underprivileged children are given free two-week vacations every Summer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 -- Harvard's swimming team defeated Navy tonight, 52 to 23. The defeat was Navy's third in Eastern Intercollegiate League competition this season and the triumph was Harvard's first. Times generally were slow although the finishes were close.

STOCFJ=IOLA, Sweden, feb. 14 -- Under threat to "go over to the enemy" a 71-year-old Swedish woman has obtained from Reichsfuehrer Hitler the restitution of 10 kronor taken by the German postal authorities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Havana Convention can be invoked with regard to Free French seizure and continued occupation of St. Pierre and Miquelon Islands, but neither the United States nor any other American republic thus far has officially done so, a State Department spokesman said today.

Martha Graham, now touring in the Middle West, has extended her travels so that her second New York performance, scheduled for Feb. 24, has had to be postponed until early in April. Her next local appearance, therefore, will be on March 2 at the Guild Theatre, in what was originally to have been the third performance of her series.
This war may yet be a blessing to millions of movie fans, who are beginning to have weightier matters on their minds.

TENSE, grim, moving steadily onward to a climax foreshadowed from the very beginning, "Hangover Square" is the tragic story of a man destroyed by his own weakness. The novel inevitably, challenges comparison with Somerset Maugham's "Of Human Bondage"; it too has for dominating theme a man's overmastering desire for an utterly worthlesswoman

EARLY in 1922, when broadcasting was beginning to be more than a mere listening fad for a few people with crude but expensive receivers, a group of up-State engineers arrived at a momentous decision. They decided to install and operate a broadcast transmitter.

The annual card party to raise funds for the Girls' Branch of the Public Schools Athletic League will take place on the afternoon of Feb. 28 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. John M. Schiff and Miss Dorothea McIlvaine are chairmen of patronesses for the benefit.

ON Aug. 24, 1542, Francisco de Orellana, a young Spanish lieutenant, with a handful of companions more dead than alive, sailed out of the mouth of the greatest waterway in the world into the blue Atlantic. Just two years and eight months Before, they had left Iquitos, Peru, as one of the largest and best-equipped expeditions of discovery ever to set out on the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Almost 400 boats that formerly were used as pleasure craft have been lent to the Coast Guard for the duration of the war, and now are engaged actively in patrol work, the United States Maritime Commission made known today.

ONE of the charms of old-fashioned houses was the conservatory or huge plant bay -- a sudden spot of green freshness in the middle of dark plush and walnut. The same idea is still a welcome one today, and although few modern houses are big enough to permit a special room for indoor greenery. the dining room, dining alcove or a large sunny window can be used instead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- At the Capitol today, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan told reporters he had drafted a resolution calling for an inquiry by the Senate Naval Committee into the Normandie fire, and would press for its consideration by the Senate on Monday.

In a sort of warm-up for the bigger things expected this week, the Dodgers yesterday signed three players, boosting to twenty-eight the number of athletes under contract on the eve of the departure for Havana, via Miami.

WHEN the House of Representatives said last Monday, by a vote of 259 to 112, that it would not fork up $80,000 with which the Treasury Department might pay for the Walt Disney tax film, "The New Spirit," that august assembly implied an attitude which bodes no assurance; it just as much as said that it looks upon money spent on movies for the building of morale as so much waste.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin of Massachusetts, Republican na tional chairman, outlined a twelve-point program for victory tonight and pledged his party "to continue vigorously to support the President's war effort 100 per cent."

"Glimpses of Inca Land," illustrated with color film of Peru and Chile, will be the subject of the free lecture to be given Saturday at 3 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden. E.H. Fulling, editor of The Botanical Review, will speak.

GENERAL FRANCISCO MIRANDA, who prefaced his career as a Spanish-American revolutionary agitator and military leader by service in the Spanish Army, in Rochambeau's contingent in the American Revolution and in the French Revolutionary Army, where he commanded a division under Dumouriez, made his first attempt to liberate South America by force of arms when he led a filibustering expedition to his native Venezuela in 1806.

A comprehensive program, suggesting methods and practices schools can adopt to help win the war, is contained in the latest report prepared by the Educational Policies Commission. Everything must be subordinated to the one major task of winning the war, the study contends.

"THIS IS WAR!" came into being shortly after the four networks' inspiring broadcast celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Bill of Rights, a program written and directed by Norman Corwin. Having heard it, various persons began to think of the wonders that might be worked by an entire series of similar quality and tone.

PHILADELPHIA. ALL one gets is a pained look when he inquires as to the probable longevity of "Hellzapoppin" at the Forrest Theatre here, where it came from its ripe old run in New York City. There is every likelihood that the show, headed by Jay C. Flippen and Happy Felton, will run into the late Spring -- say May, for example.

Explaining that on a blacked-out action-ready fleet unit there are no motion pictures, that radios have been silenced lest they betray a ship's position and that sports and all other entertainments have ceased because men are constantly at quarters, Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, Commandant Third Naval District and Commander North Atlantic Naval Coastal Frontier, declared yesterday that reading is the one off-duty pastime left to sailors.

UNCLE SAM is not taking any chances on motion pictures unintentionally divulging any information which might prove useful to the enemy or of having the United States unwittingly portrayed in an unfavorable light on the screen, and as a result the Treasury Department has invoked the 1917 Trading With the Enemy Act, under which all films leaving the country will be subject to full-fledged wartime censorship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A special Justice Department investigating committee cleared Paul P. Rao, Assistant Attorney General, today of charges of holding pro-fascist sympathies and being unfit for office.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 14 -- Strong Australian reinforcements poured into the Netherlands Indies today, and the government weighed the question of calling Australian airmen home from England to join in the United Nations defense of the Southwest Pacific.

Stockholders of the Axton Fisher Tobacco Company have been called to a special meeting on March 31 to consider the issuance of 149,954 shares of 5 per cent cumulative $25 par prior preferred stock. Approval of two-thirds of the present preferred and Class A common stocks is required.

A blackout of electric signs on Broadway and elsewhere throughout the State for the duration of the war to conserve power was urged by Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti last night at the seventy-fourth anniversary dinner of the Order of Elks at the Commodore Hotel.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 14 -- The William and Mary basketball team took a closely waged game from the Naval Academy five, 42 -- 40, this afternoon, two goals from the foul line turning out to be the margin of victory.

THE complex and far-flung situation in which we find ourselves assuredly is no mere military war. Military operations are but the most obvious part of this crisis, which to me looks like a global convulsion, an all-inclusive world upheaval.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 14 -- Although it cannot be taken as an indication that he will not attempt to advance farther, Field Marshal Erwin Rommel appears to be digging in west of El Gazala and, except for patrol sallies, his army is inactive offensively.

Although established as a public holiday only in 1892, the observance of Lincoln Day has commended itself increasingly to the American people as times goes on. The very human qualities of the man account for much of this; so does the fact that he came from virtual obscurity to victory as chief of state in a great civil war.

THE New York Botanical Garden has issued an edition of 500 copies of "An Herbal (1525)," edited and transcribed into modern English, with an introduction by Sanford V. Larkey, M.D., librarian of the Welch Medical Library of Johns Hopkins, and Thomas Pyles of the University of Maryland, $3.50.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Feb. 14 -- Nothing would do more for our good-neighbor policy than to make American textbooks, especially in engineering and technical fields, available to South American countries and to offer membership in our professional societies to them at reduced rates, according to Dean Edward Steidle of the School of Mineral Industries at the Pennsylvania State College.

ST. PIERRE and Miquelon's postal administrator, A. Savary, informed the Free French Delegation in New York last week that after Free French Naval forces occupied the islands in December some of the 1938-40 pictorial stamps were given a red overprint reading "Noel, 1941, France Libre, F.N.F.L."

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Britain's domestic price policy reached a critical stage this week. Following the increase in wages of agricultural workers in December, an adjustment of prices of farm produce has been considered by the government.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Patriotic observances and social gatherings have been planned for the Washington's Birthday week-end and one of the resort's largest crowds is expected to be on hand for the festivities that will climax the Winter season.

IN "The Gay Galliard: The Love Story of Mary Queen of Scots" Miss Margaret Irwin presents a full-blown excellently documented historical romance that moves with speed and cumulative suspense to its proper climax.
BERLIN, Feb. 14 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command's communique said today:

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 14 -- Japanese troops have forced a second crossing of the Salween River near Paan but the fragmentation bombs of a squadron of British Blenheims have thinned their ranks so frightfully that enemy pressure eased tonight along the entire east Burma front.

Money in circulation in the United States continues to rise at a disquieting rate and is now at the record figure of $11,319,000,000, despite the increasing sales of defense bonds and heavy consumer buying of goods in anticipation of higher prices.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Feb. 14 -- Putting the Army's blood classification system to a test on the home front, two Camp Upton soldiers acted yesterday to save the life of another soldier's sister, stricken with a streptococcus infection.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Valentines undoubtedly were proportionately more plentiful than varsity victories for Cadet athletes at the United States Military Academy today. Sports squads composed of future Army officers competed on ten fronts, but, collectively speaking, reaped simply fair rather than overwhelming success, for the invading forces recorded triumphs in four instances.

ON more than one occasion the radio's devotees have lamented that their favorite medium is apt to proceed on the here-today-and-gone-tomorrow principle, a system which makes for considerable novelty but not a few regrets.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 -- Walter Lippman, the columnist, was challenged today by Thomas C. Clark, enemy alien control coordinator for the Western Defense Command, to substantiate statements that the Pacific Coast was in imminent danger of attack and that communication was taking place along this shoreline between Japanese Navy units at sea and enemy agents on land.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- British, Australian, Indian and Malayan troops bitterly contested every inch of ground over which the Japanese today advanced toward the heart of Singapore City, but the stand of the defenders appeared to be as much of a losing fight as was that at Hong Kong.

A QUESTION of relative rank /_@ arises between Major Hugh IIk North of Army Intelligence and Major F. Van Wyek Mason of the Bureau of Public Relations in the United States Army. Major North, who is the hero of Major Mason's many novels of international intrigue, has the advantage of seniority since Van Wyck Mason became a maa short time ago.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Rey de la Torre, 24-year-old Cuban guitarist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, under the auspices of the Asociacion Cultural Inter-Americana, Inc. His performances were musically accurate, tonally refined and rhythmically secure.

If all geographies were as easy to read as this one the dullest students would catch the wanderlust. Exports and natural resources, agriculture and physical features are not in themselves terms to stir the imaginations of 8 to 12 year olds, but Vernon Quinn's carefully organized array of these facts about each of the South American countries supplies information in a direct and often colorful fashion.

CANDY keeps Sweetly smiling in the face of its February cut of 20 per cent in cane and beet sugar. Corn sugar, otherwise dextrose, is not yet rationed. The candy makers believe they can learn to use it, if necessary, in perhaps one-third of their formulas.

Green's Cove was a circular basin five miles across lying at the head of the Klamitia River. It was covered thickly with wonderful hard pine timber. And it was the hideout of wild gangs of cattle thieves, bank robbers and killers.

LONDON, Feb. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Arsenal, leader of the London Football League, had a field day at the expense of Millwall today, scoring ten goals without a reply in a game featured by the failure of Millwall players to get a single shot at the goal.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Cornell's basketball team handed Columbia a 50-35 defeat tonight, leading from the first score to register its fifth victory in six Eastern Intercollegiate League games.

Dedicated by her captain to "the destruction of all enemies of the United States," the U.S.S. Juneau, 6,000-ton $13,000,000 light cruiser, was commissioned yesterday at the navy yard in Brooklyn as the latest addition to the Navy's ever-growing list of fighting vessels.

EVERY ONE went to the New Theatre last week in high hopes that J.B. Priestley was going to be very funny at the expense of the British Broadcasting Company. A good many people came away feeling he had not been so funny as was expected.

THOUGH somewhat emboldened by its victory over Senator Burton K. Wheeler in last Fall's propaganda film controversy, the motion-picture industry has nevertheless remained acutely sensitive to public criticism. Renewal of the old battle on a different basis brought violent reactions in Hollywood this past week.

Our most important duty today is to train the young people who will take care of the nation in the future, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, told 400 Hunter alumnae yesterday at the annual Alumnae Breakfast at the Hotel Astor.

The importance of training children of today to cherish the democratic way of life and to prevent them from becoming scarred by the hatreds of war so they can contribute to a lasting peace gives the kindergarten teacher a vital role in education, 800 members of the New York Public School Kindergarten Association were told yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- British authorities are scrutinizing the cases of many hundreds of British subjects living in the United States who seemingly are dodging such obligations as full income-tax payments or service with Great Britain's armed forces, it was learned today.

IF children ate promptly everything put before them, clearing their plates and finishing their milk without urging, mothers could give undivided attention to the good advice they get about nutrition. Since there is a wide gap between precept and practice in this particular, here are a few experiments to try.

Miss Edith Kingdon Gould will give a tea tomorrow at La Salle du Bois for members of her junior committee in charge of the distribution of programs at the violin recital to be given by Joseph Szigeti in behalf of the British War Relief Society on the night of Feb. 25 at Carnegie Hall.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of unusually irregular trends, with cattle and sheep quotations depressed by increased supplies and the pre-Lenten season, and those on hogs strengthened by the fact that producers' shipments to market showed little expansion compared with the previous week's small run.

CONTINUING the series of exhibitions of work by late nineteenth century American artists, the Babcock Galleries have opened a carefully selected show of oils, water-colors and pastels by John H. Twachtman.

THE Schola Cantorum, under Hugh Ross, will give a concert in memory of Kurt Schindler, its founder and first conductor, March 25, in Carnegie Hall. The program will be composed of melodies chosen from various Spanish and Russian collections made by Mr. Schindler, who died in 1935, after spending a number of years in Spain working on his last collection, for which purpose he had resigned from the Schola Cantorum in 1927.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Very slowly this huge nation is mustering its tremendous energies for total warfare against the Axis. How large, numerically, those forces must be, no one yet knows. Their final size will be conditioned by the progress of the war and its toll in numbers, Just as its present size is largely conditioned by available equipment.

Mexico had its own Paul Revere in Captain Allende, and the Grito de Dolores, the first wild cry of the long-oppressed Indians for freedom from Spain, commemorated each fifteenth of September by the President of Mexico, is as much a part of that country's tradition as is our own Liberty Bell.

She was a brave ship, a gay ship. when she came up past the Statue of Liberty nearly seven years ago. She looked like a yacht, a huge yacht of 83,000 tons. Tugs welcomed her raucously, fireboats threw their traditional streams of water, even Mickey Mouse followed her on a barge.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 -- Soon after the arrival today of George S. Messersmith, the new United States Ambassador to Mexico, he told the press here in good Spanish that the good-neighbor policy was a permanent one, that Mexican-American relations were better than they had ever been and that the democracies would win the war.

Patriotic and military influences will be apparent in many of the items shown at the New York Gift Show in the Hotel Pennsylvania from Feb. 23 to 27, George F. Little, managing director, announced yesterday. Cigar lighters, for example, will be styled in the form of army tanks, airplanes, cannon, pistols and bullets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Although no date has been set for the rationing of sugar, first commodity on the government's war rationing list, "United States of America War Ration Book No. 1" has been prepared and will be mailed out soon to rationing boards in all parts of the country.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 14 -- Professional golf's doughty sophomore, Melvin (Chick) Harbert of Battle Creek, Mich., led today in the Texas open golf tournament at the end of thirty-six holes, and well deserved it, but there's another story to tell, with another pro involved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The situation on the Washington front of the civilian defense drive, vital in these days when noncombatants must bear the brunt of enemy air attacks, was definitely improved this week, and it became possible to appraise the organization's progress more accurately than heretofore had been possible.

The British Arbitration Tribunal recently awarded a flat wage rate increase of five shillings a week to all adult male workers in the engineering industry. The comment of The London Economist on this action in its issue of Dec. 20 last is worth reprinting because of its bearing on the whole problem of wages in wartime, here as well as in Great Britain:

Business in the cotton market was limited yesterday, and on the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures moved within a 7-point range. Enough trade support dribbled in, however, to edge prices upward to gains of 7 to 10 points, but at the close these advances had been reduced to final net increases of 2 to 7 points.

ON July 27, 1733, in Dresden Bach submitted a Kyrie and Gloria, fragments of the Mass in B minor, to the Elector of Saxony, August III, with a significant dedication. He complained, among other things, of the injustices he endured in the course of his professional duties in the Churches of St. Thomas and St. Nicholas in Leipzig and beseeched the Prince to engage him in his chapel.

Higher income and national defense taxes had comparatively minor effects upon retail trade in Canada in 1941 and 1940, as shown by the adjusted department store sales indexes of the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. In general, the Canadian statistics revealed that the payments of the heavier income taxes last April was followed by a short-lived recession in May and June, with a sharp recovery in subsequent months.

In your recent editorial, "Post-War Planning," you rightly oppose the idea that we should continue government spending on a huge scale for an unlimited time after the termination of hostilities to save ourselves from the postwar depression. As you say, a post-war economy permanently depending on government spending would be a "deadly prospect" for a democracy.

NOW that you have the young lady seated before your camera, how are you going to pose her? Many workers would answer: "Don't pose her at all; let her assume a natural attitude. Then shoot when pose and lighting look the most appealing."

WHEN Mary Margaret McBride was a newspaper reporter she used to be sent to meet incoming celebrities in New York Harbor with what amounted to a stock list of questions. They were not very good questions to put to strangers who were just arriving, but it has rightly occurred to Miss McBride that for Americans themselves they are fine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The officials charged with the dissemination of our war information have not yet learned one of the most fundamental psychological lessons of the war: that the Anglo-Saxon peoples will not make the revolutionary sacrifices that are now necessary until they understand that the position of their countries in the war is not only bad but desperate.

Post exchanges at Army camps have enlisted in the nation-wide drive of the newly organized Tin Salvage Institute to collect collapsible tubes, Lee H. Bristol of the Bristol-Myers Company and chairman of the institute's operations committee, announced yesterday.

MANHASSET, L.I., Feb. 14 -- Pierre Etchebaster, world open court-tennis champion, demonstrated once again today that he is one of the most accomplished players of this ancient game of kings America has seen as leading professionals and amateurs lent their services for the Red Cross War Fund.

The yachting season of 1942 gets under way officially at Travers Island this afternoon. The New Athletic Club Yachting Department will hold a reception, beginning at 4 o'clock, for its newly elected (mainly re-elected) officers, under the direction of Charles H. Bell, chairman of the entertainment committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- New signs of Congressional revolt against war programs suspected of taking emergency reads to "sociological" objectives appeared today. The Administration's plan for using $300,000,000 of Federal funds to increase unemployment compensation to workers displaced by industry conversions to defense production was found to be definitely in trouble.

THE shadowy wasteland beneath Manhattan Bridge is hardly the place where one would expect to find the old dragon of China on a Winter's eve. Between Chatham Square and the East River it is a desolate region of loft buildings, garages, pawnshops and rows of bargain dry-goods stores.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Roosevelt today summoned members of the Anglo-American War Council to the White House to discuss adverse developments in both the Atlantic and Pacific theatres of war during the past week, and to formulate counter-moves.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb 14 -- John H. Meyer of Yale won the 200-yard breast-stroke race in 2:25.9, a tenth of a second from the Yale record, tonight, to furnish the highlight of the annual swimming meet with Dartmouth, which the Elis won, 51 -- 23.

The new refrigerators have reached the floors of the department stores. The efficient, beautifully appointed cabinets look like the fixtures of a land of peace and plenty and are probably the last of their kind to be made until the war ends and normal conditions return.

FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair said today that the Army's units which have been in service for the past year needed further training before they could be classed as first-line troops.

FOR a tale of violence and rebellion in England of the seventeenth century this is an amazingly modern story. Diana Hayes, with her lively mind and lovely body, gently bred and tenderly nurtured, might be a glamour girl of today.

Two sock-knitting machines have been installed in a committee room of the Women's National Republican Club at 3 West Fifty-first Street to speed up the production of warm articles for service men by the club's national service committee.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 14 -- The possibility that General Field Marshal Walter von Brauchitsch might be restored to his former post as army chief in the German High Command was reckoned with in reports received here from Berlin today, stating that Adolf Hitler had asked Marshal von Brauchitsch to visit him at headquarters.

WE'RE asked to go easy on gasoline, we can't buy tires, we must do with what kitchen gadgets we have, we feel on income tax day like turnips turned blood donors, but now that sugar rationing has come there's no doubt in our minds about war's sacrifices.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- With the opening Thursday at the Four Arts Gallery of the next-to-the-last exhibit for this season, art plays an important role on this week's calendar. The exhibition is a tropical design show, of which Mrs. George C. Van Dusen is chairman, with Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse as head of the garden sculpture section.

TOKYO, Feb. 14 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Domei said in a dis patch from Singapore Island today that the defenders were "disputing every inch of the territory entrusted to them," and the battle "mounted in fury each hour."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- With the rapid expansion in armaments production called for under President Roosevelt's wartime program, executives of the War Production Board at present are giving considerable thought to devising ways and means by which small plants, four and six-man machine shops and even automobile repair shops can be brought into the productive picture.

LISTENERS are forever complaining that when they like a program, or especially when they don't, there isn't much they can do about it. The Blue Network's program chief, Phillips Carlin, has taken steps about that, at least in the case of sustaining programs.

AN odd little novel, this latest and most adroitly mixed offering from the pen of the Chicago literary critic, Kenneth Horan. Without being in the least bookish or pedantic, it is derivative in flavor and appears to owe almost as much to reading as to observation.

Patterson Jr., State chairman of the New York defenese savings staff of the Treasury Department, declared last night.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 -- Form players had a field day today at the Fair Grounds, but in the two best races on the program the favorites won only by fine riding.

The training and experience of technical experts "are needed by the Navy today as the abilities of no single group have ever been needed before," Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, yesterday told the fourth graduating class of the Naval Reserve Officers School of Indoctrination at Fort Schuyler, Throgs Neck, the Bronx.

AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 14 -- A week-long battery of psychological and aptitude tests to help students aim for their proper niche in the nation's victory effort was completed today at Massachusetts State College under the direction of Dr. Harry N. Glick, Professor of Psychology.

BUFFALO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Unification of United States fighting forces on land, sea and in the air under command of General MacArthur was urged today by the board of governors and executive committee of the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs.

To advance its war work program, the Women's National Republican Club has arranged for tomorrow night at its headquarters, 3 West Fifty-first Street, a lecture by Arthur Menken, accompanied by the showing of his motion picture, "The Battle for the Pacific."

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 -- Philip Murray, head of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, said tonight that the S.W.O.C. would seek Labor Board elections at all subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in an effort to establish the union as the exclusive bargaining agency.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 -- As the gun cracked, George Lawry, Tiger set-shot wizard, threw in the goal that gave Princeton a 54-52 basketball victory over Harvard tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

TACOMA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- More than 1,000 workmen affiliated with the Boilermakers Union of the A.F.L. battered early today a picket line of 400 welders, also of the A.F.L., at the plant of the Tacoma Shipbuilding Corporation.

O PENING of the Lenten season next Wednesday does not mean that menus must go in sackcloth and ashes until the Easter Parade forms. Meatless days may be a gastronomical adventure for New Yorkers, who have one of the world's greatest fish supplies swimming around in their own front yard.

Blazing away at so fierce a pace that at times they almost seemed to be playing with six men instead of the regulation five, Notre Dame crushed New York University, 55 to 43, before the enraptured gaze of 17,790 basketball fans in Madison Square Garden last night.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Transient captured the $6,340 Evening Handicap before 15,845 at Hialeah Park today, while Alsab lost the Biscayne Purse to the consternation of a great many who had thought he might redeem himself for his defeat of a week ago.
THOSE noted athletes in sailor suits on shore stations, Lieut. Comdr. Gene Tunney's bodybuilders for short, are still under occasional heavy fire. Witness the following letter:
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- The daring driving of James Bickford won the North American four-man bobsled title today and gave his crew the four-heat record on the slick Mount Van Hoevenberg run.

THE outstanding news of the day in the literary world is the institution of an unprecedented censorship. Even in time of peace the right to print and publish whatever one likes is far from absolute. There is a law of libel, and from time to time the State has exercised control over the liberty of the press, especially for the purpose of preventing injury to public morals.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 -- Hialeah race course this year again has attracted many turf followers from New York and elsewhere since it opened Jan. 14. The track will remain open until March 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The War Labor Board stated today that during the first month of its existence, it had received 65 labor disputes affecting 779,530 men working on defense orders, and had closed six of these by mediation, one by board decision, and four by interim settlements or interim decisions.
IMPROVED reception reveals that broadcasters from Berlin to Delhi are shifting to Spring wave lengths, improving programs and tuning up new transmitters to cover big war moves come.

I want to express my admiration of the letter of Henry Hazlitt in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 8 about the changes which are needed in our Federal Constitution. This is a subject which has interested me for a long time and particularly from the standpoint of an administrator responsible to a board of trustees.

An influx of skiers will converge on Lake Placid beginning Friday and extending over the week-end of Washington's Birthday. The skiers will assemble to take part in the sixth annual invitation ski tournament for the Kate Smith Trophy, which is now held by 16-year-old Marilyn Shaw of Stowe, Vt., who is a former national champion.

BETWEEN the ancient earthy certainties of their Indian neighbors and the Americans' restless pursuit of mechanical progress, the Mexicans of Sangre de Cristo in Taos Valley lived strangely orphaned lives that were marked by fatalism and poverty and disdain.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 14 -- The first public test flight of a motor produced on the new Ford assembly line at Detroit took place today at the Glenn L. Martin plant, with Army representatives and executives of the Ford and Martin plants watching the performance.

Just by way of celebrating Washington's Birthday, and to enliven some hunters who have been complaining of inactivity, the Brookhaven Game Protective Association is holding another of its open shooting dog trials on liberated pheasants next Sunday.

We first meet Lydia Courtney at a studio party given by the wife of Mark Shrader, an artist whose pictures nobody wants to buy. The wife is rich, so it doesn't matter. Lydia is curiously upset by a painting of sand dunes, and Michael Dundas wonders why.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Feb. 7 were 252,366,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented an increase of 1,626,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 1,660,000 in domestic stocks and a decline of 34,000 in foreign stocks.

A growing waiting list of young men to associate membership in the Girls Service League Club is reported by officials of the organization, which provides a variety of classes and recreation facilities for young people at its clubhouse, 138 East Nineteenth Street.

Reports of recent financial operations made by corporations to the Securities and Exchange Commission show that on Jan. 20 R.H. Macy Co. issued $5,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent promissory notes to evidence a loan of that amount. The notes will mature $1,600,000 on Jan. 20, 1945; $1,800,000 on Jan. 20, 1946, and $1,600,000 on Jan. 20, 1947.

Innovations in social facilities are promised future tenant of the Lillian Wald and Jacob Riis Houses on the recommendation to the City Housing Authority of a group of women who have made the study of the lower East Side their main avocation for the past year.

In sharp contrast to pretty nearly everything else in the newspaper, the weather has been marvelous. If any government bureau in the national capital is in charge, it has every reason to be proud of the golden tropical quality of the February sunshine which it has been supplying in a succession of shimmering previews of Spring.

CAN we protect our children in wartime? In the bottom of their hearts most Americans -- believe -- that -- we cannot, that we are condemned to seeing a whole generation of little children marred by war. This basic belief shows through the barrage of nervous, excitable questions, of rumors and cross-rumors, about evacuation and air raid shelters, about nutrition plans, identification tags, and discussion of what to tell the children about the war.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- The University of Pennsylvania basketball team chalked up its sikth victory tonight, beating the Mexico City Y. 1V[. C. A. at the Palestra, 56 44.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Quotas for tire and tubes for this month were issued today by Leon Henderson, Administrator of Price Control. For the entire country the figures are: for passenger cars, motorcycles, light trucks, 80,784 tires and 67,616 tubes; trucks and buses, 156,029 tires and 267,562 tubes.

TRAVEL LINES: New travel folders for men in camp may be had at the Greyhound Bus Terminal, 242 West Thirty-fourth Street. . . . Ski races are scheduled for Penn State Ski Center, near Boalsburg, Feb. 21-22. . . . Triple Lake Ranch, Succasunna, Pa., plans a special program for Washington's Birthday. . . .

THE death-knell for ordinary motoring in the war years ahead sounded last week when OPA decreed rationing of tire retreading, to start next Thursday. Fitting new camelback rubber in place of outworn treads had been the "hole card" for automobile owners.

The wholesale markets continued their active pace with little abatement last week as retailers covered their immediate and near future needs, not knowing what further restrictions might be imposed, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- A much more friendly feeling toward the buying side of grain futures was evident today on the Board of Trade. There was a lack of pressure from the start, and with a belief that the Administration ultimately might approve the Bank-head bill to prevent the Commodity Credit Corporation from selling cash grain and other commodities below parity prices, there was a fair run of commission-house and professional buying.

When we took over our present place we acquired an arborvitae hedge ten feet high, untrimmed and undernourished. Since an enclosure to insure privacy and to form a background for shrubs and flowers is most desirable, and since the replacement of the hedge in question would have involved considerable expense, we undertook the task of restoring it to some degree of shapeliness and health.

Parents and the schools have a joint responsibility for the care and protection of the children of a nation at war. We must look to the needs of children and then determine how the parents with the aid of the schools can best meet those demands.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 14 -- Steel railroad tracks are today reaching out across hundreds of miles of desert and mountain in the Middle East which have never before seen a locomotive.

BUFFALO, Feb. 14 -- Long Island University, one of the leading basketball teams of the nation nipped Canisius by 46 -- 43 in a thrilling overtime game tonight in Memorial Auditorium before a crowd of 8,642.

With another successful Westminster added to the canine records, local exhibitors and fanciers must look forward to the opening of the outdoor season early in May, as there are only a few scattered events in the Eastern section of the country during the next two months.

ONE of the minor characters in this "picaresque novel of our time," as the jacket has it, is a young man with a scraggly red beard, who keeps a bookstore in Chicago, named Ward Moore. He is also an unpublished writer with a gift for verbal horseplay, profanely contemptuous of most of the wares on his shelves as of most of his pseudo-intellectual bohemian circle of acquaintances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Mayor La Guardia has recommended to President Roosevelt that civilian defense activities in the voluntary participation division, now supervised by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, be transferred to regular agencies of the government.

A Staten Island Sunday School class will attend the launching this morning of the new United States Destroyer Meade by special permission of Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, because a clergyman saw in the event "a righteous lesson sorely needed at this time."

Retail trade again moved at an active pace here last week, aided by more favorable weather and the Lincoln's Birthday holiday. Department-store sales, it was estimated, showed an average increase of about 20 per cent over the corresponding week last year, which compared with a rise off 14 per cent in the preceding week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Dan Stuckey, captain of the Princeton hockey team, was the only member of his sextet to score against Harvard in the Eastern Pentagonal League clash at the Hobey Baker Memorial rink tonight.
THERE'S a way of keeping the family car available for essential uses even if civilians are not allowed any new tires for the next five years.
To aid the United States in obtaining its goal of an air force 2,000,000 strong, the winning enlistment poster in the Army's Second Corps area aviation cadet poster contest was selected yesterday.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 14 (AP) -- An Army communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A joint statement issued today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, and Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, told the American people that the tires they now had on their passenger cars would be all they would get until the war was over.

In a quiet but effective way the sixty-odd branches and sub-branches of the New York Public Library in Manhattan, the Bronx, and Staten Island are contributing to the country's war effort by supplying information on countless topics related to the struggle.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 14 -- Discontent is spreading among the Moslem troops from Bosnia serving with the Croatian Ustashi regiments assigned to the campaign against Yugoslav's General Draja Mikhailovitch in "Greater Croatia" and incidents and desertions are occurring regularly in the field and army barracks, according to reliable reports in foreign sources here this evening.

Detectives Frank Kiernan and James G. Bree of the main office squad at Police Headquarters, suspended after extortion charges had been placed against them, filed past 200 brother officers yesterday at the criminal line-up after they had admitted making a statement to the District Attorney of Kings County.

Conflicting influencer at work in the market for tax-exempt State and municipal bonds has created an atmosphere of uncertainty, if not a virtual stalemate in important investment demand, to a degree not experienced by veteran traders in a long time.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Six hundred British planes, nearly half of which are believed to have been heavy bombers, attacked the battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau and the cruiser Prinz Eugen and their escorts Thursday when they successfully ran the gantlet of the English Channel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed during January totaled 945,909 bales of lint and 116,247 bales of linters, compared with 887,326 and 110,612, respectively, during December last, and 844,839 and 114,160 during January last year.

TO Americans who clearly remember World War I this book will not seem strange. Its theme, amply illustrated by its quotations from German spokesmen of this and earlier generations, is that of the guilty nation.

The brocket-deer is an animal to endear itself to the very young who love the miniature, for Chan-Yuc is Mayan for Little-Deer-Who-Never-Grows-Up. This is the true story of one which is now the darling of the Washington zoo, and surely an engaging, if badly spoiled, creature.
While reading Marjorie Dugdale Ashe's letter on razor blades in THE TIMES last Sunday a thought occurred to me which, when carefully considered, should not be so cockeyed as it appears.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review of Feb. 1, Rainer Maria Rilke is called "the greatest mod ern German poet." A few days before another New York paper described Rilke as a Czech poet. Of course, he is neither a Czech nor a German, but an Austrian poet.

SINCE the business side of Broadway was still buzzing last week over the box-office phenomenon of "Porgy and Bess" -- the Gershwin opus that is more of a success as a revival in 1942 than it was when it made its grand premiere in 1935 -- it seemed a good idea to try to find out how come.

NOT forgetting Agnes Rothery's interesting and informative "Roundabout South America," which was in itself a milestone in the writing of travel books for children, this record of a trip by air around South America is one of the most individual and engaging books of its kind.

Japan entered 1942 with about three years' supply of scrap steel, most of which remains from the heavy stock-piles purchased from the United States prior to October, 1940, according to informed steel circles here.
MISS ROSMAN subtitles her book "A Cat of London in Peace and War" and it is hard to say whether peace, war or the cat, as projected by that graphic pen, is most attractive.

DON'T look now, but the musicals are back. After the soporific Thirties Broadway again heard the din of distant horns faintly blowing three seasons ago; one by one and more and more the song-and-dance shows began trooping in from the hinterland tryouts and the mazdas began twinkling again on long-dark marquees in the Times Square side streets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- What are inventors inventing the most of?

Detectives who, after weeks of trying to halt a series of store burglaries, finally "broke" their case by tracing a stepladder, arrested ten persons in or near a confectionery at 3343 Third Avenue, the Bronx, last night.

ENTRIES are now being accepted for the fourth annual National Photographic Exhibition of the Rockfeller Center Camera Club, Room 2515, RKO Building. The show will be held June 14 through 28 in the Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Events of this week, the busiest of the midseason in the Miami area, include today's all-age kite-flying contest, tomorrow's annual senior championship golf tournament on the Baltimore course, the annual tropical ramble of tomorrow and Tuesday to aid the Fairchild Tropical Garden and the annual fiesta of stars, scheduled for Wednesday.

THE block-long door of a final assembly plant swings upward slowly and a lean, savage-looking bomber, complete even to war paint and service insignia, moves out into the brittle Winter sunshine. A few men working near the door pause long enough to watch the tiny red tractor haul the warbird clear of the building, and as the door swings back down they resume their tasks on planes soon to join the one just finished.
AFTER five years of planning and preparation, American Export Airlines last week received a temporary CAB certificate authorizing it to operate an air route between New York and Foynes, Ireland.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A War Department communique, based on reports up until 9:30 A.M. Eastern War Time, said:

RETAIL trade is gradually getting down to normal increases over last year as "scare buying" on the part of the public shows signs of subsiding. The rules to govern sugar rationing have apparently served to convince many nervous persons that hoarding won't do them much good.
AMONG the openings of the week were two large group exhibitions and several smaller ones -- these in addition to a highly diversified though not very extensive list of one-man shows.

IN Mr. Henry Hazlitt's review of S.I. Hayakawa's "Language in Action" he makes a point which seems to me not only pertinent but, as he suggests, too often overlooked in discussions of semantics.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 -- A crowd of 14,281 persons came to the local Madison Square Garden tonight to see Cornelius Warmerdam set a new world record for the pole vault and the Pacific Coast athlete, who is more at home in the stratosphere than he is on the ground, did not disappoint a single spectator.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Feb. 14 -- Colleges and universities of this country were called upon to change their entrance requirements for prospective freshmen so as to permit greater freedom in secondary schools, in a resolution adopted unanimously today at the closing session of the three-day conference of the Progressive Education Association.

ON a May morning, when the birds were singing in a Washington suburb, the principal research writer for the United States Department of Agriculture set down his conviction that at the age of 50 he had reached the prime of life.

THE American motorist, unable to buy a new car, must turn to the 27,000,000 old machines chugging along the highways, a fair proportion of which are up for sale every day in the year. The experience will not be new to many.

Garden operations will begin during the next ten days to three weeks with the sowing of seed to start good, stocky, well-developed plants, all ready to be moved out-of-doors just as soon as the weather warms up and the danger of late Spring frosts is past.
Changes arising from wartime necessity have been introduced into the curriculum of the Young Women's Christian Association, whose Spring term opens tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- After nearly seven weeks of tenacious resistance to Japanese attempts to dislodge his American and Filipino forces from the Bataan Peninsula, General Douglas MacAthur reported to the War Department today that "on some sections of the front the enemy troops are entrenching their positions."

What will be the effect of the war upon fashions? This was the question put to six well-known New York designers. All agreed that there will be no blackout of fashions, all elegance would keep its place in the fashion picture. Glamour -- often a much-abused word -- will be adapted to war conditions: it will be restrained and over-dramatization will be absent.

CLINTON, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Under the administration of President W.H. Cowley, himself an educational research specialist, Hamilton College is making a conscious effort to preserve in the college library a complete record of Hamilton's year-by-year development.

The second Festival of Jewish Arts, directed by Jacob Weinberg, was presented last night at Town Hall, under the auspices of the Jewish Reconstructionist Foundation, Inc A program of chamber music, vocal solos, choral numbers and dances had been prepared, which was enthusiastically received by a capacity audience.

"Working women will win the war," members of the New York branch of the American Association of University Women were told yesterday by Mary Donlon, head of the newly formed War Action Center and only woman trustee of Cornell University.

Prospects of a serious shortage of canned soups, reports of heavy hoard-purchasing of soap and the appointment of zone representatives for a petroleum committee that will attempt to prevent shortages were the principal developments yesterday on the consumer front as the tenth week since Pearl Harbor came to and end.

SURPRISING how long it takes for some people to find themselves. Take Edward Arnold, for instance. At the age of 14, when ostensibly he didn't know any better, he decided to become an actor because of the plaudits he had received for his performance as Lorenzo in "The Merchant of Venice" at the East Side Settlement House in New York.

AURORA, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Broadening the defense program at Wells College, the student-faculty defense committee has announced a plan to serve communities throughout the county by providing speakers on topics relating to the national war effort and policies.

Stockholders of Canadian Breweries, Ltd., at their annual meeting on April 22 will consider a proposal for the cancellation of arrears of $6.75 a share on the preference shares, substitution of a higher cumulative dividend rate of $3.40 a year, instead of $3 as at present, and an increase in the redemption price by the amount of the arrears, or from $40 to $46.75 a share.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13 (Delayed) (AP) -- An extemporaneous appeal by Mme. Chiang Kaishek to India to prepare against Japan was regarded here today as evidence that the foremost purpose of the Chinese Generalissimo's visit here was to impress upon Indian political parties the need for an all-out war effort.

In the range of flower colors blue is by far the rarest. Compared with the 800 species of yellow, the 150 that have blue flowers may seem relatively unimportant. Yet, beside green, no other color in the entire flower garden can approximate blue's ability to lend an air of space, an atmosphere of peace and quiet coolness to the planting.

The successful flight of three Nazi warships from Brest to home waters in Helgoland Bight has brought the danger of enemy attack closer to New York, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at exercises at 87 Lafayette Street, marking the promotion of sixty-eight members of the Fire Department.

NOT only in the realm of slang do certain words achieve wide favor for a while. At present, with fascism snarling at democracy, poets and essayists, press and pulpit make constant use of the term "ideologies."

Labor unions that act as "pressure groups" to get excessive benefits for the "upper crust" of organized labor without regard to the welfare of lower paid workers or to the real needs of social security were denounced yesterday by Abraham Epstein, executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security.

Retail trade was good last week in three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with mid-Winter furniture and china and glassware sales developing steady volume, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

About the most powerful chemical known is biotin, one of the "B" vitamins -- powerful in the sense that even a submicroscopic amount maintains growth and hence life. Nothing, from a germ to man, can live and grow without it.

MONTHS after he had completed his new Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, William Walton had not had the chance to hear it performed, for he was busy in the British armed service. Probably he has heard it by now, but certainly not with Jascha Heifetz, the violinist for whom he wrote the work and to whom it is dedicated, as soloist.

Encouraging news for the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York was received yesterday when ninety-eight committee chairmen reported to headquarters that fifty industries, trades and financial fields had "gone over the top" by subscribing more than 100 per cent of their quotas pledged to the fund.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 14 -- Secretary Morgenthau declared tonight that defense bond sales had reached only about one-seventh of the nation's income earners and that other buyers must be reached "without delay."

The Dutch are not a faint-hearted people and they face with stolid determination the fact that if and when Singapore falls their Java stands as the next stronghold facing the Japanese drive southward. Even with Singapore still holding out, Tokyo's generals have landed men on Borneo and in the Celebes and yesterday attempted a new landing on Sumatra at a point only 200 miles from Batavia, capital of Java.

By tomorrow night the United States will have registered for military service about 27,000,000 men between the ages of 20 and 45 -- close to 18,000,000 in the first registrations last year and the year before; about 9,000,000 more in today's and tomorrow's signing-up of the men of 20 and 21 and the older group between 35 to 44.

STOWE, Vt., Feb. 14 -- Barney McLean of Denver, one of the nation's foremost all-around skiers, gave a fine performance today to triumph over a classy field in the annual United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association downhill championship.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 14 -- There can no longer be any doubt that the shake-up in the German High Command that began with the elimination of General Field Marshal Walther von Brauchitsch some eight weeks ago has been an extensive one.

WHEN the war postponed the return of Sylvia Brockway and her two children from a Summer visit to her father (the American composer Howard Brockway), her cook in London began a series of weekly letters, which has been kept up ever since, "to let you know how things are going to keep you in touch with Home."

The Argentine-American Chamber of Commerce Inc., in a statement yesterday, indicated that Argentina's position in the world conflict was more favorable to the democracies than the reports of the recent conference in Rio de Janeiro made apparent.

GLORIA SWANSON is about to make her Broadway debut -- as a person, not a motion picture -- in the Ladislaus Bus-Fekete-Mary Helen Fay, (Mrs. B-F.) "Tryout in Boston." The play is about an actor-play-wright and his actress wife, and who is to play opposite Miss Swanson is not yet known.

BATAVIA, Feb. 14 -- Merchant ships, escorted by British and Dutch war vessels, are daily evacuating thousands of men, women and children from Singapore, virtually under Japanese shellfire and despite constant bombing by Japanese planes.

Varied and rewarding ideas for decorating bedrooms are to be gathered from exhibition interiors around town. Traditional elegance with a touch of modern insouciance is expressed in fabric-covered dressing tables, novel wood finishes, alluring arrangements of small shelves and new wall treatments.

Proper nutrition as an important weapon in strengthening the health of those engaged in strenuous wartime programs was stressed yesterday in a report by the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, which said that more than 6,000 housewives in the city are attending 100 Red Cross nutrition classes.

HERE is a unique story of the reformation and salvation of a gay and debonair young American bandit accomplished while he busied himself in saving the life and fortune of a wealthy Mexican, a former government officer, who had been robbed, discredited and driven north by his arch-enemy; also in rescuing that Mexican's son and daughter from ail in Alzaga, miles below the ine.
