TORONTO, Feb. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario said today that Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe "a few days ago" had submitted his resignation as physician to the Dionne quintuplets but that it had not yet been accepted.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- United States air power can and will win the Battle of the Pacific because the battle for Australia may very well decide the battle for America, John Curtin, Prime Minister of Australia, predicted today in an interview.

DAILY at 1 A.M. Columbia, broadcasting twenty-four hours a day "in the interest of the American national defense effort," opens its "all night program of fine music." Every hour on the hour important news bulletins are being read, and of course that is precisely why many Americans keep tuned to WABC, sacrificing their sleep in their eagerness for war news.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- Reports reaching diplomatic sources tonight tend to show that all Europe is hungry in this third Winter of the war, but that actual starvation is confined to a few areas, most notably Greece.

The WPA program in New York City is shifting rapidly toward emergency war work, Major Irving V.A. Huie, Local WPA Administrator, announced yesterday. Within the last year work relief rolls have shrunk from 97,986 to 60,684, a reduction of 37,302.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 -- Many a habitation -- a squalid shack, quarters in a boardinghouse or a well-kept seven-room dwelling -- was being vacated week as enemy aliens in "prohibited" areas of the West Coast began to find new homes in line with a steadily developing program of the War and Justice Departments aimed at solving a highly perplexing wartime problem.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 14 -- Conservation of Venezuela's natural resources and the protection of its flora and fauna will be taught to students in every grade of every type of school in Venezuela in line with the program of the newly formed National Association for the Protection of Natural Resources, it has been announced by President Isaias Medina Angarita.

ENVOY: Forty-three years ago, on a dark night in April, 1899, a 17-year old ensign of the United States Asiatic Fleet stationed in the Philippines em barked upon a dangerous mission. Together with a quartermaster, he rowed ashore to reconnoitre Filipino positions on the hills around the Gulf of Lingayen.

The correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Ankara, Ray Brock, made a very timely broadcast on Feb. 2 in which he told much about the Yugoslav Government in London and the Allies -- especially about the Allies. In this connection it should be emphasized that any front against the Axis, wherever it may be, cannot be neglected.

THE Metropolitan Opera has set most of the dates for its Spring tour. It will follow the general lines of last year's. It will last five weeks, the company will certainly visit seven cities and possibly nine, and there will be the usual break in New York during Holy Week.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- Colonel Anthony J. Drexel Biddle, 67 years old, was called to the colors again today by the Marine Corps, which wants him back on the job for which he is famous, teaching young leathernecks the fine science of hand-to-hand fighting.

Slim Kinney was a shrewd and wily scoundrel and he had the whole range around Bear Paw pretty well cowed. Ten years before the story opens he had murdered Buck Taylor and appropriated both his ranch and his general store and bar in town.
America's first war-time draft registration since 1917 got under way yesterday when the vanguard of possibly 9,000,000 men from 20 to 44 appeared to sign themselves into the selective service system.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 14 -- Reich Ambassador Franz won Papen called again at the Turkish Foreign Office this afternoon for a conference with Turkey's Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu.

MOST of us have grown so accustomed to the idea that the invention of printing sprang full-armed from the brow of Gutenberg that we feel it needs no further demonstration. There are the products of the first presses at Mainz as ocular proof, supported by fifteenth-century accounts of Gutenberg's activities and tributes to his art.

The Nazis have a genius for adapting the modern techniques of civilization to the ancient uses of barbarism. Thus they have solved the problem of "reparations" which baffled the between-wars world by using modern finance to accomplish the age-old business of rape.

Extreme caution ruled yesterday in the stock market, although prices managed to extend the slight gains registered on Friday. Although the additions were spread, trading was held to a small group of stocks, and volume was the smallest since last Summer.

An article by Henry H. Douglas on the teaching of Far East tongues, published in THE TIMES recently, interested me greatly, as I spent over forty years in Ceylon and India as a lawyer in close touch with the peoples of those lands. I note in the list of languages given "Malay, Siamese, Persian, Northwest African Arabic, Hungarian, Russian, Chinese and Japanese."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Regulations under which personal messages to residents of enemy or enemy-occupied territory will be accepted for delivery were announced by the American Red Cross today. The Red Cross alone, under the rules of the Office of Censorship, may forward such mes sages. This it does through its international affiliations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The American Federation of Labor proposed today that wages be tied to living costs in order to maintain the present living standard of workers for the duration of the war.

The Right Rev. James Hutchison Cockburn, Moderator of the Church of Scotland, the highest ecclesiastical office in that country, will spend a month on a preaching mission in the United States and Canada. He arrived here last Thursday by clipper.

I TAKE exception to John Reinhardt's statement in last Sunday's article that "Tobacco Road" tried to make a go in South America and that it ran for one solid consecutive week in Buenos Aires. For his benefit I wish to record the fact that "Tobacco Road" opened at the Milan Theatre on March 14, 1941, and played to capacity until the closing night of May 18.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 14 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Netherlands Indies Armed Services issued this communique today:

EVER since the United States declared war on the Axis Powers the future status of private flying has been in doubt. With the outbreak of hostilities all planes were grounded, with the exception of airline transports, and all pilot certificates suspended.

The election of B.A. Tompkins as president of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry was announced yesterday at the New York City office of the school in the Graybar Building. Mr. Tompkins is vice president and a director of the Bankers Trust Company.

Queens College students, conducting a survey of wartime public opinion under the direction of the Committee for National Morale, disclosed in a report yesterday that "the man in the street is both realistic and intelligent, and his morale is good."

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Representatives of the home furnishings industry will meet with government officials in Washington on Thursday and Friday under the auspices of the National Retail Furniture Association, it was announced here today.

Those who have something better than a tourist's knowledge of Japan will view with grave misgivings a proposal regarding the Japanese Emperor. After we have defeated Japan, the argument runs, Hirohito must be deposed and the throne wiped out. Only then will the Japanese people be ready to emerge from their feudal hangover.
"REMEMBER this," said Edgar Lee Masters, prodding busily at his teeth with the butt end of a match. "I don't want to be tied up with any one, with any group. As a writer I have no relationships."

SWITZERLAND, like many other countries, gives free franking privileges to men in her military service. With special envelopes and postcards provided without charge, stamps for domestic mail are not needed. Even ordinary stampless covers would be acceptable.

LONDON seems to chatter, walks like a man in a brisk constitutional. Berlin meditates in a sullen stroll. London glances at its buildings and streets. Berlin is preoccupied. London turns a corner smartly, throws its head up to catch the good air, smiles a little at the empty sky.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 14 -- National prohibition sentiment in the United States shows a sharp upward trend today. In the latest survey conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion in its eight-year index of dry sentiment the percentage of voters favoring a return to national prohibition equals slightly less than two-fifths of the electorate, and shows a 4-point rise today as compared to a year ago.

A mob of small-time gangsters grows ambitious and pulls off a jewel robbery which ends in murder and the kidnapping of a beautiful girl. Then a much tougher gang muscles in, murders the first set of gangsters and gets away with the jewels and the girl.

IN the American college a lot of midnight oil is being burned these nights. This is normal activity for students, particularly during examination periods. But this year more is being burned more continuously by more people, as trustees, presidents, deans and professors, as well as students, prepare themselves and their institutions to fit into the nation's plans for total warfare.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Assertions that the Vatican had attempted to interfere in the political relations of the Western Hemisphere during the recent Inter-American Conference at Rio de Janeiro were denied in a statement issued here today by Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, at the direction of the Papal Secretary of State.

Through special programs of recruiting and pre-clinical training, women's colleges and coeducational universities throughout the country are assuming some of the burden of training an additional 50,000 nurses needed to meet the demands of the war, it was announced yesterday by Miss Isabel M. Stewart, director of the Division of Nursing Education at Teachers College and chairman of the Committee on Educational Policies and Resources of the Nursing Council on National Defense.

BERLIN (From official broadcasts), Feb. 14 (AP) -- A German propaganda reporter who said he was aboard the submarine that sank the 9,577-ton tanker Norness off Montauk Point, 120 miles east of New York City, declared tonight that the U-boat entered New York Harbor itself and sank another 10,000-ton tanker, providing "without doubt a terrifying sight for the Yankees."

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 -- The first meeting of the Joint Defense Commission of Mexico and the United States is expected to be held next week. It will mark the formal consummation of a kind of collaboration of the two countries, which is unique in their history.

THE practice of the law requires many skills. Few men by temperament and training, if indeed there are any, can achieve distinction in all of these skills. That skill which is most dramatic in its practice, and the most interesting to the layman, is the skill of the trial lawyer.

Congratulations to the Cunard White Star Line, Ltd., on its restitution of $9,233 in wages and overtime withheld from 548 American employes through misunderstanding of the Fair Labor Standards Act, was voiced here yesterday by Arthur J. White, regional director of the Wage and Hour Division of the United States Department of Labor.

KUNMING, China, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- American and British air reinforcements -- including "hundreds" of Royal Air Force men from the Middle East -- have arrived to bolster the Burma front, it was learned today.

In the Jan. 22 issue of your magazine, under the title "Flying the Flag," Charles Pound quotes W. A. Mandelberg, manager of the New York division of the Flag Association, as follows: "When it [our national flag] is flown with some other flag from crossed flagstaffs against a wall, it should be on the right as you face the two flags." !

To weld the complicated history of South America into a comprehensive whole for children of the middle years is a formidable task, but the authors of "The Story of the Other America" have given us, without oversimplification, a clear and concise account which might well serve as an introduction to the study of the continent.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 14 -- Royal Australian Air Force bombers again attacked enemy aircraft on the ground and shipping at Gasmata, New Britain Island, yesterday afternoon. Enemy fighters sought to intercept the Australian bombers, but the latter pressed the attack and started a large fire. All bombers returned to their base despite enemy anti-aircraft fire.

Fausto Cleva, who is now in his twenty-second season as a chorus master at the Metropolitan Opera House, last night finally got his first chance to conduct an opera there. It was Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia." He stepped in without a rehearsal, for it was not until yesterday morning that it became known that Frank St. Leger, the scheduled conductor, would be too indisposed to appear.

Although wartime restrictions on the use of tin, rubber and other supplies are challenging the ingenuity of American food manufacturers as never before, food distributors expressed the belief last week that, while substitute packages and some changes in the public's eating habits will result, ample supplies of most foods will be available on a more or less normal basis.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Winter sports in the Pocono Mountains are attracting large crowds, and over Washington's Birthday many are looking forward to a holiday week-end of skiing, skating, snow and ice tobogganing, dogsledding, sleighing in horse-drawn sleighs, and barbecues, as well as indoor programs.

DETROIT -- Since maintenance of America's "rolling stock" is essential to the war effort at home, indications are growing that the Federal Government will make provisions soon for keeping alive several thousand automobile dealers and service establishments.

The failure of United States Army engineers to approve the modernizing of the Delaware and Raritan Canal, between Bordentown and New Brunswick, N.J., may seriously penalize the nation if its Eastern transportation problem becomes urgent as a result of the war, it was declared yesterday by Joseph Sterling, New York lawyer and chairman of the State of New Jersey Delaware and Raritan Canal Commission.

COME Spring and weather conditions more favorable to the operation of military planes at a high degree of efficiency, the various fronts in this world-girdling war are apt to witness some new wrinkles in air fighting.

The formal opening of the recently established Franco-Belgian Free School of Higher Studies was attended last night by 3,000 persons, including prominent figures in education and social circles, at Hunter College.

RYE, Scotch, brandy, gin, champagne, vodka, beer -- anything will do for Mr. Marlow, so long as it is alcoholic. The reason he takes to rye just now is that he is taking a trip to the United States, where rye is the wine of the country.

WHEN Rachel Crothers and five other women of the theatre met a little more than two years ago to discuss the need for a war-relief society they were looking far ahead. Most of them had been through one war with the Stage Women's War Relief Society, which wound up its affairs with great credit to the theatre in 1920.

A program on "Women in Defense of Hemisphere Solidarity" will follow the fifty-third annual luncheon of the Woman's Press Club of New York City, to be held on Saturday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, head of the Children's Bureau, will be among the speakers, on the topic "Children and National Defense."

In reding L. H. Robbins's interesting article entitled "They Keep on Rollin'," published in the Feb. I Magazine, one small point may be of interest to railway hobbyists. In selecting the initials "A. B. C." to represent a line entering New York City, the author, presumably unowingly, selected the title of a railroad actually in operation in the Deep South, the traekage of which comes no closer to New York City than Atlanta, Ga.

Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman head a list of patrons and patronesses for an afternoon party to be given March 8 in the main ballroom of the Plaza in the interests of Madison House, a settlement on the lower East Side which was founded nearly fifty years ago by the Ethical Culture Society.

A new canteen for service men at Navy and Concord Streets, across the street from the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, was dedicated and opened for use yesterday afternoon by the Brooklyn Defense Recreation Committee. About 150 members and special guests of the committee, as well as a handful of soldiers, attended the meeting.

J.W. Von Herbulis, a veteran shipping man and former manager of ship sales for the old United States Shipping Board, has been named vice president of the Waterman Steamship Corporation of Mobile, Ala., one of the largest ship operators in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The War Production Board prepared today to purchase all of the estimated 30,000 automobiles in "graveyards" and to allocate the scrap iron and steel to those war production plants in greatest need.
An 18-year-old Campfire Girl from Rocky River, Ohio, has won the organization's seventh annual poetry contest, it was announced here yesterday.

Up the broad steps leading to the State Department in Washington walked last week Gaston Henri-Haye, Ambassador of Vichy France. He was bound for an interview with Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles. It was perhaps the most crucial conference which the French envoy has had since he first came to the United States after his country signed the armistice with Germany in June, 1940.

AS the author of the article which caused Miss Oakley to make the statements which aroused the ire of lovers of chamber music, may I be permitted to add a few remarks which, I hope, will close this "controversy."

PIANISTS, painters, violinists and the like have caused sensations at times by the large amounts of insurance they have taken out against injury to their famous hands. Now come the artists employed by the animated cartoon studios to make similar insurance history by placing a specific value on their uniquely developed digits.

DESPITE the effusions of the Yankee poet, N.P. Willis, who discovered the river some ninety years ago, the Kentucky is still perhaps "a river of whose remarkable beauty the world is strangely ignorant.''

MR. BROWNE'S basic proposition is indisputable. Something emphatically "went wrong" with civilization and world order during a generation that has experienced the two most destructive wars in history and three major revolutions that led to a contraction, not to an extension, of the frontiers of freedom within the countries where these upheavals took place.

HANOVER. N.H., Feb. 14 -- Dartmouth extended its lead in the Pentagonal Hockey League title race tonight by defeating Yale's sextet, 6 to 3, before an overflow crowd in Davis Rink. Dick Rondeau, center, tallied five of Dartmouth's goals to lead the Indians to their fourth league triumph in as many starts.

Yale's football coaching situation remained unchanged following yesterday's meeting of the Yale Corporation at which it had been hoped a new head coach would be named to succeed Emerson W. (Spike) Nelson. Indications were that it might be a week or two longer before the new mentor was announced.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, speaking yesterday at the first membership meeting of Freedom House at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, warned of the impending danger to America's freedom "unless the 130 million people unite with brain and brawn in an all-out effort to win this war."

LEON HENDERSON is a tough man with two tough jobs. As Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, he has responsibility for preventing an inflation which might be more disastrous than an Axis victory. Low and middle income groups look to him to prevent that "ol' debbil" -- the high cost of living -- from rearing his ugly head.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 14 -- An 8,000-ton Swedish steamer under charter to the British Government is loading a large cargo of wheat at Haifa, Palestine, for direct shipment to Piraeus, Greece, British official sources at Ankara declared today.
Warm clothing for shipwrecked sailors in the merchant marine and the Navy is the particular service project of a group of women working at the Downtown Athletic Club, at 19 West Street.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- German radio propaganda tonight took a new, possibly significant, turn, boasting about the Nazi naval exploit in the English Channel and displaying unusual interest in the Mediterranean and the disposition of the French fleet.

THE American people are now irrevocably involved in the worst war in history. Many of our sons have already lost their lives and millions are being asked to risk theirs. It would be criminal for us to send our boys out to all parts of the earth with no plan, no purpose. We ask them for a victory; we ourselves must define victory. And for this purpose we must look ahead.

FROM what I had heard and read about Samson Raphaelson's play "Jason" before I went to see it, I had been misled into thinking it was some kind of debate on the subject of dramatic criticism. As this is a subject of little interest to me, I nearly missed going at all.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Recent experiments have demonstrated the advisability of sowing lawn seed, over old, "thin" turf, at the earliest possible moment -- any time the surface soil is thawed, even in February or March. On level ground it may be applied on top of a thin fall of snow, one advantage being that even distribution is thus possible, as the scattered seed shows up plainly.

The nickname was no accident. Above his young face, high up in the hair over his temples, appeared two tufts of gray that at times and in certain lights had the look of small horns. For this reason the Mexicans were apt to call him 'El Diablo,' but Americans knew him as Silvertip."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14 -- Rubber, once Brazil's leading export product, is believed by Brazilians to be ready to make a comeback after twenty-five years of oblivion.

Allied Liquor Industries, Inc., 10 East Fortieth Street, an organiza tion representing all branches of the trade, in a statement yesterday pledged its best efforts to help the industry and encourage moderation and temperance.

A new joint Austrian National Committee, supported by all Austrian organizations in the United States pledged to work for their country's liberation from Nazi domination, was organized yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

The Maritime Commission has approved the establishment of the Maine Maritime Academy at Castine, Me., and has plans to increase cadet enrollment at the institution to 200 by July 1. The State Legislature early this year voted to turn over the completely equipped property of the Castine Normal School to the academy for a shore base, and Governor Sumner Sewall has approved a measure providing an appropriation of $50,000 for one year.

THIS is the thrilling story of the epic fight of the overwhelmed, harassed, hungry but valiant Serbian Army during the first World War. It is the unbiased and careful work of an excellent historian, John Clinton Adams, an assistant professor at Dartmouth.

The following statement issued yesterday by Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, shows receipts and payments of New York City for January, 1942 and 1941, together with receipts and payments from July 1, 1941, to Jan. 31, 1942, and for the similar period a year before:

TORONTO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A brief but wild flurry of goals in the second period enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to pull out a 4-2 victory over the Detroit sextet before 11,367 fans tonight. The victory sent the Leafs into a second place tie with the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League standing.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 14 -- Yale defeated Dartmouth today in a closely contested indoor track meet, 51 1/2 to 48 1/2. The meet was the first in dual competition between the two teams on the boards.

One of the most delicious vegetables for a home garden is head lettuce. As good as much of the "bought" lettuce is, the homegrown is even better. One need be no master gardener to succeed with it and no equipment is necessary, except a small cold frame for starting the seeds.
WHEN will the great moving-picture-opera arrive? For it is certain to materialize, and the first great American opera may conceivably be written for that medium.

"AT HOME': The sumptuously furnished graystone Russian Embassy in Washington was the scene last week of the first "at home" of its hostess, Mme. Ivy Low Litvinoff. In the seventy-room mansion built by the widow of George M. Pullman, the sleepingcar magnate, and once occupied by the Czar's Government, the wife of the Soviet Ambassador entertained diplomats, Cabinet members, Congressmen, columnists, capitalists and even an Episcopal clergyman, the Rev. ZeBarney T. Phillips, Senate chaplain.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 14 -- Preparations have been completed at Villanova College to put the institution on a full war basis. An accelerated academic basis has been approved by the trustees, faculty and Student Council. It provides for a third semester of fifteen weeks to extend over the Summer months.

They laughed at such fantasy when William Shakespeare wrote of Birnam Wood moving to Dunsinane, but during the next few days a sizable tract of tall timber, complete with animals, birds, fish and even some of the humans who live by or in it, will move bodily into a building on Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Acting under orders from Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, a court of inquiry has been convened to inquire into the cause of the fire on board the U.S.S. Lafayette, the former Normandie, in New York last Monday, the Navy Department announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Commander Walter E. Zimmerman took over today command of the Naval air station at Lakehurst, N.J., succeeding Commander Fred Sachse, headquarters of the Fourth Naval District reported. Commander Sachse's next assignment was not announced.

The concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, was devoted to two major symphonies and, as a preliminary a concerto grosso of Handel which served to display again the quality of the Boston Symphony strings and the art of first desk players.

Depending upon the method of accounting employed by a business enterprise, deductions from gross income for income tax purposes are allowed if they are "paid or incurred" or "paid or accrued." In either case a deductible item is generally paid either in the taxable year or in a subsequent year.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- The safety of fifty-one American Maryknoll missionaries recently interned in Hong Kong and that of the seven escorted from their posts in South China to the Portuguese colony of Macao has been confirmed in a communication just received at Maryknoll headquarters from Bishop Frederick A. Donaghy in Wuchow, South China.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Department of Labor predicted today that new building construction expenditures in the United States in 1942 would exceed $10,750,000,000 and would constitute the largest dollar volume of construction in any year since 1928.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 14 (AP) -- War demand for steel, with greater domestic needs, gave the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company in 1941 its most profitable year since 1929, its net profit being $16,124,400. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $8.89 a share on 1,675,008 common shares, according to the preliminary statement of consolidated income, made public today.

MONTREAL, Feb. 14 -- The last-place Canadiens, playing one of their best games of the season on home ice, defeated the New York Rangers, pace-setters in the National Hockey League, by 5 -- 3 tonight before a crowd of more than 8,000.

If it is news when a man bites a dog, it is certainly news when a merchant urges a customer not to buy. Yet twelve big department stores of the city have today issued a joint advertisement, published in this newspaper, warning the public against the evils of excessive buying to hoard up articles that may become scarce in the future.

ANYBODY looking for a free dance education? If so the Museum of the City of New York, on Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, is definitely his goal, for the current exhibition of "Dancing Through Two Centuries, 1740-1940," is as rich and lively an assortment of informative documents, pictures and oddments as has ever been put together hereabouts.
"WESTWARD the course of empire takes its way," averred Bishop Berkeley in historic measures, as he pointed to the "Prospect of Planting Arts and Learning in America," in the early eighteenth century.

All men, whether citizens or aliens, 20 to 44 years old, inclusive, must register for Selective Service today or tomorrow between 7 A.M. and 9 P.M., unless they have previously registered or are in the Federal armed forces.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Among the regulation one-story wooden buildings housing thousands of men at this Army post, the company day rooms with cretonne curtains and potted flowers on the window sill symbolize the practical contribution of New Jersey's clubwomen to the morale and comfort of the camp.

MR. RUSSELL has walked through wartime Berlin with a candid-camera mind of his own. He was not interested in the official masks and smiles of leaders in the limelight. But neither did he try to catch his public off guard, in odd or awkward moods.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 -- To make certain that the widest possible use is made of the productive capacities of the automobile industry, automobile manufacturers will depend on subcontractors for two-thirds of the work to be done in turning out instruments of war, George Romney, managing director of the Automotive Council for War Production, said today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Legislative machinery was started today which may bring swift repeal of the recently adopted pension plan for members of Congress.

THE other day a bookkeeper checked off as finished a long movie job itemized in the studio ledger thus: No. 1300 -- "Reap the Wild Wind." Then, being curious, he turned to the first item in the ledger, which was; No. 1 -- "The Squaw Man."

A naval gun fired a single shot through the heat haze shimmering over Singapore Island on Feb. 14, 1938. A fleet of eighty planes droned in formation aloft. While twenty-four beflagged warships of the British China and East Indies squadrons and three visiting United States cruisers stood by in Johore Strait, the yacht of Governor Sir Shenton Thomas cut a ribbon stretched across the mouth of one of the world's largest drydocks.

The decision of the State Department of Education to demand after next Jan. 1 a master's degree as a prerequisite for a secondary-school teaching license makes it "inescapable'' for the City College School of Education to institute courses leading to the doctorate, Dean Esek Ray Mosher declared this week in the second half of his annual report to President Harry N. Wright.

Thank you for the delicious bit of fun contained in the "kind poem" of K. Nippo. For several days I went about smiling to myself ms I recalled the lines and the special brand of humor, so much to my liking, that must have inspired their composition.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14 -- Displaying endurance, Dartmouth tonight defeated Yale at basketball, 59 -- 48. The Green tightened its hold on the Eastern Intercollegiate League lead. George Munroe scored 22 points, and Jim Olsen 16 to lead the Dartmouth barrage.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 14 -- The growing number of Dartmouth students turning to handicrafts in their spare time has direct relation to the war and its accompanying mental conflict, it is believed by Virgil Poling, director of the college's Student Workshop, who this week reported on the first year of Dartmouth's extra-curriculum experiment "to teach men to use their hands as well as their heads."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the promotion of nineteen members of the crew of the naval tanker Salinas for their heroism in making it possible for the ship to reach port after being torpedoed off Iceland.

MOSCOW, Feb. 14 -- Important Russian advances on the central, Kalinin and Leningrad fronts were indicated tonight in front-line dispatches, although Russian communiques continued to withhold confirmation. The large scale of the present operations is shown by the long lists of awards published in precent days.

A dance festival for the benefit of the Russian War Relief, Inc., will be given on the evening of Feb. 27 at Carnegie Hall under the patronage of Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Ambassador to the United States, and Mme. Litvinoff: They expect to be present and occupy the box of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Carter.

ABSOLUTE PITCH -- Joseph Schillinger, well-known musician and composer, pooh-poohs the notion of absolute pitch, that is the innate ability to identify a note struck on an instrument without knowing how it is keyed. "There is no such thing as absolute pitch," says he. Pitch is established by national and international conferences.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- A six-day test of men and equipment under zero temperatures and over snow-blocked highways and icy fields is under way by a picked company from the Fourth Armored Division at Pine Camp, to determine the reaction of the human and mechanical elements to the severe ordeals of Northern New York midwinter.

WHEN Pierre Monteux and the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra put on a Saturday night concert, there are no yawning empty spaces in the War Memorial Opera House. By this time a full house is traditional.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- It is not impossible that, in the same week when Prime Minister Churchill must confront what London dispatches predict will be the most openly dissatisfied House of Commons of his tenure, the President of the United States will be listening to a more openly critical Congress than at any time since the war began.
CONTRACT bridge lost its first leading figure to the war effort last week when Tom Stoddard of Los Angeles entered the Army. Mr. Stoddard, a veteran of the first World War, was a reserve officer.

When Jack Blake was a small boy of 7 or 8 he was permitted to take the long horseback ride from their ranch to Santa Rita. It was night when they arrived, and as they entered the stable-yard of the Longhorn Corral the father was murdered -- shot down by four or five gunmen -- and the $11,000 he had brought to pay for his land was stolen from his saddlebags.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The General Fireproofing Company had, in 1941, one of the most profitable years in its history, earning a net profit of $1,527,715, against $1,099,119 in 1940, before provisions of $275,000 for postwar and other emergency adjustments, the annual report shows.

Amazement that the city was "sitting idly by" while the harbor's foreign trade zone on Staten Island, the only zone of its kind in the nation, was being taken over by the government without any provision for continuance of the project was expressed yesterday at a meeting of importers and foreign traders in 1450 Broadway.
VICHY, Feb. 14 -- Nazi authorities decreed the death penalty tonight for any one aiding Americans or citizens of other countries at war with Germany to hide from occupation authorities.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 -- Steel orders for war purposes continued to flow into mills last week at a rate generally exceeding output, and the type of business was such that most of it carried exceptionally high priority ratings.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 13 (Delayed) -- Captain Arthur W. Wermuth of Chicago, who has killed 116 Japanese and captured many more, is America's No. 1 one-man army to his fellow-officers of the Fifty-seventh Filipino Scout Regiment.

After devoting six consecutive Sunday programs at Town Hall to the music of Schubert, the New Friends of Music returned yesterday to the three other composers whose works it is presenting this season, and under its auspices the Budapest String Quartet played Mozart's Quartet in D major, K. 499; Mendelssohn's Andante and Scherzo, Op. 81, and Dvorak's Quartet in E flat major, Op. 51.

A shiny blue-black car eased up to the Hotel Endicott at Columbus Avenue and Eighty-first Street yesterday and a father of two stepped out while his youngsters looked questioningly through the unclosed door.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek thanked President Roosevelt and the American people today for the $500,000,000 loan made to China last week for the common war against Japan.
Five new films will arrive on Broadway this week. The schedule follows:

In a recent column we mentioned the new .30-caliber carbine which has been designed to replace the .45-caliber pistol for about 80 per cent of the armed forces who previously carried this arm. Since then we have received numerous inquiries for more information on this new carbine, which is not quite as new as many seem to think.

Several weeks ago a letter appeared in your columns regarding a project to collect used stamps, ship them to England, where the dye was to be extracted, and the proceeds used to support six hospital beds in the Queen's Hospital in London.

The cost of world-wide domination by the United States would far outweigh the "world-wide prestige" that would follow in its wake, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer warned yesterday morning in his sermon in the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.
BERLIN, Feb. 15 (From German broadcast recorded by Reuter) -- Today's German communique said:
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for January was 156.4, compared with 155.9 the preceding month and 149.5 for January, 1941.

The Eastern intermediate saber team championship went to Salle Santelli yesterday in the annual competition at the Fencers Club. The Santelli representatives triumphed easily in the round robin, N.Y.U. placing second and the Greco Fencing Academy third.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- A new Army policy which will provide draft deferment for all medical students and all pre-medical students of acceptable standing was announced today by Colonel Leonard G. Roundtree, medical director of the Selective Service Board, who spoke at the annual meeting of the National Conference on Medical Service.

The leader of a gang of loft thieves who jumped low bail, set after he had agreed to cooperate with the District Attorney's office, was recaptured yesterday by detectives who had patiently trailed his wife for eight months.

East met West yesterday as several thousand Chinese and native Americans of both oriental and occidental descent observed the arrival of the year 4639 of the Chinese lunar calendar with day-long celebrations and a parade in New York's Chinatown.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A proposed expansion program of mineral and power developments in the United States scaled to meet the enormous demands of the President's war production schedule will be laid before the Senate tomorrow by Secretary Ickes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 15 -- "Shock troops" to augment forest fire fighters in New Jersey were recommended today by Assemblyman Vincent S. Haneman of Atlantic County, who also warned of the increased dangers to the State's forests from sabotage.

Subway, elevated, street car and bus lines operating within the city limits carried in the fiscal year ended on June 30 last 3,130,626,092 passengers, or 14,441,813 fewer than in the previous fiscal year, according to the twenty-first annual report of the Transit Commission, made public yesterday after copies had been sent to Governor Lehman and members of the Legislature.

Mourning the burning last week of the former liner Normandie, pride of the French merchant marine, the Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard, rector of the French Church of the Holy Spirit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, said yesterday that the French people can be grateful that there were no French sailors aboard when the fire started.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 15 -- Japanese forces struck from two directions tonight at Thaton, forty miles northwest of Martaban on the Rangoon railroad, and the battle for the east coast of the Gulf of Martaban neared its climax.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Charles H. Kramb of suburban Gates has given up hope at last. He knows now that none of his three sons will be back from the Navy when the war is over.

After running the gantlet of enemy submarines in a northbound voyage along the Atlantic coast, the 4,756-ton tanker Point Breeze, owned by the Atlantic Refining Company of Philadelphia, came to grief with the loss of two of her crew last night in peaceful Long Island Sound by grounding off City Island.

Coordination of the facilities of the entire advertising industry to help win the war is virtually completed, Chester J. LaRoche, chairman of the Advertising Council set up for the purpose last November, announced yesterday. The organization, whose aims have been approved by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, will undertake to assist the government in utilizing advertising to instruct the public concerning the war program.

BOSTON, Feb. 15 -- As the nation's track public buzzed excitedly about Corny Warmerdam's epic 15-foot-7 1/4-inch pole vault, the highest in history, indoors or out, the Californian was a bit disappointed today as he flew home to resume his high school teaching career.

The Newark A.C. first team of the Misses Dorothy Grieve, Imogene Mellon, Flo Riley and Evelyn Scofield won the national A.A.U. junior 200-yard free-style relay championship and Miss Helene Rains of the Women's Swimming Association had an easy triumph in the metropolitan A.A.U. senior 100-yard breast-stroke title event in a swimming meet at the W.S.A. yesterday.

VICHY, France, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Steel nets hung over their sides protected the German battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau and the cruiser Prinz Eugen from British bombs during their many months at Brest, it was learned today.
Another warship for the Navy's ever-growing fleet, the destroyer Meade, was launched yesterday from the Staten Island yard of the Bethlehem Steel and Ship Building Company at Mariners Harbor.
Plans for the transfer of many WPA employes to emergency war work were announced yesterday by Major Irving V. A. Huie, WPA administrator for New York City.

Most markets continued active last week, with expected shortages playing an important part in the placing of commitments. There was a definite trading-up tendency in the dress markets, and a number of manufacturers discontinued the $6.75 line. Demand was off on low-end dresses.

The most convincing proof of the Church's "Catholicity" lies in the work of her native clergy in the nations of the world, the Rev. Joseph M. Lynch, national secretary of the Society of St. Peter the Apostle for Native Clergy, declared yesterday at a solemn vespers service in St. Patrick's Cathedral commemorating the feast of the Chair of St. Peter at Rome, patronal feast of the society.

IRONWOOD, Mich., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Torger Tokle of Brooklyn, N.Y., was crowned Class A champion in the seventh annual open ski tournament held on the Wolverine Hill today. He had leaps of 216 and 211 feet and his form was rated near perfect.

Even before Singapore fell, Japan launched her invasion of Sumatra. If it succeeds, the enemy's steel claws will have closed around Java, last citadel of the United Nations in the Indian Ocean, from the north, west and east. But it is in Java rather than Sumatra that the Allies are expected to make their real stand.

Hub Macey and his New York Rover team-mates, scoring six straight goals in the second period and adding another in the last frame, overcame the Baltimore Orioles, 7 to 1, in the Eastern Hockey League clash featuring the amateur twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

OTTAWA, Feb. 15 -- President Roosevelt broadcast to Canada tonight from Ottawa through a recording made in Washington, stirring the people of this country to a new realization of their partnership in the war and the effort that will be needed to overcome the perils that are threatening.

Long Island University and Seton Hall, two of the East's leading quintets, will clash tonight in the feature contest of a college doubleheader that is expected to attract the second capacity basketball crowd to Madison Square Garden in three days.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Yonkers and New York detectives were investigating today "certain addresses" found in memorandum books of the late Mrs. Florence Schnoor, 24-year-old bride of Richard Schnoor of Armonk Village, who died Friday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Yonkers, from the effects of an illegal operation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The considered judgment of responsible officials in Washington is that the fall of Singapore marks the darkest moment of the war for the United Nations. Even the anticipation of the event and the rhetoric of Winston Churchill did not minimize the feeling that this blow may be decisive in the Southwest Pacific and may vitally affect the outcome of the conflict in China and the Middle East.

Dr. Sigmund Spaeth, in 212 E 48th St; John E. Woodruff, in 1060 Park Ave; Kathryn Fergueson, in 192 E 75th St; Paul Knight, in 662 Lexington Ave; Edward Leon Lewis, in 140 E 81st St; John Cromwell, in 245 E 72d St, through Douglas Gibbons Co; Culver, Hollyday Co, brokers.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15 -- With Manager Mel Ott greeting arrivals with a cheery smile and a hearty handshake, the vanguard of the Giants converged upon this famed Winter resort today to launch the Spring training season.

Suits for men and women, pajamas, sports clothes, underwear materials, dresses of every type, in fact every article in the family wardrobe will be on the market in plentiful supply this Spring and Summer, the rayon industry revealed recently with a display of products showing how far the adaptable chemical fiber can be made to go in the fields where wool, linen, silk and cotton have been used.

Cotton prices moved irregularly last week in a narrow range and closed the period showing only slight changes. At the close of the market on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 1 to 7 points for the week.

STOWE, Vt., Feb. 15 -- The Rocky Mountain flash, Barney McLean of Denver, once again showed his flashing heels to a formidable field in carrying off the ninth annual United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association combined downhill and slalom championship today.

There are still a few astonishing contrasts between the Administration's public pronouncements and some of its actual policies. To cite but one example -- though a tremendously important one -- the same Administration that is still expressing concern regarding the supposed complacency of the country at large is itself insisting on retention of the forty-hour week.

In his talk yesterday Prime Minister Churchill reminded the British people that their situation, serious as it is today, is much less serious than it was in August of 1940 or even in August of 1941. But he made no effort to belittle the recent British adverses or to promise good news in the months immediately ahead.

A sharp rise in juvenile delinquency among boys as fathers entered the armed forces and mothers are absorbed into defense industries and engage in other wartime activities is predicted by the Big Brother movement in connection with its annual report for 1941 made public yesterday.

L. Bamberger Co. leased for storage and distribution purposes the building at 489-97 Broad Street, Newark, N.J., from the 493 Broad Street Corporation. The property has a right-of-way to the rear from Essex Street and was leased through Feist Feist, brokers.
HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- The forty-fourth anniversary of the sinking of the U.S.S. Maine in Havana Harbor was jointly observed by Americans and Cubans here today with services at the Maine Monument.

Four hundred delegates to the annual conference of the Zionist Organization of America in the Hotel Astor adopted yesterday afternoon a resolution for mobilization of "the man power of the Jewish population of the country to secure the establishment of Palestine as a Jewish commonwealth after the war."

National Distillers has started an advertising campaign on Old Overholt bonded whisky in Pennsylvania, which is one of the most competitive programs to be developed since repeal of prohibition. In the 1,000-line ads which are scheduled for Easton, Erie, Scranton, Allentown, Wilkes-Barre and other Pennsylvania towns, National frankly challenges the blends with the headline "You Pay the Price, But Are You Getting All Whisky For Your Money?"

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Bob and Virginia Jahn of Cresskill put on a brother-and-sister act today in sweeping the senior men's and women's divisions of the New Jersey outdoor speed skating championships at Burnham Park.
The last mass at the marble high altar in St. Patrick's Cathedral was said yesterday by Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre at 12:20 o'clock.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Yale's program of required physical training to equip every student of the university physically for service in the armed forces was announced today by President Seymour.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Slowly rising temperatures in the South and Southwest have resulted in Fall-sown grains starting to show the usual Spring growth and field work is progressing northward, with some seeding of oats reported last week as far north as Southeastern Kansas.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- The Council on Medical Education and Hospitals of the American Medical Association today dropped the University of Georgia Medical School from its list of approved schools.

Never out of the money in the fixture, Gene Venzke will compete in his thirteenth straight Baxter Mile at the thirty-first annual indoor games of the New York Athletic Club at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Paul Pilgrim, director of the games.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 15 -- American astronomers, arriving today for the Inter-American Astrophysical Congress, which opens Tuesday at Puebla, said that the meeting would be dominated by two main themes -- first, the changing view of stellar evolution and, second, methods and results of study of the Milky Way, which will constitute the chief work to be done with the new telescope that is being mounted at Tonanzintla, in the State of Puebla.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Ottar Satre, Norsemen Club veteran, won the annual Norway S.C. invitation ski jumping tournament today before 3,000. He jumped 125 feet, then 159, the best distance of the day, for a point score of 216.8.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 15 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Following is today's regular communique of the Netherlands Indies Armed Services:

LONDON, Feb. 15 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Exactly half of the note issue of the Bank of the Netherlands is now covered by German Treasury notes and mark notes. Since the naming of Rost Van Tonningen by the Germans as director of the bank, cancellation of the clearing arrangement between Holland and Germany and lifting of the "devisen frontier" on April 1, 1941, Holland has virtually been annexed financially by the Reich.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 15 -- It was reported from Vatican circles today that the question of the canonization of Christopher Columbus has once again come to the fore. This time Pope Pius XII has received a petition signed by several thousand Americans, it was reported, requesting the granting of special procedure.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The entrance of the United States into the war is a fact that cannot be compared with anything else "in the whole world," Prime Minister Churchill said in a world broadcast tonight.

Wendell L. Willkie and Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, have been elected honorary national chairman and chairman, respectively, of United China Relief and have helped to reorganize the agency as a permanent fund-raising body for the duration of the war, United China Relief headquarters announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Curtailment in the consumption of natural and mixed natural and manufactured gas was ordered by the War Production Board today to assure adequate supplies for war production activities.

"To be the Church and not a pale imitation, not standing on anything but the fundamentals of God" was cited yesterday morning by the Right Rev. J. Hutchison Cockburn, Moderator of the Church of Scotland, as the greatest contribution that the church can make to the world today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 15 -- Draft registration varied yesterday in Nassau County with the majority of districts reporting twice as many registrants as Saturday while others reported that registrations were slow or below expectations.

The St. John's Prep swimming team retained the Brooklyn Catholic high schools dual-meet championship by defeating the St. Francis Prep squad, 41 -- 26, yesterday in the Columbus Council pool. Bishop Loughlin High finished third, downing Brooklyn Prep, 44 -- 23.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Use of steel and other key materials needed for arms production is cut to a minimum under a basic construction policy for defense public works projects, and announced today by Baird Snyder 3d, acting Federal Works Administrator.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Fence-corners and cast-off farm lands, vacant city lots and idle rural acres will be pressed into service this year to help feed America, according to Governor Prentice Cooper of Tennessee, chairman of the United States Department of Agriculture's advisory committee on war gardens.

When Japanese troops swept over Singapore, after their determined push down the Malay Peninsula, they opened a whole series of new lines of possible attack, pointing north to Rangoon and the Burma Road, south to the Netherlands Indies and Australia and across the Indian Ocean to India herself.

Lieut. Gov. Charles W. Poletti, Mayor La Guardia, the Rev. John Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, and representatives of organized labor, religious and welfare groups will participate at the opening session this morning of the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice.
William G. Bond is with Coffin Burr in the municipal bond department.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Price of wheat held within narrow limits last week, with a considerable part of the news of a bearish character. Despite this handicap and uncertainty regarding the outcome of additional price control legislation in Washington, prices averaged higher, although at one time a break carried the market to a new low since early in January.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Feb. 16 -- The German High Command has been forced to draw on its Spring reserves to throw in large formations of infantry and mechanized columns in a so-far vain attempt to halt the Russian drive on the North Central sector, according to dispatches from Moscow received here early today.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 15 -- Shells began to fall on Fort Kalang, headquarters of the Malayan command, on the evening of Tuesday, Feb. 10. Oil fires were blazing in the north of the island. Smoke from them lay like a black pall over Singapore.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 15 -- Senator James J. Davis announced today that he would run for the Republican nomination for Governor despite the opposition of the State organization to his candidacy.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Feb. 15 -- A crew of 1,600 men began work tonight in the forest of timbers under the battleship Alabama to prepare the 35,000-ton vessel for her launching at the Norfolk Navy Yard at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.

Wagner's "Parsifal" will be performed at the Metropolitan Opera House next week for the first time this season. It will be given as the fifth and final work in the Wagner matinee cycle. Kerstin Thorborg will sing the role of Kundry for the first time here, and John Garris, new American baritone, will make his debut as the first knight of the Grail.

Few days go by without notice from Washington of some new article that the American people are going to dispense with in their revision of life to win the war. Some of these are easily foreseen. Others come as a shock.

A THICK, loose-leaf volume with a heavy leather cover was deposited on this desk for inspection. It was a collector's item, with palms. It consisted of some 300-odd pages of names, dates, teams, statistics, biography, history and illustrations having to do with varied sports over a span of many years. It had a little of everything in it.

Believing that women now have less time to devote to hair arrangements, the Manhattan unit of the New York State Hairdressers and Cosmetologists Association, Inc., offered a new "time saving" coiffure last night at its beauty show at the Hotel Penn sylvania. The feature of the show, which was entitled "Wartime Trends in Hair, Hats and Beauty Fashions," was a basic coiffure cut three inches short all around the head and set in upswept lines.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 15 -- What appeared to be a possible start of a German attempt to drive eastward toward the Libyan-Egyptian border got off to a bad beginning yesterday when United States-built Kittyhawk fighters attacked and virtually annihilated a force of Stukas and fighters sent out to cover German ground movements by attacking British positions.
The Red Men of America have chosen Premier Joseph Stalin of Russia as the outstanding warrior of 1941 and named him an honorary chieftain.

Further delay in equipping New York City with the air raid sirens it has sought since the outbreak of the war developed last night when it was learned that police officials had rejected flatly installation bids by electrical contractors on the ground that they were too high.

According to an announcement yesterday by Borough President James A. Burke, Queens soon will have its own air raid engineering department. Specialists trained in the protective measures required in bombing attacks and air raids will direct the borough's defenses.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings snapped a four-game National Hockey League losing streak tonight by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 5 to 0, before 7,221 spectators for Goalie Johnny Mowers's fourth shut-out of the season.

The Very Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, announced yesterday acceptance of his election as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island. He gave his decision at the close of his sermon at the 11 o'clock service at the Cathedral.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- It was reported tonight that an Australian warship had rescued 1,300 British troops who were being evacuated from Singapore after forty Japanese bombers had attacked and set fire to a transport, seven miles off the island, with three direct hits.

For nearly two years America has been fighting a war in the future. In 1940 the country was being told how enormous its war production was going to be in 1941 and 1942. Today, in 1942, we have been told how enormous our production is going to be in 1943 and 1944.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -- Mickey Rooney will play the leading role, that of a telegraph messenger boy named Homer, in "The Human Comedy," William Saroyan's first photoplay, which Metro will produce. Saroyan has completed the scenario in 400 pages, and he will serve as a producing and directing consultant on the picture, working with a regular Metro producer and director.

The New York City Symphony Orchestra was led by Henri Pensis, Belgian conductor, for the first time at last night's concert in Carnegie Hall, presented under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 -- Mrs. Olive Wilbur, 74 years old, died today of injuries and shock suffered on Saturday when an elevator in her home fell two stories. Edna Wilbur of Los Altos, Calif., the Wilburs's daughter, said the elevator was installed at their home, 241 Frederick Street, for her mother, who found it difficult to climb stairs.

PHOENICIA, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- George Nicholson of St. Lawrence University today captured the New York State slalom championship, leading a strong array in 2:05.3. Bill Erickson of Colgate was second, third place going to Roy Wrisley of St. Lawrence.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 15 -- An eighty-mile-an-hour chase along the Pulaski Skyway ended here early today when a Newark motorcycle policeman fired a bullet that shattered the rear window of a speeder's automobile. Three youths in the car were held by Newark police pending an investigation.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Farmers in the eleven Northeastern States are planning to have women, children, the aged and convicts drafted to alleviate a severe labor shortage expected this season, J.H. Wood, regional director of the Farm Security Administration, reported today.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Although the vast majority of British investors continue to sit tight and the markets have not been troubled by heavy liquidation, it was a bleak week for the stock markets. It is some time since they encountered such a combination of adverse developments which concerned not only the military but also the financial field.

TOKYO, Feb. 15 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Military leaders here immediately hailed the conquest of Singapore as placing Japan in position to "control the fate of India and Australia."

OTTAWA, Feb. 15 -- Statements made in a radio broadcast tonight by Drew Pearson and Robert S. Allen that Canada had refused landing privileges to an American airline from Chicago to Fairbanks were denied here with the comment that the airline in question -- the Northwest Airways -- had never made formal application for such privileges and that no United States application of the kind had ever been refused by Canada.

Members of the junior division of the Navy Relief Society held an entertainment, known as a Junior Miss Valentine Party, yesterday afternoon in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre in behalf of their organization. During the afternoon there were divertissements by professional entertainers.

Federal and city authorities issued a warning yesterday to all persons whose activities entitle them to enter piers or other waterfront areas that a deadline would be set soon for the issuance of identification cards.
ROME, Feb. 15 (From Italian broadcast recorded by Reuter) -- Today's Italian communique said:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Jim Bickford, the Red Devil pilot from Saranac Lake, today added the North American two-man championship to his collection of bobsled honors. He won the four-man crown yesterday.

To obtain an income tax deduction for traveling expenses, the Bureau of Internal Revenue said yesterday, the taxpayers must conform to certain regulations. He must attach to his return a statement showing the nature of his business, number of days away from home in the taxable year on account of business, total expenses for meals and lodgings and the total of "other expenses" incident to travel.

AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, Feb. 15 (UP) -- Thirty-nine members of the crew of a British freighter and five passengers and nine crew members of a Greek freighter, both torpedoed and sunk in the North Atlantic, reached here today.

Expressing the hope that its $500,000 Emergency Building Fund campaign would be oversubscribed, Howard S. Cullman, president of the Beekman Hospital, Beekman and Water Streets, emphasized in its twentieth annual report yesterday the hospital's added responsibilities caused by the war.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- A comely 22-year-old Cornell University co-ed who likes engineering "because of its mathematical basis" is one of the nation's first women radio control operators.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- An R.A.F. communique issued here today said:

VICHY, France, Feb. 15 -- It is now as certain as anything can be that France's great unpreparedness trial, so long awaited, will open next Thursday before the Supreme Court of Justice at Riom. Joseph Barthelemy, Minister of Justice, visited the court there on Saturday and found arrangements in a state of confusion, but reported to the Cabinet that all would be in readiness at the appointed time.

The American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company, in its twenty-sixth annual report issued for publication today, reveals net earnings for 1941 of $3,194,873, equal after preferred dividends, to $3.56 a share on the 769,092 shares of common stock outstanding.

Leading Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergymen and laymen issued yesterday a declaration of fundamental religious beliefs held in common by followers of the three faiths as part of the annual observance of "Brotherhood Week" sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

A minimum of 500 volunteer workers, men and women, are needed urgently to take part in the various defense projects of the Department of Welfare under Commissioner William Hodson, according to James G. Blaine, Greater New York chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks clung to a 1-0 lead for more than fifty minutes against the Boston Bruins tonight, then counted again at 17:17 of the final period on Bob Carse's unassisted shot to beat last year's Stanley Cup winners, 2 -- 0. The National Hockey League contest drew a crowd of 17,104 to the Stadium.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of China returned to this Indian capital today from the Northwest frontier, where he inspected strategic Khyber Pass and addressed tribesmen, whom he described as "loyal friends of the British."
The following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's broadcast from London yesterday as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- The price of lard futures on the Board of Trade held within relatively narrow limits last week, with only a light speculative interest. While commission houses were fair sellers at times, packer brokers picked up the offerings and closing sales on Saturday were at gains of 2 1/2 to 10 cents a hundred pounds.

Peggy V. Taylor added something novel to the season last night by giving a recital of "hand dances" at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. The idea of concentrating on the hands is not a new one (as what is?), for Tilly Losch, Gluck-Sandor and perhaps others have done hand dances before this, but so far as the records disclose Miss Taylor is the first to devote an entire evening to the subject.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 15 -- Sixty thousand Russian prisoners of war in Rumanian concentration camps are on the verge of starvation and death from disease, according to reports from foreign military intelligence sources here tonight.

Samuel Lakow Sons, Inc., dealers in commercial furniture, who leased the four-story building at 20 Beaver Street in 1918 for a long term from Robert Walton Goelet, have bought the property from the Goelet heirs. The property fronts twenty-seven feet on Beaver Street and runs through to Marketfield Street.

Maude Runyan, English mezzosoprano, whose studies were sponsored by Lady Astor until she won a scholarship of the Royal College of Music in London, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Her program ranged from "Ah, Rendimi," a classic Italian air by Rossi, to Sioux songs the singer learned from the Indians of South Dakota.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Following is the text of a recorded address by President Roosevelt, broadcast in Canada tonight, as made public at the White House:

DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Victor C. Swearingen, State labor conciliator, announced tonight that an agreement had been reached to resume work tomorrow morning at the Aluminum Company of America's plant, where 600 employes walked out late yesterday.

Fires that the police and Fire Marshal's office charge were set deliberately caused damage early yesterday morning to Temple Emanu-El at 984 Post Avenue Port Richmond, S.I., and to the home of the congregation's rabbi at 186 Palmer Avenue, four blocks away.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Congress, facing a situation worsened by the fall of Singapore, entered today upon a new period of unpredictable mood and action in the light of its recent outcroppings of criticisms of the conduct of overseas and domestic war operations.

With the addition of John Golden, Broadway producer, the membership of the League of New York Theatres, the organization representing theatre operators and producers, has been increased to forty-seven. This was announced yesterday by James F. Reilly, the league's executive secretary, who said Mr. Golden had joined last Friday, "apparently realizing the good work the league has recently been doing and recognizing that unity among managers is also vital during these times."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The text of a War Department communique, based on reports received up to 1 P.M., Eastern war time, today said:

Notre Dame was the team of the week in college basketball. The Irish not only ran N.Y.U. into the ground here on Saturday but also conquered the mighty Great Lakes Naval Training Station quintet in Chicago last Monday. These successes made it thirteen victories in seventeen starts for Notre Dame and six straight.

VICHY, Feb. 15 -- One of the fundamental points of the government's program is to prevent a rise in prices or at least to retard it as much as possible, since a general rise in prices would be equivalent to internal depreciation of the franc.
The tinless "tin can" and the reclaimed rubber heel are on their way into the family of American products mothered by wartime necessity, it developed yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 15 -- There is no gainsaying that recent phases of the war, such as the surrender of Singapore, the setback to the British in Libya and the successful passage of the Gneisenau, Scharnhorst and Prinz Eugen through the Strait of Dover, have induced some foreign observers to doubt whether the Russian front remains the principal theatre of operations.
MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique broadcast today follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- On the basis of reports filed with the Department of Correction, crimes of all classifications in the State totaled 1,308,658 in 1941, an increase of 115,306 over 1940, Commissioner John A. Lyons informed the Legislature today.

The preliminary report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation for 1941, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $3,981,601, after all expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to 33 cents a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $6,380,815, or 52 cents a common share, in 1940.
Registration of women at the same time as men was advocated last night by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in another of her Sunday evening sponsored broadcasts over the Blue network.

As a "patriotic contribution" to the war, members of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes will waive all overtime wages resulting from screening of government films in American theatres, Richard F. Walsh, international president, announced yesterday.

Although continuing to hold that the city's civilian defense problem is distinct from that confronting other parts of the State, Mayor La Guardia conceded yesterday the desirability of a single State-wide law covering the operation of air raid wardens during alarms and providing appropriate penalties for failure to obey their orders.

The third registration under the Selective Service Act went into full swing yesterday, particularly in cities, and when the books closed for the day at 9 P.M., indications were that perhaps 7,020,000 men in the United States and 468,000 in New York City had been written into the record of the nation's manpower.

After playing al fresco for several months the American Youth Theatre has found a permanent home for "Of V We Sing" at the Concert Theatre in Fifty-eighth Street. On Saturday evening the drama critics were permitted to take a peek at it.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb 15 -- Smiling Melvin (Chick) Harbert, a kid from Michigan playing his second year of professional golf, shot a fantastic 30 on the final nine holes today to tie Ben Hogan for first place in the Texas open tournament.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Mrs. Winston Churchill, who has daughters in the Women's Auxiliary Territorial Service and the Women's Auxiliary Air Force, tonight made a "fireside" appeal for the girls in the services.

The most important composition on the program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Eugene Goossens, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was the violin concerto in B minor of Saint-Saens, with Erno Valasek as soloist. Jaromir Weinberger's "Lincoln" symphony and Gliere's "Marche Heroique" rounded out the list.

LONDON, Feb. 15 (Reuter) -- This third Spring of the war is ushered in on a subdued note. London's fashion belt has resolutely set aside frivolity and whimsies until the better times that will come with the peace, and styles for the coming season will be restricted in number and essentially practical in character.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Navy announced tonight that eight authorities on sports and physical education would advise on the physical training aspects of the new naval aviation training program.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Advance Russian columns were reported tonight to be slashing through White Russia toward the old Polish frontier in a series of lightning thrusts that appeared to be undermining the whole German position on the central front and cutting off the Nazis' key base of Smolensk.

"Constructive deeds of healing and brotherhood" are needed as foundations for "a redeemed society," the Rev. Dr. Phillips Packer Elliott declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark, Brooklyn.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose by 0.2 per cent to 102.6. The most notable change of the week took place in the miscellaneous group, which declined by 0.4 per cent in reflection of lower prices for bran, middlings, and cottonseed meal.

Approval of Winston Churchill's declaration in his radio speech that the war against the Axis powers must be fought out to a successful conclusion by the United Nations was expressed last night by Alfred M. Landon, former Governor of Kansas and Republican nominee for President in 1936, before his departure for his home in Topeka.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 15 -- For a change from northwest blows, there was a light southerly breeze today for the sailing dinghy races at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Arctic clothes were shed by the Winter windjammers instead of being piled on.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 15 -- After three conversations with Reichsfuehrer Hitler, one with Reich Marshal Hermann Goering and one with Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop, General Ion Antonescu, the Rumanian Premier, returned to Bucharest this morning "satisfied" with whatever agreement was reached.

From the hills of Pennsylvania into a Greenwich Village kitchen came the recipe for a crisp, bubbly cookie so utterly chewy and sweet that the merest sniff turns good little girls into amateur marauders. A magical mingling of spice and molasses flavors the wide, curly disks, while dates and toasted nut meats virtually burst through the tops.
VICHY, France, Feb. 15 -- Paul Charbin, Secretary of State for Supplies, spoke bluntly today over the radio to the people of France on the subject of food supplies.

Police organizations have agreed to limit retirements from the department under a plan worked out after pressure from city officials had convinced them that such a step was in the best interests of the 3,800 eligible for pensions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The "plane-ship team," which today is the spearhead of victory on the seas as the "plane-tank team" is the principal arbiter of victory on the land, participated last week in several naval actions that may shape the course of things to come.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 15 -- Fresh reports to foreign political circles in Ankara tonight said that General Draja Mikhailovitch, the Yugoslav War Minister and Generalissimo of the loyal regular and Chetnik armies in Serbia, urgently needed assistance.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 15 (AP) -- George K. Bodenschatz, 59, president of the Louisville Shoe Products Company, and his wife, Viola, 55, arrested here last night by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of failing to register as Nazi agents, were released today on bonds of $5,000 each.

The present war is not a football game with defense bonds as admission tickets. It is not enough to let our team take all the physical punishment while the spectators cheer wildly, wave flags, sing catchy songs, shout slogans such as "Let MacArthur do it," and generally enjoy themselves; and the rest of us just listen in on the radio.
The importance of the nation's foot health was stressed yesterday at the all-day sessions of the New York State Podiatry Society at Hotel Pennsylvania, attended by 300 members.
Showing little respect for their rivals' reputation, the Brooklyn Americans conquered the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Finishing with a score of 11 -- 1, Herbert Seidman of Brooklyn College won the annual tournament of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday. Seidman took ten of his games and drew two. His last victory was gained at the expense of J. Richman, who, adopting the Indian defense, lost in 37 moves.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Monday, Feb. 16 -- The Japanese, having opened their drive on Sumatra with a parachute attack Saturday on the Palembang oil region, continued their campaign yesterday with a large-scale landing of troops from ships on the coast about sixty miles from Palembang. The landing was made in an area of marshes and mangrove swamps along the muddy banks of the Musi River, which leads to Palembang.

BATAVIA, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops poured ashore in Southern Sumatra today for a land drive on Palembang. Anticipating the attack, Netherlands Indies forces destroyed oil wells in the Muara Enim area and refineries at Plaju.

The La Guardia administration is facing "the most serious budget-balancing problem in recent years" in the preparation of its budget for the fiscal year 1942-43, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick declared yesterday in a message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

Urging all New Yorkers to observe "General Douglas MacArthur Week," which will begin today under the auspices of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, Leon Fraser, local chairman, declared last night that generous contributions from all would be one way of demonstrating appreciation of the efforts of the military leader.

Greater New York is still about a million dollars short of its Red Cross War fund quota. To stimulate those who haven't given to this cause, or who haven't given all they can, this week has been designated as "General Douglas MacArthur Week." General MacArthur and the other soldiers and sailors who are fighting our battles have had as much purely verbal gratitude as they can use at the moment.

The B.S.
