Moss Company has leased for twenty-one years at an aggregate rental of $150,000 the one-story building containing bowling alleys, cocktail lounge and a restaurant at Northern Boulevard and 258th Street, in Little Neck, L.I. The structure is on a plot 150 by 100 feet and was erected by the Remsenburg Realty Company, the owner.
OTTAWA, Feb. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Fifteen thousand Victory Bond salesmen tomorrow morning will launch a nation-wide drive aimed at raising at least $600,000,000 to help meet Canada's war bill.

The surrender of Singapore is more than a lost battle in a war made immeasurably longer and harder by this defeat. It brings to an end the first phase of the struggle for the Pacific and with it the end of the world of dreams in which the almost unbroken sequence of Japanese successes, from Pearl Harbor on, took everybody by surprise.

In Mr. Krock's excellent column in THE TIMES of Feb. 8 there was a passage devoted to the subject of news censorship which I hope will be read by the interested members of your staff. You will recall that Mr. Krock deplored the current practice of playing up favorable news items and subordinating, or sugar-coating, the less pleasant news.

The ranks of internes and nurses in local hospitals have been so depleted by demands from the armed forces that hospital attendants appeared as substitutes for internes on city ambulances yesterday. At the same time that Mayor La Guardia announced the change in manning ambulances he disclosed in his weekly broadcast from City Hall that the city needed 10,000 nurses' aides, of whom 1,200 had been enrolled.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The Legislature enters its seventh week tomorrow, with the pile of routine measures growing higher daily, but with decisions still pending on the two most important matters, namely: the Governor's home defense program and the State budget.

Last week's foreign exchange market developed the curious contrast of a dip in the premium on the Cuban peso, which in previous weeks had been forging steadily ahead to the highest in several years, and to finish at a loss, while the Canadian dollar shook off the irregularity of the preceding week and closed at a gain.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Weakened but not stopped in heavy fighting with British forces, the invaders who crossed the Salween River from Paan on Friday forged ahead in small groups, hunting weak spots in the thin defense line in preparation for the next big assaults.

Speed in the reconditioning of existing buildings to provide living quarters for workers in war industries in the New York metropolitan area is stressed in a survey of housing conditions just completed by the Citizens Housing Council of New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- General Douglas MacArthur reported from his Philippine stronghold on the Island of Luzon today that enemy preparations for the long-anticipated all-out Japanese offensive against the American and Filipino positions in the Battle of Bataan were visibly under way.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The text of a British Air Ministry communique said today:
Carl Cooper Helm, formerly with Arthur Kudner, Inc., has been appointed manager of the public relations department of Best Foods, Inc.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Singapore has fallen.

HUGH BYAS, former (until May, 1941) Tokyo correspondent of this paper, talks straight from the shoulder today in a book called "The Japanese Enemy."* He says what he has to say in 100-odd pages, but the pages are worth reading word for word at this time.

TOKYO, Feb. 15 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese parachute troops landed at Palembang, Sumatra, have occupied the airdrome and other key military positions and Japanese planes already are operating from the airdrome, Imperial Headquarters announced today.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 15 -- Instead of a registered event at 100 targets, the gunners of the Nassau Trapshooting Club held two separate 50-target shoots today. In the first shoot, Lynn Hunt and B. Doerrer tied for the scratch prize, each with 49. On a toss, Hunt won.

Religion is "a very personal thing," and Jesus "demands from us a very personal discipleship," the Rev. Dr. Edgar Tilton Jr., pastor emeritus of the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church, between Madison and Park Avenues, declared in a sermon there yesterday morning.

The introduction of identity cards, favored by the Gallup poll and by Roger Paul Craig and J.R. Beckman in letters to THE NEW YORK TIMES, touches one of the most important points in the defense of the Western Hemisphere. Only by a coordination of all the individual registrations we already have can we form a real picture of our forces.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The presses will start rolling "within a day or two" on what the Office of Price Administration believes is the biggest printing order ever placed -- copies of "War Ration Book One" for every man, woman and child in the country.

At a special meeting of stockholders of the Square D Company held yesterday in Detroit F.W. Magin, president, reported for the year ended on Dec. 31 net income of $3,104,342 after all charges including provision for income and excess profits taxes of $7,687,500 and $250,000 provision for wartime and post-war adjustments.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 16 -- The first enemy attack against American soil occurred early this morning when German submarines shelled a Standard Oil refinery on Aruba Island, in the Netherland West Indies off the coast of Venezuela, and sank three tankers with the loss of twenty-three lives.
BALBOA, Canal Zone, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Captain Robert Bruskin, one of the officers accompanying Lieut. Gen. Frank Andrews on his inspection tour, gave this description today of the attack on Aruba:

RANGOON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Tonight's communique said that the British had withdrawn from their Salween River line, which the Japanese had penetrated at several points, to "concentrated positions" along the Bilin River.
The four-story apartment house for twenty-one families at 123-25 Summit Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Commercial Trust Company to Joseph Schultz.

The term "contemporary music" can be ambiguous. The thought crossed the mind at the first of the three programs of the "contemporary chamber music series" offered by the Musical Art Quartet and Frank Sheridan, pianist, last night in the Museum of Modern Art.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- While the desert armies in Libya, on the western flank of Suez, manoeuvred toward what appeared likely to be another major battle, the portent of a coming German storm through Turkey on the other flank, appeared in reports reaching London today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Japanese forces in the Southwest Pacific region followed up the conquest of Singapore by launching a fresh and formidable attack against the forces under General Douglas MacArthur, who have savagely withstood numerous other attacks against their position on the Bataan Peninsula.

Six young men in khaki stood at attention in the general's office at Governors Island yesterday and grinned like schoolboys as the Army and Navy for the first time disclosed a bit of news the public has been longing to hear for weeks -- an enemy submarine, one of the pack preying on Allied shipping off the Atlantic coast, had been spotted and blasted by bombs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today the application of the Atlantic City Electric Company and the American Gas and Electric Company for approval of the issue by Atlantic City of 62,000 shares of its cumulative preferred stock at a price of not less than $100 and a percentage of 4 1/2, the price and yield to be determined by competitive bidding.

Builders and developers from all over the nation are writing our committee to find out how many defense homes are needed around Norfolk. Most of them seem to think Norfolk has laid down on the Navy by letting the Norfolk house shortage grow so acute.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 16 (UP) -- Defense officials appealed today to Connecticut and visiting motorists to comply with blackout regulations tomorrow night when eighty miles of the State's shoreline is darkened in the Eastern Seaboard's first major rehearsal of air raid precautions.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 16 -- Ann Johnson, flight commander of the recently formed women's unit of the Georgia Civil Air Patrol, appealed today for "equality with men in non-combatant military service."

Nothing could arouse more enthusiasm among Americans than General Douglas MacArthur's heroic struggle against superior Japanese forces, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, declared in unveiling a large photograph of the General yesterday at City Hall as part of the observance of General MacArthur Week in the Red Cross War Fund drive for $7,330,000 here.

Stanley Need, New Haven pianist and former pupil of Alexander Siloti, gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. His brief program consisted of a Bach group, including Mr. Siloti's transcription of the Chaconne; a Chopin group and, in a final group, Rachmaninoff's G sharp minor Prelude, Scriabin's Poem and Liszt's transcription of the "Tannhaeuser" Overture.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said today:

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Carl Dann of Orlando, Fla., competing in the tournament for the thirteenth time, found that number a lucky charm when he led in the qualifying round of the national championship of golf club champions today on the St. Augustine links.

Stanley Clarke, trustee in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, yesterday called for an "early settlement" of the involved recapitalization litigation between the company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation in the interests of security holders of both concerns.

The resignation of Dr. J. Campbell White as pastor of the West Forty-fourth Street United Presbyterian Church was announced last night following an official meeting of the church and at the same time it was made known that the eighty-eight-year-old church was to be sold and the parish dissolved.

A manoeuvre that would do credit to a magician, but which was performed by a patriotic American furnace man who distrusted and wanted to outwit a couple of Nazis, was described in Federal court yesterday by the furnace man himself, Walter Edward Morrissey.

TOKYO, Feb. 16 -- (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Premier Hideki Tojo told Parliament today that Singapore's fall would enable Japan to dispose of Burma, China, India, the Netherlands Indies, Australia and New Zealand, in that order.

Spokesmen for the medical profession voiced approval yesterday of Mayor La Guardia's announcement on Sunday that hospital attendants with Red Cross first-aid training would replace internes on ambulances answering emergency calls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Congressional pension provision in the recently revised Civil Service retirement law will be repealed before any member of Congress can benefit from it, it was predicted today by Senator Barkley, majority leader of the upper House.

ROME, Feb. 16 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A British destroyer, a patrol boat and seven merchantmen in a big convoy bound from Alexandria to Malta were sunk by an Axis air and sea assault lasting three days, the Italian High Command announced today.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 16 -- Japanese invaders, attacking by the thousands, have seized the burned-out oil center of Palembang, Southern Sumatra, only an hour's bomber flight from this capital of the Netherlands Indies.

Governor Lehman joined yesterday with the Governors of many other States in an appeal for complete cooperation and unity of purpose among Americans of every race and religion. The appeals marked the annual observance of Brotherhood Week, which begins today.

While we were shivering on a hill, waiting for an occasional crow to pay some attention to a stuffed owl, Allen Corson was flipping a plug on a tropical river and taking big snook every other cast. To make matters still worse, he had to write and tell us about it.

Light trading which kept any pressure at a minimum characterized yesterday a steady stock market despite the heaviness of the war news. In scattered instances gains of a point or more were recorded but the general run of additions hovered in the fractions.

Continuing their cooperation with Mayor La Guardia on his suggestion that men be pensioned from the Police Department under a stagger system approved first in April, 1940, whereby thirty-nine men would be permitted to retire each month, the Police Pension Fund of New York City approved pensions yesterday for fifty members of the department who had applied for pension retirement since Jan. 19.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that sales of Series E defense savings bonds through banking issuing agents during the first fourteen days of February amounted to $38,000,000 in the Second Federal. Reserve District.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- In the presence of Governor Lehman and other ranking officials, New York State moved today to help provide adequate housing facilities for defense workers. Contracts were signed for the construction of two defense housing projects in Tonawanda and North Tonawanda, near the Buffalo industrial section.

In accordance with provisions of its constitution, the New York Stock Exchange approved last week the application of DeHaven Townsend for permission to continue its status as a member firm from Feb. 10, 1942, the date of death of the sole Exchange member partner of the firm, William B. DeHaven.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Unfavorable war news over the week-end and a decline in cotton caused the grain markets to start lower today, but a rally in the stock market and an announcement that the Commodity Credit Corporation had advanced its asking price for cash wheat one cent a bushel brought in professional and commission house buying and a strong upturn followed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- As the House debate began today on a $221,069,700 appropriation measure to finance 1948 operations of the State, Justice and Commerce Departments and the Federal judiciary, it was disclosed that vigilant visa authorities had prevented enemy agents in 750 "open-and-shut cases" from entering this country in the guise of innocents seeking asylum in this democracy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A reorganization of the Division of Industrial Economy in the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce to adjust it to new conditions in the world of business caused by the war was announced today by Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones.

The concert of the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall last night was like a cozy at home. Leon Barzin, musical director of the association, took his audience on a trip behind the scenes, hoping in this way to give an idea of how the organization works.

The advocacy of an increased birth rate to provide "inestimable numbers of men for huge American armies in time of war" was criticized yesterday as unsound by Mrs. Vincent Sheean, who scored "shallow thinkers conducting armchair campaigns."
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 16 -- The British announced today their troops had withdrawn from the Thaton-Duyinzaik area to the line of the Bilin River, about thirty miles nearer Rangoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- Kurt Arthur Max Kalb, 35-year-old German butler for John D.M. Hamilton, former Republican national chairman, is being held as an undesirable enemy alien, the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed today.
Manhattan's quintet triumphed over the Boston University Terriers by 56 -- 43 last night in the Jaspers' last home game of the season.

VICHY, Feb. 16 -- Former Premiers Eduard Daladier and Leon Blum and their fellow-defendants in the war-guilt trial are still at Bourrassol Manor in comparative comfort. They will be transferred to the prison at Riom on Wednesday.
George W. Hill Jr., a vice president and a director of the American Tobacco Company, has entered the Army.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C.P. Wichfeld entertained tonight with a dinner at the Reef for their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks and Mr. and Mrs. J. Dinsmore Tew, having also Mr. and Mrs. Crawford Hill, Mr. and Mrs. Claude K. Boettcher, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Holmsen, Mrs. George Eustis Paine Jr., Charles H. Boettcher 2d.
The British retreat in Libya, now at least temporarily halted, emphasizes the coalescent strategy of this war.

Counsel for New York City and Westchester communities urged the Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission yesterday to deny the application of the New York Central Railroad for a 10 per cent increase in commutation rates or to suspend the schedules until the need for them was established.

It is not astonishing that there should be growing opposition in Congress to the Administration's proposal for an initial appropriation of $300,000,000 for the payment of special "war displacement benefits." The original bill sponsored by the Administration is bad in more than one respect.

DETROTT, Feb. 16 -- Lack of aluminum and ill effects of a seven-day working week on employes have caused the Ford Motor Company to reduce war production in its aircraft engine and tool and die plants to a six-day schedule.

John P. Morrissey, Tammany leader of the Sixteenth Assembly District, north, and Frederick H. Gillmore, a lawyer, were nominated last night as Democratic and Republican candidates, respectively, for the Assembly seat made vacant by the resignation of Robert F. Wagner Jr. Mr. Wagner is now a captain in the Army.
MOSCOW, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

The first ray of hope that poliomyelitis, more commonly known as infantile paralysis, may actually be checked comes from Drs. Claus W. Jungeblut and Murray Sanders of Columbia's Department of Bacteriology. The two have conducted scores of experiments indicating that one strain of poliomyelitis virus, after its adaptation from the monkey to rodents and many passages from mouse to mouse, may protect monkeys infected with any one of three types of virus of human origin.

Following closely upon announcement a few days ago that the board of trustees of the National Gallery of Art in Washington had elected Chester Dale to the office of associate vice president, comes news that another large consignment of paintings from Mr. Dale's splendid collection has just been received, the work of art, like those that preceded them, sent from this city as indefinite loans.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- There is deep and intense uneasiness in this country, and under the British political system it may burst its bounds, although all people concerned want to avoid this if possible. Downing Street, resentful both of the press and Parliament, is supremely confident of its hold on the people, and is considering going to the country and having a general election.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The British Middle East Headquarters communique said today:

Air raid protection must be a "streamlined" affair from which "committees of estimable citizens" should be eliminated, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday, announcing that if this city is attacked from the air, Irving Huie, Commissioner of Public Works, would be in sole charge of civilian defense.

WILLEMSTAD, Feb. 16 (UP) -- Today's attack on Aruba appeared a far bolder foray than the raids on unescorted shipping off the United States and Canadian coasts. To reach the Netherland island, only fifteen miles off the Venezulean coast, the submarine had to run the gantlet of the Windward and Leeward Islands of the Antilles Chain or pass close to Cuba and Haiti.
ROME, Feb. 16 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- A Japanese official news agency dispatch recorded from the Tokyo wireless today said that yesterday's surrender of Singapore was agreed upon at a forty-nine-minute meeting between Lieut. Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita, the Japanese commander, and Lieut. Gen. A.E. Percival, the British commander, and the agency gave the following account of their conversation:

The shelling of an American oil refinery on the island of Aruba is Hitler's first attack on the soil of the Western Hemisphere. In terms of damage done, the early results of such exploits may be relatively slight, except as they spread confusion or fear. Symbolically they may herald heavier blows to come.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- "Knights Without Armor," a screen story by Jay Dratler and Gina Kaus about guerrilla warfare in Yugoslavia, was purchased today by Columbia for $20,000. According to the authors, the yarn is based on a Serbian legend of five champions who fought against the Turks in the Middle Ages and then fell asleep for centuries, to awaken only when their country needed them.
STOWE, Vt., Feb. 16 -- "When you think of snow, think of Stowe," a slogan coined for this quaint Green Mountain hamlet, was fittingly substantiated today.

Paul J. Kern and Wallace S. Sayre were removed as members of the Municipal Civil Service Commission last evening by Mayor La Guardia, who announced that Mr. Kern's place as president of the commission would be taken by Harry W. Marsh and that Mr. Sayre would be replaced by Mrs. Bruce D. Bromley of Brooklyn.

As the western democracies fall back before the heavy blows which Japan has struck and is continuing to strike in the Far East, let us at least take advantage of the lessons we should now have learned from two months of unsuccessful war in the Pacific:

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Russians announced official ly today the occupation of several more points on the vast Winter front with "heavy losses in man power and material" inflicted on the Germans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- After weeks of backing and filling by all concerned, followed by further weeks of negotiations between Treasury and Congressional fiscal experts, the rough outlines of a new tax bill had emerged far enough today for it to be announced that the next ten days or two weeks would see hearings start.

In an urgent plea to the paper industries to convert all its facilities to production of essential products only, Norbert A. McKenna, chief of the Pulp and Paper Branch of the War Production Board, declared yesterday that "if we lose this war we shall be destroyed for centuries to come and we can lose it at the current rate of progress."

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- Adolf Hitler yesterday completed his disinheritance of Rudolf Hess, the renegade "Vice Fuehrer," with the appointment of Richard Bohrmann to be second in line as successor to Herr Hitler "should any thing happen." Herr Bohrmann recently published a book violently attacking the Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The State Department announced today that the Bolivian Government had agreed to pay $1,500,000 in United States currency to the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in full settlement of the long-standing claims of the oil concern and its Bolivian subsidiary.
The A.L. Davis Company, retailers of surgical and orthopedic appliances and artificial limbs, has taken a store in 327 West Fifty-seventh Street through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Governor Lehman declared today that, while he favored additional Federal aid for workers made idle by conversion of industrial plants to war production, he was definitely opposed to complete Federalization of the present unemployment insurance system.

Mastery of a repertoire of inexpensive and well-balanced menus "that you can just step into the kitchen and start cooking" with the knowledge that vitamins and pocketbooks will agree will allow one to cope gracefully with the wartime budget, according to Dr. Allene Houghton.

The message which this nation intends to convey to the world by its registration of 9,000,000 men, completed yesterday, and of 18,000,000 men, completed last year and the year before, is that which Captain John Paul Jones gave when the flag of the Bonhomme Richard was shot down.
Federal Housing Administrator Abner H. Ferguson has appealed to financial institutions to get behind the FHA's current drive for more privately built housing for war workers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Government plans for making 1,000,000 radio sets, built to Federal specifications and capable of receiving short-wave as well as local programs, to be made available to Latin-Americans, were virtually completed today.
BERLIN, Feb. 16 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German communique said today:

The accent was laid on line and color in the parade of the new fashions that passed up and down the narrow room of Zoe de Salle's East Fifty-third Street establishment yesterday afternoon. Hats and bags were an integral part of all the daytime costumes, for the designer puts her best effort into making a harmonious ensemble.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works and its subsidiaries, including the Midvale Company, transferred consolidated earnings of $3,975,499 in 1941 to surplus after deducting Baldwin's proportionate share of $430,150 of the reserve for war contingencies set up by Midvale at the year-end, according to the annual report of Charles E. Brinley, president of Baldwin, for publication today.

Testifying yesterday before the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices at its first hearing in this city, Mayor La Guardia took labor unions to task for racial discrimination as a prime factor in what he termed a very difficult problem.

With trading activity restrained by the unfavorable war news, the cotton market moved in listless fashion yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures lost as much as 17 points in early trading, but recovered later as contracts grew scarce and trade buying orders dribbled in.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16 -- While American naval forces hunted submarines that attacked tankers north of the Venezuela coast, Mexico intensified her preparations today to protect her own gulf coast, especially the oil region near Tampico and Progreso, so far as additional troops can do so.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Netherland Command issued this communique today through the Aneta Agency:

A deed was recorded yesterday in the Register's office by which the five-story Racquet and Tennis Club building, covering the west blockfront on Park Avenue between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets, was conveyed by the executors of the estate of Robert W. Goelet to the club.

Mauricio Schechter, for many years Cuban representative of Cluett, Peabody Co., shirt makers, has leased an apartment of seven rooms and three baths in the building at 171 West Seventy-first Street through the Apartment Renting Company, Inc., brokers.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- State Senator Phelps Phelps, Manhattan Democrat, has been called to active duty in the Army, he notified William S. King, clerk of the upper house, today. He holds a reserve commission as first lieutenant.

Every one has a pet preference or a pet prejudice. There was the girl, for example, who was very like any other college student except in one outstanding particular. Her favorite food was grapefruit. When a feminine crowd sat on the floor, discussing Life at a midnight hour, and the smoke hung heavily in the narrow room, this young woman would reach calmly for a grapefruit instead of a sandwich.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 16 -- The $80,000,000 battleship Alabama, nine months ahead of schedule, slid from her cocoon of cranes and ways at the Norfolk Navy Yard today before a cheering crowd of 30,000, including Secretary Knox, while a fine rain fell from a sky as slate gray as the 35,000-ton monster herself.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Although staged in a setting that promised to provide a vast improvement over playing conditions here a year ago, the Giants' 1942 Spring training campaign under the new manager, Mel Ott, got off only to a 50 per cent start today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Roosevelt declared today that "we shall not falter" in pressing for the defeat of the Axis "until the task is complete and our freedom made secure." He made these remarks in receiving from Walter Nash his credentials as the first Minister of New Zealand to the United States.

Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, in his first speech since returning from the Pan-American Conference of twenty-one nations at Rio de Janeiro last month, said here last night that he wondered if the people of the United States fully appreciated the "striking demonstration of friendship and of support which has now been offered by their neighbors in the New World."
No ordinary birthday cake was the one set in front of Mrs. Adelaide Moore yesterday in the pencil workshop of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, 200 West Seventy-second Street.
Selective Service headquarters in Washington disclosed yesterday that local draft boards had been directed to defer "labor leaders" and government labor liaison men.

Vincent Starrett, who rambled through a volume he called "Books Alive," published about a year ago, has a new one in the same spirit coming from Random House on Feb. 27. This he calls "Bookman's Holiday" with a subtitle of "The Private Satisfaction of an Incurable Collector."

From San Francisco's Chinatown to New York's the arrival of the year 4639 in the Chinese calendar is being celebrated this week. The Japanese can count back only to 660 B.C., or 2,602 years, when their first Emperor, Jimmu Tenno, ascended the throne. The Japanese have had gods for emperors ever since and have found this fact very handy when they desired to commit the sort of deeds that badly needed divine sanction.

Rules of the New York Stock Exchange providing for "special offerings" through its facilities became effective yesterday, on approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission, but the first prospective instance of a special offering was handled in the regular way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A comprehensive plan for rigid and detailed control over production, consumption and allocation of steel plates was outlined to the steel industry yesterday at a meeting of plate producers by C.E. Adams, chief, iron and steel branch of the War Production Board.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The United Nations Southwest Pacific Command communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- George Sylvester Viereck, alleged mastermind of pro-German propaganda in the United States, went on trial today on a charge of violating the Agents' Registration Act, but great difficulty was experienced in selecting a jury.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 16 -- Although German columns of mixed arms continued yesterday to operate eastward toward El Gazala and as far as forty miles south of that point, it was not yet evident that Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was going to force a pitched battle.

One United States citizen, Miss Therese Bonney, a photographer who took 6,000 photographs in the last year in England, Spain and unoccupied France, was among the ten passengers who arrived from Europe yesterday on a Portuguese freighter.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16 -- The Russians are still advancing. Today's midday communique reported engagements on the entire front and front-line dispatches referred to heavy German counter-attacks, especially in the central and southwestern sectors.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Taking issue with statements that soldiers and sailors dislike being entertained by private citizens, the Westchester County Citizens Committee for Service Men will operate for the duration of the war by using 500 private homes and a number of clubhouses for parties, officers of the committee announced to night.

PRETTY strong medicine, but if you can stand it strong so long as it is the genuine article, by all means read Robert Ramsey's "Fire in Summer."* This is a first novel by a former University of Arkansas law student who is said to be now living and working in Memphis, Tenn.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 -- Colonel and Mrs. Robert H. Montgomery opened their estate yesterday to the annual tropical ramble, which will aid the Fairchild Tropical Garden. The ramble continues today. Mrs. Montgomery is general chairman for the event, and many women from the North are on committees.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 16 -- Calling strongly for a policy of "no more retreats" by the United Nations, the China Times today says:

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A member of the New York State Bridge Authority, controlling three lower Hudson River toll spans, protested today the proposed transfer of authority duties to the State Department of Public Works.

The executive offices of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey were assured yesterday by the manager of the Lago Oil and Transportation Company at Aruba that no employes ashore had been injured and that no part of the plant had been damaged by the U-boat bombardment. Executives understood that the submarine's shells had dropped among the installations.

The new Gilbert and Sullivan bill, opening tonight at the St. James, will be "The Pirates of Penzance," preceded by the Jooss ballet production of "The Prodigal Son." For the dance presentation the curtain will rise at 8:30 and for the operetta at 9:15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Spring wheat growers were warned today by the Department of Agriculture that the last day on which they may apply for crop insurance on their 1942 wheat crops is Feb. 28. All applications must be submitted to the office of the local AAA committee on or before that date in conformance with the policy of requiring applications before growers plant their crop.

The annual report of the M.A. Hanna Company, Cleveland, issued for publication today by H.M. Hanna, chairman, and G.M. Humphrey, president, shows a consolidated net profit for 1941 of $4,093,717, equal, after preferred dividends, to $3.39 a share on 1,016,961 shares of common stock of the mining and shipping concern.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Roosevelt called on his Congressional leaders today to rescue the Administration's $300,000,000 program for aiding workers displaced by war plant conversions from the deadlock into which it has fallen in the House Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Democratic party leaders from Capitol Hill, received the Minister from New Zealand, who presented his credentials, and took luncheon with Bernard M. Baruch.

Add to the list of openings this week, "A Gentleman at Heart," arriving Saturday at the Globe. Cesar Romero, Carole Landis and Milton Berle head the cast . . . "Mr. District Attorney in the Carter Case" and "Below the Border" compose the double-feature program, starting today, at the New York Theatre.

The greatly increased milk production quota for the war can be met by the dairy industry through a revised system of feeding calves without increasing present herds, which not only is unnecessary but is "not good economics," according to Dr. W.E. Krauss, head of the Ohio Agricultural Experiment Station at Wooster, Ohio.

In order to improve conditions for a world record attempt by Greg Rice, Chairman John J. Storms yesterday rearranged the field for the Toussaint two-mile at the New York A.C. games in Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

Clarence H. Low, chairman of the City Salvage Committee, announced yesterday that 6,298 salvage wardens have been appointed to date by police precinct captains. He congratulated the Police Department for its efforts in this respect and said the response of the public to the salvage campaign had been satisfactory.

Larry MacPhail taxied over to Manhattan yesterday, signed Dolph Carnilli to a 1942 contract to work for the Dodgers, then motored back to Brooklyn, where he signed Curt Davis to do some fancy flipping for the Flatbush clan. Thus two of the most promising hold-out sieges in the National League were nipped in the bud.

THERE was a picture in the paper of three smiling young fellows in the uniform of the Royal Canadian Air Force. Milt Schmidt, Bobby Bauer and Porky Dumart, late of the Boston Bruins. They were the coruscating "Kraut Line" of hockey.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 16 -- Travelers returning from Austria report increasing signs of unrest in that country. They cite as significant the spontaneous cooperation between the outlawed Christian Socialists and the Communists, though it has so far been impossible to trace any clandestine joint organization.

TOKYO, Feb. 16 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) ciated Press) -- A Singapore dispatch of Domei, official Japanese news agency, gave this account today of the preliminary negotiations for the British surrender:

Johnny Colan, promising young boxer of the West Side, and Jimmy Webb, Houston, Texas, light-heavyweight, yesterday were signed for a return battle in Madison Square Garden on March 13. The bout is expected to produce an opponent for Champion Gus Lesnevich.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 -- The jinx following "big name" horses at Hialeah Park functioned again today when William L. Brann's Challedon took a six-length beating from Frances D. Scully's $25.20-for-$2 shot, Ponty, in the Southern Cross purse.

The long-awaited return match between Long Island University and Seton Hall College had the vast majority in a crowd of 17,611 at Madison Square Garden last night bowed down in a deep and agonizing gloom, for the pride of New Jersey, giving undoubtedly its worst basketball performance of the season, was routed by the Blackbirds, 51 to 30.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 16 -- The Republican-controlled Legislature surrendered today to the demand of Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, that he be allowed to appoint Leonard Dreyfuss of Essex Fells, president of an advertising firm, chairman of the New Jersey Defense Council in place of Major Audley H.F. Stephan of Trenton, who has held the position by virtue of his office of State Budget Commissioner.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 16 -- Engineering plans for construction of the proposed Westchester County Airport on the Rye Lake site in Purchase in a manner that would prevent runaway drainage from reaching New York City's adjacent Rye Lake reservoir were filed with county officials here today by the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the War Department.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Governor Lehman virtually indicated today a veto of pay increases for State employes to equalize the rising cost of living. The Republican leadership of the Legislature is committed to a pay-rise program.

War work and defense work, not to mention tire restrictions, mean additional footwork for girls. To break in unaccustomed feminine feet and to help hardworking women step high, wide and handsome with the minimum of agony, a specialist in foot treatment has assembled in business packages four of her requisites of daily foot-care.
BATAVIA, Feb. 16 (AP) -- H.V. Quispel, a Netherlands Indies naval spokesman, said in a broadcast today:

Operations last year of the National Biscuit Company and its subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $10,732,137 after depreciation, Federal and foreign income and excess profits taxes, but exclusive of the write-down of plants, real estate and machinery, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Directors of the E.I. duPont de Nemours Co. authorized yesterday an interim dividend declaration of $1.25 a share on the common stock for the first quarter of 1942, payable on March 14. Previously the company had paid $1.75 quarterly.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 16 -Four members of the Election Board in the Twenty-third district, Eighth Ward, went on trial here today in Quarter Sessions Court before Judge Thomas H. Brown and a jury on charges of conspiracy to permit fraudulent voting in the Jersey City municipal election of May 13, 1941.

Troubled more by their own mistakes than by the opposition, the New York University basketball team nevertheless took the measure of Rutgers University, 41 -- 34, in the University Heights gymnasium last night.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- British bombers blasted at docks in the German-occupied French port of St. Nazaire last night, the Air Ministry announced today, and observers expressed the belief that the raiders were seeking out destroyers and other light craft that accompanied the Nazi battleships Scharnhorst and Gneisenau on their spectacular dash through the English Channel last Thursday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- How doctors must spread their services in all-out war and what civilians must do to aid them, were outlined today before the annual congress on medical education and licensure. The meeting is under the auspices of the Council on Medical Education and Hospitals of the American Medical Association.

The investment banking firm of Harris, Hall Co., Inc., of Chicago reported yesterday for 1941 a net income of $84,805, equivalent to $1.17 each on 61,000 shares of outstanding common stock, after deducting dividends paid on the preferred stock and a contribution of $4,463 to the employes' trust fund.

Arthur Kent, young American baritone who joined the Metropolitan Opera Company last year, reported for active duty with the Army yesterday, but because his day's duties were finished early enough, he was able to get to the Metropolitan Opera House in the evening to fulfill his scheduled engagement to sing Baron Douphol in the fifth and final "Traviata" of the season.

In one of the most rapidly completed condemnation proceedings in the city's history, Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn Supreme Court awarded yesterday a total of $994,793 to owners of 1,189 1/2 acres taken by the city for the construction of the new municipal airport in the Idlewild section of Queens.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A sweeping search by more than 200 Scotland Yard detectives resulted tonight in the arrest of a man -- identified as a member of the Royal Air Force from a near-by base -- for the slayings of at least three women during London blackouts.

American magazine cartoonists made an all-out pictorial attack against the Axis yesterday afternoon at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, at the preview of an exhibition, "Cartoons Against the Axis." The display is sponsored by the American Society of Magazine Cartoonists in cooperation with the New York Defense Savings Staff of the Treasury Department.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Melvin (Chick) Harbert, 27-year-old professional from Battle Creek, Mich., won the Texas open golf tournament today, beating Ben Hogan by four strokes in an eighteen-hole play-off.

Registration for the "father-and-son" draft closed last night, with indications that the advance estimates of 9,000,000 registrants in the nation and 600,000 in New York City had been substantially accurate.

William Kapell, 19-year-old New York pianist, has been named the winner of the 1942 Town Hall Enidowment Series Award, Walter W. Naumburg, chairman of the Town Hall music committee, announced yesterday. He is the youngest artist ever selected for the honor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Enactment of a law to make it a criminal offense, punishable by fines or imprisonment, for any one without specific authority to divulge the contents of secret or confidential government documents was urged upon Congress today by Attorney General Biddle.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- Both houses of the Hungarian Parliament, having passed the bill creating a vice-regency, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent, is now empowered to convene them within eight days to name his eventual successor, reports from Budapest today said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb 11: Increases of $77,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, and $274,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $150,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Mrs. Charles M. Higgins of the Plaza gave a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Room of the hotel. Her guests included Mrs. Alanson P. Lathrop, Mrs. Walter Magee Annette, Mrs. Edward Everett Watts, Mrs. August Zinsser, Mrs. Gustavus A. Humphreys, Mrs. Edward A. Deeds, Mrs. Theodore Stanfield, Mrs. Oakie Alexander, Mrs. Joseph A. Altsheller and Mrs. William H. McKleroy.

Irwin Kaplan, Los Angeles middleweight, won a decision over Ralph Zanelli, Providence, in the star bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Holding an eight-pound pull in weights, Kaplan proved too strong for Zanelli and easily handled his foe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Roosevelt, in a recent communication with Premier Joseph Stalin, has agreed to make another "very large and substantial loan" to the Soviet Union, it was learned tonight in responsible quarters.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Netherland West Indies, Feb. 16 (AP) -- An enemy submarine, breaking into the Caribbean through the outer screen of American and Allied bases protecting the Panama Canal, shelled the Netherland West Indies island of Aruba today, torpedoed and presumably sank three tankers off the coast and damaged another tanker off Curacao.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 17 per cent for the week ended Feb. 14, in comparison with the corresponding week a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Steel production this week will be the second highest on record in the history of the American steel industry with 1,634,100 net tons, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, comparing with 1,622,400 tons last week, 1,614,200 tons on month ago, 1,526,700 tons a year ago, and a high mark of 1,650,500 net tons in the week beginning Oct. 27, 1941.

Fashion observers who attended yesterday morning's showing at Bonwit Teller's found that the war had not cramped Molyneux's style when it came to the creating of a Spring collection. It was an ABCD collection, the themes being American, British, Chinese and Dutch.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 16 -- The fall of Singapore has naturally intensified Australia's anxieties. It is assumed today that the early release of huge Japanese forces in Malaya would provide additional enemy strength for a large scale southward drive and it is expected that the primary Japanese objective would be to cripple Australia's war effort by a bombing blockade or even an attempted invasion.
MOSCOW, Feb. 16 -- A documentary motion picture on "The Rout of the German Armies Before Moscow,'' that will probably rank among the greatest films of the sort, is now being shown here.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- On the heels of a direct statement by Mayor La Guardia to legislative leaders that so far as general defense needs are concerned, New York City must be treated apart from the rest of the State, the Legislature witnessed tonight the bipartisan sponsorship of a resolution which, if carried out, would abrogate that separation.

A Navy court of inquiry appointed by order of Secretary Frank Knox sat in the Federal Office Building at 90 Church Street yesterday in the opening session of an investigation into the burning and capsizing of the former French liner Normandie.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 16 -- In proportion to our population, less than half as many people are engaged in our war effort as at the close of the 1918 World War, the Cleveland Trust Company declared today.

Five hundred persons attending a memorial service honoring those who died on the battleship Maine on Feb. 15, 1898, heard last night a bitter attack on "the mushroom millionaires" who are taking advantage of the current conflict "to profiteer at the expense of the agony of the nation."

Plans were filed yesterday for several large building projects, including a new five-story factory building in Elmhurst and a group of thirteen dwellings in Springfield, both in Queens, and alterations costing about $200,000 in the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.

In spite of the spurt that followed Pearl Harbor the sale of defense savings bonds and stamps has not been as good as it should be. Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau calculates that only one out of seven of the nation's income earners has thus far bought defense securities and our total effort is relatively much behind what the British public has accomplished.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Office of Civilian Defense, under the new direction of James M. Landis, will limit the application of its physical fitness program to people "who are going to fight for us either on the battle line or the production line" and not include "little children."
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 16 -- Singapore was defended to the bitter, blazing end by the bravest army in the world, against probably the greatest odds an army ever faced.

OTTAWA, Feb. 16 -- A secret session of Parliament to discuss the Pacific Coast situation and the whole question of effectives and munitions for defense was promised by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King this afternoon in reply to questions from the Opposition benches.

FREEPORT, L.I., Feb. 16 -- A strike of 125 machinists and polishers in the Columbian Bronze Corporation here virtually halted today the plant's production of propellors and other ship parts for the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- On the basis of reports reaching them yesterday from all parts of the country government officials were inclined to abandon any plans for the rationing of tea to consumers and to concentrate on controlling what stocks remain.

Miss Eugenie M. Tuck, debutante daughter of Captain Alexander J.M. Tuck of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., was elected a manager of the Opportunity Shop, a permanent thrift shop at 46 West Forty-seventh Street, at a recent meeting of the organization's board of managers, of which Mrs. Charles King Morrison is chairman.

HAVANA, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Miss Georgia Tainter, Fargo, N.D., star, turned in the best gross score today in the opening round of the fifty-four-hole invitation handicap tourney for the President Batista Trophy, but Senora Adriana Martinez de Hevia, Cuban player, had the best net score, 78.

George Washington was the first Great Grand Sachem of Tammany Hall. His successor to the honorary title was John Adams. The third incumbent was Thomas Jefferson. To make the story short, all our early Presidents up to and including Andrew Jackson accepted the courtesy title regularly bestowed by the active heads of the benevolent and fraternal Society of St. Tammany or Columbian Order.

The present is not a time for recrimination but one for winning the battle of production, Miss Lucille J. Buchanan, assistant industrial commissioner of the New York State Labor Board, said yesterday at a luncheon of Advertising Men's Post 209, American Legion, in the Hotel Lexington.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 16 -- The fall of Singapore is a severe blow to the United Nations' cause, Prime Minister Peter Fraser said today. Pointing to the increased danger to the Pacific democracies, he called for preparations to meet further attacks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- From the field of opinion as to correct military and naval strategy this correspondent, in the immortal Hollywood phrase, "includes" himself out. That is an area which can be soundly explored only by trained officers and by such competent civilian experts as Mr. Hanson Baldwin of this newspaper.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Chungking radio, in a broadcast of the Chinese communique, as received here today by the Columbia Broadcasting System, said:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Feb. 11 aggregated $9,492,000,000.

The eleventh annual Bloomingdale's pet dog show will open at 1:30 P.M. today with the showing of the toy dogs. George Jessel will act as master of ceremonies as 107 entries parade before the judges on the sixth floor of the store.

It is time for Congress to stop playing politics. What I call playing politics is voting for measures that appeal to minorities for the purpose of assuring re-election, and not for the sole reason that a measure is good for the whole country. It is said that the country is not sufficiently aroused.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A drastic housecleaning by Prime Minister Winston Churchill in Britain' War Cabinet, with some leading Ministers to be swept into the discard, was predicted in informed circles tonight as an aftermath of the Singapore disaster, the English Channel humiliation and defeats in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Axton Fisher Tobacco Company of Louisville, Ky., has filed a registration statement with the San Francisco regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, covering 149,944 shares of new 5 per cent cumulative prior preferred stock, of $25 par value, to be issued under a plan of recapitalization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Supreme Court decided by four to two today in favor of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation in a long-fought lawsuit of major importance where the government attempted to recover what it terms "unconscionable" profits made by the concern from World War ship contracts.

By way of celebrating Ott Heller Night at Madison Square Garden tonight, the New York Rangers will try to beat the Montreal Canadiens for the fifth time in the final National Hockey League clash of the season between the teams.

Exporters were aroused yesterday over the latest ruling of the Board of Economic Warfare and the OPA that price ceilings on products for export would be considered retroactive and in force even though export licenses had previously been granted.

American advertising in Mexico is holding up, with increased copy on proprietaries, foodstuffs and other lines, not affected by shortages, offsetting declines in advertising for priority-affected products, Daniel C. Kaufherr, vice president of Irwin Vladimir Co., Inc., said yesterday, following his return from a survey of the Mexican market.

The behavior of the market for Treasury obligations yesterday was described as "satisfactory" in view of the character of the war news and the $1,500,000,000 offering last Friday of 2 1/4 per cent bonds, due in 1955, callable in 1952. Subscribers to the new 2 1/4s, incidentally, will have the new experience of obtaining approximately 30 per cent allotment, the largest that has been made on a new issue in several years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have recovered eight $1,000 bonds stolen from the Nebraska National Bank at Grand Island, Neb., more than nine years ago and an additional $30,000 in stolen bonds, most of which were taken from a New York brokerage house messenger Sept. 8.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The stock markets held up fairly well today in face of the surrender of Singapore, reports of Japanese landing in Java which were later denied, and the attack on Palembang. There was little actual selling, but the price decline movement was mainly a precautionary marking down by jobbers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- Twenty-five Federal raids conducted today in the Sacramento area to crack suspected spy and sabotage rings uncovered two four-foot aerial bomb casings, weapons, secret documents and uniforms in the possession of aliens unmasked as Japanese Army and Navy men.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today that he had taken over personal control of 97 per cent of the stock of the General Aniline and Film Corporation of Delaware, large American chemical and photographic supply concern, which he said was formerly owned by Germans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) --Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin today told members of the National Women's Party, which long has been an advocate of equal rights for men and women, that he intends to introduce a bill calling for the registration of women on a national scale.

The three-family brownstone dwelling at 591 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the Ulster County Savings Institution to Hyman Zdanowitz through John A. O'Connor, broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Yale defeated Colgate at hockey in a hotly contested game featured by twenty penalties tonight. The score was 3 -- 1.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Confusion is synonymous with Dodgers. Last year it came to the Brooklyn forces in Havana, when the Cuban system of bus transportation to the ball park broke down completely. This year the confusion descended in Miami, although the sun was shining brightly at the time.

Taking one consideration with another, a playgoer's lot is a happy one this week at the St. James Theatre, where "The Pirates of Penzance" was sung last evening. For Mr. Burnside, who is major-domo of these revivals, has added crispness of performance to the seasoned correctness of his direction, and the topsy-turvy yarn of the pirate apprentice is for the hundreth time droll, mischievous and enjoyable.

Directors of the Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday for 1941 a consolidated net profit of $40,114,419, or $9.22 a common share, the third largest profit in the company's history. They ordered a dividend of $1 a common share for the first quarter of 1942, the smallest payment since 1939.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Most of the favorites advanced in the first round of the fifteenth annual national championship of golf club champions today on the St. Augustine Links.

Nathan Milstein's recitals are object lessons in the mechanics of playing the violin. His appearance at Carnegie Hall last night, his first of the season, was no exception. His tone was a thing of agreeable variety, ranging from a rich and luscious roundness to a delicate, finely spun pianissimo.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 (AP) -- John L. Sullivan's Royal Roan sprang a surprise today in the Army-Navy Purse, six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds, coming from behind under a rousing ride by Johnny Deering to pass Mrs. T.M. Pruett's Doctor Reder and win drawing away.

Paul J. Kern and Wallace S. Sayre, dismissed as members of the Municipal Civil Service Commission by Mayor La Guardia on Monday, said, yesterday that they would apply to the Supreme Court for an order of reinstatement toward the end of this week.

Your editorial of Feb. 16 on Senator Byrd was splendid. But what most Americans do not know is that it is neither happenstance nor politics that makes the Virginia Senator outstanding. He has a consistent record over a period of twenty years that uniformly supports his work in the Senate for better and more businesslike government.

Stockholders of National Distillers Products Corporation, at an adjourned special meeting held yesterday in Richmond, Va., authorized a new issue of 150,000 shares of preferred stock to provide additional permanent capital. It was contemplated that an initial issue of 120,000 shares of $100 par value, carrying not less than 5 per cent nor more than 6 per cent dividends, would be offered.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- The Prudential Insurance Company announced here today that the holders of its remaining outstanding stock, amounting to 536 shares, had agreed to sell it to the company at $1,500 a share.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Chicago and North Western Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of the issue and sale of $3,750,000 of equipment trust certificates. The certificates will be issued under the Philadelphia plan and will be guaranteed unconditionally.

The second Regional Scholastic High School Art Exhibition for Greater New York will be held on the fifth floor of Macy's from March 2 through the 14th. The regional exhibition affords New Yorkers the opportunity of seeing the work by pupils in public, private and parochial schools.

Social agencies throughout the city have been "too complacent" about problems brought on by the war and should adopt "a more democratic attitude," Douglas P. Falconer, executive director of the Greater New York Fund, declared yesterday in reviewing recent developments in this field.

Charles Robert Watkins-Mence, Controller of Imperial Censorship at Bermuda, made a sudden appearance with a group of his subordinates in Federal court yesterday to testify at the trial of seven alleged Nazi spies. The group had flown up from the island, where air mail sent aboard the clippers is examined, to be surprise witnesses for United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.

While large-scale shutdowns in the paper industry as a result of the war effort are "improbable," many paper mills will be forced to curtail operations 10 to 30 per cent below present levels before the end of the year, John Darrow, Washington representative of the American Paper and Pulp Association, declared yesterday at a priorities clinic meeting, held in conjunction with the organization's annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Increased production demands brought on by War Department orders have caused a shortage of waste paper needed for conversion into cardboard casing used in the packing of shells and led directly today to the closing of the Continental Paper Company here, and another shutdown at the plant of the Standard Container Corporation at Dover, N.J., a firm that uses the finished product of the former company for shell cases.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -- Ronald Colman has been signed to play the leading male role, that of Edward Rochester, in David O. Selznick's production of "Jane Eyre" with Joan Fontaine, the United Artists producer announced today.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Colonel Lello Portella of the Portuguese General Staff said today the "British Admiralty demonstrated great tact in letting the German fleet go through the strait into the North Sea" and "very ably evaded" a German trap.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Senate passed and sent back to the House today a $163,806,854 deficiency appropriation bill carrying $100,000,000 for civilian defense, but "not one cent for frills and furbelows," as Senator McKellar of Tennessee, who was in charge of the bill, remarked.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Taking one of the worst beatings in his career, his face a gory mess from cuts over both eyes and his nose bloody, Lew Jenkins's hopes of regaining the lightweight boxing championship suffered a severe setback tonight when Marty Servo punched out a decisive ten-round decision over the former titleholder before 8,000 fans at the Arena.

The report of McKesson Robbins, Inc., for the six months ended on Dec. 31, 1941, the period following the return of the company to private management, issued to stockholders yesterday by W.J. Murray Jr., president, shows a consolidated net profit of $3,957,544 after interest, provision for Federal taxes and a contingency reserve of $1,000,000.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- The Navy's policy of withholding data on the sinking of enemy submarines was reaffirmed by Secretary Knox in a letter that was received and made public here today by Fred Harries, manager of the Broad Street Association, a merchants' group.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Far from being worsened, the British position in the Atlantic has in fact been "definitely eased" by the dash of important German Fleet units through the Strait of Dover, Prime Minister Churchill told Parliament and the Allied world today in the most reassuring message of all the recent black weeks.

The total assets of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad on Dec. 31 last were $442,535,247, compared with $365,000,000 required by the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan of reorganization for the company, Oliver E. Sweet, director of the commission's bureau of finance, and Harvey Wilkinson, examiner for the commission, were told yesterday at a hearing in the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 9 there is an article entitled "Rochester District Vital in Ordnance." The second paragraph contains a misstatement of fact. Bausch Lomb did not create "in the middle of the last century" the only factory making optical glass outside of Germany.

Sylvia Smith, New York pianist who made her local debut four years ago, gave her second Town Hall recital last night. A slight, dark-haired girl still in her twenties, she set herself a program that would have taxed the strength of much stronger artists.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The reason assigned by the President today for his veto of a bill to promote the growing in the United States of guayule and other rubber-bearing plants should help to effect the solidarity of the Americas.

LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Great Britain's biggest boxing show of the war is slated for next Monday night with young Freddie Mills opposing Jock McAvoy for the right to be the next opponent of British light heavyweight champion Len Harvey.

In the first year of the war the notion that India might become a battlefield, perhaps a decisive battlefield, would have struck most Englishmen as fantastic. This correspondent remembers listening to a discussion of the Indian situation in London back in those days in 1940 when we were still thinking of the conflict in terms of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Senate had a second field day of debate today on the question of pensions for Congressmen, but failed to reach a decision on a motion for repeal because Senator Barkley, majority leader, decided not to request a suspension of the rules to this end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Despite strong pressure from Administration circles, the Ways and Means Committee was reported tonight to be averse to reporting out an authorization for a grant of $300,000,000 for the aid of workers displaced by the necessities of wartime conversion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House swiftly and unanimously passed and sent to the Senate today a $32,070,901,900 appropriation for the Army, the Maritime Commission and lease-lend aid to our allies. This largest single appropriation in Congressional history was approved by a vote of 371 to 0.

Up in Maine lumberjacks could take out two million board feet of lumber and leave hardly a scar, but a similar cutting in Northern New Jersey brings forth a conservation problem that can only be solved through a sound reforestation program, according to a letter just received from a member of the New Jersey Board of Fish and Game Commissioners.

In their first move in sixteen years the New York City branches of the Massachusetts Protective Association and the Massachusetts Protective Life Assurance Company have taken quarters in the Fred F. French Building, 551 Fifth Avenue, through the Fred F. French Management Company, Inc.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The stock markets remained depressed today as selling was accentuated by the news of Japanese occupation of a large oil center in Sumatra, coupled with the news of a new British withdrawal in Burma.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The presence of German submarines in the Caribbean Sea was confirmed today with announcement here that U-boats had sunk three tankers with a total displacement of 17,000 tons and shelled the Standard Oil Company refinery at Aruba, off the coast of Venezuela.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, gave aircraft manufacturers today priority ratings on a par with those enjoyed by producers of tanks and ships. He overruled the Army and Navy Munitions Board, which accorded the highest priority ratings to ships scheduled for completion this year and light and medium tanks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- New cash offerings of securities in 1941 exceeded those for any other year since the first World War, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Almost three-fourths of the total, however, was accounted for by sales of United States Government direct and guaranteed securities.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Miss Ruth Fewsmith of this city, who has just been appointed assistant chief instructor at the aviation ground school of the National Aeronautics Association at the Newark Academy here, is the only government-approved woman instructor in Newark and one of a very few in the entire country.

Buying by New Orleans interests swung the cotton market yesterday lifted prices of active futures from an early aimless course on the New York Cotton Exchange to net gains of 7 to 9 points, near the best levels of the session. Trade purchases and mill price-fixing orders aided in the advance.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 17 -- Although the Ministry of Foreign Affairs declined to comment today on the torepdoing of the Brazilian ship Buarque, the sinking caused a tremendous impression here. So did the news that German submarines had shelled an oil refinery at Aruba in the Netherlands West Indies, well within the continental defense zone.

One hundred and fifty epicures, devoted to adventures of the palate, sat down last night under the auspices of Les Amis d'Escoffier and the Comite de la Bonne Bouche, with John O'Hara Cosgrave as chairman, to a dinner menu entitled "What a Fighting Man's Dinner Could Be."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 17 -- The Russians have gained "small local successes" in their various present offensives, it was admitted today by a military spokesman in Berlin, who did not reveal the exact location of these Soviet advances beyond referring vaguely to the Donets and central sectors.

Erasmus Hall High School's basketball team rallied in the last two minutes to beat New Utrecht, 45 to 43, and assure itself of at least a tie for the Section 2, Brooklyn P.S.A.L., title yesterday. Stan Danto, with 16 points, paced the Buff and Blue tossers to their seventh league success in eight games.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Wednesday, Feb. 18 -- Japanese airplanes attacked in the Lesser Sundas yesterday, indicating that that string of islands east of Java might be the next invasion objective of the Japanese forces. The Indies High Command announced that several points on the islands had been bombed and machine-gunned.

The Parents Association of Public School 152, Manhattan, in response to the recent appeal of James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, for parents to cooperate with school authorities in defense precautions, has made the school a safer place for children in case of air raids.

Mr. Churchill is a master of the political offensive. Yesterday he faced the angry representatives of an angry people, even more shocked by the parade of German warships through Dover Strait than by the capitulation of Singapore. But Mr. Churchill conceded nothing to his critics beyond the announcement that a board of inquiry had been appointed to investigate the engagement in the Channel.
Apartment houses on both the East and West Sides of Manhattan figured in realty transactions reported by brokers and institutional sellers yesterday.

Edward J. Heffron, executive secretary of the National Council of Catholic Men, wrote, under date of Feb. 4, a pleasant note to THE TIMES of Feb. 7, discussing the Catholic position with respect to family limitation and making specific reference to reports in THE TIMES of an address which I delivered on Jan. 27.

Joseph Ginzburg, an eccentric cafe comic who insisted upon being addressed as "Sir Joseph Ginzburg" because of a title he had received in a slapstick ceremony in the Bronx twenty years ago, died yesterday at the French Hospital after a long illness.

Suits have a personality this Spring. Macy proved the point at a Ritz Oval Room luncheon yesterday. Everything went in pairs. Accessories only were different. Each suit demonstrated a dual personality, for with the change of hat, gloves, bag and shoes it took on a different character.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Japanese artillery and air preparation for an all-out attack upon Bataan Peninsula was intensified yesterday, while Japanese bombers, roaring over the defenseless Philippine village of Cabcaben, on Bataan, dropped bombs on a refugee camp, killing eighteen women and five children and wounding twenty-two more, General Douglas MacArthur reported to the War Department today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference today that he did not know about the bill which Attorney General Biddle sent to Congress yesterday to give further protection to "secret" or "confidential" records, documents or papers of the government.

LONDON, Feb. 17 (U.P.) -- Coastal Command planes bombed two ships of an enemy convoy off Norway today, the Air Ministry announced. Informed quarters said they doubted that the Royal Air Force had located the new bases of the German battleships Gneisenau and Scharnhorst.

Fifty Brooklyn manufacturers or their representatives heard Sydney Hogerton, district manager of the Priorities Field Service, War Production Board, yesterday afternoon urge them to do all in their power to speed up production to assure the United States an early victory.

"Button Your Lip" posters got an official send-off at City Hall yesterday from Acting Mayor Newbold Morris, who posed with Merle Oberon, film star, to focus public attention on the need for preventing enemy access to useful military information.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The text of Prime Minister Churchill's House of Commons statement today on the air naval battle in the English Channel of last Thursday follows
The bitterness of repeated defeat continued yesterday to stimulate demands for reform here and in Britain.

The American Federation of Labor, through Frank Fenton, its representative on the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practice, announced yesterday that the labor organization would lift the charter of a Belleville, N.J., local if it persisted in alleged discrimination against employment of Negroes.

Ray Robinson, Harlem's unbeaten welterweight, and Maxie Berger, Canadian-born challenger for the title, yesterday were passed by the State Athletic Commission as physically fit for their twelve-round battle Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

The Harris Trust and Savings Bank and associates submitted yesterday the high bid for an issue of $750,000 of public improvement bonds of Alexandria, Va., naming a price of 101.857 for the issue with a fixed interest rate of 2 1/2 per cent.

American newsboys have sold defense stamps to a value of nearly $11,000,000 in the last five months. Carriers representing something less than 800 newspapers, or about one-third of all the daily papers in the country, have been the salesmen. It averages something like $15,000 per publication.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Top ranking officers of the Army and Navy were called to the White House today for conference with President Roosevelt.
TOKYO, Feb. 17 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Singapore has been renamed Shonan, "Light of the South," it was announced today.

Mounting fears of further adverse war news assailed the stock market yesterday as prices declined sharply, especially in some of the "blue chip" issues, with final quotations at the lowest levels in four years. Stocks were depressed more from the lack of support than accelerated pressure for business was still small and sales on the Stock Exchange were 389,100 shares compared with 376,180 on Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Record said tonight it had learned that Henry Frnka, head coach at Tulsa University, would be sounded out within a few days on a proposal to become head football coach at Yale University.
The Museum of Modern Art announced yesterday that it has received from Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. a gift of drawings and that these will be placed on view today in the Recent Acquisitions Room.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- When word of the death of Mr. Nelson, who was vice president and general merchandise manager of the R.H. Stearns Company, was received here, Robert W. Maynard, president of the Stearns company, left by plane to join Mrs. and Miss Nelson.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey has completed plans for cooperation with the Department of Agriculture to maintain farm production at a level essential to the nation's war effort.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Quick pursuit by United States planes that attacked in the light of parachute flares immediately after enemy submarines sank three tankers off Aruba Island before dawn Monday morning is believed to have saved many other ships from being torpedoed, Aneta (Netherland) news agency said today.

The incidence of scarlet fever continued to mount among New York children last week for the fifth consecutive week, although the increase was slight, Health Commissioner John L. Rice reported yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Whether two-for-a-nickel half-pints of milk would continue to be sold to school children here hinged today on the outcome of a dispute between municipal officials and Arthur F. Foran, State milk director, on the feasibility of using hooded or plug-type bottle caps.

PUEBLA, Mexico, Feb. 17 -- On a hill where the ancient Aztecs worshiped the sun, moon and stars, President Manuel Avila Camacho today formally dedicated the new National Astrophysical Observatory, which Professor Harlow Shapley of Harvard said was better situated for many kinds of astronomical research than any important observatory had been since the days of the ancient Mayan astronomers and those of Egypt, Arabia and India.
VICHY, France, Feb. 17 -- There will be no jury in the courtroom to hear the Supreme Court trial that opens Thursday at Riom to establish responsibility for France's unpreparedness in the war.
Gourmets of New York had bad news yesterday. "Papa" Cesare Antonio Moneta, chef and restaurateur at 32 Mulberry Street, admitted that he is planning to retire at the end of this month.

An aviation mechanic who has been trying to get into war service against the Axis powers for six months returned here yesterday on a United Nations liner to join the United States Army. He is Andre D'Avi, a former employe of the Brewster Aircraft Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- Preoccupation with war production was the argument used in the Federal District Court today by the Pullman companies to win a three-month postponement of the government's civil anti-trust suit.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- The suicide of Miss Ruth Murray Livingston, a White Plains high school senior, who shot herself Friday night and died the next day, was the result of emotional distress caused by the blackballing of her two sisters by a Greek letter sorority of which she was a member, her parents charged today in demanding the abolition of "undemocratic" sororities and fraternities in the schools here.

HAVANA, Feb. 17 -- President Fulgencio Batista signed today a decree fixing the 1942 sugar crop at 3,600,000 long tons. The entire production has already been sold to the United States under a contract signed last month with the exception of 200,000 tons for local consumption and 65,000 tons for markets other than United States.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Mr. and Mrs. LeRay Berdeau were hosts today at a swimming party followed by a buffet luncheon served from tables around the pool at Villa Today.

Councilman Louis Cohen of the Bronx accused his Democratic colleagues in the City Council yesterday of giving him "the foot" by refusing to consider his resolution upholding the five-cent transit fare at the day's meeting in City Hall.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (U.P.) -- Russia put the seal of finality on one of history's greatest mass migrations today when the government ordered the permanent resettlement in Eastern Russia of millions evacuated from the war zone in the west.
