Insurance in force of the Home Life Insurance Company of New York on Dec. 31, last was 76.2 per cent or $29,596,137 over 1940, bringing the total to the record level of $453,923,885, Ethelbert Ide Low, chairman of the board, stated in the eighty-second annual report announced yesterday. In only 1929 was so high a gain achieved, Mr. Low said.

BATAVIA, Feb. 17 (UP) -- The massing of Japanese troops and planes in Sumatra and intensified air raids on islands east of Java indicated tonight that the Japanese were preparing to strike this vital island from both west and east.
The property known as "Shore Cottage Estate" on West Shore Road, Mill Neck, L.I., was sold by Bertram Work of Bermuda to Frederick H. Gillmore, a New York attorney, through J. Ralph Bloomer, broker.

Ernie Vigh, 162 pounds, Newburgh, knocked out Lou Schwartz, 165 1/2, Brownsville, with a left hook to the jaw in 2:20 of the fifth round of the eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 4,000 saw Vigh floor the loser for nine in the first and again in the fifth, just before the end.

The pamphlet report of the Detroit Edison Company for 1941, issued yesterday by A.C. Marshall, president, shows a net income for the year of $12,443,156, after all expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $1.96 a share and compares with a net of $10,732,735, or $1.69 a share, in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Secretary Ickes, who is also Oil Coordinator, raised the specter of gasoline and oil rationing today as he revived before the House Interstate Commerce Committee, his drive for a cross-country pipeline to carry 350,000 barrels of petroleum daily to the Eastern seaboard.

Despite severe war restrictions, British book publishers were able to issue enough examples of good bookmaking last year to enable the American Institute of Graphic Arts to open its usual "Fifty British Books of the Year" exhibition last night at 115 East Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Harold Graves, director of the Defense Savings program, said today Treasury reports showed that "pretty near all" the defense stamps which have been cashed in by purchasers were turned into defense bonds.

The trend of fashion in wartime, from the standpoint of science, art and industry, was discussed last night at the fifth of the series of workroom demonstrations at the Museum of Costume Art, 630 Fifth Avenue.

Reporting yesterday to stockholders on operations in 1941, E.C. Field, president of the Childs Company, who took office last year, declared that the net loss of $121,963 was reduced from the 1940 net loss of $1,040,133, which excluded profits from the New York World's Fair concessions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Permission to pool their resources during the war emergency without fear of prosecution under the antitrust laws was formally granted by the government today to the transportation systems of the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A twenty-two-year fight by a New York City couple to recover on a claim against the government ended today with a White House announcement that President Roosevelt had signed a bill authorizing the payment of $2,132 to Mrs. Helen Rauch of 244 East 184th Street, and $500 to her husband, Max.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 AP) -- A good demand for hoes from all buying interests, coupled with continued low receipts, sent prices to another .ew sour-year peak today. Best swine brought $13.25 a hundred pounds. highest since the Summer of 193T. Average price ross to about $12.95: both the top and average quotations are more than $3 above levels prevailing immedia, tely prior to America's entry Into the war.

Revealing a first list of books, the L.B. Fischer Publishing Corporation enters the American publishing field. The company, with offices at 381 Fourth Avenue, is headed by Gottfried Bermann-Fischer, who headed the old German house of S. Fischer Verlag (which left Germany in the middle Thirties) and F.H. Landshoff, formerly of Querido in Amsterdam.

American fashion industries will now be called upon to show the greatest amount of ingenuity in their history in doing the "great patriotic job of making that which is left over for civilian consumption go as far as possible and making it as good as possible," H. Stanley Marcus, apparel consultant of the textile, clothing and leather division of the War Production Board, said yesterday.

It has long been known that when a virus is passed from one species to another it changes. When, for example, cows are infected with smallpox the virus is attenuated so that they are afflicted only with mild cowpox. The virus of this cowpox constitutes the vaccine which has made it possible to prevent and control smallpox.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Seven men were killed late yesterday afternoon when a Navy patrol bomber crashed in the mountains about nine miles east of Buena Vista, Va. Two members of the crew escaped without serious injury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Roosevelt said today that it was possible under some conditions, even tomorrow night, for example, for enemy ships to shell New York City or enemy planes to drop bombs on Detroit.

Manhattan's tankmen lost, 51 -- 24, yesterday to Fordham at the Hotel Park Central pool. By taking the 300-yard medley in the fast time of 3:16:8, the Rams assumed the lead at the outset, and never were threatened for the remainder of the meet.

Churches of virtually all faiths will hold services today or this evening in observance of Ash Wednesday, an observance that takes on a special significance because of the war. Good Friday will fall on April 3 and Easter on April 5.
ROME (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press), Feb. 17 -- The Italian High Command communique follows:

ERSKINE CALDWELL, with Mrs. Caldwell (Margaret Bourke-White), spent about six months in Russia last year, broadcasting for CBS and reporting for PM and Life Magazine. He describes the trip briefly in "All-Out on the Road to Smolensk."*

A long list of sales of small properties was made public yesterday by the Central Savings Bank. Analysis of the asking prices and assessed valuations in many of the deals gave further indication of the fact that institutions are taking a realistic view of the market, and are offering their holdings in many cases well below assessed valuations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Roosevelt accepted with regret today the resignation of Nathan Straus of New York as administrator of the United States Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Following the veto by the President today of a bill to promote the growing of guayule and other rubber producing plants in this country, Senator Downey, author of the original measure, unsuccessfully sought immediate approval of a bill revised to meet President Roosevelt's objections.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 17 -- Royal Indian Air Force planes have roared into action over Burma for the first time, a communique disclosed today as British patrols southeast of the new Bilin River defense line clashed with Japanese moving up rapidly to new attack positions.

HONOLULU, Feb. 17 -- "Baron Hee Hee," as Hawaii has nicknamed the Tokyo radio propagandist, will lose his most appreciative audience here on Thursday when an order issued by the military Governor today takes effect barring the use of shortwave radio receivers by enemy aliens in Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- George Sylvester Viereck was declared by the government today to have put words in the mouths of Congressmen and then used their free mailing privileges "to propagandize us and divide us."

Lent has arrived. And this year, during the period when fish plays so large a part in the diet, war is being felt all along the waterfront. Trawlers are turning into minesweepers, sea-going fishermen are becoming Navy sailors, and up in Boston, where most of the cod comes from, there's a strike on.
LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- R.A.F. Headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The senders of cable and radio messages henceforth must sign their surnames at least, and cannot use, alone, such signatures as "Father," "Aunt Bess," or a nickname, under the terms of new wartime regulations issued today by the Office of Censorship.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Sir Marlboro, the unusual grass track performer, did it once again at Hialeah Park today when he was first in the mile and a sixteenth Indian Creek Purse in time that equaled his track record. Under 126 pounds Mrs. J. Eitinger's winner of the turf course stake, the Miami Beach Handicap, came back to score decisively in 1:44 4/5.

Making his first appearance in a dog show, Count Montmorency, a pug owned by Mrs. Walter Rosenbart of Jackson Heights, was named best in the toy group as Bloomingdale's eleventh annual pet show opened yesterday.

On the premise that no respectable young woman should be obliged to divide the life companionship of a husband between herself and penal institutions, Justice John E. McGeehan disaffirmed yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court an official referee's report that denied an annulment to a wife who discovered several years after her marriage that her husband had served time in prison.

A recent survey of American workers shows that 81 per cent are in favor of private enterprise but that industrial management has yet to win the full public confidence to which it is entitled, Walter B. Weisenburger, executive vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared last night at the dinner of the National Association of Publicity Directors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Rather than wait until the week of March 22 to unveil "A Kiss for Cinderella" at the Music Box, its throng of sponsors yesterday decided to advance the opening to Tuesday night, March 10. Therefore the fortnight's tryout in Boston, scheduled to start March 9, has been canceled.

Mrs. James H. Tynes, in 227 E 57th St; Stanley Newman, through Gilliam McVay, Inc, in 25 W 54th St; Betty Schroeder, Eleanor Dunteman, in The Eastgate, 350 E 52d St; George R. Hummer, in 136 E 36th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers.

The thirty-eighth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America will be held at the Hotel Commodore, June 21 to 24, inclusive, and will be a "National Round Table on Advertising in War Time," J.A. Welch, vice president of Crowell-Collier, Inc., and president of the federation, announced yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, Feb. 17 -- Members of the Legislature came here this afternoon to get a firs-hand picture of war production at the plants of the General Electric and the American Locomotive companies, and while here heard Lieutenant Governor Poletti warn that public apathy was still "our public enemy No. 1."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Reports were current tonight that the Office of Price Administration, which will have charge of the rationing of sugar to individuals throughout the country, had selected the week of March 16 for the registration of consumers and the distribution of ration books.
HELSINKI, Finland (From Finish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press), Feb. 17 -- Today's Finnish High Command communique follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A resolution calling for a Senate investigation of the Normandie fire was introduced today by Senator Vandenberg, who said "this amazingly tragic event" was the work of an "enemy at home" that was either "sabotage or negligence."

SYDNEY, Feb. 17 (UP) -- It was understood today that the Cabinet, faced with the problem of conserving resources in anticipation of a Japanese attempt to blockade Australia, studied an appeal for help from the Netherlands Indies. The appeal was understood to have asked assurances that the Allies were determined to defend Java to the end.

Madison Square Garden, which bustled with basketball activity last Saturday and Monday nights, again will be the site of an important college court double-header tonight, with C.C.N.Y. opposing Fordham and St. John's taking on a threat in the form of Temple University, recent conqueror of N.Y.U. at Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The appropriations measure passed by the House today, carrying funds to finance a vast flow of munitions and construction of merchant ships at the rate of two a day, would increase the total voted for defense expenditures in 1941, 1942 and 1943 to the staggering sum of $142,000,000,000.
BERLIN (From German broadcast recorded by the Associated Press), Feb. 17 -- Today's communique from the German High Command follows:

The opening of a new Cancer Prevention Clinic for Women, as part of the cancer prevention program of the Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, York Avenue and East Sixty-eighth Street, was announced yesterday by Harry Pelham Robbins, president of the hospital.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A spokesman for the Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that representatives of the C.I.O. had discussed with Selective Service officials proposals for exemption from military service of union leaders in key positions, but denied that formal or written representations had been made.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb 17 (AP) -- The first sinking of a Brazilian ship in this war was not made known publicly tonight because it is the annual carnival time and officials sought to forestall any rioting that might arise among masquerading crowds against Axis nationals and properties.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 -- A German pilot, Henrich Freitag, who flew his fighter plane over the Russian lines from Kharkov and landed and surrendered at Lozovenka four days ago, reported that the Germans had everything ready for the evacuation of Kharkov and that his group of fighters had done everything necessary for a hasty departure, it was revealed here today.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 18 -- Soviet dispatches today said that heavily armed Russian warships were shelling German land positions around Sevastopol, the Crimean naval base, and Eupatoria, fifty miles to the north.

Personal, living or family expenses and capital expenditures are not deductible items in the computation of the net income under the Federal law, the Bureau of Internal Revenue pointed out yesterday. But, in the case of taxpayers engaged in occupations requiring use of equipment, the cost of such equipment is deductible to the extent that it is specifically required and that it does not take the place of ordinary clothing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- Raiding parties of Federal agents and police, continuing a search for alien enemy spies and saboteurs, swept through a section of Central California, and the West Bay district today, seizing contraband and taking prisoners, including a former Japanese Army officer, and a nurseryman who is believed to have been an officer in the Emperor's navy.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Governor Lehman stepped into a complicated labor union picture today to order a sweeping investigation of charges of corruption and kickbacks by union officials who bossed 5,000 workers on the $300,000,000 Delaware Water Supply Project for New York City.

Events on and since Dec. 7 have rudely shaken those Americans who insisted up to that point that all was for the best in the best of possible Republics. Some may have retired into day dreams, in which the gallant deeds of a handful of men in the Bataan Hills bulk larger than the loss of great outposts of western civilization.

MONTREAL, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The average United States citizen is "dangerously complacent" about the war, and the press, radio and government have failed so far to drive home to him the "extreme seriousness of the situation," Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York said today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following communique today:

The fifth starter in the five-man field for the Buermeyer 500, one of the features of the New York A.C. track meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, was named yesterday. He is Al Diebolt of Colgate, who has to his credit a brilliant 0:46.9 quarter.
THE Red Cross needs a little help to put the War Fund over the crest. Pitch in, boys! It's putting money in a real savings bank. Do it now!

TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- Uniform air raid instructions will be hung near the dining room door in every kitchen of every home in New Jersey in the near future, Leonard Dreyfuss, new chairman of the State Defense Council, declared today in taking up his duties.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Public reaction to the issue of pensions for members of Congress is one of strong opposition, first returns in a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Carrying out a policy he outlined to the Truman Committee of the Senate two weeks ago, Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, today set up new procedures to be followed in the appointment of "dollar-a-year" and for "without compensation" services.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 17 -- Attacking a strong formation of the Italian fleet in the Ionian Sea early yesterday, British naval torpedo planes scored direct hits on two cruisers and one destroyer. One pilot reported later that, after he had released a torpedo and banked his plane, he had seen four fires raging on four enemy ships.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 17 (AP) -- United States bombers were believed today to have inflicted swift and deadly vengeance upon some of the German submarines reported to have sunk or damaged seven tankers and left fifty-nine sailors dead or missing in barracuda-infested and flaming waters along the Venezuelan coast.

The last $1,000,000 needed to put the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York over the top will be known as the General MacArthur Victory Fund, Colby M. Chester, chairman of the drive's commerce and industry division, announced yesterday in a letter mailed to 35,000 concerns here asking their executives and employes to contribute to the city's quota of $7,330,000.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "Bahama Passage," a Paramount drama filmed in Technicolor and starring Madeleine Carroll and Stirling Hayden, will be the newcomer at the Paramount. Produced and directed by Edward H. Griffith, the film features Flora Robson, Leo G. Carroll, Mary Anderson and Cecil Kellaway. . . .

When he was re-elected for a fourth consecutive term as president of the Fifth Avenue Association yesterday, Walter A. Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, declared that the association's activities in the coming months would be shaped to help win the war.

Representative Ramspeck of Georgia, chairman of the Committee on Civil Service, accuses of "demagoguery" those members of the House who wakened somewhat late to oppose his bill to pension members of Congress. It would seem that Mr. Ramspeck puts the cart before the horse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- An appeal for better defense of the West Coast lines was voiced in the Senate today by Senator Johnson of California, and Senator Walsh, chairman of the Naval ffairs Committee, said the Atlantic and Gulf coasts also were "aLmost defenseless.''

Easing of regulations applying to enemy aliens in this country is pointed out in the new bulletin issued by the National Refugee Service, Inc., of 139 Center Street. Quoting official statements of the Department of Justice, the refugee agency noted that United States Attorneys have received discretionary powers to relax certain rules.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 17 -- Both Rome and Berlin commented today on Prime Minister Winston Churchill's radio address to the English-speaking world.
An aftermath of the Normandie fire appeared yesterday in the budget request of the Dock Department, which asked funds for 105 additional watchmen on the city piers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A plan to help Argentina dispose of some of the surplus corn which has been burdening her economy since the outbreak of the European war has been worked out by government officials responsible for obtaining industrial alcohol for the production of smokeless powder.

Several dinner parties will be given tonight in advance of the recital to be given by Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services and t_he Musicians Emergency Fund.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- The circulation of English-language daily newspapers in the United States in 1941 averaged 42,385,807,in increase of 1,612,870 over the previous year, according to the new edition of N.W. Ayer Son's Directory of Newspapers and Periodicals.

Hearings before the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices, held in this city this week, have indicated that private employment agencies, labor unions and employers in many cases discriminate against individuals because of race, nationality or religion. The Negro probably suffers most by this injustice.

The speculative market in basic chemicals, which had carried "outside market" prices on some materials to levels three times those of manufacturers, has been fairly effectively ended, according to trade reports yesterday and a result is that a number of materials which were in scant supply are now much more freely available.

To date $159,917 has been raised in the 1942 $325,000 drive of the Boy Scouts of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday at the campaign's first report meeting, held at the Hotel Astor. Dr. George J. Fisher, deputy chief Scout executive of the Boy Scouts of America, spoke on "Stabilizing Boyhood in Time of War," and Phillips R. Turnbull, president of the Rogers Peet Company and general chairman of the drive, presided.

VICHY, France, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Officials in both the occupied and unoccupied zones broke their silence today to deny reports that Marshal Erwin Rommel's German troops in Libya had received supplies through French Tunisia.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 17 -- Opening Australia's fifth war loan -- for 35,000,000 [Australian], which is already half subscribed -- before a great crowd in the heart of the city this afternoon, Prime Minister John Curtin announced that the Cabinet had decided to gazette regulations for the complete mobilization of all Australia's human and material resources for the defense of the Commonwealth.
Aaron Seltzer, 126 1/2, Bronx, gained the decision over Joey Iannotti, 129, a borough rival, in a spectacular eight-round battle before a crowd of 4,669 at the New York Coliseum last night.
Mr. and Mrs. Hulburt Taft Jr. have come from Cincinnati to the Ambassador.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 17 UP) Declaring it was a matter of taking "a lesson from Pearl Harbor and pulling together to win the war," Governor Van Wagoner vetoed today legislation to turn Michigan's clocks back an hour.

OTTAWA, Feb. 17 -- The season's most publicized hockey unit -- the Boston Bruins kraut line -- came back to the amateur ranks tonight and scored the final goal with less than a minute to play as their new team, the Royal Canadian Air Force Flyers, battled the Bruins to a 5-5 exhibition tie.

Dr. Leona Baumgartner, pediatrician, who has been acting director of the bureau of child hygiene of the City Health Department since Jan. 1, 1941, was appointed director yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. Dr. Baumgartner recently won first place in a competitive civil service competition for the position.

TRENTON, Feb. 17 -- State Controller Homer C. Zink reported today to Governor Charles Edison and the other members of the State House Commission that a deficit of upward of $7,000,000 in the State's general fund was in prospect at the close of the fiscal year on June 30 and that the highway fund's anticipated $55,000,653 available cash for the current calendar year probably would shrink by $4,800,000.

Marine and Navy contingents duplicating those of the Wake Island garrison will march up Fifth Avenue behind the famed Marine Band next Tuesday as a prelude to the opening of the national fund-raising campaign of the Navy Relief Society, it was announced yesterday.

Directors of the Central Foundry Company declared yesterday two dividends on its $5 preferred stock, clearing arrears on the issue. A dividend of $10 a share, payable in common stock at the rate of one full share of common for each $10! of such dividends was authorized.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The War Department communique based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

Withdrawal by the British Imperial forces from the strong natural line of the Salween River indicates that the defense of Rangoon is faltering. The defenders now stand only fifty miles east of the Central Burmese Railroad. This is the line that feeds the Burma Road at Lashio.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 17 -- Chinese troops in Burma are moving southward toward the main Bilin River front with the specific intention of participating in the battle for Rangoon, a military spokesman here said today. Additional Chinese troops were steadily pouring into Burma, he added.

Seven hundred men and women went to the theatre yesterday morning, but not for entertainment. A mass meeting at the Martin Beck by the American Theatre War Wing Service to prepare for the opening March 1 of the Stage Door Canteen drew so many volunteers that there were even standees.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The official German news agency, D.N.B., said today that a plan to murder Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop had been found among the personal documents of Edouard Daladier, former French Premier.

Two German admissions show that Russia's Winter offensive is not finished, despite all the reserves Hitler has thrown into the battle. The first confirms what the map shows: that on the Moscow front the German Armies have fallen back 180 miles from their point of farthest advance.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- His squad of batterymen augmented by late arrivals until it totaled an even twenty, Manager Melvin Ott finally got his Giants launched upon their 1942 training campaign in earnest today and soon there came another surprise for these skeptics who last December had feared that the shy, retiring Master Melvin might not possess sufficient forcefulness and initiative ever to make a successful baseball pilot.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 17 -- A 5-year-old boy who came up smiling after being seasick, cold and wet for eighteen hours in a lifeboat was among eighty-three survivors brought ashore at Norfolk after their ship, the 5,000-ton Brazilian passenger-cargo vessel Buarque, was sunk by an Axis submarine off the Virginia coast.

The Westinghouse Air Brake Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1941, net profit of $6,058,635 after deductions for Federal income and excess profits taxes and other charges.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The British, Middle East command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Testifying before the Interstate Commerce Commission on a request for a 10 per cent increase in sleeping and parlor car rates, D.A. Crawford, president of the Pullman Company, disclosed today that 1,500 cars had been set aside for troop movement, and that on peak days the number needed might reach 2,000.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Wednesday, Feb. 18 -- Kenneth S. Patton, American Consul-General at Singapore, is among a group of Americans who are missing after having left Singapore, presumably for Batavia, a week ago, it was learned today.

Visiting buyers registered in the market last week totaled 933, as against 1,318 in the preceding week and 940 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 437, which compared with 452 for last Tuesday.
The Dodgers, through President Larry MacPhail, yesterday announced an all-out program in support of the nation's prosecution of the war.

Leslie H. Moore, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co., who for about twenty-five years has been in charge of operation and management for that firm, is leaving that position to become president and general manager of the Mills Estates, Inc., with headquarters in San Francisco.

Young women of society acted as manikins in a fashion revue, entitled "Hope for Spring," held yesterday during the luncheon hour at the Stork Club to further the work of the Committee of French American Wives in purchasing food and clothing for distribution among the needy in the stricken areas of unoccupied France.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 17 -- Norwegian Nazis were disappointed today that Premier Major Vidkun Quisling during his Berlin visit had not been able to sign peace.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Indictments charging the Wayne Pump Company of Fort Wayne, Ind., three other companies, five individuals and a trade association with conspiracy to fix prices of computer-type gasoline pumps were quashed today by Judge Philip L. Sullivan in the Federal District Court here.

Judging from the showing made by the Canadiens against the New York Rangers in the current race, one would hardly believe that Montreal was the cellar inhabitants of the National Hockey League. Last night the Frenchmen opposed the heavily-favored Blue Shirts at Madison Square Garden and recorded a 2-to-1 triumph.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, the Netherland Foreign Minister, said tonight in a broadcast that "the fall of Singapore certainly does not mean that Java will fall."

A General Sessions jury at 7 o'clock last night returned a verdict of guilty of rape against Alfred Ortiz, 17 years old, a Puerto Rican, and George Johnson, 18, a Negro, in an attack on a young white woman in the northern part of Central Park on the evening of Oct. 23 as a part of the Harlem crime wave.

The 10,000,000 metal tokens manufactured for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company in 1928 when it was asking the Federal courts for a 7-cent fare on its subway and elevated lines are now in the hands of the city, awaiting their final destiny -- be it service in a higher fare cause or conversion into weapons for use against the enemies of democracy.

BATAVIA, Feb. 17 -- Refugees from Palembang, Sumatra, said today that the airdrome there already was in Japanese hands when they left. Many persons escaped from the city by road and train and the Netherlands Indies defense force waited until they had gone before blowing up bridges to delay the Japanese.

A sister and two brothers were arraigned before Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in Felony Court yesterday, accused of having criminally received $112,000 in food stamps, alleged to be part of $500,000 of such stamps stolen in Buffalo, Pittsburgh and this city in the last eight months.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The Admiralty said today that the 5,083-ton German steamer Spreewald, sunk last month by an Axis submarine, had first issued a distress signal identifying herself as the British Royal Mail steamer Brittany.

Late registrants continued to trickle into most of the 280 draft boards throughout the city yesterday, while officials met to begin work on the 567,940 new cards filed on Sunday and Monday. The situation was presumably the same throughout the country, where 6,163 other boards began analysis of approximately 8,432,000 new cards.

The Foreign Property Control Department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York began distribution yesterday to banks and others of Series K of Form TFR-300, which requires the reporting of all property of Philippine nationals in the United States.
HAVANA, Feb. 18 -- There will always be a Dodger with ideas never possessed by any other player on any other baseball club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, abolished two divisions today on the ground that "they have no further value." During the day he accepted without comment the resignation of Mayris Chaney, dancer and protegee of Mrs. Roosevelt, as coordinator of children's activities.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Mayor La Guardia sent word to the Legislature today that he did not contemplate any increase in the 5-cent fare in New York City "during the year."

Local rationing boards authorized yesterday delivery by automobile dealers of fifty-four new passenger cars bought before Jan. 1. In each instance the car is to be without a spare tire. Eleven applications to release cars were rejected.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Continued general advances for the Red Armies were reported this morning by the Soviet High Command, which declared that Nazi losses had been heavy in men and materiel and announced the largest bag of German planes in recent days -- thirty-five destroyed aloft and aground.

SOUTHERN Connecticut in Winter, if it is suburban and expensive enough, can be as isolated and glacial as Southern Patagonia or the Yukon. For the evidence, see Louise Field Cooper's "The Lighted Box,"* a chronicle of suburban pioneers.

George (Twinkletoes) Selkirk's signed contract for the 1942 campaign was received yesterday at the headquarters of the Yankees. He is the twelfth member of Manager Joe McCarthy's squad to come into the fold.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Chinese communique, as recorded here by the Columbia Broadcasting System, follows:

The operating income of the Children's Aid Society of 105 East Twenty-second Street last year amounted to $1,034,995, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting in the board room of the Bank of New York, 48 Wall Street.
BERLIN, Feb. 18 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press), -- The German High Command communique today said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the inventory value of livestock on farms of the country on Jan. 1 was $7,008,411,000, compared with $5,320,000,000 a year before, $5,132,448,000 two years before and $4,355,684,000 the 1930-39 ten-year average.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 -- Blue denim dungarees are displacing afternoon dresses and tea cups are giving way to riveting hammers in the hands of Detroit women who, in increasing numbers, are taking their places in war production work.

Eight Brooklyn youths who sought to capitalize on the nation's current sugar shortage were arraigned before Magistrate John F.X. Masterson in Adolescents Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, accused of breaking into the factory of the Yum Yum Baking Company at 90 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn, on the night of Jan. 30 and stealing fourteen l00-pound bags of granulated sugar.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A Royal Air Force communique said today:

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 18 -- Major Gen. Erland F. Fish of Brookline, commander of the State Guard, former commander of the Yankee Division and a former president of the State Senate, died at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital tonight of injuries suffered when he was struck by a taxicab early today as he was leaving a street car on Commonwealth Avenue.

About to sentence William Hatzis, 26 years old, a convicted burglar, to serve fifteen to thirty years in State Prison, Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions declared yesterday that the defendant's criminal career was attributable to the "pampering" he had received as a youth in the Brooklyn Adolescents Court, where he had been freed for his first two offenses.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 18 -Two American correspondents were seriously injured and two other foreign correspondents less seriously hurt when their official car -- from the Ministry of Information -- crashed into a tree returning from Riom, France, late this evening.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Bids totaling $50,000 for twenty parcels of improved real estate here were received today at an auction in City Hall of property that New Rochelle had acquired through tax lien foreclosures. The bids covered properties assessed at $200,000.

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the concert by Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, last night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the American Women's Voluntary Services and the Musicians Emergency Fund. Mr. and Mrs. Lytle Hull, the latter, president of the Musicians Emergency Fund, entertained with a supper party in their apartment at Hampshire House for Mr. Menuhin after the concert.

An exhibition of contemporary Czechoslovak art will open next Wednesday afternoon at the Demotte Galleries. The event is under the auspices of Colonel Vladimir S. Hurban, Czechoslovak Minister to the United States; Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, president of the American Friends of Czechoslovakia.

All the fifty-five commercial banks and trust companies in Manhattan have adopted payroll-deduction plans for sale of defense savings bonds to employes, it was announced yesterday by Eugene C. Donovan, president of the New York State Bankers Association.

Princeton turned back Columbia, 43 -- 35, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League engagement at Morningside Heights last night. The taller Tigers thus notched their third triumph in five ivy circuit games.

Putnam will publish on the post-income tax day of March 16 "Poor Richard Comes to Life." Bessie W. Johns dug around in the Franklin writings and gathered in 440 maxims. These she arranged under subject headings, as for instance, wealth, where are found well known ones such as, "If you'd know the Value of Money, go and borrow some," or, "The generous Mind least regards Money and yet most feels the Want of it."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Five firms in New York accounted for 23 per cent of underwritings of 167 issues amounting to $1,285,325,000 in 1941, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Comparable underwriting figures for 1940 were 179 issues for $1,620,317,000.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- John C. Clark's Waller, a threat in his previous race, came romping home at Hialeah Park today in the Hallandale Purse. A heavily played public choice, Waller raced straight down the middle after running around the field at the head of the stretch and won by a half length in the colors of Hialeah's president at $4.10 for $2.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 18 -- The recently incorporated City Affairs Committee of Jersey City announced today it had made a formal application to the State Civil Service Commission for permission to inspect immediately the official roster of Jersey City municipal employes, so the committee can make a study of the proposed budget for 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Secondary distribution of stock exchange stocks has not hurt the stock exchanges on the whole, but has helped members of the exchanges and has improved the position of the purchasers, in the opinion of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which reported on this subject to the commission today.
ROME, Feb. 18 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said:

Continuing their efforts to obtain adjustments in the current regulations affecting price ceilings on exports, foreign traders are now seeking clarification of the provisions for extra expenses incurred through the special requirements of individual nations, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Senate today unanimously approved the Vandenberg resolution for an inquiry to determine whether sabotage or negligence caused the burning of the former French liner Normandie, now the U.S.S. Lafayette.

The names of twenty winners of awards from the New York City Committee for Latin-American Scholarships were announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who expressed the hope that other cities would extend the scholarship plan until it became a substantial factor in improving cultural relations between the two continents.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The safe passage of important British convoys through the Central Mediterranean between last Friday and Monday was announced today by the Admiralty.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- The largest lease-lend purchase of shell eggs in five weeks wag announced today. The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation bought 807,000 dozen, paying 29 3/4 to 31 1/4 cents a dozen, or 1/4 cent a dozen less than for the last lots.

Emphatic opposition to the closed shop either in direct form or under any subterfuge was expressed yesterday in statements issued by the Bethlehem Steel Company, the Republic Steel Corporation and the Inland Steel Company. Together with Youngstown Sheet and Tube, they constitute so-called "Little Steel," employing nearly 175,000 workers.

TOKYO, Feb. 18 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press, New York) -- Emperor Hirohito appeared on the bridge overlooking the wide plaza in front of the Imperial Palace today to accept the "banzais" of his subjects in celebration of the fall of Singapore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The House passed today the bill appropriating $221,209,100 for the Departments of State, Justice and Commerce, and included in it an amendment earmarking $300,000 of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's funds for an investigation of Japanese activities on the West Coast.

The entire pulp and paper industry will be brought under some form of government control by April 1, either through a rigid allocation of pulp or the curtailment of paper production to that of a base period, such as 1938 or 1939, it was revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association of Pulp Consumers, held in conjunction with the convention of the American Paper and Pulp Association, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The German nation has now reached high gear in the greatest production drive in its history, and the campaign has succeeded in holding the Reich's industry at the peak it attained about two months ago, according to the British Ministry of Economic Warfare.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced yesterday a ruling by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue respecting bonds of the B. O., the Buffalo, Rochester Pittsburgh Railway and the Cincinnati, Indianapolis Western Railroad affected by an adjustment plan of Aug. 15, 1938.

Although Irving Caesar's new musical, "My Dear Public," is headed for the Broadhurst the week of March 16, this is not an indication that the Broadhurst's current tenant, "High Kickers," will wind up its New York run at that time.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Prices of hogs dropped 25 to 40 cents a hundredweight in late sales today as the advance which had carried quotations to four-year peaks in recent weeks finally ran into strong resistance. An early top of $13.15 was not duplicate. Livestock men said they thought the market was top heavy.

Prince Franz Hohenlohe Waldenburg Schillingsfurst, 26 years old, artist and student, was taken into custody by FBI agents in Northern Westchester County on Monday night, it became known yesterday, and is detained at Ellis Island with other aliens of enemy nations.

In a report filed yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, by Theodore Stitt, special master, it was indicated that creditors of the defunct Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn would receive a dividend of 2 per cent on their claims of $511,876.

Despite the war, work stoppages continue to impede production, the National Association of Manufacturers revealed yesterday in a report dealing with sixty-eight strikes throughout the country in January. Of these forty-three were in war production, involving 15,512 workers and 661,976 lost man-hours.
BATAVIA, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A stanch United Nations air defense of Java's Surabaya naval base knocked out nearly one-fourth of a Japanese raiding force today.

In the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, the six-story apartment house at 2770-80 Kingsbridge Terrace, 150 by 100 feet, has been sold by the Roberts Building Corporation, Harry Radin, secretary, to the R.W.S. Realty Corporation for cash above a 3 per cent first mortgage of $300,000.

The Berkshire Symphonic Festival will be held again this Summer by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Serge Koussevitzky, it was announced yesterday in a joint statement issued by Gertrude Robinson Smith, president of the festival, and Ernest B. Dane, president of the orchestra.

A special bulletin showing how magazine advertising increased nearly 200 per cent during the last war was issued yesterday by the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, 250 Park Avenue. The statistics, prepared in answer to numerous requests, showed that total volume increased from $26,368,384 in 1914 to $78,025,145 in 1919.

A plan for voluntary retail price control, rather than government control, has been submitted to the Office of Price Administration by eleven trade groups in the retail field, it was made known yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Photostatic copies of an appeal addressed by Nazi prisoners in Russia to their German comrades to overthrow the Hitler regime were received in New York yesterday bearing the signatures of those backing the appeal. The copies were NEW YORK TIMES radiophotos transmitted directly from Moscow by Sovfoto.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Feb. 18 -- Alert United States bombers drove enemy U-boats from the Aruba coast today and frustrated a repetition of the Monday raid in which United Nations tankers were attacked and the big refinery was shelled from the sea.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The stock markets opened steadier today with some groups improved on buying by big bargain hunters. The rail dividend season started with the London, Midland Scottish announcement of 2 per cent. This compares with 1 1/2 per cent for the two previous years.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue reminded income taxpayers yesterday that failure to make and file a return within the prescribed time would result in additions to the amount payable, unless it could be shown to the satisfaction of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue that the failure was due to reasonable cause and not to willful neglect.

Three midtown theatres will present new film offerings this morning. "Roxie Hart," with Ginger Rogers in the title role of the Twentieth Century-Fox adaptation of the Maurine Watkins play, "Chicago," will be the newcomer at the Roxy.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- The junkmen of the R.A.F., who salvage every bolt from crashed planes, are putting 60 per cent as many craft into the air as are manufactured new by the entire British aircraft industry, the Ministry of Aircraft Production revealed today.

As early as last March, before Germany had turned to war on her former ally, Russia, and before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor plunged this country into the conflict, a Nazi agent was able to detect the fundamental unity with which Americans were preparing for war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 18 -- George Montgomery and Maureen O'Hara will be co-starred in "Orchestra Wife," a musical written by Karl Tunberg and Darrell Ware, which William Le Baron will produce, Twentieth Century-Fox announced today.

Virtual control of Huyler's has been acquired from the D.A. Schulte interests by a syndicate headed by Harry O. King, chairman of the Brockway Motors Company, and R. Emerson Swart, president of R.E. Swart Co. of New York, investment bankers, for an undisclosed consideration.

John Carmody of the National Labor Relations Board has been asked by the American Federation of Office Employes to set a date for an NLRB election to determine whether the union shall represent the employes of the Stock Clearing Corporation, an affiliate of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Sugar allocations for industrial users for March will remain unchanged from last month at 80 per cent of the amount used in the corresponding period last year, it was learned authoritatively tonight.

The announcement Tuesday by D.N.B., official German news agency, of the discovery of a Netherland plot to assassinate Reichsfuehrer Hitler was described yesterday by Dr. Nichoals A.C. Slotemaker, director of the Netherlands Information Bureau in this city, as an attempt by the Nazis to establish an excuse for reprisals on the population of German-occupied Netherlands.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 18 -- Although British mechanized patrols operated yesterday out of El Gazala over a wide area south of a line from there to Mekili, they encountered no German opposition.

The Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York announced yesterday the election of William H. Pouch, president of the Concrete Steel Company, as president of the foundation. The announcement was made following the annual meeting in the Yale Club.

Plans for the first section of the "Clinton Hill" housing project in Brooklyn near the Navy Yard, consisting of three buildings costing $1,787,200, were filed yesterday in the Department of Housing and Buildings in Brooklyn. The buildings will be fourteen stories high; two accommodating 112 families each, and one, 320 families.

Louis Schlefer, 49 years old, a lawyer and accountant at 545 Fifth Avenue, was held in $5,000 bail for trial in General Sessions yesterday after he had pleaded not guilty before Judge John A. Mullen in the alleged extortion of $1,500 from a client under the representation it was to "fix" an income-tax "investigator."

One - hundred-and-thirty - seven-and-a-half is the street number of a little pink shop about as big as a bandbox, where the epicurean elite of Gotham eat omelets at lunchtime, seated at three of the tiniest tables in the city.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 18 (AP) -Carl F. Zeidler, "Boy Mayor" of Milwaukee, who holds that in addition to guns and machines, victory depends on recruiting better men than the Axis hordes, has enlisted in the Naval Reserve and will resign his $12,300-a-year municipal office.

Merchandise inventories of New York and Brooklyn department stores at the end of January showed an increase of 33 per cent over a year ago, while sales gained 31 per cent during that month, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Marshal Rommel's drive in North Africa has halted west of Mekili, in the Central Libyan highlands, and the hard-pressed British have had precious time in which to reorganize. It is impossible to tell what forced Rommel to check his rapid advance. It was certainly not effective resistance by British land forces, for the fighting has not been heavy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- American combat airplanes marked their increasing participation in the Battle of the Pacific by two victories, scored without loss or damage to themselves, which were reported today in communiques issued by the War Department.

Habits of long standing are hard to break, so City College vanquished Fordham for the twenty-second time in their twenty-eight-game basketball series at Madison Square Garden last night before a gathering of 11,658. For most of the fray the Beavers rollicked along with an eleven-point lead, got a scare when the Rams pulled up within a single marker and then won going away, 48 to 41.

The first line of defense of New York City is its waterfront. It is, in effect, one of the nation's great naval stations. Yet the waterfront zone has apparently been open to observation and investigation by almost any one who cared to enter it, provided only that he could offer a plausible excuse.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

ALBANY, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- The State's civilian population will be dependent upon its own resources for protection against enemy air raids, Lieut. Gen. Stanley H. Ford of the State Civilian Evacuation Committee said today, warning that "it is probable that certain target areas of the State will be bombed."

It is no longer possible accurately to classify corporations in accordance with peacetime practices. For instance, automobile manufacturers no longer make automobiles; some make munitions and some make tanks and other martial equipment far in excess of similar contracts held by some of the original aviation manufacturing concerns.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Princeton's swimming team pulled up to a tie with Yale in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League by defeating Penn, 64 -- 11, in Brokaw Pool tonight. It was the sixth straight victory for the Tigers, and their third triumph in the league race.

Rubber, tin and vegetable oils are not the only raw-material shortages created by the fortunes of war in the Pacific. Prominent among the sufferers is Hollywood. From the languorous isles through which Japan's armed forces have been sweeping in a far from languorous manner the motion-picture industry has long been drawing a large part of its raw material for film scenarios.

OTTAWA, Feb. 18 -- "The appropriate defense agencies of Canada and the U.S.A. are giving close consideration to the problem of communication with Alaska," Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King informed the House of Commons today in reply to a question from Howard Green, Conservative member for Vancouver South.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Attorney General Biddle told a House judiciary subcommittee today that the Justice Department had sought unsuccessfully prior to the Dec. 7 Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor to gain access to cable messages sent by the Japanese from Hawaii.

TRENTON, Feb. 18 -- Governor Charles Edison announced today he would withdraw his nomination of William Hildebrand as successor to State Athletic Commissioner Abe J. Greene at the request of Mr. Hildebrand. The nomination of Mr. Hildebrand, a Democrat and a vice president of the Edison Cement Company, was sent to the Senate on Feb. 9.

Columbia University Club's Class C squash racquets team remained at the top of the league standing following the metropolitan interclub matches last night. By turning back Jackson Heights, 4 to 1, at the victors' courts, the leaders brought their season total to 62 triumphs and 8 defeats.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 -- Ninety per cent of the captured German tanks are usable by the Russians after repairs, according to Vassili Bryl, manager of the emergency war factory your correspondent visited today.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Caucuses of two important Parliament groups, Labor and the Conservative 1922 Committee, failed today to reach a decision on the line of action to be followed in the war debate in the House of Commons.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18 -- Penn notched a 46-43 overtime victory tonight by shooting three points and holding Yale scoreless in an exciting overtime session. A toss from the foul line by Lawrence Davis and a basket by Captain Henry Soleliac netted the winning points.

HONOLULU, Feb. 18 -- Three large Japanese banks in Honolulu, with assets of $12,000,000 have been ordered liquidated by the United States Treasury Department, in instructions to Governor Joseph B. Poindexter.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Libel actions brought by the Duke of Hamilton against the writers of a pamphlet and an article on the flight of Rudolf Hess to England last May were settled in court today when the authors apologized and agreed to pay the court costs.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 18 -- Warned that this is "their last chance," the German people have been called upon to deliver a "phenomenal" effort in the industrial field "if Germany is to live."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -Legal action to break up all holdings of more than 500 acres of agricultural land in Puerto Rico, for effectuation of the island's land ownership-limitation law, enacted in 1900, was recommended today in a report by Rexford G. Tugwell, who is now Governor of Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Should Congress pass the Attorney General's war secrets bill without change from the draft he has prepared, the delegated powers could easily be used to suppress legitimate and essential information about the conduct of the war and to punish constructive critics of that effort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The government hopes to complete by the end of this week all arrangements for leasing, operating and expanding the country's short-wave stations for transmitting information and propaganda to enemy and neutral countries.

During the past four years one American organization, operating on funds obtained through voluntary contributions from hunters, has done more to increase the numbers of North American waterfowl than any other agency, public or private.

Residential buildings in many parts of the city gained new tenants in the leasing activity reported yesterday. The volume was shared by both East and West Sides, with a number of rentals made in houses on Park Avenue, in the Fifties and in the Seventies.

Machinery for the rationing of sugar in New York City was set in motion yesterday when Lee S. Buckingham, Acting Rationing Administrator, asked Dr. Harold A. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, for an estimate of the number of rationing books that will be needed at each of the public schools.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Substantial changes in the use of skilled men in the Army is urged today in the second report of the inquiry committee set up by the Labor Ministry. The committee found the army shows "continuing failure to use men of engineering skill according to their skill, which has surprised us by its extent."

The four-story building occupied by manufacturers at 17 to 23 Menahan Street, Brooklyn, was bought by the Hardemore Realty Corporation for investment from the estate of Patrick J. Menahan. The property includes a garage, also occupied by manufacturers, and was sold through the Charles F. Noyes Company.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Politics as Usual" of Feb. 12 made me hope that you will later give some information on what they should be working for to the farm bloc in Congress and to the Farm Bureau in the lobby. A little thoughtful attention will convince any one that they are widely missing the mark.

Pleas for spiritual strength and self-discipline in the nation's crisis, a call to "pray for victory" and a declaration that "our first and present duty is to win the war" came from the city's pulpits yesterday during services marking the beginning of the Lenten season.
CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 18 (UP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek met today for the first time to consider how their countries could work together to save themselves from Japan.
The election of William M. Robbins as a vice president and of Ernest L. Woodward as a director of the General Foods Corporation was announced yesterday by Colley M. Chester, chairman.

If the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's control of the Boston Maine Railroad were broken, holders of bonds of the Old Colony Railroad would do better if they took stock of a reorganized New Haven than if they accepted the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan of reorganization for the New Haven, J.B. Ely, former Governor of Massachusetts, said yesterday at a hearing ordered by the commission in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a former associate of Harry W. Marsh when we were both members of the staff of the Civil Service Reform Association, and as one who has been associated with Mrs. Bruce Bromley in many activities in Brooklyn, I should like to register my opinion that the Mayor could not have chosen more wisely two persons to fill the difficult posts on the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

A new three-year agreement covering 435 buildings and 7,500 building service employes in the midtown area was signed yesterday in the office of Mayor LaGuardia at City Hall between the Building Service Employes Union, Local 32B, and the Midtown and Penn Zone Realty Associations.

The six-story elevator apartment house at 25 Nagle Avenue, containing 142 rooms, and completed last October, has been sold by the Rommax Realty Corporation, represented by Fred S. Weitzner, to a client of E. Osborne Smith, Inc., broker.
A copy of John J. Audubon's reissue of the elephant folio of his "The Birds of America" brought $1,350 yesterday afternoon at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. It was bought by an agent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -President Roosevelt began work on his speech to the nation next Monday; his only caller was Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company purchased yesterday an issue of $1,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes of Manchester, N.H., at 0.42 per cent. The obligations, dated Feb. 20, will become payable $500,000 on July 16 and $500,000 on Dec. 10.
Paul J. Kern, ousted president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, accused Mayor La Guardia yesterday of having tried to wreck the merit system in civil service for the last two years.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 -- An order over Reichsfuehrer Hitler's signature to his generals in the field, which has fallen into Russian hands on the Southern Front, was shown to your correspondent today. Dated Jan. 15, its instructions reveal the nature of the present German defensive fighting and the call the Nazi High Command has been forced to make on its reserves.
HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 18 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Finnish communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, tonight announced his hand-picked "thinking committee," a three-man planning board set up to advise him on all production and procurement problems and headed by Robert R. Nathan, 33-year-old economist and statistician of Dayton.

Several luncheon parties were given yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Mrs. R. Bruce Estelle entertained with a luncheon there for Miss Adelaide Stedman, who spoke earlier on "Current Reactions to Current Events" in the garden of the hotel under the ausices of the New York County Unit of the National Association of Pro America.

Warning that "the utmost that Australia can do by herself is not going to stop the Japanese." Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister to the United States, made an appeal last night for all possible speed in sending American planes, tanks and other weapons to the Southwest Pacific area.

The Hamilton Arms apartment property, covering a blockfront known as 157-11 Sanford Avenue, running from 157th to 158th Streets, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the Somerset Management Corporation to the Mar-Ted Management Corporation for cash above a first mortgage of $273,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A maximum allowance of 200 pounds of sugar for home canning use is provided in the sugar-rationing plan as approved to date by officials of the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration.

Directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of $2.25 a share on the capital stock, payable on April 16 to holders of record of March 16. This continues the dividend at the $9-a-year rate that has been in effect since 1922.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Women may entrust their lives to men when they place their troths at the altar, but they reserve for themselves the prerogative of selecting their own lingerie.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A report concerning the relations of the Vichy Government with Germany was given today to Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, by Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, who also denied reports that his government was planning to turn Madagascar over to Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- By a vote of 4 to 2 the Senate Civil Service Committee tonight approved a bill repealing that section of the recently enacted Civil Service Retirement Act which permits members of Congress, of the Cabinet and the President and Vice President to retire on pension under certain conditions.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- Charges that American citizens in the British Island of Penang, off Malaya, north of Singapore, had been kept in ignorance of the evacuation of United Nations forces southward were rejected today by a government spokesman in the House of Commons.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Louisville Transmission Corporation was authorized today by the Kentucky Public Service Commission to seek bids on $3,850,000 of first mortgage sinking fund bonds to finance construction of a transmission line connecting five Midwest utilities with the Tennessee Valley Authority system.

The American Woolen Company and its subsidiary, the Pocono Company, showed in 1941 an increase of about 90 per cent in sales over the previous year, resulting in record earnings before providing $2,000,000 for war contingencies, according to the forty-third annual report issued for publication today by Moses Pendleton, president.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Further concentrated buying of wheat, which traders attributed to Northwestern of mill interests, gave the market a firm undertone early, but outside buying failed to appear, and when professional traders tried to take profits they found support lacking, and a reaction of around 1 cent a bushel from the top followed.

Priorities regulations are hampering the civilian defense program by preventing delivery of equipment for which funds have been made available by Congress, Mayor La Guardia said last night at a meeting of the public works emergency division organized in Queens under the Office of Civilian Defense.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The War Shipping Administration gave out tonight the terms on which it is prepared to provide war-risk insurance on cargoes carried by United States flag vessels after March 1.

Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt will preside at a reception and tea to be given this afternoon at the British War Relief Society's Shop, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, to mark the formal opening of a display there illustrating the activities of Young America Wants to Help, the society's junior division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Pressure to report out the $300,000,000 authorization requested by the Administration for funds to care for workers displaced by the war effort was directed again today to the Ways and and Means Committee, but the chairman, Representative Doughton, said nothing which he could discern had changed the determination of the committee to "junk" the legislation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- The government, in informing the public today of the sinking of the 5,152-ton Brazilian passenger ship Buarque off Norfolk, Va., early Sunday, said the vessel's commander, Captain Joao Joaquin Moura, was aboard a United States craft with some of the Buarque's passengers and crew, and that sixty-two others had been landed at Norfolk with one unidentified body.

PUEBLA, Mexico, Feb. 18 -- A new theory to account for the formation of the so-called young stars was outlined to the Inter-American Astrophysical Congress here today by Dr. F.L. Whipple of Harvard. This theory in substance is that these stars and possibly all stars may have been formed through condensation of the matter composing the "dust clouds" hanging in interstellar space.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

Sergeant Alvin C. York, hero of the last World War, declared yesterday that he knew from personal experience how invaluable Red Cross aid must be to the "brave boys fighting with General MacArthur." In a telegram from Jamestown, Tenn., to headquarters of the Red Cross campaign here at 57 William Street, he said:

Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, gave his second recital of the season last night before an audience of 2,600 in Carnegie Hall. It was a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund and the American Women's Voluntary Services, and more than 100 young women in the blue-gray uniforms of the latter organization were seated on the stage.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 18 -- The only official comment on the sinking of the Brazilian passenger ship Buarque off the coast of Virginia, which was not announced here until today, was that "the government is taking the necessary steps to safeguard national interests."

Rested after their smashing 5-to-1 triumph over the Rangers last Sunday night, the Americans will take to the ice again tonight at Madison Square Garden, in a National Hockey League meeting with the Bruins. Brooklyn will make a game bid to keep the Stanley Cup holders out of first place in the tight title race.

The 11,615-ton tanker E.H. Blum, owned by the Atlantic Refining Company, was damaged by three violent explosions spaced about fifteen minutes apart as she was proceeding off the Atlantic coast Monday evening, the Navy Department announced yesterday.

The police reported success yesterday in the recovery of a uniform and equipment that disappeared with Murray Kadisch of 1795 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, when he deserted the Polish Armed Forces in Canada five days after he enlisted.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Most, if not all, of the nation's customary holidays were virtually abolished for the duration of the war today, as far as factories producing war supplies are concerned.

Firmness in the railway shares and in a smattering of industrial issues enabled the stock market yesterday to return to a semblance of balance, but again business was small. If any single conclusion could be drawn from the session, it was confirmation of the general belief in Wall Street that two distinct markets now exist and have existed for months.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 18 -- The British suddenly stepped up the civil evacuation of Rangoon today in the face of an ominous military situation some seventy-five miles above the city. Meanwhile, the Royal Air Force carried out a mass attack on Chiengmai, a rail terminus in the north of Thailand that the enemy is believed using as a base for a parachute invasion of territory vital to the supplying of China.

The Home Insurance Company of New York, in its annual statement for 1941 made public today, reports the largest volume of net premiums written in its history. The amount was $71,078,064, an increase of $5,002,576 over the previous year. The company issued more than 4,500,000 separate policy contracts and reported 684,357 claims.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UP) -- President Roosevelt directed the War Department tonight to award Distinguished Flying Crosses to three officers and three enlisted men of the Army Air Corps ferrying command for extraordinary achievement in flying a four-engined bomber over three continents last Fall in pioneering a new military air route.

A concert to raise $3,000 to enable 653 girls to continue their studies at Hunter College until the end of the term will be held in the College Assembly Hall on Tuesday night, it was announced yesterday by Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 -- For the fourth straight year Princeton won the annual Polar Bear track meet on balmy Museum Field today, the weather being milder than for many mid-Winter gatherings and belying the title.

Immediate formation of a war emergency committee, representing all branches of the fur industry, was suggested yesterday by Louis F. White of Lou White, Inc., who has just been elected president of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers.
Criticism of the Churchill government and of our own war efforts continued yesterday as the Japanese exploited their break in the Malay barrier and the war drew closer to the crucial climax of 1942.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- American colleges were accused today by Brig. Gen. William C. Rose, assistant to the Adjutant General of the War Department, of paying as a rule no more than "lip service" to the ideal of leadership training.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The call for a general staff in THE TIMES touches the very crux of our war effort.

Stocks of light fuel oil, which is used almost entirely in the heating of homes, on the East Coast at the end of last week were 10,328,000 barrels, a decline of 2,428,000 from the 12,756,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

VICHY, France, Feb. 18 -- Former Premiers Leon Blum and Edouard Daladier and General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, former French Commander in Chief, and their former subordinates, Guy La Chambre and Pierre Jacomet, were brought to Riom prison tonight and tomorow will be haled before the Supreme Court of Justice, which was created to judge them for French unpreparedness in the war.

Fifteen root crops comparatively easy for the amateur vegetable gardener to grow were discussed yesterday afternoon at another "Vegetable Growing for Victory" lecture held in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
Dealers in rare books, gifts and women's wear were among the lessees of business space reported yesterday by brokers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Formation of a Brazilian-United States Rubber Corporation to meet this country's growing wartime needs and provide a perpetual rubber supply which will make the United States less dependent on East Indies sources, is being arranged in Washington, Arthur Desouza Costa, Brazilian Finance Minister, said today.

Those who are well informed on the latest method of dealing with an incendiary bomb will neither spray it with water, scream for help nor burst into panicky sobs. They will instead murmur, "Please pass the salt," and then proceed to extinguish it easily and with a minimum of fuss or noise, it was said yesterday by Professor William D. Turner of the Columbia University Department of Chemical Engineering.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- Although the third day of training for the Giant batterymen provided nothing more entertaining than running, bunting and light warm-up exercises today, one already is beginning to hear appraisals made of the youngsters and newcomers striving to win berths on Manager Mel Ott's pitching staff.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (Reuter) -- "Freed at last from the deadening hand of the Russian censorship, I hereby reaffirm every conviction of ultimate victory that for the last six months I have been sending regularly from either Moscow or Kuibishev," writes Philip Jordan in today's News Chronicle from Cairo.

Governor Lehman has ordered a sweeping investigation into the affairs of the Hodcarriers and Common Laborers Union of America. This is the international union which, under pressure, held its first convention in thirty years last Fall, and which had not had an election of officers in all that period.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (Reuter) -- "Freed at last from the deadening hand of the Russian censorship, I hereby reaffirm every conviction of ultimate victory that for the last six months I have been sending regularly from either Moscow or Kuibishev," writes Philip Jordan in today's News Chronicle from Cairo.

Governor Lehman has ordered a sweeping investigation into the affairs of the Hodcarriers and Common Laborers Union of America. This is the international union which, under pressure, held its first convention in thirty years last Fall, and which had not had an election of officers in all that period.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- American Eagle Squadron fighter pilots swooped down to fifty feet to attack factories and a freight train on occupied France during a daylight sweep today, the Air Ministry announced.

What The Tailored Woman describes as "follyless fashions" for Spring were shown in a collection yesterday presentedat the Waldorf-Astoria. This emphasis was carried out in simple, tailored suits, afternoon dresses with silhouette and fabric as the main embellishments, and evening gowns with a covered up look.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Governor Lehman was to have heard pleas for clemency today for William and Anthony Esposito, slayers of two men in a Fifth Avenue holdup on Jan. 14, 1941, who have been convicted and their sentence affirmed by the Court of Appeals.

Returning to the scene of his triumph last year, when he won the silver cup with his Kerry blue terrier Brian, Richard Waidelich handled another Kerry blue that was named the best terrier puppy on the second day of Bloomingdale's eleventh annual pet dog show yesterday.

Cesare Antonio Moneta, chef and restaurant-keeper on Mulberry Street, is about to close his temple of food and drink, frequented by many worshipers in the last twenty-five years. In this town of 20,000-odd eating houses it takes an artist of the first distinction to make himself known to a substantial coterie of intelligent clients.
Camille A. Gillotte has become associated with the realty firm of Frederick Zittell Sons and will supervise a new department handling apartment and residential hotel renting.
MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Army won from the University of Maryland at basketball today, 44 to 32, on the field house court. The cadets led all the way, the score at half time reading 24 to 13. Philpott was Army's high man with 14 points. Travis led the Old Liners with 16.

Petitions requesting Congress to oust Mayor La Guardia as New York City director of Civilian Defense and to place the responsibility for civilian protection directly under the War Department have been circulated extensively among air raid wardens in Queens, it became known yesterday.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 18 -- New Zealand expects to sell her exportable surplus of foodstuffs to Great Britain again this year, despite the submarine blockade, Marketing Minister Barclay revealed today.

A series of five lecture on "Defense Gardens," with the proceeds to be used for purchasing equipment for the Polish Hospital in Edinburgh, an American memorial to Ignace Jan Paderewski, has been arranged under the auspices of the Paderewski Testimonial Fund, Inc., through that organization's garden committee, of which Princess Paul Sapieha is chairman.

The industrial plant of the Fairfield Dairy Supply Company at 460 Main Street, Singac, N.J., consisting of an acre of land improved with several buildings and a railroad siding, has been purchased by the Singac Exchange in a transaction arranged by Robert B. Stoutenburgh, Newark broker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A price of $100 a plate is being solicited for the George Washington Dinner in Washington Monday evening. It is one of a country-wide series, the proceeds of which will go to meet the deficit incurred by the Democratic National Committee in the 1940 election of President Roosevelt.

Printed copies of the statement of condition of the Bank for International Settlements on Nov. 30 were received here yesterday from the headquarters of the bank in Basle, Switzerland. Postmarks indicated that the statement, with a summary of foreign exchange regulations compiled by the monetary and economic department of the bank, were more than two months in transit.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Groups of parents here declared open war today on the eleven Greek letter sororities and fraternities in the White Plains High School because of the recent suicide of Miss Ruth Murray Livingston, who was despondent over a sorority quarrel at the school, but the students remained adamant in refusing to disband the secret societies.

Utilization of the spiritual power and resources of the church to aid "a nation struggling for its existence" was proposed yesterday by the Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in his first interview since his election as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The names of Representatives Day, Republican of Illinois, Sweeney of Ohio and former Senator Holt of West Virginia figured today in the trial of George Sylvester Viereck, accused of concealing from the State Department pertinent information of his activities.
