CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- United Nations armed forces, Continued From Page One including new American airplanes and Chinese troops, were reported in Chinese dispatches tonight to be concentrated in North Central Burma for a climactic battle with an estimated 100,000 Japanese troops seeking to cut the Burma Road supply line.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 18 -- Dr. H.V. van Mook, Lieutenant Governor-General of the Netherlands Indies, said here today upon his return from the United States that the policy of constantly retiring to prepared positions could lead to the United Nations loss of the war.

A plea that school and college curriculums be disrupted as little as possible during war was made yesterday by Dr. Henry C. Kittredge of St. Paul's School, Concord, N.H., at a luncheon forum on "Education in a War Economy" presented by the Tuition Plan at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.
CAIRO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- R.A.F. headquarters issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The missing sixth defendant, one of those blamed by Vichy for the German defeat of France, spoke out today in behalf of the five others and described their trial, which begins tomorrow, as "a judicial comedy."

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Thursday, Feb. 19 -- The United Nations command reported yesterday that American planes had scored victories in the Southern Sumatra theatre, where Japanese activity in the Palembang region pointed to an early land, sea and air battle for control of the Strait of Sunda, the vital passage between Sumatra and Java.
SYDNEY, Thursday, Feb. 19 -- Port Darwin, port of the town of Darwin on the Northern Australian coast, has been bombed, Prime Minister John Curtin announced today.

Trade buying brought about moderate gains in the cotton market for a time yesterday, but in late trading New Orleans selling and hedging induced an easier tone. On the New York Cotton Exchange, final prices of active futures were at levels 1 point lower to 2 points higher than the previous close.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 -- The approach of "friendly aircraft," at first unidentified, plunged cities of the bay area into darkness for nineteen minutes tonight on orders from the Army's Fourth Interceptor Command.

The existence of a gang of hoodlums that forces young girls in Brooklyn to take jobs as domestics and compels them to steal from their employers and turn over all loot to the ringleaders was disclosed yesterday in Kings County Court.

The Japanese attack on the Netherlands Indies was preceded by a campaign of infiltration dating back to the first World War and making use of native agitators, bogus commercial firms and consistent violation of diplomatic privileges, according to a White Paper of the Indies Government, released here yesterday by the Netherlands Information Bureau.

SOMEWHERE IN JAVA, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- A new list of United States flying heroes -- sixty-four men decorated for bravery that cost some of them their lives -- emerged from the battle in the southwestern region of the Pacific today.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- Distinguished civic and music leaders today joined with several hundred other friends of the New England Conservatory of Music in commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the conservatory at exercises in Jordan Hall.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 -- German ground forces northwest of El Gazala continued to lie low yesterday, and although the British sent out several patrols toward Mekili, few contacts resulted, today's report of the British headquarters here said.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

A portrait of George Washington by Gilbert Stuart brought $19,000 last night at auction at the Kende Galleries at Gimbel Brothers. The sale comprised property of the Westbury Holding Corporation, collected by Mrs. Leonard K. Elmhirst, the former Miss Dorothy Payne Whitney. The first session of the three-session auction brought $26,524.

Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, at the annual meeting of the board of directors yesterday said more than 2,850,000 persons own individual policies or group certificates in the company, a new peak.

Thomas E. Dewey was honored yesterday by the directors of the United Service Organizations, receiving from Walter Hoving, chairman of the board, a scroll expressing appreciation for his work as national chairman of the 1941 campaign for funds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- News of reorganization of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's War Cabinet in Great Britain was received with pleasure in high official circles here, where the continuance in office of Mr. Churchill's assailed government was regarded as of key importance.
For the fifth consecutive week, engineering construction awards currently exceed the $100,000,000 mark with a total of $102,218,000, the Engineering News-Record reports.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- The American troops in the Indies have seen no action yet and have been taking life comparatively easy in a "certain East Java town," according to Aneta.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Japanese Army on the Bataan Peninsula pressed heavily against the defending line held by Americans and Filipinos while preparing for a still greater offensive, the War Department reported today.

A Chinese delegate to the International Labor Conference and former representative of China at the International Labor Office in Geneva, Ping-Heng Li, has taken residential quarters consisting of seven rooms and three baths in the apartment house at 285 Riverside Drive in a lease arranged by the Apartment Renting Company, Inc., brokers.
The Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York has awarded medals and cash to eleven men and boys who risked their lives saving others from drowning.
Plans for a rationing of fuel oil along the Atlantic seaboard to insure an equitable distribution of supplies were made known here and in Washington yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- Britain was building an air-borne invasion army and large new armored formations, but before they could go into action the British Isles must be secured against attack, War Secretary David Margesson said today in the House of Commons.

Two civic leaders interested in crime problems and two magistrates took issue yesterday with Judge Saul S. Streit of General Sessions Court for his statement, made in sentencing a 26-year-old burglar, that youthful offenders had been "pampered" in the Adolescents Court in Brooklyn.

In his letter which was printed in your columns yesterday. Arthur H. Weston expresses his belief that the public at large is fully alive to the true nature of the exigencies which beset us. I wish it were possible for me to share his optimism.

THE first glimpse I had of him was when he pulled up alongside of me, his police officer's badge showing. "Where do you think you are going?" he asked. In as much as I hadn't been watching the speedometer, I had no conviction of guilt -- or, for that matter, of innocence. I stood in a hazy mid-region of vacillation that left me completely tongue-tied.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- The "Free Yugoslav Army" operating in the mountains of Bosnia has destroyed a "Fascist expedition" of 5,000 soldiers and captured quantities of grenade-throwers, machine guns and ammunition, according to intelligence reports reaching here today.

There is much misunderstanding and confusion regarding naturalization, which ought to be more accurately termed "nationalization." The favor bestowed on a foreign-born person by permitting him to become, by political process, an American citizen, is not a natural nor an inherent right.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The War Department rounded out a reorganization of the Army General Staff today with the assignment of Brig. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to be chief of the War Plans Division.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- A sloppy track was credited by most with the form upsets today at Hialeah Park, where Verse and Grey Wing captured the featured races before a crowd of 7,731. The betting reached $450,492.

Metropolitan ski enthusiasts will have to travel to upper New York State, New England and Eastern Canada for their holiday week-end of sport starting tomorrow. Although the weather has deprived a large part of the local ski army from enjoying the facilities to be found in the near-by Catskills, Berkshires and Poconos, the season's largest exodus to the North Country is expected to begin tonight.

Mal Stevens, head football coach of New York University, is prepared to resign or coach without pay if that will deter Violet authorities from going through with their reported plan to abolish football, according to the N.Y.U. Heights Daily News.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- In the stock markets today gilt-edge securities improved 1/16 to 1/4 in anticipation of the reinvestment of Indian and Canadian requisition money, which will be disbursed next month. The industrials steadied but failed to hold their early improvement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The National War Labor Board, by a vote of 10 to 2, rejected tonight a C.I.O. demand for temporary suspension of a closed-shop provision in an A.F.L. contract covering 3,500 workers of the Los Angeles Railway Corporation and the Los Angeles Motor Coach Company, pending a final court decision on legality of the agreement.

All that is left of the awesome Boston Bruins of a few weeks ago are the uniforms. The Brooklyn Americans emphasized this fact last night when they beat the world champions in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden, 6 to 4.

Spring flowers arriving in substantial quantities in the city markets this week-end offer a cheerful forecast of the coming season. Freesias, iris, snap-dragons, daffodils, tulips, sweet peas and gladioluses are all available in abundance, the majority grown under glass in local greenhouses.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- Engineers of Drydock Associates, Inc., builder of the country's largest drydock at the Philadelphia Navy Yard, have been called into consultation with the Navy on the problem of refloating the Normandie at its pier in New York, it was disclosed today by Daniel C. Young, chief engineer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Formation of a Filipino battalion in the American Army, a posible forerunner of other groups to be composed of nationals of Axis-occupied countries, was announced today by Secretary Stimson.

First the bad news, then the good. That is the policy followed by the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets in its summary of current conditions along the food front. Many cuts of pork, the department points out, have risen sharply in price and now average from 3 to 9 cents a pound higher than they did a year ago.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Miss Mabel MacPherson of Philadelphia took first place in the women's school figure event for novices at the opening of the national figure skating championships in the Chicago Arena today.

A flurry of hedging offers near the close of trading yesterday shook the cotton market from an aimless course and carried prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net losses of 8 to 10 points, the low marks of the day.

The difference that a conductor makes in the performance of an orchestra has seldom been more strikingly demonstrated than it was last night, when Sergei Koussevitzky made his first appearance as guest leader of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society in Carnegie Hall.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company yesterday joined the three other companies comprising "Little Steel" in expressing opposition to any proposal that would grant the closed shop to the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, either in outright or "camouflaged" form.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of new rules enabling registered companies to maintain war secrecy.

Bank clearings at the twenty-three leading cities of the country in the five-day week ended with Wednesday were 8.5 per cent more than in the previous week of six days and 2.9 per cent ahead of the comparative full week of last year. Check transactions totaled $6,468,071,000 for the five days compared with $6,288,277,000 a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 19 -- Bishop Thomas James Wade of Providence, R.I., Vicar Apostolic in the Northern Solomon Islands since 1930, refused to leave Kieta, the capital of the Solomons, on Bougainville Island, with other whites when a Japanese warship arrived in the harbor of the undefended town, it was revealed today at Port Moresby, Papua, New Guinea.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- An American Legion Post on the Pacific Coast has written to Governor Lehman regarding the presence at in unnamed place of officers and men of the Fifty-second Brigade of the Twenty-seventh Division, stating that their soldierly bearing and deportment have won the commendation of the populace.

Characterizing the petition signed by more than 500 air raid wardens in Queens as "a vicious attempt to create dissension, to break morale, and to undermine constituted authority," Police Commissioner Valentine declared yesterday in a vigorously phrased formal statement that the Police Department would not tolerate "insubordination" in the ranks of the volunteer wardens.
SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Proposals to declare a moratorium upon the bank loans, business debts and Federal taxes owed by tire dealers and similar individuals or organizations, whose income has been cut off by stoppage of sale of the products that they normally handle, were described as dangerous and likely to dissipate assets to the detriment of both debtors and creditors, in discussions among credit men yesterday.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Immediate improvement of the running-time performance of the New York Central Railroad Company's passenger trains was ordered today by the Public Service Commission.

Chief Judge Irving Lehman and Associate Judges Albert Conway and Edward R. Finch of the Court of Appeals in Albany indulged in a veritable bus driver's holiday yesterday when they visited the new $20,000,000 Criminal Courts Building on Center Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- During the week ended Feb. 18 member bank reserve balances increased $153,000,000. Addition to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $55,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $13,000,000 in Treasury cash and $59,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and an increase of $73,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, offset in part by an increase of $20,000,000 in money circulation and a decrease of $29,000,000 in gold stock.

The Bethlehem and Republic steel companies are justified in their suspicions regarding the "maintenance-of-union-membership" clause which William H. Davis, the chairman of the War Labor Board, is said to be considering as a "compromise" of the steel unions' demand for a closed shop.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 19 -- The Japanese have broken through the Bilin River defense line, a British communique revealed tonight. Unofficial advices indicated the invaders' vanguard was within forty-five miles of the Pegu railway junction north of this endangered Burmese port.

A proposal to establish a citywide community chest to raise funds and thus eliminate competitive appeals for charity, voluntary welfare and health agencies was made yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Greater New York Fund.

The Society for the Prevention of Crime, one of New York's oldest social agencies, which was reorganized last year with Paul Blanshard, former Commissioner of Accounts, as its new director, announced yesterday that it is transforming itself into a national organization to meet the threat of increased crime under war conditions.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Declaring that "the automobile industry has shouldered arms," Ernest Kanzler, chief of the War Production Board's automotive division, said today that when General Motors, Ford and Chrysler attained capacity production on their present orders they would be running at the rate of $10,500,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A general plan to step up production of the entire cotton goods industry was discussed here today by mill representatives serving on the cotton mill advisory committee with Frank L. Walton, chief of the cotton section of the War Production Board.

Six-week-old Madeline Renaldi, obviously unconscious of the fact that her country is at war, gave all that her small person could for civilian defense yesterday. Lying contentedly on a large padded table, she smiled benignly and sneezed occasionally while serving as a model for diaper instruction.

The United States business man was urged yesterday to "become a disciple" of the program of improved inter-American relations by Joseph C. Rovensky, chief of the financial and commercial division, Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.
Lady DuBarry, a brindle Boston terrier owned by Mrs. Susan Heaney of New York, carried off top honors in yesterday afternoon's judging at Bloomingdale's eleventh annual pet dog show.

Until complacency is actually made a State and Federal crime, punishable by fine or imprisonment or both, perhaps a few bold spirits here and there will resolve to serve their country by being complacent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- "Sell it back," Leon Henderson said today in an Office of Price Administration statement directed to sugar hoarders. He advised them to sell their extra sugar to neighbors or local grocers before these stocks became a liability under the sugar-rationing orders.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 19 -- American troops and American fighter and bomber pilots stood tonight with other United Nations reinforcements and the Netherlanders against the gathering storm looming over Java, the last major position against the Japanese in the South Pacific short of Australia.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Aggressive buying of wheat futures here and at Minneapolis in the early trading today absorbed the offerings in the pit, and while trading was unusually light in the aggregate the market showed a distinctly firm undertone.

Major Honore Joseph Jaxon, 80-year-old soldier of fortune, who says he is a veteran of three wars and who has occupied for twenty years a small plot at 1383 Eastern Boulevard, on the brink of the Bronx River, crossed swords with the law yesterday when he was haled into court charged with violating health regulations.

The 70,000 employes of the Federal Government in the New York City area soon will have made available to them payroll deduction plans for the purchase of defense savings bonds, it was announced yesterday by the New York Defense Savings Staff.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 19 -- Japan's first blow at Australia proper was where it was most expected -- on the port at Darwin, the Commonwealth's front door and capital of the northern territory.

Machinery of the New York Stock Exchange made yesterday a successful beginning with the first of the new "special distributions" and by the close of trading 1,775 of 2,958 shares of the B stock of the Bon Ami Company had been sold under the new rules.
The Desmond bill to amend the 1941 Audubon plumage law has now been passed by the Senate and Assembly and is before the Governor for consideration.

Paul Pilgrim, a former double Olympic champion and now the athletic manager at the New York A.C., took time out yesterday from his task of arranging details for the Winged Foot games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow and turned prophet.

The integration program of the Securities and Exchange Commission under the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act received yesterday a sharp set-back when the North American Company, second largest holding company in the nation, abandoned its program for the sale of its largest subsidiary, the Union Electric Company of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Department store sales during the week ended Feb. 14 were 19 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Last week a gain of 20 per cent was reported. Gains of 25 per cent and 29 per cent, respectively, were reported for the four-week period and the year up to Feb. 14.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A bill sponsored by the newly organized Metropolitan Package Stores, Inc., and designed to curb retail liquor price-cutting wars, will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow, it was announced here today.

The three New York major league baseball clubs will donate approximately 600,000 free tickets to service men during the 1942 season, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, co-chairman of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Dr. T.V. Soong, the Chinese Foreign Minister, and with General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff; Donald Nelson, War Production Board chairman; Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, and other key officials in shipping.

Suit to oust George E. Roosevelt, M. Murray Weisman and Milton M. Bergerman as voting trustees of the Sherneth Corporation, which owns and operates the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, has been instituted in Supreme Court, it was disclosed yesterday.

In the possible reduction or regrouping of cosmetics because of priorities, lip rouge is sure to survive. Colors will be fewer, but there wil be lipsticks to harmonize not only with faces but with new Spring clothes as well.

Religion is "a dynamic force in the social growth" which this nation has enjoyed under a democratic government, Dr. Barclay Acheson, vice president of the Near East Relief, declared yesterday in reviewing recent social progress. He was the principal speaker at the annual luncheon of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, held in the Hotel Plaza, with 500 persons attending.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Federal Power Commission approved today a merger of five affiliated electric utilities with the Pennsylvania Electric Company and issued other orders which, with previous ones, provide for a $28,000,000 write-down in the plant accounts of companies in Western Pennsylvania in the Associated Gas and Electric holding company system.

The United States will have an increased chance of an early victory if we postpone the "grandiose and costly" St. Lawrence Waterway project, spend a few million dollars on a project like the shallow barge canal across Florida, which would make wartime transportation safer and easier, and put the difference into armaments, Governor Sam Houston Jones of Louisiana declared yesterday.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 19 -- One of the major strategic positions in the Southwestern Pacific since the fall of Hong Kong, Manila and Singapore, Darwin has a normal population of from 4,000 to 5,000, but this has been greatly increased since the war by the influx of service men.
A New York Stock Exchange membership has been transferred from John S. Chapman to W.T. Bacon of Bacon, Whipple Co., Chicago.

Contributions to the Greater New York Red Cross War Fund on the fourth day of General MacArthur Week set a new record yesterday, when $149,598 was reported by Leon Fraser, general chairman of the drive. He added that every effort was being made to raise by Marsh 4 the "MacArthur victory fund," as the final $1,000,000 needed for the local campaign's $7,330,000 quota has been designated.

Hearings on the application of the Long Island Railroad and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for a 10 per cent rise in commutation rates, effective March 1, were closed yesterday before the Public Service Commission at 80 Center Street.

Under a group program being underwritten on a cooperative basis by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, surgical operation benefits ranging up to $150 have been established for more than 375 employes of the Allen-Wales Adding Machine Corporation.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Everett N. Case, assistant dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, was elected as ninth president of Colgate University today at the trustees' meeting in New York City. He will succeed Dr. George Barton Cutten, scheduled to retire Aug. 31 after twenty years of service.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies armed forces issued this communique through the news agency Aneta today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Philip Murray, President of the Congress of Industrial Organization, and chairman of its Steel Workers' Organizing Committee, asserted tonight that "certain government and industry officials" had joined in a "premeditated publicity campaign" designed to "prejudice the public mind, and, if possible, the War Labor Board" against $1-a-day wage increase and union security demands of the S.W.O.C. against four "Little Steel" companies employing 175,000 employes.

Bizet's "Carmen" received a sluggish, lackluster presentation last night at the Metropolitan. The performance marked the return to the company of Jan Kiepura, the Polish tenor, who was cast as Don Jose. Mr. Kiepura had not appeared at the house since the season of 1938-1939.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The Republican leaders of the Legislature took themselves out of the controversy over the five-cent fare today and tossed the political issue back into the laps of the New York City Democrats.

OSSINING, N.Y., Friday, Feb. 20 -- The grim parade to the electric chair of the leaders of the Brooklyn murder syndicate continued today, with Harry (Happy) Maione and Frank (The Dasher) Abbandando paying the death penalty soon after midnight.

The Eastern railroads are protesting to the War Production Board and to Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transport, against a reduction of 50 per cent in the tonnage of rails allocated to them, F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad and chairman of the Eastern Railroads Presidents Conference, said after a meeting of the conference yesterday.

That the open market committee of the Federal Reserve System was called on to lend support to the government bond market in the week ended on Wednesday was revealed yesterday in the regular weekly figures, which showed that $7,405,000 of bonds had been purchased for the account of the twelve regional banks.

Metro's "Woma of the Year," currently in its third week at the Radio City Music Hall, recorded a total of 294,395 paid admissions during its first two weeks, the producers announced yesterday. According to the company's estimate, attendance figures for the run of the picture will be among the highest in the theatre's history.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- A new plan to encourage life insurance companies and savings banks to invest their funds in slum clearance was submitted to the Legislature today, in the form of an "urban redevelopment" bill introduced by Assemblyman Mitchell and Senator Hampton.

RIOM, France, Feb. 19 -- After nearly a year and a half two Premiers of the Third Republic, a generalissimo, an Air Minister and a Controller of the Army appeared here this afternoon before the Supreme Court especially created to try them.

Perhaps the moment is too early for congratulations, but the New York Stock Exchange's first use of its new "special offering" system appears to have been a marked success. The first block provided much more of a test than the sponsors of the scheme would have chosen had they been able to choose.

The Bell System established new records all along the line last year in handling the nation's communications needs under wartime emergency conditions, Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, declared yesterday in his 1941 annual report to stockholders.

In line with the policy of supporting "practical measures designed to improve the safety, convenience and livability of tenement houses," the housing committee of the Community Service Society announced yesterday its approval of seven bills and its opposition to four others now pending in Albany.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe handed down today an order tentatively approving the reorganization of local street car and elevated lines into a single company, thus clearing the way for Chicago's plan for unifying and modernizing its transportation system.
SAN FANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- Governor Olson was rebuffed today by Earl Warren, State Attorney General, in his proposal to revoke all business and professional licenses held by enemy aliens in California.

One thousand members of Local 65 of the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, C.I.O., staged a mass picketing demonstration in front of the building occupied by Dorset Food, Ltd., 450 West Thirty-fifth Street, at noon yesterday in support of striking employes of the concern who are demanding recognition of the union and a collective bargaining agreement.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The War Department today issued the following communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M.:

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Air Marshal Arthur T. Harris, head of the Royal Air Force delegation in Washington, has been appointed Commander in Chief of the Bomber Command, succeeding Air Marshal Sir Richard E.C. Peirse. The latter, several weeks ago, was assigned to a special appointment said to involve highly important duties.
LONDON, Feb. 19 UP) -- The Bank of England statement today showed a decrease in note circulation of almost 900,000, the first dip in three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The United States is developing its Army as an offensive weapon to carry the war to the Axis, and it will not be dispersed in small units as defensive forces, Secretary Stimson said today.

Offsetting reports of a slump in evening dress sales, the New York Dress Institute announced yesterday that distribution of New York creation labels to evening dress manufacturers increased 67 per cent during the first half of February over the total for the entire month of January.

Barrow, Leafy Co. of Shreveport received yesterday the award of an issue of $200,000 of airport bonds of Iberia Parish La., at a net interest cost of 2.409 per cent. The successful bid was par for $36,000 as 3s; $29,000 as 2 3/4s; $74,000 as 2 1/2s, and $61,000 as 21/4s. The bonds will mature serially on March 1, 1944 to 1962.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- A report on the British Army, especially prepared in rebuttal of criticism that Britons had been favored while troops of the dominions and colonies had borne the brunt of fighting, was given in the House of Commons today by War Secretary David Margesson.
The Baltimore Ohio Railroad has ordered rolling stock to cost $9,500,000, Roy B. White, president, announced yesterday.

WITH GENERAL MACARTHUR'S ARMY in the Philippines, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- United States troops have wiped out a Japanese regiment (about 4,000 men) in a bitter, week-long jungle battle and stemmed what was intended to be a major drive to clear the defenders from the Bataan Peninsula.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, chairman of the Westchester County Defense Council, demanded and received today the resignation of H. McIntyre Grout, Jr. as executive secretary of the council.

Tonight the Belasco will receive "Plan M," James Edward Grant's melodramatic conception of a Nazi attempt to invade England. The author depicts how several high British officials could be kidnapped and their staff hoodwinked by a Nazi emissary assuming full command of the War Office headquarters in London.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Elmer Van Orden, who was born on High Tor two years before the Civil War ended, died before daybreak today in Good Samaritan Hospital at Suffern.
BEELIN, Feb. 19 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
Park Commissioner Robert Moses received authority from the Board of Estimate yesterday to designate a substitute to attend meetings of the City Planning Commission.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 19 -- "The United States Army definitely believes that this area will be bombed," Leonard Dreyfuss told the Essex Electrical League today in his first public address since his appointment Monday as State Defense Council chairman.

The preliminary report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for 1941, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $7,366,240 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This compared with $3,621,581 in 1940.

Margaret Hall, young pianist from Cortland, N.Y., gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. She was heard in a program composed of Bach's B flat partita, Beethoven's sonata, Op. 110; Chopin's nocturne in F and scherzo in C sharp minor, Debussy's "Poissons d'or" and "Feux d'artifice" and Liapunoff's "Lesghinka."

DUBLIN, Feb. 19 -- The blunt speech by Deputy James Dillon on Eire's relation with the United States in the present world situation, which was delivered at the annual convention of William Cosgrave's Opposition party here on Feb. 10, had a sequel this evening when the resignation of Mr. Dillon from the party was announced.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Ways and Means Committee dealt the Administration a stunning defeat today by voting, 16 to 8, to shelve a $300,000,000 program of unemployment benefits to workers displaced by the conversion of factories to wartime production.

New mortgage loans on Manhattan real estate got off to a slow start for the new year. In January the number and dollar volume of realty financing were below the figures for December and also less than for the corresponding month of 1941, according to the monthly survey of the Real Estate Board of New York, based on reports gathered by The Real Estate Record and Builders Guide.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Further instructions have been sent Admiral William D. Leahy, the United States Ambassador in Vichy, because of the unsatisfactory information received from the French Government concerning its attitude and course toward the Axis, Sumner Welles, acting secretary of State announced today.

SO far, Ray Robinson is the practically perfect fighter. He hasn't lost a bout. The report, rushed along by Uncle Mike Jacobs's merry men at the mimeograph machines, is that he had eighty-nine fights as an amateur and won exactly eighty-nine of them. Then he turned professional. As a professional, he has had twenty-seven fights, of which he won twenty-seven.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Adrien Tixier, chief of the Free French delegation in the United States, visited the State Department today while Vichy-American relations continued at a critical stage. M. Tixier talked for about twenty minutes with Acting Secretary Sumner Welles.

DUBLIN, Feb. 19 -- With stocks of wheat running low, Eire is facing a bread crisis during the next few months. Broadcasting to the country tonight, Minister of Supplies Scan Lemass outlined drastic measures his department must take to make the present supply of wheat flour go as far as possible.

TO develop power on a Canadian stream permission must first be secured from the Dominion Parliament. It was thus that the three Beauharnois plants on the St. Lawrence came into being. One of these (Cedars Rapids) is partly owned by the Aluminum Company of America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- After four days of acrimonious debate the Senate voted today, 75 to 5, to repeal provisions of a recently passed Civil Service Retirement Act granting optional retirement pay to members of Congress, the President and the Vice President and members of the Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Following three weeks of investigation the Bureau of the Budget completed today for the consideration of President Roosevelt a detailed report criticizing the government press services and recommending a more centralized control under the Office of Facts and Figures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A story of how George Sylvester Viereck, German propaganda agent, visited Capitol Hill in 1940 and arranged for wholesale distribution of Congressional speeches attacking the Administration's foreign policy was told in Federal Court today by George Hill, former assistant secretary of Representative Hamilton Fish.

BEIRUT, Lebanon. Feb. 17 (Delayed) -- With Field Marshal Erwin Rommel in the Western Desert providing ample proof of Axis determination to maintain a hold on North Africa, in conjunction with the forecast of a German thrust toward the Caucasian oil fields, the Middle East from Libya to the Turkish-Russian frontier is on tenterhooks -- and increasingly so.

HAVANA, Feb. 19 -- "I've got just the kind of club I've always wanted," was Manager Leo Durocher's first official public utterance today after his Dodgers had finished their opening workout in beautiful Tropical Park Stadium.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Feb. 19 -- Mrs. Ruth Ryan Sanford, 24-year-old wife of Henry Sanford Jr., wealthy sportsman, died early today of a self-inflicted rifle wound in Southside Hospital, Bay Shore. Her death was listed as a suicide by Coroner Grover A. Silliman after an autopsy and inquest.

Doubtless it is a sin to be conservative and offensive to gravity to be tickled with a straw, yet the restoration, so far as the British Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs is concerned, of the old names of Persia and Siam will not be without healing effect on those of us who acquired at school a little geography for a deal of pain.

The Pennroad Corporation, a holding agency formed by the management of the Pennsylvania Railroad in 1929, is to press for the collection of $3,852,000 from the Pennsylvania Railroad which the Federal Court in Philadelphia held was due from the parent company, Benjamin F. Pepper, president, disclosed in his annual report, issued yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 19 -- The convoying by Brazil of ships carrying strategical materials to the United States was considered in Brazilian Government circles today, with the assertion that the torpedoing of the Brazilian ship Buaque would not halt ocean traffic between Brazil and North America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A move to prevent the exploitation of school children in the effort to meet potential shortages of farm labor came today in a joint statement from four Federal agencies issued by the Children's Bureau.

TOKYO, Feb. 19 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Domei dispatch from an "undisclosed base" reported today that, after completing the occupation of Singapore, Japanese troops yesterday effected a bloodless capture of Batam and Samboe Islands to the south in the Netherland-owned Rhio Archipelago.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- The newspaper Pravda today described a recent sharp engagement resulting in the capture of Kresty, near Velizh. Kresty is northeast of Velizh on the upper reaches of the Western Dvina River and some eighty miles northwest of Smolensk.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 19 -- China's government disclosed today that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had made concrete arrangements to replace the Burma Road with an India-to-China railroad-river route, now that the approaches to Rangoon are mined land that menaced city is no longer a practical port of entry for war material consigned to China.

Robert T. Bushnell, Attorney General of Massachusetts, urged yesterday a compromise in the plan to reorganize the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. He appeared at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing in the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

Defending titleholders dominated the senior metropolitan A.A.U. swimming championships at the Downtown Athletic Club last night, five of the six crowns at stake being retained by last year's winners. The sixth, left undefended in the 220-yard breaststroke by Edgar Blackledge of the New York A.C., who is now in the Army, was taken by his clubmate, Johnny Sorman.

CHUNGKING, Feb. 19 (UP) -- Today's announcement that Generalissimo Chiang had found a "satisfactory solution" to the problem of transporting Allied supplies from Indian ports directly to China suggested to experts that an agreement might have been reached on the continued use of the Burma Road as a connecting link in an overland route from India that is expected to be usable soon.

The Office of Civilian Defense is considering the distribution of thousands of extra beds to the 165 hospitals in this city to be ready for an air raid, it was indicated last night on the basis of a report made by the WPA health and hospital unit to Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, chief of the emergency medical division of the OCD here.
Ray Robinson, speedy Harlem welterweight who has yet to suffer defeat, will engage Maxie Berger, veteran from Montreal, in the feature bout of twelve rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Edward G. O'Neill, an assistant attorney general who conducted the two-year investigation of law enforcement in Orange County, was appointed yesterday to open the inquiry into the financial affairs of Local 17 of the Hod Carriers and Common Laborers Union, A.F. of L.
Sales of repossessed properties by savings banks formed the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

The halcyon days of civilian defense are over. As Director James M. Landis said on Wednesday, "It is urgently necessary that OCD be immediately stripped down for emergency action." Our seaboard cities, including this one, are within the enemy's reach if he thinks it worth while to pay what it will cost him to get here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The War Department moved today to eliminate the last vestige of old-style warfare in the Army by abolishing the "square" formations of the eighteen National Guard divisions and applying the "triangular" form already adopted for the regular army and other divisions to be created in the future.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Two trainmen were killed and more than forty other persons were injured today in the head-on collision of two tourist trains operating between Miami and New York.

The surprising thoroughness with which Kurt Frederick Ludwig was able to report details of military aircraft, the locations of Army organizations and the extent of their equipment, and the presence of "enemy" ships in New York Harbor was illustrated yesterday for the Federal court jury before which he and six others are on trial for espionage.
Conditions on board United States merchant ships were roundly criticized last night by Federal Judge John C. Knox, who placed the blame for the situation upon union seamen and their delegates.

Four sentences of fifteen years to life imprisonment, to run concurrently, were imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Stephan Catlan, 36 years old, an ex-convict with several convictions, for his part in the attempt to hold up Frank A. Erickson, horse race bookmaker, in his suite in the New York Athletic Club last April 4.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Official communiques issued here today by the War and Navy Departments on new air and sea activity against the Japanese in the South-western Pacific hinted at accretions to American forces there that may have a potent effect in the war against the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- A general advance in wholesale prices during the week ended on Feb. 14, affecting most markets, caused the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics to reach the highest level since August, 1929, it was reported today.

Consolidated net earnings of the American Can Company for 1941 amounted to $18,845,831, equal after preferred dividends to $6.45 a share for 2,473,998 common shares, comparing with $17,440,906, or $5.88 a share, earned in 1940, according to Maurice J. Sullivan, president of the company.

The lessons of the war, particularly the one that reveals that thinking in terms of defense is to invite doom, are the concerns of Lieut. Col. W.F. Kernan in one of next week's books. Assisting the "defense myth," Colonel Kernan in "Defense Will Not Win the War" (next Wednesday, Little, Brown) argues that with civilian, military and naval thinking directed offensively, America, as the only country with strength remaining, will win the war.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Indictments charging Armour Co., Swift Co., four other concerns and six individuals with conspiracy to violate the Sherman anti-trust law in the operation of the St. Joseph hog market were returned today by a Federal grand jury.

OTTAWA, Feb. 19 -- Out of the total of sixty-four Liberal members from Quebec Province in the House of Commons, only eleven stood up today and declared themselves openly anti-conscription in votes on the government's policy as outlined in the speech from the throne.

The stock market appeared early yesterday to be ripe for a technical rebound from its low position and timid feelers were put out. Some of the industrial shares responded with fractional rises, but the buying lacked enthusiasm in the face of the war news and the day's final prices showed only moderate advances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Roosevelt, confined to the White House residence with a slight head cold, limited his appointments today to an important shipping conference with top defense leaders and a discussion of Chinese military and supply problems with Dr. T.V. Soong, Chinese Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- "I need him badly to help me with this tremendous job," said a top war administrator today, and he named the man he wants. "But I'm afraid I can't get an 'H.H.' on him." To the Washington initiated, the initials are known to stand for the President's most intimate assistant, Harry Hopkins.
Conditions on board United States merchant ships were roundly criticized last night by Federal Judge John C. Knox, who placed the blame for the situation upon union seamen and their delegates.

SAN NICHOLAS, Aruba Island, Feb. 19 -- This important oil center of the Netherlands West Indies was shelled again just before dawn today by an enemy submarine that emerged suddenly about three miles offshore.

The Japanese surge across Malaya and Singapore, the threat to the Burma Road and the operations against Java, which yesterday were intensified, have made Japan and her nexus of island conquest virtually impregnable to attack from the Southwestern Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- New plans for tighter control of enemy aliens on the Pacific Coast, which may include ejection from certain zones of second generation Japanese who are American citizens, are being formulated and may be announced at any time.

The Burma Road is at once artery and symbol. Time was when the Great Wall typified China's attitude toward the rest of the world; the great inner kingdom desired only to shield itself against invasion and live its own traditional life in seclusion and peace. That was the old China -- and the Old World.

Several luncheons were given yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Mrs. Edward J. Pearson had as her guests Mrs. Robert Lee Bullard, Mrs. James Lincoln Ashley, Mrs. Harry Clinton Abell, Mrs. Frank N.B. Close, Mrs. Joseph Bell Cotton and Mrs. Charles Maxwell.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Two ships at anchorages in the Gulf of Paria off Port-of-Spain were damaged last night by explosions apparently caused by a U-boat attack, United States Army headquarters announced today.

The Metropolitan Museum will open tomorrow a special exhibition of prints arranged to mark Washington's Birthday. The seventy-five examples, all from the museum's own collection, have been placed in Gallery A22, on the second floor, and may be seen there through April. The exhibition is called "Men Who Made America."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference this morning that so far as the Treasury envisaged it there would be no Alien Property Custodian in this war, as there was in 1917, but that President Roosevelt had given the Treasury authority to carry out the duties of that office.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill bowed to the wishes of the House of Commons and of many of his critics today by shaking up and cutting down his War Cabinet and by putting into it several members with no direct Cabinet responsibilities -- one of whom, Sir Stafford Cripps, former Ambassador to Moscow, is to be leader of the Commons.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Red Wings exploded three goals within six minutes of the second period tonight and got three more in the third to defeat the Black Hawks, 6 to 1, in a National Hockey League game. It was the first defeat in four starts for the fourth-place Chicagoans.

Men from a torpedoed Norwegian tanker stood up in their drifting lifeboat in the bitter North Atlantic weather last month and fought each other to keep awake and alive. They drifted or rowed desultorily for ten days, finally sighting an American ocean patrol plane that dropped food and summoned a Canadian destroyer to the rescue.

After three weeks of patient rehearsing two payroll thieves presented their act yesterday. The opus had only one performance because detectives of the safe and loft squad also had learned the routine and a third gangster, the lookout, hadn't.

A list of 1,009 Navy and Marine Corps officers and men who were stationed at Wake Island and Guam and in China, and 1,200 civilians who were building defense works at Wake Island and Guam when the Japanese attacked on Dec. 7, all of whom are presumed to be prisoners of war, was made public yesterday at the headquarters of the Third Naval District here.
The Bureau of Internal Revenue reminded taxpayers yesterday that it has at its command many sources for checking up on delinquent returns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Confronted with the problem of devising low-price furniture, made to fit the dimensions of compact defense houses, representatives of all branches of the furniture industry met here today to assure the government that they will cooperate to produce the type of furnishings wanted.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 19 -- Dismissal of the president and two vice presidents of the Omaha Federal Land Bank yesterday by a 4-to-3 vote of the directors of the Omaha district, Farm Credit Administration, touched off fireworks today in the form of statements by the board's minority and by Senator Hugh Butler of Nebraska in Washington.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Feb. 20 -- German lines on the central front south of Vyazma have broken and Soviet forces are pursuing a disorganized enemy on the whole length of a forty-five-mile front, according to a report from Moscow received here this morning.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- Indications that Manager Melvin Ott plans to introduce a few more innovations as the Giants' training progresses came to light today. The young skipper revealed that in addition to his recent order stressing bunting practice for his pitchers he planned to have the entire club go in for a heavier program of batting practice than it ever received before.

An investing client of the Transamerica Realty Corporation has purchased from the Home Life Insurance Company the four-story corner apartment house at 391 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, paying cash above a purchase money mortgage of $15,500.

Manufacturers in the drug and toilet goods field are beginning to test quietly new products which will not be released for national distribution until after the war is over. The tests comprise not only product and packages but also in a small way advertising copy.

By a curious set of chances, two versions of "The Pirates of Penzance" are visible in Gotham this week. At the St. James a fully recruited company is skipping brightly through the traditional Gilbert and Sullivan business.

In an article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, referring to the control of Thos. Cook Son, Ltd., as being taken over by four main-line British railways, it was incorrectly stated "Cook's, Travel Agency, Passes From Existence," and that the 1927 purchase price of Cook's by the Wagon-Lits Company was $3,700,000.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- British soldiers want to see their most potent individual ally, Private Joe Louis Barrow of the United States Army, in action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Among the Navy officers serving at Guam when the island was captured by the Japanese on Dec. 12 were the Governor, Captain George Johnson McMillin of Youngstown, Ohio; Captain William Taylor Lineberry, Colerain, N.C., and Commander Donald Theodore Giles, Annapolis, Md.

Embossed, stainless steel identification tags will be furnished to New York City's 1,000,000 school children to be worn at all times as means of identification in case of an air raid or evacuation of the city, it was disclosed yesterday with the awarding of a contract by the Board of Education to the Addressograph Corporation, 329 Fifth Avenue.

" Arsenic and Old Lace'" was the phrase that jumped to mind yesterday at the presentation of Erik's Spring collection of millinery. For play was given both to the brilliant shade of Paris green and to the use of lace as trim.
Recently there has been lively verbal battle between City College's loyal basketball followers and those who feel that the fine quality of sportsmanship is lacking in all City College adherents.

That organized labor in New York State is generally abiding by the announced policy of both the A.F.of L. and C.I.O. of "no unnecessary strikes for the duration" was shown yesterday by the report of Arthur S. Meyer, chairman of the State Mediation Board, covering industrial disputes for January.
As a student of City College and a keen follower of college basketball, I read your accounts of the games and records of the metropolitan teams with particular interest.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 20 -- In a decision holding that the word Communist is too vague to permit a man who had been charged with being one to know the nature of the accusation, Federal Judge Guy L. Fake here vacated today an indictment charging a former WPA worker with falsely swearing he was not a Communist.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -Justice James W. Morris sentenced Laura Ingalls to eight months to two years in prison today for failing to register as a paid agent of the German Reich.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Trade observers saw in the testimony given by John W. Dargavel, executive secretary of the National Association of Retail Druggists, in Washington Thursday the hint of a new campaign for legislative relief for small retailers.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Feb. 20 (AP) -- The management of the North American Aviation, Inc., bomber assembly plant here said today that its production pace was far ahead of the schedule set by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, relaxed the rationing rules today to permit men entering the armed forces who have 1942 cars to sell them to any one until March 9. They must apply in writing to the local rationing board with jurisdiction over the area where the car customarily is garaged or stationed.

The President was clearly justified in disapproving the bill which would provide for the development of guayule and other rubber-bearing plants, because this measure failed to provide for the stimulation of crude rubber sources in the Americas outside of the United States.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Holding that an adequate home food supply is vital to assure the health and strength of American families in wartime, Governor Lehman proclaimed today next week as Home Food Supply Enrollment Week and urged residents of the State to join in celebration of the national victory garden program.

Dr. Leo Buerger, discoverer of Buerger's disease, who has been practicing in Los Angeles, Calif., in recent years, is one of nine recent additions to the tenancy of the new apartment house at 530 Park Avenue, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

The discovery that raw eggwhite has the power to deprive human beings of biotin, the most powerful growth-vitamin in existence, found last week to be able to break down the barrier protecting animals against a cancer-producing chemical, is reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The American Friends of German Freedom made public yesterday a statement of policy adopted by its executive committee in which it is said that "from our knowledge of developments in Germany in the last few months, we are convinced that German morale has at last begun to deteriorate."

The volume of new bond financing this week fell to the lowest figure since last December as deferments of major corporate deals restricted the formal offerings to three individual loans in the aggregate amount of $2,400,000.

New York with its great medical schools and hospitals has become the mecca for South American physicians eager to advance medicine throughout the Latin-American republics, it was said yesterday by nineteen Chilean doctors who have been studying United States medical practice during the past four months.

An early indication of the drastic manner in which Fall buying policies of wholesalers, chains and department stores are being adjusted drastically this year to conform to the changed conditions prevailing among textile manufacturers generally was noted yesterday in the Worth Street knit underwear market.

The nine commercial banks in Queens County have adopted voluntary payroll deduction plans for employes in the purchasing of defense savings bonds out of income, it was announced yesterday by Paul E. Prosswimmer, president of the Queens County Bankers Association, who is president of the Jamaica National Bank.

At the final meeting of 250 workers in the annual financial campaign of the New York City Y.M.C.A., held yesterday at the Hotel Commodore, reports showed that 93.3 per cent of the objective, or $242,353, had been contributed.

"The Island God," opera with text as well as music by Gian-Carlo Menotti, received its first performance last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. In that opera house Mr. Menotti made his debut as an opera composer when his comedy, "Amelia Goes to the Ball," was produced there, March 2, 1938.

THOSE who turn out for the New York A.C. meet at Madison Square Garden tonight will have a chance to see what effect Cornelius Warmerdam's vaulting ambition has had on Earle Meadows, who was once top man on those "tote 'em" poles himself. The 15-foot mark stood out in the Vaulting field the way the mile runners were faced with the seemingly impassable 4:10 barrier.

Churchwomen in the five boroughs of the city as well as throughout the world observed the "World Day of Prayer" yesterday, with emphasis this year on peace, racial tolerance and brotherhood. The services have been held for twenty-five years on the first Friday in Lent.

Advances in prices of both men's and women's shoes by the A.S. Beck Shoe Company will become effective Monday and probably will be followed by a number of advances by various companies in the moderate price field, according to trade comment yesterday.

Shelled, torpedoed and sunk by a midget submarine that crash-dived out of sight when American naval planes appeared, the 4,053ton Brazilian steamer Olinda has become the nineteenth acknowledged victim in the battle off the United States Atlantic coast, the Navy revealed yesterday after all forty-six member of the Olinda's crew had been landed safely in Norfolk, Va.

CAMP BORDEN, Ont., Feb. 20 -G.P.L. Drake-Brockman, brigadier who was court-martialed out of the British Army for striking two German prisoners, has risen from ordinary tank trooper to major in the Canadian Army in little more than a month, it was revealed today.

New York City, in common with the rest of the United States, will celebrate tomorrow and Monday the 210th anniversary of the birth of our first President, George Washington. Overshadowed by America's participation in the world-wide war, the celebration will provide a period of taking stock of ideals and purposes, as well as of looking back to heroic pioneer beginnings.

Federal Bureau of Investigation agents suddenly directed raids last night against scores of German, Japanese and Italian aliens who they had reason to believe were still in possession of the cameras, short-wave radios and firearms they are now forbidden to possess.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 20 -Louis Cochand of the R.C.A.F. won the downhill race on the Mount Jo course today in a field of twenty starters, and Miss Dorothy Hoyt of the Schenectady Winter Sports Club paced a team of United States women skiers to a slim lead over a Canadian team as the Washington's Birthday Carnival of the Sno Birds of the Lake Placid Club got under way.

The approach of a week-end lengthened by the holiday on Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday brought yesterday further contraction in trading on the Stock Market and changes in values were insignificant. Transfers on the Exchange were the second smallest since last June, totaling 326,406 shares, against 345,080 on Thursday.

Mrs. Helen Pauline Mayer, American born but of German parentage, started her effort yesterday to disprove the charges of espionage leveled against her and six men in Federal court. She began her testimony immediately after United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa had announced to Judge Henry W. Goddard that the government's case was complete.

The recital given by Alexander Borovsky, the Russian pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall, was too largely given over to works outside of the field in which he accomplishes his most significant playing. During the first half of the program Mr. Borovsky devoted his efforts to interpretations of a lengthy congeries of compositions by Bach, capped by the Brahms "Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel."

A recommendation that United States Girl Scout leaders be asked to go to Colombia to train leaders in Scout activities there will be made to the National Colombian Girl Scout Committee by Senorita Gomez-Vega, head of the Girl Scouts in Colombia, on her return to Bogota in the near future.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 20 -- The people of Portugal first learned of the Japanese landings in Timor today through British, German and Italian broadcasts based on the Tokyo announcement. The Japanese statement, as relayed by D.N.B., German official news agency, was printed in the evening newspapers.

The order of the Interstate Commerce Commission of Jan. 21 granting a 10 per cent rise in passenger railroad rates was permissive, not mandatory, so far as intrastate trips were concerned, Attorney General John J. Bennett argued in a brief submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Nineteen, including several leading eligibles for the $50,000 Widener, were named today for tomorrow's running at Hialeah Park of the $10,000 McLennan Handicap, a memorial to the late Joe McLennan, whose son Charles succeeded him as racing secretary.

Approximately 1,500,000 blanks are going out by mail this week to State income taxpayers in New York without any provision for the proposed rate reduction the Legislature is likely to enact before the first deadline for payments April 15.

Tomorrow, the birthday of George Washington, pastors will preach sermons paying tribute to him in the light of the present war. One clergyman will discuss "If Washington Were Alive Today," another "Our Valley Forge," and another "If Washington Were Here Today."

Clark Shaughnessy has made a favorable impression on Yale's athletic authorities and the idea of coaching the football team at New Haven definitely appeals to the mentor whose success with the T-formation at Stanford won him nationwide fame.

For purposes of melodrama, James Edward Grant has casually supposed that a Nazi spy might impersonate the chief of staff in the British War Office and betray the defense of England. "Plan M" is what Mr. Grant calls it. It was acted at the Belasco last evening.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP) -"Eight A.M. sharp -- factory" now is the most important memo in the datebook of several Philadelphia debutantes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, who was made assistant lease-lend expediter in London by President Roosevelt in January, has been transferred to a new post as adviser to Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the War Shipping Administration.

Enactment of a municipal ordinance banning gasoline sales between 7 P.M. and 7 A.M. was requested yesterday by representatives of gasoline station operators at a conference with Albert H. Morgan, a Deputy Commissioner of Public Works and chairman of the Mayor's Committee for Petroleum Conservation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- An expansion in the service of the Chicago Stock Clearing Corporation designed to effect economies in time and expense for brokers was submitted formally today for adoption. The plan provides for a central delivery department for the settlement of all securities and money balances between clearing members.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 -- Cuba will establish a national bank of issue soon, according to an announcement from the Presidential Palace. Plans for the institution are complete and President Fulgencio Batista has ordered the work of organization to start immediately, the official communique said.

Sizable offerings by three localities will comprise next week more than 75 per cent of the $12,835,560 of new issues scheduled to be sold. The total compares with $17,590,061 this week and with a weekly average of $30,422,250 for the year to date.

LOUIS FISCHER'S "Dawn of Victory"* is one of the more thoughtful of the recent books on England and the war. Part factual reporting, part analysis and part social theory, it skips about in easy fashion, from the latest gag of Comedian Vic Oliver ("Bills, bills, more bills! Never did one man owe so much to so many!") to serious disquisitions on strategy, on Russia and on the shape of things to come.

Tomorrow evening "Under This Roof" will make its Broadway debut at the Windsor Theatre. Herbert B. Ehrmann, a Boston attorney, who studied playwriting as a student of the late Professor George Pierce Baker at Harvard, is the author.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 20 -- Prime Minister John Curtin today reported on the war situation to a secret joint session of both houses of Parliament, and he emphasized that national security regulations bound all members to complete secrecy and prohibited anyone except the Prime Minister to make a statement.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 20 -- After receiving a kiss on each cheek from Japanese Ambassador Baron Shu Tomii, Reich Ambassador Edmund von Thermann left for Germany tonight on board the Spanish ship Monte Gorbea.

Three weeks ago 14-year-old James Runde of 267 East 161st Street, the Bronx, was committed to the Berkshire Industrial School, Canaan, N.Y., for stealing an automobile. A week later the boy escaped and hitch-hiked back home.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 20 -- Mexico's west coast civil defense will be put entirely under control of and handled by the Federal Army, and highways are now being built subject to military authorization to guarantee possible military needs as well as lasting commercial values, according to a statement made yesterday from the Presidency.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- An easy undertone developed today in the wheat market. At no time were prices above the finish of the previous day. Buying by mills was absent and the few rallies that occurred were due to covering by shorts.

James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, which set up quarters on the second floor of City Hall last Wednesday, issued a statement yesterday asking public confidence in the civilian defense measures organized by Mayor La Guardia as local civilian defense director.

American ingenuity not only has turned coal tar into stockings, (as nylon) but, under war stimuli, has made diapers, blankets, bathmats, rugs and handkerchiefs out of wood pulp. These rayon goads, however, are not "ersatz" in the Nazi sense but products of high quality, saleable on their own merits and not merely as substitutes for the fibre siphoned from the retail market into war service.
BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Under the spur of warning by Senator Brown of Michigan that a single well-placed bomb could "paralyze" the movement of 90 per cent of our iron ore to steel-making centers, the long-projected additional lock for the strategic St. Mary's Falls Canal at Sault Ste. Marie emerged at a hearing before the House Defense Committee today as an urgent defense need.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20 -- There was little change last week in general business activity in the Pittsburgh district, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Production of iron and steel and coal was greater.

As Washington's Birthday falls on Sunday this year, all securities and commodity markets and all banks in the United States will be closed on Monday. Various livestock markets, however, will remain open. Canadian grain and securities markets will open as usual on Monday, as will the European and Latin-American markets.
The Budd Wheel Company declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a common share. Payments in 1941 were 20 cents in January, 25 cents in August and 60 cents in December.

In a special ceremony yesterday morning at Police Headquarters, Herbert W. Satterlee, president of the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York, presented $830 in cash and silver and bronze medals to twenty policemen, including a sergeant and one detective, for saving persons from drowning in New York Harbor.

Shep, a sable colored collie with white markings, shown by his owner, Richard R. Hadden of Jackson Heights, L.I., won the best in show award at Bloomingdale's eleventh annual pet dog exhibition yesterday.

The Town of New Harlem, which was founded in upper Manhattan in 1666 and was once called so dead that it was not even a ghost, received another temporary reincarnation in Supreme Court yesterday -- much to the astonishment of court attendants, who, never having heard of "New Harlem," put it down on the calendar as "Town of New Haven."

Retail trade continued active here this week. An increase of about 18 per cent in department store sales over the same week last year was estimated yesterday by store executives. Increased consumer interest in Spring apparel was evident.

A goodly portion of the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune in which these troubled times abound are squarely aimed at the harassed homemaker. Many of the things she needs to do her job well are getting hard to come by. Prices are going up.

Unlike a great many of my friends, I have not been a violent critic of Civilian Defense, but I am beginning not only to wonder but to worry. What do we intend to do if we are bombed? Are we to be bombed first, and then find out?

Several witnesses urged yesterday that the Old Colony Railroad be continued at the concluding hearing by Oliver E. Sweet, director of the Interstate Commerce Commission's bureau of finance, on the reorganization of the New York, Hew Haven Hartford Railroad.

I was shocked on examining Form 1040 to find that I could claim no deductions for my son, over 18, who is in college. I can take credit for contributions made to religious, charitable, literary and educational, scientific or prevention of cruelty to children or animals organizations.
Prime Minister Winston Churchill's reshuffling of his Cabinet, which took effect yesterday, represents a concession to the critics of Britain's war effectiveness.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Melvin Ott got his first real taste of managerial cares today when Harry Danning suddenly bobbed up with a sharp pain in his right side. Inasmuch as this seemed to be a recurrence of an ache that bothered the Giants' catcher last Summer, it caused deep concern.

George Washington may have really been a better democrat, with a small d, than is commonly stated. People may have failed to realize what a very small nation this was when George Washington took office, and what a very simple way of life was the early American Way.
Mrs. Edward F. Hutton, who was at Hampshire House, left yesterday to spend the week-end with her daughter, Miss Joan Metzger, a student at the Foxcroft School, Middleburg, Va.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 20 -- For failing to appear before their local draft boards for assignment to a camp for conscientious objectors, two Jehovah Witnesses were sentenced here today by Federal Judge John Paul to serve four years in a Federal penitentiary.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 20 -- At the close of the first day of the Intercollegiate Ski Union championships today at the eleventh annual Middlebury Winter carnival, Dartmouth led a field of ten colleges with 196.78 points in the slalom and downhill events.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 20 -Five Paterson Aldermen and one former member of the board were named in conspiracy indictments returned to Judge Joseph A. Delaney of Quarter Sessions Court today by the January term Passaic County grand jury.

The Journal of the Medical Society of the County of New York, official organ of the largest component unit of the American Medical Association, in a leading editorial of next week's issue, out today, strongly urges the removal of existing barriers against refugee physicians particularly now when, "as a result of the military requirements, the country is facing a shortage in medical men."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 20 -- Sudden enforcement of the government's new economic policy, despite the promise of Treasurer J.B. Chifley that measures limiting investment trading on stock exchanges would be introduced progressively over a considerable period of time, brought investment trading on the stock exchanges to a standstill today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Leaders of the House were puzzled today over how to give its members a chance to go on record directly on the Congressional pensions repealer which will be taken up Tuesday.
TOKYO, Feb. 20 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- An Imperial Headquarters communique said:

Alarmed by the increased sinkings of tankers along the Atlantic seaboard, marine underwriters here announced yesterday a further increase, in war-risk rates amounting to 50 per cent for shipments in tankers and tank barges. The increases were confined principally to such vessels, although in some instances rates on shipments by other vessels were also increased.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 20 -"There is a strong possibility that Japan may attack Siberia in a little more than a month from now," General He Ying-chin, Minister of War, said yesterday in an exclusive interview here. "The attack will doubtless synchronize with the new German offensive in Europe.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 (AP) -Chick Herbert of Battle Creek, Mich., celebrated his twenty-seventh birthday today by shooting 35, 34 -- 69 to set the pace in the first round of the $5,000 New Orleans open golf tournament, but Lloyd Mangrum of Oak Park, Ill., spoiled his party by tying him almost five hours later with a 36, 33 -- 69.

Camilla Wicks, who is a pretty, flaxen-haired lass of thirteen and a half, made her New York debut as a violinist at the Town Hall last night. She was born in California of Norwegian parents. At the ripe age of 9 she appeared as soloist with the Los Angeles Symphony Orchestra, and she has given many recitals in the West.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Goos, 13-year-old New York girl, gave a sensational performance in the free-style events tonight virtually to clinch the women's national junior figure-skating championship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The announcement by the North American Company that it had called off the sale of its holdings in the Union Electric Company of Missouri because unsteady market conditions made it impossible to proceed at this time with this step in the breaking up of its holdings ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission was received today with calm by SEC circles.

The cotton market lost ground again yesterday, with hedging operations and switching the principal features in moderately active trading. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 8 to 18 points.

{ Today's events: "Aida," 2 P./Vf., and "Siegfried," 7:45, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. Iv[.; Wanda Landowska, harpsichord, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Victory Concert, New York Public Library, 5; Chiaroscuro Jazz.Concert, Town Hall, 5:30; Helen Teschner Tas, vuolin, Town Hall, 8:30; Josef Wagner, piano, 370 Central Park West, 8:30.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 20 -- The Japanese, again extending their immense South Pacific offensive, invaded the Island of Bali today, and United Nations warships, planes and fighting men closed with the invaders in a supreme effort to cast them out of the beachheads thus gained almost at the very shores of Java.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- A State survey of Westchester County relief, which was begun a year ago after county supervisors had charged that "chiselers and floaters" were defrauding the taxpayers, was completed today when the State Department of Social Welfare filed here a report giving general approval of the county's administration of public assistance.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 20 -The Daily Telegraph of Sydney, in a front-page editorial today warning that the bombing of Darwin means that Japan has opened her offensive against Australia, declares "We will show that we can take it, too."

CHUNGKING, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Chinese troops in one of their most successful actions yet in defense of Burma have hurled back Japanese troops attempting to force a river west of Chieng Sen, a town in the northernmost tip of Thailand, a Chinese communique announced tonight.

TOKYO, Feb. 20 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Imperial Headquarters said today that Japanese Army and Navy forces had invaded the Portuguese part of Timor Island today to expel Australian and Netherland forces.

While little hope is held that ocean yacht racing this Summer will be possible, the Storm Trysail Club last night laid the foundation of a plan to maintain its race-a-year program. If the members can't go out into blue water, they'll try another course, it was decided.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Feb. 14 totaled 254,463,000 barrel, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented an increase of 2,097,000 barrels, comprising an increase of 2,374,000 barrels in domestic stocks, but a decline of 277,000 in foreign stocks.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Feb..21 (U.P.) -- Australian officials believed today that the Japanese air attacks on Darwin and the southeast coast of New Guinea were designed to block United Nations reinforcements to Java rather than pave the way for any immediate invasion of this continent.

The Reliable Metal Novelty Company, manufacturers of bathroom fixtures and accessories, leased the second floor in 19 West Twenty-sixth Street from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee of the William Waldorf Astor Estate.

Gerald E. Donovan has been elected vice president and director of the Schering Corporation of Bloomfield, N.J., and will be in charge of financial operations, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Donovan has been a vice president of the investment banking firm of Schroder Rockefeller Co., Inc., of New York.
