An old rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission, issued under authority of the Public Utility Company Act and aimed at maintaining "arm's-length bargaining" between a utility company and an underwriting firm was sustained by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday.

Brattleboro, pioneer ski center of Vermont, hummed with activity last night as the nation's foremost jumpers and cross-country exponents arrived for the annual national combined championships to be contested this week-end. Led by the Broomhall brothers, Wendy and Charley, who tried the eighteen-kilometer course yesterday, a crack field will go after the cross-country championship today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Roosevelt in a drastic move authorized the Secretary of War today to eject any or all citizens or aliens from designated military control areas.

RIOM, France, Feb. 20 -- The Vichy government's Supreme Court here, which is trying five men supposed to symbolize the past regime and responsibility for the disaster to French arms, held a session today devoted to forensic sword play and thrusts by the defense at the Procurator General, who represents the law of the people.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A rewritten war damage insurance bill of large scope was released for House consideration today by the Rules Committee.

The net income of the Erie Railroad in January after fixed and contingent charges provided by the new capitalization was $753,440, Robert E. Woodruff, president, said yesterday. It was the first full month of operation since the company emerged from bankruptcy.

Victor J. Herwitz, who, as assistant district attorney, was one of the principal investigators in the Rackets Bureau created by former District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, sent in his resignation last Saturday to Mr. Dewey's successor, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- A fierce but unsuccessful attack by German planes and E-boats -- small torpedo-carrying high-speed motor boats -on a British merchant-ship convoy in which two E-boats were sunk and "considerable damage" done to others and one plane was shot down and four others damaged was disclosed tonight by British naval and air officials.

KEARNY, N.J., Feb. 20 -- Described by Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commander of the Third Naval District, as symbolic of "the day of reckoning dawning for the enemies" of the United States, two destroyers were launched within eleven minutes of each other at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here this afternoon.

Chief Fallen Trees of the Mohawk Nation, who toils by day for our war program under the prosaic name of Paul Horn as an ironworker on the super-drydock at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, last night started a chieftain's war bonnet on its way to Joseph Stalin, recently voted by the chiefs of the Indian Confederation of America as the outstanding warrior of 1941.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- While the Japanese continued to hammer the lines of the American-Filipino defenders of the Bataan Peninsula in what a communique called "positional fighting," the War Department made available for the first time today material describing the manner in which the Japanese conduct their landing operations.

The Greater New York Red Cross War Fund had received $6,601,000 in contributions yesterday toward its goal of $7,330,000, Chairman Leon Fraser of the local drive told 500 volunteer workers at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 20 -- Desert dust swept over the hillocks and wadis south of the Gulf of Bomba yesterday, threatening to black out the scene of recent British and German skirmishing.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Recent tests in New Jersey and Ohio have shown that the flare of a single match lighted in a blacked-out area strikes the eyes of an airplane pilot at an elevation of 5,000 feet "like a powerful headlight beam," it was stated at Franklin Institute last night by Major R.P. Breckenridge, chairman of the engineer board at Fort Belvoir, Va., and camouflage expert of the War Department.

President Larry MacPhail bounced back into the Dodgers' offices yesterday and vowed he had abandoned his efforts to round up such recalcitrants as Whitlow Wyatt, Dixie Walker and Kirby Higbe, The Associated Press reported.

The Belgian "gray book," the official account of Belgium's preparation for war and of the German invasion in 1940, is now being distributed in this country through Didier Publishers. Georges Theunis, Ambassador at Large for the Belgium Government, explains that the narrative was compiled by the Government-in-Exile in London.

The smashing of a bootleg alcohol ring described by Treasury Department investigators as the biggest illicit liquor producing organization ever uncovered was announced here yesterday. The evasion of Federal taxes amounting to $3,429,500 was attributed to sixty-nine defendants named in an indictment obtained by Raymond Ickes, Assistant United States Attorney.

The pamphlet report of the Sun Oil Company mailed yesterday to stockholders shows current assets on the Dec. 31, 1941, balance sheet of $67,739,209 and current liabilities of $31,728,108, which compared with $33,326,164 and $12,690,067, respectively, at the end of 1940.

TRENTON, Feb. 20 -- Adjt. Gen. James I. Bowers and State Controller Homer C. Zink said today they would begin at once the two-way investigation ordered by Governor Charles Edison of food bills contracted last Summer for the "Little White House," the Executive cottage at Sea Girt.
ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The Board of Regents went on record in opposition to continuance of the 2 per cent decrease in State aid for schools, which has been in existence for the last three years.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 -Percy R. Pyne 2d entertained with cocktails today at Whitehall, having as guests Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks, Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Vanderbilt, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Waterbury, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Holmsen, Milton W. Holden, Henry P. Fletcher and Henry L. Pratt.
Business property sales were a feature of the Manhattan trading yesterday, when brokers announced deals involving structures in Greenwich Village, in the downtown area and on the upper West Side.
McCHORD FIELD, Wash., Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- An Army bomber crashed fifteen miles south of Tacoma today, killing two occupants and injuring three others.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Roosevelt has established a unified tactical command over American land, sea and air forces, well-informed sources said today.

The Secretary of Labor has certified to the War Labor Board a wage dispute between the towboat operator of New York and the United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association that has been pending since early in December.

"A Gentleman at Heart," which arrives at the Globe, will be this morning's only film newcomer. The Twentieth Century-Fox comedy adventure features Cesar Romero, Carole Landis and Milton Berle. J. Carrol Naish, Rose Hobart, Jerome Cowan, Richard Derr and Elisha Cook Jr. are among the picture's supporting players.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20 -- With income tax day, March 15, just around the corner, American taxpayers have a suggestion to make to their Treasury Department and to the great majority of their employers.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (UP) -- Rudolf Dunbar, Negro clarinetist, will conduct the London Philharmonic Orchestra April 26 in a concert to raise funds for persons of African descent fighting for the Allies, it was announced today.

Bella Reine, European "choreographic actress," made her New York debut last night in a recital in the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, assisted by Lydia Frankfurt at the piano. Her characterizations concerned themselves with varied Parisian types, couched sometimes in the styles of Renoir, Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Vigee-Lebrun, Millet, with cross-references to Goncourt and Lafontaine, and adding up to a generally familiar pattern.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- The German Navy, despite the loss of 130 submarines since the war started, has begun terrific "all or nothing" U-boat offensive in the Atlantic to divert American and British warships from the Pacific, The Evening Standard said today.
Hanson Baldwin, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 19, has put into words what many Americans have felt but could not so neatly define.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Stephen T. Early's statement today that "the oceans on each of our coastlines are no longer the saviors or the protection of the country they were said to be not so long ago," followed statements by both President Roosevelt and Secretary Stimson that attacks on American cities and towns were not unexpected.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies High Command issued this communique today:

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Germany has launched a major submarine offensive in the North Atlantic from the Azores to Greenland, to cooperate with Japan by keeping United States naval units in the Atlantic and preventing reinforcement of the United States Pacific Fleet, informed British sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- In a telegram to can manufacturers tonight, J.S. Knowlson, director of the division of industrial operations of the War Production Board, suspended until April 30 the restrictions placed on the manufacture of certain types of special product cans and non-essential cans.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Portugal and Britain are in close touch regarding Portuguese Timor, a Foreign Office spokesman said today, but no information is available beyond the Japanese communique announcing landings.

The Ways and Means Committee was fully justified in rejecting, the Administration proposal for special unemployment benefits to workers displaced by the conversion of factories to wartime production. The proposal was bad on several grounds.

The Right Rev. James Hutchison Cockburn, Moderator of the Church of Scotland, who arrived here by Clipper last week for a month's "preaching mission" in cities of this country, will preach tomorrow at 11 A.M. in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, and at 8 P.M. in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street.

Two of the three Negroes who were convicted last December in General Sessions of third-degree forgery in the sale of bogus tickets for the Negro excursion that resulted in a stampede and the killing of three women, were sentenced yesterday by Judge Saul S. Streit to Sing Sing terms of two and one-half to five years each.

If there were blots on the public records of Loen Blum and Edouard Daladier, former Premiers of the French Republic, they wiped them out by courage when they appeared on Thursday before the court of injustice now sitting at Riom. They did not whine or cringe. They did not apologize.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The British people today remained generally relieved as a result of the Cabinet changes announced yesterday and looked forward eagerly to further government changes said to be contemplated.

Criticism of the junior defense training program, initiated in the New York City school system this semester to give basic trade training to academic high school seniors to enable them to qualify for defense jobs, was levelled yesterday by the Advisory Board of Industrial Education.
Realty trading in New Jersey recorded yesterday was marked by sales involving four parcels in Union City by one broker to separate buyers.
Ray Robinson, Harlem's unbeaten contender for the world welterweight title, continued his march toward the championship last night in Madison Square Garden.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- One hundred clubwomen and civic leaders attended a meeting today in the Contemporary Club to decide what action, if any, should be taken in connection with fraternities and sororities in the White Plains High School.
BATAVIA, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- Both Bali and Sumatra are lost, observers conceded tonight, though resistance continued as Java girded itself for imminent onslaught.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 20 -Negotiations to transfer the Highland Manor School for Girls from this village, where it has been operated since 1920, to the estate Shadow Lawn, in West Long Branch, N.J., which was used by President Wilson as a Summer White House, were announced today by Dr. Eugene H. Lehman, owner and director of the school.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -Sixty thousand American-born Japanese on the West Coast, protected up to now by their United States citizenship, waited with misgivings tonight for specific instructions from military authorities, who were ordered by President Roosevelt to take over strategic areas and oust any unwanted residents, whether aliens or citizens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Philadelphia Electric Company, it was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, has applied for approval of the proposed private sale of 48,221 shares of its 4.4 per cent preferred stock, left over after a recent exchange offer.

The requests of foreign nations demanding that the United States use more forceful means to apprehend the large number of foreign seamen who have deserted their ships in American ports will not be heeded until representatives of the foreign nations reach some common agreement regarding minimum wages and better working conditions for the seamen, Marshall Dimick, special assistant to the Attorney General in charge of immigration and naturalization, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 --Because of the possibility that Germany might try eventually to seize Portugal's Atlantic "stepping stone" islands, the Azores and the Cape Verdes, the attitude of the Lisbon Government toward the landing of Japanese troops on the Portuguese part of the Southwestern Pacific island of Timor was regarded in Washington today as vitally important.

OTTAWA, Feb. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Estimates amounting to $454,884,000, covering all government costs except war expenditures for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1943, were introduced in the House of Commons today by Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Feb. 21 -- Through tangled masses of barbed wire, wrecked buildings and blasted pillboxes, Soviet troops from east of Kharkov early today completed their investiture of the Ukraine city's northeastern suburbs, according to an unconfirmed report from Moscow received here shortly after 2 o'clock this morning.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 20 -- Since the European war began two and a half years ago one country after another has closed its gates against clamoring immigrants and refugees desperately trying to leave their war-shattered lands and has allowed the merest trickle of harassed wanderers to enter.

Definitely spiking earlier reports of cancellation of Spring sports at Hanover, Dartmouth athletic representatives yesterday made known the Green's plans to go all out in a program designed to furnish as much competition and athletic development as possible for the duration of the war.

Men over 35 years old -- the present age limit beyond which Army recruiting officers may not go -- can enlist in the armed forces, however, through the Selective Service Administration, it was announced last evening by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, the city's draft director, in a radio interview broadcast by Station WNYC.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Differences between Treasury and Congressional tax authorities have narrowed down, in the main, to a question of a general sales tax or high but selected excise taxes.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The City's satisfaction with the Cabinet changes and the finding of an alternative to the Burma Road was reflected today in better markets at the opening of trading on the Stock Exchange, but many prices eased before the close.

Indians, guides, lumberjacks, animals, birds, boats, fishing tackle, fish mounted and alive, guns -- in short, just about everything you are likely to need and almost everything you will meet in the woods or on the stream -- will be gathered in one spot today, for the National Sportsmen's Show gets under way at noon.

An investing client of Kalmon Dolgin, Inc., brokers, has purchased from the Williamsburg Savings Bank the five-story factory and loft building known as 73 Stone Avenue and 100 Somers Street, Brooklyn, on a plot 100 by 115 feet. The structure is assessed for $100,000 and contains about 50,000 square feet of floor space.

The changes which Mr. Churchill has made in his Cabinet meet part way, but no more than part way, the demands of his critics in the House of Commons. These critics wanted a smaller Cabinet, with its members less bogged down by departmental duties; they wanted "new blood"; and they wanted Mr. Churchill himself either to resign the post of Minister of Defense or at least appoint a deputy.

An exhibition of "The Netherlands East Indies at War" came to the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the R.C.A. Building yesterday afternoon for an indefinite visit. Dr. N.A.C. Slotemaker de Bruine, director of the Netherlands Information Bureau, asked a preview audience to forget the possibility that the things portrayed could be lost to the enemy.

Taxes due on a return filed for 1941, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced yesterday, may be paid in full at the time of filing the return on or before March 16, 1942. Or the tax may, at the option of the taxpayer, be paid in four equal installments, the payment dates being March 16, June 15, Sept. 15 and Dec. 15.

Following use of its distribution facilities by the United States Department of Agriculture in its "Food for Freedom" program, the Meyer Both Company has offered its services to other government bureaus for similar purposes, Stanton M. Meyer, president of the company, said yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 19 (Delayed) -- The Rumanian Army is rapidly being converted into an integral part of the German machine with the installation of German officers noncommissioned officers, according to foreign intelligence reports just received in Ankara.
There is a mermaid in the Navy Receiving Barracks in Brooklyn. How she got there is a story that involves hundreds of sailors, eleven artists and the Citizens' Committee for the Army and Navy.
AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- All of the fifty-eight members of the crew of an Allied freighter, torpedoed in the Western Atlantic, have been rescued, it was revealed tonight.

As Mayor La Guardia continued his silence yesterday on the revolt among Queens air raid wardens against his continuance as city director of civilian defense, three of the wardens issued a statement saying their attempt to have Congress remove the Mayor from defense was undertaken to prevent a general breakdown of morale among the air raid wardens.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., FEB. 20 -Three Negro soldiers, who were attached to the 372d Infantry at Fort Dix, were sentenced to life terms in the State prison by Judge Frank A. Henderson in Burlington County Court of Oyer and Terminer this afternoon after a jury had convicted them of murdering Irvin Habas, 40 years old, a Trenton jewelry salesman, who was beaten fatally in a hold-up Dec. 3.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 -- Robert Howard Chipman, only native son of Brooklyn among the Dodgers, is going to stay with them until the 1942 campaign for another pennant is concluded.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Hope for a Chinese counter-offensive to gain air bases for United States planes within striking distance of Japan was voiced by informed quarters today as a result of the imminent visit of Major Gen. Joseph W. Stillwell on a mission for President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Representative Hamilton Fish of New York, angered by a question asked by William P. Maloney, special assistant to the Attorney General, shouted from the witness stand today that the government prosecutor had uttered "a lie."

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 20 -A late report from Lisbon tonight said that Premier Salazar had called an emergency session of the Council of National Defense. No indication of the subjects discussed was revealed in the dispatch, but a usually well-informed source here said that the meeting was examining the question of "a possible change in foreign policy."

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 20 -- Behind the bare, official statistics on air combat often lie fantastic stories of daring, courage and luck. It took all three to bring a South African pilot home safely after a Messerschmitt set fire to his fighter twelve miles off shore over the Mediterranean, it was revealed today.

Map dealers reported yesterday a heavy demand for maps following President Roosevelt's suggestion that those who listen to his Monday night broadcast have a globe or map of the world available for handy reference.

DES MOINES, Feb. 20 -- The United States plans to fight a war "in which we propose to conquer" and in which the fruits of victory will be made available to all the free peoples of the world, A.A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, said today in an address before the National Farm Institute.

The tenth anniversary of the Midtown Galleries, 605 Madison Avenue, will be celebrated with a loan exhibition of paintings and sculpture borrowed from museum and important collectors through out the country, opening on March 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- This has become the nation's most expensive city to live in, according to comparative living cost figures given out today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- Factory employment dropped 1.5 per cent from the middle of December to the middle of January, but payrolls increased 2.2 per cent, Frieda Miller, Industrial Commissioner, announced today in a summary covering reports from 2,325 representative manufacturing concerns employing 538,204 shop workers on a weekly payroll of $19,466,800.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -Major Gen. Carl Spaatz, commander of the Army's air combat forces, said today that the United States intended to win unquestioned aerial supremacy on all fronts and then wage "devastating warfare."

With the athletes becoming sharper and faster as the season progresses, a bumper record crop is expected to be harvested at the New York A.C. track and field games at Madison Square Garden tonight in the renewal of America's oldest indoor meet.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Bradford Chamber of Commerce reported today that British exports of woolens have attained pre-war levels. Up to the end of last November, said a trade survey for 1941 issued by the chamber, exports of woolen and worsted yarns and manufactures thereof totaled 50,250,000 square yards worth an equivalent of $110,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -Members of a Senate appropriations sub-committee said today that Robert P. Patterson Under-Secretary of War, "amazed" them with "a most encouraging" report on the rate of increase in the country's war production.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Roosevelt's radio report to the country Monday night will be designed to bring home to every American community and every American worker the effect on them of battles thousands of miles away and to demonstrate conclusively that the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans no longer save or protect us from enemy attack, it was announced today.

HONOLULU, Feb. 20 -- The Army today asked voluntary registration of males on Oaho from 18 to 60 years old to augment defenses in the event of an extreme emergency. The Army said "such positions might vary from truck driving to firing machine guns, depending upon the exigencies of the moment."

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 20 -Some indication of the prosecution's case at Riom when the question of the insufficiency of French armament comes up in the trial was received here tonight in a document issued by the official Vichy news agency, Havas-O.F.I., for the Vichy Ministry of Information.

Although there is a growing belief that Governor Lehman may wish to run again for Governor, upState friends of United States Senator James A. Mead have started a movement to get him the Democratic nomination, it was learned yesterday.

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, active leader of the All-India Congress party, said today the visit of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to India "will mark a new epoch in the relations of India and China."

I have read many articles extolling the many good features of Private Joe Louis Barrow. Joe really deserves all this praise and he manages to hold his usual composure under the strain of back-slappers and well-wishers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt resigned today from the Office of Civilian Defense, effective immediately. Her resignation was at once accepted by James M. Landis, Director of OCD, who is expected to announce appointment of her successor over the week-end.

PUEBLA, Mexico, Feb. 20 -- A new gravitational theory as an alternative to Einstein's, propounded by Professor George Birkhoff, head of the Department of Mathematics at Harvard, emerged from the Inter-American Astrophysical Congress here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Births in the United States last year were slightly more than 2,500,000, a figure exceeded only in 1921 when 2,600,000 births were recorded. At the same time the marriages reached an unprecedented total of 1,565,000.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Under the heading, "This Was Their Sacrifice," The Evening Standard published today the story of a destroyer that manoeuvred into the path of a U-boat's torpedo in order to save a troopship bringing hundreds of R.A.F. pilots, observers and navigators to Britain from Canada.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 20 -British Imperial troops fought on desperately today in their positions on the western shores of the Bilin River, in an area about eighty miles northeast of Rangoon and only fifty miles short of the Rangoon-Mandalay railroad leg of the Burma supply road to China.

Net sales of the Continental Can Company, Inc., rose $35,612,543 over the year before to the record volume of $136,652,016, J.F. Hartlieb, president, informed stockholders in the 1941 annual report issued for publication today.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique last night:

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- Japanese planes have unleashed a shattering bombardment against Burma's storied city of Mandalay, and a Japanese invasion fleet is lurking off the Burma coast, apparently for an attempt to outflank the British Imperial Army on the Bilin River line, it was reported today.
HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 20 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Finnish High Command communique said:

Elliot H. Simpson, American rubber buyer in the Far East, who recently arrived from Penang denouncing the British for their failure to notify Americans beforehand of the evacuation of that place, and also for their defense of the Malay Peninsula, expressed his regret yesterday at "certain statements made by me to the press in New York," adding that he made those statements when he was in a "physically and emotionally overwrought condition."

Special meetings of the stockholders of the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation and the Union Potash and Chemical Company, in which latter company International has a substantial interest, have been called for March 30, to approve a merger of the two companies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 20 -George Sanders will play Charles Strickland, who is regarded as a fictional counterpart of the French painter Gauguin, in the screen version of W. Somerset Maugham's novel, "Moon and Six Pence," which David Loew and Albert Lewin will produce for United Artists release, it was learned today.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The State Banking Department has received the agreement of merger of the Bowling Green Safe Deposit Company, 26 Broadway, New York, and the National City Safe Deposit Company into the latter name, the department's weekly bulletin announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Squadron Leader Brendan (Paddy) Finucane, the famous "Flying Irishman" of the Royal Air Force, suffered his first wound of the war today in a dog-fight over the English Channel during which a German Focke-Wulf was shot down, the Air Ministry announced.

In "Snow Hill" the authors have assembled nine youngsters as pupils at a farm school for boys and girls. Spike and Anne Kenyon, the two children of the household, are delighted with their parents' plan to turn their farm into a cooperative school, since it means playmates and companionship for them.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 21 -- Victories by three Williams College Winter sports teams today cheered alumni returning for the college's twelfth annual midwinter homecoming celebration. The hockey, basketball and swimming teams conquered M.I.T., Amherst and Brown, respectively, while the squash and fencing aggregations fell victims to Harvard and Dartmouth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey said in a press conference today that in his opinion there would have to be in the future some sort of governmental allotment of the country's man power.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today to permit the Electric Bond and Share Company to spend $2,000,000 in the market to purchase shares of its $5 and $6 preferred stocks, subject to certain restrictions.

New York University's sophomore sparked basketball team closed its home campaign last night with a 54-37 triumph over Lafayette College before 1,500 spectators at the University Heights gymnasium.

ON Jan. 21 and again on Feb. 8 THE NEW YOEK TIMES carried announcements of the awarding of the Dock Street Theatre's annual playwriting prize to Thomas C. Kennedy for his play "The Song of the Bridge." THE TIMES stated, too, on both occasions, that Mr. Kennedy had failed to pay his $2 entrance fee to the competition.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Washington's relations with Vichy have been based in great measure upon the hope of keeping the French fleet and French North Africa from falling into German hands. Serious concern, therefore, has been caused among officials here by the disclosure that the battleship Dunkerque had been transferred from Algeria to Toulon.

Sterling Products, Inc., reported yesterday it had in 1941 the largest sales and operating profits in its history. Sales amounted to $47,678,025, compared with $41,733,461 in 1940, an increase of 14.2 per cent. Profits from operations before United States and foreign income taxes, were $14,801,387, against $13,159,026 in 1940.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Scoring three goals within four minutes in the last period, the New York Rovers handed the Sea Gulls a costly 4-1 defeat in an Eastern Hockey League game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- When the government, as a result of the war, increased the population of the national capital by close to 50 per cent, it did not subsidize the building of apartments and cottages for the new workers. LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The Faraday Medal, offered by the Council of Electrical Engineers either for notable scientific or industrial achievement in electrical engineering or for conspicuous service in the advancement of electrical science, has beeen awarded to Dr. Peter Kapitza, noted Russian scientist and inventor, it was learned today.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The statement made by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in India fell on London tonight with the impact of an explosive, blasting open a situation that has been growing increasingly troubled since the war began and, perhaps, paving the way for British action that will go a long way toward appeasing an increasing clamor from India for a definite understanding regarding her post-war status.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 21 -- The Princeton swimming team gave Dartmouth a decisive 50-25 dunking in the Indians' pool today to gain an undisputed hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League and keep its unbeaten record intact.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Weekend travel to Atlantic City has increased since the first of the year, according to reports of hotel men. Many of the visitors, they point out, are defense workers and executives seeking relaxation from the steady hum of industries in near-by metropolitan areas.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Mrs. Rosa Rudami Fox of New York City has been named a supervisor of adult education in the State Department of Education, to work with the State foreign-born citizens and aliens of Italian origin.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 21 -- If the United States should make the sale of armaments to this country conditional upon Chile's declaring war against the Axis powers or breaking off relations with them, it would be interfering with the internal affairs of Chile, the Mercurio, one of the leading newspapers of the country, said today.

Red Cross "benefits" may be held only after they have been approved by the local Red Cross chapter or the national organization, Mrs. David Challinor, executive chairman of the women's division of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, said yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Promising surprises for Britain's enemies, Lieut. Col. J.T.C. Moore-Brabazon, Minister of Aircraft Production, tonight predicted that a four-engined bomber would play a vital part in the war. He implied that the program had been changed to put more of these in production.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 19 -- Motorists in Venezuela, who have been faced with severe restrictions in the sale of tires and tubes for the last two months, will soon be able to buy what they need as a result of an arrangement by the National Regulating Board to obtain 4,000 tires a month from Brazil.

Retail authorities here were fairly optimistic at the close of last week that the Office of Price Administration would recognize the principle of a time-lag between wholesale and retail price advances in any form of government price control that is put into effect.

Good news has come from Washington to City Engineer Joseph Lipset and other municipal fathers of Long Beach, L.I. The office in the nation's capital of Eric R. Greenleaf, secretary of the American Power Boat Association Racing Commission, has assigned to Long Beach the requested date of July 5 for its second annual inboard regatta, which will include on its schedule of events the New York State championships.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Displaying its most productive scoring attack of the season, Princeton's basketball team swamped Cornell, 58 -- 36, and strengthened its bid for third place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Creation of a fact-finding committee under the chairmanship of Miss Bertha Nienburg, assistant director of the Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor, is announced by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

EIGHT "Colis Postal" (Parcel Post) stamps come from France. In upper right on each is "FSN." The name of the issuing country is not mentioned. In the past the publishers of the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue have not given France's parcel-post paper recognition.

Senator Davis of Pennsylvania, whose term expires Jan. 3, 1945, seeks the Republican nomination for Governor. If he gets it and is elected he will serve for four years from Jan. 1, 1943. He was Secretary of Labor from 1921 till almost the end of 1930, when he went to the Senate.

Dr. Peter Odegard, aide to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., will be the principal speaker at the first regional luncheon of the Retail Advisory Committee to the United States Treasury on Wednesday in the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- In the first permanent price regulation to be issued under the Emergency Price Control Act of 1942, Leon Henderson will establish maximum prices for domestic shorn wool at prices prevailing Dec. 15, last, he announced today.

When it came to elections they once said: "As goes Maine so goes the nation," and as we stopped at the Maine sea and shore fisheries display at the Sportsmen's Show yesterday we found ourselves wishing that a similar remark could be applied to conservation.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chief of the War Shipping Administration, announced last week that H. Harris Robson, director of the division of emergency shipping, would serve as director general of shipping under the new administration. Other officials appointed are D.F. Houlihan, director of fiscal affairs, and William Radner, general counsel.

Companies that have accumulations of unpaid dividends due on their preferred shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange are clearing up their arrearages rapidly, according to the current issue of The Exchange, publication of the institution.
The following crew list of the torpedoed tanker Pan-Massachusetts was released yesterday by the National Bulk Carriers, the ship's owners:

Switching operations continued yesterday to feature quiet trading in the cotton market. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures moved within a nine- point range and finished with net gains of 2 to 4 points.

MAYBE some one can tell us, since we've never been able to figure it out, what point there is to fixing a fancy dedication on a film. For years they've been throwing them at us, these pompous and flowery forewords, which usually come after the credits and before the picture begins, expressing deep thanks and noble sentiments for that which we are about to receive.

CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- The Rangoon radio said today that Japanese forces in rubber jungle boats and utilizing rubber pontoon bridges were moving across the Bilin River, thirty miles east of the Sittang, in considerable numbers in order to reinforce the push toward the Rangoon-Mandalay railroad.

The spread of the war into the Netherlands Indies and to Burma, together with enemy submarine activity off the Atlantic coast and in the Caribbean Sea, has complicated further the oil supply problem of the United States as well as that of the United Nations.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Feb. 21 -- Faculty and students of Stephens College have combined research and classroom efforts in an "all-out" emphasis on the school's victory program.

License Commissioner Paul Moss reserved decision yesterday after a hearing on the question of renewing the license of the Gaiety Theater, a burlesque house at Broadway and Forty-seventh Street. The license expires tomorrow.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- if it had not been for the Santa Barbara Museum of Natural History, some of the most dramatic archaeological diggings along the California coast would have been sealed irrevocably beneath the new Santa Barbara Municipal Airport.

SOMETIMES the event has a character that would shame the press agent. In March Rene LeRoy, the flutist, with a chamber orchestra, will give the first American performance of a concerto for flute and strings by Jean-Marie Leclair, the eighteenth century dancer, violinist, and brilliantly gifted composer of his epoch.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 -- A picture of California aircraft plants "surrounded entirely" by Japanese-occupied land and of Japanese beginning recently farming operations on arid tracts adjacent to air bases "on which hardly a jackrabbit could be grown" was presented to the Tolan Congressional Committee today by Earl Warren, State Attorney General.

MEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 21 -- Dedicated to do its share in helping this nation "out-train the Axis," Tufts College has adopted an accelerated program affecting present and future students for the duration of the emergency, Vice President George S. Miller, dean of the arts and science faculties, announced today.

Latin America's foreign trade, which by the declaration of the Rio Conference and other official statements of policy the United States has undertaken to promote, will be seriously hampered if the New York Foreign Trade Zone and its facilities are discontinued, the new York Customs Brokers Association declared yesterday.

THEY are not doing much about it in the way of a celebration, but if you have a moment to spare this morning, the WOR people would call your attention to the fact that their station is twenty years old today. What, these columns wanted to know the other day, had been going on over there these two decades.?
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 21 -- Authorities of the Premier Vidkun Quisling regime are greatly perturbed by what they call the "Christian Front," the Swedish press reports.

LAST night I finished reading the proofs of these four plays. I had never read them before, nor, beyond the rehearsal period, have I ever seen them played through. I had, of course, read parts of the plays, once they had opened -- always the parts I liked.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Army athletes competed in seven different sports today, but the cadets could win only three contests.

PERHAPS the South breeds hatred and violence and madness more lushly than other parts of the country. Certainly it would seem so from the creative work that has come out of there within the past few years. William Faulkner, John Faulkner, Erskine Caldwell, Carson McCullers, Eudora Welty, to mention a few names that come quickly to mind, have made or enhanced their reputations by the portrayal of the dark or twisted side of life.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 -- A substantial majority of Irish-Americans polled throughout the country by the American Institute of Public Opinion believe that the Irish Free State government of Eamon de Valera should abandon its policy of neutrality and not only give the Allies the right to use naval bases along the Irish coast but openly join the Allied side by declaring war on Germany.

THE heartiest "Ole!" of which non-Hispanic lungs are capable is certainly in order for Argentinita, who celebrated her return to Broadway last week after an absence of more than a year with a rich and rousing performance.

WITH the late pianoforte etudes, Debussy signed his name with gusto and a tremendous flourish to a lifetime of achievement in the sphere of piano music. It is almost as if he decided to present us with a retrospective showing of his own work, to save later generations the sifting out and reassembling process that inevitably accompanies any evaluation of such a body of work as Debussy bequeathed to posterity.

A special entertainment will be given Tuesday night in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre under the auspices of the junior committee of the Navy Relief Society. The proceeds obtained will establish a fund to buy tickets for soldiers and sailors who wish to attend the benefit Navy Relief Show on March 10 at Madison Square Garden.

WITH THE A.E.F. IN NORTHERN IRELAND, Feb. 21 (AP) -- United States artillerymen began range firing today. The men, who have been studying British field guns, pronounced the famed British 25-pounder superior to their own weapon.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 21 -- The tenth anniversary of Dr. Robert C. Clothier in the presidency of Rutgers University was marked with the presentation of awards to Dr. Clothier at the fifth annual all-State dinner of the Rutgers University Alumni Association in Essex House here tonight.

THIS year The Publishers' Circular's usual census of book production has not yet appeared, but the lack is supplied by a survey in The Bookseller. It makes depressing reading. The effect of the war is shown by comparative statistics of the output of new books (including reprints and new editions) over a period of five years.

THE Treasury Department has ruled that the Defense Savings Stamps are not philatelic items, notwithstanding that they comprise a special series of postal savings stamps and are on sale at postoffices. On the basis of the decision, Hugh M. Clark, president of Scott Publications, Inc., announced last week that the stamps would not be chronicled in the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue and that no spaces for them would be provided in Scott albums.

FREEPORT, L.I., Feb. 21 -- Negotiations for a settlement of a strike of 225 machinists, polishers and moulders in the Columbian Bronze Corporation here were at a standstill today with production on Naval orders worth $1,000,000 running at less than 10 per cent of capacity.

DES MOINES, Feb. 21 -- Warning against the danger of inflation, Leon Henderson, in an address before the National Farm Institute today, opposed any general increase in wages and any increase in the price of farm products much above parity.

A supposedly weak Hudson College quintet from Jersey City gave St. Francis of Brooklyn quite a scare last night but the Terriers rallied to gain a 63-to-52 victory on their home court. After trailing in the first half, 28-29, St. Francis led by Jim Agoglia, who garnered 20 points, went on to victory.

What is known in radio circles as a "soap opera" is a serial that goes on and on and on until the public gets tired of it, which it seemingly never does. Hilda Glenn has written such a serial, thus restoring the family fortunes and enabling her to reopen the family Summer home in Havenhurst-on-Sound in Connecticut. It is there that the events in this story take place.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 -- With the pitchers going through another long session of hard throwing, plus plenty of even harder running in the outfield, Manager Mel Ott concluded the first week of Giant training today satisfied that his hurling corps is prepared to meet the onslaught of the second squad of hitters that is due to arrive over the week-end.

District Attorney Farrell M. Kane of Richmond County announced yesterday that the grand jury is investigating charges of immoral practices by former employes of the Bethlehem Orphan and Half Orphan Asylum at 375 Fingerboard Road, Fort Wadsworth, S.I.

JACQUES SINGER, conductor of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, has started a move to bring Dimitri Shostakovich, Russian composer, on a goodwill visit to this country. He has written to Secretary of State Cordell Hull suggesting an invitation and to Russian Ambassador Maxim Litvinoff asking approval.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 21 -- Returning to big-time ski racing for the first time in three years, 24-year-old Howard Chivers, former Dartmouth ace, demonstrated today that he still ranks high among North America's cross-country runners.

Helen Teschner Tas, violinist, was heard in her first recital of the season last night in Town Hall. The program was composed of Tartini's sonata in G minor, the Adagio in E major of Mozart, Bach's unaccompanied partita in E major, Beethoven's "Kreutzer" sonata and Ravel's "Tzigane."

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 21 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appealed to India today for "utmost exertion" in the cause of freedom, and urged Great Britain to give India immediately "real political power" to speed her war preparation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were nominally steady here today in the usual quiet week-end trade at levels slightly higher than a week ago, except for most cattle, due largely to the smaller number of animals shipped to market from farms. This reduction in supplies was particularly noticeable in hogs.

A securities salesman, who has been investigated frequently during the last eight years by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., was arrested yesterday on charges of swindling investors in New York and New Hampshire out of $60,000.

I am writing in answer to a letter which appeared in THE TIMES of Feb. 8 concerning the mispronunciations of the news announcers. It is true that practically all announcers and newscasters make occasional mistakes, but it is not true that nothing has been done to remedy the situation.

OVER the loudspeakers of the big aircraft carrier come the clang of a bell, the shrill of a boatswain's pipe and the order to flight quarters. Out of their staterooms come tumbling the pilots, helmets on, wearing their bright yellow lifejackets and gloves and in one hand carrying their flight boards.

The war in the Pacific has reached Java, heart and strategic center of that fabulously rich archipelago which is the Netherlands Indies, From Java the Dutch govern their widespread empire; in Java General Archibald Wavell directs the operations of the United Command.

A NOTEWORTHY volume, well printed and splendidly bound, is published by the Huntington Library of San Marino, Calif. "The Cattle on a Thousand Hills" ($3.50 ) is a book of the Old West; of the social and economic history of Southern California with its grazing ranches, its hectic frontier days, and the disturbing violence that reached n spectacular climax in the Gold Rush and the building of the cross-country railroad.

Annapolis on the quiet Severn River, cloaked in history and scenic beauty, now moves to the sharply quickened tempo of war. The gray halls and broad walks are alive with increasing numbers of young Americans who have "turned to" in this emergency to learn the things that the officer of a fighting ship must know.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- With about 340,000 new 1942 passenger automobiles to dole out to civilians this year, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, announced today the rationing regulations, which will go into effect March 2.

MONTEVIDEO, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- President Alfredo Baldomir, who today crushed a revolt against his strongly anti-Axis government and dissolved Congress, told the nation tonight that he acted only "when convinced that otherwise the republic would fall into * * * anarchy."
DOVER, N.J., Feb. 21 -- -Pledging an all-out push for victory, a committee of civilian workers at Picatinny Arsenal issued this proclamation today:

TORONTO, Feb. 21 -- Captain Syl Apps shot a goal with only 20 seconds remaining to give Toronto a 4-3 victory over Brooklyn's improving Americans in a rough National Hockey League contest at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight. The victory boosted the Leafs into a first-place tie with the idle New York Rangers and was their fifth straight.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- An appeal that if heeded would be likely to have a profound effect on its prospects of survival was made to the Orthodox Church of the Ukraine by the acting Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church, Sergius, Metropolitan of Moscow and Kolomna, in a pronouncement on Feb. 5 from Ulianovsk.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Charles Blum of the Norsemen Ski Club of New York won the slalom event of the twenty-first annual invitation skiing tournament of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds today on Mount Jo. The field raced in bitter cold, with a stiff wind sweeping the course.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday questioned nine Germans and five Italians, arrested in Manhattan and Brooklyn, in the current round-up of enemy aliens. They were interrogated in particular regarding contraband found in their possession, three revolvers, two pairs of binoculars, nine shortwave radio sets and ten cameras, as well as documents, the nature of which was withheld.

A collection of hand-made textiles and silverware, now being produced by a new cooperative industry in Peru to supply products formerly made in Europe, will go on display Tuesday at the Official Commercial Agency of Peruvian Industries at 220 Fifth Avenue.

The trouble is that too often, beyond washing it and. arranging it becomingly, they scarcely know how to care for the hair.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- In the opinion of many competent observers Britain this week avoided a greater threat to the victory of the United Nations than even that presented by the Japanese in the Far East or the couched German lion.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- A number of competitive ski events are claiming attention in the Pocono Mountain resorts both this week-end and next. Outstanding among them are the annual snow and ice carnival at Onawa Lodge, Mountainhome, Pa., and the annual Hale America Invitation Ski Meet at Buck Hill Falls, both taking place next week-end.

Hybrid teas are no longer the last word in rose excellence. Today there exists a new but different perfection in the form of cluster roses which are generally labeled Polyantha or Multiflora. Theirs is, indeed, a devious origin, but while both their past and their future classification concerns the botanists, it is their great beauty and ease of culture which is now proving more and more attractive to the average gardener.

The annual Children's Village Bundle Luncheon will be held Friday at Sherry's under the chairmanship of Mrs. Frederic W. Ecker. Prospective guests have been requested to bring packages of useful articles for resale at Everybody's Thrift Shop to raise funds for the support of the Village, a home and training school for underprivileged boys situated in Dobb's Ferry-on-Hudson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Orman W. Ewing, 53-year-old former member of the Democratic National Committee, was convicted today by a Federal court jury of the rape of a 20-year-old government worker from his home State of Utah.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 21 -- Already established in south Sumatra, the Japanese are now in a position through their landing on Bali to attack Java at both ends of this narrow, strategic stronghold of the United Nations.

HAVANA, Feb. 21 -- Perhaps nothing is more deceptive than the heavy hitting of a player in Spring training, but even allowing for the soft pitches served in batting practice, there is increasing evidence in the Dodger camp that Dixie Walker is threatened with serious competition.

Several debutantes of the season will launch tomorrow a debutantes' drive for funds for a bomb shelter for blind children, to be erected by the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind on the institution's grounds in Pelham Bay, the Bronx.

When things are going wrong it is comparatively easy to be a "Sunday morning quarterback." The trouble with most of us is that we offer criticism, but rarely is it constructive. CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 21 -- Although Axis forces are reported to be still concentrated around Mekili, with lesser units around El Gazala, British patrols met no serious opposition yesterday.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

MONTREAL, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Canadiens kept their play-off hopes in the National Hockey League alive tonight when they handed the Chicago Black Hawks a 5-3 defeat before a crowd of 8,556. The victory lifted Montreal to within a point of the Detroit Red Wings and the Brooklyn Americans, co-holders of fifth place in the standing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- While events of the past fortnight apparently have confused the picture of Congressional attitude and action toward the war effort, the fact is, paradoxically, they have brought it into sharper focus. The result should be more encouraging than discouraging, for it has made possible a better taking of stock.

With a number of women's groups lending the strength of their organizations, the Victory Book campaign for men in service is already reporting some quotas filled or exceeded. Among early summaries received at headquarters in the Empire State Building are those from Pennsylvania counties, fifteen of which are directed by leaders affiliated with the State Federation of Women's Clubs.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Feb. 22 -- There was a tone of expectancy in most reports from Moscow last night as the fighting continued to turn in favor of the Red Army, whose twenty-fourth anniversary is to be celebrated tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Rear Admiral Francis W. Rockwell, the senior naval officer fighting with General Douglas MacArthur in the Philippines, is a native of South Woodstock, Conn. He was born on July 28, 1886, and was appointed to the Naval Academy from Connecticut in 1904.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--A large-scale aluminum production plant in New York City is included in an expansion program nearing completion in the power branch of the War Production Board and scheduled for announcement soon.
Police Commissioner Valentine refused yesterday to answer any questions regarding the revolt among air raid wardens, which was reported last night to be spreading throughout the five boroughs.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 -- The members of the Inter-American Astrophysical Congress returned to Mexico City today, feeling that they had asked each other a lot of questions that might one day be answered.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 21 (AP) -- All top-seeded players, including the defending champion, Charles W. Brinton of Princeton University, won their opening-round singles matches today in the thirty-fourth national squash racquets championships.

FEWER desserts and more salads are scheduled to appear on White House menus for the duration. With the announcement of sugar rationing, the First Lady quickly declared that the President's household "will have exactly what every one else does."

MIAMI, Fla. -- The twenty-ninth annual Biscayne Bay Regatta, which will be run over courses in the bay Saturday and next Sunday is of particular interest not only because of its continuance in the war as one of America's oldest regattas but because it also inaugurates Florida's annual "grapevine circuit" of speedboat events.
With the judging of mixed breeds and a competition among trick dogs trained by owners, the eleventh annual pet dog show at Bloomingdale's closed yesterday.

Stimulated by shortages and delayed deliveries, the wholesale markets here were generally very active last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Units of the American Navy and bombing planes of the Army are actively collaborating with United Nations' forces endeavoring to stem the tide of the Japanese advance in the Netherland Indies and have sunk at least two enemy warships and damaged others, communiques of the Navy and War Departments released here today revealed.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 21 -- The Mexican Foreign Minister, Ezequiel Padilla, said today he did not believe that the Catholic clergy of Mexico were making propaganda in favor of the Axis. He added that the ideology of the Axis was in contradiction with that of the principles of Christianity.

LAREDO, Texas -- If you look for the most significant celebration of Washington's Birthday, 1942, you will find it not in the solemn ceremony at Mount Vernon, nor in the thirteen colonial States. The birthday party with which the general himself probably would be most gratified will be held some 2,000 miles, as the highway runs, from Washington, D.C., and partly in a foreign land.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 21 -- An inventor has odds of one thousand to between one and two in his favor that his patent will not be held invalid by the courts, it is revealed in a study made by Justice Evan A. Evans of the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

Lord Beaverbrook reported a few days ago that during 1941 Britain had received 2,134 planes from "abroad" (meaning the United States) and had exported 9,781 planes to all theatres of war, including Russia. For the same period Britain had received 200 tanks from "abroad" (a record of which "abroad" can hardly boast) and had exported 3,000 tanks.

A large out-patient department and a premature-baby unit, one of the few in the city, are features of the new $500,000 wing of St. Clare's Hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street, to be dedicated and blessed next Sunday by the Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York.

ELIZABETH CORBETT has a happy turn for writing entertainingly about the affairs -- everyday, business and romantic -- of people no longer in the first bloom of youth. In earlier books her well-known Mrs. Meigs was as lively and amusing in her elderly days as when she was a young woman bringing up her family with the help of Mr. Meigs.

UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Curling rinks from Detroit, Farmington, Conn., Utica and Mount Hope, N.Y., reached the semi-final round today in the Mitchell Medal competition, sponsored by the Grand National Curling Club of America.

An improved system of emergency medical aid in case of air raid or other war disaster was outlined yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia to 200 superintendents, chiefs of medical staffs and other executives of the eighty hospitals in the city.

With a recital in Town Hall devoted to Bach's "Goldberg" Variations, Wanda Landowska, the eminent harpsichordist, returned in triumph to the local concert stage after an absence of fourteen years. Greeted by a capacity audience eager to welcome her back and display its undiminished admiration of her art, Mme. Landowska was not long in proving that she still remained the world's leading exponent of the instrument of her choice.

RIOM, France, Feb. 21 -- The Supreme Court that is trying two former Premiers of France, a former Commander in Chief, two former Air Ministers -- one of them in absentia -- and a former Controller General of the army, was in adjournment today until Tuesday.
Miss Emily Custis Lewis Stevens, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Basil M. Stevens, and Mrs. R. Winston Reese have gone to the Chateau Frontenac in Quebec for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Major Gen. J.K. Herr, chief of cavalry and former star polo player, will retire on Feb. 28 upon his own application. He will have served in the Army more than forty-three years.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 21 -- Albert Speer, Reich Minister of Munitions, has begun his duties as Dr. Fritz Todt's successor by sending two war industry managers to concentration camps on charges of having used a few of the workers for repair jobs in their private homes, according to word received her today from Berlin.

IN their Russian retreat the Germans have left behind them not only the wreckage of machinery and men but also the reputation for cruelty and inhumanity, The cold apparently not only pierced the inadequate uniforms of the troops but also got at their morale.

"LADIES and gentlemen, the President of the United States!" Behind that familiar phrase usually lies about a week or more of preparation by more than half of the country's broadcasters. Tomorrow Mr. Roosevelt will speak over the radio for the 243d time since he took office in the White House.

After years of shouting for a united front in the securities industry, Wall Street finally has achieved one. The battle line is hardly that which financial leaders thought they were going to defend -- Washington seems to be an ally rather than an enemy -- but cooperation is smooth and cordial and is making for progress.
Michael Calabrese, a cab driver who earns $25 a week, cheerfully donated $4 to the Red Cross yesterday a few minutes after he had received it from the police property clerk.

In the nation-wide war effort raising more vegetables is uppermost in every suburban gardener's mind and even city gardeners are longingly surveying their back yards and terraces. "Couldn't we also join in and produce our own carrots, spinach and beans?" they ask.

The "death sentence" program of the Securities and Exchange Commission against the public utility holding company industry was thrown into bold relief last week when the nation's second largest holding concern, the $1,000,000,000 North American Company, was forced to abandon its program for the sale of the Union Electric Company of Missouri in compliance with the integration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
TRENTON, Feb. 21 -- Stephen H. Barlow of Trenton, quartermaster general of New Jersey, was summarily removed today as procurement officer of this State for selective service.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 21 -- An official announcement of the Quisling authorities that for every Quisling carried off by the British during their raids ten Norwegian patriots would be taken as hostages has provoked considerable nervousness among the Norwegian population, it is reported tonight.

The 210th anniversary today of the birth of George Washington, first President of the United States, will be celebrated today and tomorrow with patriotic exercises, religious services and other gatherings. Because of the country's entrance into the war a heightened fervor in the observation is expected, with speakers citing the spiritual fortitude of Washington at Valley Forge as an example.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Cornell University will pioneer next June in the establishment of a Summer Workshop for the development of instructional aids for teachers in grade and high schools seeking to impart knowledge in the highly important and comparatively undeveloped fields of the British Commonwealth of Nations, Latin America and the Far East.

I am a theatre man and I would like to voice my opinion on the subject of Congress's refusal to pay Walt Disney for his cartoon "The New Spirit," which Disney made for the Treasury Department at the request of the Secretary of the Treasury.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Four new destroyers, it was announced, will be named for naval officers who have lost their lives in the present World War.

TRADE reports of the week told of a further subsiding of the hoarding movement among consumers, and retail sales have resumed a more normal trend. The effect of the recent hoarding, as well as of the boom in home furnishings, appliances hosiery last year will be to reduce future purchases, it is agreed, although the rise in purchasing power may offset any such "borrowing from the future."

DIRT EATERS -- Dirt eating or clay eating may be a sign of diet deficiency, not mental disease, it is revealed by a survey of school children in Oktibbeha County, Miss., made by Drs. Dorothy Dickins and Robert N. Ford (Mississippi State College).

Miss Helene Rains, the national 300-yard medley champion, won three events for New York University's co-ed swimming team yesterday for the second time in as many meets this season, but the best her mates could do was to gain a 26-26 tie with Penn Hall Junior College at the Spence Natatorial Institute.
On seeing the Ravel sonata for violin and piano programmed by Szigeti in his Carnegie Hall recital on Feb. 25, it brought back some very vivid memories of its performance by Szigeti in Vienna.
The Maritime Commission has notified the National Maritime Union that American seagoing vessels are being armed and given other protective equipment at a rate twice that of a few weeks ago.

A show-stealing quarter-mile performance by Ed Sause of Bayonne Senior High School highlighted the combined Stuyvesant-Manual indoor interscholastic track and field meet at the Bronx Coliseum yesterday. A gathering of 3,000 watched Sause, New Jersey outdoor furlong kingpin, turn in an impressive clocking of 0:50.4 to win the senior 440-yard run.

ACOUPLE of weeks back the RKO studio press department in Hollywood matter-of-factly announced the purchase of "Bundles for Freedom," a screen story by a chap named Milton Holmes as a vehicle for Cary Grant.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Mrs. Jane Vaughn Sullivan of Philadelphia tonight retained her women's senior national figure skating championship while Bobby Specht of Chicago was being crowned the new titleholder in the men's senior division.

IT is apparent that sight-seeing is not confined to the layman, since late figures show that the men in uniform are visiting our national parks by the thousands. Nor are these government preserves the only outlet for the enterprising soldier intent on getting better acquainted with his country.

AN idyll of a small Iowa town round about the turn of the century, "New Hope" is Miss Suckow's first novel since her most substantial book, "The Folks," which was published over seven years ago. In the interval, her approach has altered little, except that the mood of her new story is very definitely nostalgic -- and might even be considered escapist.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 21 -- Three Australian airmen described today how they were shot down, swam twenty-five miles through the Timor Sea with the aid of gasoline tins and finally reached land after fighting off three attacks by sharks.

Mayor La Guardia refused yesterday to discuss the case of Magistrate Alex Pisciotta, former director of the Bureau of Weights and Measures in the Market Department, who recently was called into active service in the Army after serving only seven days on the bench.

In keeping with the spirit of the Good Neighbor policy, a record number of South American scholars and students are studying in American educational institutions this year. As never before, a powerful cultural program has been established that is expected to draw the people of both continents closer together.

PRIVATE flying will never be the same after this war. And lest any one think this department is about to hang a crape, we hastily add that it will be a lot better. Thanks to the Civilian Pilot Training Program, a variety of good and not-too-expensive light planes, and several other important factors, private flying was growing to man-sized proportions before the war started in Europe.

SALINAS, Calif., Feb. 21 -- Japanese farmers in the Salinas Valley, which produces 57 per cent of the lettuce and a third of the carrots for the vegetable markets of the country, are surrendering their leases on many tracts of rich land in the face of a growing antagonism to them as potential fifth columnists.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 -- With a surge of power few suspected he had in store because of his recent injuries, Market Wise today won the $15,125 McLennan Memorial Handicap by half a length and catapulted himself into the thick of things for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup two weeks hence.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 21 -- Miss Beatrice Whitney Straight, a Shakespearean actress, and Louis Dolivet, Free French leader, of New York, were married by District Judge Frank S. Shankland in the Polk County Courthouse here this morning.

FROM Mr. E. Phillips Oppenheim's book of genial reminiscences you would scarcely gather that in the course of his seventy-five years, a long life-time though it is, he could have written a hundred and fifty books and more.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Judge Samuel I. Rosenman of the New York Supreme court has found that sixteen Federal agencies handling various aspects of housing could be coordinated into a single unit for greater efficiency.

"Sea power in this as in previous wars, is decisive," Lord Rotherwick, President of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom, said in an article printed in the Jan. 14 issue of the London Shipping World. "Ships and men at sea, shipbuilders and repairers, and all who are concerned with the operation and service of ships are the stepping stones to victory," he added.
TWO dinners were served next door to each other a few nights ago in one of those blocks where, with New York's dramatic contrasts, a great, luxurious apartment towers over a cold-water flat.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 21 -- The Melbourne Herald's Darwin correspondent said today that when the alarm sounded he was at the postoffice so he tried to write an urgent telegram but that fragments of the first bombs falling round the waterfront knocked the pen from hid hand.

VICTOR BORGE, radio's newest comedy find, who gives vent to his unique type of humor every Thursday night in Bing Crosby's Music Hall, would seem to give the lie to those skeptics who always are saying there is nothing new in comedy.

ANTI-AXIS: Uruguay's President, Alfredo Baldomir, has been known as a friend of the United States and a proponent of continental solidarity against the Axis. Yesterday he took swift moves to thwart a bid for power by Senator Luis Alberto Herrera, a leading Uruguayan foe of inter-American cooperation.

While obtaining enough raw material to stay in busines and allocating available supplies to old customers are the major problems for many companies, personnel and management questions are still important in the minds of sales managers, a survey by the American Management Association, in preparation for its marketing conference to be held here on March 4 and 5, revealed last week.

At his concert at Carnegie Hall this week Joseph Szigeti will play, from manuscript, the Fourth sonata for violin and piano of Charles Ives, the American composer, of whom it has been said that he has been written about more often than his music was played.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 21 -- As Brazil today evinced a sharper realization that the war was coming nearer, General Azumbuja Villanova charged that Germany was using French bases in the Caribbean Sea with the consent of Vichy.
ANNAPOLTS, Md., Feb. 21 -The Naval Academy basketball team broke its two-game losing streak today by defeating the University of North Carolina, 42 to 39, in an overtime contest.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) -- We went through three hours of hell out there and twenty fine men are dead in the sea, but I saw some real heroes on a rescue ship. I'm going back to the sea, as quickly as I can, out of respect for those who died and those who risked death to save us.

AN EASTERN CITY IN THE UNITED STATES, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Preconceived plans of tooling and production were scrapped by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation when it started construction of the Army's new cargo plane and, as a result, the company said today, the transports are being produced ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The National War Labor Board in a unanimous decision today denied a wage increase of $1 a day and a union shop to employes of the Phelps Dodge Corporation's Douglas Smelter Division, at Douglas, Ariz.

GRANT WOOD, who died this month, may have been "the most celebrated white hope of 100 per cent Americanism in art," as the critics said. At any rate, it was in the very citadel of such Americanism that he sought and found his inspiration. For Iowa is the heart of America. Ask any Iowan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- American prisoners interned in Japan are receiving good treatment and are making requests only for more tobacco and toilet articles, according to information sent to the American Red Cross by the International Red Cross in Geneva and made public here today by Chairman Norman H. Davis.

Intensive study of newspapers can be "1,000 per cent more valuable than the use of regular textbooks in the teaching of English," according to Miss Geraldine Saltzberg, chairman of the English department of James Monroe High School, the Bronx, where a one-week experiment which substituted daily copies of THE NEW YORK TIMES for spelling, grammar and literature texts has just been completed.

With the total of signed athletes raised to sixteen by two signature yesterday, the Yankees officially opened their new baseball season by dispatching a cargo of non-combatants to St. Petersburg from frigid New York on the Orange Blossom Special.

IN the Radio Section of this morning's TIMES Miss Erika Mann protests against the inclusion of the work of "enemy alien" musicians on our radio programs. Richard Strauss and Walter Gieseking, she says, have "put their genius at the disposal of the enemy of mankind" and consequently must be banned.

Our government is urging the farmers to increase production this year to the limit of their capacity. At the same time the Department of Agriculture has stated that there is a tremendous shortage of farm labor, due to better-paid jobs in defense industries.

During March there will be two events of genuine interest to the astronomer and layman alike. The first is a total eclipse of the moon, scheduled to occur on Monday, the 2d. Although the beginning of the eclipse will take place before moonrise in New York, we will have opportunity to see the better part of it.

The Maritime Commission exceeded all previous records for ship orders in the month of January and took a long step forward toward its goal of two ships a day for 1942 and three a day in 1943, according to figures published in the February Bulletin of the American Bureau of Shipping, the official classification society of this country.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 20 (Delayed) -- Seven and a half days after we had left Singapore's flaming waterfront we -fifty-five men and a plucky Chinese girl -- reached safety at Batavia.

The responsibilities of a liberal arts college in a camp locality are being realized and met in Spartanburg, S.C., home of Camp Croft, one of the four infantry replacement centers in the United States, and in Converse College, a liberal arts college for women.

TO bring many points in Wisconsin and upper Michigan closer to Chicago, the Chicago Northwestern has placed in service a new $3,500,000 fleet of "400" streamliners. They are the Capitol 400 to Madison, the Shoreland 400 to Green Bay, the Valley 400 from Green Bay, the Peninsula 400 to Ishpeming, the Commuter 400 and the City of Milwaukee 400 to Milwaukee.

AMONG the most valuable tools in wartime are the technical books -- the volumes concerned with such matters as how to maintain an airplane engine, how to make engineering drawings, the purification of water, the making of surveys and the drawing of maps, how best to preserve and transport large quantities of food, the rules for stowage of cargoes, and a thousand other subjects.

Andre Mathieu, French-Canadian pianist and composer, continues to be an astonishing boy. He played at the Young People's Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning and, though it was revealed that he was almost 11 instead of 9 years old when he first appeared here, he is still only 13 and by all counts his concertino, which he played yesterday, is a remarkable work for a boy of that age.

A total of $1,526,900 in cash and pledges, or 96 per cent of quota, has been raised by the commerce section of the commerce and industry division of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, Colby M. Chester, chairman of the division, announced yesterday.

BANDUNG, Java., Sunday, Feb. 22 -- United States and Netherland sea and air forces, according to announcement today, have inflicted probably the most punishing blow of the war at Japanese invasion forces off both ends of Java, sinking or damaging at least nineteen and possibly many more enemy warships and transports.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 21 -Within a single year the Remington Arms Company, Inc., expects to turn out more small arms ammunition -- indispensable to infantrymen and machine-gunners -than was produced by all manufacturers in the United States throughout the four years of the World War, it was revealed yesterday in the company's annual report to its stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received until 9:30 A.M., said:

AS historians and other interested persons have communicated with me relative to the letter of Mr. Howard R. Peckham in your issue of Dec. 21, 1941, it is necessary that I present the following facts in reply.

Tomorrow marks the twenty-fourth birthday of the Red Army which has exploded the myth of the Wehrmacht's invincibility. On Feb. 23, 1918, Nikolai Lenin summoned the citizen's of the new Russian State to wage guerrilla warfare against the Soldiers of Hohenzollern Germany.

THE Office of Civilian Defense should devise some plan to protect the common or garden variety of householder and ratepayer from the verbal barrages of furious basketball fans. The rabid followers of that bouncing game abound in crowded cities. "Nomen est legio!" to quote Wamba, the son of Witless, the son of an Alderman. Their name is legion and, unfortunately, each one of them is heartily fluent on his favorite topic.
