2, staff of fifty women volun-{ i teers headed by 1V[rs. Robert C. {Rand, completed yesterday the mailing of more than 20,000 invii rations to attend the Navy League. ! !Norway war relief benefit ice carnival on farch 3 at the Centeri Theatre.

In ascertaining the amount of net income subject to the excess profits tax credit is allowed for the average earnings of the base period years. The usual process is called the general average method [Section 713 (e) of the Internal Revenue Code].

The American movie-going public has been receiving a shock in the past two weeks which neither the script writers nor producers had counted on. It is time, however, that they count on it, if we are to win this war.

GEORGE WASHINGTON was, after all, as human as any one that ever has the toothache. What did he look like in real life? Taller than most, he stood six-feet-three in his prime and weighed 220 pounds. He was light-complexioned and florid.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- Darcy Curwen starred as Harvard defeated Pennsylvania in an Eastern Intercollegiate League swimming meet today, 40 -- 35. Curwen took the 220-yard free-style and the 200-yard breast-stroke events.

OUT of the first 2,000,000 young men who walked up to selective service and Army induction boards for examination, 900,000 walked away rejected for military service because of disease or physical defects. To thousands of these men their rejection was a surprise. To millions of people throughout the country, the 45 per cent rejection rate was a shock.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 21 -- An extraordinary session of the Portuguese National Assembly, convened by Premier Antonio de Salazar Oliveira this afternoon to hear a government report on the situation brought about by the Japanese invasion of the Pacific island of Timor, approved a resolution of condemnation of Japan's action in the following terms:

Carpet manufacturers last week challenged a report that the industry could not possibly use more than 15 per cent of its weaving capacity for the manufacture of duck if called upon to do so by the government. While no definite estimate had yet been worked out, it was generally believed that a much larger percentage could be used if necessary.

CORRESPONDENCE received from England by Charles H. Hall, president of Charles Hall, Inc., New York importers, shows that sending stamp collections to children evacuated from London and other cities to various parts of the British Isles has become a war activity of England men and women in many parts of the world.

PALiV[ BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21Mrs. James Norman Hill was a dinner hostess tonight at the Patio to Mr. and lIrs. 1. Worthington Hine, Mr. and Mrs. John McVickar, Mr. and Mrs. A. Parker Bryant, Mrs. J. Nevett Steele, Mrs. Anne Frelinghuysen, Francis Potter and Samuel R. Winslow.

Firmness in the last half-hour on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday lifted prices out of their rut and brought an active close and slight gains on the day. Trading aggregated 213,990 shares of 500 issues, of which 179 rose, 174 fell and 147 were unchanged.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- London was emphatic tonight in expressing skepticism about a Stockholm report that three powerful German warships, the von Tirpitz, Admiral Scheer and Admiral Hipper, were proceeding northward along the coast of Norway.
The strategic picture in the Southwestern Pacific remained dark with the somber clouds of defeat last week as the fall of Singapore led to new reverses.

A plan whereby members of the Fire Department will contribute $247,200 annually toward the purchase of United States defense bonds was disclosed yesterday in the department's daily orders, over the signature of Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 21 -- President Alfredo Baldomir dissolved Congress at 5 o'clock this morning and sent troops to all strategic points in Montevideo.

Picking up an exploded oil heater that was in flames and beginning to char the doorjamb and wall near it, and carrying it into the backyard although the flames burned him painfully, George Miller, 17 years old, of 156-46 115th Street, South Aqueduct, Queens, prevented a fire in his house yesterday morning that would have endangered it and adjoining bungalows because of the high wind.

Bundles for Britain and Bundles for America will share in the proceeds from a production of the operetta "Norwegian Nights," which will be presented under the joint sponsorship of the Nightingale-Bamford and Collegiate Schools, next Friday evening and Saturday afternoon at the Finch Theatre, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street.

Mayor La Guardia has received a highly important report from David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America and chairman of the Technical Communications Group for the City of New York, recently organized by Mr. Sarnoff at the request of the Mayor to study the problems of communications, including air raid warning signals and blackouts and to make a report to the Mayor on its studies and recommendations.

WHEN the British Broadcasting Company scout found Frank in the Seamen's Home in Liverpool he had found an extremely stirred-up British merchant seaman who had had some strong tastes of the war at sea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- The present war-guilt trials of former French leaders at Riom were compared tonight to the Nazi Reichstag fire trial by Pierre Cot, former French Air Minister, who barely escaped being a defendant in the courtroom.

A benefit luncheon and fashion show will be held March 10 at Hampshire House, under the auspices of the Social Service Auxiliary to City Hospital on Welfare Island. Mrs. Sherman Post Haight is chairman of the arrangements committee.

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Suit volume increased and fair demand was reported for coats and dresses.

THE annual Eastern championships begin Saturday afternoon at the Park Central Hotel. They will last through Sunday, March 8. The opening event will be the principal contest on the schedule, the open-pair tournament for the Julian Goldman Trophy.

Men in the United States Army and Navy whose hobby is art are being invited by the Society of Independent Artists to be its guests both as exhibitors and visitors at its twenty-sixth annual exhibition, to be opened on April 8 at the Fine Arts Society Galleries, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- March is the peak month of the season here, and many prominent sports events are scheduled. Headlining the program is the fortieth annual United North and South open golf championship, on March 24, 25 and 26, consisting of seventy-two holes of medal play.

Management executives, aware that the success of the battle for production of war materials depends almost entirely on the man behind the machine, are keeping an attentive eye on the American worker. Profiting by experience gained in the last war, a substantial segment of industry is taking steps to prevent a sag in employe morale.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 21 -- Dartmouth finished with a 2-point margin over New Hampshire to win the Intercollegiate Ski Union championship today at the 11th annual Middlebury College Winter Carnival. The Big Green's total for the two-day meet was 585.6 points.

A detailed information bulletin describing the best ways for a college to serve the country's defense interests has been prepared by the youth division of the Office of Civilian Defense. Local colleges, it was announced, will discuss their own problems of furthering defense efforts at a conference next Saturday at the Hotel Commodore.

Here we have a girl detective (amateur) who is invariably just a step behind the police. She is Janet Keith, daughter of a San Francisco tycoon who disapproves of her ambitions and her associates. Janet wants to be a writer, and she has actually sold a few short stories.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 21 -- Yale University's swimming team turned in one of the most thrilling triumphs in collegiate tank history tonight when it crushed Michigan, 59 to 16, in what had been billed as the world championship dual meet of the year.

A forum devoted to discussions of mobilizing civilians for war and united efforts for winning the peace will be held on Tuesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the Brooklyn section of the National Council of Jewish Women. This is the sixth annual session on world affairs sponsored by the section, in which a number of civic, educational and religious groups are cooperating.
Another round in the long-drawn-out controversy between the Federal Communications Commission and the major radio broadcasting chains ended yesterday in what appeared to be a victory for the FCC.

UNIVERSAL is fighting a losing battle with tradition in producing the fourth screen version of that cinematic institution, "The Spoilers," which has gone before the cameras with John Wayne and Marlene Dietrich as the protagonists and Randolph Scott and Margaret Lindsay as the antagonists.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 21 -- Lloyd Mangrum of Oak Park, Ill., led the field today at the halfway point of the $5,000 New Orleans open golf tournament, but a former national open champion, Lawson Little of San Francisco, shot the best round of the tournament, a five-under-par 33, 34 -- 67, to move up a stroke behind him in a second-place tie with Sam Snead.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 21 -- A rejuvenated Harvard five, using a new style of defense, defeated Columbia, 71 to 54, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game in the Harvard gym tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- For the first time since 1938, Pennsylvania defeated Dartmouth in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game at the Palestra tonight, 52 -- 49, before a cheering crowd of 4,500. Dartmouth remained deadlocked with Cornell for the lead as Princeton upset the Ithacans.
PHILADELPHIA -- Independence Hall, the grand old shrine of freedom, birthplace of the American nation, its flag and its Constitution, is fortified for the duration. More guards have been added.

THE amateur photographer is in a better position to make his hobby pay for itself than the follower of almost every other popular hobby. For aside from such business-like chores as developing the neighbors' films and selling local merchants enlargements of their storefronts, the photographer can offer his work to the many markets which cannot be serviced by professionals on a paying basis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Discovery of George E. Deatherage, former head of the alleged fascist Knights of the White Camellia and the American Nationalist Confederation, as chief engineer for private contractors on a $30,000,000 expansion project at the Norfolk Naval Base prompted guarded action in two quarters today.

HERE is a Western book for the general reader who wants to feel the lift and enthusiasm of America's sunward migrations. It is not a book for the student who is hungry for new facts. The facts of trail locations, names, dates and numbers are necessarily elementary.

Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their excellent little company have put together another bang-up program for their repertory season at their Studio Theatre in West Sixteenth Street and gave it a spirited performance last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A shortage of ships was reported today to be the principal obstacle to delivering much needed war supplies to the far-away battlefronts of the United Nations.

THE twenty new shows this reviewer visited last week divided numerically into ten that might have been roughly classified as academic or traditional in the main and ten that might loosely be called primarily modern.

One hundred and fifty veterans of the wireless key met last night at the seventeenth annual dinner and "cruise" of the Veteran Wireless Operators Association at the Hotel Astor and awarded a number of medals and citations of honor to those who in the last year had won distinction in the field of radio communication.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 21 -Dartmouth's hockey team defeated Harvard by 9 to 5 tonight at the Boston Skating Club rink. The victory was the sixteenth of the season and the fifth straight in Pentagonal League competition, virtually clinching the crown for the Big Green.

The citizens of Cherokee, way out yonder where men tote guns, are all in a dither because of a series of murders and other outrages all bearing the sign of a red triangle. No progress whatever is made toward solving the mystery until Hashknife Hartley happens along accompanied by his partner, Sleepy Stevens, who is not too sleepy to handle a gun effectively when occasion arises, as it frequently does.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Battle of Bataan was marked today by the growing extent of Japanese assaults upon General Douglas MacArthur's positions in the Philippine area, the War Department reported.

Quentin Reynolds, foreign correspondent, will be the guest of honor at a testimonial supper to be given on March 7 at the Hotel Roosevelt under the auspices of the British and American Ambulance Corps. The proceeds will be used to buy ambulances for the American and British fighting forces, according to William V.C. Ruxton, president of the joint corps.

The mood on Washington's Capitol Hill last week was uncertain and tense. Tempers were short. A bitterness, absent since the attack on Pearl Harbor, crept into debates. Congressmen, worn by accumulating war legislation and weary from months of uninterrupted sessions, were betraying the first signs of concern over the coming elections. Some struggled with the problem of mending political fences in a rapidly shifting emergency.

GENEVA, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Slow-motion picture analysis of the body mechanics of each freshman girl at William Smith College has brought home so dramatically some defects and shortcomings conspicuous to others that a program of specialized exercises to develop better poise, carriage and movement is now enthusiastically accepted where before it had simply been tolerated.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A communique issued by the headquarters of the Allied Southwest Pacific Command said:

Retriever field trial organizations plan to carry on during the Spring and Autumn months. This applies equally to the East and the Middle West, the latter sections having made great strides in the recent past.
For a while yesterday the thousands who visited the National Sportsmen's Show at Grand Central Palace were able to leave care behind and concentrate on thoughts of recreation and vacation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the United Corporation had filed under the Holding Company Act a declaration regarding the proposed reduction of the stated value of 2,488,712 shares of outstanding $3 cumulative preference stock from $50 a share to $5 each.

Rationing of repair materials, electric power, fuel oil, tires, gasoline, rail and ship transportation and even labor before the end of the year by the Government will bring about a stringent curtailment in many civilian industries, even though they are not faced with any particular raw material shortage, War Production Board officials and business executives agreed last week.

WHETHER their elders approve or not, children talk, think and play war, especially since Dec. 7. Before that parents and educators largely agreed that the war should be kept out of the classroom; now they feel the school must do what it can to guide the children in assimilating their war impressions in a healthy way.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Science and its place along the offensive, defensive, military, industrial and social fronts will be presented in a twelve-week extracurricular course, "Science in Wartime," at Sarah Lawrence College beginning next week.

Claude Phillips enjoyed one of the greatest nights ever had on a basketball court by a City College player as the Beavers routed Brooklyn College on the latter's floor last night. Although he played only twenty-eight of the forty minutes, Phillips notched 23 points and led his mates to a 57-34 victory.

THE theme of Mr. Strong's new novel is an unusual one: the fictional autobiography of a man who had always believed he had in him the makings of a writer, but who had followed, with outward complacence, the most humdrum and ordinary, of paths.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- The Soviet Union enters the last quarter of a year of war with its armies advancing with great verve on all important sectors. As has been the custom since the January successes, official sources do not disclose the names of the towns involved.

HONOLULU, Feb. 21 -- The right of the Military Governor to suspend habeas corpus under martial law was inferentially questioned by Federal Judge Delbert E. Metzger yesterday in denying a writ to Dr. Hans Zimmerman, American citizen, who, according to petition filed by his wife, is interned and about to be removed from Hawaii for alleged subversive activities.
United China Relief announced yesterday a goal of $7,000,000 for its 1942 fund to carry out an expanded program of war relief and refugee rehabilitation by the nine participating agencies.

WITH many hands idle in the midst of a war manufacturing boom, as plants are turned to armament making, automotive production centers have a second problem in conversion -- of labor. Men are needed to operate machines and to know the skills of building a 75-mm. tank cannon or a complex aircraft engine.

Ten gold cigarette cases, identically inscribed, form the key to this multiple murder mystery, and Christopher Saxe, playboy detective, is the lad who traces the crimes back to their beginning, twenty years before the story opens.

THE organization of the three large libraries that form the Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection has advanced to a point where some of its resources have already been put to work in the public interest.

The twentieth victim of submarine warfare in United States waters was acknowledged by the Navy yesterday. She was the 8,202-ton tanker Pan-Massachusetts, and her sinking, with 100,000 barrels of gasoline and oil, turned the sea into a blazing inferno that took the lives of twenty of her men.

Discontinuance of the collection of data on which the cotton-mill activity component was based has necessitated a further revision of THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity. The weight given to the cotton-mill series has been distributed among the other components.

Since last week, when a group of American foreign traders and other business men representing foreign interests held an indignation meeting to protest the threatened abolition of the New York Foreign Trade Zone, Mayor La Guardia has indicated that he was willing to assist in preserving the zone.

"How Man Became a Giant" is the title these authors give to their story of evolution and of man's long progress through the ages. Some ten years ago M. Ilin's "Black on White" (the history of writing and bookmaking) and his "What Time Is It?" (man's devices for measuring time) struck a new note in informational books for inexperienced readers.

THERE are two schools of thought on how to behave with a common or garden head cold (American, Atlantic seaboard variety). One is followed by the stalwart or rise-above-it types; they go round as if nothing had happened, breathe stoically through a half-open nose, sneeze delicately like cats and blow discreetly at infrequent intervals.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- A new General MacArthur song which will be a feature of the annual dinner March 7 of the Inner Circle, New York political writers' organization, was sent by short-wave this morning at 3:15, Pacific war time (6:15 Eastern war time) to General MacArthur's forces from KGEI, the General Electric radio station in San Francisco.

BEFORE the war Honolulu was becoming popular as a concert stop. Artists appeared there going to and from Australia and the Orient, and in some cases artists even made special trips to appear in Hawaii. But now all that is over and the following report on the local concert situation from George D. Oakley, concert manager and reporter on The Honolulu Star-Bulletin, was included in a letter to Hurok Attractions, Inc.

IT probably would take a full-grown genius to say anything new on the Latin-American world, so Mr. Schurz has limited his aims to a clear, concise and freshly informative rearrangement of the available material. Having lived for many years in South America and the countries bordering the Caribbean, he is able to give a first-hand account of the land, its people, government, economy and international relations.

AN exhibition of contemporary Czechoslovak art will open at the Demotte Galleries, 39 East Fifty-first Street, on Wednesday afternoon. The event is to be held under the auspices of Colonel Vladimir S. Hurban, Czechoslovak Minister to the United States, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, president of the American Friends of Czechoslovakia.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The Board of Regents came out strongly today in favor of stepping up the program of health training in the public schools but voiced opposition to military training. It urged that the school day be lengthened by an hour, from 3 to 4 in the afternoon, so that an enlarged health and physical training program could be carried out.

IT was with interest and enthusiasm that I read Mme. Landowska's note on Bach dealing specifically with the Goldberg Variations. There is, however, one statement which must be challenged. "In order to 'transfer' this music to the single keyboard of the modern piano, a transcription would be required.

DEVELOPMENTS of late have served substantially to broaden and enrich the resources of the National Gallery of Art in Washington. As announced last Tuesday, a fresh consignment of paintings from the Chester Dale Collection has arrived, these pictures, like those previously sent, are offered on a basis of indefinite loan.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 21 -- Looking toward a future which may demand academic acceleration to an extent not yet apparent, Mount Holyoke College has announced a twelve-week Summer session which will include both defense and acceleration elements.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- The skipper of a cargo vessel that made a perilous dash from Manila Bay on Dec. 13 told tonight how his ship had dared a rain of Japanese bombs to run the blockade and become the first merchantman known to have reached this country safely from the Philippines.

The 225 stewardesses of the United Air Lines are banding together to form a "Smash Those Lies" Club, according to Miss Roberta Schilbach, president of the club, who made the announcement at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, where the line's stewardesses stay when in New York.

One of history's absorbing speculations -- never fraught with such import as now -- has been the exact pattern of Japanese imperial ambitions. Some authorities, like Carl Crow, trace a dream of world dominion to Hideyoshi, the national hero who conquered Korea in the last decade of the sixteenth century and sent back to the homeland as a trophy the ears and noses of 38,000 slain enemies, pickled in wine.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 21 -- Eric Guerin passed Jimmy George in the last race on the closing card at the Fair Grounds today to take riding honors for the 44-day meet with 47 winners.

THE Boston Symphony, under Serge Koussevitzky, will give its first concert in Washington, D.C., in seven years March 31 for the benefit of Russian War Relief, Inc., of which Mr. Koussevitzky is a sponsor. The committee in charge for Russian War Relief is headed by Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, wife of the former American Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Officials of paper mills in this area believe a threatened shutdown of operations because of the shortage of scrap paper can be averted by adjustment of trucking charges established by the Office of Price Administration in Washington.
OLYMPIA, Wash., Feb. 21 (UP) -- The question whether the State could order amputation of the enlarged left arm of Patricia Hudson, 11, of Seattle, was being studied today by the State Supreme Court.

A bright red carnation is Just about as cheerful a sight as one could wish on a dreary Winter day. In fact, there's hardly a holiday or a social occasion for which carnations, with their spicy fragrance, are not used -- even to buttonholes dyed green for St. Patrick's Day.

MISS BABETTE DEUTSCH'S novelized life of that vagabond and immortal poet, Francois de Montcorbier -- better known as Francois Villon, is a heady mixture of fact and fiction. The extant documentation concerning Villon in "Rogue's Legacy" is brought to such a sharp and living fictional focus that the result for the reader is very like draining a huge beaker of that ruddy Beaune that the poet loved so well.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- The Army and Navy Register said today that the Army organization was going to be streamlined, with administrative operations concentrated in three key offices, all operating directly under various sections of the General Staff.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Dramatic German submarine raids this week against the Netherlands West Indies Island of Aruba, vital oil refinery center only about 700 miles from the Panama Canal, focused new attention upon the problem of defending the vital Atlantic-Pacific waterway and the whole Caribbean area.

THE Third Annual National High School Salon of Photography will be held from May 15 to June 1 in Education Hall, the American Museum of Natural History. The last day for receiving prints is April 1. Entry blanks may be obtained by writing the salon headquarters, Stuyvesant High School, 345 East Fifteenth Street.

The people of the United States last month transferred from the shelves of retail stores to their own closets, attics and cellars the greatest amount of merchandise for any January in our history. Their buying splurge, set off by government controls over wool, rubber, tin and other important materials, brought to a climax a series of hoarding forays in the months since 1939, when Hitler marched into Poland.

The recent British press release disclosing something of the part Britain's "Tommy" is playing in this war -- theme also of an editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES -- was overdue. Too long have we been hearing: "Where are the British? We heard only of Aussies, South Africans, Canadians, Indians, and so on.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 21 -Paced by the sharpshooting of Ed Golub, the St. John's quintet scored a 55-35 triumph over Hofstra tonight in the Calkin gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Roosevelt issued an Executive order today designed to speed the transfer of Federal employes to war work.

THE play that John Carradine was reported bringing East with him turned out to be one called "King Richard III," by an Elizabethan poet. No longer under rigid contract to the films, Mr. C. thought the other day he would produce the revival either this Spring or -- if various people who think the time too late have their way -- in the early Fall.

MANY otherwise well-informed Americans were shocked last week when Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, announced that all materials needed in aircraft production had been given the top priority rating, along with tanks and warships.

MILITARY events since Dec. 7 have raised two questions in the minds of Americans: Have we under-estimated the Japanese Army? And if so, why is it that the Chinese Army has been able to fight it to a standstill since the fall of Hankow on Oct. 27, 1938? To this may be added another natural question: What lesson, if any, can be drawn from the Chinese conduct of war for the eventual defeat of Japan?

With the commercial banks of the nation holding an estimated $22,000,000,000 of government securities, of which the New York City commercial banks hold nearly one-third, banking leaders are awaiting anxiously an official statement of government policy for financing the growing national deficit.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The blowing up of a Japanese troop train which resulted in 400 Japanese casualties was reported in a Chinese communique today.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -- Over the black waters of Cypress Gardens the small, pointed paddleboats are already bearing visitors to a strange world of moss-hung trees and incredible reflections. At Middleton Place on the Ashley the oldest formally landscaped gardens in America are readying for their 201st season.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 21 -- Minister of the Interior senator J.S. Collings announced that although the Japanese had damaged four miles of the southward railway from Darwin, it had been repaired by 7:45 P.M. on Thursday, thus enabling two trains to evacuate women and children and some male civilians.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Encirclement operations carried out by German tank troops on the central Russian front in the last four weeks have resulted in the killing of 27,000 Russian troops and the capture of about 5,000 more, the German High Command announced today.

A new answer to the problem of how to keep the name of a product before the public despite its diversion to war production appeared last week when the B.F. Goodrich Company, producers of koroseal, announced to the public that when the war is over new and previously unannounced applications of koroseal will be made available.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 21 -- Trailing 45 to 35 with six minutes to go, Georgetown rallied to tie the count at 50-all and clinched the victory over Yale's quintet in an overtime session tonight, 55 to 53.

THE life of Simon Bolivar is as romantic a tale as the imagination of any novelist ever conceived. It is not an easy tale to tell, for during his brief forty-seven years Bolivar, brilliant general and able statesman, was responsible for the liberation of more than half of South America and involved in the complicated affairs of five South American countries.

Five tons of scrap metal obtained from pinball machines confiscated by the Police Department were turned over to Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday as a contribution to the city's drive to salvage waste materials for war uses.

BOOTHEVILLE, La. -- "We are seventy-five miles out at sea and we are the most American of places, for we are on the soil of thirty-eight States," say the inhabitants of this town in Plaquemine Parish, in the delta country on the west bank of the Mississippi, south of New Orleans.

COMPOSITIONS from the album "Homage to Paderewski," a compilation of works contributed by important composers now resident in the Americas and written in honor of the Polish master during the golden anniversary year of his American debut, will be performed for the first time Friday at 9 P.M. at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L.M. Barlow, 11 Gramercy Park.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Roosevelt will be asked next week by a joint American Federaation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations committee to promulgate a Federal wage policy which does not bar general pay advances "in the absence of complete wartime regimentation of the economy," including drastic price controls, widespread rationing of consumers' goods, and heavy taxation of excess profits.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The anxiety of the British people over loss of control of the seas -- undisputed as far as Asiatic waters are concerned and debatable nearer home -- was reflected in the week-end speeches today by public men at Warships Week meetings.

DIRECTLY connected with the war are two exhibitions that opened in New York last week. These, respectively, consist of poster sketches at the American-British Art Center and anti-Axis cartoons at the Art Students League. Both shows will be on until the end of this month.

ALTHOUGH Ginger Rogers seems destined to play the neurosis-drenched principal whenever Moss Hart's super-deluxe musical is committed to the Paramount cameras, she is not at all a lady in the dark, no matter how you read the line.

FROM neutral Palestine comes a cover mailed a few months ago to New York. Besides showing the censor's seal put on after inspection, it has been backstamped with two orders by the inspectors. Both are in English.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 21 -- Anxious to maintain its leadership, Boston University, which was the first major co-educational university in the country to revamp its educational program because of the war, is now continuing, with many activities, to adapt its program to the changing world conditions and the entry of the United States into the war.

VICHY, France, Feb. 21 -- The Vice Premier, Admiral Francois Darlan, reported today that the 26,500-ton battleship Dunkerque had arrived under her own steam at the South France naval base of Toulon after eighteen months' repair work at Oran, Algeria, where she was badly damaged in the British fleet attack of July, 1940.
VICHY, France, Feb. 21 -- There is something strangely unreal about all the circumstances of the French unpreparedness and war-guilt trial that opened this week at Riom.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 21 -- The government ban on the public sale of automobile tires has prompted a group of residents in the wealthy Round Hill district of Greenwich to contract for the operation of a bus line to serve them in commuting to and from New York City.

OTTAWA, Feb. 21 -- Repeatedly during the past three weeks speakers in the House of Commons' debate have given warning that Canada could be invaded. These warnings have come mostly from Pacific Coast members who have suddenly begun to realize that the war is no longer a remote hypothetical business but a danger that threatens them directly.

Because of the war, physical training has been made a compulsory course at a number of our colleges. But the movement to make young men physically fit to fight is merely one phase of the readjustment which the present emergency requires. It is even more important that college men should understand the issues of this war with the perspective that can be acquired only through the study of American history.

A new departure in entertaining for younger members of society is manifest in current plans to re0rganize the Post-Debutante Assemblies, a/ series of subscription, dances which for the last few years have been among the most largely! subscribed fetes presented here forI the diversion of former debutantes and their friends.

Richard S. Childs, chairman of the Citizens Union, made public last week a set of six recommendations for improvements in the organization and policy of civilian defense in New York City, including the appointment of a full-time paid director to handle the job on a professional basis. The report follows:

The Bureau of Internal Revenue issued yesterday a reminder to Federal income taxpayers who have not filed returns that they have only until midnight of March 16 to comply with the law. Single persons who earned as much as $14.43 a week for the fifty-two weeks of 1941; or married persons living together who had aggregate earnings of as much as $28.85 a week for the year, are required to file returns.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- The School of Education at Syracuse University becomes a graduate as well as an undergraduate unit with the announcement by Chancellor William P. Graham today that the school will exercise control over all professional masters' and doctors' degrees.

THIS isn't the time or the place to present in their awful entirety a series of true confessions, but a few brief notes along the way may be in order this morning. For herewith this particular reviewer signs off for the duration of the war, after several years of exposure to authors, proofreaders, publishers, publicity directors, irate or friendly correspondents and literary functions and luncheons.

HAVANA, Feb. 22 -- Another problem for the Dodgers arrived today in the person of Les Burge, the stocky first baseman of the Atlanta club, who was unanimously voted the most valuable player in the Southern Association last year.

SAN FRANCISCO Feb 22 -- A San Francisco delegation hopes to sit down with the War Production Board in Washington next week to solve a municipal power problem that has grown increasingly acute since the United States Supreme Court in 1940 found this city to be a lawbreaker.

The Metropolitan Museum will place on view today the Albert Gallatin Collection of Greek vases which it recently purchased. This fine collection, formed by Mr. Gallatin over a period of thirty years, contains in all more than 250 examples, most of which have been temporarily installed in Gallery K6, at the southeast corner of the Fifth Avenue wing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Railroad Retirement Board has recommended that credit be given for current military service toward annuities under the Railroad Retirement Act and toward unemployment benefits under the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Accompanied by Scout Paul Krichell and a group of newspaper men, Manager Joe McCarthy of the world champion Yankees arrived today prepared to direct the training campaign of his expensive athletes in his first wartime baseball camp, the third in modern baseball history, if the Spanish-American War is included.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 22 -- Predictions that the Soviet will throw 21,000,000 troops into the Spring offensive are scoffed at in German quarters, where it is contended today that mere population figures afford no basis for such conclusions.

We publish on this page today a letter from William Hodson, New York City's Commissioner of Welfare. Mr. Hodson admits that the workers displaced by conversion of industries to war work are not altogether "unaided," as his letter would at first seem to imply, but are entitled to and are receiving State unemployment insurance benefits.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- It is a little more than a month since the Soviet Information Bureau issued a communique announcing the results of a completed operation. Since the advance on the northwestern sector, which brought the Red Army within striking distance of the great Leningrad-Vitebsk lateral, the character of the fighting has been clearly indicated in dispatches from the front, although there has been little news about the locality of the fighting.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 -- With nothing in the news indicating any important development in progress of the Bankhead and Fulmer bills in Congress and a double holiday over the week-end, cotton futures were narrower and more stable last week than for some time.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 22 (Reuter) -- In the fighting for Malaya, Singapore and the Netherlands Indies, Australians were fighting for Australia, Herbert V. Evatt, Minister of External Affairs said in a broadcast today.
Government-operated nurseries are undertaking the care in England of young children whose mothers want to take war jobs, the British Press Service reported yesterday.

After German dive bombers and tanks swept over France, many military critics assumed that ground artillery was done for. The fixed guns of the Maginot Line proved useless, and French movable batteries were unable to halt the Germans anywhere. But in Russia the story has been quite different.
Two girl skaters who fell through the ice of Brady's Pond at Grassmere, S.I., were rescued twice last night, the second time when a rowboat in which they were being taken ashore capsized.

A program for the training of "diet aides," to be given by St. Vincent's Hospital, Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street, has received so great a response that no further enrollments can be made, Miss Anne Coyle, chief dietitian, announced yesterday.

Any duck hunter who has done much traveling up and down the coast will not be surprised at the shape and color of some of the antique decoys that are attracting so much interest among the scattergun enthusiasts at the Sportsmen's Show.

VICHY, Feb. 22 -- A new law has just been issued modifying the law of March, 1941, creating a tax on stock gains, which already had been altered once in July. The essential feature of the new text is a diminution in the time during which a purchaser of stock can retain it in order that on resale it shall not be subject to tax.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Diplomatic representatives of nations fighting the Axis participated in ceremonies today at the tomb of George Washington in Mount Vernon.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Japanese have followed up their invasion of Timor Island with bombing raids on shipping off the northern coast of Australia, Air Minister Arthur S. Drakeford announced today.
As the college basketball campaign heads into its final stages, championship races nowhere are more beclouded than on the metropolitan circuit and in the Eastern League.

DETROIT, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings ended a four-game winning streak of the Toronto Maple Leafs with a 3-to-0 National Hockey League victory tonight before 10,001 spectators. It was Goalie Johnny Mowers's fifth shutout of the season and his second in three games.
In pulpits throughout the city, the character of George Washington was depicted as an inspiration on his birthday, and the present situation of the United Nations was likened to Valley Forge.

A month ago the cost of food averaged more than it has since the dark depression days of December, 1930. Between mid-December and mid-January retail food prices increased 2.7 per cent, and reached a level 18.2 per cent higher than that of the previous year.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Tass, official Russian news agency, denied today as a "provocational fabrication" a Japanese report that a representative of the Russian Embassy in Tokyo, "whose name was prudently undisclosed," was among foreign representatives congratulating the Japanese on the fall of Singapore.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 -- A two-day non-party conference on Indian problems, presided over by Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, noted Indian liberal, ended today with adoption of a resolution asking the British Government to declare India's position as "identical with those of other self-governing units of the British Commonwealth."

Taking command in the first period and remaining in the driver's seat until the end, the New York Rovers broke a first-place tie with the idle Johnstown Bluebirds and gained undisputed possession of the Eastern Hockey League lead by walloping the Washington (D.C.) Eagles, 6 to 3, in the feature of the amateur twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

In the preface of the new one-volume edition of Sandburg's "Smoke and Steel," "Slabs of the Sunburnt West" and "Good Morning, America," the author discusses free verse versus rhyme. Mainly he says there should be no argument about relative merits.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (Reuter) -- The little yellow silkworm that had virtually built an empire for Japan may, when peace comes, have to crawl a long way back to the important position it has held in the feminine world. Now that Japan is at war with the English-speaking countries, whatever silk reserves they possess are being held for defense purposes.

The New Friends of Music, which will open its orchestral series next Sunday, yesterday brought to a close its sixth season of chamber music. The final concert was held at 5:30 at Town Hall and consisted of a Dvorak and a Mozart quartet played by the Budapest String Quartet and seven Mendelssohn songs sung by Rose Bampton, American soprano.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 22 -- National output of steel ingots, on the basis of the new figures of capacity, was estimated last week to approximate 95 1/2 per cent of rated capacity, compared with a revised figure of 94 1/2 per cent in the previous week.

A preaching mission conducted by all the Episcopal parishes of the Bronx was closed yesterday evening in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by united services in which Bishop William T. Manning outlined "certain things that are required of us if we are to stand fast in the faith."

The Retail Dry Goods Association and other leading shops and stores throughout the city are organizing an all-out cooperative movement to educate customers to take home all "carriable" merchandise purchases in the interest of conserving wrapping paper, truck tires and gasoline, it was learned yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Professional operations featured trading in soy bean futures last week on the Board of Trade, but the volume of business was relatively small and prices fluctuated erratically.
MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 23 -- The following is a condensation of Premier Joseph Stalin's order of the day on the twenty-fourth anniversary of the Red Army:

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The best that can be said for the stock markets here is that they closed last week with some slight lifting of the despondency that had gripped them from Monday to Thursday. In that period the industrial share index dipped to its lowest point since last August.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The text of the announcement of the cabinet changes from No. 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Churchill's official residence, said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- All patents, whether owned by interests here or abroad, which the President found necessary for the prosecution of the war, would be made available to the government under legislation to be introduced tomorrow as the first step in a broad program of utilization of the nation's resources.
Properties in the Brooklyn Heights and Manhattan Beach sections were among parcels reported sold in Brooklyn over the week-end.
ATLANTA, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Senator George of Georgia, addressing a patriotic rally here today, called for elimination of incompetents from the nation's war effort.

BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 22 -- The United Nations forces here, heartened by the results of a strong air and sea counter-offensive, rushed preparations today for the expected desperate fight for Java, meanwhile making ready for wholesale "scorched earth" should the Japanese invaders force their way upon this most populous island of the Indies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- A United States warship convoying American troopships near Java was unable to fight back effectively against thirty-two attacking Japanese bombers because the ship's anti-aircraft ammunition was eleven years old and defective, The National Broadcasting Company's Sydney, Australia, correspondent, Martin Agronsky, reported in a broadcast from Sydney last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Garand rifle has proved itself "excellent" in combat in the Philippines, General Douglas MacArthur has reported to the War Department.

A "change of face" at midday is guaranteed to keep America's daughters in workday denim as pert and pretty as the now almost extinct ladies of elegant leisure. Removing the early morning make-up and getting a fresh start on the second half of the day seems to perk up the feminine spirit to such an extent that it has become a recognized part of the regime in wartime England.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Prices of corn, like those of wheat, held within narrow price limits last week on the Board of Trade. Good support was apparent on all dips, however, as the Commodity Credit Corporation was reported to have refused to sell any of its holdings to processors and elevator interests, forcing the former to attempt to cover their requirements by purchases in the spot market or in the country.

The House of Representatives will have a chance tomorrow to vote on repeal of the Congressional pension, and there is little doubt that it will follow the example of the Senate. But Congress will be making a serious mistake if it assumes that the resentment the public has felt lately is all due to the pension plan or that repeal will satisfy the public's indignation.

TOKYO, Feb. 22 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Domei reported today that Japanese forces in Southern Sumatra had reached and occupied Tanjong Karang, an "important railway center just north of Telokbetong," the chief port of Southern Sumatra directly across from the western end of Java.
The residence at 137 Ralston Avenue, South Orange, N.J., was sold by Stephen A. Rapier to Charles K. Wynn through Richard S. Darling, broker.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 (From German broadcasts) -- Chinese resistance to Japanese occupation in Southern Far Eastern territories, including Malaya, is hindering reestablishment of order after active fighting has ceased, Japanese newspapers reported today.

When Germany had to reduce its consumption of sugar during the last war to almost negligible amounts, and also forego some starch, there was both hardship and benefit. The Geheimrat who was as large around as a table set for six shrank visibly, with a lowering of his blood pressure and a vast improvement in his health.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Tributes to the Red Army were delivered here today at various meetings commemorating its twenty-fourth anniversary.

Leon Henderson is to be congratulated on the courage, the clarity and the economic soundness of his address before the National Farm Institute, in which he opposed any general increase in wages and any increase in the price of farm products much above parity. His argument is unanswerable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- With the charge that her critics are a "small and very vocal group of unenlightened men" renewing "the age-old fight for the privileged few against the good of the many," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight spiritedly defended the physical fitness program of the Office of Civilian Defense.

The country is facing a time of spiritual deterioration and decay that would be far worse than a military defeat, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Employes of the Edgewater plant of the Aluminum Company of America voted today to authorize George Binsted, president of their local of the Aluminum Workers of America, C.I.O., to call a strike if further negotiations for a new contract break down.

Anti-Semitism is "treason against God and country" because it is aimed not only at the Jews but at the basis of decent life and "ultimately at Christianity itself," the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, American secretary of the World Council of Churches, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Free Synagogue, Carnegie Hall.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Feb. 22 -- Warning that the cost of living was rising rapidly, John W. Edelman of the Consumers' Division, Office of Price Administration, today urged labor to act as a pressure movement to exercise control over the prices of necessaries.

The Actors Fund followed its annual custom for the sixtieth time last evening by putting on what might well pass as the most zestful Broadway show of the season. Apparently countless stars of the stage, the screen and radio were present on the stage of the Imperial Theatre with formal and informal acts that ranged from the precise dancing of the Jooss Ballet Dance Theatre to the antics of one Danny Kaye.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- Boston's annual dog show, the thirtieth exhibition of the Eastern Club, opened today in historic Mechanics Building with more than a thousand on the benches. The total, though slightly less than a year ago, indicated that interest is being sustained in New England just as it is in other sections of the country.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 22 -- Much disappointment and some apprehension became evident, not only in commercial but also in government circles, by the announcement today that the Moore-McCormack Line of passenger steamers to Brazil and Uruguay had been taken off the South American run, having been requisitioned by the United States Government.
The war was rapidly approaching a Spring climax last week as the Japanese surged on to new conquests and the Germans clung tenaciously to key points in Russia.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Informed London quarters said tonight that Prime Minister Winston Churchill was planning to consolidate the Empire's front in the Far East by granting additional powers of autonomy to India and by sending a Cabinet representative there in an effort to "put the Indian problem on a more satisfactory footing."

Annual memorial services of the 308th Infantry Post, American Legion, were held yesterday in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street. The post is composed of veterans of the regiment, including the "Lost Battalion."

Fritz Reiner, regular conductor of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, directed the New York City Symphony Orchestra for the first time at its concert last night in Carnegie Hall, given under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- As a postlude to the disclosures, controversies and shake-ups recently attending the so-called "frills and furbelows" of the Office of Civilian Defense, the Congress will receive tomorrow a bill designed to strip that agency down to the one function of protecting civilians from enemy attacks.

With the exception of "Cafe Crown" and "Of V We Sing," twenty-four of the twenty-six current Broadway entertainments will observe the Washington Birthday holiday by offering matinees. Compared to other matinee days, Washington's Birthday occupies a special niche in the hearts of showmen because it always has been marked by large turnouts.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 22 -- Uruguay passed her second quiet day since President Alfredo Baldomir carried out his coup d'etat yesterday by dissolving Congress and taking all State powers into his own hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Selective Service Headquarters today set the new draft lottery for March 17 -- St. Patrick's Day -- and announced that the numbers determining the order of liability of service of about 9,000,000 men will be enclosed in green capsules.

With the Tammany executive committee scheduled to meet Friday to elect a new leader, former Representative James H. Fay of the Twelfth Assembly District, South, seemed yesterday to have more votes than any other aspirant for the leadership in succession to Christopher D. Sullivan.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The official Central Daily News today urged Russia to "strike first" against the Japanese. At the same time Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek predicted "practical collaboration" between the Chinese and Russian armies.

A fellow looking for boats at Grand Central Palace yesterday didn't have to peer through key-holes or poke around the cellar to find them. There were plenty right on the main floor, their relatively tall masts towering over the welter of fishing gear, hunting equipment, fir trees, dried leaves (inflammable; no smoking) and sundry gadgets dear to the outdoor man's heart.

Greg Rice, who added another scintillating performance to his unparalleled string of fast-time triumphs at two miles by doing 8:53.2 at the New York A.C. games on Saturday night, will level his sights at the three-mile mark in the national A.A.U. indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden next Saturday night.
In our zeal to salvage scrap from all possible sources let us not destroy anything which could be useful in our defense effort.

Asserting that a reduction of 10 per cent in the use of the 1,000,000 automobiles in the city would save 5,000 "tire-lives" monthly, the Regional Plan Association offered yesterday seven war emergency traffic measures including curtailment of cruising by taxicabs and obstructive loading and trucking practices, greater use of public transit by motorists and staggered working and trucking hours.

Bruno Walter and Sir Thomas Beecham will return to the Metropolitan Opera House next week, the last week, but one of the season. Mr. Walter will conduct Mozart's "Don Giovanni" and Sir Thomas the double bill of Bach's "Phoebus and Pan" and Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Le Coq D'Or."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Portuguese Legation made public tonight the text of a statement made yesterday by Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar to the National Assembly of Portugal, in which he announced that an energetic protest had been made to Tokyo against Japanese occupation of the Portuguese part of the Pa cific island of Timor. The statement follows:

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 22 (Reuter) -- Indignation at the Japanese invasion of Portuguese Timor is expressed in the press today. There are long reports of yesterday's meeting of the National Assembly, at which Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar announced that a protest had been made to Japan.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- High-flying James Bickford chalked up his eleventh bobsled victory of the season on the Mount Van Hoevenberg mile run today by winning the national A.A.U. senior four-man championship and the coveted Billy Fiske Memorial Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Purchases of farm products amounting to more than $89,000,000 were made in January by the Surplus Marketing Administration under the general buying program for lease-lend and other needs, the Department of Agriculture said today.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 22 -- An ominous calm prevails over Java today as this center of Netherland power in the Indies awaits the gathering storm of Japanese attack.

NEWPORT, Ky., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Thirteen men and three women were feared drowned today as the towboat G.W. McBride smashed against a bridge pier and sank in the fog-shrouded Ohio River before dawn. Five persons were rescued.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Defending Champion Charles W. Brinton, Princeton senior, and Harold Kaese, Boston, moved into the final round of the thirty-fourth national squash racquets tournament today and will meet tomorrow for the singles title.

Fourteen thousand dollars in cash was raised and $100,000 was pledged toward Russian war relief by 1,900 delegates representing 683 groups at a conference of the Council of Jewish Benevolent and Fraternal Organizations yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 15 (Delayed) -- A lazy calm and a solitude like that of a rural Sabbath in June pervaded the East wing of the front line this morning when Major H.O. Fischer of San Antonio made an inspection tour.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- British Imperials in Burma were inflicting heavy casualties on the Japanese between the Bilin and Sittang Rivers, thirty to fifty miles east of the railway from Rangoon that feeds the Burma Road to China, a Rangoon communique rebroadcast by the All-India radio said today.

Trailing by two goals with only half the first period over, the New York Rangers trained a steady assault on the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night and their efforts brought success. The blue-jerseyed skaters' accuracy was off, but they persisted in shooting and batted enough shots past Goalie Sam LoPresti to register a 3-to-2 triumph.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 22 -- At the midwinter homecoming 300 alumni of Williams College presented to President James P. Baxter 3d, today the James S. Rogerson Cup and Medal for "outstanding merit, for service and loyalty to the college and for distinction in a field of endeavor."

The ultimate results of today's world turmoil will depend finally upon spiritual values, the Right Rev. James H. Cockburn, Moderator of the Church of Scotland, asserted at the 11 o'clock services yesterday morning in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street, where he was guest preacher.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 22 -- There is a growing conviction in political as well as military quarters here that Japan will attack Siberia within the next sixty days. Reports from Manchuria indicate extraordinary military activity and it is believed to be for a full dress Russo-Japanese clash.

PANAMA, Feb. 22 -- Submarine attacks off the Atlantic coast of the United States and off the Netherland West Indies have provided excellent propaganda material for the Axis in Latin America, particularly in countries that have ports on the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations is sending through the Red Cross "a bundle of necessities" to each of the 2,229 Americans now held as prisoners of war by the Japanese, as reported by the Army, Navy and Marine Corps last week, Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, said today.

A voice of unusual possibilities was disclosed by Winifred Watson, Negro soprano from Bermuda, at her first New York recital, given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The voice was voluminous, and inherently of exceptionally fine timbre.

Dr. William Temple, Archbishop of York, long has been known as one of the most outstanding as well as one of the most outspoken prelates of the modern Church of England. When Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain bargained with Reichsfuehrer Hitler on the future of Europe in the Fall of 1938, the Archbishop of York issued a statement condemning Mr. Chamberlain's policy as "sheer opportunism."

VICHY, Feb. 22 -- Another event last week showed that the reduction of interest rates in France has been accepted without resistance by investors. The National Railway Company issued a 5,000,000,000-franc slice of 3 1/2 per cent bonds redeemable in fifteen years and intended to be exchanged for the ten-year 5s issued in 1932, which will fall due on March 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Through their president, William Green, the 5,000,000 members of the American Federation of Labor pledged themselves tonight to buy $1,000,000,000 in defense bonds during the year.

Mayor La Guardia served notice on his critics yesterday that he has no intention of giving up active personal control of the city's civilian defense program, despite recent demands that he delegate the job to full-time paid executives.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Major Francis A. Ziegler took over today as State procurement officer for the national Selective Service system as a result of Governor Charles Edison's avowed distrust of Lieut. Col. Stephan H. Barlow, quartermaster general of New Jersey.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Mayor Thomas J. Spellacy, in a statement early today, announced that a group of citizens had underwritten a fund of $100,000 to pay rewards for the conviction of saboteurs and to recompense any employes injured by sabotage.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation tonight announced the arrest of six aliens and a man described as a German-American Bund leader and the seizure of contraband, including firearms and shortwave radios.

MOUNT GILEAD, Ohio, Feb. 22 -- Fifteen thousand farmers, shop workers and merchants and their families of this typically American community in the heart of Ohio pledged themselves in the red brick opera house here this afternoon to a direct-action "Production Now" program conceived by young Fred Sweet, who used to run the local weekly here.

Recent war news, including the report of the capture of Japanese flame-throwers by General MacArthur's troops, and the announcement of the names of the prisoners taken by the Japanese at Guam and Wake Islands and in the Far East, has stimulated interest in the Red Cross War Fund, Colby M. Chester, chairman of the Commerce and Industry Division, announced yesterday.
OTTAWA, Feb. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian homes will operate on a strict wartime economy, stripped of frills and nonessentials, within the next eighteen months, government officials said today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Continued sharp advances in the output of military products brought a rise in industrial production last month, a period when there is usually a decline, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. The board's adjusted index of industrial production rose further to 170 per cent of the 1935-39 average.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Traders in cash wheat and futures have adopted a definite program of waiting for developments in the farm bloc's efforts to rush through Congress bills which in effect would freeze government-owned stocks of grain and other commodities at the parity price level, by prohibiting sales below that figure.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A Federal District Court jury today found the Union Electric Company of Missouri guilty on all eight counts of an indictment charging violation of and conspiracy to violate the corrupt practices section of the Holding Company Act.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- The official observance of George Also at 100 per cent effectiveness will not interrupt production in the war plants in the Philadelphia area. Ship yards and industries turning out the implements of war will celebrate the day by operating full-blast.

BERLIN, Feb. 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command announced today that 56,806 Russian prisoners were taken and casualties "many times this figure" inflicted on the Red Army in the fifty-one days from Jan. 1 to Feb. 20.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Roosevelt spent the day working on the final draft of a speech which is expected to be one of the most important State papers in the history of the Republic.

NOW that ice hockey is firmly established on professional and college rinks this side of the Canadian border, Frank Crowninshield, the "Arbiter Elegantiarum" in person and quite a picture, has written a polite note calling attention, as an old St. Paul's boy, to the pioneer work of St. Paul's School of Concord, N.H., in this frozen field. Some of the points made by Mr. Crowninshield ran as follows:

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 22 -- Torger Tokle, the Norway Ski Club's sensational jumper, thrilled a crowd of 8,000 gathered around the 65-meter Brattleboro hill today as he smashed the slide record twice in taking first honors from an imposing array of rivals.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 22 -- The German Spring offensive cannot be set going much before the middle of May, in the eyes of Berlin military observers, and General Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel's visit to Slovakia has proved that no immediate move is to be scheduled, it was believed here today.
The first in a series of Lenten sermons was delivered yesterday by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

By going back to nineteenth-century New England, Herbert B. Ehrmann has found several matters of moral principle that apply today, and he has put together a play about them, "Under This Roof," which was acted at the Windsor last evening.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22 -- The annual holiday ball was held tonight at the Everglades Club. A huge Uncle Sam dominated the Inner Patio and an illuminated flag hung over the orchestra shell. The national colors were reflected in the lilies, red gladioluses and larkspur table arrangements and lighted balloons decorated the orange gardens. J. Leonard Replogle spoke.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Deputy Raul Damonte Taborda, chairman of the Argentine "Dies committee," was challenged to a duel today by seconds of Colonel Enrique Rottjer, a former acting Federal Governor of Buenos Aires Province.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Newspapers said today that Prime Minister Churchill probably weathered a governmental crisis by today's Cabinet shake-up and that the groundwork was now laid for Britain to pursue the war on more daring lines.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- Trading in lard futures on the Board of Trade was light last week, with price close to the ceiling level established by the Office of Price Administration. Loose lard sold at the ceiling figure throughout the week.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Royal Dragoons, operating more than 100 miles from their base, staged a surprise raid on Axis forces in the Msus region of Libya and brought home an unspecified number of prisoners after destroying motorized equipment, the British command reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 1:30 P.M., follows:

Through the enrollment of an additional 2,596 volunteers last week the number of those who have offered to devote spare time to civilian defense projects throughout the city has mounted to nearly 30,000 men and women, the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office announced yesterday.
LONDON, Monday, Feb. 23 -- Further Cabinet changes were announced by the government early today, involving the dropping of five men.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 -- As the American Association of School Administrators opened its sessions here today with emphasis on cooperation in the war effort Professor John K. Norton of Teachers College, Columbia University, proposed that the peace treaty at the end of the conflict set up a world board to make education an instrument for preventing war, rather than producing it.

Would it not be more to the point if, rather than merely naming things for General MacArthur, we did more to emulate him and every man, American and Filipino, on Bataan? I am getting sick of the harping, in Congress especially, on our own physical safety.

MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 23 -- In an order of the day on the Red Army's twenty-fourth anniversary, Premier Joseph Stalin confidently told the army that the German invaders would be cast from Soviet soil. But he solemnly warned that the enemy "is not yet beaten and a stern struggle is ahead of us."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 -- The training camp activities of the Giants looked more like the real thing today when Manager Mel Ott split his squad of battery men into two teams and turned them loose on each other for a blistering ball game.

Your editorial "Chaos in Relief" calls for further analysis. Passing, for the moment, the question of whether there actually is as much chaos in relief as you suggest, let us look at the basic human facts that confront us.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 -- A severe cold wave developed early last week over much of the Winter wheat belt, but reports are that it was preceded generally by rain or snow, and experts express the belief that little or no damage resulted.

HOUSTON, Texas, Feb. 22 (AP) -- More than seventy enemy aliens were taken into custody and large quantities of contraband, including 4,100 rounds of ammunition, were seized today in a widespread roundup by 150 to 200 officers in the Houston industrial area.

Reflecting the modest turnover and the unimportant fluctuations reported, interest in the foreign exchange market last week was at a low ebb. Those two currencies which had been furnishing the only worth-while movements of consequence since the beginning of the year -- the Canadian and Cuban -- were finally tied in with the other currencies to close at a fractional loss in the Dominion currency, and unchanged for the Cuban.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The working committee of the All-India Moslem League met today to weigh Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's words, and at the same time unanimously re-elected Mohammed Ali Jinnah president for the coming year.

Would it not be more to the point if, rather than merely naming things for General MacArthur, we did more to emulate him and every man, American and Filipino, on Bataan? I am getting sick of the harping, in Congress especially, on our own physical safety.

MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 23 -- General Douglas MacArthur sent an anniversary greeting today to the Red Army on the occasion of its twenty-fourth anniversary, declaring that the "scale and grandeur" of its campaign against the Germans "marks it as the greatest military achievement in all history."
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Oak Park, Ill., today scored his first tournament victory of the Winter, taking first prize of $1,000 in the New Orleans open golf competition.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that "up to this time there has been no concerted foreign-directed Axis sabotage."

FREEPORT, L.I., Feb. 22 -- The strike begun last Tuesday at the plant of the Columbian Bronze Corporation here, which has naval orders worth $1,000,000, was settled tonight when 200 workers agreed to go back to work tomorrow morning pending a decision in the dispute by the National Labor Relations Board.

Plans for swift aid to the victims of an air raid or any other form of enemy action, including cash allowances, housing clothing and food, were disclosed yesterday by Welfare Commissioner William Hodson in an interim report to Mayor La Guardia.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- With State income-tax blanks already mailed out, Republican leaders of the Legislature endeavored today to agree on a complete budgetary and fiscal program for submission to their legislative majorities either on Tuesday or Wednesday.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- Of the many Americans who have won niches in the military hall of fame during General Douglas MacArthur's defense of Bataan Peninsula, none are closer to the hard-fighting Filipinos than Brig. Gen. Albert M. Jones and Captain Rolland (Frenchy) Saulnier.
BERLIN (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press), Feb. 22 -- Today's German communique follows:

Paul Stockheimer, in 215 W 83d St; I.F. Stiel, in 255 West End Ave through Byrne, Bowman Forshay; Miss M. Ivers and Miss S. Woodward, in 305 Lexington Ave; Mrs. M. Elmslie and Mrs. R.L. Hastie, in 57 W 45th St; Houghton Co, broker.

Continuation of the closed shop controversy in war industries is a definite threat to all-out production and to the safety of the nation, the National Association of Manufacturers declared yesterday on the eve of the War Labor Board hearings in the case of the C.I.O. against the "Little Steel" companies. "

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- The flow of Russian war supplies into China has continued unbroken despite the Russo-German war, communications circles disclosed today. Contrary to what the outside world imagined, these circles said, Russian gasoline and arms shipments were arriving monthly at Alma Ata, on the Turk-Sib Railway 1,900 air miles northwest of Chungking.
A statement signed by twenty-eight Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergymen warned yesterday against anti-religious propaganda directed by the Axis powers to North and South America.

The stern and realistic qualities of George Washington were stressed yesterday by public speakers as the 210th anniversary of the birth of the nation's first Commander-in-Chief and President found the United States again in a war for its existence.

With current first-run film attractions holding up well at the box-office, only one new picture is scheduled to arrive this week -- "What's Cookin'," a comedy with music, which Loew's Criterion will present on Wednesday. The film features the Andrews Sisters, Woody Herman and his orchestra, Jan Frazee, Gloria Jean, Charles Butterworth, Billie Burke and Leo Carrillo.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose by 0.5 per cent to 103.1, a new high point for the index. Agricultural commodity price changes dominated the list. In the farm products group, price rises in hogs, live poultry, grains and cotton were balanced against declines in eggs, cattle and potatoes, resulting in a 1.2 per cent gain for the index.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, supported by local police, pressed their "mopping up" operations against "potentially dangerous" enemy aliens on the West Coast today while hundreds of Japanese, Italian and German nationals made last-minute preparations to leave "prohibited" areas by midnight Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Bette Davis's next picture at Warner Brothers will be "Now Voyager," based on the novel by Olive Higgins Prouty, which the studio bought last October and which Casey Robinson is adapting to the screen. Irene Dunne originally was sought for the starring role.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 22 (AP) -- R.A.F. Headquarters issued this communique today:

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 22 -- The crew of thirty-nine officers and seamen and thirteen gunners of the United States freighter Delplata arrived here today after a battle in the Eastern Caribbean with U-boats that torpedoed their ship twice Friday and again yesterday morning.

Prices of cotton last week again moved within a relatively narrow range. Some upward tendency was in evidence in initial dealings, but the moderate gains were lost subsequently. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 3 to 8 points on the week.
When we talk of the grim determination with which we must meet impoverishment for the sake of our war-making, it will do no harm to summon up some philosophy out of the past to sustain us.

After receiving yesterday briefs from railroads seeking a rise of 10 per cent in commutation fares and from groups opposing the increase, Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State Public Service Commission, said the matter would be decided this week.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 23 -- In a letter to Mayor Frank Hague made public here today, Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the Third Naval District, said the Navy had abandoned its plan to take over part or all of the Medical Center here.

Your recent editorial, "Fighting the War on a Forty-hour Week" was both timely and to the point. Every one familiar with industrial production knows that our present war effort is entirely unsatisfactory and the reasons therefor were ably presented in your discussion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- If only combatants were needed to fight a war all able-bodied men and some women, and a good many who are not completely able-bodied, would all volunteer or be drafted. The problem would be largely medical, and the percentage of citizens who were left behind could literally keep the home fires burning, for that is all that would be required of them.

The hoarder must be either a lonely person or one prepared to accept loneliness for the duration. He is not likely to invite company or to be popular in company, for obvious reasons. In peacetime when people speak of a hoard it is usually a miser's hoard. Alone at night in his attic or cellar he gloats over his treasure.

HAVANA, Feb. 23 -- Tomorrow, one of the four national, holidays in Cuba, the Dodgers are going to help celebrate by staging the first intraclub game between Chuck Dressen's Whites and Red Corriden's Greys at Tropical Park Stadium.

AT some period in a youth of misguided reading, from a person named Roger Pocock, I picked up the idea that Christopher Columbus was an old woman who had to be kept from turning back to Spain by his brave sailor boys. In other words, I had been caught when young and impressionable by one of the multitudinous Columbus myths -- and Columbus was thereby spoiled for me for years.

Samuel Verplanck Hoffman of Morristown, N.J., member of a family which has lived in this city for nearly three centuries, died yesterday at his town residence, the Dakota Apartments, 1 West Seventy-second Street, after a long illness, at the age of 75.

Holiday visitors jammed Grand Central Palace to attend the National Sportsmen's Show yesterday. For the most part, they came early, but the latecomers did not have to hurry home since, by special loudspeaker hook-up, they were able to listen to the broadcast of President ' Roosevelt's speech.
