WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- After representations by Mayor La Guardia, the Foreign Trade Zones Board today decided unanimously to continue, in full force, the permit of New York City to operate a foreign trade zone with headquarters on Staten Island although the War Department is taking over the island piers and warehouses.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's speech received top play in some London morning papers. All carried it prominently, giving particular emphasis to his declaration that the United States must fight all around the world and the promise that the Allies soon would be able to take the offensive.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Princeton gained undisputed possession of second place in the Pentagonal Hockey League tonight by downing Yale, 3 -- 2, on Baker Rink before an alumni day crowd of 2,000. The Tigers and Elis had shared the runner-up berth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- George E. Deatherage, described as the head of a former alleged Fascist organization, today was barred from further naval work by order of Secretary Knox. Deatherage has been employed by Doyle Russell, contractors on the naval operating base at Norfolk.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt commended today the new set-up of the Office of Civilian Defense with Jonathan Daniels heading a new Division of Civilian Mobilization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- "There is need for a Bank of North and South America and for a hemisphere dollar," Secretary Morgenthau said today. He made the assertion after having been asked about recent visits by Brazil's Minister of Finance, Dr. Arthur de Sousa Costa.

Washington's Birthday was celebrated with traditional ceremonies at Mount Vernon, Va., yesterday, but in the rest of the country the observance was underlined by the grimness of a war that knows no holiday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (/P) -- Although their plants were shut down for the holiday, processors entered the hog market today to bid prices back to the four-year peaks estahiished early last week. Packing plants received strong competition from shippers, who took 4,500 of the 12,000 head offered for sale.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The stock markets today showed a steadier tendency, with prices moving narrowly. Gilt-edge issues were up again on a good turnover, the 3 1/2 per cent way loan rose to 105 sterling, old consols to 83 1/4 and local loans to 96 5/8.

AMERICAN VOLUNTEER GROUP HEADQUARTERS, Southwest China, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Authoritative United States military sources here said today that telegraph communications between Rangoon and the outside world had been cut and that the fall of Rangoon seemed "only a matter of days."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Assurance that housewives who desire to do home canning will be able to get the cans necessary to preserve fruits and vegetables was given by the War Production Board today. The containers branch of the WPB said that the general preference order which puts restrictions on purchases of cans by commercial canners does not apply to home canners.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Philippines, Feb. 19 (Delayed) -- The men of Bataan continue to eat, but delicacies have been exhausted. Salmon and beef hash are occasionally varied with fresh carabao, more rarely beef, while fresh vegetables and fruits are highly prized, if and when obtainable.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 -- His squad augmented by the arrival of his infielders and outfielders, Manager Melvin Ott today got his first glimpse of the Giants he hopes to lead out of the second division, and what he saw apparently loomed as a most promising sight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Leading Democrats, gathered tonight for a Washington Day dinner here, heard predictions that the Axis not only would be blasted from the lands it has overrun but that the United Nations would not stop until they have reached Berlin and Tokyo.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- With formal consideration of the State budget off this week's calendar, the Legislature turned its attention today toward the hearing on all State defense measures to be held in the Assembly Chamber tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The tobacco industry presented to the Office of Price Administration today a request for higher cigarette prices, but OPA officials, who have already rejected one attempted price increase, said the matter was still in the "broad discussion" stage.

Mortgage loans made by all sayings and loan associations in New York State during January showed a 21 per cent increase in dollar volume and a 110 per cent increase in the number of loans as compared with the same month of 1941, according to Zebulon V. Woodard, executive vice president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

Appointment of a financial long-range planning commission for New York City, deduction of the Federal income tax in computing the State tax and the broadening of the bases for the Federal income tax are urged in the annual report of the New York Board of Trade made public yesterday.

The giant Wringley gum sign in Times Square -- one of the largest electrically operated signs in the world -- will be dismantled starting today to conserve electric power for the war. The plan to darken the sign was announced in Chicago yesterday by Philip K. Wrigley, president of the William Wrigley. Jr. Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Sugar production on lands irrigated by Bureau of Reclamation projects in the West will be increased by one-third this year and may be doubled in 1943, the Interior Department said today.

The three-story apartment and store property at 290 Stuyvesant Avenue, Lyndhurst, N.J., was so by the Union Loan mid Saving Association to a client of Jacob Paer through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Roosevelt told the American people tonight that the United Nations soon will have the offensive, and eventually will win the final victory, but warned that we must suffer more losses "before the turn of the tide."
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's broadcast last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

BERLIN, Feb. 23 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in London) -- Complete absorption of Australia by Japan was demanded in Tokyo today by Ichiro Kiyose, right-wing Diet member and German-educated lawyer.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 24 (UP) -- The Red Army reported today that a smashing Soviet offensive undermining the whole German position on the central front had captured the ancient town of Dorogobuzh, fifty miles east of Smolensk and about the same distance southwest of Vyazma.

Declaring that "we must have done with sentimentality," the Very Rev. James Pernette De Wolfe, Bishop-elect of Long Island, and dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, warned yesterday that "our religion in these difficult times must be very realistic" if the precepts of Christian civilization were to be preserved against "the onslaught of paganism."

The traditionally excellent business for the Washington Birthday matinees was upheld yesterday afternoon when twenty-four of the twenty-six Broadway shows observed the holiday with afternoon performances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that he would appear before the House Ways and Means Committee on March 3 to present the Treasury's proposals for a new $7,000,000,000 tax bill. He will appear on the invitation of Chairman Robert L. Doughton of the committee.
The industrial output of New York City during the war will far exceed that of the last war, predicts Benjamin Winter, operator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Feb. 18 aggregated $10,615,000,000. Total debits during the thirteen weeks ended Feb. 18 amounted to $146,917,000,000, or 18 per cent above the total reported for the corresponding period a year ago.

The rapid expansion of war plants has created a new type of industrial architecture in the United States, according to Albert Kahn of Detroit, fellow of the American Institute of Architects, who has designed fifty defense projects, including the Wright Aeronautical plant in Cincinnati, largest building in the world; the Chrysler tank arsenal in Detroit, and air bases in Hawaii, Alaska, and Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Fighting in the Philippine Islands, where constantly reinforced Japanese armies thus far have failed to break the back of a defense line established across Bataan peninsula, again had settled into a lull which at last reports today had continued for twenty-four hours.

A continuing analysis of the effect of the war upon the volume and character of traffic movements, as they affect the circulation of outdoor advertising, has been put into operation on a nationwide basis by the Traffic Audit Bureau, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 17, in a Washington dispatch, states the shocking fact that a sudden run on tea has reduced a six-months stock by half. What has become of common sense and fair play on the part of American women?

The annual memorial mass for deceased members of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday was attended by 4,000 officers and members of the forty K. of C. councils in Manhattan and the Bronx and by numerous relatives and friends.

An audience of 800 children and 200 adults heard a program devoted to "The Animal Kingdom in Music" at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. It was the third and final event in the elementary series of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 23 -- Teams from Harvard and Princeton dealt defeats to Yale varsity units today and made Eli old grads, present for the annual alumni festivities here, eager to forget virtually the entire sports portion of the program.

Wendell L. Willkie issued yesterday through Beekman Hospital a strong endorsement of its war emergency program and urged New Yorkers to contribute to the hospital's $500,000 emergency fund. Mr. Willkie is a director of the institution.

GRANITE CITY, Ill., Feb. 23 -- The Granite City plant of American Steel Foundries, which produces cast armor for Army tanks and gun mounts for the Navy, was closed today after the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee threw a picket line around the entrance to collect delinquent dues from its members.

ALBANY Feb. 23 -- Unemployed men and women numbering 526,852 received $6,545,643 in benefits in January, Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner, reported today. This amount was an increase of 54 per cent over December, 1941, but 21 per cent less than a year ago.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 23 -- The mission of former Premier Joseph G. Coates, who held army field rank in the World War, and Supply Minister D.G. Sullivan to Australia to confer on mutual defense problems is viewed here as an indication that New Zealand is resolute in her determination to carry out the existing understanding with Australia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The sinking of one of the largest Coast Guard cutters, by a submarine off Iceland, was reported today by the Navy Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Angel Garri Escalada, president of the National Chamber of Commerce and Industries of Cuba, arrived today on a three-fold mission which will include efforts to assure steady movement of Cuban sugar and other crops between the island republic and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A joint resolution declaring "invalid" grants of authority conferred by President Roosevelt in December and January on the chiefs of nine departments and agencies of the government was presented by Senator Taft to the Senate today.

If you lived on a farm as a child, or perhaps just visited one during Christmas vacation, you probably remember perching on a high stool in an out-of-the-way corner of the kitchen while the women of the household made orange marmalade. Outside it was cold and bleak with a sifting of powdery snow covering the hard ground, but inside there was a circle of warmth radiating from the big coal stove that dominated the room.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- A grave warning against wartime acceleration of college programs of study at the expense of educational standards was sounded today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, at the annual alumni day luncheon.
BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies High Command issued this communique today:
CLEVELAND, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The winning streaks of Bob Pastor and Lem Franklin will collide tomorrow night and out of the collision may come an opponent for Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis.

THE ring of the bat against the ball is heard in Spring training camps and the baseball fans back home already are choosing up sides for the season, picking their favorite teams. The players are out in the sun, but the fans are shooting in the dark.

The United States has gone to war since the senior class of Fordham College was polled last year, but the results of a similar poll, made public yesterday, indicate Fordham's seniors think pretty much the same as their predecessors.

Presenting its gold medal for outstanding achievement for the first time in nine years, the Society of Women Geographers last night awarded that coveted honor to Dr. Margaret Mead, noted ethnologist and the author of numerous books dealing with the primitive peoples of Samoa, New Guinea and Bali.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Richard W. Krakeur, theatrical producer, who leased from Daniel Mannix, explorer and lecturer, the latter's furnished apartment at 15 East Fifty-fourth Street.
Fairbanks, Morse Co. reported yesterday for 1941 net sales of $48,520,859, a new peak.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 -Lavrence Wheeler, proprietor of Wheeler's Inn, situated on High,way 101 in the midst of the Eio wood oil field, gave an account t night of the shelling by the enemy submarine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Roosevelt, opening a direct radio-telegraph circuit between the United States and New Zealand, gave assurance to Prime Minister Peter Fraser of New Zealand today that "we shall leave nothing undone to achieve our common objective of freeing our world once and for all of the forces of aggression."
BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- A grand terrier tonight was sent to the top in a field of more than a thousand to close the thirtieth annual all-breed exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club in Mechanics Building.

Chiding Americans for defeatism and discontent, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, yesterday reminded 2,500 persons attending a Washington's Birthday celebration in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Sons of the Revolution, that "if there is any one who has the right to complain, it is the American fighting men in the rugged Bataan Peninsula under the leadership of General Douglas MacArthur."
CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 23 -- Francis M. Forde, Army Minister, issued an order today virtually applying martial law to Port Darwin and the surrounding territory.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A German submarine disguised as a freighter shelled the Cape Cod shore in the first World War. Painted a dirty gray, with a dummy smokestack over the conning tower, the U-boat attacked a tug and a string of barges off Orleans, Mass., on the afternoon of July 2, 1918.

To the Plymouth Theatre this evening there comes a new play entitled "Guest in the House," by Miss Hagar Wilde and Dale Eunson, adapted from a story by Katherine Albert. It depicts, rather shudderingly, what happens to a happy suburban household when visited by a young girl cousin of psychopathic inclinations.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Royal Air Force Headquarters issued this communique today:

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 -- While almost 800 Japanese aliens who were seized in raids in California were started off for internment camps, the residential fate of about 100,000 other enemy aliens on the West Coast was being marked out today by General John L. DeWitt, in command of the western region, who was preparing strategic zones from which he may oust aliens and citizens alike under discretionary powers vested in him by Presidential decree.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 23 -- Deputy Raul Damonte Taborda, chairman Of the Chamber of Deputies investigating committee and member of the Congressional mission that visited the United States last year, will fight a duel tomorrow morning against Colonel D. Enrique Rottjer, former Intervenor, or temporary Governor, of the Province of Buenos Aires, who considered himself insulted by some remarks that Senor Taborda made in an election speech last week.

Now it can be told. The surpassing symmetry and smoothness of lip of the great ladies of stage and screen has nothing to do with their sound nerves and steady grip on their lipsticks or even their abstinence from good black coffee! Those smooth red curves are achieved by means of a virtually fool-proof and smudge-proof mechanical gadget that paints on a nice new mouth with printing-press precision.
The production of steam turbines for merchant ships was put on a twenty-four-hour basis yesterday by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in its plant in Lester, Pa.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Deputy State Rationing Administrator Irma Newell reported today after a conference with State Education Commissioner Charles H. Elliott that he had thrown his full support behind a plan to promote food conservation in the homes by teaching it in the public schools.

WASHINGTON Feb. 23 -- Jonathan Daniels, North Carolina editor mid son of Josephus Daniels, former Secretary of the Navy and Ambassador to Mexico, tonight virtually became the successor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as an assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

By fitness, not favor, the son of a former Archbishop of Canterbury comes to that exalted seat. The successor of Dr. Cosmo Lang at York succeeds him as Primate of all England. The two men are alike in their desire for economic and social amelioration. A few years ago stern and unbending Tories saw the Church of England "going Bolshevik" under the leadership of these dignitaries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee reported favorably today a $32, 762,737,900 War Supply Bill, the largest appropriation measure ever offered in Congress, and Senate consideration is expected to begin tomorrow.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 23 -- The value of Nicaragua's gold exports for January amounted to three-quarters of a million dollars, the largest on record, it was announced by Colonel Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs and High Commissioner.

The undersigned residents and Sector and Senior Air Raid Wardens of Sector H, Zone 2, Nineteenth Precinct, ask for space to state a case they believe ought to be common knowledge at this time to avert a repetition of the Pearl Harbor, Normandie and Singapore disasters in the City of New York.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Vallejo and Napa, Calif., which showed the greatest gain in department store sales last year, continued to lead all other cities during January, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Vallejo and Napa's increase of 71 per cent in sales over the corresponding month last year, was followed by a rise of 67 per cent for Charleston, S.C.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- With the most successful sales year in history behind it, the Stoker manufacturing industry is pushing the conversion of factories to a war work. While there are a few exceptions, the great majority of the members of the Stoker Manufacturers Association are now operating on a 50 to 95 per cent war basis.

The program for the "credit clinic" of the American Bankers Association, to be held March 4 to 6 in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, was announced yesterday by Henry W. Koeneke, president of the association. The meeting will deal with problems arising from the war emergency, particularly in the fields of agricultural credit, consumer credit and commercial loans.

United China Relief announces that it will conduct a $7,000,000 national fund-raising campaign this Spring. Nine agencies will spend the money. Much of it will go for medical supplies, of which there have never been enough in China -- never enough for proper care of the sick and wounded, never enough antiseptics to save lives or anesthetics to relieve agony.

Gladys Swarthout, one of the glamour girls of the Metropolitan Opera, does not sing there much these days. But her local admirers had a chance to see and hear her in person at Carnegie Hall last night, and a good thing too, for Miss Swarthout is one of our most personable singers.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Calling on workers to speed up plane production, Col. J.J. Llewellin, the new Minister of Aircraft Production, warned today that the second Battle of Britain might start at any moment.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Rollins College conferred honorary degrees on seven persons at the Founders Day convocation exercises held today to mark the College's fifty-seventh anniversary. The degrees were given by President Hamilton Holt.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 -- To balance their strong concentrations in the Libyan desert around Mekili, the Germans yesterday moved considerable forces southeastward along the coastal road from Martuba toward Tmimi, thus building a sort of defense line along the Mekili-Tmimi track, according to information reaching British headquarters here today.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- What amounted to a "gold rush" by housewives in this country took place today when the Food Ministry released the last of its imported canned fruit stocks. It was unofficially estimated that 120,000,000 this were placed on sale.

Paced by Dick Holub, who scored 30 points to create a new home record, the Long Island University basketball team defeated Canisius, 58 to 49, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Army won from Harvard's swimmers today, 41 -- 34, clinching the victory by taking the final event, the 440-yard free-style relay. The cadets' chief point scorer was Bill Criss, who took both the 100 and 220-yard free-style events and swam in the relay quartet.
VALLETTA, Malta, Feb. 23 (Reuter) -- The British issued this communique today:
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Headquarters of the United Nations' Southwest Pacific Command issued the following communique tonight:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- To simplify its corporate and security structure the Erie Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to purchase ten of its subsidiary companies in the State of New Jersey.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 -- Axis shells fell on the United States mainland tonight for the first time in World War II. The deck gun of a big submarine that rose to the surface of the Pacific a half mile off the California coast sent shellfire in the direction of a refinery at the edge of the Ellwood oil field, twelve miles west of Santa Barbara.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill and other high British officials sent warm messages today to their opposite numbers in Russia to convey Britain's gratitude for the valiant part played by the Soviet armed forces in withstanding and overcoming the onslaught of the Nazi war machine.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Demands that the government wipe out "black market" profiteering in food, clothing and other everyday necessities, sending the offenders before firing squads, if necessary, were made today by Sir William Jowitt, Solicitor General, and by newspapers.

BERLIN, Feb. 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by the United Press in New York) -- The High Command reported today between Jan. 1 and Feb. 20 the Germans captured 56,806 Russian prisoners and seized or destroyed 960 Soviet tanks, 1,789 cannon, 8,000 military vehicles and 1,209 planes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Declaring that farms had lost 1,000,000 workers through the draft, voluntary enlistments and migrations to industrial centers for war wages, House Agricultural Committeemen questioned Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, today, and demanded that skilled farm labor and management be classified on a parity with military service.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 23 -- Police intervened and prevented a street clash today between opponents and supporters of President Alfredo Baldomir, who spent the day on the reorganizing of the government following his dissolution of Congress on Saturday to avert what he declared were threats of a pro-Axis revolt.
Mayor La Guardia warned aliens of German, Italian and Japanese nationality yesterday that their registration with the Federal Government must be completed before March 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Japanese propagandists attempted to "tear down in advance" President Roosevelt's address of tonight by portraying it as a cunning trick to conceal the truth about the war, the White House said in a statement issued late this forenoon.

OTTAWA, Feb. 23 -- For the second time in Canadian parliamentary history the press will be excluded from the gallery of the House of Commons tomorrow while it meets in secret session, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- All aliens of German, Japanese or Italian nationality serving in the armed forces of the United States as well as all persons of Greek and Turkish extraction who emigrated from the Dodecanese and other Aegean Sea islands were removed today by Attorney General Biddle from the category of alien enemies.

With the supply of rubber limited, all equipment must be used at the greatest pitch of efficiency, the Port of New York Authority stated yesterday in a summary bearing on the proposal to establish a union motor truck terminal here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 18: increases of $126,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $71,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $230,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $228,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $232,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

Bali, "last earthly paradise" of the tourist, was not expected to offer important resistance to an invading army. Yet it is on Bali that Japanese landing troops find themselves more dangerously exposed than in any position they have yet occupied. With their supporting fleet sunk, damaged or in flight, they are isolated without immediate hope of supplies and under incessant bombardment by an Allied air force whose strength they underestimated.

Freddy Archer, 138 1/2, Newark, decisively outpointed Frank Martin, 138 1/4, San Francisco, Chippewa Indian known as Chief Crazy Horse, in the main bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 2,000.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Sir Douglas Hacking has resigned as chairman of the Conservative party, effective March 6, the sixth anniversary of his appointment. He will be succeeded by Major Thomas Lionel Dugdale, the vice chairman and a government whip.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 23 -- Dartmouth outplayed the Columbia basketball team tonight, crushing the Lions by 66 -- 23 in a contest even more lopsided than the score indicates.

The Reoco Corporation, the realty group headed by Gerard van Dam, the Netherlands banker, which last May purchased the four-story building at 1201-7 Lexington Avenue from the Mutual Life Insurance Company, has resold the property, after altering and modernizing it, to a syndicate.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Forty-six Pan American Airways employes and their families at Guam, Manila, Wake and Hong Kong presumably were captured by the Japanese and interned, the company announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Roosevelt spoke to the nation on the conduct of the war; he signed several bills, including the $163,000,000 deficiency appropriation measure which provides $100,000,000 for the Office of Civilian Defense, and the bill suspending the section of the Neutrality Act prohibiting financial transactions between persons in the United States and belligerent countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Administration's $300,000,000 program for increasing unemployment insurance benefits to workers displaced by the conversion of industries to war production, and rejected last week by the House Ways and Means Committee, may become a WPA project, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The State Department is working through the United States Embassy in Vichy to determine the full significance of the transfer of the French battleship Dunkerque from Oran, Algeria, to Toulon, France, but was not prepared today to express an opinion concerning it until more information had been obtained.

The President spoke last night in one of the great crises of our history, and his words were both a warning that a long war lies ahead and a reassurance of his faith in final victory. We believe that the overwhelming majority of the American people wholeheartedly agree with him that there is only one way to win that victory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Dies committee agents have seized elaborately detailed maps drawn by Japanese spies to guide an invasion of the United States through Alaska and Canada, committee sources said tonight.

A highly susceptible theatregoer wishes to say thanks for the "Iolanthe" that was sung at the St. James last evening. For this is the loveliest of the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas with the daintiest libretto and the most rapturous score in the series.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Mrs. Roosevelt's weekly press conference was held at the White House today under new and revised rules, application of which for the first time had some unexpected results.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The War Production Board acted today to acquire possession of all idle aluminum in the hands of fabricators and expected to recover 20,000,000 pounds of the metal. The Federated Metals Division of the American Smelting and Refining Company was designated as the agent of the Metals Reserve Company, a Federal organization, to handle the transactions involved in getting control of the aluminum.

The productive capacity and wealth of this country are not in themselves enough to win this war, but victory certainly will be ours if we have the willingness to fight, take serious losses and continue fighting. That view was expressed yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Thomas Holcomb, commandant of the Marine Corps, on his arrival here to attend the Navy Relief dinner tonight at the Holtel Waldorf-Astoria.

TORONTO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The stock market improved today to show index gains in the golds and base metals. Industrials finished narrowly lower and Western oils held steady. Trading was dull and turnover was well under 100,000 shares, including 25,000 shares of J.M. Consolidated, selling at 1 cent.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Mary Elizabeth Lush, 17 years old, a high school senior from Ames, Iowa, who had never baked a pie up to two weeks ago, baked two cherry pies today and won a cherry pie baking contest conducted by the National Hatchet Club of America.

Plans for women's work in the war will be discussed at a meeting on Thursday night in the Women's University Club in the Hotel Biltmore. Officers of 108 women's college clubs in the metropolitan area and college women registered with the volunteer service bureau of the College and University Women's Center are expected to attend, the center announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Combined forces of Indian, British and American Volunteer fighter planes have established a "measure" of air superiority over the Burma battle front, but the Japanese continued to press their attacks "with utmost intensity," Far Eastern advices said tonight.
BERLIN, Feb. 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's German High Command communique:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Torger Tokle again demonstrated his ski jumping supremacy today by winning the twenty-first annual Washington's Birthday invitation event conducted by the Lake Placid Sno Birds. On the 65-meter Olympic hill Tokle leaped 217 and 230 feet for the top score of 226 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- American planes fighting in the Netherlands Indies have sunk nine Japanese vessels, damaged twenty-four others and destroyed forty-eight enemy planes since Jan. 1, the War Department announced tonight.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Brazil's first aircraft engine company became a reality here today when representatives of the largest South American country signed an agreement with the Wright Aeronautical Corporation to manufacture airplane engines ranging from 235 to 450-horsepower in a modern factory now under construction near Rio de Janeiro.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- About 70 per cent of all selective service registrants classified so far have been deferred, Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey reported today, but that percentage is expected to drop sharply as a result of the Army's recent relaxation of standards for teeth and eyesight.

RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 23 -- A heart attack suffered by Mrs. Ida Kerly, 32 years old, while she was preparing breakfast in her home here was believed by police today to have been responsible for the deaths by illuminating gas of herself, her husband, Joseph, 35, and their two children, Arlene, 6, and Donald, 3.

The War Production Board will be pleased if American women stay as vain as they are, Stanley Marcus, apparel consultant with the WPB, told The Associated Press yesterday. He is depending on vanity rather than rationing to save war-valuable dyes, wools, silks, metals.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 23 -- A steady Army basketball team defeated Harvard, 46 -- 38, today. Sparked by Tiny Rebh and Jim Philpott, the cadets came from behind in the second half.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 -- The Rhymer, from the Greentree Stable of Mrs. Payne Whitney, won the American Purse on the grass at Hialeah Park today before 13,942 persons who wagered $629,290. Since the son of St. Germans was the 11-to-5 favorite, the posting of his number was greeted with a cheer after he had raced a mile and a sixteenth in 1:48 4-5 under 111 pounds.

RIO DE JANIERO, Brazil, Feb. 23 -- Stefan Zweig, noted Austrian-born author who became a man without a country because of the spread of nazism in Europe, and his wife, Elizabeth, said to have been about 30 years old, committed suicide today.

Two clubs playing their best hockey since the National League campaign got under way will clash at Madison Square Garden tonight as the Brooklyn Americans cross sticks with the Detroit Red Wings. Fresh from their 3-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs, the Red Wings have won three in a row, two of them shut-outs for Goalie Johnny Mowers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- Cabinet members, Congressional leaders and defense officials tonight termed President Roosevelt's address one of the greatest of his career, designed to give the nation confidence and realization of tasks ahead.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 23 -- To break the shipping bottleneck in Bermuda, the government is tackling the problem through conscription of dock labor, it was disclosed to the Assembly today.

The Container Corporation of America, maker of paperboard boxes, will report today for 1941 a net income of $2,327,177, or $2.98 a capital share, against a net income of $2,227,682, or $2.85 a share, in 1940. Sales were $46,714,221, against $30,464,677.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The National Retail Furniture Association committee on defense and war housing will hold its first meeting in Cleveland on Friday, and will attempt to evolve specific suggestions for cooperation in the government housing program.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 23 -- There was only slight enemy air activity in the New Guinea area over the week-end. The Royal Australian Air Force communique reported that enemy flyingboats again bombed Allied shipping in the Timor Sea, without result so far as is known.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23 -- Joe McCarthy launched his twelfth training campaign as skipper of the world champion Yankees at Huggins Field today, facing the largest group of salary mutineers with which he has ever been forced to contend.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 23 -- The private married the lieutenant in an unusual ceremony in the reception center chapel this afternoon when Private (first class) Edward S. (Porky) Oliver, golfing star, took Second Lieutenant Clara E. Hee, an Army nurse of Allegany, N.Y., as his bride.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Feb. 24 -- Outflanking the Germans' positions at Vyazma and cutting their communications with Smolensk, Russian forces after more than ten days' fierce fighting have reached and occupied the town of Dorogobuzh, according to a Russian communique broadcast early today.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 23 -- The United States and Great Britain must continue to make the strongest possible effort to hold Java, Dr. Hubertus J. Van Mook, Lieutenant Governor General and "strong man" of the Netherlands Indies, emphasized in an interview with this correspondent here today.

Mayor La Guardia didn't get much nearer to solving the problem of civil air defense in his radio talk on Sunday evening. One need not wonder, for this is a new field in which there will be no perfection without many experiments. If air defense were a police job only, it would be simple to supplement the regular police forces by deputized civilians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The following communique was issued today by the Navy Department:

A move to bring James A. Farley, former national chairman of the Democratic party, back to Washington for an important role in the war was indicated here last night at the George Washington's Birthday dinner in the Hotel Commodore which, this year, replaced the annual Jackson Day dinners.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Light purchases by Canadian mills and locals were noted in listless trading on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today. Intermarket operations were at a standstill due to the holiday in the United States.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- In seven sailing dinghy contests today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Arthur Knapp, with his Class B craft Prissy, beat Howard McMichael's Ordeal by a single point, 58 to 57. In Class X, George Isdale in the Queen Mary won by a point from Ted Reynolds's Junior, 48 to 47.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 -- With "vast curricular changes and new instructional processes" deemed necessary, American educators took their measure of "total war" today at the opening business sessions of the annual convention of the American Association of School Administrators.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Following are highlights of the President's address:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- Re-make rights to "If Winter Comes," a novel by A.S.M. Hutchinson, have been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer from Twentieth Century-Fox, and the property will be used as a vehicle for Greer Garson, Metro announced today.

Excellent, if not generally record-making business was reported by motion picture theatre managers in the midtown area yesterday for the holiday week-end. The Roxy, however, claimed a record Sunday with its attraction, "Roxie Hart," grossing a total of $20,082 for the day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- By a liberalization of regulations for freezing foreign funds, refugees who arrived in the United States after June 17, 1940, and before Feb. 23, 1942, will receive after today the same treatment as that previously extended to refugees who arrived before that date, the fall of France.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Clark Shaughnessy, Stanford football coach, today said "it's just a possibility -- no more, no less," when asked about reports that he might be Yale's next head coach.

Dairy farmers in the New York milkshed are scheduled to collect $12,993,898 from the January milk pool, or 39.3 per cent more than the value of their deliveries in January, 1941, N.J. Cladakis, administrator of the metropolitan milk marketing area, announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie, in a ten-minute plane stopover today, called on the Navy Department to give the American people "the whole truth" on the Pearl Harbor disaster of Dec. 7.

There is an urgent need for men qualified as junior inspectors, ordnance material, for possible duty in New York State, New Jersey, Eastern Pennsylvania, Delaware or Maryland, according to an announcement yesterday by the United States Civil Service Commission.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 23 -- Senator W. Warren Barbour asked the government today not to "soft pedal" bad news, in an address at the joint Washington Birthday luncheon sponsored by the New Jersey Sons and Daughters and Children of the American Revolution at the Newark Athletic Club.

Publishers have been working out plans for participating in the Victory Book Campaign, the national drive that seeks 10,000,000 books for the armed services. Some houses have made contributions to the pool of books from their stocks.

A case history of a subcontracting set-up which, together with the application of engineering skill to overcome the necessity of waiting for new machines, has operated successfully for a Midwestern concern that has more than fifty subcontractors in eight States, was described yesterday by the Office of Emergency Management as an example of how manufacturers can speed war production.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- All Burma was threatened gravely tonight as Japanese assaults units were reported still smashing against the swaying British lines between the Bilin and Sittang Rivers.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Keene Valley's young Bud Washbond took advantage of an off-stride favorite today to capture the National A.A.U. two-man bobsled title.

An eight-car train of the Queens IRT subway was derailed at 8:51 o'clock last night between the Times Square and Fifth Avenue stations as the wheels of the last car jumped the tracks, hurling it against a side wall, Six persons were injured.

Rationing of the recapping and retreading of automobile tires began yesterday as motorists were warned to conserve tires now if they wish to drive their cars next Summer when the weather is pleasant.

Asserting that the United States can profit in the war from practical lessons which are being given by Canada, the Guaranty Trust Company in the current issue of its monthly publication, the Guaranty Survey, says that the Dominion, not only in the field of price control but in many other fields as well, is repeatedly revising procedures in the light of experience.

VICHY, France, Feb. 23 -- Early tomorrow the five defendants will be back in Riom for the third session of the trial intended to fix upon them responsibility for France's unpreparedness when she declared war in September, 1989.

BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 23 -- The Netherlands Indies High Command announced tonight that all the ships of a Japanese invasion fleet off Bali had been destroyed, damaged or dispersed. But the enemy has overrun part of Bali and controls the airdrome at Denpasar, in the southeastern part of the island near its only good harbor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (UP) -- The Tokyo radio claimed today that a United States aircraft carrier had been damaged heavily by Japanese planes and forced to retreat during an attempted raid Friday on Japan's "southeast islands."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 23 -- More self-styled peace envoys from Germany nave appeared recently in the Swedish capital, where they seek contact with representatives of Allied interests.

Saboteurs had nothing to do with the cause or spread of the disastrous fire on the Normandie at her pier, it has been definitely established by Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy as the result of an investigation in which 350 persons were questioned, Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The White House stated today that President Roosevelt would issue an Executive order tomorrow coordinating all housing activities, except those in the Federal Works Agency, under a single head.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Nearly 250 small war industry plants on the Pacific Coast took a holiday today because employers and unions could not agree on the rate of pay for Washington's Birthday.

DETROIT, Feb. 23 -- Overriding scattered membership objections, high-ranking officials of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., today named an arbitrator for more than 4,000 tool and die workers at the Ford Motor Company's new bomber plant.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Feb. 23 -- The Central Labor Union Defense Committee, representing 250,000 members of the American Federation of Labor, warned tonight that a freezing of wages at present levels would endanger financing of the war effort and interfere with post-war economic adjustment.

Most lines shared in the active ordering last week. Large retail organizations stressed immediate delivery, as they are well prepared financially to accept merchandise, pay for it and to hold it until wanted, whereas the smaller stores want delivery as late as possible.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- George E Deatherage was formerly national commander of the Knights of the White Camellia.
Eighty-one student nurses were "capped" yesterday afternoon at the School of Nursing in St. Vincent's Hospital. The class, first of the war, was the largest ever admitted to the school.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Governor Lehman, reiterating his opposition to any general pay increase for State employes to help equalize the rise in the cost of living, sent to the Legislature tonight a special message urging an immediate bonus of about $1,400,000 to 20,000 of the lowest paid State employes.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- The German radio reported today that a strong squadron of United States cruisers and aircraft carriers attempted to attack unidentified Japanese-mandated islands in the Pacific last Friday.

Sturdy shoes that also are comfortable and of light weight, "to avoid carrying the uniform trend too far and at the same time to answer the demands for practical footwear," were emphasized yesterday at the showing of Delman's Spring collection.
Need any lightning rods, liquor, linoleum, cheese, brewers' equipment, common or face brick or refinished handkerchiefs? Or perhaps you want magnesium chloride or magical apparatus? If so, read on.

Employes of the Wage and four Division of the Department of Labor, one of the Federal bureaus shifted from Washington to make room for war workers, were officially received in New York yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

A goal a period was the production of the Red Wings in their game with the Americans at Madison Square Garden last night. The performance proved just enough to top Red Dutton's forces, who could reach their rivals' net only in the closing session.

The performance yesterday of the stock market in so far as price enlargement was concerned was the best in approximately a month, and although the tempo of trading failed to increase, the industrials showed signs of returning to favor. The strength of the motor issues in particular was a carry-over from the spurt of Saturday and was helped along by further short covering.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -The rate of lease-lend aid to the other United Nations has tripled since Pearl Harbor, an official report disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Following is the text of the Anglo-American agreement signed yesterday by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, and Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador:

Labor leaders representing both A.F. of L. and C.I.O. organizations in State and nation pledged their support yesterday to the current national program of war savings and promised to lay aside factional differences in order to attain the goal set by the Federal Government.

Universal's "What's Cookin'" will be the new attraction today at Loew's Criterion. The comedy with music features the Andrews Sisters, Gloria Jean, Woody Herman and his orchestra, Jane Frazee, Robert Paige, Leo Carrillo, Charles Butterworth, Billie Burke and Franklin Pangborn.

New York City's new passenger car quota for the three-month period beginning March 2 and ending May 31 has been fixed at 3,772, Lee S. Buckingham, acting Federal Rationing Administrator, announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 -- Describing Americans as "illiterate" in psychological warfare, Dr. John W. Studebaker, Federal Commissioner of Education, challenged educators today to open a program "by which we find out how to defend ourselves and our ideals as self-respecting human beings against tricksters and tyrants."

HAVANA, Feb. 24 -- Today's ball game, the first of the Dodgers' training season, brought three home runs, a 7-6 victory for the Dressen Whites over the Corriden Greys and a sprained right ankle for Newell Kimball, recently named by Manager Leo Durocher as one of his first-string starters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The national quota of new passenger automobiles for the three months beginning March 2 is 120,000 cars, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, announced today. These cars will be rationed by State and county boards to eligible consumers.
If you wander among the crowds at the Sportsmen's Show-this year you will hear one phrase repeated more than any other: "What has happened to all the gun manufacturers?"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -Rear Admiral W.H.P. Blandy, chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ordnance, said today that ships of the fleet were using some ammunition that was made more than a decade ago but, he added, mere age was "no criterion of its effectiveness."

Seventy-eight per cent off the members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, who voted in a survey just completed, have indicated their support of a general Federal retail sales tax to be advocated by the association at the forthcoming hearings on the Revenue Act of 1942, which begin on March 3 in Washington, it was made known here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -Mrs. Gordon Spielman, former confidential secretary to the late Senator Lundeen, testified in District Court today that his widow stripped his files of all information relating to George Sylvester Viereck, pro-German publicist.
In the 132d annual statement to stockholders, the Hartford Fire Insurance Company reports that its total admitted assets on Dec. 31 were $129,671,484, an increase of $7,543,999 from the year before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- When farm bloc Senators pressed their fight today to forbid sales of government crop surpluses below parity prices Senator Brown of Michigan forecast that such action would add $1,000,000,000 a year to the cost of living.

A large subscription has been reported for the violin recital to be given by Joseph Szigeti tonight at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the British War Relief Society. Mr. Szigeti is donating the entire proceeds to the organization's fund for sending aid to the war-distressed civilians of England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The United Nations will help Java "as much as possible in the circumstances," Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Netherland Foreign Minister, said today as he left the White House after a conference with President Roosevelt.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24 -Mrs. Paul Healy entertained in honor of Miss Dolly Corbin at tonight's dinner at the Everglades Club. In her party were Baron and Baroness Leopold de Schnylenburch, Mr. and Mrs. Chester Milton Williams, Mrs. John T.H. Mitchell, Miss Anne Mitchell, Mrs. Frank Osgood Butler, Prince Filiberto de Bourbon, Oliver Stewart of Miami Beach, Frederick H. Wardell and Harry Skillman.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 24 -- Deputy Raul Damonte Taborda, chairman of the committee investigating anti-Argentine activities, emerged victorious but unreconciled from a duel with cavalry sabers fought at 8 o'clock this morning with Colonel Enrique Rottjer, retired, former Federal Interventor of Buenos Aires Province.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- An investigation into whether many activities of the Office of Civilian Defense fell clearly within the scope of national defense, was ordered today by Senator Byrd, chairman of the Joint Congressional Budget Committee.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 24 -- Stefan Zweig, expatriate Austrian author, and his wife, who died yesterday in a suicide pact, were buried this afternoon at Petropolis at the expense of the Brazilian Government at the request of their friend, President Getulio Vargas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Francis Biddle, Attorney General, presenting the new "government secrets" bill to a Senate Judiciary sub-committee today called it "a very broad, but extremely simple" measure, much desired by officials in the interests of national safety along both the military and nonmilitary fronts.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- In the House of Lords today Lord Cranborne, the new Colonial Secretary, referring to the India visit of China's Generalissimo Chang Kai-shek, announced that the British Government "is in favor of India's political freedom."

Effective immediately, all member banks of the Federal Reserve System in central reserve cities, including banks in the twelve cities with Federal Reserve Banks and in the twenty-four cities with branch offices of these central banks, are to make weekly instead of semi-weekly reports on their average reserve positions.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 23 (Delayed) -- The Chinese Minister to Turkey, Dr. P.C. Chang, left this morning for Baghdad, where he will negotiate between China and Iraq a treaty of friendship which is expected to include a provision for an exchange of diplomatic missions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Nonpartisan support of President Roosevelt's war policies seemed to be the reaction in Washington to the President's address of last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- American industry will be "over the hump" in conversion to full war production by late Autumn, J.S. Knowlson, director of the War Production Board's Division of Industry Operations, said tonight. By September, he added, automobile plants, where peacetime production lines are now being dismantled, will be grinding out war materials at full speed.

We can imagine a more novel program than the one presented by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. This one began with Haydn of the "Military" Symphony, preceded by Chopin's F minor piano concerto, Samuel Sorin, pianist, and ended with Brahms's Fourth Symphony.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The seven-man holdout brigade among the Yankee pitchers lost two members today. Marv Breuer, right-handed regular from last season, signed along with Johnny (Lindy) Lindell, right-handed graduate of the Newark Bears of the International League.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Choosing a moment when gunfire during the screening of a gangster film entitled "Sealed Lips" covered the sound of his own pistol, a blond youth shot to death his girl companion in a balcony of the Palace Theatre late today and apparently escaped.

The American Water Color Society and the New York Water Color Club merged last year and will function in the future, as announced at that time, under the name of the American Water Color Society. The first exhibition under the new regime will be held from March 7-29 at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 24 -- The contract for construction of the new Gatun locks was awarded to the Rosoff Panama Construction Company, Inc., of New York City. The bid of Samuel B. Rosoff, president, was $45,705,000, the lowest received.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- An army of rookie harvest hands -- school boys and girls, women and business men -- may be recruited to help gather the nation's wartime crops this year.

Revere Copper Brass Directors of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., declared yesterday four dividends of $1.31 1/4 each on the 5 1/4 per cent preferred stock, thus clearing arrearages on the issue. In addition, the regular quarterly disbursement also was ordered paid.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Java, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- The situation on Bali, invaded by the Japanese to obtain a springboard for an attack on Java, remained obscure today after the smashing of a Japanese invasion fleet.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Hog prices dropped 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds today, as practically all buying interests held aloof until they could get substantial price cuts from yesterday's four-year peaks. More salable hogs arrived than expected. Dressed pork was strong with light loins up a cent a pound to a new high for the year at 25 to 26 cents.

A new factor was injected yesterday into the contest for the vacant leadership of Tammany Hall when the New York County Committee of the American Labor party, controlled by the left wing of that group, endorsed John P. Morrissey for the Assembly seat recently vacated by Robert F. Wagner Jr.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Churchill's speech today in the House of Commons:

" Sew your own -- for fun -- for fashion -- for freedom," is the chant weaving its way across the continent as the National Needlecraft Bureau launches National Sew and Save Week. Officially opened yesterday, the campaign is conducted in cooperation with the American Red Cross to enlist women in a sew-at-home drive for 1,000,000 garments for an American war relief wardrobe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -The program to make the United States the food basket of the United Nations faces difficulties because of shortages in farm labor and equipment, Agriculture Department officials warned today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The War Department communique based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

In an effort to prevent any ban on the "Business Reply -- Postage Paid" system to save paper, Henry Hoke, publisher of the Reporter of Direct Mail Advertising has developed a substitute form which has been approved by the Post Office and which eliminates the use of a special envelope.
BERLIN (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press), Feb. 24 -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

Benjamin (Dopey Benny) Fein, 55 years old, a gangster chief who thirty years ago provided guerrillas for both industry and unions in strikes, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to a State prison term of ten to twenty years. He was convicted last October of being a fence for a gang of gunmen who looted lofts and garages in the garment center of $2,500,000 in merchandise.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The civilian population of Rangoon has been evacuated as the British Imperial troops defending Burma are now forced back to "good positions" on the west bank of the Sittang River. That stream is the last natural defensive line before the capital, a little more than sixty miles distant.

At a meeting yesterday of directors of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, Ernest R. Breech was elected president to succeed Vincent Bendix who becomes chairman of the board. Simultaneously, Mr. Breech announced his resignation as vice president of the General Motors Corporation in charge of household appliances and aviation and as a member of the administration committee.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- An entire German army of 45,000 men has been shattered in a smashing ten-day Red Army victory below Leningrad, the Russians announced early today.

Every purchase of a defense bond or stamp helps the war effort. But what helps most is the steady purchase, week after week, of a stated amount of defense securities paid for out of current income. The best way to provide for this is by the payroll savings plan, whereby employes voluntarily authorize a regular deduction from their pay envelopes for the purchase of stamps and bonds.

An underwriting group headed by Laird, Bissell Meads, and including Spencer Trask Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will offer to the public today 30,000 shares of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, Series A, of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation.

To achieve victory against the "cunning, skillful tricksters of deceit and treachery, reinforced by the mightiest accumulation of arms and armies in the history" of our enemies, will require the greatest effort in the history of this country, Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, told members of the Bond Club of New York at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Bankers Club.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Hank Leiber came back to the Giants today. To be sure, he arrived a little too late for the workout, but let no one get the notion that this is the same old Hank, whose indifference as to whether he arrived today, tomorrow or next week used to drive Bill Terry to distraction.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- The following special communique was issued early today:
Russia announces the smashing defeat of a German Army of 45,000 men below Leningrad, costing Hitler vital positions needed to protect Staraya Russa, keystone of his northwestern front.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Two Rutgers University journalism students proved today that it is simple for an enemy agent to gain access to an army camp now under construction at Stelton, near here.

VICHY, France, Feb. 24 -- The small steamer Struma, with 750 Jewish refugees from Rumania and Bulgaria aboard, was blown to pieces in the Black Sea about five miles north of the Bosporus, apparently by a stray mine, an Istanbul dispatch to the Vichy news agency said.

Tami Mauriello advanced another step along the heavyweight trail in the Bronx Coliseum last night before a crowd of 7,000 when he knocked out Buddy Knox of Cleveland. The Fordhamite flatened his rival just as the bell ended the first round and Knox was unable to answer the bell for the second.

Housewives who have been grumbling to storekeepers because of the higher prices for bananas can blame the war. It is likely that these prices may go even higher, with the relative scarcity of the fruit taking on the dimensions of a shortage, a survey among wholesale and retail banana dealers revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- This year will be the biggest in the history of the construction industry, S. Morris Livingston, Chief of the Construction Staff of the Department of Commerce, said today. Despite trimming of non-essential projects, total construction will be around $11,500,000,000 as compared with $10,800,000,000 in 1941.

Not the maps spread out before his listeners but the enemy submarine shelling the California coast furnished the most graphic illustration for the President's lesson in geography. The firing on our shores was intended to support those who "want our national bird turned into a turtle," armored only for "last-ditch defense."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 -American armed forces pressed a hunt by air and sea today for the Axis submarine which slunk close inshore last night and lobbed fifteen to twenty-five shells at the Bankline Oil Refinery near Santa Barbara.

Joseph Schoenberger, 53 years old, who was alleged to have defrauded clergymen and others of $100,000 in money and securities up to 1938 in various bogus stock promotion schemes, was sentenced yesterday by Judge John J. Sullivan in General Sessions to eighteen months to three years in Sing Sing.

Although expressing general satisfaction over the War Department's apparent recognition of the importance of the New York Foreign Trade Zone in maintaining the war effort and its decision to permit the continued operation of the zone on a limited basis, importers yesterday indicated considerable curiosity as to the actual extent of its future operations.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 24 -- Despite the recent increase in the German forces around Tmimi, German patrol activity diminished yesterday, giving at least apparent confirmation to the belief that Field Marshal Erwin Rommel will wait for further supplies and reinforcements before he attempts to smash the British positions between El Gazala and Bir Hacheim.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfid., Feb. 24 (AP) -Precipitous bluffs rising up steeply from deep water are believed to have accounted largely for the difficulty in saving lives when the United States destroyer Truxtun and the United States naval stores ship Pollux ran aground and broke up on the south coast of Newfoundland.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Five hundred persons attended a testimonial dinner in the Royal Palm Club tonight given by the turf writers to honor Joseph E. Widener, chairman of the board of the Miami Jockey Club, and to aid the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, the relief societies of the Army and Navy and the American Red Cross.

TOKYO, Feb. 24 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The Domei news agency today likened President Roosevelt's Washington's birthday speech to a "pep talk by an irate football coach" and characterized it as a "fireside disappointment."

The Anglo-American agreement on the broad principles for the post-war settlement of the lease-lend debt which was announced at the White House yesterday is a highly encouraging document. It is not the sort of news to lift people cheering to their feet, but from the longer view it is good news and important news.

The Board of Estimate at a special meeting in City Hall unanimously approved yesterday the amended plan for Edwin Markham Houses, a war workers' project on Staten Island which has been a source of contention between the City Planning Commission and the New York City Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A gale beating down on the coast of Newfoundland wrecked a naval destroyer and one of the newest naval transports with a loss of 189 lives, far more than have been killed in any of the isolated sinkings in war activity, the Navy Department reported today.

Indications that orders for railroad rolling stock would continue to be heavy were provided in railroad statements issued yesterday. There were reports of substantial orders placed recently, not all of which had been made public.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Roosevelt indicated at a press conference today that air support had not been sent to the defenders of the Philippine Islands, surrounded on the Bataan Peninsula, because there was no way of getting it there or keeping it there.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The stock markets were brighter today, President Roosevelt's speech made a good impression here, but Prime Minister Churchill's reference to shipping losses had a restraining effect.

Jarring the American people out of their complacency and creation of a national all-out demand for victory are sales promotion jobs which should be undertaken by the business men of the country, William H. Howard, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 -- The New York Rangers tightened their grip on the National Hockey League lead by outplaying the Boston Bruins for a 4-3 victory tonight before a crowd of 13,200 at the Boston Garden.

The Truxtun was one of the many flush-deck destroyers designed for the World War but completed too late for that war. Like her sister ship, the Reuben James, which was torpedoed and sunk in the North Atlantic off Iceland on Oct. 30, the 1,193-ton Truxtun was hauled from the "graveyard" to play a major role in the second World War.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 24 -- Argentina informed the Italian Embassy today that she was unable to continue to take care of Italian interests in Mexico as she undertook to do shortly after the Italian declaration of war on the United States.
Eddie Lander, 132, Chicago, rallied to defeat Terry Young, 135, East Side, in the feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night before a crowd of 3,000.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Java, Feb. 24 -The Japanese who fled from Bali in what was left of their invasion fleet are carrying home their first taste of American dive-bombing and they probably will remember it for a long time.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente refused yesterday to dismiss a suit brought by Broadcast Music, Inc., and the Edward B. Marks Music Corporation against the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and five individual composers, involving the question whether the publisher or the composer of a song controls the broadcast and performance rights.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Strength in cotton and securities gave to the wheat market a firm undertone at the start today, but there was a dearth of outside buying and when professional traders turned to the selling side the market eased quickly and closing sales were 1/4 cent a bushel lower.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Challedon won at Hialeah Park today as his admirers hoped he would -- decisively. Following two second places earlier in the meeting, the William L. Brann color-bearer, who is Challenger J. most famous son, dashed home first over a slow track in the seven-furlong Miami Shores Purse.

Secretary of the Navy Knox made two pledges to the officers and men of the United States Fleet last night: first, that outnumbered United States forces now in action will get reinforcements that will equalize the numbers at a time "not too far distant," and, second, that the welfare of all members of the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard will be watched over by the Navy Relief Society.

Darwin, the port and naval base on the northernmost tip of Australia, now under Japanese bombardment, got its name from the famous naturalist. It happened in 1869, according to Hartley Grattan's new book on Australia, when Darwin was founded as the terminus of a telegraph line to Britain via Java, Singapore and Madras.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- An eager and somewhat boisterous House of Representatives voted today by 389 to 7 to repeal the pension benefits it voted itself and others in Federal service in December.

After extensive hearings, the House Ways and Means Committee tabled the bill appropriating $300,000,000 for extra unemployment benefits to workers displaced because of war conversions or priorities. The committee's decision was thoroughly justified by the bungling and undemocratic manner in which the plan was steered through Congress and its meaningless and socially questionable provisions.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 24 -Foreign Minister Juan Bautista Rossetti assured the United States Ambassador, Claude G. Bowers, this afternoon that a special session of the Chilean Congress would be called next week to ratify the agreements reached at the Rio de Janeiro conference last month, the most important of which was the declaration recommending that all the American republics break off relations with the Axis, it was reported in usually reliable quarters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Senators supporting legislation to forbid the sale of government crop loan surpluses below parity prices were told, in effect, today by Senator Brown of Michigan that what was sauce for the gander in the lean years was sauce for the goose when war had altered the situation.

A warning that "a hit-and-run bombing of the city could be expected" was sounded yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, chairman of the St. Vincent's Hospital Building Fund. Mr. Smith announced that a city-wide campaign was in progress offering 100,000 "health bonds" at $1 each to assist the hospital in its preparations to meet war emergencies.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $3,065,000 of city of Rochester, N.Y., debt adjustment and various purpose bonds, receiving the award on a bid of 100.056 for 1.70s. The bonds, dated Feb. 1 and March 1, 1942, and maturing on Feb. 1 and March 1, 1943 to 1952, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.40 to 1.70 per cent, according to maturity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The name of Joyce Kilmer, who was killed July 30, 1918, in France while serving as a sergeant in the American Expeditionary Force, has been given to an Army camp to be established in New Jersey.
RENO, Nev., Feb. 24 -- Mrs. Emily Dupont Smith obtained a divorce today from Frank Grosvenor Smith. They were married Sept. 29, 1933, at Wilmington, Del., and have one child, Elizabeth.
ANKARA, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Franz von Papen and his wife narrowly escaped death today in a bomb explosion, and tonight the Ambassador was in conference with Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

Gilbert Dodds of the Boston A. A., who sprang from nowhere to beat Paavo Nurmi's old two-mile record by some four and a half seconds on two occasions, is forsaking the longer distance to run in the mile at the National A.A.U. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

In a lovely old hamlet tucked among the hills of Southern Vermont a colonial custom is returning to life. The village gristmill, silent for many years, is now working again in precisely the same way that it did more than 150 years ago.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 (AP) -- New York milk shed dairy producers expressed dissatisfaction today with an Agriculture Department proposal that would make the usual April 1 price reduction for milk shipped into the New York City market less drastic by 65 cents per hundred pounds than last Spring.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- A "Bomber for Bataan" Fund has been started among the American-Filipino troops fighting the Japanese on the Bataan Peninsula and Corregidor and other fortified Manila Bay islands.

If Hitler's butcher boys are the legal rulers of Austria, then Stefan Zweig, who, with his wife, committed suicide in Brazil on Monday, was a man without a country. More accurately, it can be said that the Nazis are the ones who have exiled themselves, not only from the graciousness, the art, the learning, that were the best of the old Austria, but from civilization itself.

The future of James Edward Grant's play, "Plan M," seemed uncertain yesterday. Through a spokesman, Marion Gering, director of the spy melodrama which had its premiere last Friday at the Belasco, insisted that the engagement would be resumed there tomorrow night under his own guidance.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Legislature was urged today by John Harlan Amen, assistant attorney general conducting the special investigation of law enforcement agencies in Brooklyn, to pass the Gutman bill as the first step in stamping out the "bail bond racket" in New York City.

Out-of-town buyers arriving in the market last week numbered 576 which compared with 933 in the preceding week and 1,026 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 130 as against 437 for last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -Whether the expansion of steel-making capacity in this country, when it is completed some months hence, will have access to raw materials in sufficient varieties and quantities to make good, immediate use of the new facilities is a question that is greatly troubling many of the government's war production officials.

Edward F. Barrett, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, disclosed yesterday in his 1941 report to stockholders that the company had a net income last year of $1,571,267 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, but before reservation to income of $576,000 for investment in a new utility plant in accordance with orders of the Public Service Commission.

The birthrate in New York City took an extraordinary leap last week, rising to 17.1 per 1,000 population, Dr. John L. Rice, city health commissioner, reported yesterday. The rate the week before was 14.4. At this time last year, the rate was 15.1, while in 1940 it was 12.9.
The fixed bayonets of American fighting men glinted in cold sunlight on Fifth Avenue yesterday as Navy and Marine units joined in the first parade under arms here since Pearl Harbor.
The first trained collegiate units ever accepted as official auxiliaries of the American Red Cross were inducted yesterday by the New York Chapter at a special "capping" ceremony at Barnard College.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- United Gas Corporation, in an amendment to its registration statement for the proposed private sale of $75,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due 1959, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, disclosed that it was unable to obtain a further extension of the purchase agreement under which fourteeen insurance companies had originally agreed to purchase the bonds from the company in private sale.

St. John's Prep, defending city C.H.S.A.A. champion, clinched the Brooklyn Division title yesterday by walloping Brooklyn Prep, 57 to 21, on the latter's court. It was the twelfth league victory in thirteen games for the Redmen.

The affiliation of the Todd Shipyards Corporation and the associated companies of Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast industrialist and shipbuilder, has been dissolved by mutual corsent, it was announced here yesterday by John D. Reilly, president of Todd.

MUNICH, Germany, Feb. 24 -(From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -Adolf Hitler, in a message tonight from his Russian-front headquarters to Nazi chiefs observing the twenty-second anniversary of the party platform here, declared that the Red Army's hope of inflicting "a Napoleonic retreat" on the German Army "has miserably failed."

CLEVELAND, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Bob Pastor, New York veteran, became the world's No. 2 heavyweight contender tonight by knocking out Lem Franklin, Cleveland Negro star, at 2:08 of the eighth round before a crowd of 13,278 that paid $52,457 to set a Cleveland indoor attendance and gate record at the Arena.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Deputy Damonte Taborda, who had never used a sword before, and Colonel Rottjer met on a road in the center of a palatial suburban estate of the late Natalio Botano, the Congressman's father-in-law.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -"Devotion," an unproduced play about the Bronte sisters, by Theodore Reeves and De Witt Bodeen, which Warners bought three years ago, has been scheduled for production this Summer with Olivia de Havilland in the role of Emily Bronte, the studio announced today.

One million New Yorkers have responded with gifts to the city-wide Red Cross War Fund appeal for $7,330,000, Leon Fraser, general chairman of the drive, announced yesterday. Although the campaign is within $600,000 of its objective, Mr. Fraser urged a "further flood of contributions to assure that the city's quota of the $65,000,000 national goal is not only reached by March 4 but over-subscribed."

Since the Wrigley fish made their bow above Times Square nearly six years ago many millions of people must have paused to watch their antics. Some of these people did not like to step on discarded wads of gum. Some did not like to sit on gum in the subway. Some did not care for gum at all.

Before inviting people into the home, see "Guest in the House," which was acted at the Plymouth last evening. Hagar Wilde and Dale Eunson have written a mordant torture yarn about a suburban couple who give houseroom to a female guest and live to wring their hands in anguish.
