Realty men and appraisers from various parts of the State will attend the second annual metropolitan conference of the New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers today in the Commodore Hotel. The meeting is being held in cooperation with the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -President Roosevelt reported the consolidation of Federal housing activities under the National Housing Agency headed by John Blandford Jr., signed three minor bills, met the press and the following callers: Secretary Wickard and Under-Secretary Appleby, Senator Murray and Dr. Van Kleffens.

MODESTY is the best policy. This observer caught up with Greg Rice yesterday, but it was because he was sitting down. On the run it would have been impossible. Lively lads have been chasing him around the track for a couple of years and finishing behind him at the tape.

The first wartime meetings of representatives of the investment securities business will be held in Chicago next week, when three separate gatherings are expected to attract investment bankers from all parts of the country to what may reach the status of a small convention.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Feb. 25 -- Pounding with irresistible fury on the second day of its anniversary offensive, the Red Army in the sector west of Lake Ilmen closed a vast pincers around the Germans' Sixteenth Army at Staraya Russa and seized new positions, according to a special communique issued in Moscow early today.
ROME (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press), Feb. 24 -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

The Chrysler Corporation has negotiated a revolving credit arrangement estimated in banking circles to aggregate $100,000,000 or more, over a five-year period, in which 175 commercial banks with which the company ordinarily does business will participate.

CHUNGKING, Feb. 24 -- Dr. T.F. Tsiang, speaking as government spokesman at a press conference today, recalled that he had said several weeks ago that China was self-sufficient with respect to food, clothing and small arms and had ample heavy armament that had not yet been sent to the front.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The latest in the series of work garments designed by Clarice Scott of the Bureau of Home Economics was announced today by the Department of Agriculture with the distribution of pictures of its new protect-all, a garment designed for outdoor farm work.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Governor Lehman warned the midwinter conference of the New York State Association of Public Welfare Officials tonight that America could not win the war by proxy and that victory would come only if every person dedicated himself to the "totality of the American enterprise."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 24 -- Port Moresby Papua, on the south coast of New Guinea, had its first air raid in more than a week shortly after noon today, when a medium force of Japanese bombers and fighters came over in two waves and dropped a number of bombs.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Second Lieutenant Dennis J. Dowling, 22, of Whitestone, L.I., was killed when a pursuit plane he was piloting plunged into Massachusetts Bay two and a half miles southeast of Scituate.

The report of the General Foods Corporation for 1941, made available today by C.M. Chester, chairman of the board, shows a new sales record of $180,358,903, a gain of 18 per cent over the 1940 volume of $152,188,335.
Jurors at the Federal court trial of Kurt Frederick Ludwig, Mrs. Helen Pauline Mayer and four others for espionage spent the entire day yesterday listening to Mrs. Mayer testify in her own defense.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 24 -- The greatest feat in the history of deep-sea salvage, accomplished in heavily mined waters under terrible weather conditions, has resulted in recovery of gold worth 2,397,000 [about $9,600,000] from the Australian-Canadian liner Niagara, which was sunk by an enemy mine twenty-eight miles from the New Zealand coast in June, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Roosevelt consolidated sixteen Federal housing agencies today in a single National Housing Agency, headed by John B. Blandford Jr.; abolished the Federal Loan Agency and transferred its non-housing activities to the Commerce Department and grouped seventeen Department of Agriculture bureaus and administrations into four main divisions.

By official order of Secretary Knox, George E. Deatherage has been designated as "undesirable to have access to the work and/or materials of the Navy Department," and consequently removed from the position he held, under a civilian contractor, at the Norfolk (Va.) Operating Base.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- Seventeen steamfitters, at the opening of their suit today in the Court of Common Pleas here in an effort to prevent their local union from expelling them because they ignored an order to participate in a strike at the Navy Yard last Summer, produced testimony purporting to show that they had been upheld in their stand by the rank and file membership.

A TRICKLE here, a trickle there. Forty fighter planes for China, thirty-five for Russia (ten by way of Iran, twenty-five through Archangel), sixteen for the Libyan desert. A division of soldiers for Port Darwin, three for Assam, two for Iraq, five for Ulster, four for the Western Desert, one to guard the hump of Brazil. Four anti-aircraft guns for Detroit, ten for Santa Barbara, one for Bath, Me.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The health of children was declared today to be one of the three major concerns of the country. The other two are the American fighting front and production of needed war materials. The statement was made by Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor, before the State Association of Public Welfare Officials.

Resignation of Colonel William A. Lockwood, for twenty years general counsel of the New York Curb Exchange, was accepted yesterday by its board of governors "with great reluctance." The board appointed Francis Adams Truslow to the post, effective on March 1.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 24 -Wendell Willkie said today that the post-war economy agreement between Great Britain and the United States "recognizes principles for which I have fought all of my active life."

Serge Rubinstein did not appear yesterday at the hearing before Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon into the question of New York State courts' jurisdiction over the Chosen Corporation. His counsel, Monroe Goldwater, said that Mr. Rubinstein had reported getting a train reservation Monday night, only to have it canceled because of "troop movements."

Events tonight: "Tosca," the Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 o'clock; Joseph Szigeti, violin recital, assisted by Mason Jones, horn, and Andor Foldes, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Robert Goldsand, piano recital, Town Hall, 8:30; "Iphigenia in Tauris," presented by the opera department, Albert Stoessel conducting, Juilliard School of Music, 8:30; Budapest String Quartet, Beethoven program, Y.M.H.A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, 9; Alexander Brailowsky, piano recital, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

The Monsanto Chemical Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington a registration statement covering 35,000 shares of additional no par value $4 dividend cumulative preferred stock, Series C. Under an application for acceleration of the registration statement the offering is expected to be made through Smith, Barney Co. on or about March 4, subject to the approval of the SEC.
Little attention has been given to a problem which is vital to our national defense -- the Soo locks connecting Lake Superior with the lower lakes.

Two more American tankers have been torpedoed by submarines off our East Coast, the Navy revealed yesterday. One was the 8,103-ton Cities Service Empire, which sank in flames after having been hit by three torpedoes early Sunday.

RAS EN NAKURAH, Palestine, Feb. 24 -- A feat of remarkable engineering carried out in a short space of time and destined, no doubt, to be of considerable value to the Allied effort in this theatre of war may now be partially described.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- What purported to be a Vichy broadcast relaying a German announcement was heard in London today asserting that the Russians had launched their biggest offensive of the war and that the relief of Leningrad was expected at any moment.

HONOLULU, Feb. 24 -- The military government today relaxed the ban on liquor that his held Hawaii in the grip of absolute prohibition since Dec. 7. The suspension is an experiment and depends upon public cooperation with new restrictions calculated to keep the parched population from going on a joyous spree.
Ten Manhattan parcels were sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street auction rooms in one of the busiest days that sales center has seen in some time. The details of the auctions follow:

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has withdrawn 3,500 of his employes from the Fire Department Auxiliary on the ground that they are needed to provide adequate air raid protection in the city's parks, it became known yesterday when Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh made public a letter from Mr. Moses giving his reasons for the action.

NEW DELHI, India, Wednesday, Feb. 25 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, in an exchange of farewell messages with the Viceroy before leaving India, said he was glad that a satisfactory decision had been reached on a plan for concerted action on the part of India and China against aggression.

A thirty-three-page pamphlet issued by the Greystone Press is an index of characters to the 963-page novel about Lady Hamilton, "Bride of Glory," which the house will publish tomorrow. When Bradda Field, the author, was working out her material and her prospectus for the historical novel, it is explained, she decided to deal with real people and to avoid "puppets."

FBI agents in New Jersey, Texas, Louisiana and Florida announced yesterday that continued raids and seizures on Monday night resulted in detention of seventy-even more aliens of enemy nations and confiscation of contraband.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 24 -- This community went through its first test blackout tonight with a record of not more than three or four minor violations. Greenwich was in total darkness for the last five minutes of the blackout period which started at 9 P.M. and ended at 9:15.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 24 -- Sweden is girding itself for whatever Spring may bring from both sides. In this connection it is interesting to note the extensive Swedish manoeuvres now going on in the northwestern province of Jaemtland, which borders on Norway, and the new travel restrictions announced today for that same part of Sweden, effective less than a week from now.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- London morning newspapers gave President Roosevelt's speech prominent places, emphasizing his declaration that the United States must fight all around the world and his promise that the Allied powers soon would be able to assume the offensive.

Alexander W. Weddell, Ambassador to Spain, who was called home for consultation by the State Department, arrived here yesterday by Pan American Airways clipper. Although he indicated that after reporting to the State Department he might "have something to say," Mr. Weddells only definite statement about the situation abroad was that while food conditions in Spain were still bad they were now better for the more favored classes than in the occupied nations of Europe.
The United States Government Manual for 1942, revised up to Jan. 31, has just been issued by the Office of Government Reports, the New York State directorship of which is now at 521 Fifth Avenue.

Alumni groups of Bryn Mawr, Haverford and Swarthmore Colleges met together last night for the first time in their history to discuss a program of cooperation for the three colleges. At a dinner meeting at the Vanderbilt Hotel, Dr. John W. Nason, president of Swarthmore College, said that the time was ripe for the three colleges to work together so that each would be enriched by the mutual association without losing its identity.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 24 -Commenting on President Roosevelt's radio address of last night the Berlin press comes to the unanimously inspired conclusion: "The President expressed himself very modestly -- for the President."

Corporations which maintain revolving credits in excess of the $100,000,000 reported to have been arranged by Chrysler Corporation point out that it is good business to maintain such credit lines instead of outright bank borrowings or more permanent forms of financing.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 24 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

The priorities system as it is now operating is virtually forcing manufacturers to operate under the Production Requirements Plan, according to Stanley Oppenheim, consulting analyst for the Priorities Field Service of the War Production Board.

Fifty-five men in the Office of Price Administration are busily studying the proper administrative methods to be set up to stabilize rents in defense centers throughout the country, and designation of the first areas where rental ceilings are believed necessary probably will be announced shortly.

CALDWELL, N.J., Feb. 24 -Employes of the propeller division of the Curtiss Wright Corporation plants, here, and at Clifton, N.J., will receive wage increases of five to thirteen cents an hour under the terms of a new "no-strike" contract signed by representatives of the company and Propellocraft, Inc., an independent union, according to announcement made today.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops have captured the ancient city of Pegu, forty-eight miles northeast of Rangoon, cutting the Burma Road railway, and now are marching toward the Bay of Bengal in an attempt to trap the British defenders in Southern Burma, an official military spokesman said today.

A 10 per cent increase in commutation rates within the State was denied to eleven railroads yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The ruling applies to the New York Central, Long Island and New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads, the three lines within its jurisdiction that serve the New York metropolitan area.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 24 -- That there is no fifth column in Mexico, but that the government is closely watching those who might form one were assertions made today to this correpsondent by Miguel Aleman, Minister of the Interior, whose department is responsible for checking Axis activities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- President Roosevelt said today that he had no plans for changes in his Cabinet.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 24 -Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador, and his wife narrowly escaped assassination shortly after 10 o'clock this morning when, in the course of their customary walk from their residence to the German Embassy, an unidentified young man exploded a bomb, blowing himself to bits.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today possession of pinball or bagatelle machines to be illegal and upheld the Township of Teaneck in banning their use under a local ordinance. The effects of the decision spread immediately to Essex County, where Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld ordered police officials in the county's twenty-two municipalities to seize and impound all pinball machines, and raids in some areas began at once.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The All-India radio broadcast this communique of the British command in Burma:

Early last evening, after a long meeting at Washington Square College, the Council of New York University announced that it had taken the step predicted some time ago and dropped the sport of intercollegiate football, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase, in making the statement confirming the action of the council, said the sport had been dropped for reasons of economy only, and stated that the Violet would maintain other intercollegiate sports already on its program.

The St. John's, N.Y.U. and City College quintets, all battling for the metropolitan championship and thus a ticket to the national invitation tournament, and Manhattan, which is going nowhere, will be the principals in the collegiate basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Fearful that a general censorship of the New York stage might be in the offing, representatives of the legitimate theatres of Broadway tried unsuccessfully yesterday to protest the closing of three burlesque houses by License Commissioner Paul Moss.

An exhibition of Czechoslovak art, arranged as a benefit for Czechoslovak Relief, will open with a preview this afternoon at 5 o'clock in the Demotte Galleries, 39 East Fifty-first Street. The exhibition, which opens to the public tomorrow, is held under the auspices of Colonel Vladimir S. Hurban, Czechoslovak Minister to the United States.

BERLIN (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press), Feb. 24--President Roosevelt was right twice and wrong once in his Washington speech last night, a German radio commentator said today. He was right when he said Germany, Italy and Japan had staked "their last ounce of energy" to cut Anglo-American supply lines all over the globe, he declared.

Of the 256 commercial banks and trust companies in this State that have reported the establishment of payroll deduction plans for the sale of defense savings bonds to employes, 114, or 44 1/2 per cent, indicate that they have 100 per cent employee participation, it was announced yesterday by Eugene C. Donovan, president of the New York State Bankers Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today prices at which it would buy or make loans on 1942-grown soy beans produced under the war food program.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Revision of the mortgage moratorium formula, designed to afford "improved features of protection to the property owner," were recommended in the report of the Joint Legislative Committee on Mortgage Moratorium and Deficiency Judgments, made public today by Senator Janes, chairman.

The attendant in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday called for the fourth case on the calendar and James Dooley, 50 years old, of 410 East 162d Street, the Bronx, shuffled from the prisoner's pen to the front of the magistrate's bench. Monday night Dooley had walked into the Morrisania station and had asked to be arrested as a vagrant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The United States and Great Britain have agreed to cooperate in creating after the war a liberal international economic system which would reduce tariffs, expand production and free trade from the restrictions which have helped produce two world wars in the last twenty-eight years.

Of the 256 commercial banks and trust companies in this State that have reported the establishment of payroll deduction plans for the sale of defense savings bonds to employes, 114, or 44 1/2 per cent, indicate that they have 100 per cent employee participation, it was announced yesterday by Eugene C. Donovan, president of the New York State Bankers Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today prices at which it would buy or make loans on 1942-grown soy beans produced under the war food program.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Revision of the mortgage moratorium formula, designed to afford "improved features of protection to the property owner," were recommended in the report of the Joint Legislative Committee on Mortgage Moratorium and Deficiency Judgments, made public today by Senator Janes, chairman.

The attendant in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday called for the fourth case on the calendar and James Dooley, 50 years old, of 410 East 162d Street, the Bronx, shuffled from the prisoner's pen to the front of the magistrate's bench. Monday night Dooley had walked into the Morrisania station and had asked to be arrested as a vagrant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The United States and Great Britain have agreed to cooperate in creating after the war a liberal international economic system which would reduce tariffs, expand production and free trade from the restrictions which have helped produce two world wars in the last twenty-eight years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Polish refugees in Russia will be the next to receive highly nutritive dried soups developed by the Bureau of Home Economics, manufactured by private concerns and bought by the agency now known as the Agricultural Marketing Administration.

Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange registered gains of 13 to 14 points in early trading yesterday, but at the close these had been reduced by hedging and local selling to final net advances of 3 to 8 points.

A young man posing as a rookie from the Police Academy entered the office of Greenhouse-Brandt, Inc., a finance company, at 2 Maiden Lane, at noon yesterday and, after striking a clerk with a wrench, escaped with $1,500 to $1,800.

Though it was unfortunately still necessary to do it, the President was merely pointing to the obvious when he described the folly of the advice from some of our still uncured isolationists that we should pull our warships, planes and merchant ships to our own home waters and concentrate solely on defense.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The past two months have seen "a most serious increase" in United Nations shipping losses, while at the same time anti-U-boat flotillas and light forces have been strained to the utmost, Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today.

Holding a four-point edge over Toronto in the standings, the Rangers will seek to add to their advantage in the National Hockey League race tonight when they clash with the Red Wings at Madison Square Garden. Following this encounter the Blue Shirts will be left with only two more home games.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The legislative commission which was appointed to re-apportion the Senate and Assembly seats in the Legislature has brought its work to the point where a tentative plan has been drawn up, and the district lines are being mapped on the basis of this plan, sponsored by the Republican majority on the commission.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP) -- California redeemed $57,451,912 in warrants today in a record cash transaction which State Treasurer Charles G. Johnson declared balanced the budget and placed the State Government on a cash basis after years of debt.

Except for some activity in a handful of favorites and scattered swings of major proportions in a few issues touched by special news developments, yesterday's session of the stock market was drab. The tenor of the war developments, particularly the reported enemy aerial activity off the California coast, brought a contraction in the mild enthusiasm of Monday, with a resultant drop in volume.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- How Leningrad's soldiers and workers kept fifty-four German and Finnish divisions at bay at the city's gates along lines that have changed little in six months was told by Leningrad writers at a meeting here Monday night.

The preliminary report for 1941 of the North American Company, issued yesterday by Edward L. Shea, president, shows a net income of $13,652,489 available for the common stock, after all charges, including preferred dividends.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- An informed source reported today that the Administration might ask soon for a drastic "work or fight" measure. Some Senators discussed the feasibility of legislation to formulate a definite policy, which they held was now lacking, to govern settlement of disputes Before the War Labor Board.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 25 -- Negotiations for the renewal of the Danube shipping pool, in progress in Budapest for the last few weeks, have been completed, according to reports reaching informed quarters here.

Carpet manufacturers may soon appeal for an additional price increase to compensate for the increase in unit costs that will result under the wool limitation order for the second quarter, which reduces wool available for production to 25 per cent of that used in the base period.
MANDALAY, Burma, Feb. 25 (UP) -- Japanese troops have opened a drive on Mandalay without waiting to crack the Sittang River line before Rangoon, it was reported tonight.

The New Opera Company has abandoned its plans for a Spring season and instead will reopen in the Autumn, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. George. H. Shaw, chairman of the subscription committee. The Autumn season will start on Nov. 3 with a double bill including Dr. Walter Damrosch's new one-act opera, "The Opera Cloak," and Mussorgsky's "The Fair of Sorochinsk."

Retailers throughout the nation, from newsboys to store executives, are pledged to sell $1,072,000,000 of defense bonds and stamps this year, it was announced yesterday at the first regional meeting in this area of the Retail Advisory Committee to the United States Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Explaining that the halt in automobile production was making available large quantities of critical materials for the production of essential weapons, the War Production Board figuratively took the average car apart today in terms of the munitions materials it contains.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Settlement of two suits asking $8,000,000 from George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., in connection with his sale of control of the Van Sweringen railroad empire, was announced today by opposing attorneys.

The turnstiles furiously clocking off the parade of millions of Dodger fans into the rectangular enclosure where Mudville joy is gained or lost amid a hysteria that at times has captured the nation spelled out a success story in Brooklyn Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Feb. 25 (AP) -- The rescue of an additional 125 survivors of the United States Destroyer Truxtun and the United States naval supply ship Pollux was reported here tonight along with the first details of the heroic battle Newfoundlanders and the American officers and seamen waged against the storm as their vessels were pounded to pieces on Newfoundland's rocks.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Legislative leaders and the executive branch of the State government were wide apart today on a question vital to the State's defense set-up.
BERLIN, Feb. 25 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) ciated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A British communique said today:

PETERSBURG, Va., Feb. 25 (AP) -- George E. Deatherage, dismissed from an important engineering post at the Norfolk naval base at the order of Secretary Knox, said today that he was one of "millions of American citizens who wanted to stay out" of the war, but since we have been attacked "our only job now is to win this war."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Norma Lundeen, widow of Minnesota's Farm-Laborite Senator, took the stand today to declare that she had never heard George Sylvester Viereck, registered agent of German interests, make any un-American remarks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- An assertion that the government could save more than $1,000,000,000 in the next fiscal year on war contracts already let and also save for contractors large amounts of time and trouble by exempting such contracts from State and local sales taxes and similar levies, was made today by Representative Cochran in offering a bill to that end.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 25 -- The Navy Department has confirmed a government investment in an $8,000,000 expansion of the facilities of the Dravo Corporation plant on Neville Island for construction of minesweepers, submarine chasers and other types of naval vessels.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Pennsylvania made another stride toward the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship by defeating Cornell at the Palestra tonight, 48 -- 35, to go into a second-place tie with Princeton. Cornell dropped to fourth place.

The Homestead Hotel, whose situation at the Kew Gardens railroad station has made it a landmark to many Long Island commuters, has been sold by the Underwriters Trust Company, trustee for the certificate holders of issue B 217,000, to the Kew Gardens Realty Corporation, a newly organized concern, for $25,000 above a purchase money mortgage of $170,000.

A campaign to confine tire and tube sales and capping and maintenance service to the 60,000 independent tire dealers throughout the country on an exclusive basis was urged yesterday by J.P. Seiberling, president of the Seiberling Rubber Company, Akron, in an address before a luncheon meeting of several hundred members of the Greater New York Tire and Battery Association at the Hotel Park Central.

Twelve hundred employe groups throughout the city have obtained 100 per cent support in their fundraising efforts for the Red Cross War Fund, Colby M. Chester, chairman of the commerce and industry division, announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Feb. 25 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Headquarters announced today that Japanese air raiders delivered a "mortal blow to the British and Netherland air forces" yesterday by destroying sixty-eight planes based on Java.
SOME days the luck breaks just right. In the noon mail there came a letter raising a question about hockey, and an hour later along came a man who knew the answer. The letter ran as follows:

Plans for the removal from Washington to this city of the United States Employes Compensation Commission were revealed yesterday with the announcement that the agency had leased three floors in the Grand Central district and would transfer its activities to the new quarters over the weekend.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Springfield, which does not see the legitimate theatre very often, had a taste today of William Saroyan.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- The Giants, preparing for their weekend invasion of Havana to grapple with the Dodgers in a two-game series, put on a spirited workout today. Not the least impressive and significant feature of the session came when the infield quartet went to work for a brief but snappy drill.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 25 -- America, with her resources and facilities, will be called upon to assume the burden of rehabilitating a broken world after the war, Roy W. Moore, president of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., said tonight in an address at the annual dinner of the Bond Club of New Jersey in the Robert Treat Hotel.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25 -- Members of the American Field Ambulance Service have arrived in Syria and Lebanon and their uniforms have caused rumors that American troops are here. They are attached to medical units under British command and are headed by Captain George F. King, who helped evacuate 12,000 wounded during the Battle of France.

KEARNY, N.J., Feb. 25 -- The Western Electric Employes Association has notified the management of the Western Electric works here that it will call a strike if demands for a wage increase of 10 cents an hour are not settled within the next 30 days.

An intensive manhunt in Harlem yesterday by fifty detectives resulted in the arrest of a WPA carpenter who is alleged to have kidnapped and raped an 8-year-old girl after luring her from in front of her home in the Bronx to his furnished room in Harlem.

Two remarkable individual scoring exploits went for naught in Madison Square Garden last night as St. John's came from behind in the last four minutes to overhaul N.Y.U., 54 to 53, in a hair-raising basketball exhibition after City College had barely clung to the remnants of a huge lead to topple Manhattan, 38 to 35.

On Feb. 23 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a condensation of Premier Joseph Stalin's Order of the Day to the Red Army. In this account Mr. Stalin was quoted as saying in effect that Russia had no allies fighting with her and he predicted that the Red banner would float wherever it had floated before.

"Tilt your hat over one eye." This was the message of Bergdorf Goodman's millinery showing yesterday afternoon. It gives an enormous amount of zest to Spring millinery and looked new in the small shapes that came into view through the opening in an amazing pale blue satin screen designed by Mab Wilson.
A record-smashing performance by Miss Gloria Callen, back-stroke ace of the Women's Swimming Association, highlighted an A.A.U. aquatic carnival last night in the New York A.C. pool.

Speaking at a luncheon under the auspices of the Council for Democracy in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Soviet Russia, pleaded for confidence in the Soviet Government as "our great ally" and warned that failure to give adequate support and assistance to the Red Army might lead to a debacle of the anti-Axis cause.
Charges yesterday of discrimination against Negroes by the American Women's Voluntary Services in its organizational work in Harlem brought immediate denial from the A.W.V.S.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations jointly asked President Roosevelt today to renounce any plan to bar general wage increases, and to create an independent agency within the Department of Labor to handle the problems of mobilizing millions of men and women for the war effort on the industrial front.

UTICA, Feb. 25 -- Ralph Marlatt, national director of the United Dairy Farmers, C.I.O., conferred here today' with leaders of the Dairy Farmers Union on an organizational drive by the C.I.O. in the New York milk shed, and announced that the United Mine Workers are hoping to organize all of the 3,000,000 dairymen in the United States.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Feb. 23 (delayed) (AP) -- The Battle of Bataan appears to have entered a definite stalemate, with the Japanese abandoning, at least temporarily, their hitherto costly efforts to crack General Douglas MacArthur's line across the peninsula.

The goal of $5,000,000 for the campaign of the Greater New York Fund this year was announced by John W. Hanes, campaign chairman, at a conference yesterday in the Yale Club. The drive, scheduled to begin March 23, will aid 400 voluntary welfare and health agencies.

The second annual newspaper and radio awards by the Overseas Press Club of America for outstanding coverage of news abroad in 1941 were announced yesterday by the club. The recipients are Cyrus L. Sulzberger and Otto D. Tolischus, correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES, for outstanding coverage in Europe and the Far East, respectively, and Cecil Brown of the Columbia Broadcasting System for outstanding radio coverage.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 25 -- Strict measures are being taken by the Argentine Government to prevent Buenos Aires from becoming a refuge for Axis diplomats oblige to leave other Latin-American countries as a result of rupture in relations following the Rio de Janeiro conference.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 25 -- The Southern skies are richer in stars than the Northern, and consequently the new telescope at Tonanzintla, Mexico, will usefully supplement those in the United States, said Dr. Harlow Shapley of Harvard tonight in an address on recent studies of galaxies, the final paper of the Inter-American Astrophysical Congress meeting here.

AT AMERICAN VOLUNTEER HEADQUARTERS, in Southwest China, Feb. 25 -- The British have put the torch to Rangoon, converting it into an inferno of flames and smoke, and looters are pillaging the city, an American Volunteer Group flier who left the Burmese capital reported today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Clarence McDonald, 17, confessed to police and coroner's investigators this afternoon that he had kissed and then killed during a film performance at the Palace Theatre yesterday, Dorothy Broz, also 17, an honor student and beauty award winner at the Berwyn High School.

The War Department announced yesterday that a contingent of British troops had arrived in the New York metropolitan area as the first combat force of the British Empire to set foot on soil of the continental United States since the first World War.

BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 25 -- United Nations aircraft, continuing to fight back at the Japanese, have sunk three large transports in a concentration off Macassar, Southern Celebes, and set afire three enemy planes on an airfield near Palembang, Sumatra, the Netherlands Indies High Command announced today.
Representatives of at least thirty-five foreign-language groups will meet tonight in Times Hall for a forum discussion of the part Americans of foreign origin can take in civilian defense.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Senator Byrd demanded today that Congress adopt a national labor policy during the war to assure full-time production, and as "a first and important step" toward that goal, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, should be removed from office.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Thursday, Feb. 26 -- Major Gen. Henry Gordon Bennett, commander of the Australian Imperial Forces in Malaya, has reached Batavia after escaping from Singapore in a large Chinese junk that sailed from Singapore to Sumatra in four days.

Net premium income of The Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company in 1941, its one hundredth year of operations, amounted to $6,556,843, against $5,262,620 for 1940, after deducting reinsurance ceded to other companies, it was announced yesterday by William D. Winter, president.

Under the patronage of Lord and Lady Halifax, Joseph Szigeti gave a violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall, the proceeds of which he is contributing to the British War Relief Society, Inc. Mason Jones, the youthful first-horn player of the Philadelphia Orchestra, was the guest artist and Andor Foldes presided at the piano.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A recent lull in the Japanese attack on the United States and Filipino forces defending the positions on the Bataan Peninsula was reported broken today by "sharp encounters between our patrols and the enemy all along the line."
CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 25 A Royal Australian Air Force communique issued tonight said that operations last night extended from Timor to New Britain.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Severe sandstorms are hampering land and air operations in Libya, but before they began a South African patrol on Monday night virtually wiped out an enemy scouting party, while Royal Air Force planes raided Axis strongholds as far west as Tripoli, main Axis supply port, it was announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- W. Averell Harriman, United States Minister to London, made an oblique reference to Burma today when he said that President Roosevelt was determined to keep up the line of supplies to China "no matter what particular road might be cut."

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Just as Parliament has forced Prime Minister Churchill to revise his Cabinet, so have the parliamentary ladies forced the government to change the set-up of a committee formed to inquire into the amenities of welfare conditions in the three women's services.

One Jail sentence and fines ranging from $10 to $50 were imposed in Municipal Term Court in Brooklyn yesterday against seventeen defendants accused of smoking in factories. Magistrate Charles Solomon, who meted out the sentences intimated that Washington was behind the movement as part of a program to reduce fires in plants that have war contracts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Department of Agriculture is concerned over the prospect of a shortage of farm labor in 1943, Secretary Wickard said today, and is making surveys to determine in what branches of production a women's land army could be most useful.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- There was one public worker for each eleven workers in the entire labor force of the United States at the end of 1941, the Census Bureau stated today. With the 2,000,000 men in the armed forces included as government employes, there would be one public worker for eight.
PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, Feb. 25 -- This Pacific outpost suffered its first day bombing on Tuesday, when nine heavy Japanese bombers from Rabaul attacked the city.

War requirements for steel in 1942 are estimated at more than 43,000,000 net tons of ingots, according to Iron Age, which says this volume of steel will be earmarked for such direct war needs as the shipbuilding and railroad industries, the shell steel and tank manufacturers, and for the lease-lend program.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25 -- The Yankees today acquired Outfielder Tuck Stainback from their Kansas City farm in exchange for Frenchy Bordagaray, utility outfielder, and Pitcher George Washburn. Stainback, who has been here for several days, promptly signed a contract and engaged in his first workout with the world champions.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in Near York) -- A Foreign Office spokesman said today that the alleged attempt on Ambassador Franz von Papen's life in Ankara Turkey, was an obvious effort by British and Russian spies to remove the man who supplied the Turkish Government with information about British Foreign Minister Anthony Eden's recent talks in Moscow.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Ellis O. Jones, self-styled head of the National Copperheads and co-director with Robert Noble of the Friends of Progress organization, was arrested tonight on a complaint issued by Municipal Judge F. Gray Bennet charging violation of the State penal code.

At the request of city officials, the Commerce and Industry Association sent out yesterday a questionnaire intended to determine the attitude of business and industrial establishments toward "staggering" work hours as means of reducing rush-hour transit congestion.

Although sales of the National Lead Company and its wholly owned domestic subsidiaries increased in 1941 to $139,192,540 from $90,696,461 the year before, in the fiftieth annual statement the net profit was adversely affected by larger provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes and other operating expenditures, Fletcher W. Rockwell, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A dispute over the plan of Representative Smith of Virginia to seek legislation suspending for the duration the forty-hour work week limitation, which he said is contained in seventeen Federal laws, stirred the House today as it was considering the Second War Powers Bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate by a vote of 50 to 23 today passed a bill prohibiting the Commodity Credit Corporation from selling at less than parity prices government-owned or held farm products. This action was taken in the face of a last-minute plea by President Roosevelt for defeat of the measure on the ground that it would mean food-price inflation.

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Postponed since Monday by inclement weather, the national field trials finally got under way here today over the vast acres of the picturesque Hobart Ames plantation.
BANDUNG, Netherland Indies, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Netherland Indies High, Command communique today said:

Net income of the St. Regis Paper Company for 1941 amounted to $3,228,080, an increase of 54 per cent over the $2,087,105 earned in 1940 and the largest profit since 1929, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Roy K. Ferguson, president.

Officials of the Louisville Municipal Housing Commission, Ky., will consider bids today on $8,673,000 of refunding housing bonds, it was announced yesterday. The bonds, dated April 1, 1942, will mature beginning on April 1, 1943, and ending not later than April 1, 1998. of the total, $4,260,000 will bear interest at 3 per cent, and $4,413,000 at 3 1/4 per cent.

The Navy Department announces that our forces have sunk three enemy submarines in the Atlantic and damaged four more. This is good news, but not good enough. Merchant ship losses off the Atlantic Coast have reached a point at which they gravely threaten our war effort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The War Production Board today barred rubber for rubber thread for the manufacture of corsets, girdles, brassieres and foundation garments for general use. It was also expected to rule out the material for production of men's suspenders, garters and similar products.

Although hailing the Anglo-American economic agreement as a move to implement the Atlantic charter, foreign traders here yesterday pointed out that .the document is not a pact but merely an outline of a course proposed for the future.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Registrations under the Securities Act in 1941 totaled $2,787,153,000 and were the highest for any calendar year since 1937, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. This total compared with $2,124,429,000 in 1940 and $1,815,046,000 in 1939.

In the first act of Gluck's "Iphigenia in Tauris," revived last night by student soloists, chorus and orchestra of the Juilliard School of Music on Claremont Avenue, Iphigenia is made by Gluck, according to Ernest Newman, to appear "as one with the wind and the storm."

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 -- Anti-aircraft batteries protecting airplane factories and oil depots in the Los Angeles metropolitan district directed barrage after barrage in the pre-dawn darkness today against planes which late in the afternoon were still unidentiffed.

Replanning and rebuilding of outmoded and Blighted areas in large American cities should be one of the major steps in the reconstruction period which will follow the war, and Federal, State and municipal cooperation will be necessary to achieve the desired results, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendant of Insurance, suggested yesterday.

Indications are that the question of higher commission rates for transactions on the New York Stock Exchange will be decided soon. Emil Schram, president of the Exchange, was in Washington yesterday and talked with the Securities and Exchange Commission on rates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Approval of the controversial measure came after the Senate had rejected, 48 to 24, a compromise version offered as an amendment by Senator Brown. He proposed to deduct the amount of government farm benefit payments from parity levels and let the resultant figure be the minimum at which the government could dispose of its surplus stocks.
HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Walter Kirby Higbe, the 22-game winner who doesn't like Havana, is here -- but he still doesn't like it.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- H.L. Myer's Sheriff Culkin breezed away from four rivals, including two Widener Challenge Cup hopefuls, in the Grade A Handicap at Hialeah Park today. Toting top weight of 122 pounds, with Wendell Eads in the saddle, the Head Play colt romped the seven furlongs in 1:24 3-5 and registered by half a dozen lengths. He paid 14 to 5.

The five-story building with two stores at 47 West Thirty-seventh Street was purchased by Calm Cahn, operators, from the Union Dime Savings Bank, which took back a purchase money mortgage for ten years at 3 1/2 per cent. It is assessed at $54,000 and was sold through Leonard J. Beck. Inc.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- Increases of record proportions in orders booked during January by textile mills and metal trades factories within the State were reported today by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts. The textile field shows an increase over December, 1941, of nearly 66 per cent; the metal industry of approximately 63 per cent.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Dr. and Mrs. Lelanel Eggleston Cofer entertained with a dinner tonight at Capricho for Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad has ordered 500 coal cars from the Bethlehem Steel Company and five oil-electric switching engines each from the American Locomotive Company and the General Motors Corporation for delivery next Fall, R.W. Brown, president, said yesterday after the board meeting in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Roosevelt conferred with his party leaders from Capitol Hill; received a delegation from the C.I.O. and A.F.L. with a proposal for war-labor mobilization and talked with the following callers: The Polish Ambassador and Count Edward Raczynski, acting Foreign Minister of the Polish Government in Exile; Secretaries Morgenthau, Knox and Stimson.

Unofficial inquiries by the United States Public Health Service have been started into safeguards against benzol poisoning in States where local regulations do not prohibit its use in industrial plants, it was reported here yesterday. The survey was expected to build a body of precedent upon which could be based an appeal to authorities in other States to permit relaxation of anti-benzol regulations in war industries.

THIS is a seagoing week. After tracing out the four voyages of Columbus with Skipper Samuel Eliot Morison, we are now invited to sail down the west coast of Mexico and Central America in William Beebe's "Book of Bays."* Mr. Beebe's impulses are very like Professor Morison's; he is interested in establishing the scientific truth, but he is also enamored of sunburn, seascapes, wide, white beaches, tropical laziness and copious drafts of clean, salt air.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 25 -- A resolution authorizing the Municipal Purchasing Bureau to advertise for bids from milk dealers within a 300-mile radius of this city was adopted today by the Newark City Commission as the first step in what promised to become a rebellion against Arthur F. Foran, State Milk Control Director.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- British and American fliers brought down at least thirty Japanese fighter planes today over Burma, according to incomplete reports received by Royal Air Force headquarters in Burma. Continuing their vigorous offensive this evening, the pilots were reported attacking formations of enemy bombers, heavily escorted by fighters, and destroying "a considerable number" of the enemy.

In a war-torn world in which the tempo of living has been greatly accelerated, the modern doughboy, having obtained the bride-to-be's "yes," wants to get married as quickly as possible, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Legal Aid Society in the headquarters of the Downtown Association, 60 Pine Street.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Post-war Poland will be a democratic republic, with a government responsible to a freely elected Parliament safeguarding equality and justice, politically and socially. This solemn pledge was given yesterday by the Polish Government at the opening in London of the second wartime substitute Parliament, the National Council.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 25 (Science Service) -- Exploring outward in the time and space of the universe, Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of Harvard Observatory, in the closing address of the Inter-American Astrophysical Conference here tonight, declared that by studying hundreds of thousands of great systems of stars, each comparable to our own Milky Way, it should be possible to work out whence our own system of stars came and where it is going.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Lehigh gained an overtime 53-51 victory over Rutgers tonight in a Middle Three basketball contest. Jack Lane threw in a set shot from center court to decide the issue with one minute remaining in the extra period.

Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved within a narrow range early in the session yesterday, but in late trading steady hedging and liquidation caused a sharp setback and the list ended with net losses of 14 to 22 points, or 70 cents to $1.10 a bale.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Four exhausted survivors of the torpedoed 9,262-ton Belgian freighter Gandia, who saw twenty-four of their comrades collapse and die while adrift more than three weeks in their lifeboat, were landed here today by the Portuguese fishing trawler Corte Real.

Members of the Tammany executive committee that ousted Christopher D. Sullivan as leader moved yesterday for delay in the selection of a new leader. The executive committee will meet tomorrow afternoon and it is proposed then to move to adjourn for four weeks or a month.

German thoroughness is very thorough but not quite so wonderfully thorough as we are sometimes led to believe. The Foreign Office at Berlin reproves President Roosevelt on Washington's Birthday for violating the spirit of "Washington's political legacy which is read solemnly on Feb. 22 every year to Congress."

Stocks of light fuel oil along the Atlantic seaboard at the close of last week amounted to 9,053,000 barrels, a drop of 1,275,000 from the 10,328,000 reported a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Heavy fuel oil supplies were down 996,000 barrels to 7,590,000.

The Bankers Foreign Exchange Committee, headed by R.F. Loree, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, announced yesterday the receipt of the following cable message from the London Exchange Control:

A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., the sporting goods concern, has sold to the Dean-Sixth Realty Corporation, representing the Pickwick Cosmetics Corporation, I. Perimutter, president, the six-story concrete industrial building and the one-story office building on the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn.

Operations of the New York Curb Exchange last year resulted in a $55,871 excess of expenses over income or, after charge-offs and adjustments, a net loss of $93,461. Before depreciation of $104,949 and amortization of other items amounting to $8,233, the Curb showed an operating profit of $57,311, against $5,514 in the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Representative Dickstein charged today that William Drechsel, whom he described as "the nation's No. 1 Nazi," supplied "more than thirty guards" for the former French liner Normandie, which burned and capsized at its New York pier on Feb. 9.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A bill introduced today by Senator Murray of Montana, and backed by members of the Small Business Committee which he heads, asks the government to give financial relief to retail dealers in automobiles and other rationed articles.

Professor John H.H. Lyon of Columbia University gave a luncheon yesterday in the Cafe Lounge of the Savoy-Plaza. Among big guests were Princess Windisch-Graetz, Mrs. Prince Sykes, Mrs. Georg Gripenberg, Mrs. George Blumenthal, Mrs. Victor Morawetz, Lawrence Smith Butler, Reginald T. Townsend, Commander Cobb, R.N.; James H. Van Alen and Basil Davenport.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Best hogs again brought $13.25 a hundredweight on the livestock market today, equal to the four-year peak reached twice previously in the last ten days, as prices generally advanced 15 to 25 cents in active trading. In the dressed meat market, light pork loins were up another cent a pound at 26 to 27 cents.

Nat Smilen, 44 years old, president of a retail, fruit and vegetable chain-store corporation that does a $3,000,000 yearly business, was sentenced to one year in the penitentiary yesterday by Justices Troy, Hackenburg and Flood in Special Sessions for testifying falsely before the grand jury two years ago in its investigation of racketeering by a group of union leaders, all of whom now are in State prison.

Every one working for the cause of the United Nations has to "go 120 per cent," especially in the next few months, "when things are going to be bad," Jan Masaryk, Vice Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Czechoslovak Government-in-Exile, declared yesterday.

Having been associated with many shows as a writer, the next step in Max Liebman's Broadway career is to turn producer. He is planning to take this step immediately with the Norma Mitchell-John Harris collaboration entitled "Autumn Hill," formerly identified as "Fool's Paradise."

Promulgation by April 1 or earlier of the official women's garment regulations designed to conserve fabrics is desirable to avoid confusion in the production of initial Fall lines, according to comment in the women's garment field here yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Dealing with the cigarette and tobacco situation in Britain, Lord Dulverton, chairman of the Imperial Tobacco Company, in a statement yesterday said that the acute shortage had been replaced not by a period of plenty but by one in which smokers generally could obtain as much to smoke as could reasonably be 'expected in these times of stringency.

Buying was brisk, but spotty, yesterday at the New York Gift Show in the Hotel Pennsylvania, Dollar volume as a whole continued to run about 25 per cent over a year ago, but much of the activity was concentrated in metal wares and in the showrooms of a few other manufacturers whose lines were new and exceptional.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The text of a Navy commuique issued today follows:
TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- Governor Charles Edison announced today that two weeks ago he had received and had just accepted the resignation of Brig. Gen. Richard P. Williams as State Secretary for Defense.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 25 -- A thousand-mile journey by an amateur crew of eleven from the Solomon Islands to Mackay, a settlement on the Queensland coast, was described here by members of the group today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Soon after the battle of Pearl Harbor the Navy, in announcing the death of Captain Mervyn S. Bennion pointed out that the officer had declined to leave the bridge of his ship even after his stomach had been laid open by the splinter of a bomb.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- More than 100 members of the C.I.O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee picketed the main gates of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation in Gary, Ind., tonight for the purpose of preventing members who are behind in their union dues from working.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The situation in the Far East offset the satisfactory war news from Russia on the stock markets today. Gilt-edged issues maintained their prices but home rails were dull.
With the exception of one match, the opening round of the invitation squash tennis tournament at the Whitehall Club was completed yesterday.
Just to prove that even a Sportsmen's Show can have an academic touch, or should we say influence, Professor John Alden Knight came riding out of the (near) west and settled down in the Mills booth.

Rene Froehlich, German-born trainee who was taken from his post on Governors Island to answer to charges of espionage for Hitler, took his turn on the witness stand in Federal court yesterday to deny the allegations. Mrs. Helen Pauline Mayer completed her testimony during the morning session.

The National Housing Agency, which the President has created by executive order, will take the place of sixteen governmental subdivisions which have been giving some or all of their attention to housing. They include the United States Housing Authority, which stood for good housing as a necessary reform.

The National A.A.U. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday have drawn the fastest quartets of the season for what looms as the best relay racing card the meet ever has had. Meet Director Dan Ferris yesterday completed his seedings for the sprint medley and mile relays and announced his full field for the two-mile relay.

Willcox . ikdsit and David iVfcElroy of the University Club started defense' of their metropolitan squash racquets doubles title by defeating Ivy Lee Jr., University Club, and Villiam J. IVfcQueenay, Sleepy Hollow, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 9, as the eleventh annual championship got under way at the University Club and Heights Casino last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Major Gen. Joseph W. Stillwell, who has gone to China on a secret mission, was nominated by President Roosevelt today for promotion to the rank of lieutenant general. His nomination was included in a list of twenty officers.
Countess Giuseppe Cippico of the Waldorf-Astoria and Southbury, Conn., has gone to Belleair, Fla., for a stay of several weeks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- An investigation of anti-liquor activities in the capital was demanded in the House today by Representative Sweeney of Ohio.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Republican majority in the Senate defeated by a straight party vote today a motion by Senator Dunnigan, the minority leader, to discharge from the Public Service Committee his bill seeking to write into the State law that no increase in subway fares in New York City could be made until the people of the city had decided that question by referendum this Fall.

The First Boston Corporation and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $3,750,000 of Chicago North Western Railway Company ten-year serial equipment trust certificates in a sale marked by extremely close competition.

A curtailment in colored inks will be the chief effect of the present shortages in chemicals and metals and plenty of black ink will be available for newspapers, magazines and books, manufacturers of printing inks reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Imports of tea into the United States are continuing and will continue as long as the sea lanes around Africa and Australia are open to American shipping, informed sources in Washington said today.

"Roxie Hart," which enters its second week today at the Roxy, grossed in excess of $70,000 for its first week, the management estimated yesterday. Receipts through Monday totaled $62,009, the theatre stated. . . . "Johnny Eager" begins a second and final week today at the Capitol. . . .
We English-speaking peoples have been brought up in a tradition which finds one of its best expressions on the fields of sport. It seems to me that many of us have forgotten that tradition now.

Now that General MacArthur has paid his tribute to the efficacy of the Garand there is every reason why John C. Garand, if he were that kind of an inventor, should put his thumbs in his armpits, puff on his cigar and say, "I told you so ten years ago." What General MacArthur reports is no news at all to Garand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Through an agreement reached between the National Symphony Orchestra Association and the Musicians Protective Union, the orchestra's 1942-43 season will consist of a twenty-week Winter season and a six-week series of Watergate concerts in the Summer, it was announced today by Corcoran Thom, president of the orchestra's board of directors.
CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 25 (AP) -- An Australian communique today said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Such tremendous blows have been dealt to Japan's Navy and merchant marine that if the rate of destruction continues for one year, her eventual doom will be sealed, United States naval officials indicated tonight.

New York City's famous gas-lit era finally flickered out yesterday when the flames of two gas street lamps, only survivors of the thousands whose dim yellow beams formerly illumined night life in the city, were extinguished in Macdougal Alley in Greenwich Village.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that the holders of $15,093,800 face value of outstanding debentures of the United Light and Power Company are not entitled to receive a premium of 9 per cent on their holdings in the liquidation and dissolution of the company in obedience to an order which was issued by the commission under the Holding Company Act.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- District school superintendents were told today that rationing of sugar of all kinds, brown, white, confectioners' and the like, would begin about March 28. This was stated at the first meeting of registration and rationing officials.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Scoring in every period, the Baltimore Orioles defeated the New York Rovers, 5 to 3, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League match tonight. The game was fast throughout, but only one penalty was called.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 25 (AP) -- An Army communiqe today said:

Donald W. Douglas, president of the Douglas Aircraft Company, reported yesterday to stockholders that in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 sales were triple those of the preceding year and earnings were up to a new high.

Spring colors for shoes were displayed yesterday by I. Miller in a coordinated fashion show at the concern's Long Island City factory. Patriotic colors predominated, with bright footwear setting the keynote for wartime styles in uniforms, gowns and hats.

Both at Honolulu and at Manila, Boy Scouts were on the job. They proved their steadiness and usefulness in first, aid, guiding ambulances to hospitals, carrying messages, fighting fire, serving food, placing evacuees and looking after children. The 50,000 Boy Scouts of this city are being trained for similar duties and are taking their place on the home front in many useful ways.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 -- Asking $215,890.13 damages, a suit against the American Guild of Variety Artists has been brought by Earl Carroll, producer, through the Hollywood Theatrical Corporation.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Feb. 25 -- State and Federal mediation forces intervened today in a dispute between 160 welders working on defense orders and officials of the local ship repair yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company. The trouble started with a strike this morning of 125 members of the day shift.

Once again it has been necessary for the President, with all the burdens that are on him, to plead with the Congressional farm bloc not to do "irreparable damage to the war effort." And once again the Congressional farm bloc has recklessly ignored his appeal and bluntly rejected his leadership.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Congressman Raul Damonte Taborda, wounded hero of a sabre duel with Lieut. Col. Enrique Rottjers, a political opponent, today rallied pro-democratic factions in their drive for Congressional seats in Sunday's elections against National Democratic and other Rightist candidates supporting the isolationist policies of the administration of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Navy today reported the results of its fighting on two fronts -- the Western Atlantic where its enemy is the Nazi submarine, and the Pacific where it is battling the Japanese from California to the gates of the Indian Ocean.

Mrs. Beatrice de Tavaro, 66 years old, a first cousin of the late George B. McClellan, former Mayor, received a suspended sentence yesterday from Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions in what the court described as a "premeditated assault" on an elderly process server.

Following a ruling by the Federal Communications Commission against Mayor La Guardia's request that WNYC, the city station, be permitted to broadcast at night, city officials will appeal for an oral argument before the FCC in an effort to change the decision, it was learned yesterday.

Enemy submarines have sunk two more ships in waters off our East Coast, it was disclosed yesterday. They were the twentieth and twenty-first vessels known to have been sent to the bottom since the undersea warfare began on Jan. 14, and brought the total of tonnage known to have been destroyed to 147,059.

SOMEWHERE IN JAVA, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Her executive officer lay badly wounded, her steering engine was out of commission and live steam was driving a gun crew from its station, but the old United States destroyer never faltered in the battle line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Army Air Corps planes fighting in the Battle of the Pacific added today to their already impressive score two more large Japanese transports, two Japanese bombers and a fighting plane, the War Department announced in communiques. There were no American losses.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Guy (Red) Mackey and Elmer Burnham today were appointed athletic director and head football coach, respectively, at Purdue University. The announcement was made by President Edward C. Elliott after a meeting of the board of trustees.

Herbert L. Howe, librarian of the American Merchant Marine Library, who has sorted 250,000 gift books himself, has a few words to say in the latest Wilson Library Bulletin about the types of contributions that will come in to the Victory Book Campaign as it continues toward its goal of 10,000,000 books for the armed services.

In the difficult-to-define category is the cracker that is really a cereal and the cereal that may be used like a cracker. For such is a fragile brittle biscuit about the size and shape of a chocolate brownie, though perhaps only half as thick. This biscuit, or cereal-cracker, is made of crumbly layers of flaked wholewheat and packs enough Vitamin B for the health of a kindergarten and the morale of a regiment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- American high schools were urged today to teach "as vigorously as possible" that this country "is now and forever bound up in the affairs of the world; that it is foolish for it ever again to retreat to the position of isolation."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 25 -- United States Ambassador Claude G. Bowers called on President-elect Juan Antonio Rios this morning in a courtesy visit, which is said to have taken place in an atmosphere of cordiality.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- The Russians' encirclement of a large area around Staraya Russa, where the German Sixteenth Army, under Col. Gen. von Busch, occupied strongly protected positions, puts within the Red Army's grasp a region that may become a springboard for the future offensive operations envisaged by Premier Joseph Stalin's recent order to his forces.

Workmen in an aeronautical plant brought before a Queens magistrate for smoking inside it were curiously defended by a trade union functionary. He said the offenders had smoked only in the washroom, esteemed fireproof. The magistrate imposed a fine. Refusal by the management of the "right" to smoke in the washroom of a factory has caused strikes elsewhere.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- James Craig will play the male lead opposite Maureen O'Hara in RKO's "One Hour of Glory," a story by Mary Roberts Rinehart about snobbery in Washington society. RKO has exercised an option on the "Gay Falcon" yarns by Michael Arlen and will continue its series based on the stories for another year.

HONOLULU, Feb. 25 -- Youthful Americans of Japanese ancestry piled into army trucks and left for a camp "somewhere on Oahu" today as a volunteer labor battalion, having offered their services to Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commander of the Hawaiian Department, "for whatever service you see fit."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Of 1,084 enemy aliens who have been heard by local boards and passed upon by Attorney General Biddle, 448 have been interned for the duration of the war, 421 have been paroled and 215 released outright, Mr. Biddle said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The revolutionary form of ocean freighte known as the "Sea Otter" will probably not be constructed beyond the one experimental ship now undergoing tests, Secretary Knox indicated today. He gave this intimation in a discussion of findings which he said had caused disappointment to President Roosevelt and himself.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- The National Retail Furniture Association, through Roscoe Rau, executive vice president, insisted today that there will be no direct or other purchasing of consequence by the government of furniture for the defense housing program.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 25 -- Italian public pessimism about the duration of the war has reached a point where Premier Benito Mussolini has stepped out of his official "silence" to launch a blast against those inside the country who "continually talk of peace."

The American Red Cross, in cooperation with the Office of Civilian Defense, has trained or is training 10,000 nurses' aides throughout the country. That is the number needed for New York City alone and is only one-tenth of the quota set for the United States up to the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Seven aircraft manufacturers are already erecting duplicate plants, or completing arrangements for construction, away from the Pacific and Atlantic coasts. This was told as the air raid alarm at Los Angeles today focused attention on the fact that more than half of our airplane plants are on or near the Pacific coast, where they are subject to air attacks.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Liquidation by tired longs was in evidence in wheat from the opening today and continued until the close, with final sales on the Board of Trade near the bottom at losses of 1 1/8 cents a bushel. Reports from Minneapolis indicated the same condition prevailed in that market.

The Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 25,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, series C, of $100 a share par value. The stock will be underwritten and offered to the public by a group headed by the Union Securities Corporation.

The Fordham University basketball team, a little slow in starting but, once under way, moving in clockwork fashion, beat Brooklyn College, 62 to 49, in the Rams' gymnasium last night. Brooklyn led early in the game but after that it was all Fordham.

Robert Goldsand, Viennese pianist, whose last recital here won him the award for the outstanding Town Hall recital by an artist under 30 during 1940, gave last night the recital that was his reward. It was the seventh event in the twelfth Town Hall Endowment Series.

Private Joe Louis of the United States Army soon will make a donation to the Army Emergency Fund that will be comparable to his donation to the Navy Relief Society. Yesterday the world heavyweight champion signed for the twenty-first defense of his title against Abe Simon at Madison Square Garden on Friday, March 27.

Hitler's latest message, addressed particularly to the Nazi chiefs on the twenty-second anniversary of the party platform, shows that he is still troubled with obsessions. A good psychiatrist might relieve him of them, but apparently he hasn't got a good psychiatrist.

THE TIMES'S editorial of Feb. 20 which surveyed the situation of civilian defense seems to be unique among recent newspaper comments on the subject -- it does make a certain amount of sense. There is need for a good deal more comment and thought of this type and almost no necessity for the kind of intemperate criticism which the OCD has had in the past couple of weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- March tire and tube allotments for passenger cars and light trucks were fixed today by Leon Henderson, the Price Administrator, at levels more than 25 per cent greater than those for the current month. Allotments for heavy trucks, buses, farm equipment and other heavy vehicles were increased by even wider margin as compared with the current month.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Feb. 26 -- An estimated 300,000 German soldiers in the central Russian sector early yesterday morning began what the Moscow spokesman called "a battle for their very existence" as Soviet troops on two fronts in the neighborhood of Dorogobuzh started closing one of the largest pincers yet attempted in this war.
BANDUNG, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Authoritative Netherland sources warned tonight that this island stronghold was now encircled and declared that "considerable reinforcements" were urgently needed.

In a recent list of apartment rentals, the Fred F. French Management Company was inadvertently referred to as agent for London Terrace. The leases referred to were in Tudor City buildings, for which the French concern is agent. Wm. A. White Sons are agents for London Terrace.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 25 -- After five years of superficial respectability as the wife of a local realty broker and church leader, Mrs. Amelia M. Carr, flimflam queen and ex-convict, was placed behind prison bars today to serve an eight to twelve-year sentence on eight complaints of fraud.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Speaking at the annual dinner of the Republican State Committee tonight its chairman, Edwin F. Jaeckle, toasted the nation's armed forces and their Commander in Chief President Roosevelt and pledged the unquestioned loyalty of the party in the State to the country's war efforts.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Bills barring Federal elective officials from benefiting from the State retirement system if any future Federal law again makes them eligible for Federal pensions were introduced in the Senate today by Senators Wallace and Burney, Republicans.
The text of Ambassador Litvinoff's address last might before the Overseas Press Club at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel follows:

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Arthur F. Foran, State milk director, who had threatened to stop the sale of two-for-a-nickel half-pints of milk to school children here because local health officials insisted on hood instead of plug-type bottle caps, disclosed today that the sales would continue.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, February (Delayed) -- The crew members of the Coast Guard cutter Alexander Hamilton conducted themselves like steady, unruffled Navy veterans during the exciting moments after she had been torpedoed somewhere off the coast of Iceland, the vessel's officers said today.

In what is believed to be the first such step by an asociation, the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association has selected an alternate slate of officers to replace any of the incumbents who is called into the armed services, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- General Charles de Gaulle, head of the Free French organization, has summoned Vice Admiral Emile Muselier, chief of the Free French forces at St. Pierre-Miquelon, and Adrien P. Tixier, Free French agent in Washington, to London for consultations, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, warned tonight that England and America were in danger of winning the war but losing the peace unless they stopped "pulling one another apart," and presented instead a home front which the Nazis with their "arsenal of lies" could not breach.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Lefty Gomez's plaintive distress calls for Johnny Murphy were answered today. The Bronx Fireman, so-called because of his success in extinguishing the blazes which menaced so many of the fifteen games Gomez won last year, signed a contract after four days as a determined holdout, pledging himself to come running at the slightest alarm in aid of Gomez or any other hurler on the Yankee staff this year.
Mr. and Mrs. George Arents of 6 East Seventy-seventh Street are at the Breakers, Palm Beach.

A tract of about thirty acres of land in the Lakeville section of Nassau County, near the Queens County line, ha been sold by the Rolling Ridge Estates and the Lakeville Realty Corporation in a cash deal to a client of the Herbert Callman Company, brokers.
CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 26 -- Japanese aircraft made a reconnaissance flight over the Darwin area at a great height about noon today, but no bombs were dropped.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company reported yesterday in its twenty-fifth annual statement a net profit of $8,821,437 in 1941, after a reserve of $8,150,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes, special write-offs and other charges.

The continued growth in population in the District of Columbia, together with the daily increasing war activities of the government, resulted in a record volume of business for operating subsidiaries of the Washington Railway and Electric Company during 1941, according to the company's annual report, issued for publication today.

News comes from San Pedro, Calif., that 3,500 C.I.O. workers at the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation walked out on Feb. 23. A spokesman said it was against a ten-hour day started Feb. 12.
