"This definitely is no strike," he said. "We merely called the men off the job at the end of eight hours to bring the company to terms."
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26 -- Strikes closed two defense plants in this area today, the first of the kind here since the war began, and walkouts were threatened at two others.

An ample supply of vitamins in the diet will not only provide better physical and mental health but will also foster the development of morality, Professor Roger J. Williams of the University of Texas, told a distinguished gathering of scientists at Columbia University last night.
Assisted by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, the British and American Ambulance Corps formally launched its "Show Your Colors in Your Garden" campaign yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The official wartime insignia for the American Merchant Marine, the Maritime Eagle, a symbol of Ships for Victory, was unveiled today by Mrs. Henry A. Wallace, wife of the Vice President.
Recent letters in THE TIMES over the signatures of Chauncey B. Garver and Morris L. Ernst undertake to answer a letter of mine having reference to birth control published in THE TIMES of Feb. 7.

The piers and facilities of the New York Foreign Trade Zone, with the exception of the tobacco warehouse, will be completely taken over by the Army and present users of the area are being asked to vacate within a "reasonable time," Thomas E. Lyons, executive secretary of the Free Trade Zones Board, announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26 -- The American public has been ahead of Congress at virtually every stage of the war up to Pearl Harbor and now shows evidence of being equally far ahead in its willingness to make sacrifices.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- By formal resolution, the American Association of School Administrators put itself at the country's service in making any adjustments judged necessary to "the successful conduct of the war."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- Mrs. Eugene Meyer of Mount Kisco and Washington resigned today as chairman and as a member of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, an organization she had headed since its inception in 1923 and had developed from a sponsor of a few sandlot playgrounds to a promoter of music festivals, athletic contests, arts and crafts, children's camps and the $1,250,000 County Center.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Feb. 27 -- A broadcast from Moscow last night announced that all Japanese holdings in Soviet territory had been sequestered and placed under control of a commissar for alien property by order of the Soviet Presidium.

I.J. Miranda, an investing client of Prince Ripley, brokers, has bought from Alexander H. Pincus the two-story taxpayer store and apartment building at the corner of Chatsworth and Myrtle Avenues, in Larchmont, just west of the Larchmont station of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, and next to the Chatsworth Gardens apartments.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

It fell to Mortimer N. Buckner to be head of the New York Clearing House Association from 1931 to 1933, when the American banking system was passing through its greatest crisis. Few other men could have been so well qualified for that heavy and almost thankless task.

Yesterday's weekly statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities increased $12,426,000; they were at the highest point since November, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Several United States diplomatic and consular officials in the war zones of the Far East were reported today by the State Department to be safe. They include the staff in Burma.

Warning that the farm labor situation in the East probably is more acute than in any other section of the country and that it will be a more difficult problem this year than in 1941, Dr. Thomas B. Symons, dean and director of the University of Maryland extension service, urged yesterday the adoption of a rule of "work or fight."

Eleventh-hour pleas for support of the campaign for $750,000 to finance the modernization of St. Vincent's Hospital were made yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore by Alfred E. Smith, chairman of the building fund; Archbishop Francis J. Spellman and Mayor La Gua dia.

The governors of the Bond Club of New York have voted unanimously to discontinue for this year the annual field day and publication of The Bawl Street Journal, it was disclosed yesterday, ending a record of twenty-one consecutive annual outings of the club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- An exchange of letters between Secretary Ickes and Representative Taber of New York has caused amusement here. After President Roosevelt suggested recently that "parasites" move out of Washington to make room for war workers, Representative Taber named Mr. Ickes as one who "unquestionably falls in this category."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -Admiral William H. Standley, retired, a member of the commission that drew up the Roberts report on the Pearl Harbor attacks, said here today that the report had been "misunderstood or misinterpreted."

The Frank G. Shattuck Company, operator of the Schrafft's chain of restaurants and confectionery stores, has purchased in an all-cash deal from the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., paint manufacturers, the three-story factory building at 460-6 Smith Street, on the southwest corner of Huntington Street, and a connecting two-story L-shaped structure facing on West Ninth Street, known as 197-9, in South Brooklyn.
The love of a homing pigeon for its "civilian" pals and its master is stronger than the confining walls of a United States Army pigeon coop.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Sparrows, starlings, crows, larks, curlews and even swans -- some of them counted inedible in peacetime or too small to bother with -are helping to feed Great Britain at war.

BATAVIA, Friday, Feb. 27 -- The consolidation of Japanese control in south Sumatra and Borneo and the occupation of Banka, revealed in the latest communique here, mean firmer Japanese control of land bodies near Java and a further enhancement of the Japanese position in relation to the anticipated invasion of Java.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- A Chinese Government spokesman said today that 52,000 Japanese troops were massed in Northwestern Thailand in apparent preparation for an imminent drive on Northern Burma.

Warning against strikes and interruption of war work was sounded last night at a meeting sponsored by the American Communications Association, C.I.O., to start a nation-wide effort on the part of all union locals for the donation of blood to the Red Cross and for the sale of defense bonds and stamps.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -President Roosevelt elevated legations in Bolivia, Ecuador and Paraguay to the status of embassies, promoting Boaz Long and Wesley Frost, Ministers to Ecuador and Paraguay, respectively, to the rank of Ambassador and nominating Pierre del Boal to be Ambassador to Bolivia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The United States and Filipino defenders of Bataan peninsula, who for weeks fought desperately in an effort to hold their lines, have taken the initiative and pushed back the Japanese "all along the line," the War Department announced today.

The weird story of what happened to two little men from New Jersey who fell under the spell of a big man from Manhattan was related yesterday as a background to a warning from J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

A man who is actually supporting a wife or family and whose marriage did not take place when drafting was imminent need not fear induction into military service merely because his dependents might be able to "eke out a bare existence during his absence," Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Director of Selective Service for New York City, declared yesterday at a Salvation Army campaign luncheon at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.
Harold Mittelstadt has been elected president of Wilson Brothers Men's Wear. He was vice president and general manager. He succeeds Charles G. Little, who has been elected chairman of the board.

Any enemy of the United Nations who wishes to contrive their defeat in this war will do what he can to stir up trouble between the United States and Britain. Any enemy of humanity who does not desire to see this earth organized for peace will do the same thing.

Soaring prices for second-hand tires are creating a major problem in the scrap rubber market and are bringing pressure for the fixing of price ceilings, it was reported yesterday. Price ceilings have already been fixed for new tires and tubes that can be purchased only by a restricted group of buyers, with the approval of local rationing boards.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The action of the Senate in overriding, 50 to 23, the President's plea against pegging farm prices at artificially high levels should be viewed against the general background of current pressure group activities. When the following concomitant circumstances are noted, the Senate's vote can be analyzed as merely the effort of one economic class to keep pace with others in a scramble for special privileges:

The only sane solution for protecting the credit of customers who are unable to buy sufficient materials to carry on their normal business is for credit managers of companies carrying them on their books to see that they get war work, according to Harry J. Delaney of Meinhard Greeff Co., factors, president of the New York Credit Men's Association.
Spring ensembles that had the freshness and appeal of a new season in their treatment, designed by Norell of Traina-Norell, were presented yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Pierre.

With manufacturers of refrigerators and washing machines scheduled to convert their facilities to war work, makers of electric ranges will be next on the list, according to reports in the local appliance market yesterday. Some production may continue for defense housing or other government needs but it is expected to be chiefly of the "cook-stove" variety, which is the government term for cheap, stripped models.

Especially in a war in which Fifth Column work has played an important part in the immense successes of our enemies, it is essential that genuine military secrets be guarded closely. The most elementary considerations of self-preservation, and of loyalty to our armed forces in the field, require this.

Paul J. Kern, ousted president of the Civil Service Commission, predicted yesterday that his departure from city service would be temporary when he sent a letter to the employes of the commission criticizing Mayor La Guardia for removing him with Commissioner Wallace S. Sayre.

HONOLULU, Feb. 26 -- The Army announced today that "about thirty additional Japanese enemy aliens or suspected sympathizers are now being detained" at Hilo, on the island of Hawaii. They were taken into custody during the past few days.

Buyers returned yesterday to the stock market with sufficient aggressiveness to give the list a slight push, but the rally came too late to allow the advance to be distributed evenly. After moving narrowly in dull trading through the greater part of the session, the market perked up in the final hour under the leadership of the rails.

BATAVIA, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- A group of 170 evacuees from the city of Banjermassin in South Borneo, most of them Roman Catholic priests and nuns, said today that the Netherlanders had destroyed all important installations before the Japanese occupation earlier this month.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 26 -Closing disputes and negotiations covering nearly 150 years, Great Britain today ceded to Venezuela her claim to Patos Island, a tiny piece of land between the eastern tip of this country and Trinidad inhabited by wild ducks and occasionally by fishermen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it has worked out a "tire return plan" under which dealers and jobbers can dispose of their stocks of new passenger car tires and tubes, thus getting relief from the financial burden of carrying such stocks during a period in which they can make few sales under the tire rationing regulations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Securities with a face value of $225,171,000, almost double the volume of the preceding month, were registered in January under the Securities Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Steel plate production for sale in January amounted to 713,182 net tons, against 635,812 tons in December and a monthly average of 502,250 net tons in 1941, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Output was at the rate of 118.2 per cent of plate mill capacity, against 106.6 per cent for all 1941, reflecting increased production of plates on sheet and strip mills.

A liberal supply of carnations in city markets this week-end makes these flowers a popular choice for home decoration. A wide range of colors is available, from pure white through pink to scarlet and dark red.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 26 -- Wendell L. Willkie, Republican candidate for the Presidency in 1940, called upon the United States tonight to take aggressive action in the war against the Axis. "Let's begin to strike" and "let's begin to win," he said.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Department store sales continued to show a large increase over a year ago and for the week ended Feb. 21 were 25 per cent greater, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. For the four-week period ended Feb. 21 and for the year up to that date the sales were 23 per cent and 2 per cent, respectively, above the like periods of 1941.

The insurgents whose complaints precipitated an investigation by Governor Lehman into the financial affairs of Local 17 of the International Hod Carriers and Common Laborers Union, A.F. of L., won control of the union yesterday as the result of an election conducted under court order.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- An expanded program of aluminum production which will reach the staggering total of more than 2,500,000,000 pounds a year was announced today by William L. Batt, head of the materials division of the War Production Board.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 26 -Germany's capacity for producing synthetic petroleum lubricating oils and other motor fuels is now reported to approximate 5,200,000 tons annually, according to estimates of the Economist, a well-known Netherland publication.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Floor covering manufacturers were advised by the War Production Board today to get their mills ready to handle war contracts in preparation for a day in the near future when they will be ordered to suspend production of rugs and carpets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Truman committee investigating defense matters will hear Leon Henderson, Administrator of Price Control, Thursday concerning the extent to which rubber will be available for nonmilitary uses.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 26 -George Cvek, 24-year-old hitch-hiking vagrant, was put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison tonight for the murder of Mrs. Catherine Pappas, who was strangled to death and robbed in her Bronx apartment on Feb. 4, 1941.

TOKYO, Feb. 26 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Headquarters said today that an "enemy aircraft carrier" was severely damaged and set afire last Saturday when several Japanese naval planes plunged headlong onto her, detonating their still-racked bombs in the crash.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- The House burst into heated debate today over charges by Representative Pheiffer of New York City that the Navy was giving "favored treatment" to Lieutenant Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

Eight pianists will perform compositions from the album "Homage to Paderewski" at the concert to be given tonight at 9 o'clock at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. M. Barlow, 11 Gramercy Park, for the benefit of the Paderewski Memorial Hospital in Edinburgh, Scotland.

Beginning on March 16, commissions on the New York Stock Exchange will be increased an average of a little more than 25 per cent and the minimum commission lifted to $5 from $3. The new schedule, announced yesterday, has been submitted to the membership in the form of a constitutional revision.
BERLIN, Feb. 26 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press ) -- The German High Command issued this special announcement today:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The listening post system by means of which the government analyzes foreign radio broadcasts now has a staff of 300 to 350 experts.

A first-period outburst which netted them four goals aided the Rangers tremendously in their game with the Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. The National Hockey League leaders encountered somewhat stubborn opposition in the succeeding sessions, but the Detroiters found themselves espousing a lost cause and had to skate off the ice on the short end of a 7-to-4 count.

Serene is the scene in metropolitan markets this week-end. Many meats wear price tags identical with those of last Friday. The few fluctuations that have occurred are definitely in the downward direction. Center chops of pork -- the one exception to this trend -- are averaging 39 cents a pound, a penny higher than they were a week ago, with the range from 35 to 41 cents.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The War Department issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The State Department is being pressed today to ask Great Britain for an immediate pledge of post-war self-government for India. Influential members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, it is learned, have made such a demand on Breckenridge Long, Assistant Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The House defeated by 218 to 14 today an effort to block a vote on a proposal by Representative Smith of Virginia to suspend during the war the work hour limitations found in seventeen Federal laws. Thus a ballot tomorrow on this proposal was assured.

If the two gas street lamps in Macdougal Alley, whose light was put out for good Wednesday, are the last of their kind in this town, as is said, we have a date, an end of an era, to store up in memory and bore our grandchildren with. Illuminating gas was in no hurry to come here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Black Hawks scored all of their goals in a wild second period tonight as they defeated the Canadiens, 5 to 4, in a National Hockey League game. Three of the Chicago goals were tallied within a minute and 18 seconds.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The stock markets today saw a slump in Dorman Long shares on the passing of the dividends on the ordinary and preferred ordinary stocks. The ordiary fell sharply and other steel shares were dull in sympathy.
The resale by an operator of a blockfront yesterday featured realty activity in the Washington Heights and West Side areas.
ENID, Okla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- A Rock Island freight train tore through a bus here today, killing seven enlisted men in the Army Air Corps.

Ending speculation on the possibility of producing "tinless" cans through special treatment of black plate and lacquering or enameling, the Parker Rust-Proof Company, Detroit, yesterday made the first official announcement of the availability of its Bonderizing process for steel and other container metals, which will save several thousand long tons of tin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Representative Baldwin, Republican, of New York City, said today that he believed that Lewis E. Lawes, former warden of Sing Sing, would make a good Representative from New York's twenty-sixth district, which now is represented by Hamilton Fish.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- Anti-aircraft batteries which poured hundreds of rounds of shells at unidentified planes in the night sky above Los Angeles yesterday received official commendation today from Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt, Western defense commander, for their "readiness to meet possible enemy action."

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 26 -- Two more enemy troopships, a naval auxiliary and a freighter have been torpedoed by United States submarines in the intensive United Nations counteraction against Japanese invasion trains massing in these waters, the Netherlands Indies High Command announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Senate took under consideration today the $32,762,737,900 supplemental bill for war expenses, but withheld action when leaders, fearing that the farm bloc might be able to add an amendment prohibiting sale of government-owned farm products at less than parity prices, postponed the vote until Monday to gain time.

Sefton Tranter of the New York A.C., third in the favored group in the invitation squash tennis tournament at the Whitehall Club, was put out of the running yesterday in the quarter-final round when O. Donald Noble of the Crescent A.C. came from behind to win, 6 -- 15, 15 -- 12, 18 -- 13.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $165,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $885,000,000, lowest since Nov. 12, 1941, reflecting heavy purchases here of the new government 2 1/4 per cent bond issue.

What has become of our forward looking, imaginative, courageous and daring people who builded this country to its greatness? I hear on all sides the word "defense" until I am sick at heart. A country that adopts a policy of defense is doomed, because it would take numerous armies to anticipate on every side the attack of even an inferior enemy.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 27 (AP) -Germany's organized "pillage masquerading as purchase" in occupied Europe has reached such proportions that 500,000 Greeks probably will die from hunger this Winter, "and one whole generation appears to be already doomed," the Inter-Allied Information Committee said today.

Archibald MacLeish calls the Library of Congress the physiological nerve center of today's fighting country and the most expressive symbol of the principles for which the nation fights. Mr. MacLeish, as librarian, has written the introduction to a full-length history of the library that will make its appearance late next month under the Lippincott imprint.

Three of the six persons on trial in Federal court on espionage charges were on the witness stand yesterday. Rene Froehlich finished his testimony begun earlier; Frederick Edward Schlosser began and ended his, and Paul T. Borchardt opened his defense statements.

The bill to forbid the sale of government-held crop surpluses at prices below "parity," which the Senate passed in disregard of the President's plea, is calculated to raise the cost of living $1,000,000,000. This is a serious matter for the consumers of the country.

I notice that contributors to your columns are preoccupied with the grave and doubtless urgent question of what we shall do with Hirohito and the Japanese throne -- presumably after we have gone through the routine formality of sending a few reinforcements to Bataan Peninsula and quite a lot of other places.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Jockey Eddie Wielander, 18-year-old apprentice from Cicero, Ill., practically unknown to Easterners before the present meeting, scored four times at Hialeah Park today, but missed the main race in his sweep. Curious Roman captured the featured Greynolds Park purse with Leon (Buddy) Haas aboard, while Wielander read a book in the jockey's quarters, having no mount in the race.

Reflecting payments of subscriptions to the recent $1,500,000,000 government bond issue, member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, in the week ended on Wednesday, showed a sharp decline in excess reserves, a heavy increase in holdings of government bonds, a substantial decline in demand deposits, a moderate decline in out-of-town bank deposits here and a sharp increase in government deposits.

The first ad in the cooperative advertising campaign of the Savings Banks of New York State will break today in newspapers with the theme "Foolish Spending Is Sabotage." More than ninety mutual savings banks are cooperating in the campaign, which will run for a year in about 200 daily and weekly newspapers in the State.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (A.P.) -- Prices of hogs held steady today, with best offerings again selling at $13.25 a hundred pounds. All classes in the cattle section met a good demand. The lamb market was slow but prices held steady.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 (AP) -Fletcher Bowron, former newspaper man who was swept into the Mayor's office on a reform wave three and a half years ago, was accused by the county grand jury today of wilful misconduct in office. Conviction on the indictment would involve only dismissal from the Mayoralty.

The First Boston Corporation and associates received the award yesterday of $4,000,000 city of Tacoma, Wash., light and power revenue bonds at a net interest cost basis to the city of 2.72027 per cent. The winning tender was 100.28 for $1,850,000 as 3s, $975,000 as 2 1/2s and $1,175,000 as 2 3/4s.

Formation of a war committee act as a liaison instrument between industry and the War Production Board and other government agencies having to do with output of war supplies and equipment was announced yesterday by William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, following approval of the action by the association's board of directors.

A large exhibition of prints entitled "Between Two Wars," selected and arranged by Carl Zigrosser, curator of prints at the Philadelphia Museum, will open at the Whitney Museum on Tuesday. These prints, by American artists, cover the period between 1914 and 1941 in the development of American art.

Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Ambassador to the United States last night urged the United Nations to launch simultaneous offensives against the Axis this Spring on two or more widely separated fronts, and at the same time to supply Russia with materials for the Eastern front by Spring, in order that she may keep the initiative she has now seized.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- A hearing on the "serious shortage" of farm labor alleged to result from the drafting of farm youth was ordered today by Representative Fulmer, chairman of the Agriculture Committee. Mr. Fulmer named to a subcommittee Representatives Flannagan, Pace, Poage, Hope and Murray.

Eastern ski enthusiasm continued to run high last night as reports from the North Country indicated that good sport will be available this week-end in the upper reaches of the Catskills, Berkshires, the Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 -- After putting his Giants through another strenuous session of batting and fielding practice, Manager Mel Ott announced today he would take twenty-six players, including himself, to Havana by plane Saturday morning for the week-end exhibition series of two games with the Dodgers.

Dr. Koussevitzky's second Thursday night concert with the philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall found the hall packed as it had not been at his first appearance. The occasion made it clear that in the week of his incumbency as guest leader he had reached a more intimate understanding with the players and that he had further clarified and sensitized the orchestral tone.

HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- Kirby Higbe was a tired if not disappointed pitcher today after getting his first workout of the season in the Dodgers' training camp. Before he left Miami for his belated appearance here, the young fireball pitcher guessed his "tongue would hang out" after the first session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The air raid alarm in the Los Angeles area yesterday morning was caused by the presence of some fifteen aircraft whose origin remain a mystery, Secretary Stimson told reporters today. The evidence suggests, the Secretary stated, that the aircraft in question were commercial planes operated by enemy agents.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Ida Lupino will play the feminine lead in the screen version of "Blind Man's House," which will go before the cameras at Twentieth Century-Fox in April, it was learned today. R.C. Sherriff has adapted the Hugh Walpole novel to the screen and Milton Sperling will produce the film.

Miss F. Tracy Haight gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Her guests included Mrs. Austen T. Gray, Mrs. Kenneth Fenton Trimingham Jr., Mrs. Stirling S. Adams, Mrs. John Wood, the Misses Helen L. Michalis, Elaine G. Eldredge and Marion S. Oates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Roosevelt nominated today L. Metcalfe Walling of Rhode Island to be administrator of the Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department, with headquarters in New York City.

Plans are going forward for the showing of a new British film, a short feature and the latest news reels, followed by a buffet supper, on the night of March 9 at the Little Carnegie Theatre, West Fifty-seventh Street, to raise funds for the Health and Personal Service Committee of Greenwich House.

Stanley Schleifer 24-year-old ex-convict, pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree murder, as his trial for the killing of Frank Clayton Cole, 62, patent attorney, was about to begin before General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein and a jury.

Once a year Dan Ferris gets very occult, dons his prophetic robes, dusts off his crystal ball and predicts the number of records that will be broken at his National A.A.U. track and field championships. Yesterday he went into his trance again and came out with the guess that at least ten marks will go at Madison Square Garden tomorrow.

Steady absorption of contracts by trade sources, coupled with some late covering operations by local interests, checked a decline in the cotton market yesterday, and at the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures showed net gains of 3 to 8 points.

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, received the medal awarded annually by the New York Academy of Public Education for "distinguished service in the field of education" at a dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Roosevelt put on Colonel Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, today primary responsibility for protecting vessels, harbors, ports and other waterfront facilities, except those operated by the War Department, in the United States and its territories against destruction or injury from accidents and sabotage "or other subversive acts."

Milk for contented curls -- soft, silky and amenable -- is the newest wrinkle at a Park Avenue salon. Not a milk shampoo in imitation of Marie Antoinette, but a revolutionary padding for permanent waves -- a gossmear fiber made of dairy fresh milk and a spot of lanolin.

ROME, Feb. 26 (from Italian broadcasts)(AP) (--Cardinal Boggianl, who had one' of the most turbulent careers' of any member of the College of Cardinals, had been in poor health for several years, lie was involved in several theological debates and at one time was the center of a dispute concerning the administration of the Archbishop of Genoa.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Henry Gordon Bennett, commander of the Australian forces in Malaya, said today that Singapore, from which he escaped in a Chinese junk after its surrender on Feb. 15, fell because of "lack of water, incessant bombing and greatly superior numbers" of the enemy.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Sir Edward Cook, whose public service career began in India in 190 but who has since 1931 been governor of the National Bank of Egypt, has been designated as China relations officer in the first series appointments to intensify cooperation between India and China.

Broadway will have to wait a while longer before seeing Katharine Cornell's next presentation. The actress-manager is winding up an eight-week tour in the Henri Bernstein play, "Rose Burke," on March 14 in Toronto, it was officially announced yesterday.

Doctors at St. Vincent's Hospital at West New Brighton, S.I., reported the birth of twin daughters joined to each other from chest to abdomen. The mother is Mrs. Jessie Picciotto, 24 years old, wife of Carmine Picciotto of 48 Scribner Avenue, New Brighton. This is said to be the first birth of Siamese twins in the history of Staten Island.

The exigencies of wartime were manifest in Milgrim's custom-made collection of Spring and Summer clothes which had its press preview yesterday afternoon. There was no waste of materials. In many of the daytime frocks four and even less yards of material were consumed. Gone were the full and sweeping skirts of past seasons. Only one romantic type of gown passed before the reviewers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Although the wheat market was firm at the start today, following announcement that the Senate had passed the Bankhead bill seeking to prevent sales of government-owned grain below parity prices, the small upturn was disappointing to the trade as a whole and sufficient professional and scattered selling developed to carry prices below yesterday's finish.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Friday, Feb. 27 -- Outnumbered, operating often from makeshift bases, virtually without weather reports, America's naval and air forces in the Netherlands Indies are daily performing acts of heroism and endurance that rank with the finest individual feats in American military history.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A Senate-House committee reached an agreement this afternoon on legislation repealing the retirement pension provisions for Congress.

Earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 3 are estimated at $10,125,000 after all charges including interest, reserves and provision for all Federal taxes, according to the official statement of the company announced yesterday.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Twenty-nine shipwrecked officers and members of the crew of an American freighter which ran aground and broke up off the North Carolina coast arrived here today after being rescued by the Coast Guard.

Maurice Eisenberg, who has given several recitals in this city since his return in 1939 after an absence of seventeen years abroad, was heard again by a large and responsive audience last night in Town Hall. The accomplished 'cellist, who was Professor of the Classe Casals at the Ecole Normale de Musique in Paris at the time he left Europe, had devised a noble program reflecting his scholarly type of approach to his art.

FORT DIX, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Arrangements to have the heavyweight champion, Private Joe Louis, train in Fort Dix's new $85,000 sports arena for his bout with Abe Simon on March 27 were completed today with Colonel Cassius M. Dowell, post commandant.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 26 -The conflict between the Arrow Cross (Nazi) party and the government party in Hungary advanced a step closer to an open break with expulsion from the Nazi organization of Koloman Hubay, Vice Fuehrer of the group, by its leader, Ferenc Szalasi.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Both the Scharnhorst and the Gneisenau, German 26,000-ton battleships, have been hit, and one of them is in drydock, A.V. Alexander, the First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Commons today in a review of the war at sea, which, he said, had now developed from a battle of the Atlantic into a battle of the seven seas.

New highs in sales of domestic wines, champagnes and brandies, particularly during the second half of this year, were forecast yesterday at the regional meeting of sales representatives of McKesson Robbins, Inc., one of the largest liquor wholesalers in the country, at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Radio Corporation of America gave national defense the right-of-way in every phase of its activities throughout 1941, David Sarnoff, president, declared yesterday in his annual report to stockholders. Calling attention to the fact that the personnel of RCA, to the extent of 30,000 workers, is responding "whole-heartedly to the war effort," the report stresses the part being played by radio in the nation's war work.

A fight that is likely to produce the next challenger for the lightweight championship of the world will be staged at Madison Square Garden tonight, when Allie Stolz, sharp-punching Newark warrior, opposes Bobby Ruffin of Long Island City. The clash, the third between the pair, is listed over the twelve-round route.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 26 -Announcement was made today that Governor Charles Edison, a resident of West Orange, had been chosen by the Chamber of Commerce and Civics of the Oranges and Maplewood as the outstanding citizen of the area in 1941.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Evacuees, arriving here today from New Guinea said the main streets of small towns on the island had been raked with Japanese machine gun fire from low-flying planes. They said that huge fires had been started by incendiary bombs at Port Moresby.

About 30,000,000 government forms and instruction sheets will be needed to put the Government's sugar rationing program into effect in New York City, the Office of Price Administration has been informed.

Albert S. Koury, penthouse in 121 Madison Ave; Philip D. Andrews, in 27 E 30th St; Ralph Birns, in 121 E 31st St; Mary McDonald, in 201 E 35th St; Victor L. Johnson, in 211 E 35th St; Marcus Glaser, in 25 W 54th St; Gilliam McVay, Inc, brokers.

To conserve its remaining supplies of burlap, Armstrong Cork Company will use cotton sheeting as a backing for Marbelle linoleum in the future, Kenneth O. Bates, general sales manager of the floor covering division, announced yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Friday, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Gary Cooper and Joan Fontaine were proclaimed the outstanding actors of 1941 by The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences early today.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 26 (AP) -Representatives of four chains operating groceries in New Jersey reported today only a negligible amount of sugar had been offered for resale by housewives, who were urged to reduce their hoarded stocks acquired during a recent sugar-buying spree.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26 -- The ring of Red Army troops around the remnants of an Axis force of 96,000 trapped in the Staraya Russa region today fought down the desperate attempts of its foe to break out of the slowly constricting circle. Equally desperate German attempts to fly supplies and munitions to the trapped units also were frustrated by Russian fliers and ground action, according to official information available here.

BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, Friday, Feb. 27 (AP) -- United States, British and Australian troops now in Java to defend this United Nations outpost against the expected Japanese direct onslaught now number "many thousands," General ter Poorten declared in a broadcast last night.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The reaction of sporting circles in London to Sir Stafford Cripps's proposal for further curtailing sporting events is that any additional restrictions will mean that it will not be worth while to carry on.

In this marvelous sunshine and despite the fairly low temperatures, people around town are displaying unmistakable symptoms of adiophoria. The word is not new, but The Columbia Alumni News claims it for a new disease invented by the members of the class of 1900, Physicians and Surgeons, at their recent class reunion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Supreme Commander of all United Nations forces in the Southwest Pacific, was wounded at Singapore shortly before that bastion fell to the enemy, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson revealed this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Roosevelt elevated the legations in Bolivia, Ecuador and Paraguay today to the status of embassies. The change, forecast for weeks, means that every United States mission in South America is now an embassy.
Police Commissioner Valentine revealed last night that Mayor La Guardia has provided $200,000 for the purchase and installation of enough air raid warning sirens "to cover the entire city."

The Fifth Avenue Playhouse will begin an indefinite engagement today of a "Dostoyevsky Film Program," composed of revivals of "The Brothers Karamazov" and "Crime and Punishment." The film adaptation of "Karamazov" was produced in pre-Hitler Germany and features Anna Sten and Fritz Kortner.

Real estate, mercantile, industrial and insurance interests in New York and other sections of the country are showing marked interest in the quotation of war and bombardment property damage insurance by two companies. The writers of this insurance are the General Insurance Company of America, with headquarters in Seattle, Wash., and the Rhode Island Insurance Company of Providence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Corset manufacturers have "a tremendous" amount of rubber, enough to continue abnormally high production levels for at least three months, a War Production Board spokesman said today in response to an inquiry about the order of yesterday barring further manufacture of rubber thread for use in corsets, girdles, brassieres and foundation garments.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Feb. 27 -- Russian spokesmen this morning announced further destructive blows against the Germans at several points on the Western Front. The heaviest of these appears to have been struck at a German column that tried to drive down the Seton River to relieve the beleaguered Sixteenth German Army in the Staraya Russa region.

The six men of the crew paddled away from the sinking plane in the rubber boat and then fought wind, weather, hunger, thirst and sunburn for six days and nights before finally drifting ashore on a small island east of Java.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Secretary Knox and Rear Admiral John H. Towers, chief of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics, publicly commended today the performance of four types of airplanes which have been tested repeatedly in combat service with the Navy.

According to the 1942 yearbook of the Travelers Insurance Company, 40,000 Americans were killed, almost 1,500,000 were injured and more than 1,000,000 automobiles were damaged in road accidents that occurred in 1941. Despite the warnings that have been sounded in the press, last year's record of automobile accidents and fatalities was the worst ever.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 26 -- Juan Pradenas, Minister of Labor, this morning telephoned direct to New York to E. Tappan Stannard, president of the Braden Copper Company, in an effort to induce him to meet the terms demanded by the workers in the strikebound Teniente Mine.

The seventeen-story and penthouse apartment building at 954 and 955 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the southeast corner of Seventy-seventh Street, has been sold by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, as liquidator of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company.

One fireman was slightly hurt and twelve others were affected by smoke yesterday while fighting a stubborn blaze in the basement of a Childs restaurant at 36 West Thirty-fourth Street. The fire disrupted traffic on that street between Broadway and Fifth Avenue for six hours.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26 -British Army and R.A.F. personnel recently in the small British possesson of Gambia, some hundred miles below the Vichy naval base at Dakar, and in Sierra Leone, another British colony set wedgewise in the French West African coast, report pervading apprehension in those territories.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Japanese fliers launched heavy attacks on the Rangoon area today and suffered heavy casualties. Planes of China's American Volunteer Group and Britain's Royal Air Force tore into big enemy formations and knocked down at least twenty-seven of the raiders, plus seven "probables."

Bank clearings for the five-day week ended on Wednesday fell $761,286,000 below the preceding holiday week, but were 6.9 per cent ahead of the five-day week ended on Feb. 26, 1941, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Substantial gains over the corresponding period last year were registered by all major cities except New York, which reported a decline.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies High Command issued the following communique today through Aneta News Agency:

The wisdom of the President in suggesting and participating in the formation of a "combined labor war board" consisting of three members of the C.I.O. and three members of the A.F. of L., to consult frequently with him, was questionable from the first. By doing this he made himself, in effect, the arbiter between the two great national unions.

Mayor La Guardia conferred with the five county commanders of the American Legion at City Hall yesterday on his efforts to develop a New York City Patrol Corps on a volunteer basis, with veterans of the last war constituting its backbone.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 26 -- As the result of a political upheaval in Camden's bi-partisan City Commission, Mrs. Mary W. Kobus was ousted today as Director of Public Safety and relegated to the comparatively minor post of Director of Parks and Public Property.

A UNITED NATIONS AIR BASE IN JAVA, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Colonel Eugene L. Eubank arrived to take command of the United States air forces in the Netherlands Indies today and found a heroe's medal waiting for him.

Americans of foreign birth, particularly those who came here within recent years from totalitarian countries or who have been in contact with relatives there, can perform a special function in national defense by making native Americans aware of what is at stake when democracy is under attack, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt declared last night.

A stockholders' accounting suit against officers and directors of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation and other defendants, for recovery of losses alleged to exceed $10,000,000, was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when Justice Carroll G. Walter signed an order for examination of certain defendants before trial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The story of how one submarine was sunk in the Atlantic battle area was reported today by the Navy Department following yesterday's disclosure by Secretary Knox that at least three enemy submersibles had been sunk and four damaged in fifty-six attacks in the last two months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Japanese cutting of the Burma supply road, together with British evacuation of Rangoon and the perilous position of Java in the Netherlands Indies, brought the British-American staff Council here face to face today with the problem of devising strategy to keep China from being isolated.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, denied published reports yesterday that Alex Pisciotta, former director of the Bureau of Weights and Measures in the Markets Department, had been under investigation at the time Mayor La Guardia promoted him to the post of city magistrate.
When an angler or hunter returns from a North Woods trip you hear quite a bit about his guide, but unless you are another guide you hear very little concerning the sportsman.

APPARENTLY it's true what they said about Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, the new leader in the House of Commons. He doesn't pull his punches. As soon as he had taken his stand and cleared his throat he hauled off and let loose a blast at dog racing and boxing as spectacles in Britain while an all-out war was going on there and elsewhere. Of these condemned sports he said:
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today without opinion that New York City had the right to tax receipts from interstate sales under the gross-receipts tax statutes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 26 -- Royal Air Force bombers were busy Tuesday night, raiding the Martuba and Derna areas, which are just behind the German front line in Libya, and attacking Tripoli harbor, which is the gateway for German supplies from Sicily.

Following the suggestion of Maxim Litvinoff, Russian Ambassador to the United States, made at the Overseas Press Club dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Thursday night, Burnet Hershey, president of the club, last night released the text of a message sent to General Douglas MacArthur, American commander in the Philippines.

I have been an all-around sports fan for fifty years. I have regularly attended baseball, polo, track, football, rowing, auto racing, tennis, yachting, boxing, etc., and have known intimately many amateur and professional athletes and coaches.
BOSTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 27 -- Patrolling over the Mediterranean a single Hurricane fighter drove off five German bombers which attempted to attack British shipping and shot down at least one and probably two and damaged a third, it was reported today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Expulsions and arrests of German and Italian nationals appeared to be increasing today as the government took measures against possible subversive activity.

Many women are leading double lives these days, holding down the home front and taking their tour of duty at the Red Cross, the A.W. V.S., or in a chilly "spotter's" post. Others are in factories replacing men called to the colors. Some schedules just can't be arranged to have mother home to prepare luncheon when the small fry come trooping in from school.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- On the ground that movement of vital war supplies was being interrupted by a labor dispute, the War Labor Board ordered today the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company, operating a belt railroad near Chicago, and the Brotherhoods of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen and of Railroad Trainmen to submit their differences to arbitration by the National Mediation Board.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A possibility that the controversial "war secrets" bill might be scrapped developed today from a conference between Senators and Attorney General Biddle.
HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- An unusually soft-spoken Larry MacPhail flew to Havana today from Miami, immediately went to Tropical Park and got his first look at the 1942 Dodgers.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 -- With seventeen named for the Flamingo, and the principal Widener Cup stars named for the Eastern Air Lines Purse, Hialeah Park tomorrow will stage what some here expect will be the best day of racing in the history of the Miami Jockey Club.

A program to stimulate recreational travel and correlate it, through staggered vacations and by other means, with the government's use of transportation facilities in wartime was adopted yesterday by 120 executives of travel interests in the United States, Canada, Cuba and Mexico, meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.

What promises to be the best National A.A.U. track and field championships of all, the fifty-third annual title meet of the world's largest amateur sports governing body, will be staged in Madison Square Garden this afternoon and tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Six suggested activities to which floor coverings manufacturers might convert their plants when orders restricting rug and carpet production are issued were offered by the Industry Advisory Committee, which met with government officials yesterday.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday urged that women continue work in organizations that existed before the war as well as engaging in "specifically war work."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -- Well in command over their respective rivals most of the time, Long Island University and St. Joseph's College bagged impressive basketball victories before 5,183 fans in Convention Hall tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 27 -- Thirteen political parties and groups today concluded their campaigning for the crucial national election that will be held in the Federal capital and thirteen out of fourteen Argentine Provinces on Sunday, when slightly more than 3,150,000 voters go to the polls to elect eighty-five new Deputies out of a total of 158 composing the Chamber.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Roosevelt signed an Executive Order creating an Army Specialist Corps, conferred with Senators Barkley and Doxey and presided at a Cabinet meeting.

Despite the increased burdens created by the war, public response to the appeals of local welfare institutions "continues to surpass all previous records," George Z. Medalie, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, reported yesterday at the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the federation in its headquarters, 71 West Forty-seventh Street.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Ignoring reports that he plans to go into the open market for a seasoned draft-proof campaigner to add to the Yankees' pitching staff, Manager Joe McCarthy is proceeding carefully with the development of yearling hurlers to fill the vacancies left by Charley Stanceu and Steve Peek, who have gone into the service.

VICHY, France, Feb. 27 -- Explanations have been furnished to the United States regarding French policy by Admiral Francois Darlan, Vice Premier, and by the French Ambassador to Washington, Gaston Henry-Haye. Admiral William B. Leahy, United States Ambassador, visited Admiral Darlan today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Government agencies dealing with wartime consumer problems are being subjected to an increasing number of inquiries from housewives all over the country, a checkup indicated today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 -- Flames of mysterious origin swept a gasoline tanker and an oil dock at Avon, on Suisun Bay, near here, today, resulting in the probable drowning of two members of the tanker's crew.
Consolidated net sales of the B.F. Goodrich Company rose 45.5 per cent last year to a record $211,454,790 from $145,354,278 in 1940, the company disclosed yesterday in releasing its annual report.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- The intention of legislative leaders to enact a State rent control law at the current session was shown today, when the first rent control measure was introduced, for consideration. It was sponsored by Senator Desmond and Assemblyman Moffat, but comes from the Citizens Housing Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- How to reduce the fire danger from all kinds of incendiary bombs by applying an incombustibule covering over attic or uper floors of houses was described today by the Bureau of Standards of the Commerce Department.
" Our enemies hoped that they could now inflict on the German Army the fate of a Napoleonic retreat. This attempt has miserably failed." -- Adolf Hitler.

PORT HENRY, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- A $5,000,000 village of about 1,000 homes will be constructed between Mineville and Moriah Center, near this Essex County community, to meet expanding needs of the Republic Steel Corporation's mining operations.

Representatives of virtually all of the 60,000 dairy farmers in the New York metropolitan milkshed met with Deputy Health Commissioner Sol Pincus yesterday at the Commodore Hotel to protest a proposal by the City Health Department to remove about 10,000 farms from the city inspection service.

A service that will combine in its order of worship ten different languages in use in the various parts of the Empire of the Netherlands, as well as Afrikaans, as used in British South Africa, will be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- General Douglas MacArthur's miracle men continued to press their surprise offensive today after racking up gains along the Bataan battlefront in the last forty-eight hours.

Contract bridge experts will open the Eastern Championships, the first major bridge tournament since this country entered the war, at the Park Central Hotel today. The tournament will last through Sunday, March 8.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The House approved today and sent to the Senate for final action a conference report on an Army-Navy Pay Bill carrying the provision for repeal of the Congressional pension plan.

" Survey your own neighborhood, know what air raid precautions have been taken and, where more are needed, become very vocal and see that something is done," Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the Manhattan branch of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, advised yesterday.

Your recent editorial "Don't Be a Hoarder," following Mr. Pike's rather scathing letter against "hoarders" in THE TIMES two weeks previously, constrains me to write these few lines, not by way of argument against the position you have taken, but rather in the sincere hope of getting light upon a situation that seems to be leaving me "on a spot."

William Gerald Bishop, who won acquittal on charges of sedition in Brooklyn nearly two years ago, was arrested yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and taken to Ellis Island, it was learned from outside sources last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Business in the folding paper box business is booming and factories are having trouble in cutting down their heavy backlogs of orders, it was learned today as the Folding Paper Box Association announced plans for a three-day industry meeting here, beginning March 25.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 27 -- Lanky Ted Williams had his mind made up in an unusual but conclusive way today that he will do his slugging for the Red Sox this Summer instead of for the United States Army.

Standard Brands, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries had net sales in 1941 of $119,563,282, or 21 per cent in excess of the 1940 volume of $98,874,608, James S. Adams, president, reported in the annual statement issued for release today.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 27 -- President Roosevelt sent the following reply to President Somoza's birthday greetings:

Allie Stolz, Newark boxer, projected himself into the lightweight title picture last night by pounding out a convincing triumph over Bobby Ruffin of Long Island City in a twelve-round battle at Madison Square Garden.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 27 -- A forty-mile stretch along the New Jersey coast from Sandy Hook to Barnegat Bay and about twenty miles inland was blacked out tonight in a test described as highly successful. The darkened area embraced sixty-three municipalities in Monmouth County and the northern half of Ocean County and Fort Hancock and Fort Monmouth.

The two New Jersey men who paid more than $4,000 to a thoughtful stranger who promised to teach them how to be detectives and get jobs with the Federal Bureau of Investigation made a mistake. They have indeed got in touch with the FBI after two years of conscientious work and semi-starvation, but their introduction was not happy.

Paul T. Borchardt testified yesterday that he was one of the 50,000 "non-Aryans" rounded up in Germany in 1938 because "a madman named Grynszpan, a Jew, murdered a German diplomat, von Rath, in Paris." His story was related on the witness stand in Federal court, where Borchardt has been labeled a "fake refugee" and is on trial with five other persons for espionage.

Lieut. Comdr. Walter C. Freeman of the Communications Division of the Third Naval District told 200 persons last night at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, that he did not know "why women shouldn't be as well fitted as men to be radio operators."

Earnings of the International Silver Company in the year ended on Dec. 31 amounted to $3,513,306 before provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes and for a special reserve, according to the annual report of E.C. Stevens, president, issued for publication today.

The sum of $209,300 had been tabulated as organized labor's contribution to the Greater New York Red Cross War Fund up to yesterday afternoon, but this group has until March 15 to obtain its quota of $1,000,000 in the city-wide appeal for $7,330,000.

The defeat in the House yesterday of the proposal for wartime suspension of the forty-hour week is a blow to maximum production and national defense. We believe that to a large extent this vote was the product of what has now become alarmingly muddled thinking.

Virtually every known form of theatrical dancing was represented on the stage of Carnegie Hall last night in the "Dance Festival" arranged by Russian War Relief, Inc., to raise funds for medical supplies and civilian aid to those courageous fighters, on and off the actual battle lines, the Russian people.

All indications are that the series of price indexes for individual retail departments, essential to the use of the last-in, first-out, or "lifo," method of inventory valuation by retailers as a safeguard against inflation, will be available by March 15, it was made known yesterday by H.I. Kleinhaus, manager, of the controllers congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Dr. Jerome Gross gave his first New York violin recital last night at Town Hall. Since his early days Dr. Gross, who is a practicing surgeon in Cleveland, Ohio, has been a serious student of music. He has appeared as soloist with the Cleveland Orchestra and last season played a group of numbers at Arthur Loesser's "Music in Crinoline" concert in this city.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27 -- A course in household mechanics for women began this week at the Central Avenue Grammar School here under the auspices of the Newark Board of Education, with thirty women, including several grandmothers, enrolled.

Writing that many Negroes in "natural bitterness" against injustices suffered in the past from white men think that "it might be as well if Japan should win this war," Pearl Buck, novelist, in an open letter addressed to Negroes, urges them to overcome their indifference and to get behind America's war effort with their full strength.

The help of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in rooting out racketeers from the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union was asked yesterday by 254 members of Local 147. They also requested him to do everything in his power to speed up the construction of the Battery-Brooklyn tunnel.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- For the second consecutive day government buyers spent more than $300,000 here today in attempting to hold up prices of butter. An additional $100,000 was spent in New York, as the United States financed Dairy Products Marketing Association purchased 1,349,412 pounds of butter on the two markets.

Art work by hundreds of New York City's boys and girls will go on display Monday on the fifth floor of R.H. Macy Co. in the second Regional High School Art Exhibit, as part of the fifteenth National High School Art Exhibition.

Lever Brothers Company will break advertising for Vimms vitamin-mineral tablets in this area next week after having introduced the product in various other markets. Twenty-nine newspapers, radio, car cards and outdoor advertising will be used, with more than half the expenditure in newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Every enemy alien must apply for his certificate of identification before postoffices close tomorrow night or face possible internment for the duration of the war, Attorney General Biddle warned today. The only exceptions are the German, Japanese and Italian aliens in eight Far Western States where the application period ended Feb. 9.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Small business can save itself by adapting its facilities to "bread and butter" civilian production, Floyd B. Odlum said here today.

The cotton market advanced moderately yesterday as mill interests and other trade sources absorbed a steady stream of hedging offers. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures closed at their best levels for the session with net gains of 7 to 13 points.
With no aspirant able to muster a majority of votes, the Tammany executive committee postponed yesterday until April 14 election of a leader to succeed Christopher D. Sullivan.

Loss of one business day because of the celebration of Washington's Birthday on Monday is likely to result in a small percentage decline in retail sales here this week, as compared with a year ago. Department store executives estimated the drop yesterday at 1 or 2 per cent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 27 -- As the Axis is mobilizing the totality of its military resources for one more mighty and, it is hoped, decisive blow, it is said in Berlin that Reichsfuehrer Hitler has taken a vow never again to set foot on Reich German territory until the last Russian Army unit has been annihilated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Tension was eased between the United States and the French Government at Vichy with the announcement today that the government of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain had given formal assurances of its intention to remain neutral and to keep the French fleet out of German hands.

VICHY, France, Feb. 27 -- Edouard Daladier, Premier of France at the beginning of war in 1939, argued today in his defense before the Supreme Court at Riom that the responsibility for France's un- preparedness, of which he is accused, was shared by French governments preceding his, including that in which Marshal Petain was War Minister.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Desmond "plumage" bill permitting the State Conservation Department to license and regulate manufacturers making fishing flies from plumages of birds.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said at La Guardia Field last night that she would not accept any more government offices so long as she is First Lady.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 27 -- The formation of a new labor federation here today caused considerable unrest among the two biggest worker organizations in Mexico, the Confederation of Mexican Workers and the Confederation of Peasants, which cover about 90 per cent of the country's organized labor.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- E.W. Hanks, 77-year-old inventor from Maine, extinguished fourteen dangerous types of fire here this afternoon with a new variety of fire-fighting powder he has perfected but he was stumped when he undertook to quell the 3,000-degree flames of a magnesium thermit incendiary bomb.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The text of a War Department communique, based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M., Eastern war time today, follows:

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27 -- The strike of 1,300 C.I.O. employes at the Crucible Steel Company's La Belle plant was apparently settled today with a tentative agreement between officials of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee and company representatives on shop grievances which caused the work stoppage yesterday.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Feb. 27 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Netherlands Indies High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A record of Japanese espionage and fifth columnist operations, pictured as having paved the way for the Pearl Harbor attack and as geared to a plan to invade and conquer the United States, laid down in a Japanese "Mein Kampf" of fifteen years ago, was reported to the House tonight by the Dies Committee on Un-American Activities.

Upsetting the Board of Education's policy of appointing teachers to subjects for which they hold no licenses, the Appellate Division, by unanimous decision yesterday, ordered the board to appoint teachers from the existing eligible lists. This order reversed the Supreme Court decision that upheld the board's policy.

HOBOKEN, N.J. Feb. 27 -- Their patriotism having got the better of their dislike of a foreman, the 160 welders who walked out Wednesday at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's shipyard here because of the alleged "abusive conduct" of the foreman returned to their jobs today.

A British sea captain, relaxed in the solarium of Long Island College Hospital, told yesterday afternoon how his cargo ship had been torpedoed in the North Atlantic early in February. Only fifteen members of his crew of seventy-one survived.

BERLIN, Feb. 27 (From German broadcasts to The Associated Press) -- The Red Army has launched attacks on the Sevastopol and Kerch fronts in the Crimea, the German High Command communique acknowledged today, but it declared the assaults had been repulsed with heavy Soviet losses.

The Greenwich Village Center of the Friends of Democracy started last night a three-month program of study and action to combat subversive propaganda, at a well-attended meeting in the Hotel Grosvenor, 35 Fifth Avenue, at which L.M. Birkhead, national director of Friends of Democracy, was the principal speaker.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 -- Japanese-American leaders waited with an air of resignation today for an order from Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt, Western defense commander, which, they predicted, would make it necessary for them, as well as enemy aliens, to find new homes outside of the West Coast "combat zone."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Germans as they advanced in Russia not only found scorched earth, with crops and industrial plants destroyed, but since have had their economic plans in the rear of their lines sabotaged by peasants, according to a report by Leonid Levitin, Soviet writer, received by the Russian Embassy today.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Saturday, Feb. 28 -- A thundering naval engagement between United Nations and Japanese warships broke out in full fury in the Java Sea last night and presumably raged on today in what may be the first major clash of an attempted Japanese invasion of Java, the last United Nations bastion in the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The blackout along the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf Coasts of all advertising signs, store window displays and similar lighting which could not be extinguished at once in the event of an air raid alert was requested of OCD regional directors tonight by James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 27 -- This city's record budget of $42,000,000 was adopted by the City Commission today after a three-and-one-half-hour public hearing in which T. James Tumulty, Republican lawyer and Hague foe, appeared as the only objector.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The War Production Board acted today to assure sufficient supplies of power to war industries in the Buffalo, Niagara Falls and Western New York industrial areas in event of breakdowns or power shortages developing from other causes.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Colonel and Mrs. Harold A. Braman were dinner hosts tonight at their home. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ladd, Mr. and Mrs. J. Lester Parsons, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Reisinger, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Sidley Dow, Mrs. Antoinette Johnson and Captain Charles A. MacDonald.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Key Democrats of the House organized a movement today to combat "individual partisan" criticisms in Congress of the war which had ceased to be "constructive" and become "unfair, poisonous sniping at the President" aimed at "undermining confidence" in him and at "dividing the country."

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- For the second night in succession the Royal Air Force last night sent out a strong force against the docks and shipyards of Kiel, where the German battleship Gneisenau is reported to be lying badly damaged in a floating dock.

Overruling John P. Cohalan, official referee, and Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora and reversing a long-standing requirement for at least two witnesses in divorce suits based on adultery charges, the Appellate Division, in a decision made public yesterday, ruled unanimously that a single witness was sufficient.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- The British Labor party, apparently breaking with its pacifist past, today demanded "total victory" in the war and opposed any revengeful peace but asked for stern punishment and permanent disarmament of the Axis nations.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Sir Stafford Cripps stepped out of his role as leader of the House of Commons today to urge the people in territory occupied by the Germans to "strike now, strike silently again and again and repeat blows small and great."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Army Air Corps, counting up its score in the Battle of the Pacific, announced today that since Dec. 7 it had sunk at least nineteen Japanese ships, seriously damaged thirty-one others and had shot down 245 enemy planes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Federal debt jumped $1,508,750,360 this week to come within sight of the $65,000,000,000, limit. The Treasury said that the jump resulted from the sale of a bond issue and placed the debt at $62,252,495,250 as of Feb. 25.

In resigning from the Westchester County Recreation Commission, which she had headed since its inception in 1923, Mrs. Eugene Meyer can take satisfaction in a job well done. During many of these years there were political leaders holding the county's purse-strings who saw little importance in spending taxpayers' money for musical events, arts and crafts, and other recreational activities.

An increase of four points during January carried the national construction cost index of the American Appraisal Company to 225 from 221 in the final month of last year, the company reported yesterday. In January, 1941, the index stood at 212, and in the first month of 1940 it was 203.

The Manhattan branch of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, 93 Park Avenue, yesterday issued an appeal for 530 women to serve as school defense aides for the protection of children in Manhattan's elementary and high schools.

VALLEJO, Calif., Feb. 27 -- Rear Admiral W.L. Friedell, Mare Island navy yard commandant, said today that examinations to establish a list of women workers there would be held soon in California, Nevada and Arizona.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The counter-attack against Japanese forces on Bataan Peninsula in the Philippines announced yesterday by the United States and Filipino forces under General Douglas MacArthur resulted in gains of two-thirds of a mile to nearly five miles all along the line, the War Department announced today.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 28 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco and New York) -- Imperial Headquarters said today that one enemy cruiser and three destroyers had been sunk off Java at dusk yesterday during a battle between the main Japanese naval forces and the "combined fleet of the United States and Netherlands Indies."

Emphasizing the theme of "Women in Defense of Hemisphere Solidarity," the Woman's Press Club will hold its 53rd annual luncheon today at the Hotel Pennsylvania. An all-round picture of women's participation in the civilian defense efforts of the Americas is to be outlined in talks during the course of the program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- An "acute" shortage of mechanics in the transport industry in some areas and a threatened scarcity of seamen for Great Lakes shipping next season prompted the Office of Defense Transportation today to order a survey of manpower needs in the transportation field.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The War Department moved today to recruit large numbers of highly specialized civilians who will receive commissions in the Army.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- An exchange stabilization agreement between Ecuador and the United States involving a $5,000,000 loan was signed today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. for the United States and the Ecuadoran Ambassador, Colon Eloy Alfaro, and the Minister-Counselor, Eduardo Salazar.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Although 80-square percales and certain other textiles are virtually non-existant in the wholesale field here, some of the houses fear that worse shortages are ahead on goods that will be ordered for Fall delivery and are going to extraordinary lengths to protect themselves in the event of non-deliveries by mills.

The railroads of the country began yesterday a survey to determine how to avert a possible shortage of labor in the industry within a few months. Freight and passenger traffic on the rails is at the highest level in years, and freight movement may surpass the record set last year.

" At least $500,000,000" in additional appropriations for public housing, continued cooperation between the USHA and local housing authorities, and erection of permanent rather than temporary living quarters for defense workers "wherever feasible," are among the proposals for extending war housing which have been suggested to President Roosevelt by the National Public Housing Conference, of which Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch is president.

Brooklyn realty buyers in the deals reported yesterday selected properties in scattered areas of the borough. Most of the parcels traded were residential in character, and included both apartment houses and one-family dwellings.
Charges made by the government against two men in widely different walks of life that they failed to pay income tax came up yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $2,000,000 of road and bridge bonds of Harris County, Texas, on a bid of 100,389 for 2.20s. The bonds, dated March 10, 1942 and maturing on March 10, 1943 to 1962, were reoffered at prices to yield 0.60 to 2.20 per cent, according to maturity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 -- "The Man on America's Conscience," a biography of Andrew Johnson by Alvin Meyer and Lowell Brodeaux, has been scheduled for late production at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, with Van Heflin as the Reconstruction President and Lionel Barrymore as Thaddeus Stevens, his chief political enemy, the studio announced today.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman denied yesterday a plea by the Art Students League and other defendants for dismissal of a suit brought by the Architectural League of New York charging conspiracy and fraud in a dispute involving financial control of the American Fine Arts Building at 315 West Fifty-seventh Street, long an art exhibition center.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (A.P.) -- Prices of hogs were about steady today, although the top declined to $13.20 from $13.25 yesterday. Salable arrivals were moderately large, bringing the total this week to 63,800 head, against 57,782 in the comparable period last week.

The President's statement of "three high purposes for every American" was admirably phrased, but what I and, unless I miss my guess, millions of my fellow-citizens want from him in this crisis is not fine words but action to implement those words.

The heirs of the late Sumner Ballard, who was the president of the International Insurance Company, have sold his town house at 10 East Seventy-ninth Street, near Fifth Avenue, to the Archdiocese of North and South America of the Greek Orthodox Church as a residence for its Archbishop.

An oddity of the war at sea was revealed here yesterday after the arrival of a case of antique glass from Great Britain. This frail shipment had survived rigors of warfare which could hardly fail to send any object to Davy Jones's locker.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- The Duke of Windsor conferred today with United States naval officers regarding measures for the defense of the Bahama Islands in his official capacity as Governor and Commander in Chief of the British Crown Colony.

In connection with a suit attacking the city's financing of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen's investigation into a $1,000,000 paving racket, a limited temporary injunction was handed down yesterday setting forth conditions of payment for the inquiry that were hailed by Mr. Amen as confirmation of the jurisdictional conduct of his office.

The thought suggests itself that one line in particular from President Roosevelt's speech on Washington's Birthday might serve as an added stimulus to harder work and greater accomplishments in all phases of the war effort: "Never before have we had so little time in which to do so much."

The more the whole incident of the early morning of Feb. 25 in the Los Angeles district is examined, the more incredible it becomes. First reports were that "a big floating object resembling a balloon" was seen in the sky and fired upon. Another report is that one plane was seen; still another that it was "twenty-seven" planes; still another that it was "hundreds."
