WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Wholesale commodity prices have advanced 1 per cent on the average in the past four weeks and are now 20 per cent above last year at this time, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The National Safety Council reported today that 3,140 persons died in traffic accidents in January, an increase of 210, or 7 per cent, over January, 1941, despite curtailment of automobiles and tires.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- White dinner shirts and snowy bed linen soon will be things of the past, under a War Production Board order issued today curtailing the civilian use of chlorine, but the home laundress need not worry about the appearance of her weekly wash according to the WPB's division of chemical and allied products.

Instructing children to lie on their stomachs and turn their heads to one side to avoid swallowing their tongues in case of air attack is not enough, Harold F. Strong, executive director of Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., declared yesterday.

Representatives of legislative and welfare departments from nine Northeastern States and others in the Council of State Governments joined yesterday in seeking the establishment of a uniform settlement law among the States which would provide relief for persons who establish definite residence of at least one year.

The Siamese twin girls born to Mrs. Jessie Picciotto, 25 years old, of 48 Scribner Avenue, New Brighton, S.I., on Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital at West New Brighton, S.I., died at 3:15 P.M. yesterday. Doctors at the hospital were puzzled by their death.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora signed yesterday an order confirming the report of Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti as special referee which denied the claim of the Mexican Government of ownership of any part of the fund of nearly $7,000,000 still held by the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, headed by Thomas W. Lamont.

The finals in the surf-angler-versus-swimmer contest are scheduled for tonight, and we suggest that Sportsmen's Show visitors get a vantage point early if they hope to witness this event, for the competition between both spectators and contestants is due to be keen.
Joseph Lordi, national champion from the New York A.C., and H. Robert Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club moved into the final of the invitation squash tennis tournament at the Whitehall Club yesterday.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Senator Carl Hatch suffered a fractured spine, internal injuries, shock and exposure in an automobile accident early today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 -- Tass, the official Soviet news agency, repudiated today foreign reports of Russian broadcasts concerning Russo-Japanese relations, which mentioned troop movements eastward, mining of the Gulf of Tartary and the sequestering of Japanese holdings.

A special revival engagement of Warners' "The Life of Emile Zola," starring Paul Muni, will begin next Saturday at the Globe Theatre, the company announced yesterday. "A Gentleman at Heart," the theatre's current tenant, will start its Second week today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Feb. 21 were 255,861,000 barrels, it was said today by the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior.
MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

Protests against birth control, "mercy killings" and the conscription of women for national defense at this time were registered yesterday in resolutions adopted at the semi-annual meeting of the national board of directors of the Catholic Daughters of America.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 26 (Delayed) -- An unconfirmed report reaching high foreign intelligence sources here today said that General Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, commander of the Axis forces in Libya, had flown from the North African front early this week to Rome and Vienna, en route to Berlin, "possibly to assume an Eastern Front command" under Adolf Hitler.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The railroads expect to be able to continue handling all war traffic and they hope delivery of new equipment between the present and October will enable them to complete their current car-building program, John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, said here today at a special meeting of the association.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Master Melvin Ott made a startling discovery today as he mapped the resumption of training activities here after the Giants' return from their excursion to Havana to play the Dodgers tomorrow and Sunday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Although prices of wheat held within a range of slightly less than 1 cent a bushel today, the market showed a relativelyy firm undertone, especially in the face of a renewed attack on the Senate bill to freeze government-owned stocks of commodities at parity prices.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The War Labor Board refused today to make a decision on the question of extra compensation for war production workers on swing shifts, Sundays and holidays.

BOSTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- An injunction to prevent Hugh B. Monjar of Ardmore, Pa., and alleged agents in Massachusetts, Wilmington (Del.) and New York from selling securities to members of the sixteen State organizations of the Mantle Club without filing registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission, was requested in Federal Court today.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- The Saigon radio, heard in London, broadcast a Domei news agency dispatch asserting that the Japanese had cut all communications between Rangoon and Mandalay. If true, this would mean they had crossed not only the railway but the motor highway and were astride the Irrawaddy River, on which boat and barge traffic between the two cities had been heavy.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- A Russian Army estimated at 630,000 men is ranged behind Siberia's defense wall of blockhouses, ready to ward off a Japanese attack that, if it comes at all, must come before the Spring thaws, Chinese military analysts said today.

Spasmodic buying with a minimum of selling pressure helped yesterday to move the stock market higher, but the volume of business continued to be small. Despite the less ominous aspect of the war in the Pacific, Wall Street appeared to be less concerned with war news than with ascertaining what the heads of the Treasury consider should make up the forthcoming tax legislation.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 27 -- National Youth Administration directors in all parts of the country were instructed today by Aubrey Williams, national chief of the NYA program, to abolish all sewing, music, art, recreation and other projects that did not contribute directly to victory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Warning was given that stocks of house heating oils on the East Coast were at a dangerously low level. With about five weeks of the heating season still remaining, Ralph K. Davies, Deputy Petroleum Coordinator, today directed fifteen oil companies to step up their deliveries of domestic fuel oil to the East Coast as quickly as possible.

Thomas A. Morgan, president of the Sperry Corporation and a member of the New York State Council of National Defense, was elected a director of the Lehman Corporation at a meeting of the board of directors here yesterday. He succeeds Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and chairman of the Standard Gas and Electric Corporation, who resigned from the Lehman Corporation board upon becoming also Alien Property Custodian.

The "Parsifal" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House attracted, not the largest, but a large audience, though there was no Flagstad in the cast. But there was a Melchior in one of the roles which Mr. Melchior mastered in his early experience as a tenor raised from a baritone.
WITH the national indoor A.A.U. track and field championships coming up at Madison Square Garden this evening, there is added excitement concerning Leslie MacMitchell and Greg Rice.

RIOM, France, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Former Premier Edouard Daladier announced defiantly at the war guilt trial today that France had more tanks than Germany for the Western Front campaign of May, 1940, and he praised General Charles de Gaulle, mechanized warfare advocate and now Free French leader, "who I am proud to have named a general."

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- A dispute over editorial policy has caused the resignation of J.L. Garvin, one of the oldest and most influential of British newspaper men, as editor of The Observer. The Observer is owned by Viscount Astor.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 27 -- News of a "veteran" that went home to tell its story gave a lift to Royal Air Force headquarters here today. The "veteran" is a damaged Allison motor, and the news is a message from workers at the Allison plant at Indianapolis -- "Heartfelt cheerio and keep 'em flying."

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company will observe today its 120th anniversary. Chartered on Feb. 28, 1822, by the New York Legislature as the Farmers Fire Insurance and Loan Company, the company was granted on April 17, 1822, by special legislative act, the first trust powers ever given to any corporation in the United States.

The residence of William Matheus Sullivan at 322 East Fifty-seventh Street will be the setting for a concert on the night of March 21 for the benefit of the music department of the Union Settlement. The artists will be Miss Rose Bampton, soprano, of the Metropolitan Opera; Miss Muriel Kerr, pianist, and Felix Salmond, 'cellist. The musicale has been arranged by the women's auxiliary of the settlement.

Having had ample time to rest since its sensational victory over Michigan last week, Yale University's crack swimming squad got back to serious business last night and launched its stretch drive for the Eastern Intercollegiate League crown by downing Columbia, 52 -- 23, in the Lions' pool.
BERLIN, Feb. 27 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- After a conference today of Congressional fiscal leaders, Secretary Morgenthau and their tax experts, it was announced that the national debt limit would be increased to $125,000,000,000. It was added that a gratifying measure of agreement had been reached between the administrative and legislative branches on the new seven billion dollar tax bill.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Note circulation in the week ended on Wednesday increased more than 900,000, the Bank of England's statement shows, while reserve decreased almost 1,000,000.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- There was an atmosphere of cheerfulness in most sections of the stock market today and in some directions business was better. There was a steadier tendency in the gil t-edged group but there was little movement in the railways apart from the further rise in Argentines.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 27 -- For twelve hours yesterday, between midday and midnight, the Jewish population of Palestine observed a voluntary stoppage of business activity and traffic and during half that period all persons remained indoors in a self-imposed curfew, as a sign of mourning for the loss of the more than 700 passengers of the refugee ship Struma, which sank in the Black Sea north of the Bosporus Tuesday morning.

A split in the membership of Phi Delta Kappa, the leading American educators' national honor or fraternity, over the question of admitting non-white members to the organization, is threatened, it was learned yesterday when the group's Beta Chapter at Teachers College, Columbia University, announced its strong support of a move to admit men of all races.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- After three days of debate, often impassioned, the House in a surprise vote today rejected, by 226 to 62, a proposal to suspend for the duration of the war the work hours limitations and extra overtime pay provisions of seventeen Federal statutes, chief of which is the Wages and Hours law.

The National Committee for the Resettlement of Foreign Physicians courageously took the county medical societies to task for having played their part in erecting barriers against the practice of medicine by qualified emigre physicians and even by Americans who had graduated from great European universities.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Fol-[ lowing ia the tet o! Acting tec-, retary of tate Sumner Welles' announcement of the Vicky reply to President Roosevelt:

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Normal tanker traffic has been resumed between the Venezuelan oil fields and the Standard Oil refinery on the island of Aruba after being suspended last week when Nazi submarines began intensive raids in the area, Henry E. Linam, president of the Standard Oil Company of Venezuela, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Uniform Manufacturers' Exchange, Inc., of 112 East Nineteenth Street, New York, and its twenty-four member concerns also located in New York, have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with conspiracy to suppress competition in the manufacture and sale of uniforms worn by policemen, firemen, doormen, bell boys, porters and chauffeurs.

A painting by Titian, "The Man With a Falcon," which was shown in the "Masterpieces of Art Exhibition" at the New York World's Fair, has been bought by the Joslyn. Memorial, Omaha, Nebraska, from Wildenstein Co., 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

Agreements for the merger of G.M-P. Murphy Co. with Hornblower Weeks, stock brokers, are to be signed this morning, it was announced yesterday. Final details of the deal remain to be settled, but the name of Hornblower Weeks will continue.
ROME, Feb. 27 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Princeton's basketball team moved into undisputed possession of second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League as it staged a second half scoring spree to rout Harvard, 54 -- 32, before 1,000 in the university gymnasium tonight.

More than ordinary interest centers around the competitive sale on Monday of $32,500,000 of bonds and 34,000 shares of preferred stock of the Pennsylvania Electric Company inasmuch as it will provide the first test of the market for a sizable new issue of utility securities since the $80,000,000 Alabama Power financing late in January.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Roosevelt declared today that a Senate farm bloc group proposal to prohibit the sale of government-held agricultural surpluses below parity would add $1,000,000,000 to the cost of living, and denounced as reprehensible any effort to attach such a proposal as a rider to the $32,762,737,000 supplemental war-funds bill, which the President would hesitate to veto.

Eight tenancies in John Murray House, the recently completed apartment at 220 Madison Avenue, during the past week are reported by Duff Conger, Inc., managing agent. The lessees are: Doris Kavanagh, Clarence H. Dickey, Gilbert J. Kitching Jr., Hugh G. Krein, Edward M. Rickel, Maude Faulkner, Mae D. Huettig and Mrs. Maude P. Collester.

There is cheering news in the statement made by Dr. C.-E.A. Winslow in the current "Fitness-for-Freedom" issue of the Survey Graphic that "our draft army is probably the most physically and mentally competent large body of young men ever gathered together under any flag."

In England the ominous events of February, capping two and a half years of fighting on the defensive, have stirred up a popular demand for new blood in the government and in the military command which the shake-up in the Cabinet has only partially satisfied.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Russian troops in three powerful offensives are wiping out the German army corps of 96,000 men trapped at Staraya Russa, pulverizing the Leningrad siege lines and liberating Kursk province between Kharkov and Orel, military dispatches said tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 27 -- For the third successive night Australian bombers wrought havoc at Japanese-occupied bases at Rabaul, New Britain, last night despite intense anti-aircraft fire from ships in Blanche Bay and from the land.

Operations last year of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation and its subsidiaries in the United States resulted in earnings for 1941 of $16,698,952 before provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes, compared with $9,741,171 the year before, according to the annual report announced yesterday.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- The selective service deferment granted to Ted Williams, the American League batting champion, tonight created considerable excitement in the Red Sox training camp.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Just before the House defeated the Smith amendnlent this afternoon, Secretary Perkins voiced her disapproval of the measure to suspend the forty-hour work week for the duration of the war by saying that she did not see how the measure would increase production in any way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Seven submarine commanders serving with the American forces in the Southwestern Pacific and adjacent waters in the Far East tonight were named as having received the Navy Cross for "especially meritorious conduct" in operations against the Japanese.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 27 -- In a gesture that should go far toward strengthening the united American front, Chile energetically protested today against the sinkings by Axis submarines of ships belonging to Brazil and Venezuela.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Baron Fritz Von Opel, wealthy son of a German automobile manufacturer, was arrested early today as a "potentially dangerous alien" and his Winter home here was searched by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- As the lull in land fighting in Burma continued today it was revealed that the Japanese had made their first attack on India by twice bombing and machine-gunning Port Blair, capital of the strategic Andaman Islands in the Bay of Bengal.

If a player on a New York college basketball team broke Hank Luisetti's four-year scoring record, it would make the headlines of the sports page. Long articles would be written extolling the virtues of this great player.
Leases for large units of business space were reported by several brokers yesterday.

The appearance this week of several sizable tax-exempt loans lifted the total of new bond offerings in this market to $14,392,000, compared with $2,400,000 last week. In this period last year $9,950,000 in new bonds were placed on the market.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Armed with rent control powers equivalent to his price authority, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, will move soon into war-boom areas with orders for rent reductions.

Three attractions will terminate their Broadway careers tonight. They are: (1) the Maurice Evans revival of "Macbeth," which will have grossed approximately $240,000 during its record run of 131 performances. (2) "Papa Is All," the Theatre Guild Production, after sixty-three performances.

Tex O'Rourke's letter of last week concerning the Coliseum's board running track raises interesting questions. As chairman of the senior Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field committee, which held the first track meet ever staged at the Coliseum and two of the five held there thus far, I have definite ideas on the subject.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique said today:

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Feb. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Russian-Japanese negotiations for renewal of the Far Eastern fisheries agreement, which expired Dec. 31, still are under way and no new accord is in sight, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Members of the Joint Congressional Committee on Nonessential Expenditures questioned James M. Landis for more than two and one-half hours this morning on the work of the Office of Civilian Defense of which he is director.

Budget Director Kenneth Dayton flatly contradicted Councilman Joseph E. Kinsley, chairman of the Council Finance Committee, yesterday on his statement that the consolidation of the Sheriff's and Register's offices would cost the taxpayers $95,000 more this year, and said the consolidation would effect a minimum saving of almost $468.000.

It is quite possible, if the bills to place the Office of Civilian Defense within the control of the War Department are enacted into law, that the department may decide to utilize the services of the hundreds of retired officers who, despite their years of experience at government expense, are now overlooked in the mad scramble to get on the payroll.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The State Department gave out tonight the following report received from the French Consul General in Shanghai through our Vichy Embassy:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator Thomas of Utah, chairman of the Senate Committee on Education and Labor, said today, after an appearance before his group of W.H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, that no legislation was needed now on the subject of strikes or walkouts.

The Rev. Ralph W. Key, pastor for the last ten years of the Harlem-New York Presbyterian Church, 2 West 122d Street, will be installed at 8 P.M. tomorrow as co-pastor with the Rev. Dr. Daniel Russell, for twenty-five years pastor of Rutgers Presbyterian Church.

The week's developments in the war will be discussed by pastors tomorrow in their sermons with many commenting on the Washington's Birthday "fireside chat" of President Roosevelt to the United States. In the ecclesiastical calendar tomorrow will be the second Sunday in Lent. Easter will be April 5.
Last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES, in the account of the Princeton Dartmouth swimming meet, reported that "the Elis were not scheduled for competition today (Saturday)."

Three books on the Far East are included in Doubleday, Doran's plans for next month. The first two are "Ramparts of the Pacific," by Hallett Abend, and "Our Enemy Japan," by Wilfrid Fleisher, both due next Friday. On March 20 Maurice Hindus's "Russia and Japan Must Fight" will be released.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that all sales on registered securities exchanges during January totaled $638,247,406, a decrease of 47.7 per cent from the value of the turnover in December and of 16.1 per cent, as compared with January, a year ago.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- The Melbourne Herald today quoted "a highly qualified American observer" just arrived from Singapore as saying that Japan's next probable move against Australia would be powerful bombing attacks designed to immobilize such industrial centers as New Castle, Sydney and Melbourne rather than an immediate invasion.

MAINE is already making plans for the Summer camping season, a season that usually finds crowds of vacationists turning to Northern pines and lakes. The State has 225 children's camps, and from present indications there will be unusual demands made on them.

WITH GENERAL MacARTHUR'S ARMY IN THE PHILIPPINES, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- There is a growing belief among American troops on Bataan Peninsula that the Japanese "missed the boat" when they failed to reinforce the crack shock troops they landed behind General Douglas MacArthur's lines.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Closing of spreads with rye, combined with persistent buying by cash and commission houses resulted today in corn showing independent strength on the Board of Trade. There was some buying, brokers said, by traders who frequently operate on the so-called "calendar date" theory.

THE set-backs of the United States in the first three months of the war have been the result not so much of military failure as of intellectual failure. It is true that we have not been prepared, but we have been better prepared materially than mentally. We have not been outfought or out-manned or outgunned so much as we have been out-manoeuvred and out-thought.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 28 -- Eighty days before the celebration of the Red Army's twenty-fourth birthday, Russia -- if German propaganda claims were to be believed -- stood no chance of ever celebrating that anniversary unless it were at gatherings of veterans of the Hitler Blitzkrieg in tiny hamlets "somewhere in Siberia.

The Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church, organized in 1916-1917 with an initial reserve of $8,750,000, completed yesterday its twenty-fifth year of operation for the benefit of aged and infirm clergymen and their families. Its assets have increased to a total of more than $35,500,000.

Between today and midnight of Monday, March 16, more persons than ever before will pay the largest sum ever collected through a government's income tax levies. The nation, from the individual who is to get his baptism into the rapidly broadening group of income tax payers to the giant corporation which will pay millions of dollars into the government's coffers, is becoming tax-conscious.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Britain is rationed one way or another up to the hilt. Things not pegged down by coupon are in such short supply that most often a search for some innocent article quickly turns into an exhausting treasure hunt.

THIS may be an aimless observation, but has it ever occurred to you that every American screen idol of the masculine sex, bar a few, has had to submit his screen person to a shocking amount of abuse? We don't mean abuse of a mental or emotional variety alone, we mean some real physical punishment, or shellacking, as it is commonly known.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- How science in the Soviet Union has been mobilied for war is described by the physicist Peter Kapitza in an article in the Red Star, the army newspaper.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Will Harridge, American League president, said today that speculation about this player and that leaving his Army or Navy post this Summer to play in an occasional game with his former team is a waste of words, inasmuch as a major league rule prevents such a step.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 28 -- Despite favorable construction placed on dispatches from Washington, some foreign circles here consider that "explanations" between the Vichy and Washington governments are by no means at an end and remain "delicate."

IT might be inopportune, when eminence is judged by the quantity of successfully engineered publicity, when snap judgment as recorded by the inquiring reporter method is accepted as valid public opinion, to measure the stature of the patient, unspectacular man of character who is Secretary of State. Cordell Hull is no pay dirt for the gossip columns.

LAKELAND, Fla. -- Florida's season has flourished with surprising vigor during the past two weeks because thousands of persons who had decided to remain close to their home base because of the tire shortage have turned to train and plane to get the vacation they thought would have to wait until the war was won.
THE jacket has forestalled us. This is a "lovely" book, lovely as a beautiful face mirroring an exquisite spirit is lovely; or as an old-world garden can be lovely on a fresh, cool Summer morning.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- The British merchant ship Macgregor was sunk Friday off the Dominican coast by two enemy submarines, it was announced officially today.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- In bright moonlight last night British parachute troops carried out a raid on a German radio detection station at Bruneval, twelve miles north of Havre, with light casualties.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- To assure more effective counseling of students on problems growing out of America's war efforts, Colgate University has adopted a six-point program recommended by its emergency curriculum committee headed by Dr. Leo L. Rockwell, director of the School of Languages.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communiqu today:

Around metropolitan waterways where yachtsmen must be registered by the Coast Guard henceforth, the commodores and flag officers of clubs are very sensibly arranging special gatherings of members, inviting Coast Guard officers to come and describe the new regulations.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A joint Admiralty, War Office and Air Ministry communiqu said:

SLOW paralysis of that useful implement, the automobile, has set in. The condition will spread over the United States gradually next Summer, Fall and thereafter. Already a few passenger cars, caught with worn tires by Federal rationing, stand in ghostly solitude gathering dust in garages.

Although one-eighth of the total output of the Swedish shipyards has been pledged to Germany under a reciprocal agreement covering the four-year period of 1941 to 1944, Germany has not been able to fulfill her commitments and the program is far behind schedule, according to figures received here by radio last week by the American-Swedish News Exchange, Inc., 630 Fifth Avenue.

Increasing war production is offsetting declines in nonessential manufacturing with the result that general business conditions showed little change last month, according to the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, released yesterday.

THE historical novel may be defined as that novel in which the world of yesterday is pictured in terms which the world of today can understand. Our own time, so abundant in those dubious virtues which go under the general heading of "history in the making," seems particularly conducive to intelligent interpretation of turbulent historic epochs of the remote past.

The unpredictable Gilbert Dodds of the Boston A.A. essayed his first major mile race in Madison Square Garden last night and, amid the thunderous roar of a frenzied crowd of 14,000, he beat the hitherto unbeatable one, Leslie MacMitchell.

TOKYO, Feb. 28 (From Japanese Broadcasts Recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Naotaka Sato, one of Japan's most astute diplomats, was named Ambassador to Russia today. The Premier, General Hideki Tojo, warned that Japan's northern defenses were so strong that they provide "absolute security" against any threat from that direction.

A SENSE of desperate urgency grips this mass-production capital. The city that fathered the speed age in the factory and on the highway and helped step up the whole pace of modern living is being called upon to give fresh proof of its productive genius in a field in which speed may determine the course of civilization for centuries to come -- the conversion of automobile facilities to the manufacture of arms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- From July 1, 1941, to Jan. 31, 1942, 1,800,000 men and women received defense training as compared with 1,500,000 during the preceding twelve-month period, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, stated today.

Despite the dispatch from Baltimore to the effect that a photographic robot last year saved the Glenn L. Martin Company's airplane plant fully 750,000 draftsman-hours, there need be no fear of the draftsman's displacement. He is indispensable. He is the man behind the blueprint.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A half-dozen additional industries will feel the pinch of wartime restrictions in March, as orders of the War Production Board, limiting the manufacture and delivery of a number of products, go into effect. The orders, designed to save supplies of critical raw materials, range from partial curtailment of the use of certain materials to complete prohibition of manufacture.

BLACKOUT: For almost six years the giant, block-long Wrigley electric display sign, one of the world's largest, has blazed on New York's Times Square. It used 29,508 lamps and 1,084 feet of neon tubing and cost $10,000 monthly to operate. Last week it was blacked out.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Weathering one of the longest and most turbulent Congressional storms that have broken since this country became a belligerent, the second War Powers Bill, granting new and broadened authorities to the executive branch of the government and imposing stiff penalties for violations of priorities orders, was passed by an almost unanimous viva voce vote of the House of Representatives late today.

FLASH bulbs are obtainable at the stores in about the same quantities that amateurs normally purchase them, despite current rumors to the contrary. The rumors were based on a temporary freezing order on aluminum issued a few weeks back, which has now been lifted.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Armstrong Rowley of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Schuyler Rowley, to Ensign Herbert Melville Dowsett Jr., U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dowsett of Honolulu and New York.

MARYKNOLL, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- On an exposed hilltop during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor a group of Maryknoll sisters, on an errand of mercy, escaped injury from the bombs and machine-gun bullets that rained about them, according to a letter received by the mother house here from one of the group, Sister Mary Cecile O'Neill, of Forge Village, Mass.

THE use of simple and graphic symbols in political propaganda by the totalitarian States -- swastika or fasces -- is based on two principles, according to experts in the field. The first is the direct eye appeal, which makes the symbol register forcefully and unmistakably on the mind; the second is the infinite variety of ideas which can be associated with the symbol, limited only by the ingenuity of the partisan interpreters.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- In its communiqu today, reporting the line now held by General MacArthur's forces, the War Department said that the Japanese, greatly superior numerically, were holding their main battle positions on Bataan Peninsula; but it was assumed from the Army's report that they had lost considerable men and materials, in addition to having the initiative taken from them.

Thoroughgoing revision of the college curriculum to permit students to concentrate on a few areas of knowledge instead of touching many subjects only briefly was proposed in a report yesterday by Professor Harry N. Rivlin, chairman of the Queens College Education Department.

"HISTORIC Silver of the Colonies, and Its Makers," by Francis Hill Bigelow, is another one of the splendid standard books of reference that the Macmillan Company has brought out in a low-priced edition of merit and durability ($1.69).

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 28 -- Vinum, lightly regarded gelding of Endovina and Terry, challenged powerfully in the stretch today to win the Mountain Valley Handicap at Oaklawn Park. The 5-year-old bay traversed the mile and sixteenth course in 1:48 3-5 and paid 9 to 2.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Requested and Market Wise won at Hialeah Park today, the former in the Flamingo Stakes to establish himself as the Kentucky Derby favorite and the other in a thrilling clash of champions to become the standout horse for next Saturday's $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup Handicap.
WHETHER another little spurt in the hoarding movement is under way or not was not too clear from retail reports in the week. The holiday threw out comparisons with last year on a week-to-week basis.

MODERN war has raised many questions, of which the mental attitude toward war may after all be the most important. The history of this warfare, now that whole populations are involved, transcends more than ever the records of the War Office.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- Scores of whites and Negroes were injured today in a race riot at the site of a 200-unit defense housing project, the Sojourner Truth Settlement at Fenelon and Nevada Avenues, which the United States Housing Authority designated for Negro occupancy over Detroit protests.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook signed yesterday an order requiring the city to show cause why it should not pay a difference in salary to Henry M. Williams of New Dorp, S.I., a member of the Fire Department who enlisted in the Marine Corps.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Leon Henderson, Price Control Administrator, gave out today some details of a national registration for War Ration Book No. 1 near the end of March. Persons desiring sugar will be required to obtain one of the books.

A more cautious note is beginning to creep into the purchasing picture and retailers have begun to ask themselves if some of the advance quantity purchasing has not been overdone, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A temporary price "ceiling" on twenty-five varieties of canned fruits and vegetables was ordered today by Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration, in one of the first moves by the agency to prevent further price increases in foodstuffs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- In 1934, Vice President Henry A. Wallace, then Secretary of Agriculture, wrote a provocative pamphlet called "America Must Choose," in which he urged the people of the country to make up their minds whether they wanted to cooperate with the rest of the world or go through another long series of wars.

Retail trade here continued active last week as consumer demand for Spring apparel broadened. Sales comparisons with a year ago, however, were affected by the fact there were five business days in the week against six in the corresponding week of 1941.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 28 (AP) -- The "mountain" two-man championships, which attracted the top-rinking drivers of Mount Van Hoevenberg's waning bobsled season, went today to Curtis Stevens in the senior division and Charlie Keough in the junior class.

May I suggest that the people who are making nuisances of themselves by constantly shouting on the radio that we are at war be gagged. We know we are at war. Is there anything to be done about it other than to devote our energies to our job and our civic duties?

TO paraphrase Gertrude Stein's immortal words, a Beebe is a Beebe is a Beebe. So when we pick up Mr. Beebe's "Book of Bays," which relates how "for five months of 1937-38, on the slim yacht Zaca, he and his associates prowled along 3,000 miles of Pacific Coast from Mexico to Colombia," we know fairly well what we are about to receive.

The closed shop issue is probably the most serious and difficult labor problem confronting the war effort today. Unlike the issue of wages, which can be settled by compromise, the closed shop issue will not yield to such an approach, for it involves matters of principle upon which management and labor appear to be equally intransigent.

Many housewives throw away as useless the small atomizer sprayers, so helpful for house plants or the very small garden, without realizing that if two tiny screws are removed the plunger may be taken out and fitted with a new washer. The larger compressed air cylinder may need a new rubber washer to fit at the mouth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was told today that "the right of a private person to speak freely in criticism of the acts and attitudes of national officials" was just as important as "the right of a national official to speak freely on public matters."

VACOUVER -- Canada's two great transcontinental railroad systems, which in recent years have been competing for supremacy in air transport, are ranged against each other in a contest for control over the more profitable flying routes to the northland.

Award of a bachelor's degree in recognition of completion of the period of general education is a logical extension of the educational theories and organization of the University of Chicago. Universal award of that degree would clarify the present confused organization of American education, and so contribute to the elimination of waste, in time and results, which now exists.
"Green Growing Things for the City" will be the subject of the free lecture to be given at the New York Botanical Garden Saturday at 3 P.M. by Harriet K. Morse

NON-MASTERS' pairs will play their annual two-session tournament in the Eastern championships today at the Park Central Hotel. The sessions will begin at 2 and 8:20 P.M. Only those players who have fewer than ten master points of the American Contract Bridge League are eligible to enter.

MONTREAL, Feb. 28 -- The Montreal Canadiens brought a two-month cellar stay to an end tonight by defeating the Brooklyn Americans, 8 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game before 9,937 fans at the Forum. The victory enhanced the Canadiens' chances of gaining the last Stanley Cup play-off spot as they rose to sixth place and forced Brooklyn into the cellar.

Paintings by European and American artists consigned by various owners and estates will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., on Thursday evening. The collection comprises largely French and American nineteenth and twentieth century examples.
Despite the realties of a world at war, the gardens along the River Oaks Garden Club's Azalea Trail in Houston, Texas, will be open again next Saturday and Sunday.

HONOLULU, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Hawaii has come a long way since Dec. 7 in preparing to repel another Japanese attack, but authorities reported tonight that still more guns, planes and men were needed to insure the safety of these strategic islands guarding the Pacific coast of the Americas.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- "That way lies madness," quoth John Kieran in a recent column in which he dwelt upon the futility of trying to forecast what will happen in the baseball season of 1942. And today Manager Joe McCarthy of the Yankees echoed the words.
The 11,100-ton ore carrier Leon Fraser, the largest vessel ever built on the Great Lakes, was launched yesterday at the River Rouge yards of the Great Lakes Engineering Works at Ecorse, Mich.

AN old lady "with a sweet, placid, spinsterish face and a mind that has plumbed the depths of human iniquity and taken it all in the day's work" -- that is Miss Marple; and every one who has met this quiet-spoken village sleuth of Agatha Christie's will welcome her again with delight.

With Mayor La Guardia expressing approval, the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc., gave yesterday afternoon a preview of its Stage Door Canteen in the West Forty-fourth Street Theatre, west of Broadway. The center will be for the exclusive use of members of the armed forces of the United States.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: If seed of any vegetables or flowers has already been sown, the emerging seedlings must be watched with greatest care. As soon as they get above ground, full light and preferably all day long direct sunshine must be provided to prevent their "running up" and becoming spindly. It is best to water the seed flats or pans from the bottom; where this cannot be done, early morning watering is desirable.

Three wholly intrastate electric utility companies have made applications for membership in the Edison Electric Institute, statistical and fact-finding organization of the power industry, it was disclosed yesterday. They are the Indianapolis Power and Light Company, the Concord Electric Company and the Exeter and Hampton Electric Company.

IN a quiet, unassuming way this novel helps us recognize what we are fighting for. It is very much a book of our time, though neither a war book nor a political story. It does not attempt to analyze fascism. Yet at the end one knows quite clearly why the fascists must not win this war.

THERE postage and three airmail stamps from Mexico commemorate the "IV Centenario de la Fundacion de Guadalajara" (Fourth Centenary of the Founding of Guadalajara), Mexico's inland "Queen City of the West," 5,200 feet above sea level and with a population of 180,000. Considered "more Spanish than Mexican," it was named after Spain's Moorish city of Guadalajara, derived from the Arabic "Wala-l-Hajarah," meaning "Rocky River."

HAVING recently acquired the Albert Gallatin Collection of Greek vases, the Metropolitan Museum is now showing a large part of this treasure in Gallery K6, at the southeast corner of the Fifth Avenue Wing. The new pieces augment an already magnificent collection which the museum had formed in the past.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- While trains fully loaded with food and munitions are arriving at Leningrad, the destruction of a force of nearly 100,000 German and Finnish troops continues on the Staraya Russa sector, more than 100 miles south of Leningrad.

Although the Japanese have overrun the rich tin-bearing areas of Malaya and the Netherlands East Indies, the position of the United Nations with respect to tin for essential military purposes remains less serious than generally had been contemplated.

AT Governors Island Benny Goodman had the soldiers jumping to the jive. At Camp Edwards in Massachusetts applause, whistles and stamping of army boots kept Deanna Durbin on stage for twelve numbers, although her program called for only five.

The war has created a great demand for women high school teachers trained in practical skills as well as in academic subjects, according to Dr. Philip R.V. Curoe, who supervises the teacher-training program at Hunter College as head of the education department there.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- A fighting Harvard sextet made a gallant bid to upset a favored Yale team on the Boston arena ice in the eighty-seventh contest between these teams tonight, but the Elis prevailed, 4 -- 2. It was their fifth straight victory over the Crimson as the forty-second annual series between the old rivals was opened before the season's largest local college hockey crowd.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- United States Army officials today definitely squelched rumors that the military planned to "take over" the resort city of Miami Beach.

The 1941 champions led a field of sixty-seven pairs at the end of the first session of play in the Eastern States contract bridge tournament here yesterday. Charles Goren of Philadelphia and Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York, the present titleholders, scored 311 points. Other leaders were:

IT is sad to have to report the disbanding of the Jooss Ballet for the time being, a casualty of the war. For the past two years its road has been a hard one, but it has traveled it with such spirit and such morale that it has become a very much better company than it ever was before, and its suspension of activities becomes doubly regrettable.

REMOVING a character out of its familiar environment into a totally different one is a favorite and usually interesting fictional experiment. Mr. Hichens utilizes it for his new novel, with a transition about as radical as could well be imagined.

ELLIOT PAUL, author of a number of novels, but perhaps best known for his "The Life and Death of a Spanish Town" and for his detective stories that some people like very much and that other people dislike in a thorough and wholehearted way, said that when writing he was ready to sacrifice anything for spontaneity.

The first solemn pontifical mass at the new liturgical altar in Saint Patrick's Cathedral will be celebrated on May 13, the silver jubilee of the episcopal consecration of Pope Pius XII by Pope Benedict XV on May 13, 1917, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday.

J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., as sinking fund agent, has drawn by lot for redemption on April 1, at 105, out of the moneys in the sinking fund, $600,000 of Duluth, Missabe Iron Range Railway Company first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1962. Payment will be made on and after April 1.

ABSENT these several years from the air waves, Ed Wynn would return in no great while if -- but only if -- a program he is now writing turns out as he hopes it will. He ought to know in another week or so, he said the other afternoon, and added: "It's an absolute novelty.

ANOTHER exhibition at the Metropolitan (it opened a week ago) was arranged to honor Washington's Birthday. "Men Who Made America," composed entirely of prints from the museum's own collection, will be found in Gallery A 22 on the second floor.

Needy New York families have received a "food dividend" of $16, 000,000 in the first year of city-wide operation of the Federal food stamp program, the Surplus Marketing Administration announced yesterday. It estimated the number of food-stamp users at 400,000 and said 75 per cent of all eligible relief families were now participating.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Army defeated the University of Pittsburgh at basketball today, 38 to 28. The game was played in the field house before a crowd of 3,000. It was the final game for Army before the annual Army-Navy clash here next Saturday, and Pitt's final of the season.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 -- The C.I.O. United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers will demand vacation pay each year for its members in military service from the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company at wage contract negotiations which are to open in New York City on Tuesday.

New securities offered to the public in February in the New York market were the smallest for any month since October, 1939. The total of $93,410,000, consisting of $74,735,000 in twenty-four bond issues and $18,675,000 in two stock offerings, compared with $261,661,000 marketed in the preceding month, when $240,871,000 represented twenty-eight bond issues and $20,790,000 five stock emissions.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 28 (AP) -- The world's largest army of forest fire fighters is mobilizing today in the Northwest. It will be motorized and trained for war against the triple threat of carelessness, lightning and sabotage.

HERE is a new light novel which makes the old familiar triangle take on fresh charm. It is Louise Field Cooper's first novel, smoothly written as if. by an old hand and yet fresh as a new laid egg. It is brightly humorous and gayly biting about a very ordinary group of Connecticut people.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The War Department communiqu based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

The sixth annual show of the American Hobby Federation, with exhibits by 359 men, women and children from all sections of the nation, will open tomorrow in Hearns Auditorium, Fifth Avenue at Fourteenth Street, and will continue through March. 14.

DETROIT -- At peak war output the automotive industry will have to buy about 40 per cent of its work from subcontractors. This year the industry has placed about $1,500,000,000 in subcontracts to outside sources and the average of $750,000,000 monthly will rise materially in March.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 28 -- Reports reaching here of the activities of Minister of Finance Arthur de Souza Costa in Washington open a wide vista to Brazilians for vast industrial achievements in this country.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 - "We are like the stars in the sky -- no one can count us and no one can reach us." With these words a young, bearded partisan entered and leaned forward to warm his hands over the kerosene stove in the dugout. A dozen men lay wrapped in blankets on the earth floor, rifles at their sides.

RECENTLY a small experimental radio station was moved from the corner of a Long Island City laboratory to a new location atop a Manhattan skyscraper. A few days ago the almost magical effect of the change was revealed from the results of a survey to discover how far the waves leaped into space from the 800-foot pinnacle.

AS text for his new novel, "Sabbath Has No End," John weld quotes James Weldon Johnson, who in his autobiography declared, "In the core of the heart of the American race problem the sex factor is rooted.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Feb. 28 -- Penn State's rangy basketball team used its height to advantage tonight to defeat New York University, 43 to 35, before 6,500 fans. It was one of the largest crowds ever to witness an athletic event in Recreation Hall.

FOR the actress Florence Farr, Bernard Shaw wrote "Arms and the Man," and W.B. Yeats the exquisite "Land of Heart's Desire," with which memory still associates her name. Although she must have been about 50 years old when Clifford Bax met her in 1912, she stands out in his thought now as "one of the four or five genuinely poetic women" of his lifelong acquaintance.

The Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company filed yesterday their expected notice of intention to appeal from a divided ruling of the Federal Statutory Court here which in effect denied an injunction against the Federal Communications Commission.

DRIED VEGETABLES -- In World War I great quantities of dried vegetables were used, but they had many shortcomings. Today it is understood that vegetables must be blanched or scalded before they are canned, frozen or dried. Scalding destroys enzymes which otherwise would not only impair palatability but cause rapid destruction of essential vitamins, particularly vitamins C and A.

Transatlantic radio circuits, out of service throughout the greater part of yesterday because of the effects of a magnetic disturbance resulting from a solar condition, appeared to be improving late in the day. An unusually prominent solar spot, almost visible to the unaided eye, was said to be the primary cause.

Responsibility for maintaining discipline in the air raid warden service was placed directly on the zone wardens by Mayor La Guardia yesterday when he held his first war-time meeting with them at Police Headquarteres.

The fastest mile ever run indoors by a schoolboy was unfolded by Frank Dixon of St. Francis Prep at the ninth annual running of the National A.A.U. high and prep school track and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

One man who feels no need to look at the map in order to follow the war news from the Orient is the well-known exhibition golfer Joe Kirkwood. He said the other day, "Singapore, Rangoon, Batavia, Manila, Darwin -- these places whose names a lot of people are hearing for the first time are very familiar to me.

LOOKING back on three Winters of war, I should say that our preoccupations in England were roughly these: first Winter, blackout; second Winter, bombs; third and current Winter, meals -- what to get, where to get them, and how to vary their monotony.

Yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall the National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, gave the fourth program of the Winners Series being presented this season at the organization's Gabrilowitsch Memorial Concerts.

City College's metropolitan basketball champions clinched at least a tie for the 1942 title last night as they defeated St. Francis, 50 to 34, for their fifth successive victory in intracity competition. A crowd of 1,500, filling the City College gymnasium to the rafters, saw the Beavers take the lead early and draw away.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Informed sources in the national capital believed today that the 1,500 Japanese cherry trees in Potomac Park along the river would blossom as usual this Spring, war or no war. One high civic official even predicted that "a lot of people will take delight in seeing them again."

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H., Feb. 28 -- The Ski Club Hochgebirge of Boston carried off the major honors as team racing was elevated to championship status today in the first half of the men's United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's competitions on the Richard Taft Trail atop Cannon Mountain.

Furniture manufacturers and retailers prepared last week to operate on reduced margins, if necessary, in handling the furnishing of defense housing, as requested by government officials recently at a meeting with the industry in Washington.

KNOWING that cultural bonds are strong, the State Department, the Nelson A. Rockefeller committee, the Simon Guggenheim Foundation and various other organizations in this country have been busy trying to hasten the ordinarily slow natural processes of history, commerce and geography in tying such bonds between the United States and its Latin-American neighbors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Army must have at least 375,000 more fliers in the next two years, according to an estimate by members of the American Association for the Advancement of Science named by the War Department as a committee to determine the minimum educational requirements and how they can be met by existing educational institutions.

TORONTO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs strengthened their hold on second place in the National Hockey League tonight when they downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 8 -- 2, in a game which proved to be a farce of penalties. The teams meet again in Chicago tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Here is the text of the President's order for more production and Mr. Nelson's reply:

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Dr. Claude Riopelle Gouin Forrester, who hadI practiced medicine here since 1902, was the son of Fruum Gouin and :Jessie G. Forrester. After a course at Upper Canada College, he was graduated from Bennett Medical College here and took post-graduate courses at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at the University of Illinois and at the Harvard Yiedical School.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- More vigorous conscription for war industry, closer coordination of the fighting services and prompt offensive action with special attention to sea warfare were demanded today by speakers at several rallies in Britain.

Sulphur, the versatile yellow mineral mentioned by Homer in the Odyssey, has gone today "all out" in helping the United States fight its enemies in a war some thirty centuries after the troubled days described by the old Greek epic poet.

Another sleek, gray-painted submarine combat ship was launched in the Harlem River for the Navy yesterday morning, as its sponsor, Mrs. John D. Bulkeley, wife of the Navy officer who torpedoed a 5,000-ton Japanese ship off the Philippines in January, intoned "I name thee PC-487."

BACK in 1931, best remembered perhaps as the year when Manchuria was just a gleam in the eye of Japan, this country's radio listeners heard the first Metropolitan Opera broadcast on Christmas Day. Next Saturday the series, which is now carried over an international Blue Network of 172 stations, will present the 200th complete Metropolitan Opera broadcast, a performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Success of the speed-up war curriculum adopted by colleges and universities throughout the country will be disappointing unless ways are found to help students meet the costs of year-round education, President Alan Valentine of the University of Rochester declared today as he studied a faculty report which shows that 400 to 500 Rochester undergraduates who wish to attend one or both of the special Summer terms need financial assistance.

IMMACULATA, Pa., Feb. 28 -- Adopting the theme "The Catholic Student's Place in Inter-American Relations," the first conference in spiritual inter-Americanism of the Inter-American Federation of Catholic Seminars will be held at Immaculata College here on Saturday.

FORT-DE-FRANCE, Martinique -- She sailed into the broad harbor of Fort-de-France, the American flag fluttering from her masthead and emblazoned on her sides. Boston's last four-master in the merchant service, the schooner Herbert L. Rawding, bringing a cargo of coal to the French island of Martinique, had been ten days at sea when the United States entered the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 28 -- Authoritative warnings to the German public not to expect too much from the conquest of the Ukraine have appeared in the Boersen Zeitung and the Hamburger Fremdenblatt. These articles come at a time when indications point to in tensification of German rationing of meat and bread before the end of April.

THE Battle of the Atlantic has gone on night and day for two and a half years. It ranges from the Arctic Circle to the fringes of the Antarctic Ocean, from the bleak shores of Norway to the blue Caribbean. It is fought in snow and cold and fog and under burning tropical sun.

A RECEPTION and tea will be held this afternoon at the National Arts Club in honor of the diplomatic and consular representatives of the nations included in the current Artists of the United Nations exhibition. An exhibition of paintings and sculpture by artist life members of the National Arts Club will open on Thursday, following a private view on Wednesday evening.

THIS has proved a fertile season for young people delving into our country's past, for never before at one time have there been offered so many biographies of the men and women who have helped to make and preserve the nation, whose deeds have become part of the cherished heritage which today we are fighting to perpetuate.

A large conference of bankers, described as a "clinic on credit problems," will be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Wednesday, Thursday and Friday under the auspices of the American Bankers Association, it was announced yesterday. Officers of the association estimate that about 1,000 bankers will attend the conference, at which a code of action for banks in wartime is expected to be recommended and adopted.

Contrary to the general impression, cancellations of conventions since Pearl Harbor have been held to a minimum, with most of them having taken place immediately after the Japanese attack, C.N. Nichols, executive director of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau of the Commerce and Industry Association, declared yesterday.

It was rather discouraging to read in THE TIMES of Feb. 14, "Service Men Shy at Home Dinners." New York does offer almost unlimited outlets for recreation and entertainment to visitors, be they military or civilian. Yet one feels rather sad to learn that the New York Defense Recreation Committee has given up home hospitality as an unsatisfactory means of entertaining our men in uniform.
BATAVIA, N.E.I., Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies Headquarters communiqu said today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The War and Navy Departments announced today that Major Gen. Walter C. Short and Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel are to be tried by courts-martial at such time "as the public interest and safety" permits.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 28 -- The world's first aviation rescue boat, the P-73, built for the United States Army to aid planes and pilots forced down in the seas, was launched near here today before 2,000 guests.

Emil Ludwig, the author, told 500 persons at a Stefan Zweig memorial meeting last night that Zweig's suicide was not to be regarded as a discouraging symbol for European refugees here. The meeting, held at the Community Center, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street, was arranged by Aufbau, a Jewish publication for immigrants.

WILLIAM GILLETTE'S old play, "All the Comforts of Home," is to be done -- with due bows to fate and things -- on Broadway late this month, the auspices being Mollie B. Steinberg and Ludwig R. Simmons. All about jealousy, love and misunderstanding in an age that is gone, the comedy has not been seen hereabout since 1901.

Today concludes the Sportsmen's Show, and those who waited until the last day will have to be resigned to a short session, for the curfew will sound at 7:30 o'clock tonight and many of the animals, fish and birds will be shipped to Philadelphia for the exposition to be held there.

SPRING tours to areas where bright blossoms star the landscape are in preparation. Flower pilgrimages at this season have become as important as the Easter parade. They may lead to the Southwest where prairies and canyons are bursting into bloom, to Mexico, or to the deep South with its royal road of historic azaleas.

BEATRIX LEHMANN is a very fine actress. It was she who drew all of London's favor as the daughter in "Mourning Becomes Electra" and again as the woman in "Desire Under the Elms." She is queer in personality and angular in figure.

ONE of the outstanding black- and-white shows of the season has just opened at the Kraushaar Gallery with more than a score of American artists, living or dead, included. Representative examples of the work of Pop Hart and William Glackens are exceptions to an otherwise strictly contemporary show.

The stock market took another turn for the better yesterday both in prices and volume with the railroad issues again assuming the leadership. Trading was the largest of the month for a two-hour session as transfers on the Stock Exchange rose to 234,460 shares from 213,990 on the preceding Saturday.

IF ever Hollywood harbored at paradox, it's this fellow Harold Huber, he of the scar and scowl. For an even decade, come the dandelions, he has been bucking the adage that crime doesn't pay and has been dying the death of a dog, mostly, for exactly 100 films come "A Gentleman After Dark," the erstwhile "Heliotrope Harry," his next.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- That the United Nations have a powerful potential fifth column within the Japanese Empire itself was emphasized today when the Korean Liberty Conference, meeting here, approved resolutions calling upon President Roosevelt and Congress to recognize the independence of Korea, with its 21,000,000 inhabitants and 2,000,000 more Koreans scattered through the Far East.

FRILLS: Sacrifice Urged In an editorial this morning you say that in England the small savers alone provided voluntary war savings last year equal to 10 per cent of the entire national income, and by inference it was pointed out that here was a good yardstick by which we could measure our own efforts.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- This will be a busy week-end in the Green Mountain skiing areas. High school skiing teams are completing their competition for the interscholastic skiing title on the eastern slopes of Mount Mansfield and Norwich University is staging its twenty-second annual Winter carnival.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 28 -- British ground forces and planes dealt stinging blows yesterday to enemy units on the front in Libya while the Germans delivered another of their aerial assaults on Malta.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The United States Consulate General in Batavia, capital of Japanese-beleaguered Java and of the Nether lands Indies, has been closed and the staff has left for an undisclosed destination, the State Department was informed late today by Dr. Walter A. Foote, the Consul General.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- One of the largest invitation backgammon tourneys ever held in this country opened tonight at the Everglades Club with the proceeds being donated to Good Samaritan Hospital. Laurens M. Hamilton and D. Dulany Hunter conducted the auction of players tonight, when two rounds were played.

A sparkling rally late in the final half propelled Yale to a 51-to-42 triumph over Columbia in the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night and lifted the Elis out of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League cellar, into which the Lions dropped.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- More significant than ever will be the annual style revues on Atlantic City's Boardwalk on Palm Sunday and Easter. Fashion trends of the nation under war restriction of materials will create heightened interest among feminine stylists, many of whom will join the thousands of marchers on the promenade.

THERE being only twenty-four hours in a day, although the radio is loath to admit it, quite possibly you have been overlooking a few items while cocking an ear in the direction of those great events which the air waves reflect in such profusion.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- We are seeing a radical change in the wintering habits of visitors to the Southwest. Hitherto it has been their practice to go to some resort or deep into the dude ranch country, and there spend a vacation in a comparatively circumscribed area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- J.E. Barnes, Washington representative of the Todd Shipyards Company, was called today to appear next Thursday before the Joint Congressional Committee on Non-Essential Expenditures, to present data on profits made by his company on war contracts.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Sunday, March 1 -- Japanese invasion forces ran a gantlet of United Nations warships and planes and landed last night and early today in the western and central parts of Java, the last bastion of the United Nations in the Netherlands Indies. Defending American, Netherland and Australian forces engaged the invaders.

IT Often happens that one or the other of my American friends asks me: "Has the spirit of France changed? Are Frenchmen ready to accept a foreign domination in their country? Do they give up all hope of liberation?"
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 28 -- Dartmouth's powerful hockey team kept its Pentagonal League record clear of defeats tonight by defeating Army's sextet, 9 -- 4, on the slushy ice of Davis Rink.

Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera" received its second and final performance of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Richard Bonelli sang the role of Renato, and Bruna Castagna was heard as Ulrica, which illness prevented her from singing at the first performance.

The following quotation is taken from the closing words of a lecture about Stefan Zweig delivered by Jules Remains in Paris and in Nice in the Spring of 1939. The lecture was published by the Viking Press late last year in honor of Zweig's sixtieth anniversary and was privately distributed.

Out of this great war, which is even more a war of ideas than of machines and men, one truth appears: men do not die, or risk death, or make great sacrifices, for things that seem to them far away. In 1938 a British Prime Minister thought Czecho-Slovakia, some six or seven hundred miles distant by air from London, too far off and too little known to be worth a war.

BEAR MOUNTAIN PARK -- When snow comes to Bear Mountain, this great State playground in New York City's dooryard really packs 'em in. On the Sunday which marked the official opening of the season, the crowd was conservatively estimated at 15,000.

There is an old landscaping rule to the effect that a vine is always in good taste, provided one chooses the right kind and its support can be logically arranged. And yet in almost every garden excellent opportunities for the growing of vines -- places where vines would be not only logical, but almost essential -- are overlooked.

Menus duplicating the hot meals served to Palestinian children are planned as part of the observance here this month of the founding of Hadassah and as a means of swelling its funds for continuing this welfare work. The idea has been adopted specifically by the Bronx chapter of the Zionist organization to bring home to its members an appreciation of the work carried on abroad.

A system of priorities on all shipping, under which many foods and other imported items will vanish from American markets within the next few months, is being worked out in Washington, it was revealed yesterday by William L. Batt, director of materials of the War Production Board.

We have put far too great an emphasis upon what might be called the passive phase of our war effort," Miss Mary N. Winslow of the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs told 700 members of the Woman's Press Club at the fifty-third anniversary luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

TWO vast battles are being fought today on two vast oceans. High drama and swift action mark the Battle of the Pacific: grinding monotony, punctuated by sharp thrusts of undersea and surface ships, makes the Battle of the Atlantic a grim endurance contest. The maps furnish a backdrop for understanding the strategy of the conflicts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Prices of livestock closed steady today after a week of mixed gains and losses in various branches of the trade largely resulting from varying trends in volume of marketings. The report of the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Featured by a steady demand for new Spring merchandise, retail trade was active last week in the major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

Ski troops have been a regular part of the United States Army for some time, but now we have para-ski troops, men who jump from planes after tossing their skis and guns out with small chutes to let them down gently. They are the 503d Parachute Battalion, shown here after training for a mouth at Alta, Utah.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., in its annual report showed today net operating losses of $487,613 in 1941, compared with a $97,972 loss the previous year.

FOR nearly 300 years Telefair Island in Virginia had been the home of the Telefair family. But David Telefair was 20 before a letter from his great-uncle, Philip Telefair, its owner, bade him make his first visit to the island.

Prospective legislation by States under which local rent-control boards would be established was discussed here yesterday at a conference under the auspices of the New York State Joint Legislative Committe on Interstate Legislation and the Council of State Governments.

Marianne Lorraine, French diseuse, made her English-speaking debut at Town Hall last night. Assisted by Lou Cooper, pianist, and John Serry, accordionist, she presented her One Woman Theatre before an enthusiastic audience.

America's millions of clubwomen have been integrated so gradually into the war effort that their total contribution is perceptible only in a broad survey. One significant phase of the story in the metropolitan area is the number of clubhouses being utilized on behalf of winning the war.

RIOM, France, Feb. 28 -- Former Premier Edouard Daladier, under examination as a defendant before the Supreme Court here today, made the counter-charge that the French Army High Command, with Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, now Chief of State, as its guiding authority, was responsible for negligence in French defenses and for the country's defeat.

With rising prices, rationing, changing qualities of merchandise and curtailed store services highlighting the growing merchandising difficulties created by the war, the manifold problem of favorable retailer and consumer relations looms up as one of the major issues likely to confront merchants throughout the country for some time to come.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 28 -- Winning every event except the dive and the 400-yard relay, the strong Princeton swimming team swamped Harvard, 53 -- 22, at the Harvard pool tonight and took an undisputed hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

FOR some time it has been known that Dr. Samuel Eliot Morison was preparing an important biography of Columbus. Now, here it is, in two simultaneously issued editions. In either of its forms it generously fulfills even the highest expectations heretofore entertained regarding it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 -- Within a few weeks 60,000 or more American-born Japanese doubtless will be on the march away from the West Coast "combat zone." With them will go many thousands of alien Japanese not affected by Department of Justice orders, which this month sent 8,000 nationals of Germany, Italy and Japan out of "prohibited" zones adjacent to defense plants and military installations.

AT AN ORDNANCE DEPOT SOMEWHERE IN THE UNITED STATES, Feb. 28 -- Now that the production of tanks, guns and other fighting tools for our armies is gathering momentum, the Ordnance Department of the Army permits a view, which is almost a preview, of the greatest distribution problem any nation ever undertook.

Smolensk, on the Dnieper, is one of Russia's oldest cities. Its history traces to Europe's Dark Ages when it was a stopover for traders carrying their wares from the Baltic to the bazaars of Constantinople. In modern times it has been a center of copper and iron smelting, saw-milling and manufacturing, a rail junction and a marketplace for a wealthy farm area.

YOHO National Park, in British Columbia, is one of the great beauty spots of the Banff district that prospective travelers are charting for future excursions. It has an area of 507 square miles, through which a scenic drive of thirty-odd miles crosses the Great Divide, skirts Wapta Lake and follows Kicking Horse River.

LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- Determined to bring to the attention of the rest of the country the fact that life in California has been little disturbed by the war, this section is holding a Morale Week from tomorrow through March 9.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Great Britain's lack of coal -- a natural resource with which this island is plentifully endowed -- has forced the government to restrict supplies to London householders, over the next six weeks, to one hundred-weight a week.

MIAMI, Fla. -- True to custom and with no indication of lack of interest, horse racing in the Greater Miami area will reach its climax on Saturday in the running of the $50,000 Widener, richest stake of the season, which annually marks the close of the sport at Hialeah Park.

ONE important result of recent efforts to extend the field of fiction, according to an article by Anne Owtrarn in The Guardian, has been the more frequent presentation of characters not taken from the writer's own surroundings.

OF all the plays about the war produced this season only one remains on the stage: Lesley Storm's "Heart of a City." Many people think highly of this episodic portrait of life backstage at the Windmill Theatre in London.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 28 -- The Pacific Fleet authorities today released the first details on the experiences of American submarines on offensive forays into the far Pacific. The fleet's press release said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Enrollment in the First Reserve for American Red Cross nurses has increased 400 per cent in the country as a whole and 500 percent in New York City since the United States declared war, according to an announcement today by Marguerite Wales, Eastern area director of the nursing service.

What with the increased needs of the expanding armed forces, wool is apparently on its way out of the civilian scene. When existing stocks of woolen cloth are exhausted, it is likely that "woolen" fabrics will consist of reprocessed wool and mixtures of wool with other yarns.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 28 -- Morris M. Davidson, acting director of the placement bureau of Rutgers University reported today that only 10 per cent of the liberal arts seniors this year would be eligible to assume positions upon graduation, due to selective service requirements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Navy announced this evening that the initial attempt by the Japanese to land men on Java from the sea to the north had been repulsed and that United Nations naval forces had put out of action one Japanese cruiser and three enemy destroyers.

Questionnaires issued by women's organizations both local and national are indicating services potentially available in civilian defense from thousands of home-makers, teachers and business women. In view of the plan suggested to channelize responsibility to accredited private organizations, in accordance with their special lines of endeavor, pertinent indications are seen in the most recent surveys made by the New York City League of Women Voters and the Women's City Club.
