ONE night last week there was broadcast by short wave from this country in the direction of Japan a speech in the Japanese language by an American scholar. It was an address -- an appeal -- to the Japanese people advising them to repudiate the war lords who had led them into savage conflict with the United States.

THIS amazingly comprehensive "display" of American "substandard language" (the words quoted are from Dr. Louise Pound's foreword) is the first work of its kind and will probably remain the only one for a long time to come.

NATCHEZ, Miss. -- Neighborliness will be in order in Natchez this Spring, with the two rival garden clubs laying aside their feuding for the pilgrimage season. That is the good word to a war-weary traveling public from leaders of the clubs. Eleven years ago the door~ of

The city turned over yesterday to the New York City Defense Recreation Committee a new service department at South Ferry to be operated by the Salvation Army for men in the armed forces of the United States and other nations.

Once upon a time we counted our calories. Now we worry about our vitamins. We buy about fifty millions' worth a year in the form of tablets, capsules, liquids, yeast and liver preparations. Now comes the news from the WPB that we must curtail our consumption of vitamin A, which happens to be the one that prevents night-blindness and some other defects of vision.

In a repetition of the preceding session the cotton market yesterday registered moderate gains as trade buying absorbed small but steady hedging offers. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures again closed near their best levels of the day and showed final net gains of 6 to 8 points.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Australia adopted tonight a strategic plan that is designed to turn this continent into a springboard from which a major counter-stroke may be launched -- soon, it is hoped -- against Japan.

Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, U.S.N., vice chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, will be the principal speaker at a luncheon meeting of the marine section of the National Safety Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Wednesday.

Fifty American soldiers in Iceland were "adopted" yesterday by the New York University Employees Committee for National Defense, which has solemnly pledged to "supply the boys with letters, gifts of cake, candy and cigarettes, and to make them feel that the girls back home think they are tops."
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 28 -- Korean revolutionary headquarters here were elated by President Roosevelt's promise of freedom to Korea through application of the Atlantic Charter to the whole world.

AN attempt to answer the question, "How can I help in the war?" being put by amateur photographers throughout the country, was made recently at the Museum of Modern Art in an exploratory meeting led by Lieut. Comdr. Eward Steichen of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics.

OWNING to disparity in size, the motor vehicle always has been regarded as "picked on" when it had a showdown with a railroad train. A recent report by the New York Central System, however, refutes this popular notion.

THE Tanaka Memorial, setting forth Japan's blueprint of Oriental and world conquest, has long been a subject of spirited controversy in the Far East. It purports to be a report to the Emperor drawn up by General Baron Tanaka after a conference of high Japanese officials in Manchuria in 1927.

Henry Hazlitt's splendid letter in THE TIMES of Feb. 8 provoked only one of the two types of replies which are usually made against the proposed constitutional amendment. The two objections are in direct opposition.

THE motion picture extra players, who constitute Hollywood's worst sociological problem, growled more than usual this week before an incident which underlined their growing difficulty in earning a living.

Shippers in 300 communities have organized themselves into "vigilance committees" to see that railroad freight cars are loaded and unloaded promptly, Alvin W. Vogtle, president of the National Association of Shippers Advisory Boards, announced yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Feb. 28 -John F. Nickel, associated with Dow, Jones Co., Inc., 44 Broad Street, New York, died at the Huntington Hospital this morning half an hour after he had slipped beneath the 6:1S westbound train of the Long Island railroad at Huntington station when he attempted to swing on aboard while the train was in motion.

To assist income-tax payers in making out their returns, Deputy Collectors of Internal Revenue and revenue agents will be assigned to many large banks, trust companies and stores in the Second District of New York, which extends from the Battery to Twenty-third Street, tomorrow through March 16, William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second District, announced yesterday.

The United States Office of Education has selected three schools in this city as "demonstration centers for inter-American education," it was announced yesterday. Beginning with this semester, virtually every course at Evander Childs High School, Lincoln School of Teachers College and Corpus Christi Parochial School will include some phase of Latin-Americanism.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Dartmouth defeated Cornell, 68 -- 53, tonight and strengthened its hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race. With eight games now won out of ten played, the Indians have only contests with tail-end Columbia and Yale left.

Heralded as one of the largest benefit theatrical events of all time, the gala Madison Square Garden Show for the Navy Relief Society, to be held March 10, has enlisted in arrangements the cooperation of many men and women prominent in society and the fields of business, art and entertainment.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 28 -- A big issue looming on the horizon, perhaps the biggest ever faced in this country, is total mobilization and allotment of American man power to speed up the war production effort. Russia, Germany, England -- nearly all the major nations at war -- have the power to conscript their entire populations for the war effort.

All the rough-stuff fans know Johnny Fletcher and Sam Cragg, those ever-resourceful book agents who can outwit anybody at anything. And they know that any tale where these are the sleuths is sure to be one of the wild ones, and one of the best of its kind.

Ecuadorean universities are veering away from traditional ties with Europe and turning toward the United States for their cultural ideals, according to Dr. Julian Lara, official spokesman for the University of Guayas, in Guayaquil, now here.

LEOPOLD INFELD'S "Quest: The Evolution of a Scientist" is the winner of one of the two John Anisfield Awards of $1,000 each for 1941. It was judged the best book concerned with racial problems in the field of creative literature.

IN 1800, when London was seething with Whigs, and French escaped from the worst horrors of the revolution, and plots against the King, Clarissa Richmond left school and was presented at court. She was only 16, but she was a great beauty and she had the poise that comes from never having a wish denied.

LOS ANGELES, Calif. -- Church bells silent for sixty-seven years now chime again and at last the city of Los Angeles possesses, in actual operating order, one of the old missions which are California's great historical shrines.

TRAVEL LINES: One hundred photographs embellish the pages of "Florida Sports, Recreation and Points of Interest," a descriptive booklet just issued by that States Commissioner of Agriculture. . . . The registration of New York City's aliens of German, Italian and Japanese nationally ended last night and officials expressed a belief that practically all individuals 14 years of age or over had compiled with the government order that they must file applications for identification certificates.

Employment opportunities for young men and women in wartime will be reviewed at the seventh annual career conference to be held this week by the Vocational Service for Juniors. Three sessions will be held at the Engineering Societies Auditorium, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, one on Thursday morning, two on Friday.

Mr. and Mrs. Kneeland L. Green of 1170 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia L' Amoureux Green, to John Read Taylor, son of Mrs. James Christy Bell of New York and Brookville, L.I., and of Talbot J. Taylor of Southport, Conn.

In getting children to eat a food they don't like very well, suggestion has its uses. One way is by saying -- as the spook is poised for serving: "Do you want a big or a small helping?" Often it never occurs to a child that he doesn't want any.

CABLEGRAMS and letters received last week from St. Pierre, capital of St. Pierre and Miquelon, tell of difficulties experienced by the postal authorities when dealers deluged them with orders for the over-printed provisionals prepared after Free French naval forces occupied the French colony in December.

THE gifted writer whose "Wind, Sand and Stars" brought something new to contemporary literature and whose "Flight to Arras" has just been published, sets down at the close of his new book a Credo of which, after his experience of the war, he felt the need.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A "final" solution of the Ecuador-Peru boundary dispute, through ratification by the Ecuadorean Congress of the Rio de Janeiro Protocol providing for a settlement, was hailed today by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, as "further proof of the ability and determination of the American republics to settle all disputes by pacific methods."

Store people are much cooler about the current pot-and-pan situation than some of their frantic customers. Some retailers are, in fact, quite out of patience with women who rush in and buy heavily, and act as if the bottom were about to fall out of the pot-and-pan business.
Two entertainments will be given on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis in the near future to raise funds for two nurseries maintained for the welfare of infants and children of pre-school ages.

A sprightly cynicism marks the beginning of the story of the cold-hearted professor's two unharmonious daughters, and the other inhabitants of Muskoka's six cottages in the wilderness of Northern Ontario. And a brisk gayety accompanies the mystery story all the way.

A few hours before Singapore fell 700 Japanese parachute troops were dropped on the island of Sumatra. They attempted to take possession of the refineries and oil wells at Palembang. Nearly all these parachutists were either killed or taken prisoner, but, anticipating the large-scale attack that followed, the Netherlands Indies armed services immediately took steps to destroy the refineries, the wells and all the stocks of oil.

THE American male has, if he chooses to indulge it, a new gripe. Red nails, open-toed shoes and psychopathic hats are now dead issues; the current affront to male taste is women all over the place in pants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A new flurry of strikes, most of them of short duration but important because they indicated, possibly an end of the "honeymoon" which had been observed by capital and labor since Dec. 7, brought new demands on Capitol Hill this week for enactment of anti-strike legislation and a general clarification of labor policy.

Formation of export pools under government auspices to assure a flow of exports of vital chemical materials under the Good Neighbor policy was discussed in the chemical export market last week as it became apparent that the increasing number of ceilings on chemical materials was making it impossible for exporters to obtain them in the "open" market, where prices have been well above producers' contract prices.

OTTAWA, Feb. 28 -- Switching from the fixed idea that the war must be fought and won in Europe the Canadian authorities and general staff are beginning to turn their attention to the defense of the Pacific Coast and ultimate participation in 'Pacific strategy, it was observed today.

Isedore Spetter, chief cashier of the Holland-America Line, was honored last week at a luncheon given a the Netherlands Clubs, in Rockefeller Plaza, by company executives and business associates, marking the completion of forty years of service with the shipping concern.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- With $112,000,000,000 already appropriated for the war effort, Congress this week prepared to vote another $32,700,000,000 addition to the total to speed production of the guns, tanks, ships and airplanes which the United States and its Allies must have to defeat the Axis.

Something distinctive in the way of curtain arrangement can always be depended upon to help make a room look its best. Windows, with their convenient eye-level location, offer a strategic place to introduce a fabric with a fine design. Hand-blocked linens and chintzes with their sensitive use of color and design are good for this purpose.

The soap and the sample of textile had been smuggled out of Germany and they were displayed to demonstrate what happens when fabrics of poor quality are washed with ersatz soap.

AN American, married to a Polish nobleman of very distinguished lineage, Virgilia Sapieha published in 1940 a vivid and excellent book which portrayed her experiences among her husband's people. "Polish Profile" -- which attracted, deservedly, a great deal of attention -- not only pictured its author's adjustment to an alien, baffling and semi-feudal way of life, but it gave an account of the break-up of that world which was peculiarly moving and memorable.

Restrictions have been put on the custom. Mr. Roosevelt is introduced now as "the President of the United States."

BEETHOVEN is always in season, especially in memorable interpretations. Columbia brings out this month not one but two excellent performances of Beethoven. The Piano Concerto No. 5, in E flat (The Emperor) is played by an all-star combination: Bruno Walter conducting the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra with Rudolf Serkin as soloist (M-500, five twelve-inch records).

THIS year's National Music Week, to be observed May 3-10, will be international in character, all anti - Axis countries and in particular the Latin - American republics being specially invited to participate, in order to help achieve a closer feeling of unity among the United Nations at war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Seven educators have been named by the Navy as curriculum policy consultants in connection with its plans to recruit from the colleges 80,000 men a year, many of whom will be commissioned as reserve officers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- Pennsylvania's Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League winning streak of four games was broken by Harvard tonight in one of the biggest upsets of the season, the Crimson gaining a comparatively easy victory by 53 -- 40 before 2,500 spectators.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -Pocono Manor on Saturday will be the center of another of the series of Winter sports outings for this season, this time for more than 350 members of the Athletic Association of the Prudential Insurance Company of Newark.

The long-discussed national nutrition program, which had its origin in the special conference on nutrition called by President Roosevelt on March 5 of last year, is now about to be actually launched under the joint sponsor ship of the government and the food industry, it was learned last week.

True enough, they get lots of publicity, but little of it is calculated to send any one rushing to the nearest greengrocer's with a whopping appetite. Every nutrition chart reads, "One leafy, green or yellow vegetable every day; one other vegetable" -- a recommendation that nobody but a rabbit would find irresistibly hunger-provoking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Board of Economic Warfare announced today that the governments of the twenty South and Central American republics have established, in cooperation with the United States, a system for controlling the distribution of scarce commodities imported from this country.

Mary Hallard's smart apartment, her devoted maid and loyal secretary, her cocktailing friends, successful playwright admirer and Connecticut week-end hosts could have been devised by any one of half a dozen suave-spoken writers for the slicks.

Japan began her career of expansion with the conquest of Korea. This jutting peninsula represents her first foothold on the Asiatic mainland, and the subjugation of the Korean people served as the pattern for the occupation of Manchuria and the attempt to dominate China.

INTO the fastnesses of Alaska a military road, later to aid in developing the Territory's peacetime resources, may run from the United States within two years. Under the spur of warfare in the Pacific, Congressional action is reopening the perennial subject of the Alaska International Highway.

An exhibition of postal paper of the Pan American countries as selected from the finest available collections will be held by Gimbel Brothers on March 30 through April 11 in cooperation with the Avenue of the Americas Association. Treasures to be borrowed from albums of top-flight philatelists will be worth a quarter-million dollars and will include classics of all twenty-one republics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Non-agricultural employment decreased 1,235,000 between Dec. 15 and Jan. 15, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins announced today. This decline followed several months of rising employment and was due, the Secretary said, to seasonal declines in trade, construction and manufacturing.

The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the lowest since August, 1940; the turnover for a February was the smallest since 1915, or before the entry of the United States into the first World War, and stocks declined for the seventh consecutive month, with industrial shares at new four-year low levels.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Ordered by President Roosevelt to increase the speed of arms production, Donald M. Nelson adopted today three major measures to bring this result.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The "bread-and-butter" argument over how to fight the war -- whether to trim the bread of geography so that the butter of armament will cover it all thickly -- seemed this week to be moving definitely in the direction of Secretary Stimson's solution.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Senator Stokes of Cooperstown said today that he would introduce a resolution Monday night memorializing Congress to pass at once "work or fight" legislation for defense workers who have been exempted from the draft because of the nature of their employment.

EARLY in the morning, around 10 o'clock, Vichy is on 17.84 megacycles with broadcasts for the Far East. At 11:15 A.M., Eastern war time, it comes on 15.24 megacycles with French news. At 11:30 P.M. it recently broadcast in Portuguese and followed up at 2 with a Spanish transmission.

HAVANA, Feb. 2B -- A three-run outburst in the seventh inning, staged by Leo Durocher's second-stringers, broke a deadlock and gave the Dodgers a 6-3 victory in the opening exhibition against Mel Ott's Giants in Tropical Stadium today before a crowd of 6,000 Cuban fans.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Colleges can no longer continue on a "business as usual" basis, but must adjust their curricula to meet the realities of the war emergency, speakers told the Vassar College Political Association conference at its opening session today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 28 -- Princeton's wrestling team clinched laurels in the Big Three by defeating Harvard, 25 -- 5, in the university gymnasium today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Desperate German attempts to save the trapped Sixteenth Army by rushing up air-borne reinforcements drawn from the Spring-offensive reserve have been frustrated by Russian anti-aircraft gunners and fighter planes, dispatches from the Staraya Russa front declared tonight.

The annual opera benefit for the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement will be the evening performance of "Parsifal" on April 1 at the Metropolitan Opera House. As in past years, the proceeds will augment the maintenance and scholarship funds of the school, which is situated at 8 Pitt Street.

QUEBEC -- Preparations are under way for a celebration of St. Patrick's Day by members of the United States Winter sports colony in Quebec and the "Seventeenth of March" promises to be a day that will rival the day a couple of weeks ago, when United States soldiers were in Quebec for the first time in a century.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- C.E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, revealed in a radio address today that despite conversion the corporation's payroll of 161,832 factory workers in mid-February was already 88 per cent of the average 1940 figure of 187,000, and 66 per cent of the peak of 243,000 reached last June.

Members of Local 147 of the International Hod Carriers and Common Laborers Union, which was stripped of its A.F. of L. charter after it had initiated a campaign for the ouster of racketeer elements from the parent union, were refused employment yesterday on the $80,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery tunnel project.
DETROIT, Feb. 28 -- The twenty-seventh annual all-breed show of the Detroit Kennel Club opened today with an entry list of 950 dogs. The judging drew a large attendance throughout the day.

FALCONER, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Presiding Justice Harley N. Crosby of the Fourth Department, Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, and Mrs. Crosby of Falconer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Crosby, to Corporal Nicholas G. Chaltas, U.S.A., son of George Chaltas of New Haven, Conn., and nephew of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Phillies of Buffalo, with whom he makes his home.

Bonds called before maturity for redemption in February totaled $81,920,000, the smallest amount for any one month since October, when $31,351,000 was retired, and the lowest February figure since 1940, when $76,545,000 was redeemed.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- British bombers seeking out the berths of the already damaged 26,000-ton German battleships Gneisenau and Scharnhorst struck by moonlight last night at the great naval bases of Kiel and Wilhelmshaven in a developing campaign to hold the Nazi fleet at home and hit it there.

In a message directed to all American workers, Colonel Roy M. Jones, supervisor of the Eastern procurement district of the Army Air Corps, warned yesterday that "trouble-raising traitors" were seeking to create discontent and slow up vital war production by telling workers they were being exploited while their employers made huge profits on war orders.

Mr. Farnham, who has the gift of making the world laugh at his problems, has subtitled his new book "Or Why Women are Queer in the Country." Those who are familiar with his former book "A Place in the Country" know all about Toodles (his wife), and their adventures in establishing a rural home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company, failed to agree by noon today to arbitration of the controversy with the railway brotherhoods as he had been requested by the War Labor Board.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Five American swimming records, three set by the Yale free style relay teams, were created at the tenth annual carnival of the Yale Swimming Association in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the adoption of an amendment to Rule U-70 (a) (7) under the Holding Company Act extending until March 1, 1943, the exemption provided under such rule.

Five commercial airlines operating in sixteen countries in Central and South America will receive the annual aviation safety awards of the Inter-American Safety Council on Friday, it was announced yesterday. Planes of these lines flew 70,835,860 passenger miles during 1941 without serious accident.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 28 -- A general revision of the curriculum of Hofstra College was made known today by Dean William Hunter Beckwith.
LONDON, Feb. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Arsenal clinched the London Football League championship today with a 1-0 victory over the Queens Park Rangers. The only goal was scored in the second half.

To mark its twenty-fifth anniversary and also to augment its scholarship fund, the Child Education Foundation will give a benefit theatre party on the night of March 23. The benefit committees have chosen for the occasion a play which also is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary -- Barrie's "A Kiss for Cinderella" -- which will be staged at the Music Box Theatre.

TO most people, aircraft production stories mean nothing more or less than the rate at which finished airplanes are-being turned out. But to engineers and persons more closely connected with the building of aircraft that is only the punch line in a much longer story.

WITH THE A.E.F. IN NORTHERN IRELAND, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Husky American troops paraded through Belfast today, helping to inaugurate War Savings Week, during which they hope to raise $22,000,000 to "adopt" an aircraft carrier.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 28 -- "Learning by arguing" as a method of education is having a strenuous workout at Middlebury College in an undergraduate course entitled "Government Regulation of Industry in Peace and War," offered jointly this semester by the departments of economics and political science.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- There was ominously emphatic silence here today about fighting on the Burma front where, according to last reports, the British Imperial troops had retired along the Sittang River after inflicting heavy losses on the advancing Japanese. Up to a late hour tonight there was no news made public about fighting on the Burma land front or of the latest exploits of the American Volunteer Group or R.A.F. fliers.

Although crime of all sorts, including all crimes of violence against the person considered as a group, decreased in the city during the year ended June 30, 1941, murders and offenses against property rights increased, it was revealed yesterday in a report by the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime, made public by its president, Harry F. Guggenheim.

Income tax experts will be stationed at various centers in the Bronx and Westchester from tomorrow through April 15 to assist State taxpayers in making their returns, it was announced yesterday by Wesley M. Dawson, State income tax supervisor for this district.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 28 -- Ten priceless additions to Harvard's extensive collections in the field of English and American literature were announced by President Conant here tonight before 3,000 guests at the opening of the new Houghton Library at the university.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 -- Leaders of the Japanese-American League, with a membership of 20,000, have been called in by Army and Department of Justice representatives and told that a decision had been made to move all Japanese, citizens as well as aliens, out of the Pacific Coast "combat zones."

Paintings and drawings of men in the United States armed services are likely to assume more ruggedness if a movement begun by the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue, achieves its purpose. The club includes in its membership many well-known artists.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 28 -- A new use for nylon, in making longer-lasting auto tires which can withstand rough treatment, is revealed in a patent (No. 2,273,000) granted to George P. Hoff of Wilmington, Del.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Senate farm group decided today to seek an agreement with President Roosevelt on commodity price policies rather than to press efforts aimed at forcing the Administration to let corn, wheat and cotton prices rise.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who defied his wealthy family in his youth and later became famous in his own right as soldier, inventor, engineer, business man and financier, died here today of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 68.

DETROIT, March 1 -- Ch. Mahoney's O'Toole, Irish water spaniel owned by Mrs. Charles M. Wynns of North Highland Park, Ill., won the special for best-in-show as the twenty-seventh annual all-breed fixture of the Detroit Kennel Club closed tonight.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- A fairly liberal business in cash lard is reported to be passing, with the government continuing to take liberal quantities for lease-lend purposes. Shipments to England are expected to be stepped up soon. In addition there may be considerable hog products shipped to Russia, it is officially announced, and it is claimed that a shortage of canned pork may develop ultimately owing to the prospective large demand.

VICHY, March 1 -- More and more attention is being given by French financial writers to postwar monetary problems and economics. Some of the questions most discussed are the methods by which the war will be financed, the future of the franc and that of gold.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The expansion program on which the Army is about to embark to build a force strong enough to win the war "decisively" will require 75,000 new officers this year "for the ground forces alone," John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, told the American people in a radio address today.

RYE, N.Y., March 1 -- Mike Zilinski won all the scratch cups over the Westchester Country Club traps today. He took the singles event with a card of 47 out of 50 targets, and the doubles with 43. At skeet he tied G. Skouras, each with 48, then took the prize on a shoot-off.

PITTSBURGH, March 1 -- The concentration of steel production into the higher priority levels involving requirements for ships, guns, shells and the lease-lend program continued last week throughout the steel industry with unmistakable evidence that this tempo will be unchanged for some time.

Erica Morini's performance of the Mendelssohn violin concerto was the outstanding feature of the concert given by the New York City Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 -- In the seven days ending Feb. 24 a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion found colds reported in nearly two-fifths of American homes, with an estimated total of 23,000,000 persons afflicted.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1 -- Although veto of the Bankhead bill is considered a surety, the heavy vote in its favor by the Senate in direct contradiction of the President's appeal on a basis of war necessity gave rise to limited bullish enthusiasm in cotton futures after the mid-week.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Price Administrator Henderson today put bedding equipment under a sixty-day temporary maximum price regulation. The order specifically controls manufacturers' prices and becomes effective on Wednesday.

Harry Foo, the last of four men wanted in the murder of a Chinese policy collector six years ago, was brought back here yesterday from Seattle, Wash. He will be arraigned today in General Sessions Court to plead to an indictment that on Nov. 29, 1935, he was one of the group that robbed and killed Yip Chow in his apartment at 305 Broome Street.

PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 28 -- Dr. Seth Nicholson, head of the solar department at Mount Wilson Observatory, said today that magnetic disturbances severe enough to cause disruption of wire and radio communications may occur within the next few days.

Scoring in every event, St. Francis Prep experienced little difficulty in retaining its Brooklyn Catholic high school individual swimming championship by rolling up 62 points to finish far in front of St. John's Prep, the runner-up with 48, yesterday in the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, pool in Brooklyn.

Jeffries prepared to leave for Washington to confer with Federal authorities over the problem.

Perhaps it's imagination, perhaps it's only a vernal quickening of the senses; but it does seem that there are more baby chicks and earlier chicks than usual arriving in the suburbs. Properly perforated cartons of them are rallied around the venerable coal stove in the commuter station.

Warren Marks and Herbert Michaels were re-elected president and vice president, respectively, of Federated Land Estates at the annual meeting of the stockholders. Arthur M. Bulowa was elected secretary and director, and James Seligman was added to the board of directors.

The forward steps of our civilization are marked not by individuals or nations who sought to save themselves but by people who sacrificed themselves for their own good, the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton declared yesterday in his sermon in Broadway Temple Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway.

Shortages have restricted retail trade turnover comparatively little as yet, although they have become more pronounced in wholesale markets and are causing buyers greater difficulty in filling their needs fully, the Dun Bradstreet weekly trade review declared yesterday.

Voluntary hospitals must remain in existence after the war to provide a "retraining ground" for young internes who are being called into service with the armed forces before their medical education has been completed, Colonel George Baehr, chief medical officer of the Office of Civilian Defense in Washington, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- At no time last week was the price of corn on the Board of Trade here above that at the close of the preceding week. While trading was only fair there was sufficient pressure to keep prices on the downgrade, with some stop-loss orders uncovered on the way.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Republican reduction in Governor Lehman's executive budget of $377,000,000 and revision of defense bills to include New York City in their coverage and give local officials authority over civilian defense matters are expected to feature the legislative session this week.

More than one interesting angle marked the New York Rovers' easy triumph over the second-place Boston Olympics at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, Not only did Goalie Jack McGill turn in the first shut-out of the Eastern Hockey League drive at the Eighth Avenue arena this season but his mates tallied two goals in the second frame and four in the last to drub the Hub skaters, 6 -- 0
LONDON, Monday, March 2 (AP) -- Big guns, planes and smaller guns that may have been anti-aircraft or naval weapons engaged in sharp firing over the English Channel last night and early today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The dollar value of wholesalers' sales in January continued the record increases noted in the last three quarters of 1941, advancing 37 per cent over the corresponding month a year ago, the Commerce Department reports.

Affirmation of God and His teachings, proclamation and promotion of fellowship by fighting race discrimination and race inequalities, and search for the unity of all churches as a complement to the unity of nations must be the task that Christians must pursue in the present world crisis, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared in his sermon yesterday in James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 120th Street.
SOUTH WEYMOUTH, Mass., March 1 (AP) -- The Navy's lighter- than-air craft "have already contacted enemy vessels," Artemus Gates, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, asserted today.

LONDON, March l -- Scanty reports reaching London today indicated increasing activity on the Burma front after a lull of several days in hostilities. Apparently using picked troops, the Japanese are attempting to force their way northward along the Sittang River. A Rangoon communique said the United Nations' air forces were operating "in forward areas" but that no enemy air activity was reported.

Five new films will reach Broadway this week. The line-up follows: Wednesday -- "The Lady Has Plans," featuring Paulette Goddard and Ray Milland, at the Paramount; "Ride 'Em, Cowboy," co-starring Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, at Loew's Criterion; "Tanya," Russian drama, at the Stanley.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Layoffs because of conversion of plants to war production and curtailment of non-essential industries increased unemployment-insurance benefits during January by 48 per cent above December, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, reported today.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, March 1 -- Seamen from four Allied ships sunk by U-boats in mid-Atlantic, brought to this port by rescue ships, reported today the possibility that six to nine ships in a convoy were torpedoed.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Although crop reports from the West and Southwest continue unusually favorable, the advent of higher temperatures has increased the need of additional moisture in parts of the Southwest, especially in Texas. Official returns from that State indicate that actual crop deterioration is in progress due to lack of surface moisture.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 (AP) -- A "blackout" will be staged in varying degrees over most of the United States tomorrow night, but defense authorities will have nothing to do with it -- because it's to be a "blackout" of the moon.

0nly a very strong interest on both sides prevents the irreparable rupture in the frayed and tenuous tie between the governments of the United States and Vichy. Over and over again, in the dismal stretch since the fall of France, now nearly twenty months long, relations between the two governments have been strained to the breaking point.

Five hundred children from Lower East Side settlement houses attended a revue staged yesterday afternoon in the theatre of the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street, by a group of fifty-seven British children, who are orphans of English actors and actresses.

CHUNGKING, China, March 1 (U.P.) -- Israel Epstein, former United Press correspondent whose wife is now in Brooklyn, was believed to have been killed by a shell during the siege of Hong Kong, Norman Soong, former NEW YORK TIMES correspondent who escaped from the Japanese-occupied city, said here today.

War production in this city has not absorbed all the men workers available and there are few such jobs for women, Richard C. Brockway, director of the United States Employment Service for New York, declared yesterday.
Police heroism, from the ultimate sacrifice to stopping runaway horses, was rewarded again yesterday in general orders by Commissioner Valentine naming 207 men, one dead.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H., March 1 -- The Ski Club Hochgebirge of Boston, apparently forgetful that it was the host organization, made a grand slam of all the men's awards today as the first annual United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association team and veterans' individual downhill, slalom and combined championships were concluded here under ideal weather and snow conditions.

CHUNGKING, China, March 1 -- Thousands of gas masks have been distributed to government workers in Chungking during the past several weeks while the public has been urged to buy an expensive type of mask like those carried in Britain.

Richard L. Frey of Great Neck and A. Moyse Jr. of New York won the open-pair event of the Eastern contract bridge championships last night, topping thirty-one other pairs in the finals. The score of the winning team was 618 points.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 1 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Procedures governing the issuance of entry and quota visas under the system established by the State Department for the control of persons entering and leaving the United States, will be brought up before the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association at its midwinter meeting opening tomorrow in Chicago, for appraisal and criticism.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The text of a War Department communique, based on reports received up to 1 P.M. Eastern war time, follows:

LONDON, March 1 -- With announcements of decorations for three officers of the Royal Air Force Wing sent to Russia shortly after the German drive began, it was revealed today that the Wing had returned some weeks ago.

The ninety-seventh annual report of the Women's Prison Association of New York and the Isaac T. Hopper Home, released yesterday, expressed appreciation for the opportunity, provided by Governor Lehman to the association, to apply some of its experience to the care of women in the State Reformatory for Women and after their parole.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 1 -- Planes of the Royal Australian Air Force added to their week-end blows at Japanese-occupied centers in the Bismarck Archipelago with an attack last night on Gasmata, which is on the southern coast of New Britain Island.

Volunteers numbering 2,074 offered their services through the Greater New York Civilian Defense Office last week, bringing the aggregate of men and women who have enrolled with the CDVO since its inception two months ago to 33,334, it was announced yesterday from the CDVO headquarters in City Hall.

This week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged from the previous week's figure of 103.1. The price increases occurred almost entirely in finished food products, while the price decreases were confined chiefly to agricultural raw materials.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 1 -- "Waiting for the next torpedo -- the one you know is going to get you -- is hell," said Captain R.H. Cairns of the torpedoed British tanker La Carriere today. His ship was sunk early Wednesday morning in the Eastern Caribbean.

Just as the week preceding was marked by doubt and discouragement, so last week created reviving hope. Heavy losses were reported as being repeatedly inflicted on the Japanese planes and ships. It was indicated that the long ocean journey to the battleground of the Asiatic coast had been completed by some of the reinforcing American craft, so that we were at least not so heavily outnumbered in Pacific waters as last December.

DETROIT, March 1 (AP) -- Herman Van Putten of New York won the senior men's honors in the North American indoor speed skating championships tonight by placing second in the five-mile race, last event on the long program.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 1 -- As frequent sand storms continued to mark the advent of a somewhat dubious desert Spring, the British and German forces in Cyrenaica today remained content to face each other across the no-man's land between El Gazala and Tmimi

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 1 -- Underestimating the thaw of the last few days, five Brooklyn residents went skating on a pond near here this afternoon. Two of the skaters, a man and a boy, were drowned when the thin ice gave way, and the man's brother and the boy's father nearly suffered the same fate in an effort to rescue them.

The hope that the United Nations will build "a city of peace which will live forever and ever" was expressed yesterday morning by the Very Rev. Charles E. Riley, dean of St. James Cathedral, Toronto, in his sermon at the St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

Life in the country, where fishing and hunting are figuratively at the back door, is now being considered seriously by thousands of safety-minded New Yorkers. That was one of the most significant trends noted by exhibitors during the National Sportsmen's Show, which closed last night at Grand Central Palace.

HAVANA, March 1 -- Mel Ott and his "Gigantes" flew back to Miami tonight with only one bit of consolation -- that they had started out ahead of the Dodgers in both exhibition games played in Tropical Stadium. But the Stoneham clan couldn't finish in front in either contest, although they were stubborn enough to carry today's battle into the twelfth inning before losing, 3 -- 2.

Feminine forecast for Spring: Bright-eyed American beauties with rosy cheeks and rosy red lips will appear with the first crocus and the faint warble of the first robin in Central Park. Windows will burst open and curly headed ladies will lean out and sniff appreciatively and skip down the stairs and along the avenue to buy themselves a ruffly bonnet and bright lipstick.

MOSCOW, March 1 -- Soviet forces drawing an ever-tighter noose about the shattered Sixteenth German Army now are within sight of Staraya Russa, keystone of all German communications on the northwestern front below Leningrad, front-line dispatches said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The striking power demonstrated by the Japanese enemy in the initial stages of the war in the Pacific is rapidly being spent, now "the tide is turning," and the United Nations are "seizing the initiative on several fronts," Manuel L. Quezon, president of the Commonwealth of the Philippines, told his people in a proclamation issued from his temporary-capital "somewhere in the Philippines."

VICHY, March 1 -- The decline that affected prices on the Bourse at the close of the week before last was shortlived. The market was still weak on Monday, but on the following day firmness was general although the market was still somewhat irregular.

When we undertook the production of airplanes on an unprecedented scale we knew that we needed aluminum and hence enormous blocks of power. It was apparent from the beginning that some cities had a surplus of steam-generated electricity which could be supplied to local aluminum works.
Members of the Vassar Club of New York gave a tea dance, the first in series of entertainments for service men, yesterday at the headquarters of the club at the New Weston.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., March 1 (AP) -- Torger Tokle, the Norwegian carpenter from Brooklyn, N.Y., established a new American ski jumping record today as he soared 289 feet off the icy Pine Mountain chute.

The Japanese invasion of Java, last citadel of the United Nations in the South Seas, is now in full swing. It was launched with terrific force and is meeting stubborn resistance. On the outcome of this assault depends the entire Allied strategy in the Southwest Pacific.

Mrs. Betsey Cushing Roosevelt, former wife of Captain James Roosevelt, U.S.M.C., eldest son of President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, and daughter of Mrs. Harvey W. Cushing and the late Dr. Cushing, internationally known surgeon and brain specialist, was married here yesterday afternoon to John Hay Whitney, wealthy sportsman, now stationed in Washington as director of the motion-picture division of the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

Never before has the world needed the power of the church and its leadership more than now, declared the Rev. Dr. Otto H. Bostrom in his sermon yesterday in the Lutheran Church of Gustavus Adolphus, 121 East Twenty-second Street.

The preliminary report for 1941 of the General Electric Company, released for publication today, shows a net income of $57,197,000 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $1.98 each on the 28,845,927 capital shares outstanding.

A goal by Pat Egan saved the Brooklyn Americans from defeat in their National Hockey League game with the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night. The tally, coming exactly a minute after the Habitants had forged to the front as the result of a score by Toe Blake in the second period, enabled the Brooklyn skaters to gain a 1-1 deadlock.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 1 -- With March coming in like a lamb, sixteen sailing dinghies went out from the Larchmont Yacht Club today and competed in three races.

A unique church service in thirteen of the languages currently used in the Netherlands and its possessions was held yesterday afternoon at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 1 (AP) -- Jim Bickford of Saranac Lake's bobsledding Red Devils claimed a sweep of this season's major four-man events at this resort today by capturing the closing race for the Lowell Thomas Trophy.

The first of the series of six orchestral concerts of music of Mozart and Bach to be given by the New Friends of Music in Town Hall on Sunday afternoons, took place yesterday and the program constituted delightful entertainment.

In company with several shipping and economic experts from Belgium and Norway, Maximilian P.L. Steenberghe, former Netherlands Minister of Economics, arrived from Europe at La Guardia Field yesterday morning aboard a Pan American Airways clipper.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The War Shipping Administration announced today that it would make available war-risk insurance for several trades at rates lower than those currently quoted by commercial underwriters.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The first launching of a combat vessel on the Gulf of Mexico since the Civil War will take place tomorrow, according to an announcement by the Navy, when the destroyer Aulick goes down the ways at the Consolidated Steel Corporation's plant at Orange, Texas.
The Metropolitan Opera Association will close its fifty-eighth season a week from Saturday, and Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday the schedule for the final week, the sixteenth.

Henri Mondi, British baritone from South Africa, who proved himself to be an intelligent and versatile singer at his New York debut a year ago, made last night at his second Town Hall recital an even more favorable impression, for while his interpretations had the same sympathy and style, his voice was richer, more ample and under more secure control.

The American Theatre Wing War Service Canteen in the basement of the Forty-fourth Street Theatre having been inspected by people of the theatre and the general public the last two evenings (some 3,500 stepped in last night), it will go on to its original purpose tonight, the feeding and entertaining of soldiers, sailors and marines.
BERLIN, March 1 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German communique today said:

Thirty-six survivors of six weeks of eliminations will compete tonight in the finals of the sixteenth annual Golden Gloves tournament, amateur boxing's big show, in Madison Square Garden. The program is sponsored by the News Welfare Association, which will turn the proceeds over to the United Service Organizations.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, March 1 (AP) -- The Seventh symphony of Dmitri Shostakovich, a work reflecting modern Russia's battle against the invading Germans, received its first public performance today by the Bolshoi Theatre Orchestra and was hailed as a masterpiece.

British authors and publishers are not excessively cheerful at present. Paper and other material are scarce and high. Taxes are heaven-high. Noses may be as thick as ever at the booksellers' windows, but too few go in. Yet books continue to be published. Buyers are found.

A drive to unmask Axis agents and to wipe out any remnants of Nazi ideology from those groups that have not yet given complete support to the United States in the war was pledged yesterday by delegates of sixty German-American organizations at an all-day emergency conference at Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

TOKYO, March 1 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Headquarters claimed today that five United Nations cruisers, including one United States warship, and six destroyers had been sunk in two great week-end sea battles off Java.

BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, Monday, March 2 -- In three separate naval battles beginning Friday in an effort to prevent the Japanese invasion of Java, the outgunned warships of the United States and the Netherlands Indies, assisted by their air forces, took a toll of at least seventeen enemy transports sunk and damaged and nine warships sunk and damaged, it was revealed here today.

Record net sales of $96,814,098 during 1941 are announced in the annual report of the National Distillers Products Corporation received by stockholders today from Seton Porter, president of the company. For 1940 net sales amounted to $79,650,785.

HAVANA, March 1 -- The Senate last night approved a bill giving President Fulgencio Batista authority to issue silver certificates to be guaranteed by gold reserves or United States dollars. No amount was specified in the bill, although Alonso Pujol, President of the Senate, said recently that the government intended to issue $20,000,000 of the certificates.

LONDON, March 1 -- The City is well satisfied generally with the new lease-lend agreement with the United States, even though it is only a provisional arrangement with many details yet to be filled in. "Sensible," "satisfactory," "wise," "constructive" are among the opinions expressed in describing this effort of the two governments to look well ahead and avoid the mistakes made in dealing with world economic affairs after the last war.

Americans must enter the war in the same spirit that Christ entered the Garden of Gethsemane, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday in the second in a series of Lenten sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Connecticut Light and Power Company reported yesterday for 1941 a net income of $3,752,340, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $2.94 a common share and compared with $4,063,698, or $3.21 a common share, in 1940.

Long island University and City College virtually assured themselves of berths in the national invitation tournament; Dartmouth moved closer to its fifth successive Eastern League title and Rochester Rhode Island State and Penn State carried on at the head of the general standings in the East's major developments in college basketball last week.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 28 (Delayed) -- The thin veneer of admiration for Greece, her culture and her people that the Germans professed so ardently when they conquered that country has now rubbed away. It has been replaced by hatred and contempt. Adolf Hitler's "new order" is being deliberately foisted on the country; and the "new order" in Greece means, plainly, starvation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 1 -- Reports were current in Stockholm tonight that the visit to Reichsfuehrer Hitler's headquarters of Count Fredrich Werner von der Schulenburg, former German Ambassador to Moscow, was connected with the possibility of an offer of peace to Russia.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 1 -- This community of 145,000 persons staged tonight the first blackout in the history of Westchester County but failed to reckon with a moon so bright that a boy played solitaire on a main street all through the test.

The new month will bring the usually varied list of new books but particularly there will be an abundance of new fiction. Much of it will be of the "escape" or recreational reading category. Books on the war also will be plentiful.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- The grain markets last week again were dominated by action by Congress on bills designed to prevent sales of government-owned grain, especially wheat and corn, below parity prices and a possible Presidential veto if the farm bloc should succeed in obtaining favorable action.

Interruptions to package campaigns as a result of packaging difficulties will be only temporary, it is believed by manufacturers and agency men. For the next few months packers of coffee, pork and beans, dog foods and other products barred from the use of tin will spend their time developing new containers, and when these are ready advertising will be resumed to announce them.

PEARL HARBOR, March 1 -- Details were added today to a story of survival against the sea and starvation by three enlisted fliers from a Navy bomber who crashed in the South Pacific in January and who returned safely to a Pacific operating base.

Tin cans were added yesterday to the list of waste materials that should be saved for possible conversion to war purposes. Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee, appealed to New York housewives to save their tin cans, pointing out that the fall of Singapore had deprived the United States of its principal source of tin.

Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved last week within a narrow range, and at the close of trading on Saturday showed net gains for the period of 8 to 12 points. This compared with net decreases of 3 to 8 points in the previous week.

In his latest book Richard Church, an accomplished English poet and critic of poetry, as well as novelist, fears for the future of his ancient trade. Poetry has flourished like a green bay tree in the last forty years, but this war, he thinks, may ruin it. Poets will be poor after the war.
Changes in the control of two hotels in the midtown section of Manhattan were announced over the week-end.
Increased activity in industrial realty in New Jersey is indicated by reports of deals over the weekend.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Netherlands Indies, Monday, March, 2 (U.P.) -- Bombing of enemy vessels off Rembang that lasted throughout Saturday night and continued without cease yesterday sank at least one transport and damaged another, it was reported here today.

Following the failure of the Tammany executive committee last Friday to elect a leader to succeed Christopher D. Sullivan, Harold R. Moskovit, State president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, announced yesterday that this New Deal organization had demanded that David H. Knott, chairman, call a meeting of the New York County Democratic Committee to elect a new leader and return control of the party organization in Manhattan to its rank and file.

The report of the Pure Oil Company for 1941, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $15,285,255 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $2.86 on each of 3,982,031 common shares outstanding.

An article in your Feb. 22 issue gives the erroneous impression that the Investment Bankers Association of America had made a sudden about face in policy, particularly in its relations with such governmental agencies as the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Treasury Department.

Following a wave of early morning hold-ups yesterday in Brooklyn and Queens in which four men, including a Brooklyn police lieutenant, were shot, the Brooklyn police arrested last night four ex-convicts who, according to Assistant District Attorney Edward Hefferman, admitted committing twenty-three robberies in Brooklyn and Queens within the last two months.
A syndicate headed by R.S. Dickson Co., Inc., was the successful bidder on Saturday for $975,000 of refunding bonds of Sheffield, Ala., bearing interest at the rate of 4 per cent.

The New York Contract Distribution Branch of the War Production Board is now negotiating for small business men of New York State more than $55,000,000 monthly in prime- and sub-contracts, it was announced at the local office last night.

In its quarterly survey of loans and commitments made by commercial banks to finance war goods production, the American Bankers Association states that in the three months ended Dec. 31, 1941, there was a further increase of $464,289,460 in such bank loans and commitments.

The Alleghany Corporation reported yesterday for 1941 a net income of $1,999,043 after expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with $1,434,839 in 1940. The company's total income from dividends and interest was $6,290,828, against $6,877,081.

Entry of the United States into World War II has resulted in a deeper and "mellower" interest in religious expression among the 50,000 students in New York's four municipal colleges, according to the results of a survey made public yesterday by the Board of Higher Education.

LONDON, March 1 -- The stock markets here experienced last week a noticeable recovery from the numbing shock of the loss of Singapore. The nervous selling that followed that disaster ceased and fresh buyers appeared, encouraged by the formation of a new War Cabinet and the consequent averting of a domestic political crisis.
BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, March 1 (AP) -- The text of today's regular communique follows:

The Times Square and Columbus Circle areas experienced a partial "blackout" for seven minutes last night, beginning at 8:15 o'clock, when sixteen large advertising signs were switched off simultaneously from a central control point.

High marks in college do not indicate high salaries or advancement in later life, according to a ten-year analysis made public here yesterday in the Thirty-sixth Annual Report of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.

LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- A charge led by a sergeant of the Seaforth Highlanders was the turning-point in the raid by British parachute troops on the French, coast at Bruneval, twelve miles north of Havre, in the early hours yesterday morning.

Prizes were announced yesterday in the second Regional High School Art Exhibit, which will be opened to the public today on the fifth floor of R.H. Macy Co. This show is a part of the Fifteenth Annual National High School Art Exhibition co-sponsored by the department store and Scholastic Magazine.

Several days ago I read an article in your paper to the effect that the government, through the Donovan and Rockefeller committees, was endeavoring to arrange with the owners of short-wave transmitters in the United States to purchase all the available time for propaganda purposes.

BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, Monday, March 2 -- Striking swiftly through the plantations and estates of a broad coastal plain, Japan's invading forces have driven forty miles to capture the city of Subang, which lies about the same distance north and slightly east of this headquarters of the Royal Netherlands Indies Army, the defenders acknowledged today.

The city's brilliant electric advertising signs, within the next ten days, either will be so wired that they can be turned off instantly in case of a blackout alarm or darkened permanently, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in one of his weekly "Talks to the People" from City Hall via WNYC, the municipal radio station.
Hornblower Weeks and G.M.-P. Murphy Co. will complete their consolidation on March 16, according to a joint announcement yesterday. The name of the first firm will be continued.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 1 -- If the United Nations are to win the war as well as the peace a constructive world unity program based on a new international order must be formulated at once, Dr. Frederick L. Schuman, Professor of Political Science at Williams College, said today at the closing session of the Vassar College Political Association Conference.

Management troubles of the Breeze Corporations, Inc., took a new turn over the week-end, when material mailed to the stockholders indicated that a proxy fight was in preparation for the general meeting of March 18.
The consumer with an eye on the rubber situation as it affects her personal and household comfort can take heart in the fact that two wise old "institutions" of responsibility are not neglecting her.

Women's suits and slacks continued among the most active items last week, where fabric and labor scarcities did not interfere. Shortages prevail in practically all markets, with deliveries growing more acute every day and many lines being withdrawn from sale.

Coordination of the functions of Federal, State and municipal civil service agencies to recruit personnel for all levels of government is of "foremost importance" to meet war demands, the National Civil Service Reform League declared yesterday in its annual report.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The lull that followed the general advance of General Douglas MacArthur's forces against the Japanese in the Battle of Bataan in the Philippines continued throughout yesterday, a communique issued by the War Department this afternoon reported.

AMERICAN VOLUNTEER GROUP HEADQUARTERS IN SOUTHWESTERN CHINA, Feb. 28 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- An American volunteer pilot, returning here from Burma, said today that the Burmese were killing unarmed British citizens and aiding the advancing Japanese in every way.

BOSTON, March 1 (AP) -- Held scoreless for ten games, Roy Conacher, owner of one of the hardest shots in the National Hockey League ranks, rifled in two goals tonight while the Boston Bruins battled the Detroit Red Wings to an overtime 3-3 tie at the Garden.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- Hank Goldup's goal with less than three minutes to play gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 4-to-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight. A crowd of 18,149 witnessed the contest at the Chicago Stadium.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Anne Baxter will play the feminine lead in "The Pied Piper" with Monty Woolley and Roddy McDowall. Irving Pichel will direct the film for Twentieth Century-Fox, replacing Archie Mayo, who has been switched to "The Night the World Shook," which will be Jean Gabin's next picture.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1 -- A statement that labor must do more to solve the complex economic problems brought by the war was made today by Dan A. West, director of the consumer division of the Office of Price Administration.

The Port of New York Authority in 1941 had total operating revenue and income of $18,711,641, an increase of 10 per cent, according to a report to be made public today. The net available for sinking funds, reserve funds, etc., amounted to $8,740,131.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 1 -- ''Military necessity," not "public clamor," will be the Army's only guide in determining the extent of the coming evacuation from West Coast areas, Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt declared today in denouncing "unfounded rumors and so- called 'official statements'" regarding evacuation plans.

City department heads who were instructed by Budget Director Kenneth Dayton to cut their requests for the 1942-43 tax levy budget $25,000,000 below this year's appropriations not only have failed to do so but have raised their figures, the Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday.

An obituary article opposite this page the other day told of how Francis Erskine Gosling entered the newspaper business. He did it by way of the fire escape, as follows: At 26 years of age he walked into a New York newsroom and intimated to the city editor that he would "be a natural reporter."
MIAMI, Fla., March., 1 (AP) -- Marion J. Cooper of Louisville, Ky., drove his speedy Gold Cup class boat Mercury to victory in the Emil Auerbach Trophy race today.

Except for a moderately lower swing in the Canadian and Cuban remittances, last week's foreign exchange market was colorless. Little business was reported in any of the currencies, and what went on to account for the softness of Canadian and Cuban was a slight bulge in offerings over the buying interest.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today purchased "The Sun Is My Undoing," a novel by Marguerite Steen about the Jamaican slave trade in the late eighteenth century, as a vehicle for Clark Gable, who will be seen in the role of Mathew Flood.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Sidney Hillman, labor director of the War Production Board, was accused on the House floor today of having caused the barring of manufacturers of women's wear from bidding on contracts to provide uniforms and other clothing for men of the Army and Navy.

The ousting in recent months of persons hostile to John L. Lewis and his policies among officials of District 50 of the United Mine Workers was continued yesterday with the announcement of the dismissal of Sam Machlis as assistant regional director of the organization.

LONDON, March 2 (U.P.) -- Imminent starvation may force the early surrender of the dwindling Sixteenth German Army Corps trapped by the Red Army in the Staraya Russa area below Lake Ilmen, the Moscow radio reported today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 16 per cent in February over the same month last year, according to the preliminary figure of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The figure compares with a rise of 31 per cent in January.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The United States Employment Service will conduct a campaign of "organized recruiting" in New York City in an effort to get city families to work on up-State farms, which are threatened with shortage of help, Governor Lehman said today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The House was told today by the chairman of its Naval Affairs Committee, Representative Vinson of Georgia, that he had "advised" the Navy Department to recall Walter Winchell, New York columnist, to active duty or "disenroll" him.
BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, March 2 (AP) -- A communique said today:
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Senate completed today legislative action on an Army-Navy Pay Bill, containing the repeal of the socalled Congressional pension, and sent it to the White House.
Joe Lordi, national amateur squash tennis champion from the New York A.C., finally caught up with H. Robert Reeve of the Bayside Tennis Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The United States will cooperate with the Free French forces that are in administrative control of New Caledonia in the Southwest Pacific for the defense of that strategic island as well as other islands in that general area that also are in control of the Free French.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- I The Paramount Theatre was filled i to capacity tonight for the seventeenth annual Kiwanis benefit, the proceeds of which 11 maintain free medical and dental clinics for underprivileged children of neighboring towns.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Java, March 2 -- The Japanese invaders of Java are operating the way they operated in Malaya -- skulking almost unseen through deep jungles and slithering across rice plantations -- but here, for a change, they are getting a terrific mauling at the hands of United Nations fliers.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 2 -- Twenty-two crew races and eleven track meets are included in the Princeton Spring sports schedules, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, athletic director.

The arrest of one Japanese before noon yesterday near the Consolidated Edison Company production plant at Twentieth Street and East River led to the rounding up, later in the day, of an additional nineteen in the Olive Tree Inn at 338 East Twenty-third Street.

Robert L. Stott, the incumbent, and George R. Kantzler, member of the board of governors, were proposed for chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange at the first of three open meetings of the nominating committee yesterday.

The seventy-fourth anniversary of the founding of Sorosis, an organization of women's clubs, was celebrated at a luncheon yesterday on the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Eugene Willis Denton, president, presided. Guests of honor at the luncheon included representatives of State and city women's groups.

The Electric Storage Battery Company and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income last year of $3,312,415 after provision for fluctuation in inventory values, loss on foreign exchange and $3,126,875 provision for State and Federal income and excess-profits taxes and estimated foreign income taxes, according to the annual report made available today.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 3 (AP) -- A Daily Mail dispatch from Bandung said today the Netherlands Indies Lieutenant Governor, Hubertus J. Van Mook, was "bitterly criticizing" the United Nations Command in the Pacific and quoted him as saying "this has been a war of lost chances."

Railroad men expressed yesterday appreciation at the speed with which the Interstate Commerce Commission disposed of their application for a general freight rate increase, but were disappointed at the amount of the increase awarded.
Mr. and Mrs. James Lakeman Ward of Oyster Bay and the Sherry-Netherland have gone to Palm Beach to spend several weeks.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The power of the Wages and Hours Administrator was sharply curbed by the Supreme Court today in two decisions, both denying his authority to delegate to a subordinate the right to issue subpoenas to force submission of records and books of corporations for inspection.

Miss Anne Morgan made a fervent plea for coordinated civilian defense committee work in New York City last night in addressing six hundred women representing fifty organizations. She spoke at a dinner given in her honor by the American Woman's Association, of which she has been president for fifteen years, at the Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- The specter of the left-handed second baseman rose in the Yankee training camp today, but not seriously. Tommy Henrich, the Massillon Macer, was on second while the volatile Joe Gordon, a holdout was on the sidelines.

With some blackout preparations completed and others under way, it was made known yesterday that the myriad lights of Coney Island -- visited last year by 50,000,000 persons -- will shine this Summer despite the fact that their glow could possibly guide enemy air or sea raiders to New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Supreme Commander of all United Nations Forces in the Southwest Pacific, has been ordered to resume his former post as Commander in Chief of India and Burma, leaving the Netherlanders in command of the final battle for the East Indies, the War and Navy Departments announced tonight.

Handicapped by a broken left arm, Jackie Wilson of Pittsburgh, National Boxing Association world featherweight champion, lost an eight-round decision to Terry Young, East Side boxer, at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Young weighed 134, Wilson, 126 3/4.

The loss of a high priority rating for steel and other materials necessary for the construction of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel has halted the letting of any new contracts and may delay completion of the project until after the war, it was learned yesterday.

A large part of the sixth floor of the Combustion Engineering Building at 200 Madison Avenue has been leased to Frank A. Hall Sons for a sales and show room for custom furniture. The Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation negotiated the lease.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Senate agreed today to begin consideration on Monday of a resolution to unseat Senator Langer of North Dakota on grounds of moral turpitude. This action was recommended some weeks ago by the Privileges and Elections Committee after extended hearings.

Carpet manufacturers prepared yesterday for an immediate cut in production to comply with the limitation order just issued by the War Production Board, which reduces their jute supply to 50 per cent for March. Unlike the order issued earlier on wool, the jute order, as interpreted by manufacturers, will result in a more sudden curtailment in operations since it does not exclude processed inventories.

Citing a steady increase in tuberculosis as a result of wartime conditions, speakers at the annual meeting of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania called yesterday for an adequate standard of nutrition and other measures to forestall a further rise.

The Japanese were landing on Java at the very time that a small force of British parachute troops was being wafted down to the coast of France near Havre. This adventure, supported by R.A.F. planes and a naval detachment to pick up the parachutists after they had destroyed the Bruneval radio detection station which was their objective, was entirely successful.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Rejecting appeals from several up-State cities for State aid toward defraying the cost of local defense programs, Governor Lehman today warned all communities that they would have to assume full financial responsibility and not count on State subsidies.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Arrangements for collaboration for hemispheric defense between Brazil and the United States will be formally completed with respect to three agreements tomorrow. Two will be signed by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, and Arthur Souza-Costa, the Brazilian Finance Minister, who has been conducting negotiations here for several weeks.

A tract of more than twenty acres of a rich deposit of peat humus has been found on land that had been acquired for the future expansion of the Flower Hill Estates home development at Flower Hill, L.I., according to Walter Uhl, builder and developer, who has erected and sold forty-five homes on half-acre plots in that development.

A plot of ten acres of the thirty-eight-acre Swinburne Hale estate on the Shore Road in Greens Farms, Conn., near Westport and Southport, has been purchased, according to Previews, Inc. by Mrs. Hulda Steeves of New York City. The tract was formerly known as the Welsh property and the old house built in 1850 was completely remodeled by the late Major Welsh.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The conviction of New York City Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., and twenty-six of its members on charges of violating the Federal Anti-Racketeering Act was upset by the Supreme Court in a 6-to-1 decision today on the ground that the union men were exempt from operation of the law.

Mellon Securities Corporation and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for $32,500,000 of first mortgage bonds and 34,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of the Pennsylvania Electric Company. The award was made by the company on a so-called "package" bid of 102.3177 for the bonds carrying a 3 3/8 per cent coupon and 100.3789 for the preferred stock with a 5.10 per cent dividend rate.

Schoolrooms typical of those of 1842, with the reading of the Scriptures, lessons on slates, oral multiplication table sessions and pupils in century-old costumes will be produced in the city's public schools during the week of April 13 as part of the 100th anniversary celebration of the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

An antidote for that dusty, dreary feeling that follows a long-hard-day-at-the-office is a common, garden variety bath plus a dash of that nice, new eau de cologne with the rich consistency of top milk and the lovely, lingering fragrance of a fine perfume. Gently smoothed over arms and throat, the soothing stuff leaves you refreshed and fascinating.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, promised the American public today that it could "count with certainty" upon receiving all information that "does not give aid and comfort to the enemy" about the activities of fleet units in the war.

CHUNGKING, China, March 2 -Chinese withdrawals before the ravenous Japanese have developed an improvement of the "scorched-earth" technique, according to Norman Soong, a former correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who has just arrived in Chungking after a harrowing escape from Japanese occupied Hong Kong.

With the demand for contracts discouraged by the war news and continued confusion over moves by the Congressional farm bloc, the cotton market drifted yesterday to lower levels in quiet trading. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 9 to 11 points.
MOSCOW, March 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:
Trading in a wide variety of properties featured the Manhattan realty sales yesterday. Lofts, apartments, offices, a tenement and a private dwelling went into new ownerships.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation has painstakingly and relentlessly run down "an abortive fifth column in America" without resorting to the "Gestapo's persecution and official brutality," Attorney General Biddle declared today in an address before 200 members of the house of delegates of the American Bar Association.
