WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -Counsel for George Sylvester Viereck sought unsuccessfully today to introduce in evidence at his trial a letter which the agent for German interests wrote to President Roosevelt in 1933.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21 -- A revolt by Norwegian churchmen against the Quisling regime is expected to follow the resignation of all Norwegian Bishops, announcement of which was read yesterday in all pulpits.

Outgo, as a factor in determining the value of a market, is just as important as income, and when this is taken into consideration it becomes apparent that many so-called boom markets will have an actual net purchasing power this year that will be about equal to that in 1933, according to Current Problems, a monthly business report issued yesterday by Lewis Tokar, advertising agency.
LONDON, March 2 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued this communique today:
TOKYO, March 2 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- An Imperial Headquarters communique said today:

HAVANA, March 2 -- Although the "Esqivadors de Brooklyn" were unable to go through their usual limbering-up exercises today, President Larry MacPhail of the Dodgers had quite a workout -- a vocal one.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 2 -Some well-informed diplomats here believe that the Axis military alliance signed soon after Japan entered the war includes a pledge by Germany to launch an all-out drive on Egypt and the Middle East as soon as feasible, to gain control of Suez and open a connection between Europe and Japan across the Indian Ocean.

LONDON, March 2 -- Britain has learned the lesson that to maintain the most efficient, maximum output of her essential industries, such as coal mines, armament factories, and shipyards -- in other words, war production -- the workers should not put in more than sixty hours weekly and that the average weekly work hours should be about fifty-five.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -President Roosevelt issued an executive order calling for reorganization of the War Department; he gave to the Coast Guard the responsibility of training seamen and officers for the Merchant Marine; he had no engagements.

While the Rangers will be seeking to retain undivided possession of the lead, the Americans will be out to vacate the National Hockey League cellar tonight when the local rivals clash at Madison Square Garden. At the moment the Rangers have a 2-point edge over the Maple Leafs, who will be at Boston tonight, while the Brooklyn sextet trails the idle Canadiens by a point.

Phelps, Fenn Co. headed the successful syndicate on Saturday in the purchase of $526,000 of Monroe, La., electric revenue certificates, receiving the award on a bid of 100.00019 for $112,000 as 3 1/4s and $414,000 as 2 1/2s, or a net interest cost of 2.56 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The farm bloc fight with President Roosevelt over the restricting of prices for which government-owned agricultural surpluses can be sold shifted to the House today as the result of an unheralded move by the House Appropriations Committee.

Clair Bee, Long Island University's energetic basketball coach, makes it his business to know as much about his opponents as he knows about his own team. Very often this added burden of knowledge is so onerous that the Blackbird mentor wishes he did not take his scouting so seriously.

Although the American Tobacco Company increased its sales $51,000,000 in 1941 to a total of $336,638,665, net income declined from the previous year as a result of rising taxes, according to the annual report for publication today.

A colorful and varied array of Spring and Summer slacks, including denim for air raid duty and Red Cross work, was presented by Gimbel Brothers at a fashion show at the store, Broadway at Thirty-third Street, yesterday afternoon.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 2 -- Real estate assessment reductions of $476,160 to seventeen members of the Pratt family of Glen Cove were recommended to the Board of Supervisors today for action next Monday. The cuts, from the current rolls, were suggested by the County Board of Assessors and the County Attorney in settlement of tax certiorari suits.

General Marshall's letter yesterday to a member of the Senate ought to be read and taken to heart in every community in this country. In it the Chief of Staff reports that the Army has been "deluged" in recent weeks with "requests and demands" for the use of combat troops not only to protect coastal cities but "to guard installations throughout the United States."

The noisy demonstration of fifty protesting gypsies failed to prevent the induction into the Army yesterday of one of their tribe, 24-year-old Samuel Lola Dimitro of 199 East Second Street. But their ruler, King Steve Kaslow, remained unreconciled with the reasoning and procedure of Selective Service officials here.

Rowland Brown has set Monday evening, March 16, for the opening of his new play with music, which he calls "Johnny 2 X 4" after its central character, the pounder of a pint-sized piano in a Greenwich Village night club. The theatre is the Longacre.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2 -- It was a woman's horse that won the filly and mare stake, the Black Helen Handicap, at Hialeah Park today when Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Pomayya got home first by three lengths over a sloppy track in the $12,575 feature which began Widener Week.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today the public had bought $703,200,000 worth of defense bonds in February, compared with a record-breaking $1,060,547,000 in January.

The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System won a temporary victory yesterday in their fight to prevent the Federal Communications Commission from putting into effect its so-called "anti-monopoly" rules.

DETROIT, March 2 -- Word was received here tonight at the office of Mayor Edward J. Jeffries Jr. that occupancy of Detroit's Sojourner Truth housing project, the scene of rioting between whites and Negroes had been postponed indefinitely.

Historical photographs of the Civil War, taken before either photography or war had reached its present speed, will go on exhibition this morning at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (U.P.) -The Federal Security Agency released a red, white and blue Food Guide today, telling the people what "foods to eat for health and victory."

Despite Mayor La Guardia's efforts to check large-scale retirements from the Police Department, the names of fifty-nine members of the department were listed in the City Record yesterday as having retired from city service.

ALBANY, March 2 -- A resolution memorializing Congress to pass immediately legislation for the registration of women between the ages of 21 and 60 for war production and defense work was introduced in the Assembly tonight by Jane Todd, Westchester Republican.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 -At least one civilian and an undisclosed number of enlisted men were under arrest here tonight under the Espionage Act as Rear Admiral John W. Greenslade, Commandant of the Twelfth Naval District, began a campaign against "loose talk" about Navy matters.

Morris L. Ernst, counsel for I. Herk and Harold Minsky, owners of the closed Gaiety Theatre, Broadway near Forty-sixth Street, announced last night that he is planning to serve Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, in a mandamus action to compel the reissuing of a license for the burlesque house.

Republic Steel Corporation is building a large gun bloom forging plant and has authorized construction of a rough turned and bored gun forging plant among other new facilities for war production, according to a pamphlet report mailed yesterday to stockholders.

Until the last bout of the four-hour program at Madison Square Garden last night it appeared that the 1942 Golden Gloves finals would produce little in the way of future professional talent. But shortly before midnight an 18-year-old heavyweight from Corona stepped into the ring to convince a crowd of 16,503 that here, at least, was one lad worth watching.

The New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the Bell System, has taken special precautions to assure uninterrupted telephone service in case of power failures during the war and has increased precautions against plant sabotage, James W. Hubbell, president, declared yesterday in his 1941 annual report.

On April 30, 1938, the President sent a letter to Representative Norton, the chairman of the Labor Committee in the House, in which he protested the action of the Rules Committee in preventing the then proposed Wages and Hours Bill from reaching the floor of the House.

A few days ago, in a large department store, a customer asked for a paper of pins. She was told that they were all, sold. She went to another store, to meet the same answer. She was told in both that people had been buying pins in large quantities, dozens of papers at a time.

ALBANY, March 2 -- The Public Service Commission reported to Governor Lehman and the Legislature tonight in its statement of its activities in 1941 that fifty-two municipally owned electric plants in the State were in sound financial and operating condition. There are fifty-three such plants in the States.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A strong appeal in the Senate today that Congress and the public insist that tremendous funds being voted for war be used to put men and arms on the battle fronts and not on "home defense" lines, was followed by the passage of the largest war bill in the nation's history in almost less time than it takes to tell it.

Among the unhappiest individuals in the world today are the American citizens or legal residents, most of them living in California, who have Japanese faces and loyal American hearts. There are such people. They cannot help their ancestry, any more than the rest of us can. There is much in it of which they can be proud.

The Brooklyn College swimming team routed Manhattan, 48 to 27, last night for the twentieth straight triumph since February, 1939, and the twenty-third in a row at the home pool. The victors captured six of the nine tests for their eighth success of the current campaign.

MOSCOW, March 2 (AP) -- The Russians reported tonight that they were steadily frustrating airborne attempts to supply the German Army trapped in the Staraya Russa sector, were enlarging their free zone around Leningrad 140 miles to the north and were mountings a new attack on Kharkov in the south.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A suggestion that refrigerator producers be permitted to manufacture enough domestic mechanical refrigerators to fill minimum needs of the Latin-American countries, on a basis similar to that under which 1,000,000 radio sets are to be produced for that area, has been put forward here and is receiving serious consideration by government officials.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., March 2 -Martin G. Schwarz Jr., for twenty-two years secretary of the Dover Mutual Loan and Building Association of Toms River and regarded as one of this town's leading citizens, has confessed to having embezzled $309,000 from the association in fifteen years, State banking officials announced today.

Declaring that the Office of Censorship has no desire to diminish the effectiveness of advertising, John H. Sorrells, assistant director, said yesterday that "advertising, properly conceived, can help speed the industrial effort as it has in the past been a tremendous factor in promoting the American system of mass production."

Jay Thorpe, Inc., operator of a shop for women at 24 West Fifty-seventh Street, filed yesterday a petition in Federal court for approval of an arrangement to be made with creditors. The petition was filed under the bankruptcy laws by the firm of Proskauer, Rose Raskus.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Acting at the suggestion of the War Department, Senator Wicks and Assemblyman Moffat tonight introduced a bill to make the State's architectural and engineering services available for Federal military construction projects.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 2 -- Pending resumption tomorrow of the trial at Riom that is supposed to determine how far Edouard Daladier and Leon Blum, both former Premiers, are responsible for French unpreparedness for the war -- the three other defendants for the moment remain in the background -- it seems possible that there may be repercussions before the judgment of the Supreme Court specially appointed to this end.

Two five-story apartment houses, known as 3212-16 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx, have been sold by the Simpson Construction Company to the 3216 Decatur Avenue Corporation, Samuel Marcus, president, for cash above a first mortgage of $104,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- In the first official action he has taken to bring down inflated rents in defense areas, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, today gave twenty communities sixty days in which to restore "inflated" rentals to proper levels or face the probability of Federal action to establishment ceilings.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M., Eastern war time today, follows:
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Feb. 25 aggregated $9,844,000,000.

The world champion Yankees will make their first New York appearance of the 1942 championship campaign against Boston on Friday, April 17, according to the official American League schedule released yesterday. As previously announced, competition in the junior circuit's forty-second season will begin Tuesday, April 14.

Sammy Angott, world lightweight champion, and Bob Montgomery, who will meet in a twelve-round non-title bout at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, will appear for physical examinations at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission this afternoon.

MELBOURNE, March 2 (U.P.) -- The United States has been designated the key nation in Australia's new war strategy, it was reported today, and The Sydney Telegraph urged that an American -- General Douglas MacArthur -- be named Supreme Allied Commander in the Pacific.

IN view of the frequent fire directed at the Tunney battalion of body-builders in the U.S. Navy, particularly the athletic notables enlisted therein, the following calm survey of the situation is recommended for perusal:

Prices on dissolving and paper pulp will be maintained by the Rayonier Corporation for the second quarter of the year, the company announced yesterday. The rayon pulp continues at $85 a ton, Atlantic seaboard, and the higher Alpha pulp for high tenacity yarn at $100 a ton, Atlantic seaboard.

LONDON, March 2 -- A battle between the lightest naval units of each side took place last night in the English Channel when British motor torpedo boats attacked two medium-sized enemy tankers near the coast of France and succeeded in crippling one of them, it was revealed here today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- One of the most interesting questions hanging over the Cardinals' Spring training camp is who will replace Johnny Mize at first base.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N.H., March 2 -- Skiers who like to go shirtless in the sunshine will be happy to learn that the best Spring skiing in several years is anticipated here, where the snow is now thirty-six to sixty-two inches in depth.

The railroads asked for a 10 per cent increase in freight rates, with some exceptions, and the Interstate Commerce Commission awarded them 6 per cent, with some exceptions, yesterday. The immediate reaction of the managements was one of relief that the decision, whatever its terms, had been announced, because the increases in wages which necessitated the increase had been in effect since Sept. 1 last and were eating into profits.

At an altitude of sixty to a hundred miles lies the ionosphere, a kind of electrical mirror which reflects radio waves to their remote destinations. If it were not for the ionosphere there would be no transatlantic radio communication. Radio waves shoot off into space like light, but the mirror in the sky reflects them back to the earth, the earth back to the ionosphere, until at last they reach the receiving antenna.

War Time does not completely account for the lengthening days. Many are the signs that speak loudly of Spring. And so, too, do the round tender steaks that have come to town remind us of the pleasant things that lie just ahead -- walks through leafing woods, picnics and open fires.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Roosevelt stripped from the Army the cumbersome overhead developed in more than a century in a sweeping Executive order today designed to streamline administration and leadership in a manner comparable with the changes wrought in modern warfare.

Paul T. Borchardt spent an entire court session on the witness stand in Federal Court yesterday interspersing stories of his life in this country with identifications of documents that his counsel tried, often vainly, to place in evidence. Borchardt is one of the five persons on trial with Kurt Frederick Ludwig for espionage here for Hitler.

LONDON, March 2 -- The Russians have a certain type of faster pursuit planes than the British Hurricane fighters, and they also have "extraordinarily accurate antiaircraft fire," according to Wing Commander Henry Neville Gynes Ramsbottom-Isherwood, holder of the coveted decoration of the Order of Lenin, who recently returned to Britain after leading two Royal Air Force fighter squadrons in fights against the German Air Force on the Russian front.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Department of Agriculture today authorized extension of 1941 loans on wheat, rye and barley stored on farms and in good condition for a period of twelve months from the current maturity date of April 30 except in certain Eastern and Southern areas to be designated later.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 -- Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general in charge of the anti-trust division, appeared before the Third Circuit Court of Appeals today to warn that "blackmail plots" and "chaos and disorder" would obstruct the nation's war effort unless anti-trust prosecutions were removed from the hands of private citizens.

A 53-year-old veteran pickpocket with a long police record, who was arraigned yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court on a charge of grand larceny, is scot-free for the present, having brazenly walked out of the court shortly before noon, a few seconds after he had been held without bail for a further hearing.
LONDON, March 2 -- United Nations forces are "on the advance" in a bitter counter-offensive against the Japanese forces landed in Java, according to a dispatch today to The Star.

HAMELTON, Bermuda, March 2 -- Sufficient United States and Canadian tonnage is to be supplied to insure the transportation of essential commodities to Bermuda, according to a joint statement issued today by Kenneth F. Trimingham and Henry P. Vesey, chairman of the Trade Development and Food and Supply Control Boards, following their return from visits to Washington and Ottawa.

Not everybody in the world today is ready to subscribe to the proposition that the way to win a war is always to take the offensive. One can think of at least three possible voices in the minority. One is Hitler. Another is Stalin.

John A. Sweetser, president of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, Inc., said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Boston yesterday that further conversion of the company's facilities to war production and manufacture of new types of wartime rugs and carpets are the objectives of the company for 1942.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "To Be or Not to Be," the Jack Benny-Carole Lombard comedy produced and directed by Ernst Lubitsch, which will have its local premiere at the Rivoli on Friday. Felix Bressart, Sig Rumann, and Robert Stack are among the film's supporting players.

An attendance of 3,000 persons, including as special guests of honor Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway, and Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Minister, and Mrs. de Morgenstierne, is anticipated for the Navy League-Norway war relief benefit performance of "It Happens on Ice" and a "Parade of Stars" tonight at the Center Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (AP) -- The Third Circuit Court of Appeals authorized today the Securities and Exchange Commisison to investigate the proposed sale of $15,000,000 in bonds of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey to seven insurance companies.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 2 -- Soon after daybreak yesterday Messerschmitts began sweeping over Malta, using small bombs and machine-guns to prepare the way for one of the heaviest air attacks that the Germans have yet made on the island, an attack that raged from noon until dark, the Royal Air Force command reported today.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 3 -Dispatches from Batavia said today that a huge new Japanese invasion armada was bearing down upon Java and was being met by continuous relays of United States Flying Fortresses and other United Nations bombers.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -Secretary Ickes and Senator O'Mahoney demanded tonight that the metal and power resources of the nation be developed immediately to supply the nation with material needed to win the war.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Supreme Court told all the States of the Union today -- and Congress, too -- that it will uphold any labor dispute statute that does not invade the specific constitutional guarantees, and that no State need feel bound to make such statutes conform to the unilateral Wagner Act, which consists of a series of "don'ts" for employers and none for employes.

LONDON, March 2 -- The stock markets began the week quietly with price changes small. Gilt-edge issues were influenced by the anticipation of the reinvestment on the 74,000,000 payout for the called up Indian money which will be followed by 65,000,000 for Canadian securities requisitioned later this month.
BERNE, March 2 -- Germany is determined to go through with her Spring offensive, cost what it may, according to information from Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Calling for an end to disputes and to "buck-passing" in armaments output, Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, tonight told American workers and management that they have ten months left -- "only 304 days" -- in which to step up production to a point "where victory can come within our grasp."

Production of steel this week will establish a new high record of 1,651,100 net tons, surpassing the previous peak of 1,650,500 reached in the week of Oct. 27 last, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Last week's output was 1,635,800 net tons. One year ago production was 1,573,500 tons.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Indications that German-made bombers were being used by the Japanese in their air forays against the defenders of Bataan Peninsula in the Philippines were reported today to the War Department by General Douglas MacArthur. In local bombing raids behind the defenders lines, he-said, were some two-engine airplanes painted black, with white crosses on their wings.

Dartmouth defeated Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game last night, but it was not the scalping party that the Hanover Indians expected. The Green had to go all out to win, 46 to 43, at the Morningside Heights gymnasium and thus advanced closer to its fifth straight championship.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Following is the text of the radio address prepared by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, for delivery tonight:

Gian-Carlo Menotti's new opera, "The Island God," which had its premiere eleven days ago, had its second performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Sharing the bill with this work was the old standby of the repertory, "Pagliacci."
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The text of President Roosevelt's executive order reorganizing the Army follows:

Three hundred and fifty-nine men and women hobbyists who believe they have the best answer to the age-old riddle of how to get the most out of leisure opened yesterday the largest hobby show ever seen, comprising 2,000,000 items. The exhibition, held in Hearn's Auditorium, Fifth Avenue at Fourteenth Street, under the auspices of the American Hobby Federation, is limited in its range only by the human imagination.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The House voted today to provide a $1,000,000,000 fund for the insurance of real and personal property, tangible or intangible, throughout the United States and its possessions against damage by enemy attack or by our own forces in resisting assault or to prevent vital facilities from falling into the hands of an invading foe.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -A manual prepared by the WageHour Administration as a tentative guide for classifying newspaper employes for exemption from the wage-hour law was opposed in part today by both publishers and the American Newspaper Guild.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Laclede Gas Light Company of St. Louis, Mo., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement covering certificates of deposit to be issued under an offer to extend the maturities of its $10,000,000 of refunding and extension mortgage 5 per cent bonds of 1904 to April 1, 1945.

Resignation of five officers of the American Women's Voluntary Services because of disagreement over "matters of organization and policies" was disclosed in a statement released yesterday by Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel, director of public relations of the A.W.V.S., with the approval of Mrs. Preston Davie, one of the executives resigning.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 2 (U.P.) -- Jack Doyle, baseball pricemaker, favors the Cardinals to win the National League pennant and the Yankees to repeat for the American circuit flag.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The United States will soon send an important supply mission to India, it was learned tonight. The purpose of the mission will be to help in the defense of India and to assist in the distribution of war materials from India to the Chinese and to United Nations forces in Middle Eastern theatres of the war.

By order of the Japanese military authorities the Peiping Union Medical College was discontinued Feb. 1 and its director, controller and chief physician were taken into custody, according to advices received here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 -- Gun crews of an American tanker rushed to their posts and fought off an enemy craft, presumably a submarine, which had opened fire without warning Saturday night not far from the Golden Gate, it was disclosed today by Rear Admiral John W. Greenslade, commandant of the Twelfth Naval District.

A New York-Philadelphia team led a field of thirteen teams at the end of the first session of play in the Eastern States contract bridge team-of-four tournament here last night. The leaders, Harry J. Fishbein, Tobias Stone and George Rapee of New York and Simon Becker of Philadelphia, scored 21 out of 30 possible points.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -Claims by the Federal government for unpaid taxes under the old-age section of the Social Security Act have priority when the assets of a bankrupt are divided, the Supreme Court ruled today.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 2 -- The Russians are massing "almost unheard-of forces" all along the front for what is believed to be a large-scale attack, reports originating in official Berlin quarters said tonight.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Joseph W. Rowe, vice president in charge of the foreign department of the Irving Trust Company, who leased an apartment in 955 Lexington Avenue through Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Roosevelt strengthened the Coast Guard today by an executive order which shifted responsibility for training 40,000 to 50,000 seamen and 10,000 to 15,000 new officers to man America's growing merchant marine from the Maritime Commission to the Coast Guard.
It is nice and easy to be an armchair strategist, but I would like to ask a couple of rhetorical questions.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2 -- One detachment of the Giants returned to Miami by plane from Havana today, after an unsuccessful two-day invasion of Cuba, where they lost two exhibition games to the Dodgers. Another plane bearing Manager Mel Ott and the remainder of the team is expected here tomorrow.

MELBOURNE, March 2 -- Coupled with an announcement that the War Council's deliberations with the New Zealand delegation and Allied advisers had produced an agreement on a new basis for strategy in the Southwest Pacific, it was revealed today that the Australian Government had decided to utilize its powers under the national mobilization law to draft labor at army pay for work deemed essential to defense and the armed forces.

Another major exhibition of its current season opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, to continue until the end of the month. "Between Two Wars" is made up of prints by American artists, this graphic survey covering the period 1914-1941.

A decision by the National Labor Relations Board, it was learned yesterday, has upheld the professional status of chemists by laying down the principle that professional employes should not be forced into a bargaining unit composed of a miscellaneous group of skilled and unskilled workers as well as professional employes.

Five hundred women paraded in their uniforms as volunteer hospital aides yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria at a meeting called by the United Hospital Fund of New York and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Offices to enroll more aides for the same work.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 2 -- The Russians are massing "almost unheard-of forces" all along the front for what is believed to be a large-scale attack, reports originating in official Berlin quarters said tonight.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Joseph W. Rowe, vice president in charge of the foreign department of the Irving Trust Company, who leased an apartment in 955 Lexington Avenue through Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Roosevelt strengthened the Coast Guard today by an executive order which shifted responsibility for training 40,000 to 50,000 seamen and 10,000 to 15,000 new officers to man America's growing merchant marine from the Maritime Commission to the Coast Guard.
It is nice and easy to be an armchair strategist, but I would like to ask a couple of rhetorical questions.

Five hundred women paraded in their uniforms as volunteer hospital aides yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria at a meeting called by the United Hospital Fund of New York and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Offices to enroll more aides for the same work.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 2 -- A new Cabinet was sworn in by President Enrique Penaranda del Castillo tonight.

From the latest report of the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime, covering the year that ended on June 30, 1941, it appears that in that period and especially in its last six months there was a curious rise in murder with malice prepense. There were 309 cases, an increase of fifty-six from the year before.

Bob Giegengack is worried about Penn State. The showing of the Nittany Lions in the National A.A.U. track and field championships last Saturday, when they finished second to the New York A.C. in the team race, has the Fordham coach concerned that they may go all the way at Madison Square Garden this Saturday at the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. show.

Mrs. Margaret Boyle, the 48-year-old Washington widow who pleaded guilty on Jan. 25 at her General Sessions trial to defrauding a jewelry broker here of $121,000 in jewels she had obtained on memorandum, was sentenced to a State prison term yesterday of eighteen months to three years.

The market for government securities can be expected to withstand even more adverse developments than those of 1941, when it showed unexpected strength in resisting a combination of unfavorable circumstances, it was said yesterday by C.J. Devine Co., specialists in United States Government obligations.
BERLIN, March 2 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Conflicting reports from Washington in regard to the status of the proposed farm legislation caused uncertainty in the grain pits here today, and some operators who bought last week started to sell and found support rather slow.

DETROIT, March 2 (AP) -- Retail automobile dealers dissatisfied with the Office of Price Administration rationing program and the consequent freezing of considerable capital, are to have an opportunity to liquidate a large part of their stocks on a not-less-than-cost basis.

BANDUNG, Java, Tuesday, March 3 (AP) -- Netherland, United States and British troops, in a great comradeship of arms, struck out against the Japanese invader last night in strong, widespread counter-attacks that a guarded official summary declared had "developed satisfactorily," critical though the situation remained.

LONDON, March 2 -- A Reuter special correspondent reported tonight after a trip over a part of the Burma Road that it was "virtually closed" and was lined with wrecked and burnt trucks. There was little traffic.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 2 -- More than a score of Fort Dix soldiers, directed by Lieut. Col. Joseph Donoghue, post morale officer, and Major Carl Anderson, special services officer for the Second Corps Area, made final preparations today for the arrival of Private Joe Louis tomorrow morning.

Many things may happen between now and June to make offshore fishing impossible, and in view of the rather dreary prospects the Department of Parks has listed several areas where anglers may fish from piers, bulkheads and beaches in the five boroughs.
The House Naval Affairs subcommittee investigating the Normandie fire spent three hours yesterday afternoon inspecting the overturned hulk at the foot of West Forty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A Senate Civil Liberties subcommittee reported today that the national labor policy "had not been honored or observed" in important sectors of California's industry and asserted that "policies of industrial management, which, in tranquil times, bore the bitter fruit of strikes and violence may, when the nation is engaged in a great national defense effort, prove our undoing."
The House Naval Affairs subcommittee investigating the Normandie fire spent three hours yesterday afternoon inspecting the overturned hulk at the foot of West Forty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A Senate Civil Liberties subcommittee reported today that the national labor policy "had not been honored or observed" in important sectors of California's industry and asserted that "policies of industrial management, which, in tranquil times, bore the bitter fruit of strikes and violence may, when the nation is engaged in a great national defense effort, prove our undoing."

Another American ship, loaded with 23,000 tons of iron ore, has been sunk in home waters by three enemy submarines that first pounded her with a torpedo and then riddled her with more than 100 shells, the Navy announced yesterday.

Dorothy Sayers makes a stand against an over amount of psychology in mystery novels. The writer gave a talk in London recently on some of the broader considerations of mystery writing and reading. On the adding of more and more psychology she declared:...

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 25: Increases of $426,000,00 in holdings of United States Government bonds and $434,000,000 in United States Government deposits and decreases of $393,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $249,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $211,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

TRENTON, N.J., March 2--State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner, whose administration of the Road Department has been under investigation for many months, accommodated Governor Charles Edison today by resigning, but in two other instances the Governor was compelled to commission as members of county election boards persons not of his own choosing.

Terminating its run on Saturday night at Henry Miller's Theatre is "Heart of a City," the Lesley Storm play picturing backstage life in wartime London. It will be the second closing of the week -- the other one is the previously announced "Claudia."

The Bombshell Artists Group is holding its first exhibition at the Riverside Museum (Riverside Drive at 103d Street). The large show, containing more than 200 items, will continue through March 22. The museum is open daily (except Monday) from 1 to 5 P.M.

Despite Axis submarines preying along the Atlantic coast, an official good-will exhibition of contemporary Chilean art has arrived here for display in a number of cities in the United States. This is believed to be the first official showing of the art of a South American nation in North America.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The American Institute of Laundering asserted today that clothes washed in commercial laundries would be just as white and just as clean as ever, despite last week's War Production Board order curtailing the civilian uses of chlorine.
LONDON, March 3 (U.P.) -- The London Star received this dispatch today from John Elmore, a correspondent in Java:

The fifty-three-acre estate formerly owned by Mrs. Celia Danziger in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., has been sold to a client of Mrs. A.J. Higgins, broker. On the land are a sixteen-room house, an eight-room stone cottage, a five-car garage, a swimming pool and tennis courts.

Just before dawn last Saturday the United States destroyer Jacob Jones, a 1,090-ton craft dating back to the first World War, was torpedoed and sunk by an enemy submarine off Cape May, N.J., it was announced yesterday. Only eleven enlisted men were saved. The Navy did not disclose the exact number lost, but the normal complement of a ship of this type is about seven officers and 125 to 150 enlisted men.

PITTSBURGH, March 3 -- The worst blizzard in the recent history of the city paralyzed transportation today, caused suspension of schools and courts and temporarily slackened war production at defense plants in the Western Pennsylvania area.
From the jungle-girt beaches of the Indies to the white wilderness of Russia the war was moving rapidly toward its Spring climax yesterday.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Republican majorities in the Senate and Assembly after separate conferences today adopted a party budgetary plan restoring full State aid to education, providing for salary increases to State employes receiving less than $2,000 annually to compensate for rising costs of living, and claiming an over-all reduction of $2,284,357 in Governor Lehman's Executive Budget.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- Oceanblown was the setting today for a cocktail party given by Mrs. John T. Mitchell and Miss Anne Mitchell for Arthur Menken, their overnight guest. Mr. Menken addressed members of the Round Table on "The Economic Front in the Far East" at the Everglades Club before the party.

LONDON, March 3 -- Blunt statements that the Dutch could not possibly hope to hold out in Java indefinitely without reinforcements and that the prospect of reinforcements in existing circumstances was slight were made in London today by W.G. Peekema of the Netherland Ministry of Colonies. Mr. Peekema was formerly the government spokesman of the People's Council in Batavia.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 3 -- Virtually all possibility that Chile will break off relations with the Axis before next month has vanished with a statement by the Interior Ministry that there is no prospect that Congress will be called in special session to ratify the Rio de Janeiro accords.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., March 3 -- Forced indoors by a State law against testing sirens except at noon Saturdays, a new air raid warning device almost pierced the ears of its two inventors and an audience of ten in a soundproof room here today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 -- Practically a quarter of a million square miles of the Western coastal region, an area almost as large as the entire Japanese Empire, was set apart today by Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt, Western Defense Commander, as a military zone from which all Japanese, American citizens as well as aliens, must move.

LONDON, March 3 -- Lady Macrobert, who after the death of her third and last son in the air gave the Air Ministry 25,000 for a Stirling bomber named "Macrobert's Reply" has now given 20,000 for four fighters to be named after her sons and herself.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 3 -- In a second raid on the Australian mainland this morning Japanese aircraft attacked the northwestern ports of Wyndham, on the Cambridge Gulf, 284 miles southwest of Darwin, and Broome, on Roebuck Bay, 600 miles southwest of Wyndham.
Loft buildings in widely separated areas of the city changed hands in the Manhattan transactions reported yesterday.

The largest and most complete collection of rare documents, pamphlets, cartoons and posters pertaining to the history of the Society of Tammany has been given to the Columbia University Library by Edwin P. Kilroe, New York attorney and a director of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Charles M. Adams, assistant director of libraries at Columbia.

If Sir William Osler was right in saying that "no man is really happy or safe without a hobby," safe and really happy men do now abound. The Stock Exchange had a hobby exhibition not long ago. Our old friend, the Union League, forgetting its fundamental hobby, treated itself to a special hobby show.

War conditions, which in some instances have forced the evacuation of families from large industrial areas, will increase the need for social welfare services, Charles I. Schottland, assistant chief of the Children's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor, declared yesterday.

A distinguished audience, including Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway, notables of society and naval officials, attended last night the Navy League-Norway war relief benefit performance of "It Happens on Ice" and a "Parade of Stars" at the Center Theatre.

As the date for organized labor's "Red Cross mobilization" on March 11 drew nearer it was announced yesterday that contributions from all unions here to the Greater New York War Fund amounted to $241,800.

Lack of authority and the necessity of cajoling State and local authorities to get cooperation are hampering the work of the office of Civilian Defense, Colonel Walter W. Metcalf, acting regional director for the Second Defense Area, declared yesterday at the opening of the thirteenth annual Safety Convention sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

LONDON, March 3 -- It will take more than another year to scale the British standard of living down to a strict war-economy level, Hugh Dalton, president of the Board of Trade, said today in commenting on his new job and on the one he has just left at the Ministry of Economic Warfare.
LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- Here are Britain's basic war rations in the thirtieth month of war:

Resignation of Dr. Herman Feldman from the $9,000-a-year post of dean of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration was announced last night by the college administrative committee of the Board of Higher Education.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Indication that amendments to the installment credit regulations designed to tighten them and extend their scope would be announced within the next ten days was given today by the Federal Reserve Board simultaneously with a Commerce Department prediction that before the war ends Americans will have paid off most of the $9,500,000,000 of installment debt they owed at the end of 1941.

Health problems of war workers, particularly those of the women who have entered industry, were emphasized at a forum on industrial nursing held last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania as part of the thirteenth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council.

Leaders in labor, society and the arts mingled in an unusual combination last night at a beefsteak party given by Mr. and Mrs. George Ruppert at the Ruppert brewery, 1639 Third Avenue, to further the cause of recreation rooms for service camps.

Leroy Schwarzkopf, mile and two-mile star from Yale, has decided to try for the two-mile title in the annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. This decision was announced by Coach Charley Hoyt yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Cuffs and pleats will disappear from men's trousers, the patch pocket and fancy-back jacket popularized by Clark Gable will be banned, and no longer will the vest go with a double-breasted suit, the War Production Board decreed today, in an order imposing twenty-five restrictions on men's and boys' clothing to save cloth.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 3 (AP) -- Because American Bowling Congress officials changed their minds, Governor John W. Bricker tonight missed a chance to bowl 36 strikes in a single blast at the pins, as the ABC tourney opened.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 3 (AP) -- Fighting off a last-half bid, Seton Hall College defeated a tenacious La Salle quintet, 40 to 37, tonight and closed its season with a record of 16 victories in 19 starts.

The New York Central Railroad spent $25,800,000 on facilities and equipment, including rolling stock to be delivered this year, F.E. Williamson, president, said in a preliminary report for 1941 issued yesterday. Equipment put in service in 1941 included ten fast freight locomotives, thirty-six oil-electric switching engines and 2,324 freight cars.

Wage increases for 130,000 workers in shipyards from Bath, Me., to Jacksonville, Fla., were demanded by the executive board of the East Coast Alliance of Ship Builders of America, an independent union, in a communication addressed yesterday to Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board Chief.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A change in procedure which will hasten inductions into the Army under the Selective Service system was announced today by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service.

Home makers and home economics experts have been chosen as members of the consumers' committee of the Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, which will hold its first meeting today at CDVO headquarters, 131 Livingston Street, to formulate a program for easing the consumer's problems.
Investors and operators were active in purchases of Manhattan residential properties yesterday, with brokers reporting sales on both East and West Sides.

The Spool Cotton Company, distributor of threads and cottons, zippers and wools, has leased two and one-half floors in the Squibb Building at 745 Fifth Avenue, comprising about 35,000 square feet of floor space, through Culver, Holly-day Co., Inc., managing agents.

LONDON, March 3 (U.P.) -- The Pacific War Council, led by Prime Minister Churchill, met tonight, presumably to map plans for Allied strategy to meet imminent Japanese threats against India and Australia.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Dairy leaders from eleven Northeastern States at a conference today heard sharp criticism of government efforts to check farm prices and an appeal from the Agricultural Department for increased production to meet demands of the war emergency.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Japanese forces bearing on the Philippine Islands have turned from costly frontal attacks on the main defense lines on Bataan Peninsula to attempts to clear away numerous strong pockets of guerrillas on the islands south of Luzon, the War Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) -- The Nation's Capital began its first dusk-to-dawn "blackout" tonight but it was not an "all-out" test. The curfew was imposed promptly at 8 P.M., and will remain in effect until 6 A.M. tomorrow, for both the city and its suburban communities.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- A new style of play, which will enable him to cover more ground at shortstop, is being perfected by Phil Rizzuto at the Yankee proving grounds. Meanwhile the other half of that dazzling second-base combination that came up from Kansas City last year, Gerry Priddy, is being drilled around third base.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- United States exports and imports in 1941 were greater in volume than for any other year in the nation's history, the Bureau of Census reported today.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Senator James M. Mead, in a letter to John J. Dunnigan, Democratic Leader of the State Senate, urged the Legislature today to pass a proposed bill prohibiting elective Federal officials from deriving benefit by membership in the State and Federal retirement Systems.

Warning that borrowing by individuals from banks to pay taxes is against the best interests of the nation and the taxpayers themselves, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review of credit and business conditions yesterday observed that most of the tax anticipation notes sold by the Treasury aggregating more than $2,800,000,000, were bought by corporations, and only a relatively small amount by individuals.

Mrs. Oliver B. James gave a luncheon yesterday in the Green Room of La Salle du Bois. Her guests were members of the Lafayette Guild of the Maternity Center Association who conduct weekly sewing classes during the season in behalf of the organization.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Public Service Commission reported to the Legislature in one section of its annual report that in 1941 it issued authorizations for $83,885,000 in securities. Since 1929 the commission has authorized the issuance of stocks and bonds aggregating nearly $2,000,000,000.

Elements that promote disunity in the nation will be examined and defined at an all-day session on Friday under auspices of the National Council of Women, at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. Mrs. Harold V. Milligan, president of the organization, in announcing the program yesterday, said that the public is welcome to attend and that tickets are obtainable at headquarters of the council at 501 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Six men from the steel industry were named today to key posts in the iron and steel branch of the War Production Board today. The appointments were reported by C.E. Adams, chief of the branch.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The vast stake of the United States in the Netherlands Indies, which is now disintegrating under the Japanese invasion, is more important in terms of things we use and need from that island empire than in dollars and cents.

TOKYO, March 3 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Premier Hideki Tojo, addressing a five-day conference of provincial governors today, warned that the war still was in its initial stage and urged Japan "to unite closer and overcome all difficulties in order to achieve our final victory."

Estimating that $4,000,000,000 of defense savings bonds have been sold since the present series went on sale on May 1, 1941, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in a special summary on defense bonds issued yesterday, asserts that purchases of savings bonds out of current income "constitute the most important contribution of this character to the over-all war effort."

Captain Joas Moura, master of the 5,000-ton Brazilian passenger-cargo vessel Buarque, torpedoed off Cape Hatteras in the early morning of Feb. 15, revealed here last night that he had been rescued after two days in a lifeboat by the United States destroyer Jacob Jones, the loss of which was announced yesterday.

Anna Antoniades, young Greek pianist who last season gave two recitals at Town Hall, last night gave a recital at Carnegie Hall. The principal items on her program were Chopin's B flat minor Sonata and Schumann's Carnaval. She also played the Bach-Liszt Prelude and Fugue in A minor, the Albeniz-Godowsky Tango and Stravinsky's own transcription of his Danse Russe from "Petrouchka."
WASHINGTON, March, 3 -- The War Department communique based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

The collection shown last night at Bergdorf Goodman's, with the customary ceremony, was virtually created at the "request of men-at-war," the announcement said. If so, it must be admitted that these men certainly know their styles.

Recently an acquaintance said she did not want to buy defense bonds "because we might have inflation and the money would not be worth so much ten years from now." It had not occurred to her that she cannot live without some cash ten years from now, and the more she has the better off she will he, no matter how much or how little it will buy.

ST. PAUL, March 3 -- Colonel J.E. Nelson, chief of the State draft set-up, "just to keep the records straight," today summoned reporters to emphasize, he said, that Ted Williams, Boston Red Sox slugger, had sought draft deferment for the benefit of his recently divorced mother.

Aside from financing the war, one of the primary purposes of higher taxes and the sale of defense savings bonds is to sharply reduce the purchasing power of consumers and thus check bidding of consumers for the diminishing supplies of many lines of consumer goods.

HAVANA, March 3 -- Because of a controversy that has developed between him and Manager Hans Lobert of the Phils, President Larry MacPhail of the Dodgers said today he was "definitely advising the president of the Philadelphia club that we do not desire to play them at Miami, Daytona Beach or any other spot in Florida."

Working in a roped-off square bounded by Posts 1, 2, 5 and 6 on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, the staff of the Beekman Hospital staged a first-aid demonstration yesterday, showing the institution's ability to care for emergency cases in the event of an air raid in Wall Street.

War production in the plants of the Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company in the first two months of 1942 was 36 per cent above output in the last two months of last year, George R. Hanks, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in High Bridge, N.J.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Civilian knitting for men in the armed services must be drastically curtailed because of the wool shortage and will probably soon be handled exclusively by the American Red Cross, it was indicated today by officials of the Army, Navy and War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House began general debate today on the Agriculture Department Appropriation Bill carrying a provision forbidding sale of government-held surplus farm crops below parity prices with little indication that this provision, estimated to cost consumers at least one billion dollars a year, will meet formidable opposition, despite Administration objection to it.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- One reaction to the Treasury's new tax proposals was that they would leave a New York millionaire with nothing a year in the way of income after he had paid the State and Federal income taxes.

The President's budget recommendations had clearly forecast the magnitude of the new tax bill. Nevertheless, the actual schedules published today, showing individual income taxes doubled and maximum rates running up to 90 per cent for personal incomes and 88.75 per cent for corporation incomes, are staggering.

Two teams with records almost identical will feature tonight's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, where Long Island University will clash with the University of Toledo. Also on the card is the twenty-third meeting in the series between N.Y.U. and Fordham, who will start play at 8:15 o'clock.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 3 -- Three teams from Philadelphia worked their way into the semi-finals of the fifth annual women's Greenwich Field Club invitation Class A and Class B squash racquets tournament today.

The Mellon Securities Corporation and associated underwriters will offer today to the public $15,000,000 of Schenley Distillers Corporation ten-year sinking fund 4 per cent debentures due in 1952. They will be priced at par and accrued interest.
CAIRO, Egypt, Mach 3 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique today stated:

A record score for contract bridge championship pair competition was set yesterday in the Eastern championships played at the Park Central Hotel. The defending champions, Mrs. Edith Selignman and Mrs. Barbara Collyer Cook, in leading a field of twenty-six pairs at the end of the first session of women's pair play, scored 195 1/2 out of a possible 264 points, or 74 per cent of the maximum.
Mike Belloise, former featherweight champion, sang his pugilistic swan song in the Bronx Coliseum last night at the end of his return bout with Chester Rico.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 3 -- "I cannot understand the motive of the Governor's attack upon me," Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City said in a statement issued at City Hall today after yesterday's widening of the breach between him and the State's Democratic Governor, Charles Edison.

The American Red Cross will receive the proceeds from the $1 admissions charged yesterday when the British War Relief Society Shop, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, was formally reopened as "The Street of United Nations." About $1,000 was collected during the day.

If the furniture industry eliminates duplication of effort and other forms of waste, it should have little difficulty furnishing houses in war production a as for less than $500 as suggested by government officials, Margaret G. Devereux, merchandise consultant, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the home furnishings division of the Fashion Group in the Hotel Murray Hill.

A message to the entire membership of the National Association of Manufacturers, totaling some 8,000 manufacturers, of which 80 per cent are engaged in war production, is being dispatched by the headquarters offi urging them to "support to the fullest degree" the appeal of Donald M. Nelson for a change-over to the 168-hour, seven-day week, it was learned last night.

Robert Hogue, 46 years old, of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, went on trial in Special Sessions yesterday in what was believed to be the first prosecution under the State law of 1936 forbidding surgery or the use of a device known as the tail set on the tails of saddle horses.

The American Library Association, the American Red Cross and the United Service Organizations are working desperately hard in the effort to obtain ten million books. At this writing only about three million have been secured. There could be no more appropriate gift for the men in service than a book.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Secretary Morgenthau asked Congress today to supply $9,610,000,000 in additional taxes to help finance the war, and remarked that while the impact of the suggested levies would be felt in every American home, "it is a million times cheaper to win than to lose."

As the House Naval Affairs subcommittee continued its investigation yesterday into the burning and capsizing of the Normandie, the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs opened an office in Brooklyn and began preparing for its own study into the disaster.

RIOM, France, March 3 -- General Maurice Gustave Gamelin, former Allied generalissimo, in dark-blue civilian dress, stood mute before the Supreme Court here this afternoon and steadfastly refused entreaties of the Chief Magistrate to defend himself against charges of blame for alleged French unpreparedness. The General made only two timid remarks.

Scarlet fever continued its seven-week rise among New York children last week, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner. New cases rose to 234 from 228 the previous week. So far this year there have been 1,499 cases and one death from scarlet fever, more than last year, but considerably fewer than at this time in 1940.

The three-story store and apartment building at 45-13 Laurel Hill Boulevard, Long Island City, L.I., was sold by Dr. Elwood Harlow to Mrs. Mary Gerstenberger through Hosinger Bode, Inc., brokers. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 3 -- Mrs. Gertrude C. Fritche, village treasurer and tax receiver of Ardsley for the last eleven years, was accused today by the Westchester County District Attorney's office of misappropriating $6,200 of village funds, partly by writing off the tax debts of friends who could not pay.

BANDUNG, Java, Wednesday, March 4 -- Troops of the Netherlands Indies Army and their allies have driven infiltrating Japanese invaders back seven miles on one important sector, it was disclosed today, and are thrusting forward in a counter-offensive intended to cast the enemy into the sea.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Organization of a rationing division in the Office of Price Administration was announced today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, who has ordered a general realignment of executive personnel in his office to meet the expanded responsibilities arising out of the new Emergency Price Control Act.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Senate judiciary subcommittee which is about to scrap the "War Secrets" bill proposed by Attorney General Biddle and write another was told today by Frank B. Jewett, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and member of the National Defense Research Committee, that there was already more secrecy imposed than was "really justified."

ST. LOUIS, March 3 (U.P.) -- "I think it's swell, I'm all elated," was Mrs. Selma O'Hare's comment tonight on the accomplishment of her son, Lieutenant Edward H. O'Hare, a navy fighter plane pilot, in shooting down six Japanese bombers in an air battle over the Pacific.

These are just some of the things that will go into Simon Schuster's forthcoming edition of Tolstoy's "War and Peace" -- a long introduction by Clifton Fadiman, maps, basic notes prepared by Aylmer Maude and supplementary notes that will "explain obscure passages, vital historical or biographical background and difficult phrases," and an introductory section that will summarize tributes to the novel by "leading men of letters of our time."

The Jacob Jones, struck in the night by a German U-boat off Cape May, had no chance to fight back. That will be the chief regret of her eleven survivors. There is only this pitiful handful to report the attack. Lieut. Comdr. Black and all the rest of a normal complement of 145 men went down with the stricken ship.

Four goals behind with half the game completed, the New York Rangers came through with a scoring burst that saw them register three goals in less than three minutes. They went on from there and tallied an isolated marker in the third frame that served to earn a 4-to-4 deadlock with the Brooklyn Americans at Madison Square Garden last night.

Four new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. The new tenant at the Paramount will be a comedy adventure, "The Lady Has Plans," starring Paulette Goddard and Ray Milland. Roland Young, Albert Dekker, Margaret Hayes and Cecil Kellaway are featured in supporting roles .

BOSTON, March 3 (AP) -- Boston's war-shattered and injury-riddled Bruins found themselves during a wild second period tonight and went on to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game before 10,000 spectators at the Garden.

George L. Harrison, president of the New York Life Insurance Company, announced in the ninety-seventh annual report issued for publication today, that the gain in insurance in force last year was the largest since 1930 and the number of policies exceeded 3,000,000 for the first time.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A brilliant air and naval victory in which a task force of the Pacific Fleet shot down sixteen of eighteen attacking Japanese bombers without damage to the United States ships and with a loss of only two of our fighter planes and one pilot was reported tonight by the Navy.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Following is the prepared text of Secretary Morgenthau's statement today before the Ways and Means Committee:

The Authors League of America, Inc., of 6 East Thirty-ninth Street, made public last night a letter sent to Mayor La Guardia protesting "the illegal and high-handed methods" employed by him and License Commissioner Paul Moss in refusing to renew licenses of burlesque theatres.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted the application of the trustees of Associated Gas and Electric Corporation for approval of the sale of their 90 per cent interest in the common stock of Northeastern Water and Electric Corporation to John H. Ware Jr., and the Penn-Jersey Water Company for $3,800,000.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Representatives of retail grocery organizations here to confer with government officials on trade problems were advised today that the Office of Price Administration plans specify that sugar ration stamps can be spent only every other week and when presented by consumers will call for a pound of sugar for each individual for each two-week period.
BERLIN, March 3 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Norway is occupied but not conquered. A few days ago all seven Bishops of the Norwegian State Church resigned following an invasion of the Trondheim Cathedral by the Nazi police and an edict of the Quisling Government requiring all children between 10 and 18 to join the Quisling version of the Nazi Hitlerjugend.

Smith, Barney Co. will offer to the public today an additional issue of 35,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, series C, $4 dividend, no par value, of Monsanto Chemical Company at 105 1/2 a share.

Members of the City Council concurred yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's request for a home rule message to the Legislature permitting the fixing of a local assessment area in connection with the demolition of the Second Avenue Elevated line, after a debate which split the Council into fifteen affirmative and seven negative votes.

Alexander Irving 2d, in 125 E 74th St; Stuart Kent Harper, in 135 E 53d St; Harold Kessler, in 14 W 52d St; Henry S. Noble, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., in 227 E 57th St; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

ORADELL, N.J., March 3 -- Mrs. Frances Black, widow of the commander of the Jacob Jones, was visiting with their children "somewhere in Massachusetts" when the news of her husband's loss was communicated to their home at 416 Second Street here, according to her father-in-law, Howard D. Black. He said he had telephoned the sad news to her.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Competitive bidding was abolished as a general practice in the placing of military supply contracts in an order issued tonight by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Traders in wheat were caught flatfooted by an overnight announcement that the Commodity Credit Corporation would cease offering cash wheat to mills after March 14, resulting in a broad wave of buying which lifted prices around 2 cents a bushel over yesterday's finish before the advance was checked by profit-taking.

A new plan for marketing motion pictures to replace the selling arrangements under the consent decree was disclosed yesterday by the joint committee of exhibitor and distributor representatives appointed by the United Motion Picture Industry organization to formulate such a proposal.

The six-story apartment house comprising sixty apartments at 2166 Bronx Park East, the Bronx, was sold by Jacob Janos, builder, to an investing client of Pearce Mayer, co-brokers in the deal with Omnia Properties, Inc.

We are in a desperate, merciless and bloody war for our very lives, and yet spies roam all over the country. When they are caught they are turned over to our civil courts for trial for espionage, being enemy agents, violation of emigration laws, etc., with all the resultant delays and probable inadequate serving of full sentences, if convicted.

A plea that the State Legislature pass a bill introduced by Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. to fix 65 years instead of 70 as the mandatory age of retirement for the supervising and teaching staff in this city was made yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- Bullpen and Wise Bob won the two divisions of the Peter A.B. Widener Dinner Stakes at Hialeah Park today, the former's victory being as much expected as Wise Bob's was a surprise. Bullpen, a brown son of Bull Dog, ran in the name of Miss Mary Jo Corral, sister-in-law of Secretary C.C. (Milo) Vega of the Florida Racing Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 3 (AP) -- Deputy Raul Damonte Taborda, head of the so-called Argentine Congressional "Dies committee" and outspoken opponent of maintaining diplomatic relations with the Axis powers, appeared certain of reelection to the Chamber tonight.

March managed to come in like a lion yesterday, although it was two days late. Winds of gale force, two and a quarter inches of rain and the high tides that accompany a full moon combined to give the Northeastern coastal area a taste of flood conditions reminiscent of the hurricane of 1938.
MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- With the safe arrival of the last of the Giant squad from Cuba today Manager Mel Ott's training campaign quickly moved back into normal gear.

Nine thousand persons visited yesterday the income tax bureau of the second New York district at the Custom House, it was estimated by aides of William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue. This compared with 2,000 on Monday and was described as "terrific for this time of the month."

An experimental test of an air raid siren will be held between noon and 12:30 o'clock today in an effort to provide an audible alarm for the Manhattan area south of Canal Street, it was announced yesterday by Irving V.A Huie, Commissioner of Public Parks.

It hardly seems possible that the opening day of the trout season is only six weeks off, but the calendar can't be wrong, and it is time you looked over your fly rod for loose ferrules and worn guides and checked the rest of your tackle.

If "Perplexed," who is confused about hoarding, had gone as far as the dictionary for a definition, he would have eliminated at once most of the causes of his confusion. All definitions of hoarding involve the notion of amassing or storing up for future use or for mere miserly pleasure.

VICHY, France, March 3 -- The shooting of twenty hostages has been ordered in reprisal for the slaying of a German sentry in Paris on Sunday, the German authorities in Paris announced today. Twenty more are to be executed if the soldier's attackers have not been apprehended by March 16.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Java, Wednesday, March 4 -- During a torrential rainstorm yesterday afternoon the writer and two other correspondents accompanied Netherland and Indonesian tank and infantry forces into a re-won region northeast of Bandung, where one sector more than seven miles deep had been cleared of enemy units and where Japanese snipers lurked the day before.

Formal offering to the public will be made today by an underwriting syndicate headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation of two new issues of securities of the Pennsylvania Electric Company, which were awarded to the group at competitive bidding on Monday.

The unified command in the Southwest Pacific lasted just two months to the days. It was set up Jan. 3 in Washington as the outstanding result of the historic conference between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill establishing the United Nations' front.

Lieut. Col. Charles D. Trexler has resigned his pastorate at Grace Lutheran Church, Forest Hills, Queens, to accept appointment by the War Department as Post Chaplain of the Army Medical Center in Washington, it was learned yesterday.
A 26-year-old father of two children became the first winner yesterday of a $25 defense bond under a plan by which 10,500 firemen in the city will buy $250,000 worth of bonds each year.

A loan exhibition of oils, gouaches and drawings by two nineteenth century Spanish artists, father and son, opens with a private view today at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. The artists -- Eugenio Lucas y Padilla and Eugenio Lucas de Villamil -- are by no means widely known here, and the event is heralded as the first comprehensive showing of their work in this country.

LONDON, March 3 -- Because it has been said so often that the Battle of the Atlantic is not going so badly for Britain and because there has been no heavy bombing of London in nearly a year, there is a tendency outside this country to underestimate the difficulties under which the people are living and to jump to the conclusion that life is getting back to normal.

The gift of a teddy bear with fur the color of burnished gold is one way of engaging the wholehearted attention of a person who has just celebrated her fourth birthday. But better than a bear, and even more fascinating than a brand new tricycle, is the privilege of kneeling on a kitchen chair and stirring melted chocolate into the pudding that's being made for lunch.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 4 -- Official confirmation by authorities in London that the Royal Air Force had raided the big Renault motor works at Billancourt, southwest of Paris, last night was issued early this morning.

Washington's announcement that the United States will cooperate with Free French forces in New Caledonia suggests that American troops are already on the island. It is a timely step, of military necessity. But it is also a significant political gesture, made in order to uphold the French people in preserving the integrity of the French Empire wherever it is threatened by the enemy.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations Steel Workers Organizing Committee asked a special fact-finding panel of the National War Labor Board today to sanction a $1 per day wage increase and a "union security" clause covering about 175,000 employes of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the Republic Steel Corporation, the Inland Steel Company and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 3 -- Intercepting enemy aircraft during an Axis air raid on the area of the Suez Canal last night, British night fighters shot down one bomber and damaged another so severely that when it was last seen it was flying only fifty feet above the sea, with one of its engines blazing. German planes dropped some bombs.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) -- The oil industry was nearly ready today to begin training thousands of girls to replace drafted filling station attendants.
MOSCOW, March 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following communique today:

Inexorably the heat and glare of war sweep on toward India. These flames are no respecters of boundary lines. They are carried on the wind across vast expanses of ocean. Today's monsoon does not blow from the perfumed coasts of Araby. It comes from the East, bringing consternation to the weak, stirring the strong to action waking up the sleepers and, almost, the dead.

OTTAWA, March 3 (Canadian Press) -- With the nominal $600, 000,000 objective of the second Victory Loan certain to have been exceeded, G.W. Spinney, chairman of the National War Finance Committee, said tonight that the aim now was to raise a total of $900, 000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Several agreements were signed today by Brazil and the United States providing for the speeding up of Brazilian armament for self-defense through expanded lease-lend aid and for intensive production of Brazilian strategic materials, including rubber and iron ore, through a credit of $100,000,000 from the Export-Import Bank.

The late Martha Berry's pioneer school labors among the poor white mountain folk of Northern Georgia were financed in part by large contributions from Northern sympathizers. This was, of course, the continuance of a tradition which goes back to the end of the War Between the States.

TOKYO, March 3 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The United States cruiser Houston was listed today among twenty-three United Nations warships reported to have been sunk by the Japanese in week-end naval clashes off Java.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Senator Vandenberg proposed with Democratic support today that President Roosevelt receive the power to veto legislative riders to appropriation bills.
ROME, March 3 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique today said:

FORT DIX, N.J., March 3 --Private Joe Louis, on a thirty-day furlough from Camp Upton, L.I., arrived here this afternoon to begin training for his March 27 bout with Abe Simon at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Army Emergency Fund.

With the exception of classified, all advertising categories of eight New York newspapers registered a decline in February, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. As a result, total advertising linage for the papers covered dropped 6.7 per cent from February of last year.

With two pressing domestic questions answered -- the railroad freight rates ruling and the Treasury's war taxes proposals -- more active trading was resumed yesterday on the Stock Exchange as buyers hunted out issues they felt had been oversold.

OTTAWA, March 3 -- By a "yes" and "no" response the House of Commons in committee this afternoon approved the form of the question to be asked in the plebiscite that the government seeks to hold on the question of military service.

A COUPLE of weeks ago educators from all over the country met at the University of Chicago to read papers on the function of the colleges in wartime. Arthur Rubin, head of Chicago's new Institute of Military Studies, had called the conference. But the tenor of the educators' remarks left him with a feeling of frustration.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 3 -- Certainly there will be German attacks on the Russian front in the Spring. It could scarcely be otherwise, since the German High Command is fully committed. But still it be the "great general offensive," as advertised, destined to bring about a decision and annihilate the Soviet Union; in other words, a second edition of the offensive of last, June? This question was raised in competent foreign military circles here today.

Although Japanese forces have swarmed over several areas whence American Chicle Company obtains important raw materials and the submarine menace has brought a halt to its chicle shipments from Mexico, the 1942 sales volume of the company is expected to be only 10 to 15 per cent below the 1941 peak, when sales were in excess of $20,000,000, Thomas J. Blodgett, chairman and president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

LONDON, March 3 -- The final dividend on the Cammell Laird Company is 6 per cent, making 10 per cent for the fourth consecutive year. Net profits after taxation amounted to 186,548 against 241,852. The 5s units eased to 7 3/4s.

A demand for a Congressional investigation into charges that industrial alcohol manufacturers, with the collaboration of officials in the War Production Board, have blocked use of grain for production of alcohols needed in the manufacture of explosives and thereby contributed to the necessity for rationing sugar is being circulated in Washington, it was learned here yesterday.
