Bixie, a 3-month-old gray and white kitten that was born in Pearl Harbor on the day the Japanese launched their attack, arrived yesterday at the home of her 12-year-old mistress, Rita Ginn, at 98-76 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills Queens, after a ship, plane, train and automobile journey of 7,000 miles.

The testimony of four criminals, two of them serving life terms, that Charles Adams, 53 years old, a Negro, had boasted to them last Summer in the Bronx Detention Prison how he had strangled Miss Frances Marks, 23, a bookkeeper, in a Harlem garage sixteen months before in a rape attempt, resulted last night in a General Sessions jury convicting Adams of second-degree manslaughter.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- Governor Spessard L. Holland of Florida and Mrs. Holland, here for the running of the P.A.B. Widener Dinner Stakes, were honor guests at a luncheon given at Hialeah Park today by John C. Clark, president of the Miami Jockey Club, and Mrs. Clark.

Visiting buyers registered in the market last week totaled 1,236, as against 576 in the preceding week and 924 in the like period of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations numbered 426, which compared with 130 for last Tuesday.

Union demands for the "peacetime penalty rule of time-and-a- half or double "time" for Saturday and Sunday work in war industries may "seriously retard" the industrial change-over to the seven-day, 168-hour work week demanded by Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chief, the National Association of Manufacturers declared yesterday.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 3 (AP) -- An enemy vessel, presumably a submarine, made the war's first attack on United States soil in the Atlantic last night, harmlessly shelling the cliffs of Mona Island, a pinpoint of volcanic rock in the Mona Passage, fifty miles southwest of Puerto Rico.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700.000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250, 000; Staten Island, $80,000.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Congressional approval of the fifth supplemental war appropriation bill, with its direct appropriation and other provisions for leaselend, carried the authorized dollar limit on aid which the President may provide to the United Nations under the lease-lend act beyond $47,000,000,000, the Office of Lease-Lend Administration made known today.

The First Boston Corporation won yesterday the award of $500,000 of temporary-loan notes of Somerville, Mass., at 0.48 per cent, plus a premium of $1.25. The obligations, dated March 3, will become payable on Nov. 27.

Reporting to stockholders in the annual statement issued for publication today, George M. Moffett, president of the Corn Products Refining Company, says that sales during 1941 in bushels were the largest in the history of the company, export business was greater than for many years and dollar sales were the best since 1920.

Patrolman Michael J. Davitt of the Liberty Avenue Station, Brooklyn, was arrested on a charge of felonious assault and suspended from duty last night after a quarrel in a bar at 75 Lexington Avenue, in which the police said he pointed his pistol at two civilians. His suspension was ordered by Deputy Commissioner Francis J. Kear after a police surgeon had pronounced him unfit for duty.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Serious consideration was being given by the Navy Department today on releasing more quickly news of the sinking of German submarines by American vessels.

Cotton futures advanced moderately yesterday more from a lack of selling pressure than from any aggressive demand. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts showed net gains of 9 to 11 points.

Near the end of the first quarter- year of our participation in the war, and in the twenty-second month following the German attack on France, the President has made some belated reforms in the organization of the Army. Secretary Stimson believes that they will have the effect of "streamlining" the War Department.

After picking their way carefully through most of the Savoy opera book, the visiting minstrels have arrived at "The Gondoliers," which they sang at the St. James last evening. Since this is the place where Gilbert and Sullivan came to the end of their successful days together, it is a logical place to conclude a repertory cycle.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- News available here tonight includes details of what is described as the biggest air battle fought since last Autumn over Murmansk. Thirteen German planes were destroyed in the engagement over the important Arctic base.

The American Association for Social Security assailed yesterday the special proposal for a $300,000,000 appropriation to increase unemployment insurance benefits to workers made idle temporarily by the conversion of industrial plants as unfair to other unemployed and detrimental to the unemployment insurance principle.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that a naval board had recommended seventy-one commanders on the retired list for temporary promotion to the rank of captain and 174 lieutenants on the retired list for temporary advancement to the rank of lieutenant commander.
OFFICIAL Release No. 29 of the United States Army Information Service, Second Corps Area, contained the following items that may be of interest to the followers of sports:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, March 4 (U.P.) -- Australian and Japanese planes traded new aerial blows following yesterday's nuisance raids on Wyndham and Broome in Northwest Australia, Air Minister Arthur S. Drakeford revealed today.

LONDON, March 3 (U.P.) -- Soviet reports of violent Red Army offensives all along the front said tonight that shock troops had driven twenty-seven miles into the German lines below Leningrad and that Junkers transport planes were trying desperately to reinforce the Nazi army corps trapped at Staraya Russa.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt ended his ninth year in the White House tonight, not as the man who steered the nation through a grave economic crisis but as a pivotal figure in the world struggle against totalitarian enslavement.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Emil Morosini, defense attorney, was barred today from further participation in the trial of George Sylvester Viereck, German-born publicist, after he had openly accused Justice F. Dickinson Letts in Federal District Court of being "biased" in favor of the government and "prejudiced" against the defendant.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- The House of delegates of the American Bar Association went on record today as favoring an immediate call to military service of workers who participate in a strike or slow-down at armament plants.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- Miss Georgia Tainter of Fargo, N.D., led the field in the qualifying round of the seventeenth annual South Atlantic women's golf championship today with 42, 39 -- 81. Miss Ann Pink of Daytona Beach was only one stroke back of the medalist with 41, 41 -- 82, requiring only 24 putts for the round.

Pete Scalzo, 134 1/4, veteran West Side lightweight and former world featherweight champion, pounded out a decision over Nat Litfin, 135 3/4, of the Bronx, in the eight-round main bout at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A near-capacity crowd of 4,500 saw Scalzo repeat his victory of a few weeks ago.

LONDON, March 3 -- Patrol skirmishes at Waw, about fifteen miles northeast of Pegu, were reported in tonight's communique as the day's principal ground activity on the Burma front. Otherwise, it was stated, the situation remained unchanged on Burma's southern front.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Robert Preston, Martha O'Driscoll and Eva Gabor will play the leads in "Sky Over China," a story of a Chinese air line operated by American commercial fliers before the United States entry into the war, Paramount announced today.

Title to most of the land to be utilized as the site for Edwin Markham Houses, low-rent housing project for Staten Island, has passed to the New York City Housing Authority, and the work of demolishing 110 small buildings on the twelve-acre site will begin today, the Authority announced yesterday.

Frequent association with the man credited with drawing up Hitler's invasion plans was admitted yesterday by Paul T. Borchardt, one of the six persons on trial in Federal court for espionage here in behalf of Germany. The admission was obtained by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa soon after the prosecutor had begun his cross-examination of the defendant, who was testifying in his own defense.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Representative Vinson of Georgia told a House Judiciary subcommittee today that, through accretion of wealth since the defense program started in 1939, labor unions had become of "such vast economic importance" that government supervision of them had become necessary.

A sentence of two to four years in the Women's State Prison at Bedford Hills was imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Mrs. Orelia Marconi, 47 years old, of 244 East Twenty-first Street, on her recent conviction for defrauding a waiter in the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel of $7,000 under pretense she would make him wealthy by investing in the promotion of a "lizard oil" concoction she said she had invented to restore hair on bald heads.

Faced with an excellent opportunity to escape the National Hockey League cellar, which they now share with the Montreal Canadiens, the Brooklyn Americans will tackle the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden tonight. Fresh from their 4-4 deadlock with the Rangers, Red Dutton's men are confident that the contest will enable them to rise in the race and go a long way toward clinching a play-off berth.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Using methods developed by American research, domestic producers of manganese will increase their production by 1,400 per cent a year when new plants now under construction are in full operation, the War Production Board announced today.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh disclosed yesterday that he had removed Deputy Chief Hugh A. Halligan from the post of First Deputy Fire Commissioner, which he had held since last August, and that he had replaced him with Deputy Chief Ferdinand Butenschoen of the Twelfth Division.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Representative Dies, chairman of the Committee Investigating Un-American Activities, asserted in the House today that his committee had obtained evidence indicating that some Axis propaganda had been directed against "the personal integrity" of President Roosevelt.
Election of Hugh L. Smith as vice president in charge of operations of American Airlines, Inc., was announced yesterday by C.R. Smith, president. The 1941 operating results also were disclosed.

The decision of the Supreme Court this week in the case of the teamsters' union in this city reveals an almost incredible state of the Federal law on racketeering. The Department of Justice brought an action, under the Federal Anti-Racketeering Act, against New York City Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters of the A.F. of L., and twenty-six of its members.

Impact of the war economy upon the coat and suit industry will demand further major readjustments involving fabrics, styles, man power and government contracts, and may extend to rationing and price control on finished merchandise, J.L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, warned last night at the annual membership meeting of the organization at the Hotel Astor.
Senator James M. Mead is not a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, James J. Dorman, his former campaign manager, declared yesterday.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- In one of history's greatest air raids the Royal Air Force spread ruin last night in the Paris suburban area where French arms plants are working for the Germans.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 4 -- There is growing resentment in Germany that the Supreme Court at Riom is concerning itself merely with French unpreparedness for war and not at all with the responsibility for its outbreak.

The new revenue bill, as Secretary Morgenthau pointed out, must do more than raise a huge amount of money. It must strengthen the war effort. This means, Mr. Morgenthau said, that the bill "must help to check inflation, for nothing in the economic field can interfere with the war effort as much as an uncontrolled rise in prices."
MOSCOW, March 4 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau midday communique said:

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- George Sylvester Viereck, who is charged with withholding information from the State Department when he registered as a German agent, was pictured in District Court today as a man who had "shamed and defiled his American citizenship."

ORADELL, N.J., March 4 -- This municipality was in mourning today for Lieut. Comdr. Hugh David Black and others of the crew of the destroyer Jacob Jones who lost their lives when the ship was torpedoed and sunk off Cape May, N.J., last Saturday.

Pie was 23 years old, the oldest son of/Ir, and /V[rs. Patrick Bradley of 18-05 l0th Street, Whitestone, Queens,

I must protest against your leading editorial of Feb. 28 in which you assert that the defeat in the House of Representatives of the proposal for wartime suspension of the forty-hour week is a blow to maximum production and national defense.

LONDON, March 4 -- The records of all officers of the British Army over the age of 45, both at home and abroad, up to the rank of lieutenant colonel, are to be scrutinized for their fitness to lead in modern war, under an Army order announced today.

A group calling itself "Democracy in Action" is being formed in New York to rally Negro support in the war and its first activity will be to raise funds to buy ambulances for the British and American Ambulance Corps for service on the "fighting and home fronts of America and her allies," the corps announced yesterday.
Showings by Hattie Carnegie and Henri Bendel continued yesterday the revelation of the new trends of wartime fashion for Spring and Summer.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Heavy consumer buying in January resulted in less than the usual seasonal decline from December in retail sales, the Department of Commerce reported today. Dollar volume of all retail stores was $4,212.000,000, 16 per cent above January a year ago.
PITTSBURGH, March 4 -- War production and almost all other business returned to normal operations today as the city dug out from its heaviest snowfall on record.

Exporters learned full details yesterday of the new instructions to be followed in the filing of export clearance proposals, when the text of the order of the Office of Export Controls, OEC 49 A, containing new regulations for export license applications, was made available by officials of the office here.

RIOM, France, March 4 -- Former Air Minister Guy la Chambre, under examination in the Supreme Court here today for his responsibilities. The France's unpreparedness for war in 1939, hotly contested charges by his successors at the Air Ministry that he had juggled figures and delivered unfinished materiel in an effort to magnify aviation production.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 4 -- A practice blackout in the southeastern part of Westchester County, affecting 289,000 persons living in seventeen communities covering ninety-four square miles, was ordered today by defense officials for 9:03 P.M. Sunday.

Announcement of the so-called Victory suits for men yesterday brought about renewed interest in clothing and some stores feared a resumption of the recent buying boom. At any rate, demand was appreciably above that of recent weeks in many stores but still below the hectic pace of January.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Representatives of several State taxing agencies opposed today as "fundamentally wrong" legislation which would exempt from State and local sales taxes the activities of contractors engaged in war work.
CHUNGKING, China, March 4 -- Chinese, particularly in military circles, are becoming increasingly disturbed over the attitude and actions of the Vichy French authorities of Indo-China.

HONOLULU, March 4 -- Three medium-sized bombs were dropped on the outskirts of Honolulu early today by what the Army believed was an enemy plane flying at a high altitude. One air raid siren was heard.
Another air raid siren was tested here yesterday and did the best job yet, despite isolated "deaf spots" in the exposed area -- Manhattan south of Canal Street.

A banking group headed by the Union Securities Corporation and including Piper, Jaffray Hopwood of Minneapolis and Burns, Potter Co. of Omaha will offer today to the public a new issue of 25,000 shares of Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company 4 1/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock, Series C, with a par value of $100 a share.

All electric power stations of the city and Westchester County are now interconnected and ready for any war emergency, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday in its annual report. The only utilities not yet connected with other systems in the city, the report disclosed, are the Long Island Lighting Company and the Staten Island Edison Company.

In front throughout, unbeaten James Monroe High gained the semi-finals of the city P.S.A.L. basketball tournament by subduing Benjamin Franklin High, winner of the city crown for the last two seasons, 43 to 37, in one of three playoff battles held before 7,000 fans at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Thursday, March 5 (U.P.) -- Japanese raiders struck twice early today at Port Moresby. Air Minister Arthur S. Drakeford said "slight damage" resulted from the raids. There were no casualties, however. The raiders were believed to have come from Japanese-occupied Gasmata.

I would like to take issue with the position stated by Harold Callender in his letter to THE TIMES by denying that planning for the post-war world is either "nonessential" or an "amusement." Obviously, we must in the coming months and years direct our supreme effort to winning the war.

The creamy-colored loaves that are causing so much interested comment in grocery stores about the city have all the flavor and fragrance of homemade bread. They are, as a matter of fact, the delightful result of following old-fashioned methods.

VICHY, France, March 4 (U.P.) -- As rescue crews continued today to dig into the heaps of wreckage left by last night's British air raid on industrial suburbs of Paris it was believed that final casualty figures would be much higher than estimates so far made.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 4 -- Dartmouth buried Army under a 12-2 count at hockey today and thereby clinched the Pentagonal League championship. The game was played in the West Point arena on fast ice.
Allow me to express appreciation and thanks for the editorial in THE TIMES of Feb. 28, "Who Is Labor?"

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Higher retail prices for gasoline, kerosene and fuel oil in the East and the closing of filling stations nights and Sundays throughout the country were recommended tonight by the Petroleum Industry War Council, an advisory group of industry executives with official standing.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The United Nations hold about 1,271,000,000 bushels of the world's known wheat surplus of 1,524,000,000 bushels, the Department of Agriculture reported today. The remaining 253,000,000 bushels are held by Argentina, which is neutral.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Rayon stockings will replace silk and nylon hose to a large extent in a few months, according to indications of a new War Production Board order today, increasing the amount of rayon yarn which rayon producers must set aside for the hosiery industry.

Hyman Schorenstein, Commissioner of Records in Brooklyn until the consolidation of county offices at the beginning of the year, asked the Board of Estimate yesterday for authorization to retire on an annual pension of $4,372 after twenty-six Years of public life.

VICHY, France, March 4 (U.P.) -- The French Government tonight denied reports that it was negotiating with Japan for possible Japanese use of the French island of Madagascar, which lies off the southeastern coast of Africa across Indian Ocean supply lanes.

LONDON, March 4 -- Changes in the Far Eastern land and sea commands were announced here today by the Netherland Government. The Government General of the Netherlands Indies was instructed to transfer command of the fighting forces to Lieut. Gen. Hein ter Poorten and Acting Rear Admiral J.J.A. van Staveren.

First of a fleet of thirty-five new box cars equipped with a utility loader which eliminates 98 per cent of damage to shipments was put in operation by the Missouri Pacific Railroad this week for shipment of war materials and civilian necessities.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- A move for an $8,000,000 slash in the travel allotment in the $695,065,859 Agriculture Appropriations Bill delayed today a House showdown on the issue of selling government-held farm surpluses below parity.

The threat of shiny noses as a "major war calamity" is still far in the future and American women, instead of being deprived of perfumes, may even sniff scents with new characteristics, experts in the toilet goods field yesterday assured the luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group at the Murray Hill Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that he favored financial aid to small business and said that such aid was essential if these concerns were to be fitted within the war production program.
RANGOON, Burma, March 4 (AP) -- A British headquarters communique said today:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 4 -- A Danish newspaper announces that a conflict between the occupying German authorities and the Danish court threatens to become aggravated through the Danish authorities' insistence that a Professor of History, Wilhelm le Cour, arrested several days ago for delivering a lecture containing thinly veiled remarks about German-Danish relations, be released.

LONDON, Thursday, March 5 (AP) -- The surrounded German Army Corps of 96,000 in the Staraya Russa sector "has lost 36,000 killed since the attack began," the News-Chronicle reported today in a dispatch from its Stockholm correspondent.

By virtue of an order issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Francis J. Hooley in Queens, 269 holders of certificates of membership in the Spring Valley Golf Club, until recently in Queens, are to share equally in the distribution of $127,978.

The new destroyer Aaron Ward, second ship of its name to serve in the present war, was placed in commission yesterday at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn as 200 members of her crew were called upon to dedicate "everything they have" to their country and to sacrifice, if necessary, even their lives in the war at sea.

LONDON, March 4 -- Presenting his budget for next year before a critical House of Commons, Air Minister Sir Archibald Sinclair defended the R.A.F. and declared that it was ready to counter any Nazi offensive against Russia by striking hard at the vital centers of German industry and transport.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange have ordered Avery Co. to dissolve as a Curb Exchange firm and have suspended Clarence B. Rogers and John M. Jones, partners in the firm, from Curb membership for eighteen and six months, respectively.
BERLIN, March 4 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

LONDON, March 4 -- Last week's total for ordinary revenue of 62,902,125 has enabled the Chancellor of the Exchequer's estimate for the whole year to be exceeded, with more than four weeks to spare. The amount budgeted was 1,786,360,000 and the revenue to date as shown in the Exchequer returns was 1,848,034,622.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt began his tenth year as Chief Executive by attending services at St. John's Church. His visitors included Harold Smith, Director of the Budget; Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, and Frank Walker, Postmaster General.

LEWES, Del., March 4 -- The 3,915-ton British freighter Gypsum Prince was sunk three and a half miles off this port early this morning after a collision with the British tanker Voco of 5,090 tons. Six members of the crew of the Gypsum Prince, including her master, Captain Owen Jones, lost their lives and twenty others were rescued by the Coast Guard.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4 -- Princeton's high-scoring quintet applied the usual pressure in the second half to take its Eastern Intercollegiate League game from Pennsylvania, 52 -- 31, before more than 1,000 students in the university gymnasium tonight.

Fourteen religious or educational institutions share in the $2,192,610 residuary estate of Henry Pfeiffer, manufacturing pharmaceutist and philanthropist. This was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where executors made their final accounting showing that they had established trusts for the institutions named.

Thirty planes -- nationality unspecified -- have attacked Minamitori Shima, a Japanese island in the Bonin group 3,000 miles west of Honolulu, the Tokyo radio announced today in a broadcast heard by the Columbia Broadcasting System, according to The Associated Press.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Republican chairmen of the Excise Committees of the Legislature introduced today a bill designed to eliminate "unfair trade practices" on the part of liquor manufacturers and wholesalers and thus reduce recurrent liquor price wars, particularly in New York City.

Under the sponsorship of the Brazilian Government, sculpture by Irene Hamar will have its first showing in this country, beginning on Monday, at the Acquavella Gallery, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street. The daughter of a Brazilian coffee planter, Miss Hamar studied in Paris and returned to her native country, where she worked for several years.

NEWARK, N.J., March 4 -- Because of the refusal of Arthur F. Foran, State Milk Control Director, to relax price regulations, Newark seek bids from out-of-State dealers on milk for city institutions, John A. Brady, Public Affairs Director, announced today.

Surprise raids on 350 places occupied by enemy aliens in Yorkville, the upper East Side German-American community, resulted Tuesday night in the arrest of thirty-three persons and the seizure of much contraband material, it was revealed yesterday by P.E. Fox-worth, local chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- Piercing the defenses of the encircled Sixteenth German Army Corps at a weak spot, a Russian force was reported today to have advanced several miles after striking a surprise blow. Meanwhile, the main Red Army forces were relentlessly tightening their grip and forcing General von Busch to relinquish village after village, abandoning his wounded.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Senate passed today by unanimous vote and sent to the Governor the Anderson bill amending the Motor Financial Responsibility Law to eliminate the necessity for reporting accidents where damages of less than $25 are susined.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 28 (Delayed) -- The taking over of Vichy's warships by Germany is considered here a definite possibility if not more and evidences are said to exist that in recent months Nazi crews have been surreptitiously busy at Toulon and other naval bases learning how to operate them, it was stated here today.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Grain markets showed an easy undertone today on the Board of Trade, although the opening was slightly higher. Uneasiness over developments in the Far East and a decline in cotton caused professional traders to turn to the selling side, and disclosed a lack of support.

BANDUNG, Java, March 4 -- The Japanese invasion forces expanded their footholds in Java today and swarms of their planes bombed and machine-gunned almost at will the crowded highways along which stubborn Netherland, American, Australian and British defenders still were moving up for fierce counter-attacks.

The annual report of Stone Webster, Inc., for 1941, made public yesterday by George O. Muhlfeld, president, shows for the year a consolidated net income of $1,824,065. This is equal to 87 cents a share on the company's 2,104,391 capital shares outstanding, and compares with a net of $1,354,147, or 64 cents a share, in 1940.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $65,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A possibility that 6,000,000 women can be recruited for war industries and other essential services by the end of 1942 was suggested today by Mary Anderson, director of the women's bureau of the Department of Labor.

The Eastern States contract bridge championship for women's pairs, and the Wainwright trophy emblematic of it, went to Mrs. Barbara Collyer Cook and Mrs. Edith Seligman of New York for the second successive year in the two-session contest completed here yesterday afternoon.

Crowds of income tax payers, apparently eager to make their contributions to the government's war chest as soon as possible, continued yesterday to throng the offices of the Collectors of Internal Revenue for the Second and Third Districts. Many, especially in the small-income brackets, paid the full amount of the tax at once instead of taking advantage of the installment method.
MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- The Giatns' hold-out situation was reduced today to one player when Manager Melvin Ott announced that Sid Gordon, rookie infielder-outfielder, had accepted terms.

BINGHAMTON, March 4 (AP) -- Endicott Johnson Corporation officials said today that a wage dispute leading to interruption in the production of rubber soles and heels had precipitated a decision to substitute leather for rubber parts in all shoes.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- A big drive to increase Russian crop yields is being launched as March begins. Failure in the agricultural field, President Mikhail Kalinin asserts in an article in Pravda, would have consequences as grave as defeat on the battlefield.

The Bankers Bond Company of Louisville has received the award of an issue of $329,500 of refunding 3 3/4per cent bonds of Pulaski County, Ky., on a bid of 102. The bonds will mature serially from 1943 to 1980.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Roosevelt began today his tenth year as Chief Executive of the United States, a post in which he fought the battle against the depression and, as Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy, now directs the greatest war in the country's history.

LONDON, March 4 -- Preparing for all possibilities in the war, Britain has established some, and is establishing more, underground factories for the manufacture of the vital parts of warplanes. The plants under construction should be in operation by August.

Active hedge sales against purchases of government-owned cotton induced a downward trend in the cotton market yesterday. Trade sources appeared to be the best buyers, but this demand was not aggressive and at the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts showed final net losses of 10 to 15 points.
PAL BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- Mrs..Alvin T. Herr entertained at a dinner tonight at Lyndon for Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler.

Toledo scored the moral victory and Long Island University the actual one before 16,473 basketball fans in Madison Square Garden last night. The Blackbirds toppled the Rockets, 43 to 38, but the Midwesterners had to perform without their star of stars, Bob Gerber, which is like the Yankees without DiMaggio.

The large, topical re,ue, tentatively known as "Fun to Be Free," will go into rehearsal next Monday at the Fifty-fourth Street Theatre, the former Adelphi. Scheduled for an opening on April 14, the production, which will aid American war relief agencies, will be the result of the united efforts of men and women from every corner of show business -- actors, dramatists, managers, musicians, producers, stage designers, and stage hands.

Four Royal Air Force instructors, on leave from Canada, called on Mayor La Guardia at City Hall on their arrival here yesterday and talked with him for twenty to twenty-five minutes. Later the Mayor sent them in a car to the New York City Defense Recreation Center, 99 Park Avenue.

Remarks in the financial column of March 1 on the practice of United States Reserve Banks in purchasing government issues in the open money market in competition with investment bankers have come to my notice.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- An improvement in the asset position of national banks was noted by Controller of the Currency Preston Delano in his annual report for the year ended on Oct. 31 last, published today. The quality of bond portfolios was improved and the volume of criticized assets showed a steady decline, it was said.

The normal seasonal trends in advertising may be forgotten for the duration, as shortages develop in various types of goods, agency men remarked yesterday. Retailers, particularly, will be anxious to promote whatever goods are available and it is likely that new buying habits will be developed.

The newspaper committee to study methods of newsprint conservation and elimination of waste, authorized at a general conference of publishers on Feb. 18, has been appointed by Walter M. Dear of The Jersey City Journal, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, as follows:

If you haven't received that new gun you ordered, whether it be revolver, pistol, rifle or shotgun, you may as well abandon hope, temporarily at least, for the government has frozen all new guns in the retail shops.

IT'S all different now. And slightly confused. It used to be that a man could get a line on the approaching baseball season by looking over the clubs in their Spring training activities. The worth of veteran players was a known quantity, subject to accidents or seasonal variations for which allowances could be made. The benefits and losses among clubs by trade and purchase could be estimated.

The desperate defense of Java recalls the old school reader story of the little Dutch boy who thrust his arm into a leak in the dike and held back the sea until help arrived. On the beaches and in the mountain citadels of the one unconquered island in the Indies, the Netherlanders are holding their last dike against invading waves of planes and ships and men.

LONDON, March 4 -- Some sections of the stock markets were quieter today, but prices were maintained. Gilt-edge issues attracted most of the business. The 3 1/2 per cent war loan rose to 105 3/4, old consols to 83 3/8 and local loans touched 97 1-16.

As the first step in a campaign to break up "black markets" in new tires and tubes, Price Administrator Leon Henderson has cited three Albany concerns to show cause on Saturday why action should not be taken against them for alleged violations of the tire rationing regulations, it was announced here last night.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Republicans in the Legislature followed up their budget "reduction" plan of yesterday by moving toward final passage the bill permitting quarterly installment payments of the reduced State income tax.

A NORTHERN IRELAND PORT, March 4 -- Many thousands of United States troops, including young selectees and veterans of the Rainbow Division of the World War, have landed under United States warship escort to form the second contingent of the A.E.F. in Europe. They crossed without incident, except for rough weather and an emergency appendicitis operation at sea, and landed eager for news of General Douglas MacArthur's campaign in the Philippines.

LONDON, March 4 -- Important concessions, which, however, fall far short of the independence demanded by the All-India Congress, are about to be offered to India by the British Government in an effort to win the wholehearted cooperation of the people of that vast subcontinent in the struggle against the Axis powers.

Nettie Rosenstein Gowns, Inc., recognized as one of the leading designing establishments in this country, will go out of business at the end of the current Spring wholesale season, it was announced yesterday by Charles Gumprecht, a partner with Miss Rosenstein in the business.

The volume of business of the Crane Company in 1941 was greater than in any other year in its history, according to the annual report yesterday. Sales of the United States companies amounted to $137,900,015, or 55.9 per cent above the 1940 figure of $88,477,081.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 4 -- Instructions to send twenty priests to Northern Bolivia for Catholic church work were received from Rome today by the headquarters here of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, known as the Maryknoll Fathers.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry oovmuniq6 8aid today:

ABOARD A BRITISH CORVETTE, in the Mediterranean, March 3 (Delayed) -- The task of convoying vessels in the Mediterranean, guarding their precious cargoes from air attack and hunting down submarines falls to the British Navy, usually its smaller and even smallest units, and remnants of the fleets of the temporarily vanquished nations likewise fighting against the Axis.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A tiny fleet of battle-worn airplanes operated by the defenders of Bataan Peninsula in the Philippines sank more than 30,000 tons of Japanese shipping in Subic Bay in a surprise raid over enemy concentrations, General Douglas MacArthur reported to the War Department today.
LONDON, March 4 -- Britain's black markets now have reached proportions estimated to represent an annual cash turnover of 156,000,000 and the government has undertaken stern efforts to suppress them.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 4 -- Occupied Europe once more is astir with the approach of Spring for the third time in this World War, as the snow begins to melt in the Balkan passes. Indications come from all quarters that the necessary military preparations for Germany's next offensive are under way.

Tolstoy's "War and Peace," noted here yesterday with reference to a forthcoming annotated edition, has been experiencing a considerable vogue in recent months. Bennett Cerf has supplied some information on the Modern Library "giant" edition of the Russian classic.

If pictures of the Navy are not more ruggedly realistic hereafter, it will not be the fault of the service, for last night it assigned two of the sailors who help man its guns to help artists improve their Navy background.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A Senate military subcommittee approved legislation today which would double the starting pay of enlisted men and give pay increases to noncommissioned officers and the lowest rank of commissioned offices in the armed forces, the Coast Guard, Coast and Geodetic Survey and Public Health service.

Tuesday had been a bad day Peter Brenner Jr., or Captain Philip Del Fungo Giera, as the bristly, 67-year-old little man also is known, but yesterday was worse. Tuesday he had heard his "inventions" branded as century-old stuff and vaudeville tricks, but yesterday he heard himself pronounced guilty of impersonating public officials and sentenced to eighteen months in prison and fined $1,000.

MANDALAY, Burma, March 4 -- The British have lost the west bank of the Sittang River near its mouth in the Gulf of Martaban, and the Japanese have reached Waw, a town halfway between the river and Pegu.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 4 (P) -- Miss Georgia Tainter of Fargo, N. D., the medalist, advanced into the second round of the annual South Atlantic womer['s golf tournament today by defeating Mrs. Henry Johnson of New Smyrna Beach, Fla., 9 and 7.

The story of murder and assault unfolded to hundreds of horror- stricken spectators in a crowded Kings County court room by Abe Reles, leader of the Brooklyn murder syndicate, echoed hollowly in the same court room yesterday before a handful of observers who shifted restlessly in their seats and broke the monotony by stepping outside for an occasional smoke.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Senate passed today by a vote of 29 to 5 the Young Bill establishing a Youth Court Division in the Domestic Relations Court in New York City to handle cases of juvenile offenders up to the age of 19.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt entered today upon his tenth year as President of the United States. Here is a brief review of his administration:

United Artists has purchased the film rights to "Shadow and Substance" for $20,000, it was learned yesterday from a reliable source. This is the Paul Vincent Carroll play rated by the New York Drama Critics Circle as "the most distinguished drama of foreign authorship" for the season of 1937-1938.

Robert Hoge, a riding master of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was acquitted yesterday in Special Sessions of cruelty to two saddle horses that were exhibited in the Madison Square Garden Horse Show last November. A "tail set" had been used on the horses.

One settled oneself in the accustomed chair at Town Hall last night for the concert to be given by Mr. Rene Le Roy, the flutist, and his associates. This affair promised excellent entertainment, prevailingly of the classic order.

LONDON, March 4 -- Six junior Ministers were dropped from the government today in a shake-up among lesser members that had been predicted when Prime Minister Winston Churchill changed his Cabinet recently.

When Jascha Heifetz played the national anthem at the start of his recital last night in Carnegie Hall, he stood in the midst of 250 service men, who had received free tickets for all of the seats on stage. In the large group were soldiers from the British contingent now visiting this city.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 4 -- While reports reach here that the Germans are likely to use many parachute troops for their offensive "in the Spring," it seems more and more evident that the Russians are seizing every opportunity of utilizing their Cossack cavalry.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The United States has sent an important scientific and technical mission to Ecuador to assist in the construction of a base vital to the defense of the Western Hemisphere, it was learned tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

Plans for further development of the New York State system of savings bank life insurance were announced yesterday in a joint statement issued by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, the Trustees of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Fund and the Savings Bank Life Insurance Council, an organization composed of the issuing banks in the State.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Byron Nelson, the Texan now playing out of Toledo, Ohio, today flashed the golf form that has made him a money winner in his last thirty tournaments, and the result was a four under par 34, 34 -- 68 to lead the first round of the 72-hole $5,000 St. Petersburg open at the Lakewood Country Club.

Speech and voice disorders are one of the chief public health problems in the country today, afflicting 13,000,000 persons, or 10 per cent of the American population, Dr. James Sonnett Greene, founder and medical director of the National Hospital for Speech Disorders, 61 Irving Place, declared in the annual report of the institution made public yesterday.
CAIRO, March 4 (AP) -- A British Middle East communique said today:
BANDUNG, Java, March 4 (AP) -- The following Netherland communique was issued here:

The C.I.O. union whose conflict with the old management at the plant of Air Associates, Inc., in Bendix, N.J., led the Army to take over the factory, issued yesterday a statement praising the new management of the company and promising unstinted effort to accelerate war production.

HANOVER, N.H., March 4 -- Dartmouth's basketball team closed its season tonight assured of at least a tie for the title it has won four years in a row in the Eastern Intercollegiate League by defeating Yale, 68 -- 52. The Green now has a record of ten victories and two losses.

The British people today are precisely the same men and women whose bravery we were admiring so much only a few weeks ago, before we got into the war ourselves. This is something we seem to have forgotten while we have been watching the Axis victories in the Pacific.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 4 -- Darwin suffered its third air raid this afternoon, with Japanese Zero fighters machine-gunning R.A.A.F. installations. Some damage was done, but no casualties were reported. The raid was on a small scale, with no reports indicating any bombing.

VICHY, France, March 4 -- National mourning was proclaimed today by the Chief of State, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, for the burial of the victims of the British bombing raid of last night on industrial suburbs of Paris.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag ruled yesterday that the Climax Molybdenum Company and certain officers and directors of the American Metal Company, Ltd., must account to American Metal for "profits and benefits accruing to them" over a ten-year period as a result of the "wrongful conduct" of the officers and directors of American Metal in permitting use of its "resources, facilities and personnel" for the benefit of Climax Molybdenum.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles declined today at his press conference to subscribe to the theory projected in some circles in London that the Royal Air Force bombings of industrial plants in the suburbs of Paris marked the end of efforts by anti-Axis nations to maintain normal relations with the Vichy government.
ROME, March 4 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

HAVANA, March 4 -- The Cuban All-Stars beat the Dodgers, 2 -- 1, today, which brought forth a torrent of acclamation in Spanish from the 3,000 fans present. This was Brooklyn's first defeat in three exhibitions.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 4 (AP) -- The ban against freshmen playing on varsity teams at Cornell University was dropped today, according to an announcement by Robert J. Kane, acting director of athletics. He said the Board of Physical Education and Athletics had approved allowing freshmen to play on varsity teams starting next Fall.

WITH UNITED NATIONS FORCES IN JAVA, March 4 -- Americans from Texas are holding a town on the Javanese front. I have not visited that part of the front, but the Americans, an artillery unit commanded by Lieut. Col. B.S. Tharp of Plainview, Texas, are reported to be defending a sector in company with British and Australian troops.

VICHY, France, March 4 -- National mourning was proclaimed today by the Chief of State, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, for the burial of the victims of the British bombing raid of last night on industrial suburbs of Paris.

The British people today are precisely the same men and women whose bravery we were admiring so much only a few weeks ago, before we got into the war ourselves. This is something we seem to have forgotten while we have been watching the Axis victories in the Pacific.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag ruled yesterday that the Climax Molybdenum Company and certain officers and directors of the American Metal Company, Ltd., must account to American Metal for "profits and benefits accruing to them" over a ten-year period as a result of the "wrongful conduct" of the officers and directors of American Metal in permitting use of its "resources, facilities and personnel" for the benefit of Climax Molybdenum.

A 60-cent dividend on the common stock was voted yesterday by the American Snuff Company. On Jan. 2 payments of 60 cents plus 40 cents special were distributed out of non-recurring income, before which 75 cents was paid quarterly.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- There are many reasons why the ninth anniversary of the President's first inaugural should be a marked day in American history. Two, however, are outstanding:

Yoichi Hiraoka, xylophonist, who has given four Town Hall recitals and appeared on sustaining programs of the National Broadcasting Company since October, 1930, was notified the evening of Dec. 7 that his services would not be required by the company until further notice because he was Japanese.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Paul Muni and Luise Rainer, who were starred by Metro in "The Good Earth" in 1937, will be reunited in another film adaptation of a Pearl S. Buck novel, "China Sky," at RKO, it was learned today.

Life in the United States is easily supportable without trouser cuffs, patch pockets, pleats, belts and vests for double-breasted suits. These things have now been banned by the War Production Board to conserve woolen cloth.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- A conference of dairymen from eleven Northeastern States appointed a committee today to confer with Federal authorities on steps to check the flow of workers from the farms. The action followed reports presented at the two-day meeting of the Northeastern Dairy Conference that competition from war industries and the draft were making large inroads into farm labor supplies.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 4 -- The Military Academy, in today's orders, acknowledged receipt of this message from Geneeral Douglas MacArthur, in reply to a Washington Birthday greeting sent him by Major Gen. Francis B. Wilby, superintendent, on behalf of the Corps of Cadets:...

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Henry Francis Grady, former assistant secretary of state, has been chosen to head the United States war mission to India, it was learned tonight. The mission will be sent to New Delhi immediately after the reorganization of the India war establishment, which is expected to be announced from London some time this week.

Police Captains William Streib of the East Sixty-seventh Street station, John J. Padian Jr. of the West Sixty-eighth Street station and James Lynch of the Lee Avenue station in Brooklyn have filed retirement applications, it was disclosed yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, March 4 (U.P.) -- Simultaneously with today's shake-up in the Naval High Command, the Netherland Government's order to all commanders, "including those having to operate singly," to fight on to the last was interpreted here to mean that units cut off from contact with headquarters would continue to press guerrilla warfare against the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Preparations are being made to send an American economic mission to South Africa to arrange for increased production there and for greatly amplified shipments of essential mine products, including chrome, asbestos and copper.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (U.P.) -- Australian Minister Richard G. Casey said tonight that Australia alone could not halt the Japanese onslaught and appealed for immediate reinforcements to preserve l the last stronghold of the United Nations in the Pacific "as a base from which ultimate victory in the Far East will come."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- For one of the rare occasions in the history of local Yankee training -- veteran camp followers were undecided whether it ever had happened previously in the eighteen years at Huggins Field -- the world champions today passed the appointed date for a scrub game without any action.

Dark news from most other fronts is brightened at least a little by the success of American fliers in a battle over Japan's home waters west of the Gilbert Islands. The destruction of sixteen enemy planes at the cost of two American craft seems to demonstrate the superiority of these Grumman fighters from our carriers even over Japanese land-based bombers.

A model of the new women's coat designed and manufactured to conform with the proposed specifications of the War Production Board for conserving wool was shown last night at the annual membership dinner and meeting of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association at the Hotel Astor.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, March 4 -- At least seven persons were killed and more than fifteen were injured late tonight in an explosion which rocked the Burlington ordnance works and the surrounding countryside, Police Sergeant Hurley Eland reported.

A three-day conference of 800 Eastern members of the American Bankers Association opened yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with an examination of the "major role" of bankers in wartime. At this conference the customary cocktail parties, dinners and social events have been eliminated.

When the British bombers went over the industrial suburbs west and southwest of Paris on Tuesday night they were trying to destroy factories known to be making trucks, tanks and airplane engines for the use of the German Army. That is, they were trying to intercept at the source machines and weapons destined to destroy lives among the Allied peoples.

ALVIN JOHNSON predicts that German literature for the generation after the war will be largely a matter of frost-bite, freezing, pneumonia and the oppressive sweep of miles -- or versts -- of Russian snow. If one were to extend the scope of Professor Johnson's prophecy, one would forecast a French literature full of sly subtleties surpassing anything in Gide or Proust, for indirection should feed on the presence of a conqueror.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A guide for nutrition-conscious housewives was issued today by the Bureau of Home Economics in the form of a low-cost diet schedule so arranged that a household planner may determine how much food of all types is needed by her family each week.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Claude B. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, called today on cotton farmers in the United States to plant their full national acreage allotment of 27,400,000 acres in 1942 and told potato growers that the department would support prices for the 1942 crop of Irish potatoes.

Although the making of certain types of toys may have to be further curtailed as war production is expanded, representatives of the toy industry said yesterday that they expected no drastic changes in their wares this year. Simpler styles and fewer varieties, however, will be offered to the retail market by the manufacturers, who will present their complete lines for 1942 at the American Toy Fair opening next Monday.

Yesterday's experience with the offerings of about $55,000,000 of new securities, both bonds and stocks, proved that a ready market prevails for new issues "at a price," despite the uncertainties in the investment market generally growing out of the war and pending tax legislation.

The strength exhibited by the stock market on Tuesday proved to be only an interlude, for the list returned yesterday to weakness and meager volume. If, as it was argued in brokerage circles, the rally of the previous day had stemmed from relief over the hurdling of the freight-rate and tax questions, these same factors produced the return yesterday to lower levels.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The House Military Affairs Committee adopted today a report which Representative Faddis of Pennsylvania said accused the Rural Electrification Administration of diverting vitally needed copper from the war program to nonessential projects.

Thousands of man-hours of production are being lost in the metropolitan district every day through the failure of some aircraft manufacturers to achieve the goal of round-the-clock operation set by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, a survey indicated yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- Coming on with a rush, one of the most modest starters in today's Lynnewood Handicap at Hialeah Park scored decisively and left observers wondering about the grass course. The winner was Hillblond, entered in her previous race to be claimed for $1,600.

Plans for scuttling American merchant ships quickly and with a minimum loss of life if it appears likely that valuable cargoes or the ships themselves will fall into enemy hands, are being considered by the Maritime Commission, Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the commission, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Automotive Safety Foundation is to begin a nation-wide program to enlist the cooperation of the public in conservation of vehicles, tires, fuels and highways, with simultaneous promotion of the safe and efficient use of these for war purposes.

VICHY, France, March 5 -- Funeral services will be held at 10 A.M. Saturday in various localities for victims of Tuesday night's Royal Air Force bombardment of Paris suburbs. Joseph Barthelemy, Minister of Justice, has left for Paris to represent the Chief of State.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., March 5 -- Mayor Frank Hague countered today Governor Charles Edison's latest blow to the prestige and patronage of the Hague organization by enlarging on his off-repeated charge that the Governor was taking dictation from the State "railroad lobby" because it served his private business interests to do so.

LONDON, March 5 (AP)--The government's announcement of a plan to grant more independence to India--and thereby to get fuller cooperation from India in the war effort--has been postponed because Conservatives in London and New Delhi consider the first draft too advanced, it was stated in informed quarters tonight.

ALBANY, March 5 -- A reapportionment of Congressional seats in the State, giving to New York City the two additional Representatives allotted to the State a decade ago, has been drafted by the Legislative Reapportionment Commission. The measure will be submitted simultaneously with the legislative reapportionment measure within two weeks, by the committee of which Harry A. Reoux is chairman and William F. Bleakley the counsel.

Sales executives were warned yesterday not to rely on the old and costly distribution systems, if they expected to distribute in the post-war period the huge production which expanded American factories will turn out, in an address by Edwin G. Nourse, director of the Institute of Economics of the Brookings Institution, at the marketing conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Nine policemen, eight of them Negroes, were questioned yesterday in the Homicide Bureau of the District Attorney's office on reports that twenty-five policemen in civilian clothes were present at a dice game in a vacant Harlem apartment when John D. Brown, 52 years old, a Negro, shot and killed two Negro gamblers.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 5 -- German expressions of fury over the Britain bombardment of French factories and German materiel plants in the Paris region rose to new heights of invective today. The Wilhelmstrasse in particular was "outraged," according to agency dispatches, over the "blood bath which had no military objective."

MEXICO CITY, March 5 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho has asked Mexico's railroad and oil workers to abandon strikes during the world crisis for the country's sake and to aid the democracies in their struggle against the Axis powers.

The popular weekly magazine at 5 cents will soon be another casualty of the war, it was indicated yesterday with announcements that the price of the Saturday Evening Post and Liberty magazine would be advanced to 10 cents in April. The Post price increase is effective with the issue of April 11 and the Liberty rise with the April 18 issue.

The arrival of a new enemy convoy of Mindanao in the Philippines is further evidence that Japan is having trouble with guerrilla bands and needs reinforcements to handle them. Long experience, from which we ourselves once suffered, has taught the native population how to organize areas which an invading army in a great hurry must necessarily leave open.

For seven months last year the labor-employer relationship in the Air Associates plant at Bendix, N.J., was appalling. Five of those months were marked by strife which impeded the execution of war orders. For two months the Army Air Corps had control.

A tired proofreader on The Times of London has done something less than promote a better knowledge of American history among his British countrymen. On the eve of Lincoln's Birthday the British Ambassador spoke at Springfield, Ill.

The German production of aluminum in 1943 is expected to be about 300,000 short tons, an increase of only 35,000 over the output in 1940, according to survey of light metal industries by George S. Armstrong Co., Inc., industrial engineers and management consultants.

The trial of six alleged Nazi spies entered its final stages yesterday as two of the three defense counsel ended their cases with pleas for observance of true democratic principles in the treatment of their clients. Abraham C. Bein, counsel for Paul T. Borchardt, spoke very briefly, telling the jurors that his client, labeled a "fake refugee" by the prosecution, had been a devout servant of his fatherland, Germany, a country eminent in culture.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- President Roosevelt signed today a resolution authorizing the Maritime Commission to acquire, as a site for a permanent Atlantic Coast Cadet Training School, property at Kings Point, Great Neck, L.I., opposite Fort Schuyler.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Department stores sales for the week ended Feb. 28 increased 18 per cent over the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Sales in the week ended Feb. 21 rose 25 per cent. For the four-week period ended Feb. 28 and the year to that date, sales were up 21 per cent and 27 per cent, respectively.

The recent rain had little effect on the general Eastern ski picture, for snow, and in many places, plenty of it, accompanied the storm, according to reports received last night from the North Country. From three to eighteen inches of new flakes fell in the Northlands, with the result that skiing, generally speaking, will be good this week-end.

The drive to lure city workers to farms to relieve a threatened shortage of agricultural labor took on the aspects of a tug-of-war last night, with three States competing for the services of young men and women from the metropolitan district.

TOKYO, Friday, March 6 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco and New York) -- An Imperial Headquarters announcement at 11:50 A.M. today said that "Japanese naval flying units" had carried out "devastating raids" yesterday over Bandung, Java, " bringing down and destroying on the ground a total of eighteen enemy planes."

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, took up with Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, at a conference of an hour and a quarter today, the status of New Caledonia, the French island that lies about 600 miles east of Australia, and also expressed his deep indignation over the Royal Air Force bombing of industrial suburbs of Paris.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Army and Selective Service officials have ruled out any plan of inducting the new draft registrants by age groups and will follow the present system of drawing order numbers in a national lottery, which will be held March 17, Secretary Stimson said today.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, March 5 (AP) -- Lieut. Gem William S. Knudsen, the Army's production chief, will visit tomorrow the scene of the Iowa Ordnance Works disaster where at least fifteen persons died last night in the second explosion there within three months.

The lights of Carnegie Hall are variously lowered for evening concerts given in that auditorium. The effect last night, when the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, led by Eugene Goossens, played, communicated a singularly dreary impression. It had no life for the eye and it blended all too well with the prevailing character of the occasion.

Today marks the end of the third month after the tragedy at Pearl Harbor. Secretary Knox's original statement of the damage done was probably as candid as he was able to make it at the time without giving vital information to the enemy. But now that three months have passed, some restatement of the extent of this tragedy is due.

The flower market this week-end is characterized by an abundant supply of top quality corsage flowers, in a wide range of varieties and prices. Gardenias, camellias, violets, sweet peas and orchids are all available in quantity at local flower markets. Prices are scaled according to the quantity on hand.

CHUNGKING, China, March 5 (UP) -- China's 2,000,000 guerrilla soldiers, striking deep within occupied areas as far as Manchuria, where the Japanese have been entrenched ten years, killed or wounded 150,000 of the enemy and captured huge stocks of war material in the thirteen-month period ended Jan. 31, a military spokesman said today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- "Johnny's allowance, sister's misplaced coat, and even the broadest questions of family finance and conduct, can best be treated in open discussion, when each member of the family realizes that his or her rights will be respected," Dr. James J. Waygood, neuro-psychiatrist at St. Christopher's Hospital, told the annual Institute on Family Relations today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Roosevelt conferred today at the White House for three hours with representatives of the Anglo-American Combined Staffs Council, presumably to devise new strategy to meet the situation resulting from Japanese successes in Java.
BANDUNG, Netherlands Indies, March 5 (AP) -- A Netherlands Indies comnunique said today:

Yesterday's weekly statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted and reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities were unchanged.

For a time it appeared that all school children were to be treated as infants on the question of war. They were asked to conserve paper, tin, live frugally and keep well because we are at war. They were prepared for bombings, sang "The Star-Spangled Banner" more often and intensified salutes to the flag.

Some time ago we suggested that some of the fox hunters who have been complaining that the foxes are less plentiful than last year make a trip out to Montauk with their hounds and get a real day's sport.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 5 -- Fear of vengeance from an angry crowd caused her to flee after running over and killing a child in Mamaroneck last Dec. 19, Mrs. Dorothy Black Milligan, Harrison clubwoman and wife of a war hero, declared today when placed on trial in Westchester County Court as an alleged hit and run driver involved in homicide.

I have read with great interest the editorial of March 1 with reference to India. You might have added to the other truths you set forth that the hopeless British situation in Burma is in no small measure due to the treatment accorded U Saw by Prime Minister Churchill.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 (AP) -- Barbara Bennett, who signed away custody of her five children to expedite her marriage to Jack Randall, movie cowboy, has instructed her attorney to sue for their return.

With war production taking up all available trained workers and making necessary the rapid employment of others less skilled, the day of the generally trained technical employe is gone, Robert F. Nelson, vice president of the Arma Corporation, declared yesterday at the opening meeting of the seventh annual career conference of the Vocational Service for Juniors.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 5 (AP) -- The Japanese already are feeling out the Australian coast for invasion and may attempt early landings in the north, northwest and east, Australians were told today.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5 -- The Giants' training camp, working smoothly and efficiently under the adroit handling of Manager Melvin Ott, suffered a disturbing jolt today. That questionable right shoulder of Johnny Mize has been acting up a bit, and for the first time since the Polo Grounders swung the deal for the slugging Cardinal first sacker last December, there seems to be apprehension that all might not be well with Johnny's throwing arm.

TOKYO, March 5 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Domei agency quoted Japanese military headquarters tonight as saying 90,000 soldiers were captured at Singapore. It said 42,000 of these were Indians.

HAVANA, March 5 -- Any one long associated with the Dodgers should be prepared for anything, especially since Ringmaster Larry MacPhail and Lippy Leo Durocher have been directing the Brooklyn club's destinies.

A few securities dealers who were members of the selling group in the offering of $32,500,000 of the Pennsylvania Electric Company's 3 3/8 per cent bonds on Wednesday failed to profit by the experience gained in the $80,000,000 financing of the Alabama Power Company last January when an over-sold situation squeezed quite a few dealers as the bonds quickly "went out the window."

Entrance into the furniture field is being considered seriously by many of the leading finance companies that heretofore specialized in handling automobile and appliance accounts, it was learned yesterday. To offset to some extent the severe blow to their business caused by curtailed production of automobiles and appliances, many of those which are already engaged in financing war contracts will also seek further expansion in that direstion.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Thousands of Japanese soldiers were believed to have been killed in the raid conducted over Subic Bay by the small air force that General Douglas MacArthur mustered for the surprise blow reported yesterday, he stated in a dispatch to the War Department today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)--Choice of Representative James W. Wadsworth of New York for Secretary of War if Henry L. Stimson resigns received today the endorsement of two Democrats and a Republican in speeches on the House floor.
Mingled tidings came this weekend from the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, for the latest bulletin contains bad news counterbalanced by good.

Reserves of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York have been built up to meet possible economic shocks and other measures have been adopted to safeguard policyholders, according to the ninety-ninth annual report of the company, which is being mailed today.

All the real action in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night was packed into the last period. And what developed in this closing session proved satisfactory to the Brooklyn Americans' rooters in the crowd of 7,153 observers, for Red Dutton's skaters kept alive their hopes of qualifying for a play-off berth by defeating the Black Hawks, 2 to 1.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 5 (AP) -- The Consolidated Aircraft Corporation reported today for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30, 1941, a net profit of $8,024,882 after reduction of Federal taxes on an income of $18,195,390. The profit amounted to $6.22 a common share.

The United States can lose this war, Floyd B. Odlum, economic adviser to the War Production Board, warned last night in an address at the annual dinner of the Greater New York Safety Council. The dinner, held at the Hotel Pennsylvania, was in connection with the council's thirteenth annual safety convention and exposition.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 -- The question whether 50,000 or so of the California Japanese who must leave a designated military area along the coast will be sent to a registration center in the Owens Valley, near the source of the Los Angeles water supply, was discussed at length today and an announcement of the decision is expected soon from Lieut. Gen. John L. De Witt, Western defense commander.
" CONQUEST after conquest, deeper and deeper into molasses. Maybe the Leader is crazy. Flies conquer the flypaper. Flies capture 200 miles of new flypaper!"

MOSCOW, March 5 (AP) -- The vicinity of the town of Yukhnov, captured by the Red Army today, had been converted by the Germans into a network of strongly fortified points to which reinforcements had been rushed by plane from Germany, France, Czechoslovakia and other occupied countries.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (U.P.) -- Plans for "a foreign legion" of United Nations citizens in the United States are nearly complete.
CHICAGO, March 5 -- Mergers among the country's nineteen existing air transport systems were predicted today by William A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines.

The annual intercollegiate A.A. A.A. track and field championships place less of a premium on records than do the ordinary meets. It is the fierce team competition that will lift tomorrow's meet at Madison Square Garden out of the ordinary. But the intercollegiates always turn up with a crop of new marks.

Sammy Angott will make his first ring appearance since he won the lightweight championship of the world when he opposes Bob Montgomery, rugged Philadelphia fighter, in the star bout of twelve rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Angott took the 135-pound crown from Lew Jenkins two months ago, but will not be risking it in his joust with the Philadelphia Negro, since each warrior will be above weight.

LONDON, March 5 (U.P.) -- Great Britain's Burma army battled knee-deep in the rice paddy fields west of the Sittang River today against a Japanese spearhead that had rounded the head of the Gulf of Martaban and turned southwest for a direct drive on Rangoon, less than seventy miles away, according to Far Eastern dispatches.

LONDON, Friday, March 6 -- The Air Ministry released today photographs proving conclusively that British bombers made an accurate attack on the Renault factory in Billancourt, a suburb of Paris, Tuesday night, leaving great damage in the most important parts of the plant and spreading only incidental damage to surrounding houses near by.

The School of Nursing at New York Hospital has become part of Cornell University, it was announced yesterday by the two institutions. The school, a unit in the group of medical buildings at York Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, will be known as the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing.

" To Be Or Not To Be," the Carole Lombard-Jack Benny comedy, which was produced and directed by Ernst Lubitsch, will open this morning at the Rivoli. The picture features Robert Stack, Lionel Atwill, Stanley Ridges, Felix Bressart, Tom Dugan, Sig Rumann and Maude Eburne.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- That a showdown is approaching in the cases of six Yankee regulars who refuse to sign contracts at the terms offered by Ed Barrow was indicated today when the incomplete squad went through an abbreviated drill on the eve of the first exhibition game with the Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Immediate enactment of excise tax levies designed to raise $1,340,000,000 was suggested today by the Senate Finance Committee, but it met a cool reception among Ways and Means Committee members, some of whom called it an attempt to "sidetrack" a general sales tax.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 5 -- German propaganda in Turkey is working hard to mesmerize the Turks into the belief that they will not be attacked by the Axis, although immediately across the frontier the Nazis are inciting the Bulgars to war fever by assuring them that they will have a crack at their ancient enemies before the year is up and will be able to add European Turkey and Istanbul to the growing Bulgarian kingdom.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Java, March 5 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces advancing steadily in a savage battle raging "all over Java" have hammered invasion spearheads closer to Batavia and Bandung and half way across the slim waistline of the island, the Netherlands Indies High Command reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A program aiming to promote the health and defense of the Western Hemisphere was outlined today by Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

Among the best of the anti-Nazi pictures which have yet been exhibited hereabouts, you can list the British-made "The Invaders," which opened at the Capitol yesterday. For this, indeed, is a picture which not only argues trenchantly but is filmed and played with such intelligence that it gives an illusion of documented fact.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5 -- Hans W. Wulf, 41 years old, president of the Red Bank (N.J.) Marine Works, a former German U-boat commander, has been turned over to immigration authorities at Ellis Island for questioning on suspicion of being a dangerous enemy alien, it was disclosed at the local FBI office today.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Actress Mary Boland explained today that she has quit the cast of "The Rivals" because she was very ill.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The House economy advocates achieved relatively small but significant victories today over the farm group as debate over the $695,505,859 Agriculture Department supply bill entered its fourth day.

George W. Kirchwey made his mark in a number of ways, as an eminent teacher of law, a public-spirited citizen of various and long service in political reform, municipal and national, the highly capable director of the United States Employment Service after the First World War.

Jim Crowley, for the last nine years football coach at Fordham University, is planning to leave Rose Hill and his coaching duties and enlist in naval aviation for the duration of the war, it was revealed yesterday.

Despite a defeat by Brown in its final game, Rhode Island State yesterday accepted an invitation to compete in the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden, scheduled for March 17, 19 23 and 25. That set-back hardly hurt the New England Rams, since they were beaten by a giddy 83 -- 82 score when Stutz Modzelewski's last-second basket was disallowed.

LONDON, March 5 -- Two government spokesmen -- L.S. Amery, Secretary of State for India and Burma, and Sir Stafford Cripps, leader of the House of Commons -- begged off today when members of the House asked them about the political situation in India.
Black and white, favorites of long standing in Spring wardrobes, took the spotlight yesterday when Russeks showed part of its Spring collection during luncheon at the Stork Club.

Deep drifts of snow in Tuckerman's Ravine, the weather reports say. And the northbound trains are bristling with skis, ski poles, duffle bags, wax-kits, knapsacks and all manner of miscellaneous luggage. Spring skiing is the paradoxical name for this enthusiastic madness; but up on Mount Washington Spring is only a myth and that bright sunshine glistening on the snow is an idle gesture.

Seymour (Blue Jaw) Magoon, a soft-spoken professional killer and automobile thief for the Brooklyn murder ring, said yesterday in Kings County Court that for eight years he had been on intimate terms with the city's most notorious gangsters, but that he always refrained from voicing his opinion of them because it would not have been the polite thing to do.
