The moon which stole through an open window in China twenty years ago and kept the young scholar Hu Shih awake all night with thoughts of a departed love cast a tender reflection into the perilous present at Columbia University yesterday afternoon.

Formation of the International Committee for Cooperative Reconstruction to centralize the aid of consumer cooperatives in the democratic solution of both current and post-war problems was announced here yesterday by Dr. Henry Szoskes, chairman of the executive board of the committee and former general manager of the Central Cooperative Bank of Warsaw.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, March 6 -- The southern pivot of the Germans' easternmost defenses of the Rzhev-Vyazma-Dorogobuzh pocket fell to the Russians yesterday when Soviet troops captured the town of Yukhnov, the Russian High Command announced last night.
LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- Note circulation increased about 2,000,000 in the last week, while reserve decreased almost a similar amount, the Bank of England statement showed today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- George Sylvester Viereck, alleged to be a leading propagandist for Nazi Germany in the United States, was convicted by a jury in Federal District Court today of withholding essential information when he registered with the State Department as an agent of Reich interests.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5 -- Mrs. Irving Hall Chase of Waterbury, Conn., gave a luncheon at the Bath and Tennis Club today for Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef of Austria. Her other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sidney, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Sir William and Lady Garthwaite, Mrs. George Luke Mesker, Countess Helene Chlapowska, Countess Narkiewicz-Jodko, Sydney Emlen Hutchinson, George MacDonald, Channing W. Hare and Stephen Kellogg.

Illuminating gas leaking from a jet exposed by the loosening of a hose connection to a heater caused the death last night of a woman in a four-room flat above a vacant store at 54 Third Avenue, near Pacific Street in downtown Brooklyn.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York adopted unanimously yesterday, at its monthly meeting at 65 Liberty Street, a resolution requesting the District Attorneys and grand juries of the counties within the City of New York "to inquire into the conduct of public officials responsible for over-assessments (of real estate) in order to determine if they have violated any laws and are guilty of misconduct."

Bank clearings in twenty-three major cities in the United States in the week ended on Wednesday reached a new high for this year of $7,911,018,000, an increase of 16.7 per cent over the $6,779,077,000 in the corresponding week of last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

ALBANY, March 5 -- A bill exempting New York City from liability for accidents or injuries suffered by passengers on the city's subway lines during a blackout or other emergency periods was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator Coudert and Assemblyman Mitchell, Manhattan Republicans.

CRANFORD, N.J., March 5 -- A sixteen-unit defense housing project, the first of its type here, will be erected in a 300-foot tract in Centennial Avenue near South Avenue, by T.V. Albert, Cranford builder. The project will consist of one-family houses, linked together.

Batavia, the capital and greatest city of the Netherlands Indies, is in the west part of the north coastal region of Java on the Bay of Batavia. It was founded in 1619 and named for the Bataven, the inhabitants of the Low Countries about 50 A.D.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 5 -- Reports received tonight from a usually reliable source tend to confirm recent information that the Germans are preparing to take over from the Finns the Karelian Isthmus front for an expected offensive against Leningrad from the north.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Telling the Senate that an increasing number of men who were being drafted had dependents and that in some parts of the country "practically every man being selected" had definite obligations at home -- Senator Taft introduced bills today to pay benefits to dependents of service men about twice those granted during the World War.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Some of the spices and condiments formerly imported into this country from Europe and Asia are being replaced with an American grown product, but others cannot be produced here for various reasons, Dr. D.M. Crooks, principal plant anatomist for the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Plant Industry, said today.

Patriotic color notes of red and blue highlighted the Spring fashion show presented yesterday by R.H. Macy Co. at the Hotel Astor as part of the fifth annual luncheon and Spring Festival of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs.

LONDON, March 5 -- A year ago the coming Wednesday Joseph Kouba, 22, of East Seventy-second Street, New York City, a laboratory assistant and night student of chemistry at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, dropped a nickel in a telephone coin box at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory in New York and called his wife Edna.

DETROIT, March 5 -- A picket line of more than 3,000 unemployed workers of the Briggs Manufacturing Company was thrown around the company's Mack Avenue plant for several hours here today in protest against alleged delay in converting operations from peace-to-war-time basis.

The cotton market moved quietly and within a seven-point range yesterday as traders found nothing in the outside news to motivate important business on either side of the market. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were at the low levels of the session, unchanged to 2 points higher than the previous close.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The owners of some 30,000,000 motor cars were warned bluntly today, in effect, that they were now running on their last sets of tires for possibly three years, and thus had better make them last as best they could.

DETROIT, March 5 -- Detroit's Red Wings finally ended the jinx held over them by the New York Rangers by winning the final series game, a fist-swinging affair, 5 to 2, tonight before 7,883 roaring fans.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., March 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Albert Payson Terhune indicated today that she may offer for sale about four of the remaining nine of the famous dogs which were left in her charge under terms of Mr. Terhune's will, probated yesterday in Paterson.

ALBANY, March 5 -- A newspaper has the right to hold "national legislators" to strict official accountability, the Appellate Division Third Department ruled today by a vote of three to two, dismissing an action brought by Representative Edwin A. Hall of Binghamton against the Binghamton Press Company for criticism of his vote against the lease-lend bill, which Congress approved. Mr. Hall asked $75,000 damages.

ROME, Ga., March 5 (AP) -- Miss Martha Berry, founder of the Berry Schools, made numerous bequests to relatives and enjoined the trustees of the schools to uphold the standard and Christian ideals upon which the institution was founded, in a will filed today for probate.

The issuing of official conservation orders during the past week covering wool and rayon staple allotments for the second quarter helped clear the way for future wool goods production, according to the weekly trade report issued yesterday by the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5 -- Signator, the Woolford Farm speedster who did so well in his previous try, was a game winner in the Bougainvillea Handicap today at Hialeah Park, where 11,035 persons wagered $542,410 on the forty-fourth day of the meeting which comes to an end Saturday.

The consolidated net profit of Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., and subsidiaries for 1941 was $175,516, equivalent to $3.38 a share on 52,000 outstanding shares of $25-par 6 per cent preferred stock, against $108,712, or $2.09 a share on the same stock, in 1940, according to a report issued yesterday.

Two teams of four emerged last night from the semi-final round of the Eastern States contract bridge contest at the Park Central Hotel, and won the right to play this afternoon and tonight for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Sharp increases in prices for textiles, particularly woolen and worsted materials, featured primary commodity markets during the last week of February. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' all-commodity index of wholesale prices for nearly 900 series advanced 0.3 per cent to 96.8 per cent of the 1926 average, the highest level reached since September, 1928.

Directors of the United States Rubber Company have deferred dividend action on the 8 per cent preferred stock. F.B. Davis Jr., chairman and president, announced yesterday. Dividends, which are non-cumulative, were resumed in 1938.

To the Chinese, above all other people, the fiasco of Allied defense in the Pacific has come as a stunning blow. For years, fighting alone, the Chinese lived on the hope of intervention by the Western Powers to hold Japan to the solemn promise she had given them to respect the integrity of her neighbor on the continent of Asia.

While engineering construction awards this week are well above the volume reported in the same week of last year, they are sharply off from the 1942 high established last week, according to the Engineering News-Record. The current figure of $145,401,000 exceeds the 1941 total by 40 per cent, but fails by 45 per cent to attain that for last week.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Wheat continued to act with extreme caution on either side of the market pending developments in regard to the bill now before Congress which seeks to prevent the Commodity Credit Corporation from selling its holdings at less than the so-called parity prices.

With men and machines which last year produced civilian goods urgently needed to supply half of the nation's scheduled 1942 $40,000,000 war output, the National Industrial Conference Board declared yesterday that adoption by this country seems imminent of a "nucleus" plan similar to that developed in Great Britain for supplying essential civil needs in the affected industries.

One of the most important gifts of park land made to the city in recent years was approved by the Board of Estimate at City Hall yesterday when it accepted forty-two acres of land on a high bluff facing the Hudson River between West 247th and West 254th Streets.

Supreme Court Justice Philip A. Brennan in Brooklyn signed yesterday an order to enforce the terms of his decision of last week granting a temporary injunction setting forth conditions of payment for the investigation of a citywide $1,000,000 paving racket by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen.

From beginning to end Fira Benenson's collection, presented yesterday morning in Bonwit Teller's Salon de Couture, was consistent. It had a single motif developed with many variations: The elimination of the unnecessary so that the essential might be stressed. Simple undyed jerseys with flat bow pockets and jeweled buttons set the tempo of what was to follow.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The State Supreme Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine an action brought by the Bank of France against assignees of the Bank of Belgium, the Court of Appeals ruled today. Involved are some $228,000,000 gold now in the possession of the Federal Reserve Bank.

" The Germans indulge themselves in open discussion of what other peoples consider deep military and diplomatic secrets. This frankness has worked to their advantage, because the rest of the world has hesitated to believe what the Nazis did not hesitate to reveal."

FOR some years this baffled bystander has been campaigning against over-the-weight matches for boxing titleholders and has obtained about as much success as good old King Canute did when he ordered the ocean tide to stop rising. It's wonderful how little attention is paid to sensible suggestions. Or as Prince Hal said: "Wisdom cries out in the street, and no man regards it."

ALBANY, March 5 -- The Court of Appeals brushed aside today rulings of the lower courts and upheld Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate's action in failing to include in the 1941-42 budget an appropriation of $295,297 for the Townsend-Harris High School.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 5 (AP) -- William J. Cox, State Highway Commissioner, was accused today in removal proceedings filed by Attorney General Francis A. Pallotti of "laxity" in enforcing contracts, allowing the use of "improper material" on a Hartford dike that collapsed with damage of $313,250, and failure to take disciplinary measures after women employes had complained to him about the actions of a subordinate.

Cortland Onet entertained with a supper party last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Palmedo. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. George R. Kent, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Barker, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Travers, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J.C. Henderson, Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. McDonnell, Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Wolf and Maurice Dreicer.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority nominally to issue $8,000,000 of consolidated refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds to be held in the Treasury after authentication, subject to the commission's further order.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5 -- The impressionistic school of painting ran afoul of the realistic art of sleuthing when Van Rearing Perrine, member of the National Academy of Design, was arrested yesterday as a suspected spy while he was sketching "a turmoil of trash" at the Newark dumps, an area ringed by defense plants.

Needing 7,000 new officers this year the Army has worked out what John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, calls "a simple and straightforward system whereby these officers will be chosen." Men with good civilian records and "marked qualities of leadership" will be chosen from the ranks after three or four months of service and sent to training schools.
LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- A secret conference between Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, presumably over the defense of Burma, was disclosed tonight.

The Maple Leaf Fund will gain from the presentation on Monday in the Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria of the motion picture "The Battle for the Pacific," taken recently by Arthur Menken. The fund, which cooperates with the American Red Cross, will use the proceeds to further its work of sending surgical kits, blankets and other supplies to disaster-stricken areas.

One of the largest apartment buildings in Hudson County, N.J., the five-story Delphic Towers at 1009 Eighty-seventh Street, North Bergen, has been sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to the P.E. Realty Company in a deal negotiated by J.I. Kislak, Inc., brokers.

The city of Cleveland, Ohio, will enter the market on March 26 with an issue of $901,000 of sewage-disposal bonds, for which bidders are asked to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds, dated April 1, 1942, will mature serially on Oct. 1, 1943 to 1967.

PITTSBURGH, March 5 -- The question whether $60,000 a year provided proper living expenses for Mrs. Madelaine Horne Austin of Southampton, L.I., granddaughter of one of the founders of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, was argued in Orphans' Court today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The appointment of Naotake Sato as Japanese Ambassador to Moscow bears comparison to the mission on which, last October, Saburo Kurusu was sent to the United States. It may be taken as the portent of a conflict.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Army reorganization program, which will become effective Monday, was largely designed to give the air forces a status comparable to the position held by air warfare in modern combat, Secretary Stimson said today.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 5 -- A number of persons were arrested last Saturday night and interned in Syria for the duration of the war, and the Free French authorities today issued a stern warning addressed to others against "playing the Axis game," it was revealed in a communique published here.

CHUNGKING, China, March 5 (U.P.) -- The commander of Formosan volunteers in China, Li Yu-pang, said today that since the start of the Pacific war the Japanese had double-tracked all railroads on Formosa and increased its airfields to thirty-five by building eleven new ones.
Quick resales were among the realty transactions reported yesterday in Manhattan.

Thirty-four stores in the metropolitan area, including all of the major dry goods establishments, opened yesterday a joint appeal to New York shoppers to carry home all portable parcels as a patriotic measure. The opening step in the campaign was the publication of the first of a series of advertisements headed: "To Help Save Things Your Country Needs, Will You Carry Your Share?"

We have been reminded so often in this war that men and materials take precedence over money that there is a tendency to go to the extreme and assume that finance no longer counts. The fact is that finance is an essential instrument whereby the resources of a country are mobilized for war and the enormous process of production, transportation and exchange of goods is facilitated.

In General De Witt's designation of the West Coast evacuation zone he has asked for the voluntary cooperation of the Japanese now living in the forbidden area. Only those who have been reading the Japanese vernacular press know how freely such cooperation has been offered by the American-Japanese.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Roosevelt conferred with representatives of the Anglo-American Combined Staffs Council and discussed railway labor problems with B.M. Jewell, head of the American Federation of Labor Railway Employees Department, and T.C. Cassen, president of the Switchmen's Union of North America.

The effect of conscription and wartime restrictions in making millions of average American citizens less acceptable banking risks was revealed yesterday in detail by more than a dozen speakers at a credit clinic in the Hotel Waldorf Astoria attended by some 800 Eastern members of the American Bankers Association.

Table showing the details of the budget increases requested by various city agencies for next year, which Budget Director Kenneth Dayton made public yesterday with the comment that increases sought by the courts were "inexcusable."

The threat of an increased rapid transit fare came close yesterday when Budget Director Kenneth Dayton reported that city departments and agencies had asked for a total of $620,580,000 for next year, an increase of $46,840,000 over the 1941-42 budget of $573,740,594.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 5 (U.P.) -- American newspapermen and diplomatic officials detained in Bad Nauheim, Germany, awaiting transfer home are spending their spare time studying seventeen subjects ranging from Russian philosophy to tap-dancing.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, March 5 (Canadian Press) -- Telling how two enemy submarines apparently "ganged up" to sink their allied freighter somewhere in the Western Atlantic, thirty-one survivors, including a group of American sailors, have been brought to port by an English merchantman.
In this morning's mail comes a letter from an officer who is serving his country in the Pacific which ought to be of interest to every American.

PITTSBURGH, March 5 -- Allegheny County authorities today held William Johann Adams, 40 years old, a German alien of Pittsburgh and New York, on charges of blackmail and extortion in an alleged $20,000 swindle of German-born residents accomplished with threats of harm against their relatives living under the Nazi regime.

The battle for Java and the battle for Burma were still fiercely joined yesterday, though the defenders in both theatres were fighting losing engagements. And the eyes of the world were already focused on potential new battlefields, the most important of them India, where General Sir Archibald P. Wavell resumed supreme command.

William J. Pedrick, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second District, said yesterday that Federal income tax payments since March 1 have totaled 287 per cent more than for the same period in 1941. The total paid by taxpayers at the Custom House office, Mr. Pedrick disclosed, is $16,243,500, with yesterday's payments aggregating $1,621,967, a gain of 78 per cent over the corresponding day of last year.
TORONTO, March 5 (AP) -- The Canadiens won their first hockey game on Toronto ice in more than three years tonight, defeating the Maple Leafs, 5 -- 2.

BANDUNG, Java, Friday, March 6 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Lieutenant Governor General, Hubertus van Mook, said last night that the United Nations might at any moment counter-attack the Japanese invaders "from another side" and he urged Java's teeming millions to concentrate their resistance in favorable areas, as General Douglas MacArthur has done in the Philippines.

New York cannot depend on the experience of London in its preparation for air raid protection, since the two cities present entirely different problems, but must work out its own defense system, in the opinion of James G. Blaine, newly appointed chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office of Greater New York.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- New and used typewriters were "frozen" in the hands of manufacturers and retailers by a War Production Board order which is preliminary to rationing of all sales of machines to consumers.

Awards have been made to six artists for paintings included in the seventy-fifth annual exhibition of the American Water-Color Society, which will be opened tomorrow at the National Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Roosevelt was said today to favor a railway labor proposal that he establish a permanent Wartime Emergency Fact-Finding Board which would take over efforts to settle disputes between the railroads and their 1,200,000 employes if and when conciliation efforts by the National Mediation Board failed.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The text of a War Department communique, based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M., Eastern war time today, follows:

Mrs. Marion Karil Reich, 52 years old, of the Hotel Woodrow, 35 West Sixty-fourth Street, was found dead at 8 o'clock yesterday morning in a two-room suite on the second floor of the Hotel Sutton 330 East Fifty-sixth Street. She had been bound, gagged and suffocated, apparently by thieves.

The average annual earnings of employes of the General Electric Company last year were $2,346, or $45.11 a week, Charles E. Wilson, president of the company, announced yesterday. They were the highest in the history of the company and compared with $2,011, or $38.67 weekly, paid in 1940.

Demand from retailers for electrical appliances has reached a point far in excess of available supply, distributors reported yesterday. Despite the fact that stocks in retail hands are relatively high, mail order houses, chain, department and furniture stores and the public utilities are buying everything they can lay their hands on, it was reported.

The stock market cracked yesterday to the lowest levels in four years under the impact of depressing war news and calculations, seemingly from every conceivable source, as to those groups of shares which will absorb the full burden of the new war taxation program.

" Under This Roof," vacating the Windsor tomorrow night, will be the third closing of the week. The other two departures, formerly announced, are "Claudia" and "Heart of a City." Under the aegis of Russell Lewis and Rita Hassan, "Under This Roof," written by Herbert B. Ehrmann and directed by Mr. Lewis, opened here on Feb. 22.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City regained $60,000,000, or 36 per cent, of the excess reserves lost the week before, according to figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York covering the week ended on Wednesday.
RIOM, France, March 5 -- In his plea before the Supreme Court here today, former Air Minister Guy La Chambre asked comparison of his pre-war efforts with production results in other countries.

LONDON, March 5--The stock markets today saw a general decline in the Kaffirs on reports from New York that a United States mission will endeavor to induce South Africa to reduce its gold production and transfer the machinery and labor for production of war metals.

Frederick D. Corley, president of Marshall Field F Co., informed stockholders in the annual report mailed yesterday to stockholders that while the number of sales was the highest on record for the stores now operated, most of the increased sales volume resulted from a larger average sales check.

Stockholders of the Foster Wheeler Corporation will vote at a special meeting on April 9 on a plan of recapitalization under which each share of $7 preferred stock will be exchanged for six shares of new 6 per cent $25 par prior preferred stock and two shares of $10 par common stock.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Owners of idle machine tools were asked to put them on the market today so that they can be utilized in plants engaged in war production.

Sugar wholesalers and industrial users of suger were warned yesterday by A.E. Bowman, chief of the sugar section of the War Production Board, that the government would insist upon equitable distribution of available supplies as work continued on plans for consumer rationing.

Sarcastically hitting at those who ask for "a destroyer in every bathtub" and who clamor to have the troops brought home, Thomas E. Dewey told a B'nai B'rith "Wake Up America" rally at Manhattan Center last night that the war can be won only by having the armed forces "where they can hit the hardest."

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Ten small Connecticut manufacturing plants will be selected in the next few days to serve as a test on how the country can best put its small establishments to work in the war program.
Hyman Schorenstein, Brooklyn's Commissioner of Records, was both praised and belittled yesterday when the Board of Estimate approved, unanimously, his retirement on an annual allowance of $4,372.75.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Secretary Ickes said today that gasoline might be rationed to equalize the distribution to consumers of the steadily diminishing quantities reaching the markets from the areas of production and supply. He added that a definite decision probably would he reached this week end.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Charges that the Rural Electrification Administration had dissipated and wasted copper sorely needed for defense and that the War Production Board showed "a reckless disregard for the conservation of critical war materials" by approving two REA projects in Texas, Arkansas and Oklahoma, were made today in a report to the House from a majority of the Military Affairs Committee.

Because of the failure of the Western Cartridge Company to publish financial statements, the New York Curb Exchange has announced that its preferred stock will be removed from unlisted trading on iarch 14. Dealings were suspended yesterd.ay but will be resumed this morning and continue until the close of business on Saturday.

An exhibition of still-life prints has been arranged by the Prints Division of the New York Public Library and will be on view in Room 321 through May 16. Among the artists represented are Rembrandt, Whistler, Van Huysum, Fantin-Latour, Jacquemart, Smillie, Falls, Gaucherel, Sheeler, Kuniyoshi, Ganso, Weir, Galanis, Wanda Gag, Manet and Buhot.

Aiming at more direct labor participation in planning increased production for the war, the Greater New York Industrial Council last night authorized all local C.I.O. unions to set up committees in individual plants and factories to devise ways of stepping up the output of war materials and eliminating waste.

LONDON, March 5 -- Britain is coming rapidly to the end of her man power and the scarcity of labor must be made up with women if the country is going to attain its full war effort. This was the general conclusion after today's debate in the House of Commons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- Plans to reunite Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers have been revived by RKO, and David Hempstead is preparing a musical film which will serve as a vehicle for the team if the deal with Astaire is concluded. Miss Rogers is scheduled to report to RKO on June 22 for her next picture at the studio, and Hempstead is also preparing "I'll Never Tell," a story by Stephen Longstreet, for her.

The real danger that most of the financing of the war program will pass from private banking into direct government financing was proclaimed by the closing speakers at a three-day credit clinic of the American Bankers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, before an audience of Eastern bankers which yesterday reached 1,000.

The Wiliam H. Nichols Medal, which is awarded by the New York section of the American Chemical Society to stimulate original research in chemistry, was presented last night to Dr. Luncan A. MacInnes of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, at a dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Sam Snead, the Hot Springs, Va., slugger, with a reputation for repeating over favorite courses, shot a two-under-par 70 at the Lakewood Country Club late today to capture his third St. Petersburg open title in four years.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -Methods used by the majority of the Senate Privileges and Elections Committee in assembling evidence to support its proposal to unseat Senator Langer of North Dakota on ground of moral turpitude were assailed today in a formal report supported by three of the thirteen members who voted on the committee action.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- The Red Army reported tonight that it was pursuing two German divisions and remnants of a third from recaptured Yukhnov in a major blow to Nazi designs for a Spring offensive against Moscow.

ALLAHABAD, India, March 5 (Delayed) (AP) -- Speaking plainly at a time when Britain is expected to make new overtures to India in an effort to gain greater aid for the British war effort, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru declared in an interview today that "the Indian problem can be approached only on a basis of Indian freedom."

When greater virtuosity is lavished on the art of playing the piano probably Vladimir Horowitz will do the lavishing. That impression was inescapable at Carnegie Hall last night when Mr. Horowitz played the piano as it is given to few pianists in any generation to play it.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The insurance group committee of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company notified the Interstate Commerce Commission today that it would be willing to see inserted in the reorganization plan for the road a provision authorizing the deferment of payment of fixed interest coupons with the approval of 75 per cent of the outstanding bonds in question.

MEXICO CITY, March 6 -- Official circles reported tonight that four of the top ranking Nazis in Mexico had been arrested by the Department of Interior and by the Federal District Police, on charges of violating the new Mexican Espionage Act under which nobody has yet been tried.

ALBANY, March 6 -- New York City will probably receive about $7,000,000 additional in revenues for its general fund, to help it out of the fiscal crisis, which was described yesterday by the City Budget Director, Kenneth F. Dayton, as the worst since 1934.

The flotation this week of two fair-sized corporate loans lifted the total of new bonds offered in this market to $51,301,000, the largest weekly volume since the period ended on Jan. 23, when $152,835,000 in new bonds were marketed, including the $80,000,000 Alabama Power Company issue.

A veteran impressionist painter and member of the National Academy of Design got himself arrested on suspicion of espionage while sketching at the Newark garbage dumps. "I am not so much interested in form and structure," he said, "as in the play of light on objects -- on such things as sodden paper, shattered varicolored bottles, smoldering garbage, wisps of greasy smoke."

LONDON, March 6 -- British forces hurled tanks and planes against the Japanese invaders of Burma today in fierce counter-attacks near Pegu, inflicting heavy casualties and giving "a very good account of themselves," according to a Rangoon communique that reached London tonight.

Responsibility for strengthening the morale of the American people was placed squarely on the shoulders of the homemaker yesterday by a dozen men and women from as many fields of endeavor at an all-day conference on "The factors which influence national morale."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 6 -- The possibility that President Roberto M. Ortiz might return to power in the more or less distant future -- bringing about the retirement of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo, was seen today when Jorge Ortiz, the President's son, left for the United States by air to consult an American eye specialist about an operation to restore his father's eyesight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 6 -- The Germans have suddenly admitted the existence of pockets well behind the Russian line of advance, according to the Berlin correspondent of the Svenska Dagbladet. These pockets are in addition to the one enclosing the German Sixteenth Army in the Staraya Russa region.

In considering the won-and-lost records of the outstanding basketball teams I believe the national invitation tournament committee may pass up one of the most powerful and talented combines in the country -- St. Joseph's of Philadelphia.

Handbag maufacturers are being advised to maintain a balanced inventory of raw materials so far as possible to avoid situations where government restrictions on any material would render other items unusable, the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry reported yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, March 6 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek and Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, sent here by President Roosevelt on a special mission, today began consultations on China's part in Allied operations against Japan.

LONDON, March 6 -- L.S. Amery, Secretary of State for India and Burma, speaking before the Oxford Union tonight, recalled that a few years ago some people were denouncing the "militarism" of the Indian Government and the "crushing burdens imposed on a poor country by the scale of war preparations."

Overruling objections of dissenting bondholders, the Appellate Division sustained unanimously yesterday a ruling of Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins authorizing the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as trustees of bond issues of the Third Avenue Railway Company and two subsidiaries to consent to a plan for substitution of buses for street cars on the lines of the railways.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, enunciated tonight a C.I.O. slogan of "Work, Work, Work; Produce, Produce, Produce."

Consumer sugar rationing may be temporarily delayed until there is assurance that all ration stamps to be issued can be promptly honored on presentation, it was reported yesterday in the grocery and sugar trade.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 6 -- Twenty-two small manufacturers in the Oranges and Maplewood combined here today to form a pool of manufacturing facilities and man-power to obtain war contracts.

LONDON, March 6 -- The stock markets were unsettled again today by the news from the Far East but the declines were small. Gilt-edged issues were steadier in most sections. The industries lost ground, Imperial Tobacco falling another 1 1/4.

A shareholders' committee consisting of Charles B. Alcott of Orlando, Fla., Edward T. Butler Jr., a director, and Clifford S. Dangler, both of Cleveland, Ohio, is soliciting proxies for the annual meeting of the American Stove Company on March 24 for the purpose of reducing the number of directors and removing by-law restrictions limiting officers to board members.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- James M. Landis, Civilian Defense Director, announced tonight that first allocations of fire-fighting equipment, gas masks, steel helmets, stretchers and other items in the program to protect the civilian population against air raids, sabotage and other war hazards would be made principally to cities in 300 mile strips on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts which are regarded as "target areas" and to inland centers of war production.

Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the City College Administrative Committee of the Board of Higher Education, which directs the affairs of Townsend Harris High School, yesterday attacked as intemperate and untrue" a statement by the Harris defense committee characterizing as "a shocking attack" on democratic education the ruling of the Court of Appeals upholding the city's right to abolish the school.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A bill is reported to be under consideration to give President Roosevelt power to suspend the operation of customs tariffs when he thinks the emergency justifies such action. This would be in addition to a bill already approved by the House which would admit free of duty iron and steel, nonferrous metals and scrap.

LONDON, March 6 -- The facility of the British Communist party in changing its attitude suddenly to suit what it believes to be the feeling of MOSCOW was given yesterday by Home Secretary Herbert Morrison as one of the reasons why the ban on the party organ, The Daily Worker, could not yet be lifted.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 6 (AP) -- Caulkers returned to work at two San Diego shipyards today, ending a six-day walkout, and the Navy withdrew emergency crews sent to complete construction on a naval patrol vessel "urgently required for service."

The ever colorful Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships, a meet with glamour all its own, will be staged in Madison Square Garden tonight. Despite the gloomy prediction of Coach Bob Giegengack, who fears the worst, Fordham will be favored to retain its team title and thus give New York colleges their ninth successive crown.

An American Foreign Legion, not made up of motion-picture romantics trying to "forget," but including hardheaded, hard-fisted refugees who remember only too well -- such is a project reported to be taking shape in Washington. About 2,000,000 citizens of the other United Nations are now in this country.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 6 (AP) -- American Bowling Congress officials announced tonight that Ned Day of West Allis, Wis., holds the best ten-year A.B.C. tourney record with a 90-game all-events mark of 204.

I am chairman of the subcommittee of the Citizens Housing Council which drafted the rent control bill introduced in Albany by Senator Desmond and Assemblyman Moffatt, regarding which there is an article in THE TIMES of Feb. 28.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation held $991,100,000 of unfinished orders for ship construction and repairs at the end of 1941, compared with $1,036,000,000 a year before, according to its pamphlet report, issued yesterday by Eugene G. Grace, president.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 -Thomas J. 1Vfooney, who served I more than twenty-two years in prison for the dynamiting of a San [Francisco Preparedness Day pa[rade in 1916, a crime he swore he never committed, died today in St. [Luke's Hospital.

Pierre Matisse has rounded up some of the artists who have fled war-wracked Europe and is holding an exhibition of their work in his gallery at 41 East Fifty-seventh Street. This interesting and timely show will continue until March 28.

ON THE PEGU FRONT IN SOUTH BURMA, March 6 (Reuter) -A powerful force of British tanks, manned by some of the finest and most seasoned tank troops in the world, has arrived here. The Japanese have no tanks and have no anti-tank guns, although they have adapted trench-mortars to cover this deficiency.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -The Federal Works Agency awarded contracts today totaling $42,296,391 for 14,315 prefabricated, demountable defense houses, bringing to 45,708 the number of such dwellings purchased in forty-five days.

Quite a lot of American history between 1916 and 1942 was interwoven with the case of Thomas J. Mooney, who died yesterday in San Francisco. A maverick labor leader, fighting the California utilities, Mooney was convicted of throwing a bomb into the San Francisco Preparedness Parade in July, 1916.

A special amendment to the OPA's lithopone ceiling, issued early this week to extricate exporters from an impossible situation, is of virtually no value because the prime essential -- the authority to approve an export price above the ceiling -- has not been given to any one, exporters learned after several days of fruitless search for any official who could give them action.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- While the Yankees were battling today to bag an overtime decision over the Cardinals in their first 1942 grapefruit league outing, Joe DiMaggio was taking things easy in his Lido Beach penthouse after declining an offer of $40,000 to play ball with the world champions.

A green leather pocketbook containing $625 lay unnoticed for three hours Thursday afternoon in the street near Broadway and 173d Street before a 14-year-old junior high school girl picked it up. The money and pocketbook were returned to the owner yesterday after the girl's mother saw an advertisement in the Lost and Found column in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Basing their pleas on the argument that taxicabs are essential to war, representatives of New York cab owners appealed yesterday to Price Administrator Leon Henderson for tires to keep their cars in operation. Under Federal eligibility regulations taxis are on list "B," which means their tires can be recapped, but because of truck needs no passenger car tires are being recapped until the end of this month.

Sammy Angott, holder of the lightweight championship of the world, eliminated Bob Montgomery of Philadelphia from the ranks of title contenders in a twelve-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Angott, engaging Montgomery in an over-the-weight, non-title battle, had little trouble with the favored Negro, winning the unanimous votes of Referee Arthur Donovan and Judges George Le Cron and Jim Reilly.

The first definite action toward the formation of the New York City Patrol Corps, which will relieve the police force in guarding vital areas, will be taken today with the official issuance of application blanks for the corps at the American Legion Headquarters in Brooklyn, 160 Pierrepont Street, it was announced last night by John J. Kenney, Kings County Commander of the American Legion.

TOKYO, March 6 (From Japanese broadcast) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters claimed today that a special flotilla of naval craft, none of which survived, made a night assault on Pearl Harbor and sank a battleship of the Arizona class thirteen hours after the original air attack on Dec. 7.

New crisp currency is to become scarcer. Large hotels and other establishments that have long made it a practice to give change in new bills will have to forego this custom for the duration of the war. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York notified banks in the Second Federal Reserve District yesterday that it has lowered the standard that it uses in determining whether currency is fit for further circulation.

Net profits of all member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District in 1941 averaged 5.5 per cent of total capital funds, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday in its annual compilation of bank operating ratios.

There is dissatisfaction on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the new commission schedule now before the membership for adoption. Some of the members feel that the firms that produce the business and clear the money are getting too great a share of the advances and that those who handle the orders on the floor have not received enough consideration.
On March 5 Senator Allan A. Ryan Jr. and Assemblyman Fred S. Hollowell introduced in their respective branches of the State Legislature a bill to eliminate price wars in the retail liquor industry.

As a basketball fan, I would like to call your attention to the record of the University of Rochester quintet. I have followed them closely throughout this season, for which their record is sixteen wins and no defeats.

The Continental Hotel, at 101-103 Hudson Street, Hoboken, N.J., has been sold by Rudolph F. Rabe to Joseph Samperi. The building occupies a plot 48 by 75 feet, is assessed for $55,400 and was sold for $38,000, according to the stamps on the deed, the seller taking back a purchase money mortgage for $33,000.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- The fall of Yukhnov is a serious blow to the Germans, who lose yet another strong point where they had expected to remain undisturbed until ready to launch their eventual offensive. On the right bank of the Ugra River, the town lies on a branch rail line between Gzhatsk and Vyazma, both of which are held by the Germans.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Legislation to authorize Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, to appoint a special deputy to handle problems of small manufacturers and bring them into the production program seems likely to receive favorable action from the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

BABYLON, L.I., March 6 -"Fort Robbins" is without its American flag today, but the fort's commanding officer-garrison is determined to stick to a wartime variation of the postoffice slogan, "Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night, etc."
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today started a transfer of its activities to Philadelphia that will take some eighteen days to complete.

WINNIPEG, March 6 (Canadian Press) -- Georg H. McIvor, chairman of the Canadian Wheat Board, notified the grain trade through the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today that all open wheat futures will be adjusted to the board's new level of wheat prices on or before July 31.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -Forced adjournment of the House of Representatives late today halted an attack on the Dies committee's recent report on Japanese espionage and fifth column activities. Assertions were made that the report told old stories from public, not secret, documents and "plagiarized" some of them.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- In reports to the War Department that were included in a communique issued here today, General Douglas MacArthur revealed that the Japanese were attempting to take from Filipinos in the conquered areas their bolos, which are used occasionally by the natives as weapons but more often as an essential tool in normal life.

STUART, Fla., March 6 (AP) -Military authorities today gave up as dead the seven men who were aboard an Army twin-engined transport plane which lost a wing, caught fire and crashed near here last night.

Whence come book and play titles? This is one instance of their origin. Last April Prime Minister Winston Churchill ended a report on the war with two stanzas from the poem "Say Not the Struggle Naught Availeth," by the nineteenth-century poet Arthur Hugh Clough.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 6 -- More than 5,000 Norwegians between the ages of 12 and 75 are in concentration camps or otherwise detained for "political crimes" -- meaning anti-Nazi activities -according to an estimate received from Norway today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A bill to increase the national debt limit to $125,000,000,000 was unanimously reported today by the Ways and Means Committee and the House gave unanimous consent to consider it at any time the committee desired.

DETROIT, March 6 (AP) -- The appointment of George Romney as general manager of the Automobile Manufacturers Association was announced today by Alvan Macauley, president. Mr. Romney has been Detroit manager of the association for several years and recently became managing director of the Automotive Council for War Production.

Four more ships have been lost, and ninety-three seamen are believed to have perished, the Navy Department and other official sources revealed yesterday. Three of the losses, announced by the Navy, were a Norwegian motor-ship, torpedoed off the Atlantic coast last Saturday, and two other ships -- an American freighter and a tanker of Panamanian registry -- that are "overdue and presumed lost."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6 -- Fredric March will play the lead opposite Veronica Lake in Paramount's "I Married a Witch," if the studio's negotiations with the actor are concluded, it was learned today. March has accepted the assignment subject to his approval of the scenario, Paramount disclosed, and production has been scheduled to start in May with Rene Clair directing and Preston Sturges producing.

The United States Pacific Fleet has been concentrating on the establishment of a trans-Pacific supply line since the attack on Pearl Harbor, according to recent statements by Navy officials. A naval force early this month escorted convoys to Wellington, New Zealand, which was made the terminus for the pouring of supplies to the Far East.

The Brazzaville radio, the Free French station in West Africa, yesterday announced "important changes" in the French National Committee in London, the Columbia Broadcasting System reported. It said Vice Admiral Jean Muselier had resigned from his post as National Commissioner of the French Navy and would take over the "command of the forces in operation."
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Donald M. Nelson moved today to carry through the accelerated arms production program.
A series of steps being taken by General Motors to assist its dealers maintain operations during and after the war was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation.

Though the war is beginning to pinch America, it has not yet pinched our essential foods. Raymond Daniell of this newspaper, returning to his London post after a year spent in this country, cables his impressions of the quite different situation in Britain. Restaurant prices have risen.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 6 -- United States naval and air forces delayed the invasion of Java for a week by magnificent fighting, but American bombers had to abandon the island in its hour of direst need for lack of fighter plane support. That is the story of American participation in the Battle of Java.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 6 (AP) -- The administration building of the basic magnesium plant being built with givernment funds sixteen miles southeast of Las Vegas was destroyed tonight by fire which the contractor declared was the result of sabotage.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 6 -- Under the title "A Word to All," Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, in this week's Das Reich launches another of his reminders to the German nation that it still has a long fight ahead if it is going to win the war.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 6 -- A Defense Act proclamation issued today orders men in Classes 4 and 5 to register for military service within seven days. These classes include married men and widowers 35 to 45 years old who have children, and all men, married and single, from 45 to 60.

Pending the granting of full authorization by the Transit Commission, the Third Avenue Railway Company announced last night that buses will be substituted for trolley cars a week from tomorrow on two of the company's oldest lines -- the Fifty-ninth Street crosstown and the Tenth Avenue routes.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter granted yesterday the application of the Transit Commission for a permanent injunction restraining the Long Island Railroad, the New York Central Railroad and the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad from increasing by 10 per cent their intrastate rates within the city limits.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The War Department communique based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. follows:

Blackout orders affecting all forms of exterior illumination in the city were issued yesterday by Patrick Quilty, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, who also took steps to control lights inside buildings so that they cannot be seen from the street.

Some of the experiences of a night club manager were described before a Federal bankruptcy referee yesterday by a night club executive who wanted to stay in the business. The testimony was given by Felix Ferry, managing director of Fefe's Monte Carlo at 49 East Fifty-fourth Street, before Referee Peter B. Olney.

Graduation exercises were held yesterday for a group of women who had completed a two-day course in rationing procedure so that they could give clerical assistance on a volunteer basis to local rationing boards. Sylvan Joseph, regional director of the Office of Price Administration, presided at the exercises, held in the New York office of the OPA at 122 East Forty-second Street.

If there are any dance performances at which it is possible to have a more thoroughly good time than at Argentinita's, this reviewer has not been lucky enough to find them. It is accordingly cheering news that she has settled down at the Shubert Theatre for the week-end, assuring at least three delighful evenings in a period that certainly can do with them.
ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, Philippines, March 6 -- I flew with Kelly.
PALM, BEACH, Fla., March 6 -Land's End was the setting this afternoon for a cocktail party given by Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Henderson to celebrate Mr. Henderson's birthday.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -Dwelling units in suburban districts outside Atlantic City and Trenton had an average monthly rental value much higher than dwellings in those cities, it was shown in the 1940 census of housing statistics, released today.

ALBANY, March 6 -- New York State lost today the services of Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission. Mr. Graves, who has been seriously ill for some months, filed a retirement application on Feb. 7, and it becomes effective tomorrow.

LONDON, March 6 -- Military objectives in the Middle East depend ultimately on the protection of the two lifelines of the Red Sea and Persian Gulf through which British and American supplies flow. Captain Oliver Lyttelton said today.

HAVANA, March 6 -- The Dodgers and Cuban All-Stars threw a monkey wrench into the machinery of the good neighbor policy at Tropical Park today during the ninth inning of an overtime battle that Brooklyn finally won in the eleventh, 6 -- 4.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, March 6 (Canadian Press) -- Their hulls holed by torpedo explosions, two tankers of the allied merchant fleets have made their way to this harbor with their crews intact and under their own steam. One of them was still carrying the bulk of the gasoline cargo she had aboard when a submarine struck.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The House economy group continued its inroads on the Agriculture Department's big supply bill today by confirming a $1,000,000 reduction temporarily voted yesterday and adding another of $300,000 to one of $600,000 previously voted to bring the total to $1,900,000.

GARFIELD, N.J., March 6 -This city of 30,000 persons, the largest municipality in Bergen County, has been wishing for a Gilbert and Sullivan Pooh-Bah ever since Mayor John M. Gabriel, 31-year-old teacher in near-by Lodi High School, was inducted into the Army three months ago.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- John L. Lewis welcomed 30,000 organized dairy farmers into his United Mine Workers Union today, announced a nation-wide drive to enroll 3,000,000 more and declined several opportunities to deny reports that this extension of the coal miners' union to embrace farmers was a prelude to formation of a third labor movement in opposition to the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which he founded, and the American Federation of Labor.

It often has occurred to me that track fans are the most discriminating and best informed of all sports followers. This judgment was seconded by the balloting of the spectators at last Saturday's National A.A.U. meet which resulted in Greg Rice being voted the outstanding performer of the meet.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Roosevelt said he thought only one side had been presented when he was asked to comment today on the House Military Affairs Committee's criticism of Donald N. Nelson, War Production Chief, in releasing critical materials to Rural Electrification Administration projects for transmission lines to serve an aluminum plant in Arkansas.

The platinum band stolen from Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, 52-year-old Austrian refugee whose body was found Thursday in a second-floor suite in the Hotel Sutton, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street, was recovered yesterday by detectives.

The lowest level for stocks in four years was reached yesterday as the market was subjected to unrelenting liquidation as more holders of securities became aware of the severe effects which the new war tax proposals could have on the earnings of corporations.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 6 -Mrs. Adah Hopkins Aime, elder sister of Harry Hopkins, adviser to the President, resigned last night as executive secretary of the Yonkers Chapter of the American Red Cross. She explained this afternoon that she had disagreed with the chapter chairman, Adolf F. Grossman, over administrative policies.

The Boston Comic Opera Company, which has been giving Gilbert and Sullivan at the St. James Theatre since Jan. 21, will leave Broadway on March 14. The Shuberts, sponsors of the Savoyards, originally had announced today as the closing date.

Mr. Lehman and three other Governors have taken and given official notice that today is the anniversary of the birth of Thomas Garrigue Masaryk in Moravia ninety-two years ago. It was a gracious act to recall the presence and memory of one who played before our eyes so great a part.

Since the Federal regulation restricting the sale of new firearms went into effect we have received a number of letters from sportsmen who see dire things in the offing, such as "firearms confiscation" and similar moves that would disarm the citizen.

THE word going around is that Fordham University is about to lose a good football coach and win a good track meet. The good football coach is Somnolent James Crowley, who is heading for the Naval Air Corps, and the track meet is the indoor I.C. 4-A championship program coming off at Madison Square Garden this evening.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 6 (AP) -- The University of Maryland, competing in its first Eastern intercollegiate boxing tournament as the guest of the member colleges, sent seven of its eight-man team into the semi-finals tonight as the preliminary round was completed before some 3,000 fans in the University of Virginia gymnasium.

The report of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for 1941, issued yesterday by C.E. Paige, chairman, shows net income, after all expenses and charges, of $1,548,942. This was equal to $2.08 a share on 745,364 capital shares and compares with $1,802,425, or $2.42 a capital share, in 1940.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A continued battle for New Deal liberalism was pledged in a speech here by Attorney General Biddle who assented to the view, expressed by a questioner, that there would always be politics in wartime.

A special revival engagement of Warners' "The Life of Emile Zola," starring Paul Muni, will begin today at the Globe Theatre. The cast of the film drama, which received the Academy Award as the best picture of 1937, includes Joseph Schildkraut, Donald Crisp, Gloria Holden, Morris Carnovsky, Gale Sondergaard, Montagu Love, Louis Calhern and Grant Mitchell. . . .

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 -Federal agents and local police swept through Northern California today in a series of simultaneous raids, based on recently acquired "secret documents," and arrested leading members of Japanese organizations.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by twenty-six municipalities aggregates $6,190,312, compared with $3,809,566 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $26,600,812.

The Pepsi-Cola Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit for the year ended Dec. 31, last, of $9,363,105 after all charges including Federal income and excess profits taxes, computed after deducting non-recurring losses of Loft, Inc., of approximately $2,800,000, for which adequate reserves had been established previously.

Exactly three months have passed since the tragic day when Japanese treachery struck simultaneouly at Pearl Harbor, Guam and the Philippines, Northern Malaya and Singapore. In these three months we have witnessed a series of Japanese successes, and of corresponding defeats for the United Nations, that previously would have been thought incredible.

CHICAGO, March 6 (U.P.) -- Two Conference indoor records and an American indoor record were shattered in the Big Ten indoor track championship preliminaries held in the University of Chicago field house tonight.

Sam Byrd, who has been actor, manager, director and producer in Broadway presentations and who will be recalled by most persons as the original Dude Lester in "Tobacco Road," has hopped a fence into literary fields. The publishing firm of Houghton Mifflin has awarded $2,500 to him, it was revealed yesterday, for his forthcoming book, "Small Town South."

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Wheat traders who are anxiously awaiting the result of Congressional action on the bill to freeze government holdings of agricultural products at parity prices found little in the news today to encourage taking a firm stand on the buying side of the market.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 6 -- Construction by the United States of a highway through Canada to Alaska has been approved by both governments, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King told the House of Commons today, and engineers have been authorized to survey and lay out a pioneer road without delay.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Wholesale egg prices here climbed 1/4 to 1 1/4 cents a dozen today as processors scoured producing sections and the markets to obtain eggs to fill the vast lease-end order placed yesterday. The government buyers made contracts for 6,290,700 pounds of powdered eggs, the equivalent of more than 1,585 carlots of eggs in the shell.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 -- Twenty-two, the largest field in Hialeah history, have been named for tomorrow's $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup, which will gross beyond $71,000 if all go to the post for the mile-and-a-quarter run. More than 20,000 are expected to attend this final afternoon of the Miami Jockey Club's forty-six-day meeting, which has been such a success despite the stress of the times.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6 -- Nine hundred couples tonight took part in the ninety-first annual Junior Promenade of Yale University, which was held in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium. In the number of dancers and charm of decoration the event compared favorably with its immediate predecessors.
MIAMI, Fla., March 6 -- The training activities of the Giants, who tomorrow launch their local exhibition campaign with a two-game series against the Red Sox, stepped up perceptibly today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The House Appropriations Committee took a hand today in wartime conservation of non-military motor transport by reporting a bill prohibiting the expenditure of Federal funds for the purchase of any new automobiles except by the White House and by the military and naval establishments, and in the latter case only with the specific approval of the heads of the War and Navy Departments.

Because he expects to be called as a witness in the anti-trust suit begun more than a year ago against the General Electric Company by the Attorney General of the United States, Gerard Swope, former president of General Electric, has resigned as assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury, he disclosed yesterday.

After a score of persons had taken a series of tests at the Museum of Science and Industry last night, Dr. Theodore A. Jackson of Columbia University, who devised the tests to determine how persons will react in an air raid, warned against drawing conclusions -- but certain facts were self-evident.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Mathews of the Carlyle gave a luncheon yesterday in the Regency Room there for three members of the Royal Air Force, Lieutenants Desmond Wright of Liverpool and Ronald E. Voller and Anthony J. Ransome of London.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 6 -- The $1,000,000 Belknap Mountain Recreation Area will be the scene of the national and Eastern four-event ski championships tomorrow and Sunday. Tonight the nation's greatest all-around figures were on hand, eager to pit their skill and technique in the slalom tomorrow morning and the grueling cross-country race in the afternoon.

If the results to date of the Battle of the Pacific have prolonged the war, they have also shortened the perspective and forced the pace of the fighting nations. In January everybody was echoing Mr. Churchill's prediction that 1943 and 1944 would be the years of decision.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The shipment of 2,300 long tons of flour from the United States to starving Greece has been authorized by the American and British Governments. This was revealed today by the State Department, which is concerned by the distressed condition of the people of Greece, particularly of children, as a result of plundering of food supplies by Nazi and Fascist conquerors.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Roosevelt got a hearty laugh today when a reporter said that he understood that the Work Projects Administration was only $23 a share.

A New York Stock Exchange membership has been transferred from William E. Tobias Jr. to G. Philip Lynch. Henry D. Talbot has been approved as an alternate on the floor for Alan H. Kempner. On March 19 the board will consider transferring the seat of the late Claude C. Pinney to Carl M. Loeb and that of Oliver D. Filley to L. Raymond Billett.

The efforts of Police Commissioner Valentine to bring greater safety to motorists and pedestrians were recognized yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council when it presented to him an award of merit as the concluding act of its thirteenth annual safety convention.

The urgency of the poster that greets visitors in Donald M. Nelson's office as they confer with the top man of WPB -- "A year from now what will we wish we had done today" -- is pervading our whole urban scene.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6 -- Before today's races at Hialeah Park, Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d and Mr. Widener's cousin, Harry R. Neilson of Philadelphia, were hosts to a company of seventy at a buffet luncheon in the Board Room of the Hialeah Club.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., March 6 -- Further impetus was put behind the war-conversion plan of the carpet industry today when technical representatives of fourteen manufacturers met at the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company mill here. The meeting followed a three-hour inspection tour of Bigelow's blanket-weaving department, which has been making blankets for the Army since last Summer, and which was selected as a guide to the industry.

During the course of registering for air raid warden duty at the local police station my fingerprints were taken, and I was informed that after a routine check with the criminal files the record would be placed in a separate file for civilians.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A warning issued by the Office of Price Administration that it is prepared to invoke penalties for violations of wholesale price ceilings on women's nylon hosiery lent color today to trade reports that the governmental agency is conducting a widespread investigation of violations of the hosiery schedule.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., March 6 -- Further impetus was put behind the war-conversion plan of the carpet industry today when technical representatives of fourteen manufacturers met at the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company mill here. The meeting followed a three-hour inspection tour of Bigelow's blanket-weaving department, which has been making blankets for the Army since last Summer, and which was selected as a guide to the industry.

During the course of registering for air raid warden duty at the local police station my fingerprints were taken, and I was informed that after a routine check with the criminal files the record would be placed in a separate file for civilians.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A warning issued by the Office of Price Administration that it is prepared to invoke penalties for violations of wholesale price ceilings on women's nylon hosiery lent color today to trade reports that the governmental agency is conducting a widespread investigation of violations of the hosiery schedule.

The Eastern States contract bridge championship for teams-of-four, a closely fought contest for the Curt H. Reisinger trophy, was won last night by the Fishbein team, which included two brothers. The losing team included a father and son.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- No more oil-burning equipment will be provided for the heating of public buildings and other public works in East Coast areas which are under the supervision of the Federal Works Agency, or for any other purpose which, in the opinion of FWA officials, other fuels can reasonably be substituted.

Edwin P. Kilroe, a graduate of Columbia, has given to that university a great collection of Tammanyana, which he has been nearly forty years in getting together. Columbian Order, the alternative name of the Society of St. Tammany, makes the new local habitation of Mr. Kilroe's treasures additionally fit, and, different as they are, the college and the philanthropic society are old New Yorkers.
GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., March 6 (AP) -- A second-series run-off appeared almost certain today as the national field trials neared the end of a long list without producing a sensational performance.

LONDON, March 6 -- The "appalling" increase in wholesale robberies and petty pilfering from railway cars, yards and warehouses -- one of the major sources of supply for black market operators -- was officially reported today to the directors of the London, Midland and Scottish Railway which handles 34 per cent of Britain's railway freight.

Business in the cotton market continued to be limited yesterday and futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved aimlessly within an 11-point range. At the close of trading active contracts showed net losses of 4 to 7 points, the low marks of the day.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A plan to operate tankers along the coasts only during daylight hours and anchor them in safe ports during the night was being considered today. Most of the torepdoings along the Atlantic coast have occurred at night. The daylight sailing plan is similar to one used in the last war.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Formal announcement that a United States technical mission would operate in India to aid in developing a supply base there for United Nations forces in the Far and Near East was made today by the State Department.

The four-story building at 285 Hudson Street consisting of a store and three lofts on a plot 24 by 90 feet has been sold by the Bank for Savings to the 285 ttudson lealty Corporation for cash above a five-year purchase-money mortgage of $3,000.

A major "on parole" from the German Army and five American citizens of German origin were convicted in Federal court yesterday of espionage for Nazi Germany. Although the group represented active enemies of this country, their trial had been exactly like any other criminal case, and their guilt was announced only after the twelve men on the jury had deliberated for two hours and forty minutes.

In a setting designed to resemble a typical army mess hall, with red tablecloths on wooden benches in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Governor Lehman last night spurred on 1,000 volunteer workers of the Defense Savings Staff to increased efforts in the sale of Defense Bonds and Stamps.

VICHY, France, March 6 -- All day tomorrow and until noon Sunday France will observe mourning for the victims of the British bombings of Paris industrial suburbs who are to be buried tomorrow morning.
A poster containing a Lenten message will be erected at the "Crossroads of the World" next Wednesday at 10 A.M. by the Lutheran churches of the metropolitan area.

The public relations organization built up on a nation-wide basis by the Investment Bankers Association of America is henceforth to devote its energy to furthering the sale of defense bonds, it was announced yesterday by John S. Fleek of Cleveland, president of the association and chairman of its committee directing public relations.

While some slowing up was noted on higher unit price goods such as furniture, furs and rugs, approach of the income tax payment period did not produce any markedly adverse effect on retail trade here this week. Daily sales volume tended to be spotty, but it was estimated that the week as a whole would probably show a gain for department stores of 10 to 15 per cent over last year.

The thirteenth annual report of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, announced yesterday, disclosed a consolidated net income for 1941 of $10,035,323 before Federal income taxes, or almost double the $5,266,050 net before taxes made the year before.

The extent to which British advertising has been curtailed by the war was illustrated yesterday in a check of linage for six British papers for the first week in December for the years 1938 to 1941, inclusive, made by a government office.

BANDUNG, Java, March 6 -- The United Nations forces, approaching a state of exhaustion under unending Japanese pressure, fell back tonight into the rough interior for a last stand after abandoning much of Western Java, including Batavia, capital of the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Roosevelt called upon all government agencies and civilians to conserve electric power wherever possible, but said today that the use of current to light night baseball games should not be restricted unnecessarily since such games contributed to morale on the home front.

New opportunities in jobs for young women during the war were discussed yesterday at the closing session of the two-day Career Conference of Vocational Service for Juniors, held at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Saturday, March 7 -A correspondent of The Daily Mail assigned to the United States Pacific Fleet said in a dispatch appearing in his newspaper today that "great convoys of ships carrying American troops, pilots, planes, tanks and guns" were heading through the Southwest Pacific.

Feeding animals extra amounts of a group of the constituents of proteins (amino acids) has resulted in the disappearance of transplanted tumors in 69 to 82.9 per cent of the animals, according to a report submitted to the American Society for the Control of Cancer by Professor Howard H. Beard of Louisiana State University.

A women's council of 100 members, including prominent business and professional women of the city, has been formed to aid the 1942 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, according to announcement made yesterday by John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury and chairman of this year's drive.

Governor Lehman's civil defense message to the Legislature was well received by the Republicans, as it deserved to be. No one can dispute the necessity for a central command of the volunteer air raid agencies. Nor can it be plausibly argued that the Mayor of a large city should add this duty to his other responsibilities.
Detailed instructions for conduct in case of an air raid alarm were posted yesterday throughout Police Headquarters for the guidance of the 500 men and women employed there.

Breaking up what David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, characterized as "the last strong-united front" in the garment union, anti-Communist forces succeeded yesterday in electing their candidates to office as business manager and chairman of the Cloak Finishers Union, Local 9.

RIOM, France, March 6 -- Today's session of the Supreme Court here was entirely secret, devoted to hearing testimony regarding a meeting in Paris Aug. 23, 1939, at which Premier Edouard Daladier and his Ministers and military experts decided France was ready to keep her commitment to Poland to go to war in her aid.

John Moore, young pianist from Kansas, was heard in his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program contained as its principal offerings the Liszt sonata in B minor and the Brahms "Variations on a Theme by Handel." Shorter items by Bach, de Falla, Stojowski, Griffes and Carl Adolph Preyer completed the schedule.

As a loyal N.Y.U. alumnus, I feel bitterly about the abandonment of football at my alma mater. In fact, I am heartily in favor of the proposal that we adopt the New York Giants as our gridiron representative.

MEXICO CITY, March 6 (AP) -Federal police said tonight that paraffin tests on the hands of Fernando Ortiz, questioned in connection with the shooting of Governor Alfredo Zarate Albarran of the State of Mexico, indicated that he had not fired a gun.

CHUNGKING, China, March 6 (U.P.) -- Carried part way on the backs of elephants that lurched through dense jungle, war materials have started to reach China by one of the two new supply routes from India, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- To provide living quarters for women war workers in congested areas raises "exceedingly acute" problems, the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor says in a pamphlet on recreation and housing.

A resolution pledging the full facilities and the complete cooperation of all safety councils in the nation to civilian defense groups, governmental agencies and industrial concerns in the prosecution of the war was adopted yesterday at the closing session of the thirteenth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CANBERRA, March 7 (Australian Associated Press) -- Prime Minister John Curtin declared today that the Labor Government's outlook is founded and its program framed on the indissolubility of the empire.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Women's chances for jobs with the Federal. Government were increasing noticeably even before the total reached "the fantastic number now on Uncle Sam's wartime payroll," according to a bulletin of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

Argentinita gave the second of her three scheduled performances at the Shubert Theatre last night before an audience that packed the house and stood in considerable numbers at the back. Though the program contained no premieres, it had as its feature the Ravel "Bolero," which is new this season, and restored to the repertory several dances from other seasons.

To see that every opportunity of making a fine showing is given to 2,000,000 women going into industry this year, the National Consumers League is initiating a policy of action supported by scientific surveys and experience of industry during this war and the former conflict.

CHUNGKING, China, March 7 (U.P.) -- Considerable Chinese ingenuity, financed by part of the recent United States loan of $500,000,000, is reshaping Chinese economy to make possible stronger resistance to Japan and to offset the adverse effects of possible complete stoppage of exports.

TRADITIONAL motifs and techniques, with modern treatments noticeably in the minority, dominate the ninth International Salon of the Pictorial Photographers of America, now on view in Education Hall at the American Museum of Natural History.

"TODAY? Let me see, what is today?" says one person to another throughout Oahu, island of the blast. Our days are completely "kapakahi" -- Hawaiian for what has happened to our way of life. Stores are open on Sundays.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Donald M.
