Nelson, War Production Board Chairman, and Sidney Hillman, Director of the WPB Labor Division, sent letters today to Representative Engel of Michigan denying and denouncing Mr. Engel's statements on the House floor last Monday that the two officials had entered into an agreement not to place any Army clothing orders with manufacturers of women's clothes.

SEARCHLIGHTS made an inverted cone in the sky. Its white core and margins were pricked with the yellow flashes of anti-aircraft shells. Red globules of tracers drifted up lazily like incandescent balloons released at a county fair. Low on the horizon to the east, south and west was the heat-lightning blaze of defense batteries.

Anita Brenner, who was born in Mexico and spent her childhood there and whose books. "Idols Behind Altars" and "Your Mexican Holiday," have furthered American understanding of Mexico, has now set down twenty-four folk tales as they are being told in Mexico today.

HERE is told the long story of cloth and how, through the centuries, man has made it; how he has spun it and woven it and dyed it, fashioned it into clothing for himself and used it for many another purpose.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Ohio State lived up to all advance notices tonight in winning its first Big Ten indoor track and field championship in a meet which saw one American record bettered and another tied.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- National income reached the record total of $94,500,000,000 last year, the Department of Commerce reported today. This was 22 per cent more than 1940's and 13 per cent above the former peak of 1929. Although paced by the rearmament drive, all industries shared in the upswing which resulted in the new high mark, and the production of most types of civilian goods was at record levels.

ONE of the pleasantest tasks of the reviewer is to record the progress of painters between exhibitions. In two of the one-man shows last week such progress was to be noted to an unusual degree. One of these was of recent paintings by John Atherton, at Julien Levy's; the other was of water-colors by James Lechay, at the Ferargil.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7 -- Yale defeated Harvard, 4 to 3, tonight and won the forty-second annual series in two straight games at the New Haven Arena before 3,500 spectators, one of the largest hockey attendances ever recorded here.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Corn developed independent strength today on the Board of Trade here, going counter to the action of other grains. Its action was the result of a better undertone in the spot market and a growing expectation of a steady increase in the demand for grain from both industrial and farm users.

The American Emergency Committee for Zionist Affairs announced yesterday that Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, rabbi of The Temple of Cleveland, co-chairman of the United Jewish Appeal and chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, had departed for London to confer with British leaders on problems affecting Jewish refugees and the Jewish National Home in Palestine.

HERE is an expert item of the James M. Cain school of popular fiction, the school in which strong men weep into their beer while telling the stories of their respective lives and what a heel almost everybody else is, although admitting, all too frankly, that they have been little better themselves.

From day to day the negotiations in progress between Washington and Vichy become more complicated as new problems are continuously being brought forward. The supplies sent from Tunis to the Germans in Libya were first discussed, and then the reported transfer of French merchant ships to the Japanese, the de facto recognition by this country of General de Gaulle's administrative control over French islands in the Pacific.
Governor Lehman, calling for unity, tolerance and for prayers for those in the government charged with responsibility, evoked the lusty yells and promises yesterday of 3,500 children.

HOLLYWOOD. LEWIS STONE'S contribution to the war effort is what might be expected of a man who already has stood by his country in two wars, and now is ready to do his duty in a third. Holding the rank of lieutenant colonel in the California State Guard, Stone, since the rise of the national emergency, has formed an Evacuation Regiment as a unit within the Guard.

One of the delights of folklore and a reason why the folktales of different countries are an invaluable part of a child's experience is the folktale's power to make the reader -- even a reader young in years -- aware of the spirit of a people, of an inner essential quality that helps to explain outward actions and the course of history.
No one has ever seen an atom; no one ever expects to see one. Yet physicists speak of atomic weights as if atoms were as big as bullets.

TOKYO, March 7 (from Japanese broadcasts recorded by the Associated Press) -- The Japanese Navy Imperial Headquarters claimed tonight that 219 United Nations warships and merchantmen, including five United States battleships, have been sunk since the start of the "greater East Asia war."

For a touch of elegance at comparatively little cost, the revived use of fringe on chairs, sofas, curtains and dressing-table skirts is suggested. Without the fussiness of Victorian days, when little discretion was used in their selection, these trimming accessories can be made to give a new, sophisticated air.

Nine matches in the first round for the Class C singles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association were decided yesterday at the Harvard Club. All four seeded players in action came through to win.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 7 -- Jammie Philpott leaped high at the north end of the floor to tip in a rebound from a set shot and give Army's basketball team a 35-34 victory over Navy today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Some local labor organizations, acting upon the government's support of union participation in factory air-raid protection units, are reported to be seeking to form organizations "along military lines."

IN all fairness to readers it should be made clear at the outset that "The New Day" is not a novel. Despite its 554 pages, it is but the tenth part of a novel, and any one who reads it without a previous knowledge of its characters and expecting a conventional denouement will be sorely disappointed.

UNDER a new plan, whereby the Town Hall Composition Award will be independently sponsored by Town Hall, new works by young composers within the student bodies of music conservatories and college and university music departments will be commissioned annually.

LONDON, March 7 -- Blacked-out communications left events in Java in doubt tonight after a thirteen-hour-old dispatch had told of a Japanese break-through in the outer northern defenses of Bandung, the military headquarters and arsenal where the Netherlands Indies had concentrated most of its remaining effective forces.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 7 -- It is considered axiomatic by many military observers that this year Adolf Hitler, in addition to striving to batter through Russian defenses protecting the Caucasus, will launch an attack across the Middle East in an effort to reach the Indian Ocean area.

Health requirements or the admittance and continued study of the 50,000 students in New York City's four municipal colleges will be raised considerably by a new ruling of the Board of Higher Education requiring annual X-ray and serological tests as a means of preventing the spread of tuberculosis and other diseases, it was disclosed yesterday by Mrs. Carrie K. Medalie, secretary of the board and chairman of its student interest committee.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- A possible shortage of bituminous coal, which might necessitate Federal allocation of available supplies, was prescribed today by the Office of Solid Fuels Coordination.
HAVANA, March 7 -- All was sweetness and light in Tropical Park today, in contrast to the tumultuous doings in yesterday's game between the Dodgers and Cuban All-Stars.

VICHY, France, March 7 -- In a memorial message read for him today at the mass funeral service for the victims of the British bombing raid on the industrial plants situated around German-occupied Paris, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain accused the British of "criminal aggression."

RICHMOND, Va., March 7 -Helium, the non-inflammable gas used to keep aloft submarine-spotting blimps, will speed the production of war planes, according to a patent (No. 2,274,631) granted to Russell Meredith of Los Angeles.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -Columbia played one of its best games of the season to defeat Pennsylvania tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate League engagement at the Palestra, 53 -- 40, before a crowd of 2,000.

NORFOLK, Va., Mar. 7 (AP) -- The keel of the Navy's newest battleship, the 45,000-ton Kentucky, was laid today at the Norfolk Navy Yard on the same ways from which the 35,000-ton Alabama was launched on Feb. 16.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, speaking yesterday at the dedication ceremonies of the Victory Arch on the terrace of the Bronx County Courthouse, urged "every American to purchase Defense Bonds until it hurts" to insure victory.

PATERSON, N.J., March 7 -- A 13-year-old girl was drowned, and four other children were taken to the General Hospital here after a small, homemade rowboat in which they were riding this afternoon as guests of a blind man, capsized on the Passaic River.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The War Production Board, headed by Donald M. Nelson, gave orders today that the manufacture of radios and phonographs for civilian use be discontinued after April 22 so that the fifty-five manufacturers in the industry could devote their plants to war production, chiefly radio sending and receiving sets and airplane detection apparatus for the Army and Navy.

With the United States at war, the silver jubilee dinner of the Inner Circle, an organization of past and present political reporters, at the Hotel Astor last night had a decidedly patriotic tinge. More than 1,000 persons, including Governor Lehman, Lieutenant Governor Poletti, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., State Controller Joseph V. O'Leary, Wendell L. Willkie, James A. Farley and Thomas E. Dewey, were present.

THE change of pace is a strategy much admired by movie producers. Hollywood, type-conscious though it is, jumps at the chance to have the comedians do Hamlet and the emoters try comedy. The arrival of Walter Huston on the Strand Theatre screen next Friday as the singing, harmonica-playing co-star of Gloria Warren and Kay Francis in "Always in My Heart" is the latest proof of this particular pudding.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 7 -- Princeton defeated Cornell, 54 -- 30, in a one-sided basketball game tonight and kept alive its chance to tie Dartmouth for the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Business men who have been obtaining materials by use of PD-1 applications were warned yesterday by Sydney Hogerton, district manager of the Priorities Field Service, that they must change over this week -- by March 15 -- to the new PD-1a form.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- No more serious game has been played in the current war than the one which keeps many staff and line officers of the Navy alert twenty-four hours a day in their difficult task of ferreting out and hunting down the German U-boats which have delivered serious blows to American and Allied shipping in the Western Atlantic.

Despite the imminence of income tax payments, retail trade here gave a fairly good account of itself last week. Department store sales were estimated as running ahead of a year ago by 10 to 15 per cent although some slowing down was evident in purchases of higher unit price items such as furniture, rugs and furs.

L. Metcalfe Walling, newly appointed administrator of the wage-hour division of the United States Labor Department, said yesterday that he had seen no evidence that war production was being retarded by the legal requirement that employers pay time and one-half for all work in excess of forty hours a week.

LONDON, March 7 -- France is producing twice as many motor trucks as she did before the war and a quarter of the total was being made at the Renault works which the British bombed this week, it was said here today.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $994,224,567 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on Feb. 28 was $24.02, compared with $24.70 at the end of January.

The recent action of the House of Representatives in refusing to suspend the forty-hour week for the period of the war was profoundly discouraging. Republican Congressmen joined with Administration spokesmen in contending that the forty-hour week must be continued.

The need of forestalling panic, fear and terrorism caused by enemy bombings received renewed emphasis yesterday from Police Commissioner Valentine when he opened a "mass and group education forum" of 499 college professors and instructors to qualify them to teach air raid wardens the "psychic dangers of war."

In all the Catholic parishes of New York and throughout the country an appeal will be made on Laetare Sunday, March 15, for the sufferers in every country on the globe. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York describes this appeal in a letter as a "mission of mercy, great and generous."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -President Roosevelt signed an Executive order today giving the Defense Communications Board, headed by James L. Fly, full powers with regard to "the use, control and closing of stations and facilities" for wire communications.

IN this month's Harper's Albert Spalding begins his musical autobiography, "Boy With Violin.'' It is a story delightfully old, with refreshing presence of humor and self-criticism. There are matters in it of sound counsel to those who study the violin, or, for that matter, any phase of music.

The views of several women's groups will be brought to bear on Albany legislators this week when their representatives will appear at a committee hearing on a number of educational hills in the Senate chamber on Tuesday.

THE Germans were already closing in on Paris when the two English girls drove their ambulance toward the front, in their American Red Cross unit attached to the Sixth French Army. But Bessy Myers and Mary Darby did not know that they were being caught in a maelstrom of defeat.

Though enemy submarines continue to do heavy damage along our coasts, the results of the submarine war to date have not been wholly one-sided. Only a few days ago dispatches from Pearl Harbor revealed that American submarines operating off the Japanese coast have sunk 45,000 tons of enemy shipping, including a 16,000-ton liner.

FOR reasons as obvious as this morning's headlines people in Washington these days are not very good-natured. In fact, if one may risk giving aid and comfort to the enemy, it is wholly accurate to say that since the fall of Singapore and the introduction of the new, always busy government telephone system this is the shortest-tempered town in Christendom.

THE war has already changed life in America. Three months after the attack on Pearl Harbor we have rationing of sugar, rationing of tires and no more new automobiles. Buckets of sand and fire-fighting equipment have appeared in homes and office buildings. Blackout materials are the new decorative motif.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Lucy Parsons, 83 years old, noted anarchist whose husband was hanged for his part in the Chicago Haymarket riot in 1886, was burned to death late today when a fire broke out in her frame residence at 3130 North Troy Street.

MEXICO CITY, March 7 -- One department of the Mexican Government denied today and another declined to confirm, that severe measures had been taken against Axis agents in Mexico; in spite the semi-officially confirmed arrest of four Nazi leaders here, as reported in these dispatches yesterday.

Winning four of the eight bouts by falls, Columbia's varsity wrestlers ended their dual-meet season with a victory over N.Y.U. yesterday on the Morningside Heights mats. The Lions defeated their metropolitan rivals, 23 -- 13, to finish their campaign with a record of three victories and five setbacks.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The faculty committee of the Western Conference today approved a football schedule limit of ten games for Big Ten teams in 1942, provided that the two extra contests are played against service teams.

Committees composed of many young women of society, including debutantes of this season and former years, as well as several girls who will make their debuts next season, have been organized for the Bomb Shelter Cocktail Party to be given April 6 at the Sherry-Netherland.

American citizens who know foreign languages well have become a wartime necessity, according to Mrs. Sarah Lorge, secretary of the Metropolitan chapter of the American Association of Teachers of French and chairman of the French department at James Monroe High School.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 7 (AP) -- The Brazilian Government announced tonight that its Embassy in Japan had been occupied by military police, its Ambassador held incommunicado and its "functionaries treated like prisoners of war," and that, accordingly, it was taking "similar measures" in retaliation against Japanese diplomats in Brazil.

When the rubber plant, native to the Amazon Valley, is transplanted to Malaya, Burma and the East Indian Islands; when most of the world's rubber begins to come from those new sources; when the ingenious little Samurai from Tokyo grab these sources -- then, as we are all beginning to know, something happens to the United States. For the United States runs on rubber.

AT AN AUSTRALIAN PORT, March 7 -- Americans, Australians, British and Chinese refugees from Java have arrived in Australia in the last few days aboard ships that left the Indies from a week to two weeks ago and reached friendly harbors despite intensive Japanese sea and air patrol of the northern part of the Indian Ocean.

THIS small and sightly volume by a distinguished writer who has given us many excellent works on a great variety of subjects tells in brief space a story unique in history. It is saddening to realize that this was his last work, for just as the book appeared, the news came of Stefan Zweig's death by suicide in Brazil, where, in unhappy exile, he had recently made his home.

The total German male population between the ages of 18 and 48 runs to some twenty millions. Half of it is today in the German Army. In the earlier campaigns, during the first and second year of the present war, only about a quarter served in the army.

IT was Edmund I who decreed that the kinsmen of a man-slayer were not obliged to make amends to the kin of the victim. This recognition of the moral accountability of the individual (proclaimed 1,500 years earlier by the prophet Jeremiah) did not result in the immediate abolition of the blood feud, but at least from that time on it was against the law.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7 -Ernesto Barros Jarpa, a distinguished lawyer who is considered one of the best friends the United States has in Chile, has accepted an offer of appointment as Minister of Foreign Affairs in the coming administration of President-elect Juan Antonio Rios, it was reported in usually well-informed circles tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- An assertion that there was enough rubber in shoes having crepe-rubber soles to retread every passenger car in the country for ten years was made today by Elliot E. Simpson of the Drexsage Company of New York, who criticized the handling of the tire problem by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator.

HIROHITO, Son of the Sun, listened all night at the palace radio to the fall of Singapore. Next day he set up the wine to Tojo, freed a flock of jailbirds, rode a white horse in public. To look at him with the naked eye is said to be sure blindness, but that day the rule was suspended.
I have found that when starting seeds indoors (I use ordinary red clay bulb pans) watering before the seed is sown is a satisfactory procedure.

TWENTY-FIVE or thirty bright-faced little boys and girls are, apparently, just having fun -- scooping sand, fitting pegs in peg boards, modeling airplanes from blobs of plasticine or playing nursery games with their teachers. Actually they are learning to talk.

With organization for the 1942 war emergency campaign of the United Jewish Appeal going forward throughout the metropolitan area, 120 of the city's business, professional and civic leaders have accepted offices in the drive, according to an announcement yesterday by Sylvan Gotshal, executive chairman of the campaign.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., March 7 (AP) -- Clarence (Ace) Parker of Portsmouth, former Duke All-American football player and Brooklyn Dodgers' quarterback, and Thelma Sykes, daughter of Portsmouth's fire chief, were married today in the Baptist parsonage. Before leaving for Miami he said he expected to be in the Navy within a month or so.

Major Gen. Follett Bradley, whose first taste of flying was in the Wright Brothers' famous biplane at Fort Riley, Kan., in 1912, became commanding general yesterday of the First Air Force and the Air Force of the Eastern Theatre of Operations, with headquarters at Mitchel Field, L.I. He succeeded Brig. Gen. Arnold N. Krogstad.

The Central States Electric Corporation, corporate vehicle through which Harrison Williams, dominant utility financier, pyramided an original investment of $2,072,000 into securities valued at $680,000,000 between 1906 and 1929, has entered bankruptcy proceedings in the Federal Court in Richmond, Va., it was learned yesterday.

A wartime contribution which women's groups are now making collectively, and to a cause which eagerly welcomes them, is attracting numbers of women to the Red Cross Blood Donors Center at 138 East Thirty-sixth Street. While many organizations have interested their members this Winter in applying to the center and making their arrangements individually, visits to the blood bank are currently being encouraged as a club undertaking for the entire membership.

An intensified program for recruiting executive and administrative personnel for all war agencies will be started this week by the United States Civil Service Commission, James E. Rossell, manager of the New York district announced yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- With Tommy Henrich driving in all the runs and the enemy contributing a couple of timely misplays, the Yankees won their second in a row from the St. Louis Cardinals before 1,926 fans today. The score was 3 to 2.

EVERYMAN'S Library has issued Henryk Sienkiewicz's "Quo Vadis" (95 cents), the intensely dramatic story of Roman society under Nero. When this superb piece of historical fiction came out, after his great Trilogy, its popularity spread over the whole literate world and it was translated into almost every language.

A spectacular fire early yesterday morning swept a four-story rooming house at 239 West Sixteenth Street, resulting in the death of five persons, two of whom were children, five other tenants were removed to a hospital, three in a serious condition, after leaping from windows.

For several reasons the pentstemon, or beardtongue, family has been slighted in gardens. The family has been difficult to know because the taller herbaceous garden hybrids are only half-hardy, and chaos reigns in the nomenclature of the really hardy species, which are, for the most part, shrubby in habit.

LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- The British Cabinet is finding India's demands for more freedom one of the knottiest problems of the war, and one reliable source said today that the announcement concerning India, which had been expected next week, probably would be postponed.

Payrolls attained a new high mark of $1,301,000,000 for the American steel industry in 1941, an increase of 35.4 per cent over 1940, when payrolls were $961,000,000, and 54.7 per cent above the 1929 figure of $841,000,000, according to American Iron and Steel Institute data.

A clipping from your paper dated Feb. 7 was sent to me recently by a New York friend, dealing with the death of the last hereditary chief of the Blackfeet Tribe, Mountain Chief, or sometimes called Big Brave. I believe that further comment should be made, but first I wish to sincerely thank you for making note of the passing of this colorful character whom I had known for a long time.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Secretary Morgenthau gave the nation a preview of what it is going to cost to win the war when he appeared before the House Ways and Means Committee this week with the department's long-expected program for additional taxes to meet part of this cost.

TAXCO for its silver, Puebla for its tiles, Saltillo for its serapes, and Uruapan for its lacquer ware -- these and many another handicraft towns of Mexico have had their praises sung and the virtues of their products extolled.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 7 -- German pressure on the Hungarian Cabinet has led to another Magyar sacrifice with the attempted suicide of Premier Ladislaus de Bardossy, according to Italian reports received here this evening.

The heavy buying wave has subsided in most of the wholesale markets here, many of which are now partly or completely curtailing Spring production, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio predicted yesterday afternoon that the new tax schedule proposed by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau will be "very much readjusted'' by Congress to shift more of the burden of war costs from corporations and wealthy persons to the lower income group.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Feb. 28 were 259,373,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 3,512,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 3,702,000 in domestic stocks and a decline of 190,000 in foreign stocks.

THE bestowal of the annual Academy Awards for film achievement last week was, as usual, a tribal celebration which reflected the peculiarities of Hollywood. The dinner was informal this year, but the ceremonies were no less ponderous than usual.

WE have had a good many realistic studies of the self-made man since "The Rise of Silas Lapham" (1885), most notably, perhaps, that of the Frank Cowperwood of Dreiser's "The Financier" and "The Titan." One of the best, maybe the shrewdest and certainly the wittiest, is that of the hero of W.E. Voodward's "Lottery.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Spring is at hand in the Midsouth, land of the horse and dog -- for Spring comes to this section earlier than to the colder clicks of compass points north and west of this region in Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 7 -- Allison Merrill, University of New Hampshire sophomore, and 18-year-old Abbott (Bud) Philips, New Hampton School senior, romped off with the honors as the first half of the national four-event championship, held concurrently with the Eastern title competition, was concluded today at the Belknap Mountains recreation area.

Field trials for spaniels will be held next Autumn in the Eastern section unless there is a radical change in the situation. It is not expected that the few veteran trainers here will be called for military service, while the older amateurs are prepared to carry on.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 7 (AP) -A rise of 1.9 per cent within a three-month period brought the cost of living in Pennsylvania to the highest level in more than ten years, the Department of Labor and Industry reported today.
A vivid instance of the war's influence on women's clubs is evidenced in a major change in the character of a business and professional women's group known as Saturday's Children.

THIS latest collection of sketches on the humorous side by Stephen Leacock carries on his own tradition of jovial nonsense and personal philosophy. At 70 (we know there's a year or more to be added now, but don't bother about that) Mr. Leacock's writing is full of cheer -- and mellow.

Conversion of a part of the largest diamond-cutting factory in America to production of diamond machine tools was announced yesterday by Baumgold Brothers, Inc., diamond cutters, whose principal work until the outbreak of the war had been cutting of gem diamonds.

Job opportunities in a wartime world for girls who have enjoyed training in specific types of work will be the theme of a conference to be held at the Hotel Mayflower in Washington larch 20 and 21, under the auspices of the Institute for Women's Professional Relations.

CHUNGKING, China, March 7 (U.P.) -- Two United States business men, Jan Hendrik Marsman, Philippines gold mine operator, and J. Arthur Duff, of the New York firm of Starr, Park and Freeman, who escaped from Japanese-occupied Hong Kong, disclosed today that an acute food shortage -- including rice -- developed after the city fell.

The advertising field has started to enter a transition period, in which some advertisers are retrenching for the duration, others are temporarily canceling time and space to solve various problems, particularly in the packaging field, and some new ones are coming to the fore, according to agency executives last week.

AGAIN it is a pleasure to hail one of Mr. Havens's admirably thorough literary studies. To this one, as to "The Influence of Milton on English Poetry," published in 1922, he devoted fifteen years. Such painstaking efforts of accurate and unhurried research create confidence.

WHEN blossoms unfold, covering a hitherto drab earth with a brilliant play of color, when birds in their radiant plumage joyously greet the rebirth of nature, and when women enliven Fifth Avenue with a glow of colorful new clothes, it is time for the amateur photographer to turn to color pictures.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 (AP) -- More than 21,000 shipyard workers in the San Francisco Bay area pledged their support yesterday to an intensified production effort.

NORMAN, Okla., March 7 -- A sweeping reorganization of the University of Oklahoma's entire instructional and administrative system by the creation of a university college, planned by President Joseph A. Brandt, has been approved by the Oklahoma Regents for Higher Education.

The production of Mozart's Don Giovanni, with Bruno Walter in the conductor's chair, is now one of the brightest ornaments of the Metropolitan repertory, and the performance of yesterday afternoon, when Alexander Kipnis made his first appearance in Leporello's role, was if anything superior to previous ones under the same great leader.

A FEW years ago Anne Green astonished the admirers of her light and goofy tales by producing, without warning, a very different kind of novel. "The Silent Duchess" was not only a story of the French Revolution and the days just preceding it, but it displayed a knowledge of its historical background which was altogether unexpected and extraordinary.

JOHN COSGRAVE, former Georgetown University track star, driving down to Calverton on St. Clements Bay in Southern Maryland, followed an idealistic impulse that pleased neither his well-to-do father nor his pretty society girl fiancee who would have much preferred that he become a lawyer, marry and settle down to affluent conventional domesticity in his native Brooklyn.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 7 -- The Turkish police early this morning surrounded the Soviet Consulate at Istanbul, where one of the suspects identified in connection with the attempt to bomb Franz von Papen, German Ambassador, was reported to have taken refuge.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 6 Delayed (U.P.) -- A crisis in Turkish-Russian relations appeared near tonight when Turkish police threw a cordon around the Soviet consulate at Istanbul and allegedly obtained the surrender of a suspect in the recent bombing that threatened the life of Franz von Papen, the German Ambassador.

ALEXANDER WERTH, whose "Moscow War Diary" is to be published soon by Alfred A. Knopf, is half English and half Russian in blood. He was born in St. Petersburg (now Leningrad) in 1901, and in that city he grew up, had his preliminary schooling, and developed a deep love of Russian music, theatre and letters.
BERLIN, March 7 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

MORE than 20,000 of the 105,055 students trained in the Civilian Pilot Training Program of the CAA have already found their way to the armed services of the nation, Major John P. Morris, director of the CPTP, announced last week at the thirteenth annual safety convention and exposition sponsored by the Greater New York Safety Council.

JAMES MADISON, artificer-in-chief of the Constitution of the United States of America, is not precisely a forgotten man. But to most Americans who read history and historical romance he borrows what humanity he has from his wife Dolly, lively mistress of the White House (before it got that name), who had to skip out of it just ahead of invading incendiaries -perhaps with George Washington's portrait rolled up under her arm.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 7 -- Federal acquisition of 5,800 acres of land in Owens Valley, Southeastern California, as a site for a reception center for American-born and alien Japanese who are to be excluded from a 1,000-mile-long military area in the Far West was announced tonight by Lieut. Gen. John L. Dewitt, Western defense commander.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Use of the Aleutian Islands as a base for attacks on Japan was advocated today by Chairman Robert R. Reynolds of the Senate Military Affairs Committee. Other members of Congress likewise were calling for speedy offensive action by the United Nations.

THERE were a number of changes in the conductors at the Metropolitan during the season that will close at the end of this week, but statistics show that the singing picture remained essentially the same as last year.

HE is no superman, this new United States Army aviator, although the tasks he has to perform seem herculean to the ordinary earthbound mortal. He would resent being called glamorous, although the movies have built him up into a dashing combination of Beau Brummell, Mad Anthony Wayne and Sydney Carton.

Dr. N.E. Sprague excelled at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the high-over-all scratch prize with 97 out of 100, won a leg on the doubles handicap with 20 -- 3 -- 23 and scored on both the scratch and handicap trophies at 149 targets with a 138 -- 6 -- 144.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, said today that he believed that the nation's merchant shipbuilding goal should be increased, if possible, rather than be permitted to lag because of any scarcity of materials.

ON the day in mid-February when Sir Stafford Cripps returned to the House of Commons after an absence of nearly two years he asked for an explanation of House geography. A friend pointed out the arrangement of front benchers, Conservatives and Liberals, and, finally indicating the Opposition bench, said: "I supposes that's where you'll want to be." Instead.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Eugene Goossens, gave a concert last night in Carnegie Hall with Reginald Stewart, the British pianist, as soloist. Mr. Stewart, former conductor of the Toronto Philharmonic, which he founded, had chosen the Tchaikovsky concerto in B flat minor as his vehicle, and from the technical point of view his performance of the work was masterly and brilliant.

MANDALAY, Burma, March 7 -- The Japanese, despite heavy losses inflicted by American-built tanks and bomber squadrons, are pouring reinforcements into the Pegu River salient about fifty miles northeast of Rangoon in an effort to capture the Burmese capital as an "Army Day" gift for Emperor Hirohito next Tuesday, it was reported tonight.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The beach-playground-for-children program of the resort, begun last year, will be continued this coming season, with expanded facilities for Atlantic City's younger visitors.
THERE seems recently to have been a great deal of rather silly comment on the Goldberg Variations to the effect that:
WASHINGTON, March 7 (U.P.) -Representative Hamilton Fish said today that he planned to apply for duty as a colonel in combat service, "preferably with a colored regiment," by July 1.

BOSTON, Mass., March 7 -- Legal authorities from Washington, New York, Indiana, Tennessee, Illinois and each New England State will be guests of President Daniel L. Marsh and Boston University at the annual Founders Day celebration to take place Thursday and Friday at the university.

OTTAWA, March 7 -- A fraction of over one in twelve of the people of Canada have subscribed to the Second Victory Loan which today, with one day to go, reported a total of $885,960,800, or nearly $300,000,000 more than the amount originally aimed at.

MIAMI, Fla. -- "MacArthur Night" will be observed by a gala dinner at the Royal Palm Club tonight and will serve the double purpose of honoring the hero of the Philippines and, at $25 a plate, of aiding a determined effort to put the American Red Cross War Relief drive in this area over the top.
During this week a number of auction sales will be held here of period furnishings, paintings, rare books and other collector's items.

Even in the midst of global war, the accession of William Temple to the See of Canterbury seems to many of us here in America an event of outstanding importance. It might mark a crucial point in the history of Anglo-Saxon Christianity.

When in his letters to THE TIMES of March 1 Sir Norman Angell made the case of Eire analogous to that of India, he was in error, and he was not very complimentary to the Irish people at home and abroad to put their country in the same political category as India.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7 -- Joe Cronin's Red Sox, looking anything but their usually robust selves, what with Ted Williams and numerous other front-line notables absent, nevertheless mustered sufficient strength today to slip over a 3-to-2 victory over Mel Ott's Giants.

LONDON, March 7 -- Offer shillings in place of coupons when buying clothes. Buy lots of unrationed meats that are not wanted and occasionally get an extra share of the rationed kind. License an automobile that is not needed arid get enough gasoline for one that is.
"Plant Collecting in Kashmir," a lecture by R.R. Stewart of Gordon College, Rawalpindi, India, will be open to the public at the New York Botanical Garden at 3 P.M. on Saturday.

When Morris Glassberg was a kid the cracker barrel was the most economical means of food distribution, as he writes in his letter published in THE TIMES of March 1. The change from bulk to unit packaging required the investment of large sums in machinery and materials.

THE Natchez Trace Parkway -- the newest bright star among this country's growing network of beautiful elongated parks -is a historic 455-mile route between Nashville, Tenn., and Natchez, Miss. Up to March, 1941, Congress had appropriated $6,390,500 to transform into a modern highway this ancient wild-animal trail, worn by the light, moccasined feet of prehistoric Indians and later enduring the creak and rattle of stage coaches and freight wagons.
"WAR has its ups and downs." Thus wrote General Sir Archibald Wavell to a twelve-year-old New York boy, Francis George Steiner, a student at Horace Mann School.

A few weeks ago I enlisted in the Army. I was considerably surprised at the wonder expressed by many of my acquaintances over why I did so, especially since I had been deferred in the draft. I have noticed that many of the fellows in the Army feel the same way.
The Camellia Festival, an annual celebration of Charlestonians for more than a hundred years, is now in progress at Charleston, S.C.

To prepare housewives in adjusting their buying and budgeting habits to wartime necessities, the Women's City Club is opening a course of ten lectures tomorrow with the assistance of the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration.

NONE of the footage shot in Hawaii by a special Technicolor camera crew for Twentieth Century-Fox's forthcoming salute to the Marine Corps, "To the Shores of Tripoli," will be used in the picture. The Navy Department seized the film in Hawaii following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and, after inspecting the material, is understood to have suggested to the producers that they forego using it.
Chuchundra, in Kipling's "Rikitikitavi," was a very timid muskrat. He did manage, with palpitating heart, to run around the wails, but was far too terrified to venture to the middle of the floor.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Evidence that the Japanese were meeting continuing resistance in the Philippines outside the beleaguered Bataan Peninsula came in today's War Department communique, telling of arrival of new enemy forces that landed at Calapan, on the island of Mindoro, about seventy miles south of the entrance to Manila Bay.

The first company of the New York City Patrol Corps was formally organized in Brooklyn yesterday, and it was announced that John J. Kenney, Kings County Commander of the American Legion, will serve as its colonel.

Huylers, manufacturer and merchandiser of foods, reported yesterday that it had received a statement from Lawrence Scudder Co., accountants, showing that $101,627, or $2.26 a share, of accrued dividends had accumulated on the company's first preferred stock in the fourteen months ended on Dec. 31, 1941.

City College's basketball team concluded its home season at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium by setting a modern Lavender scoring record, crushing Montclair Teachers College, 66 -- 42. No C.C.N.Y. five had run up that many points since the 1905 Beaver quintet scored 95 against Adelphi.

EVEN in a rapidly changing world profitable lessons can still be learned from the pages of our history. Today we are striving to attain a sense of national unity. It is not the first time. At the very birth of the nation the achievement of unity and the acceptance of an undisputed goal for all the people required years of effort.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The government has made no move to freeze retail stocks of radio sets, and the WPB said today that sales would continue on a "first come, first served" basis until available supplies were exhausted.

With a motif this year of "These United States," the twenty-ninth International Flower Show will open March 16 and last through March 21, occupying the four exposition floors of Grand Central Palace. Contrary to the past custom of selecting a certain section of the country as a keynote, the show will be representative of the horticulture of the entire country.

The government needs huge quantities of cotton duck for uniforms, wool for blankets for service men, burlap for sandbags and strips of cloth to be tied to great camouflage nets and for bags in which to get food supplies to the armed forces.

WITH tire rations and rubber shortage making tires in use a necessity, increased legal protection against their theft is the object of proposals in the Congress and ten State legislatures, the National Highway Users Conference reports in a summary of pending bills.

Intimations that high grade specialty shops are likely to dwindle in merchandising importance for the duration of the war were regarded as unfounded in retail circles here last week. Many of these specialty organizations have already established broader and lower price brackets which are creating considerable competition for other retailers in their trading areas, it was pointed out.

IT'S quite possible a wry smile would tug at the corners of his mouth if Mark Twain could step aboard one of the streamlined, de luxe working craft that today ply the waters of the mighty Mississippi. He might come up with something that sounded like "a yacht in overalls," then ask, "Where in thunder's the smokestack?"

CASTING his lot with the Theatre Guild, Paul Muni started rehearsals of Emlyn Williams's play, "The Light of Heart," last Tuesday with Jessica Tandy as his vis-a-vis. Another important member of the east will be Hans Jaray.

Billy Conn, who announced his intention of entering the Naval Reserve a few days ago, did an about-face yesterday and joined the Army. The Pittsburgher, former holder of the light heavyweight boxing championship of the world, signed up as a private at the Army recruiting office in this city.

WHEN a native son takes to writing about his home town, he usually presents it as seen through either the rosiest or the most densely black of spectacles. Not so Mr. Alexander. He writes affectionately of Baltimore and the Maryland countryside, but he is by no means blind to their failings and foibles.

AMONG the many cars that commute of a late afternoon along the historic Cambridge-Concord route, and among the few that turn off on the narrow, tree-lined road to Harvard, Mass., are always to be found, if the skies are clear, a few whose passengers are literally traversing a pathway to the stars.

Five thousand men, mostly city employes, and 350 trucks and assorted motorized equipment, virtually all city-owned, assembled from the five boroughs yesterday at 3 P.M. on the East River Drive from Eighteenth to Thirty-fourth Street for inspection by Mayor La Guardia.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- President Roosevelt signed an executive order today which prohibited flights by civilian aircraft over or near his Hyde Park estate without special permission.

HONOLULU, March 7 -- Hawaii had a sixty-seven-minute air raid alarm this morning, which Army authorities described as precautionary, after first announcing that the alarm had been caused by detection of the approach of "unidentified elements at sea."
LONDON, March 7 -- British armored forces in action against the Japanese north of Pegu are not ""very large," it was officially stated here today.

Charles Weidman was certainly well advised to revive his long dance work called "This Passion," which had only one presentation in 1937, for it is more pertinent today than it was then and just as novel in design. As presented last night at the Studio Theatre of the Humphrey-Weidman company in West Sixteenth Street, it looked very much like a permanent addition to the repertory.

New York steamship agents said yesterday that despite the risk of being sunk by submarines and the trials of long, rough voyages in small ships, there is a steady demand for passage to British ports by American business men and women.

IT seems to me that Samuel F. Pogue's answer [in THE TIMES, Feb. 22] to Miss Erika Mann's protest against the playing by radio of records by Nazi musicians missed the point rather. I wish to protest in turn against Mr. Pogue's point of view, for he has given too much importance to Miss Mann's emotions in the matter, and has overlooked entirely the very sound financial and economic basis of her objections.

WARS are fought by people. Nazis are people. Their victims are people. War psychology and Nazi psychology are the strange-flowers that blossom from the unchanging, or very slowly changing, stalk of human nature. In the end it is human nature that counts.
LONDON, March 7 (U.P.) -- Vasa Prihoda, famous Czech violinist who made many concert tours all over the world, has committed suicide in Czecho-Slovakia, the Exchange Telegraph said today.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., March 7 -- H. Copland Robinson of Lakeville has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Ann Carter Robinson, to Peter Dunne Garvan, son of Mrs. Francis P. Garvan of 740 Park Avenue and Roslyn, L.I., and the late Mr. Garvan.
AMONG Winter sports, one of the most unusual is ice "scootering" as practiced by a small but highly enthusiastic group on Great South Bay out around Bellport and near-by points.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 7 (AP) -- Supporters of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo and Argentine isolationism had control of the Chamber of Deputies almost within their grasp tonight when tabulation of last Sunday's Congressional elections was suspended for the week-end.

A great deal in children's behavior depends on how we look at it. Baby's grab at a guest's string of beads may mean one thing to a mother -- depending on the guest -- and something else to the specialist in child development. The latter looks at it as "the unceasing, inquisitive investigation," which is part of learning and growth, and gives three rousing cheers because baby is so smart.

This announcement over the German radio had heralded the end of a major battle in the northern sector of the Russo-German front. The Germans claimed the capture of Staraya Russa, in days of peace a picturesque Russian spa, in war a vital communications link along the Leningrad-Moscow line.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 7 -Army teams turned back the Navy in two of three sports today while the middies defeated the fencers of St. John's University of Brooklyn, N.Y.

WITH GENERAL MacARTHUR'S ARMY IN THE PHILIPPINES, March 7 -- The Japanese are finding the guerrilla warfare of the Filipinos hard to overcome, and the effective fighting of these behind-the-lines warriors is believed one of the reasons for the reduced Japanese activity on Bataan.

Schoolboy action in track an field took place on two fronts yesterday, with Bishop Loughlin High of Brooklyn garnering a major share of the honors. Aside from the fact that George Peters of Loughlin retained his city C.H.S.A.A. 12-pound shot-put title Loughlin's two-mile relay team see a new indoor interscholastic record in one of three races stage at Madison Square Garden in the afternoon.

SMITHFIELD, N.C., March 7 (AP) -- Like a great time bomb dealing death and destruction after attracting a crowd of the curious, a blazing truck and trailer loaded with 30,000 pounds of munitions exploded near here early today, killing at least four persons and injuring at least 100.

War may interrupt the arts but it c,not smother them completely. Not while there are talented children left to carry on. On this page is shownsome of the work of the children in refugee camps maintained abroad by the American Friends Service Committee. In those camps are children of many nationalities--French,-Spanish, Polish, Chinese, English--who are being housed, fed, clothed and educated for the post-war world.

MANY times in the past two years -- especially since the advent of "Let's Face It!" -- I have seriously considered the advisability of wearing a large sandwich sign, boldly inscribed "SORRY, BUT HE'S NORMAL." Fervently and often, when interviewed as "Danny Kaye's wife," I have wished that I could bring a grateful glow into the reporter's eye by admitting that Danny collects one-eyed horses, sleeps in Russian, and charms bill-collectors with double talk.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 7 (AP) -- A Japanese military, naval and air mission has been making surveys for naval and air bases on Madagascar Island for the last six weeks in what is believed to be an at tempt to extend Japanese power across the Indian Ocean, it was learned on good authority here today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Com merce Department economic experts predicted tonight that all-out war production would raise the 1942 national income to a record-shattering $113,000,000,000 -- almost three times the depression low of $39,900,000,000 in 1932 and $18,500,000,000 above 1941's figures.

CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows; Salable hogs 300; total 4,300. Not enough strictly good and choice fresh hogs on sale to make a market; undertone about steady; quotable top around $13.50; shippers took none; holdover, 1,000. Compared with week ago: Barrows and gilts, 180 pounds up, 25 to 35 cents higher; sows, up 30 to 40 cents.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The experimental community at Arthurdale, W. Va., which was recently "sold" to its residents, was described by Mrs. Roosevelt at her press conference today as a valuable project which has taught the economic lesson that industry cannot be decentralized by setting up an "artificial" town and trying to attract industry to it.

Closing its home-court season undefeated for the fourth successive year, the St. John's University five turned back the Camp Upton quintet, 72 to 47, in the De Gray Gymnasium in Brooklyn last night. It was the forty-seventh consecutive home-court triumph for St. John's, since losing to George Washington University during the 1937-38 campaign, and its fifteenth victory in nineteen games this season.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 7 -Dartmouth's Pentagonal League champion hockey sextet loosed a scoring barrage that overwhelmed Princeton, 9 -- 3, before 1,500 fans in Baker Rink tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7 -- Upsetting the nation's champions in a sensational whip and heel drive for the line, three comparatively obscure horses -- The Rhymer, Best Seller and Olympus -- finished one, two, three in the $67,950 Widener Challenge Cup Handicap at Hialeah Park today before 25,048 persons.

MADRID, March 7 (AP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco signed a decree today providing the death penalty for attacks on Cabinet Ministers, high government officials or their families if such assaults are fatal or with intent to kill.

LONDON, March 7 (U.P.) -- Far-reaching moves to bulwark Australia and India as bases from which a United Nations offensive can be launched against Japan appear to be in progress. It seems likely that a campaign in the west, probably through intensified Commando and parachute troop raids along the European coast, may be ordered.

Members of the board of trustees of the Ladies Catholic Benevolent Association, a fraternal insurance society with a national membership, authorized the investment of $1,250,000 in United States Treasury bonds at an executive session yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

The eight-year reign of the metropolitan colleges over the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships came to an abrupt end before 10,000 spectators in Madison Square Garden last night as Penn State, riding the inspirational waves that these games always produce, dethroned Fordham for the team title.

NORTH CREEK -- There is an inner circle in the confraternity of skiers to whom the most beautiful sight in the world is an expert making a run down a steep slope with a white spume of powder following his skis.

IN time of peace the deeds and the international concerns of Gregor Fitelberg, the conductor, carried him far. The war pursued him from country to country and finally brought him to America. In Warsaw he conducted the radio orchestra which he had developed from a small band to the celebrated symphonic organization which represented Poland at the International Exposition in Paris of 1937.

THIS is a last-minute preview of the far-flung Pacific war front. The authors must have been very nearly the last journalists who completed a tour of the Far East before the bombs fell on Pearl Harbor and travel in the Orient became a matter of high personal risk and adventure.

WHILE you wouldn't say that the boys along Radio Row are getting panicky over program cancellations, there is admittedly some nervousness, although the networks profess to be confident of replacements.

GARDEN clubs as well as individual travelers are choosing this time to tour the land south of the Rio Grande, where garden owners are opening their private grounds to visitors from the United States. In and around Mexico City and adjacent to villages within a short motor trip of the capital are many gardens whose formal courts and patterned terraces offer suggestions to the horticulturalist.
The history of the world at war was written last week in a checkered pattern of dramatic episodes, apparently as disparate in strategy as they were diffused in space.

LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- Soviet pressure for a second front in Northern Europe that might swiftly link British, United States and Russian troops on a solid line was increasing in London tonight, with considerable British-American support.

A reorganization and extension of peacetime measures for safety at sea to meet new dangers in time of war was urged last week by Captain Logan Cresap, marine superintendent of the Isthmian Steamship Company, in an address before the Greater New York Safety Council.

Cutting through administrative or academic obstacles the public schools of this country are now conducting a gigantic program of vocational education, training thousands of men and women monthly to take their places in vital industries and defense plants.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7 -- Brazil has created a National Defense Board headed by President Getulio Vargas. Among the members are the chiefs of staff of the army, navy and air force.

SOME of the trade slackening that was expected to result from the approach of the income tax date was disclosed in the week. Luxury goods and the higher priced items such as furniture were affected. As an offset the new regulations cutting down the use of fabric in men's clothing brought another spurt in the demand.

Beginning next June Goddard College students will extend their work experiences by taking jobs in essential industries in which labor shortages exist. These job experiences will constitute an important part of the college program and will alternate with periods of study at the college.

Prices were moderately firmer on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and closed irregularly higher in trading which, while dull, was the heaviest for a Saturday in a month. Deals were 271,980 shares, against 234,460 in the previous week-end session.

First, may I congratulate you on your illuminating continued coverage of India and her pressing problems for months past and your fairness of comment. Both news and views appear to me to be accurate, thorough and sound.

OMAHA, Neb., March 7 -- With Spring just around the corner the shortage of farm labor looms as an imposing agricultural problem for the coming year. Many believe it to be the most serious with which the farmer will have to contend, especially if he is to fulfill his commitments to the Secretary of Agriculture to increase food production substantially during the year that lies ahead.

BY ordering a sweeping reorganization of the Army, President Roosevelt has put into effect one of the great lessons of the current war -- that fighting field forces are more important than the intricate paper detail of headquarters operations.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 7 (AP) -- Australians linked reports via London today that "great convoys" of American troops are moving through the Southwestern Pacific with assertions of their own government leaders that London and Washington are working out plans for an offensive from Australia and India aimed at driving the Japanese back to Tokyo and Yokohoma.

THIS is the week for serving those readers of this column who urge that we dish them more often some pointers on the current crop of films. Somehow our good intentions in this direction seem always to gang agley, and the best we can usually manage is a scattering of "Reviews in Brief."

DURING the recent Congressional insurrection against Mrs. Roosevelt some of our lawfully elected representatives brushed off the profession of acting with some ignominious remarks. Actors were bracketed with the gaudier parasites like perfume peddlers, fan dancers, parlor pinks, fancy uplifters, frills and furbelows.

"Attack, attack, always attack!" Such was the creed of Ferdinand Foch, great apostle of the offensive in warfare. It was a creed that fell into disrepute after World War I. In its place, among the democracies, rose the concept of the defensive. Britain's Liddell Hart was the spokesman of the "far less exhausting" war of "limited liability" in which the aggressor would be beaten into defeat at the barriers of his intended victim.

United China Relief is giving direct medical, nutritional and other aid to 17,000,000 men, women and children, according to a report yesterday by W.R. Herod, president of the relief society. Mr. Herod, who is vice president of the International General Electric Company, said more millions would benefit from the $7,000,000 fund being raised by the society to send relief to China this year.

The first membership meeting of women's organizations supporting the War Action Center will be a forum on "Women in the War and After," scheduled for tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

GUATEMALA CITY -- Land of endless striking contrasts, Guatemala makes music from the extreme of the ancient chirimiya to that of the modern string quartet and symphony orchestra. Because of her stupendous scenery and her gorgeously garbed Indians, this music of Guatemala which spreads like a streak of rainbow color over the brilliant pattern of life in the country, is apt to be overlooked by the visitor.

The little dog was the only witness to the murder. And his quick action saved another intended victim too. Yet how, Helen Turner pondered, could jealousy of a fellow-playwright go so far as the attempted murder of the leading actress in a try-out performance?

FOR THE COMING WEEK: House plants that have become overgrown and are now beginning to look "leggy" can be severely cut back to encourage new growth from the base of the plant; this applies especially to such branching subjects as geraniums, coleus, heliotrope, fuschias, and the like. . . . Cuttings from firm (but not hard) portions of the prunings root readily at this time.

The annual Spring dancing party of the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club will be a "Furlough Frolic," to be given the night of March 27 at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street Officers of the Army, Navy and Marine Corps will be guests of honor.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Top defense officials said today that the war production program of the United States was coming along well, moving steadily toward the high goals established by President Roosevelt, but admitted candidly that the present output, measured in terms of winning battles today, was far from adequate.

Many a highly qualified engineer, chemist and physicist came out of the universities and technical schools during the years of depression, only to find the doors of industry shut against him. Some of those men won through despite the scarcity of jobs, and today, in a period of rapid expansion, stand high in the professions for which they were trained.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 -- A smooth-passing Harvard basketball team defeated the Yale five, 60 -- 47, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at the Harvard gym tonight.

THE death by suicide of Stefan Zweig, whose last work is reviewed elsewhere in this issue, is more than a personal tragedy. In that aspect it weighs heavily upon his friends, who loved in him the gentleness, modesty and quick sympathies which were so deep in him.

FROM London came word last week that Belgian Congo is issuing a 10-francs plus 40fr showing a "V" on a shield supported by the Lion of Brabant and carrying an inscription meaning "Belgium Shall Rise Again." The surtax is to aid a colonial war fund.

The colleges and universities of the United States have unanimously pledged themselves to 100 per cent cooperation toward winning the war. Their one desire is to serve to the utmost in this great emergency.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- When the American Government decided that, as fundamental anti-Axis policy, the United States was to be the "arsenal of democracy" on which all opponents of Berlin, Tokyo and Rome could draw, criticism from those nations of the quantity and delivery rate of that assistance was inevitably foreshadowed.

TORONTO, March 7 -- Toronto spotted the New York Rangers one goal at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight and then came on fast to beat the National Hockey League pace-setters, 4 -- 2, before 13,902 spectators in a game that bristled with speed throughout.

Contemporary accounts of events now a part of history appeal strongly to the imagination of boys and girls, and thus it is gratifying to have available at this time, when interest in Latin-American countries is keen, Bernal del Castillo's story of the Spanish conquest of Mexico in 1521, admirably edited for young readers.

AUTOMOBILE trips now must be planned with a saving eye to save time, mileage, gasoline and car wear. Since automobiles may have to last for several years, spare parts are difficult to obtain and tires are impossible to replace, a decided change is occurring in the driving habits of wise and prudent motorists.

With business still too limited to indicate a trend, the cotton market moved yesterday within a 7-point range and at the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts showed final net gains of 1 to 4 points.

Four-fifths of the sugar produced in continental United States comes from beets grown in such cool-weather States as Colorado, Utah, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Oregon. With imports of cane sugar from the Philippines cut off, we shall need more sugar beets. Fortunately, they are easily and quickly grown. They mature from seed to sugar-packed root in about six months.

THE Metropolitan Opera Company is going to perform for the first time at a university. The date is April 13, the opera will be "Aida" and the place is the new auditorium of the University of Indiana at Bloomington. "

When a people of spirit cannot resist the urge to fight back and in desperation takes up arms to give blows as well as take them, they become automatically outlawed guerrillas, summarily subject to the degradation of death at the hands of a firing squad if caught.

RENO, Nev., March 7 (U.P.) -- A parachute with pantaloons invented by Dr. Christian Volf of Los Angeles, was called a success today by Fred Waltz, veteran parachute rigger, who gave it the first "live" test.

ALMOST every one, especially every one who likes to make things -- bookshelves or gardens or gadgets, or dresses or good things to eat -- has thought: "I wish I could paint." Almost every one sees imaginary pictures, or sometimes with sudden intensity a face, a tree, a sky, flowers, or perhaps a man at bat; and thinks, "I would like to make a picture of it.

The headquarters of the Commandant of the Third Naval District announced last week that the removal of the Maritime Commission's cadet training school to its new Atlantic headquarters at Great Neck, L.I., had permitted expansion of the Naval Training School at the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at Fort Schuyler, in the Bronx.

Retail trade continued good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. The suit and blouse demand was active, with coat volume picking up toward the end of the week.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 7 -- State's Attorney Lorin W. Willis acted today in the investigation of the alleged birth certificate "mill" of Bridgeport by obtaining bench warrants for the arrest on conspiracy charges of Warren Glaser, a reporter for The New York Daily Mirror, and three Bridgeport men involved with him in the preparation of a false affidavit with which he obtained a birth certificate here.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The House made a small reduction in the Agriculture Department appropriation bill today despite an obvious stiffening of Democrats against the economy group's proposed cuts. The rallying of the majority party followed a visit of Congressional leaders to the White House for an hour's talk with President Roosevelt on the farm question, taxes and rivers and harbors projects.

OTTAWA, March 7 (U.P.) "Marked" gasoline of a distinctive color will be allocated under the rationing plan to internal combustion engines for farm and industrial machinery for which no provincial license plates are needed, it has been announced by Munitions Minister C.D. Howe.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 7 -While reports from German sources continue to stress preparations for the "Spring offensive" against Russia, there are sufficient signs that man power is beginning to tell as a factor in the conflict in Russia.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 7 (AP) -- Wesleyan University hailed Eugene J. Frechette Jr., a junior, as the new champion today for a performance that was literally breath-taking.
Two benefit theatre parties have been arranged for a fortnight hence under the auspices of groups aiding patriotic and philanthropic endeavor.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., March 7 -- When the State Institute of Agriculture at Farmingdale holds its graduation on April 1 the twenty-six students finishing the eighteen months' course in the School of Horticulture will have 100 jobs from which to make their choice.

NELL MARCLE'S grim demise in the woods above Marstow Village looked like murder. But it wasn't, Mr. Fortune, called from London, made that plain. The only possible verdict was "natural death." It will surprise none of H.C. Bailey's justly devoted readers, however, to learn that Mr. Fortune was far from satisfied with the Marstow situation.

BUCKLING down to war jobs on the home front, the nation at once must tighten up its traffic habits to prevent irreplaceable loss of workers, materials and time. On the roads every morning and afternoon, seven days a week under the war effort, are millions of hustling cars.

The stream of salvage materials out of city apartments and basements into war channels is gathering additional force from the spirited entrance into the campaign of a number of women's organizations who have set out to align their memberships with this direct contribution to the country's war effort.

DETROIT, March 7 (AP) -- A little more than five weeks ago the automobile industry stepped on its plant conversion accelerator. It began tearing out overhead conveyors and car assembling lines, shifting machine tools about and installing new equipment so that all its famed mass production technique could be turned to the task of war weapon manufacture.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Eleven railroads which were forced by the New York State Public Service Commission and Transit Commission to rescind a 10 per cent increase on commutation fares within the State petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today for an order permitting the increase.

A DETAILED survey of the recreational resources of the Denison Dam and Reservoir project on the Texas-Oklahoma border will soon be made by the National Park Service, 'and plans will be made for the most effective recreational use of the area.

MONTREAL, March 7 (AP) -- The National Hockey League play-off hopes of Montreal's Canadiens took a sharp upswing tonight when they came surging back in the closing minutes of a game with Boston to tie the score and then win, 4 -- 3, in the overtime session on a goal by Joe Benoit.

Mrs. Arthur C. Patterson, vice chairman of the Social Service Auxiliary to City Hospital, will have the Countess of Gainsborough and her daughter, Lady Maureen Noel, among her guests at the luncheon fashion show to be held Tuesday at the Hampshire House under the auspices of the auxiliary.

MOSCOW, March 7 -- Storming one of the most strongly defended German fortress towns they have yet encountered, Russian troops by taking Yukhnov and a group of surrounding villages have taken bases that had served as springboards for the attack on Moscow and were being used as a spearhead of the German menace to Russian forces that had pushed far beyond this point.

ON Thursday of last week the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, more cozily known to the world at large as the "Hays office," quietly passed its twentieth anniversary marked by nothing more unusual than a mountain of congratulatory telegrams on the desk of Will H. Hays himself.

The people of Great Britain under rationing get one pound of meat a week, including the bone, as against 1 3/4 pounds in normal times; but the normal consumption in this country is between two and three pounds a week.

NOTWITHSTANDING its title, which suggests a study in military tactics, this is a book that reads almost as vividly as good fiction, and it will be of special interest to those who at the present moment have every reason for following and learning what they can from military operations.

TO every age its own particular brand of nonsense. The eighteenth century, a highly skeptical and profoundly unsettled time, with explosives throbbing in its veins which ultimately detonated in the American and French Revolutions, preferred the line of talk about polite behavior and sedate enlightenment as though the world were likely to go on taking snuff and sipping tea forever in an atmosphere of mezzotints and Chippendale sidetables.

WHEN a phonograph company executive missed a Long Island commuters' train one evening back in 1930, one of radio's longest and most successful manager-talent partnerships was in the making. The executive was Ted Collins; the talent was none other than Kate Smith, now the "Songbird of the South" -- she of the mellow voice and the Friday night variety show.

HITHERTO biographers of the crusty old Commodore have been primarily interested in him as a human being or as a social symbol, and most of them, with pardonable manifestations of personal bias, have approached his presence either angrily or with hat in hand.

The entire graphic work of Alphonse Legros, French painter and etcher, numbering more than 1,600 items, has been presented to the Boston Public Library by Albert H. Wiggin, former president and chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Talk that a United Nations offensive at some undisclosed point on the world's far-flung battle fronts was being planned spread wider in Washington today as President Roosevelt conferred with his military, naval and air high command for the second time in three days.

TOKYO, March 7 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Japanese forces are only "a few kilometers" from Bandung and Netherland forces are retreating southward, with the collapse of the whole of Java's defenses expected shortly, a dispatch from a Japanese Army base in Java reported today.

THE contract bridge experts, who were generally untouched by the draft until after American entry into the war, are beginning to be called into the armed services. At the Eastern championships which have been in progress through the past week, some uniforms were in evidence and several of the better known players had been instructed to appear for their final examinations.

THE war is making a not-unexpected change in the plans of the annual dance project at Bennington, Vt., next Summer, but happily it is not as serious as it might be. Though there will be no festival, as there has been in past years, at least the framework of the project itself will be maintained, so that things may be picked up as soon as the world situation allows.

Production at the Long Island City factory of the National Casket Company was shut down yesterday by a strike of 225 members of the Casket Makers Union, Local 1,728 of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, A.F. of L.
SWITZERLAND has commemorated the 650th anniversary of the beginning of her confederation with the issuance of a special five-franc coin made of silver.

NEW ORLEANS, La. -- Southern travelers who regretted the cancellation of the New Orleans Mardi Gras will rejoice in the Crescent City's Spring Fiesta. Lasting for three weeks, from today to March 29, this annual event promises a series of features designed to make the 1942 season memorable in many ways.

The following is the final message received by the New York office of Aneta, Netherlands Indies News Agency, from its Bandung correspondent.BANDUNG, Java, March 7 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The situation on Java, at least on the western part of the island, has now become critical. The Japanese, again attacking with great superiority, have broken through the defenses on the northern side of the volcano of Tangkuban Prahu.

LIGHTNING -- Contrary to general opinion, lightning strokes are more severe in valleys and near the ground than in the high mountains according to L.M. Robertson of the Public Service Company of Colorado, W.W. Lewis of the General Electric Company's Central Station Engineering Department and C.M. Foust of that company's General Engineering Laboratory.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 7 -- Maryland's boxers lost every fight in the final round of the Eastern intercollegiate boxing tournament tonight, but still managed to win the team title with a total of 15 points.

The demand for bank credit to finance war industries is mounting rapidly and has the right of way at every bank, but there are straws in the wind that indicate that bank loans for non-defense purposes must be curtailed voluntarily or official "suggestions" will be forthcoming soon.

CLAREMONT, Calif., March 7 -The call of the United States Navy and Army to provide skilled radio operators has been answered by sixty students at Pomona College, where a volunteer course has been provided by the physics department, outside the regular curriculum.
BIELLEAIR, Fla. -- The height of the season has been reached at the Belleview Biltmore at Belleair. Amid the sports and social activities, many guests continue to arrive daily.

A 5 per cent decrease in fatal accidents was achieved in New York City in 1941, compared with the previous year, according to a preliminary report given yesterday morning by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, in his weekly radio talk over Station WNYC.

SPORTS are intertwined with the war network now and will be further enmeshed as the campaign goes on. "Enmeshed" in the best sense of that word. Champions, runners-up and hordes of competitors of the common or garden variety in many fields, all the better prepared for their activities in competition, have been Called into the armed services. More will go.

It is just three months ago yesterday that the nightmare began at Pearl Harbor, three months ago today that it was recognized by action of President and Congress. The nation still stirs uneasily, like a man half-awake on a morning of disaster, still half-hoping that the evil thing is in the dream and not a reality.

LAKE PLACID -- March is officially midseason for Winter sports up here. At lower altitudes, Spring may have already arrived, but the Adirondacks country around Placid usually holds on to snow and ice well into April.

Objecting to the "hysterical" attitude of school officials, Dr. Abraham Lefkowitz, principal of Samuel J. Tilden High School, charged yesterday that New York City teachers were subjected to unnecessary and conflicting administrative orders, red-tape and senseless "made work," all in the name of the war.

AS a result of the present world conflict there are few people who doubt the value of the airplane as a military weapon. It has been demonstrated too clearly too often that an army or navy lacking sufficient air support cannot hope to cope with an adversary equipped with adequate air power.

Apparently having pieced together to their official satisfaction the circumstances surrounding the murder in an East Side hotel of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, the police of the East Fifty-first Street Station yesterday set in motion an eleven-State teletype alarm for two men and a woman.
