Now that the trout season is in the offing, many anglers who are afraid that they will find some forms of salt-water sport curtailed because of the war are showing an interest in lake and stream fishing.

KEARNY, N.J., March 7 -- Two youths were killed and a man was injured here at 1 A.M. today when the car in which they were riding had a head-on collision with another machine on Belleville Turnpike. Their automobile caught fire after the crash.

IN collectors' albums are numerous stamps illustrating maps that have become obsolete by virtue of negotiations or conquests. There are other bits of postal paper that carry maps which were correct in the eyes of the countries issuing them but inaccurate from the viewpoint of rival nations claiming part or all of the territory depicted.

Extensive reorganization of the curriculum of the Columbia University Department of History, consisting in the addition of nine new courses and a shift in emphasis on subject-matter in both the graduate and undergraduate divisions, was announced yesterday by Professor Carlton J.H. Hayes, head of the department.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 7 -- New Zealand rushed defense plans toward completion this week, including organizations of the most secret nature, it was revealed today.

GRANBY, Mo., March 7 -- The steel-rending collision of a troop train and the Frisco railroad's passenger, the Will Rogers, killed seven persons tonight, four of them soldiers, and injured at least twenty-eight.

BOSTON, March 7 -- Meeting the challenge presented by the current opening of new professional fields for women, Simmons College has taken steps to bring about a higher degree of coordination of programs with the schools from which it draws its students, President Bancroft Beatley announced today.

There's something about a March rain, even if it starts out as sleet or ends as short-lived snow, that partakes of a changing season. It isn't a warm rain, such as falls in mid-April. But it isn't the cold rain of November, either, cheerless and filled with Winter's warning.

Although conceding the general desirability of the pact just signed with Brazil and the importance of maintaining the principle of hemispheric unity on which it is based, American foreign traders last week indicated their concern over the difficulties involved in coordinating diplomatic promises to Latin-America with the situation actually existing.

FREEPORT, L.I., March 7 -The First National Bank and Trust Company of Freeport assumed all deposit liabilities of the Citizens National Bank here as of the close of business today. The transaction was made possible by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which purchased certain assets of the Citizens National for $350,000.

BERLIN, March 7 (from German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Soviet forces, without consideration of heavy losses in men and materials, are continuing attacks to break through the German lines on the Eastern front, military dispatches said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 7 -Capturing seven first places and four seconds, Yale's powerful swimming team defeated Princeton, 45 -- 30, and virtually clinched its fourth straight Eastern Intercollegiate League title in Brokaw Pool today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- To effectuate the Executive order putting primary responsibility on the Navy for safeguarding American ports and waterfront facilities from acts of sabotage, Secretary Knox has organized a coordinated protective system, to be administered by Rear Admiral R.R. Waesche, commandant of the Coast Guard.

The government precautionary campaign to examine and identify every person in the United States whose business may take him on or near piers, beaches, bulkheads and all other waterfront properly, was gathering headway last week.

SAVANNAH, Ga. -- Most persons think of Georgia as a State abounding in luscious peach groves, as the source of unsavory stories of prison camps and, if one travels through it by rail, as strangely similar to the Blue Ridge country because of an escarpment of rugged heights which are in reality a continuation of the same mountains.

Miss White in her many stories has given us not only a succession of some of the most delightfully real little girls in fiction but a number of engaging cat portraits as well, as those who are acquainted with "Sally in Her Fur Coat" and "Brothers in Fur," a lively account of a cat family known as the "Furbush-Tailbys," or who recall the magnificent "General Harry Fluff" in "An Only Child," will gladly testify.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7 -Yale University scientists are playing important roles in the hemisphere-wide program of archaeological research in Latin American countries now being conducted in cooperation with the Nelson Rockefeller Committee on Inter-American Affairs.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 7 -- A Free French column from the Chad Territory in the north of French Equatorial Africa has captured an Axis position in Fezzan, province in the extreme south of Tripolitania, after violent fighting.

SOMEWHERE IN THE NEW YORK METROPOLITAN AREA, March 7 -- While Army planes roared overhead, more than 1,000 residents of surrounding communities, among them many municipal officials, witnessed this afternoon a regimental retreat ceremony staged by Scots pipers and a military band of Britons billeted with fellow soldiers of the British Isles at an Army post in this area.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Attention here the forthcoming week will be centered on several benefits and sports events, chief among them the Red, White and Blue Ball in which Palm Beach will join the nation in raising funds for the -ny Emergency Fund and the Navy Relief Society.

Tomatoes can be grown successfully in every garden, even though there is not room enough for a real vegetable garden. The possibility of fitting the plant into the ornamental garden as a hedge, background or green corner planting makes it possible for any family to feast on home-grown specimens of this staple vegetable.

CLEVELAND, March 7 -- The Cleveland Classic, twenty-sixth annual all-breed show of the Western Reserve Kennel Club opened today in the Public Auditorium with an entry of 930 dogs, representing sixty-four breeds.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 -The Student Defense Board at Radcliffe College has planned a program of courses and community service for the entire student body. Composed of the chairmen of seven committees, the board has for its purpose the correlation of all student war service.

MOSCOW, March 7 -- Russian troops have hurled back strong counter-attacks by the Sixteenth German Army trapped in the Staraya Russa area and on several sectors of that front they have forced part of the Nazis' army of 250,000 to retreat "several kilometers," war dispatches said tonight.

MR. MORAN is an American obsessed by a nostalgia for Europe. He was graduated at Columbia Law School, ran a railway in Oregon and served in Peru and Puerto Rico with the Naval Reserve. But by upbringing in the Riviera and Algiers he is a child of the Old World's inland sea, and he is lonely except in the company of the buccaneers and merchant adventurers, whose exploits enrapture his mind with "memories" of yore.

To assist its rapidly expanding civilian defense program as well as to advance its regular philanthropic work, the Carroll Club will benefit from the performance of the circus on April 13 at Madison Square Garden. Mrs. Basil Harris, president of the advisory board, and her arrangements committee have taken over the boxes, promenade and arena seats for the performance.

IN Tolstoy's "War and Peace" Andrew Bolkonsky talked with Peter on the eve of the Battle of Borodino. "Victory,'' said he, "never can be and never has been the outcome of position, numbers or character of arms -- least of all, position.''

DEDICATED to "people of good-will everywhere," Arch Oboler's "Plays for Americans" -- of which the sixth in a weekly series of thirteen will be heard at 4:30 this afternoon on WEAF and the Red Network -- are the work of an angry man.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (U.P.) -- Thirty-five thousand young men and women are being dropped from National Youth Administration rolls under the new order eliminating all projects with no direct bearing on the war effort, NYA officials said tonight.

PHILIP LIGHTFOOT SCRUGGS draws the title of this serious and imposing chronicle of colonial Virginia from a sonnet by Lawrence Lee: "Man cannot tell what roots hold him to earth that bore him like a blossom from the loam.

Guiomar Novaes enthralled the large audience at her recital in Town Hall yesterday with a remarkable series of performances of the sort that place her in a special niche of her own among contemporary keyboard artists. The Brazilian pianist, who was never more completely in the vein, informed all of her work with a technical perfection and inexhaustible fund of varied color that in themselves would have made the recital notable.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 7 (U.P.) -- Rear Admiral Frank H. Sadler, commandant of the Fifteenth Naval District, told a press conference today that enemy submarines had been reported in the Gulf of Darien and off Cristobal, C.Z., but he said that these reports should be taken "with a grain of salt."

Six faculty members, sixty graduate students and two alumni have been elected to the Columbia University chapter of Sigma Xi, honorary scientific research society, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announces.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Secret baseball contracts, the kind in which a college baseball player usually gets financial assistance for promising to join the paying club after graduation, are legally worthless, says Commissioner K.M. Landis.

The hardships put by the second World War upon the American family were emphasized in a report issued yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, executive director of the Greater New York Fund, to John W. Hanes, campaign chairman for 1942.

THE week has worn a somewhat warlike mien, implied when not belligerent. An outstanding event was the opening, on Tuesday, of the Whitney Museum's print annual. Unlike its predecessors, this exhibition is not confined to work by living American artists.

NOW that the sun is getting a little stronger, dusty windows framed by stale Winter curtains become more obvious. It might be nice to give in to a bout of Spring fever and put up some fresh curtains that are gay and a touch unconventional.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Royce G. Martin of Toledo, Ohio, were hosts this afternoon at a farewell luncheon in the board room of the Hialeah Club to mark the close of the racing for this season at the track.

WHILE reading THE TIMES Magazine of Feb. 22 I was amazed to find in the top illustration on Page 28 a picture of myself taken twenty-five years ago. In view of conditions "Then and Now," I thought you might be interested in hearing a little about those dances from one who attended them each week during their existence.

THOUGHTLESSNESS and indifference are important reasons for censorship of mail written by those who least suspect that their chatty letters to members of their families contain information which might be helpful to unfriendly eyes and ears.

FIRST Selectman Charlie Loveland was feeding his hogs, but he paused to say: 'We haven't done anything special. Just what any other town has done, I guess. Probably there's plenty done a better defense job. But we're ready for what comes." And he went on with his chores.

Wails of the new Myers-Velazco "dynatone" air raid signal, tested for the first time outdoors on the New Jersey Palisades opposite Ninety-sixth Street, startled residents of Manhattan's upper West Side yesterday from noon to 2 P.M. until they became used to the sounds.

Conversion of the automobile industry to war production has actually resulted in hardship to manufacturers of only five of the wenty or so major materials which went into the manufacture or the promotion of passenger cars, according to executives in the various fields covered last week.

NEWARK, N.J., March 7 -- War industry in Northern New Jersey, one of this country's leading manufacturing centers, is utilizing only 49 per cent of its productive capacity, Irving Abramson, president of the State Industrial Union Council, C.I.O., charged here today on the basis of a survey that had been made by C.I.O. members of seventy-seven plants in this section.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Conscious of the difficulties exporters face when applications for export licenses are rejected without a complete explanation of the reasons, the Office of Export Control of the Board of Economic Warfare is giving serious study to devising some means for conveying information on rejected applications to American shippers.

Paul G. Boise, New York shipping executive, has been named manager of the Chilean Line in the United States, it was announced yesterday by Agustin Huneeus, general manager for the line in this country. Mr. Boise, who formerly was with the shipping firm of Garcia Diaz, has had considerable experience in South American shipping, and has been engaged in shipping activities for thirty-five years.

Secretary Morgenthau's tax proposals have some commendable features. The most general of these is the fact that the taxpayer is given a year's notice of their possible impact. This year's additional tax burden was not disclosed until nearly three-quarters of last year had elapsed.

First there is an impoverished scion of the Social Register trying to get a job as a reporter by landing an exclusive story of the clip-girls on New York's honky-tonk row. But soon we discover that what the book is really about is the strange set of adventurers menaced by flood in the Big River, somewhere out West.

Malthus published his "Principles of Population" in 1798, enunciating therein the postulate that population tends to increase in geometrical and subsistence in arithmetical ratio, whereby there are entailed chronic poverty, misery, and even vice and crime. Both Darwin and Wallace in 1858 predicated their thesis, "survival of the fittest," on Malthus, and handsomely acknowledged their debt to him, as set forth in Topics of The Times.

PAOLI, Pa., March 7 -- A statement that the Rockefeller Committee would fail in its efforts to improve cultural relations with Latin America unless it recognize that "the spiritual element alone can knit the whole Western Hemisphere together," was made today by Dr. Joseph Thorning, Professor of Ethics and Sociology at Mount St. Mary's College.

UNCLE SAM needs more radio men -- a lot more of them. Ships are sliding off the ways, scores of tanks and hundreds of planes daily are roaring off factory production lines, and every new unit in service requires radio men on board.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 7 -- Boysy, a 6-year-old gelding owned and trained by Thomas H. Heard Jr., made up a three-length deficit in the stretch today to win the Memphis Handicap at Oaklawn Park in a photo finish with the Lexbrook Stable's Potranco.

Miss Anne Delafield Finch and many of her friends, who during the last several years have been subscribers to the various subscription dances that draw a large attendance from younger members of society, have organized in a patriotic undertaking.

THIS soldier escaped to England, with part of his battalion, between Dunkerque and the surrender. He is neither a soldier nor a writer by profession. But shortly after his arrival in London, when the news of the collapse of his country reached him in ins hospital, his amazement, his sadness, his resolute effort to explain her downfall, his undying love of France, his vision of her resurrection poured out irresistibly on the written page.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., March 7 -- Spring comes early to Sea Island, with the result that while many members of society in Eastern States are indulging in late Winter sports elsewhere, others now residing at this all-year-round resort find the Spring season here at its peak.

MY theme is an old one, and indeed we are fighting today in order that it may not become prehistoric. From the beginning of the modern period noble spirits and shrewd minds, like John Milton, have seen how closely the printed word and freedom are entangled.

Victories by Clinton P. Stephens and Charles Wagner in the men's singles quarter-final round matches contested yesterday were among the highlights as the tenth annual metropolitan championships continued at the Manhattan Badminton Club.

Another milestone in the hectic course of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company's financing program is scheduled to take place on March 17 when the Louisville Transmission Corporation, a subsidiary, will offer in competitive bidding $3,850,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1967.

JUST CHIPS: One reaction to Secretary Morgenthau's proposal for higher revenues came last week from Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen. The former OP/Vf head termed taxes "just the chips in the great game of production." hWhat difference do taxes make now ?" he asked.

DRIED navy beans, beef liver, canned red salmon, round steak, pork chops, rolled oats and American cheese are foods that give big amounts of protein for small figures on the grocery slip. Spinach, in spite of what Popeye thinks about it, comes out fifth on the list of iron foods, but this green which is said to cause so much dissension in nursery circles is an inexpensive source of Vitamin A.

All commercial employment agencies were warned yesterday by License Commissioner Paul Moss that their licenses would be revoked if they did not abandon the practice of sending workers out on temporary jobs and collecting fees based on a percentage of the pay the worker would receive if the job lasted a full year.

ERNEST CHAUSSON, whose life was cut short in 1899 when he was 44 by a bicycle accident, wrote a limited number of compositions. The Poeme for violin and orchestra and the Symphony in B flat, which are the best known, are on records, but a hasty glance through domestic catalogues reveals no recording of the Concerto in D, for Violin, Piano and String Quartet, Op. 21.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- A member of the House Naval Affairs subcommittee investigating the fire aboard the former French liner Normandie said today that a mass of evidence has been developed to show it would have been comparatively simple to have sabotaged her.

THOUGH the title says the book is about Michael's girl, his daughter Letty, it is really about the gentle lady of the house for whom Michael was gardener. Her troubled life took Letty into account, almost with the same ardor that she lavished on her son Van.

THE City of Benares sailed from Liverpool on Sept. 13, 1940: a "children's ship," carrying ninety evacuees between the ages of 5 and 15 toward the hope of safety from England's bombings. On Sept. 26 six of the seven children who survived the ship's torpedoing were brought ashore in Scotland, after eight days in an open boat on a stormy sea.

Eight of thirteen defendants in a $10,000,000 oil securities swindle were convicted yesterday by a jury in Federal District Court that had deliberated on the evidence for three days after the longest criminal prosecution in the court's records. The trial began Aug. 4 and lasted 214 days.

LONDON, March 7 -- Owing to Britain's constant need to keep raw materials and finished products moving to and from her war factories over the railroads and highways, the normal Easter holiday period this year - April 2 to April 7 -- will be marked by the absence of Easter travel because there will not be any extra trains or buses, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A "peremptory request" to distributors and dealers in domestic mechanical refrigerators that they immediately restore wholesale and retail prices to the level of Feb. 2 was issued today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator.

An unusual, not to say heterodox, note is struck by The Economist in discussing the book famine. Far from sympathizing with Stanley Unwin's complaint that so many people are content to borrow books instead of buying them, it considers it a very fortunate thing that books have the capacity to be "consumed" by many more than one consumer.

AMERICAN VOLUNTEER GROUP HEADQUARTERS, Somewhere in Burma, March 7 (AP) -Guns loaded and motors tuned for combat, another American Volunteer Group squadron roared from out of the China skies today to take over their share of the Battle for Burma from the little band of Yankee aces who smashed the last big Japanese air offensive on Rangoon.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- Fifty young R.A.F. cadets, who completed their training at Clewiston this week-end and will leave shortly for a war zone, were entertained tonight at the Everglades Club dinner dance. Also in the party were fourteen American instructors and their wives.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 7 (AP) -- The Coca Cola Company reported today for 1941 a net income of $27,108,374 applicable to the common stock, equal to $6.78 a share. This compared with $27,084,752, or $6.77 a share in 1940. The company's business in 1941 established a new high record.

A large increase in the number of automobile tires and tubes rationed in the first week of March, compared with the first week of February, was reported yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, acting Federal rationing administrator for New York City, 330 West Forty-second Street.

LONDON, March 7 -- Grim overtones of war,some of them marked by risible passages, are sounded in the 1942 edition of Debrett's Peerage, which is the ordinarily matter of fact record of the aristocracy, it is revealed.

The very purpose of the hours provisions of the Wage-Hour Law was to make it prohibitively costly for employers to maintain a working week of more than forty hours. At a time when it was considered unpatriotic to maintain hours above forty, the employer was forced to pay a penalty of a 50 per cent wage increase for hours above forty.

NEW ORLEANS, March 8 -- With little news from Washington concerning the status of the contest for parity prices on government-owned stocks of cotton and with the spot business only a small proportion of that in the corresponding period last year, cotton futures had little last week to influence price trends except for apprehension over the reverses of the United Nations in the Far East.

A pale-faced 39-year-old hotel porter, with twoprevious arrests on his record, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Anthony F. Burke in Felony Court on homicide charges in connection with the deaths of five persons in a fire in an old three-story tenement house at 239 West Sixteenth Street early Saturday morning.

One of the longest criminal trials on record in the United States District court here ended shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, as a worn-out jury after four days of deliberation returned a verdict of guilty against three defendants and acquitted one in a $10,000,000 mail fraud case.

LONDON, March 8 -- Lord Strabolgi, Labor peer, in a speech at Frome today, urged a British offensive in Western Europe while the expected Spring campaign on the Russian front was still hanging in the balance. He spoke on behalf of the Russian Red Cross.

The six finalists of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air will appear at the "Gala Program" to be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House next Sunday night. Their deportment before an audience, on the stage where at least two of them will win contracts, will be additional factors in selecting the winners, for the judges will be in the audience.

All the agencies of Catholic Charities in the archdiocese of New York are not only geared to give added wartime services in health, social programs and all emergencies, but are prepared to meet rehabilitation problems and simultaneously carry on their normal services to the community, Mgr. Robert Keegan, executive director of Catholic Charities of New York, declared yesterday over WOR.

America's desire for "things, possessions rather than ideals" was blamed for much of "our difficulty and obvious disunity today" by the Very Rev. James P. De Wolfe, Bishop-elect of the diocese of Long Island, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where he is dean.

Bernardo Segall, Brazilian pianist who made his debut here five years ago, last night gave his fourth Town Hall recital. His program consisted of transcriptions of Bach organ works, Scriabin's Fourth Sonata, Beethoven's Sonata in D minor, Op. 31, No. 2; Albeniz's "El Albacin," and five studies by five different composer-pianists.

A novel experience was enjoyed by Jim Henry, youthful goalie of the New York Rangers, in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The shut-out that had been eluding him all season, his first in the major loop, finally came his way, and, to make his satisfaction all the greater, it was registered against the sharpshooting, fast-skating Toronto Maple Leafs.
As the father of a boy with the Pacific Fleet, I wish to commend highly your editorial "The Public and the War," particularly the last two paragraphs.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Johnny Revolta's 40-foot putt for an eagle 3 on the thirty-sixth hole today set the pace for a series of surprises as the nation's top professionals staged an amazing scoring exhibition in the first round of the Miami Biltmore International four-ball golf tournament.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Outside interest in corn shows a tendency to increase, as the result of continued limited country offerings and a near record consumption by processors and livestock feeders. There is a big demand for corn products, including alcohol, and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics forecasts a record number of grain-consuming animals on farms by the end of this year.

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, at Fifty-sixth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning that "the conventionally good people of our day cannot escape from responsibility for the evil of the world."

PITTSBURGH, March 8 -- Labor groups in this industrial district, responding to appeals of their international leaders for a drastic acceleration in production of war materials, are taking steps to accomplish the task of exceeding by 25 per cent the heavy 1942 output schedules set by President Roosevelt.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 8 -- In a nip-and-tuck struggle through eight sailing dinghy races at the Larchmont Yacht Club today, Bob De Coppet, with his Class B boat Zotom, beat Arthur Knapp and his craft Prissy by 2 points. George Isdale was the Class X winner with his Queen Mary.

In the eighteen months since the fall of France, "rescue through emigration" of 25,000 men, women and children from Europe has been aided by the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society and its European affiliate, it was reported yesterday at the annual convention attended by 2,500 delegates in the Hotel Astor.

The net profit of $17,436,977 reported in the 1941 annual statement of the Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries, equal to $3.92 a share on 4,449,052 capital shares outstanding, compares with $11,590,317 or $2.61 a share earned in 1940.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 -- Restrictions on tires are likely to cause an upswing in the volume of sales by local grocers because of the resulting curtailment of "out-of-the-neighborhood" shopping, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, asserted today.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 8 -- On Washington alone rests the fate of the Near East -- Northern and Eastern Africa and Western Asia -- in the opinion of responsible circles here.

MOSCOW, March 8 (AP) -- Russia paid tribute today to its women who are doing a magnificent job fighting Reichsfuehrer Hitler and producing the tools with which their men are forcing back the invaders from the vast Soviet homeland.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Grain traders continue to await official action on the bills designed to freeze government-owned stocks of wheat and other agricultural products, although the action of the wheat market last week suggested to traders that this factor was decreasing as a price-making influence.

Last week's sharp decline in stocks was not accompanied by active trading, but primarily by lower bid prices. It carried the average for railway shares to the lowest since March, 1938, and for industrial shares to the lowest since 1933.
VICHY, March 8 -- Showings of the Parisian fashion houses, interrupted since the armistice, have been resumed with a series of presentations at the Lyons Fair.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Taking the Congress economy group to task for advocating reduction of the Farm Security appropriation, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said tonight, in another of her weekly broadcasts over the Blue Network, that the proposed economies were "short-sighted" and would prove "vastly wasteful in the future."

LONDON, March 8 -- The tax proposals of the United States Treasury are being examined and criticized here in the light of the burden which the British taxpayer has to bear. Although direct comparison between British and American results of taxation are difficult, it is seen that the American taxpayer still is being let off lightly, compared with his British counterpart, except recipients of really large incomes.

While providing for immediate Spring and Summer needs, retailers continued to arrange advance purchases of both staple and semistaple merchandise for delivery into the Fall and Winter months during the week, it was indicated in a summary of last week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading New York resident buyers.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 8 -- The growing conviction in German military quarters that the Allies are on the eve of answering Premier Joseph Stalin's appeal for a second front, plus Sweden's refusal to allow transit of troops and arms to Northern Norway over her territory, continue to cause another war of nerves.

This, being March, is a month in which many a man on the home front will lose a battle against conscience. It is the month for deciding, if one is ever to decide, to have or not to have a vegetable garden. Only the laggard waits until this season, of course; the real dirt gardener starts planning next year's crops before September's harvest is on the table.

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged yesterday that "meddling people" in high government office were attempting to "frustrate the operations" of President Roosevelt's War Labor Board in passing on C.I.O. demands for wage increases and a union shop in four "Little Steel" companies.

Miss Mary Hagan and Carl Loveday impressively continued their defense of the men's and women's metropolitan badminton singles championships yesterday by scoring straight-game triumphs at the Manhattan Badminton Club in the semi-finals.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, March 9 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces landed from transports early yesterday at two points in Northeast New Guinea -- Salamaua and Lae, which is the capital of the Australian-mandated Territory of New Guinea -- and thus advanced the eastern arm of a pincers threatening Australia.
The cornerstone of the Harlem Hospital Dispensary, 137th Street between Lenox and Fifth Avenues, now nearing completion at a cost of $957,000, will be laid Wednesday afternoon at 4 o'clock.
LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- The Netherland Government here, in its denial today of the surrender of Java, said:

LONDON, March 8 -- Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, laid upon the British Government today responsibility for the death of 760 Jewish refugees from Rumania who perished when the steamer Struma sank in the Black Sea recently.

Today "Lady in the Dark" starts its final six weeks at the Alvin, terminating a satisfactory run for all concerned on April 25. A glance at the calendar indicates that Gertrude Lawrence's starring vehicle is really in its last seven weeks, but the difference of one week is accounted for by the fact that there will be no performances Holy Week (week of March 29).
NEW CITY, N.Y., March 8 -- The horse-and-buggy is back in Rockland County after an eclipse of at least a quarter of a century dating from the advent of the automobile age.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Loans held by national banks in the United States and possessions on Dec. 31, last year, increased $282,000,000 in the quarter ended on that date, it was reported today by the Controller of the Currency. They were $1,724,000,000 more than those held at the end of December, 1940.

LONDON, March 8 -- British bombers, accompanied by a strong escort of fighter planes, delivered a savage attack in the Paris area today for the second time within five days, living up to Britain's threat to pound henceforth any factories in German-occupied France that are turning out war materials for the Nazis.

SEATTLE, March 8 -- A naval lieutenant and seven enlisted men died today in the crash of a Catalina bomber in the Columbia River at Tongue Point, Ore., the Thirteenth Naval District Headquarters reported.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C.P. Wichfeld gave a dinner tonight at The Reef to celebrate Mr. Wichfeld's birthday. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick, Mr. and Mrs. Claude K. Boettcher, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Holmsen, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, Joseph E. Widener, Charles B. Alexander 2d and Gurnee Munn.
CANBERRA, Australia, Monday, March 9 (AP) -- An Australian communique today said:

Karl Krueger, the accomplished conductor of the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra, made his first appearance here late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, when he directed the concert given by the New York City Symphony Orchestra, under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project. Previously, Mr. Krueger had led a radio broadcast in this city, but had not otherwise been active hereabout.

In a letter printed elsewhere on this page the director of information of the American Farm Bureau Federation, John J. Lacey, contends that parity prices for the farmer do not mean inflation. Actually the editorial to which Mr. Lacey referred concerned the tactics of the farm bloc in seeking to handicap the Administration's efforts to stabilize living costs, rather than parity prices as such, but his argument deserves examination.

All the human qualities that once might have won battles against superior odds were exhibited at their best in the defense of Java. The bravery of the Dutch is beyond praise. They fought with fierce tenacity for days on end without sleep or rest, at every point of attack.

The United Aircraft Corporation relinquished $10,000,000 of its revenues from contracts with the United States Navy in 1941 through its determination to avoid excessive profits resulting from an accelerating volume of war production, according to the annual report for 1941 signed by Eugene E. Wilson, president, and Frederick B. Rentschler, chairman of the company, and released for publication today.

James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, in a statement supporting legislation in Albany to fix a mandatory retirement age of 65 years for teachers and supervisors in the city school system, declared yesterday that the city's schools were "confronted with an aging school staff and no prospect of appointment of young teachers."

CINCINNATI, March 8 (AP) -- Production is going ahead at a satisfactory rate along all industrial fronts, despite the cries of scarcity in some materials, Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen, war production chief, declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- War refugees face a persecution comparable to that which filled the Roman Empire with refugees and called forth an order from the Apostle Paul, bidding the early Christians to arouse themselves to a sense of responsibility to those in need, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared in a nation-wide broadcast tonight.
MOSCOW, March 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of information issued the following communique today:

The august procession of the seasons, need time and harvest, snowfall and blossoming tree, have lost their natural significance in a world at war. For three long Winters the peoples of Europe have been warmed mostly by their smoldering angers, fed on the husks the conquerors left them, lighted by the dimming flames of deferred hopes.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- In an anti-inflation measure designed to help neutralize the government's unprecedented war expenditures, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System tonight imposed new restrictions on installment buying.

PITTSBURGH, March 8 (AP) -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced today that C.M. Mason, district sales manager at Buffalo, N.Y., had been appointed to the same position in Cleveland, succeeding E.A. France, who has retired after thirty-seven years of service.

The War Action Center, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, a cooperative organization of business and professional women's groups formed to provide a channel through which women with skills can make an effective war contribution, will be formally launched at a meeting on "Women in the War and After" at 8:30 o'clock tonight, it was announced yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, March 8 (AP) -- A government ordinance today authorized the formation of a new civil pioneer force officered by Indians for civil defense and maintenance of public order and safety.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 8 -- Champion Rosecroft Premier tonight won his eleventh best-in-show award when he took the highest honors in the twenty-sixth annual show of the Providence County Kennel Club.
As a Parisian recently returned from occupied France, I want to let Americans know how the French feel about the bombardment of industrial suburbs of Paris on March 3.

In your editorial on farm prices in your issue of Feb. 27 you assume that parity prices for the farmer will mean inflation, and you say, in effect, that if farm prices are permitted to rise to parity, farmers will be "looked upon as wartime profiteers."

CAIRO, Egypt, March 8 -- Brigadier John C. Campbell, a hero of the fighting at Rezegh, in Libya last November, died recently as a result of injuries suffered in an automobile accident in the desert. He was 48.
LONDON, March 8 -- The stock markets have been pulled first one way and then another in the last week by financial and war developments.

ANKARA, March 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Soviet Consulate in Istanbul surrendered to Turkish police today two of its nationals who had taken refuge there, bringing to at least five the number of Russians under arrest in connection with the bombing attempt on German Ambassador Fritz von Papen Feb. 24.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- The Red Army has captured Sychevka, Central Front town on the Rzhev-Vyazma railroad, following a two-day battle in which virtually all of the 15,000 men of the German Forty-eighth Division were wiped out, front-line dispatches said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution have transferred their fifty-first Continental Congress from Washington to Chicago because of the congestion in the capital. It will be held April 12 to 19.

Despite higher taxes and operating expenditures, sales and earnings last year of the Borden Company and its subsidiaries were the largest since 1931, according to the eighty-fourth annual statement, to be made public today by Theodore G. Montague, president.

Their pride outraged at being pushed around by agroup of youngsters loitering on the sidewalk, two East Side hoodlums returned with a pistol and critically wounded one of them about to enter his home at 111 East Third Street at 2:50 A.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- A group of Senators, who are not convinced that the "sea otter" type of vessel is impractical, has started an inquiry into what tests were given the craft, once heralded as the answer to submarine warfare.

The ice-out prophets, comprising veteran anglers and guides from scores of New England lakes and streams, are out with their ice-picks and tape measures testing the thickness of the ice in order to have something to help them in estimating the opening date of the fishing season.

Mayor La Guardia delivered his weekly "Talk to the People" yesterday from his desk at City Hall, via WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station. As usual, newspaper men were barred from his office and were not permitted to interview him afterward.
LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

MIAMI, March 8 -- The newly installed power plant of the Giants, which up to now seemed to be functioning with crossed wires, finally exploded today to smear the Red Sox, 13 to 5. That squared the two-game series at a victory apiece and convinced 3,000 onlookers as well as the Sox that Mel Ott's Polo Grounders possess a pile-driving punch.

LONDON, March 8 -- Financial London has expressed its fullest approval of the bombing raid on Paris. It is felt that factories in occupied France working for Germany are as legitimate targets for British attack as are military objectives in Germany itself.

LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- The biggest problems confronting Britain's textile industries this week, as they turned increasing effort to utility products, were allocations of materials and shortages of labor.

ALBANY, March 8 -- All prospects of a short session of the Legislature have virtually disappeared. The program for the coming week, the ninth, calls for speedy disposition of the budget in both houses, probably on Tuesday, but even this will not clear the decks sufficiently for a March adjournment, such as had been hoped for at the start of the year.

An all-out spiritual drive, with increased emphasis on personal religion, was urged by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale in his sermon yesterday morning before 1,200 persons in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Coming to life with a third-period rally that netted two goals, the pace-setting New York Rovers maintained their two-point advantage over the Johnstown Blue Birds by battling the Flood City skaters to a 3-all overtime deadlock in the Eastern Hockey League game featuring an amateur twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Hitler's death by suicide was predicted by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen yesterday in his third Lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

Home together from widely separated centers of the war, John G. Winant, Ambassador to Great Britain, and Admiral Thomas C. Hart, former Commander in Chief of the Allied Naval Forces in the Far East, arrived yesterday on a Pan American Airways clipper.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- The United States Government was urged today by the national administrative council of the Zionist Organization in America to intercede with the British Government for a change in British policies in Palestine to make impossible the repetition of the recent sinking of the Jewish refugee ship Struma in the Black Sea.

With all the power of the modern machine age at its disposal, mankind "still needs the power of God" to strengthen it in the performance of its daily tasks, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday morning in his sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

ON THE BATAAN PENINSULA, March 6 (Delayed) -- Underfed, overworked, treated with cruelty, Filipinos formed into labor battalions by the Japanese invaders of Luzon are subjected to an existence comparable in some instances to that of medieval galley slaves.

Although war demands are taking internes,resident physicians and nurses from New York'svoluntary and city hospitals, these institutions arewell organized to handle major casualties in thecity through eight emergency field units and 716medical teams for day and night squads staffed by2,140 internes, residents, nurses and auxiliarypersonnel, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Commissionerof Hospitals, said in his annual report to Mayor LaGuardia, which was made public yesterday.

HAVANA, March 8 -- More than 12,000 fanaticos jammed Tropical Park and overflowed down to the field today as the Dodgers and the Cuban All-Stars concluded their exhibition series by splitting a double-header.

The sixth of a series of "priorities round tables," which will be devoted to the printing and publishing industries, has been announced by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc. The meeting will be held in the association's assembly room tomorrow at 2 P.M. and is one of a series of meetings devoted to specific industrial groups.
A preview of Easter styles could be seen on Parkand Fifth Avenues yesterday when record temperatures seemed to indicate that Spring or a reasonable facsimile thereof was upon the city.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Commending the publishing and broadcasting industries "by and large" for "excellent" cooperation with the Office of Censorship, Byron Price, director, warned tonight that "dark hours may be ahead for free speech in the United States" if the present system of voluntary censorship proved a failure.

The orchestra of the New Friends of Music presented its second successive all-Mozart program late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. This time it was under its regular conductor, Fritz Stiedry. Joseph Szigeti, violinist, was the soloist.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 8 -- Merrill (Mezzie) Barber, Norwich University senior and crack jumper who last year turned his skiing skill to all phases of the sport, today was acclaimed as the country's most versatile skier after winning the national and Eastern four-event championships, held in ideal conditions at the Belknap Mountains Recreational Center.

Another bracket in the national invitation tournament which opens at Madison Square Garden on March 17 has been filled. Announcement was made yesterday that the University of Toledo had been invited -- and had promptly accepted -- an invitation to join West Texas State and Rhode Island State in the fifth annual post-season classic.

Advertising campaigns for men's Spring clothing and furnishings will get under way this week and their extent will be guided by the public's buying psychology. Fear of shortages and of reduced quality created a buying boom in January which brought sales gains as high as 150 per cent over 1941 and now there is worry that the announcement last week of style changes may revive the buying spurt.
BERLIN, March 8 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German communique said today:

The Japanese invaded Java hardly more than a week ago. Desultory fighting may still continue, but they have already overwhelmed the island. That tragic farewell of "Long Live the Queen" from Bandung's abandoned radio station seems to have announced the blackout of Allied power in all the Dutch Indies.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., March 8 -- A large Army plane from Langley Field has been missing on a routine training flight over the North Carolina coast since Thursday, and the Army public relations office said today its crew of eight was feared lost.

LONDON, March 8 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler has arrived in Kiev, occupied capital of the Ukraine, to establish German Army headquarters for a Spring offensive in which he expects to hurl against Russia about 280 divisions totaling more than 5,000,000 Axis troops, Stockholm dispatches said tonight.
TOLUCA, Mexico, March 8 (AP) -- Governor Alfredo Zarate Albarran, Governor of the State of Mexico, died today from bullet wounds inflicted Thursday night at a party in this State capital.

Throughout the United States 1,500,000 individuals have contributed in one way or another to the work of the British War Relief Society, Inc., according to its first annual report, made public yesterday. The report emphasized the need for continuing and possibly increasing the assistance being given through the society to the "front line of defense" in Great Britain.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The War Production Board announced today the reorganization of its Bureau of Industry Operations and the establishment of twenty-four industry branches.

VICHY, France, March 8 -- Religious services for the victims of Tuesday night's air raid on suburbs of Paris were observed throughout France today in a spirit of unmitigated grief. Not a word of resentment was spoken. Public gatherings were held with quiet dignity.

WITH BRITISH NAVY, in the Mediterranean, March 8 -- A British motor launch which bears no name, the smallest seagoing fighting ship in the British Navy and the newly born baby sister of the destroyer and corvette, is proving itself an effective instrument in the unceasing warfare against marauding U-boats and aircraft in this sea.

MARION, S.C., March 8 -- More than 500 residents of Marion met at the court house Thursday and adopted a resolution demanding that Congress and the President put a stop to strikes which "are endangering our sons in the armed forces and our country's very existence."
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Two American aces of the First World War who between them shot down thirty-four German planes will set out tomorrow to help teach youthful fliers of the present Army.

An investor bought from the Puritan Building and Loan Association a one-story factory building on a plot 120 by 100 feet on Hillside Avenue, Newark, N.J., through Leo Flaster, broker. The seller is in liquidation and was represented by the trustees.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- No agreements made by industry members with the Office of Price Administration pursuant to the Emergency Price Control Act of 1942 would violate anti-trust laws, Leon Henderson said today. The terms of the act, the Price Administrator said, obviate such a possibility.

Total shipments by domestic mills of all types of hosiery during January this year, amounting to 12,869,303 dozen pairs, were the largest for any January in the history of the industry, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

IN the search for some hint of how war conditions might influence the big league pennant races, this ready reader turned back some pages of history and looked up the final standings of the big league clubs for the seasons of 1917 and 1918, at which time, it may be remembered with a sad smile, this nation was engaged in "a war to end all wars."

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Scattered liquidation developed last week in oats futures on the Board of Trade here and that grain lost 1/2 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel in the week, with May closing yesterday at 55 7/8 cents, July at 55 3/8 and September at 55 5/8.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- David O. Selznick has signed Cary Grant to play the male lead opposite Dorothy McGuire in the film version of Rose Franken's play, "Claudia," which Miss Franken and her husband, William Brown Meloney, are adapting to the screen.

The percentage of women now employed in war industries is only a fraction of that at the peak of the last World War, the National Industrial Conference Board pointed out yesterday, adding that it "now appears necessary" to conduct a national labor registry to determine how many women are available and able to take war production jobs.

Five Broadway theatres will bring in new films during the week. On Wednesday the Paramount will present "The Fleet's In," starring Dorothy Lamour with William Holden, Eddie Bracken and the Jimmy Dorsey band. Also on Wednesday the Roxy, opening a day earlier than usual, will present "Song of the Islands," which numbers among its principal players Betty Grable, Thomas Mitchell, Jack Oakie and Victor Mature.

Visibility had dropped to two miles and a brisk wind added to the difficulty at 10 o'clock yesterday morning when First Class Scout Donald Walsh of Troop 472, Kips Bay Boys Club, stepped to the telescope on the observation tower of the Empire State Building. The telescope was trained on the roof of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

Mayor La Guardia reported "regretfully" yesterday the suspension of thirty-two plumbing inspectors by Commissioner William Wilson of the Department of Housing and Building, pending a departmental trial on charges of accepting gratuities from plumbing contractors.

Warning that we can't fight the devil with his own tactics, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer declared yesterday that the Christian gospel is "marked urgent" as never before and that the Kingdom of God is about to lay its finger on us in judgment.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- Manager Joe McCarthy threw three of his veteran hurlers at the Cardinals today in the teams' third grapefruit league contest, but St. Louis scored its first victory, 4 to 2. Unearned runs saved the world champions from a shutout.

PORT MORESBY, Papua, New Guinea, March 8 -- The Japanese, making a new move against Australia, landed troops early today at Salamaua, Northeast New Guinea. Salamaua is only 150 miles -- or forty-five minutes' flying time -- from this town in Australia's outer defenses and 400 miles from the Australian mainland.

Pleasant precursors of Spring are the peas that may be seen in metropolitan markets. The plump, green pods with their soft, velvety texture are bright vision on a brisk March morning. And at the moment peas are even more practical than they are pretty.

The practice of the Congressional Record is to print all matter, whether or not delivered in actuality on the floor of either house of Congress, as desired by any member. Such a lack of inhibition goes far toward explaining the uselessness of the Record to most non-members, except for historical or research purposes.

LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- The London Daily Mail cited the United States Navy Department's statement today regarding The Mail's story of "great convoys" of American troops in the Pacific as "complete vindication" and said "protests of the noisier newspapers forced official revelation of the one real military secret involved."

Asserting that "the specter of defeat very definitely shows itself in each communique," William P. Witherow, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, yesterday addressed an appeal to the 8,000 members of the association challenging every manufacturer to rise to the "supreme test of the nation" and "turn the tide of war" in the next ten months by speeding production to the maximum.

LONDON, March 8 (U.P.) -- The authoritative commentator of The Sunday Times of London, "Scrutator," said today that the naval phase of the Java campaign was one in which the Netherland bastion could have been saved most easily, and concluded its review with the question:

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Roosevelt is expected to appeal to the farmers tomorrow night in his fight against the Congressional farm group which is trying to prevent the sale of government-owned crop surplusses at prices below parity.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Lard futures on the Board of Trade are selling at the highest prices permitted by the Office of Price Administration, and while there has been talk that the ceiling might be raised on fats and oils, this view cannot be confirmed in any quarter.

What has become of those 200,000 youths, about half of our first selectees, who were rejected as physically unfit for military service? Last October the President announced that they would be rehabilitated at Government expense and then inducted. He also suggested that something would be done on "broader lines."

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Springlike weather prevailed in some sections of the Central West last week. The frost has commenced to leave the ground, but there has been little or no field work as the soil is much too wet to work. However, some progress in seeding oats is reported in the drier sections of the Southwest, but as a whole this work would be facilitated by a period of dry weather.

IN writing her memoirs Genevieve Tabouis, the French columnist who learned to give the intricacies of news of foreign affairs the high seasoning of dog-wagon cooking and became one of the most popular journalists of Europe, is emotionally concerned with two topics: herself and the causes behind her exile.

LONDON, March 8 -- A great tidying up has been going on here in the ten months since the Luftwaffe interrupted its effort to raze London to take up the more urgent mission of destroying the Soviet armies at Adolf Hitler's bidding.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 8 -- A test blackout of ninety-four square miles of Westchester County between 9:03 and 9:20 here tonight was called "highly satisfactory" by Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, chairman of the County Defense Council, which next Sunday night will try a blackout of the whole county.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx said yesterday that an investigation by him had revealed that city employes "on vacation" and city-owned materials were used last November to pave an antique Belgian courtyard at the estate of Edward J. Flynn, Democratic National Chairman and Bronx party leader, at Lake Mahopac, Putnam County.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 8 (U.P.) -- Competent observers were resigned today to the fact that the Japanese, with effective resistance in Java crushed, were in a position to take over New Guinea and other islands north of Australia in preparation for an attack on the Australian mainland and New Zealand.
HONOLULU, March 8 -- Hawaiian politicians today were beginning to prepare for the Fall election which they are not sure will be held, since the territory is under martial law.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 8 -- Joe Louis boxed four rounds today with as many sparring partners. This marked his first boxing for his encounter with Abe Simon on March 27 in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Army Emergency Fund.

Cotton prices continued to move within a narrow range last week and changes were relatively unimportant. At the close of trading on Saturday, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 9 to 18 points.

In the name of rapprochement, eminently desirable between the people of the United States and the nations of South America, a concert of music by South American composers was given under the auspices of the League of Composers yesterday afternoon in the New York Public Library.
TOKYO, Monday, March 9 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded in San Francisco) -- Imperial Headquarters announced today that Japanese forces had occupied Rangoon, Burma.

LONDON, March 8 -- Japanese forces that for days have been concentrating east of the Sittang River have at last begun to move west in what is assumed here to be the initial step for an assault on Rangoon.

The continued though reduced successes of the Germans in their submarine attacks on our Atlantic coastal shipping last week were a dangerous drain upon the shipping pool of the United Nations, the inadequate size of which is already the principal restrictive factor in our war effort.

AN AUSTRALIAN PORT, March 8 -- With the apparently imminent loss of Java giving the Japanese access to the Indian Ocean, the sea connection between the British and Allied forces in India, the Middle East and Africa and the Australians and Americans in Australia will now be very difficult to maintain, in the opinion of observers here today.

Attempts on my part to salvage paper bags are met variously by tradesmen: one smirks depreciatingly, though the returned bag has only contained a glass packaged product. Another wants to charge the customer for bags -- he may have something there. A third is proud of a customer bringing back an egg carton time and again for repacking.

LONDON, March 8 -- Java has not sued for peace, the Netherland Government here asserted today in an emphatic denial of Japanese claims that the defenders of the major Netherlands Indies island had asked for an armistice.

While virtually all but one winner in Saturday's I.C.A.A.A.A championships will be on hand for the Knights of Columbus games which bring New York's indoor track campaign to a close at Madison Square Garden next Saturday night, it will be the post-graduate athletes who will command the greatest interest.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 8 (AP) -- A post-election dispute that threatened national repercussions developed in Entre Rios Province today between Conservatives and Radicals over returns that gave a majority to Congressional candidates of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo, exponent of Argentine isolationism.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 (AP) -- Arrest of 105 Japanese aliens was reported by the FBI tonight in a drive directed at leaders and active members of Japanese secret societies.

NAVAL BASE, MAGDALENA BAY, Lower California, March 8 (AP) -- Mexican troops and fighting material are streaming constantly into strategic posts on the West Coast guarding the United States left flank, and General Lazaro Cardenas, the Commander in Chief in this vital area, declared tonight that Mexico would make the utmost sacrifice to help beat the Axis powers.
CHICAGO, March 8 -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored in every period to defeat the Brooklyn Americans, 6 to 1, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 12,883 persons at the Chicago Stadium.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose by 0.3 per cent to 103.4. This rise is almost wholly a reflection of higher prices for agricultural raw materials, as evidenced by the fact that the raw materials major group rose by 0.8 per cent and the farm products subgroup rose by 1.3 per cent.

New high records in sales volume and profit were set by the Celanese Corporation of America in 1941, according to the annual report of Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president, issued today. Net profit of $7,105,685 for 1941 was equal to $3.43 a share on 1,376,551 common shares, comparing with $6,376,896, or $3.38 a share on 1,112,788 common shares, in 1940.

KANSAS CITY, March 8 -- Urging the American people to accept willingly "a Spartan existence" for the sake of victory, Alf M. Landon, Republican candidate for President in 1936, said today that it was up to the American people "to decide how long this war will last."

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Masaharu Homma, who was reported, in information received by General MacArthur on Bataan Peninsula and announced by the War Department today, to have killed himself, was commander of the Japanese Fourteenth Army.

DETROIT, March 8 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, hottest National Hockey League team in the last fortnight, achieved their fifth straight home victory tonight by defeating the rebuilt Boston Bruins, 3 to 1, before 8,464 spectators. Detroit has been beaten only once in its last eight starts.
CHUNGKING, China, March 8 (U.P) -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek called on China's nearly 200,000,000 women today to help win the war by redoubling their efforts to increase production in volunteer work.
VICHY, March 8 -- From the financial point of view the outstanding event of the past week was the conversion of two issues of rentes with exchange guarantees -- the 4s of 1925 and the 4 1/2s of 1937.

America's first-ranking woman contract bridge player added another championship title to her long list of victories last night, when Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York, playing with Edward Hymes Jr., won the Eastern States mixed-pair championship from a field of seventy-two pairs.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 8 (AP) -- Free French forces wrought havoc on three fortified Italian positions in Fezzan, a district in the south of Tripolitania, after a 1,200-mile journey from the Lake Chad region, in the north of French Equatorial Africa, it was confirmed here today.

Wood will be worn this season--wood eases on lipsticks, wooden tops on bottles, and even "woven" wood for campacts. In a national crisis, with priority raising its head on all sides, beauty has gone back to nature.

The need for wartime clothing conservation measures has resulted in the establishment of evening classes in remodeling and repairing worn clothing at Pratt Institute and the Y.W.C.A., both in Brooklyn. Wardrobe planning and the proper use of remnants from cast-off clothing are features of the classes.

NEWARK, N.J., March 8 -- The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce, it was learned today, is making its own survey to check charges of Irving Abramson, State C.I.O. president, that war industry in North Jersey is operating at only 49 per cent of capacity because of its failure to utilize full second and third shifts.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 8 -- Showing blank spaces in her trade with Asia and Europe, except Great Britain and Sweden, Brazil ended January with total exports amounting to 624,953 contos, gaining 138,911 over the same period in 1941. American nations, especially the United States, were responsible for the increase.

More than six million citizens are this month making their first acquaintance with a Federal income tax blank. A like number, many of whom previously filed returns but paid no tax, are this month making their first direct contribution to the cost of the National Government.

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 8 -- An imaginary raid by fifteen planes supposed to have been released from carriers off Long Island and carrying 6,000 incendiary and 200 high explosive bombs took place over the North Shore this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The War Department communique based on reports received until 1 P.M. follows:

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Rationing of all types of new trucks, truck tractors and trailers, to be administered through the joint facilities of the War Production Board and the Office of Defense Transportation becomes effective tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 -- More than 4,000 persons attended a funeral service for Tom Mooney today in the Civic Auditorium. Instead of vitriolic tirades which had marked many Mooney meetings in the past, speakers told of a worldwide threat to the democratic processes and a need for labor to unite and defend democracy.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Navy today issued a "final" report on the "Farr incident" in which it said that the dispatch printed in The London Daily Mail on Saturday and reprinted throughout this country reporting the movement of great convoys of American troops and material to the Southwest Pacific "contains no positive fact having any relation to new convoy operations" in that area.

PITTSBURGH, March 8 -- Still subject to minor variation upward and downward, the steel industry was able last week to reach a new high record for weekly steel ingot output when the operating rate for the country approximated 97 per cent of the revised rated steel capacity.
A Chicago stenographer and a British seaman who had carried on a correspondence for five years without once meeting each other finally came face to face yesterday in the plaza of Rockefeller Center.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 8 -- During the past fortnight Reichfuehrer Hitler has begun swinging into action new contingents of Central European and Balkan troops that are already being moved to the east for use in the anticipated Spring offensive against the Soviet Union.

MOSCOW, March 7 (delayed) -- The three-month-old Russian nonstop offensive does not show any sign of lagging in intensity. To the contrary, the fighting in at least four sectors is increasingly fierce -- around Leningrad, in the Lake Ilmen region, in the Ukraine and in the Crimea.

Declaring that it is of paramount importance that the government promote and maintain a strong spirit of patriotism and unity among all groups and between all units of government, the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America adopted, at its Winter meeting in Chicago last week, a resolution in which it reiterated its opposition to the Treasury's attempt to subject, by legislation, State and municipal bonds to the Federal income tax laws.

A nine-room and three-bath apartment at 30 East Fifty-fifth Street has been leased to Mrs. Marjorie W. Cunningham, through Huberth Huberth, brokers, one of the reports on residential renting received yesterday disclosed.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Navy issued for the Marine Corps today an account of the sinking of a Japanese cruiser on Dec. 11 and a submarine on Dec. 12 by Marine aviators at Wake Island before that tiny outpost fell to the enemy.

Renovation work is about to start on the old four-story building at 249 East Thirty-sixth Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue, owned by Peter Doelger, Inc. The building has been vacant for several years above the bar and grill occupying the ground floor.

Dorothy Barret made her solo debut last night in a dance recital at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, assisted by Esther Ostroff at the piano. Technically she proved to be exceptionally well equipped, producing her movement easily and controlling it excellently.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Republican majority in the Legislature moved tonight, on the eve of their consideration tomorrow of the State budget, to gain more credit for themselves for tax reduction and at the same time to afford additional fiscal relief for distressed cities, many of which face acute budgetary problems.

Evidence will be presented to the grand jury probably today or tomorrow against Eli Shonbrun, Madeline Webb and John D. Cullen, whom police of eleven States are seeking in connection with the murder last week of Mrs. Susan Flora Reich, wealthy Polish refugee.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Here at the invitation of President Roosevelt to report on plans and prospects for an invasion of the European Continent by the anti-Axis forces, Lieut. Gen. Andrew McNaughton, commander of the Canadian Corps in Great Britain, conferred today with the President and with General George C. Marshall and other naval and military leaders.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Brokers' commissions on war contracts again were brought to the attention of the House today with a claim by Representative Engel of Michigan that a sales corporation owned by three men had made $850,000 in a little more than a year on subcontracts from one company alone.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today proposals by the Laclede Gas Light Company of St. Louis and the Ogden Corporation, its parent, to extend for three years $12,000,000 in bond and note obligations of Laclede.

LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- The Russian capture of Sychevka, in a deep wedge between Rzhev and Vyazma, was believed tonight to have virtually completed a second huge-scale encirclement of German forces on the front northwest of Moscow.

Sentences ranging from probation to four years in prison were meted out yesterday by Federal Judge Gaston L. Porterie to sixteen of the fifty-three persons who pleaded guilty or were convicted in a $10,000,000 mail fraud in oil securities.

LONDON, March 9 -- Discrediting reports sent from here by The Associated Press to the effect that Prime Minister Churchill would soon be replaced by Sir Stafford Cripps, The Manchester Guardian declared flatly today in an editorial headed "Much Ado" that Britain is "really set on winning the war and until we find some one better to lead us we will stick to Mr. Churchill."

Little girls without noses are apt to be amusing, to other little girls, at least when they are only illustrations in a book. However, grown-ups probably will gain just as much pleasure from the gay, colorful Marie Laurencin portraits in "Les Petites Filles," one of the many French books to go on display starting next Monday and continuing until March 29 at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Fears that the President and other administration members would come out tonight in radio addresses as strongly opposed to the proposed measures now before Congress seeking to prevent sales of government-owned commodities at less than parity prices started a selling movement today which carried all before it.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A special House committee asserted today that this country will not achieve President Roosevelt's high armament production goals for 1942 or 1943 "if we follow prevailing procedure." Establishment of a single civilian-directed procurement agency for the Army, Navy, Maritime Commission and lease-lend was advocated.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday directed Brown Brothers Harriman Co. to turn over securities valued at $5,000,000 to the Colonial Trust Company for the account of the N.V. Nederlandsche Handelskantoor, a Netherlands concern with headquarters now in Curacao, Dutch West Indies.

For weeks the propaganda loudspeaker of Berlin has been telling the world in general and the German people in particular of colossal preparations for a Spring drive against the Russians, and that the Russian Winter had made it impossible to carry out the General Staff's plans on time.

Fresh evidence of the continuing toll taken by Axis U-boats in United States and Caribbean waters was revealed last night in reports of the torpedoing -- possibly by an Italian submarine -- of a Brazilian cargo ship off Newport News, Va., and the sinking of two American vessels, one near Haiti and the other twenty miles off the eastern tip of Cuba.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Perhaps the most tangled controversy of facts and wartime policy that has been posed for the WPB and Congress is that arising from the construction by the Rural Electrification Administration of transmission power lines to war industrial plants. The center of the argument is in the Southwest, but the issue is general.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The War Department put its streamlined reorganization into effect today, giving added importance to the air forces and creating a more youthful General Staff reduced to a fifth of its former size.

Mrs. Charles Harrison Goddard will give a luncheon Thursday at Hampshire House for Mrs. Frank N. Doubleday, president of the National Plant, Flower and Fruit Guild, and other officers sponsoring the lecture in behalf of the Guild to be given by Duncan Aikman on "What the New Inter-American Unity Means," on Monday at the Colony Club.

LONDON, March 9 -- Faith in the fighting spirit of their fellow-countrymen in Java led officials of the Netherland Government here tonight steadfastly to deny the formal claim by Tokyo today that the main Netherland and Allied forces there had surrendered to the Japanese.
MOSCOW, March 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The National Progress League of Chicago and its officers, Frank J. Mackey and Harold C. Sherman, have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with promotion of the sale of history books by deceptive use of the name "Military Order of the Purple Heart" and the false statement that the proceeds would be used to combat subversive activities in the United States.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 9 -- Paris newspapers arriving here today belatedly gave details of the killing for which twenty hostages have been executed and twenty others may suffer the same fate.

HONOLULU, March 9 -- A former lieutenant in the Japanese Army, found in possession of maps showing military and naval establishments in California, was sentenced to five years of hard labor and fined $5,000 in Provost Court here today.

More than 1,000 buyers, a new record, attended the opening yesterday of the American Toy Fair, being held under the auspices of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. at the Hotel McAlpin and 200 Fifth Avenue. They found rationing of orders in effect on most lines of playthings, which featured substitutions of non-critical materials for metal and rubber, design simplification and a drastic cut in the variety of items to aid the country's war program.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Impending edicts will make no attempt to eliminate the style factor in women's apparel, R.R. Guthrie, chief of the textile, clothing and leather goods branch of the War Production Board, said today, but from the viewpoint of cloth conservation it is important to avoid radical fashion changes.

Two additional names were placed before the New York Stock Exchange nominating committee at its second open meeting of the year yesterday afternoon as suggestions for the office of chairman of the board of governors. Last week Robert L. Stott, the incumbent, and George R. Kantzler, now a governor, were recommended for the post.

In a short-wave address to Sweden yesterday Carl Sandburg, poet and biographer of Lincoln, praised the people of that nation for having prepared to "resist any outside power that might try to enter your country and take away your independence."

Latin-American solidarity with the United States is now an established fact and Brazil is ready to defend it with all her energies, Dr. Arthur de Sousa Costa, Minister of Finance of Brazil, told a dinner gathering last night at the Yale Club.

CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Prices of hogs rose 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds today, starting the eighth consecutive week of advance, as the Surplus Marketing Administration, government purchasing agency, lifted prices at which it was willing to buy pork and lard.

SECRET AGENT NO. 167-D (ring twice) reports from San Francisco that a Central California vegetable merchant has in mind a scheme to help the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Washington Senators in the big league races up ahead. Already, in letters, he has outlined his plans to Mr. L.S. MacPhail, the strong, silent man of the Dodger club, and Mr. Clark Calvin Griffith, the owner of the Senators.

War deaths are not all on the battlefield. In the long run, in fact, the greatest effect on population may be measured in increased civilian death rates. The statistical yearbook of the League of Nations, just published in Switzerland, shows that in Germany and England the war increase through 1940 was about 1 per cent, in Belgium about 3 per cent.

Fifteen hundred persons from every craft in the theatre -- actors, stagehands, musicians and technicians -- will join hands tonight to present for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society the largest stage show ever given at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 9--A wife must pay income taxes on proceeds from an annuity given to her before divorce if the decree relieves the husband of the burden of support, the Supreme Court ruled in an opinion by Justice Douglas. A dissent by Justice Frankfurter was shared by Chief Justice Stone.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 10 -- British commentators voiced surprise today at the reorganization of the United States Naval High Command, and particularly at the establishment of the post of Commander of American fleet forces in European waters.

CHUNGKING, China, March 9 -- "It is quite clear that the appointment of Naotake Sato as the new Japanese Ambassador to Moscow, replacing General Yoshitsugu Tatekawa, bears a strong parallel to the mission of Saburo Kurusu to Washington last November," said General No Ying-chin, Chinese Minister of War, today.

Mayor La Guardia told 1,000 employes and guests of the Wheeler Shipbuilding Corporation in Whitestone, Queens, yesterday that "the sooner Washington realizes that the quicker and better they want something done they must come to New York City, we will get something done."

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Emergency authority to the Securities and Exchange Commission to suspend for the duration of the war the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 would be granted under terms of a measure introduced in the House today by Representative Paddock of Illinois.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 10 -- British bombers were believed to have returned to Western Germany last night and early today to strike new blows at Nazi war industries in a newly unleashed air offensive.
LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:
