WASHINGTON, March 9 -- After approving provisions of the $700,000,000 Agriculture Appropriation Bill which assure growers of basic crops returns at 1ong-demanded parity levels, the House of Representatives deadlocked late today over whether the full parity prices should be achieved with continued Treasury assistance or out of the country's household budgets.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 9 (AP) -- Charles (Chick) Werner, Penn State track coach, said today it "seems like throwing mud" to question whether Norman Gordon was eligible for competition in the indoor I.C. 4-A track meet at New York on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The dispatch of a new Japanese Commander in Chief to the Philippines gave added strength today to the "persistent reports" relayed yesterday that Lieut. Gen. Masaharu Homma had ended his life some two weeks ago because of his failure to vanquish a foe possessing only a fraction of the Japanese numerical strength.

The largest theft of automobile tires reported in New York since rationing began occurred early yesterday morning when three young men robbed the Pilgrim Gas Station at 1043 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, of eighty-five to ninety new tires, worth $1,275 under normal market conditions.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department urged New York City health authorities today to postpone action on a reported plan to reduce the number of country milk plants serving the metropolitan market.

LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- The last great Dutch position on Java, Bandung, on the high plateau, has fallen, and the Japanese enemy, now having overrun substantially all the island, appeared tonight to be stamping out the last bright, gallant sparks of Allied resistance.

Net earnings of the American Home Products Corporation and its subsidiaries in 1941 amounted to $7,531,699 before deductions for income and excess profits taxes, representing an increase of $1,260,887 over earnings of $6,270,811 before taxes in 1940, Alvin G. Brush, chairman, reported yesterday.

The war should not be allowed to interrupt the continuity of our art and learning, Mayor LaGuardia said yesterday afternoon in presenting two awards at the Second Regional High School Art Exhibit at R.H. Macy Co., Inc.

In setting forth the Treasury's tax proposals Secretary Morgenthau said that taxes must be levied "so as to withdraw the greatest possible volume of purchasing power." Presumably this means that taxes must be levied where the greatest volume of purchasing power exists. The figures of national income for last year just published by the Department of Commerce throw some light on this.

Prominent citizens including Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt, chairman of Young America Wants to Help, have issued statements "to help persuade" the Board of Higher Education to continue the life of Townsend Harris High School, it was announced yesterday by the Townsend Harris committee, a joint faculty alumni group.

A group of bondholders, known as the King Edward Hotel Corporation, of which Solomon Zauderer is president, has purchased the sixteen-story King Edward Hotel at 120 West Forty-fourth Street, containing 300 rooms and four stores. The building is on a plot 75 by 100 feet and is assessed for $755,000.

MAYWOOD, Ill., March 9 (U.P.) -- A month ago the Rev. Roy W. Merrifield read to his congregation a list of soldiers from Western Chicago suburbs fighting with General Douglas MacArthur in Bataan. In conclusion he said:

The cream of Lord Taylor's Spring selections was offered for inspection yesterday afternoon. These interesting clothes were highly representative of what some of the best among the ready-to-wear designers have prepared for smart women for town wear.

OTTAWA, March 9 (Canadian Press) -- A dovetailed wheat and feed grains program for Canada was announced in the House of Commons today, providing for the purchase of 280,000,000 bushels of wheat at an increased price and the setting of minimum prices for oats, barley and flaxseed.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 9 -- During a fierce air battle over the Cyrenaican front a Royal Australian Air Force squadron flying American-built Kittyhawk fighters shot down three German dive bombers and six Italian fighters yesterday. None of the Kittyhawks was lost.

An interpretation of two War Production Board orders, according to which inventories of floor covering retailers would be limited to one-sixth of their 1941 volume, caused considerable confusion in the trade yesterday. The interpretation was reported to have been made by William J. Cheyney, vice president of the National Retail Furniture Association, at a meeting of retailers in Boston.

R. McAvoy of the Columbia U.C. upset the third seeded player, D. Lyall of the Princeton Club, to reach the third round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C championship at the Harvard Club last night. It was a close fight, with the final score being 15 -- 11, 10 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 8.

LONDON, March 9 -- With a total increase of 356,983 over 1941, the figures for Britain's budget group of departments classified as the central government and finance, submitted today, reflected a shift in activity produced by the war.

A ten-year lease calling for an aggregate rental of about $130,000 has been arranged with the Royal Manufacturing Company of Duquesne, manufacturers and distributors of medicinal products, on the five-story structure at 100 Somers Street and 73 Stone Avenue, Brooklyn, by Kalmon Dolgin, Inc., broker.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, March 10 (AP) -- Spurred by the large-scale Japanese invasion of New Guinea, the Australian Government took over today broad powers to put public and private property to the torch, kill livestock and remove civilians from any threatened area of this continental commonwealth.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 9 -- Supervised boards with local civilian representation would be set up to adjudge the loyalty of German and Italian aliens in the Far West's 2,000-mile-long military area under a program considered here today by the Tolan House investigating committee and John J. McCloy, assistant secretary of war.

KANSAS CITY, March 9 (AP) -- Kentucky State College of Murray, Ky., last year's runner-up and this year's favorite, fell in a stunning upset in today's opening round of the national intercollegiate basketball tournament. East Central State, Ada, Okla., toppled Kentucky State's five, 46 -- 45, in overtime.
MELBOURNE, March 9 (UP) -- The Australian War Cabinet, assembled in emergency session in

NEWARK, N.J., March 9 -- Declaring that New Jersey consistently had ranked among the "top States" in war production, the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce denied here today a charge made on Saturday by Irving Abramson, president of the State Industrial Union Council, C.I.O., that war industry in Northern New Jersey was utilizing only 49 per cent of its productive capacity.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 9 (UP) -- Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, Lieutenant Governor General of the Netherlands Indies, was in Australia today to mold a new army from Netherland forces that have escaped the Japanese.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 -- Entertaining featured the opening today of Tropical Park for the Spring meet of horse racing. Among those having luncheon and box parties were Mrs. James Barlow Cullum of Sewickley, Pa.; Henry L. Straus of Baltimore, president of the Gables Racing Association; Charles A. Munn of Palm Beach, Thomas Henry of Detroit and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Rudgely.

At the head of a list that we unoriginally call Life Small Pleasures is the name of a certain spice shop. A visit to this friendly oasis has a soothing effect in a world where even sugar and rubber tires and silk stockings present problems.
A few days ago I dropped in at a newsreel theatre on Broadway to kill an hour or so of time between appointments.

WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Feb. 23 (Delayed) -- United States fliers and anti-aircraft gunners of this task force of the Pacific Fleet had their first brush with Japanese airmen on Feb. 20 and finished the day with a neat batting average of .900.

An inventory of the woman power of the country should be taken by the government and taken now, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, declared last night at a meeting at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- In instructions directed particularly to large steel mills which have several operations under one roof, the War Production Board's iron and steel branch today warned that orders for steel must be produced in proper sequence of preference rating regardless of the product involved.

Though American attention has been focused on the amazing gains of the Japanese in the Far East, let us not forget that Hitler is resourceful and that this is March. Whether through superstition, intuition or a cold-blooded calculation of chances, Hitler has usually chosen the "Ides of March" for his most spectacular coups.

It smacks pretty much of the obvious to stress the traditional rivalry angle of tomorrow night's City College-New York University and St. John's-St. Francis basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, but this intangible factor has the weight of reality to the parties most directly concerned.

The contemplated change from street cars to buses on De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, part of the modernization planned with the removal of elevated structures in the borough, may be deferred because of the war, it was learned yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 -- Fears that the purchase of Johnny Mize from the Cardinals last December might prove a dud for the Giants because of the recent recurrence of a shoulder ailment were lessened considerably today when the husky first sacker went back to full-time duty.

A profit of $1,609,706, or $2.81 a share on 573,183 shares, was realized from operations in 1941 by Eastern Air Lines, Inc., according to the annual financial statement to stockholders issued yesterday from the office of Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager.

Wilmington, N.C., will enter the market on March 17 with $635,000 of sewer and water works bonds for which bidders are to name the interest rate. The bonds, dated April 1, 1942, are to mature on April 1, 1944 to 1982.

Events tonight: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, Emanuel Feuermann, 'cello, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conducting, concert for members of Philharmonic -Symphony League, Hotel Plaza, 8:45; Leota Lane, soprano, and Dorothy Kendrick, piano, joint recital, Steinway Hall, 8:40; Virginia Blair, soprano, and Gordon Gifford, baritone, joint recital, Barbizon Recital Hall, 8:30.

The five-story apartment house at 1001-15 Seventy-ninth Street, North Bergen, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, trustees for the mortgage certificate holders of the Fidelity Union Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company, to the P.E. Realty Company, Cecil T. Woolsey, president.

The first establishment of ceiling prices on a product by the American and Canadian governments simultaneously is expected before April 1, when maximum quotations are to be set for newsprint, it was learned here yesterday.

British aerial bombing of the industrial suburbs of Paris is "one of the sad necessities" of the war because the workers there, under Nazi pressure, are turning out armaments to kill soldiers of the United Nations, including the Free French, Professor Jean Perrin, former Nobel Prize winner and member of the Institut de France, declared last night.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 23 per cent last week over the comparative week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The action of the Federal Reserve Board in tightening installment credit terms through its amendment 3 to Regulation W, effective on March 23, is calculated to bring under the regulation many lenders and sellers of durable goods who have not heretofore been licensed under the regulation.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Republican leadership in the State and in the Legislature decided today as a matter of party policy that it will not embark on a political fight with Governor Lehman over defense legislation at the current session, but will continue trying to work out a negotiated major defense bill in conferences with the Governor.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 9 -- Ten Japanese bombers raided Port Moresby, capital of Papua, New Guinea, this morning, attacking service installations. Good anti-aircraft shooting kept the planes at 24,000 feet.

Several new books on different fields of science are due within the next ten days. For the most part they are in the popular vein. England's experience with nervous disorders and mental breakdowns resulting from air raids will be reported in a book to be brought out by Norton on Thursday.

Women in America are going to become a determining factor in public affairs as never before, not only for the duration of the war but after the peace, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, told seventy student leaders of campus organizations yesterday when he conducted the first session of a course in leadership training introduced this term by the Hunter Student Self-Government Association.
AIKEN, S.C., March 9 (U.P.) -- Directors of the United States Trotting Association, holding their annual meeting here, predicted tonight the sport would enjoy a boom year.

Greater production of dried milk will help win the war, according to a report to the American Chemical Society by Carlos C. Van Leer Jr. of Washington, former assistant to the Director of the Budget. The report, made public yesterday here by the society, says that 61,000,000 quarts daily of separated milk, now of limited commercial value, could be turned into an asset that would help in the "battle of transportation."

LONDON, March 9 -- The Japanese flag flies over Rangoon tonight. This grim news was given in a communique from New Delhi, India, saying that British forces started to withdraw from the capital of Burma on Saturday. Before abandoning the city, which had been the principal port of entry for the Burma Road, the British destroyed everything that could have been used by the enemy.

The young South American sculptor, Irene Hamar, is having her first one-man show in the United States. Sponsored by the Brazilian Government, it opened yesterday at the Acquavella Galleries, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street. It is reported that the work of Miss Hamar, who is 29 years old, is well known in both Brazil and Argentina.

TOKYO, March 9 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Headquarters tonight claimed the conquest of the Netherlands Indies with the unconditional surrender of 93,000 Netherland troops and 5,000 British and Americans about Surabaya and Bandung in Java.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Japanese Government has sent General Tomoyuki Yamashita, the conqueror of Malaya and Singapore, into the Philippines to oppose the forces under General Douglas MacArthur, who have successfully withstood overwhelming invading forces for the past three months, the War Department reported today.
Delicate in treatment and tone and practical in essence were the ensembles designed by Jean Schlumberger and presented yesterday at Chez Ninon.

The Loyalty insurance group, headed by the Firemen's Insurance Company of Newark, entered the field of bomb insurance yesterday in which the Rhode Island and General of Seattle have been the sole direct participants up to the present.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Complete command of the American Navy in war operations shifted tonight to Admiral Ernest J. King, as Secretary Knox relieved Admiral Harold R. Stark of the post of chief of naval operations and combined this title with Admiral King's current one of Commander in Chief, United States Fleet.
BRAZZAVILLE, French, Equatorial Africa, March 9 (Reuter) -- The Free French issued this communique today:

Tonight, for the first time since the faithful turned out on Christmas night, 1916, to pay homage to Maude Adams in what was then "the new Barrie play," New Yorkers will have an opportunity to witness Sir James's cherished fantasy when the curtain goes up at 8:30 P.M. on "A Kiss for Cinderella" at the Music Box.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 -- Tanned, fit and almost ready for the National League starting bell, the Dodgers checked in at a Miami hotel for an overnight stop before proceeding to their Florida training base at Daytona Beach tomorrow.

Miklos Scwalb, Hungarian pianist who arrived here five months ago after escaping from German occupied Paris and enduring many of the vicissitudes of war, last night gave his first New York recital at Town Hall. He proved to be an interesting player with a brilliant technique.

With a news background not pitched to generate any enthusiasm, the stock market plodded wearily along yesterday in the dullest and narrowest session since last June. While the close revealed prices holding their ground, the averages registered new lows.

Practical suggestions regarding the conservation of steel during the emergency have been made by expert engineers to the OPM through a committee composed of members of the American Society of Civil Engineers. The committee's report, released by OPM is in the February edition of the society's magazine, Civil Engineering.
LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- The Government of the Netherlands issued this statement tonight about the situation in Java:

LONDON, March 9 -- Britain and Greece signed an agreement today pledging the closest cooperation for the successful prosecution of the war and setting forth that one of their war aims was complete liberation of the Hellenes and re-establishment of Greek freedom and independence.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 9 -- A head victory for G.W. Peak's Scotch Trap thrilled 8,814 spectators as the Gables Racing Association opened its second meeting of the season at Tropical Park today.

A limited amount of common stock of the State Street Investment Corporation of Boston will be offered to the public today by a nation-wide group of investment firms associated with the Massachusetts Distributors, Inc., underwriters of the first new capital financing undertaken by the fund since 1938.
Net sales of the Climax Molybdenum Company and its subsidiaries increased last year to $20,070,025 from $12,920,982 in 1940, according to the annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

In retail credit circles, the new installment selling regulations were described yesterday as "not as serious as they might be." The point was made that priorities, rationing and, in some instances, complete stoppage of production were already serving as major control factors affecting consumer durable goods such as refrigerators, washing machines, etc.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A ban on the sale and manufacture of firecrackers and "torpedoes" in order to conserve materials used in the manufacture of munitions was announced today by Dr. R.R. Sayers, Director of the Bureau of Mines.

The Union Electric Company of Missouri is expanding its installed generating capacity by 240,000 kilowatts, or 40 per cent, in order to meet the growing needs of war production in the St. Louis area, J. Wesley McAfee, president, announced yesterday in his 1941 annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Senate today began debate on the Langer case with Senator Lucas, in charge of the prosecution, under repeated fire from Democratic members as he began to read the charges of moral turpitude upon which the majority of the Privileges and Elections Committee bases its recommendation that the North Dakota Republican be unseated.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Roosevelt spoke by radio to the nation's farmers; his visitors included John G. Winant, Ambassador to Britain; Alexander W. Weddell, Ambassador to Spain; Leon Henderson, Price Administrator; Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, and the Canadian Minister and Lieut. Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton of the Canadian Army.

A $100-a-week underworld trigger man described in Kings County Court yesterday how he drove the death car in one of six murder assignments, gave the pre-arranged signal for the killing and then, twenty minutes later, while sipping a bottle of soda water, inquired of his gangland boss the identity of the victim.

Everywhere in the daily round the new faces confront you. A new face peers out at you from the bank teller's window when you stop in to find out the exact size of your bank balance -- guess for what! In the morning you step into the elevator cage at home and you look up, when, after a good many years, a new face says good morning.

With potential buyers still withholding important commitments to await further developments in Washington, the cotton market continued yesterday its quiet and aimless course. Scattered liquidation and hedging offers and selling by New Orleans interests induced a moderate downward trend and losses on the New York Cotton Exchange were 4 to 11 points.

TOKYO, March 9 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Allied forces in Java accepted a Japanese demand for unconditional surrender and ceased fighting today, turning over control of the Netherlands Indies island to the Japanese Army, the Domei news agency reported tonight.
Nearly 30,000 income tax payers and persons seeking information and help in filing their eturns flocked to the two collection offices of the Department of Internal Revenue in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The appointment of an Anglo-American Caribbean Commission was announced jointly in the White House and in London today for the purpose of making a study of social and economic problems in the British West Indies from which recommendations could be made for improving "the standards of living in all of the islands concerned."

General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it has put into effect a plan whereby its employes will be rewarded in defense savings bonds and stamps for suggestions for increasing production of their own jobs, improving quality, saving material, reducing waste or improving working conditions.

WEIRTON, W.Va., March 9 (AP) -- An independent union of Weirton Steel employes has asked the management of the National Steel Corporation subsidiary, for a $1.25 daily wage increase, the union's newspaper, The Weirton Worker, reported.
BERLIN, March 9 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's German High Command communique:

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 9 -- Pressure to allow the entry of motor cars for doctors was put on in the Assembly this afternoon during a discussion on the reorganization of the Health Department which, incidentally, calls for the introduction of five motor lorries for garbage collection.

A new plan to bring home to sportsmen the necessity for observing National Wildlife Week, held from April 12 to 18, inclusive, has been drawn up and will include trap and skeet shoots sponsored by clubs throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard told Senator Byrd today that elimination of Agriculture Department benefit payments to producers of sugar beets and sugar cane would cause "a drain on the Treasury" as well as higher sugar prices to consumers.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- American forces sufficiently strong to engage the Japanese in combat in the Southwestern Pacific are pouring into that region by convoys assembled and equipped in the three months since Japan precipitated the battle of the Pacific. This is apparent by material that it is now possible to publish.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Rationing of gasoline to consumers along the Atlantic seaboard, first through curtailing deliveries to dealers and subsequently through a formal rationing program under which automobile users will receive coupons, authorizing their purchases of gasoline, was reported to be imminent here tonight.

WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Feb. 20 (Delayed) -- Commenting on today's battle with the Japanese bombers, the commander of this task force said that the entire United States squadron had "attacked the enemy with determination and skill and deadly effect."

The Automotive Safety Foundation has brought forward some valuable recommendations in the matter of economy in the use of motor cars. It strongly endorses the "Michigan Plan," which calls for the rearrangement of shifts at manufacturing plants and of school and business hours so as to make possible a wider employment of public utility carriers.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- United States submarines operating in the Far East have sunk two more Japanese combat ships and severely damaged four others with hits by one or two torpedoes each, the Navy Department reported tonight. The latest compilation of new sinkings included a Japanese destroyer leader -- a heavy type of destroyer of more than 2,000 tons -- and a large naval tanker, or one presumably of about 12,000 tons displacement.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 9 -- "We will repulse it if there is an attempted invasion, we will hurl it back, but we must work as never before," Prime Minister Peter Fraser told New Zealanders in a nation-wide broadcast today.
WASHINGTON, March 9--President Roosevelt told the country tonight that the United States would have inflation "of a very dangerous kind" if all prices kept on going up.

Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order yesterday authorizing Thomas B. Gilchrist, general guardian of the property of Mrs. Pasquale Di Cicco, the former Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, to withdraw from the income of his ward's estate an additional $35,000 for expenses incurred in connection with her wedding on Dec. 28 and the setting up of her new home.

Panic buying of food products has generally subsided and consumer purchases are returning to more or less normal volume, the National American Wholesale Grocers Association reported yesterday following an informal survey of a number of its members in various sections of the country.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 9 -- The measures taken on Saturday by the Brazilian Government against Japanese diplomats will be extended to apply to Japanese civilians, it was learned today.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Because the Legislature has not acted on a proposed 25 per cent reduction in State income taxes, the State Tax Commission extended today until April 1 the time for filing returns of income tax withholding agents.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Admiral King assumed supreme command of all naval operations today. Relief of Admiral Stark with the delegation of his powers to Admiral King, was promptly interpreted by naval authorities as a streamlining process comparable to that by which the War Department recently was reorganized into three main divisions -- ground forces, air forces and service of supply -- all responsible directly to General George C. Marshall, the Chief of Staff.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended March 4 aggregated $11,757,000,000.

Following is the text of the address last night of President Roosevelt, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, on the anniversary of the Administration's farm program, together with the texts of the addresses of Vice President Wallace and Secretary Wickard, as supplied by The Associated Press:

MIAMI, Fla., March 9 -- A couple of players who almost were left out of the invitation list knocked the favorites out of the Miami Biltmore's international four-ball golf tournament today with a sterling exhibition of team-work.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 4: Increases of $103,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $113,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and $232,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

MOSCOW, March 9 (U.P.) -- Russian shock troops, in bloody fighting from house to house and street to street, are driving the Germans out of a key town tipping the easternmost spearhead inside the Soviet positions northwest of Moscow, the Red Army reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Curses and other objectionable words do not come within the Constitutional provisions safeguarding freedom of speech, the Supreme Court said today in unanimously sustaining a New Hampshire law under which a member of the Jehovah's Witnesses was convicted.

As art organizations go, the group called American Abstract Artists is still youthful. Its sixth annual exhibition has just opened in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, to remain until March 23.

Jose Raoul Capablanca of Havana and New York will be mourned not only in two countries but in the worldwide realm of chess. Though a genius to start with, champion at 12, he was without priggishness or conceit, handsome, polished, urbane, an honor to Columbia College and to his country.

Steel production this week will establish a new weekly high record of 1,654,500 net tons of ingots, comparing with the previous high mark of 1,651,100 last week, with 1,622,400 produced in the same week one month ago, and 1,594,500 in the corresponding week of 1941, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Intensive search was under way yesterday for Robert Lawson Kakerbeck, 19 years old, of Saw Mill River Road in the Worthington district of Greenburg, Westchester County, missing since Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (U.P.) -- Retail food prices continued to rise during the last half of February, with the exception of a few seasonal declines, Secretary Perkins said tonight in a report on the cost of eighteen important food items in nineteen major cities.

New campaigns on products, intended as wartime substitutes for established items, will help to maintain advertising expenditures to some degree, it was indicated yesterday. Newest products, which will be introduced soon to the public, include a wooden ice box, a "rubberless" wringer and dehydrated dog food.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- John G. Winant, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, said after a two-hour war conference with President Roosevelt today that he did not believe reports that the Churchill ill government would fall because of reverses in the Far East.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Senate and then the Assembly passed bills tonight permitting the New York City Council to order a referendum if the Board of Estimate attempted to increase the subway fare from five cents to seven or ten.

MANDALAY, Burma, March 9 (AP) -- The British have evacuated Rangoon, it was announced here tonight. Light enemy patrols were reported active in the region of Taukkyan, twenty-one miles north of Rangoon.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 9 -- Colombian property and investments of non-resident Axis nationals and non-resident citizens of countries occupied by Axis powers have been taken over by the government for administration, and the value involved may reach $50,000,000 or more, according to Hector Jose Vargas, chief administrator.

" Woman of The Year," the Katharine Hepburn-Spencer Tracy comedy, will enter its sixth and last week on Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall, thereby equaling the run of Miss Hepburn's "The Philadelphia Story" at the theatre last year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- "She Walks in Beauty," a screen adaptation of Henry James's novel, "The Wing of a Dove," published in 1902, will be produced by David O. Selznick, with Ingrid Bergman in the leading role, Selznick announced today. Filming is scheduled to start early this Summer, before Miss Bergman does "The Keys of the Kingdom." Franchot Tone will be tested this week for the role of Father Chisholm in "Keys."

Michael F. Drinkhouse, operator of the Churchill Restaurant at 139 Broadway, the Fleetwood at 39 Broadway and the Frontenac at 183 Varick Street, has leased the ground floor corner and basement in the Airlines Terminal Building at Park Avenue and Forty-second Street and will soon open there another eating establishment to be known as Churchill's Terminal Restaurant.

Engineers of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company have worked out an arrangement in aircraft factories whereby electric power is generated from airplane engines undergoing "break in" tests, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's 1941 annual report to stockholders.

BERLIN, March 9 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command reported today that Nazi troops had scored local successes in some sectors of the eastern front, but acknowledged that they were fighting "heavy defensive battles" in the south.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary Ickes approved today a plan to allocate available tanker space for movement of oil to the Atlantic Coast whereby participants would be assured space in proportion to their use of tankers from July 1, 1939 to June 30, 1941.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd in a letter to Dean James M. Landis today asked the latter to state whether the Office of Civilian Defense intended to undertake a "boondoggling" program of enrolling 25,000,000 persons to take up bowling to "roll their way to physical fitness."

PITTSBURGH, March 9 -- The Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers, gorged with rain and a run-off of melted snow, surged today toward a predicted crest of twenty-three feet at their confluence here to form the Ohio, as a gale, which at times reached a velocity of eighty miles per hour, lashed this district.

A certain young gentleman of our acquaintance (going on 5) enthusiastically describes the manoeuvres that take place before a dressing table as "putting on a party face." This process of donning a nice new complexion just before dinner is as refreshing and exhilarating as the biggest, chilliest martini in the city -- but we have a very special "paint pot complexion" in mind.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 9 -- Long Island University's basketball team had a terrific scare in its game with Springfield College tonight but managed to snatch enough points midway through the last half to gain a 57-to-55 decision.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary Knox commended two naval air force members today for risking their lives to render live bombs harmless so that four patrol planes at the San Diego air base could carry out their flights on schedule.
WASHINGTON, Merck 9 -- The Navy Department issued the following communique today:
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Louis Johnson, former assistant secretary of war, was appointed today chairman of the United States advisory mission that will go to India to assist in the war effort there.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Gregory Rice, the former Notre Dame distance flier, clipped more than seven seconds from the world record for the two and one-half mile run in the ninth annual Catholic University games here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, in connection with the application of the New York Curb Exchange for "when issued" dealing in the capital stock of The Niles-Bement-Pond Company, said today that it was "willing to consider revision of our 'when issued' trading rules so as to permit trading in some circumstances in the period between the directors' recommendation and the stockholders' approval."

BRAZZAVILLE, French Equatorial Africa, March 9 (AP) -- Free French forces stabbing across the sands of the great Fezzan desert region in Southwest Libya have smashed four Italian outposts in operations still proceeding, General Charles de Gaulle's military command announced here today.

The annual report of the British War Relief Society of the United States shows what an immense and useful enterprise it has become. Receipts since the inception of the organization have now reached $16,256,625, which is more than the contributions to all other American-British relief organizations combined. Yet these millions have been disbursed with an overhead expense of only 7.89 per cent.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 9 -- Four holdouts came into the Yankee fold today to brighten a day that was otherwise a washout. In their first appearance away from the St. Petersburg training base, the world champions bowed to the Senators by the amazing score of 9 to 2.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9 -- Spencer Miller Jr., a registered Republican who voted for President Roosevelt in 1932 and 1936 and who is "more concerned with partisanship as a principle than with party," was nominated by Governor Charles Edison, Demo crat, today as State Highway Commissioner to succeed E. Donald Sterner, Belmar Republican, whose resignation is to become effective April 29.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 9 -- Although operations in the Pacific have entered the fourth month, foreign military observers here do not vary in their opinion that Europe remains the principal theatre of the war -- so much so, indeed, that the creation of a second front now looms as a very definite possibility.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had placed $1,000,000,000 of insurance on its plants and equipments with the Factory Insurance Association as a protection not only against fire and windstorm damage, but also against sabotage and malicious mischief.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 9 -- King Gustav was resting easily tonight after a bladder operation performed at noon by three of the country's ablest surgeons. The King, who is 83 years old, stood the anesthetic well, according to one of his physicians, who added, "His Majesty has a heart like a boy's and he should live to be 100 if there are no complications."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 9 -- Acting ahead of schedule because of an injunction threat, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors ratified this afternoon the contracts with the Federal Government for development of an airport on property adjacent to Rye Lake in the estate area of Purchase.

In an address broadcast over a national network from Kansas City, Alf M. Landon has given as good an answer as can be given to a question every American has asked himself: How long will the war last? He thinks it depends upon how hard we work, and how soon we begin to work our hardest.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 9 -- A plea that the government release all idle WPA tools and equipment for use by local defense councils was made today by the Atlantic City Defense Council.

LONDON, March 9 -- The stock markets were depressed today on the week-end war news from the Far East. Gilt-edged issues remained steady and the home rails were fractionally better. Leading industrials were dull, with Marks Spencer, Imperial Tobacco, the breweries and Cable ordinary showing losses.

A plan to set up a shipbuilding center in the port of New York to train workers for shipyards and to give supplementel training to those already in the industry will be submitted to the Board of Education when it meets tomorrow, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The probability of a fight to the finish between the Administration and Congress over the question of subjecting persons now exempt under the income tax laws to direct levies or a general sales tax was heightened by two developments today.

One of the last American civilian to travel the Burma Road from Rangoon to Chungking, China, before it was closed by Japanese military operations was Dr. George A. Fitch, director of the Young Men's Christian Association's Emergency Service for Chinese Soldiers and coordinator between the Chinese Government and the Industrial Cooperatives, it was disclosed here yesterday by Dr. Fitch's wire, Mrs. Geraldine T. Fitch.

The proposed regulation of men's clothing to save wool is sound as far as it goes. But elimination of cutaways and trouser cuffs, or even the debatable two-trousered suits, is a half-hearted approach to the problem.

VICHY, France, March 9--British bombers flew over the Paris region and attacked and damaged a factory at Poissy yesterday, according to an announcement authorized tonight, but it is declared that there were no killed or injured.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- James M. Landis replied today to Senator Byrd's letter of yesterday asking whether the Office of Civilian Defense was engaged in a bowling project whereby 25,000,000 persons were "to bowl their way to physical fitness."

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday the arrest in St. Petersburg, Fla., of Frank A. Miller, 42 years old, former superintendent of the claim department of the Eagle Star Insurance Company, Ltd., at 90 John Street, accused of stealing $125,000 from the concern in the last six years.

Japanese forces are driving for Port Moresby, strongest base on the Australian mandate. This port is protected on its land side by mountains, but the enemy means to take it from the sea and air. If he does, Australia will be in even greater danger of invasion and Tortes Strait, last gateway to the interior waters of the Far East, will be closed.

A twelve-point program of national objectives in the war and of ultimate peace aims looking toward permanent security was offered in Town Hall yesterday by Archibald Henderson, Professor at the University of North Carolina and biographer of George Bernard Shaw.

Out-of-town buyers visiting the New York market last week numbered 1,152, which compared with 1,236 in the preceding week and 889 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 602, as against 426 for last Tuesday.

Negotiations for a new agreement affecting 20,000 union members in 3,000 office, loft and apartment buildings throughout the city were begun yesterday between the Realty Advisory Board, speaking for the owners, and Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt declared today his belief that the war effort be improved, not hampered, by "sensible participation in healthy, recreational pursuits, within reasonable limits.

Sharp weakness in chemical issues and scattered high-priced groups pushed the stock market sufficiently lower yesterday on balance to penetrate the low levels of 1938. As gauged by the averages, the list crashed through to the worst prices recorded since May, 1933, although this statistical viewpoint was slightly warped in view of the stand made by many leading sections.

A majority of the 175 member companies that replied to a questionnaire recently submitted by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc. (formerly the Merchants Association of New York), on the question of staggering working hours in this city, favored the proposal, according to a report made public yesterday by the association.

LONDON, March 10 -- British forces evacuated from Southern Burma after the fall of Rangoon have consolidated new positions beside the Chinese division fighting in Central Burma, it was reported here today. Twenty-five miles north of Rangoon the Japanese succeeded in cutting the road to Prome, it was reported.

WASHINGTON, March 10--President Roosevelt, who has denounced as unethical the congressional practice of attaching non-germane and controversial riders to major appropriation bills, advised Senator A. Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, today that he believed the power to veto individual items in a bill was much needed and could be given by Congress to the Chief Executive without amending the Constitution.

An appeal to New York City housewives to salvage tin cans today and tomorrow because "100 pounds of cans will yield enough tin for a swooping American fighter plane -- 200 pounds of soup and spaghetti containers will help send another powerful Army Flying Fortress bomber over the enemy," was made yesterday by Clarence A. Low, chairman of the City Salvage Committee.

The sinking of three ships and serious damaging of a fourth, with the loss of eighty lives in all, was revealed yesterday as Axis submarines continued their depredations in American waters. But, to counterbalance these bad tidings, it was reported that United States destroyers had sent at least one of the attacking submarines to the bottom.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 10 (AP) -- Dr. Carl P. Schott, director of athletics at Pennsylvania State College, declared today that Penn State recognized that it had "overlooked" a paragraph of the I.C. 14-A by-laws in permitting Norman Gordon to compete in the track games at New York Saturday.

Now that England is at war again, it is time to revive Barrie's "A Kiss for Cinderella," which Maude Adams first played in New York on Christmas Day in 1916. For a kind of misty war atmosphere hovers around this fantastic drama about an underfed and over-imaginative London slavey.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Monthly reports which will show the progress being made in conversion of plants to wartime production and furnish the War Production Board with other pertinent data were ordered from American industry today by Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- "Every time a 16-inch gun is fired it eats up the distilled product of a fifth of an acre of sugar cane."

Events tonight: "The Magic Flute," conducted by Bruno Walter, Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conducting, Zino Francescatti, violin, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Yvonne Druian, piano recital, Town Hall, 8:30; Schubert program by students of Angela E. Weschler, Steinway Hall, 8:30; Victor Wittgenstein, piano recital for the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, 35 East Sixty-second Street, 8:30; Marian Anderson, song recital, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

Since Pearl Harbor there has been considerable discussion on the need for citizen training in the use of firearms, but until last week little seems to have been accomplished in the way of a program to stimulate such training.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, March 11 -- From behind hastily prepared defensive positions thrown up since Sunday morning on the Staraya Russa front, German forces early this morning were fighting to stem a Russian onslaught launched at dawn yesterday, two weeks after Soviet forces had surrounded the Sixteenth German Army.

The Medal of Honor for City Planning was awarded yesterday to John D. Rockefeller Jr. by four architectural and engineering societies "in recognition of his unique service to professional ideals in city planning."

The crescendo of demand on the part of the American public that the India issue be resolved stems from considerations deeper than military. There is a growing sense of uneasiness over the embarrassment to the cause of democracy which is involved, an embarrassment none the less real because the Axis powers have not been slow to exploit it.

The railroads again have demonstrated their ability under private management to meet the demands of the unlimited national emergency, M.W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said in his report for 1941, issued yesterday.

Mary Boland, for many years a star of the legitimate theatre, has been barred from appearing on any stage, in motion pictures, before a microphone or in a night club until March 31. On that date she will receive a hearing by Actors Equity Association on charges of "contract jumping" brought against her by the Theatre Guild.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Chartering of stock corporations in the State continued to fall below corresponding figures of a year ago, Secretary of State Walsh reported today. In February 867 were formed as against 1,259 in that month in 1941.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 11 -- Large forces of Britain's heavy bombing planes, flying wave upon wave, blasted Essen, home of the great Krupp armaments factory, on Monday night for the second night in succession, "stoking" up some fires lit on Sunday night, lighting fresh ones and spreading what the Air Ministry today described as extensive havoc.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Representative Eugene Cox of Georgia asserted today that remarks made by Attorney General Biddle March 4 urging advancement of New Deal social reforms despite the war constituted "an insult to the nation." Representative Carl Vinson, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, agreed with this view.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 10 -- At over a week's distance from the March 1 national elections in which the Argentine voters were called upon to decide whether or not acting President Ramon S. Castillo was to have a majority in the Chamber, as he already has in the Senate, the final results are still in doubt today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The polished polysyllabic profundities of James M. Landis, dean of the Harvard Law School and Director of Civilian Defense, seem to be a little too fancy for President Roosevelt.

Richard Strauss's "Don Quixote" dominated last night's concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Despite its obvious realistic touches such as the bleating of the sheep and the wind machine, the tone poem's stature has not diminished perceptibly with the years.

CANBERRA, Wednesday, March 11 (AP) -- The Royal Australian Air Force bombed Japanese troop concentrations in Northeast New Guinea after the enemy had made a third landing there, it was reported today.

The National Association of Manufacturers will submit to Congress today its proposed program of "taxation to the limit -- leaving only enough for survival -- in order to guarantee victory, to eliminate profiteering and to insure the future solvency of our government."

The continuance of heavy shipments of United States currency to Cuba, but in smaller denomination bills than in previous months, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly survey of currency shipments for February. Of the total exports of United States currency by banks in the United States during the month of $6,816,000, $6,600,000 went to Cuba.

Three more teams were added yesterday to the roster of contestants for the national invitation basketball tournament which will be held at Madison Square Garden on March 17, 19, 23 and 25. Since three had previously accepted bids to participate only two spots remain to be filled.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Axis propagandists are seeking to create disunion in the United States through short-wave broadcasts and by making use of fifth columnists in this country, Archibald MacLeish, director of the Office of Facts and Figures, stated in a report today.
LONDON, March 10 -- The British Government is now spending 14,500,000 [the pound was quoted
The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will begin mixing, play with art this morning to make a festival for its child public. No adult need apply unless accompanied by a child.

The University of Chicago's recent abbreviation of the requirements for the Bachelor of Arts degree to two years of study is "out of keeping with American educational standards and can lead only to academic chaos," Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Poland may be totally occupied by the Germans, but the Poles are still printing more than 100 underground newspapers, which are passed through the ranks of the Gestapo to more than 3,000,000 Polish patriots.

For many years the problem of the farmer has been low prices. Every political speech that was made to the farmer dwelt upon the need for raising prices. The whole philosophy of the Administration's farm program was founded on the effort to advance the prices of farm products.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Farm Security Administration, under recent investigation and sharply attacked for deciding in an election year that its loans to low-income farmers could include funds with which to pay Southern poll taxes, was the target today of new attacks for alleged "communistic" activities.

The feud between Mayor La Guardia and Paul J. Kern became more bitter yesterday when Mr. Kern was subpoenaed to appear at 10 o'clock Friday morning before William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, to substantiate his charges that there was "widespread fraud" in the La Guardia administration in addition to the Flynn case, which Mr. Kern investigated last November.

BERLIN, March 10 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German troops repulsed a Russian attack twenty miles west of Leningrad near Oranienbaum, opposite the great Kronstadt naval base, it was announced today. The Germans said they "wrought havoc" on Soviet transport columns on the ice.
LONDON, March 10 -- Conditions brightened in most sections of the stock markets today, encouraged by reports of big American forces in the Pacific.

Joe Louis made a speech. Constance Bennett read her own poem about a man named MacArthur. James J. Walker was a pro-tem master of ceremonies. And before more than 20,000 persons in Madison Square Garden last night (and early this morning), the Navy Relief Show went over with the promised bang.

A rare development, that of a private label promoted by a retail store for several years blossoming out with the added identification of its national brand maker, will take place this week, when Weber Heilbroner advertises the Jayson and Excello Shirts, previously carried under the store's name. F. Jacobson Sons, Inc., maker of the shirts, has supplied Weber for years, but last Fall adopted the policy of abandoning all private and combination labels.
MOSCOW, March 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- More than once, of recent weeks, word has come from Brazil that German submarines had taken fuel and supplies from Martinique and that their raids off the eastern American coast had thus been made easier.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A general sales tax, with no exemptions, was urged today by the New York State Chamber of Commerce as the major base of the proposed war revenue act.

The charges which Foreign Minister Anthony Eden yesterday made against the conduct of the Japanese Army in Hong Kong take added weight from the circumstances under which they were uttered. They were addressed to the House of Commons, in which a misstatement of fact, for whatever purpose, is considered to be a breach of faith.

Eli Shonbrun, an ex-convict, and Madeleine Webb, a former photographer's model, both sought in connection with the slaying of Mrs. Susie Flora Reich, Polish refugee, in the Hotel Sutton last Thursday, were found last night by detectives in a furnished apartment at 438 East 147th Street, the Bronx.

Organization of an informal priorities committee to determine the degree of importance to the war effort of the various branches of the printing and publishing industry was urged yesterday by Sydney Hogerton, district manager of the Priorities Field Service, War Production Board, at a priorities round table held in the assembly room of the Commerce and Industry Association, 233 Broadway.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 10 -- Mrs. Dorothy Black Milligan, 36 years old, wife of Edward D.W. Milligan, landscape architect and the commander of a United States Navy destroyer that patrolled the English Channel during the World War, was found guilty in Westchester County Court tonight on a charge of killing an 11-year-old boy through the negligent operation of an automobile.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A relatively unimportant shelling of the port of Cebu constituted the only military activity in the Philippines reported by the War Department today. Nevertheless, informed officials here expected to hear at any time that another, all-out drive had been started by the Japanese against the defenders of Bataan Peninsula.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Rising prices of nearly every pork product were halted today with the issuance of a temporary maximum price ceiling order by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator.

MOSCOW, March 10 (U.P.) -- The government newspaper, Izvestia, charged today that the bomb explosion near German Ambassador Franz von Papen in the Turkish capital two weeks ago was part of a Nazi plot to blackmail Turkey into abandoning neutrality and becoming an Axis vassal.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The way to beat the Axis is to open up an offensive in Europe and other principal theatres of war and not be diverted to the defensive by enemy raiding of the American coasts, said Lieut. Gen. Andrew McNaughton, commander of the Canadian Forces in Great Britain, at a press conference today.
Contributions to the government by persons whose incomes were not taxable were reported yesterday by the three Collectors of Internal Revenue with offices in this city.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- The first of four emergency stations to be established here as part of civilian defense was opened with appropriate ceremonies this afternoon in the Bassett Building, lent by Hood Bassett. The Red Cross Motor Corps, Volunteers for Victory mobile canteen unit headed by Mrs. Margaret Emerson and Mrs. Joseph Frederick Gunster, and first-aid units participated.

Of conspicuous interest among the canvases in Umberto Romano's exhibition at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, is a portrait of the President's mother, Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, for which she posed twice.

An investment of less than $15 a passenger car in facilities to produce synthetic rubber will provide sufficient rubber to keep the automobiles of the United States on the roads, according to a statement yesterday by W.S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

Dr. John Roscoe Turner, dean of men at City College since 1935, will submit his resignation to the Board of Higher Education with the request that he be allowed to assume teaching duties as a Professor of Economics at the college, it was learned yesterday.

Operations of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and its domestic subsidiary sales company in 1941 resulted in a net profit of $2,766,602 after $5,960,000 provision for Federal taxes, $379,244 write-off of investments in German subsidiaries and $100,000 for contingencies, the concern reported yesterday.

Far in the future a learned historian will be minutely studying the manners and morals of the twentieth century. After long research a book will be published to crown his career. Students searching this volume will discover, for instance, that their ancestors had a predilection for frankfurters and apple pie.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Failure of administration officials in radio addresses last night to openly oppose or criticize the efforts of the farm bloc in Congress in the latter's efforts to prevent the Commodity Credit Corporation from selling cash, wheat below parity prices caused a rush of buying of futures when trading started on the Board of Trade here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- Diana Barrymore's second picture at Universal will be "Love and Kisses, Caroline," formerly titled "Boy Meets Baby," in which she will play the feminine lead opposite Robert Cummings. Henry Koster will direct the film starting next month, after Miss Barrymore completes her current assignment in "Eagle Squadron."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Revolt among House members today for a second time within less than three weeks blocked indefinitely -- this time possibly permanently -- President Roosevelt's program for providing special unemployment benefits for workers displaced by conversions of industries from peacetime to war production.
Daisies scattered on prints and blue and green combined in evening and daytime frocks, marked the Spring collection shown yesterday by Harry Collins.

Three midtown theatres will offer new films this morning. "The Fleet's In," a Paramount musical with Dorothy Lamour, William Holden and Eddie Bracken, will be the new attraction at the Paramount. Betty Hutton, Cass Daley, Gil Lamb, Leif Erikson and Jimmy Dorsey and his orchestra are featured. . . .

Four default judgments for a total of $1,230,000 were entered in Supreme Court yesterday in favor of James B. Gordon, as assignee of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, against four subsidiaries of the company in Germany and German-occupied countries.

With no relief in sight, 2,000,000 passenger cars will be junked this year in the United States and only 340,000 rationed automobiles will offset the loss, Dr. Rolf Nugent, associate price executive of the automobile and truck section of the Office of Price Administration, warned yesterday.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Appeals for the passage at this session of the Dorn-Johnson bill, which calls for establishment of child health centers throughout the State to care for children whose mothers are engaged in war production or civilian defense jobs, were made today at a public hearing of the Education Committees of both houses of the Legislature, by representatives of many leading women's organizations.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 10 (U.P.) -- Netherlands Indies troops and their allies, facing "hundreds of thousands" of Japanese, still are fighting in Eastern and Central Java, although an armistice has been declared in the Bandung area to save the civilian population from "massacre," it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The House passed today, 367 to 0, the bill increasing the national debt limit from $65,000,000,000 to $125,000,000,000 and making more flexible the Treasury's financing operations, amid pleas that the country get behind an all-out effort to make the war as short as possible.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 10 (AP) -- British Army General Headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt said today that the Army and Navy are working together pretty well, thus indicating his opposition to suggestions for a "Supreme Command" or unification of the land, naval and air forces into a Department of National Defense as was proposed in a bill introduced in the Senate today by Senator Clark, Democrat of Missouri.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- An official war inventory of the nation's human resources indicated today that several millions of women would have to be shifted from housework to munitions factories in the expansion of war industries.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The battle for the world produced a thousand variants-yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, March 10 -- The arrest of four Germans mentioned in these dispatches last Friday, plus the subsequent detention of several others connected with the fifth column, was confirmed to this correspondent today by one of the highest officials here. This disposes of the formal denial that one of the arresting departments thought it necessary to make.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt and Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, both said at their press conferences today they had no official information to confirm a Russian press report that forty French warships that were nearing completion when France fell had been turned over to Germany.

Miss Louise Edgar gave a tea yesterday at her home, 1050 Park Avenue, for members of the debutante committee aiding in plans for a fashion show and luncheon to be held May 7 in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop and its eight auxiliary philanthropies.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- The Dodgers rolled into their Florida training base today by rail -- a unique mode of travel for the National League champions this Spring. They'll pause here only until Friday night, when they must return to Miami for the two-game series with the Giants.

LONDON, March 10 -- Two Italian warships -- a cruiser and a destroyer -- as well as a merchant vessel, were set on fire when Royal Air Force planes carried out a successful torpedo attack on an enemy convoy that was escorted by units of the Italian fleet in the central Mediterranean yesterday, and a Junkers-88 was shot down into the sea, it was announced today.

The responsibilities of social workers have increased with the war and their services will be widely needed during its aftermath, leaders in this field declared yesterday at the fifth Metropolitan Conference on Social Group Work and Recreation.
LONDON, March 10 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden made the following statement today in thai House of Commons:

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., March 10 (AP) -- A smart 5-year-old pointer won the title of the nation's outstanding bird dog today with a spectacular victory in an extra heat of the historic national field trials.
Delegates to the American Kennel Club elected Edward Dana Knight of Charleston, W. Va., to a vacancy in the board of directors at the annual meeting in the club's offices yesterday.

After an unsuccessful attempt to settle the dispute, between burlesque theatre owners and Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday Morris Ernst, counsel for the theatre men, announced that he would apply for a writ of mandamus in Supreme Court today to compel the Mayor and Paul Moss, License Commissioner, to permit reopening of the burlesque houses they closed.

PEARL HARBOR, March 10 -- Three sunburned sailors of the United States Pacific Fleet sat in an officers' lounge here today and casually told the greatest story of men against the sea that has come out of this war. These three men, armed at the last only with a pocket knife and provisioned with ingenuity alone, sailed 1,000 miles in a rubber life raft 8 feet by 4 over-all.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that Robert E. McConnell, chairman of the Engineers Defense Board, has been chosen as president and chairman of the Board of General Aniline and Film Corporation of Delaware, formerly German-owned organization which has been under the control of the Treasury for several months.

The Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $18,692,242 last year, after all expenses and charges, H.P. Liversidge, president, disclosed yesterday in his annual report to stockholders. This was equal to $1.55 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with $22,115, 629, or $1.88 a share, in 1940.
PITTSBURGH, March 10 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Marie Smith was turned down today when she volunteered to serve in the Army in the place of her brother, Frank J. Humbrecht, 26, a conscientious objector.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain store companies continued to maintain a high level during February, although the percentage gain last month was below the record increase noted in January. The February increase was 22.3 per cent over the same month last year, against a rise of 34.6 per cent in the preceding month, according to a compilation yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

In your issue of Feb. 26, bearing an Associated Press dispatch from Washington, in reference to the trial of George Sylvester Viereck, there is a reference to me as counsel for George Hill, a former clerk to Representative Hamilton Fish.

The metropolitan basketball championship will be decided in Madison Square Garden tonight when City College faces N.Y.U. in a renewal of their ancient rivalry, while St. John's and St. Francis, two old foes, will have it out in the opener.
There will be two openings this evening, both off the beaten Broadway track.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- A quiet, strategic race was reported to be under way or imminent tonight, between the Axis powers and the United Nations for control of the French island of Madagascar.

Many persons entertained at the Spring luncheon and fashion show held yesterday at Hampshire House under the auspices of the Social Service Auxiliary to City Hospital. Guests had been requested to bring packages of rummage to be sold later for the benefit of the auxiliary's work.

CLEVELAND, March 10 (AP) -- Of the thirteen present directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, only Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation; George D. Brooke, president of the C., and four others are expected to be re-elected at the railway's annual meeting on April 21 in Richmond, Va.

LONDON, March 10 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, government leader, told the House of Commons today that Prime Ainister Churchill would make a statement on India after questions at the next session of the House.

A dance festival consisting of some forty performances by leading artists in various styles of dance will be given at Lee, Mass., by the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, Inc., beginning July 8 and running until the middle of September.

BOSTON, March 10 (AP) -- The champion Boston Bruins assured themselves of at least third place in the current National Hockey League campaign by overwhelming the Chicago Black Hawks, 9 to 1, tonight before a crowd of 8,600 at the Garden.

RIOM, France, March 10 -- Pleading before the Supreme Court here today former Premier Leon Blum insistently contended that neither the social legislation nor the general policies of his Popular Front government in any way hampered or delayed French preparation for national defense.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Secretary Ickes organized a Solid Fuels Advisory War Council today and proposed that it immediately start a campaign for coal storage by consumers to avoid the necessity of allocating supplies when transportation facilities become scarce.

Trade demand and buying by New Orleans interests and commission houses lent steady support to the cotton market yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices of active futures closed near their best levels for the session, with net gains of 8 to 14 points.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The promised 25 per cent cut in the State income tax moved a step nearer a fact today as both houses of the Legislature passed all major budget and tax bills. Governor Lehman, who recommended the cut in his budget message, is expected to sign the bills in a few days, after which taxpayers will be told how to make the deduction on their returns.

MIAMI, Fla., March 10 -- Two long-shot combinations -- neither rater better than 50 to 1 -- reached the final of the Miami Biltmore's international four-ball golf tournament today with dramatic victories.

A syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., was the successful bidder yesterday for $1,925,000 city of Houston, Texas, various purpose bonds, receiving the award on an interest cost basis to the city of 2.0627 per cent. The group paid 100.025 for $500,000 as 2 1/4s and $1,425,000 as 2s.

MIAMI, Fla., March 10 -- Managerial cares, which had been resting lightly on the youthful shoulders of Melvin Ott, took on added weight today when a mysterious ailment to Johnny Mize's throwing arm came back with renewed vigor.

A BRITISH PORT, March 10 (Canadian Press) -- Another great convoy bearing reinforcements for the Canadian forces overseas, American technicians, nurses and fighting men of the occupied countries has arrived in Great Britain following a smooth, swift crossing marked by a brief brush with a submarine.

Past and present mingled in the millinery parade at Franklin Simon's yesterday afternoon. The nostalgic theme was played on creations that were displayed in the show cases and on headgear taken from "Life With Father" and "Gone With the Wind."

A 125-year-old novel will be published by Doubleday, Doran on March 20. The book is "The Itching Parrot," by Jose Joaquin Fernandez de Lizardi, a fiery Mexican character who in the early nineteenth century fought for social reforms, for Mexican independence and for anything else in sight that needed fighting for.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The report and recommendations of the oil industry's special committee on supply, on which depends to a great extent the question of whether to ration or not to ration gasoline, was received today by Secretary Ickes.

The industrial building, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, at 34-33 Thirty-sixth Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been leased to the Aviation Institute of Technology, Inc., Frank Ambrose, president, which recently received a contract from the United States Army to house, feed and instruct enlisted men of the Army Aviation Corp.

CANBERRA, Australia, Wednesday, March 11 -- The Japanese, who are believed by many responsible observers here to be preparing an early and large-scale assault against this continent, made their third landing in Northeast New Guinea yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, March 10 -- A bitter discussion on the Halpern-Latham bill, which seeks to remove regulation of varsity athletic schedules in high schools from the State Education Department and the Board of Regents and place it under the supervision of local education boards, marked the public hearing today of the education committees of both Houses.

Last night at the Music Box took one back to the Empire Theatre of Christmas Eve, 1916. But what is time in timeless Barrieland, west of the sun and east of the moon? "A Kiss for Cinderella" is an invitation to an enchanted country. Dreams are realities. Mr. Dickens is arm in arm with Mr. Charles Perrault and Mother Goose is laughing at Puck's latest jest.
The incidence of scarlet fever continued to rise for the eighth straight week among New York children last week, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner.

The Union Electric Company of Missouri filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering of $10,000,000 more of its first mortgage and collateral trust 3 3/8 per cent bonds due in 1971. Last May the company sold $80,000,000 of bonds of this series, listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
BALTIMORE, March 10 (AP) -- Dr. Hugh H. Young will retire July 1 as director of the Brady Urological Institute at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, and as Professor of Urology.

The generosity and patriotism of the legitimate theatre of New York City in providing tickets to Broadway plays at half price for officers in the services was praised yesterday by Mrs. Marshall Field, co-chairman of the Officers Service Committee, a subcommittee of the New York City Defense Council.
BERLIN, March 10 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

It is a most heartening thing to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 9 that the residents of Marion, S.C., have sent a resolution to the President and Congress demanding that they put a step to the strikes that are constantly threatening the war production efforts of this country.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 10 -- Eddie Arcaro accounted for another feature race at Tropical Park today. The veteran, who guided Requested home in the Flamingo Stakes and The Rhymer to victory in the Widener Cup at Hialeah, had a lot to do with the triumph of Eternal Peace in the Okeechobee Purse at one mile and seventy yards.

LONDON, March 10 -- Japan's conquering army at Hong Kong was accused by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in Parliament today of perpetrating the most wanton cruelties against helpless civilian and military prisoners.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 10 -- In the wake of news that Red Robert Rolfe may be at the end of his baseball career, the Yankees today snapped out of their losing streak. That the world champions had to go eleven innings to beat the Boston Red Sox, 3 to 1, only made the struggle more interesting for 1,684 fans.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 10 -- All freshman sports activities at Princeton University will be abolished next Fall for the duration of the war, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, '34, graduate manager of athletics. The move is a result of the recent agreement made among Harvard, Yale and Princeton to make first-year men eligible for competition as members of varsity and jayvee squads.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt added a prize today to his collection of model sailing ships. It was a model of the Mayflower, made with wood from the original Mayflower. It was brought from London by Ambassador John G. Winant.

Francois Latry, long recognized as the leading chef of Europe, has retired as maitre chef des cuisines of the Hotel Savoy of London on account of ill health, it was disclosed yesterday. Marius Dutrey has been appointed his successor.
LONDON, March 10 -- Viscount Cranborne, Colonial Secretary; speaking in the House of Lords today, uttered a vigorous denial of the charge that anti-Semitism existed in the Palestine administration.

Ten prizes, totaling $2,000, have been awarded by the Art Institute of Chicago in the forty-sixth annual exhibition of work by artists of that city-and vicinity which opens tomorrow at the Art Institute of Chicago. Six of the ten prizes were awarded to newcomers.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Had your meal of weeds today -- a marsh marigold soup, perhaps, or a pig weed pie, stinging nettle pudding or green grass salad?

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Statistics showing the quarterly earnings and dividends of large corporations, published by the Federal Reserve Board today for the first time, indicate that both have climbed sharply in the last three years.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Representative Taber told the House today, as it opened debate on the $350,650,826 Appropriations Bill for the War Department's civil functions, that the WPA had approved a $940,106 music project for New York City.

CHUNGKING, China, March 10 (AP) -- A Chinese Government spokesman announced today the appointment of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, a former United States military attache at Peiping, as Chief of Staff in the China theatre under Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Renewing his attacks on the Dies Committee, on the eve of a scheduled House decision as to the continuance of the investigating body until January, Representative Eliot of Massachusetts took the floor late today to cite the case of Edward James Smythe, whose activities, he alleged, had received insufficient probing and exposure.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 10 -- Nicholas von Kallay, 55 years old, former Minister of Agriculture and a permanent member of the upper House of Parliament, has formed a new Hungarian Cabinet to succeed that of Dr. Ladislaus de Bardossy. All the former Ministers remain, with Mr. von Kallay temporarily serving as Foreign Minister as well as Premier.
NEW DELHI, India, March 10 (AP) -- A British communique today said:
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Following is the text of the speech by Donald Nelson over the Mutual network tonight:

Aaron Seltzer, 125 1/2, Bronx, out-pointed Joe Iannotti, 128 1/4, also of the Bronx, in the feature eight-rounder before a crowd of 4,000 at the New York Coliseum last night. With this triumph he evened the score between the two, each having won twice.

James H.R. Cromwell, former Minister to Canada, filed suit for $1,000,000 damages in Federal court yesterday, charging that Bruce Minton, in an article published in The New Masses, had libelously called him an appeaser, an associate of fifth columnists, a Munichman and a slanderer of President Roosevelt.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- With the full approval of the War Department, Secretary Morgenthau today hastened the evacuation of American-born and alien Japanese from the West Coast's military area No. 1 by appointing the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco as custodian of evacuees' property.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Admirals King and Hart and Secretary Knox, received the Nicaraguan Minister and the Minister of Foreign Affairs and held his regular Tuesday press conference.

The war has already created a situation where a new and permanent industry for the United States is in the making. For more than ten years the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has been experimenting with the production of synthetic rubber made from oil and gas.
