Total business for 1941 exceeded that of the previous year by about 30 per cent and was the largest in the history of the company, H.F. Atherton, president of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation informed stockholders in the annual report released today.

In providing credit for war industries, bankers are paying more attention to the ability of the manufacturers to handle the defense contracts than to precise financial information as the basis for bank credit, according to Roy A. Foulke, manager of the specialized report department of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., in a credit survey issued yesterday.

Members of the Fordham Athletic Council, meeting last night at the university, granted a leave of absence for the duration of the war to Jim Crowley, head football coach, and designated Earl F. Walsh, one of his assistants for years, as acting chief pilot of the Rams.

It is a welcome move that puts Admiral Ernest J. King in complete command of the American Navy. Few officers in any navy in the world have had his well-rounded experience. It is especially reassuring that this experience has included an opportunity to understand at firsthand the immense importance of air power in modern naval warfare.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 10 -- A rumor prevalent in Stockholm for some weeks that Reichsfuehrer Hitler is contemplating an approach to Premier Joseph Stalin for a separate peace, and the fact that Nazi circles here are helping to propagate this rumor, has led to much speculation in Sweden, where the immediate reaction is renewed anxiety over the fate of Finland.

Premium income of the Aetna Life Insurance Company and its affiliates rose from $164,940,711 in 1940 to $193,110,867 in 1941, according to the pamphlet report issued yesterday. The affiliates are the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company, the Automobile Insurance Company and the Standard Fire Insurance Company.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 10 -- Private Joe Louis, the world heavy- weight champion, appeared before a battery of newsreel camera men and a crowd of 500 soldiers today as he continued training for his Army Emergency Fund bout on March 27 with Abe Simon at Madison Square Garden in New York.

Too many alleged inside stories of why France fell in 1940 have laid too much stress on the fatal role played by the particular women friends of various French leaders. It really does not get us anywhere.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased new residential space was Dr. Frank Kingdon, lecturer and educator, who took an apartment of seven rooms and four baths at 98 Riverside Drive through C.H. Gifford Co., Inc., agents.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Public wrath will destroy any agency of labor, management or of the government itself which interferes with the all-out production demanded for an offensive war, Donald M. Nelson, head of the War Production Board, warned tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, March 11 -- Several persons were killed and an unspecified number seriously injured in the Brussels market place yesterday when two "terrorists" threw a bomb during the departure of a formation of Walloon legionaries to fight with the German armies on the Eastern Front.

Volunteer Red Cross workers have made themselves so useful in Manhattan headquarters of the Federal Rationing Administrator, 330 West Forty-second Street, that the New York City Rationing Administration has decided to utilize those workers in all twenty-seven local rationing board offices throughout the city, it was disclosed yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, Acting Federal Rationing Administrator.

Buy about three pounds of stewing meat, either beef or lamb, cut it in small squares and roll each piece in flour. Melt a piece of suet in a top-of-the-stove oven, and when the fat is very hot, brown the meat. Then add two carrots that have been cubed, a white turnip and two or three small onions that have been sliced.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that price ceilings on used tires and tubes would be invoked on Monday.

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- The Pure Milk Association, marketing cooperative with more than 12,000 members in Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin, joined the Wisconsin Council of Agriculture today in condemning proposed organization of farmers by industrial unions.

Francis J. Dowling, 47 years old, of 231 West Sixteenth Street, a member of the Republican County Committee and an election district captain in the Chelsea section of the Third Assembly District, was found guilty yesterday by a General Sessions jury of having stabbed Edward Abrams, a seaman, during a dispute over a Communist placard at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

The Inter-American Cooperative Marketing Corporation, importers and exporters, have leased a large unit of space on the twenty-eighth floor of the building at 165 Broadway through Charles F. Noyes Co., Inc. An unnamed department of the United States Government also took quarters and the Foster-Wheeler Corporation, engineers, contracted for additional room in the same structure.

Every once in a while there slips into the news a story or a picture that points up the phantasmagoric quality of this war. In a dispatch from Burma the other day it was reported that herds of elephants had gone mad under the bombing and were stampeding in the villages along the marshy river banks.

CLEVELAND, March 10 (AP) -- John P. Murphy and Charles L. Bradley, operators of the Higbee Company here, sued today to enjoin public sale Friday of securities which nominally control the department store. They received a temporary injunction pending a hearing Thursday.

An investing syndicate represented by Irving Brodsky, lawyer, has bought the fourteen-story loft and store building at 214-18 William Street, running through to 18-20 Rose Street, from the Bank for Savings. The deal was made for cash above a ten-year first mortgage of $170,000.

Dr. R.F. McGannon of the Columbia University Club, seeded No. 1 in the metropolitan Class C squash racquets championship now in progress at the Harvard University Club, won his way into the quarter-final round yesterday by defeating. A. Arguedas of Jackson Heights. The score was 15 -- 10, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 9.

A blunt warning that foreign trade is of relative unimportance and will continue so for the duration of the war was given to more than 1,000 foreign traders yesterday at the twenty-fifth anniversary "get-together" of the Export Managers Club of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

While awaiting possible action on gasoline rationing by Washington, the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Association, through Leo A. Herzog, their general counsel, declared yesterday that these filling station owners would approve of dealer rationing, of a 7 P.M. to 7 A.M. curfew, and of Sunday closing, but would not approve of coupon rationing.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (U.P.) -- A representative group of Senators indicated general agreement today with the theory that wartime wages should be held in line with the cost of living.

Mayor La Guardia sought yesterday to avert the complete loss of the city's right to operate a foreign trade zone in New York Harbor by asking the City Council to endorse a bill at Albany that would permit the city to operate such a zone anywhere within the city limits.

The annual reports of the American Bemberg Corporation and the North American Rayon Corporation both disclose that control of the capital stock held by subjects, citizens or residents of the Netherlands has been assumed by the Royal Netherlands Government, temporarily residing in London.
The style factor in women's apparel will not be affected by the government's determination to "freeze the silhouette," according to two of New York's leading dress designers for the wholesale market.

With the sentencing of thirty-one men, Judge Gaston L. Porterie in Federal court yesterday completed for the present the sentencing of a large group who had admitted or been convicted of taking part in a $10,000,000 oil swindle. In all, fifty-three persons have been shown to have had parts in the affair; of these sixteen were sentenced Monday, one is too ill to come to court and five were sentenced earlier.

MEXICO CITY, March 11 -- Mexico is about to make the biggest attack on the fifth column yet made in Latin America in the arrest, and probable transfer to the United States authorities, of some thirty-five Nazi leaders, it was said by a high official source here tonight.

The war spirit that has swept the lower East Side carried with it yesterday 3-year-old Philip Edward Goodman of 647 East Fifth Street. He refused to leave the workrooms at the Educational Alliance, where women, many of them with two and three sons in the armed forces, were sewing and knitting garments for the American Red Cross.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- A decisive Soviet victory in the preliminary phase of the 1942 air war, which "will be no less severe than last year's," was claimed today by the Army newspaper Red Star, which reported that 576 enemy planes were destroyed in the fortnight ended March 6, against Russian losses of 127 planes.

Mainbocher established himself as a great American couturier yesterday afternoon. This designer swung into fame on the wings of a reputation acquired in Paris in pre-war days. When he came to New York a couple of years ago he brought with him the aura of the French couture.
By means of a "Report to Our Friends" now in the mails, the United Service Organizations announced yesterday that it had made an accounting of the $14,365,161 pledged to its 1941 campaign.

LONDON, March 11 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal and Leader of the House of Commons, who is one of Great Britain's great lawyers, accepted today the most difficult and most important case of his brilliant career, with his country as his client.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The British Government informed the United States Government today of the basis of negotiations for a solution of the India problem.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 11 (AP) -- The Air Corps is seeking civilian fliers aged 21-41 who have commercial licenses, offering them commissions as service pilots and $300 a month, Major Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, commanding the Southeast Air Corps Training Center, said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, March 12 -- Twenty-four miles northeast of Dniepropetrovsk, on a bend of the Samara River just south of Andreyevka, German forces were reported this morning to be putting up a stubborn fight before overwhelming forces of Russian tanks supported by cavalry and infantry as the third day of the Donets offensive ended with fighting in the Russians' favor.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 -- In its final home appearance of the season, Princeton's smoothly coordinated varsity basketball team outclassed a ragged Columbia quintet, 56 -- 30, before a capacity crowd in the university gym tonight.

Two women who have been fighting in and out of court for more than a year for possession of a 4-year-old German Shepherd dog rehearsed their troubles yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court. Magistrate Ambrose Haddock made his decision after giving each woman an opportunity to call the dog.

If corporate taxes are increased farther the National Biscuit Company will have to consider a reduction in dividends on its common stock, Frederick Beers, vice president, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Jersey City. In 1941 the company paid four dividends of 40 cents each, although earnings in the period were equal to $1.43 a common share, or 17 cents a share less than was paid out in dividends.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A decision not to undertake to raise $2,000,000,000 additional in Social Security taxes at this time was announced today by Representative Doughton of North Carolina, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

LONDON, March 11 -- Russian shock troops have cut the Smolensk-Vyazma highway, tightening the drawstring on the neck of the German salient looping northeast of Rzhev, and farther north they have smashed through a line that Adolf Hitler ordered held at all cost, Soviet dispatches said tonight.

Police Commissioner Valentine revealed yesterday that he favored an amendment to the city administrative code to require "every householder" to furnish complete information about his home and family to air raid wardens.
CLEVELAND, March 11 (AP) -Those who will not work are not good enough to serve in the Army, Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress a report on the first year of lease-lend operations and issued an executive order establishing an independent agency to handle alien property under the direction of Leo T. Crowley, who also is chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Donald S. Stralem, president of the Travelers Aid Society of New York, and Mrs. Stralem gave a dinner last night in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for Paul V. McNutt, who came from Washington to attend the annual meeting of the society, held earlier in the day in the main ballroom of the same hotel.

The Otis Steel Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for April 24, to vote on a proposal to sell its assets to the Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation and the distribution of the proceeds among Otis shareholders, according to an announcement by E.J. Kulas, president of Otis.

ROME, March 11 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -Italian torpedo boats have sunk two submarines, ! and the British have definitely lost SiX submarines in the iIediteri ranean in the last four weeks, the High Command said today.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Herman Keiser and Chandler Harper, a pair of workaday golfers who got to the final over the toughest route, won the Miami Biltmore's international four-ball tournament today with a relentless display of birdies and pars.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Gifts of securities declined sharply in January from the year-end spurt in December, the monthly summary of "insider" transactions by the Securities Commission showed today. The commission reports all transactions by officers, directors and principal owners of corporations.

LONDON, March 11 -- News that white bread soon would vanish from the British table for the duration of the war was accompanied today by an announcement of sharper penalties for persons guilty of dealing in black markets. The adoption of the "national wheat-meal loaf" will mean a saving of nearly 700,000 tons of shipping space yearly.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pell celebrated the seventh anniversary of their marriage, which took place here at Mrs. Alfred J. Brosseau's home, with a cocktail party this afternoon at their residence.

LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- The British pursuit of the Tirpitz suggest that strong naval forces of both sides, were operating off Alorway in the opening phases of what is expected to become a prolonged battle for control of the supply lane to Russia.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Senate passed and sent to the Assembly today the Young bill permitting school children more than 14 years of age to take off a month of their school year to work on farms during the harvesting and planting seasons.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Some members of the House contended that sub-parity sales could be carried on despite the restriction adopted today against the Commodity Credit Corporation. Representative Dirksen of Illinois said that existing law permits transfer of departmental funds up to 5 per cent, and that the President had "a blank check" emergency, fund which he could use for that purpose if he desired.

Urging Americans to overcome their attitude of complacency, Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, said yesterday that this nation must learn to become tough if it was to win the war. He told 1,000 persons at the annual meeting of the Travelers Aid Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that the struggle ahead would be long and difficult.

LONDON, March 11 -- Charges that the British Navy was equipped with obsolete sea-borne torpedo-carrying planes that are easy prey for land-based enemy fighter machines were made in the House of Commons today, together with accusations of chaos and mismanagement in Great Britain's naval and mercantile shipbuilding industry.

The editorial "Invitation to Racketeering" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 5 creates an entirely erroneous impression of the decision of the United States Supreme Court, rendered last Monday, in the case of the teamsters of this city.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Secretary Ickes said today that, as petroleum coordinator, he planned soon to reduce the sale of gasoline to East Coast filling stations, effective until the Office of Price Administration, headed by Leon Henderson, sets up a card rationing system for gasoline.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Formal assurances have been given to this government by the French Government that Madagascar will not willingly be permitted to fall into Japanese hands.
WASHINGTON, March, 11 -Following is the text of a statement by Admiral Thomas C. Hart concerning features of the naval campaign in the Western Pacific area:

Readjustment of prices of securities to the all-out war economy dropped quotations on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday into further low ground. Major inroads, which ran to more than 3 points in some prime investment issues and to 16 1/2 points in one preferred stock, kept the averages at the lowest levels since 1933, but the volume of business showed only a slight increase.

TOLEDO, March 11 -- An untapped supply of machinery, skilled mechanics and manufacturing space is lying idle in the nation's 40,000 automobile dealer shops, according to a nation-wide survey submitted to the War Production Board by Joseph W. Frazer, president of Willys-Overland Motors.

Out of the mouths of experimental theatres come some simple truths occasionally. "Nathan the Wise," which was acted at the New School for Social Research last evening, has more than the usual share. It is Ferdinand Bruckner's adaptation of a play Lessing wrote in 1779 for religious and racial equality.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The House voted today, 116 to 47, to forbid the Commodity Credit Corporation to sell government-held farm surpluses below parity prices. This was in the face of the opposition expressed by President Roosevelt recently when the Senate took action to the same end.

James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, taking cognizance of some feeling of opposition in the school system toward a Summer defense program requiring participation by the teachers, told the New York Principals Association last night that he could not see how any one connected with children could satisfy his conscience if he took the regular ten-week vacation.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- In a will filed here today which, in effect, disinherits his estranged wife, Rena Mooney, Tom Mooney left his personal effects to his brother, John B. Mooney, and his sister, Arena Mooney, both of this city.

As part of the program of consumer protection, two bills to standardize bread weight and meat grading for the retail market in New York City have been introduced in the City Council by Minority Leader Genevieve B. Earle, Brooklyn, and Councilman Salvatore Ninfo, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- On the first anniversary of the lease-lend program President Roosevelt reported to Congress today that the United States had spent $2,570,452,441 for defense aid, and had actually exported to its Allies items valued at $1,100,000,000.

Poland is under the Nazi heel, but more than a hundred Polish underground newspapers are printed in cellars and forest hideouts. They reach a public of three million undaunted readers, bidding them work and wait for the day of liberation.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Domestic production of many of the imported essential oils required in American industry but no longer available because of the war would be entirely feasible, witnesses assured the House Committee on Agriculture which began initial hearings today on a bill to provide for the "discovery, introduction, breeding and testing of agricultural crops for utilization in industry and manufacturing and for replacement of surplus crops."
It is disturbing to one attempting to direct a salvage campaign that your paper prints a letter such as Harold Wanger's of March 10, on the supposed confusion in salvage rules.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

The complete schedule of programs to be presented by the Ballet Theatre and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in their joint season at the Metropolitan Opera House for two weeks beginning April 6, has been announced by S. Hurok.

EVERYBODY who is anybody has his or her own pet theory of why France fell. Genevieve Tabouis, the lady who glories in the name of Cassandra, puts a good deal of the blame on a few highly placed women. Military activists talk of the paralyzing Maginot Line complex. The more sedentary men of arms insist the Maginot Line was a failure, not because it immobilized troops, but because it was not completed to the sea.

Having set for themselves two marks to be achieved, the Rangers will attempt to clinch one and stride a step closer to the other tonight, when they face the Bruins at Madison Square Garden. Item No. 1 will be to add to their brilliant consecutive-game scoring streak as Lester Patrick's men make their final home stand of the regular National Hockey League campaign.

Partly as a result of a shutdown of a Southern plant for repairs, steel plant operations this week have declined a point to 95 1/2 per cent of theoretical capacity, according to The Iron Age. The publication reported also that shortages of scrap metal were increasing in other areas.

ROME, Thursday, March 12 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Premier Hideki Tojo told the Japanese Parliament today that if Australia did not modify her present attitude she inevitably would suffer the same fate as the Netherlands Indies, Tokyo dispatches reported.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- Mrs. Charles G. Mueller of Philadelphia was among those entertaining at the final fashion luncheon of the season at the Surf Club this afternoon. Mrs. Frank Hastings Stephens of Pittsburgh and Mrs. Oscar Dooly Jr. also gave parties.

Officers of the armed forces "can be just as lonesome in this town as the men," Mrs. Anna Rosenberg, regional director of the Office of Defense, Health, Welfare and Related Services, told 250 persons last night at the formal opening of new headquarters of the Officers Service Committee in the Hotel Commodore.

Columbia Grammar's mermen dominated the elimination heats of the seventeenth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools swimming championships yesterday in the Columbia University pool, qualifying men for the finals in ten events.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Representative O'Toole of New York told the House today that the lives of New York City residents were being endangered by the loading of ammunition ships in New York Harbor.

The organization of an inter-American bank was urged by Eduardo Villasenor, director general of the Bank of Mexico, in a radio broadcast yesterday. Mr. Villasenor said that "the American continent must increase the value of its resources, both by increasing the action of capital as well as by human effort."

John-Barbirolli conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall for the first time in five months. Previously this season he had led six concerts during the final fortnight of October, but his chief activities on the podium for the orchestra's centennial year have just begun.

TRENTON, March 11 -- A "dimout" of New Jersey's beachfront is soon to be ordered by the State Defense Council in an effort to prevent ships offshore from being silhouetted against the lights and made easier targets for submarines.

A plea for prompt passage of the Coudert-Jarema bills authorizing the city to demolish the remaining section of the Second Avenue elevated structure, between Sixtieth Street and Chatham Square, was sent to all New York City members of the Legislature yesterday by the First Avenue Association.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the First Army, declared yesterday that attacks on this country's shores could be reduced and eventually eliminated by "a powerful striking force" carrying the war to the enemy in his own homeland.

At forty minutes past noon yesterday, when the crowds filing Federal income tax returns in temporary quarters on the seventh and eighth floors of the twenty-eight-story Court-Remsen Building at 26 Court Street, Brooklyn, was at its peak for the day, twenty-seven building service men, including a dozen elevator operators, went on strike.

LONDON, March 11 -- Advocating healthy if adverse criticism of the conduct of national affairs, Alfred Edwards, M.P., representing Middlesbrough East, announced yesterday that he had called a Labor party meeting for the discussion of a proposal to establish a firmer and more independent Opposition in the House of Commons.

Attorneys for a Queens developing company will attempt to upset the city's claim to several parcels of land in Forest Hills North in Supreme Court, Jamaica, on March 23 by referring back to one of the oldest customs of the earliest Long Island settlers.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 11 (AP) -A British headquarters communique said today:

A wage increase of 10 cents an hour for 135,000 men's clothing workers in all parts of the country has been agreed upon tentatively by negotiating committees representing the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., and the United States Clothing Manufacturers Association, it was learned yesterday.

The cotton market experienced yesterday another quiet session as outside news offered little encouragement for activity. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures moved within a 10-point range and finished at levels unchanged to 1 point higher than the previous close.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The controversy over the letting of contracts to make Army clothing was continued today by Representative Engel of Michigan when he wrote to Donald M. Nelson saying that the chairman of the War Production Board "amazed" him with "inaccuracies, misstatements and misquotations" in a letter of rebuke to Mr. Engel.

An injunction restraining the city from enforcing a new local law prohibiting peddling on the streets was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn on the ground that the statute was unconstitutional and not reasonably necessary to deal with the abuses of the peddling problem.

President Roosevelt's first annual report on operations under the Lease-Lend Act is, as he himself is the first to admit, no record of great achievement. We have actually furnished to our allies $1,411,000,000 worth of goods. Another $539,000,000 went into the servicing, repair, rental and charter of ships and into production facilities in this country placed at our friends' disposal.

Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, expressed confidence yesterday that India would come into the war and take an active part on the side of the Allies. He spoke at a luncheon of the Canadian Club of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

During the past five years there have been sporadic attempts, most of them without adequate organization, to introduce bills that would remove all political angles from the fish and game division of the Conservation Department and create a "nonpartisan commission made up of representative sportsmen from all areas of the State."

The largest piece of industrial bond financing to be undertaken under the Securities Acts is in the making. It consists of an issue of $100,000,000 of twenty-year debentures of the American Tobacco Company. Morgan Stanley Co. will head a nation-wide syndicate of underwriters to handle the publice distribution of the issue.

As hundreds of persons watched from the street, roof-tops and windows, members of two police emergency squads yesterday raised a large net and lowered a patrolman from the roof of a fourteen-story apartment building to a tenth floor bathroom window to prevent a possible suicide leap by a distraught woman who had locked herself in the bathroom four hours earlier.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The American Navy is going to take the offensive against the nation's enemies, Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief, United States Fleet, and new Chief of Naval Operations, stated today at a press conference.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (U.P.) -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox announced today that the Navy henceforth would not announce names or types of merchant ships sunk by Axis sea raiders. The order is designed to prevent information of prime military value from reaching the enemy.

THOSE subscribers who don't give a good hoot about ice hockey are herewith warned to overlook this and come back tomorrow. For hockey fans this is the time when things are getting red hot on ice. The play-offs are in the offing. And the Rangers and Bruins play tonight. That's enough to set real hockey followers all aquiver.

Showing plenty of drive and playing heads-up basketball all the way, an inspired Erasmus Hall five dropped James Monroe from the ranks of the unbeaten and gained the final round of the city P.S.A.L. play-offs by beating the Bronx champions, 36 -- 33, in one of two semi-final games at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, has moved with the full support of President Roosevelt to make certain that basic relations with Allied and neutral nations shall be coordinated through one government agency -- the State Department.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 11 -- Americans who are impatient over the progress of our armed forces were urged tonight by Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, to take a lesson in patience from his country.

CHUNGKING, China, March 11 (AP) -- Phyllis Harrop, first foreign woman to escape from Japanese-occupied Hong Kong, today confirmed the report before Britain's House of Commons yesterday by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of the atrocities committed by the conquerors of the British crown colony.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- With the income tax deadline only five days off, hundreds of thousands of small taxpayers today forsook the mysteries of complicated returns and signed up on the Treasury's new simplified income tax blank.

AN AUSTRALIAN PORT, March 11 -- Many possible future lines of attack have been opened up to the Japanese by their capture of Rangoon and virtual completion of their conquest of the Netherlands Indies.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday unless otherwise specified.

George Z. Medalie, former United States Attorney, was re-elected president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, which embraces ninety-one medical and welfare institutions, at a meeting of the board of trustees last night.

A special dispatch from Washington, which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 6, refers to a conversation which took place the day previous between Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles and the Vichy Ambassador, Henry-Haye, in the following terms:
TRENTON, March 11 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison recommended today salary bonuses for State employes earning $3,000 a year or less to help them meet war-boosted living costs.

The Eastman Kodak Company, in its annual report made public today, stated that 1941 was the greatest in its history from the standpoint of sales and operating income, but it said the year "undoubtedly marked the end of the normal business operations of industry in general for some time to come."

CHUNGKING, China, March 11 (U.P.) -- Chinese military observers predicted today that the Japanese would unleash almost immediately a full-scale drive into Northern Burma to cut off China from India and possibly to pave the way for invasion of India.
BERLIN, March 11 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

City College vaulted blithely over N.Y.U. last night and captured the mythical metropolitan basketball championship as well as a place in the national invitation tournament. The Beavers rallied in the second half of their traditional game with the Violet to win, 48 to 47, a feat that received the uproarious acclaim of a gathering of 16,373 at Madison Square Garden.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 11 (AP) -- A Royal Australian Air Force communique said today:

Defending the New York City WPA music project against Congressional criticism, Horace Johnson, director of the project, said yesterday that its current program had been drawn in consultation with officers of the Army and Navy "for the primary purpose of servicing the personnel of the armed forces."
MOSCOW, Thursday, March 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following special communique today:

America's 1,200 cotton textile mills will be asked by their selling agents to allocate at least 50 per cent of their production to contracts that bear approved preference ratings, it was announced last night by the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Prices of hogs dropped 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight today as livestock circles endeavored to adjust the relationship between the cost of live hogs and dressed pork, upon which price ceilings will become effective on March 23.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- For that shellacking inflicted upon them last Monday at Orlando by the Senators, the Yankees had their revenge today with interest. They made Bucky Harris's crew the victims of their first shut-out of the Grapefruit League season, 4 to 0.

The memory of picking peaches on a sunny Summer morning, when the branches and the leaves traced a pattern of shadows on the floor of the orchard, is a pleasant one. And it's a memory that came vividly to mind one dark, chilly day this week when we listened to the soft, slurring speech of a gentleman from Virginia.

Loomis J. Grossman, the operator, has purchased from the Brooklyn Trust Company for cash above a 3 per cent new first mortgage of $58,500 the six-story elevator apartment house at 296 Sterling Place, on the corner of Butler Place, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Renewing a fight started late yesterday over what a strong bi-partisan group declared to be nonessential projects found in the War Department's civil functions appropriation bill, the House today cut $16,700,000 from the measure, then passed it and sent it to the Senate at a total of $333,950,826, including $107,516,810 for maintenance and improvements of the Panama Canal.

While the Japanese in Burma have reached the very border of India, the Conservative Prime Minister of Great Britain dispatches his ranking aide, an extreme Socialist, to win the acceptance of the divergent elements in the Indian world for a precise plan of full dominion status.

DETROIT, March 11 -- Miss Alberta Ward, a bookkeeper, testified today that the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's Radio League of the Little Flower had paid over to his parish more than $1,458,658 since the organization of the league.

CANBERRA, Australia, Thursday, March 12 -- Reports reaching here today said that a Japanese invasion convoy had been sighted en route to Port Moresby, capital of Papua, New Guinea. The reports, broadcast from America and quoting authority regarded as reliable, are not denied by the Australian Government.

Tired of waiting for John L. Lewis to put forward a program whereby members of the United Mine Workers could contribute in an organized way to help win the war, sixty delegates from New Jersey locals of the union have taken the initiative in forming a "victory committee" to speed up the production of war materials, it was announced yesterday by Charles Davey, secretary of the Bergen County Industrial Union Council of the C.I.O.

Yvonne Druian, young American pianist who was graduated from the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia and is now living in Texas, made her New York debut last night at Town Hall. She revealed herself to be a sensitive player with a talent of considerable charm who is not yet fully ready for the rigors of the concert stage.
NEW DELHI, India, March 11 -- Sir Stafford Cripps's mission to India has the Viceroy's heartiest welcome, it is authoritatively stated here.

Labor's Red Cross Mobilization last night at the Cosmopolitan Opera House, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street, brought together 300 executives and Red Cross committee chairmen from the A.F. of L., from the C.I.O. and from independent unions to hear reports on labor's progress toward its $1,000,000 quota.
ROME, March 11 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued the following communique today:

Thomas E. Dewey, chairman of the Navy Relief Society of the Third Naval District, appointed Frank E. Gannett, publisher, chairman of the Navy Relief Society New York State Citizens Committee in ceremonies yesterday in the office of Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the Third Naval District, at 90 Church Street.

An exhibition including paintings by members of the American British Art Center and sculpture by Jacob Epstein will open with a private view on Tuesday afternoon at the center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. Work by contemporary American, British and Australian artists will be included in the group show of paintings.

Madeline Webb, Eli Shonbrun and John D. Cullen were held without bail by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Homicide Court yesterday for hearing March 19 on a short affidavit alleging "suspicion of homicide by strangulation."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Olivia de Havilland will play Olivia Langdon, the wife of Mark Twain, in "The Adventures of Mark Twain," Jesse L. Lasky's next production for Warner Brothers, according to Lasky's present plans, it was learned today.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11 -- It took an odds-on favorite, Happy Note, to break the jinx which had hung over the No. 1 post position in sprint races at Tropical Park. Carrying the silks of Mrs. Aubrey Crouch, the 3-year-old son of Happy Argo never left the result of the Dania Purse in doubt today.

Splitting 20,000 toothpicks and glueing them together isn't much fun anyway and when another fellow gets all the credit, life becomes pretty dark. That's why Allen Simon, 9 years old, is getting his name in the paper.

A man and his wife were killed and five other persons were overcome yesterday morning by coal gas from a defective flue in a two-story apartment house at 718 Schenck Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

LONDON, March 11 -- The stock markets maintained today their cheerful tone. Gilt-edge issues were steady. Home rails continued in demand. Industrials were better again, with the stores, molasses, chemicals and Dunlop shares improved.

TOKYO, March 11 (from Japanese broadcasts recorded by the United Press in New York) -- A Japanese Cabinet Information Board spokesman hinted today that Australia could "come to term" with Japan and escape bloodshed, though Japan's Axis commitments precluded a separate peace.

The war has brought many new problems as well as opportunities for service to the New York Public Library, according to the institution's annual report made yesterday to its board of trustees. The central building of the library and its branches are serving as reservoirs of information about many aspects of the conflict.

Inquiries for credit information received by the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men during February showed an increase of 10 per cent over the preceding month, the bureau announced yesterday. Compared with the same months in 1941, 1940 and 1939, however, the inquiries received in February, 1942, showed a decline of 6, 32 and 3 per cent, respectively, it was stated.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 11 -- An official statement sent by the State Department at Washington and made public here this afternoon said that reports had been brought to the attention of President Roosevelt that the Government of the United States was considering asking the British Government for an indefinite extension of the 99-year leases granted by the British Government to the United States for bases in certain British colonies in the Western Hemisphere.

LONDON, March 11 -- Viscount Kano, 55-year-old former manager of the Yokohama Specie Bank's London branch, today was ordered interned for having said in an interview that Anthony Eden's charges of Japanese atrocities in Hong Kong were "so much propaganda."

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 11 -- Lieut. Gen. V.A.H. Sturdee, Chief of the General Staff, in a general order to the Australian military forces reminds them that wars are won only by offensive action and there can be no half-hearted training measures.
Here is a collection of random notes bringing up to date the publishing career of that poorly written but significant best seller, "Mein Kampf," by Adolf Hitler.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The National Association of Retail Grocers revealed today that the campaign to economize on tires had cut delivery truck mileage among "most" grocers from 15 to 50 per cent. Small grocers have less to start with and deliver a bigger proportion of staples per order, and have, therefore, made a less impressive percentage showing than companies operating ten to fifteen trucks daily.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 11 -- The Cabinet today voted to renew efforts to settle the strike in the Braden Copper Company's El Teniente mine, commissioning Minister of the Interior Alfredo Rosende and Minister of Labor Juan Pradenas, to meet with workers' and company representatives. The strike has been going on for three weeks.

Bundles for America, Inc., since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7 has been extended to forty-six States, where branches are now in operation, Mrs. Owen Cates Torrey, executive vice president, announced yesterday. Only Nevada and West Virginia remain to be enrolled.

LONDON, March 11 -- A further cut of 10 per cent in the consumption of newsprint goes into force next Monday. British newspapers can effect a reduction by reducing the size of the newspaper in the number of pages published or by decreasing the number of copies printed or by a combination of both.

LONDON, March 11 -- The Tirpitz, the mightiest battleship in the German Navy, sister ship of the Bismarck, was attacked by British naval torpedo-carrying planes while sneaking northward along the Norwegian coast, apparently bent on sinking Russian-bound shipping, it was announced tonight.

Two hundred and fifty speakers will address 2,500 student journalists from 450 schools throughout the United States during the eighteenth annual Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention, which will be held at Columbia University today, tomorrow and Saturday.

Although Treasury balances with the Federal Reserve Banks were pulled down sharply last week, dropping $511,000,000 and leaving only $287,000,000, and will show a further but smaller decline this week, the Treasury has not elected to draw on its deposits with commercial bank depositaries.

MANDALAY, Burma, March 11 (AP) -- British forces some 150 miles north of lost Rangoon braced themselves today for expected assaults on Toungoo and Prome by Japanese who already have gained possession of the broad Irrawaddy Delta of Lower Burma.

The five-story building containing two stores and eight apartments on a plot 28 by 100 feet at 1314 Hudson Street, Hoboken, N.J., has been sold by the Ranken Realty Company, R.B. Mattern, president, to Angelo Loukatos, who gave back a purchase money mortgage for $12,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- Prepared for a rush of Japanese-Americans and Japanese nationals seeking aid in disposition of their properties before their evacuation from West Coast military zones, the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco will begin opening offices in leading coastal cities tomorrow.

CHUNGKING, China, March 11 (U.P.) -- Shantung Province guerrilla strongholds have stood firmly in "mopping-up" attacks by 30,000 Japanese, a Chinese Army communique said today as the approach of Spring brought signs of a new Japanese offensive against Changsha, in Honan Province, where thousands of Japanese were killed early this year.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 11 -- The fight of Bermuda women for suffrage seems a step nearer to victory with the presentation of a majority report by a select committee that since last June has been considering the petition of the Woman's Suffrage Society.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The President has often complained that people make proposals to him they don't understand themselves and has asked how, then, can he be expected to. With reference to government economizing in non-war expenses, however, his frequent statement that no advocates of this seem able to give him workable details is not borne out by the record Senator Byrd has made for a long time.

ALBANY, March 11 -- With the State budget and tax program but of the way, leaders of the Legislature turned their attention today to two of the main problems remaining to be solved, namely, rent control and defense legislation.

DETROIT, March 11 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) said today it had complained to Donald M. Nelson, director of the War Production Board, that General Motors Corporation was using "several critical materials in very large quantities" in the manufacture of replacement parts for civilian automobiles.

An appeal to passers-by to turn to the church as a source of faith, courage and strength appeared in Times Square yesterday when a large poster was put up on a billboard behind the police booth in Forty-third Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue.

PEORIA, Ill., March 11 -- Pickets from the ranks of the A.F.L. and C.I.O. who volunteered their aid to members of brotherhoods striking against the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad halted two freight trains today, but a third picked up speed and rumbled through their lines.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 11 -- Yale's polo team rode into the final round of the indoor intercollegiate championship today and will meet Princeton Saturday afternoon in the cadet riding hall for the title. Facing surprisingly stubborn resistance from the Army trio, the Elis came through in the last of the semi-final matches, 7 to 6.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 11 -- The new Hungarian Premier was received in audience today by Vice Regent Stephen Horthy, representing his father, the Regent. It is understood that the conversation turned on future policies and that the Prime Minister indicated he would follow those of his predecessor, Dr. Ladislaus de Bardossy, who remains in a Budapest clinic.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- The Giants' supposedly high-powered offensive, which had exploded in all directions Sunday, faded to a faint whisper today as John Lobert's surprisingly enthusiastic Phils slipped over a 2-to-0 victory.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Marguerite N. Wells, president of the National League of Women Voters, said today that she found the history of the league stimulating rather than discouraging, as the organization prepares to discuss, at its biennial convention in Chicago, the problems of a new war in the light of the original program devised at the end of the last war.

"Our Russian Front," the Soviet feature, which completed a four-week engagement at the Rialto on Tuesday, will be added to the program at the World Theatre on Saturday. On that day the theatre's principal attraction, Sacha Guitry's French comedy, "Nine Bachelors," will begin its sixth week. . . .

A client of the Halleran Agency, broker has purchased from Walter H. Pritchard the two-family dwelling at 35-15 169th Street, Flushing, Queens, on a plot 50 by 100 feet. The apartments contain six rooms each.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he had sold by allotment to the usual twenty-four banks and trust companies $60,000,000 of New York City revenue bills, bearing interest at the rate of 0.50 per cent.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- One-sided victories for the favorites marked the opening of match play in the annual Florida East Coast women's golf tournament today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11 -- Scoring almost at will, the Harvard varsity basketball team made a successful ending of its home season by defeating Pennsylvania, 58 -- 31, tonight in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company had a net profit in 1941 of $5,291,373 after a provision of $9,405,000 for taxes and after a contingency reserve of $500,000, according to the annual report of Homer L. Ferguson, chairman of the board, issued for publication today.

BOULDER, Col., March 11 -- Old Ted, a little mule bleached gray by his years underground, walked out of the Crackerjack coal mine under his own power today and yawned in the faces of weary miners who had dug for nine days to rescue him from a cave-in.

Employment in all plants of the Studebaker Corporation as well as total dollar volume will be at a rate at least two and one-half times that for 1941 when the concern reaches capacity production on its present commitments for various war materials, Paul G. Hoffman, president, disclosed yesterday in his report for 1941 to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Sugar ration books will be handed to more than 131,000,000 Americans in the near future, with distribution to be made by 1,423,000 persons operating in 245,000 elementary schools which have been designated as registration sites, the Office of Price Administration said today in the second of a series of three articles calculated to aid the consumer in understanding the rationing system.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 11 -- The iron hand of Dodger discipline reached out today and seized Johnny Allen, veteran right-handed pitcher.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Professional traders were inclined to press the selling side of wheat futures in the early trading today on the Board of Trade but operations were restricted, and late in the session when smaller shorts tried to cover they found offerings light.

Despite increased taxation and sales of government securities to the public and to institutions other than banks, there is little prospect that the Treasury can avoid reliance on commercial banks to provide substantial amounts of funds required to finance the war effort, according to Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in the bank's twenty-seventh annual report to member bank stockholders.

The Girl Scout movement, founded thirty years ago to promote the friendly virtues of peace, was hailed last night at an anniversary dinner in the Hotel Biltmore as a mighty influence and practical aid to this country in the war.

American bewilderment over the development of naval operations in Far Eastern waters will not be reduced by the Navy Department's comment on a dispatch to The London Daily Mail purporting to reveal the movement of huge American convoys through the Southwest Pacific.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The task of mobilizing 10,500,000 additional men and women this year for work in war factories was described today by John J. Corson, director of the United States Employment Service, as "the biggest job of its kind ever imposed on a democracy."

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Although official reports were lacking concerning the direct measures taken by President Vargas today to place Brazil in position to meet war emergencies, Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, said that on the basis of press reports he assumed the Brazilian Government has been very wise in taking the necessary precautionary measures in view of the indiscriminate and ruthless sinking of Brazilian ships by German and possibly Italian submarines.

"Little Lulu on Parade" is surefire gift material. The book whose cover depicts the youthful cartoon character astride an elephant was the first article to be sold yesterday at the formal opening of the new gift shop and work center of the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States at 746 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The number of employed persons in the United States rose during February by 400,000 to a total of 48,000,000, this representing, collaterally an increase of 200,000 in the number in the labor market, and a decline of 200,000 in the total of jobless, making the current figure 4,000,000, according to the monthly report on the gainfully employed issued by the WPA.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation reported yesterday for 1941 a consolidated net income of $14,206,745 after all charges, taxes and depreciation but before mine depletion, equal to $2.80 each on the 5,071,260 capital shares outstanding. For 1940, the company had reported a net income of $12,603,980 or $2.49 a capital share.

A serious shortage of doctors and nurses in 1943 was predicted yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in an address at the laying of the cornerstone for the Harlem Hospital Dispensary, 137th Street between Lenox and Fifth Avenues.

Reprieves were asked of Governor Lehman yesterday for William and Anthony Esposito, who are to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison tonight for the murder on Jan. 14, 1941, of a payroll messenger and a policeman in a hold-up on Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Control of alien property in the United States was given today by President Roosevelt to Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. He will become Alien Property Custodian and will set up an office within the Office for Emergency Management.

A government agency has made a cash offer in an effort to obtain release of 5,000 tons of metal on property of the defunct New York, Westchester Boston Railway, it was learned yesterday. The metal, needed for war purposes, must be sold, but difficulties over the precise terms of sale have kept it out of reach of munitions makers many months.

Elsewhere on this page the counsel who argued the case in the Supreme Court for the teamsters union contends that this newspaper's editorial of March 5 created "an entirely erroneous impression" of that decision. The best answer to Mr. Boudin's contentions can be found in the dissenting opinion of Chief Justice Stone.

The press of North and South America is the strongest single factor working for promotion of inter-American solidarity and understanding, according to Latin-American students just completing the first "Winter Summer session" at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Retail stores were told today by the Office of Civilian Defense that they must assume direct responsibility for the protection of shoppers in the event of an air raid. A fifteen-page OCD pamphlet suggested regulations for blackouts and other raid precautions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 11 -- The number of Danish workers who have gone to Germany to work in munitions factories and other war industries has now risen to 50,000, according to information from Copenhagen.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- By a 331-46 vote the House of Representatives extended today for the fourth time operations of its Dies Committee on un-American Activities which were due to expire March 31. Today's vote continues its investigations and reportings of findings until the convening of the new Congress on Jan. 3.

Coke pig iron production in February, according to The Iron Age, totaled 4,458,273 net tons, compared with 4,970,531 tons in January. Output on a daily basis last month decreased slightly to 159,188 tons from 160,340 tons in January, while the February operating rate was 96.4 per cent, off slightly from the 97.7 rate in the preceding month.

The eleven-story loft building at 11-13 West Thirty-second Street was sold by the New York Trust Company, as trustee, to an investing client of Alexander Bicks. Spear Co. were the brokers, and Sage, Gray, Todd Sims were attorneys for the seller.

The Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday voted to dismiss Alfred J. Brooks of 1771 Topping Avenue, the Bronx, from the school system. Brooks, a teacher in Public School 61, the Bronx, was found guilty by a trial committee several months ago of conduct unbecoming a teacher.

LONDON, March 11 -- There is mounting uneasiness in London over what can be done to protect the vast areas of the Southwestern Pacific and the Indian Ocean, now that the defensive barrier in Malaya and the Netherlands has been broken by Japan.
LONDON, March 11 -- The text of a statement on the Indian question made today by Prime Minister Winston Churchill in the House of Commons:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.Y., March 11 -- Eighty followers of Father Divine, Negro cult leader, have bought the pretentious Brigantine Hotel in Brigantine, an adjoining resort connected with Atlantic City to the south by a bridge and boulevard.

You certainly made it clear in editorials of Sunday and Monday that maintenance of the forty-hour week means nothing else but wage increases for labor. You also mentioned that by raising the living standards of workers at this time the standards of every one else would be greatly reduced.
Mr. and Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Brooklawn, their home in Unionville, Pa.

LONDON, March 11 -- The campaign in the German press against Sweden is arousing interest here, where it is felt that anything may happen. It is noted that such wars of nerves have in the past preceded the actual opening of hostilities by the Nazis.

The Allied cause is missing a good bet in not giving more publicity to speeches by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek. By accident I heard her just before 9 o'clock Sunday morning, March 8. Her voice is pleasant to listen to, her diction is perfect, what she says carries a punch -- in fact, you realize you are hearing one of the proudest products of Wellesley.

The Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday voted to dismiss Alfred J. Brooks of 1771 Topping Avenue, the Bronx, from the school system. Brooks, a teacher in Public School 61, the Bronx, was found guilty by a trial committee several months ago of conduct unbecoming a teacher.

LONDON, March 11 -- There is mounting uneasiness in London over what can be done to protect the vast areas of the Southwestern Pacific and the Indian Ocean, now that the defensive barrier in Malaya and the Netherlands has been broken by Japan.
LONDON, March 11 -- The text of a statement on the Indian question made today by Prime Minister Winston Churchill in the House of Commons:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.Y., March 11 -- Eighty followers of Father Divine, Negro cult leader, have bought the pretentious Brigantine Hotel in Brigantine, an adjoining resort connected with Atlantic City to the south by a bridge and boulevard.

While fur prices may show renewed strength when Fall manufacturing operations begin, the leveling off of activity in the raw fur market this week should signalize price stability around present levels for some time to come, according to reports in the industry here yesterday.

Declaring that official city time sheets covering three employes of the Bronx Bureau of Sewer and Highway Maintenance had been altered to convey the impression that they were "on vacation" when they actually were engaged in beautifying the Lake Mahopac estate of Edward J. Flynn, Paul J. Kern charged last night that there was an agreement with Bronx Democrats to smother his charges against Mr. Flynn, who is chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

SCHENECTADY, March 11 (AP) -- C.I.O. union spokesmen asserted today that the General Electric Company is producing "far below capacity" and offered to work "for subsistence pay" if G.E. would forego profits on its millions of dollars of war orders.

TOKYO, March 11 (From Japanese Broadcasts recorded by the United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters said today that a Japanese squadron operating west of Australia in the Indian Ocean sank the United States cruiser Marblehead March 9.

Men in the country's armed services who turn from the sword to the cartoonist's pen for recreation were rewarded yesterday afternoon with prizes for their winning entries in the Service Men's Cartoon Contest held under the auspices of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue.

Mozart's "The Magic Flute," the Metropolitan's costliest new production of the season, received its fourth and final performance before a large audience last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Bruno Walter was again the conductor.

RIOM, France, March 11 -- In closing his defense today former Premier Leon Blum avowed his expectation that the Supreme Court before which he stands accused of France's unpreparedness would condemn him on the record of his Popular Front government.

How seriously sales promotion activities of industry will be affected by the growing insistence of the War Production Board that vital materials be given only to essential activities cannot be gauged yet but that there will be some curtailment is inevitable, according to government officials.
MONTERREY, Mex., March 11 (U.P.) -- The case against Dr. Arthur F. Torrance, charged with manslaughter in connection with his wealthy bride's death, was believed closed today.

The Citizens Preparatory Center, Inc., which specializes in welding instruction, is extending its quarters in the building at 9 West Sixty-first Street, where it now occupies the second floor and has leased the remaining upper floors through the Cross Brown Company.

Today the Chinese people mark the anniversary of the death of Sun Yatsen, founder of the Chinese Republic. With the exception perhaps of Gandhi, no man in modern times influenced so great a number of people on the continent of Asia. Yet much of Sun Yatsen's life was spent far from his country.

Explosives, firearms, Axis propaganda material, contraband cameras and short-wave radio receiving sets were confiscated Tuesday night by FBI agents, who also arrested six enemy aliens in the immediate vicinity of the Military Academy at West Point, it was learned yesterday.

Manufacturers of small electrical appliances, using heating elements, originally scheduled to wind up manufacturing operations on March 31 as a result of restrictions on nickel-chrome wire and plating, will probably get a month of grace, it was reported in the local market yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The C.I.O. and the A.F. of L. combined efforts today to sidetrack a House measure requiring government registration of labor unions and trade and business associations. Meanwhile, the Senate heard a request by Senator Lee of Oklahoma for the immediate passage of anti-strike legislation.

The "backbone of medicine and morale" in the city's home defense must be supplied by private charitable institutions, Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, executive director of the New York Catholic Charities, declared yesterday in a report to Archbishop Francis J. Spellman and his committee of the laity.

LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- Premier Pieter S. Gerbrandy of the Netherland Government in Exile declared in a broadcast tonight that the Netherlanders now would carry on guerrilla warfare in the Pacific in preparation for a large-scale offensive in 1943.

The total dollar value of major engineering construction awards during the four-week statistical month of February was $634,823,000, or a weekly average of $158,706,000. The latter figure, the Engineering News-Record points out, tops all previous weekly averages excepting that for July, 1941, when the mean was $191,733,000.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Three months after the entry of the United States into the global war military censorship of news has reached a degree more stringent than ever before in our history. This is worth noting for the contemporary record.

The men's style committee of the National Shoe Retailers Association recommended yesterday that retail stores in the South, Southwest and some parts of the Far West introduce men's sport shoes on Monday and in the rest of the country around April 15 to 30.

BERLIN, March 12 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in London) -- A special High Command communique said today that submarines operating in North and Central American waters had sunk "another" seventeen merchant ships totaling 109,000 tons, a large escort vessel and a submarine chaser.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- During the week ended March 11 member bank reserve balances increased $133,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $227,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks and $4,000,000 in Treasury cash and increases of $4,000,000 in gold stock and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by a decrease of $55,000,000.

All deliveries of women's coats, suits and dresses in the metropolitan area were halted yesterday by a strike of 1,500 A.F. of L. drivers and helpers. The strike, called by Local 102 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to enforce a demand for a blanket wage increase of $5 a week, came at the height of the pre-Easter manufacturing season.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 12 (AP) -- Six Army fliers, including three officers and three enlisted men, were killed last night in the crash of a B-25 medium bomber nine miles east of Yoakum, Texas, Duncan Field officials disclosed today. The machine was burned.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The National War Labor Board rejected a C.I.O. demand for a union shop today and a little while later admitted the public for the first time to a hearing at which the union shop was a vital issue.

Under our American system of jurisprudence the most despised and forsaken individual is entitled to receive the full protection of the law because this land has been dedicated to the principle of justice for all the people, declared Justice John E. MccGeehan yesterday in a decision handed down in Bronx Supreme Court.

OTTAWA, March 12 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada announced today in its weekly statement that Dominion Government deposits increased $217,212,000 to $291,182,000 in the week ended yesterday. It explained that this abnormal change reflected transfer by the government of part of the proceeds of the second Victory loan, on deposit with the chartered banks, to the Bank of Canada.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The National War Labor Board unanimously condemned today "the defiance of the Government of the United States" by officials of the struck Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad and called upon the railroad management "for the last time" to accept arbitration of their wage dispute with the unaffiliated Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx said yesterday afternoon that he would take the Flynn paving case before the Bronx County Grand Jury within a week or ten days on a John Doe inquiry that would include all persons involved in the two city investigations that laid the groundwork for his action.
The leasing of several large apartments was reported yesterday by brokers.

Unless they wish to know their order number as soon as the results of the national lottery in Washington are announced by radio next Tuesday evening, men enrolled in the third registration for Selective Service will not have to visit their local draft boards beforehand to ascertain their serial numbers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 12 -- The size of the proposed Westchester County airport adjacent to Rye Lake in Purchase was increased today to 503 acres and the price raised to $285,316 because of a Civil Aeronautics Administration request that all property under option be acquired.

The Argentine Government is effecting economies in foreign-debt services, particularly on high interest-bearing securities, by using its blocked sterling balances in London to buy Argentine bonds there, according to the Argentine Information Bureau here.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 12 -- Because he said he was unable to certify "honestly" that the sixty employes of his office had performed their duties since March 1, Hudson County Registrar James F. Murray held up today the payroll for the first half of March.

The first investigation by the Department of Justice to determine compliance with a WPB order came to light yesterday when worsted yarn houses, sweater manufacturers and contracting jobbers received questionnaires requiring them to report their yarn stocks as of the end of February this year and a year ago.

An unknown "knight" made a stealthy visit to the headquarters of a woman's organization early this week and left such startling evidence of his presence that the women have been in a dither ever since. Finally, desperate with natural curiosity, they decided yesterday to publicize the fact that some one had made them temporary owners of:
Ezio Pinza, Metropolitan Opera basso, has been detained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and taken to Ellis Island, it was learned yesterday.

Three national labor leaders who represent 11,000,000 organized workers in the nation called last night upon the 1,250,000 unionists in this city to rally to the support of the Greater New York Fund as a vital instrument for forging national morale and unity.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The first of a series of provisional reports showing relative scarcity of certain materials was issued by the Conservation and Substitution Branch of the Bureau of Industrial Conservation. Harvey A. Anderson, branch chief, said similar reports will be issued at regular intervals to reflect changing conditions.

LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- Heavy Soviet tank forces were reported smashing ahead today in the Orel sector 250 miles north of Kharkov. The German High Command admitted over the Berlin radio that the Russians had broken through the line northeast of Orel and that the mass attack had put the Germans entirely on the defensive.

IN 1939 John Steinbeck's "The Grapes of Wrath" focused the attention of a nation on the plight of the uprooted Okies who had streamed into a California which no longer needed any new agricultural migrants. The whole problem, however, was generally dismissed as something which concerned the interlocking relationships of the Dust Bowl and the Pacific Southwest.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Three enemy freighters and one passenger-cargo ship have been sunk by an American submarine operating in Japanese waters, the Navy Department announced this afternoon. The communique said also that one of two fourengined Japanese seaplanes engaged west of Midway Island in the Central Pacific had been shot down by our fighters on Tuesday.

The American Rolling Mill Company reported yesterday for 1941 a profit of $11,228,475, equal to $3.21 a common share, against $7,642,714, or $1.96 a share, in 1940. The annual report, signed by George M. Verity, chairman, and Charles R. Hook, president, said the profit was the largest in the company's history.

HONOLULU, March 12 -- A second lieutenant and a staff sergeant who shot down a Japanese plane with automatic rifles on Dec. 7 stood before their regiment today and received from their commandng officer the Silver Star decoration for gallantry.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- "Patch it up -- don't throw it out" is the advice given by the Consumer Division of the Office of Price Administration to all persons who find their rubber raincoats, hot-water bottles or overshoes showing signs of wear.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- More than 700 young women from many States and some from Puerto Rico and Honolulu will begin to arrive here tomorrow for the festivities of Princeton University's annual junior promenade weekend.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- An order forbidding the manufacture of children's bicycles, but permitting an increase of nearly 300 per cent in the rate of production of bicycles for adults, was issued today by the War Production Board. The ban on children's machines becomes effective April 1.
New formulae for beauty are hidden beneath the lid of a miniature Mexican wedding chest of white-painted wood decorated with bright birds and blossoms.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Six veteran candidates for the Governorship, traveling for years in search of the Fountain of Political Youth, discovered it tonight, only to find Ponce de Lehman in control, as sole proprietor. The Governor, holding the contents of the fountain to be "a military secret," left Messrs.

Yesterday's weekly statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted and the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities decreased $9,250,000.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The evacuation and identification of children in the event of air raids are among the subjects on the agenda for the first meeting, next week, of the Commission on Children in Wartime, it was announced today by Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau.

CHUNGKING, China, March 12 -- According to a report from the Northwest Institute of Research, which is a Chinese Government organization founded shortly after the Japanese seized Manchuria and which collects information on conditions obtaining in occupied territories, labor conscription is being carried out by the Japanese exploiters on a staggering scale.

I have read, with interest and approval, your editorials of March 8 and 9 on the subject of the forty-hour week. There is a definite, determined trend of politically powerful groups to change the meaning and purpose of a law after its enactment.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 12 -- Armed with warrants, fifty agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and fifty Nassau County detectives searched the homes and business establishments of suspected enemy aliens in Nassau County today, taking into custody only those possessing firearms, outlawed radios, cameras and binoculars.

Congress seems to have adopted the Dies committee as one of its permanent fixtures. It was on May 26, 1938 that the House by a voice vote passed the resolution providing for the appointment of the seven-man committee to investigate un-American propaganda in the United States.

The Theatrical Artists' Representatives Association announced yesterday the election of William Morris as president. Other officers elected are Martin Jurow, first vice president; Walter Batchelor, second vice president; Jane Broder, third vice president; Olga Lee, secretary, and Eve Gincher, treasurer.

Countless friends of Oswald Garrison Villard will be telling him today, on the occasion of his seventieth birthday, that though they don't always agree with him they do have for him the deepest admiration, respect and affection. It has long been Mr. Villard's lot to be disagreed with by his loving friends. Following wherever his conscience led, he has done a good deal of disagreeing himself.

The draw was completed yesterday for the national invitation tournament when the West Virginia quintet was named for the eighth and last remaining spot in the brackets. The Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Committee met at the Hotel Biltmore, seeded its teams and ironed out all details for the show at Madison Square Garden on March 17, 19, 23 and 25.

Local, State and national officers of 1,100 Junior Chamber of Commerce associations in all parts of the country have been asked in letters mailed recently to call on Congress to enact a labor policy freezing the closed-shop issue and prohibiting strikes for the duration of the war, it was disclosed yesterday.

Among those who arrived yesterday aboard a Pan American Airways Clipper at La Guardia Field was Air Vice Mairshal Robert Leckie of the Royal Air Force, in charge of training pilots for the Royal Canadian Air Force. He had attended a conference on pilot training in London at which United States naval and Army officers were present.

ON BATAAN PENINSULA, March 9 (Delayed) -- With the war in the Pacific entering its fourth month, Japan's propaganda machine is working overtime in efforts to crack both General Douglas MacArthur's troops and Filipino civilians into capitulation.

RIOM, France, March 12 -- Pierr Jacomet, former Secretary-General of the French War Ministry who is accused with ministerial and military chieftains of responsibility for France's unpreparedness, pleaded not guilty today in answering charges in the Supreme Court here.

In voting to forbid the Commodity Credit Corporation from selling Government-held farm surpluses below parity prices the House of Representatives has given one more demonstration of the seeming inability of Congress to rise above conventional smalltime politics in this period of great national danger.

I'll put it this way: If all our equipment now involved in war production were used twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, we would practically double the man-hours being put into military production.

Some fifty refugee cats that have been left ashore on the Chelsea piers along the North River front are being fed by dockmen and the crews of foreign freighters that are tied up there, it was learned yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- Joe DiMaggio agreed to terms with the Yankees late tonight in a conference with Edward G. Barrow, the club president.

An ingenious coin-operated device named the Drive-Mobile, in which the player attempts to pilot a miniature automobile between goals labeled New York and Los Angeles, was demonstrated yesterday before Magistrate Samuel Orr in the West Fifty-fourth Street police station.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 12--The value of the estate left by Mortimer N. Buckner of 142 East Seventy-first Street, Manhattan, and a Summer resident of Fishers Island, does not exceed $120,000, all of which is personal property, according to a petition for the probate of his will filed with Surrogate Richard W. Hawkins of Suffolk County, it was announced today.

CLEVELAND, March 12 (AP) -- Representatives of Robert R. Young and Allan P. Kirby of New York rejected today a $566,000 cash offer from Charles L. Bradley and John P. Murphy of Cleveland to complete purchase of securities controlling the Higbee Company here.

LONDON, March 12 (U.P.) -- American-made dive bombers soon will join in the offensive of the Royal Air Force against German industry and German warships, which has been launched with devastating raids on the munitions center of Essen, the Paris industrial suburbs and on German battleships, official informants said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Secretary Knox approved today award of the Navy Cross to fourteen officers who distinguished themselves in action during a Japanese bombardment of the Cavite naval base and letters of commendation to three civilians who were employed there.

CHUNGKING, China, March 12 (U.P.) -- Crack, hardened Chinese armies holding the left wing of the Allied defense line in Burma and an estimated 56,000 Japanese were reported squaring off today in the wilderness along Thailand's frontier for a supreme battle for Mandalay, the Burma Road and the route to India.
ROME, March 12 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:
