WARDHA, India, March 12 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi exhorted Britain today to confess that her imperialism "has been the greatest crime against India" and to undo it, but he added sadly:

The cotton market failed yesterday to respond to the action of the House late on Wednesday in voting to forbid the sale by the Commodity Credit Corporation of government-held farm commodities below parity prices. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures moved within a 10-point range in quiet trading and finished at levels 1 point lower to 3 points higher than the previous close.

The delay in obtaining the 370 air raid sirens still needed to give the city's population an adequate air raid warning system, which has become a serious problem to city officials, is being caused not so much by the demand of other cities for sirens as by the failure of the city to receive from the War Production Board a priority rating for sirens for which it applied on March 3, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Roosevelt was said on Capitol Hill today to be considering proposals to put ceilings on wages, profits and prices, as demands for over-all control during the war emergency continued to be received by members responsible for framing the greatest tax bill in history.

News of the sinking of the Jewish refugee ship Struma in the Black Sea has stirred up indignation in this country as the facts have become known. The Struma was the last of many vessels on which refugees from Central Europe have attempted to reach Palestine -- or at least to get free of their cruel oppressors. It was fifty feet long and it was carrying 769 exiles.

LONDON, March 12 -- Preparing for possible attack on Ceylon, Admiral Sir Geoffrey Layton, Commander in Chief of that British base off the southern tip of India, today announced plans for evacuation of noncombatants. Many civilians already have been evacuated from danger zones to camps prepared in other parts of the island.

Buses will replace trolley cars on the Fifty-ninth Street and Tenth Avenue lines of the Third Avenue Railway System, starting at 7 A.M. on Sunday, the company announced yesterday from its offices at 2396 Third Avenue. Thirty buses, each with a capacity of forty-four passengers, will be assigned to the service, twenty on the Fifty-ninth Street run and ten on the Tenth Avenue route.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 12 -- The Cariocans -- as the residents of Rio proudly call themselves -- took the law into their own hands this afternoon by smashing German stores and attacking other Axis establishments in reprisal for the sinking of Brazilian ships.

MIAMI, Fla., March 12 -- Elmer Stever, husky young left-hander from Woodside, Queens, came close to recording a major upset in favor of our military forces today by giving the Giants a battle in an exhibition game played at the nearby Opa-Locka Naval Air Station.
MOSCOW, March 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The State Department said today that small amounts of United States Government funds will be advanced to American nationals in enemy and enemy occupied territories, except the Philippines, sufficient to meet the ordinary needs of existence.

The Brooklyn Museum's exhibition of print techniques will reopen today in the Balcony Gallery. This display, when it was installed in October, illustrated the various hand techniques employed in the graphic arts. The new installation includes a more extensive showing of the silk screen printing process and other new features.

The preliminary annual statement of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and its subsidiaries shows a net profit for the year ended on Dec. 31 of $2,904,170 after interest, $200,000 reserve for contingencies, Federal Income and excess profits taxes and other charges.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 12 -- The recent Australian aerial offensive against the spearhead of the Japanese invasion fleet that was heading for Port Moresby, New Guinea, was believed tonight to have sunk or otherwise knocked out of action thirteen transports and warships, and to have staved off the enemy threat for the time being.

The services that advertising performs in war time were emphasized yesterday by two associations in the field, the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, and the Associated Business Papers. The bureau announced the first of a special series of ads directed to the people of this country and Canada, while the A.B.P. issued a "Guide to Effective War-Time Advertising."

The Blizzard Men of 1888, an organization of New Yorkers who witnessed Nature's memorable blitzkrieg of March 12, 1888, held their thirteenth annual luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, but the blizzard played second fiddle to the war and how to win it.

Latest news from the Consumers' Service Bureau of the Department of Markets centers about pork. All cuts listed on the department's recent report advanced again this week an average of a penny. And the peak, shoppers will be glad to hear, may now have been reached.

PEORIA, Ill., March 12 -- George P. McNear Jr., president of the Toledo, Perio Western Railroad, said tonight that "we are not going to be buffaloed or cave in" and asserted he would have "a counter-statement" tomorrow.

" Louisiana Purchase," the Morrie Ryskind-Irving Berlin musical comedy, which for a time seemed headed back to Broadway after a successful tour, will not get here after all. Some of the cast, it seems, have moving-picture commitments and others want a rest, and so A.L. Berman, aide-de-camp to B.G. DeSylva, the producer, has had to abandon his intention of returning it, as he had hoped, at a $3.30 top.

With 157 tons of tin cans set out on New York sidewalks to be converted into vital material for war tools, the two-day salvage drive definitely was a success, and it will be repeated on March 25 and 26, Clarence H. Low, chairman of the City Salvage Committee, announced last night.
An initial dividend of $1.25 a share on its preferred stock was voted yesterday by the Follansbee Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Senator Byrd, chairman of the joint Congressional economy committee, contended today that a Todd Shipyards Corporation's fee of $4,070,000 for the construction of thirty-seven maritime commission vessels at Houston, Texas, was exorbitant, despite company testimony that 75 or 80 per cent of the money would go back to the government in taxes.

The New York Stock Exchange will increase its commissions an average of 25 per cent on Monday. Results of the polling of the membership are not yet completely tabulated but officials of the institution reported last night that 996 ballots had been cast and that the proposal appeared to have won a 4-to-1 approval.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Having voted to assure parity price levels to farm commodities, to pay benefits to increase sugar production for the food-for-freedom program and to continue crop insurance for at least another year, the House started swinging the "economy" cleaver on the $650,000,000 Agriculture Department Supply Bill late today.

Application for membership in the Federal Reserve System has been made by J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., it was disclosed yesterday. Since the institution's status was changed from that of a banking partnership to a commercial bank, as of April 1, 1940, it has been the largest bank in the country not a member of the Reserve System.

MOSCOW, March 12--The Red Army has broken through strongly held German lines at several places on the southern front, killing 2,000 Nazis and seizing two large junction points, front-line dispatches reported today.

Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran informed Mayor La Guardia yesterday that, despite a substantial increase the in the number of cases and fines in the Magistrates Courts, the judges and staff have undertaken "as part of the general war effort, to do more work with fewer people."

MOSCOW, March 12 -- The encircled Sixteenth German Army is killing and eating its horses as the remnants of four or five divisions shrink in the tightening Russian ring, according to today's reports from the Staraya Russa sector. "Pate a la Staraya Russa" is what the Russian press calls the minced horse spread for which a recipe was found in captured German circulars.

KINHUA, Chekiang Province, China, March 9 (delayed) (AP) -- All news obtainable from evacuees and other sources indicates that American and British nationals in Shanghai and other occupied cities of East China are safe, but their financial difficulties are increasing, their food is limited and their freedom restricted in varying degrees.

CHUNGKING, China, March 12 -- Japanese invasion troops are storming the harbor city of Siangshan on the Central China coast in Chekiang Province in an apparent attempt to gain another base from which to protect long communications lines to the Southwestern Pacific, official war dispatches said today.

The official designation of the fund for which Joe Louis will risk his heavyweight championship of the world against Abe Simon at Madison Square Garden on March 27 will be the Army Emergency Relief, it was decided yesterday at a conference attended by a number of military notables and Mike Jacobs, promoter of the show.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Such frozen alien assets as the gold of the Bank of France in the United States will remain under the control of the Treasury, but alien business enterprises will be taken over by the Alien Property Custodian, it was stated today by Secretary Morgenthau and Leo T. Crowley, custodian, at a joint press conference.

The death of Sir William Henry Bragg, who with his son won the Nobel Prize for placing the new science of X-ray spectroscopy on a solid basis, is a grievous loss to his country and to the world not only because of his position in the world of physicists but because of the technical counsel that he was giving to half a dozen scientific war commissions.
May I congratulate you on the handling of the National Victory Garden Program in Topics of The Times of March 9. That was a very sane presentation of the subject.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 12 -- Joseph G. Coates, member of the War Cabinet, and D.G. Sullivan, the Minister of Munitions, reached home today after discussions in Australia, greatly heartened by the outcome of their errand.

The tentative agreement on a wage rise for clothing workers will add further to the rise in cost of men's clothing for Fall, manufacturers said here yesterday. Most makers expect to have their final costs figured by the end of next week and indications are that wholesale prices may advance as much as $3 over those now prevailing on Spring merchandise, and retail prices as much as $5.

Concerning the bombing of the environs of Paris, public opinion in this country seems to differ. Arthur Krock in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 6 reports that signs were to be discerned, among strong supporters of the anti-Axis war, of regret mingled with disapproval, and that the Ambassador of Vichy to Washington showed more indignation over the recent bombing of Paris than over any similar consequences of the unhappy situation of occupied France.

George A. Sloan, Commissioner of Commerce of New York City and president of the Metropolitan Opera Association, has been named president of the Nutrition Foundation, Inc., recently founded by a group of food industries "to develop and apply the science of nutrition for the improvement of the diet and health of the American people."

LONDON, March 12 -- Rankling dissatisfaction in some quarters of the House of Commons over the recent reorganization of the government manifested itself afresh today when Prime Minister Winston Churchill undertook to explain the vast powers he had assigned to Oliver Lyttelton, who as Minister of Production will bear full responsibility for building the nation's war machine.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Federal war agencies joined today in telling the housewife that her coffee supply would not be materially affected by the order calling Brazilian vessels to home ports and stopping further sailings of Brazilian ships.
BERLIN, March 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A German High Command communique said today:

Irving Nitzberg, reputedly a killer imported from the Bronx by Brooklyn's murder ring, was convicted for the second time of murder in the first degree in the killing of Albert Shuman in Brooklyn on Jan. 9, 1939, by a jury that returned its verdict last midnight.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 12 -- The seizure of fourteen newspapers and periodicals by orders of the government in Stockholm increased uneasiness in Sweden today. The reason advanced was that the newspapers had printed information "unfriendly to a foreign power."

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, asserted before the House Rules Committee today that the commission had no preconceived plan to break up joint newspaper-radio ownership of broadcasting stations.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 7 were 28 per cent above those in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Last week's comparison showed a gain of 19 per cent.

The steady erosion of values of stocks in the last two weeks was checked yesterday, at least temporarily, as the market assumed an offensive position when opening weakness failed to induce further liquidation of importance. For lack of any better interpretation of this situation, brokers attributed the stand to technicalities, or an over-sold condition.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Amateur photographers were urged today by Byron Price, Director of Censorship, to refrain from taking pictures of anything of a military nature lest vital information be made available to the enemy.

Four additional ship sinkings by enemy submarines operating on the American side of the Atlantic became known yesterday. In Washington the Navy Department announced the torpedoing of a medium-sized British tanker and a small Swedish freighter in the Caribbean area, while British authorities in Nassau disclosed that survivors of another vessel had reached there.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Acting on reports that the Japanese Government is seeking to establish a mission to the Holy See, the State Department has made representations to the Vatican expressing disapproval of the project, it was learned here tonight.

With a single exception the performances given by Sergei Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall must be ranked among their most brilliant accomplishments of late seasons in this city. The exception was the reading of Mozart's "Jupiter" symphony that opened the concert.

The charter of a New York local of the United Mine Workers was revoked yesterday by personal order of John L. Lewis after a three-month controversy in which its officers accused Mr. Lewis of adopting an attitude of "appeasement" and non-cooperation toward war work.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 12 -- Apparently almost oblivious of their surroundings and what was being done to them, William and Anthony Esposito were put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison tonight for the murder of Patrolman Edward F. Maher, who was shot to death as he pursued the brothers after a hold-up in New York City on Jan. 14, 1941.

The fourth and last of the free "all-out" concerts for the War Fund Drive of the American Red Cross was given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall before an enthusiastic audience. Elisabeth Rethberg, soprano, and Richard Bonelli, baritone, both of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, duo-pianists, provided the program.

Bank clearings for the leading twenty-three cities amounted in the week ended on Wednesday to $6,369,250,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was a drop of $1,536,859,000, or 19.4 per cent, from the previous week, but it represented a gain of 16.6 per cent from the $5,464,727,000 in the similar week last year.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12 -- Public sentiment in favor of a law to forbid strikes in the defense industries has shown a sharp and dramatic increase since America entered the war. Throughout every section, every income group, every age group and among the rank and file of both political parties such a law is favored today by an overwhelming vote which averages nearly nine to one for the country as a whole.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- About 25,000,000 men from 20 to 44 now registered under the selective service system will be required to list their occupational skills which may be needed in war production industries, the service said today.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- In a Moscow hospital there are 160 children, mostly under 10 years of age, each of whom is a deliberate victim of German soldiers. These are not casual victims of bombing or artillery fire caught up in the machinery of war by mischance.

BOSTON, March 12 -- Although strong measures must be taken now to protect the country against sabotage and other subversive activities, government control in the post-war period should be strongly curbed, speakers declared tonight at the opening session of Boston University's annual founder's day observance, which this year is a celebration also of the seventieth anniversary of the founding of the university's school of law.

LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- The Stockholm correspondent of The News Chronicle reported today that the huge, new German battleship Tirpitz, which put back into a Norwegian port after being attacked Monday by British torpedo-carrying planes, failed to get within 300 miles of "her prospective prey," a convoy that now has reached Russia.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Contracts for Army uniforms are being distributed on principles laid down by a committee of purchasing experts and not along lines dictated by Sidney Hillman, head of the War Production Board's Labor Division, or by any other spokesman for labor, WPB executives stated today.
A new record for the number of persons appearing at the Federal income tax offices in the Second and Third districts was established yesterday, when more than 35,000 returns were filed.

DENVER, March 12 (AP) -- Nineteen of the country's major distilling companies were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of fixing wholesale and retail liquor prices in violation of the anti-trust statutes. The indictment also named eight wholesale liquor dealers, two liquor associations and fifty-four individuals.

THE loudest laugh of the Spring training season to date came in the thick of the On Again-Off Again-Back Again Allen imbroglio when Manager Lippy Leo Durocher announced calmly that Johnny had been suspended "for conduct unbecoming a Dodger"! Now, what in the world could that be? Maybe he did the Indian rope trick without a rope.

LONDON, March 12 -- Americans and nationals of some other countries living in Britain shortly will be able to drive automobiles and go out at night without getting special permits and generally will enjoy the privileges of British civilians.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Roosevelt originated the idea of constructing a $600,000 building in central Washington to house the Office of Government Reports and chose the location, Lowell Mellett, director of the information agency, told the joint Congressional Economy Committee today.

The New York Rangers were beaten in their last home stand of the regular National Hockey League season by the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 1, last night in Madison Square Garden. The Bruins thereby tightened the race for first place in the closing stages of the campaign.

The local Brazilian papers are encouraging us with optimistic news from American sources regarding our commercial and financial relations. Secretary Morgenthau's plan regarding the establishment of a stabilized currency for South America is ingenious but impracticable in the financial sense.

The brush between British planes and the great German battleship Tirpitz off Norway not only is another episode in the recurring drama of the "new warfare" at sea, but also offers redundant proof of the importance of Norway in the war's strategy.

According to plans under discussion, the Southern New England Telephone Company, a unit in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company system, intends to raise between $6,000,000 and $8,000,000 of new money to facilitate its expansion program.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- An "official plan book" of directions for speeding the war production drive was sent to labor-management committees of the country's mills and factories today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

NEW DELHI, India, March 12 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, semi-retired spiritual leader of India's Hindu millions, will preside over a meeting of the Congress Party Working Committee at Wardha on March 17 to discuss the forthcoming visit of Sir Stafford Cripps.
Trading in the Bronx shows increasing activity.

WASHINGTON, March 12--An increase of more than 100 per cent in pilot training by the Civilian Aeronautics Authority was ordered today as part of the program to expand the Army air forces to 2,000,000 men.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 12 -- The Renault motor works outside Paris were almost entirely wrecked in the Royal Air Force raid on March 3, according to an eyewitness who has just arrived in Stockholm.

TOKYO, March 12 (From broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco and New York) -- Premier Hideki Tojo told Parliament today that Japan planned even "more vigorous" operations against the United States and Great Britain, and Navy Minister Admiral Shigetaro Shimada listed Japanese losses so far in the war as nineteen warships and twenty-seven transports.

Serge Rubinstein denied yesterday repeatedly that the Chosen Union of Mines (Chosen Godo Kozan Kabushiki Kaisha) was his creature, that it was formed with his money or at his prompting or that he had ever held shares in it until after the Chosen Corporation had disposed of its interest in the Nurupi Mining Company, Ltd., once a subsidiary.

Deliveries of war materials by the General Motors Corporation in the first quarter of 1942 are expected to show an increase of 50 per cent over shipments to the government in the final quarter of 1941, and a gain of more than 100 per cent compared with the third quarter of last year, Alfred J. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation, says in his quarterly letter to stockholders.

The official documents and public statements dealing with this country's efforts to keep the peace and with the events that made our entry into the war inevitable are being compiled into a so-called American White Paper. Ruby Black, Washington newspaper woman, with the cooperation of members of the Committee for Nationale Morale, is editing the book for Alliance.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Dubonnet of the Savoy-Plaza entertained with a dinner at the hotel last night for Mrs. Frederick McEvoy of the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Stevenson Scott, Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. Foss, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Watson Jr. and Mrs. Helen Talley.
Deputy Chief Inspector Harry L. Lobdell, head of the uniformed city police in Queens, filed application yesterday for retirement as of midnight.
The national amateur squash tennis championship started on the Yale Club courts last night with Joseph Lordi of the New York A.C. in the role of defending titleholder.

" Always In My Heart," which opens at the Strand, is today's lone screen newcomer. The film introduces a 15-year-old singer, Gloria Warren, with Walter Huston and Kay Francis in the other leading roles. The featured cast includes Frankie Thomas, Armida, Patty Hale and Borrah Minnevitch and his Harmonica Rascals. . . .

Two thousand five hundred and seventy-six boys and girls, delegates from 250 schools in twenty-three States gathered on Columbia University Campus yesterday for the eighteenth annual Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention, which will continue today and tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- John J. Burns, counsel for the United Corporation, testified today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission that if the plan to reduce the par value of the concern's preferred stock from $50 to $5 a share were approved, dividend arrearages amounting to $7,466,136 would be met promptly.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Grain traders placed a bullish construction on the action of the House in passing the amendments to the Department of Agriculture bill late yesterday which seeks to prevent the Commodity Credit Corporation from selling its holdings of grain below the so-called parity price.

Metropolitan skiing enthusiasts will have to travel a considerable distance to get any good running this week-end, for recent rains, combined with rising temperatures, have ruined the snow covers of many Eastern slopes and trails.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Wholesale prices during the Week ended on March 7 fluctuated within a narrow margin, with the general level rising slightly to a new thirteen-year peak, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, advanced to 96.9 last week, compared with 96.8 on Feb. 28, 96.5 on Feb. 21, 95.7 on Feb. 7 and 80.6 on March 8, 1941.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Loyal members of the Catholic Church were urged today by the Rt. Rev. Mgr. Michael J. Ready to rally to her defense against "enemies" seeking alike to destroy her mission and the human rights of free peoples everywhere.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- An offer to help in clearing plans for "pooled" deliveries worked out by retailers in the interests of greater conservation through the Department of Justice was made by the War Production Board's Office of Defense Transportation today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12--Leo McCarey's first film under a two-picture producing-directing contract with RKO will be "Beloved Saboteur," in which Ginger Rogers and Cary Grant will be starred, it was learned today. The McCarey deal is not yet actually signed, because the producer-director is still working out the settlement of a previous agreement with Howard Hughes.

More than 6,000 dozen daffodils and 2,000 dozen tulips are arriving daily in city flower markets, the major part being brought by truck from near-by greenhouses, with a few scattered shipments from Southern areas completing the total.

LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- The Bank of England reported today a decrease of almost 15,000,000 in private deposits for the week. Note circulation increased for the third consecutive week with a rise of more than 2,000,000.

An increase of 10 per cent in gross revenues and one of more than 8 per cent in telephones in service at the end of the year are shown in the annual report of the General Telephone Corporation for 1941, issued yesterday by Harold V. Bozell, president.

German aircraft engines are built of excellent materials and use gasoline of a higher octane number than was generally believed in this country, but a comparable American-built engine has a better power output a pound, 360 delegates to the two-day national aeronautic meeting sponsored by the Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., were told yesterday.
The Police Department seemed astonished yesterday over the sudden protest against the distribution of warning tags contributed by local merchants.
LONDON, March 12 -- The stock markets made a good showing today. Advance reinvestment of Canadian money improved Canadian Pacific stock.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Staff Sergeant Joseph Lockard was decorated with the Distinguished Service Medal by the Under-Secretary of War, Robert P. Patterson, today "for exceptionally meritorious service" to the nation.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Problems of the United Nations in conducting their war against Japan in the Southwest Pacific were placed before President Roosevelt today in three separate conferences.

The National Dairy Products Corporation reported in the annual statement which will be sent today to its 68,820 stockholders that its net sales of $431,049,000 in 1941 established a new high record and were an increase of $83,639,000, or 24 per cent, over the volume of the previous year.

Any number of reasons, in the opinion of this column, back up the Supreme Court justice who has just declared unconstitutional the new city law against street peddlers. Among other reasons is the time we live in. The court ruled that the itinerant merchant has always performed a useful economic function.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The flexibility of the sugar rationing plan was described today by the Office of Price Administration in the last of three articles explaining to the public the whys and wherefores of the coming sugar distribution system.

LONDON, March 12 -- Further gasoline restrictions, designed to take pleasure cars off the roads, were announced in the House of Commons today by Geoffrey Lloyd, the Board of Trade's Parliamentary Secretary for Petroleum. Cuts in fuel rations will be graduated, not becoming fully effective until July.

Dressed in a ragged array of ancient clothing, Alice Jones, who thinks she is "about 70 years old," walked into the West 126th Street Station yesterday and reported that some one had stolen $10,000 in cash and bank books showing deposits of more than $40,000 from her rooms at 225 East 125th Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago and Lawson Little of San Francisco turned in two-under-par 70s today to share leadership at the halfway point in the $4,350 Victory golf tournament at the Seminole Club.

Possibly Paul Draper did not know that he was the hero of ordinary theatregoers. But he knows it now. Toward the close of a mediocre vaudeville show, "Priorities of 1942," he came on the stage of the Forty-sixth Street Theatre last evening to try two or three of his lean and crisp dances, and the audience would not let him go.

Private Marion T. Payne of Alabama, stationed at Fort Monmouth, N.J., was held in $1,200 bail in Felony Court yesterday on charges growing out of an alleged assault on Patrolman James Sloane of the West 123d Street station.

PATERSON, N.J., March 12 -- Harold D. Rhodes, an Alderman from Paterson's Fifth Ward, was dismissed today as secretary to the Passaic County Road Department by the Board of Freeholders because of alleged shortages in his accounts and then he was arrested on three charges of forgery and one of embezzlement on orders from County Prosecutor Arthur C. Dunn.

Argentina and her little company of Spanish and Latin-American dancers and musicians will begin a final series of three performances at the Shubert Theatre tonight, with further presentations tomorrow and Sunday evenings. This extension of the season's schedule has been made in response to the demand for seats at the three performances given at the last week-end when many people were turned away.

MIAMI, Fla., March 12 -- The six-furlong track record was equaled at Tropical Park today by N.S. McCarthy's Augury, a 5-year-old mare who had been shipped across the continent from California and was making her first start in Florida.

BOONTON, N.J., March 12 -- Claude Habberstad of Sheep Hill demonstrated a set of wooden automobile tires on Route 6 today. He got the speed up to seventy-five miles an hour on the smooth concrete highway. Vibration increased but not to an annoying degree.
A client of the Colonial Realty Company, Inc., has purchased for occupancy from Churchill Pond, painters, the two-family building at 88 Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn.

Opening the 1942 fund appeal of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman and other campaign leaders yesterday urged New Yorkers to show that the democratic way of life can continue to meet additional wartime responsibilities to the poor and afflicted.

The vacant, irregularly shaped block bounded by Skillman Avenue and Forty-third Avenue, Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets, Long Island City, has been sold by the trustees of Series Q to Hell's Kitchen, Inc. The latter concern will erect on the land a factory building to be occupied by a subsidiary which manufactures war materials.

The six-story store and loft building at 137-9 Wooster Street has been sold by the United States Trust Company to a client of Jerome Tanenbaum, broker. It contains 30,000 square feet and was owned by the seller for thirty-four years. Stewart Shearer, attorneys, represented the seller, and Irving B. Loonin acted for the buyer.

ROME, March 12 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Three British cruisers were hit, one of them probably was sunk, and other ships were damaged yesterday in an attack on a large British naval formation in the Eastern Mediterranean, the Italian High Command said today.

Seeing a "real and grave" danger to New York City's congested areas if air raids should come, the United Neighborhood Houses of New York recommended yesterday to Mayor La Guardia a "thorough overhauling" of the air raid warden system, including the appointment of a full-time paid civilian director, who would welcome, not squelch, constructive criticism.
Cimon P. Diamantopoulos, the Greek Minister, and Mrs. Diamantopoulos have arrived from Denver, and are at the Pierre.

Reflecting the steadily increased participation by commercial banks in financing war industries, commercial loans of the sixteen regular reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $40,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,774,000,000, highest since 1930.

Leedy, Wheeler Co. and Robert Hawkins Co. were the successful bidders yesterday for $225,000 of hospital building certificates of the city of Tallahassee, Fla., receiving the award on their bid of 100.299 for a fixed interest rate of 2 per cent. The bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1942, will mature serially on Jan. 1, 1943 to 1951.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- Johnny Allen, veteran right-hand hurler, who yesterday was suspended indefinitely for violation of training rules, today was reinstated without penalty.

A chance at the light-heavyweight championship of the world will be the prize when Johnny Colan, West Side warrior, and Jimmy Webb of Houston, Texas, clash in the star bout of twelve rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 12 (AP) -- A sudden rainstorm and some 2,500 civil and military police late this afternoon finally dispersed the crowds that had stormed Axis businesses, causing heavy damage and injuring a few Axis nationals.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- More than 500 persons attended the Red, White and Blue ball for the Army emergency fund and the Navy Relief Society tonight at the Everglades Club. Large figures of Uncle Sam, John Bull and the Russian bear flanked the orchestra shell, and national flags and colors were everywhere.

Establishment of a centralized office to coordinate all regulatory matters pertaining to priorities, export licenses and perhaps shipping of the British Empire, Egypt, and Ireland, is now being considered, W.J. Button, assistant controller of the License Control and Permit Division, British Purchasing Commission, disclosed yesterday.

Eli Shonbrun, the ex-convict who, with a woman and another man, was held without bail in the robbery slaying of Mrs. Susan Flora Reich, 52-year-old Polish refugee, on March 4 in Shonbrun's suite in the Hotel Sutton, in East Fifty-sixth Street, turned accuser against another man yesterday in District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office.

Calling on all Americans to fall in behind President Roosevelt as their Commander in Chief in support of an offensive war, Secretary of the Interior Ickes said also last night the President should be left to decide whether the United States should strike first against Berlin or Tokyo.

A proposed bill now before the Joint Committee on Conservation of the New York State Legislature, amending the law in relation to waterfowl transportation in this State, would result in hardship on sportsmen who make hunting trips to other commonwealths whose duck seasons open earlier or close later than the season in this State.

Several leading corporations, whose shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange and whose dividend declarations in 1941 differed from the payments ordered in 1940, are listed herewith for the benefit of persons now engaged in compiling their income tax returns:

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- An order already drafted by the War Production Board will prohibit the use of bronze leaf and bronze powder in the printing, publishing and related industries after March 31, it was learned from reliable sources today.

President Roosevelt, faced with continued pressure for higher wages on the part of organized labor and for higher prices on the part of organized farm groups, is reported to be worried about the growing danger of inflation. He is said to be considering the wisdom of "freezing" wages, prices and profits by the imposition of "ceilings" upon them.

Voluntarily relinquishing the six-hour day it won in 1936, Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L., agreed yesterday to put its 17,000 members in the construction, maintenance and service fields on an eight-hour work schedule.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on March 7 totaled 260,064,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 691,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 891,000 barrels in domestic stocks but a decline of 200,000 barrels in foreign stocks.

RIOM, France, March 13 -- The conclusion of the examination of Pierre Jacomet, former secretary general of the War Ministry, by the Supreme Court here today afforded Edouard Daladier, who was the French Premier at the declaration of war, an opportunity to give one of the most impressive displays of elocution of his career.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 14 (AP) -- A special Russian announcement today listed 14,000 Germans killed on the northwestern front in fifteen days, making a grand total of 63,700 Nazis officially reported slain between Leningrad and Moscow within a month.

Continued submarine activity along the Atlantic coast of this hemisphere has made necessary further increases in war risk rates, amounting to as much as 1 1/2 per cent on cargo shipments in those waters, marine underwriters announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 13 -- With a propaganda tone designed to appear ominous for the enemies of the Axis, similar to that used by Berlin before previous major military operations, the German press discussed today the possibilities of a Spring offensive by the German Army and asks the question: Against whom?

HONOLULU, March 13 -- In an editorial titled "Don't Let It Happen Here" The Advertiser tomorrow morning will ask whether Hawaii is strong enough now and whether it is getting sufficient reinforcements to withstand any all-out Japanese effort to capture this mid-Pacific bastion of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A step was taken by Secretary Wickard today toward the mobilization of man power and woman power for the farms, whether from the usual sources of agriculture labor or from the schools, the WPA, the NYA, town dwellers eager for a change of air and the ranks of women volunteers.

LONDON, March 13 (U.P.) -- The German-controlled Paris radio today urged that the French Government at Vichy break off relations with the United States because of America's "intolerable intimidation" in the recent inquiries about the rumored transfer of the French fleet to Germany and Japanese use of Madagascar.

MALDEN, Mass., March 13 (AP) -- A group of Malden women urged today the establishment of a national chain of government-aided nursery schools to provide safe "parking" for children and release mothers for war work on defense committees or in industry.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The total of the public assistance population, which in November reversed an eight-month decline, has continued to rise, according to the annual report of the State Board of Social Welfare made public today.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The first definite State project in the line of post-war planning was broached today. Assemblyman Moffat, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Hampton introduced legislation mapping a modern cross-State highway somewhat similar to the Pennsylvania Turnpike.
Johnny Colan, New Yorker who had to go to distant fields to make good, returned to his home surroundings last night to score the most important victory of his career.

While leaders of the revolt against John L. Lewis threatened to contest his revocation of the charter of an insurgent United Mine Workers local in the courts and in the councils of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, two personal representatives of Mr. Lewis issued a formal statement yesterday charging that the opposition to the U.M.W. president had its inspiration in the "dingy cellars and underground agitation railways of the Communist party."

A Portuguese ship arrived yesterday with eighty-five passengers, of whom nine were citizens of the United States. Among them was Lawrence Dame of Boston, a writer, who said Germany and Great Britain were fighting an economic battle in Portugal for the possession of wolframite, a mineral from which tungsten is made.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- The nation's industries were urged today at the Midwest regional conference of the National Industrial Advertisers Association to shift the focus of their advertising copy from straight sales appeals to the more informative themes of availability of products for the victory drive, training of employes and maintenance of public good-will, and preparation for post-war marketing problems.

ABINGDON, Va., March 13 -- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was slain and another seriously wounded early this morning in a gun battle in an all-night restaurant here where they had gone to arrest two youthful Army deserters. Later the soldiers were captured in an abandoned house under tear-gas fire from a large force of officers.

Representatives of many walks of life gathered at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt last night in honor of the seventieth birthday anniversary of Oswald Garrison Villard, editor, journalist, author, and champion of many liberal causes.
The following books of a religious or inspirational nature have been published recently:
There is another angle to labor's insistence upon overtime rates which your editorial of March 9 overlooks.

All records for income tax collections in one day at the office of the Second District were broken yesterday with receipts of $22,036,328. Another record was made when 100,000 returns were received by mail, William J. Pedrick, Collector of the district, announced.

To the tune of a carpenter's hammer, instead of the usual soft music and informative announcer's voice, the Tailored Woman yesterday held a press preview of its new junior miss department. Located on the freshly decorated third floor and featuring sizes 9 to 15, the innovation will be opened to the public on Monday.

LACONIA-GILFORD, N.H., March 13. -- Virgil Adams, long-striding 18-year-old senior, paced the unbeaten Gould Academy forces of Bethel, Me., into a convincing lead as the cross-country run, opening phase of the annual United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's interscholastic individual and team championships, got under way today.
MOSCOW, Saturday, March 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following special communique today:

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The government took control today of the nation's entire supply of wood pulp, effective May 1, under a War Production Board order, assuming power to allocate both domestic and imported pulp to paper mills and other users.

The official program and line of march for the St. Patrick's Day parade and celebration on Tuesday, when Fifth Avenue again will echo to the strains of traditional Irish airs, was made public yesterday by John J. Sheahan, chairman of the celebration committee.

Despite the tightening of securities laws and banking regulations, one of the oldest practices in the relationships between banks and stock brokerage houses -- the negotiability of "street certificates" -- has just been affirmed by the highest court in New York State, it was learned yesterday.

VALPARAISO, Ind., March 13 -- A United States marshal supported by two military policemen moved into the Frank Shumak junk-yard today and requisitioned for the government 200,000 pounds of metal-scrap which the owner had "persistently refused" to sell at price administration rates.

The market for new investments had a "breathing spell" this week in respect to corporate bond financing, all the new issues being in the tax-exempt field. Seven municipal loans reached the market, but they aggregated only $2,827,000.
I have often wondered if the majority of the citizens of Greater New York have any real comprehension of the quality and quantity of the work that is being done in the city's hospitals.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Senator Byrd made public today a list of national coordinators of sports and activities received from Ellwood A. Geuges, administrative executive of the OCD. Among them were these:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 13 -- Final arrangements for Westchester's first county-wide practice blackout, affecting 575,000 persons in an area of 450 square miles, were made tonight with orders being issued to 50,000 defense workers.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, announced today the allocation to the Social Security Board of $750,000 for temporary monthly benefit payments to dependents of American civilians affected by enemy action outside the continental United States.

The Unity Engineering Company, shipwrights and machinists, have purchased the two-story brick building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 129 Boerum Place, near Bergen Street, Brooklyn, from James O'Connor. The Bulkley Horton Company was the broker.

The plan of the Third Avenue Railway Company to substitute buses for trolley cars on the Fifty-ninth Street crosstown and Tenth Avenue lines starting at 7 A.M. tomorrow was indefinitely postponed yesterday at the order of the Federal government.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 13 -- The State's decision, prompted by the war emergency, to withhold indefinitely funds on which Westchester County was depending for parkway repairs may necessitate the closing this year of the Bronx River Parkway, the County Park Commission declared today in its annual report to the Board of Supervisors.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- New financing in the United States by all issuers of securities in January amounted to $1,345,000,000, of which the sale of defense savings bonds accounted for $1,061,000,000, or almost 80 per cent, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Declaring that "the charge that he has been friendly with Mussolini is ridiculous," Mrs. Ezio Pinza, the former Doris Neal Leak, an American, came yesterday to the defense of her husband, the Metropolitan Opera Company basso, who was detained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Thursday as "an alien of enemy nationality."

Women are not in this world when it comes to being out of it, according to orchestra leaders. Jivingly speaking, "out of this world" signifies a mark of achievement on a musical instrument. It developed yesterday that leaders of swing bands prefer to take their chances with masculine talent, subject to Uncle Sam's call to arms, rather than to try out feminine octave-climbers.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Army Nurse Corps has immediate need for 3,000 qualified registered nurses, and will need 10,000 in all before the end of 1942 to keep pace with the expanding forces, the War Department stated today.

The war of nerves that harrows and breaks up the ground before each Spring campaign has broken out in Europe. It's hard to tear one's eyes from the long scissors of Japan, sharpened now to cut the two crucial supply lines on which the Pacific battle depends.
"Few contests are as trying as this form of sport," writes Lawson Robertson of Penn. "It is more tiring than the mile run," adds T.E. Jones of Wisconsin.

Fire started in the scarred hull of the U.S.S. Lafayette, the former French liner Normandie, yesterday morning, set for the second time by an electric welding torch, but the blaze was small and was quickly extinguished. Officials said the fire was purely accidental, that it was confined to a small area and that the damage was inconsequential.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, March 14 -- The fifth day of the Donets offensive ended at midnight with two Russian Army corps -- about 200,000 men -- fiercely capitalizing their advantage as they pushed strong German forces back along a triangular line formed by Andreyevka, in the west; Verbki, in the east, and Sinelnikovo, in the south.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13 -- Countess Helene Chlapowska, who is visiting Mrs. George Luke Mesker, was honored at a luncheon given today by Arthur Bradley Campbell at the Bath and Tennis Club.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Although the wheat market showed an easy undertone in the early trading toi day, there was good support on a ,dip of around % cent a bushel. Houses with Eastern connections i and brokers who frequently act for mills absorbed the selling by professional traders.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- A measure was approved unanimously today by the Senate Military Affairs Committee to give the Army privates and the Navy seamen $42 a month, instead of the $21 they now receive at the start of service.

MOSCOW, March 13 -- German counter-attacks of increasing intensity were reported from many sectors of the front today. As the Spring thaws approach, the necessity of regaining control of communications that daring Russian penetrations have cut becomes urgent and the Nazis are not sparing their men and equipment in their efforts.
I would like to put in my two cents' worth concerning an injustice that has been going on for years. That is the lack of credit given to Penn State for its athletic accomplishments.

Conversion of part of the activities of manufacturers of cosmetics and toilet preparations to defense work has been discussed with Washington officials by a committee comprising H.L. Brooks, H. Gregory Thomas and S.L. Mayham of the Toilet Goods Association, it was learned here yesterday.

Bills have been introduced in Albany authorizing $300,000 of bonds to build ski trails on Whiteface Mountain. These bills undertake to get the money without an appropriation by organizing a Whiteface Mountain Authority empowered to issue bonds.
District Attorney William O'Dwyer spent $34,300 on special expenses in his investigation of the Brooklyn murder ring, according to an itemization that appeared yesterday in the City Record.

Speaking as assistant administrator of the Office of Price Administration before railroad traffic officials in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday, Dexter M. Keezer urged the managements to suspend the increased rates on ten important commodities recently authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

DETROIT, March 13 -- Machines are being shifted daily to points where they are most vitally needed, bottlenecks in the flow of materials are being broken, and war production in the automotive industry is beginning to speed up, Ernest Kanzler, chief of the automotive branch, War Production Board, said today.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 13 -- President Eduardo Santos was decorated today by the Government of Venezuela with the Order of Francisco de Miranda at the Presidencia, and in acceptance he said:

To what extent should a referee or umpire in any sport intrude his own personality on the game? Don't you feel that referees should remain in the background as much as possible and allow the participants to dominate the contest?

Pleas that seven Nazi spies had collected information through misguided loyalty under instructions from others, or in submission to the irresistible pressure exerted by Adolf Hitler, failed yesterday to save three from twenty-year prison terms, three from fifteen-year sentences and one from a twelve-year penalty.

The General Sessions trial of twelve men accused of participation in a $2,500,000 milk racket conspiracy, opened for the second time yesterday after a postponement of nearly two months because of the illness of Judge James G. Wallace.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 13 -- Yale defeated Harvard at basketball tonight in a close game, 37 to 34.

On Monday the Board of Higher Education is to decide the fate of the Townsend Harris High School, the only city institution of its class which is of such high standing that it can give a four-year academic course in three years and which has a teaching staff of such eminence that its members have more than once been promoted to professorships in the City College.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Total round lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Feb. 21 was 2,100,460 shares, compared with 2,065,240 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Helping to place New York State at the top of the list nationally, more than $614,000 in United States defense bonds and stamps have been sold at booths in New York City during the last two months, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Douglas Gibbons, chairman of the booth committee of the New York defense savings staff in an interview at her office, 1270 Sixth Avenue.

Enemy submarines have scored against two more ships, one a small Norwegian vessel sunk off the Delaware-Maryland coast with the possible loss of six lives; the other, a small United States merchant ship, attacked in the Caribbean area, the Navy announced last night.

Employes of the New York Stock Exchange went through an air raid drill at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, shortly after the anti-aircraft shell knocked a bit of cornice from the Equitable Building. Robert L. Stott, chairman of the board, operated the new intramural air raid signal while Howland S. Davis, executive vice president, timed the waits between blasts.

The art collection and household furnishings of the late James Speyer will be sold at auction next month at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., by order of the executors of the estate. Only family portraits, silver and similar articles which have been reserved as "suitable souvenirs for relatives, partners and friends will not be sold.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 13 (AP) -- Philip Granett of New Brunswick calculates he has been bitten by mosquitoes 300,000 times in the past seven years. Now he plans to feed himself to bedbugs, chiggerrs, horseflies, ticks, greenhead flies, body lice, sand flies -- and more mosquitoes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 13 -- Yale defeated Harvard by 55 -- 20 in the final Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet of the season for both teams tonight, thereby winning the championship for the fourth straight year with a perfect record in six league meets.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Asserting that the price rise in finished piece goods made of cotton, rayon and their mixtures has been at a rate "accelerating so rapidly as to suggest profiteering," John E. Hamm, acting price administrator, today ordered prices of such goods frozen at levels no higher than those prevailing between March 7 and March 11.

Stockholm dispatches assert that Japan has made "certain demands" on Vichy regarding Madagascar. In September, 1940, Japan made "certain demands" on Vichy regarding Indo-China. When Vichy yielded, Japan occupied Indo-China and won a base from which to launch an attack on Singapore.

LONDON, Saturday, March 14 -- The Royal Air Force battered points in Northwest Germany, especially Kiel, where the battleship Gneisenau is undergoing repairs, through Thursday night and followed these attacks with all-day raids over Northern France yesterday.

Bankers' dollar acceptances decreased $7,268,000 in February, while commercial paper outstanding increased $7,800,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly surveys of these markets. The drop in bankers' acceptances reversed the trend of the months immediately previous, while the expansion of commercial paper continued the present trend of that market.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Difficulties encountered in determining allotments for industrial consumers probably will delay the start of sugar rationing until some time in April, OPA officials predicted today.

The steward and eleven patrons, who, with forty-seven other men, were arrested last Nov. 25 in a gambling raid on the old Lincoln League Republican Club at 281 Grand Street, paid $3,250 in fines in Special Sessions yesterday to avoid going to jail.

You have recently given considerable editorial space to the present efforts of the farm bloc to maintain commodity prices for the American farmer by not permitting the government to sell grains from the surplus stocks below parity.

LONDON, March 13 -- A conference called yesterday by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden with the foreign Ministers of all the exiled governments was followed today by the disclosure that General Wladyslaw Sikorski, the Polish Premier, is going to Washington to confer with President Roosevelt.

Samuel Zemurray, president of the United Fruit Company, reported to stockholders in the annual statement issued for publication today that the operating profit in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 3 rose to $32,411,481 from $25,527,859 the year before.

Little or no effect of the approaching income tax payments was evident in retail trade here this week. Department store sales were estimated as showing an average gain of around 25 per cent over last year, an increase slightly higher than that noted last week.

NEW DELHI, India, March 13 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Commander in Chief of the British forces in India and Burma, today outlined the defense of India in terms of tactical methods foreseen and declared that the loss of Lower Burma was in many respects more serious than the loss of Singapore.
BOSTON, March 13 (AP) -- Three naval vessels, a destroyer, a patrol boat and a mine sweeper will be launched tomorrow from Maine yards.

Because the danger of sabotage on Great Lakes shipping has been reduced since the United States entered the war, marine insurance underwriters yesterday paradoxically advanced their rates for shipping in the Lakes.

John Curtin, Prime Minister of Australia, in an address broadcast to the United States from Canberra, warned last night that a Japanese conquest of his nation would leave the Americas "wide open" to attack across the Pacific. His talk was broadcast nationally here by stations of the Blue Network Company.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -Negotiations have started for the; transfer of American citizens from the armed forces of other United Nations to service under the American flag.

Mr. Roosevelt, whose opposition to the strong-arm Congressional practice of sticking objectionable items into appropriation bills and daring the Executive to veto, is well known, has allowed publication of some parts of his letter on the subject to Senator Vandenberg. As Governor of New York Air. Roosevelt had the constitutional right to veto single items in appropriation bills and seldom had to use it.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Continuance in the New York area of a "substantial part" of the operations of the Stapleton Foreign Trade Zone on Staten Island, most of whose facilities have been taken over by the War Department for the duration, was promised by Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones today in a formal order promulgated as chairman of the Foreign Trade Zones Board.

If it were lifted by a mighty hand and planted in corresponding parallels of latitude on the North American Continent, European Russia would more than blanket Canada. It does not follow that the climate of Russia duplicates that of Canada, yet this imaginary transplantation drives home the northerly position of Russia on the globe.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (U.P.) -- The Maritime Commission stepped up its 1942-43 "victory" ship construction program today from 18,000,000 to 20,000,000 deadweight tons -- making a projected two-year program calling for nearly 2,000 ships.

I have read the letter in today's TIMES written by my learned friend, Louis B. Boudin, who argued the Teamsters Union case in the Supreme Court, as well as your editorial "Inviting Labor Racketeers," also published today commenting on Mr. Boudin's letter.

LONDON, March 13 -- Adolf Hitler has escaped -- for this Winter -- the fate of Napoleon in the snows of Russia. That is the frank, realistic view of the Winter war in Russia expressed by responsible military circles, which attribute Herr Hitler's escape to a good supply system and an ingenious method of establishing defensive strong points known as "hedgehogs" or "porcupines."

"Adventures of Martin Eden," Columbia's screen version of the Jack London work, which opens at the Globe this morning, completes the week's roster of film arrivals. Heading the picture's cast are Glenn Ford, who plays the title role; Claire Trevor, Evelyn Keyes and Stuart Erwin.
